column5: On tap at the brewery pours dark brown topped with a tan head. Nose is roast malts some coffee and chocolate. Taste is more of the nice coffee forward notes then a little sweetness.
Very nice vanilla malty flavor. Sweet thin on tongue. Toasted flavor but not nutty grain and light burnt flavor. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Had on tap at the brewery. The roasted malts are a little more noticeable then in the brown ale. Notes of chocolate, coffee, some fruit character. This beer had a dry finish. A nice beer.

Glad to see another brewery with a brewmistress! Draft at the 18th Mountain Brewers fest. This is a proper London style porter, not overly rich or thick like some of the American porters, which more closely resemble stounts. Just enough coffee grounds and toast, with some dark fruit.
On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Dark brown with a medium sized beige head and good lacing Aroma: Toasted malts and coffee Taste: Roasted malts, coffee and bitter chocolate Nice
Pours a deep dark brown color. Aromas of chocolate, coffee and a hint of hops. Flavor light chocolate, coffee, and a touch of tobacco. Medium body with a smooth dry finish.

At brewery: Very dark with a nice, tan head. Creamy-silky texture made me raise an eyebrow of approval. Bitter chocolate, tar, and dark toast exuded. Healthy amount of bitterness balanced out the sweetness well. Loved the coffee aroma in the background, also. Pretty bold and robust porter.
Hazel Nut Porter-on tap-pours a light brown head and black color. Aroma is sweet dark malt-dark caramel. Taste is sweet dark malt-dark caramel, roasty, faint hops. OK/mild carbonation.

This was a tasty little porter. Big flavors come in small packages. Lots of thick roasted coffee and milk chocolate. Nice follow through of hops in the finish. Well balanced and silky, with a smooth creamy finish.

Dark brown pour with a tannish head and nice lacing. Roasted malts with coffee and chocolate in the nose. Bitter and floral hops as well. The flavors are similar whereas the malts are concerned but the hops come out a bit more. Roasty palate and an alcohol laced finish of hops.
On tap at the brewery Black with a thin tan head Classic dry sharp roast flavors. Light dry body. Some coffee and ash bitterness .
Had on tap at the brewery. This was thin bodied, had a creamy mouth feel, notes of coffee and bitter chocolate. A drinkable stout, I would have enjoyed more with a fuller body.
on tap-pours a light brown head and black color. Aroma is rich dark malt-espresso/molasses/roasty. Taste is espresso-dark malt, ashy, slight earthy hops.

On tap at the brewery in Pocatello, Idaho. 3.9% ABV Pale and slightly hazy amber body. Citrus aroma with enough lime that I think some slipped in this. Flavor follows. Overall: a pale lager with inadvertent lime juice addition?
On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Hazy golden with a small white head and some lacing <br. Aroma: Toast malts, caramel and nutty Taste: Caramel, nutty and toffee Nice, smooth and easy drinking.
At brewery: Amber in color with a creamy-soft head. Nice palate. Toast, nuts and toffee mostly. Mild bitterness. Residual caramel on the tongue. Decent session beer.

AMber with red tones, a creamy head and nice lacing. Caramel, base malts, biscuit, hops and ctirus aromas. Caramel crystal and 2 row malts dominant in the flavors. Musky palate that finish fruity and bitter.
2004 NABA Festival: Deap amber in color. Thick tan colored foamy head. Strong biscuit smell. Yeasty. Dry taste, little spicey.

NABA ’04: Amber bronze color with a sticky light head & some lacing. The aroma is lightly hoppy with a good maltiness, medium body. Flavor is sweet, nicely balanced. Finishes nice. This is a very well build beer!
On tap at the brewery rather light and pale. A bit more hoppy and more bitter than I expected.
Had on draft at the brewery. Great bready maltiness, soft caramel notes, light bodied, a firm bitterness that lingers. The Bitterness level is high for the style

On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Clear golden with a medium sized white head and some lacing Aroma: Caramel malts and buttery Taste: Caramel, buttery with some bitterness in the finish Ok, somewhat light for a Oktoberfest but that is good fine with me.

Draft. Orange-amber with a small ring of bubbles. Mild nose is sweet caramel malt and dry grass. Taste is a nice balance of the same with some touches of sour apple and hints of citrus. LIght-medium body is balanced and slightly astringent for a nice drinkability.
on cask. ultra smooth. nice dark roasty porter. strong traces og milk chocolate and cafe au lait. one of their better seasonals.
On cask. A nice beer. A little on the malty side. Slight hint of raisins. Quite good though.
On Cask. Smooth as hell. A nice change to the Stouts of the Ale Works. A nice all around drinking beer.

"Winkler Alt-Amberger UrHell", Flasche von Edeka, Schlicht. - Satt goldgelb, klar. - In der Nase intensives, leicht brotiges und vanillesüßes helles Malz und milde aber aromatisch kräuterige Hopfenherbe. - Antrunk rund hellmalzig-süß mit zarter fruchtiger Säure, Anklänge an Honig. Milde, an Kräutertee erinnernde Hopfung. Milder rezent, vollmundig. Im Abgang noch deutlich süß mit fruchtiger aber wenig herber zitroniger Hopfung. - Sauberes Helles, vielleicht eine Spur zu süß, aber kerniger und tiefer als das gleichzeitig verkostete, ebenfalls beim Amberger Winkler gebraute Schlichter Ursprung hell. (17.9.2019.)
Muffig-getreidiger Geruch. Beginnt schwach getreidig, muffig. Anschließend Getreide mit etwas Süße und bescheidener Würze bis in den Abgang. Nicht mein Fall.
*Nice and refreshing Helles. Not much bitterness, grain with sweetish hints but round and good. Fresh stiff and easy to drink with still having depth.
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts mild, malty, light spicy. A bit metallically. Dry background. Finish still mild. Okay.

Bottle shared by a group of men in Colin’s hotel room during the Bamberg Jolly of 2014. Pours clear, pale yellow with a foamy white head. Sweet with simple, cheap cereal, slight bitter hay. Light bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish, pretty well balanced, with more cereal and faint hay. Nice and easygoing.

Bottle. Pours a pale golden color with a fair head. Aroma of citrus, malt sweetness and grassy. Taste of malt sweetness, grain and bit of citrus. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Light body, crisp and refreshing. Nice beer for the style.

Bamberg jolly Day1 24/01/2014. Bottle shared in Colin’s room. Aroma comprises of sweet pils, earthy, nobel hop. Very pale yellow coloured with a lasting white head. Flavour is sweetish cereal, corn flakes, and straw. Waterish palate, thin. Finish has a nice solid earthy bitterness.
Nettes Helles mit viel Süffigkeit, etwas Vanille und leicht brotigen Momenten. Ordentlich zu trinken mit einer milden Süße und ausbalanciertem Abgang. Vollkommen in Ordnung.

Pours out of the bottle (with many thanks to Pivnizub!) in a clear golden colour with steady low ehad and medium body. Aroma of hops and barley. Taste of hops, bread, grains, grass and citrus. Fruity-mild finish. Nice and easy to drink - very refreshing.

Bottle in room 104 of Fassla Bamberg aka "Colins Room" and whose carpet was besmirched by at least 3 different beer stains during this mini tasting late on day 1 of the post Xmas Bamberg jolly - 24/01/14. Clear golden with a white head. Nose is pale malts, grass, light citrus, orange. Taste comprises straw, lemon tang, grass. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, drying close. So so helles pretty boring.
Aromat słód, lekki chmiel, kukurydza. Barwa złota, piana obfita. W smaku słód, chmiel. Goryczka niska do średniej, wysycenie średnie. Ok.

Dieses Bier kenne ich schon lange. Es ist mir im Laufe meiner Reisen nach Brünn ein bisschen ans Herz gewachsen. Aber es ist wirklich nicht sonderlich schmackhaft. Es hat einen öligen, fast schon fischigen, Beigeschmack, der nur durch eine leichte Hopfigkeit kaschiert wird. Das mieseste der Altbrünner Biere.
Złotej barwy, klarowne. Piana średnio obfita, niezbyt trwała. Aromat słodowy. W smaku lekkie, słodowe, goryczka niska, wyczuwalna.
Vo Vytopne Brno. Nevyrazna leziakova vona. Nadherna medova farba. Chut jemne horka osviezi v tomto teple.
Fles 50cl in Benesov. Wat grassig, wat weeïg, licht zoetig, hoptonen. (7-2014).
Plechovka od starkeho. Vona sladova xhmelovo razna. Farba zlatista. Chut jemne sladova. Chmelova.
Prakticky tady přidávám tento komentář, jen aby tady něco bylo, protože zpětně dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.

Złote, klarowne piwo o średniej pianie, która dość szybko redukuje się do zera. Aromat nikły, słodowy. W smaku puste, wodniste, słodowe z lekką nutą ziołową. Goryczka niska, ziołowa. Ogólnie słaby czeski pils, nie ma sensu się nad nim rozwodzić.
Dorada limpia, espuma blanca. Aroma cereal y miel. En boca es malteada, dulce, notas de miel y frutos secos. Cansina.

Barwa złota, klarowne. Piana dość obfita, nie utrzymuje sie zbyt długo. W aromacie słody, lekkie utlenienie, delikatne owocowe estry, trochę mydlany. W smaku słód, lekko karmelowy. Goryczka wyczuwalna ale niska, ziołowa. Piwo pomiędzy euro lagerem a pilsem. Dość pijalne.

I’ll echo pauls sediments on the 5$ 20 oz. Draft. Pours a golden body with a white head. Grainy and husky notes, light citrus. A bit dank with a hint of oats. A light bread y body with a mild husk y bitterness. A grape note, reminiscent of flowers and grape pop. Nice crisp and clean finish. Decent offering.

Tap at Spuyten. $5 for a 20 oz pint! Best deal ever from Spuyten! Pours a clear clean yellow golden with a thin white head. Aroma is clean- light grassy, hints of citrus, lemon, toast, light cracker and cereal malts, mineral- low ester. Flavor is also clean, crisp, light toast, some cereal, pale malts, grass, earth, citrus lemon zest hint, green and minerally in the end with a clean crisp finish- very easy drinking- had a couple pints.

On tap at the Brooklyn Brewery. I was not expecting much from this "Light" Dinner Ale. It was quite refreshing and pretty good considering it was a light ale. Pale yellowish color not too pleasing to look at. Nice and refreshing.
I trust it isn't additives-laden, but it still emits some old, dirty aromas. Off-amber color, watery palate, very light finish, very forgettable. (on tap, Brooklyn Brewery)

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: Ruby copper pour with a sandy tan head. Nose is nutty with notes of toasted grain and caramel. Well balanced. Leafy/herbal hop quality. Very nice grain character with just the right amount of sweetness and hop bite. I enjoyed this one

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: Served on draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear dark reddish brown color with a medium sized white head. Poor head retention. Nutty malt aroma with a bit of chocolate. The taste is nuts, caramel and a tart finish. Thin bodied.

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft @ Hickory Hops 2011, Hickory, NC. Pours a clear copper color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty nutty caramel aroma. Sweetish malty nutty caramel flavor. Has a sweetish malty finish with nutty caramel hints in the aftertaste.

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: Date: April 17, 2010 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory Hops Appearance: clear copper, fine beige head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, big nutty character Flavor: sweet chocolate flavor, caramel sweetness, nice nuttyness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **+ /4

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: This beer has very little body and nothing to make you want more. There is some toastyness, but without a malt background or hop flavor to balance it, I was not impressed.

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: ...sampler at gainesville location. Well, as with thier other beers, nothing special. At least this one had some sort of flavor of roasted malts, and some dough. Finish was to short, with not really any flavor to ake you want more. Sad.

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: Freshly poured growler from the Manchester, CT location. Pours a clear mahogany brown with a thin diminishing white head. Smells of nutty malt and doughy. Taste is of sweet nutty malt with some minor tea like hops and hints of tanginess. Mouthfeel is watery and the finish on this one is semi-sweet. This is a sub par brown ale.

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft... West Palm Beach location... Clear copper ale with a small, creamy, white head. Nutty, toasted malt aroma with notes of chocolate and caramel. Mild diacetyl. Thin flavor... more malt please! Hints of bitterness and pungency. Light to medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and harmless carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish... too much so for a nut brown.

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft sampler at the brewpub in Sanford, FL. Poured a clear brown color with a medium white frothy head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Medium toasted nutty malty aroma. Medium body. Medium toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of average duration.

column1: Hops Flying Squirrel Nut Brown Ale
column5: FBG07. Nose is sweet malts, simple and one-dimensional. Doesn’t beg to be drank, and insinuates its own thinness. Ruby brown with nothing more than the suggestion of a head. Very watery palate. Sweet and thin, boring. Almost offensive. Flavor is boring as all hell.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Draft pour. Hazy golden color. A decent white head. Light and grainy. Refreshing and drinkable but not much here.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Part of the 5 beer sampler. Orange gold, white head. Aroma is hoppy and malty, flavor is the same. Nice bitterness, not very complex, but still drinkable.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: I had one last night and it looked and tasted more like a pale ale then a wheat beer. It was amber in color and pretty hoppy. I thought the waitress made a mistake but she double checked. If I was rating a Pale Ale it would get good reviews as a wheat it’s not good

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Location: Had this at the Golden, CO branch Summer ’08 Overall Impression: Fairly typical summer season, was really needed and tasted really good on draft after a long hot day, so I’m probably overrating by a bit.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Tastes like wheat and not much else. A mild, weak watery beer. Nothing speacial at all.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Pale cloudy gold body with a white head. Clean wheat and hops aroma. Wheat and hops dominate the taste as well. Pleasent warm ending.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Hazy light yellow body with a small creamy head. Sweet banana aroma. Sweet banana flavor with some light hints of spice.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: This went nicely after the honey bock, if that is possible. This is another one otheir beers that has a strong amount of honey flavoring, followed by some toasty cereal malt, some sweaty spice and a bit off citrus rinds.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Palm Harbor Location. <!-- P --> Aroma is VERY faint, probably due to the frozen mugged it is served in but that is how they choose to serve it so that is how I will rate it. Body is a cloudy orange/yellow and it is utterly headless. Fore is lightly citric followed by a slightly sweet grainy middle and a slightly stale/musty fruit.bread tasting finish.

column1: Hops Beat The Heat Summer Wheat
column5: Poured a cloudy lemon rind color with a frothy white head. The smell is orange and corinader with a musty bready background. The taste is thick sweet wheat and lemon orange citrus that comes highly carbonated. The finish has a slight wheat twang that is nicely balanced by some slight honey sweetness on the palate.

Fascinating nose on this one. Loads of cherries with a rich cocoa backup. Flavor is significantly less interesting. Rather medicine-y with a quantity of sour cherry. Liquid cough drops, if you will. Per the brewer, it was first fermented with ale yeast, then lager yeast, then champagne yeast, and brewed with whatever happened to be lying around. While interesting in some ways, the chaos of its production is noticeable in the oddness of its flavors.
Black-brown body with minimal tan head. Aroma is cherry, some cocoa. Taste is medicinal cherry, with sour bitterness. Finish is quite sour.

Hazy yellow-amber body. Nice pillowy white head. Big yeasty aromas, bubblegum with a slightly acrid aroma way back in the mix. The flavor is big bubblegum, quite sweet with some vanilla in the finish. The alcohol (9.5% on the 2004 vintage that I tried) on this monster is totally hidden. Medium slightly sticky body. Quite a nice beer.

Cloudy yellow-brown. Odd nose. Very peppery, also get a strange pungency similar to steamed asparagus. Also has a taffy-like sweetness to it. Quite sugary, a bit like liquid bubblegum. Very spicy, has loads of pepper, some nutmeg and clove. A bit thin on the palate, could use a bit more heft. Does mask the alcohol quite well. Frankly, seemed a heck of a lot more like a tripel than anything else. Reminded me of a vaguely wussy Don de Dieu.

Big fluffy white head which disapates, leaving good lace. Argo"s description of big clove, banana, pepper and bubblegum in flavor and aroma is right on, though I found no astringency whatever. I found the body to be rather thick, lending perfect support to the tremendous flavors in this Weizenbock. Brilliant.

Hazy amber with minimal white head. Aroma is clove, bubblegum fruity, banana, peppery -- very sweet. Taste is at first sweet, pepper, fruity, but the banana and clove make their presence known as the beer warms. A trifle astringent. Fairly light body, and it goes down nicely with an alcohol warming (no burn).
I had this beer a while back and from what I can remember I enjoyed it. I’ve had this at the pub/brewery so it was fresh. Nothing special about it is popping into my head at the moment.

Tap at Downtown. This beer arrived and it’s almost luminous. Bright dayglow yellow with a thick white head that doesn’t last. Plenty of citrus and dusty hops in the aroma. Smells quite lively and pungent. Mouth is massive hops, citrus, but quite light mouthfeel. Hides the alcohol really well. Very refreshing and enjoyable IPA for a muggy day.

GABF 2007: Poured a very hazy copper color with an off-white head. Citrus and sweaty hop aroma. The flavor was hop forward with citrus and floral notes. Sweet malt after. The malt was short. Dry bitter finish. Medium bodied.

Date: 07/15/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy light amber, thin fine off white head, lots of lace, light sweet grapefruit aroma, sweet grapefruit flavor, touch of pine sweetness that grows as it warms, nice long bitter finish, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4

Draught from Capitol Hill poured into quite the heavy goblet - Pours cloudy orange brown with a 1/2 finger white head that left nice lacing; Pine, floral, and citrus (specifically orange and lemon) hops on a sweet and hoppy aroma; Light citrus and malt with a huge helping of floral and pine hops on the initial taste; A pleasantly bitter aftertaste powered by a big pine note; Full body; Medium carbonation; A great beer if I’ve ever had one. The hop heads out there would love it. Had this with the grilled chicken and it balanced the meal VERY well.

Sampled on tap on 7/15/06 at the Capitol Hill location: Pours a slightly hazy copper orange with a nicely-lacing coating of wispy white head. Big, fresh grapefruity hoppy aroma has a subtle caramel malty balance. Body starts with a good, sweet, caramel maltiness along with lots of sticky resiny bittering and flavor hops. Fairly well-balanced and drinkable with floral hoppy character throughout.

On tap at the Capitol Hill location. Light, almost copper color, with a creamy white head. Aroma is a nice sweet hops smell. When drinking it I didn’t really think of it as I do with most Imperial beverages. Smooth, a little dry, and a nice citrus and grapefruit finish.

On tap at the postal one of these pubs. Clear orange color with a lasting creamy white head. Very sticky lace on the side of the chalice. Fresh pungent hop nose with hints of pineapple juice and orange peel. Body seems a little light. The hops dominate this beer with flavors of sweet pineapple, grapefruit, orange and apple juice. The finish is a long grapefruit rind bitterness. The hops don’t seem supported enough to be a first class example.

Draft @ Capitol City Capitol Hill Copper color, white creamy head, full sheet of lacing. The nose is very sweet and floral; grapefruit and pine, strawberry and kiwi, melon and grass. The flavor is tasty, a bit strong in alcohol, but that’s ok. Nice citric character and a flavorful rich finish. Decent! Almost San Diegoish. Haha, no way.

A hazy dark orange beer with a thick off-white head - served in the heaviest "stilk" glass I’ve ever had in my hand. The aroma is sweet hoppy - in the light end for the style - but still good. The flavor is sweet with a powerful note of hops, that very early on gives it a dryness in the mouth, before notes of citrus and grapefruit appears, which finally lends room for a long lasting bitterness.

Aroma; dark caramel, sweet roasted malt, plum syrup. Look; pale beige flathead and dark mahogany red-like body. Taste; dark caramel, sweet roasted malt, dark sweet fruit cocktail, toffee, prune, and ends well malted with soft hops blended into the lingering finish. Feel; solid body and soft co2. Overall; danish masterbock. [btl tasted@Gl.Toldboden Melfar june2018] 6585'16

Copenhagen 1/9 2018. 33 cl bottle from Meny, Østerfælled Torv, Kbh Ø. As "Ørbæk Double Bock Beer" with an ABV of 7,2. Checkered red and black label with a Goat's head. Pours hazy amber with small, bubbly, white head. Settles as thin, patchy layer of foam struggling to cover the surface of the beer. Very moderate lacing. Aroma is sweet and slightly boozy. Caramel, brown sugar and lightly metallic alcohol. Solidly malty. Light carbonation. Slightly thick, soft texture. A little bit thin for a beer of this type. Flavor is rather sweet followed by moderate bitterness. Aftertaste is sweet and with a alcoholic burn. Lingers for a while. If you like it sweet and with a strong alcohol presence this might be an option. A bit too sweet for me.

bottiglia 33 cl, schiuma beige fine media persistenza, colore mogano/ambrato velato, in bocca e al naso caramello zucchero di canna frutta matura, corpo medio, carbonazione legera, dolce con amaro medio. Si sente un po' troppo l'alcool. 07.07.18
Den rammer stilen meget godt, har en fin afslutning. Ikke helt på højde med de tyske
Bottle from friend tasting. Low beige head, unclear brown color, slim body, light sour malty taste. Meeh

Bottle, 50cl. Pours copper, amber colour with an ½-finger off-white/light beige head. Caramel, fruits, citrus and malt is domination in the aroma. Rich and complex, thick malt flavour. Caramel, sweet fruit and alcohol. Medium oily body, moderate bitter finish. Average carbonation. Bit one-dimensioned to be really interesting.

Flaske, Ørbæk økologisk Duble Bock Beer. Fargen er mørk kobber med et hvit skum som holder bra. Deilig aroma av malt, karamell og mørk frukt. Søtlig smak som følger aroma, lang fin ettersmak og fin fylde.
(bottle 10/11-2013) Low beige head, unclear brown color, slim body, light sour malty taste.

Bottle, as Ørbæk Double Bock Beer Økologisk, ABV 7.8%. Pours hazy full amber with airy but stable light beige head. Clear aroma of malt, caramel, and dried fruit. Sweetish, malty taste with notes of caramel, fruity touches and a hint of roast towards the finish. Discernible alcohol presence, making the beer rather heavy and giving boozy bubbles in the nose. Bittersweet aftertaste. OK, well-balanced and drinkable.

500 ml bottle, as Ørbæk Double Bock Beer Extra Strong, bought in Denmark. ABV is 7.8%. Økologisk / organic. Hazy brown colour, large off-white head. Strong sweetish aroma of malts, caramel, molasses, brown bread and alcohol. The flavour is medium sweet, with the same elements as in the aroma. Very moderate hops. Not a very refined character, coarse and fairly simple. I’ve had worse though, clearly a drinkable beer..
Sampled on tap at the brewpub. Standard light lager, not a whole lot to say. Heavy carbonation (a nuisance). Grassy nose, grassy flavor, a finish that has a distinct minerality.

Draft at brewery, 02/18/08. Extremely pale yellow brew. Almost clear. A little foam for a head. Aroma of candied corn. Parching on the tongue. Almost no flavor: slight sweetness up front, trace of bitterness on finish. I’ve had non alcoholic beer that was more flavorful than this.

Tap at brewery tap room in santa barbara. Pint glass. Cloudy orange with small white head. Smells like a wheat with off notes . Weird sour tang, like it went bad. Medium body but pretty flat. They might have poured this beer in the morning and let it sit out in the gold coast sun all day.
An interesting wheat. Pours a cloudy yellow with a light white head. Not any smell. Very wheaty taste, with a ginger bite at the finish. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Overall decent wheat ale on tap in Santa Barbara, smooth, nice head, hazy, overall good one!

Pours a cloudy orange with a white head. Mild hefeweizen notes of spice and banana, maybe some bubblegum. Bready malt sweetness, and a ton of lemony citrus notes. No hop character at all. The flavor is essentially the same. Lemon and citrus heavy with a bit of spice and bubblegum. A fairly faint banana flavor to it. No bitterness or hops to speak of.
On draught at brewpub. Pours an orange-hued gold color with fine bubbles in a slight head and lace. Light body, clean wheaty flavor. Effervescent mouthfeel from carbo ation. OK overall.

Draught at the brewpub. Hazy gold with a thick white head. Wheat and bready aroma. Pretty much straight up here. The flavor is the same lightly sweet wheat, with a fuller texture and creaminess that comes across pretty well. No hops or bitterness to be noted. Works the wheat aspect to some success, but pretty bland other than that.
Sampled on tap at the brewpub. Blonde color with a white head. Bubblegum and spice in the nose. Grass, herbs and spice on the tongue. Chalky finish.

Sampler at the brewery (served with lemon, which was overkill). Pours a slightly coudy yellow with a quickly diminishing white head. Aroma of wheat, lemon and earth. Taste is astringent and way, way too much lemon (taste like it was brewed with the rinds). Some light clove at the end. Tastes like a mistake, and is nearly undrinkable. Fizzy mouthfeel.

Draft at brewery, 02/18/08. Clear gold. Odd, I thought it was supposed ot be unfiltered. Head is thin skin of foam. No active carbonation or aroma. Light glutenous wheat flavor, slightly sweet. Finish is corn. No thanks.
Clear yellow with no head. Sweet wheat bread aroma. Bready taste clean dry finish.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours black with a medium sized brown head. The aroma has a lot of coffee and roasted malt. The taste is big roasty, milk chocolate, slight coffee.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at Rock Bottom KOP - Darker brown pour with a lighter head. Aroma is mocha-ey with some light chocolate and roast. Flavor has some mild roastiness with a bit of chocolate, coffee, and a nuttiness that is very pleasant. Smooth feel. One of their better brews.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at KOP. Deep brown pour with minimal off-white head. Aroma of roasty patent malt, some chocoff, and some almonds. The flavor was dry and roasty, with a slight finsihing dryness. Not real dense, but fairly well balanced.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Nearly black opaque body with medium tan lacing head. Light aroma of sour chocolate malt and cocoa. Smokey cocolate sour cocoa flavor. Rich creamy palate.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at the KOP location. Pours a dark brown almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel and dark chocolate. Chocolate and slight bitter malts, cocoa.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at the KoP, PA location. Poured a dark black with reddish-brown on the edges and a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of light chocolate and light coffee. Tastes of roasted malts, coffee (heavier than the aroma) and light chocolate. Medium bitter finish. Thinner body.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Had cask-conditioned at the King of Prussia location. Aroma: Roasty, dark malt prominent. Coffeish aroma. Appearance: Black, head retention good. Flavor: Dark malts nice throughout with hops in the finish which lends a nice touch. Chocolatey, but hoppy, and these flavors go well together in this brew. The roasty, chocolatey dark malt flavor is good throughout the tasting of this beer. Mouthfeel: Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Carbonation lower, which is what it should be for cask-conditioned. Overall: Good stuff. Very drinkable and tasty.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Black, with some reddish hue, and a nice tan head and lacing. Mild roasted malt aroma with a watery taste of chocolate. Eh, an OK porter.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Deep black in color with a thin, tan head that clings nicely to the side of the glass. Aromas of coffee, roasted barley, and floral hops. Flavor is that of a medium bodied porter with a sweet malt body and an excellent bitterness provided by roasted grains and generous hopping. Overall all - a very decent US style porter. Similar to Sierra Nevada Porter.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia New World Porter
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Very nice porter, black in color, soft lacy tan head, hints of chocolate, roasted flavors, sweet malty aftertaste, very good porter
Bready, fruity. Amber with great white head. Bread, fruits with small sourness in dry finish. Medium body, smooth, medium carbonation.

bottiglia 33 cl, bel cappello di schiuma bianca fine molto persistente, color oro velato, al naso malto e note di frutta matura, in bocca malto caramello uva e leggero spezie, carbonatazione forte, corpo medio, alcool ben bilanciato, leggero dolce con amaro moderato. 01.10.17
Troebel geel bier met schuim. Smaak is licht zoet en kruidig, licht fris fruitig met iets van vanille en abrikoos. Gewoon goed bier. Volgens etiket wordt dit gebrouwen bij brouwerij Sterkens.

schenkt helder gouden, goede kraagvullende co2, en witte kraag. Aroma van koriander, citrus, mout, graan, gras, hooi, gist. Smaken zijn meer naar een tripel neigende dan een grand cru. Belgische gist, floraal, citrus, iets banaan, koriander, sinaasappel, zacht, glad, matig/redelijk zoet, matig bitter, matige body. Ik snap niet waarom dit bier zo’n lage rating krijgt ..... hij is gewoon goed gebrouwen... (zonder brouwfouten).... en smaakt gewoon prima...

Dorata un po’ opaca e con schiuma persistente e cremosa, aroma di malto ma piatto. Sapore secco, maltato, e con finale amaro molto deciso e dalla elevata carbonazione. Alcool relativamente presente. Una birra nel complesso mediocre.
bottle a golden yellow colored beer with a white head aroma malts citrus spicy and fruits flavor malts citrus spicy fruits and some hops

Tasted ten years ago in Venice, but never found this on the Belgian market. Apparently made by Huyghe now but I swear the label said Sterkens. A strong, peach blonde beer with a mainly fruity character (apple), malt sweetness and restrained hoppiness in the finish; on the bland side.

75 cl bottle. Dark yellow color, hazed with lots of sediment. Short white head, short lived, fizzy. Glucose on the nose. Aroma is glucose syrup with apricot, some grains and belgian style yeast. Sweetish with a faint bitterness, sugary sharply dry finish. Meh, quite average and unimpressive.

Bottle from Tigros Supermarket. Profuma di anguria e di prugna. Si avverte distinatamente l’alcolico della fermentazione, il cereale maltato, e un luppolato resinoso. Colore giallo paglierino scarico opaca. Evidente carbonatazione. Schiuma bianca finissima e cremosa piuttosto stabile. In bocca è estremamante deludente. Ogni sentore fruttato scompare. Si fa largo un alcolico slegato, il sapore è maltato, di cereale e luppolato. Off rispetto allo stile. Nessun corpo, scompae come acqua di fonte. Nessuna complessità al palato. Finale immediato e fastidiosamente amaro, come un mallo di noce.
Bottle at Polpo. Hazy piss yellow pour with a white head. Lemon, bread, and yeasty aromas. Light body with lemon, yeast, and cereal notes. Not that it was bad, just unimpressive.

On tap at the Hard Times Chili Parlor on King Street in Alexandria. Pours golden with a small, off-white head. Malty aroma, with a nicely balanced malt flavor and a mildly hoppy finish. An excellent accompaniment to the establishment’s fine chilis, and it’s just $2.00 a pint from 5-7 pm.
Poured a golden color with a small white head. Aroma of toasted dough, sweet malts and light hops, dry. Lightly hopped, citrus, dry toasty qualities. Medium carbonation.
An excellent session beer. I buy this every week on free pint night. Which is every tuesday night, for anyone that wants to join me. (free pint glass)

As I drank this beer at the Victory brewpub, I found myself thinking: Geez, this is one terrific...pizza! For those who don't know, Victory makes incredible brick oven pizzas. Oh, turning to the beer. For once, Victory Brewing demonstrates that they don't have to overhop each and every beer they make. This lager is much less-bittered than their All-Malt Lager and is a session lager. Forget their horrible Milltown Mild, this Hard Times Lager is the thing to drink in quantity.
Dark golden, clear ... an alcohol-malt aroma. Smooth. Very malty flavor with a sense of alcohol even though it's not that strong.

A truly beautiful, brilliantly clear lager, enjoyed draft at the Victory brew pub. I don"t think that it is available in bottles yet. Taste of light malt and bitter hop in balance, served at perfect temperature, but in the end it is just a lager, one of my least favorite styles.

Reviewed from old notes. On tap at the brewpub. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a semi-dark red to brown color with a bar pour’s kind of head that died off quickly. The smell started off with the blueberries sweet and tight up front. A decent grainy malt base ended up coming across. The taste combined the blueberries and the graininess which tasted better than it smelled -more or less like wheat to me. On the palate, this sat about a light to medium with a decent sessionable quality about it. Carbonation seemed fairly subdued but probably due to the want of having the wheat give it a little kick, which actually Dorset really happen. Overall, the taste was there but something in the smell seemed a bit off in the grainy/what was supposed to be wheat. For the most part, not bad.

En fût. Verre de dégustation chez Jack Russell’s Steakhouse & Brewery (Bar Harbor, ME). Arôme: Odeur de bleuets. Apparence: La couleur ets ambrée légèrement voilée. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de bleuets légèrement amer. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps et la texture sont mince. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence d’amertume venant de la pulpe des bleuets en arrière goût. (Rating #1796)

Any first impressions? -An immense opaque head throned over the rusty brown clarity. -The sweet, fruity perfume of blueberries reached my nostrils even before the waitress set the pint glass on our table. -The first half of the sip is full of blueberry sweetness, the second half of its dry and lightly tart skin. -The mouthfeel appears bloated (some nitro?), but fits the pie clone attempt. What if you dig deeper? -A toasty, dry finish cuts the fruity wave just enough to make you want to get another gulp. -A brown ale base could have yielded more malt flavors to render complexity. -A smidge of buttery fat emboldens the rich blueberry nose. -Quite the idiosyncratic fruit beer; not up to New Glarus levels of course, but this batch was pleasantly flavorful. On tap at the brewery restaurant.

Pours a cream, five-finger+ head that goes very slowly and leaves a chunks of lace. Amber color. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Strong bluberry nose. Starts sweet, blueberry flavor is not overwhelming, dry finish with some hops barely lingering. $2.13 for a 12oz bottle from Bayside Liquors Bar Harbor, Me.

Ok, so this one finally works, but I think it is only coincidence. On draught at the brewery, 8/14/2005. The little, bittersweet wild blueberries are fresh and real in here and well-prepared for the corky, rusty yeast assault. Good crisp mouthfeel, low, pleasing carbonation, kind of feels like an Abbey Trippel, dry and perfumey. Light grainy malt and tons of tartness/dryness from the yeast. A touch of sweet honey malt on the end. Light to medium-light bodied. Huge foamy head, moderate retention and a pale-copper-golden appearance with some rusty earthen-clay tones and the head being white. The crazy, drying, sourish yeast works, coincidentally, I have to believe, because it keeps this fruit beer tart and dry, as a good fruit beer should be (in my opinion).
Pours copper with no real head to speak of. Smell and taste was dominated by blueberries (one of my favorite berries), but fell way short of the other Bar Harbor area blueberry offerings.

Tasted fresh before it even touched the bottle. This is the best blueberry beer I’ve ever had! I dont like blueberries, and I dont like fruit beers (which this should be in for a category). The smell is pleasent dominated by blueberries. Flavor is pretty good, they say it’s based on the brown ale then they add the extracts to get the blueberry flavor. Thank god the blueberry extract somehow gets rid of the poor tastes in their brown. This is the king of blueberry beers.

Pours a surprising ruby red. Clear with a small white head. Smells strongly of blueberries but not overpoweringly sweet. Light malt aromas. Taste is very nice! Not what I was expecting after the aroma. Bitter and tart, not syrupy sweet like so many fruit beers. Creamy malt. Low carbonation with the blueberry bitterness coming through and finishing with a light sweet flavor. Bluebery flavors actually complement the beer and don’t drown it out. (Imagine that!) A nice medium bodied ale. I like the taste of the darker malt with the bluberries in contrast to other fruit beers that have light wheat malt. This one actually stands up well to the bluberries. I would put this blueberry ale right up there with Bar Harbor Blueberry Ale as two beers that have mastered this style. Head and shoulders above the rest.

The color a translucent burnished copper color, the head frothy and light tan also modest in stature with the lace a velum like sheet to coat the glass. Nose is blueberry sweet, fresh, crisp and quite pleasing to the senses, start is nicely malted and somewhat sweet, top is thin. Finish is mild in its carbonation, hops subdued and the taste of blueberries quite evident though out, drinkable, and pleasant enough, but a bit to thin-waisted to get much respect from me.
Bottled. Interesting. A notably foamy head and nice aroma. The blueberry taste is very subtle, but I noticed a whiff of green peas. Don’t know why.
From tap at the brewery. Black color with beige head. Malty aroma, roasted, chocolate, coffee, cocoa, licorice. Sweet and light bitter taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.
Like this easy to drink stout. Not very strong but chocolately as hell. Smells like chocolate and pours dark brown in clot with a tan head. Had at piece ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at Piece. Opaque black, classic looking Stout. Sweet, sugary, smells like a Milk Stout. Thin and sweet, medium bodied. Sugary Milk Stout feel. Not so great. The 3 seems generous.

Sampled at the brewery. Pours near black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, light coffee and chocolate, light dough, and hints of bitterness. Flavor the same. Average texture. Not a bad stout at all.
Draft at piece pizza. From notes. Coffee and chocolate dominate. Pretty darn good for sure.

A dark brown stout with a thin mocha head. In aroma, nice sweet caramel chocolate malt with butterscotch notes, dark fruits, nice. In mouth, a light bodied stout with sweet chocolate and caramel, light bodied, OK. On tap at brewery.
On tap at Piece. Pouted black with thinning tan head. Sweet caramel toffee aroma. On the thinner palate type with light carb. Light roasted taste thats balanced. Solid.

Draft sampled at the brewpub. Pours near black with a small tan head. Aroma of roast, dark chocolate, coffee, toffee and a touch of licorice. Flavour is light moderate sweet and over moderate bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

7/20/2011: Piece Flat Iron Stout... Aroma: Coffee, roast, maybe smells a bit scortched. Appearance: Brunette color with a splash of ruby; off-white crown. Flavor: Dark chocolate cake and coffee; rish, very roasty like espresso c 7/20/2011: Piece Flat Iron Stout... Aroma: Coffee, roast, maybe smells a bit scorched. Appearance: Brunette color with a splash of ruby; off-white crown. Flavor: Dark chocolate cake and coffee; fresh, very roasty like espresso coffee beans; semi-dry. Palate: Medium-light body and quite SMOOTH! Overall: Very flavory and well-done; pushes the roastiness without going over the line (burnt). Draught (4.0 ABV) at Piece in Chicago, IL. Rating #52 for this beer. offee beans; semi-dry. Palate: Medium-light body and quite SMOOTH! Overall: Very flavory and well-done; pushes the roastiness without going ove the line (burnt). Draught (4.0 ABV) at Piece in Chicago, IL. Rating #52 for this beer.

At the brewery. Good color, very little head. Lots of roasted malts. Coffee with caramel and chocolate and lingering bitterness. Relatively high carbonation. Thin mouthfeel. Not a bad stout. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Gold coloured, creamy head with a nice malty nose, with some biscuits. Sweet malty taste with some nuttiness, fair body, creamy, although a bit thin. Still better than most CT fare.

Thick and white foam head with a reddish body. Very faint bitter hops, smoke and vanilla aromas. Soft body with strong hop flavours and a smooth, creamy finish. Amazingly, there are many parallels between this beer and a Boddington's brew?
Mild oatmeal and honey aroma with a bit of spicy continental al hops. Pretty golden pour with a smallish pie wire head. No lace. Decent Marzen with classic maltiness, but not a top contender.
Draft. Clear gold color with a small white head and fair lacing. Sweet-ish Euro Marzen taste. Very clean and smooth. Repeatable. Very good.
Bottle from Duisburg. Deep gold with a medium head. Aroma of dusty bread. Flavour is honey malt, sweet grain on an oily fruit base. Lingering full mouth finish

From old tasting notes. Deep orange gold color with a few small bubbles and a beige head. Lovely roasted malt and spicy hp aroma. Subtle, well balanced malt/hop flavor with a touch of smokiness. Subtle spicy hop finish and aftertaste that lays long and pleasingly on the palate. Full bodied and well rounded.
The beer has got a deep clear light amber colour with a small head and medium body. Aroma of malt and bread. Taste of bread, malt, hops, grass and mild fruits.
Alla spina, dorata, schiuma bianca non molto persistente. Note di malto e cereali, acquosa, corpo medio, molto dissetante. Classica Märzen senza particolari note distintive.

Draft at Dutch’s, served in a pint glass. Pours a totally clear, very bright orange-gold with a small off-white head that leaves just a few spots of lace. The aroma and flavor are the same - corn flakes, toast, caramel, sugars, straw, and some grains. Light-bodied, with moderate to medium carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel. A bit underwhelming.

Draft. Cloudy golden body with light orange highlights. Aroma of toasted grain, caramel, raw grain. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, moderate carbonation. Husky, grainy finish.
Clear golden color with medium head. Aroma is malt, some hops. Flavor is malt, some alcohol, sweet.

Deep gold in color. Smells of biscuit malt, grains, cereal etc. Body is a little thicker than expected. Flavor mostly matches the aroma with the exception of some indistinct spices and notes of caramel. Pretty good..

Bottle. Brilliant gold with tall fluffy white head. Stays. Spicy hops and restrained pale malts on nose. Light body. Very clean taste. Lightly malty and moderately hoppy. Medium dry. Highly drinkable and thirst quenching.
Draught at the brewery. Clear, gold colored. AROMA- malty. FLAVOR- slightly sweet, moderately bitter, malty, hoppy. Medium bodied. Not bad.

#840 Tap at the brewery. Clear pale yellow body, high white head. Aroma of bread and honey. Taste is unpleasantly bitter: adhering bitterness, touch of sweetness behind. Wood, earthy, bread, malt. Light body, high carbonation. Drinkable, but not really good.

Bottle 500ml. @ home on the terrace. [ As Schweiger Premium Pilsener ]. [ Trade by Nightfall ]. Clear medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, sweet malt, moderate hoppy, grass, fruity hops. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, pale malt, fruity hops, sweet malt. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160727]

the aroma is malty and herbal with some shades of hop... the taste is rather clear and refreshening, malty with some notes of citrus and grasses... light hoppy bitterness... bitter and dry aftertaste...
Drunk on draught at restaurant in Predozzo, Italy. Enjoyable refreshing pilsener. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Goldgelbes Pils mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, herb, grasig. Geschmack angenehm bitter, getreidig, leicht metallisch.
0,33 l bottle BB 05. Feb 14 citrus, bread, golden, clear, frothy, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation,

Bottle. Light golden, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate malty - grainy and lightly sweetish aroma, faint bread, light grassy - herbal hoppyness. Light to medium, malty - lightly grainy and lightly sweetish flavor, light grassy hoppyness. Finish is average, malty - grainy and dryish, some grassy - light herbal hoppyness. OK dryish and well hopped pils - flavor lacks the hoppyness.

Bottled (from bierzwerg.de). Yellowish golden colour, small white head. Aroma is floral, grassy, herbal and a bit bready as well. Flavour is kind of bitter floral and grassy along with mild bready notes. Also some slight saltiness to it. Balanced, and refreshing, although otherwise being quite basic.
Hazy brownish amber. Aroma is yeast forward slight chocolate not mich banana. Taste is somewhat thick spiced chocolate and fruity banana carbonation and lime. Drinkable. A bit green. Why not?

Draught @ The Brewery. Pours cloudy brown with a creamy offwhite head, some yeasty floaties. Aroma of wheat, yeast, caramel, candy, little fruit, banana. Flavor is sweet, wheat, yeast, caramel, candy, little sour, banana. Medium body, average carbonation, light sweet finish. 150717

500 ml bottle. The beer is a moderately hazy copper woth a beige head of foam. Good head retention. The aroma is spice and bready. Lots of cinnamon and coriander esters come through strong. Medium body and lighter carbonation. Pretty nice beer.
300ml on tap at the brewpub. Aroma is malt, light apple, light caramel. Appearance of cloudy brown with a brownish foam. Taste is light sour abd light bitter sweet. A medium carbonation. Good.

Draught at the brewery. Hazy, light brown colored. AROMA- very pleasant, sweet, wheat, caramel, lots of honey. FLAVOR- neutral, lightly sour, caramel, wheat, cinnamon, dark honey, beeswax. Medium bodied. Delicious.

#839 Tap at the brewery. Hazy, dark amber body,medium white head. Aroma of dark honey, peaches, wheat, some roasted tones, cinnamon. Taste is neutral with light sourness. Cinnamon, wheat, fermented honey, yeast, honeycomb, touch of roasteness. Medium body, average to high carbonation, sour aftertaste. Rich flavored, very good one.
Atom egy sör. Kiváló bajor búzakavalkád, élesztővel valóra váltva. Érdemes.
500ml Flasche. Trübes dunkel bernsteinfarbenes Weizen mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, nussig, Karamell, leicht würzig. Geschmack hefig, nussig, leicht würzig.

Bottle:Hazy, chestnut-amber coloured, mid-sized off-white head with a little lace, sweetish nutty nose, caramelly and wheaty traces quite subdued; more sweet than sourish flavour, almost medium bodied and pretty sticky; hardly detectable chocolatey traces in the sweet caramelly finish. Less sugar, more wheat would be better…

(bottle) Hazy, dark amber colour with a big and slightly off-white foamy head. Yeasty, wheaty and mildly dark malty aroma with hints of caramel, cloves and vanilla, backed by a present fruit character of banana and red berries. Quite sweet flavour, light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Wheaty and mildly cara-malty and bready taste with notes of banana and a touch of phenolic spices; finishes rather sweet and a bit slim with notes of banana and cloves in the aftertaste. 03.VI.13

Tap at brewpub nr City Hall. Amber reddish colour, small white head. Sweetish raspberry and raspberry stones in the aroma. Light-bodied. Crisp, clean, wheaty with berryish raspberry. Easy Summer drink.
On tap at the brewpub in Ottawa. Pours s hazy deep golden colour with a small head that lingers. Bread and raspberry on the nose. Taste matches the aroma. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

On tap @ Clocktower Elgin St Ottawa. Pours a hazy yellow with a thin white head. Aromas are raspberry dominant. Tastes are dominated by sweet raspberry (maybe a touch too sweet). Light body, tangy, medium sweet finish. Pleasant beer for a summer day. Would better if it was a little less sweet as it’s not very complex. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

Keg at Clocktower Elgin St, Ottawa. Cloudy pinkish golden, small head. Aroma of bubblegum and raspberry candy. Sweet and fruity with medium body and clean, rounded mouthfeel. Butter, raspberry syrup and banana. No bitterness. Not great.

On tap at Ottawa Brewpub. Taste tested this one without the lemon slice. Arrived with a nice thick creamy head. Has a pale golden appearance with a slight red hue. Hardly any carbonation. The raspberry aroma is readily apparent. Flavours are also of the raspberry variety as well as malts, wheats and a bit of sweetness on the palate. Tangy mouthfeel. Not too bad.

Aroma: Smelling of sweet lemon, wheat dough and some raspberry. Appearance: A hazy straw colored brew, some lacing and curtains. Taste: Starting whit sweet white wheat bread, a very discrete raspberry presence, lemon juice and some grape-fruit peel. Palate: Little carbonation, soft and smooth, refreshing with a medium body and a smooth dry finish. Overall: Very cleverly balanced raspberry touch to this one. Note: On-tap in Clarence Street Reviewed 2012-03-23.

Average wheat beer with very light dose of raspberry. Its good that the raspberry is this low, otherwise it would obliterate this beer. Pours golden. Finishes with light sweetness and sourness. Balance is ok but super light lager here. Tap at Burden brewpub.

On tap @ Murray Street, Ottawa. Hazy light golden with a low creamy head. Aroma is lightly sweaty with sweet raspberry. The palate offers dominant raspberry character, slightly powdery but with low sweetness, and a light wheaty base. Toward the end I was getting little hints of watermelon. Good for the patio.

Sweet, almost totally natural raspberry aroma in front of subtle, sweet caramel base malt. Almost clear gold under a white ring. Dry raspberry and malt flavour with a crispifying bitterness. Very quaffable. Light body, crisp and clean.
Kind of boring. Faint bit of raspberry taste and aroma, but really not much going on here. Pass.
Tap at brewpub nr City Hall. As "ESB". Amber colour, small beige head and lace. Light nutty malts in the nose. Light-bodied. Nuttyness, caramalt, some Earthy hops. Ok British style esb.

Just found this rating from a few years ago with this special brewing of their bitter with Apollo hops. Poured a cloudy amber colour with not much head, as was from cask. Hoppy nose with hints of fruity malts. Lots of these fruity malt notes in the taste with some oranges and hops. Mild citrus grapefruits. The mouthfeel is decently dry. Milder hops than usual, but still quite a nice alternative on their classic. Earlier Rating: 3/29/2014 Total Score: 3.3 A special one-off that is unfiltered with lots of hops and yeast floating all around. Amber colour with a frothy warm cap and good retention. Probably the biggest head and longest lasting I have had at this brewpub. Sweet honey and fruity malt nose with a bit of grassy hops. Wet mouthfeel and medium-bodied. Not as hoppy as expected, but a nice consistent dry bitterness. Decent fruity malts with hints of burnt notes and nuts. A pretty good experiment with one of their classic brews and adding Cascade hops for those who prefer hoppier beers. Earlier Rating: 11/2/2011 Total Score: 3.6 Use to have this one on cask back in the day, but had it recently on draft. Pours a clean amber colour with a small off-white head and decent lacing. The nose was fresh and nicely hoppy. Great crisp mouthfeel with a hoppy taste and grainy aftertaste. Nicely balanced between the hop and the malt (which give it a little burnt grain to it). I really like this one as it is a nice bitter and great session beer.

Keg at Clocktower Elgin St, Ottawa. Clear copper colour, small head. Fruity caramelly nose. Sweet with medium-full body and rounded mouthfeel. Syrupy sweet with some spice and hay. Caramelly malt. Mid bitter finish. Lifeless.

On tap at the Elgin Street brewpub. Limpid copper body with a thin white frothy head. Hoppy aroma with brown sugar notes. Its sharp hoppy taste carries nutty and woody notes. Ends with a solid bitter finish. Not bad.

At Glebe brewpub, Ottawa. Pint arrived with a thin layer of head, and has a reddish copper colour. Some carbonation. Good lacing. Malty aromas and flavours. Not much hops but it’s still pretty noticeable in the aroma. Fairly smooth mouthfeel. Hints of cinnamon and some mild spices also in the flavour. Pretty good.
Pint on tap at Clocktower Brewpub in Ottawa. Pours a nice copper color. Flavor is light, balanced, and malty. Overall very drinkable.
Aroma:light butter nose... Appearance:Hazy amber, light lacing head.. Flavor:light butter,light bitter...

Decent bitter. Pours orange with ok head and lacing. Crisp malt aroma with some hops in finish to give it a taste of bitterness. Not much more going on here otherwise. Well_balanced British session ale though. Tap at Burden brewpub.

Dégustée en fût sur place (Bank St) sous le nom de "Clocktower Wisharts ESB". De couleur dorée-orangée et claire. Nez de grains de malt légèrement sucrés, léger de houblon herbeux aux notes florales avec des notes de pain et de levures fruitées (agrumes). Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi qu’une texture légèrement huileuse. Léger goût de levures fruitées (agrumes) lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de grains de malt pâle frais et légèrement sucrés avec des notes de pain puis en finale l’on retrouve une légère amertume asséchante de houblon herbeux aux notes florales. Post-goût moyen et aux notes sèches, légèrement amer de houblon herbeux aux notes florales avec des notes de grains et quelques traces fruitées (zeste d’agrumes). (5 avril 2013)
On tap at the Bank St. brewpub. Moderate perfume hoppiness with honey malt. Balanced overall.

Sweet aroma which is reflected in the foretaste. Afterwards some fruity and buttery taste to the malt. Definitely some diacteyl here. I don't always mind that but not sure it works here. I also wouldn't identify this as a Kölsch if it did not say so on the can. The diacteyl makes it taste more like a cream ale. Still easy drinking and not unpleasant.
Tap at brewpub nr City Hall. Clear golden colour, small white head. Light a bit worty aroma. Light-bodied. Light citrus, light grain. Quite watery so typical German Kölsch.

Draft @ Clock Tower Brew Pub - Byward Market, Ottawa. Pours a slightly hazy yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy weak grassy aroma. Fruity malty grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy weak grassy finish.
This is my preferred Kolsch of the many I’ve tried. It’s smooth, and a bit creamy, nutty oatmeal taste. Very enjoyable!

Lads. This might be the worst brew I’ve imbibed in all me dear sweet 24 years on God’s good, green Earth. Let me tell ya, by, if I’s be given the choice betwin never seein me wife an four kids again or crackin open a cold one of these, I’d kiss that ol duck gby an leave the sud in the tap. By Jeezus, the look on me waitress’ face when me lad ordered up a pint of the swill, I near shat me drawers.

Keg at Clocktower Elgin St, Ottawa. Clear pale golden, small head. Fruity nose with notes of red apples. Sweetish with medium body and well rounded mouthfeel. Fruity with light notes of butter and grass. Low bitterness. A tough style to do, never had a good keg version anywhere I can remember.

Out of the can, poured a medium gold, filtered/clear with a tall white head that faded after a few minutes. I got notes of grainy cereal malt, cracker, and honey. On the palate, replays of sweet cereal malt, with the addition of lemon/lemon rind. Good carbonation, slight sweetness (as advertised on the can) but it doesn’t linger on too long - still I wouldn’t crush this one like other Kolsch’s.

Can: Poured a hazy golden color Kolsch with a nice white foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of cereal notes with light faint sweet notes is enticing enough for the style. Taste is a nice mix cereal notes with some final sweet notes and some light subtle buttery notes. Body is above average for the style with good carbonation. Easily drinkable even though it is a bit off from the style guideline.

Une lumineuse blonde pétillante, d’une parfaite limpidité, présentant un nez délicat de foin et de céréales fraiches. Au goût on reste grosso modo dans les mêmes notes, un peu de sucre résiduel en plus ; d’une extrême simplicité, elle atteint facilement son but, désaltérer le buveur. Comme noté sur la canette, c’est une bière pour débutant, mais dans le style elle est quasi irréprochable.

On tap at Glebe brewpub location. Pint has an inch thick of creamy head, with a dark golden copper colour. Medium carbonation. Prett dirty lacing. Aromas are light malts. Flavours are sweet, citrus tartiness. Well balanced hops and malts. A bit grassy. Stronger orange taste. Mouthfeel is creamy and malty. More hoppy in the finish. Easy drinking any time kinda brew. Above average light beer.
On tap at Hingham. good lacing not much head, smooth and low carbonation, not much malt and light though not thin.

Tap at Canal Street Location: Golden pour with a dense creamy lacing white head. The aroma is mainly ale yeast character with some fruity esters. Buttery malt flavor upfront, mild floral character, with a light lemony bitterness in the finish. Straight forward.

Tap @ Salem. Billed as a Pale Ale. Pours an opaque yellow gold with a light head. Nose is light, slight hop notes. Brew is incredibly creamy for a brew with limited body. Soft throughout, there wasn’t much else going on in this one besides the persistant mouthfeel.

Golden colour, poured from a sparkler on a nitro push. Creamy white head. Aroma is mildly hoppy, with Fuggles and Goldings being the most prominent hops here over a soft UK type base. Lightly sulphurous which adds authenticity to this brew. Flavour is quite well-balanced, fruity yeastiness (strawberry/cherry) set against the soft spicy Goldings. Soft textured brew. Moderate bitterness, but the crispness and mineral character set it off quite nicely. Lovely pint and a great session beer.
Creamy off-white head atop a crystal clear straw body. Aroma is mild, medium sweet, light grapefruit, bread. Taste is medium sweet, orange/floral, light grapefruit, tea. Watery light body, creamy.

Medium golden in color, with a thick and creamy white head that lasted to the end. Light aroma is mostly malty & sweet. Flavor is sweet, malty, with a subtle hoppiness in the end. Some creaminess from the nitro tap, but it also feels thin and watery at the same time.

18th February 2015 Chelmsford Winter Beer Festival in KEGS. Cask. Almost clear dark amber beer, good bubbly pale cream colour head. Palate is light and semi dry, mild fine carbonation. Smooth malts, mild caramel semi sweetness. Bitterish dried fruits turning tangy. Semi dry finish brings a little spice and citric peel. Okay.

Cask@Charlies Bar, Copenhagen - pours brown with a off white head. Medium sweet bready and toasty malts, twiggy and herbal hoppy, some caramel, getting some dark berry fruits as well. Overall a nice winter ale.
From cask. Pours clear and golden brown with a small off white head. Toasted malty and light fruity. Grassy, toasted and bitter. Dry and slight herbal finish.
Cask, The Hop Beer Shop, Moulsham St, 6th January 2015. Nice white lacing copper brown appearance. Nice hoppy nose. A lot of blackcurrants and a bit twiggy on the taste. A bit of an esb

Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Ale Festival 2003) Lovely rich colour, spongy head. Subtle, but interesting fruity and sweet aroma. Lovely smooth palate. Full taste - dark and roasty, but not going all the way to burntness. Like a winter warmer but without the alcohol - good winter quaffer.

Strictly speaking a Winter Warmer. Winter Warmers can sometimes be a Barley Wine or a Strong Bitter, but can also be an Old Ale. This had a soft (oh so soft!) malty base. This was all about the deep, deep, deeply delicious malt. There was a slight wine edge, and a restrained alcohol warmth that kept urging to burst through, but was held back by the smooth (oh so smooth) malt. Gone too soon!

Cask, Cow & Plough, Stoughton. Amber gold with an off white head. Aromas are biscuit and nutty tea with hints of caramel. Autumn fruit with some leafiness. Flavours are dry biscuit and tea with spices. Leafy with herbal notes. Dry with a fruity bitterness to finish.
Hand pulled at The Major Oak, Nottingham. Clear amber ale with a nice head. Really not much aroma - slight toffee malt. Bitter watery creamy taste with no duration. Poor.
Cask@GBBF2012. Amber colour, small off-white head. Aroma is nutty, wooden, floral and some mild toffeeish notes. Flavour is fruity, nutty, wooden, herbal and mild toffeeish notes.
Cask handpull at Market Porter, Borough. It’s a yeasty bitter, with good earthy hop on finish. Yeasty ok bitter. Nice earth and dry hop on finish.
Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Copper amber. Buttery malt aroma and taste. Someone said like Werthers Originals. Mid bitter finish. Tasty and pretty good.
3 Judges. Aroma is honey, apply, over ripe fruits, peachys. Taste is sweet apples, again overly ripe fruit, hints of bittering hops, leave s a bad taste in my mouth.

Cask (gravity dispense) at London Drinker Beer Festival (Friday session), March 2006. An unashamedly traditional, copper coloured, English style bitter with dry malt and earthy UK hops in evidence. A bit more body than many "ordinary" bitters but a touch less than many "bests". Nothing that really stands out but a solid bread and butter bitter..

(Cask at Market Porter, Borough, London, 1 Aug) Colour is amber with foamy head. Nose is malty and nutty. Taste is fruity, nutty with a nice hoppy bitterness in the finish. Citrussy and slightly earthy hop character. Dry, but rather short finish. Not really complex, but nice enough.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 21/09/2001 Amber coloured strong in alcohol and bitter on the palate. Hoppy finish.
Dark bitter with a weakly hopped aroma and a light toffee flavour. Overall a standard dry bitter.
Cask Handpump at the Penny Black JDW, Northwich 28/12/2008 Some hop aroma. Small white head. Golden coloured hoppy and floral with a little sour fruit flavour. Some dryness in a bitter malt finish.

Burton Winter Fest. Aromas are fresh and clean with buttery malts and some zesty hops. Flavours are soft, buttery and malty with sweet grapefruit and lemon. Dry and hoppy on the finish. As refreshing as a snowball in the face.
Straight from the Cask at the Burton Winter Beer Festival on Sat 29th Jan. Golden Amber in colour. Quite tangy, destinctly dey & bitter. Quite a thickness to it. A little acidic for me
Sampled cask conditioned at Nynäshamn Real Ale Festival, Sweden. Amber coloured. Fruity, malty and full bodied. Salty with thick, dense mouthfeel and a resiny, very bitter finish.

22nd Nov 2018. Cask half-pint, hand-pulled at The Pheasant Inn, Wellington Shropshire. Ruby coloured brew, tanned foaming head. Coffee and chocolate led the way aroma wise, in the taste also. Semi-sweet, semi-dry. Nice Black Beast!

Black color with a beige layer. Ok intensity in the aroma. Medium body and a soft carbonation level. Semi dry ending. Roast, toffee and some licorice in the flavor. Decent [Cask at Murderers in Norwich, England] Brewery #1657

Dark beige head soon left a cover on an oily looking, jet black, still body. Strong malt, caramel & coffee aroma. Medium bodied, very tingly on the palate. A bit thin & crisp on the back but clean. Dry. Malt, brown sugar & coffee to the fore followed by a bitter aft of berries, bitter coffee & slight hints of citrus.
On tap from Ritz JDW, Lincoln. Black colour with an off white head. Aroma has roasted malt and fruit taste the same. Nice drinkable stout.

By gravicask, minifest at Murderers in Norwich. A bubbly filmy layer to a jet black body. Toffee aroma, slightly smoked. Chocolate and toffee flavours, hints of liquorice. Mid-sweet malty ending. Pleasing (Shared with Cunningham, 18.02.2017).
Cask @ Murderers, Norwich. No head. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, caramel, licorice and hops. A little on the sweet side.

Cask @ Gardeners Arms, Norwich. Pours black with an offwhite head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, licorice, dark chocolate. Flavor is light swet, malt, caramel, licorice. Medium body, soft carbonation. 180217

Cask @ Gardeners Arms, Norwich. Hazy very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and dark chocolate. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and roasted moderate bitter finish. 180217

Flaske (thanks, Cimbasso!), hjemme: brunsvart med rubinrødt skjær og flott beige skum som varer. Deilig aroma med røstet malt, kaffe, mørk karamell og noe bæraktig. Lekker og ganske slank smak, hvor jeg finner sviskeplommer og mørk sjokolade i tillegg. Elegant bitterhet i avslutningen, som er ganske tørr tross sødme-elementene i smaken.
Bottle in hotel room Leeds. M dark black.. Thin tan lacing... Soft sweet caramel toffee chocolate roast malts nose.. Soft sweet caramel toffee chocolate roast malts.. Sweet toffee malts

Cask conditioned at The Fat Cat, Sheffield. Gold with white head. Tricky to rate as not in the greatest of condition, a theme I found regularly in Sheffield. However; thinnish body, a little winey on the nose, perhaps some tangy orange, below par really.

Bottle. Golden with minimal head. Aromas are lemon and vinegar with dry, earthy hops. Sweet and sour. Flavours are biscuit and caramel malts with dry graininess and some citrus towards the finish. Black tea dryness on the finish. No sign of the aroma sourness in the flavour. A decent glugger.
Cask/gravity at The St Albans Beer Festival 28 Sep 06. Yellowish coloured. A tiny head - that lasted. Artificial flavour. Watery impression. More like a soft-drink.
Pale golden body under a tiny white head. Light aroma of lemon. Hints of citric lemon in taste. Smooth and watered. A light weight drink ( Half on gravity at The St Albans Beer Festival, 28.09.2006).

A light, golden to amber coloured beer with a weak white head. A strong hoppy nose that is slightly zesty, is followed by a sweet malty aroma. The taste is a perfect balance of dry, zesty hops and a wonderful buttery, fudgy, caramel malt flavour that peaks towards the end, then finished with a drying hoppiness. (Cask - @ The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk.

(Bottle 50 cl) Ever so slightly hazy pilsener golden with a tiny, white head. Vague citrusy nose. Very light and watery body. Weak citrusy accents in the flavour without any real acidity. Light bitter finish. Quaffable all right but simply too thin for my liking. 120206

Tasted 22/02/2006. 500ml bottle conditioned ale from Rumble’s, Wellington. Very very pale (pilsner and wheat malts?), bright, with a creamy white head that disapates pretty quickly and laces slightly. Nose is mild sweet malt, some melon and tropical fuits, plus a slightly musty yeast profile (hints of lager yeast, to me). Pilsner-like grainy malt flavour with a stoney fruit bitterness in the middle and a lingering grassy bitterness to finish. Palate is coated in an almost puckering bitterness. Very lightweight, without being watery, and low carbonation. I can barely believe this is a ale. Everything above average, especially freshness, but nothing jumps out and demands attention (not even it’s sessional qaulity).
Hazy blond color. Strange aroma, maybe chemicals, saffran, grapefruit. Very weak mouthfeel and taste, with some citrus fruits and some hop resins. Too odd; unprofessional.
Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts, caramel and hops. Flavour of malts, caramel and hops.
Cask Handpump at the Fat Cat, Sheffield 22/12/2002 Clear golden coloured slightly pale and fruity. Some dryness in a hop finish.
Bottle at Salud. Black wet cork. Cloudy purple amber color, few bubbles. Aroma of mushrooms and cherry. Taste is lightly funky peppery cherry. Very drinkable.
Santé 1-19 vertical. Thanks Brad! The beer is light golden and clear (later pours are murky). Rain, basement, funk, mineral. Light bodied, slight oxidation. Fun but unremarkable.

750, capped and corked. Pours a hazy dark orange with a loose whute head. Oranges and pencils and blackberries on the nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Blackberries, oranges, and pencils on the mid palats. Long vinous finish.

Bottle at James’ for the multi-K tasting. Pours a hazed amber brown with a thin white head. Old cardboard and paper filled caramel. Certainly old, medium bodied, loaded with sweet caramel ,a bit of old malt vinegar. Old and tangy, paper and sweet fruit leather. Tangy, interesting.

One of a whole series of one-offs by Fantôme, this one, I believe, from 2002; all of them have been brewed for the Heikantse Bierliefhebbers but profits go to charity. Vintage tasted in 2009. Off-white, quickly opening head (typical for an old beer), warm amber colour. Oxidized aroma with clear cardboard apart from notes of lemon juice, caramel, hay, rhubarb, overripe peach, walnuts. Pretty sharp lemony acidid onset, nutty malts, hints of sherry, gooseberry, sour cream, jute, soft floral hop bitter finish, slick mouthfeel, retronasal tartness and oxidation. Didn’t stand the test of time too well but still feisty like all other Fantôme brews - and being an amateur of this brewery’s products, I willingly ignore the oxidized flavours.

Bottle. Pours amber with an off white head. Sweet caramel malts, leather, some fruity notes, odd yeasty notes, and evident oxidation. Honestly, the oxidation really doesn’t kill this at all. Still pretty good.
Bottle. Pale amber colour with no head. Aroma and flavour is sourness, oxidation, sugar, malt, caramel, citrus. OK beer.

75 cl bottle purchased from Etre. Shared at Fantomefest. Bottle pours a murky burnt orange color with minimal head. Nose is malty with a little funk and oxidation. Flavor is some oxidation again, but in addition, also some pleasant lactic acidity. Mouthfeel is moderate and dull, almost flat. Maybe it was because of Sante 4 was bad before this, but I happened to like Sante 5 a decent amount more than the rest of the group. Definitely on the back end of it’s drinking years, but still quite drinkable.

Bottle 750ml. @ [ Fastelavn Smagning - Carnival Tasting, Ulfborg ]. [ As Fantôme Santé-5! (Pinocchio) ]. Clear medium amber orange color with a small, open and fizzy - virtually none, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, wood, light strawberry, light barnyard. Flavour is moderate sweet and light acidic with a long duration, wood, funky, tart, sour. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. [20140301]

Bottle courtesy of Clocks. Pours a deep amber with white lacing. Aroma is soft and muted overall - probably a bit oxidized. Mouthfeel is thin with light sour tart flavor. Obviously past its prime, but probably killer at its peak.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and caramel aroma. Sweetish malty slightly roasted flavor with some hints of caramel and chocolate. Dry roasted malty caramel and chocolate finish.

Bottle from the brewery. A very safe beer from a brewery which doesn’t take risks. Sweet (as are all their beers) and grainy with liquorice and lots of treacle then a short dry caramel finish. Hints of unfermented wort. Not bad, but there are many better beers in Argentina.

Appearance: very dark. Little head, beige color without persistence. Aroma: malty, candy and sweet toasty. Reminiscences of sweet chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Something liquory. Flavor: Intensive toasty, smoked touch; notes of coffee and bitter chocolate. Finish with bitterness of toast and a few of hops; metallic and smoked sensation. Palate: Medium body with semi-oily texture. Medium carbonation. I agree with others ratebeers, this beer is not a dunkel, I classify it like a porter. Advisable.
Black coca cola color with a white head. Aroma is roasted coffee and chocolate. Taste is also chocolate and coffee. Sweet with a bitter end

mahogany black body with a reddish bottom. Small, off-white head. Aroma is sweet, of coffee, burnt sugar, some chocolate and toasted grains. Flavor matches the aroma and adds a bitter-sour end. Bottle shared with Panzerfaust , Nigredo and Omhper

Bottled, thanks Lilith, Nigredo & Panzerfaust! Very dark brown, small creamy head. Chocolatey and very roasty. Mildly malty with light notes of toffee. The chocolate combines nicely with some spicy hops. Finishes with a fair amount of salty bitterness. Tasty and well balanced.

Pours a hazy dark brown color. It looks pretty much like a coca cola in every glass except Per’s one. He got all the head. It seems it was in the bottom of the bottle xD Aroma is malty with a good presence of chocolate, caramel and burnt aromas. If this beer is a Dunkel then I’m The Pope. It’s a Stout, or maybe a Porter. Flavor is sweet with a soft ending burnt bitterness. There are notes of chocolate, prunes and intense coffee roastiness. Body is medium, like the carbonation. Texture is oily and the finish is good and sticky. The best Argentinian brew we had in the tasting with Per. Bought in Mendoza, Argentina Shared with omhper, Lilith and nigredo
Thanks to Fukito. Bottle: Nice dunkel, well balanced with bittersweet smokey taste. Head is a bit thin.

Bottle - May 2006 Pours a black colour with a brownish head. Aroma is very neutral, with some sublte notes of coffee. Taste is of coffee and a bit cocoa and tobacco, aftertaste being slightly fruit. A regular stout, nor bad, nor remarkable.

Imbibed December 02. Chocolate and malt aroma with a light yeastiness. A dark, root beer color with a light brown medium thickness head that quickly disappeared. Roasted malt flavor with some chocolate. Very light hop aftertaste. Fizzy on the tongue.

Bottle 330ml. Unclear matt medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, sweet malt, cereal, brew mash - mesk. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, sweet malt, sugar (whitesugar), fruity notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130617]
(bottle) Golden, hazy, small head. Aroma of unfermented wort, honey, corn flakes, carrot juice. Slightly sour taste, light bitterness. Unbalanced.

Appearance: golden some straw color. Little head, white color with low persistency. Aroma: malty and rarely yeasty. Interesting fruitiness for the style; grapes, pears, apples and banana. Peppery yeasty touch. Hoppy some citric. Flavor: sweet pale malty start, peppery progress from yeasty (I remember to yeasty taste of “Cervecería Artesanal el Bolsón”). Fruitiness like red apple. Medium dryness from hops, but short. Palate: light to medium body. Low carbonation. Mediocre.
INteresting flavour, at leats it is a well brewed beer. It has some sediments and the colour is original.

Bottle - July 2006. Pours a light yellow color with a medium white head and vivid carbonatation, slightly hazy. Aroma is yeasty and slightly spicy. Taste is slightly wayery, sweet, balanced but very bland and flat. Mouthfeel is medium to thin, aftertaste is very short. Could do much better with more of everything.
(330ml bottle) Pours a hazy golden body with a small white head. Aroma of banana, lemon, wheat, and honeycomb. Flavor of butter, toffee, peach, and wheat. Diacetyl mess. Thin mouthfeel.
Bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a malty wheaty aroma. Fruity wheat malty flavor with some yeasty hints. Fruity wheat malty finish.
Bottle from the brewery. What the hell is this rubbish?!? A 3% wheat beer which is so sweet to rot my teeth on contact and with very little wheat flavour just isn’t worth drinking. Horrible.

Appearance: blond straw-color. Little head, white foam and low persistent. Aroma: Typical pale malt smells; vanilla, honey and sugar notes. Fruitiness of peaches, red apple and tangerines. Yeast smells, with reminiscences of sponge cake. Low hoppy. Flavor: very sweet start (too much), evidently notes of wheat and sugar. Reminiscences of honey and sauco. Sweet-fruity like peaches in syrup. Yeasty. Where is the hop? Palate: light body and watery texture. Low carbonation. Too much unbalanced, very sweet. Not hoppy. Not advisable.
NOt very special, I thoguht it was going to be apunch, but it was mor elike a sweet hefe like the Berlin KIndl one.
