Hazy pale yellow with a tall white head. Aroma is citric and wheat. Taste is very citric and yeast. Weak body, a bit watery.

(My bottle fell and started leaking so I had to drink this directly from it, rather warm...) Color is clear light yellow. Lots of white, thick foam. Aroma is malty and yeasty with notes of fruits, dough and bread. Pretty much like a Low-Alcohol beer. It’s a little disturbing and I couldn’t find the banana aroma of german hefes. Sweet fruity flavor with hints of cherries, anise, curazao and mint. Rather cloying and sticky. Lots of flavor but nothing resembling BEER flavor. Body is thin, extremely light watery texture. A little like a Root Beer or Ginger Ale....as the flavor. High fizzy carbonation. I’m confused by this beer and definitely don’t like it. I don’t know what this guys tried to do....3% ABV? I guess it’s better colder and from a glass. (Drunk in a Park in Mendoza warm, agitated and directly from the bottle)
Bottle - July 2006. Pours a hazy pale straw-yellowish color wit a fine white head and vivid carbonatation. Aroma is citric and yeasty. Taste is citric, acidic, sweet, watery. Somewhat boring.

Imbibed in December 2002. Light honey and slight hop aroma. Yellowish amber with a thin white head. Yeast present at the bottom of the bottle. Honey flavor and quite bitter. Wheat flavor not obvious at all. Watery mouthfeel. There is a lot of bottle to bottle variation in this beer.
Dark ruby, hints of berries and cherry, it has a good balance but it lacks bitterness, not excellent but it is a good beer
NIce, a little spicy but very sweet without being annoying. These gus know how to brew. the colour is dark but red in the light.

Bottle, black with a bubbly beige head. A slight berry fruit aroma. A malty flavour at first with a reasonably mild palate, and then a syrupy fruit flavour comes through, increasing to a sickening point in the finish.
Extremely artificial beer. Good appearance but awful taste and aroma. Too much carbonatation. It taste like a coca cola strawery flavored with no body.

Imbibed in December 2002. Slight malt and moderate strawberry aroma. Opaque brown color with root beer colored edges. Tannish white head which rapidly faded but left some nice lacings. Fruity strawberry flavor with the faintest malt notes. Basically a lightly carbonated fruit pop.

Artisanal fruit beer made with sloe berries, which may sound exotic nowadays, but were commonly used in beer in medieval times. Moussy, off-pinkish, regular head, ’dirty’ bronze colour with pinkish glow, dark and cloudy. Powerful fruity aroma, obvious sloe berries, subjective hints of apple, strawberry, pear, cherries, rhubarb, ginger, cinnamon along with a fortunately very faint sulphuric presence (rotten egg). Sourish fruit taste, unripe plums, sorrel, green apple, strong carbo, light maltiness with vague sweetness but the (genuine) fruit acidity dominates and dries the palate, brief and late hint of hop bitterishness in the end.

18/IV/14 - 33cl bottle from Den Zytholoog / Bierloods (Adegem) @ home - BBE: 2010 (2014-371) A rare find, that alas didn’t survive time. Although I’m not sure it was very good when fresh, either. Anyway. Little cloudy reddish amber beer, small pinkish head, irregular, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: dusty, cardboard, bit sourish. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: sourish start, black currants, bit dusty, some cardboard. Aftertaste: bit lemony, cardboard, sourish, dusty, citric touch. Actually, the acidity of the berries is probably what keeps this beer pretty drinkable, but it has aged too much and was probably to low in ABV to survive properly.

33cl bottle from A Tutta Birra, Milan. It pours a peach color with a fluffy white head. Subtle fruit and brettanomyces aroma, yeasty. Definite horseblanket character in the flavor. I like this brewery
Why is it so hard to brew a decent non-lambiek fruit beer? Even Smisje kind of failed, since this beer is too sweet and a little metallic. A shame really.

translucent tan. Nose has heavy brett rubber band, cherry, light earth. Heavy bandaid and rubber cement, light lemon and Brett. Finish is Brett citrus, bit of out of place smoke. Short smoke, bit imbalanced.
Strange vegetal and squash-y nose. Dirty dishwasher taste, some pinesol and a touch of rotten fruits.

Draft at Ginger Man NYC with Linh. Pours a hazy orange body. Aroma is very light fruit? Mouthfeel is incredibly thin and smooth with no carbonation (can’t remember if this was cask or not). DAMN YOU SLOEBERRIES!
22nd December 2007 Cloudy orange beer, sherbet nose. Very sharp note with unusual orange and tomoto tones. Good but a little bit too off the wall!

bottle, reddish-amber coloured with small and unstable white head. Smell: like cigarettes, pipes and some blueberrys. taste: very smoked, blueberry, monotone, very strange and heavy beer! Beer for real man who want to try some fruitbeers.

Draft at Redlight Redlight. Poured into a flute glass, the lightly hazy body glows a dusky orange-gold color. A small but lasting head of smooth, snow white foam coats the entire glass with thick, solid sheets of lacing. The aroma is downright strange. I’m talking off-the-charts strange. First to hit are notes of dirt and minerals, combining to mimic the scent of well-circulated coins. Copper, nickel, and worn tin are then joined by unidentified, slightly minty berries, with a touch strawberry sweetness, and then some aquavit burn. Did I mention that this stuff smelled strange? Well, the flavor is just as weird, showing a smoky ash contingent, sweet-tart berries, sugary alcohol, and caustic metals. Ugh! The palate sports the consistency of tonic water, spritzy and fizzy, with a light body and some residual sugars. I can’t really find a redeeming quality. This stuff is practically a crime against beer. Pretty horrid.

column4: Fábrica de Cerveza Artesanal Viejo Munich
column5: Nice, a little bit creamy and crafty. Enjoyable and somewhat sweet. But good to drink it.

column4: Fábrica de Cerveza Artesanal Viejo Munich
column5: De color dorado, clara y con buena espuma blanca y cremosa. Con marcado sabor y amargor que dura hasta el final.

column4: Fábrica de Cerveza Artesanal Viejo Munich
column5: Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Hazy golden with a low white foam. Fusty aroma of dough, almonds and honey. Light-bodied with notes of cerals, dough, minerals and straw. Low bitterness.

column4: Fábrica de Cerveza Artesanal Viejo Munich
column5: Bottled at Monk’s Café Wallingatan, Stockholm. Lightly hazy golden. Grain and perfumy honey in the nose. Medium sweet, soft and grainy, salty and chewy. Lovely deep soft malt with some butter underneath. Medium bitterness.

column4: Fábrica de Cerveza Artesanal Viejo Munich
column5: yellow golden colour. Aroma is sweet, caramel and candy notes. Taste is sweet too, honey, caramel and strong presence of bready yeast. Good carbonatation.

column4: Fábrica de Cerveza Artesanal Viejo Munich
column5: Excellent aroma, strong hop presence. Tastes like honey with faint fruity notes. Pours pale golden with little gass. Very recommendable.

column4: Fábrica de Cerveza Artesanal Viejo Munich
column5: Imbibed in December 2002. An aroma of faint hops and honey. Poured a yellowish gold with a white head. Left some nice lacing on the glass. A sweet, honey flavor with faint hops. Medium carbonation. Somewhat crisp with medium mouthfeel.

Skummet er begrænset og duften slår tydelig an med den Ørbæk'ske karakteristika, som jeg efterhånden har indskærpet til at måtte skyldes malten. Var overrasket over bittterheden og tørheden i øllen, der sætter ind allerede fra begyndelsen - havde måske haft den dejligt afrundede Classic fra samme bryggeri i tankerne, men her er der lidt mere gang i humlen. Jeg synes også at kunne smage spor af hyldeblomst i en lidt mere sur og bitter udgave end Fynsk Forår. Alligevel mangler der harmoni i brygget, synes jeg, og mit indtryk er umiddelbart, at dette er en god øl, men heller ikke mere.

Bottle. A light smell of hops, light malty. The head is quite large, foamy with a long duration. The body is pale yellow. The taste is light bitter and metallic. The head is light with a lively carbonation and dry.

Bottle 330ml. @ home. Clear medium yellow orange color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, hay - grass, moderate hoppy, flowers, grass, light moderate yeasty, soap - perfume. Initaial flavor is moderate sweet and bitter, middle flavor is moderate sweet and bitter, finish flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to light heavy bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20091104]
330 ml bottle. 5.0%. From Ørbæk, Denmark (J). Clear golden colour with small white head. Grainy malty aroma with some fruits and hops. Crisp hoppy, fruity and malty flavour. Refreshing for a Lager.

Yellow with a low head. Floral aroma, lots of grass and mash. It starts out a bit watery and thin, dominated by floral hops and the sweetness from the malts. Then the bitternes kicks in, dry and metallic.
Bottle. MAlt aroma with some citrus and hops. Golden yellow colour with white head. Nice bitter flavour mixed with malt and flowers. Rich carbonation.

33cl bottle at home clear yellow, large white head. sweet malty, faint fruity, nice hoppy aroma too. flavor is bitter , flowery &#40both probably from hops&#41, malty , a little bit of oxidation &#40sunburned beer&#41, overall nice quite bitter a little sweet, some hops.
Bottle. Golden colour with a nice white head. Aroma and flavour of hops and malt

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma with some hopy hints. Fruity malty grainy and bready flavor with some bitterness. Has a sweetish malty grainy bitter finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.
Heavy malty aroma. Small white head. Cloudy body. Moderate bitter initial flavor. Light to medium palate.

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Dark amber pour, tiny head. Big aroma, dark fruits, caramel, spices, smoke. Fruity up front, a bit of booze, cinnamon, dark toffee, oak, liquorice, molasses,. Medium body with lower carbonation. Quite liked this, and funny that I notice this rating from this past February in my offline ratings on the hottest day of the year.

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is woody with distinct smokiness. Flavor is licorice, caramel, wood, brown sugar, and meaty, jerky notes of smokiness. Smooth medium body with soft carbonation. Very nicely done.

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Sample on tap at brewery. Dark amber in color. Zero head. Aroma sweet dark fruits, cinnamon, alcohol. Not great. Taste is very sweet. A little sharpness in the finsih. Palate is medium/full. Rich texture. Medium finish.

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Bottle. Black with thin head. Aroma of smoked malt (smoked meats and jerky). Medium body, medium sweetness, dark fruit, strong notes of smoked meats, and a sweet finish.

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: "pretty much the aroma and flavors you’d expect from the style, but nothing really stood out. definitely on the dark side with a little toffee and dark fruit aroma, similar taste with some caramel as well and a bit of alcohol. medium bodied. just ok for a barlwywine."

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Dark ale, strong falvor, but smooth to drink. Alcohol is high, but not overpowering. Would definitely get again, great value for such a strong beer.

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Bottle @ home via Secret Krampus courtesy toss from Andy. Mahogany pour with a short lived khaki head. This smells like Red Man chewing tobacco. Smoke, caramel, band aids, and candied orange peel. W@? Tastes of tobacco, beef jerky, smoke, and plastic. This is gross. According to vacax: "the lake may be superior, but this beer is a fucking piece of shit."

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Very dark pour with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel, sweet sugars, and dark fruit. Medium palate, some carbonation. Taste is rich dark fruit, ABV is well hidden.

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Black which turns into a dark crimson when held up to a light. Aroma of licorice, caramel, toffee, oak, vanilla and chocolate. Rather smoky upfront with licorice, chocolate, oak, hops, chocolate and roasted barley; Very chocolatey/roasty finish. Light weight body and carbonation. Very smooth tasting!

column1: Lake Superior Old Man Winter Warmer
column5: Cola brown pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is smokey and dark fruit. Flavour continues with smoke, roasted malt, hints of licorice. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma; soft sweet caramel malts, sweet herbs, toffee, mild syrup. Look; very good n creamy off white head, clear amber body. Taste; soft sweet caramel malts, sweet herbs, toffee, mild syrupy bread, and finishes mild bread n malted. Feel; ok body and low co2. Overall; very alright Amber Vienna Lager-type of beer. [btl tasted@Gl.Toldboden Melfar june2018] 5463'11

bottiglia 33 cl, schiuma bianco sporco fine evanescente, colore ambrato torbido, al naso malto miele cereali, in bocca malto miele pane, corpo medio leggero, carbonazione leggera, olily, amaro moderato acidula nel finale. Pilsener? Mah..... 13.07.18

Copenhagen 22/10 2017. 33 cl bottle from Meny. A lot of corn on the label. I wonder if this means that I am in for an All Malt Experience - without any undue influence from hops or other troublemakers. Pours hazy golden amber with white head. Settles as 0,5 cm thick layer of foam. No lacing. Aroma is not sweet malts. Rather something slightly sour - an something chemical. Like Hobby Glue. Medium carbonation and slightly thick palate. Flavor is medium sweet. Balanced by medium bitterness. Aftertaste is lightly bitter Hobby Glue. Nicely balanced - but I am not crazy about the slightly chemical tang which I can't place.
En ordinær, men noget kedelig pilsener. Frisk smag - men ikke noget der gør denne øl til noget særligt.

Bottled (backlog). Yellowish golden colour with a mediumsized white head. Aroma is grass, some bready malts as well as some slight metallic notes. Flavour is rather similar with a rough graininess to it.
From tap. Hazy light amber. No head. Medium carbonation. Malty and sweet. Mild taste ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy amber with small off-white head. Clear aroma of bread, yeast and malt. Sweetish, malty and bready flavour, with estery notes of touches. Hoppy hints and touches of metal. Grainy aftertaste. Watery and rather boring.
Bottle. Aroma of flowers and malt. Amber colour with softe beige head. Sweet malt flavour with some fruit and caramel and only very discrete hops.

Bottle 330ml. @ home. Clear medium yellow amber color with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, grain, keller, metalic, light roasted. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. [20091026]
Yellow with a low head. Hay, grass, metal and caramel in the aroma - weak notes though. The flavours are sweet and hay-like with a dry metallic ending.

Draught as a pot size at International Hotel (Spring Hill Craft Brewery), Brisbane. On July 23, 2013. Clear deep copper color, dense tan head. Sweet, malty, a bit fruity taste. Medium a bit fizzy mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Mineral aftertaste. Sweet, malty, bread scent.

On tap at brewhouse. A clear red-brown dark amber colour with a very thin white coloured small bubbled head. Virtually no bubbles, let alone any bubble trails! Laced OK. Aroma with very faint caramel. Taste has caramel malt with a very slight trace of hops bitterness. Very light to light body. Lingering slightly bitter finish.

Draught at brewery tap @ International Hotel, Brisbane. This is the pick of the beers brewed on the premises in my opinion. It pours clear red-brown with a medium off white head. Nose and palate is sweet caramel malts with a touch of fruity hop bitterness. Rather thin bodied but has that freshly-brewed easy going mouthfeel. Sessionable.
On tap. Bronzed red colour with a modest head and a mild aroma with traces of hops in the aroma. Some caramel malt flavours come through and there is a nice sweet aftertaste.

Bland stuff but the best this supposed superstar german brewer puts out. Toffee malt but really thin and bland. Slight bite on the end then it’s gone. If you find yourself at the international this is the pick of the bunch!
Draught at International Hotel, Brisbane. Pours a reddish brown with small beige head. Predominately roasted malt aroma and flavour. Short, harsh bitterness. Poorly balanced.

Very ligh brown, low carbonation with a small, tight and holding head. Light aroma with hints of coffee. Surprising roast malt/coffee flavour (especially considering the colour) with a low level of supporting bitterness.
im with motelpogo on this one, nothing exciting happening here, but nice enough to drink.
English aley. Typical malt sweetness and not much character. I remember duff and pogo arguing which sweet breakfast cereal it remeinded them of. Brown sugary.
Honeyed, which seemed to be a common theme with Cheers Tavern beers. Nutty, cereally malts, lightly sweet, and failry well balanced, quite drinkable, if nothing special.

Draught as a pot size at International Hotel (Spring Hill Craft Brewery), Brisbane. On July 23, 2013. Made sure to let them know I did not want lemon in it. Cloudy yellow color, white head. sweet, malty, yeasty, choriander, herbal taste. Yeasty, some lemon aftertaste. Fizzy high co2 mouthfeel, medium low bitterness. Sweet, lemon, choriander scent.

On tap at International Hotel, Brisbane. Poured a cloudy golden colour with a thin white bubble head. Laced OK. Moderate carbonation. Aroma of wheat, yeast and a hint of cloves. Taste of sweet wheat, a hint of cloves/spices followed by a trace of citrus. Light body. Short smooth clean finish.

The International Hotel in Spring Hill (about 15mins walk from CBD) is a nice unpretentious pub with attached microbrewery. The front bar serves standard Aussie macro beers but on the side there are taps that sell 5 beers brewed on the premises. This one is a Belgian-style wheat beer that is rather lacking in flavour and body but at least the palate is clean and refreshing. It pours pale cloudy yellow with a small white head. OK and cheap at $5.50 a pint.

On tap. There is the familiar haziness of a wheat beer and the pale lemon rind straw colour. The flavour was basic and non descript and the beer was light in the mouth. Would make for a good session beer.
Rock bottom. Water with the taste of wheat in it. Don’t get any spice. 50 characters yeah!

Draught at International Hotel, Brisbane. Pours golden with small white head. Strange aroma similar to lemon tea mixed with coriander. The flavour is not much better. I couldn’t finish a glass of this. Unpleasant.
Pale gold, very lightly carbonated with a thin weak head which drops very quickly. Light citric aroma. Cry citrusy flavour with an overly bitter finish for the style.
Tasty. Some musk sticks, actually fags/fads. OK stuff if a little salty. Kind of gimmicy cool and peppery. Afterwards some infection Kmart confection.

nfob03. i changed my mind a couple of times about this one. i was put off a bit by the leaded petrol aroma. some wheat tartness was pleasant but a nasty lemon-scented toilet cleaner tang crept through. not sure if the keg was looked after well enough at the beer festival

Slightly eggy sulfuric nose, sweet start, with a peppery, spicy finish. hoppy, slightly citric tang, the body is quite light and watery. Interesting that they use corn in this one. Having a lemon with it never crossed my mind while having it.
On tap at Tribeca Tavern, Raleigh. Black pour with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and whiskey. Taste is a milk stout with Jack Daniels. Decent overall.

Pint at Tribeca Tavern. Good.aroma, sweet. Brown color, ok head, fa a foam cover. Sweet flavor. Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, sweet finish. It’s good, not harsh barrel taste. Sweet cocoa, mixed with Jack. Gets tad dull on finish.

21-Feb-11 (12-oz sample bottle: Free bottle for stewarding the 2008 World Beer Cup in San Diego, CA) Having let this whiskey barrel-aged stout mellow a few years, this beer isn’t so much about Jack Daniels as it is about the flavor and aroma of an oak barrel. The nose offers aromas of oak, red cherry, earth, and dark chocolate. On the palate, the oak and tart cherry flavors are prominent in the entry, but these fade a bit in the finish where dark chocolate gradually overtakes the other flavors, reminding you that this is still a stout at heart. The medium-weight beer has moderate carbonation and a fair amount of acidity in the entry, but the finish is mostly just dry and surprisingly refreshing for a stout. In the glass, the beer is dark brown in color and fairly hazy in appearance and is capped with barely a wispy head that quickly dissipates. Overall, this is a very drinkable barrel-aged stout, and thankfully the flavor of Jack Daniels is kept light rather than dominating like in so many similar beers, but the base beer doesn’t seem to have much personality.

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/09/2009 Hop and roast aromas. Small white head. Black smooth on the palate and hoppy with a little dryness in a crisp roast finish.

Date: 04/12/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory Hops Appearance: black, fine tan head, Aroma: dark chocolate aroma with a vanilla and whisky sweetness, Body: big body with a touch of creamyness, Flavor: sweet chocolate and vanilla flavor with a perfect level of balancing bourbon, touch of roasted adds balance to the sweetness, hint of oaky tartness, Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.8/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4

Draft at Mash House. Pours an oily black with a fat, foamy tan head. Excellent lacing. The color is spectacular, as is the darkness residing inside the glass. Aromas of whiskey creep from the glass as it’s being handed across the bar. Upon closer inspection, every scent in the nose is angrily drowned out by one of the strongest whisky profiles I’ve encountered in a barrel aged beer. It seems like the barrel still had liquor in it when it was filled. Light notes, deep underneath, of roasted malt, baking chocolate, vanilla, wood, cold and burnt coffee grounds and lactose. Alcohol is very evident. The flavor almost drops off the charts of acceptability. Notes of whisky completely dominate, imparting cloying sweetness and heavy vanilla. A light smoke addition enters the fray. Bitterness is mild to medium, though it seems like most of it comes from a grossly overstated alcohol presence. Acidity is even high; this is going nowhere fast. The finish is chocolate and whisky, medium in duration, acrid and cloying. Mouthfeel is oily, watery and scattered, light-medium bodied, unpleasant. This beer was awful, almost undrinkable.
on tap-pours a light brown head and black color. Aroma is very sweet, Jack Daniels. Taste is Jack Daniels, alcohol. Not my style.

OK, I admit it - I’m a sucker for the aroma of these bourbon barrell beers. Really nice smells of vanilla, bourbon chocolate and coffee mix to form a really enticing aroma. Flavor is similarly balanced, perhaps a bt more vanilla than bourbon. Sampled at the 2007 Hickory Hops.
On tap at the brewery. Really good sout. Nice and thick with plenty of flavor. Roasted, coffee, earthy flavors.
This is an interisting stout. The whiskey taste is most definitely noticeable and blends in fairly well.

best before 05. Pours clear blonde, Ok white head. Smell is weak, some dry malts. Taste sharp, mild bitter, full-on oxidation and its paired-with madeira features. Mild sweetness underneath. not dry at all. ok
Sweet malts, sour lemon, grapes and yeast. Nice carbonation. Backlog from 2014/04/02.

Spring beer with slightly misty, golden blond robe and snow white head. Subdued fruitiness in the nose, malt sweetness, bit yeasty, flowery hops; malt sweetish and restrained fruity taste with some citrus freshness, flowery, dry grassy hops in the finish. Refreshing but otherwise rather forgettable.

Draft @ de Paas. Pours a clear golden beer with a big white head on top. Aroma is very boring, typical Belgian and yeasty. Not even some peppery notes in there. Flavor is medium bitter, slight funky and very bland. This is a typical example of another Belgian Ale/Saison.
Tap. Clear golden with small white head. Sweet malts, sour lemon and green fruits. Some grapes and yeast. Medium bodied, nice carbonation. Nice stuff but quite sweet.
Draft. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of citrus, yeast and light fruits. Flavour is light sweet and moderate bitter. Light medium bodied with light carbonation. Super refreshing.

33cl, few years old, still gushed out upon opening. Incroyable que malgré son age, cette bière aie encore un semblant de caractère. Doréeorangéeavec pas mal de sédiments et un col qui persiste. Arôme a évidemment pris un coup, et donne plus des notes de fermenté et soja; le tout avec encore du malt et caramel ainsi que qcq traces de houblon. Bière qui de suite reflète son age de part un profile de soja. Pointe de houblon et amertume avec en retrait du malt, caramel/pils avec une effervescence marquée surtout pour l’age de la bouteille. Petite note de citron sur la fin. Les traces de saisons semblent s’être évaporées.

Taste this first tima somewhere at 2006. This may 2011 again: from bottle @ home. Bit hazy golden color, with an white head Aroma fruity notes, hops, malts. Medium body. Taste malts, hops, fruits, citrus, refresing. Good.

Das trübe und alkoholisch süßlich riechende Bier schäumt stark, die Blume hält mittellang. Das Bier hat sehr viel Kohlensäure, jedoch ist dies noch ertragbar. Es schmeckt anfänglich nach Wasser, im Mittelteil schmeckt man den Alkohol und ein leicht metallernen Unterton, der jedoch verschwindend gering ist. Im Nachgeschmack entwickelt sich eine gewisse Herbe, was auch dringend Notwendig ist, um das Ganze überhaupt als Bier bezeichnen zu können. Muss man nicht getrunken haben - ein Geschmackserlebnis bleibt aus. Übrigens: Dieses Bier ist ein Saison - Frühlingsbier. Test vom 2.10.2005, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 7,5,10,8,10,5 - 6,65
An alright saison beer. Refreshing, though not something that’s awesome enough to be memorable.

column1: Carolina Brewery To Hell and Bock
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: pint at Pittsboro location 7/31/11. Good aroma, sweet, choclate, nutty, little vineous/soy sauce as it warmed. Dark orangy brown color, good head, ok lace. bitter sweet flavor. Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, bitter dry finish. Pretty tasty, nice malty brew. 8% beer in 100 degree heat, well it was air conditioned, but seems like this could be served during cooler months. Nice chocolate roasty flavor

column1: Carolina Brewery To Hell and Bock
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Tap at the brewery. Dark brownish amber with a reddish hue, small white head. Nose of dark fruits, lots of malt, roast, a little vinegar, char, ash. Taste is really strange, a little soap, vacuum cleaner, light vinegar. Ashy finish. Don’t know what’s going on here, but it needs some work.

column1: Carolina Brewery To Hell and Bock
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Name: To Hell n Bock Date: 04/12/2008 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory Hops Appearance: clear dark ruby red, wispy beige head, Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma with a light earthy character, Flavor: sweet dark caramel flavor, nice earthy character, touch of candy caramel is kept in control by the earthyness, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **+/4

column1: Carolina Brewery To Hell and Bock
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Again, a mediocre beer from Carolina. This one seems to have a vegetal characteristic that is pronounced to the point of unpleasantness. I must say, however, that when paired with the vinegary NC BBQ sauce, the malty sweetness really comes out.

column1: Carolina Brewery To Hell and Bock
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: This beer has obviously been amped up since the NC "Pop the Cap" law. Previous ratings are from a time when beer over 6% ABV couldn’t be served and this recent one was a solid 8%. Very deep red with a thin but firm caramel head. Foam coats the glass with every sip but doesn’t really leave any permanent lacing. Light fruit, prune aroma with some toffee notes. Not quite as fruity as the aroma had me believe it would be. Some toffee with a tangy finish. Perhaps a little coffee lurking in the background. Dry finish. Solid beer that I began to enjoy more and more as I finished my second glass.

column1: Carolina Brewery To Hell and Bock
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Dark brownish red, minimal (draft) tan head. Minimal malty aroma. Not too exciting. Flavor almost exactly mirrors the aroma, malty caramel. Medium somewhat watery body. Ok but just kind of there.

column1: Carolina Brewery To Hell and Bock
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Attempted Doppelbock. Not a bad try. It would have been bettre with more agreeable NC beer laws. Sweet, and strong. Nice malty flavor, but a lot of watery taste. Lacks the balance of palate and flavor that only the appropriate alcohol content can bring.
On nitro draft at the brewery in Tucson. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Aromas are of coffee and cocoa. Flavors are bitter roast espresso.
Sampled at GTBF/Tucson trip 2006: Jet black, low creamy brown head. Light nutty aroma. Coffee, strong chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel. Dark chocolate aftertaste. Medium body, light mouthfeel.

Dark brown with a big creamy tan head that looks like nitro. Feela like nitro too. Creamy feel. Rich and muted ala nitro. Coffee and chocolate. It is sweet and has lactic notes. It's quite good. Rich and enjoyable, qlmost decadent. A little roast late.

On tap at The Independent Distillery in Tucson, pours a deep dark reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma brings out lots of coffee upfront, accentuated with a touch of cocoa. Flavour is very dry, with dark cocoa powder and moderate coffee notes. Rather dry and bitter, but it has a smooth palate. Decent.

nitro tap @ tap & bottle: listed as 5.5% abv american stout, not 7.0%. Nose is roast aromas all the way, not a hint of burnt grains nor weird coldbrew aromatics. Distinct wet grain bag smell, taste is sadly a little watery and light. Finish is again fairly light and water but covered in quite a bit of coffee and roasted aromatics. For me this doesn’t quite come together, with a little bit more body it would be the perfect refreshing low-abv stout but in its current form I cannot get away from the watery feel.
Listed as Nitro through Barrio at Strong Beer Fest. Coffee smell. Taste is mocha coffee with some black coffee bitterness in the finish. Medium body, low carbonation, and low foam.
(En fût à la brasserie): Une base de céréales intéressants agrémentée d’un mocha aiguisé, chocolat au lait et d’une finale piquante torréfiée.

On tap at barrio’s. Dark sparkly cola color with nitrogen head. Some burnt paper smell and coffee on the nose. A bit of sweetness, minerals, hoppy bitterness, not a lot of mocha or java. Weird woody burnt paper bitter aftertaste. Not pleasant. Probably a bad choice of hops and not enough roast. Bleh.
Brown/Black pour with thin tan head. Light roasted malt nose, notes of chocolate and coffee Smooth light coffee flavored stout. Bitter finish.
Fresh growler. Listed as Barrio. Deep brown/black with large fluffy lasting beige head. Lots of coffee. Chocolatey. Fairly sweet. Lighter roastiness. Minimal bitterness. Creamy, medium body. Tasty.
Sample @ 6th Annual Strong Beer Festival. Mesa, Az. Detected a spice aroma. Gold/copper body with decent head. Had a decent mix of spice and citrus for flavor. Good brew.
Dark cloudy amber with a thin head and lacing. Aroma is hops and citrus with a flavor of hops,spice, citrus and caramel. Creamy hops and citrus finish

Light amber color, decent full-bodied head. Aroma is a light mix of hops and citrus. Somewhat zesty in the initial taste. Then the flavor desends to plainville. Very little character, needs more roundness. Don’t know if I would call this a winter seasonal, taste better in the summertime.

The color a very deep amber to burnished copper color to the pour, the head impressive in size, the texture frothy and the lace thick and clinging. Malt at the front and the hops underlying this sweet nose, start malt and lightly sweet, top middling and the finish spicy in its hop presence, moderately acidic, dry as a bone aftertaste. An easy drinking beer that is hopped just right, the malts perfect and one I will look for in the bottle.
Sonora's Winter brew. A pale orange hue. Slight white head. Very fruity nose. Spicy flavor with none that stood out above others. Surprisingly dry, slightly bitter finish.

2002 vintage. 8.5% ABV bitter? Hmm... don't think so. Derek, the brewer at Chandler BJs, recently served this at a barleywine tasting, and at the end of the night. This beer was huge! Rich, heavy malt flavors of caramel, butterscotch, toffee, and molasses combine with strong herbal hop flavors and bitterness. Intensely sweet and bitter at the same time, that is, there is obviously a ton of residual sugars in this beer, but there are also a ton of bittering alpha acids from hops. Thick, syrupy body. Not my cup of tea, too intense. Would like to try again in a few years.
This is an interesting combination of bitter & sweet. You get a nice hoppy flavor w/ a sweet toffee finish & some maltiness. It was very unique. Had it on draught a BJ's in Irvine, CA.

Very interesting Bitter. The waitress described as "Barleywine" like. Close but no cigar...Very dark cloudy brown (reminded me of Rochefort). By the time I received the beer there was no head left so Cna't really judge that. Nice maltly front and a fair amount of bitterness in middle/finish. Pretty complex middle that had some alcholic flavor. Warm finish. I would try this again. Derek did a nice job on this one.

A beer for those who like them bitter. 82 IBU'S but on the cask...It tastes like so much more. It looked like prune juice in the glass. a cloudy brown. And if there were any other flavors they were completely hidden by the overwhelming taste of yellow grapefruit juice. Unique but not that great for a malt lover.

A farmhouse with a weak body, no complex malt, and little Belgian yeast. To compensate, the brewers have attempted to overburden the ale with odd and unnecessary flavors. It’s a very poor representation of the style.

(Old BA rate - tap) Bright (but hazy) yellow gold color; mostly white head that dissipated rapidly. Yeasty; bit of spice; cloves; some sourness. Tastes like a solid saison with few frills; yeasty; spicy; cloves; and a very tart finish. Thinner; subtle carbonation; carried the brew well. Pretty good; refreshing and tart for the style. Overall, pretty nice and took me off-guard.
Had on tap at the Indy brewpub awhile back but unfortunately did not take good notes beyond the numbers.

Saison’s can vary widely in aroma and flavor depending on the spices, but this just wasn’t anything close to a saison in my opinion. Amber and no head (strike 1). Sugar and no spice in the aroma (strike 2). Very sweet with little else in the flavor (strike 3). In addition, very little yeast and carbonation. Less than a dry finish. The lacing wasn’t bad, though.

This was the first beer we tried at the downtown Indy location - it was one of their seasonals. Pours a amber with no head. The nose is sugary sweet with hints of caramel. The body was simply underattenuated on this - lots of residual sugars made it hard to drink. The delicate saison yeast was just lost in this and the finish was far from drying. Not a good example IMO.

Draft at Cincinnati RB location. Hazy yellow color with an average fizzy white head thar mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate sour citrus and spice aroma. Light to medium body with lively carbonation. Medium sour flavor with a medium sour citrus finish of moderate duration. Refreshing flavor.

ok, well, knowing little about saisons in can only guess that this is an average attempt from this chain micro. brew has quite bit of body and some spice along with a faint sourness at the finish. an enjoyable pint
(Draught) Pours a hazy maze color with a small head. Descent tasting saison.

Rock Bottom in downtown Indianapolis, IN:This beer's appearance consisted of a large sized white head with fine-large sized bubbles.The body was uncarbonated cloudy and it had a pale yellow hue.The nose was definitely fruity with a bitter taste.The palate was tingly and light-medium bodied.There was a good amount of lacing with this beer.

THis brew poured a large head of fine to large sized white colored mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a hazy yellow colored body with no visible carbonation. It had a fruity saison-like aroma and a biting fruity mouthfeel. The flavor was also biting and fruity.

I really enjoyed this bitter from a Micro that I think has a good future. Dry and refreshing, with a strong hoppy finish and a good mouthfeel. Whilst it is undistinguished in a way, it is an excellent quaffing beer - and lets face it, that's what beer is for, right?

Cask/gravity at Battersea BF. Black-red with no head and not much condition, nose has some coffee and a little port, body is dry, roasty, a dried fruitcake tang, some hops, dry bitter finish. Quite quaffable.

Cask at the Battersea Beer Festival, 12th Feb 2010. Slightly reddish dark brown with little head. Very soft palate. Light yet velvety. Sweet. Caramel & burnt sugar nose. Dry and roasty in the mouth. Not cloying or sticky. Falls between two stools a bit: Not full-on dry, but too bitter a finish for the sweet-toothed.
Cask, Leicester Fest ’08 (Thurs afternoon session). Rubyish with tan lid. Biscuit, body, chocolate and vanilla, with almost citrussy hop reinforcement. Slick, sturdy mild.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Battersea Beer Festival 2006 as Belvoir Mild Ale. A reddish coloured mild with a rather ashy, toasty malt aroma. Fairly dry with chalky, powdery mouthfeel. Hints of licorice and a slightly sour edge on the finish. A drinkable mild, if a touch more bitter than I’d expect.
a sim rate: (on tap at Battersea Beer Festival) Glorious red/black color, but no head whatsoever. Flat, but with distinct slightly sour flavour of off milk. Smells exactly like blue cheese.
Half pint gravity fed at the Battersea Beer Fest, colour a deep ruby/brown and a slight chocolate malty aroma. Very smooth and easy to drink - an enjoyable malty taste.

Cask gravity at Battersea Beer Festival 2006. Very deep ruby colour with bubbly beige head. Quite a hoppy/herby nose, not what you’d expect from a mild at all. Some mild flavt malt in mouth, then more herb and some powdery charcoal. Fairly low on flavour and a drying finish. Its a mild and it does exactly what it says on the tin.
Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 14/05/2003 Dark red mild which poured lively. Hoppy with a little bitterness in a lasting roast malt finish.

[Cask at GBBF 2004] A red-brown beer with no head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and licorice. The flavor contains hints of roasted malt and licorice on a sour background - the sourness stems from the lack of residual suger. The end is quite bitter.
Cask@Leicester Beer Festival. Plain looking mild with a light coffee aroma and a very dry and bitter flavour. Overall a good complex tasting mild.
Cask at The Kings Head Bridgnorth. Clear gold with white head. Lightly hopped bitter malty dark fruity beer

Abbeydale Absolution Cask at Fighting Cocks, Bradford. It pours clear yellow with a medium body foamy whjte head. The aroma is sweet, perfumed, floral, pear drops, apple skin, doughy bread and candied lemon peel. The taste is dry, bitter - sweet, spicy, floral, apple, melon, pear drops, bread and cereal with dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. A bit sweet and estery. Not so bad anyhow.
Tap @Stoneworks,Peterborough. Pale gold,clear. Taste and nose almost nonexistent,no carbonation. Goes down like water. Something went horribly wrong with this one.

Cask. Rising Sun, Nether Green, Sheffield. A bonus tick while the missus gets her hair cut over the road. Dark straw colour. Light haze. Dense and blotchy, lasting, lacing, white head. Nose has stewed citrus fruit. Some marmalade. Sweet, bready grain. Taste is fairly sweet and grainy, with stewed citrus bitterness. Medium body. Bit of chew here. Low carbonation. Perfect nick this, as were the other cask beers in here. Light bitterness to finish. Punchy golde.

Cask at the Peterborough beer Festival 2017. A clear golden yellow coloured pour with a a loose white head. Aroma is nice rustic cereal grains, hay, straw, lemon rind, spicy hop notes. Flavour is composed of semi sweet, grassy citrus, cereal grains, honey. Palate is semi sweet, moderate carbonation, decent cask condition. Good.
Light hop aroma, some fruit on the tongue, which is quite sweet. A gentle hop finish .
Cask at cloisters. Pours clear golden, nose is floral, toffee, light citrus, marzipan, taste is sweet, chewy toffee, caramel, spicy, juicy citrus. Not at all what I was expecting.
Clear golden beer with a white head and fruity aroma. Taste is tangy citrus, quite lemony, some bitter hop. I think too much would start to get sickly but it’s nice.

Cask at The Congress, Longton. A clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma of butterscotch and toffee initially then fruity malt, honey, some lemon and vanilla. Taste of butterscotch, toffee, honey, vanilla with fruity malt and floral hops in the background. Medium bodied and a smooth texture. A sweetish vanilla, toffee finish. This is weird one, if these flavours were in a stout I would love it. Sweet and only a subtle citrus flavour makes this below average for a golden ale, which is a shame.
Tried at the Threekingham beer festival 2015. Golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is fruity with spice taste was a touch too sweet for me.
A lot of bubbles. The color reminds me a Kvass with adding of water. Usuall smell but with a littke bit caramel. Taste with accumulating bitterness. But aftertaste is better with malt and no so harsh

Huge thanks to kevnic2008 for that one! Bottle looks really good. Beer in the glass deep golden, nice head. Spicy aroma. Starts strong-malty, more and more spicy with light sourish background. Well balanced finish, still fine malty-spicy. Not bad!
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkel goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, würzig. Geschmack würzig malzig, leicht fruchtig, minimale Bitterkeit.

Bottle 500ml. w. swing top. Clear medium yellow orange colour with a average, creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, toasted - caramel, sweet malt, sugary malt. Flavour is moderate tol ight light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, sweet malt, hay. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130216]
Bottle. Deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is malt, pine, grass, caramel. Flavour is malt, hop, caramel, pien, grass. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

Bottle.Pours golden with a small off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, yeast and some fruitiness. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, red apples and fruitiness. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle. It’s a clear, dark golden to amber beer with a small, dense, off-white head. Weak but pleasant aroma with piney notes, grass, pale malts and some peppery hints. Caramel hints, pine cones, grass and pale malts in the mouth, with a decent bitterness all the way. Medium body, dry and pleasantly carbonated. A quite pleasant one, but it fails to put me in the Christmas mood. 130216

Bottle 500ml @ fonefan Pours clear deep golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and floral. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a clear amber with a small white head. Sweet caramellish nose. Medium body, caramellish with some flowery hops. Subdued bittterness. Very clean. 160213
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and grainy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 160213

tap at brewery. hazy dark copper pour with thin creamy head. hoppy, sugar, cardboard, oak, caramel malt aroma. smooth, nicely hopped, citrus, caramel malts. medium body. mild oak. easy drinking. nice brew.

[Aged 4 years] Poured a hazy, red amber color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of madeira, tobacco, light citrus, and orange peel. Taste of sherry, citrus fruits, vanilla, caramel malts, with pine, a bit of cardboard, grassy hops, more, tobacco, and light alcohol in the finish.
Tapped at Southern Sun. I’m feelin this flavor, some hops with real toasty malts and a decent alcohol presence. Strong but clean. Sweeter than my usual tastes but with enough spine to hold it up.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is murky medium-hued caramel-brownn colored with a small, frothy, creamy beigh head. Slowly diminishes. The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, caramel; Hoppy with heavy notes of resin/pine, moderate notes of chewy dried apricot; Yeasty with a light note of dough and a trace of dish rag; Tracec boozy alcohol note. The flavor is moderately-to-heavily sweet, moderately bitter, lightly-to-moderately acidic with a long, light-to-moderately bitter, lightly sweet, trace acidic finish. Light alcohol warmth on finish. The body is full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively.
An unclear brown beer with no head. The aroma is sweet malty, while the flavor is sweet malty combined with notes of roasted malt and alcohol, leading to a dry end. The body is nice.

I thought this beer was "ashy," somewhat harsh, and a little unbalanced. Big, smoky flavors seemed to rule. The palate was spikey (carbonation and alcohol) on the top and a little watery underneath. Finished with a cabbage-like off-flavor I wasn't too fond of. I didn't find it quite as bad as I'm describing it, but I'm focusing on the negatives I found. This beer could be much better after laying down a while.

Draught, served at the Pumphouse strong ale fest. Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately yeaty (dough), lightly malty (dark bread, caramel), moderately hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.
Tap at Pumphouse. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is chocolatey, hint of roast and coffee. Taste is sweet upfront with a little roast to finish, full-bodied, smooth, rich. Overall, nice.

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/09/2009 (2008 Vintage) Big coffee roast aroma. Beige head. Black strong in alcohol and rich on the palate with a little bitterness in a dry hoppy chocolate and coffee roast finish.

Tap at GABF 2005. Pours a deep dark brownish almost black with a thin head. Aroma is very sweet- fruity esters along with a sharp dark crystal malt profile light nutty chocolate and almost no roasted barley. Flavor is also very sweet- too much crystal, lacking on the Roasted barley, no coffee, and low on the chocolate- herbal hops in the end. Meh.

Medium dark brown colored body with light easily shining through at the edges. Somewhat lactic on the tip of the tongue, and harsh as well, with a charred milk note, candied dark plum, cherry syrup and sweet cocoa. Hints at some cream in the middle but finished harsh and astringent.

Crushed with Jakebra at the brewpub. Why is this rated so low? Dark fruits, roast, booze, chocolate and vanilla on the nose. And awesomeness. Plenty of that. Flavor is sexy and the mouthfell might be the best I’ve had in any Imperial Stout. So thick and velvety. Unexpected and absolutely awesome.

2008. Look great, thick black and oily. Brown dissapating head. Weak aroma, dried fruit (maybe). Palate is smooth, not too coating but lingering. Taste of sweet fruit, molassas, alcohol and mocha. Not bad, however we have lefthand imperial stout down the streer and Ten Fidy on tap nearby.
tap at brewery. 2007. black wit thin coffee head. big vanilla aroma. strong vainilla. borders on being very good but it was off just a bit too much and not easy to finish

On tap @ Pumphouse poured an opaque dark brown nearly black with a small lasting brown head. Aromas of dark fruit, bitter chocolate, carmel and light licorice. Palate was medium to full bodied smooth and warming. Flavors of milk chocolate, fruittiness, light vanilla and a hint of carmel with a smooth warming lingering bittersweet finish.
Very high alcohol. Thin-bodied. The aroma, palate, and taste all reveal roasted malts. Burnt brown sugar. Sweet like sherry.

Draft: Black with a beige edge. Tight tiny-bubbled tan head is broken but holds well. Diacetyl (buttered popcorn) and chocolate fudge leap from the glass. Whispers of iron, caramel, dried plums, and a seductive cherry fruitiness. Deceptively light in body. Soft pricks of carbonation. Opens with a refreshingly bright cinnamon-dusted cherry expression which curtails the slight graininess. Crunchy char and black-malt phenols contribute plenty of snap. Fruit character is notably succulent. Lack of malt depth causes the acidity to neutralize much of the fudgelike richness. Irony zing complements the sharpness of the deeply kilned malt. Roasted barley also helps to quell the graininess with its feathery softness. Finishes well-integrated with roasted barley and chalky char with a lasting afterimage of cinnamon and raisins. Phenolic burps. Not a bad effort by any means but the mouthfeel definitely suffers from being too prickly, and the diacetyl hinders what is otherwise a pleasant aroma. Also served way too cold.
tap at brewery. hazy straw pour with thin soapy head. light aroma of wheat and cherry. smooth. light sour chery. mild tartness. well balanced.

Draught. Body is light amber. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly yeasty (dough), moderately hoppy (lemon, flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.
Light and airy with an orange pour. Nose is orange peel and spice. Rated 12/10/04

Dark brown with some reddish-orange highlights. Wonderful nose; powerful rush of sweet malts, specialty grains and wafty yeast esters. Malty, sweet, and yeasty flavors seem to meld perfectly. Banana sweetness is very strong, with maybe too much sweetness; has a sugar water flavor and texture that I didn't like. Hint of bubblegum.

Draught. Body is dark orange-brown. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, dark bread, cookie), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with strong notes of banana, clove, toffee, and brown sugar. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation. A bit sweet, but a great estery aroma.

This is simple the best beer I’ve ever had. Enjoyed on tap at the Blue Cat, it had the best flavor and coffee aroma. A strong malt and chocolate flavor with an excellent coffee finish. An excellent example of a coffee stout! I would like to see it on their permanent menu...definitley worth a 4 hour drive to get some more.

tap at the brewpub. by far the best beer I’ve had at the Blue Cat. this one is all about the coffee. strong aroma and flavor of smooth Guatemalan coffee. medium-bodied with some malt and hops for some balance, but like I said, it’s all about the coffee!

Tried this at the brewpub. I’m a big fan of coffee stouts and I thought this one was good, not much head or body but a very potent coffee flavor hits you in the face like a quadruple shot of espresso. I like that in a beer.

Sampled this beer at the Great Taste of the Midwest in Madison WI. Even though my scores on this are accurate and well researched, ?Da Man? wants me to say more about the beer, so I will. Had a coffee flavor to it, but not one of the better stouts I've ever had.

500ml bottle conditioned; BBE June 2020. Poured slowly into an Abbot Ale glass tankard at home on 27th June 2019. Dull old gold in colour, slight haze; full off-white crown on top. Yeasty 'home brew' sort of aroma, taste also yeast forward in the flavours; some fruitiness and bitterness also to the fore. Got better and better as the 'home brew' initial thoughts got overthrown in my head.

Cask (backlog). Deep golden colour with a small foamy head. Aroma is mild sweet fruits, some wood, mild sap as well as some slight yeasty notes. Flavour is citrus, some tropical fruits, mild maltiness with some herbal notes too.
Fra cask på Fawn Private Members Club, Plymouth 26 Sep 16. Gyldenbrun. Filmskum. Tynn lacing. Lett ferskenaroma. Myk munnfølelse. Lett plommesmak. Blir tørr etter hvert. Lett syrlig ettersmak.

Cask ale, half pint, shared with Finn at Fawn Private Members Club. Clear golden-brown body, solid lacing rings down the glass, filmy layer. Malt-fruity aromas. Flavoured with oily hops and citrus. Rounded bittersweet tail. Refreshing and tasty (Plymouth 26.09.2016).
Bottle from Sidmouth Wines, Sidmouth. Deeper golden-amber coloured ale. with a very small head. Has a very drinkable texture with a good hoppy fruitiness to it.
Cask at Candlelight Inn, Bishopswood. Pours chestnut with off white froth. An earthy traditional bitter. Some toffee, dry. Good nick but nothing more than average.

16th October 2015 Bottle in the Shed Steakhouse, Seaton. Lightly hazy amber beer, small white head. Palate is light and semi dry. Mild fine carbonation. Some tangy caramel. Trace of dust. Tangy dried fruits. Whisper of esters. Semi dry finish. Pretty average.

On cask at Henry’s Bar, Paignton, Devon. Appearance - golden amber with a decent head. Nose - toffee and red fruits. Taste - toffee and jam hybrid. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a dry tangy finish. Overall - would consider this more of a bitter or English pale ale than a golden ale.
(Bottle). Aroma and flavor of malt, grassy hops and some citrus. Unusual amount of carbonation for this type of beer.

Bottle 24th May. Darken golden with a frothy lasting head. Reasonable amount of lacing. Nose is slightly peach with a small hint of sulphur. Taste is citrus with some pineapple notes coming through. Didn't have particularly high expectations but this was pretty enjoyable. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Tap, gold pour, white head, nose is malty, sweet, taste is sweet as well, some toffee, nice.

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Tap. Pours cloudy orange with a small creamy off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is faint pine, citrus, dust. Flavor is lightly sweet, light-plus bitterness. Light body. Meh.

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Tap - small fomay head, dark copper color, fair sized hop flavor, well balanced with sweet malt

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Draught at the Half Moon Bay brewpub. Beige head. Clowdy amber color. Typical English piny hop aroma with just a tuch of caramell. Small but fine bitterness in the taste followed by a piny hop taste and a dry finnish.

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 5/16/11 Aroma: The nose is balanced between caramel malts and some hoppy notes Appearance: It pours a caramel-orange looking color with an off-white head Flavor: The taste is fairly malty for the style, leaning sweet, light hop, unexciting Palate: The body is light-medium, and it has an aliright, but unexciting mouthfeel to it Overall Impression: Overall, I found this to be a decently matly pale ale that isn’t particularly exciting. I don’t have too much to say beyond that.

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Draft. A pale golden beer with a thin white head. The aorma has notes of malt and straw. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and straw, as well as an odd note - I can’t tell if it is an off note or a weird hop, but it gives the beer a note of moldy hay.

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear golden-copper color with a lasting one-finger white head. Aroma is sweet malt and citrus hops, along with a slight marijuana note. Fairly typical except for the wacky weed. Flavor also has sweet pale and caramel malt, orangish and piney hops, and the weed that is wacky. Nothing too out of the ordinary. Medium-bodied with average carbonation and mouthfeel. A decent pale ale overall, drinkable if nothing else. I’m giving a lot of these HMB beers similar ratings, because the quality is very, very consistent here: slightly above average.

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Clear yellow with a creamy white head. Musty grain aroma and a malty slightly brassy vanilla taste and a hint of citrus to the finish.

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: On tap. Clear golden with an off-white head. Lightly piney hop aroma. Medium body, sweetish fruit and malt with some lightly perfumy hops in the finish that don’t leave much bitterness. 090709

column1: Half Moon Bay Pillar Point Pale Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Light fruity and malty aroma. Flavour is mild fruity and slight malty flavoured. Bitter and medium dry finish, light bodied.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: A bit harsh and astringent but not bitter. Just a bit off on the brewing process, pacific standard berkeley

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: From a bomber purchased at the brewery. Pors a hazy amber with an ecru head. Nutty aroma. Flavors of grains, moderately sweet, with a bitter finish.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: This is a very easy to drink amber ale. It doesn't have a ton of flavor which would be my biggest complaint about it

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: On tap at Facebook in Menlo Park, CA. Aroma is wood, caramel, stale herbs, something floral like from my grandma’s house (despite that sounding terrible, I actually enjoyed the aroma). Taste moves to bitter / vegetal wood pretty quickly. Didn’t get a great malt balance but again, enjoyed the strange aroma.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Sampled draft @ Delirium Hoppy Loft. Dark amber orange, little white head. Nose is sweet industrial woody herbal syrup, oddly sticky, unpleasant with low pine resin. Taste is weird plaster, dough, industrial woody syrup,… Feels processed almost. Not a fun, unpleasant industrial-like syrup affair.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Bottle from Cellar Door Four Oaks via Sarkynortherner cheers Martin; clear amber pour with a creamy light tan, aroma has dark fruits, autumn leaves and caramel, taste has toffee, dark fruits, a bit nutty.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Bottle from cellar door, four oaks. Dark amber beer with medium head. Aroma of malts, dry hop and toffee. Taste is toffee, red leaf, malts and some spice. Decent.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Bomber. Tall Boys, Leeds. As Mavericks Amber Ale. Hazy, reddy amber. Good covering of lasting, off white head. Nose has light toffee malts. Some berry fruit. Some earthy nuttiness. Taste is light dry. Light sweet. Foamy mouthfeel. Light dry finish. Probably well past it’s prime, and just about OK as a result.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Draft. Copper beer with a tan head. Malt and light citrus aroma. Light cocoa and light caramel flavor with light citrus. Medium bodied. Light cocoa and light citrus linger. Earlier Rating: 10/29/2008 Total Score: 3.1 Bottle. Rich amber beer with an off-white head. Low malty, light earthy aroma. Caramel, light roast flavor with some lemony citrus hops. Medium body. LIngering citrus hops and caramel. No infection like others have mentioned. Bottle lists alcohol at 4.8%.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Tap, pour is amber, taste is coffee, nose is toffee, malty taste, overall a decent amber.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Tap, brown pour, tan head, nose is coffee, taste is caramel, toffee, overall pretty nice.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Pours a dark brown color with brown head. Malt, caramel and nutty aromas. Malt, caramel and nut flavors. Medium light body and malt finish.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Tap. Pours clear chestnut with a tiny tan head and no lacing. Aroma is caramel and roasted malts. Flavor is the same, lightly sweet, a bit of brown sugar. No real bitterness. Medium body, very little carbonation. Taste is pretty good, but the lack of carbonation hurt the appearance and palate scores.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Draught at the Half Moon Bay brewpub. Short beige head. Nice brown-red color. Light roasted malt aroma. The malts also is perfectly balanced in the taste were it makes a smooth malt carratair that don’t over power your tastebuds. This is complemented by a small bitterness and a medium body.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Draft. A hazy chestnut-brown beer with thin orangey head. The aroma has notes of malt and toffee as well as lighter notes of butterscotch and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of roasted malt and nuts. The body is light. Not really true to style - with the roasted malt and not enough nut flavor.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear medium brown color with an off-white head and average retention. Aroma is your typical nuts, caramel, and mild roast. Not too much going on here. Flavor is that of a rather weak but fairly tasty standard American brown ale. Roasted nuts and caramel are the main flavor notes I get. Simple. "Light bodied" is correct in the description. In fact, it’s pretty watery. Below average on the mouthfeel. Overall, well, it’s not offensive and it’s pretty decent for a true session beer. I like a little more heft to this style though.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with a thin beige head and a treacle aroma. There is a musty smoked malt flavor that is a bit thin, and a dry bitter finish.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Clear reddish copper with a creamy tan head. Sweet malty and mildly chocolate aroma. Tastes of grain toffee and a nice smooth finish with nut notes.

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: On tap. Slightly hazy orangey brown with an off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts and nuts. Medium-bodied, a little low in carbonation, roasted malts and a little nuts and brown sugar. Absolutely no bitterness. 090709

column1: Half Moon Bay Bootleggers Brown Ale
column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: From tap at the brewpub. Pours almost clear and golden brown with a small off-white head. Roasted breadish malt aroma, light caramelish note. Light bodied, dry and roasted malt flavoured. Bitter and roasted malt flavoured finish.

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: On draft at the Brewpub. Mild mannered forgettable brew. Maybe a "starter" beer for folks looking to learn and experience something beyond Bud, Miller, and Coors?

column2: Saratoga Springs, New York, United States
column5: Amber body topped by a medium thick head. Sweet malty aroma and flavor with fruity accents and hoppy undertones with a slightly hoppy finish. Medium bodied and relatively smooth.
Dark copper, clear, beige head. Aroma of bready-nutty malt, a little raisin. Flavor: toffee, hint of leather, raisins, toasty notes, finishes malty. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A step up from other McMenamins, mainly because it wasn"t carbonated to the level of soda pop. Frothy, with a huge mouthfeel and head. Taste could be better, but this was alright.
Much higher in alcohol than other McMenamins brews. Has a nice coppery coloring to it, with a medium head. Rather bitter, brewmaster said it was over 70 ibu"s. Not bad.

*Old rating, best before 16.06.10. Würzig-getreidiges, feinherb aber zu süßliches Alkoholfrei. Etwas penetrant, die Herbe ist etwas eindimensional und kann die alkoholfrei-getreidige Note nicht ganz überdecken.

Hellgelb mit ordentlicher Blume. Typisch leicht säuerliche Nase von der Gärungskohlensäure umgibt den verhaltenen Hopfenduft. Dünner, wässriger Antrunk. Ziemlich herb für ein Bleifreies, was ich aber nicht schlecht finde.
Getreidiger Antrunk, typisch alkoholfrei. Ansonsten mild, penetrant bitter. Ein Alkoholfreies, das sich von anderen nicht abhebt. 10/6/5/6/7/5

Bottle 33cl. Clear medium to dark yellow color with a large, frothy - fizzy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, corn, vegetable, coocked corn, cardboard. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20090309]
Pale yellow, almost no head. Aroma and flavor of mash and raw barley, watery and gross.
Pale yellow with a disappearing white head. Unripe sweet malt and maize aroma. Thin and harsh flavor of maize and some citrus. Bad!
Bottled: Light yellow coloured. White head. Samle. Sweet, malty and skunky aroma. Man is that unpleasant. Flavour is water with iron. Some vague hops notes. Well, this is one hell of a shitty beer.

A yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet malty, but also like soap water. The flavor is sour and hoppy - hoppy to cover for the lack of alcohol, and ofcourse the body is thin. I’ve tried better non-alcoholic beers.

Yellow gold, highly carbonated, huge white fluffy head, fast collapsing. Nose with grain, straw and honey. Quite bitter initial taste. Problem is, nothing follows. Watery palate, extremely thin. For what it is, it's OK (nice nose). And it proves once more nablabs are not for the likes o' me.
Straw aroma. Golden, no carbonbation, no head. Water + cardboard = next beer please.
Decent helles, crisp and clean. Not as grainy as the others. But very drinkable. D&S Dresden
Many thanks for this bottle to kappldav123. Pours clear pale yellow with a small white head. Malty flavor. Very grassy. Medium bodied
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.

Bottle 500ml. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, pale malt, straw - grass, sour malt notes, light hoppy, grass - straw. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, dry, dusty malt, sweet malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20121110]
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, grain. Flavour is fruit, malt, grain. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

Bottle, danke David. Light hazy amber, offwhite creamy lace. Fresh apple aromatics. Fruity base, apple and pear notes, light grain/bread, good grassy, light citric hops. Medium chewy body, light sparkly, a hint minerals. Grassy, salty aftertaste. Pleasant.

500 ml bottle. BB 07/12/12. From bierzwerg.de. Clear pale golden colour with tiny white head. Weak aroma of malt and mild sweetish fruitiness. Flavour is malt, grain, straw and maybe a little hint of sweetish fruits. Hmm... maybe a bit too plain and easy to step up.

Bottle. It’s a clear, golden beer topped by a small, dense, off-white head. Grainy, malty and lighlty fruity nose with some notes of DMS. The flavor too has that DMS touch, but it’s mostly hidden by the grains and fruityness. Medium body, quite dry. A nice bitterness in the end. Not a favorite of mine, but it drinks easily and has some quenching qualities. 121110
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and grainy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 101112
Bottle, 5% @ FOneFan. Clear golden with small white head. Aroma is malt, straw and grainy. Flavour is malt, grainy, little sweet, grass, straw and a little bitter.
33cl Flasche. Gelbes Bier, heller flacher Schaum. Malz, Getreide und etwas Säure in der Base. Dünner Geschmack.

(Falsche) Es hat eine zitronengelbe Farbe, ist blank filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist getreidig, süßlich mit einem klein Bisschen Diacetyl und einer leichten Weißweinnote. Der Geschmack ist schlank, weißweinartig, wird dann wässrig im Abgang. Nach dem Abgang bleibt eine kleine breite unangenehme Bittere übrig .

(bottle) pours a slightly hazy golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of herbal hops, straw and grass, slightly metallic, with a hint of bread dough. flavour is straw, marzipan and peaches, slightly sweet and oxidized, with a very faint bitter finish. light to medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Bottle 33cl. Small white head. Very light color, carbonation quite normal. Aroma has corn and malt. Flavour is malt with a cardboard touch. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma i is malt, grain, grass. Flavour is malt, grain, grass, citrus. Thin body. Boring beer.
Bottle from Haus der 131 Biere, Hamburg. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, light malty and grainy. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. Watery. 221212

Bottle. Pours golden with an off-white head. Aroma of fruitiness, malt, sugar, grains and rubber. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some sour yellow apples and metallic notes. Medium to thin body, average carbonation.

Bottle. It pours a small, white head over a clear, pale golden body. The aroma is quite fruity, lightly lemony and with some pale malts. Sort of feels a bit infected. Strange thing is, I think it adds an interesting twist to the beer. It’s lightly acidic on the palate, with lemon peel, pale malts and a generic fruityness. Rather thin on the palate, with decent carbonation. Well, drinkable it is, but it’s certainly far, far from interesting. 121102
Bottle 330ml @ Geokkjer Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and grass. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottled 330ml. -at Allstars Cafe, Bratislava. Paid 4.50€ for this crap. Yellow coloured, small white head, ordinary dusty pils nose. Grassy, weak malty and cardboard with short finish. Waste of money and time for sure.
Bouteille 341 ml. 4%. Couleur jaune, arôme de maïs. En bouche c’est une light mais encore mieux que la Coors Light et Bud Light.

nothing special about this one. Aroma is of a stale iron-like quality. Has a slight and fast disappearing head with golden yellow color. Has an inoffensive taste of corn and hops, neither bold nor daring. A little too carbonated to be a favorite. The price is right for those summer afternoons out on the lake with relatives.
Bottle. Pours pale yellow with a white head. Aroma of corn, grain, and sweet malts. Flavor is watered down, weak, corn, grain. Thin bodied, nothing good.
Pale, yellow, huge fizzy white head. No lacing. Faint aromas of corn, minerals, some malt. Taste is watery, iron, corn. Sweet aftertaste in the least amount. Plain, ordinary. Another coors light.

An uncle had a few bottles of this at a recent family function so I thought what the hell, give it a try. A piss poor pale piss colour beer (get the idea?) but the taste is actually quite inoffensive - only mildly grain like with no real offensive of skunky tastes - just a watery light malt taste and no finish at all. Like Coors Light, for people who like to pee.
Rather sweet aroma, light and soft. Pours white medium head. Medium to light body. Fairly clean , smooth . Drinkable .Slightly watery finish . Not bad for a light beer from big maker .
Light sweet aroma. Pale gold with thin white fully diminishing head. Watery, grainy, sweet flavour. Thin. Bottle.
I think this is a great beer and it has nothing to do with price. I've been drinking it for around 7 years and have had no reason to switch. It tastes great, smells great, and looks great.
This beer is ok, but not really, since molson has taken this product off the market

Bottle, 2016. Red gold, fine pearling. Dry pear, appleskin marzipan sparkles, medium dry sparkly, fullbodied sweetness, sparkly chewy. Hazlenut, old pear, marzipan, impressive balance - dry to sweet, fruity to dry spice. No nonsense great drink.

2016 bottle. Clear deep golden color with white head. Aroma is red apples, vanilla, custard, good funk. Taste is vanilla, juicy red apples at first, then immediately the funk takes over, light hazelnut, going towards a dusty, bone-dry finish. Bone dry, foamy carbonation. Great bone dry Cidre if you are into that. Lots of character going on here, no compromises, bold and balanced at the same time.
Glass at Byn. Golden with low head. Funky aroma. Fresh apple, some sweetness and funky notes.
Sampled at the 2018 MN Craft Cider Festival at Como Park in St. Paul, MN. I just didn't like this one.
75cl bottle. Clear golden with a small white head. Apples, wood, lightly mineral and funky.

750ml bottle from Systembolaget vintage 2015. Clear golden, a lot of bubbles in the glass. Sweet red apple aroma, earthy and oaky background. Sweet and dry feel. Sweet ripe red apple taste, woody and white sugars. Bone dry finish.
Bottle - pours clear gold with a white head. It’s dry, funky, barnyard, and did I say dry?
Bottle from Cellar D’Or. pours light brown with a lot of effervescence and carbonation. Nice Apple notes on the nose. Very dry on the tongue. Lots of Apple and wood notes. Finished clean. Nice!
Sample at SBWF 2016. Fruity smell with oak and apples. Similar taste. Crisp. Dry finish. Refreshing.

Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle corked and capped, 2014 bottle poured into a glass. Hazy deep golden with small white head. Aroma is light Apple & wood, medium/light body, medium carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is lighter apple, a little wood, and pretty dry. May of been sweeter and better for my tastes fresh.
Bottled. Hazy orange coloured with an off white head. Aroma of spices, caramel and fruits. Flavour of spices, caramel and fruits.
Bottled. Pours a cloudy dark brown. Aroma is yeasty, wheaty, and of bananas. Taste is sweet wheat, caramel, and some banana.
Bottle. Red brown colour with a small tan head. Sweet wheaty caramel aroma and taste. Medium body and a sweet light dry finish.

An unclear red-brown beer with a small collapsing brown head. The aroma is sweet with clear notes of wheat and very strong notes of caramel and toffee, but also hints of banana. The flavor is sweet with lots of caramel, but also light notes of wheat and a dry roasted end.

Bottle opens with a bang and seems to be heavily carbonated - this is not noticable later in the beer however. A sour nose more fitting for a dairy product. Murky brown, head dies quickly. Bland soapy taste. Feels like it leaves a sticky residue on the tounge. This beer is the worst dunkelweizen I have ever tasted!

Pale yellow body. The nose is rich apples with some dry oak notes. Very sweet smelling. The taste is very dry with only a little bit of apple core. It is a very muted flavor. The finish is lingering with some more of that apple core character and hints of black pepper spice. The alcohol isn’t really noticed. This is a weird one in that it seems like it wants to have more character than a macro cider, and it does with obvious real ingredients. However, it is still fairly muted in the taste. I would like a little more character.

750 ml bottle. Very pale yellow with almost no head. Strong apple aromas. A nice tart, dry apple flavor with a hint of pears as well. Very dry finish. My first "micro-cider". Very drinkable, I’d have it again.

Name: Gale’s Hard Cider Date: 07/21/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Indy clear pale yellow, frothy white head, strone apple aroma with a good balance between the sweet and the tart, very dry apple flavor with wave after wave of tartness, very clean finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
Sweet aroma of apples. Light yellow in color, no head. Light mouth feel with mild sourness. Pleasant, sweet body. Very akin to white wine. I’m a fan.

Sampled on 10/14/2006 at the winery... Sample was poured from a large pitcher. Color was *almost* the color of water and just as clear. Barely any carbonation. Light apple aroma. Crisp, subtle apple flavor. Not really sweet, but not really dry either. Finish reminded me of a generic white wine. Palate was very thin, again like water. Everything about this cidar seemed to be light - too light. I was hoping for a little more fruit flavor and carbonation. Overall this cidar was not very exciting, but I will give this winery credit for offering something a little different besides just having wine. I also grabbed a bottle of the Gale’s Hard Cidar "The Chieftan’s Blend" which might be a bit more interesting...
(draft- Indiana brewers fest) Yellow fizzy and smooth commerical cider with a sour apple nose, and a dry lactic taste with fresh apple.

750 ml bottle, labeled as 7% ABV. Very pale, almost totally clear yellow with slight bubbling and no top fizziness, no "pop." Light fresh nose, slight hints of alcohol. Very light and dry, rather bland actually...lightly alcoholic, lightly buttery, but overall lacking in fruity sweetness and too smooth. A disappointment. Purchased at that Mecca of great cider and beer in S. Indiana, New Albanian/Rich-O’s.
