Though described as "strong and dry", I'd have to cast my vote differently. It is actualy more sweet and crisp than strong and dry. It is up to par with most most domestice ciders made at small orchards. Its light with little to no carbonation. Very clear and tastes best well chilled. Mild alcohol aftertaste.

Gelb-braun, reichlich trüb und mit viel Schaum. Ein schönes Apfelaroma macht sich neben der Hefenote breit. Weicher Antrunk. Würzig-brotiger Geschmack, der in eine ausgeprägte Hopfenbittere übergeht. Was mir nicht gefällt ist, dass das Bier so gut wie keine Kohlensäure aufweist. Insgesamt ok.
Bottled. A hazy orange beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of straw, leading to a bitter finish. The body is thin.
Bottle, 5.6%. Slightly bready aroma. Clear golden colour, very small white head. A bit of sweet notes, and quite bready. 2 months past BB date.
Ölbaren, Copenhagen: nice head, sweetly light aroma. Fairly thin and unremarkable but not bad.
(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pilsener golden with a small, creamy, off-white head. Slightly buttery nose. Medium body with very sweet malt. Almost no bitterness. A classical Helles. 261006
Bottle. Golden colour with a big white head. Hoppy aroma and a light bitter taste. Medium body and a light sweet bitter finish.
Golden color with a white head. The taste is full bodied malty sweetnes with a very light bitterness on the palate. Comes off a little thin, but overall drinkable.

Like their dunkelweisse the swing-top bottle opens with a bang - curiously enough there is little CO_2 in the beer itself. Straw golden, low head. Maltish sweet aroma, a little hint of chlorine. Very bland and watery, and they definetly forgot to buy sensible hops in it - even if I would pee in my homebrew it would be better. Maximilian must be a cheap beer outlet for another brewery - I will have to investigate that.
Bottle pours out a pale straw topped with a small fizzy head. Nose is earthy sour apple and a touch of sweetness. Taste is more of the earthy sour tart notes and a funky apple.
Bottle. A- Apple. A- Gold color, clear liquid, no head. T- Stale, apples. P- Light body, average texture, flat carbonation, bland finish. O- Tasted like an expired Redds. Bleh.

Poured from a jug at Froschkonig in Frankfurt, Hesse, Germany. Pale straw with no head. My first experience of German Apfelwein and it was rather unfortunate. Thin and watery with a vague apple note. Slight tartness, dry. Not good at all.
Aroma: earth, apple juice, acid. Taste: sour, appel-y, refreshing. Not much else to say here
09-12-17 // 300ml at Rüsselsheimer Bräu. Classic Frankfurt applewine. Clear golden. Dry apples,, mild yeast. Some sourness.

Trockener Apfelantrunk. Wässriger Hintergrund, weich fruchtig. Die eh milden Apfelnoten verschwinden zusehends im Hintergrund, es bleibt ein trockenes und wenig karbonisiertes Getränk. Noch ok. 9/7/8/7/7/7
A classic in the region of Frankfurt. Drinkable, but from the bottle it does not match the individually pressed ones of the many smaller cellars and pubs.

Bottle from a supermarket in Dusseldorf. Pours straw colour. The taste is sour watery apple. A little tartness. Flat carbonation. I can see why apfelwein hasn’t conquered the world. Just about drinkable.

Many thanks fort this Apple wine to marisz. 1000ml and drink only about 150ml. Zwykly, wodnisty napoj lekko gazowany, lekko kwaskowy i lekko owocowy, oczywiscie delikatne odmiany jablek. Przypominalo mi troche nasze papierowki z ogrodu. Na upal i dla kilku osob jakos moze byc. Ale do powolnego saczenia i sie delektowania to raczej nie, bardzo wodniste.
100cl bottle. clear golden color. no head. dry and sourish. taste of sour apples. medium bitterness. ok considering the cost (~2 euros)

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: Enjoyed on tap at the brewery, clocking in at 8.3% and IBU 32. Two months of barrelageing. A bite of burnon. Very dark Colour had red highlights, lace lines left as she went. Some sour stout roast. A winish taste, in a word. Above average mouthfeel.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: ~8oz glass @ brewpub, 8.4%. Pours with a black body and a tan head. Absolutely no clarity and looks like a stout. Very roasty aroma, again akin to a stout. However here come the other aspects, a traditional earthy maltiness and some chocolate even below that. Taste is not heavy, peppered with nutty/earthy maltiness, light peat, some cocoa sweetness. No alcohol burn but just a hint of alcohol heft. Slightly under-carbonated body. A great thirst quencher with lots of character, recommended and would have again.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: On tap in a snifter at the brewery. This year’s has some chocolate in it and weighs in at 8.6% ABV. Very nice beer, a bit like a scotch ale/porter hybrid. Cocoa and peat in the flavor. Sooo very easy drinking, the high ABV is practically undetectable. Watch City nailed this one.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: On draught 4/06/2005 at Redbones. Though the glass was convex and I was in a bar (though not smokey), I could immediately smell a strong treacle/molasses aroma, with brown sugar, thick, dark malts, quite sweet, and a bit of light roast. Very intense aroma. The body is a dark brown, opaque and unfiltered with a small light beige head, that slowly recedes to a ring. There is not so much lacing, as there is coating of the glass. Flavor begins with a sugary (brown sugar, molasses) malt, that is thick, chewy and lasting of flavor. A touch of dryness, ever so light, begins to show on the palate, with light roast, a touch of earthiness and faint warming from the alcohol. Sweet chocolate, caramel and toffee are in full force through the middle of the beer. As it begins to finish, the flavors continue to dry some, with the peat smoke lingering lightly in the background, increasing in apparency as the beer warms, but never adding more than just an enticing hint. On the very finish, dry, earthy notes (light wood, barley, brown bread) are apparent but do not really challenge the caramel and brown sugar. Full body, wonderfully creamy and yet drinkable. Though the beer leans heavily towards the sweet side, I didnt feel the balance was thrown off. If they knew how to bottle beer well at Watch City (based on all of my experiences, they don’t) this could age marvelously.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: Big round malty aroma is very sweet and appealing. Clear dark brown with ruby highlights and generous, fine-bubbled, off-white head that recedes to ring with some lacing. Big, sweet, round malty flavours with some doughy yeast notes and caramel and toffee sweetness that lead you through to a lightly roasty finish with just a hint of peat. Smooth creamy texture with moderate carbonation and medium-full body. Truly well-made and enjoyable. Sampled at the brewpub with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: Roasted malts and the dry crust of pumpernickel bread gain weight with the rich caramel it is fed with...Coffee beans and fruity esters dance freely in the round body, as roasty bitterness serves as a curtain call...The hands-down winner of this afternoon of sampling at Watch City...

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: Very dark brown body. Head is initially quite big, light brown, foamy and displaying excellent lacing. Aroma initially scares with its sour hints, but that’s more from the breadiness than anything else. It smells very toasty, biscuity with strong dried caramel, molasses and pudding notes. I wish this were more intense because this is truly enjoyable to whiff. The palate answers the expectations. A strong peatiness ensures a lengthy finish, earthy, rich and generous. Ample sweet malt profile procures a generous body, creamy, comfortable through its light carbonation. More malt development leads into toasty chocolate and leather goodness. This may actually be one of the top 5 scotch ales I’ve had.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: Dark brown in color with ruby highlights and a small tan head with large loose bubbles. Sweet malty aroma with a touch of alcohol,oak, dark fruit and cherries. Flavor starts sweet and ends dry with a good malt presence, subtle roasted grain,chocolate and molasses.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: Yeah, this was a strong ale that felt strong going down. Deep color that draws you in, with a type of light brown froth around the edge of the glass. Maybe its the peat that makes it so heavy, but you feel as if you've eaten a joint of beef after drinking half a glass. Otherwise, quite smooth, with a medium bite and a nice pointed flavor.

column1: Watch City Skye High Scotch Ale
column5: Sweet and malty the way a scotch ale should be, but this one is much more heavily hopped than most, which makes of a more pleasant, drinkable beer.
Bottle. Hazy dark golden colour with a big white head. Wheaty citrus and banana aroma and taste. Medium body and a light sweet finish.

Ok, now I am used to it: All the bottles from Maximilian open with a bang. Some standard clove aroma, but also a hint of chlorinelike aromas. Looks are pretty ordinary, allthough the cloud is a bit grey and the head retention could be better. Lightbodied, but other than that a standard cheap weisse.
A beautiful, smooth, roasty, dark beer with mild acid fizz and some oaky wine qualities. A light to medium body which is disturbed by the constant mild fizz. Enjoyable, decent quality beer.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Enjoyable beer, brewed with vanilla beans. There is cinnamon and nutmeg in the aroma. I enjoyed this brew. Hoppy and malty.

column2: New Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
column5: Previous rating 2.1. This beer did not smell anything like it tasted. Nutmeg/Cinnamon nose reminded me of XMas. There was a very obvious "chemical" flavor on first swallow however, which laid on the tongue throughout the entire glass. The cinnamon flavor remained prominent throughout, but that could not save this watery beer. ****RE-RATE 02/13/2005 on tap at brewery**** This brew has improved. No more sickly chemical flavor and the aroma resonated with pine and resin. Flavor is filled with vanilla esscence with a bit of cinnamon and ginger.

pours clear bright yellow with a small white head, little retention and lno lacing. faint grainy maltiness - sweetish, booze (!), lots of cardboard, caramel touch, corn, dust, grass, pepper, chalk and minerals. moderate carbonation, light body - slightly watery, bland yet balanced herbal-grassy finish. awkward booziness for stated abv. inoffensive yet some flaws show compared to regular carling.

Can (710 ml). Shared by AdamJackson, thanks(?). Clear yellow with a small white head and little lacing. Aroma is of corn, light sweetness and hints of lemon. Taste is very similar. Light body. Medium carbonation. Bland, but not offensive.
Totally no appearance I mean sort of yellow. meh. leather shoe, dry grain, corn and a touch of lemon. Quite bland. Not a lot going on. creamed corn, some light sweetness at the finish.

Alors, je suis tombé sur une autre bière qui ne mérite pas l’appellation. Elle est jaune pâle, ayant une mousse respectable qui dure un tant soit peu. Les odeurs sont propres aux bières bon marché/grand public, c’est-à-dire qu’il y a du malt et c’est à peu près tout. De la gazéification s’immiscent au travers. Un goût sans surprise d’effervescence, de sirop de maïs et de malt. Bière pour les gens qui n’aiment pas la bière. Parfait pour se gargariser. (376-280912)

Cannette 710 ml. 5.5%. Une nouvelle image pour Carling. Couleur jaune or, mousse blanche. Arôme de céréale. En bouche, douce, pas trop d’alcool...un peu plus relevé que la lager. Finale sans histoire.

Canette de 710ml. Version 5,5%. Bière blonde dorée avec une mousse blanche commerciale. Nez de grain et d’alcool. La bouche est classique des ales-lagers mal de têtes canadiennes. Du grain, du glucose et avec pas de houblon !!!
Very thin head, boring carbonated gold body. Yawn. Faint lemon aroma. Yawn. Slight grain-caramel taste with a dry finish. Yawn. Not an awful lager, but certainly a boring one.
Swillfest ’04: Pale. Aroma stings with highly inappropriate phenols. Grainy palate thankfully shows no sign of them. Slightly tart finish. A non-event after that disgusting aroma.
Clear gold, small white head. Fruity malt, sweet sugars. Bready , sweet lager , plain brew . Extra dry ? Now that’s a joke.
this beer, is not one of molson good beers. Better off just getting the regular carling.

Pours cloudy amber with a really frothy head. Aroma of pineapple, pine, maybe some guava. Taste is piney, malty, quite bitter, then ends on a slightly sweet note. Not super good, but still appealing. Aftertaste lingers. Like the bike theme on the bottle. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Blah...very disappointing brew. Light mild grainy nose with a bit of a perfumey floral and grassy hop note. Light maltiness in the taste as well with a mild dry finish and a few citrus notes. The hops are boring, the malts are non-existant. This beer is boring!

pours clear yellow-y brown with a thin ring of white. very perfume-y aroma... a combination of citrus, caramel malt and dirty pine. the flavor is a lot alike... buttery caramel, orange/citrus-y hops, citrus pith, sweet earthy pine and some spice on the finish. it is medium bodied... a little prickly and sharp yet creamy at times. 6/3/6/3/13/3.1
Pours copper with a thin off white head. Smells citrussy with some resiny hints. Tastes bitter and peppery with a splash of resin on the finish.
Deep gold with creamy white head and lace. Light citrus aroma. Medium malt, citrus, and a nice finishing bitter. A foamy medium bodied beer. Not bad but not your standard ipa either.

Im going to put my rating here. On tap at the 2008 Strong Ale Festival and listed as an IPA although the notes say Big IPA and ABV of 8.6. Poured a medium golden-amber color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of some fresh hoppiness and earthy. Tastes of fresh hops, citrus, pine, and lighter caramel.

Sample at the brewpub. This beer pours a clear amber-orange color with a medium thin and foamy white head that dissipates steadily. Large patches of lacing on the glass. Some hops and earthy malt in the nose. Medium-bodied with a fairly even ratio of hops and malt flavor. Light floral notes here and there as well. The finish is sweet malt with a touch of hops lingering in the aftertaste. Average overall.

From a growler (which I now wish I hadn’t bought): Pours a very light amber with a thin head that lasts through out. Aromas of malt, hops, and pine. Flavor is more of the same with some earth and mustiness. Light dry finish. Not a bad beer but it was hardly worth the trip, and I live in Vegas.

Consumed on draft at brewery, 12/30/07. Clear, medium gold. No lacing. Thin skin of foam. Metallic note in aroma with citrusy hops. Moderately hoppy on initial taste with malt character emerging after. Aftertaste of malt. Weird: reversed the usual order of malt and hop flavors! Regardless, it is well-balanced and smooth. Not bad and a little unusual to boot.
on tap-pours a retaining off white head and gold color. Aroma is funky earthy/woody hops, earthy medium malt. Taste is earthy/woody hops, earthy medium malt. OK carbonation. Fully English style.

Name: Max American Porter Date: 08/30/2002 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Brown, whispy head, rich slightly sweet chocolate aroma, rich chocolate malt flavor, dry, touch of roasted bitterness in the finish Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Very similar to the Max Black, with the burned brownies and smoke although there was more brownie and less burning and smoking. The flavor is more subdued, less sharp. It's also darker than the Black with smaller highlights that are just brown instead of ruby. That's topped by a fluffy light tan head that is slow to leave.

column1: Hal and Mals Trophy Buck Stout
column5: I could detect very little aroma; very dark, as you'd expect from a stout; definite coffee taste

column1: Hal and Mals Trophy Buck Stout
column5: Great mocha and cream aroma, unfortunately the beer didn't deliver what the smell promised. Flat, milky palate that needs more CO2 or hops or bitter malt or something. Pitch with camel head. Lactose sweet and only moderately bitter. Decent, but lacking character and too one-dimensional in the lactose sweet department. Nothing like Guiness, as the commercial desc suggests.

column1: Hal and Mals Trophy Buck Stout
column5: Nice flavor, very similar to Guinness. Think and chocolatey. Will drink again. Even better this time. A more complex and thicker chocolatey flavor. Almost like Young's double chocolate stout. Much better than last time with the flavor suddenly tasting unlike Guinness in a draught can.

Pint. Czarny kolor. Piana obfita,gęsta,kremowa o beżowym kolorze. Dominuje ciemna czekolada,kawa,dość dużą paloność,gorzkie ziarna kakaowca,w tle nuty lukrecji i ciemnych owoców. Gładkie o małym wysyceniu jak na portera.

Cask at great northern hall jdw, Liverpool [be] had this loads of times before but hadn't yet rated it for some reason. Rich and leafy bitterness, dark brown with frothy grey-tan head. Cocoa and burnt toast nose. Moderate body and carbonation dry finish

Bottle @ benzai. Black colour with a small offwhite head. Smells liquorice, roasty, earthy. Tastes liquorice, roasty, chocolate. Unfortunately some iron too I think. Iron goes away as it warms up a little. Medium body, soft carbo.
From cask at Cask, Manchester, with OGJ 07.01.18. Ebony. Dense and persistent brown head and lacing. Aroma and taste of rosted malt, creosote, tar, coffee and cigar box. Smooth mouthfeel.

Cask at Cask, Manchester. Pours black with a big creamy tan head. Stoutish aroma, weak roast, sweet coffee and chocolate. Taste is initially sweet dark fruits, pluss with a light charred finish. Creamy mouthfeel , soft carbonated

Cask @ Trades Club, Hebden Bridge. Black with a frothy off-white head. Light tasting and easy drinking as it slips down the palate with ease. Has a hardly noticeable roasted aroma and taste, but even so is very enjoyable and could easily be a dark session ale.

Cask at Sheffield Tap. Nearly black. Thin, tight, lasting all the way down, milky coffee coloured head. Lovely looking beer. Aroma is dark, vinous fruit. Roast malt. Some licorice. Taste is dark fruit dry, with a hint of treacle sweetness. Long, dry roasty finish, with some bitterness. Very nice.

Cask at Charlies. Clear red-brown coloured with a small off-white head. Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel and licorice. Sweet and roasted flavour of caramel and bread with notes of hops and eucalyptus. Hoppy finish.

Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. Dark amber beer with a small beige head. Malty fruity aroma, chocolate, sweet licorice, raisins, prunes, citrus notes, some vanilla, some weak hop notes. Malty flavor, roasted, chocolate, sweet licorice, caramel, raisins, some soot. Drinkable but a bit thin.
Gravicask (CWAF2013, Sat) Soft mellow roast malts. Mellow sweet grains. A touch of bitter hops. A very good porter despite there being no jump-out features. Solid.
Perfectly pleasant bitter, not too sweet, balanced bitterness and a nice bit of fruit. Pale amber, cream head. Fine.
Not as cloyingly sweet as expected. Amber ale. Honey (obviously), a slight tartness, stone fruits, plums.

Cask gravity at the Watford beer fest 2015. Amber / copper coloured pour with a sticky off white head. Aroma is unrefined sugars, burnt toffee, honey, earthy, brambles. Flavour is composed of tangy earthy honey, green apple, nutty grains, quite sweet. But stale. Palate is medium sweet, dry grains, tangy moderate carbonation. Honey munch cereal.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A clear amber colour with a medium white head. Aroma of caramel, honey, biscuit and some fruit. Taste of caramel, sweet honey, berry fruitiness and soft floral hops. Light bodied and a smooth texture. A sweet, smooth, malty finish. A pleasant, smooth honey beer
Cask @ Polished Knob, Todmorden. Bright copper-golden with a small head. Sweet aroma and a fine smooth drinking texture. A medium bitterness elsewhere.

Cask handpump at The Norfolk, Colchester. A dull brown colour, minimal head. Not overpowering on the honey front, but its there, along with hint of caramel. Not great, but OK (have had much better from this brewer in the past).
Cask by handpump at Wee Howff, Paisley (6 Oct 12) - clear amber, medium bubbly white head, sweet malt aroma, fruity, toffee, very sweet, easy to drink

Cask [gravity dispense] at GBBF, day 3 on 3 August 2006. Clear amber colour. Aroma is not too bad - some light biscuit malt with a touch of fruit salad. However, on the palate there’s a sort of washed out honey feel that I find rather unpleasant. It’s as if the honey flavour has gone but the sweetness is left behind. And in a rather watery body with very little hop presence to liven things up. Not great.
Cask. A hazy golden beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, leading to a dry toffeeish finish.

Cask (handpump) @ Rat & Ratchet (Ossett), 40 Chapel Hill, West Yorkshire, Huddersfield Road, HD1 3EB. Clear medium amber color with a average to large, creamy to frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, honey, keller, berry, sour malt notes. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100119]

Second beer with my meal and better than the first but not by much. Amber with a bit of bubbly off white head. Light caramel and a bit of sugary maybe its honey with some faint earthy hop to counter. Sitting in a restaurant on the French Shore in Newfoundland with country music coming through the speakers overhead and 3 tables around me speaking french is a bit of a culture clash. Drink up the bar is calling.

Bottle at The Ship. Clear golden color white edge head. Subtle cocoa aroma. Even more subtle malt taste on a lager like background. Given the color I thought it might be a predecessor of today’s blonde stouts, sadly no
Draft - Biscuit and light malts. Clear gold with a decent white head. Light honey sweetness and a long honey malty bready finish.

341 ml bottle @ Mariner's Goose Bay. Pours a clear dark gold with a very thin white head. Aromas of crystal malt and and purple cabbage (verified by wife!). Tastes are mildly sweet malt and a bit of biscuit (thankfully no cabbage!). Light body, low carbonation, short malty finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy
Poured from a bottle. Clear golden color, medium white. Medium sweet and sour grain aroma. Medium body with a crisp grain flavor and a medium finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma of malt with a hint of yeast and honey. Pours a clear pale honey color. Taste of honey and malt with a light body and a sweet honey finish.

Pours a clear deep gold to pale amber with a short white head dissipating rapidly to a thin ring and no lacing. Nose is honey, light grain and malt, slightly floral. Taste is caramel and biscuity malt with hint of honey. Medium body and smooth, with moderate to prickly sustained carbonation. Well, it’s not brown, but it’s sorta honey. (I’ll be generous there, since it’s local, and assume it’s more "honey" and less "corn syrup".) I’ve of course had a great many of these over the years, but really the best one can say about it is, it gets the job done. Eventually. If “the job” is “quench thirst” and/or “impair judgement”. It’s better than an adjunct lager… barely. Fairly mediocre, overall.
In bottle .. this wasn’t good. very light bodied, almost watery. No aroma and really no flavor. I would not buy this again at all.

Thanks to my bro for bringing this back for me from NFLD. This is pretty bad. Especially for a "honey brown". This is even worse than Sleeman’s Honey brown, which i found more palatable than this. Pours golden with grain and corn aromas. Nothing sweet or honey-like about this beer. Bitter finish....but not in a good way. It’s so mediocre in every way I’m surprised the Manitoba Liquor Commission hasn’t brought it in yet.

Golden colored beer with not very much aroma. The honey taste is not overpowering but it's definitely there. The aftertaste is a bit lingering but overall not horrible. Crisp taste off the top that eventually mellows.
Sampled at Great American Beer Festival 2019 in Denver, Colorado. Smooth, sweet, hints of coffee.
Roast and some caramel. Dark chocolate. Pours black with good head and lacing. Bittersweet finish.
12 oz can poured into a frosted pint glass. A delicious and classic Porter. Just perfect on this first seemingly chilly day of Autumn. Will be drinking more of these this Winter. Cheers!

Draft sample at the source. The beer is a clear brown with a beige head of foam. Roast and caramel with nuts and toffee in the aroma. Fairly roasty and a little sweet. Medium body and medium carbonation.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazed brown with a medium sized tan head. Soft roast, toast, malt on the nose, toast and cocoa, chocolate and cocoa. Medium bodied, roast, chocolate, thins a touch. Cocoa, slow roast and chocolate into the finish.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a cloudy brown with medium tan head that lasts. The aroma is roast, cocoa, wheat. Medium body, roasted malt, dark chocolate, cracker, light dry finish, good.

Type: 12-oz. can Glass: Clear 14.75-oz. porter/stout tulip From: Whole Foods in Boise, Idaho Price: $9.99 for a variety 6-pack Purchased: April 21, 2017 Consumed: April 25, 2017 Reviewed as: American Porter Misc.: Canned on Feb. 13, 2017 Picked this up with five others at Whole Foods on a recent work rip to Boise and later grabbing five more at Bier:Thirty. Had reviewed two others from Sockeye back in 2013 and enjoyed them both, giving the original Dagger Falls a 4.04 and a special cranberry kolsch at 4.13. Also liked the Mango Dagger Falls (3.81) and Winterfest (3.88), which I also picked up on the trip. Poured a dark brown color with 1-to-2 fingers of khaki frothy head that thinned out quickly. A few bubbles coming up from the bottom of the glass. Good sporadic lacing. Very good retention. (Sight - 3.75) Smelled big roasty malts in espresso, dark chocolate, anise, semi-char wood, toast, roasted barley, dark cocoa powder and toasted toffee. (Smell - 3.75) Tasted a bit better than the nose, almost like a dark milk stout. Liked it. Got dark milk chocolate, espresso, cocoa nibs, chocolate syrup, roasty malts, toast, woody anise, hints of char wood and sweetly toasted toffee. (Taste - 4.25) Medium body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, roasty finish. (Feel - 4.00) Really liked this one. Would like to have some more. (Overall - 4.00) 4.03 90 A-
Can: Poured a brown with clear edges, head was ring of light brown. Aroma is sweet caramel malts. Taste is thin sweet malt, not much body.
Drank out of the can at home in the dark. Some burnt sugar / caramel, light smoke, and mild chocolate. Medium / medium thin body. A touch sweet, low bitterness. Below average but not bad.
Pours brown with a beige head, aroma of chocolate, coffee, nuts, flavor of chocolate, coffee, nuts, caramel, some hops, medium bodied

Bottle Conditioned. Hazy chestnut, low head and condition. Smoky nose with a spicy pepper note. More smokiness in the mouth but not enough sweet maltiness to make it a true rauchbier. Finish is nutty with a metalic twang.

Cask (handpump) @ The Bree Louise, 69 Coburg Street, Euston, London, England NW1 2HH. Clear medium to dark red brown colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, chocolate, wood, spicy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, dark malt, spicy. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20121208]

Cask at The Anchor, Digbeth, Birmingham. Poured a slightly cloudy orange colour with a thin broken head. The aroma is warm and fruity. The flavour is very fruity and very slightly sour. It has a rich barrel aged feel to it but it I’m sure it’s not! A well drinkable Christmas ale.

Cask (gravity dispense) at the Pigs Ear Beer Festival, London on 6 December 2006. Reddish colour. Fruity malt aroma, with some plummy notes. Fruity on the palate too with some light, tangy balancing hops. Touches of toffee. Smooth, fairly light mouthfeel. Decent enough but seemed a little short of impact for the strength.
Cask@Pigs Ear BF 06. Slightly sweet, caramel, with some light earthy toastyness, some citric hops in the finish. A bit boring, but drinkable.

Bottle conditioned. Chestnut red, low head and moderate condition. Nice balance of hop and fruity malt aromas, hoppy start in the mouth followed by nuts, fruit and a slight smokiness. Finishes dry and fruity.

Tap at brewery in Bethlehem with commonmac and rosskyle and samadouche. Copper gold with small white head. Subtle Belgian hop aroma. Sweet taste, with grain, subtle hop. Finish is clean and nice. Very easy to drink. Not bad at all.
Draft. Little aroma. Flavor is lightly sweet, yeasty. Subtle flavors creep up through out and a nice medium body.
on tap-pours a white head and yellow color. Aroma is rock candy, fruit, some yeast, spice. Taste is rock candy, medium malt, fruit, some yeast, spice.

Tap @ the brew pub. Poured a clear gold color with an almost white head. Spicy Belgian yeast aroma with light bready malt. Light notes of fruity orange and pear. Spicy clove flavor. Malty finish with some warmth. Medium bodied.

On tap at Bethlehem location. Pours a lightly hazy golden with a medium creamy white head that left some lacing. Aroma of green apple, bubblegum, peppery notes, Belgian yeast esters, lemon peel and dough. Flavor of yeast, earthy notes, pepper, light lemon notes, doughy, light alcohol and rather dry. A solid brewpub Tripel.
Golden color with a big, sugary aroma with spices. Flavor is sweet, spicy, and a bit lacking. Average at best.
Straw yellow color with no head. Good lacing. Minimal fruit and spice aroma. Taste of green apple, pear with a hint of spice. No alcohol edge.

On tap at the Allentown location. Poured a medium golden color with a small sized head. Aromas of fruitiness (apples), spices, and citrus. Tastes follow suit with some alcohol in the finish. On the sweeter side.

Served in a 12oz goblet at the Allentown Brew Works. Clear, light golden body with a quickly diminishing white head. Not as aromatic as I would expect from the style; smells of citrus, bread, and spice. Flavor was also less powerful than I would expect. Citrus, cloves, bread, and light hops were present. Quite sweet, and the 9% alcohol was hidden very well. Overall a good beer, but not the most flavorful or complex tripel.

On tap at BBW, a very sweet aroma on a pale clear gold body. Definitely didn’t look like a tripel in the glass, but the flavor was very nice, a little on the sweet side, with neither component taking control of the flavor. The mouthfeel was almost a little tingly, possibly part of the 8.7% ABV that they say this has, but I didn’t really taste the alcohol as part of the beer.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at brewpub in Buenos Aires. Rich amber color with a creamy white head. Nitro tap. A simple malt flavor with little hops. Some caramel at the finish.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Recoleta location. Bright orange color with some cheeky chemical foam. Sweet citrus notes, mandarin oranges, cream candies on the nose. Wax paper-wrapped vanilla and butterscotch tastes. Authentic tastes seem swallowed up in odd plastics and offensive foreign sensations. Dry, synthetic and dull.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Clear, amber color, medium white head. Aroma of cereal, roasted, butter, flowers and apples. Flavor is not "creamy" , sticky, dryish finish, bit watery.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Copper color with creamy nitro head. Aroma is flowery. Light body and low bitterness. Taste is malty.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden with creamy nitro head. Papery from nose to finish. Sweetish, vaguely toffeish and light bodied. Low bitterness. Forgettable and soulless.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draft: nice lacing, taste is flat and simple, quite watery and overall tasteless. nothing great about this one. Guagh.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: A really mediocre attempt at a Boddington’s type brew--lacking in flavor, bouquet or "cream". Also, Buller’s prices are horrific for Argentina--though their brew pubs are packed with Argentines willing to pay London/East Coast prices to avoid contamination by the riff raff.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap in May 2006. Golden ale with a thin white very lacing head. Nice floral hops in aroma, with light caramle notes. In outh, a run of the mill ale, but with nice hopping (especially for BA). Very nice and quaffable ale, could be my daily beer here! Me gusta esta!

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On draught at the brewpub. Pretty much the IPA on nitro. A dense dark gold color with thick white head. Medium-bodied with early hop bitterness, slightly seew malty falvor balance, but hoppy flavor throughout. Very nice results.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draft - December 2005 Pours a light copper colour, almost orange. Aroma is flowery, maybe a bit citric. Taste is subtle and soft, a hint of mineral, not very bitter nor malty. It flows very smoothly and, because of the head that remains at the bottom of the glass at the end of my pint i´m inclined to think it is nitro drafted.
12oz bottle old notes (Trader Joe’s)-Pours a slightly hazy golden with no head. Aroma of light hops. Taste of citrus and light hops. This light bodied brew gave me no indication it was a pale ale.
Best damn beer Trader Joes has to offer. It taste great, gets tow up from the flow up.

Cardboard, corn , Kinda tastes like MGD. or what I remember of MGD. tried it once , won’t try again. If I had to choose over MGD, I would drink water. Also Mendocino brewing is not claiming this beer as one of theirs on their website. My bottle says brewed by River Trent in Ukiah, CA

Celebration Ales Brewing Company--Trader Joes Contract--"Fat Weasel Celebration Ale--""Laissez Le Bon Temps Rouler""--Green Bottle". 2000 Release--25.9 oz. Bottle. 8.00% ABV--40 IBU’s? (4.0 / 5.0) Belgian Ale--Dubbel--Mild lace head. Clear rich amber color. Hot Belgian floral mild hop front. Hot sweet mellow Belgian rich caramel fruit ester body mellowed by light dead sediment. Clean mild hop end.Aged Well! 2/16/2005

Bottle givien to me by a friend cuz I "..like wierd beer..." Poures a sllightly hasy yellow with a lively but quickly dissipating white head. Soft grain and cereal aroma wth a tough of hops. Flavor is bland and of corn and paper. A bit sweet and lacking any decent hops flavor. Goes down easy I suppose and OK if your thirsty.
Fairly weak for a pale ale. Definitely drinkable, but not the pale ale I’d choose most nights.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. Aroma is a bit weak and reminds me of cheap beer. A nice semi-opaque orange color. Starts out with a good, strong flavor, but it fades quickly into a kind of watered-down finish. It’s okay, but not great.

Pours a pale copper with a good bit of head. Aroma is almost non-existent, but what is there is mostly metallic and faintly bitter. Taste matches the aroma, starts out decently enough, with a light bitterness and hint of hops and malty sweetness. This fades pretty quickly, however, and just waters down to a residual coppery taste. There is something slightly unpleasant about the finish, which I suspect is just lower-end quality brewing. Not bad... just not very good.
Bottled. Not a very big nor complex APA but better than macro stuff. Just a really light and low alcohol beer that is fine for a really hot day outside.
Ya, doesn’t pack much of a punch at all. Just a faint hoppy note, and a bland bitterness and washed out mouthfeel at the end. Just not very enjoyable, especially from a style I normally love.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Smooth and creamy milky with a ton of sticky off white head. A lot of flavor. Cocoa and coffee and milky. Delicious. Had this as part of a flight at Buller brewing in Buenos Aires

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On tap at Buller, creamy cocoa roast and creamy soft palate. Not too bad for a dry stout.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Tap at brewpub. Dark brown color, steady creamy beige head. Aroma has tobacco, hints of chocolate and lactic notes. Medium-bodied. Tobacco, ash, chocolate and some alcohol and hops in the finish. Nothing special but propaply their best beer.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Coffee. A taste of old oak furniture reminds me of a smell carried over from the antique market of San Telmo I visited earlier. Soft on carbonation and bitterness without any sweet malt. Probably the best beer at Buller’s.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Pours deep black colour with a consistent and persistent beige head. Far roasted malty aroma. Some hints of chocolate in the taste toguether with roasted malt, lightly bitter. Medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, light bitter after taste. Good.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: On tap at Bullers downtown, Buenos Aires Appearance: Dark brown with a medium beige head and good lacing Aroma: Roasted malts and coffee Taste: Roasted malts, grains and coffee A very nice stout, I had a few pints of this one. My favorite of the night.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Draught @ Buller Downtown Brewpub, Buenos Aires, Argentina. Aroma of malt & rose perfume. Dark brown colour. Complex aromatic perfume flavour. Quite smooth. I don’t normally like stout but this is a good one.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Buller Pub, Recoleta. Part of 6 beer testing tray. Black beer with off-white head. Roasted malt, with a touch of hops.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Pour opaque dark brown. Nice roasted malts with coffee overtones and a dry finish. This really surprised me, a very solid stout.

column2: Tristán Suárez, Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, Argentina
column5: Coloração preta, com espuma bege escura volumosa e de longa duração. O aroma não de desprende com facilidade. Notas de malte torrado e café, com forte amargor. Na verdade, eu a achei amarga até demais, prejudicando o conjunto e a drinkability. Final torrado.

Keg at Ceres brewpub, october 07. Turbid, golden with an almost non existant white rim. Slightly rancid arome, but otherwise no nose. Begins malty, with some sweetness but ends with a strange lemony sourness. Slightly infected. Medium to light MF, refreshing. Nice try, what a shame it was off.
Draught at the brewpub. A golden beer with a slightly sour twang over the malty taste which is sadly infected.
What´s the matter with this place. A really bad beer, full of dirty. Don´t less your time with this brewery
Poured directly from the tank in December 2002. Faint hop aroma with a slight yeastiness. Cloudy yellow gold with a moderate white head. Slight hoppy flavor with some yeastiness. Almost crip.

Keg at Ceres, october 07. Turbid brown color with a white rim. Toasty, caramel malts but very restrained aroma. Raisiny, cereal flavor but rather bland. Light to medium MF, watery with no aftertaste. Bland, through drinkable brown ale.
Draught at the brewpub. Thin in texture with some toastiness and sweet malt in the mainly grainy flavour and a very slight bitterness.

Poured directly from the tank in December 2002. Light malty aroma. Clear ruby amber color with a moderate white head. Light bitter hop flavor followed by smooth maltiness (faint caramel). Malty sweet but light. Made with pilsen malt from Argentina, vienna and crystal malts.

Bottle from ScandiKitchen. The yeasty malty aroma I was expecting for a beer such as this, with added floral and spice notes. Pours opaque darkest brown. Bubbly off-white head has decent enough longevity. Medium sweet. Cola-esque with an underlying saltiness. Medium bodied. Slick. Flat carbonation. Abrupt finish. I suspect that some people will cry, "Tis not beer," however I like it. Was expecting more of a basic yeasty kotikalja beverage but it's more like the traditional non-alcoholic Christmas drinks I've had from Sweden but not as sweet..

Can @ grandmother/druid. Appearance: pours clear amber-brown with ok off-white soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: caramel, sugar, some liquorice. and light metallic notes. palette: light to medium sweet malty aroma, light to average carbonation, medium body, notable sweetness, unbalanced by a light bitterness, average duration and a watery texture. Overall: way to sweet
Clear dark brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma is honey, caramel and malt. Taste is bread, caramel and sugar
Bottle from Brugsen, Copenhagen - brown pour with off-white to beige head. Sweet malty aroma and taste, some artificial caramel and toffeish sweetness, some treacle, body is watery, not a fan.
Poured a caramel brown with whisper head. Aroma is sweet caramel and licorice. Taste is super sweet malt.
How: Bottle. Where: From a grocery store in Copenhagen. Appearance: Amber colour with a tan head. Aroma: Sweet malt, caramel, some fruit. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Malt, caramel.
Denne juleøl har et klart mørkt udseende med et svagt hvidt. Øllen har en sød aroma og smager sødt af malt og karamel. Lav karbonering.
Sweet malt aroma, notes of caramel. Dark brown, clear liquid. High sweetness, not much bitterness. Soft carbonation.
Flaske. farven er meget mørk brun til sort. Skumkronen er beigefarvet og forsvinder hurtigt. Aroma og smag er malt, farin og let lakrids. Lettere vandet.

Clear dark brown body with a light brown head. Sweet aroma with metallic notes. Very sweet taste with no bitterness. Almost no malt or hop flavours. Sweet finish. Light, watery body with average carbonation. As a child, I loved this beer together with rice pudding. The pudding is still great, but the beer is too sweet and lacking in any real taste.
Pours clear golden with minimal head. A: diacetyl, malty T: diacetyl, acid, waterly,
Butelka 0,5 litra. Barwa złota, klarowna. Biała piana, która szybko opada. Bardzo nijaki produkt ze słabym aromatem i niską goryczką.
Prakticky tady přidávám tento komentář, jen aby tady něco bylo, protože zpětně dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.
0,5l bottle,Golden yellow color, good foamy white head. Light papery nose. Very watery. Only light metallic-harsh flavors.

F: big, white, average retention. C: pale gold/gold, clear. A: malty, grassy, floral, bit of bready. T: malty, caramel, bread, grassy, metallic, unnatural bitterness, medium body, medium carbonation, not enjoyable, 0,5l can from Coop Jednota Martin-Záturčie.
Solid white head, aroma of malt and straw, light yellow, urine like, colour. Taste of malt, very soft on bitterness, rather sweet finish.
Better than average pilsner from Slovakia. Refreshing and crisp with a smooth aftertaste. Pairs good with spicy food.
0.5l can. Malty aroma. Clear golden color, no head. Malty taste. Light body, watery texture, average carbonation, during the light bitter finish appears an unpleasant soury notes.
50 cl. can. Clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, straw, hops and a bitter finish.
On tap. Taste is pretty much the same as other corporate light watery brews. For instance like Zlaty Bazant 10°.
Good for a honey beer, which can be sickening. Gentle, not too sweet. Actually quite enjoyable while it lasted.

(650ml bottle) I have no idea how this found its way onto the BC Liquor Store floor after three years of retirement - is it back? If not, I remember seeing another bottle in the "Single’s Bin" on the Left side of the store. Pours a medium, frothy white head with a clouded golden body. Nose of flowers and bathroom tiles (mildew?). Flavours are very mutes and tell its age: honey flakes, mild english malt and an off grainy flavour. It would have been nice to have had a fresh bottle.
Hazy gold,large fluffy off white head.light hop and honey nose.Sweet mild honey then light citrus hop flavor.Rather gassy
pours deep golden, offwhite head. mildly perfumy, sweet hoppy aroma. good balance of bready malts, citrus and flowery hops.
Doesn’t taste to me like honey pale ale at all. BUT it was very nice and refreshing, light and just right amount of kick .With time gets even better, hoppines shows up nicely.
Fluffy white head atop a light speckled golden appearance. Fresh roasty/citrusy hops with just a touch of sweet honey. Light piney hops comprise most of the body, finishes dry.

Light bronze; honey & herbal hops on the nose; smooth body, quite sweet; honeyish in the middle, cascadey at the end (though still sweet, as the hops seem to all have been added at the end of the boil).

From tap at the brewery. Clear golden orange color with almost no head. Malty and light hoppy aroma, bread, wheat, grain, caramel. Sweet and light bitter taste. Light to medium oily body with soft carbonation.
On tap at the brewery. Comes a clear gold with a decent white head. Mild aroma of grain and malt. Taste is malt, wheat, and a bit of citrus. Average.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange gold with small white head that lasts. The aroma is wheat and corn malt. Thin body, wheat, citrus, corn, dry finish, ok.
@ Third Street Aleworks brewpub 16-3-7: Små vetetoner, lite lagerkänsla. Nja
On tap at the Brewpub. Golden with a white head. Aroma of wheat, light citrus and bread. Similar taste. Drinkable but nothing special.

"the consensus for this beer was "eh". no, not the canadian pronunciation. what you’d expect from an average american wheat, no more, no less. refreshing when hot, boring otherwise. i’d prefer a hefe."
Draft at the brewpub. Light in color and body, decent but plain taste of slightly sour bubblegum. Served with a lemon wedge, so points off for that
Draft at brewery. Nose is grainy and a touch of citrus. Lightly crisp. Ok overall but nothing mind blowing. It’s a wheat beer.
Draft - Light grains and a bit of citrus. Pale clear gold with almost no head. Lots of grain and the euro skunky hops. Looks filtered and tastes like a euro lager.

On tap @ Third St Aleworks. Slightly hazed golden pour with a white head. Sweet grape and grain on the nose. Some apple, sugar, and grass. A bit papery on the tongue; quite astringent. Some sweet grain and fruit juice. Light sugar. Somewhat watery. Not a fan.
Tap. A yellow color with a foamy white head. A little lemon zest..........

column1: Third Street Aleworks One Ton Blackberry Ale
column5: Swing top 1/2 liter bottle poured a hazy reddish purple with a small, diminishing light purple head. Aromas of berries and a hint of malt. Palate was light and crisp. Flavors of mild blackberry and a hint of wheat with a crisp, lightly sweet finish.

column1: Third Street Aleworks One Ton Blackberry Ale
column5: Tap. Reddish color with a tan head. Good blackberry aroma and flavor. A nice tart finish.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: Draught @ Third Street Aleworks, Santa Rosa. Pours black with a creamy brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter, roast malt, caramel, dark chocolate, little coffee. Medium body, soft to average carbonation, light sweet finish. 200718

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: At at the brewpub. in my sampler was near black with a tan head. Nose of roasted malts. Kindo a dusty aroma. Full body with a smooth nitro mount feel. Flavor is smooth roasted matls iwth some coffee and chocolate. Bitter finish. Quite good.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: Nitro pour at brewery. Near black pour with small creamy head. No aroma....ok. Taste...slightly bitter. Not much else. Weak. Thin, too. And this is one of their higher rated beers. Ouch! Hopefully the crowler I got is better.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: From tap at the brewery. Black color with light beige head. Roasted malty aroma, chocolate, coffee, licorice. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Almost medium oily body with soft carbonation.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: On tap at the brewery. Comes almost black with a decent khaki head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Somewhat dry. Tasty.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: On nitro at the brewery. Pours a very dark brown with medium beige head that lasts. The aroma is roast, cocoa, raisin. Medium body, cocoa, cracker, roast, dry finish, decent.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: @ Third Street Aleworks brewpub 16-3-7: En stilren öl med tydlig rostat kaffe och lite choklad. Torr.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: On tap at the Brewpub. Almost black with a small tan head. Roasted with light chocolate and caramel. Soft and easy to drink.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: On tap from brewery, part of a taster. Very dark brown with some nice chocolate notes.

column1: Third Street Aleworks Blarney Sisters Dry Irish Stout
column5: "an ok offering, subpar for the Bear though. balanced sweet and bicuity malts and light citrus hopping make for a quaffable but ultimately uninteresting brew."
This one was called Anderson valley Anniversary XV Little big horn at the Toronado.Fruity strawberry peach aroma.Medium light brown appearance.Dry fruity peach, hoppy flavor. Herbal Dry finish.

Tap @ The Buckhorn Saloon in Boonville, CA. I enjoyed this fine beer after a 30 mile bike ride in Anderson Valley (thanks Kathleen). Hot dark reddish amber color with a white laced head. The nose has a hint of cherry with a good malt and hop balance. The flavor is a little alcohol harsh.
Draft. Straw beer with a whitish head. Light spice and light grass aroma. Spice and malt flavor. Medium bodied. Spice and malt linger with light grass.
"the aroma (more the malt profile than the hops) was a bit harsh in this one. just not to my liking. it was otherwise an average pilsner at best. not very intruiging."

On tap at the brewpub in Ukiah. Pour is golden, slightly hazy, with a very good head and very good sticky lacing. Should have more clarity. Aroma: herbal and floral hops with just a hint of light malts. Flavor: too much like a macro lager. Feel: light bodied with medium carbonation level. O: light and refreshing, but just OK for style.
Sampler at the brewpub. Light grainy aroma. Flavor is pretty typical Pilsner, but a little too sweet and grainy for my tastes.
Poured a clear yellow, with a slight head that laced nicely. Aroma was mild hops. Taste was mild and hopped, some bitter on the front. Mouthfeel was OK, bittering on back was good.
Hazed yellow pour with watery white head and lace. Lemon and paper aroma. Lemon, sour malt, and skunk. Thin and watery. Not as good as the number indicate.
Still nothing else to do tasting with Suttree. Clear yellow with virtually no head. Grass and corn aroma. Lightly sweet, some sourness, with a dry finish.
Whitish yellow, white cover. Aroma is grassy, sweet pils malt. Taste is again sweet, crisp, grassy. Really fantastic.

Maybe I was just in the mood for this, but I thoroughly enjoyed this pils. Pours pale yellow, with a thin schmear of white foam on top. Grainy, lightly spicy, lightly toasty aroma. Flavor is also grainy, with a very asssertive hop bite at the end. Very clean palate, no off flavors and seems to be very fresh. From a can, and served fairly cold.
on tap-pours a retaining tight white head that lacss and hazy straw color. Aroma is grain, some lemon. Taste is sweet grain, secondary lemon/grass/spice hops. Finishes with a bite.
Tap. Some spice but mostly malty. The spice is too subtle to make this beer interesting.

Sunset Amber–on tap-pours an off white head and amber color. Aroma is light/medium malt-caramel, light fruit-pear. Taste is sweet light/medium malt-caramel, light fruit-pear. OK effervescence. Occasional/interesting.
Tap. Medium golden color. (where is the red). Malty but pretty light - the damning quality of most ambers.

draft at YBC, The word for this brew is smooth. A bitter-sweet malt flavor that was all I expect from an imperial porter. I really enjoyed this one. I hope folks in california don’t ever take for granted these local brews up and down highway 101.
Sampler at the brewpub. Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is the same. Smooth oatmeal stout like palate.
Poured dark brown, little thin but smooth, roasted malts, maple, chocolate, little nutty, dry finish.

Draft @ Ukaih Brewing Company, Ukaih, CA. Pours a dark brown color with a longlasting off-white head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and licorice flavor. Has a roasted malty licorice finish.
(Bottle) Organic beer blind tasting at Brouwers’s in Seattle, March 3, 2007. Nose of cold metal and small machine oil. Flavour of roasted malt. Like cards in the spokes - neither cool nor exciting.
Light chestnut color. Faint, nutty aroma. Sort of extracty gasoline taste. Vague nuts. Really unpleasant.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear mid brown. Fruiy chocolatey nose. Quite sweet and intensely roasty with soft mouthfeel and near full body. Notes of prunes before a finish with licorice and good bitterness.
Tap. Dark brown with a tan head. A rich spicy and malty roasted flavor....
Clear gold with white cap. Bitter and a little abrasive, and overall lacking pleasantness. Slight lemon, grassy. Soft carb.
A golden wheat with thin creamy white head. In aroma, a light wheaty malt with light caramel notes. In mouth, a light watery malt with mineral notesm light bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 17, 2009.

Draft at the brewpub. Light amber gold color; served with a lemon slice (quickly removed to the water glass). Light grainy aroma. Rather thick bodied with creamy carbonation. Flavor is mostly grain with noble hop astringency/bitter. Plain but tasty finish. Bitter builds. Surprisingly good considering the style.

Tap at the brewpub. the body was hazy dark gold with a white colored head. The aroma was bananas and light clove. Notes of bread came through. The taste was banana peels with some hints of clove. An earthy, spicy finish.
Grain astringent and acidic nose. Thin and soft palate. Boring rather innocuous brew.
Slight sulfur in the nose, gold color, fizzy head. Fruity wheat body, dry spicy end. Thin and weak, with an off balance. Below average even for the style.
Golden color, soft carbonation. Crushed grain nose and taste. all in all a bit plain and light.
Hazy golden in color. Nothing notable about this one. Just your standard easy-drinking refreshing wheat beer.
Draft at the brewpub/Inn. Gorgeous biergarden, absoutely worth a small detour if you are in wine country. American style wheat - not my favorite, but still very drinkable.
Tap @ brewpub. A slightly hazy golden color. Malty and a touch of spice but rather bland and weak.
Color by numbers pils, not bad, just plain. Clear gold with a little bite, just the faintest touch of butter, mostly clean malt and a splash of noble hops.

Pre-volcanic bath pint (NOT recommended) at the bar of the Calistoga Inn, 14/08/12. Brassy, conditioned gold topped with white. Sappy, herbal, mown grass aroma. Bready, shrubby and nuanced with a lipsmacking drying bitterness accompanied by a shave of pith and orange. Fizzy but it suits. Curd on crackers. VERY pilsener-ish. "Awesome!"

A hazy golden pils with almost no head. In aroma, light mineral hops. In mouth, a very mineral pils, with a light crisp malt, of bit of german hops, run of the mill. Light to medium bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 17, 2009.

Draft at the brewpub. Pale gold color with a slight white head. Light grassy aroma. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Flavor is pale malt and grassy hop. Finishes a bit grainy, but the hop is very nice. It laced a tad.

Tap at the brewpub. The body was bright gold with a slight haze and a thick head. The aroma was soapy with some flowers and potato. The taste was sweet potatoes with some light hints of apple core. Drinkable but with a vegetable finish.
Grassy nose with an overly soft mouthfeel and mild grain astringency. Diacetyl and dms on the palate with grainy finish.

Draught, Calistoga Inn. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is dark yellow. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (cookie, caramel), lightly hoppy (flowers, apricot), with notes of peach, diacetyl, and corn syrup. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately bitter, husky. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Not very pilsner-ish.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is clear, light caramel brown-gold colored with a small, frothy, white, lasting head.The aroma is malty with moderate notes of husky toasted grain, light toasted bread and caramel; Hoppy with a light note of orange zest, moderate note of honeysuckle, resin/pine; Yeasty with a light note of dough, trace of sweat; Light miscellaneous note of tropical fruit.The flavor is light-to-moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter with a long, light-to-moderately bitter, lightly acidic, lightly sweet finish. Light astringency on the gums. Husky retros.The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.
Grainy nose, gold color. Short sweet malt with a slight cardboard taste. Spicy hop bitter end. Light body. Clear palate.
At the brewpub: Golden color, lemon nose. Light hay taste- short lasting. Not exciting.

A reddish copper ale with a thick moka head. In aroma, light nutty malt. In mouth, a light silky biscuitty malt, with some herbal notes, butterscotch, light bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 17, 2009.

Draft at the brewpub. Red tinged amber color with a decent beige head. Roasted caramel aroma. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Flavor is a mix of citrus and dark red roasted caramel/malt. Finish is dry and decently bitter. Agree with YogiBeera.
Tap at the brewpub. The body was deep amber with a light khaki colored head. The aroma was sweet caramel with some apples. the taste was oranges with some bitterness. Bread crust in the finish.
Draft. Brown beer with an off-white head. Light malt and light roast aroma. Tooasty, light roast, caramel malt flavor. Medium bodied. Light roast and malt lingers.
Caramel and tea nose with a touch of biscuit and nuts. Good lacing with a soft mouthfeel. More tea and caramel on th epalate with a semi clean finish.

Smells slightly of tree bark. Dark chesnut color, low tight head. Toasted malt, almost smokey at times. Dry tight woody end. Off balance, but holds together for the most part. Good enough to wash down a pizza, but not so interesting otherwise.
At the brewpub. IMO their best beer. Roasted malt taste. Red color, small head. Long lasting - well bodied. Decent!
Lots of malt and alcohol are apparent in this brew. Full bodied, strong. I don’t detect much of the hops that are noted in the description though.
Draft at the brewpub/Inn. Gorgeous biergarden, absoutely worth a small detour if you are in wine country. Beer very enjoyable.
Tap @ brewpub. Reddish brown color with a tan head. Nice malty body with a little fruit.

One of 2 beers (out of 6) I would have finished a pint of. Dark brown with khaki head. Light roast, caramel, chocolate, coffee nose. A little soft on the palate, with a slightly bitter bite, complex malts.

Draft. Deep brown with diminishing khaki head. Aroma comes across with a lactic tartness at first, but warms into some choc and herb stuff. Flavor is neatly strung between cranberries, tea, cola, and some more mysterious woody tobacco things. Finishes mostly sharp with some lingering rooty roundness.

A dark brown porter with cherry hues and a thick moka head. in aroma, a strong butterscotch and chocolate, with some coffee notes. In mouth, a bit of herbal hops, chocolate, and butterscotch, light bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 17, 2009.

Dark brown color with ruby glints. Decent tan head. Aroma is primarily coffee. Medium body with sharply creamy carbonation. Flavor is coffee over dark toasted malt. Chocolate is a minor feature. There’s hop bitter to go with the toast. Very decent porter.

Tap at the brewpub. Deep brown body with red at the edges. A thick, yellowish khaki head topped it. The aroma was milk chocolate with some light coffee and almonds. The taste was milk chocolate with some mocha. A nice roasted finish. Decent.

I had this 5(?) years ago when I stayed in Calistoga with my wife. Nice beer. I remember it being very toasty and having some nice java and mocha flavors. I think I tried 4 beers at dinner there and this one was one of the 2 that I really liked.
Mildly roasted lactic nose with a touch of cocoa. Thin and dissipating on the palate with an overly astringent finish.
Roasted malt nose, deep dark opaque brown color, low tight head. Slight chocolate in the body at first, deep burnt flavor emerges. Dry coffee end, thinish body. A little too roated, but fun to drink.
Draft. Brown beer with a thin tan head. Roasty aroma. Big roasty, chocolate, coffee flavor. Medium bodied. Slight astringency. Lingering roast.
At the brewpub: Black with a small head. Chocolate and toasted malt nose and taste. Medium bodied- medium long lasting finish.
[Puszka 13.06.2020] Barwa brunatna, klarowne. Piana średnia, średnio pęcherzykowa. Aromat i smak lekko karmelowe, słodowe. Goryczka niska, nasycenie średnie.

Botella 500ml Color marron oscuro-cobrizo,espuma de color beige,fina,mediana,media resistente.Aroma malta tostada,caramelo,frutas secas.Sabor dulce muy intenso ,malta tostada,caramelo,frutas secas,en postgusto aparece suave amargor
Dark brown color, foam last long enough. Caramel malty aroma and a strange metallic smell. Taste is far too sweet for me, aftertaste gets worse, but a drinkable, sweet dark lager.
Dark color, middle foam size. Usual beer, aroma and taste fit into the style.
Clear chestnut brown. Moderate off-white head. Aroma and taste: lots of treacle and caramel, dried fruit, brown bread. Sweet. Too sweet.
Édeskés malátás íz egy pici fém utóízzel. Összeségében egy iható barna lager. Aki szereti az édes italokat, annak még jobban tetszeni fog.

22-07-2017; draft; somewhere in Bratislava, Slovakia. The looks of the beer are good. The color is nice ruby red, quite dark. It seems to be crystal clear. On top there is a nice soft creamy ayer of soft brown foam, with good foam retention. The smell of the beer is nice. There are nice sweet malts, some caramel and hints of liquorice and dark fruits. The hops give nice bitter notes. I like it. It is not the strongest dark beer, but defiantly not bad. The taste of the beer is nice. It is quote a sweet beer. There are some nice sweet fruit flavours and some nice sweet and malts, with a bitter touch of toast. The hops are also nice and bitter, but they aren't to strong. The palate of the beer is nice. Medium body, smooth texture and low carbonation. The finish is nice and malty. All in all, not bad.

500ml can from Bliznetsy in Moscow. Pours brown with a medium-sized beige head. Aroma is coffee, syrup, dried feuits. Taste is medium sweet, caramel and coffee, butterscotch notes. Light bitter finish. Ok, but a bit artificial tasting.

0.5 can. Mély vörösesbarna szín, hab nagyon hamar semmi... illat édeskés. Miért kell egy 1473- ban alapított sörfőzdének szacharint tenni egy barna sörbe??? Émelyítően édes, barna sörbe nem illő módon. Nem is írok többet
sladkasta vona. pena na zaciatku husta. farba vyrazna tmava. chut sladkssta trochu vodova

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a pale clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty grainy aroma. Fruity crisp wheat malty flavor with some weak hints of citrus. Has a fruity wheat malty grainy finish.
On tap at TableRock. Pours a medium yellow color with a medium white head. The aroma is thin grains, citrus, honey. Basically a sweet thin hefe, not much wheat. OK.

SLC to OLY 877 Miles – Table Rock Brewing - Boise, ID Aroma – Light wheat malt with some grapefruit and clove aromas. Appearance – Pale yellow in color, slight haze, with a thin head. Flavor – This had a nice wheat flavor light grapefruit and banana flavors. Palate – Dry Wheat finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. Overall – Again a good light ale for the hot Boise days.
Can’t really taste the beer over the fruit that is added. Supposedly the brewpub’s most popular beer, but I’m not convinced at all.
on tap-pours a disappearing white head and hazy yellow color. Aroma is musty/barn, some wheat. Taste is musty, some wheat/grain, some spice hops.

Tasted on tap at the brewpub 10/25/2008. This wheat pours a medium orange gold color. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is wheat and cereal. A medium bodied wheat. The malts are cereal and bready with a touch of banana and clove, it more of a wheat beer than a hefeweizen. Hops are floral and slightly spicy. Kind of your standard American Wheat. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter with a touch of sweetness at the very end.
Has kind of a grainy mouthfeel, some light cereal grain maltiness. Very light, with some bitter flavors and a sour acidity.

3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is light and grainy, with faint wheat sourness and no hop flora. Appearance is very clear yellow gold with a well maintained white head. Flavor is very tangy and light, with more sourness than sweetness and low on hop characteristics. Mouthfeel is very light bodied with medium carb feel and funky earthy finish. Overall, not too easy drinking and a bit rough for those looking for an american hef.
On Tap at the brewpub pours out cloudy gold topped with a small white head. A nice aroma of wheat and citrus. I also picked up a little citrus in the tast as well. not bad.

Draft: Yellow color with a light haze, smaller white head and light lacing. Nose is light citrus and wheat. Tastes sweet with caramel and citrus, some wheat and malt tones. Caught me off guard, this was pretty good.

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a hazy orange amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with some earhty hoppy hints in the aftertaste.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark ruby color with a medium white head. The aroma is sweet caramel and toast- very sweet. The flavor is a smooth caramel malt, some fruit. Light spicy hops.

SLC to OLY 877 Miles – Table Rock Brewing - Boise, ID Aroma – Mild hops and a good malt balance in the aroma. Appearance – Amber in color, Clear, with a thin head. Flavor – Light hops in the flavor with good roasty malt. Palate – Dry finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. Overall – This was a good average Amber ale. Easy drinking.
Not an incredibly interesting amber but well fit to style. Their Irish Red (Copperhead) is much better.
on tap-pours an off white ring for a head and amber color. Aroma is light/medium malt-caramel. Taste is sweet light/medium malt-caramel, some spice hops.

Tasted on tap at the brewpub 10/25/2008. This amber ale pours a light amber color from the tap. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel malts and sweet. A medium bodied amber. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are earthy and floral. Nicely balanced, with good carbonation. A not too sweet, not very hoppy amber. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Pours an amberish fresh penny color. Sweet caramel and honey aroma, with a bit of herbal hoppiness. Bright fruit flavors on the palate, with a medium bodied caramel malt background. A hint of nuttiness in the finish. Not bad at all.

3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is sweet with caramel notes and fruit. Appearance is clear copper gold with a very low white head. Flavor is earthy and sweet, with light bready notes and moderate bittering. Mouthfeel is low/medium bodied with medium carb texture. Overall, not too bad, but lacking complexity.

Draught sample at brewery. Mild malty aroma, caramel and biscuit. Light fruity hops. Reddish amber clear with thin off-white lacing head. Medium watery body with medium carbonation. Starts with good caramel grain sweetness. Light brown sugar, good hoppy finish with nutty bitterness although a bit chalky. Bit of fruity tannic tang, with bitter after.
On Tap at the brewpub pours out O lets see and amber topped with a small head. A little hop and sweet but not much else going on. just so so.
Orange amber body with tight head. Pine astringency on fitst taste, mild hoppy nose. Dry finish

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity hoppy pine and grapefruit aroma. FRuity malty hoppy bitter grapefruit flavor with piney hints. Has a fruity hoppy bitter grapefruit finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Listed as Hop Head 2.0, a slightly new version. Pours a cloudy copper hue with a medium white head. The aroma is huge citrus, oranges and grapefruit. The flavor is a very nice IPA; bitter, apricot and orange, huge cascade and simcoe. Very good.

SLC to OLY 877 Miles – Table Rock Brewing - Boise, ID
…

This is actually a new 2.0 recipe. Not sure if it should be rated separately or not. Starts with good hop aromas and flavors. Doesn’t kill the palette like a lot of IPAs but still brings with it a lot of great hoppiness.
Pours a clear amber color. Aromas of hops, hops, and more hops. Maybe a hint of malt. Flavor is all hops, light body with a long dry finish and aftertaste.
Hophead IPA 2.0-on tap-pours a white head and gold color. Aroma is pine. Taste is resin/pine hops with dry bite, secondary light malt.

Tasted on tap at the brewpub 10/25/2008. This IPA pours a light orange gold color from the tap. Small sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet with a touch of floral hops. A medium bodied IPA. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are mildly earthy and floral. Very low bitterness, and a touch
…

I have to say this was pretty enjoyable, with some intriguing hop varietals that don’t necessarily clash, but you have the the citrus, you have the floral, and the fruit, all combining to make a very unique nose. The malt background is immdeiately apparent. Well balanced and well kept, with a creamy palate. Finishes
…

Tablerock hophead ipa 7 2 15 4 7 3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is verysweet and seems almost caramel dominant at first,
…
Hazy dark orange. Malty palate, defined with some hoppy bitterness up front that fades to a nice hoppy aftertaste.

Despite the success of the Hopzilla on paper, I think the Red ale was probably my favorite all-around beer I had at the Table Rock. Very hoppy, while maintaining a good balance with the malt. The balance was really good here, making it a very drinkable. It was hard to place the malt, and after looking at the description it seems evident that it is due to the combination of malts. Well done.
A sweet hoppy nose. Red pour, almost a cloudy amber. Nice lacing. Hoppy taste, almost reminds me of SNPA. Smooth palate. Too reminiscent of SNPA but without as much hops, though it was pleasing.

A very thin head dominates this very amber-brown ale, with very interesting lacing, which I was not expceting, I expected this to be boring, but it was actually pretty good. Very dry and slightly hoppy, with a nicely balanced malty sweetness in the finish.
A gold/red tint. This beer had a nice size head to it. What stood out to me was the dry pale finish, but nice and hoppy too. Enjoyable.

Floral hop smell. Opaque brown, good head and lacing. Perfect combonation of hops and malt, tastes like Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. Palate is nice and dry, but refreshing from the hops. Overall a good mix of sweet and bitter for this well rounded beer.
Sampled at GABF on Thursday October 11, 2012 Hazy golden color, yellow head. Sweet, malty scent. Sweet, apple taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a slightly hazy amber brownish color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty nutty caramel aroma. Fruity malty nutty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty nutty caramel finish.

SLC to OLY 877 Miles – Table Rock Brewing - Boise, ID Aroma – Nutty with roasty malt this was sweet to the nose. Appearance – Dark Amber in color, Clear, with a thin head. Flavor – Roasty malt with a nut like flavor. This was sweet to the taste. Palate – Dry finish with a Nice Nutty Mouthfeel. Overall – A very nice Nut brown.
Very little aroma and quite cloudy, this "nut brown" has a good flavor, but not one that says nut brown to me. Good mouthfeel though but not enough for much of an overall score boost.

on tap-pours a light tan ring for a head and cloudy orange/brown color. Aroma is medium/dark malt-chocolate/caramel, earthy. Taste is sweet medium/dark malt-roasty/chocolate/caramel, nutty, secondary earthy hops.

Tasted on tap at the brewpub 10/25/2008. The brown ale pours a medium dark brown color. Small to medium sized tan foamy head. The aroma is nutty, sweet, caramel and brown sugar. A medium to full bodied brown ale. The malts are caramel, nutty and sweet. The hops are floral and earthy. Nice sweet nutty malt flavors. Very smooth taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
This is a great session ale. Sweet malty aroma, rich and full of caramel, toffee and nuttiness. Medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Very enjoyable.

3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is malty and bready, with light fruit malt/hop flora to round it out. Appearance is clear amber with a medium retained off white head. Flavor is more like the aroma with malt dominating, sweet, low bittering and english in strength. Mouthfeel is medium body with a a very low carb texture. Overall, good and very easy drinking.
On Tap at the brewpub pours out ligth brown. A nice sweet aroma of hazel nut and roast malts. Pretty nice.

Draft: Pours a dark brown with reddish tones, nearly as dark as thier porter! Nose is roasted malt and toffee, taste is more oriented in the roasted malt dept. Some earth and nutty flavor also. Nice roasty and woody character.

Port barrel aged and on cask. Had at the mountain brewers festival. This was a highlight for me. Notes of plum, raisin, port, vanilla, dark stone fruits. A solid sour beer. Reminds me of Squatters Root Cellar or a Flanders red ale. Had many samples of this one. Loved it!
Had at MBBF in Idaho Falls Hazy brown with a tan head. Taste is biscuity, tart and vinegar. Toasted malts and vinegar. A nice palate cleanser and good beer.
Draft. Murky brown color, brown head. Aroma of sour brown bread, dark fruit. Aroma has both sweet and sour notes, reminds me of a Flemish red. Weird.
on tap-pours a light tan head and copper color. Aroma is soft sweet medium malt, hint of citrus. Taste is soft sweet medium malt-secondary citrus rind hops. Solid medium body.
On tap at TableRock Brew Pub, Boise Pours out a nice hazy brown topped with a nice cream head. A nice spice aroma and tast. A pretty good winter brew.

On Tap @ Burger n’ Brew: Rich brown color with reddish tones and a thick head. Aroma is mostly malt with some spices evident. Taste is a smooth maltiness with cloves and a bit of hops to finish. A nice, rich winter ale.
Very good, and very basic for the style, some sweet fruity maltiness, really easy to drink, hoppiness comes through in the end. Not bad, but not my favorite.
Growler from the Boise Co-Op. Pours a nice dark brown. Aroma of malt, fruit, hops. Tastes malty, with some hops and fruit.
Medium murky brown. Spicey malt syrup aroma and flavor. Kind of a plastic caramel and amaretto/scotch flavor. Very thick.
Fuity nose, very cheery. Very dark pour with nice head and very nice lace. Yeah, flavors are that of most winters. Pretty cloying palate. Pretty enjoyable winter brew.

Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a slightly hazy and very pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity grainy aroma. Fruity grainy watery flavor with some weak hop hints. Has a fruity grainy finish with some weak bitterness in the aftertaste.
On tap in Boise at the brewpub. Pours a clear yellow with a medium white head. The aroma is light grains and honey. A thin flavor; watery, honey and light earthy malts. OK.

SLC to OLY 877 Miles – Table Rock Brewing - Boise, ID
…
on tap-pours a white head and pale yellow color. Aroma is mild sweet grain, grassy. Taste is sweet grain, grassy.
Only gets a 10/20 overall for being true to style &#40a knockoff of a domestic lager&#41. Otherwise a completely uninteresting beer

Tasted on tap at the brewpub 10/25/2008. This light lager pours a light gold color from the tap. Small sized white foamy head. The aroma is cereal and grain. A light bodied low alcohol lager.
…
A solid light ale without any uniqueness. Not the best beer from Idaho. Domestic knock off, yech!

A very typical beer for the BMC drinkers that come into the brewpub. Everything about this beer is light. I mean it is clean and crisp, but has absolutely no body. There is nothing to it, extremely bland and watery.

3/7/08 on draught at the brewpub. Aroma is light and fruity, very similar to better national examples. Appearance is extremely light straw yellow with a very low white head. Flavor is dry and simple, with stronger than average noble hops. Mouthfeel is very light bodied with stronger than average carb feel.
…

Draft at brewpub: Light copper and orange color with a modest white head. Faint aroma of malt and lagerish qualities. Tastes clean and light, just as I imagine the brewers intention for this one. Look honey, I’m drinking a mircrobrew!

Growlerout of the tap that afternoon. Very dark but not quite opaque. Small light tan head and sparse lacing. Flavor is plain dark roasted notes and tasted slightly of coffee. Rather thin feel and an odd slightly sour biterness at the end. Just so-so
Pours a nice jet black color, with a creamy reddish brown head. Aromas of coffee, chocolate, and smoke. Flavor is a nice blend of coffee and chocolate with a nice bitter smoke aftertaste.

Very dark brown with glints of amber when held to a light. Thick fine-particle head that lasts. Served quite cold at the brewery, but even when cold the aroma was strong burnt malts with hints of choclate.
