column5: Tap at the brewery. Pours clear amber with a medium, frothy white, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is toast and nutty malt, earthy and spicy hops, dates and figs. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness, light esters and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Station House Red Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Reddish in color with a light white head. Smooth and drinkbale. Hints of caramel.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Station House Red Ale
column5: On cask. Deep red color and unfiltered and very cloudy, nice body. Aroma is modest but has some mellow hops and grain. Average red taste and finish.. Sweet malts and a little hoppy end. Clean and light, good cask.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Station House Red Ale
column5: Deep amber with white head and lace. Medium malt and a funky caramel or brown sugar aroma. Medium caramel/molasses flavor with a medium bitter. A bit foamy and a tad thin. Not a bad drinker but not very special.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Station House Red Ale
column5: Pours red (obviously) with a small white head. Tastes much like a Killians red with light flavor of caramel. Light palate overall its just OK. Worth a try.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Station House Red Ale
column5: Not much aroma, but what was there was all malt and nothing else. Has a reddish-copper hue and a very short off white head that provided nice lacing all the way down. A bit overcarbonated and watery, this doesn’t taste like any Irish Red (or Amber ale) I’ve ever had, but was crisp and easy to drink. Not much flavor here, with almost no hop presence makes it balanced in a bland sort of way. I would consider this to be a "starter" more than even a session type offering. Nothing special.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Station House Red Ale
column5: sampled at the brewpub. Amber in color, aroma is light floral hops and malt, some light roast. Taste is pretty much the same with a lighly bitter finish. not bad.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Station House Red Ale
column5: Sample at Metuchen,NJ location. Not much aroma here, maybe because of the sample size? Copper red brown color. Initial flavor that is strong in caramel and brown suger, but quickly dissipates. Hoppy finisih is spicy with some notes of pumperknickel, but I pick up too much hairspray flavors. The weakest of the sampler.
Draft. Pours cloudy yellow with white head. Nose/taste of spicy yeast, lemon and peppercorn. Lighter bodied.
Draft at the source. Clear pale yellow color, thick white head, champagne bubbles. Aroma of white pepper and hay. Taste is straw and pepper.

Tap at the brewery. Pours clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with excellent lacing. Aroma is Pils and corn malt, spicy and earthy hops. Flavor is malt forward with medium hops and bitterness, a clean lager character and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
On tap at the brewery. A nice light crisp pilsner to style. Not much hops. A little grassy. Drinkable.
Pours gold with a white head. Smells of sweet malt and appley. Tastes sweet and crisp with an earthy finish.
Deep gold with gooey head and lace. Very lemony aroma. Cloying malt with a hint of funk. Full body for a pils but fizzy. Nice refreshing beer easy to drink.

The waitress described this beer as being much like a Heinekein but to me it had a stronger flavor and was pretty good, but nothing special. Tasted like a commercial beer, but more fresh - makes sense. Very small white head/amber yellow pour.

Second beer of the night that I tried at Uno. Nice flavor for a summertime blonde ale, but wait.........it’s supposed to be a pilsener? I guess it tastes like a pilsener? Had a slightly buttery, yet clean, texture and was leaning more towards the doughy, malty flavor of a traditional Czech pilsener than the more hoppy styles to be had near the German coast. Golden coloring with a small white head. Tough to get much head when Uno freezes the glasses before serving, but the carbonation was still towards the stronger side and I have no complaints about that. The mouthfeel was nice and the aftertaste was nil. A decent offering that compliments greasy deep dish pizza well.

sampled at the brewpub. very light clear straw color. Butter/vanilla notes in the aroma, along with some grain. Taste is lightly buttery, vanilla, diacetyl but not completely overwhelming, grainy, clean watery finish.

Did they use ale yeast when they call it a Bohemian Pilsner? Pours golden with white head. Pale malt and pilsneresque lager aroma. Flavor is bread like, with hints of pils malt, grass, and hay. Crisp hoppy finish, but the soapines is a bit overwhelming.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Draft at brewpub. New recipe. Pours unfiltered orange with white head. Nose/taste of orange peel, caramel malt, dank grapefruit and pineapple. Medium body. Very hoppy.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Gravity cask at Uno. Hazy variegated golden yellow color, white head, solid lacing. Aroma of flowers, pineapple, citrus, nice! Taste is bitter fruit, citrus, straw.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Cask with Amarillo hops at the brewery. Pours lightly hazy orange with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is grassy, herbal, and dank hops with biscuit malt and pear esters. Flavor is heavy hops and bitterness, light malt and fruity esters with a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: On draft at the metutchen uno restarant/brewery. A light citrusy example of an ipa. Golden color with a medium head. Drinkable.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Pours out a dark copper color with a big off white head. Aroma is of some light grassy, citrus hops and some caramel. Taste is of some light grass notes, citrus hops, some caramel, light grains and a dry spicy hop finish. Solid, drinkable IPA. Average.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Pours copper with a thin white head. Smells of earth, grass, some wildflowers. Tastes of pine resin, spice, some earthy hints on the finish.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Below average for an IPA. Not much aroma. Good looking though. Flavor was bland. A bit thin.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Growler sampled at Noog Four-0 5/31/08 courtesy of jcwattsrugger: Pours a transparent copper bronze with spotty-lacing white head. Aroma of toasty grainy sweet pale malts and some grassy English hops. Body starts fairly full and well-carbonated with a grainy malty sweetness and grassy earthy resiny bittering hops before a drier toasty bittersweet finish. A pretty good IPA.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: On cask this was boring. Average for a light pale ale not close to an IPA on cask. Draft version definitely had more hops present than the cask version. Draft was way more vibrant and carbonation was very, even ultra low for a cask. Even though it was on cask I expected some carb. The red was better. Rating average of two.

column1: Pizzeria Uno Ikes India Pale Ale
column5: Red/copper pour with off white head and lace. Medium malt and medium hops on the nose. Caramel malt and a nice finishing bitter. Medium bodied with good carbonation. A fine beer. I also had this beer at noogfest 08 but could not find it on the site.
Draft at brewpub. Pours brown with brown head. Nose/taste of toasted oatmeal, roast chocolate malt and touch of burnt brown sugar. Medium body.

Tap at the brewery. Pours clear brown with a medium, frothy off-white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is toast and cookie malt, chocolate, earthy hops and dates. Flavor is malt dominant with medium hops and bitterness, light esters and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Draft at the source. Clear dark maroon brown color, beige head. Aroma of coffee grounds. Taste id sweet milk chocolate, light caffe au lait.
On tap at the brewery. Nice porter. Black color with choclaty notes. A hint of coffee. A nice example of the style.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 11/10/2007 Fruity aroma. Dark coloured slightly rich on the palate and fruity with some bitterness in a crisp roast finish.
Dark with a nice fluffy head. A bit mild and roasty. Taste is sweet and roasty with some sweetness. Not bad.

Deep brown with hints of red. Tan head and lace. Peat and toasted malt on the nose. Rich toasted malt and vanilla flavor with a light to medium bitter. Creamy full bodied. Nice porter. Head and shoulders above the beers I had to this point.

Poured a dark brown with a small white/tannish head that lasted probably half way down the glass. The flavor was coffee, chocolate. Palate was nice with beautiful carbonation. One of my favorites at this brewpub.

Poured a nearly opaque brown, with blonde highlights. Little head or lacing. Smelled and tasted a bit like iced coffee. Carbonation was pretty much spot on, flavor was mild, yet all the right flavors were there, the coffee, the malt, the slightest hint of toffee. Looks like a Porter or almost even a stout, yet tastes more like a Porter leaning towars a Brown. However, that’s not a bad thing and it might be the best out of the handfull of Pizzeria Uno offerings I’ve tried.

Pint served very cold. Hazy dark brown pour leaving a lasting beige foam. Surprisingly hoppy and ridiculously cheap at 1.75$. Bready, well-roasted ale with flowery aromas. Gentle brown chocolate flavours together with a minimally lactic tang. Highly effervescent, exaggeratedly so even cuts the flavour evolution short and bites the tongue sharply and unfortunately.

Pours black with a thin tan/almost brown head. Aroma is of sweet chocolate, and some light roasty notes. Taste is complex, with a nice thick mouthfeel. Dark roasted malts, chocolate, some sweet flavors, light coffee. Very well done.
on tap-pours a rich light brown head and black color. Aroma is mild roasty. Taste is dark malt-roasty/molasses, secondary earthy hops. Full body.

I didn’t have a notepad with me when I tried this, so I have to go with what I remember. Nice head, malty aroma with a perfect nose of hops, color alone made my mouth water. Taste completed my rave. This beer was delicious! I believe it’s a seasonal brew, but dang, if it’s served fresh...get it and get it often. I had three of these bad boys with a damn good cheeseburger. I highly recommend.
NJ Brewers Fest. Brown with medium sized head. The aroma and taste are fabulous. Dark chocolate and roasted coffee and a light bitter cherry taste. Nice sweet finish.
Nice black color. Big malty flavor with a american hop finish. Good beer. enjoyable.
Nice black color, tan head. Roasty aroma. Big malty roasty flavor with a slightly sour/American hop finish. Consistantly good and drinkable to the end.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Long Valley Oatmeal Stout - 4.5% abv - Winter 2010 batch (No longer Joe’s Oatmeal Stout). Had on nitro-tap at brewery in shaker. Poured with unusually large oat head, just off-white. Dark brown with lots of ruby highlights. Nose of oats and roasted malt. Light to medium bodied, relatively flat with smooth texture. Mellow roasted flavor, little to no hop presence. Super easy to drink.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Deepest brown, but clear around the edges. Oatmeal comes out nicely in the nose. Sugary flour, brown sugar, rather cakey misture of malts. A tiny alcohol note manages to sneak in. Minimal perceived hoppiness. A bit sloppy on the palate, the carbonation appears faded. The little coffee notes in there are toppled by rich chocolate warmth, that, paired with the oats, make for a rather rich medium body, bready and with full-on maltiness.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap at the brew pub. Pours black with an average size creamy tan head that left some lacing. Aroma of lactose, oats, coffee and chocolate. Flavor was malty, roasty, chocolate, hints of coffee and lactose sweetness.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tan head atop black body. Aroma is medium sweet, coffee/roast, light chocolate. Taste is medium sweet, chococoffee, some cream. Light-medium body, low carbonation.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap-pours a tan head and black color. Aroma is licorice/oatmeal-dark malt. Taste is oatmeal-dark malt, acidic. OK/mild carbonation.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: GABF 2005: Rich deep brown hue with a small but lasting creamy head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of oats and grains, chocolate, aromatic hops, and woody yeast esters. The taste is similar to the the nose and in this beers case, that is a good thing. Lots of sweetness and malty goodness but a nice dose of finishing bitters and a touch of coffee keep it from becoming cloy. Smooth and lush, this is one solid sweet stout, yummy!

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Take your gold medal winner Lazy Jake Porter, take some slightly more roasted malts, toss in some oatmeal, and you have Oatmeal Stout. Pours with a head as hard to penetrate as styrofoam, and a color so beautiful it makes you want to cry. Long Valley Pub & Brewery proves that when it comes to dark craft beers, they are still the king.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. A delicious stout. This seems to have been built off the model of their Lazy Jake Porter. No complaints here about that. Nice seasonal stout. LVBP offers a couple stouts through the year and I think they do a pretty nice job of them. Drink this one

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Deep dark brown in color, with a nice head. Nitro poured. Nitro head. Sweet malty aroma. Sweet flavor. Full body and full mouth feel. Nice beer.

column2: Long Valley, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Deeep dark brown, with the nitro tan head. 4.5% ABV. Sweet roasty malt aroma. Flavor is on the sweet side and a bit worty. Full body and mouth feel. Roasty finish. Not bad, but there are better.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: A great example of an Irish red ale. Irish red is one of my favorite styles and this beer is excellent, Balances the sweetness and caramel flavor with just enough hops, not overly sweet or overly bitter.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Thus far I've had a hit-and-miss experience with this popular red ale from Thomas Creek, some bottles have been overtly sweet and thin-bodied while others have had a bit more complex caramel maltiness and texture. Not sure if that's a production issue or a shelf-life issue, hard to say without a date on the bottle. Anyhow, from a recent good bottle, this poured a pale amber-red color with a cap of bright white foam and decent lacing, although I normally look for a brighter ruby color in red ales. Sweet caramel and toffee candy on the nose, followed by a predominantly caramel malt flavor with notes of subtle toasted malt and breadiness. Perhaps some earthiness from the bready malt, but not really any complex earthy or bitter hop notes. Overall, strikes me as a just a higher quality rendition of the macro Irish red Killians.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: 12oz bottle at the Peace Center before the Nutcracker. Pours clear reddish amber with a thin white head. Cereal notes, sweet malt. Very light body, somewhat sweet finish. OK.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Re-rating after having it on draft. appearance: amber orange, short creamy/soapy light beige head. aroma: caramel, earth, brown sugar, hint of herbal hops. taste: caramel, hint of brown sugar and walnuts, orange peel, brown bread, cola. finish: slightly sweet, hint of cola and grass. notes: Not bad. Better on draft than in the bottle. Bottle from Total Wine in Charleston, then draft at Craft Conundrum, also in Charleston, South Carolina.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Poured from the tap into a pint glass at the Thomas Creek brewery in Greenville, SC. The appearance is a reddish orange color with a small white head. The aroma is slight malt and grains. The taste is toasted malt and is slightly bitter.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Nope, not to my taste. Not good and would not recommend to anyone for any conceivable reason.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Pours a nice amber color. Not a lot of aroma, sweet malt with a hint of fruit/hops. Flavor is malty, with a touch of bitterness.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Pours a clear golden orange on tap with fluffy white head that dissipates to leave moderate lace. Aroma of sweet maltiness with a hint of citrus hops. Taste is all the malt, a bit of crisp yeast. Clean and easy, just not too exciting.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Red/amber pour. I can smell a bit of carmel and some nuttiness. Taste is sweet and smooth. A bit better than the rating would leave you to believe.

column1: Thomas Creek River Falls Red Ale
column5: Keg at Craft Conundrum, Charleston, 18/02/15. Reddish amber with a decent off white cap. Nose is caramel, buttery notes, sweet tunes, light malt. Taste comrpises apple notes, caramel, straw, faint biscuit. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. So so.

Name: Blind Man Ale Date: February 23, 1996 Mode: Draft Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs clear dark yellow, no head hoppy ale with a slight bitter aftertaste Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.3/5.0 Score: * /4 The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

This is one of the best pale ales that I have ever had the pleasure of drinking. I had this on draft at Smith's Olde Bar, and it is delicious. Cloudy and opaque in appearance, a unique floral smell that smells very musty and sweaty but in a good way. Tastes extrememly sweet and bitter all at the same time, with a nice yeasty finish, because of the layer of sediment unique to Blind Man Ales.

Date: 04/19/1996 Mode: Draft Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs black, good head, roastie malt aroma with hints of coffee, rich roasted flavor with a hint of coffee and choclate, more coffee and bitterness as it warms, aftertaste of coffee bitterness lasts forever Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Blind Man ales was a very innovative brewery. I remember having a sample of their Brown Ale and it being so different from any other beer (although I don’t remember it enough to provide an entry for it here). On to the beer at hand: the espresso stout was available in Atlanta in 6-packs along with one or two other beers by blind man (btw, a new Athens, GA brewery called Terrapin has started relatively recently and they also have a beer that uses coffee from Jittery Joes). The beer had a very nice aroma of roasted/burnt malts and strong coffee. The beer poured black with a very dark head. The time I bought bottles from a grocery store, the bottles were a little over-carbonated - it would foam out of the bottle without even pouring it. After letting some of the CO2 gas out, the mouthfeel was pleasant and properly carbonated. The taste was big and bitter - coffee bitterness combined with unmalted roasted barley bitterness overpowered any bitterness provided by hops. But in a good way (if you like coffee stouts). It was a very memorable beer.

This is a small local brewery in Athens, GA. This is truly the best stout I have ever had, hands down. The coffee taste comes from actual turkish ground espresso grounds from a local coffee house called Jittery Joes. The aroma is captivating, what a mean scent it is. Columbus hops for bittering. WIth a mixture of roasted barley, black and two-row malts provides most of the beers dark dark appearance. A must for all, you can get this now I am told you can still find this is small batches, if you ever are in the south, you must try this!
Light sweet caramel notes. Clear gold with a small white head. Caramel and a light bitterness.

On tap at Mt Begbie, pours a clear amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is quite malty, with bready malt and barely any hop content. Flavour is balanced between the malts and hops, being more characterized by bready malt and toasted caramel. A little bit of bittering hops to balance. Not too interesting.

650ml brown bottle. Golden colour, clear, thin white head. Nose is toasty and grainy with caramel sweetness. Taste is malty, sweet caramel, grains and toasty notes. Not much of a finish. A fairly plain English pale ale.

Appearance: clear pale amber with a short ivory head, good retention and patchy lacing. (3/5) Aroma: biscuity and caramel malt, honey, grassy, light diacetyl. (6/10) Taste: moderate sweet, mild bitter. (6/10) Palate: medium body, lively carbonation, brief duration finish. (3/5) I guess it’s reasonably true to style, but I’d be happier with more hop presence. Sessionable, and would probably go well with fish and chips. Can’t see ever bothering to try it again. (12/20)

This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a mostly clear amber color with a slim white head that just capped the top of the pint glass. A basic film glossed the top of the beer. Light carbonation was seen rising to the top. The smell had a huge roasty caramel aroma over top of a light "soapy" English-like flavor. The taste copied the aroma and gave off a light sweet malty soapy aftertaste. A quick sweet semi-watery finish accompanies the aftertaste. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. The carbonation seemed okay. Overall, I say this was a good English Pale ale I could have again and with some fish n’ chips if I would find again.
Bottle. Clear amber pour with small white head. Sweet malty aroma. Taste is quite flat and sweet. Low carbonation.

A nice sessionable crisp PA but nothing special. Grainy cereal malts with a hint of caramel and a mild floral, herbacious hop build. Very mild flavour with a hint of off skunky malt and tons of grainy, bready malts.

Draught at Burgoo on 10th Ave W, Vancouver, as “Burgoo Brew” house ale Light amber color, with creamy head. Aroma of biscuits, malt, cereals. Dry mouthfeel, with a decent grainy caramel flavor and ordinary bitterness. Pleasant, with a personal touch.

The aroma and taste of this one are both recognizable, but feels like they come from different beers... the aroma is of crystalline hay, the flavour (which I admit is mainly aroma itself, but what you feel when exhaling while drinking) is caramel coffeeish. Only at the finish did I pick up on hops, which were mildly lemony. OK, but not coherent.

650ml bottle pours a pale amber color with a finger and a half of white head that settles quite quickly leaving only a few spots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is light grassy hops with some caramel. Taste is a light caramel malty sweetness with some grassy hop bitterness. Light to medium body with abundant carbonation. A pretty decent pale ale, but would be better with a more pronounced hoppiness.

First tasted this at the Boswell Hotel, Glasgow in December 1994. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale garnet in colour with a thick off white creamy head. Sweet aroma of malt and berry fruit, short in intensity. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Mixed malts give a moist maltloaf base with sultanas, raisins and brown sugar. Slight prickle of dusty hops gives a brief bitter aftertaste. Finish is malty with chocolate powder, maple syrup and oak cask notes laced through. An ok session bitter.

Cask various locations over many years. brown, almost orange colour with white head. Fruity, mainly citrus, aroma with a touch of yeast and malt to finish. Initially sweet, fruity malt flavour with the hops coming through leading to a bitter finish. Light palate makes this an ideal session beer if well-kept.

1. Cask Handpump at the Lower Angel, Warrington 31/07/2001 Mid brown coloured with citrussy aroma. Malty hop finish. 2. Cask Stillage at the Community Centre, Frodsham 25/05/2002 Golden amber coloured and slightly sweet on the palate. Some sour fruit flavour with a dry finish. 3. Cask Handpump at the George & Dragon, Great Budworth 28/04/2005 Golden hoppy and slightly fruity. Some dryness in a creamy malt finish.
Cask Conditioned, at the Head of Steam, Euston, London. Clear golden amber appearance. Fruity aroma. Sweet malty, fruity flavor, mildly bitter in the finish.

Cask Conditioned, at the Head of Steam, Euston, London. Amber with a frothy beige head, dissipating. A little thin but with predominate malt flavour. Part of the Beerlimey & Spiesy, tearing it up in London tour (on a Wed night, ouch!!)

Hand pulled at the Anchor, Birmingham (during Phoenix weekend). A light brown looking bitter. Fairly fruity, but balanced with bitter malt. Balanced and light - this didn’t set my trousers on fire, but was palateable and easily supped.
Sampled cask conditioned at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, Sweden. Pale orange with citrusy aroma. Clean and medium bodied with salty very bitter finish. Solid.
Hand-pulled half-pint in The Pilgrim, Liverpool on 29th June 2019. Golden body, white top. A little malty aroma with a floral note or two, taste also malts first with a floral hop finish.

9/2/2019. Cask at the Sir Thomas Gerard, Ashton-in-Makerfield. Pours pale gold with a white head. Aroma of malt, hops, citrus, caramel and grass. Medium sweetness, moderate bitterness and body. An average golden.

Cask @ Sir Thomas Gerard, Ashton-in-Makerfield. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 090219
Cask @ Sir Thomas Gerard, Ashton-in-Makerfield. Nice head with good duration. Color is yellow. Aroma and taste are fruits, hops, malt and has a sweet light bitter finish.

Cask @ The Three Fishes, Shrewsbury. Pours clear gold, white head. Aroma of pale malt, light floral citrus. Taste is typical golden ale vibes, lightly bitter, bready pale malt, light citrus. Pedestrian golden ale.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Aug 2009 - Pale Yellowy Gold in colour. Very Fruity; citrus grapefruit and orange. Hoppy; grassy hops. Malty; toasty malts, caramel. Good fruit/hops/malt balance. Bitter citrus hoppy throughout. Dry hoppy finish. Refreshing. Very drinkable. Nice beer! (2009-08)
Pours a blonde colour. Taste is dry and wheat beer like. Some citrus on the palate. Quite a good beer
Cask at London Drinker Beer Festival. Clear golden colour, no head. Citrus fruit taste. Lightly hoppy. Light body.
On cask at Congress, Longton. Pours golden with white head. Hoppy golden session, bitter finish. Pleasant.

Nice pint on cask at the hornet in Rochdale perfect looking pint with I need finger of white head that leaves nice ringlets all the way down glass citrus syruppy taste but not overdone would have guessed at this being an american pa or English pa if it had no description decent pint.
Sixteen ounce glass. A rather weak IPA, medium lacing , not very bitter. It was alright , but I am not in a hurry to have another.

From Nov 2007 I got this one in a trade with autumnaldave. Thanks Dave! This is the 2007 edition, best by 041208 and it pours a clear gold with a nice 2 finger head of foam that settles down to a 1/2" layer further into the session. Lots of nice lacing to be had here. The smell is a wonderful nose of floral hoppiness along with a touch of spice. The taste is hoppy to the max. Lots of floral and some grapefruit are tickling my taste buds. There's some malt character in the background to somewhat balance things out but this fresh bottle really is all about the hops. Tasty son of a gun. It has a medium mouthfeel and the carbonation is nice and lightly done. It finishes very florally with just the smallest of touches of caramel malt. Yummy. And...the alcohol is hidden pretty well so I'd say this is quite drinkable. I reviewed a 2006 version that was slightly past its best by last year and the hop character was quite subdued compared to this. Either way, you get a top quality DIPA but I defintely prefer the fresher sample. Thanks again, Dave!
Tried for the first time back in 2008, still a very solid DIPA. Very well balanced. Orangish pour. Thick caramel body, nice blend of piney and citrus character. A real pleasure.
Outstanding beer! Wonderful grapefruit notes and strong hoppy taste that stays with you. Smooth yet firm. Great color. Great, great beer.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with small frothy off white head that lasts. The aroma is pine, floral, grass. Medium mouth, light bitterness, citrus, light dry finish, very good.

Draft at The Pour House in Westmont, NJ. Pours a very cloudy, very dark golden orange color with light tangerine edges and a 1.5 finger white head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. Really good retention with streaks of soapy lacing left behind. Dank resinous hop aroma with lots of pine needle, spruce tip and earthy grass character. This is countered by a subtle citrus presence along with boozy sweetness and a caramel malt backbone. On the fuller end of medium bodied with a very dry and dank earthy hop presence that lingers over the malt backbone and boozy sweetness into a slightly dry finish. Dry, sticky and bitter with aggressive hops up front. The hop profile is a bit one dimensional however with only very subtle citrus character. Could use some more sweetness for balance. Malt backbone is a bit too heavy for my liking with notes of caramel, toffee and biscuit followed by boozy heat in finish. Decently hoppy but alcohol and strong malt flavors hinder the flavor a bit.
Golden and cloudy with a ton of white foamy head. Nice grapefruit and apricot flavor to it. Hoppy and bitter but flows smooth. Good shizz
Fresh clean taste while drinking but leaves strong bitter after taste that lingers for hours.

Pours an amber color with a full bouquet of flowers emitting from it. Taste is crisp but distinctly bitter. The full hops taste overpowers this beer, leaving it all on the palate after the swallow. A mild clove and lasting bitterness in the aftertaste. A good Imperial IPA, just not my style.
Draft at JD Reardons - pours a medium orange . Big citrus and mild earthy aromas . Taste is thick citrus . Very good . ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: English Ales Edinburgh Winter Ale Special Reserve
column5: This beer poured a hazy dark greenish brown with hardly any head. Aromas included cookie, carmel, molasses and some sort of mysterious aftershave like aroma—bay leaves, maybe? The palate was light-to-medium with a velvety texure and soft carbonation. The flavor was lightly bitter and a short, slightly sweet finish. I didn’t find this beer terribly engaging, but not bad.

column1: English Ales Edinburgh Winter Ale Special Reserve
column5: 2003 vintage. Pours a clear reddish-brown with a thin amber head that dissapates quickly except for the side of the glass.Malty aroma with some vinous notes, spices and chocolate. Very thin body for a winter ale. Tastes of chocolatey malt up front, followed by more malt and spices.

column1: English Ales Edinburgh Winter Ale Special Reserve
column5: Pours medium brown with little head. They're not messing around with this winter warmer - it's all spice and more spice. Aftertaste of orange peel, pumpkin and apples. Unfortunately, the flavor does not match up to the amazing aroma.

column1: English Ales Edinburgh Winter Ale Special Reserve
column5: Medium brown color. Small head. Aroma is amazing spicy and malty and perfumey. Malty and slightly sweet. Carmel and toffee. Very spicy. Nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger and others. A milder flavored ale. Very drinkable but it does NOT live up to its wonderful nose. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

column1: English Ales Edinburgh Winter Ale Special Reserve
column5: Light brown with a small head. Nice spicy, somewhat-perfumey aroma alongside a beautiful malt aroma. Very strong caramelized malt flavor. Slight sweetness. I can't really put my finger on the spices--cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg? Fairly light bodied. Wonderful aroma whose promise is left unfulfilled.

Tap at the brewpub. Pours very dark brown with a creamy beige head. Nice chocolate aroma. Smooth dark malt. Med body or better. Flavor is smooth dark malt with a little chocolate and something suggesting chicory. Brewer suggests that’s roasted barley. Pretty dry; decently bitter. Good stout.

On tap at Hangar on the Wharf: appearance was a pure jet black color with a thin less than a finger’s worth of head (bar pour); light lacing is left in the wake; roasty coffee smell; its got the same taste; dry roasty aftertaste and finish (kinda hits ya like an Irish Dry Stout); not too heavy on the palate but still sits well enough like any stout should; overall good Irish Dry Stout that I would have again

Draft at the brewery: Poured a murky black with red hue, head was a creamy tan. Aroma is roasted malts and chocolate. Taste is similar with a roasty malt and dark chocolate. Finish is dry on the palate.
Draft at GABBF. Murky dark maroon color, fluffy tan head. Aroma of coffee grounds. Taste is similar. Medium body.
Great Alaska Beer And Barleywine Fest 2011. Almost black color/ tan head. Chocolate malt, dirt aromas. Thin chocolate, medium roast malt, earthy dirt flavors.

Draft at Cafe Amsterdam, Anchorage (Thanks Ken!). This is a nice American stout ... delicious sweet chocolate at its core, but also with a subtle coffee aspect to it as well, I enjoyed a couple of these while visiting my favorite Anchorage beer haunt. (#3563, 6/23/2009)

19-Jan-08 (Draft: Connoisseur’s Session, 2008 Great Alaskan Beer and Barley Wine Festival in Anchorage, AK) Earthy hay aroma is most prominent, with some chocolate, coffee and roast, but oddly for a stout, these are more background flavors. Some roast in the flavor, light sweetness, finishing with some milk chocolate. The finish is easily the best part of this stout. Medium body seems too thin, dry, medium in carbonation. Very dark brown in color and nearly opaque. The tan head settles to a film and a wide, bubbly ring. As stouts go, this one is on the mediocre side.

From multiple growlers filled at the brewery while in Haines, 12/2005. Rich, Deep, complex, but still pretty clean. A slight fruitiness from the yeast, with a touch of diacetyl. The finish is on the dry side. Nice woody/mapley flavours of a homebrewed style stout that you never taste in a commercial stout. Very low hop flavor and bitterness, allows the nice roasted grain flavor to shine through. Haines brewing Co. apparently sells more of this than any of their other beers, and it shows.
A fantastic stout. Dark roasted flavors abound, but not bitter, more of a creamy taste. Don’t drink it too cold. Let it warm up a bit. Highly drinkable.

From growler, Good nose, roasty, carmel chocolate. Orangy blackish brown. small beige head. Bittersweet flavors. Chocolate, roasty, molasses. Medium body, tad creamy. Drier bitter finish. Very tasty. Had it as part of tour of brewery. Brewer called it a foreign extra stout

On tap at brewery 2016 vintage 11.6% Amber caramel color. Thin collar. Nose is dark fruits and lots of caramel. Very warming nose. Taste is caramel, dark fruits, subtle pine and earth. Still a touch hoppy. Big bodied. Slow sipper. Complex and well balanced. Worth seeking out.

Draft at the brewery: Poured a dark brown with a reddish hint, head is flat bubbles. Aroma is caramel malts. Taste is nice mix of caramel malts and fruit, alcohol is well hidden yet can be realized in the warm mouth.
Draft at GABBF. Murky variegated brown color. Aroma of butters otch and fruit. Taste is chewy toffee. Very nice.

Had this on tap this past weekend at the Great Alaskan Beer and Barley Wine Festival in Anchorage, AK. Colour... medium amber with no head. Nose... brown sugar, molasses, melted caramel. Palate... spent malt, light brown sugar, dark corn sirop, burnt sugar sirop, toffee, dried dark fruits and a medium finish.

Draft@ the 2009 Great Alaska Beer and Barleywine Festival. Clear dark amber with a thin head. Nice pit fruit caramel boozy aroma. Medium body with light carbonation. Good bittersweet flavors of light pit fruits, caramel, with a spicy, warming alcohol twang to finish. Another great Alaskan Barleywine.

19-Jan-08 (Draft: Connoisseur’s Session, 2008 Great Alaskan Beer and Barley Wine Festival in Anchorage, AK) Fruity, malty, chocolaty with some light tart fruitiness in the background. Less body than most barley wines, and carbonation is light-medium. Slight tart fruit aroma, but mostly malty and fruity. Medium-brown in color and fairly hazy. A good barley wine, but not one that stands out.

A swingtop bottle, saved with care by Alaskanwarren, since June 2004. A picturesque strong beer pour, with a small, fine layer of creamy head. Amber body. Hops are entirely gone from the nose, which seems appropriate for an aged barleywine. Very buttery carmel aroma. Smooth. Flavor reminds me of a failry dry-leaning manzilla sherry, with toasty almond flavors and a finish that is cleaner and dryer than the initial aroma might lead you to expect. The alcohol is there, but blends well with the rest of the flavors. Full body, but not sticky. This is a fabulous barleywine! Sort of what I hoped an old barleywine would taste like, but the first chance I’ve had to taste a well cared for example. Thank you Alaskanwarren for the chance to taste this!

From growler, 2002 vintage,Good nose, Perfumey sweet, carmel, butterscotch, orange. Clean, reddish orange color. no head. Sweet flavors, same as nose, with dried fruit also. Meduim body, sticky sweet flavors. Very warming. Tasty, touch out of style. Brewer said scottish/ wee heavy influence. Very good .

Talked at length with the brewer about his barleywines. A true craftsman. Not as hoppy as many barleywines. This is a rich beer, sweet and smooth. I’ve tried the longer-aged barleywine, and it’s very good as well. More rich, smoother with barely noticeable carbonation. Good beer, worth taking the time to sip and savour.

Out of the keg at the 2003 Great Alaska Beer and Barley Wine Festival. Dark orange color with no head and a subtle, sherry nose. Complex malt sweetness of dark plums, burnt caramel and butterscotch. Well balanced with hops in finish. Really good and I bet it will be better aged another year.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: 2003 vintage on tap at Fredfest. Pours reddish brown with a decent beige head and a sour spice and toffee aroma. There is a complex flavor that includes sour malt, date, toffee, chocolate, yeast and a warm alcohol trail. Very delicious and well-aged.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: Tap @ Fredfest... [2003 Vintage] Poured cloudy, orange. Still pretty hoppy even after seven years. Some toffee sweet notes. And a bit oxidized but added some nice flavors.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: Tap @ Bier Stein - Amazing how well this one has held up. You could definitely tell this had some ages on it, still very sweet and syrupy, with some nice maple syrup and brown sugar notes. Caramel maltiness, with cherries and grahams. Very heavy alcoholic mouthfeel combined with alot of sweetness. This would make a wonderful desert beer.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: On tap at the Sasquatch brew fest in Eugene,OR. Pours a red/copper color, slightly cloudy with a off-white head. Strong sweet aroma of carmel. Sweet flavor of carmel and slightly fruity taste. There was a slight alcohol taste near the end. Very smooth barleywine with a nice slight bitterness towards the end.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: Gold Medal GABF ’03. Dirty brown water color with roasted malt and candy aromas. Sweet taste went nicely with bitter hops.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: ON CASK AT THE DUCK: soft, vibrant ruby body. DENSE foamy white head, perfectly uniform. teeny tiny bubbles. Nose is lightly fruity, floral and sweet. some candy, ripe fruits as well as the alcohol (it is 13.9% in this case!). Syrupy and intense. Front is sweet and fruity, followed by wonderful grainy character. Smooth, soft and velvety. warm and inviting, big, full mouthfeel. Chocolate and woody notes emerge through the syrupy sweetness. I couldn't believe it was so strong until I stood up. One of my all time favorite barley wines, I am eternally grateful for even geting a glass off the cask. A freind who works at the resturant let me know it was on the cask. I went in for a glass that night and the next. Unfortunately though, that next evening, the cask had run out 10 minutes prior to my arrival. Awesome nonetheless!! I cant wait for the next!

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: gabf 2003, many many samples: wow! Some candy and dark spice qualities aggresively firming to a substantial bitter through along a roasty bridge. Full bodied and richly textured. Warming. Excellent.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: Wonderful nose, alcohol, fruity, burnt aroma - chewy, sweet and nice balance of malt and hops. This lingers on the palate - a very good brew.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: GABF 2003 (six ounce pour, plus numerous other 1OZ samples): Murky brown color, molasses, caramel ginger bread aroma. Syrupy palate, starts a tad sweet and gets really bitter fast. A great barleywine with a long bitter aftertaste.

column1: Wild Duck Old Gnarley Head Barley Wine
column5: Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival. Dark amber color with no head. Strong wood, alcohol, fruits, and honey in the flavor.

column1: Sleeping Lady Dancing Kilt Scotch Ale
column5: On tap at the 2003 Great Alaska Beer and Barley Wine Festival. Amber color with a nice beige lace ring. Sweet malty profile with a subtle smokey peat-ish taste. Good hop bitterness, but not what I think of as a Scotch ale.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Cask at AK BW fest 2016. Hazy brown color. Aroma of burnt caramel. Taste is rich toasted caramel. Nice body.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: GABBF, dark amber, little head, aroma raisin and molasses, vanilla, cookies. Taste raisin, molasses, vanilla, cookies, candy. Sweet sweet. Palate rich, carb subdued.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Draught at GABBF. Pours murky brown with a small, frothy beige head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel and cookie malt, lightly oxidized, Sherry, stone fruit, vanilla, and alcohol. Flavor is sweet caramel and cookie malt, spicy alcohol, Sherry oxidation notes, light earthy hops and bitterness with dark fruits and a sweet finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a reddish amber color with a medium white head. A big fruity sugary nose. The flavor is light oxidation, caramel, toffee, berries, light fruity hops. Very big and tasty.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Tap at GABBF Dark brown with a small beige head, no lacing. Aroma is woody, dark malts and brown sugar. Taste is woody, dark fruit and sweet caramel Very good

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Draft: Poured a dark brown. The nose is very complex. Taste was sweet buttery with soft alcohol balance.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Sampled at Alaskan Barleywine Festival. Brown, hazy, tan head. Big malt character with toffee, bread crusts, figs, raisins. Resiny hops. Bourbon barrel character evident and contributes some coconut notes.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Growler. Murky copper/brown with a small, dense, beige head. Aroma of toffee, dates, bourbon, vanilla and oak. Flavor is sweet toffee malt, warming alcoholic bourbon, dark fruity esters and oak tannins. Medium to full body with a soft, smooth mouth feel. Very good English style barley wine, lots of dark sweet malt and great barrel character.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Sampled at the Alaskan Barleywine Festival. A great example of a barleywine. A big malt bomb, sweet, vinous, raisin. Good beer.

column1: Sleeping Lady Old Gander Barley Wine
column5: Dark Amber in color, clear with a thin head. Super sweet dried fruit aroma. big nose and lots of alcohol. Big malt and a lingering fruit and light hops bittering affect. A very tasty Barley wine.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Pint on tap. Clear deep mahogany with a thin covering of bubbles. Aroma of sourish cream and dark toffee. Taste is earthy vanilla toffee and lactose. Finish has earthy leaf, dark whole grain bread and toasted walnut. Medium body has medium carbonation and a very drinkable balance, the requisite big malt presence notwithstanding.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Caramel, mild roast, mild chocolate aroma. Lite bodied for a Scottish ale, caramel, sweet malt dominant, minimal hop presence, mild licorice notes, watery finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Hazy orange, off white foam. Very malty, toasty, grassy aroma. Taste is malts, toast, bread, biscuits, lingering grassy bitter finish.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Seasonal with a nice orange-red color, smells indiscreet and average. It tastes about the same. This is definitely a scottish style but just by the barest stretch of the imagination. It really didn’t have any smoky flavors or peatiness to it nor was it very strong. I would be sad with a pint of this. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 02-11-2009 04:29:54 --

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at Big River – Chattanooga. Poured clear coppery caramel with a light cap of beige head. The aroma picked up sweet caramel with a touch of molasses.. sweet overall and simple.. but decent. The flavor found very sweet toasty caramel at the core with a touch of smoke.. the back-end had thicker caramel and a little darker fruit.. also decent. A touch lighter than medium-bodied on the palate with high carbonation.. a little odd sourness rounded out the finish.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Date: 01/25/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Dark amber, big tan head, toasted malt aroma, lots of sweet toasted malt flavor, touch of sweetness, more of a big viennia than a scottish ale -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 02/06/2007 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Score: 3.3 to 3.4 sweet caramel aroma with a yeasty bread character, still lots of the toasted malt aroma and flavor from before, picking up much more caramel sweetness than before, nice biscuit in the final sip, this place makes lots of drinkable viennia ales with many names, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20 Rating: 3.4/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: ***/4

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: A dark copper pour with little or no head. A mediciny bite with a raisin kicker not a lot of maltiness nor hops but a good flavor overall. Good carbonation and a prety good mouthfeel make it a solid palate.. Not bad for a brew chain Scottish Ale.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft at brewpub. Poured clear brown pour with a moderate off-white fizzy head that lasted and had good lacing. Solid toasted malt aroma. Medium body. Good toasted malt flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable brew.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draught. Pours a light red hue. The aroma is certainly akin to a Scottish ale, though rather generic. Notes of peat, caramel, pipe smoke are detected though mostly a sweet malty aroma dominates. The body is almost sticky with a fairly smoky, nutty finish like toasted almonds perhaps. Mild notes of rose and peat turn up in the sweet flavor. Pretty average, sweet, malty beer. Drinkable.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: I was told this was the best brew that Big River produced. Medium brown color, average tan head. Some malt in the aroma, but no rich maltyness or smoky notes anywhere. The flavor was middle of the road sweet, with no real assertiveness. Drinkable but very tame.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: My Bottom Line: Dark fruit and roasted nuts are ably balanced out by earthy and leafy hoppiness in this able-bodied quencher. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam tops the hazy reddish brown. -Plantane bread subtleties rise in the nose upon warming. -The head dies rather quickly in the glass. -The fruitiness is raisiny and sometimes appears as cherries. -The hops do contribute some calculated bitterness. -I’m not sure this follows any style really; Brown Ale? Red Ale? Imperial Mild? On tap at the brewpub.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Pours copper with a thin tan head. Smells of fresh hops, and sweet malt. Tastes hoppy with a nice amount of bitterness balanced against a raisony finish.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Copper coloured. Woody/spicy hop aroma. Fresh dry-hopped resinousness. Very dry flavour. Good balance. Lingering hoppy resiny flavour. Nicely balanced. Very similar to the Pig Red but with the hop flavour bumped up a notch. Fairly fruity as well, with nice sweet cherry/berry flavour.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Light amber in color with a medium white head fading quickly into a small white lacing. Malty, spicy hop aroma. Flavors of malt,spicy hops, subtle roasted,toasted and nutty malt.Starts sweet ends dry.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: On tap at the brewpub: Clear amber color with a thin head, light malts in the aroma, light bitter start with a touch of butter, not much carbonation, ends sweet.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Deep amber body topped with a thin head and some lace. Slightly sweet hoppy aroma with a nutty background. Sweet fruity flavor with a slight hoppy character. Medium bodied and dry.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Dark amber nose is vanilla and chestnuts. Very bitter oak and honey taste with some plums and figs

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: On draft at the brew pub. Brownish color with a light head. Nice oak on the palate. Drinkable and smooth.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: (22oz bottle) Pours a huge almond-coloured head with an opaque body. Nose has hints of cinnamon and nutmeg. Full malted flavour with a burnt caramel and sugar, figs and seeds. Mildly iodine in the finish - expressing the high alcohol. Very good.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Bottle out of brewers private stock. Brown in color with a nice clear tan head. Raisiny, fig like aroma. Nice and fruity flavor. Rich tasting. Well balanced. Fruity. Drinkable and nice.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Bottle out of Tim’s private stock, literally. Brown, clear, tan head. Fruity aroma, raisins, figs, some malt. Bold malty flavors, rich and fruity. Real nice ale.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: On tap at the brewpub. I would've said this is more like an English strong (little hoppiness, woody-sweet character) but whatever. The important thing is the quality of the beer. Extremely dark molasses brown, nearly opaque, no head and very still. Big malty-sweet nose with hints of blueberries; it was served too cold so the nose was impeded for much of my sample. Very nice fruitiness throughout, very drinkable and pleasant, almost no carbonation, just a hint of bitterness at the end. Very nice, I just wish they had more offerings tonight.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Orange/brown color, spicy sweet citrus (orange) aroma, ends sweet in a caramel sort of way with a long aftertaste. Full bodied and very nice, even though the 7% was noticeable.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Deep brown in color,thin white head.Citrus/malty aroma.Roasted malt flavor,sweet rasiny. Lingering hoppy finish,slightly bitter.

column4: Jasper Murdock's Alehouse At The Norwich Inn
column5: Dark reddish brown color with a thin head and not much lace. Sweet fruity (berries) malt aroma with a slight hoppiness. Sweet malty flavor with some fruity notes. Medium to full bodied.

I had it on tap. It pours a reddish brown color with no head and barely any lacing. The aroma was faint spice. The taste was strange with hints of apple and other fruit and lots of spice. It was pretty sweet. The cinnamon and nutmeg flavors are strong. The palate was thin and a little flat. Batches of this in past years have been better.
Draft at brewpub. Pours dirty brown with off white head. Nose and taste of clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, malt and vanilla bean. Medium body.

Pours a clear, somewhat copper color with a tiny lacing of a head. Aroma is of some cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla, caramel and a little more spice. Taste is solid, some cinnamon, sweet caramel notes, vanilla, clove and a light earth taste as it warms a bit, big on the cinnamon flavor, but not in an offensive way. Definitely the standout of the trip there.

Draft from a sampler. This was far and away the best if the six beers I tried. Deep amber body with a smaller off white head. Aroma of cinnamon and nutmeg over a grainy malty base. Medium bodied with a lingering aftertaste. Flavor has lots of spices up front that blend nicely over the malty body.

At the brewery. Dark brown/black body with minimal head. Sweet smell. Cola, toffee, corn syrup notes. A little too sweet. Despite dark color, not too thick; on the thin side palate-wise. A pretty good beer.

Nice dark mahogany coloring with miles of tan head. Honestly, too much head for the style. However, the carbonation level was right where it should be, and letting it sit in my glass for a while brought everything out. Hints of coffee, chocolate, spice, etc. Lots going on here with the flavor. Medium to thinner body, with a nice bittersweet finish. Seek it out.
Growler me! Oh yeah, great beer. Wonderful when you are snowed in, deep in the winter. Powerful aroma, and swimming with flavor. Can’t miss this one if you have the chance.

This beer is very good... It lives up to its name. You can taste the nutmeg, cloves, cinnamon and vanilla... you can certainly taste the nutmeg as it exudes this beer. Served cold... probably would be better at room temp.

on tap-pours a light tan head and brown color with red tint. Aroma is dark malt-chocolate, slight coffee. Taste is dark malt-chocolate (no coffee), hops bitterness. OK carbonation. Occasional. 081227- nice, malty, spice, nutmeg on the aroma. Taste follows with a balanced hop backbone.
Truly enjoyable!!! Lots of thick spiciness with nutmeg, cinnamon and other stuff. Lovely richness and very sweet. My favorite from Bittings so far.

On tap at the Vista location. Pours with a clear, deep golden body with no head. Aroma of honey, biscuit, toast, and caramel. Flavors are caramel, grainy, husky and toasty. Medium bubbles. Pretty average tasting ESB.

A: The pour is a nice light copper color with a mild off-white head. S: The aroma is somewhat light, but what is there is pretty enjoyable. Hints of toffee and bread with a light grassy hop aroma. T: Fairly heavy on the bread with a light sweetness in the form of toffee. There’s a slight creaminess to this beer that was sort of surprising, but also enjoyable. A very moderate level of bitterness. M: The body is a bit on the heavy side for an ESB, but still good. Medium carbonation to go with it. D: Like most US drinkers, I prefer my ESBs more on the bitter side, but this was still pretty good.
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Malt and hop aromas. Golden coloured and smooth on the palate with a crisp malt finish.
Tap @ Vista location. Poured a hazed copper with an off-white head. Toasty caramel malt aroma. Caramel and citrus flavor. Light to medium body.
[Part of sampler @Vista, CA] Very drinkable beer. The best I sampled at Back Street. Light amber colour, hoppy with a sweet aftertaste. Warm. Nice.

From tap in Irvine. Light amber brown color with a thin layer of creamy white head and a semi translucent, syrupy appearance. Light aromas of english toffee, along with a touch of honey and some grassy hops. The flavor is quite a nice balance of cookie dough maltiness and bitter hops. Some floral marigold flowers and nutty almonds make a palate appearance as well. Final smack brings out the bitter hop characters more cleanly.

light brown color tiny white head, aroma is barly there, toffee & light grain w/ some other sugars. Palate is well coated and has an average body flavor is mostly toffee quite sweet and a light dry finish. Ok.

Pours to a clean brassy body with a thin white head. The aroma is lightly bitter and has hints of graham cracker. The flavor is subtle bitterness, yellow grapes, and graham crackers. I also get Hershey’s almond bars. The palate is medium bodied, slick, so-so.

Nioce aroma, decent head, little lacing. Very thin tasting beer. Not what I expect from an ESB. Mild hop aroma and finish, not really very bitter. Very mild malt flavor. I hate to say it, but this is probably the best this joint has to offer! A palatable beer, nothing to write home about.
More mellow sweet crap from this strip mall crap, er I mean Tap House. The finish was a little more balance than the others.
On tap at the Vista, CA location in March, 2008. Pours gold. Aroma and flavor of straw hops, grains, minerals. A bit rough but gets better as it warms up.

A: The pour is a clear golden color with a white head that recedes somewhat quickly. S: The aroma has a decent hoppiness to it. Some mild grapefruit and orange notes and a slight bit of pine. The rest of the nose is made up of caramel malts. T: The flavor is about what you would expect from the aroma. A bit of citrus on the front with the caramel malt doing the majority of the work. The finish has a nice bitterness to it. M: The mouthfeel was a touch thin and watery and the carbonation was appropriate. D: Another easy to drink pale ale (as if there weren’t enough of them). I wasn’t totally crazy about the beer, but with some pizza, it’s wouldn’t be a bad pint to have.
Tap @ Vista location. Poured a clear light copper with an off-white head. Some citrus hops mixed with light malt in the aroma. Citrus and earthy hop flavor that rides on top of a bland malt.
[Part of sampler @Vista, CA]dark yellow/gold colour. hopy, as many San Diego County pales are. clean mouthfeel. Nice, not exciting or great though

Date: 11/29/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy dark gold, fine white head, streaks of lace, sweet crystal malt aroma with soft floral hops, sweet malt flavor, lots of floral hops for balance, lingering bold bitter finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
Clear golden amber with no head. faint citrus and malty aroma. Sweet citrus taste, malty, slightly hoppy finish.

Nice tart citrus hop aroma. Some lemon, some orange, and some grapefruit. Pours gold with a nice fluffy white head. A nice balance between citrus hops and sweet bready malt. Some lemon notes as well. Not overly carbonated. Pretty cmooth. It finishes nice.

Had at Vista California after real ale fest, very tight and astringent which believe it or not was ery pleasing after all the malty goop at real ale fest, very bitter with a great clean crips flavor in the endo.
tap at La Quinta brewpub: this was their best offering IMO. It had more flavor than the IPA. Citrusy and grapefruity hops with usual notes of caramel. An enjoyable APA.
Light amber color with smallish head. Aroma of light caramel. Flavor had a light bitterness to it and a disgusting bitter aftertaste, like dishwater.
Cloudy amber pour.Big ice tea nose.Nice tart bite.Crisp hoppy finish. Only drawback is a thin/watery body.

A: The beer pours an almost neon yellow color and it’s incredibly pale with a short lived white head. S: Very cidery. It’s got an almost apple juice aroma that seems to be augmented in the fruit department by some pears. Certainly some corn in there, and a lot of sugar (smells very, very sweet). T: Oh boy, this is not good. How did this beer come to taste like cardboard? I get a mild hop character that is sort of grassy and floral. A lot of corn on the palate too. M: The body is light as can be with a high level of carbonation. D: I guess to put a positive spin on this dreadful beer: at least it wasn’t skunky.

On tap in Irvine, it’s extremely mild in flavor with virtually no hop presence. The brewer told me that this "Mexican Lager" was done per the suggestion of a good customer, Chava, who wanted a beer that was like a Mexican macro
From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 13/10/2007 Hop aroma. Some carbonation. Small white head. Clear golden coloured and hoppy with a slightly dry pale malt finish.
[Part of sampler @Vista, CA] I agree with herbjones on this one. I don’t like lagers and I didnt really like this one. I guess it might be nice with pizza. honey flavour, sweet and sticky mouthfeel.
I dont think I've ever had a lager that I liked. This one is no different. Clear gold pour. Has all the usual lager qualities.

On tap @ Rock Bottom Westminster poured a clear gold with no head. Aroma was fruity, citrus, banana and ginger. Palate was medium bodied and slightly syrupy. Flavors of pepper, ginger, and fruity with a warming, lingering sweet finish.

Trouble Tripel from Westminster, CO: Slightly hazy and apricot-colored; thin head. Full-bodied with a lively carbonation. Subtle sweetness. Sharp clove carried by a moderate bitterness. Big notes of spices and flowers. Warming and drying. Pretty clean and well-made.

Draught. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie), moderately hoppy (flowers, herbs, lemon), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of banana and clove. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery (almost syrupy) texture, lively carbonation. Nice stuff, surprisingly...very aromatic and Belgian styled, well-hidden alcohol.

Growler thanks to Smoky. Pours slightly hazy copper with quickly settling white head. Aroma is mildly hoppy, resinous, citrus, mild malt. Flavor is strong citrus, mildly bitter, resinous hop finish. Soft carbonation, light body. Mild.
Poured at walnut. Has small amount of head that dissipated quickly. Pours a clear golden color. Medium amount of lacing. Crisp and citrusy.
Amber body with and off white head. Citrusy nose. Flavors are mainly of hop resin, but there’s a little bit of malt in there to balnce it out a bit. Jazzy carbonation. Crisp, bitter finish.

Draught, Walnut Brewery. Head is initially small, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is dark yellow. Aroma is trace to lightly malty (cookie), trace to lightly hoppy (grapefruit), with light notes of chemicals and diacetyl. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, unclean. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. It’s been three years since I’ve sampled this, so I kinda thought I’d be a little more forgiving on this one (previous rating, 2.6), but man, this is some foul stuff. The usual absence of aroma Walnut is known for, but some unpleasant notes are along for the ride. Dirty aftertaste. The mouthfeel and appearance are nice, but that’s where that ends.

On tap at the Brea location 12/26/07. Dark amber; rich malt aroma anf flavor. Biting rich malts and hops...long, cloying finish w/ rich, sweet fruits...strong in alcohol; rich finish. They said 8.7% for this batch.

Date: 12/02/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Strong Ale Fest Woodland Hills hazy amber, thin beige head, big earthy aroma, sweet tart hot and alcoholic, big bitterness, big body, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.5/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: **/4

2005 SD Strong Ale Fest: Brewed at Woodland location. Here since no other place to stick it. Poured a hazy amber-brown color with s small off-white head. The aroma was of old fruit and a tartness that was almost bile like. Malty flavor with light fruitiness. Moderate hoppy flavors on the end. bitter finish and semi-dry. Medium to full bodied.
Very, very, sweet, cloying beer. Hops are present, but this one's just a little over the top.
Extra points for the high ABV. I agree with aubrey, it's easy drinking for the strength. It mad Bud-drinking Raven gag ands she put an ice cube in my glass.
Hazy amber. Smooth and rather malty. Hops are more bitter than aromatic, but nice. Alcohol nips add a nice touch here and there. Tasty and "easy to drink."

Draught. Body is murky medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), lightly yeasty (dough). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, heavily bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent. Not my kind of barleywine (extremely hoppy), and still needs some aging, but decently balanced and something hopheads will probably enjoy. Very well-hidden alcohol.

One of the four Ocean Avenue beers on my flight at the brewpub on 12th May 2015. The least interesting of the four tried, pale gold with a small head it had a mild hoppy nose and flavour, balanced by a malt backbone. It could not compete with the two beers either side of it: the Sunshine Red had a semi-sweetness and the Main Beach IPA out hopped it. Maybe drank alone it would have faired better, but on the flight it sank into oblivion.
Tap, gold pour, white head, nose is lacking, taste is watery, some hops, smooth

Keg at Ocean Avenue, Laguna Beach, 17/04/14. Clear golden amber with a thin off white swirl. Nose is pale malts, toasty ring, grass, light citrus, orange - pretty thin. Taste comprises lightly toasted malt, straw, lemon, citric peel, where are the hops ??? Medium bodied, a little prickle in the carbonation, crisp close. Mediocre stuff with little hop presence. This is a golden blonde in my book - not an APA, just no hop presence. Come to England where you can tick dozens of medicore golden blondes, most better than this !!!
Smak och doft av humle, malt, karamell, viss fruktighet och en grape- och tallbarrsbeska.
Bottled. Pours amber with a white head. Smells very sweet hoppy. Tastes sweet hoppy with a sweet grassy hoppy finish.

The pour is an amber/orange color with a finger of white head. Floral hops start things off on the nose. A bit of sweet orange fruitiness along with some citrus peel. A definite grain husk note, a mild breadiness, and some sweet toffee. The flavor is on the sweet side with lots of toffee, bread, and oranges. The finish somewhat bitter, but it may be a bit more toward the astringent side of things. Not terribly hoppy, but some floral and citrus flavors to it. Mediocre pale ale.
On draft, clear amber with a white head, mild aroma with some hoppiness, smooth and simple

Draft@OABC 07.03.2009. Clear amber with a white head. Mild floral, piney hop aromas. Smooth medium body. Flavor is same as aroma with mild floral and pine hops on a lightly sweet bready malt base. Clean finish. No off flavors/flaws. All day drinker.
Draft at the brewpub. Pours golden. A decent hop aromas. Hop flavors a little week. Nothing more then your average brewpub beer.
(11/07) Tap at brewpub, Laguna Beach. Deep golden, flowery nose, moderate bitterness and slightly sweetish bitter aftertaste.
Poured the color of grapefruit juice. Little head. First sip reveals the overwhelming taste of black pepper. It is overpowering everything.
brown pour with little head. Nice nose full of roasted malt. First sip shows the roasted malt with a little bitter chocolate.

column1: Newport Beach Mo Bitta Double IPA
column5: Dark copper pour with a huge citrus nose. Flavor backs up the nose and then some. Balanced nicely with a huge dose of malt.

Light caramel brown with no head. This is pretty much a scotch session ale. Very malty aroma...not much else (but there was smoke in the bar). Flavor was toasty and carmel...with the typical scotch ale sweetness. Mouthfel was wet...but medium bodied. Not too bad.
Brownish red pour with a huge malty nose. Very full bodied with a hint of smokiness. Toast and caramel with a slight hop finish.

Majority of a 4 oz. pour, on tap at the brewpub in Jacksonville, Florida. Consumed on 2-26-18. Clear gold. Moderate amount of cream-colored head. Bright and nice head. Simple, fresh, lightly fruity aroma. Some dryness in the smell. Maybe a touch of butyric acid which isn't ideal but light enough not to be ruinous. Bitter flavor. Acetaldehyde, I think. A bit beery. Not a ton of fundamental flavor beyond the bitterness. Corn chip. Frothy and smooth in the palate. Not crisp as a lager should be. Imperfect. 5.4.5.3.10=>2.7
On tap at brewpub. Pours a clear gold color white head. The aroma is faint corn malt. The taste is sweet corn malt and light honey.
I looked this more than most pilsners. Not great, but drinkable. Bud drinkers would like it.
had last night, pours golden, some hazy, fuzzy white head that disappears. nose has some grass. mostly malt in the taste, some bitterness but not much. chewy body that leads to an abrupt end.

Served on tap at the JAX Seven Bridges location. Golden yellow with a small but durable head. Very good lacing. Light-medium body with medium carbonation. A bit thin for style. Very light\ aroma of lemon and bready malt. Flavor: weak and earthy for style, but with a normal level of bitterness and hops in the finish and aftertaste.

A pretty good pilsener, but more of a premium lager .. . gold yellow .. . medium lacing .. . clean grain mostly .. . i’d drain a pitcher of this no problem .. . . ever had a cigar put out on your skin?
On tap at the brewery, RBWG Appearance: Clear light yellow with a medium sized white head Pilsner malts, hay and honey. OK, mild but clean
Pours a clear gold on tap with pillowy white head that dissipates to leave moderate lacing. Aroma of bready grains and pils malt, taste follows, nothing special but at least its fresh.
Tap at Seven Bridges. Weak retention on sparkling straw. Nose is old apple, paper. Taste is massive diacetyl, paper, paper, paper. No thanks.

Keg at Seven Bridges during RBWG 2013. Pours clear yellow with a small, white foam head. Decent stuff, sugary white bread, mellow cereal and hay. Light bodied with average carbonation. Does sit a bit heavy on the tongue. Sweet finish, low bitterness. Simple, sweet.

Pours a mostly clear golden yellow from the traditional wooden beer barrel, with a fluffy cap of white foam that dissipates fairly quickly in the ceramic glass. Aroma of clean pilsner and melanoidin malts, herbal and earthy hops, and a traditional German lager yeast. Taste follows, extremely crushable with a soft mouth from the lower carbonation, but loads of flavor. Really awesome, a real treat.
500 ml bottle bought in Salzburg. Not a lot of smell, yeasty. Clear color low head. Fantastic beer taste!!! 😍 this is what beer is supooser to be.

Augustiner is renowned for brewing Munich’s best bier. As early as 1328, The Augustiner Brothers were brewing bier within the Augustinian monastery in Munich. With about 680 years of tradition, Augustinerbräu is the city’s oldest brewery and has survived many extensions without ever forgetting its philosophy or risking the quality of its bier. Augustinerbräu is mostly sweet with faint hints of honey and a soft bitterness on the aftertaste. Its pale yellow complexion and full white head is smooth and quaffable.

0,5 L pour from the big cask at the brewery. Unknown color, in the opaque stein, but the head is pretty think and persistent. The nose is cream, hay, white sugar, honey, and cardamom. Sweet and malty, with a mild bitterness. Light body, with a creamy, effervescent feel. This is a simple, light, and enjoyable beer.

Dieses Bier habe ich einfach aus der Flasche und vom Holzfass in einem Wr. Bierheuriger und auch vor Ort in Salzburg getrunken. Es ist ein uriges Helles mit einer unglaublichen Süffigkeit, das am besten im Tonkrug schmeckt. Es hat leicht erdige und stark brotige Aromen, welche die Süffigkeit aber nur erhöhen. Ein wirklich gutes Bier.
Gutes süffiges Märzen, direkt im Augustiner Bräustübl in Salzburg, Strohgelb, viel Schaum, sehr Süffig; leichte Bittere, leichte Süße, angenehme Kohlensäure

Bottle. Golden, small to average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty and lightly sweetish aroma, light butter and faint toffee, light - some grassy hoppyness. Body is medium, malty and lightly sweetish, faint toffee, light - some grassy hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and dryish - lightly sweetish, faint toffee, light - some herbal/grassy hoppyness. OK märzen with notes of toffee (wood in the bottled version). Decently hopped but could be drier.

Gravity wooden mug at the brewpub in Salzburg-Austria. Appearance can’t be described, aroma is grainy with a soft yeast note, pastry and almonds milk. Bit sweet as an aroma. Mouth: carbonation is fantastic, sparkling start and flat overall, medium body, sweetness is soft, hay. Crazy clean

Aroma is malty, fresh. It smells like grain, bread with grassy and nutty overtones. Flavor is medium sweet. It tastes bready and grainy, a bit like nuts. Mouthfeel is very creamy, body is medium. Finish is short and balanced sweet. A wonderful Austrian Märzen. 0,5l bottle.

500 ml bottle, bought directly from the brewery in Salzburg. Pours clear dark golden with medium foamy head. Sweet malty nose. Hay, grain, bread, some caramel, malts, citrus. Medium bitterness with a sweet hint; very balanced and perfect Märzen taste. Lively carbonated, dry finish, medium bodied, süffig. Very palatable and refreshing Märzen. I can't get enough of it. Fantastic.

0,5 L pour from a small cask at the brewery. Pours a pale golden color, with a thick, rocky, off-white head. The aroma is toffee, walnuts, rye, vanilla, and oak. Sweet and syrupy. Just a little bitter. Medium body, with a thick, chewy palate, and a little hard finish. Clean, malty, and enjoyable.

0,5l bottle at home courtesy of Saeglopur, big thanks for this one. BB 06. Feb 2017. amber clear color, small off-white head. smells grains, some sweetness, some ripe fruits, plums, chlorophyl, tobacco. average smell. full body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes lightly sweet, dark fruits, plums, bit breadish, tobacco, some grains, light grassy notes. finishes lightly bitter with notes of plums, grains and grassy notes. decent overall, but also not overly exciting, I guess a good style example though.

500 ml bottle, bb 06 Feb 17, bought at the brewery. Amber, clear body, with a big, creamy, lacing, yellowish head. Aroma of bread, flowers, caramel, some grains, slight grass. Tastes of bread, caramel, flowers, some hay, slight grass. Medium, oily mouthfeel, with an average carbonation. Finishes bready, moderate sweet, a bit dry, floral, a bit grassy, slightly herbal. Nice one. Quaffable and well balanced, with nice bready and floral notes throughout and enough sweetness. Not on par with their Märzen overall, I’m missing some more character, but still an above average style example.

sweet in flavour and aroma, little bit spicy, taste is sweet for this beer style, good body, but good to drink, not really clear but ok, good carbonated good to drink nothing special, but the perfect bock beer to drink at this special place of beer culture in austria

500 ml bottle. From Salzburg. Big thank you to Jukka & Tanja! Slightly cloudy golden colour with tiny white head. Heavy malty aroma with notes of manure. Flavour is malt, mild alcohol, some sweetness and balancing bitterness. Drinkable Bock but not my favourite.

Mild getreidig-süßer Geruch. Eher milder Antrunk, etwas süßlich, drückend muffig-hopfig. Hell-malzig, wenig würzig, zurückhaltend. Mit der Zeit etwas würziger werdend, es bleibt aber trotzdem ein milder Bock. Zum Ende wenig alkoholisch, hopfiger, süßlich wie am Anfang. Ein milder Vertreter des Bockgenres, mit seiner Bestimmtheit aber interessant. Süffig! Vielen Dank an den Doppelbock für das Bier! 12/11/11/11/9/11

15th December 2007 Draft at the Brewpub in Salzburg, Austria. Rich with tart fruit. Sweet juicy malt. Lingering but subtle marmaladey finish. Very smooth and incredibly drinkable. Lovely fresh beer, could drink this all night.
Bottle; Pale golden color. Aroma is light malty, light spicy and grassy. Flavor is malt and light sweet. Good balanced bitterness.

This is the other beer I had that day at the Monastary. In fact the picture in my profile is me drinking this beer in the beer hall. This beer was out of the small barrel. Anyway it has a dark amber/red color, a hop taste and a bitter finish. Overall I liked this beer, but I had it a while ago so my memories are more of the experience then of the actual technicalities of the beer.

column1: Maplewood Farms I C D Light
column5: Has a light yellow/golden color and a lightly malted smell. Taste is lightly malted and finishes very smooth with little bitterness. Overall this was my least favorite of the six I tried, but it was better than any other "light" beer that I have tried.

12 ounce bottle poured to wine glass light brown amber, hazy, small tan head that disappears quickly good, fragrant, some grains, fruity vg, low bitterness vg, lively carbonation, long tart finish, bitter aftertaste very good beer, ok to repeat drank: 11/13/2016 11:14 PM
Draft - Lots of sweet caramel. Clear gold with a decent beige head. Sweet caramel and a light bitterness with a sweet and bit booze in the finish.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy brown color with a rather small white head on it. Nose is a little toasty, with a slight bit of bread in there. Taste is a tad bitter and malt forward with just a hint of sweetness on the finish. Decent beer, but nothing remarkable.
Nice bready, floral aromas. Pours a clear Amber/red with a nice off white head and good lacing. Good mouthfeel slightly creamy with a malty bready sweetness some toffee and a pleasant finish.

Bottle in a pint. Label says Dick’s Mountain Amber Ale - from their delightful mixed 12 pack. Pours clear, light amber-brown. No head. Aroma of fruit, malt, and something spoiled. Light sweet malty flavor, light-med body, and fruity finish. It’s your typical amber.

Medium amber, egg-shell head which fades to a ring at the edges. Aroma is a light, medium-darkness caramel with notes of forest and earth. Body is medium-light.
