column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Třešní
column5: Brown reddish colour with a light brown head. Malty, buttery aroma with a cherry note. Marzipan sweet flavor again with notes of cherry.

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: tap @ Danup. hazy golden color,nice head, honey taste with long palate. drinkable.

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: Draught at the brewery. Brown with an off-white head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel, roasted, chocolate, lots of honey) and hoppy. Flavor moderate to heavy sweet, light bitter. Medium body, almost flat. Very fine.

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: Bottle: Hazy, chestnut-amber coloured, big, slowly diminishing off-white head, burnt malt, molasses and a bigger amount of honey in the nose; harsh bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied, "greenish"-yeasty, dark-malty and honeyish finish. Not well rounded, not very pleasant..............

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: Dark brown colour. Aroma of honey and malt. Flavours of honey can be found in the taste. The combination of honey with rather dry hoppyness makes this beer really interesting.

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: On tap at the brewpub: The Lure: Gargantuan honey allows some smoking wood and soil to play along. A chocolatey dessert with fruity topping. I admit I was pleasantly surprised when I saw this honey beer was made with a dark, not blond, lager base. The Festivities: Honey lathers the tongue mercilessly and a body full of love handles gifts sweet cherries, chocolate truffles and roasted, almost burnt, bread crumbs. This is so portly, it really doesn’t feel like a lager. Transcendence: Oh no! Grandma’s coming with another pie!

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: Bottled. Dark ruby, beige head. Aroma of menthe and honey. Very roasty with clean mouthfeel. Sweetness that is rounded off by some grassy hops. Interesting and quite tasty, but on the sweet side, and with too clean malt character.

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: bottle. darkish murky copper colour. aroma of no frills honey. lots of honey flavour but pretty sweet with hints of apple juice and compost in the finish. this brewery is very hit and miss

column1: Krkonošský Medvěd Pivo s Příchutí Medu
column5: Bottle. I didn’t mind their cherry beer so much, but this was just too sweet. Sweet Capilano honey and brown sugar. Very sweet flavour and texture, some maple syrup. Didn’t work for me, one dimensionally sweet.
*Old Rating, best before 25.03.02. Rated as "Geburtstags-Bier" with same ABV and style. Malzig-neutrales, süffiges Bier. Nicht zu tief, leicht malzig-karamellig. Nicht zu tief, aber nett süffig.

bottle from the fridge at klub malych pivovaru in pilsen, as zwiesel weihnachtsbier. paler than expected - golden with a steady white head; aroma of malted vanilla; quite sweet with a modest tinny bitterness and not much else happening
Sweet honey and hay nose, dark apple juice like color. No head or carbonation to speak of. Sweet sugary malt taste and a light hop character. Watery and not christmas like.

Sweet, bandaid, cereal nose. No head - and ...no amber color - it is more like orange/apple juice. Light oranges taste, short and light bitter kick, thin. IMO not a Christmas beer, not strong and not spicey at all.

50cl bottle. A clear brown beer with a mid-sized most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of mild caramelish dark malt, bread, nuts. Taste of mild caramelish malt, red malt, nuts, brown malt, mild bitterness.
Dark red-brown color beer with a beige short head. Typical Munich malt aroma. Sweet taste with a low bitterness. The beer is more an autumn beer than a spring beer. A nice full body beer.

Bottle (Gasthaus Frey, Eichstätt):Clear, chestnut-amber coloured, medium-sized creamy off-white head; mild traces of toasted malt and coffee in the delicate caramelly nose; mild to moderate bitter-sweet flavour,light to medium bodied;slightly lingering coffeeish and malty finish. Quite O.K.…
Trinkbares, recht dunkelfruchtiges Piwo mit einer milden Malznote und annehmbarer Süffigkeit. Im Grunde eins wie viele andere auch, aber dabei durchaus zufriedenstellend.

Pours out of the bottle in a deep brown colour with steady head and medium body. Aroma of bread and wheat. Taste of dark grains, bread, malt, straw, plums and raisins. Easy to drink yet nothing special.

It’s dark brown with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of caramel, roasted malt and light nuts. The flavor has a light to moderate sweetness and notes of roasted malt, caramel, and a little nuts and milk chocolate towards the slightly dry finish!

50cl Bottle via bierkoning, thanks Edo! Dark brown colour with a red hue, off-white head. Aroma of dusty cocoa, roasted malts, nuts. Flavour is roasted malts, burnt caramel, cocoa, light chocolate, light nutty, light bitter finish. Light-bodied.

Pours an orangish brown color with a nice tan head. The aroma is toasted malt, caramel. The taste is Caramel, bread with a slightly dry and fruity finish. The body is light/medium with active yet smooth carbonation. Overall a very nice dunkel.

500ml bottle. Clear brown colour with average, frothy, minimally lacing, tan head. Minimally sweet, slightly grainy, dark malty aroma with a touch of hay. Taste is dark malty, minimally grassy hop overtones, very subtle sweetness. A bit watery. fizzy carbonation.

Hmmmm...finally discovered an average German dunkel. Not much in the flavor department, barely any hints of the nuttiness or roast grains this style is usually noted for. Falls flat on the tongue ...almost watery. After enjoying their Festmarzen so much, this one was a little disappointing. With so many good examples of this style, this one leaves a lot to be desired.
Not the greatest example of style. Mild banana and clove. Okay but have had much richer

Bottle (kindly delivered by joss!): Hazy, mahagony coloured, quite firm smaller off-white layer; sweet fruity-wheaty and also caramelly nose with a touch of almomds and raisins; moderate sweet-sourish flavour, a bit fizzy, medium bodied; sweet caramelly finish, balanced by a light acidity. A friendly, well crafted Weizen, creating a very faint illusion of an belgian ale......

Bottle. Roasted almond aroma. Cloudy brown with nougat cream on top. Nutty, bready base with banana and clove notes. Chewy body, medium. Mellow mouthfull. Desert finish. Pleasant enough, but not overly exiting.

Bottled. A slightly hazy amber coloured beer with a decent thickish whitish head. The aroma is wheaty and has hints of bubblegum. The taste is on the thin side. A little banana and a little caramel. Pleasant enough but uninspiring.

Bottle: Aroma is malty, light fruity with roasted malt notes. Hazy, dark amber color. Flavor is round, malty and velvety. Notes of spices, light fruitiness and caramel. Light astringent, dry finish with roasted malt notes. More like a dunkelweizen.

Bottle. Dark brown with an off-white head. Aromas are wheat with chocolate. Malty with citrus notes. Flavours are dry wheat with lots of metal notes. Earthy malts with some soft citrus. Tastes a little stale. Fairly bland but unoffensive.

Nice sessionable hefeweizen... as if any decent one isn’t. Pouring a very hazy, deep amber body with a thick, creamy ecru head, the base of the nose is a soft wheat atop which is heaped vast quantities of banana and bubblegum scents. Soft mouthfeel. The flavor has some buttered toffee to it with a handful of Wheaties, but the bubblegum and banana surge forward accompanied by a spritz of lemon. Surprisingly dry finish. More. Hi-Time Wine Cellars, Costa Mesa CA

Hazed oxidized copper color with a tall stable brownish white head. Mild wheat aromas with faint smells of peat, earth and buttery caramel corn. Rather weak bouquet. Pleasant flavors, though still rather light. Dry malt and wheat start and lead to a mild citric middle. For a ur-weisse this is very mild and unexciting, but quite drinkable.

(500 ml bottle: $2.19 at Hi-Time Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA) So I can’t figure out what the deal is with this beer. According to the company web site, there are three different versions of the Malteser Weisse (Hefe, Dunkel, Kristall), but none of the bottles match mine. My bottle is entirely in German, so that’s not helping me either. The only thing that might identify the beer is the word "Naturtrüb", but I doubt that is a clue either. Anyway, this beer is pretty dark, pouring a murky ruddy brown color. The off-white head rises quickly to about an inch before slowly subsiding to a thin, broken layer. Moderate aromas of wheat, banana and bubble gum, but not much in the way of spices. The flavor is actually pretty bland and really disappointing. Yeah, it’s wheaty, but the banana-like esters are extremely timid, and again, no spices. Sweetness is very light, and there’s a mild citric tartness in the finish. Light bodied, flimsy, and kind of watery in the finish. So this looks like a Dunkelweizen, but tastes like a watery Hefeweizen. Whatever it is, it’s entirely forgettable.

The bottle I had poured a deep brown, with a decent head, true, its pretty smooth, but the aftertaste is quite good, lots of spicy banana flavor, nice beer. Maybe bottle quality varies with posters, but I think I got a good one from Hollingshead!
Nice beige head. Light cloudy as a normal unfiltriert should be. Typical wheat aroma with but not much bananas but still a big clowe aroma and taste. Nice body.
500nl on tap at Pfaffenhofen. Aroma is light yeast, malt, banana. Appearance is cloudy orange with a huge white foam. Taste is sweet and light bitter. Good.
0,5 l bottle BB 14.Feb. 14 amber-orange, cloudy, stable frothy white foam Aroma: cereal / wheat, banana, fruits, dough medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation,

It’s unclear golden with a huge, creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of mild yeast, fruit and wheat and a little touch of butter, but not as it gets warmer. The sweet flavor has notes of mild yeast, fruit, wheat and initially a hint of butter, but not when it gets warmer. The finish is slightly dry. Letting this beer getting warmer before rating gave it more points, probably from 3.1 to what I gave it...
Poured cloudy yellow in colour with white foamy head. Fruity banana and bubblegum flavour with some spices as well.

Murky golden color, much darker than a normal weissbier, especially as it is labelled as a "hell". Head fades fast to skin on bier, flavor leaning heavily on the banana overtones. Cloudy, but bier darkness adds color confusion. Thick , oily mouthfeel, with slight tang on the tongue. Nice entry into the lineup, but almost halfway to a dunkel weiss...

(draught) pours a murky golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of wheat, light banana and grassy hops, with a hint of straw. flavour is heavy banana, wheat, caramel and vanilla, with a hint of crème brûlée. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.

Pours a hazy and golden beer with a white head. The aroma is malt, yeast, fruit and banana. The flavor follows the nose with additional notes of acidity. The palate is dry with sweetness. Overall a beer below average.
Pours cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma is wheat, phenolic notes, clove and orange. Flavour is wheat, light acidic, clove and orange.
Bottle @ Odense Summer Tasting, 2011. Pours cloudy golden with a creamy white head and lacings. Nose is wheat and grain. A bit of paper and banana.
Yellow, with an ok head. A sweetish, smoky(?) aroma. Extremely sweet, it's hiding all other flavours.

Bottled. Chestnut red, low head and moderate condition. Initialy grainy nose with sweet malt and chocolate/dunkle notes. Sweet and grainy in the mouth, almost wort-like with some caramel and whisky developing. Quite sweet and smooth in the finish with alcohol finally apparent.

Bottled. Copper coloured with a low head and moderate condition. First aroma is honey, then nuts and finally hops. In the mouth the fruitiness of the hops dominates and becomes nicely bitter in the finish. Crap clipart label.

Cask at the Cross keys, City. A clear orange amber coloured pour with fading halo of off white head. Aroma is subdued, nutty watery malts, low silage. Flavour is composed of nutty toasted malts, spicy Rye, leafy grassy hop, sileage. Some dried apple in the finish. Palate is semi sweet, watery, spicy. Decent condition.

Cask handpull at the brewery. Bright tawny amber with a collapsing foamy head. Discreet smokiness in the aroma, lingering nuts, Ovaltine, peat, big balancing hop. Peated malt dominant but not overpowering. Certainly enough to qualify it as a ’Smoked’. Schlenkerla shandy. Lovely
Cask at Merton Beer Festival Sept’ 04. Bronze colour, roasted and fruity flavours, hoppier tasting as you get through it and nice bitter finish.

1. Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2001 Mid brown coloured with earthy and wheat aromas. Bitter finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 04/11/2001 Dark red colour roasted and fruity. MAlt finish. 3. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich 21/10/2004 Mid brown colour slightly hoppy and fruity. Bitter lasting malt finish. 4. Cask Handpump at the Alma, Scarborough 04/12/2009 Smoked aroma. Small white head. Copper amber coloured a little rich on the palate and fruity with a crisp and bitter smoked malt finish.
Cask conditioned @ JDW, Soton. Malty aromas and liqourice. Thin and salty, a bit on the sweet side. Could be pretty decent with a fuller body and less saltiness.
Medway Fest. Ruby colour. Licorice nose. Mmm. Malty and roasty. A deep and gorgeous Autumnal ale. long, lingering dark toffee notes merging with damp Autumnal leaves.
Cask at The Golden Lion, Ipswich. Deep brown colour. Full malty flavour, prunes and forest fruits aroma, hints of English malt vinegar and HP Sauce in both aroma and flavour. Dusty finish. Nice.

Cask Conditioned at The Hare & Hounds, Wardington. Copper bronze colour with thinnish head. A heady mix of flavours without anything too oustanding. A dry tea type hop note and a good dose of lightly roasted malt, some smokeyness. Refreshing but confusing.
Cask conditioned. Bronze with a good tight head and fine condition. Fruity nose, flavours of nut and hop with a little smokey malt and a finish that starts with toffee and gets hop bitter at the end.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Et fransk bud på en hvedeøl. Det er en syrlig uklar øl, der har undertoner af citrus. Den er meget frisk i smagen og skal helst drikkes godt kold, god til sommeren. De første par mundfulde var næsten for sure, den vandt dog i løbet af øllen. (75cl hjælper på det). Ikke det bedste af wit/hvedeøl, men et godt fransk alternativ til en fransk hvidvin om sommeren.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle. Hazy yellow and orange with a small head. Aromas are bitter citrus and floral notes with sweet wheat. Flavours are soft wheat malts with lemon sherbert followed by decent bitterness. Lemon rind and some resinous citrus. Very refreshing.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle. Pours a quite hazy and very pale yellow. Head is lacing a lot, thin and slightly bubbly. Quite wheaty aroma. Taste is sweet, quite bubbly. Some coriander and wheaty sweetness. Not bad, though not spectacular.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: The color is hazy straw and the head is very nice. The aroma is wheaty and has sweetness just as the flavour that has notes of citrus and is refreshing. It’s an OK wit, but I would prefer much more depth in the flavour, but if you like Hoegaarden Witbier, then you probably like this one too.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: 75cl bottle from Auchan, Calais. Hazy old gold colour with thick white fluffy head. Lemon and wheat aroma. A little bit soapy maybe. A bit like lemon sherbert sweets. Okay, balanced hop on the end. I had it as my first beer on a Friday evening as an apperatif and it was great.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: (Bottle 75 cl) French wheat beers are a close relative to their Belgian brothers - and then again quite different. Spiced yes, but not in the typical Belgian way with coriander and orange peel. I believe this has more of a gingery touch. Very dry, almost without any body or any sweetness - or bitterness for that matter. Pale and slightly hazy with a frothy head. OK and quenching but rather bland and uninteresting for it’s type. 270103

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Very pale wheat beer with a light floral nose that has very little bitterness behind it. The flavour is quite strong and dry but lacks the citric characteristics of a typical wheat. Overall a little disappointing.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Airy citrus & meringue, ozone in the aroma. Very white foamy head that dissipates quickly with no lacing. Pale yellow cloudy beer, but apparently not bottle conditioned. Light body and carb. Weak, watery citrus wheat flavor with lemon-wax finish and no after. Not very good beer.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Orange cloudy appearance. A pretty average Belgian White. A little thin and watery though.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Cloudy light yellow colour. Very yeasty flavour with a thin and watery finish.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle at Nicolas on Great Portland Street. Herby, a little metallic, pleasant enough though.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Robe ambrée assez vive, troublée par de fins flocons de levure. Mousse correcte, carbo moyenne. Nez très malté. En bouche, pas mal de sucre, une légère amertume aux arômes de genièvre, assez présent. Le malt domine de loin, avec le corps, plus typé garde que triple, le genièvre est présent et n'est donc pas menteur, et dure dans la longueur, avec son amertume typique. Pas mal, pas fou. Je subodore un changement de nom de « l'Estaminet ».

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Backlog rating from RBESG 2008, grand tasting: Cloudy yellow, off-white head. Salty orange notes. Surprisingly light body.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle from Carrefour, Calais, France.Hazy, light amber coloured with malty and toffee flavours followed by candy sugar and sweet fruit on the warming finish. Not bad.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Small bottle from a mixed box found in a French supermarket. Clear and amber, flat and no head. Not much aroma, slight almond notes. Sweet and with only a little bitterness. Nut and caramel notes and a sticky finish. There is an odd taste I can’t place. Would not bother with another.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle. Pours nearly clear amber with airy off-white head. Clear aroma of malt and fruit, with notes of hops and caramel and touches of yeast. Bitter, hoppy flavour with grassy and estery notes and touches of malt, yeast and caramel. Estery aftertaste with some acidic and metallic touches. Okay but nothing really illuminating.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: 330ml bottle from Auchan. Pours a lightly misty amber, large off-white head. Aroma hints towards earthy malts with a light sweetness. Taste is rather tame malts with faint yeast and even fainter juniper berries. For a biere de garde it’s nice enough, but not really hitting the high notes.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bière mousseuse au teint orangé, assez légère pour une triple (seulement 7%).

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Alone at biking trip vogses. Hazy amber colored beer with medium diminishing white head. Herby malty aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is dry herby.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: from Au Grain d’Orge, Crissier; 2010 vintage - pours a hazy reddish-amber beer with particles floating within; little white foam left; aroma of candi sugar, chewy malts and bread; slightly peppery and with hints of apple, sweet and full-bodied; highly carbonated; lot of residual sugars with more notes of bread - not terrible

Bottle, many thanks Koelschtrinker! Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is light böckser, peach, lemon rind, moldy basement. Taste is moldy basement, lime, horseblanket, peach, oxidized indeed. Silky mouthfeel with high carbonation. Already quite old, but it is still good.

“Whose hair is this?“ Many thanks to SinH4. Orange colour, egshell head, fruty and moldy aroma, refreshing sourness, citrus shells and nice tannins. Already quite oxidised, but still incredibly well balanced.

A 750ml bottle at 1420, 1998 vintage, with a best before date of 2010. Poured into a 3 Fonteinen gueuze glass. After a careful pour, it was a mostly clear golden orange colour with a one finger white head that had decent retention, while leaving only sparse to no lacing. Aromas with slight musty dusty notes, hay, funky, citrusy lemon and oak. Tastes of complex goodness. Lightly sour, funk, barnyard, musty, hay, citrusy lemon, green apple, apple skin and oak. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall, wow, just so lucky and happy I got to try this while there are still bottles around. To be honest, I wouldn’t know if it is past its prime yet, but what I drank was very balanced and had wonderful complexity and was just an absolute joy to drink. Must try if you can still find and afford it.

10k rating! 750ml bottle @ 1420. Smooth, farmyardy and funky with loads of cellary notes, some cheesy notes, gooseberries, tartness, mild sourness and wood. Really well balanced and quite tasty still after 21 years. Awesome.

Old rating rerated 09.05.2018, 0,75l bottle sampled @ 1420 "The great geriatric geuze get-together" tasting: Nice fizzy-creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly dry sour-ish mineraly, oak, hay, minerals, mild cork, old cellar, bark, old rope, berry skin, unripe berries, mild vinegar, old citrus peel. Taste is slightly dry sour-ish, old rope, sorrel, oak, hay, minerals, bark, berry skin, unripe berries, old citrus peel, old cellar. Medium bitterness, slightly dry sour-ish mouthfeel. Fair enough, seems over the top to me...
Pours orange with a small head, aroma of fruits, brett, flavor of brett, fruits, green tea, medium to full bodied

750ml bottle back log entry thanks to Eric and Toby. Pours out straw color topped with a fizzy white head. Nose is amazing old dust basement musty notes lemon cheese tons going on. Taste is more of the nice funky bugs cheese wow this was great.

Bottle at Ryan’s January 2017 tasting - huge thanks for this one - wow. Pours a deep orange body with short white head and minimal lacing. Nose is dusty old lambic, fruit and dank basement. Mouthfeel is essentially perfect for a Gueuze - and a bit surprising given the age on this (+19 years??) Notes of lemon funk, old aged Gouda cheese, light perfume, dank basement cement, fruit, oak and cedar.

Another one off the bucket list. Huge thanks to Ryan for sharing this dusty butthole of a beer. Pours golden orange with small head. Smell is old and perfumey with complex oak, blanket, and lemon skin geueze. Flavor is lemon Earth, oak, leather, and Spanish cedar closet. Medium bodied. Such a perfect geuze...holding up great at 19 years old. Amazing!
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. Niesamowicie bogate i dojrzałe piwo.

Cask: A very dark red beer with no head. It has no aroma to speak of. The flavor is very bitter and a little flat (cask). It's a good beer but very bitter for an english bitter. Usually I love bitter beer - but this was too much.
Was soll ich sagen? Morgens um 11 bei 32°C schmeckt doch alles irgendwie, aber nüchtern betrachtet is es ein getreidig malzig Bier mit 0 Charakter, typisch Karibik
(peux pas mettre plus à ce ‘truc’ - degré zéro de la ‘bière’ (dire que tout le monde, là-bas, en boit), thanks Soizic)
Bottle, courtesy of Rasmus40. Clear golden, white head. Grainy, malty aroma. Sweetish flavour, sweet malt, mild hoppy bitterness. Ok thirst quencher.
Clear golden beer with small white head. Aroma is weak malty, bread. Aroma is weak sweet and little crispy bitter ending. Light body. Drinkable, but nothing more. Typical standard production lager.

Robe dorée brillante et limpide, carbo très correcte, mousse correcte, reste 5mm. Nez très herbacé, avec dans un deuxième temps un nez de pain frais aux notes fleuries légères. En bouche, l'attaque est clairement sur le pain, léger et très facile à boire, avec une légère note herbacée qui arrive rapidement par dessus, mais disparaît vite au profit du pain. On a une lager très classique, pas mauvaise, mais clairement lambda.

Pale lager de 5,4 % abv. Mon exemplaire était à 1 mois avant sa date. Couleur doré moyen, à la grande brillance. Bulles moyennes, partout, vives. Mousse blanche, soyeuse, stable à 2 mm. Arômes de malt pils, pointe de riz. 1ère bouche avec un blé sur pied, très douce. Arrière-bouche agréable, très courte. 2ème bouche tout à fait acceptable, à la douceur constante. Arrière-bouche un rien plus longue que la 1ère. La longueur tourne un peu sur les pâtes fraîches. Jambes fines, longues. Alcool qui auparavant de 5 % abv, mais il n'a rien gagné … Finale douce, comme un corsaire ... CONCLUSION : moins mauvais que beaucoup d'autres … (2/2/2/2/2)

Tallboy can from Super U in Petit Bourg, Guadeloupe. Clear golden color dense white head with good retention and solid lacing. Aroma of light ppper and lemon. Taste is light light lemon. Light. For hydration purposes only.
Couleur dorée claire, presque aucune mousse. Nez typique de houblon poussiéreux, carton humide, note sucrée. Gout leger malté céréales aqueux avec aucune amertume et corps leger.
Botella, color dorada,espuma blanca,moderada,poco resistente.Aroma cereales,malta,herbal.Sabor ligero amargor,malta,cereales,herbal

Bottle shared at GBBF 2015 - London. Cheers! Pours clear, pale yellow with a small, foamy white head. Pretty papery, some pale bread, white bread. Light sweet flavour, oddly with a little smokey note, more white bread, cereal flakes. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Sugary finish, more dry papery notes. Meh.

On tap at GRBC. Deep brown body, thin clumping tan head with shades of dingy gray. Dry slightly acrid roast aroma with sharply metallic grain notes. Plenty of dry roast in the flavor with bitter dark chocolate providing the rest. A bit sharp on the tongue, finishing with a suggestion of spicy rye and the slightest hint of fruit, but these essences were slight.

dark brown with a nice brown head, aroma is chocolate malt with hint of rye, mouthfeel was quite thin and chololate malt flavor was not as roasty as I like my stouts to be, nice hints of rye, but overall it is just to thin and weak tasting to be a real good stout

355ml can pours a darker golden color with a small white head leaving almost no lacing on the glass. Aroma is mild cereal grains and mild hops. Taste is light malty sweet with a sharper hop bitterness. Nothing special, just another cheap beer.

Light for a wheat beer. Thick head. Yellow/gold brown. Distinct taste compaired to the other western beers. Scent weak, again seems a bit sweet. Has the western hop-taste, but more hoppy and a bit better, which seems very odd for a Honey.
Pours gold with a fluffy white head. Has a sweet, flowery aroma. Has a fruity taste, some wheat. Goes down really well!

Golden coloured, on the darker side really, like piss gets when you’re dehydrated. Pretty neutral aroma, faintly grainy. Pretty neutral palate too; on the thin side, maybe slightly sweeter than average but no true honey character that I could discern. Whatever.
Can. Brewnosers Meeting September 2006. Golden yellow, small white head. Muted aroma, with mild honey and grains. Thin watery flavour, light honey and grains again. Inoffensive but quite thin.
faint malty aroma. Pours a amber brown, half decent head. Flavour is musty yeast with some sweetish notes. Watery finish.

355ml can. Poured gold, held a bit of a fluffy white head. Sweet aroma, faintly floral. Malty flavour, medium sweetness with honey notes. A bit of wheat detectable in the finish. Medium body and lightly carboanted.
Poured with a nice fluffy head. Medium golden in colorLight fruity smell and sweert taste. Beer went down very smooth and had little after taste. OK beer to end a hard work week

Started with a fruity-light aroma and poured with a thin quickly fading head. A light flavor with bittersweet tones...but not strong enough to really distinguish any honey or wheat flavors. This is my favorate of the Great Western lineup so far and is a nice beer to drink cold on a hot Saskatchewan summer day.
Pale yellow with hardly any aroma to speak of. It tastes pretty much like any domestic North American macro lager, only with a slightly sweeter finish. Where’s the wheat?

Gotta be the same as the Old Blitzen...I’ll sort that out later. Slightly hazy dark amber. Somewhat candyish, orangey aroma wit underlying malts hinting at caramel and chocolate. Sweet, buttery texture with delicate hints of mace and cinnamon. There’s a fair bit of caramelly malt.

(Draught) Sampled on November 23rd, 2006 at the brewpub. She’s back! A frothy head and a deep orange body. Nose of caramel and little else; yet the flavour is wildly complex: vanilla, allspice, pumpkin and an old rotten apple. An interesting mix with good complexity.

This one was a tough one. It had such a mixture of flavors it was hard to isolate them. Cloudy brown color with off white head. Lightly spiced citrus and carmel nose. Flavor initially was citrus (lime) and changed to spice (cinnamon) with a hint of raisins. Nothing but cranberries and cinnamon? hmmm

O, ktos to wbil w RB :) to historycznie, bo iles razy bylem gosciem Somy - wbije ocenke... pamietam tyle, ze bylo niezle, na tyle, ze wolalem isc tam na piwo niz do irish pubu :) i bylo mocno drozdzowe sensu stricte :) kurde, wzruszylem sie normalnie, to bylo sto lat temu :) pszeniczne bylo jeszcze lepsiejsze... tzn we wspomnieniach wyidealizowanych ;)
Ciemnozłote, trwała piana. Zapachu niewiele, głównie słodki imbir, a la piwo Gingers, tylko mocniejszy. W smaku męcząca, imbirowa goryczka, nic nie kontruje tego imbiru, piwo męczy. Brać maks. 0.3.
0.15 draft @ CK Browar Clear, gold with a small white head. Aroma of ginger. Taste of ginger. Insanely sweet, bad.
light sweet ginger aroma,brown, hazy, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light harmonic ginger finish.
Don’t like ginger in my beer. Light brown coloured and unclear. Has a white head, medium duration. Perfumed, ginger aroma. Sweet.
On tap. Pours a dark amber color with a small white head. Has a fruity spicy ginger aroma. Sweet fruity ginger flavor.
Tap. Hazy dark amber color. Small size, yellow head, stays. No aroma at all. Sweet, caramel, grainy, dusty taste. Sweet body. Dusty grains in aftertaste. Where is ginger?
Tap (C.K.Browar, Krakow) So, where’s the ginger? Simple sweet malts in aroma. light caramelly toffee in the taste. Husky finish. Simple sweetish smooth body. Kinda OK, best so far.
Treściwe piwo o delikatnym ale wyczuwalnym posmaku goryczki pochodzącej od imbiru.

The head is ok, the body brown, it smells a bit spicy, darkmalty, full bodied, less hoppy. The taste is spicy, maltaromatic, darkmalty, ginger, balanced. The ginger taste is there but it is not to intensive, well balanced. Great! 11/11/11/12/-/11

Draught at the brewpub. Bready and gingery aroma though not like gingerbread. light toasted, yeasty and nutty. An unpleasant chlorine medicinal note drags the aroma down. Rather light body, light sweet taste, the bitterness is a tad too strong for this kind of flavour. Astringent, medicinal, chlorine finish. Not a pleasant beer.
Ocena z pamięci w celu uzupełnienia profilu. Degustacja przed założeniem konta na RateBeer.
Bursztynowe piwo o ładnej, gęstej pianie. W smaku niezbyt wyraziste, raczej słodowe z niewielką goryczką pasującą do stylu.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a mostly clear copper colored body with an inch thick, dense and creamy, off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is a good amount of DMS up front with a light toasty caramel sweetness, some grassy hops, and a light fruitiness. Flavor is better. A lightly toasted caramel sweetness with touches of bread, a balanced grassy hopping, a few fruit notes, and just a slight DMS hint. Finishes clean and lightly bitter before leaving a medium length aftertaste. Medium body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, a decent marzen. A bit too much DMS on the nose, but the flavor was better. Easy drinking and balanced. Not bad.
A little sweet, it is a a fest anyway, but it was very dark, almost like a Vienna.
Pajiza nebulosa de escasa espuma. Aroma muy cereal que recuerda palomitas. En boca muy ligera, con apenas gas. Sabor ligeramente citrico de toques especiados.
Golden colour, cloudy, small head. Aroma is intensive white bread and straw, some llmon. Light bitterness. Lively carbonation. Good.
Ocena z pamięci w celu uzupełnienia profilu. Degustacja przed założeniem konta na RateBeer.
On tap at source. Pours hazy weak golden with a tiny white head. Sweet aroma and taste, grainy malts, reminds me of wort, no bitterness detected at all.
On tap @ C.K. Browar, Kraków. Milky yellow with a thin white head. Grainy aroma with some citrus. Sweet taste with some buttery notes. Quite unclean for a pilsener.
Decent enough for what it is. Not very crisp hops or anything. More of a buttery vibe here. Slightly cloying. Pours golden with ok head. Tap at brewpub.

On tap at C.K. Browar, pours a hazy blonde with a small white head. Nose brings out bready malts, with straw and a touch of grass. Flavour is clean, with grassy hops, biscuity malt and straw. Clean and punchy. Nothing special, but it’s alright.

Degustacja 100 ml w krakowskim CK Browar. Flagowe piwo okrętu CK. Mocno, mocno pijalne, niewielka goryczka; jak sugeruje nazwa - jest dość jasne, ale w sumie nie takie klarowne, chyba było nieodfiltrowywane; niskie wysycenie. Świeżutkie i bardzo dobre.

Zmętnione, zlore, piana się trzyma. Zapach chmielowy, świeży, nieco surowy, w stronę pilsa niemieckiego. Ciekawa, rześka, niezalegająca goryczka. Słodowość poprawna, ciała jest dość. Lekko kwaskowy finisz. Jak na restauracyjny to szacun.
0.15 draft @ CK Browar Clear, gold, small, white. Simple, pale malts. Ultra sweet like all the other CK brews.
10-09-19 // on tap at the brewpub. Solid. Unfiltered golden. White head. Belgian wit light, but not to spicy fruity.
On tap at Spiz. Hazy yellow with a medium white head. Aroma of wheat, some citrus and banana. The same in the taste, also mild esters. Relaxed and easy to drink. An ok one.

On tap at Minibrowar Spiz, pours a hazy blonde with a medium white head. Aroma brings out fresh wheat, with a hint of banana and clove. Flavour is clean, with wheat, light esters and biscuity malt. Clean and drinkable. Forgettable but not bad.
From tap. Pours hazy yellow. Small white head. Aroma is estery and bubblegum. Dry, estery, slight citrusy. Herbal estery and dry far finish.

Sampled @ Festival Dobrego Piwa Wroclaw 2017. Sehr trübes hell goldgelbes Bier mit einer geringen weißen Schaumkrone. Geruch ist mild bananig, phenolisch hefig. Geschmack ist mild süß bananig, hefig phenolisch, naja.
Hefiger, wässrig herber Beginn. Trocken bananig, langweilig kräutrig. Okay. 10/8/7/8//8

Keg in the square in Wroclaw. Just warm enough to still sit outside in Autumn. A really beautiful spot. The pub is very nice inside too. Aimed at tourists but some times you’ve got to suck it up. The beer is pale cloudy Yellow with a White head. hefe notes. Banana & Clove etc. A bit on the sweet side. Pretty forgettable if it weren’t for the unforgettable surroundings.
Yellow, hazy beer with little head. Aroma of bread, yeasts and little sourness. Finish with small sourness.

Spiż Pszeniczne Draught at the Spiż Minibrowar, Wrocław, Poland. Hazy yellow color with a mid-size foamy white head. Rubber, wheat and citrus in the aroma. The flavor is yeast, wheat and citrus. Very thin. Goes down with the food but otherwise very plain Hefeweizen. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Schwach ausgeprägtes hefiges Aroma. Säuerlicher, nicht zu intensiver, dennoch durchaus angenehmer Geschmack. Leicht wässrig.
On tap at Minibrowar Spiz, pours a hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out cereal malts and bready notes. Flavour is dry, with cereal malts and straw. Dry and drinkable. Meh.
From tap. Pours hazy dark orange with a small white head. Aroma is grainy and slight toasted malty. Sweet, slight malty and caramelish. Toasted. Sweet malty finish.

Sampled @ Festival Dobrego Piwa Wroclaw 2017. Trübes dunkel orange goldenes Bier mit einer geringen weißen Schaumkrone. Geruch ist süß getreidig malzig, Müsli, Karamell. Geschmack ist süß getreidig malzig, pappig, naja.
Süßlich herber Beginn, etwas Honig. Moderat würzig, dumpf getreidig. Okay. 8/7/7/7//7
Yellow hazy beer with small head with small bubbles. Sourness in the aroma. Sunflowers seeds, malt in taste. Sourness in finish.
Tap @ the brewpub. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sweet malt, alcohol, hops and little grass. Light bitter finish from the alcohol.
Tap @ Spiz. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish with some alcohol. 290715
Keg 0.5 l, Spi?, Wroc?aw, Poland. Bursztynowe, m?tnawe piwo z puszyst? pian? i przyjemnym, s?odowym aromatem. W smaku pe?ne, s?odowe z ?agodn? goryczk? i posmakiem alkoholu na finiszu.
Color is ambar and hazy. Initial head is nice and white nut rappidly turns into a small lace. Carbonation is high and lively. Aroma is yeast, malt and hops. Aftertaste is dry and spicy...
Sample. Dark gold with fluffy head. Pretty neutral on the aroma. Grassy taste that ends bitter. Just alright.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at tbonz. Quite impressive for the style. Not much in lace or head but clear gold. Nose is grassy and fresh. Taste has a nice malt backbone yes light but not corn or cheap adjunct. Finishes clean. No off tastes. Refreshing.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Slightly hazy straw colour. Not much aroma...I really tried. Slight bready malt. Clean, decent, but yeah, it is that type of beer.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught @ Charleston location. Clear golden, no head or lacing. Sweet grain aroma is mild with distinct lagering yeast. Finishes watery but clean. Sweet granular feel but almost painfully thin.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Date: 12/17/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy yellow, wispy white head, Aroma: light sweet malt aroma with light floral hops, Flavor: flavor has a nice light bitterness well balanced with only a hint of sweetness, very well done for the style Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught. Man, I was already pumped up to sample this fine beer, but the description on the menu stoked my fires even more. Pours just like stale urine with some bubbles coming up and no discernable head. I was hoping for a tru pale lager, y’know, one that tastes as much like carbonated water as possible. Unfortunately, there is some a presence of this stuff, hops, I think. The good news is that the hops mostly resemble newspaper in smell and taste, and nothing else is really present except a sacchrine-like sweetness in the flavor. Bottom line: this beer is much too dark and heavy, but it’s still delicious. [September 3, 2010] Pint at the T-Bonz. . . ordered accidentally due to my poor observation skills. A beer that I originally thought was so lackluster that I could only mock it in a sarcastic review turned out to be almost alright. While I will hopefully never drink this again, it did have discernable beer flavor of cereal, grain and veggies. It was fairly clean without a lot of off-putting notes. But please don’t drink light lager.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: on tap-pours with little fizzy to no head with yellow-gold color. Aroma is sweet grain. Taste is sweet grain, an OK light beer. OK carbonation.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught sample at the Mount Pleasant, SC location. Bubbly, clear pale gold with tiny remnants of fizzy foam....very minimal sweet corn -- applesauce aroma....sweet, cidery-soda character in the body, fairly clean at least, a touch sticky late....fizzy 7UP is what it’s closest to with a bit of dryness at the end making it shade more into tonic water territory...yeah, not much here.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught at Charleston, SC location. Clear golden color with no head or lace. Hint of sprucy hops in the aroma, but little else. Crisp and light up front with a little bit of sweetness and cereal grain malt. Pleasant grainy aftertaste that lingers.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: An extremely fizzy Bud-clone of a beer with light malt flavors and lots of refreshing wateriness. Good if you’re thirsty or don’t want to fill up.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: [September 3, 2010] Well here’s a beer that is worse than their light, by a fair margin. The pour is bright yellow with a cloudy body and a sudsy head. The aroma is not good from the get go. It’s soapy with some lemon zest and crackers. Quite astringent and soapy beer all around. It was tough getting through this one. No me gusta.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Tried this at the Myrtle Beach location. Not a bad wheat beer, light in color and taste. Decent enough.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: good body, tasty, served with lemon. Didn’t squeeze. American style I guess because I didn’t notice the banana/clove, clean looking.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: This beer is watery and a taste of lemon and thats all i have to say about that.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Date: 12/17/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear pale yellow, wispy white head, Aroma: light undescernable aroma, Flavor: light flavor with a fruity sweetness to go along with some raspy wheat character, Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *+/4

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Sampled at the Myrtle Beach Location at Barefoot Landing. Nothing special here. Had hints of some wheat with a sharp citrus kick. Very bland. Finished like a glass of lemon water that had carbonation.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy yellow with white head. The aroma is mild citrus and slight grass. The flavor is bland and grainy with stray citrus notes. Very typical wheat beer, nothing outstanding.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Tap. Lt lemon wheat aroma. Hazy golden yellow with small head. Lemon and wheat malt flavor. An average American Wheat - nothing great, nothing bad.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: on tap-pours with no head and a gold color. Aroma is wheat. Taste is wheat. OK carbonation.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught sample at the Mount Pleasant, SC location. Clear gold, bubbly, no head at all -- pretty much not the way a wheat beer should look....buttered, creamed bananas in the nose, caramel, lemon-lime, bakery-sweet at first but with a hint of sour wheat gradually creeping in.....watery, terribly bland body, touch of dry stale wort...biscuity, doughy malts, low carbonation, syrupy, awful.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: [Sept 29, 2010] Pint at the brewpub in Charleston. Pours a very cloudy yellowish with a small head. Thank goodness it’s not stark red. The aroma is wheaty with a tasteful addition of raspberry. The flavor is of crackers, grain and a pretty decent raspberry thing going on. This is not supersweet, just about right for what it is. Of course what it is is still a raspberry wheat beer. . .

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: (Old BA rate - tap) Lightly hazy yellowish hue; poured with little to no head at all. Pretty muted, but with a touch of tart fruitiness and a bit yeasty. Fruity raspberriness; little bit dry and tart; sweeter and bready finish. Pretty thin, but not bad prickly carbonation to liven it up. Decent, but not great for me. Just a bit too much on the yeasty which masked the decent tartness of the brew

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: On draft in Barefoot location. So so appearance. Lots of raspberry, some wheat, American style. Nothing special.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Date: 12/17/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub pale yellow with a slight haze, wispy white head, sweet raspberry aroma, nice light raspberry flavor on a bland base, no exciting but also not overdone on the raspberry or sweetness making it a good example of this brewpub staple Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *+/4

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught. Pours hazy pale yellow with a small fizzy white head. The aroma is faintly grainy and a little bit fruity. The flavor is a very distinct artificial-seeming raspberry over a very earthy, grainy malt. It dries out slightly toward the finish and becomes a little bit chalky.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught sample at the Mount Pleasant, SC location. Faintly hazy, yellow (no pink in this one surprisingly), no head, bubbly-fizzy.....light sweet raspberry cookie-vanilla wafer aroma with little to no hints of sour wheat, or any malt or hop character for that matter....very bland and sour body, overattenuated and extremely thin, dry and mineralic, with a weird aloe/soapy tang at the finish. No sir, I won’t have another.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Golden-amber colour. Caramelly, slightly earthy aroma. Fairly thin. Lightly metallic caramel character. Off-dry finish. Kind of bland.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Deep cherry wood color with thick off-white head and lacing. Mild, dark bread aroma. Slick, soft mouthfeel with low carbonation. Some tannic character, maybe a touch of cinnamon but otherwise not so spicy. Nice lingering hop finish. Thin but decent.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Date: 12/17/2006 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub hazy amber, wispy beige head, sweet caramel biscuit and floral hop aroma, nice sweet caramel malt flavor, well balanced, nice lingering sweetness but not too sweet, almost a spicy note from the hops Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **/4

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught at the Charleston location. Pours hazy burnt orange witha small whitish head. The aroma is mild caramel, some hay. The flavor is very earthy. Some crackery malt, dirty esters, and spicy hops. Single minded and very discordant, but somehow it comes across as tasty to me.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught. Pours slightly hazy light amber with minimal head. The aroma, much like their other offerings, was rather weak though I could detect caramel, butter, and paper. The flavor is slightly astringent with the faintest of spices, a bit of nutmeg perhaps. There is a flat earthiness which is upfront, but not much else to balance. I thought it was just okay.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Tap at Charleston. Sweet malt aroma with hints of orange and apple. Clear amber color with small head. Sweet malt flavor with hint of orange and light hops finish. A very good session beer - very quaffable.

column2: Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, United States
column5: Draught at Charleston, SC location. Clear brown color with no head or lace. Spicy nose and flavor, nutmeg I guess. Kind of nutty as well. A bit over-carbonated. Ehh.
Draught at the Keg: transparent light gold. Nice cascade hop aroma and a of sweet honey. Smooth palate and a good N. Brewer flavour. A light sugary caramel rounds out a pretty good brew.

I have a fond memory of visiting the Isadore Street Brewing Co., which is what the Keg was under previous ownership. It was therefore with great anticipation that I visited the Keg recently. When I sat down at the bar, the first thing I noticed was this Alaskan Pale Ale. Immediately I was excited thinking that this was one of those places that, in addition to brewing their own beer, also served several craft brews made by other brewers (e.g., Alaskan Brewing Co., etc.) Alas, I was wrong; it was just the Keg's Pale Ale, for some reason named after the state of Alaska. Anyway, the aroma was sweet and had some characteristics that reminded me of a x-mas beer (cinnamon, nutmeg, holly, etc.) I also picked up some grape jelly notes. There was no visible carbonation in the beer, which was the case in all of their beers. Amber body, white head and good lace. Nice initial mouthfeel, but no real bite in the finish. Malty, with a lack of balance.

Draught at the Keg: burnt/charred bronze colour with an extremely light milk chocolate aroma. Thin, watery palate that has a bit of cocoa and a hint of hops in the finish, though this one left quite a bit to be desired.

Bourbon cask aroma with some off notes. No head except a thin off-white ring around the edge of the glass. Dark reddish black in color. Tastes of molasses. Is flat and thin without any zing or punch. Easy drinking; just not all that enjoyable. Almost tastes non-alcoholic. Not bad, especially around mid-glass, although the recipe for this brew needs some tinkering. Still probably their second best brew after the Night Train IPA.

Clear medium gold body and little foam, rotting cabbage on the nose. Flavour is 7-up with rotten hop hints in the background. You know, after a few hundred "pilsner" beers brewed around the world I realize how hard it is to do one well - this thing is a mess, most won't notice, but it sure does make me appreciate the good ones.
Can. Pale yellow, aroma of creamed corn, flavour of sweet grain, a touch of corn, very watery.

For a budget beer it’s pretty good. It had a head made to dissolve into nothingness. No lace. It actually comes with some flavour at a budget price. It has topside malt sweetness mixed with some lingering bitterness. It has hop and only a light wateriness, better than most budget offerings. I have had what this brewer considers top flight and this will do nicely to put me over the top, after the expensive beer tastings are over.

A couple of 4oz samples at VCBW 2012 pours a pale straw color with a finger of white head that leaves some spotty lacing. Aroma is grass and cereal grains. Taste is a grassy hop bitterness with a grainy malty sweetness and a nice clean finish. Light in body with a decent amount of carbonation providing a nice sensation on the palate. After reading some of the reviews here I think they are confusing this with Great Western’s Brewhouse Pilsner which is just a terrible beer. This is not that beer, it is much better with a fuller flavor and cleaner finish. I do not believe this beer is sold in a can, so if you had a can it is definitely the Great Western version.

Actually a very refreshing beer for how cheap it is ($1 a can). My baseball team drinks it after games and we never complain about it.... but it must be cold. It rivals PC Light as my favorite cheap beer which I use to clear out pesky garden slugs (LOL).

Pours golden yellow, nice carbonation, tall thick head. Malty skunky aroma. Flavour is light not much body a lot of filler in this beer. This was a great beer when it was $1 per can. but now that it’s $16/per 12 pack it has kind of lost its appeal.

35.5 cl can, Winnipeg, MB, Canada. Pale golden colour, actually some pilsner like aroma, grains and grass. Probably tasted too warm, slightly seet, could be moer crisp, with a thicker mouthfeel than I would have liked. Better than I thought though.

Light, golden a white head. An overall soft feel. Funny almost sour smell that is rather faint. I liked it. I find it to be a quite toned down compared to most pils. Smooth, but almost flat. Overall I like it, especially the taste.

Every beer tastes best when you shotgun it. But for its price i enjoyed it. Its pretty average pils for me, and just good to get drunk with. Cans are pretty goofy though, You wont really look cool at a party with this.
From teh can. It was free. It was cold. And I was thirsty. Another corny-tasting beer for people who just want to get drunk for cheap.

On tap at Whistler, pours a dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma brings out bready malt and caramel. Flavour is along the same lines, with a dry bready caramel malt backbone. Thick palate but not overly complex. Not bad.

Draught at the brewpub; 12oz Cloudy red-amber color with small creamy head. The aroma is too light, there is some malt, nuts, milk chocolate. Round mouthfeel, a bit less body than expected, some malt and caramel flavor, moderately sweet, lightly nutty in the final, ordinary bitterness. A good beer, but simple, not trying to achieve anything special.

Just as every dog has his day, every brewpub brews at least one beer of note (NB: this general rule seemingly does not apply to the Rock Bottom Brewery). But I digress. This scotch ale is truly a standout. A man among boys. Weighing in at 6.7%, it packs a mighty wallop and delivers taste by the truckload. A cornucopia of flavors, I was truly impressed with its combo of malt and yet mildness. A real winner with alcohol better hidden than most.

12oz bottle: Pours a clear medium orange color with minimal alabaster bubbles, mostly around edges of glass. Aroma is of light malts, grass and bizarre spice. Crisp and light bodied with ample carbonation. Astringent/metallic ending.
The beer pours amber with nice notes of allspice and cardomon. These flavors work well with the malt and light hops on the palate and finish in a balanced manner.

12 oz bottle via trade with hopdog, who probably got it from jjpm74, who I traded with before hopdog. Anyway, this beer was very decent with breakfast this morning. Eggs and toast, by the way. I digress however. The pour was glassy amber with almost no head. Aroma was of winter spices such as nutmeg and cinnamon- almost pumpkin ale spiced. Taste was caramel and those same spices. Not a bad beer at all.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with jjpm74 (thanks!). Poured a medium and slightly hazy orange color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, lightly floral and very lightly spicy. Tastes of caramel with a light spicy finish. Thinner body.
Pours amber with a white head. Smells rosey with some caramel qualities. Tastes a little sweet with some tangy notes.

Poured a nice amber with a white frothy head. I found it a little on the sweet side, I don’t know. The first five bottles of the six pack I enjoyed a lot. But when I poured the sixth (not on a row, mind you!) for rating, I found it not as good as I remembered from earlier in the week. A little malty sweet, kind of nutty.

2004 bottle. Dosent pour a pale color. Not at all. Very robust orange-copper color with a small white, lasting head. Light lacing as well. Aroma is a bit off-putting; rusty yeast, some bits of dirty earthy wet grass, lightly sharp notes of grains. Strong scent of dry dog food. As you dive right in, it is certainly a strange experience. At first it tastes like spicy English yeast, but that quickly fades in to a spicy lager bite, mixed with notes of copper, tin and iron. Earthy, graininess, and a lightly dull meat-like quality. A hint of bittersweet nuttiness. Some light hop notes on the finish. Watery mouthfeel, medium-light body. Some breadiness on the end. Not altogether filtered tasting; it may not be the most spectacular tasting yeast in the world, but at least it has a good apparency. Very interesting experiment here. I will agree it shares some common flavors with SA Boston Lager.
Copper in color with a small white head.Malty,spicey, with a somewhat sweet/sourness.Finishes dry with a malt tang.
Clear orange with a small white head. Orange spicy aroma, slightly sweet ending. Astringent taste.

Has a nice amber color with light carbonation and a light malt smell. Taste is lightly malted and almost a bit sunked and finishes with a moderate bitterness. Overall this wasn't the better 'winter' type beers that I have had.
red / pink color with a white head. cherry smell is quiet strong as is the taste. not too sweet. a nice summer beer. Have to admit that I have not tatses a kriek often

330ml bottle drunk at home on a perfect July evening. Pours opaque ruby pink with not a lot of head, some lacing but no visible rising carbonation. On the nose, sour cherry and hints of mirabelle plum. In the mouth, medium carbonation, sour from the first sip and throughout but not excessively so, minimal apparent sweetness but there is plenty in the aftertaste, sour cherry flavour, thin but not watery before a dry finish, no real bitterness, just sour. A fairly one-dimensional fruit beer that only a lambic lover could love.
Although Floris loves to cut corners, this version of a kriek is not the worst ever. Light sour cherry notes.

Bottle from Darts Farm near Exeter. Pours clear deep pink with a light pink head. Aroma is full of sweet cherry plus some marzipan. Taste is more sweet cherry & marzipan ,barely balanced by some acidity & a little oak. Lightish bodied with decent carbonation. The finish is sweet with more cherry with some balancing tartness. Ok but not great!
Fles thuis geprobeerd. Het is een roodkleurig bier met een dun rose schuim. De geur is voornamelijk kersen. De smaak is zoet en kersen achtig, beetje syroop achtig.
A very nice cherry juice! I don´t know how a good Kriek should taste, but I was imagining that it would still taste somewhat like beer. This one didn´t.
Halványpiros szín, kevés hab. Meggyes, cukros illat. Könnyed test. Fanyar meggyes íz. Üdítő.
Drank on tap at Delirium Tremens bar in Brussels. Bright aroma. Pours red to pink. Very sweet, powerful cherry taste. Too much so for my taste.

0,33l bottle. Hazy ruby colour with slowly shrinking fluffy pink head. Aroma: Lots of cherry/bubblegum with hint of almonds. Taste: Quite sweet fruity start with a decent sour mouthfeel. Has an oily texture. Light body with medium carbonation. Medium lasting tarty/sweet a bit acidic finish. Not bad, the lambic one is better.

(Bottle) Pours hazy dark pink red with short lived head. Pleasant aroma - cherries, candy hints of chocolate. Smooth, light body with pleasant carbonation. Intense cherry flavour, underpinned by citrus tartness and candy. Very pleasant, but is it really a beer?

Pours a deep brown color with a roasted malt aroma. Taste is slightly sweet with a burnt rolled oats flavor. The sweetness is truly evident at first sip then dissipates as you swallow. A dry, roasted malt aftertaste that finished the beer quite well.

Tap. Pours dark black, medium creamy beige head, great lacing. Aroma is light, roasty, hints of smoke, lactose, hints of burnt rubber, chocolate. Docks is medium sweet, light plus bitter, roasty and rich. Fullish body, creamy mouthfeel. Soft and velvety.
On draft at the brewpub. Pours a murky cola with a tan head. Aroma of toasted oats. Flavors of licorice and leather. Bitter roast finish.

Draft to taster at brew pub pour opaque dark brown with moderate tan head. Nose roasted malt and dark chocolate. Taste brief green fruit flavor followed by light roast and mineral powdered chocolate. Smooth mouth feel from the oats and nitro.

4 oz pour on draft at District ChopHouse. Black with light tan head. Nice lacing. Aromas of cinnamon, spices, chocolate. Tastes of dark chocolate, light caramel and vanilla, roasty notes, light malt. Medium-full body with a dry finish. Great oatmeal stout, my favorite of the flight.
On tap at the brewpub. Near black body with a decent head. Medium-full body and light soft carbonation which, with the smoothness from the oats, makes this feel like a cask ale.
Farbe sehr dunkel. Geruch sehr Richtung Kaffee und röst. Wenig karbonisiert. Rund, kaum bitter.
Geruch sehr kräftig, schokoladig, lecker. Geschmack bleibt dann weit hinter den Erwartungen, wässrig, nichtssagend.
Pours black , small white head . Smell is oats, bit sweet . Some coffee , dark malts . Very aromatic . Slightly bitter , but not much .

What I expect to be among their better beers but we’ll see. Light sweet breakfast oat aroma and some roast. Pours black with good head and lacing. Finishes with light sweetness and mostly bitter, consistent with style. Tap at brewpub.

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Bottle from Champion of the Thames, Cambridge. Very cloudy brownish gold. Lots of sediment in the bottom of the bottle. Strong apple smell, with a hint of candy sugar sweetness. Taste is ambrosially sweet, with just enough tang to keep the balance. Shorter finish than I expected. Harsh carbonation, giving it an mouthfeel, like fizzy candy. Very refreshing and nicely put together.

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Бутылка 1 литр. Не понял в чём отличие от обычного сухого. Цвет более мутноватый. Вкус как будто посвежее. Понравился больше всего.

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Super cydr. Pachnie spalinami samochodowymi, lekko metne i mgliste, ciemno pomaranczowa barwa wchodzaca w odcienie brazu. W smaku jablka podwedzane i pieczone w popiole lub na grilu. W smaku przypominalo nawet mi niektore oude gueuze. Za to wlasnie uwielbiam bretonskie cydry. Naturalny i wedzony posmak. Koncowka wytrawna, bardzo malo slodkosci pochodzacej od jablek

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Bottle @ Gunmakers, Clerkenwell, London. Very hazy golden-orange with a fair sweetness to its apple and a fair nose. It’s s little dry in its texture

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: bottle lieve ambrato torbido succo di mela matura filo ossidato non molto secco tannico leggero

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Bottle at Quo Vadis. It pours cloudy deep orange with a thick white head. The nose is earthy, musty, apple skin, lemon peel, apple pie and a touch of farmyard. The taste is crisp, soft sweetness, mellow apple, light earth, touch of tannins, wood, apple pie and poached pear with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate, effervescent carbonation. Very well balanced and very drinkable stuff.

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Aroma: intense apple, some wood. Appearance: clear gold, small, white head. Taste: light sweet. Plate: apples continue, light alcohol, turning lightly dry in the finish. Overall: very nice Cider, intense apple in aroma. Pint at Ten Bells, Spitalfields.

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Tap at olutexpo. Clear deep golden color, white head. Aroma sweet, earth, stables, apples, sour. Taste is sweet and sour apples, stables, earth.

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: 330ml bottle from Drinkswell, Ripon. Hazy yellow gold colour, fizzy white foam head that dissipates to a thin layer and aroma of fruity apple, woody, earthy, light barnyard. Taste is tart juicy apple, apple skins, wood, tannins, light barnyard. Light to medium bodied, spritzy carbonation, dry tannic finish. Quite drinkable.

column4: Ets Guillet Frères SA - Cidrerie Kerisac (Eclor-Agrial)
column5: Bottle poured into tumbler. Very cloudy brassy colour, no head. Musty, funky aromas, quite strong. Unripe apples. Very tart taste, dry finish. Not really to my taste, but apparently this is desirable in a Breton cider? Kinda like the way I don’t get lambics... yet.

(Bottle 33 cl) Damn, it doesn’t happen often, but this beer is utterly dead - well, almost dead. Deep, dark brown and very, very flat almost without any head at all. Fortunately there’s still a lot of flavour left. Roasted malt, dried fruit and some spices - coriander is there but also some "darker" more christmasy stuff. Probably would’ve been an excellent beer had it been fresh. 290998

BBD: 12/2003 - Hah! It’s a real one, not some blasted Huyghe wannabe Fully dark brown beer, with small, dirty brown, creamy head, reasonably stable. Very malty & chocolatety nose - though more like some chocolate Ersatz. Sweet coffee. Bit rubbery aroma - probably Michael’s "fruity old gym shoe". Dusty indeed. Taste is chocolate malt, and a ton of liquorice, but not its sweetness, leaning towards drop. Finishes sweeter, and yet drier. Apparent body is misleading, adjunct-like; behind it rather thin-watery, which is rather unsettling for a 9%ABV beer. Somehow, this beer is thinnish without age playing a role. It doesn’t taste as if it’s tired, it tastes as if it was born tired.

Dark amber coloured beer with a light brown small creamy head. Sweet fruity old gym shoe aroma. Now tasting; A slight sweet start followed by a malty ,medicinal gym shoe taste. A bit dry, chalky finish.
Very nice, was my first impression, and this stayed with me, a very exciting and unexpected flavor followed by an even more unexpected palate, good one.

Moderate organic lager from an Irish "craft brwer". Poured a cloudy yellow colour with a fleeting 1cm head. Fresh hay in the nose and some zesty hop characters. Spoiled by some faint uric notes. Medium-bodied - firmer than you might expect for a lager. Undermined by some sour notes but it’s possible the sample was past its best (two weeks after Best Before). Quenching but unremarkable. (Bottle)
Bottled. Clear golden ale. Larger malt aroma. Low carbonation. Moderate bitterness. Just.
This is an excellent lager in my point of view. Very tastful compared to other similar beers - and organic! Is for sale at Superquinn’s
Bottle. Sweet and malty with a metallic hop finish. Main body is fine - if a little sticky - but the finish is poor.

Dark golden color, rapidly diminishing head. Fruit and honey aroma. Fullmouth fruity and sweet malty flavours. in company with some aroma hops. Little dry finish. Sweet and fruity aftertaste. Fresh, soft and creamy impression. Very nice lager.
Cask. Pours cloudy brown. Creamy tan head. Nose and taste of caramel, lightly toasted dates and hops.
on tap-pours an offwhite head with copper color. Aroma is fruit, sweet medium malt-caramel. Taste is spice hop bite, medium fruit, medium malt-caramel. Good effervescence.
Great doppelbock. I had this on tap at the brewery. It has strong chocolate notes with light caramel background.

Clear mahogany body with a beige head. Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate, cherry, caramel. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, cherry, light chocolate. Smooth medium-full body. Alcohol is well hidden.

The version I sampled was an 8.0% ABV version that they served in a 12 oz glass. Claimed that they could not serve it in a pint glass because of the higher ABV. Whatever. Thin head with good carbonation. Bit surprised at the decent carbonation. Light roasted malt aroma with a hint of spices. Color is a very dark brownish red. Flavor is quite smooth and clean with more malts and a decent alcohol warming which was nice because it was about 55 degrees inside the building. Slightly sweet (caramel) with a pretty clean finish. A decent dopplebock.

Bursting with malty goodness. Thick rocky white head, reddish brown in color and nearly opaque. Aroma shows chocolate, earthy hops, and butterscotch.. Not overly sweet for a Doppelbock. High warming quality in the swallow. Starts of with light earthy hops, malt sweetness builds, then ends on a sweet grassy note. The spiciness of the beer does not hit until mid glass. Best served in a snifter.

Yeah aint it just typical that Sloth/slob gave me this dusty old can from his basement silo of a beer warehouse and said to me..."Yeah well you didn’t drink it when you were here last time" (ten years prior). So here it goes. Can cracks open with a distinct Pfttt! The best buy date is August 7, 1997. So at least the can and carbonation were successful. Nose of sweet lollipop/ cotton candy. Pours a semi glowing golden in the glass. It would be perfect if not for the large grey chunks of whoknowswhat floating about in patrol boat like precision. The finger taste revealed a sweet sugary smelling vinegaresque type of undrinkable liquid. A testament to canning.

Enormous thanks to Sloth who sent me this rare gem simply because it was on my wants list. What a freakin’ great guy. Pours a nice golden color with a very small head that pretty well goes away after a minute. The aroma is malty, sweet, tinny, and cidery. Some mild alcohol is present but it seems natural in the mix. The flavor is doughy and sweet. The beer has a distinct cidery character, it’s lightly spicy, relatively clean, and totally weird. There’s no doubt I’m giving it points for originality here, I’ve never tasted a pale lager like this one, nothing is even close. What a strange strange beer.

Cheers to slob for sending this fine ancient can of old school swill my way. I love it! Cloudy dull beige colour. Smells like an aged macrobrew, mixing overly heavy (slightly sherryish) bread notes with medicinal phenols and rotting pork. The taste, surprisingly, isn’t bad. There’s some light oxidized notes and vague cough syrup phenols but mainly just clean pale malts, the faintest hop. It’s almost gained a certain freshness, a second wind if you will. Seriously, this is actually drinkable.

I found this beer at a local liquor store not long ago. Since I am from Maryland I thought it would be something neat to try. I bought a six pack and it was about $2.00. The can is very interesting. It has a list of foods that go well with this beer. And the can also has a map of Maryland on it, but the map is wrong. The map also includes part of Virginia. This should have warned me not to buy it. But it's said Maryland's Best on the can. I had to try it. Eventhough it's brewed in Milwaukee. When I got home I poured one in a glass. It was very light and had almost no head. It smelled like chemicals, and it tasted like it was made from an old bale of hay. It was the worst beer I ever had. I managed to suck the one beer down but it was hard. I gave the other five away to this Belgian guy that I know. He loved them. But he also thinks Budweiser is wonderful.
Mild nutty caramel nose with a smattering of hops thrown in for the ride. Overall lacking.
NO mention of "Bobby Magee" on the menu, this one had a nice and simple malt profile that was caramelly and nutty. Some slight grassy hops was present at the end.

Zigs seems to have undergone a recent revolution. If you look at their old beer menu, they were crazy, kaleidoscopic, out of control with style ideas. Now they are more strait laced, cleaner, simpler, more attractive to the off-the-freeway-can-I-just-get-a-beer crowd. This beer is deadly clear, exceptionally clear, and tastes like that too - rather uninteresting and monochromatic, based on hop action. It has more significant head retention than it's brethern Zig brews, but is basically lackluster. I'd guess the recipe has been simplified from the award winning ways, like the menu and the marketing approach at this place.

Since this was the first beer on my sampler I got a pretty good taste of it. My first thought - This is an ESB? Not nearly enough malts and body - and too much alcohol. I think Zig's need to narrow their focus and work on creating two or three decent brews before they make offensive imitations of every well-known European style they can think of.

I was all hyped up for this...my first time at Zig's (formerly Jackson Brewing Co), as this beer won a World Beer Cup award for the Strong Bitter category in 2002. I can tell you that there are only three possible reasons why my experience was the way it was: either the beer was stored/served improperly, was intentionally made this way, or the brewer doesn't know a lot about ESBs. There's a bit of ESB malting, a fair hop level, but an underlying sweet flavor that had nothing to do with malt, hops, ESBs or anything else. This was like drinking an ESB served with the remanants of a poorly made Belgian Dubbel. Some bitterness. Hop variety not obviously English or West Coast. Thin. Noticeable ABV even at 4.8%. No beer menu. Hmmm, I was wondering how my Zig's experience was gonna turn out at this point.
Hip-hop-da-hibby-hop. Really hopped nose. Some perfume and floral arrangments, but pretty much dominanted by the bitter hops. Fizzy with medium finish.

Nice and hoppy! The citrus and grassy hops mix well to make it perfumy and a bit oily at first sip. Some graininess is drowned out by some caramel malts. Finish is bitter, leaving a nice hoppy aftertaste.

Cask Conditioned. Cloudy, glowing orange. Very hoppy and has some body...lots of floaties. The malt depth is lacking....yet the beer still maintains heft...weird (hop oil overload...I dunno). Orange juice sweetness...in the aroma and the flavor, a little flowers...quite artificial tasting and looking. Marginally better than the previous beer I had there.

This is a pretty decent Imperial stout giving off a nice chocolate coffee aroma. Thick and chewy, the roasty malts are the most dominant feature, but hints of smoke, nuts, coffee and especially chocolate at the finish make it a very pleasurable experience.

Compared to their other selections, this is probably the best showing. Well hopped and malt balanced, and the nose has a port/alochol sweet aroma. Roasted and smoked flavors peak through at times. Could be thickened up a bit.

You have to drink this from a bottle - they won't serve it to you on tap. This phenomenon happens a lot - either the microbrerwery makes you buy tiny glasses of the good stuff, or won't let you drink it on premise at all. What's up with that? Anyway, when you fight through the shrink rap and swing top, you get a very nice imperial. I mean that in the way a young goddess would tell me - you're very "nice" back in my frustrated dating days. All the pieces are in place - decent dark malts, a touch sweet and on the edge of deeper darkeness from the hops, but nothing rages against the dying of the light.

Bottled from draught in a 500 ml swing-top. Middle-weight consistency, nice dark brown fading to lighter head.Slight alcohol, nut, chocoalte malt and brown sugar nose. Flavors are initially sweet (sugar), nutty and some salt in the finish (noticeably less salty than Founders Imperial Stout). Closer to 60 deg and up salt and bacon bits show up a little brusquely. Hops are very well balanced. I was pleasantly surprised by this one.

Draft pour at the brewery during the RBSG bus tour. In my tasting glass copper orange with a white hesf. Nose of yeast and toffee. Medium plus body. Flavor is full of fruit and for sure banana. Finishes sweet and with the fruit. Good. I liked tins one.
Draft sample at the source. The beer is a hazed copper with a white head of foam. Banana and bread aroma. Sweet and earthy. Medium body and lower carbonation.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange with a thin white head. Soft orange, wheat, a nice yeast note, toast, a bit of musk. Medium bodied, soft yeast, musk, a bit of banana, toast, sweetness. Slow wheat, a bit of fruit. Soft fruit and wheat.
RBSG Boise @Sockeye Pours clear golden with a medium sized off-white head. Belgian malts, straw and herbal Good
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is yeast, spice, dark fruit. Medium body, spice, bready malt, pure sugar, nice sweetness, good.
Draft - Sweet bready notes. Cloudy gold with a small white head. Belgian fruity yeasts with a bready notes.

Draught at the brewery. Pours clear gold with a small, frothy white head, short retention. Aroma is moderate Candi sugar with cracker malt. Flavor is sweet Belgian Candi sugar, banana esters with cracker malt and a dry finish. Full body and medium carbonation.
Reconsidering this after a year, much better tripel than originally rated. Big and buttery, malt, savory spice, slick and smooth.

Growler courtesy of ditmier. Pours a hazy amber with a nice white head. Smells of dry pilsner malt, spice, some clove, coriander, ginger, perfumy. Tastes dry and crisp with some nice spicy elements, pepper, some citrus on the finish. Very enjoyable. Hopefully someday they’ll bottle this!

Draught @ Pie Hole Fairview - Poured opaque orange/brown with a small off white head...aroma is all bread with a bit of citrus, flavour follows, yeast, spice, great alcohol, malt and bitter balance...this was a killer suprise..too bad the pizza there tasted like shit...

From tap. Pours dark brown to black with a small brown head. Aroma is roasted malty and roasted malty. Dark malty, vanilla, sourish and slight wooden. Dry malty. Toasted and fruity. Wooden and sourish finish.
[Backlog] Schwarz, ohne Schaum, kein CO2. Geruch nach Whiskey, alkohlisch. Im Geschmack der absolute Vanielle-Bourbon-Einschlag, ohne besonders alkoholisch zu sein.

Tap. Pours deep clear black, large creamy tan head, dissipates slowly, nice lacing. Aroma is bourbon, cherry, lemon peel, hints of vinous and Brett things, vanilla. Flavors is fairly sweet, light bitter, a hint of tartness, lots of bourbon and weird notes, woody, lemon peel, weird. Just weird. Lightish body, creamy mouthfeel. Weird.
On cask at the brewpub. Pours black with a thin tan head. Roast aroma. Flavors of bourbon and smoky wood. Light bitter roast finish.

Draft to taster at brew pub pour opaque black with minimal to no head. Nose vanilla, Bourbon, molasses. Taste big vanilla, Bourbon, light roast. No carbonation, served via "traditional English beer engine" feels thin for style, but decent flavors.

Dark brown colour with low head. Medium intensive aroma of bourbon, vanilla, peat and some smoke notes. Very nice at nose. Taste is medium to heavy sweet, light bitter and light sour with short roasty fisnish. Unfortunately, taste is very thin and surprisingly watery. Soft carbonation. Overall, it’s a beer with very nice, full of bourbon note aroma, but taste is very thin. More body could help it.

On cask at the brewpub. Has an essentially black body with a decent head. Lots of bourbon flavor and aroma, suggesting the bourbon barrel was not ruined before brewery use. Smooth but overly light body.
Im Geruch gibt es eine wahnsinnige Vanille-Komponente, die sich auch im Geschmack wiederfindet. Dickflüssig, fast wie ein Cocktail. Kaum karbonisiert.
