(On Tap) Jet black with big white head. Smoky, peaty, oaky. Great palate - smooth but quite light at the same time. Great taste primarily oaky whisky over a sweetish dark roast malt. Very well balanced combination of flavours. This is bourbon, not stout, dominated. I like whisky so this works well for me. I guess if you are looking for a stout with whisky notes you may be disappointed.
Bourbon rules this one. Not much of a stout behind it. Pours black with OK head and lacing. Light sweet finish. Lots of booze and bourbon barrel aroma doesn’t help. Tap at brewpub.

Pours ruby-tinged dark amber with a small off-white head. Nose shows resinous pine and some juicy fruits alongside loads of caramel and bready malt. Same story with the flavours, lots of rich sweet malt with some resinous pine. Bitterness doesn’t quite manage to balance the heavy malt. Carbonation could be a fair bit higher, it might even cut through the sweetness then. Extremely malty for an IPA but still very enjoyable.

Tap. Hazy brownish orange pour with a fluffy, lasting white head that leaves lots of lacing. While the aroma has lots of fruity hops it also has a solid malt profile, with notes of passionfruit, orange, grapefruit, caramel and nuts. Flavour pretty much mirrors the aroma, striking a nice balance between the malty sweetness and the hoppy bitterness. Fairly slick mouthfeel with prickly carbonation and a long bitter finish. Overall a good IPA, nice but fairly run-of-the-mill.

2 separate experiences with this beer. First one was disappointing. Lacked flavour and bitterness. Second experience: awesome! big tropical fruit hop flavour. Bitterness was just great. Good looking beer. Thick head. Heaps of lacing. A really good IPA!!
this IPA is quite tasty. full of hops, but could be a bit more in your face with them. slightly grassy, with a strong citrus undertone
Draught (at the brewery bar). This one was full of hoppy goodness, while still have a great chewy malt base. The Galaxy hops come through big time.

330ml bottle. Deep orange russet colour with a well compacted head that looks good when poured into the glass. Inviting aromas of floral hops that allure you in with citrus notes breaking through. Slight tartness in the finish and a mellow bitterness in the mouth. Overall a good effort.
Good appearance but stops there. Rubbery, musky. Not aged but unpleasant. Disappointed
Tap. Hoppy and tasty. Aroma has grass, and fruit. Flavour produces nice bitterness, and good duration. Medium bodied in the palate. Copper in colour, with a long-lasting head.
This is not really hoppy enough to call itself an IPA. It’s a respectable drop, but don’t come looking for hops. Very malty. Disappointing.
Had this one during my holiday in Australia april/may 2009. Copper colored brew. Floral aroma. Aggressive bitter hops. Nice hoppy aftertaste. Nice.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: July 22nd, 2015 - English Ale's ESB should be an excellent beer given the brewery's name, and indeed fits the bill. A nice toasted bread crust color, it is true to what I expect from ESB. Crispy and biscuity on the nose, it is savory and delicious, with a great carbonated palate and a nice firmness.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: On tap at DeMarco’s Pizzeria in Seaside, CA. Aroma is mild earthy malts and hops. Taste is slightly earthy and bitter. Not much flavor here...same as my Chicken Parm.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: Tap. Pours clear golden amber, small beige head, dissipates fairly slowly, decent lacing. Aroma is pretty faint; fuggles and dishwater. Flavor is fairly nondescript as well. Light plus sweet malt base, hints of grassy hops, a bit of caramel. Oddly acidic. Light plus body, lingering bitterness. MEh

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: Clear Amber, light white head. Light toffee, slight pine. Very light bitterness, mostly a mild biscuity sweetness. Light body, watery. Mild carbonation, short finish. Okay.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: Golden color with small white head, only slightly darker than the pale beers of this brewery. Amber ale? Aroma is just a hint of caramel malt. Taste is slight caramel, quite a bitterness, okay. Would have called this an ESB... hm...

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: Tap at Cooper’s Pub on Cannery Row. Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma? Not much. Med body. Flavor is smooth malt, light fruit, minimal hop. However, it drinks surprisingly well. Finishes towards dry!, fruity, very lightly bitter.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: Tap in downtown Monterey. Clear golden color, small white head. Aroma of plain malt. Flavor is also fairly plain.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: On tap at trials pub in San Jose. I enjoyed this beer, a nice mild Scottish ale. Would drink again.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: Draft at Famous Dave’s, Salinas. Nose is caramel, lightly nutty, and toasted corn. Clear amber with a medium, heavy lacing beige head. Flavor is lightly bitter with some nutty caramel.

column1: English Ales Ramsays Fat Lip Ale
column5: Sampled on tap in Carmel. A decent Scotch ale. Heavily malted brew that is nice on the palate with a bit of an aftertaste.
Tap @ Lane Splitter in Berkeley. Like an IPA with vinous and bitter qualities. A copper color with a nice full body.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft at the source. Clear amber brown color, tan head. Aroma of toasted caramel. Taste is caramel and medicine.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Decent brown ale from one of our very favorite bars in chapel hill, roasted nuts for sure, easy to drink.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Quite nice, dark honey color, little head and lacing butlots of malt aromas, with coffee and sweet dried fruits in the tatstes, plenty of nuts with a clean finish.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Pours a deep, clear amber/light brown with a thin off-white head with good retention and lace. Aroma is toast, oats, maple, caramel. Taste is a bit sickly with a metallic/copper character, moldy toast, some astringent bitterness. Not very good.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Yikes! Not sure what was going on here, but this was a light/medium brown pour without much head. Didn’t taste much like a brown ale. Sweet, metallic, somewhat malty, but generally not so good. Earthy in a not good way.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Dark brown pour with medium tan head. Aroma of toasted malts and some caramel. Light sweetness and slight bitterness in the flavor. Looks and tastes like a brown ale, so a decent effort.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Dark brown pour with a creamy tan head and lace. Toasted malt aroma with a hint of caramel. Semi sweet with very light bitter. Creamy mouthfeel and decent carbonation. Very nice brown ale.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: on tap-pours a tan head and mahogany color. Aroma is medium malt, musty/earthy hops. Taste is grainy/medium malt-caramel/chocolate, musty/earthy hops, some yeast. The highlight of our stop here was getting to share some time with emacgee! Nice meeting you Ethan and good trades too.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper. Managed to coax a fizzy light tan head. The nose was sweet, malty, leafy, hop character, subdued and one dimensional. The flavor is toasty, nutty, crisp, mild neutral hop bitterness, sweet earthy malt, caramel. Mild bitterness with some residual sweetness on the mouthfeel.

column1: Top of the Hill Big Bertha Brown
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Had this on tap at the brewpub. Dark brown color with thin head. Aroma was faint brown sugar and roasted malt. Slightyl malty without being sweet. Hint of roasty flavor without much in the way of hop flavor or bitterness. Pretty much what you would expect from a brown ale. Decent but not sexy.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Roast, licorice, mild alcohol, and chocolate aroma. Black, lite tan head, and mild lacing. Mild whiskey, chocolate, and dark roast flavor. Watery, lite bitterness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at Top of the Hill. Nice appearance, dark brown in color with a large cascading nitro head. Roast and coffee characterize the aroma. Not much else to say - it’s a standard Irish stout more or less, nothing wrong with it but nothing outstanding. As for the flavor, well, I hate to use the mantra of the uninitiated, but honestly, "It’s like Guinness." Maybe a little more to it. Fairly dry and toasty with coffee and earthiness. Slightly dry on the mouthfeel with medium body and good nitro carbonation. A decent beer overall - the best I had at TotH.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap, tan creamy head off the nitro, aroma of burnt coffee, maybe a but if bacon, this really isn’t that good. Like stale, old Guinness.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: looks fine. mouthfeel is light and thin with an unpleasant slickness at the finish. nose is slightly acrid coffee and roasted malt with a strong note of, help us, bacon. the bacon doesn’t persist into the taste, thankfully, where you get more of a weak but singed coffee character.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. One of their least offensive beers. Attractive enough pour... dark brown with creamy tan head. Ever had Guinness ice cream? You know, when it sort of tastes like stout, but is just more sweet and creamy. That’s how this beer was, but not even that good. Watery, but not horrible.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a deep ruby with a thin creamy nitro cap with good retention and lacing (but it’s nitro so not that impressive). Aroma of stale coffee grinds, roasted malt. Taste is sort of like if there existed instant stout mix poured and stirred into cold water. Slight cocoa mix in there too but- I agree- very artificial. Overall watery body with a bitter, stale coffee finish almost like drinking left out cold coffee.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Black pour with small white head. Roasted malts aroma, felt like it was a coffee with cream at times. Very heavy, bittersweet flavor.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Name: Stout Date: 04/12/2003 Mode: Draft, Nitro Source: Brewfest, Hickory, NC Black with ruby highlights, big creamy nitro head (at a fest!), dry roasted aroma, very creamy, mild roasted malt flavor, hint of sweetness?, touch of malt bitterness in the finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Top of the Hill Blackwood Mountain Stout
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: As thin as the porter. Black pour, on nitro. Chalky chocolate flavor to it that is incredibly artificial -- not the slightly powdery texture of Rogue’s chocolate stout, more of a chewing semi-sweet hot cocoa mix texture. Some roastiness. Not worth your time.

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Amber in appearance with an off white head. Caramel, spicy, a bit of toffee,

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft at the source. Clear amber color, small white head. Grassy aroma. taste is lightly medicinal.

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Pours a reddish color with an off white head. Watery malt, caramel, faint pink/orange citrus, and a little dust.

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draught in a flight. Pours a reddish amber color with almost no head. Nose is hoppy, but it smells like the hops have turned on it. Taste is similar, in that the hops taste old and no longer fresh. Not a fan.

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Average in wvery way, amazing bar at top o but not bitter enough to compete with anything

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap. Copper pour with a thin white head. Scent is citrus, tea and caramel. Taste is pine and some earth.

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Mild caramel, grapefruit and fruit aroma. Clear red with off white head. Caramel, centennial hips, pear flavor notes. Medium hop bitter finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: A: Nice medium-amber body. Large creamy egg-shell white head. Good retention and some spotty lacing left down the sides. Quite a bit of carbonation flying up from the bottom. Some floaties. S: Grassy and floral hops. Quite a bit of caramel malts are present here. T: Again, some grassy and floral hops are upfront. Only the slightest hints of citrus. Mostly malt, but not particularly rich or complex. Somewhat grainy. M: Lighter bodied and somewhat thin in places. The finish is a bit muted and not particularly crisp or bitter. O: A decent brew. But not something I am likely to seek out in the future.

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Ok beer. This IPA is nicely done. It has a light bitterness taste paired with citrus.

column1: Top of the Hill Rams Head IPA
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft @ Hickory Hops 2011, Hickory, NC. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity floral hoppy citrus aroma. Fruity malty hoppy caramel flavor with hints of citrus. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter finish.

column1: Top of the Hill Iron Mine Pale Ale
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: straw colored. small head. huge diacetyl presence. well worth a taste for that very reason, actually, if you want to pinpoint what diacetyl smells/tastes like.

column1: Top of the Hill Iron Mine Pale Ale
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours golden/orange. Not very much white head. Some decent citrus and sweet malt on this. Really not all that bad.

column1: Top of the Hill Iron Mine Pale Ale
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft sample at the brewpub. Pours a light copper color with a small head. Fair head retention and poor lacing. Aroma is herbal and floral hops. Taste is bitter, metallic and resiny hop notes. Metallic... Iron Mine? I guess that makes sense. Really no maltiness anywhere. Watery, thin-medium bodied.

column1: Top of the Hill Iron Mine Pale Ale
column2: Chapel Hill, North Carolina, United States
column5: Name: Pale Ale Date: 04/12/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory, NC Dark yellow, big white head, nice fresh citrus cascade hop aroma, beautiful balanced full hop flavor, nice mild bitter finish, impressive Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.9/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Very light, barley enough color to classify as amber. Drinks with a firm malt, apple character, with a toffee swirl. Pleasant-enough amber lager. (#5824, 10/11/2014)

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Tap at the brewery. Pours clear amber with a small, frothy off-white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is toast, caramel, and cookie malt with earthy hops. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness, a clean lager character and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Draft at the source. Hazy yellow color, off white edge head. Aroma of caramel biscuit ctaste is sweet lightly toasted caramel.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 10/5/12 Aroma: It has some caramel, toasted malts, and a little earth on the nose Appearance: It pours a clear caramel color without any head or lace on the glass Flavor: The taste is mostly malty, it is medium sweet, and has a mild earthy bitterness Palate: The body is fairly light, there’s a smooth/clean feel and a soft carbonation to this one Overall Impression: I felt that this was a solid, malty beer. It drinks fairly typical of the Marzen style, and hits on what it is trying to be, but it isn’t the beer for my taste.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Served on draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear copper color with a thin off-white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of caramel, toasted malts and floral hops. The taste is toasted grainy malts, herbal and leafy hops. Medium bodied.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: On tap at Trap Rock. Poured a medium amber color with a small sized off white head. Aromas and tastes of caramel, a little toasty, and lighter earthiness. Some nuts and also getting a buttery popcorn.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Had this on draft-Poured a nice amber color,looked very inviting.The aromas were of malt and light spice.The taste was caramel,malt and light hops.Overall not too bad.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: Clear light caramel-amber pour. Fading white head quickly resumes to a ring. Clean-flavoured, rather crisp and toasty, kinda caramelly lager with a medium body of sparkling carbonation. Fresh finish offering soft almondy nuances. Straightforward and efficient.

column2: Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, United States
column5: on tap -pours a retaining off white head and copper color. Aroma is roasty medium malt, secondary citrus/Northwest hops (and some spicy/earthy hops). Taste is roasty medium malt-caramel, secondary citrus/Northwest hops (and some spicy/earthy hops), some yeast/fruitiness. Smooth. OK/mild carbonation.
Always strikes me as a bit watery, but a decent lager from a very nice local brewpub.
Extremely pale, some DMS and cascades in the aroma, subdued, though. Low aroma intensity. Fairly good american lager. Light bodied, but well bittered. Dare I say thirst quenching?
(Tap 5/2004) Sweet malt and some cheesy hops. A bit of coffee, harsh roast and some very weird whiskeyish notes. (Infected?) This ones a mess.

I thought thi sone was a nice example of the "northern" style of British brown ale, on the order of Newcastle, but better. Very nice deep caramel color, some [but not much] malt sweetness, nice hops finish. I ony wish I could have had another, but it was time to go!
Dark copper color with a small head. Malty, slightly fruity aroma. Nutty, toasted malt taste. Dry finish.

Woody earth aroma, with vanilla and a hint of sweetness.Deep brown umber color, with a rapidly vanishing head. Medium body, with slight nut taste. Earthy undertones. Not a bad nut brown, but not a standout.

Deep, amber-brown color with a quickly dissipating head. Smells like a belgian strong (a vanilla sweetness to it). The aroma is lovely, inviting. Yum! Tastes a lot like a Belgian strong, too, but without much of the sweet, biting alcohol. There's definitely vanilla in the flavor (it would probably make a great vanilla float!). It's lovely, sweet, with a hint of balancing sourness in the finish. Very good.

DuClaw Brewery and Eatery in Belair, MD. Sparkling clear, cherry wood hue with a small, bone-colored, creamy head. Minimal lacing, but a very nice creamy head remains for the duration. The aroma is of dark chocolate and English toffee. The flavor is rich and malty up front with blasts of milk chocolate, caramel and English toffee up front. Well-balanced by a tart hop addition on the backside. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, crisp and clean finish. A great, grown Springtime beer!... and hey, it's 67 degrees outside. Perfecto!!
Clear red-brown body. Aroma and taste are both vanilla, sweet, and nutty malty. Medium body. Nothing special, but pleasant in its own right.
Fantastic beer all around. This beer is a true meaning of a Brown Ale. The aroma and the taste of this beer is textured perfectly. I also had the Cask Fantome. This one exceeded my expectations.

Firkin version. This was awesome. Can only hope more is on the way. Every Friday should be a firkin Friday. Caramel, buttery, toffee for both smell and tastes. Slight hint of hops. Almost Scottish Ale like in flavor and character. The extra molasses used in this version really stood out in a good way. Smooth velvety mouthfeel, served the way real beer should be. Will rate standard Fantome on next visit. Was having trouble ordering anything but the firkin. It was too good to not keep drinking it.

Bottle from Belmont Station. Pours a clear, medium golden color. No head forms. Very sparse, delicate carbonation. Aroma is indeed musty and horsey. Semi-dry, not really bone puckering dry but enough that you notice. Sour/sweet apple flavor that battles the dryness and a hint of alcohol. Just doesn’t seem to flow very well and blend.

Pale golden. Headless. Gigantic musty horseblanket aroma. Very leathery with a flourishing white oak character. Wax and juicy apples underneath. Brushing carbonation. Musty and grainy initially with a faint tannic note in the middle pursued by musty oak flavors and plump apple hints. It showcases some lovely tartness which keeps the leather and brett notes at bay. Finishes extremely dry with a grainy, musty edge and a perpetual medicinal character. Lingering apple notes lurk under the huge brett notes. Certainly a Cider worth examining from all angles.

One of the few domestic ciders I've tried that does a very good job replicating the dry and subtle sweetness of traditional English ciders. The nose is rich and full of apple aroma while its mildly bubbly. Its has a true cask taste that will follow you for a while. Some might find this a bit strong (like myself), but after a couple of sips its not too difficult to get past. This is a little difficult to find as it appears to only be sold in Oregon, but it can be ordered from their website so longas you live in certain states. Worth trying if you can find.
Bottle at White Winter Winery on Nov. 18, 2011. A clear almost white pour, faint nose of lemon, taste was lemon/lime. I enjoyed this.

750ml foiled and corked, thanks after4ever. Pours a touch thicker than water and show light legs on the walls of the glass. Nose is fairly light with obvious honey notes as well as bright white grape and touches of riesling, light floral as well. Not overly sweet and the riesling notes show through in the flavor quite well. Drinks easy and is a good intro mead that would pair well also with a meal.

Nice honey nose fermented light fruirts on the nose. White wine notes. Ppurs light yellow. Flavor is light honey, light tart fruit. Medium sweet, some alcohol. Smooth introductory mead. Nice and drinkablr at 11percent.

750, corked and foiled. thanks tyler! pours clear, headless, laceless, legless. looks like thick water. mild white wine grapes on the nose, tart, not much honey aromatic. fairly easy drinking creamy medium body, nice mix of light honey and white wine grapes. almost refreshing.

Bottle. Light pour with a sweet aroma of honey and light spice. This was a basic dry mead but was done quite well. Body was nice and light with the balance of sweetness kept nice and low. Easy to drink and nice.

Bottle via a trade from the man, the myth, the legend, tytoanderso...as an extra along with 3 other White Winter EXTRAS! (BEER KARMA to him!). Pours nearly as clear as water, with some legs. Aroma is straight forward with honey, some freshly cut grass, sage brush, light citrus, and desert flora and dryness. Nice spiciness to the honey. Taste is very dry but near watery with alcohol, mint water and dry wine. Odd trade duality of alcohol flavor and thin body. Strange, and I am not sure quite how they accomplished that (along with the water like hue). A few too many wine tannins (added after, not from oak). Very dry in residual sugars and finish. Would be interested in talking to the brewer about their process in making this.
ABR 2008. Light aroma of honey with a bit of wood in there as well. Sweet, finishes very dry. Alcohol seemed stronger in this than in the others from White Winter I tried.

Appearance is almost water like with just the slightest of golden tint to the clear headless liquid. Aroma of oak, light honey, and a bunch of other things I’m not real sure of. Taste of honey, yeast and tannins. Reminds me of a dry wine rather than something I should typing up a paragraph about on ratebeer.com. Semi-watery, mildly tart with a nice dry finish. It’s okay, but I’d just assume have a dry wine made of red grapes than a honey concoction.
Sampled at the White Winter Winery. Nice dry mead nose on this pale yellow pour. Dry flavor but still a little too sweet for a dry mead in my book. A good product nonetheless.

During May ’07 brewpub tour, stopped at the winery in Iron River, WI. Pours a clear, light yellow chardonnay wine color. Aroma of dry grass, some sour pineapple, earth and light honey. Taste is sweet honey at first and then finishes very dry. A slight tart apple aftertaste. Did not pick any citrus but an excellenet dry mead.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: From the file last updated in 2010. Pours gold. Citrus aroma. Flavor is fruit, citrus and malt. finishes bitter.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company, Ltd.--Spring Run IPA--India Pale Ale--2003--12 oz. Bottle. 6.50% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) IPA--Clear thin bright golden color. Light lacy head. Floral earthy distilled hop front. Crisp thin dry sweet body. Tangy rich hot citrus hop spice end. Unusual hop flavor. Mild body. Sampled 2/23/2003. Widmer Brothers Brewing Company, Ltd.--Spring Run IPA--2004 12 oz. Bottle. 6.50% ABV--55 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0) IPA--Clear rich bright golden color. Light head. Rich mild earthy floral hop front. Smooth balanced clean dry sweet citrus caramel earthy body. Smooth clean tangy citrus hop spice end. Mild hoppy rich IPA. Sampled 3/7/2004.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Poured a cloudy gold with white head and good lacing. Nose of citrus hops and caramel malts. Rich and smooth mouthfeel. Flavor is nicely bitter and there is pine in the finish. Not the best IPA ever, but for sure drinkable.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: This is not the most exciting IPA I have ever tasted. Big on the hops and not alot of attention to detail when it comes to flavor and have a strong malt background. Lots of fruit and citrus with a chalky bitter finish.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Pours a medium hazy golden yellow. Aromas of citrus hops and a touch of pale malts. Flavor is crisp bitter citrus hop with a nice lingering aftertaste.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Probably my favorite Widmer at the moment. Has a nice fruity nose to it, and pours with a nice head. Coloring is the standard Widmer haze.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: Hazy gold, lasting stark white head.Tiny bead. Citrus hop nose.Grapefruit ho profile, med strength lasting finish. Great lace

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap 2005. Hazy gold colour with thin lasting frothy head. Strong citric hoppy nose. Bitter grapefruit taste with lingering bitter hop finish.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On draught 2005 at Redbones. Pours a pretty lucid yellow. No head, clear, lightly bubbly. Aroma of dusty leaves, some hints of citrus, pale malt. Flavor is all leafy, dry, earthy hops. That’s about the extent of the flavor. Little to no malt presence. No yeast. Argh. Maybe I’m just in a shitty mood because the last 4 beers I had at Redbones have been complete shit. If that’s the case, Mr. Widmer IPA, I’m sorry and I will certainly rerate you. But for now, you sure seem like a regular American IPA gone bad. No balance, no complexity.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: (12 oz bottle: Cost Plus in La Jolla, CA) Man, this is one bland and boring IPA. There’s nothing in the flavor that is at all noteworthy here. It’s somewhat malty, balanced by a moderately bitter, citrusy hoppiness, and a slight smokiness seems to come out in the finish, but this really tastes like a generic IPA from a generic brewpub. The nose seems a bit more malty than the flavor, but the hops is rather light, which I guess is why the malt is in the foregroung. Somewhat crisp and clean on the palate. Dark yellow color and fairly cloudy in appearance. Small whitish head quickly settles to a sheen, but manages to produce a moth-eaten curtain of lace. Yawn...... ......zzZZ

I wasn't expecting to find a brewpub in a small place like West Yellowstone. Not a bad little place though. The Altbier was my favorite of the ones I tried. (They were also featuring a Kolsch and Hefeweizen which don't appear on this list).

crystal malt aroma with light hops. bronze color with an initially large head that lingers. creamy, lightly hopped. a nice beer with a round finish. Enjoyed the brewpub. I stopped by for a few while getting gas in West Yellowstone
Can pour with a lightly cloudy gold color. Chalky pepper aroma. The pepper is mostly aroma without the spice.

Too overwhelming with Chili peppers in taste and aroma. Nothing subtle about it. If I wanted chili peppers in a water, I would have asked for it. We couldn't even drink the flight sample. tap at brewery.
medium yellow color,hot pepper aroma, nice flavor or peppers but not overpowering or spicy

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty weak spicy chili aroma with hoppy hints. Fruity malty spicy chili flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy chili hoppy finish.

Golden color. Bright peppery nose - maybe with a hint of underlying malt, but all about the pepper aroma and flavor here. Light heat and a hint of implied smoke (though I don't think there is any). Well done.
Backlog entry: Flight at the brewery in Denver. Decent beers, all average. Most on the lighter side but aligned with the style.

12 oz. can. Opens a moderate gusher. Pours a moderate, poorly retained white head, over a clear, effervescent, dark gold (SRM 6) body........ nose is green chile, very slight hints of smoke, cereal, minimal hops, balance to the chile........taste is moderate green chile, mild chile heat, light base malts, ending with mild lingering chile heat, with vague hints of hop bitterness.......mouth feel, light body, no alcohol, high carbonation. This is a very subtle chile beer. The chile aroma and flavor are there with only minimal chile heat. The base beer is very light in both the malt and hop back bones, with the resulting creation being a very simple beer. BJCP 6/2/10/4/6
Draft at Ale House at Amato’s. Pours a clear, dark golden color with a thin white head. Malty aroma with a slight hint of spice. Smooth taste. Grassy feel with a light kick. Not too shabby.
Can. Pours clear orange with white head. Aroma is of spicy peppers, green peppers, earthy. Taste is very hot pepper but no heat, lingering pepper finish, light body, a bit flat. Good.

Pours a classic golden color with a short white cap perpetually fed by carbination bubbles from the bottom. Big chile nose. Wet, but mildly astringent. Some carbonation burn. Chile flavors and that’s about all. But that’s fine with me. Love chile beers.
On tap at the brewery pours golden topped with a white head. Nose is floral tangerine sweetness. Taste is more of the nice sweet malts and sweet malts.
Koperen kleur met een goede kraag. Ruikt kruidig, fruitig, zoetig. Smaakt fruitig, honing, kruiden.

Pleasant, but non-descript. I would gladly have a growler of this at a 4th of July party, but I wouldn’t expect anyone to ask what was so they could buy it themselves. My bottle also had a best-by date of 04-Aug-16. Edit: 5/18/2017 I got in touch with Alpine, and confirmed that the bottle I got from my local IS out of date. I’ll re-rate this when I can get a fresh bottle. Great customer service from Alpine, and I’m going to complain at the bottle shop.

Draft to taster at The Pint Room. Looks solid; a transparent golden orange with white head. Smells and tastes of honey, oranges, and ale yeast with a mildly bittersweet backbone. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied. Inoffensive, but underwhelming.

Darkish orange, almost amber pour with a one finger, creamy off white head. Aroma is mostly honey and coriander, some bread, oxidation. Flavor is quite heavy in the honey department, but in a good way, a fair amount of coriander, but not as much as the aroma implies, nice floral notes, really nice orange blossom honey aftertaste, hampered, slightly by a slight metallic twinge. Medium body, creamy at first, then somewhat drying, light, soft carbonation. Good stuff, I really like the way it shows off the honey.
Heavy on the honey and herbs, light on the beer itself. Needs more backbone.
Bomber. Deep honey golden with a short loved head. Mandarin aroma with malts and some honey. Mandarin and honey lead the flavor profile and there isn’t a lot more. Feel is too thin.
On tap at Green Flash, Mira Mesa. A bit hazy orange with a small white head. Sweet with honey, some herbs, light fruit and some malt. The body was soft as was the bitterness. Nothing special.

Pours cloudy orange with a medium frothy white head. Aromas of peach, lactose, tangerine, resin. Taste is quite fruity with low bitterness. Mouthfeel is juicy and light bodied with moderate carbonation.
Pours cloudy apricot with low white head Aromas bready, malty, herbal Taste has herbal, bready notes with coriander

Growler, thanks to Alison, poured an opaque black with a big tan head. Aroma was sweet chocolate, hints of dark roasted coffee, and lots of whiskey as well. Flavor was silky smooth, lots of whiskey and chocolatey sweetness. Good Stuff.

Draught at the Church. Jet black pour with no head. Rich, winey, plummy aroma with lots of raisin...very nice! Flavor is also winey and malty but with more noticeable roasted coffee and dark chocolate particularly on the finish. Smooth and full bodied palate. Alcohol is well hidden. Outstanding Imperial Stout!

&#40draft @ Church Brew Works - Pittsburgh, PA&#41 Pitch black pour with no head and very light carbonation. Aroma is huge and full of whiskey, oak, and vanilla notes. Flavor is much the same. Sweet and roasty at the start with a very solid whiskey and vanilla finish. Oak is present throughout. Really, really nice.

Draft at the brewpub. Black with a chocolate brown head. Roasted malt aroma with some whiskey like sweetness. The flavor has dark chocolate and roast, with more whiskey and a touch of hops. Pretty good.

Snifter off of tap. Aroma of roast malt, dark chocolate, some whiskey. Midnight black, with a dark tan head. Huge flavor of whiskey aged oak, with lots of chocolate and sweet malts. Good beer from them, they are starting to get on quite the whiskey aged kick right now.

This was probably the best beer I’ve had from them. Aroma was nice. Strong roasted malt, black licorice with a hint of chocolate. Pour was perfect. Deep dark black with a thick and pillowy dark tan head. One of the best appearances I’ve ever seen. Taste was great also. Strong chocolate and burnt licorice but with a chocolatey aftertaste. This beer tastes like some of the big brewer’s EXCEPT for this off metallic aftertaste. It wasn’t strong enough to ruin the beer, but it hurt the score. Very nice.

This poured an opaque black color with a big tan head. Aroma was sweet chocolate, soem dark roasted coffee hints and lots of whiskey as well. Flavor was silky smooth, lots of whiskey and chocolatey sweetness. Good Stuff.

Name: Manya’s Imperial Stout Date: 07/23/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub black, frothy beige head, streaks of lace, sweet vanilla and roasted malt aroma with a hint of dark fruits, rich dark chocolate flavor, nice caramel sweetness balances a wave of roasted providing a bitter edge, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
On cask at the Church. Manya’s Imperial Stout served in a british pint glass. Dark black brown, tan head. Aroma is metallic, caramel, toffee, licorice. Flavor is the same, slightly smoky and sweet.

This stuff was called ’MANYA’S" imperial stout. Cask conditioned and flat to the palate. Coal black and chocolate mousse head. Slight roasty impy stout aroma. Smells fairly attractive. Bitter and alky. Very strong and oppressive to an exrtent. Do you like your beer filtered through an old wet campfire? A little rude but this is the opinion of a lager lover. Very good example of the style.
Caramel and apple aroma. Very dark color, almost no head. Coffee flavor with a slight sourness. Apple and cherry. Very thin. Disappointing, amateuristic beer with a dirty palate.
Dark brown pour big dense head. Aroma molasses, thyme, sweet gale. Tastes very herby. Surprisingly light palate. Very buttery some char. Tastes like witches brew - something out of harry potter.

Dark ruby color with a tiny ring of head. Aroma is spruce, pine needles, parsley and lavender. Holy hell, it tastes just like it smells. The finish has a lingering spruce and herbal kick. THIS should be named Prescription Gruit! damn fine traditional ale, but be prepared for the herbs. Honestly, I really kind of like it.
On tap at Magnolia. Hazy brown. Aroma of light spice and molasses. Taste is slightly rootbeer-esque... sweet but not too sweet, caramel, liquorice, spices, spicy finish. Interesting, and good enough.

A very interesting, classic style beer. Pours a beautiful thick red-brown. Smells like strawberries and herbs, and fermentation. Taste is very sweet, with some more strawberries. Very different taste then any modern beer. Had on tap at Magnolia. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

a - pours a hazy golden light cola with high tan head. Hazy effervescent brown M - light medium palate, lightly tangy, simple palate. T - strong pumpkin seeds, very floral, with honey and dough. o interesting honey flower wheat 3.1

Draught @ Magnolia Pub & Brewery, San Francisco. Rated on 15.10.2012. Pours a brown colour with a small creamy head. Aroma of strong toasted almonds and raisins. Flavpur of strong and pungent almonds, toasted malts, grassy hops and bread. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Rich nutty and malty finish. Surprisingly good.

Dark amber pour with an off-white head. Acidic and roasted malt aromas with a bit of an herbal spruce note. Some chocolate, toast, and a bit of toffee maltiness. Light bitter on the palate, lots of roast, spruce, and a light herbal note. Some hints of toast, a bit of grass, and a nice toffee sweetness.

On tap. Pours with a deep, cola hued body with a medium sized tan/off-white head that fades. Aromas are nutty, caramel, brown sugar, cola, sarsaparilla, walnut, light clove, medium spicy. Flavors are malty, honey, brown sugar, nutty, cola, chamomile tea and slightly floral. Low bitterness, a bit herbal with a malty balance. Dry finish with a touch of tannin left on the tongue. Medium to slightly fuller bodied, medium-low carbonation. Very slightly warming, but otherwise the alcohol is quite well hidden.
Sampled at the Blue Palms Farmer’s Market FestivALE. Another beer where the spices underwhelm. Not a bad beer but not too exciting to my palate. A bit boring actually.
I wish I could remember more of this beer to properly describe it. It’s an ok beer, but nothing to get too excited about.

“Eisenacher Wartburg Pils“, Flasche (50 cl) vom Bahnhof Eisenach. - “Gebraut und abgefüllt in Einsiedel“, verrät das Etikett - in Eisenach wird seit 2006 nicht mehr gebraut, erfährt man aus dem Internet. - Goldgelb, blank, handelsüblicher Schaum. - In der Nase unauffälliger hopfenwürziger Hopfen, Zitronenschale. - Antrunk zitronig hopfig mit stumpfer Herbe im Hintergrund. Durchschnittlich rezent, schlank, etwas dünner Körper. Derb hopfenbitterer, wenig aromatischer Abgang mit Zitronenschale und unschönen Anklängen an Schweineschmalz. Nachtrunk dito. - Etwas dünnes, billig schmeckendes Lohnbier, kein Genuß.
*Old rating. Best before 12.02.05. Nettes, herbes und leicht getreidiges Pils. Süffig und leicht süßlich. Schön!

Pours a clear light yellow with a small white cap. The smell grain, grass with a bit of sharpness. The taste is grain, mild corn, artificial sweetener, ending dry and crisp. The body is very light, with light tickled carbonation. Not loving it as the artificial sweetener flavor puts me off.
Geruch getreidig, leicht würzig, etwas Gras. Beginnt süßlich, grasig. Anschließend würzige Züge, brotig. Leicht bitter im Abgang. Ok.
0.5 l bottle from Eisenach... Very clear golden color, almost no head... Mild herb hop aroma, bitter aftertaste... Not too herb standard German Pilsener taste... Nice ending...
Wässrig herber Antrunk. Das Aroma verbessert sich leider nicht, das Bier bleibt leer, kaum würzig, monoton bitter. 8/7/7/6/9/6

#628 Das tolle Flaschenetikett mit reichlich Gold verzierter Schrift und dem Retro-Look hat mich wohl diese Flasche kaufen lassen. Im Glas dann auch gülden mit viel Schaum; das Aroma ist sehr verhalten, um nicht zu sagen kaum auszumachen. Im Antrunk dann eher malzig mit gewisser wäßriger Herbe im Abgang. Das ginge ja noch, wenn nicht permanent eine gewisse Säuerlichkeit zu schmecken wäre. Irgendwie hatte ich da mehr erwartet. Dieses Bier wird der imposanten und geschichtsträchtigen Wartburg nicht gerecht! Test vom 8.1.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,8,9,8,13,9 - 9,20
Bottle. Clear golden color. Hops, sweet, herbs in aroma. Hoppy bitter flavor. O.K.
Bottle. Golden color. Metal and grass in the aroma. Grassy hopbitter, almost herbal flavor, with some metal in the aftertaste. Dry and reasonably firm.

Draught @ Hotel Glockenhof, Grimmelgasse 4, 99817 Eisenach, Thuringia, Germany. Clear medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, pale malt, light grain, light to light moderate hoppy, fruity. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average duration, malty, sweet malt, fruity hop notes. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20110711]
0,5 l Flasche. Helles Gold, flacher, cremiger, stabiler, weißer Schaum. Leicht würzig, etwas wässrig, typisches Helles.
Boca 0,5L - kupljena u Njemačkoj - dosta sladna aroma..crvena jqabuka u aftertasteu?..prosječno
Middle of the road Dortmunder. Looks, taste and smell all are okay but nothing special. Taste doesn't last but beer is very drinkable.
14-10-18 // 330ml bottle shared at a tasting with the Rhein-Main crew. 07/17 MHD. Grainy sweet.

Botella de 500ml servida en una pinta spigleau. Apariencia amarilla brillante con una corona de espuma blanca cremosa de buena estabilidad. Su aroma es a granos ligeramente horneados con sutiles notas a especias que dejan una sensación final seca en la boca. Cuerpo ligero de buena carbonatación.

Bottle from Trinkgut in Kleve, Germany. The beer is clear yellow colored and has a small and stable head, with low carbonation. The aroma is very malty, with notes of grass, yeast, bread, grains and some spices. The taste is sweet and malty with no special surprises, just like the aroma says. The finish is light bitter and a little watery. Boring Dortmunder, had better ones.

Bottle. Clear pale yellow with white head. The aroma has notes of grains, black pepper, white bread and hay. The flavor is bitter and mild sweet with notes of grains, black pepper, some flowers, lemon and hay. Medium-bodied.
Cristal clear yellow, white white foam head. No surprises in aroma and taste, strictly barley. (Velp 201803)
From Costco. In Teku glass. Playing Neighbouring Islands. Light and plain, with just some grassy notes to give it some flavor but not managing to make it something more enjoyable than an industrial

Kalea Advent Calendar. Sweet aroma with a yeasty sour edge. Light gold. Bubbly white head soon fades away. In fact more bitter than I was expecting. With some sour sweetness. As I drink more gains a syruppy sweetness. Light bodied. Thin. Average carbonation. Long, if low key, finish. Has a bit of a kick to it. Not too bad for a larger style.

Pours a deep brown on tap with fluffy peaks of tan head that leave moderate lace on the way down. Aroma of mild caramel and chocolate malt notes with a clean earthy hop note and German lager yeast. Taste follows, a touch of sweetness with a mild bitter to back, a touch of umami from the roast malts. Crushable dark lager.
Dark amber with a frothy head. Roasted smell of caramel and chocolate. Roasted spicy and malty taste but not very sweet. Low carbonation.

From the bottle. Brown with a foamy head that slowly fades. Aroma is overripe plum and caramel. Taste is mildly sweet with toasted notes up front and lingering plum, minerals and caramel at the end. Medium body, mild carbonation. Pretty good.

Dark kopper beer. Taste and smell both have a touch of raisins. The sweet tast is compensated with a sour fruity tone. Altogether taste is nice and strong but unfortunately the taste is gone as fast as the head.

Draught at Schneider Weisse Brauhaus, Munich, Germany. Poured a crystal clear coppery red with 2cm of beige dense foam that diminished quickly to a blitchy cap that laced OK. Carbonation low, average and very fine. Aroma slughtly of malt and sweet caramel. Taste slightly of caramel and malt with hints of roasted malt. Light body. Slightly dry with slight sweetness on a short finish.

licht caramel bruin met lichte kraag, aroma van caramel, bruine suiker, rozijn, en ander donker fruit, kandy, mout, smaken zijn redelijk zoet, weeïg, zacht, moutig, gebrande mout, caramel, gestacheld bier, noten, ok, zwak tot matige body, iets meer smaak dan 't standaard Duitse aanbod

Bottle from Trinkgut in Kleve, Germany. The beer is brown colored and has a small cream colored head, with average carbonation. The aroma is very malty, with notes of caramel, dried fruits, toffee, chocolate and a hint of spices. The taste is sweet malty and medium bodied with clear caramel, dried fruits and toffee and goes to light bitter with chocolate and spices. The finish is light bitter, little dry.
Taste: Crisp, bready, tangy dark malts, clean finish. Bready nose. Ruby/Brown hue, mostly clear, with a nice head and lace. Medium body. Would pair well with many dishes.
50cl. bottle @ home, bought @ Trinkgut, Kleve. Brown with an off-white head. Dark malty aroma. Sweet taste. Tasty dunkel but nothing spectacular.

Bottle. Clear caramel dark color, fine beige head. Light roast malty aroma, herbal, floral hop notes. Dry taste, medium bitterness. Round, smooth, full body, carbonation. Noticeable caramel malty aftertaste, nice balanced bitterness.
Roasty aroma. Deep coffee black with soft suds of white head. Lightly roasty with an oat character. Smooth light mouthfeel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at brewery. Not getting much on the nose, might be the fault of the overbearing perfume from one table away. Maybe a bit of roast. Pretty thin body. Some powdered cocoa and coffee flavor. Tiny bit of licorice. Kinda dry for something described as a "sweet stout," which is ok by me. Finishes slightly sour.
Just about black colored beer. Thin white ring head. Roasted malt aroma. Coffee and roasted nalt flavor. Nice bitter end. Kinda thin and sharp. Fi.d the oatmeal. Its there, just find it.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear dark amber brown with a light brown head that dissipates slowly and completely. Aroma has dry roasted malts and a bit of creamy dark grains. Flavor has dark grains with a bit of bitter coffee and creamy chocolate.

Growler split, served in a DFH IPA glass A - Black body with very little head. S - Sweet creamy coffee, roasted chocolate malts, leafy green hops, sweet alcohol comes through. T - Roasty upfront with dark chocolate and coffee, some bitterness mixed in with a tangy character on the back end. Finished roasted and slightly bitter. M - Medium body, semi-syrupy, not as creamy as I wanted it be. An average all around oatmeal stout. Nice aroma but the mouthfeel fell a little short. I would drink this again. Serving type: growler 04-08-2013
Tap @ 75th Street. Pours a black appearance with a creamy dark brown head. Anise, a touch fruity, chocolate, light vanilla aroma. Somewhat bitter, light coffee, roasty malty, earthy, oaty flavor. Ok.

Draft at the brewpub. Black pour with thin tan head. Aroma and flavor were some roasted malt, light, rather acrid chocolate, mild bitterness and sweetness. Mouthfeel on the thin side and not as smooth as I’d expect for an oatmeal stout.

Tap at brewpub. Perfectly black body with a thin khaki head. Rich roasted coffe nose with milk chocolate. The taste is milk chocolate with some light roast. There is some bread crust. Decebt middle of the road stout.
Dark brown. Strong coffee taste. Very roasted. No head. Pretty lame stout. Not memorable.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a black color with tan head. Burnt, roasted, toasty, oatmeal flavors. Very mediocre stout.

330ml glass bottle from Hop Lords, Worcester. Dated as best before 23.03.2019. Served fridge cold in a pint glass. Medium amber in colour, small thin head with high-medium level of carbonation. The head dissipates almost instantly. Lots of streams and a few bubbles clinging to the inside of the glass. Aroma is more sweet than anything else. Caramel biscuit malt, straw, grass. Nothing overly prominent or dominating. The taste follows a above with a slight hint of bitterness. Clean but grainy as the beer warms. A nice mouthfeel with the grain taste lasting, but not for too long. Easy to drink, tasty. I’d happily take this over the mass produced lagers but it is slightly uninspiring.
300ml on tap at the brewery, Rothaus. Aroma is make and slightly hops. Appearance is golden with a thick white foam. Taste is bitter and light sweet. Dry. Strong carbonation. Delicious Märzen.

Ich verstehe den Hype nicht, der um das Tannenzäpfle gemacht wird. So finde ich dieses Eiszäpfle, das kein Eisbock, sondern ein einfaches deutsches Märzen ist, nicht sonderlich berauschend (vom Geschmack her). Es ist recht süß und der getreidige Körper wirkt etwas muffig. Ich brauche es nicht mehr.
Bottle from Edeka - clear dark golden color. malty, sticky, sweetish. poor example of a Märzen.
0,33 l Flasche. Dunkel goldenes Bier, flacher, weißer Schaum. Riecht mech Getreide, schmeckt kräftig, malzig, süßlich, kaum bitter, minimal alkoholisch.
Sold as Märzen Export. Clear and super bright golden. Head is a little lumpy and doesn't last long. Aroma is faintly herbal. Taste is some orchard fruit. Pretty sweet and slick texture. Not great.
Fles 33cl in La Spezia. Zoetig, maltig, fris. (7-2017).-------------------.
Tiefgold, geringe Krone. Dünner, leicht malziger Duft. Geschmack nur leicht, etwas zu mild.
Rothaus Märzen Export. Geel bier met schuim. Smaak is licht bitter hoppig en ietwat zoetzuur. Best aardig bier, niet echt bijzonder.
Pours clear golden with a white head that won‘t stay too long. Has a hearty grainy aroma. Flavour is grain, bread, and slightly sweet, accompanied by a very sligtly boozy palate. Very drinkable.
The beer has got a hazy amber color with a small head and smooth body. Aroma of Belgian yeast and fruits. Taste is Belgian, wheat, fruits, warm bread. Smooth finish.
12oz bottle. Pours orange with a big fluffy head. Banana, booze, honey, spice, peach, banana bread, little boozy heat in the finish. Medium body. Decent enough.
Bottle from Village Beer Merchant. Malty, candied sugar, very sweet, some spices, yeasty, grainy. Slightly alcoholic with a sickly sweet finish.
Belgian hops with some spices mild carbonation nice bitter finish and a strong alcohol taste. Tastes like a typical Belgian beer. Nice aftertaste. Good overall beer!

10/19/18 With A after Target and McD’s. Flying to AL tomorrow. Poured from bottle into a tulip. Darker with less head than I’d expect from a tripel. Nose spicy and warm with lots of Belgian yeasty goodness. Getting cloves, cinnamon and vanilla almost reminiscent of pumpkin spice. Taste is warm, powerful and very yeasty with clove and vanilla dominating. Really rich flavor with some warming alcohol. Decently sweet on the tongue then finishes pretty dry with a fair presence of floral noble hops. Wow! Palate is big, light and fluffy as expected for the style. Really digging the hoppy hint in a Tripel! Overall, this is absolutely delicious! Huge and so very warm with a slightly darker and more robust flavor than expected for a tripel. Among my favorites of the style!

Bottle from Pennsport. Medium golden pour, head a bit weak for the style. Aroma is yeasty, grainy and rich. Taste follows the pattern, Belgian yeast, fairly hefty body, nice slick feel. Some savory, herbal noes help accent the taste.
Thick and lasting white head. Cloudy light golden color. Spicy aroma with hints of cherries in chocolate. Sweet caramel taste with fine bitterness.
Bottle from Beers of the World. Nice spicy aroma with some Belgian yeast notes.
Rich and big with coffee, vanilla and some wooden notes such as oak. Dry with a little sweetness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Somewhat similar to golden monkey. Sweet/bitter and 10% abv, I like a beer that feels like you're drinking alcohol.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: Tap at Goose Island Clybourn as part of a flight. Wasn’t expecting much of this as I usually don’t like Scottish ales. However, this beer had a lot more character and smoothness than typical of the style and most importantly it had clean finish. Fairly sweet and fruity with a somewhat acidic quality. Fairly dark in color.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: tap @ Blind Tiger for GI event. Nice and smooth. sweet malts, orange and citrus. The lightest touch of bitterness rounds it off nicely. Brown sugar and toffee and some clover honey. nice. I’m becoming a fan of this style now that I’ve had a couple.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: As per Blind Tigers printout ABV was listed at 7%. Draft, pours a deep red body with a brune and thin bubbly lacing. Sweeter citrus, with a smoky wooden tones, light scotch and caramel. Peat y with a mild roastiness with a mild warming and a dry woody finish.l Nice.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: Tap at BT for the GI event. Pours a slight hazy deep amber with almost no head (I think most of their beers head- diminishes too quickly- may be the way BT handles their glassware?). Aroma is a light kick of roasted barley and light peat smoke over a bigger caramel malt backbone- light honey sweetness and toffee. Flavor is smooth creamy and sweet, toasted malts, biscuit, sweet caramel , brown sugar, toffee and honey sweet- a bit slick with some peat and smoke prickliness in the end but it is just a nice wisp that adds to the beer. Pretty smooth and easy drinking.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: On tap at the GI Pub on Clybourn. Pours a clear, amber-brown colored body with a thin, creamy, beige head that dissipates quickly and leaves a light lacing. Aroma has a rich maltiness with a light caramel cookie sweetness and some smoke. A hint of roast, peat, and earthy fruit hops. Flavor is the same with a thinner, smooth body and a somewhat dry finish. Lengthy aftertaste of smoke and sweeter malts. Overall, not the most explosive scotch ale, but it grew on me more and more as it warmed. Not bad.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: [cask at Clybourn brewpub] Hazy brownish red color. Nicely topped with a foamy tan head. Malty, slightly sweet aroma. Very subtle smoke character. Malt-focused flavors with a mellow, earthy bitterness. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: Cask pull at the Goose Island brewpub in Chicago. Nice off white head with a reddish brown body. Not too hoppy and a touch of roasty malt. I would have this again.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: Draft at Clybourn brewpub. Poured clear brown color with an average off-white creamy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate earthy tart citrus aroma. Medium body with light carbonation. Medium earthy bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable brew.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: On tap at GI. Served in a pint glass, brown body with very thin white head. It has a nice flavor of caramel and smoky notes really come through in this beer. I thought it was very good.

column1: Goose Island Robert Burns Scottish Ale
column5: 5% version on tap, from memory. poured amber with small off white head. nose has toasted grains, smoke, and peat. mouthfeel was thin and finished watery. flavor had a nice caramel and subtle smoke notes. pretty decent.

Yellow color. Lime and ginger in the nose and throughout the body. Absolutely disgusting. Terrible, not even remotely good after 15 or whatever beers at the Great Toronto Beer Festival or whatever it is.

I tried this at the Hamilton Good Beer Expo. Uh... this isn't good beer. Metalic artifical Lime. Rotten smell that isn't realy even there. I actally ended up throwing the rest of my sample in the garbage. My friend did the same thing and considering herself as Joe Q Public on beer and seeing her throw it out as well tells me more about the beer. I'm sure the only reason why they would sell it in 24's is just to get rid of it and say that it is marketable. Heed warnings and avoid further consuption. A poor variant on a poor beer.

I was poking around the site looking for some Ontario beers that I haven't tried yet, and noticed that this hideous brew that I made the mistake of sampling at last summer's Toronto Beer Festival had yet to be added to the database. Imagine a crappy Corona/Sol knock-off mixed with lime dish soap, and you'll have some idea of what this beer tastes like. It amazes me that they can sell this crap exclusively in cases of 24 and people actually buy it.
Draught at the brewpub. Medium gold with a thin head. Aroma is light citrus hop. Flavour is floral citrus with a very nice even bitter finish. Lingering palate
Tap @ the brewpub. Aroma is floral, citric and hoppy. Slightly hazy, yellow coloured with a thin, white head. Taste is fresh floral hoppy, citric. Just a bit thin, but a quite well balanced brew.
Draught at the brewpub Hazy light blond color. Green hop aroma. Light mouthfeel (thin), with a touch of green hops. Refreshing, but a bit metallic.
Draught at the brewpub, Berlin 2004: Farty nose, fizzy head. Light yello color. Weak fruity and grainy taste.
Draught at the brewpub. Hazy golden. Not much aroma. A dry palate with a fruity, grassy, spicy flavour with some alte bitterness.
Draught at the brewpub. Golden coulour, slightly hazy. Grassy oak flavour and a little watery with a light bitterness.

Light orange color with many particles in it, o.k. lace. Nice aroma, some fruit, fresh. Aroma starts with a mixture of hop and fruit. First only a hint sweet, but gets sweeter in the aftertaste. Really good stuff.

Malty, peach aroma. Hazy, golden/orange color, off-white head, good lace. Starts very dry and hoppy, soon sweeter and fruity. Little thin in the end, but still very hoppy and gets bitter. A very good example of a helles.
Golden, nice white head. Aroma from yeast, fruit and hops. Hoppy flavor, some grapefruit.
One of the best Pilseners I´ve ever tasted. Golden in colour with a firm head, that you sizzle the bitter tastes through. Dry in the finish.
This beer is a classic golden Czech-style pils. Love it! Hopefully this small brewery keeps this standard also next time.
Draught at Pannrummet, Gothenburg Hazy golden with a malty, sourish aroma. RAther lively and dry, though well balanced. A malty, sweetish flavour with a fine bitterness.

Hazy pale golden, quite carbonated. Aroma is clearly malty, maybe with some vanilla, but also sour. Hoppy aroma. Has a long and very nice finish from hops, but also mix some malts in it. A very nice mix.

Draught at Pannrummet, Göteborg, Sweden. Golden in colour with a cotton-like head. Rounded malt aroma with a hoppy background. Full bodied flavour with a thick fizziness and a mild smooth carbonation. A very nice well balanced pils.
Clearly one of their best pils over the years. A yellow, golden pils with a heavy bitternes, a perfekt partner to seafood.

This is a seasonal beer and they brew 150 litres,the taste changes from the first week (jan 24) which was a real "tasteexplosion" to yesterday (feb 13)which is more like normal fresh German Pils,so my rating is from the first taste.

Sampled draught at Pannrummet, Gothenburg. This is an odd brewpub. It is located in an inustrial area and only open on friday evenings. Furthermore they only brew 150-160 l/week. Anyway, this beer in near orange coloured and really hazy with very little head. It has a bready, spicy and pleasantly hoppy aroma. It is suitably dry and yhe maltiness is nicely soft and reasonably firm. The finish is hoppy bitter. A flavourful and well balanced pilsener.
Rating added 1/27/2006 A faint burned taste but not much else, almost no smell to it at all, black in color and non-transparent. 4/3/4/3/12=2.6
My favourite among black beers at the moment. As long as you´re not in Ireland. Here you get a stoutish drieness but not as full body as a stout.
Dark as the Swedish winternight dry vith a burnt malty finish. Nice yellow/brown frothy crown
Not quite as good as their previous Winter Warmer Ale but very dry and chocolate-malty finish

Samled draught at Pannrummet, Gothenburg. Near black with small beige head. Rich coffee aroma. Clean, dry and lightly spicy with notes of licorice and chocolate and a mild toffee finish. A bit hard/sharp mouthfeel.

If you like strong beers and are in Gothenburg, you´d better hurry because the last cask is soon coming up. That´s seasonal beers problem, and they only brew 150 litres of each brew. A fullbodied Bock with a certain sweet ending.
Darkish yellow with a nice white crown full of dextrines with a masculin body
A very strong, malty Bock-pilsner with a surprising sweetness in the finish.

Sampled draught at Pannrummet, Gothenburg. Golden in clour, and near clear with creamy head. Estery winegum aroma. Sweet and soflty malty, rich and creamy. Moderately bitter finish. Full bodied and rather complex.
Cask Handpump at Oakwood High School, Rotherham 22/02/2003 Golden coloured and strong in alcohol with a malt aroma. Slightly earthy taste. Lasting finish.
Sampled cask conditioned at The Rover, Gothenburg, Sweden. Amber coloured. Medium bodied with tarry licorice flavour. Reasonably dry. Salty, bitter finish.
50cl can from a night shop in Conisbrough. Thin white head. Clear pale golden pour. Pretty dreadful.

500ml can, as White Storm 7.5%, from off-license, Liverpool, for 99p. Pale yellow gold colour, short-lived fizzy white foam head and aroma of sugar, sulphur, oil. Taste is sweet, tangy, apple-like flavour, sulphury, with artificial sweeteners & booze. Slick mouthfeel, medium bodied, spritzy carbonation, drying finish with residual sweetener. Not the best

Tried at 7.5% in the early 2000s. Pours clear white with a slight yellow tinge. Smells like stale urine and chemical. Nasty sour apple taste like those fizzy Chewits sweets, more chemicals and powdered sugar. I doubt any apples were used in this. Leaves a worse aftertaste than menstrual blood, not that I would know.
Wanna see me chug this bitch? Copy and paste this link: https://youtu.be/ss6p0hHdqj4 Drank real good. Way better than I was expecting, actually. Nice finish. Loved it.
Can from local off licence, great Barr. Almost clear with yellow hint, lots of carbonation. Aroma of dry apple core. Taste is sweetener and apple core, dry. Drinkable.
1000ml bottle. Pours very pale white with little carbonation. Aroma is slightly meaty sour apple juice. Taste is meaty apple to start with a dusty finish.

Can (500ml). Poured a super clear watery colour with a tinge of greenish yellow and a fizzy white head which was full diminishing. Aroma was of vinegar, sulfur, hints of apple and an odd eggy smell in the back, almost like someone let one go! Taste was insanely sweet with more sugar than apple present and some unwelcome acidic/sulfury notes. This one hid its alcohol volume well, but other than that it was a disaster.

Plastic 2 Liter Bottle. Mildly intimidating. Slight sour apple aroma, somewhat skunky. Flavor is sour at the open and overly sugary in the finish. The sugar content kind of hurts my stomach. Dangerously high abv.

Oh please pinch me so I can wake up!!! It looks like someone has urinated into a filled water dispenser, though the bubbles that lift rapidly from the sides of the glass give it a post-mix flare. It smells mousy, hairy, a touch too much walnut puree and timber varnish. It tastes of unexcitement. Brashly carbonated, biting, light bodied, fizzy soda water with very little apple yet I clung on just hoping some juicy succulence might peek its welcome head out. Its husky, the alcohol, not hot, but just harsh. The clean spirit aftershock is bewildering. It is vinous and astringent on the swallow, crisp and carbonic, really bites in, but the alcohol is not shy at all. It leaves a mess on the palate, or is that your palate in a mess. This isn’t cider. It’s alcohol for football hooligans too young and daft, too bloody stupid but preyed upon by products like this. Nothing truly nasty, I survived a pint, but this is just evil. (50cL can, 31/01/08, The Beer Store Morley)
The only good thing about this beer is the price tag! Gets you hammered quick, but tasted like hell!
33cl bottle. Pours clear deep golden colour with a huge good lasting off-white head. aroma of strong grainy malt, cereals. Taste of dry grainy malt, spicy hops, boring!
Getreidiger Beginn, eher muffig hopfig. Laffe Herbe, keine besonderen Aromen. Gut wenn man am Strand verdurstet. 7/6/7/6/8/6
*Old rating, best before 07.10. Neutral-süßlich-goldenes Bier. Nicht zu tief, recht süffig-süßlich, keine Herbe.

It’s fairly dark golden with a white head. The aroma has notes of malt, light fruit and caramel. The flavor has a light sweetness and pretty much the same notes as the aroma, and the finish is slightly dry. It’s very mild, but I guess that was what it was supposed to be.

In der Optik recht dunkel und fuer ein tausend Mal gefiltertes Bier sehr ungewoehnlich, ohne jedoch besonders zu sein. Mild in der Hopfung, malzdominiert, aber im Endeffekt ganz normaler Einheitsbrei. Ganz ok.

Deep clear light amber colour with steady head and medium body. Nose of hops. Taste of mild hops, fresh grains, grass, roses and coriander green. Very easy and nice to drink with moderate malt part. Good and solid Zwiefalter but just nothing that special.
Pours gold with a white head. Spicy and piney hoppy aroma with a clean pale base. The flavor has spicy hops, grass, earthy notes, and a hint of pine.

Bottle 330ml. clear glass @ home. Clear light to medium yellow amber color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, toasted, light roasted, cardboard notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, malty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light metalic. [20101124]
White bottle. Golden color. Flowery buttery maltaroma. Malty flowery flavor with hints of apple, peach and cardboard. Hint of butter in the finish.

bottle from Schlecker-Getränkemarkt Ehingen/Donau. Clear golden colour, large white head. Malty nose. Malty, slightly fruity (lemon) with rather shy hoppy notes. A rather mild beer, but not at all boring. A beer that is sold in stylish modern bottles following the German Goldbier trend. I expected this to be a flavourless brew, which it didn’t turn out to be. Good one!
Poors light yellow with big lacing white foam head. Aroma and taste are nothing special, just another German beer. (Bad Urach 201905)
Milder, leicht herber Antrunk. Geringfügig süß, insgesamt eher trocken. Helles Malz, herber werdend. Okay. 7/9/8/8/11/8
50cl bottle. Pours clear golden colour with a mid-sized to small white head. Aroma of mild hops, grainy malt, cardboard. Taste of dry grainy malt, not too sweet, cardboard, nothing special.

Bottle. Golden yellow with a nice head. Aroma of toasted malts, straw, grains and butter - but in a good way. Taste is grainy, bready spicy and grassy. Medium carbonation. Overall this is a nice, mild, inoffensive and sessionable Export.
0,5l Flasche. Klare hellgoldene Farbe mit viel weissem festem Schaum. Frischer grassiger Duft. Getreidiger Antrunk, etwas Zitronenschale und Hopfen. Süffg, aber etwas flach.

50 bottle @ Timo A. BBE 16.06.2016. Pours clear golden color with a small head. Hay aroma, faint toffee, some clove. Flavor is buttery sweet, hay and pale malts, some very subtle grain notes. Slick palate, clean. 3313

Bottled, from Biershop Baden-Württemberg. Almost clear golden colour, dense creamy head. Fruity, mildly floral nose. Mid sweet with medium body and firm, well rounded mouthfeel. Solid fruity bready malt, mild floral hops. Mid bitter finish. Harmonious and moreish.
Gelbe Farbe. Weisser mittelporiger Schaum. Riecht etwas butterig. Sonst malzig, strohig. Im Mund malzig-süsslich. Gute Kohlensäure. Honignoten. Leichte Hopfenbittere. Bier ist gut.
500ml bottle at home. Aroma is light malty, light yeast. Bread. Appearance is clear golden with a light white foam. Taste is light sweet light bitter. Good.
a run of the mill beer. not good, not bad. just beer. really no different than most of the others.
This beer is a dark golden color. It is smooth and crisp with a bitter aftertaste. It's not that bad.
A dark golden color with a sweet aroma of caramel and malts. Smooth and malty with some sweetness to the flavor. Quite oily to the palate. A bit of a bitter finish and crisp.
A brown lager with a whitishe head. Carmel, malty and nutty aroma. The flavor was of caramel malts and a bit of hoppiness for a smooth balance. A little bitter finish.

Got this in a can at a small grocery store in Taipei. Funny name, looks very generic. Taste is nothing which is actually a one up compared to other Asian lagers which are mostly offensive. Incredibly watery which some notes of candy sugar and corn.
330ml can - thanks LP! Sweet aroma. Horrifically light. Fizzy soda water palate. Water, yes, water. Taste is papery. Some almond. Finish thin. Ug.

Clearly correct in its message, just as there is essential air, essential water, essential shelter and essential bodily functions, either pleasurable or otherwise. What is not essential is THIS beer. This brewery is coming up with some real gems.
Light straw colour. Grass vs. ammonia in the nose. Light and tasteless, slightly grassy and sour. Man, Korean beer blows.
Yellow color, light white head. Slight grassiness in the nose which also comes across in the sweet, smooth body. Bland.

Canned (bought in Taiwan). Pale yellow with fizzy looks and quickly vanishing head. Aroma of rotting vegetables. Thin, but with decent soft mouthfeel. More vegetables in a finish that hasn't seen hops on a postcard.
Bottled. Pale golden with no head. Adjunct aroma. Sweet with mellow body, and -wait - here's a flavour: burned malt. No bitterness.

Canned. A 'beer' probably aimed for the Libyan market, as a lot of the info is in Arabic writing, and Malta trades a lot with Libya. Well, it pours pale golden and has an offputting aroma of old dates. The body is really thin and mellow, and it is also very sweet and in fact utterly revolting. Poor Libyans.

Canned. This was an oddity. I saw only one can available in the whole country, no matter how hard I looked. I was fearful that it would be well out of date or something, but it seemed OK. It poured golden and somewhat hazy with small, airy head. Reasonably malty and rather sweet with near decent hop rate and some late bitternes. An average lager.
Obfita piana, mega gładka i trwała, klarowne złote rubinowe. Aromat nikły z słodowy, mleczny. Bardo gładkie, pijalne, niska goryczka ciekawe
기네스라 해야하나... 에일인데 질소충전으로 만든 맛??? 질소 위젯이 있는 것 같은데....아 청량함이없넹... 거의 에일의 기네스라 보면댐... 다시는 먹지말자...
Fles 50cl in Valetta. Licht, vlak. Wat zoetig. (10-2012).--------------------.

Bottle - 330ml. Amber body with a thin, lasting, off-white frothy head. Fair malty aroma with brown sugar, woody, and grassy hints. Its decent malty/hoppy taste carries woody notes. Ends with a robust woody finish. Not bad.

Bottle 0.33l sample at Samo Pivo Belgrade, Serbia. 20.07.2016. Small tasting with Ogi and Vlada. Pour it clear dark amber color with small white head. Aroma of amber malts. Taste kind of watery, just a pinch of malty grainy flavour and that’s it, light body, thin feel, average carbonation, bitter just a pinch finish.
Very tasty amber ale from Malta. Enjoyable to drink but it is so filling that it becomes hard to drink with a heavy meal.
Nice amber color with medium head. Light body, low bitter, medium carbonation. Nothing special happened here, but this is quite nice drink.
Can at Malta. Clear golden - white head. Amber malty. Sweet malty. Caramel. Red berries. Fruity notes. Light hoppy. Light ryebread. Raisins. OK - nothing special, but ok drinkability.

Színe mint amikor egész nap nem pisil az ember azt este ereszti ki magából a zuhany alatt, olyan sötét hogy csak na. Habja tartós de nagybuborékos , íze vas. Jól behűtve ajánlom. Kesernyés hosszú utóiz.
Clear amber color, white lasting, lacing foam head. Small bitter aroma, likewise in taste - nothing outspoken. Good drink. (Malta 201604)
500ml can from Malta. The first really good beer with nice amount of grassy hop, some malt help, medium body and co2. A little boring, but correct, quite expensive beer.
Bardzo cienkie w aromacie i smaku. Goryczka śladowa. Aromat płaski, słodowy. W smaku pustawe, lekko słodkie. Prezencja wyborna i to właściwie jedyna silna strona tego piwa.
330ml Dose. Klar und golden mit großer Schaumkrone. Leicht hopfig, ansonsten malzig. Süßlich. Leichter Körper.

Głęboko złota barwa, bardzo fajna piana, raczej klarowne. Aromat chmielu z ale raczej ziolowy i trawiasty niż cytrusowo żywiczny. Średnia goryczka, jakiś tam posmak skórki cytrusow, trawa cytrusowa, chmiel. Pijalny Ale ale bez szału.
Somewhere in Malta. Bottled 4 months ago, BB in 8 months. Raw noble hop pellet character, reminiscent of some random floral kind of British pub ales but not a good exaple at that. Pretty bad brew.

Bottle. Pours clear copper with a large, rocky off-white head, long retention with sticky lacing. Medium grainy malt, medium earthy and catty hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
Fles 33cl in Valetta. Fris, licht. Wat zoet ook wel vlak. (10-2012).-------.
caramel, hay, floral, golden, clear, frothy, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, lively,
Decent enough for style. Some light pine and decent malt complex. Pours golden amber with ok head. Bottle in Malta.

Can. Pours Light amber with an off-white head. Aroma of unmalted grain, slightly hoppy. Taste is sweetish, low bitterness. Flavors of malt, barely noticeable fruity hops. Medium body, slick texture, average carbonation. Lacks the character of a pale ale.

500ml bottle that amusingly rips off the design of Pilsner Urquell. Pours clear gold with a tall white head. Aroma is buttery, grain, skunkiness, some hop. Taste is light sweet, grain, sulphur and butter. It’s not that bad, really.
Butelka 0,5l wypite w Uzbekistanie w 2014r. Kolor jasny złoty. Aromat zbóż i cukru. Smak kwaskowy, lekko słodowe. Mocno nagazowane, piwo bez wyrazu.Podobno kiedyś było gorsze w co trudno uwierzyc.
Glass bottle 0.5l had in Samarkand. This is not a good beer. Even chilled there is def something of...so far Uzbekistan has not impressed me on the beer side...
Blonde bien dorée, carbo moyenne, petit collet de bulles moyennes. Aromes cereales, pate d’amande douce, miel. Vraiment très mince même si l’attaque carbonaté est vive.

Bottle in a restaurant in Tashkent. Different bottle to the plastic monstrosity pictured above! The Czechs can’t be too happy with having their name attached to this one. Unless most Uzbek beer felt like they had actually tried to do something with it, namely a bit of hop, but it didn’t work and it felt unbalanced, bitter in the wrong way and actually a bit hard to drink.
Bottled. Golden color, short head. Grainy aroma, buttery. Sharp bubbly taste, soapy. Crap.

Bottle @ Dutch Ratebeer Session. Aroma has wet dog, grain: a dirty smell. Clear, golden coloured with a thin, white head. Taste is bit sharp, bit oily. Horrible. Luckily it wasn’t in a big PET-bottle as in the picture but in a normal glas one.
Bottled. Clear golden coloured, white head. Smells really bad, it’s the wet dog jbrus mentioned, some grain as well. Soapy. Dry and bitter finish. Absolutely horrible.
Bottle @ DTS. Grain and olive oil in the aroma. Grainy, oily flavor, perfumed. Old hops, probably. Hint of butter in the aftertaste. Terrible.

Bottle@DTS. Horrible aroma of Uzbekian wild wet dog. Golden color, small off-white head, no lace. Soapy, grainy, metallic, nasty mouthfeel. Why did they sacrifice malts and hops to creat this awful stuff.

cloudy bright orange colour, fine head, deep spicy aroma (coriander, cloves) with notes of honey and lemon, smooth and medium-bodied with a brutal sourness/acidity, the finish is dry, long, sour and citric -interesting nose but lacking seriously of balance
