Pale blond (not cloudy). Nice fresh and spicy aroma (cloves, blackpepper...) and a faint sour note. Light mouthfeel, characterized by some sourness; citrus fruits.
Bottle from Brittany, France. Amber color, white head. Malts, caramel.. Meh
Cuivrée trouble, léger sucré et notes caramel et maltées, légère amertume mêlée dans une petite douceur. Bouteille 33cl bue en restaurant à Perros-Guirec, France, le 22/08/2017.

33cl bottle shared by hugi 11/2014. Stale bronzish pour, emanating wet autumn wood, shrub and fading caramel. Taste has the same sundued nuttiness with indefined kitchen cabinet spice, bière de garde yeasts workign against rousse malts. Dry, woody, dropping down flat with little sparkle between BdG and red ale.

Shared this beer with bastarda, Bierle and bartlebier. Brown, whited medium head, a bit hazy. At first malty and berries. Later also caramel, vanilla and a bit of wood. Full body, a bit malty-sweet finish.
Bona cervesa, es equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza, es equilibrada y sabrosa.
Appearance with copper color, cloudy liquid and low foaming. Sour and caramel aroma. Taste slightly sweet (caramel) and toasted. On the palate, acidity and bitterness.

(Keg at Põrgu, 20130703) The beer poured reddish brown and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had caramell and Belgian style yeast. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, Belgian style yeast, spices, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, spicy and bitter. Not a bad brew but somewhat confusing.
Tap (Põrgu, Tallinn) sweet malty aroma, bit of woodiness. reddy amber, tight head. slipd down superbly easily. no sign of 6%. mellow and woody. Nothing exciting, but very tasty.
At the Tap. Nice brown color, not too dark. Aromas of caramel, a bit smoky. Cloudy in mouth. Long after taste.

Tap. Clear dark amber color, with some red hue. Small white head, stays. Caramel, butter, malty and faint hops in aroma. Weak aroma. Caramel, roasted malts and fruity hops in flavor. Dry roasted malts in aftertaste.
I’m with HighGravity. A total bust, this one. Nondescript in just about every way. If you see it on the shelf and you've already rated a Chilian beer, just turn around and walk away.
Extremely pale and thin with little to no aroma. Lots of corn and pateurization flavors are heavy on the palate. Very musty. Avoid at all costs.

column2: Atlantic City, New Jersey, United States
column5: Slight maple in nose. Very light brown with weak head. Sligh sweetness in swallow only. Sharp hop bite around middle.
Pours clear, dark mahogany with a two finger, tan head. Aroma is molasses and roast. Taste is candy sugar and light raisin, moving to roast. Finish is candy sugar. Too sweet for a good Baltic porter.
11.2 oz bottle. Pours a dark nut brown with tan head of micro bubbles. Scents of dried fruit and malt. Nutty raisiny flavors and alcohol overtones don’t dominate. Well balanced. Really nice.

Pours dark, clear brown with a thin brown head. Aroma of nutty chocolate. Taste has a creamy mouthfeel along with intense roasted malt notes. Palate includes nutty notes that linger on the nose as well as a nice smokey finish.

Poured from 11.2 oz bottle into tulip glass. A 3" tan head drops slowly with nice lacing. Aroma of sweet malts, chocolate, coffee, floral hops. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy with a pleasant dry finish. Flavor of chocolate, coffee, cocoa, floral and earthy hops. Overall: extremely delicious.

500 ml bottle. Pours a dark brown with light head. Aromas of aromas of almonds, chalks, woody chocolate, and roasted malts. Flavors of sweet chocolate, praline, nougat, and dry roasted malts. Slick. Nice.

500 ml bottle. Since when is a porter Amber in color??? This is amber. Aroma shows mild toffee, toasted grain. Bread hints. Kind of a strong dark Amber lager. Kind of thin bodied. Not bad if you tell yourself it is not a porter.
Poured from bottle thanks Stacey brownish black tan head. Aroma is light roasted malt caramel yeast. Taste follows more like an amber lager than a porter.

Pitch black colored pour, with a thin tan head. Aroma is dark malts, something like burnt bark and a pancake syrup like sweetness. Quite sweet tasting with a big malty body. Flavor profile is licorice, burnt sugar and jelly beans, with molasses. This is certainly interesting, but very good.

Given that it's a rarer find, I always pick up a Polish-made Baltic Porter when I see one, and this one does not disappoint, although that being said I found it overall not as enjoyable as other examples of the style. From the bottle into a snifter, this poured a faintly reddish brown-black color with a small top of khaki foam, not as intense black as others and not completely opaque, surprising given its assertive name. Aroma of dry chocolate and licorice, with raisin and cherry fruit notes. Flavor follows with licorice-accented roasted malts and a cocoa sweetness. There's a slight boozy hint in the aroma and taste as well. No coffee notes that I could discern. Relatively light and thin on the palate but with a rounded mouthfeel. Overall this brew is good but not great, with fairly complex flavors but not as rich and textured as my personal favorite Zywiec Baltic Porter.

Aromas of macerated strawberries, raisiny, licorice, faint smoky tree branch. Brown-black with faint ruby highlights, and a mostly fading beige head. Earthy, mildly fruity, light roast. Medium bodied.
Tried at the Deepings Beer Festival. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma has hop and pine. Taste light bittersweet. Not much to it.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2015, Great British Beer Festival, London Olympia, Hammersmith Road, London, England W14 8UX. [ As Abbeydale Belfry ]. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, light to moderate hoppy, citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, pale malt, citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20150812]

Aroma: light floral hops, some citrus, light fruitiness. Appearance: clear gold, small, white, frothy head. Taste: light bitter. Palate: light bitters continue, similar to aroma, somewhat watery. Overall: OK Golden Ale, nothing too exciting though. Pint at GBBF 2015, Kensington Olympia.
At Great British Beer Festival 2015, Day 2. Clear pale golden beer with a small beige head. Fruity grape aroma, hay, floral, om bread. Kinda the same flavor, a bit dull but also flawless.

Golden ale with loose, snow white head and clear golden blonde colour. Weakish aroma, some bready malts, flowers, white pepper, apple, grass but also an unpleasant H2S odour (stale urine)... Plain pale malt sweetishness in the mouth, subdued fruitiness (more malt fruitiness than yeast fruitiness), touch bready, becoming more vegetable-like in the finish with a light amount of grassy hoppiness. This type of light and relatively uncomplicated session beers has to be absolutely flawless to delight, and unfortunately that is not the case here.
From cask. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is citrusy and crisp hoppy. Smooth fruity, crisp hoppy. Bitter, straw and slight grainy. Bitter and slight herbal dry finish.

Cask from Old Hall Inn, Whitehough, Derbyshire, £2.95/pint. Pours piss yellow (but that’s the worst thing about it) with thin but creamy white head. Strong and pleasant hoppy aroma with hint of spruce and some fruit. Opens and finishes hoppy and bitter but with well balanced tartness and some malt. Enjoyed this one.

9th July 2015 Chelmsford Beer Festival. Cask. Light haze on this pale gold beer, thin white head. Palate is light with decent fine carbonation. Light smooth pale malts. Mild floralness. Orange and orange marmalade. Touch of pith. Light dry finish. A tad dry but it feels fresh and it’s tasty.
Cask, Chelmsford Summer Beer Festival 2015. White lacing and a golden appearance. Sweet honey on aroma. Fruity yeast esters. Taste is honey, citrus, light fruits. Clean and easy but boring.
On cask at Holy Inadequate, Etruria - 8/10/14. Pours clear golden, well balanced golden session ale. Some malt to the fore, decent.

16 February 2019. At Cambrinus, Bruges. Cheers to the family! Also known as 'Brugse Babbelaar'. Pours clear golden with a big, lasting, foamy, white head; lots of lacing. Aroma of overripe banana, honey, apricot, apple peel, white bread, white sugar, yeast. Taste is medium fruity sweet, notes of banana, apricot & apple peel on a bready malty base; light to medium spicy bitterness has pepper, faint coriander, bit lemony sourish & overall yeasty. Dryish, grassy hoppy finish, yeasty & spicy. Medium body, slick-oily texture, fizzy carbonation. One of those cliché blonde ales I never get around to tasting, but here it was. Inoffensive, that's about it.
Net aan voldoende. Zacht zonder waterig te zijn maar wel licht van smaak. Zit meer in, maar prima.

Bottle consumed at Cambrinus, Brugge, Belgium, Friday 15th September 2017 with Lynn and Barry. Light gold, burnished appearance thin white rim. A dabble of sweetshop, banana, spice, good. A6 A4 T7 P3 Ov13 3.3
A gift on a visit. Cloudy amber color with a foamy white head. Nose is hevier than palate. Palate of light fruits, apples, citruses. A dry and spicy aftertaste. B@H
9/3/2010 2:09:22 PM Bottle from Beer Tempel. Murky yellow body with foamy top. Nose of fruits and citrus. Taste of fruits, citrus and malts. Quite nice actually.
Pajiza turbia, un dedo de espuma. Aroma poco marcado. Cuerpo medio carbonatacion baja. Sabor inicial dulce, caramelo y afrutado para evolucionr hacia un final bastante amargo que sube al paladar.
At cafe gambrinus. Pours rather clear blonde good white head. Smell is. Sweet, malty. Taste is yeasty, bit sweet, malty. Kinda blank though. Ok

At my home. Clear blond colored beer with large diminishing white head and lots of carbonation. Fruited hopped aroma. Medium slightly sparkling palate. Finish is sweet fruited ending a bit bitter dry.

Tasted at the beach in 2005 and apparently this is still around. Typical outdoors café blonde, golden coloured, hazy under a snow white head; malt sweet, yeasty with some estery fruitiness, orange touch, somewhat thin, yeasty finish with grassy hops, dryish. Stereotypical, on the bland side and forgettable but still, quite balanced and quenching.

13/VIII/13 - 33cl bottle from Rotsaert (Zedelgem) @ home - BB: 13/II/14 (2013-762) Clear light orange beer, big creamy white head, stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: very sweet and sugary, lots of banana, some alcohol, that’s about it. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: sweet sugary start, almonds and marzipan, orange peel, some citrus, soft bitterness. Aftertaste: pretty dry and bitter, little herbal, sweet banana touch, but quite a bitter ending with some alcohol.

Misty gold, tall white frothy head. Aroma: malt, bread, fruity yeast, straw, some hop. Light to medium body. Soft palate. Taste: light sweet, malty, fruity, straw, grassy hop bitterness. Long hoppy aftertaste. Very drinkable
Flasche bei Marktkauf. Leicht trüb, gelb, viel Schaum. Aroma: Malz, Getreide, etwas Gras, Hauch Karamell. Geschmack: Malz, Hopfen, wohl auch Hefe. Süßlich. Bitter.

the aroma is malty and floral with hints of grain, buckwheat, hay and some herbs... the taste: malty and floral with notes of grain, straw, dry leaves and some grasses... the aftertaste: bitter and dry...
Leicht trübes gelb schaum is Ok, malzig getreidig in Geruch und Geschmack dazu leicht süsslich muffig, nicht meins
0,5l Bügelflasche. Dunkles klares Bier. Heller fester Schaum. Getreide Geruch. Honigantrunk. Getreide.
Tap in a pizzeria in memmelsdorf - served in a stone mug. refreshing landbier, rather high in carbonation. grainy. okay.
Bottle imported by mum and dad and shared with JMD on board Fridtjofen 30.06.18. Clear golden. Bright white head. Aroma and taste of pilsner malt and fresh grass. Good drinkability.
0,5 flaske med vippekork, delt med skibsrederen, på fordekket i sommervarmen: klar gylden med ok skum. Mild aroma og smak med urter, gress og høy. Tørr, avrundet bitterhed i afslutningen.
Fles 50cl thuis. Fris, licht kruidig. Wel wat vlak. (11-2012).------------.

Bottle from a supermarket near Koln, Germany. The beer is light hazy yellow colored and has a large and stable white foam, with good carbonation. The aroma is malty, with notes of grass, hay, light citrus, bread, yeast and a little honey. The taste is starts sweet with malts and honey, and goes to light bitter with hay, grass and bread. The finish is light bitter with some honey notes and is further a little watery.

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: F: medium, white, quickly diminishing. C: blonde, hazy. A: wheat, light orange, bit banana, yeasty, fruity. T: wheat, vaguely fruity, orange peels, bit spicy, medium body and lower carbonation, nothing really tasty or memorable for me, 33cl bottle from Beerwulf webshop.

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Bouteille 33cl @ Niamey Carft beer tasting at Villa Abdou, merci Rémi. BB 01/2020. Dorée sur léger voile, col blanc. Arôme classique mettant en avant le bouquet de grains et un accompagnement de fins esters - qcq pointes d'épices et léger effet agrumes. Palais sur effervescence moyenne voire haute qui renforce l'effet d'ester de banane en lieu d''apporter l'attende d'épaisseur de bouche. Le tout plus proche d'une weisse allemande que belge - impression de citron vert sur la fin et pointe d'épice.

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: July 2018. 330ml dark bottle, unfiltered, from BeerWulf - part of the World Cup Beers package. 6%. Nice wheat beer. I like this. Classic. Traditional. Tastes if wheat with a pleasing sweetness.

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Robe jaune pale. Peu d'effervescence, pas de mousse, peu de saveurs et une faible longueur. Pas terrible.

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Thin n ugly. Bit winery which does not work in slightest, missus didn’t like it despite the light Amber pour...

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Blanche couleur paille, semi-translucide et d’un jaune tout juste troublé. À l’oeil, un peu de doré. Du citron, de l’orange et des épices. On la sent un peu poivrée, et on distingue même du fromage à croûte lavée (du brie, par exemple). Extrêmement douce et toute en agrumes, effervescence quasi nulle, assez ronde en bouche. Un peu de houblon pour la forme. Alcool dissimulé, saveur de jus de poire en finale. Aqueuse et totalement neutre. Pas mauvaise et assez originale ; par contre elle ne conquiert pas facilement le buveur, surtout de par son absence d’effervescence et ses saveurs correctes sans plus.

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Bottle, 75cl corked, courtesy of Pinball. It pours a hazy, yellowish-golden body with a rather small, off-white head. The aroma is quite spiced, with orange and some lemon, low on maltyness. Spiced, orangey and lemony flavor with some flowery notes. Medium body, quite effervescent. Bitter, flowery finish. A nice-tasting one, but there’s nothing special about it either. 100814

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Okay yellow body and a modest pillow of head. Very faint aroma of lemon and grain. The taste is a hint of citrus with a very perfume-like hop finish. Not quite detergent but feels cloying. Not my favourite wit.

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma of grain and cookie spices. Sweet and rather bland malty flavour

column1: La Rouget de Lisle La Marseillaise
column5: Bottle. Aroma of wheat and barley malt with some fruit and a discrete sniff of citrus. Unclear yellow colour with small white head. Wheat malt flavour with some flowers and citrus. Nice and refreshing. Rich carbonation.

500 ml bottle. BB Jun/16. Thanks to Timo A! Clear yellow golden color with a small white head. Dry grassy hops and mild bitterness in the aroma. Grassy hops, moderate bitterness and dry grainy maltiness in the flavor. Fresh.

How: Bottle. Where: From omhper, thanks! Appearance: Dark golden colour with a large white head. Aroma: Malt, bread, grass, hay. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Malt, citrus, a bit bitter, grass, hay.

Bottle thanks to Per. Clear golden beer with a small offwhite head. Malty bready aroma, caramel, biscuits, grapes, some grass. Malty bready flavor, grassy, hay, floral, some citrus and biscuits. Quite drinkable well balanced beer.

Bottled, from Biershop Baden-Württemberg. Clear pale golden, mid sized firm head. Mild grassy nose. Dry with light-medium body and firm, crisp mouthfeel. Rich but mild grassy hops, crisp bready malt. Balanced bitter finish. Harmonious and moreish.
* Old rating. Thanks to kevnic2008 for this bottle. Best before Sep 10. Malty-grainy, slightly bitter Pils. Smooth, fresh, easy to drink, crisp and round, but not too deep.

It’s yellow-golden with a firm, white head. The aroma has notes of hops, straw, flowers and fruit. The flavor has a light sweetness and pleasant and refreshing notes of malt, fruit, flower and straw. The finish is slightly dry and slightly bitter.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittler Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig herb, grasig, getreidig. Geschmack herb, grasig, minimaler würziger Abgang.

Die Herren aus Zwiefalten bieten neben dem Export auch ein sehr feines, recht mildes, aber im Nachgeschmack beeindruckendes Pilsner, das zu überzeugen weiß. Malz, etwas Hopfen und schon erhält man ein sehr trinkbares, zuweilen feines, Pils.

Clear light golden colour with steady head and medium body. Nose of mild hops. Taste of medium bitter hops, ripe grains, citrus fruits, grass and cloves. Very easy to drink and perfect for a warm day or / and when you are thirsty.
Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma of straw, malts, grassy hops, light fruity. Flavour is light sweet, malty, grassy, light fruity like sour green apple skin, medium bitter finish.

Originally rated June 2005. This one used to be brewed by Silvercreek Brewery in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia. Now it is owned by Sleeman. This is part of the value brands (cheap shit) at The Beer Store in Ontario. The colour is pale yellow. Hardly no head, and there is no lacing. The mild aroma I get from this beer is sweet malt. So is the taste. Slight grain finish. A very poor brew, but nothing offensive in this one. Great for a cheap evening... comes in a 15 pack only.

341ml bottle sample. Ahhhh the wolf. I remember drinking this quite a bit in my younger days, particularly because you could get it in 18 packs, quantity over quality for this beast. Pours a golden yellow. Aroma and taste is of grains and corn. Your typical macro that should only be had when there is no other option, and must be drank ice cold while cutting the lawn.

It’s a good thing they don’t carbonate and bottle that canine pee anymore. I remember buying a case of 24 of that some years ago, thinking I’d be getting another nice craft beer. What a disappointment. I couldn’t give it a real rating now but I remember it being thin and acid-like. Blechhh!!!

Not bad an ok beer for the price. It Is prone to be very skunky. This is probably because it sits around the beer store along time before being bought. If you get a good batch it’s a nice refreshing beer. Sleeman should really put expiration dates on the box, to prevent the beer store from selling old product

Bottle- Another " I want a new ratings" purchase. 18 bottles in a pack, with the expectation of only drinking 1. Sparkling gold pour with a fizzy white head that lasts a short while. Ok aroma of some faint hops and then the corn takes over. Some malt also present in the aroma. FLavours are slightly hoppy with mainly sweet bready malt lasting through the finish. Not really my gig.
Swillfest ’04: Pale colour. Malty, bready aroma with a hint of lime. Vaguely malty palate, a little wet. Relatively clean.

Nice, clean malty aroma with some light mineral nose. Gold, white head, that did not lasted to long. Arctic Wolf had strange wet bitterness, could be fault of malt ? In this case aroma promises more than flavour can give.

(Bottle) I do not know if people buy this? I bought a case in Ottawa and blew the dust off - another less than exceptional Sleeman beers was my guess - I was right on. Pours a medium white head and a light golden body. Aroma of cheap American Standard. Flavours of very little other than a company's desire to offer more products than they can afford to host. Really, really boring. Finishes with my desire to fill the bottles with water and glue-gun the box re-shut and return it to the place I got it. 18 beers are a lot... 18 crap beers are projectiles! I see you coming down my street... and out my window the remainder of this beer goes!
Your average nothing special lager. There is nothing distinguishing about it other then it comes in an 18 pack it's just odd.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured into a pint glass, the appearance was a semi-dark amber color with a thin white foamy cap. Messy clingy white lace. The aroma had a butterscotch to caramel to toffee malty sweetness up front with a delicate grassy hop bitterness underneath. The flavor leans to the sweet malty side. Hop bitterness is once again, far underneath. Super malty aftertaste. Quick malty dry finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. Overall, adequate amber ale with a respectable sort of cleanliness all around. I don’t want to knock this too much. But I often find other amber ales much more flavor worthy.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the Algonquin. Nose is buttery w. some caramel malt. Butterscotch continues into the flavor with a nice, refreshing fruitiness. A hint of nutmeg in the finish.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours with an amber body with gold notes, topped by a medium thick head with a good amount of lace left behind. Well balanced aroma with a slightly sweet yet bitter character. Slightly fruity background. Slightly sweet hoppy flavor with a good malt balance. The finish is slightly hoppy and bitter. Medium bodied and slightly dry.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured into an English pint glass, the appearance was a soft mildly burnt yellow to off-white color with a semi-foamy white head. Soapy stringy lace. The aroma reaches at some citrus and floral notes faintly flowing over some earthy tones and then a nice malt backbone. The flavor leans towards the malt backbone and ends up embracing a nice balance with the citrus and floral hoppy notes. Earthiness seems to be a lot fainter in this department. Crisp clean malty to lightly hopped aftertaste rolling into the finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a good sessionability about it. Good carbonation. ABV felt appropriate. Overall, pretty good English pale ale worthy of coming back to.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub with a 5oz sample. Mildly floral hoppiness in the nose, but very faint. Maybe a bit of citrus notes are also presesnt. Aroma needs to stand out more. Transparent yellow/blonde color with a whitish head. Slight floral/peppert hops to start, turning a bit maltier and somewhat milky to finish. Nice mouthfeel, crisp and clean. Refreshing for the style.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Mousse fugace. Bière trouble. Bonne présence du houblon. Corps bien présent. Une bonne bière en soi.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Aroma:caramel and butter... Appearance:Hazy orange,small head... Flavor:Caramel and hopy...

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: April 2004. Very fresh malt with citrusy qualities, very fresh. Very fresh malt with butterscotch notes and floral hops in after taste and caramel. Medium bodied.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Sweet, fruity malt playing off of the citrus and pine hoppiness...Earth tones competently links it all together and even a few litchis bud every once in a while...Stretching its purpose of drinkability further to the realms of pleasant tastings...

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: (Draught) Lightly carbonated, mellow golden with a thin, white head. Fresh malt nose with perfumy hops. Creamy, hoppy flavour. Very impressed. Nice and sweet vanilla. SO DRINKABLE!

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Fresh malt aroma but not much hop nose. Smells a bit like a nice mash. Clear gold coloured with nice white head that recedes to cover. Nice hoppy flavour with a toasty malt base. Good carbonation with medium body. Straight forward, very well done and enjoyable to drink. On tap at the brewery.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours with a slightly cloudy golden body topped by a medium thick white head with a good amount of lace. Slightly sweet malt aroma with a good hop balance. Sweet and malty flavor quickly followed by a bitter hoppiness. Light to medium bodied and dry.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Decent head, medium clear straw color; I'm reminded of Michelob. Very pleasant, sweet, slightly piney, some hops, balanced, better than a typical American Standard, but real beer lovers can skip this; Davidson always has something better.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bottle. Pours reddish brown with small foamy light beige head, caramel aroma, high carbonation, medium bitter taste with molasses, plum and a bit of metallic twang, thin body, medium finish. Not bad, but there is strange metallic taste.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Called BRN, is this the same? Pours clear medium brown, light brown head. Aroma is light toffee. Tastell is toffee, a little nuts, a bit of hops. Medium mouthfeel. Okay, nothing special.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: This was poured into a becher pint glass. The appearance was a glossy burnt amber almost close to a brown color. Sly transparency weaves about. Finger’s worth of white foamy head roamed here and there. Semi-sticky lacing, kinda messy. The aroma starts off with the normal qualities of an English Brown ale, sweet toffee rich to nutty character. The flavor leans sweet and smooth. More toffee than expected, but decent. Sly crisp sweet nutty to toffee aftertaste. Sweet wet finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a fantastic sessionability about it. Carbonation seems to barely hit. Just really moves really nicely on my tongue. Overall, just a tad lighter in color than expected, but everything else is right on for the style.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown with a thin ring of foam around the glass. Aromas of slight wet dog, citrus. Crisp cola flavor. Slight citrus. Mild hop presence. Not a very sturdy brown ale. Not much distinctive character. Not very memorable.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bottle. Poured a clear brown with a slight reddish hue and a very slight thin fizzy white head. Floral nutty aroma and flavor with a medium mouthfeel and lively carbonation. A slight astringent taste to it. A sessionable Ale.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours deep mahogany into a shaker. White head with little retention recedes to skim surface. Dark caramel and candy corn aromas. Soft with dark caramel and toffee upfront turning to bitter earth in the lasting finish.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Caramelized malty aroma and flavor. A little syrupy but not too much. Other than the malty not too much else going on here, but does have a full body. Little bit of odd home brew like taste. But an ok brown. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: A bit boring brown and bland. Yeah it is true to style. On tap at lager house.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: A decent brown. Pours a very nice deep red color with white head. Smells of maple syrup and a bit of chocolate. Taste is similar, not the most interesting but smooth and well balanced. Had on tap in Saratoga.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft in Saratoga Springs. Standard brow pour. A bit overly roasted + nutty average at best.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours with a deep golden color with amber undertones topped by a thin white head with a good amount of lace. Slightly sweet and malty aroma with a touch of fruit. Slightly sweet and fruity hop flavor with a good malt balance. medium bodied and relatively smooth.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Slightly lower quality than the IPA which it most resembles, this is intensely fruity and sweet, very clean and bright, with strong apricot/peach and vanilla flavors, but marred a bit by a thin body and weak nose. Still worth trying for sure.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured into a mug, the appearance had an amber color with a thin white foamy head that dissipated immediately. Concave sliding lace. The aroma had some toast, nuts, caramel and toffee. The flavor leaned towards the sweet side flowing over some grassy hops trying to provide some bittering but ultimately failing, I’m okay with that. Rich toasty to nutty sweet aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Mild carbonation. ABV felt fine. Overall, good Irish red ale worthy of more pours.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured an amber red color with aromas of caramel, malt and some light grain. Flavors are caramel and malt with some light grass and burntness. Decent overall for a red ale.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Tap Dinosaur BBQ Troy. Pours reddish amber with light toffee nose. Tastes lightly sweet. Of caramel, malt, medicinal, earth, and and some piney hops.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Another tick courtesy of that hotel bar. Thank god the keg of Saratoga IPA finally kicked, It had to be like half a year on. So I am sure this wil be on 9 months from now when by doucher boss schedules last minute 3 hr meetings. Nevermind it takes me 8-9 hr round trip windshield time. I wonder if my boss once worked for amtrak or someother government subsidied RR not named Conrail. Great productivity/ cost ratio. Fuck stick. Pours amber with copper edges. The off white head disipates like the bald skull of me boss. Nose of toast and caramel. Taste is slightly sweet but otherwise uninteresting. Body is medium.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Ok smell nice color not a whole lot going on taste wise. Finishes like it began drinkable but a little bland ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft. On st. Paddys day. Brown bronze color. Hop and malt balance with a nutty backbone. Nothing special ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft from Saratoga. Red brown pour. White head. Easy drinkin ambery malts with light hop finish.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft. Pours light copper with an off white head. Light sweet toffee malty aroma with some toasty malts. The flavor has toffee, toast, just a tiny hint of diacetyl, and low bitterness. Not bad.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Very solid Irish Red. Pours a nice reddish brown. Taste is very well balanced with just enough bitterness. Bought a growler of it after getting it in the sampler

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the Charlton Tavern. Pours clear red and orange with a 1-finger beige head. Aromas of fruity and doughy malt. Berry and caramel malt flavor, with some grass present. Pretty boring. [710]

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured into a pint glass, the appearance was a semi-dark brown color with a thin off white cap of a head. Sly lace. The aroma took an English yeast to create some butterscotch, sweet bread, caramel and toffee tones rolling over a delicate chocolate malt. Super subtle roast. The flavor chose the malty sweet side of those previously mentioned aromas. Just a touch of acceptable diacetyl touching down in the aftertaste and runs into the finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Decent carbonation. ABV felt fine. Overall, as an English porter it works. I would have again.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured from a tap. Dark brown color, nice medium creamy off white head. Slight sour milk and malt aroma. Medium body with a malt and mineral flavor with a light finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft @ brewpub. Color is dark brown, almost black. Comes with a light brown head that sticks around. Aroma is burnt coffee and slight diacetyl, which is not too bad for the style; butterscotch works. Has a watery yet dry feel to it, like an Irish Stout. Flavor has a very dry ashy aspect. There is some diacetyl as well, very light.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: 10 oz. pour at the source. Poured dark brown with a finger of creamy beige head. Good amount of lace. Aroma of milk chocolate, roasted malt, light coffee and oatmeal. Lightly sweet flavor. Medium bodied and silky smooth on the tongue. Dry finish.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Dark brown pour with a medium creamy tan head. Aroma of coffee, vanilla, faint roasted malt and bitter chocolate. Medium body with a nice creamy slightly sweet finish.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured from a tap. Dark brown color, medium creamy off white head. Not much of an aroma. Medium body with a light bitter peppery malt flavor and a light finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Bark’s Beer Cave (Plattsburgh, NY). Arôme: Légère odeur de chocolat et de céréale grillée. Apparence: La couleur est noire. Présence d’un mince col beige mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréale grillée avec une pointe de chocolat et de caramel. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de torréfaction en arrière goût. (Rating #5067)

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: [Backlog 2013.] Draft at Pony with Linh. Pours a deep blackish brown body with nice off white head. Aroma is deep roast, roasted malt and bitter cocoa. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of roast, light coffee, bitter chocolate and oat.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On nitro tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a thick foamy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, lactose, light chocolate. Flavor of roasted malt, light char/burnt malt, bitter chocolate. This is a decent oatmeal stout, drinkable but nothing special. Smooth nitro mouthfeel. 6/4/7/4/14 (3.5/5)

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Served a deep dark brown with a hint of ruby. A Lasting tight head graces the top of the sampler glass. To the nose it is sweet chocolate, the olfactory equivalent of a tootsie roll. Smooth and light on the tongue, this beer quickly wins me over with its subtle maltiness and subdued hops. An easy choice for a winter session beer. Has a pleasant roasty character without the burnt or bitter notes characteristic of some other examples of the style. On tap at the brewpub in Glens Falls.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draught poured as part of sampler at the brewpub. Poured black with a thick off white head. Malty richness in the flavor with caramel notes. Thick, creamy head with a solid bodied beer. Significant contrast to the other brews at this brewery.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: I really liked this one. Pours a deep brown with a medium tan head to it. Taste is very malty - chocolate, cocoa. Finishes smooth and dry. Pretty thick. Very good stout.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Growler. Pours dark red, dark brown in the glass, with a small tan head. Aromas of coffee, raisin, chocolate and some cherry, and mildly tart fruit. The flavor is slightly bitter cocoa and earthy bitterness, sweet chocolate, and mocha. Creamy, with low carbonation and a dry finish. Pretty good. [818]

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: 10 oz. pour at the source. Poured a clear amber/brown with a thin tan head. Sweet caramel malt aroma with hints of vanilla and fruit. Flavor is sweet, but not as much as you would expect for the style. Body is medium. Not bad, but not quite what I was expecting either.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Seeing the last review for this can make one apprehensive, but after pouring into a thistle, a nice looking, smelling and flavorful Scotch ale shows its favor upon my palate. Here’s the rest: The appearance was a dark chestnut red to ruddy brown color with a sly transparency about it. Finger’s worth of white foamy head dissipates adequately. The aroma blends black tea to a subtle smoke and sly sweet peat. Super subtle toffee, caramel and nuts play far underneath. Light raisin and some red delicious apples smooth out the aroma. The flavor takes all of the previously mentioned aromas and lets the dry woodiness come across nicely. I will mention that that as it warms, the black tea level seems to be a bit higher than expected. Dry sweet woody aftertaste and finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a great sessionability about it. Carbonation feels good and low. Some stickiness hits but acceptable. Overall, very nice scotch ale/wee heavy that I would have again despite a stronger black tea level flavor hits more than expected.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bomber shared at a tasting. As "Scot." Clear amber, thin fizzy tan head, good retention. Aroma of toffee, toasted malt, hints of smoke. The taste is toasted malt, dark fruits, raisin. Thin bodied, high carbonation.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: 22 oz. bottle. Pours a clear deep red with a thin tan head that lasted through the second sip and left scant lace. Pleasant aroma of sweet malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet malt and caramel with some mild peat and a bit of resinous pine. Mild bitterness at the finish. Slight booziness towards the finish as well. Fairly silky on the palate. No problems.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: A - Pours a deep, but still slightly clear red-brown color with a bit of off-white head. The head faded fairly quickly to a ring around the glass and left some lace behind. S - Aroma is full of sweet caramel malts and some sweet dark fruits. There is also just a touch of vanilla and oak. T - Starts off with some sweet dark fruit flavors and rich caramel malts. Little bit of vanilla notes in the background. Through the middle some oak flavor alongside just a touch of hops come through. The finish is a mix of the sweet malt and fruit flavors and just a touch of oak and booze that linger. M - Medium bodied and moderate-low carbonation. Feels a touch thick and syrupy with just a hint of a oily finish, but fairly clean. Could use a touch more carbonation. D - Very drinkable. The 9+%abv here stays very well hidden and the beer is very smooth. Could use a bit more punch in the flavor and the nose, but otherwise a pretty tasty beer.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Had on tap at Dinosaur BBQ. Pours a real deep brown with hints of red. Taste is pretty bitter, with hints of scotch and alcohol. Full-bodied and rich, this one is hard to suck down. Solid beer though, pretty complex, a good sipper.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draught. Pours a dark copper color with a fine tan head. Aromas of sweet fruit and caramel. Flavor is slightly bitter pine, citrus, and slight alcohol. Alcohol is well-hidden! Creamy mouthfeel. Not bad.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Draft @ the brewpub. Color is dark brown but the beer is completely clear. Has a strong head. Aroma has lots of diacetyl but it is not too bad, doable for the style. The vanilla and butterscotch go well with the earth-soil aspects. Flavor has less diacetyl, some mineral and a very nice burnt aspect to round it off. I love the burnt aspect but everything else is just not that special. Easy to drink otherwise.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: &#40draft&#41 Crystal clear amber body with tan head. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, strawberry/melon, light medicinal. Taste is moderately sweet, strawberry, caramel, some medicinal, light earthy. Medium body, light stickiness.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear brown with a thin white head. Aromas of malt, toast, caramel, raisins, and maybe even a hint of brown sugar. Flavor is sweet and malty. Ends sweet and malty with a light bitterness.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: on tap-pours a creamy offwhite head that laces with yellow color. Aroma is musty, creamy malt, sweet-rock candy. Taste is musty, creamy malt. OK carbonation. Sipping, occasional.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours with a pale golden body topped by a thick white head with lots of lace hugging the glass. Spicy, yeasty malt aroma with a slight bitterness. Bitter, yeasty flavor with a spicy lemon background. Full bodied and slightly dry.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Large, very long-lasting white head tops a light straw-yellow (macro) colored head; lady near me wondered if I was drinking a Coors light and I just glared at her. Yeasty, lemony nose leads to a tobacco/pepper overtoned sweet, smooth, fruity (sour apples) body. Very very smooth; my server told me it was on nitro, horrors! But it's very good, regardless. Alcohol really not all that evident except for the pepperiness.
this is one of the best ESBs. Those charming english malts shine with a great sweet maltiness. A light lingering hop bitterness in the finish. Awesome brew, love this one.
Draught at the brewpub. Pours copper with a tan head. Smells of caramel, lightly rosey, earthy. Tastes earthy and caramelly with some peppery hints on the finish.

Dark Amber in coloration, with a thin almost nonexistant head. Prominant notes of malt and hops. The hoppiness isn’t overpowering and at times it seems like there could be a little more flavor. However this is a good session beer.

Tap at the brewpub. Deep amber colour with a thin tight white head. Nice caramel malt aroma, rich toastiness and an earthy malt character with light citrus notes on top. Lightly grassy with a fairly fresh dry hop character. Flavour is good, earthy and quite lean. Decent body and an earthy hop and minerally finish. Slightly nutty.

Deep yellow gold, tiny white head with faint lacing, very clear. Soapy orangey and earthy adequate hops give a fair dry feeling. Support malt lacking, enhancing the Americanized grapefruity hop feel, herbal and with honest bitterness, but finishing a bit short. Astringence lasting, citric and thankfully not acid. Active carbonation. Heavily filtered and thinned out, but it remains one of my favourites at Northampton.
Nice, but light, bitter. Is it really an ESB? Sure. Not bad from a small brewery.

Has nice amber color and a sweet malt smell. Taste is also pretty malty with some spice(?) flavor and finishes with a mild bitterness. Overall I thought this was the holiday special, but still a pretty good beer. One of the better from this brewery.

Deep amber brown body with a thin head and good lace. SLightly sweet and buttery hop aroma with a slight fruitiness. Sweet fruity hop flavor with a buttery undertone and a hoppy finish. Dry and medium to full bodied.

Dark copper in color. Hops evident in the nose but not overpowering. They were about the same in the taste.: very evident, but a tad less prevalent than what I would like in an ESB. Fairly heavy on the malts, but not really sweet at all. Overall, quite good!
Shared a sampler that had this in it. It had a brown color with a big fruity flavor. Slightly on the watery side.
On tap at the brewpub. Very dark brown color with a big ol’ pile of blackberries spraying out at you like some FLAVORBLAST candy commercial.

Dark ruby brown. Roasted/burnt grain nose. Starts roasty and a litlle on the sweet side, coffee, faint chocolate, thin light body, finishing with a surge of blackberry. Very subtle fruit, which is nice...I wish this had some more body to it, then it would be excellent.

Has a very dark brown color and a slightly smoke/roasted smell. Taste was a bit watery, but was smoked/malts/nut and finishes with a slight blackberry flavor. Overall a pretty good porter, but it was a little watery.

Clear red-brown body with beige head. Aroma is blackberry and light nutty. Taste is definitely blackberry, some nutty, some cola, the result of which is something that bears a passing resemblance to a blackberry soda. Light-medium body, light tartness.

Full bodied and rich. A very good Porter. The blackberries were however non-evident. I had to ask if I had gotten the right one. The waitress said that they were subtle, but I think a little too subtle. Overall, still a good quaff. Re-rate (02-04): Ahhh, there were Notes of Blackberries in the nose and the taste this time. Also a good hit of roastiness to the nose. The taste of them, while not overly strong had an almost syrupy feel to it. There were also notes of roastiness and coffee to the taste.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear deep amber brown with a creamy off white head that lasts throughout the beer. Aroma has notes of roasted malts, sweet dark grains and a bit of butterscotch. Flavor has a bit of roasted malts but also an off putting red fruit and butterscotch combination.
(Draught) Pours a black body with no head. Aroma of coffee. This was the worst stout I have ever had. It tasted like they poured the mornings old coffee into a bud light

(Draught) Pours a black body with a medium creamy khaki head. Aroma of roasted malt, lactose, and coffee. Flavor of roasted malt, lightly charred toasted bread, coffee, and some dark baking chocolate.

Date: February 23, 2009 Mode: Draft, Nitro Source: Brewpub, Bricktown Appearance: black, creamy nitro head, layers upon layers of solid lace Aroma: light roasted aroma Body: creamy nitro body thins out once the nitro subsides Flavor: light roasted malt flavor, hint of bitter dark chocolate is the only bitterness, touch of dirty line funk in the finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 6/20 Rating: 2/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: 4
Although the flavor and aroma of this stout are not bad...its way too watery. This throws off the overall beer.
On tap in Norman, muddy brown color with no head. Aroma and flavor of mild roasted malt and coffee.

Deep dark brown in colour with a nice nitrogenated light brown head that tops the beer. Aroma of roasted malt, alcohol, cherries and a light coffee. Light-bodied; Candy sweetness with some tartness & lactic qualities soon following. Aftertaste shows a sweet and bitter flavour at once. Overall, interesting - not typical for the style, but nice to try! I sampled this beer from draught at the brewpub in Bricktown, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma on 13-December-2005.

Sooner stout pours opaque black with a tan head. Has a roasted nut, grainy smell. Medium bodied with very little carbonation. Nice lacing even though the head fades quickly. The dark roasted malt flavor was decent, pretty straight forward stout here. A 4% abv and good drinkability makes this a nice session brew. 2003
this is a poor excuse for a stout. i only had a sample glass of this stuff waiting for a burger so im only glad i didnt pay for it.

(Tap) Pours black with a small, fading head. Doesn’t taste much like a stout, probably because of the weak mouthfeel. Interesting character, with a unique blend of malts. It wasn’t great, but it wasn’t too bad. Not something I would drink on a regular basis.
on tap-pours a thin tan head and copper color. Aroma is dark malt-some cocoa. Taste is dark malt-some cocoa, some earthy/citrus hops.
Pretty weak porter...watery with little roasted aroma. Flavor doesn’t have much in the way of coffee/roasted/dark chocolate components. Mouthfeel is thin.

[Tap] Sample notes from May 2009. Pours a dark amber color with an off-white head. Sweet and malty aroma. Muted dark malt flavoring. Little in the way of hops. Thin mouthfeel. Tastes similar to their stout. I am convinced Coach’s uses either a light or dark malt base for every beer that they make... with no variations.

Chocolatey pour, big head and lace. No carb, nitrous tap? Nice and sweet, but very little malt for a porter, no wood or smoke flavor. Some lemon and soda-type flavor. Very strange, doesn’t really taste like a porter, no carbonation at all.
Draft@ Coaches Norman, Ok. Dark brown with a tan head. Mild roasty, nutty aroma. Thin mouthfeel. Soggy sour dark wheat bread flavor with not much else. What the fuck?

Date: February 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear dark brown with ruby edges, fine tan head, streaks of drippy lace Aroma: rich chocolate aroma, nice dark caramel sweetness enrichens the chocolate Body: body is a bit watery Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, caramel sweetness is kept pretty dry by a light earthyness, hint of bitterness in the finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

Sample from growler provided by the brewer: pours dark cola brown with a medium tan head. Light smokiness in the aroma; yes, much like bacon grease. Body is pretty thin. Flavor is lightly smokey: light bacon and short on hops. Thin and watery.

Draught-OKC Bricktown. Pours black with brown hints and a small foamy tan head. Aroma is smoked bacon grease, roasted malt (grain) and yeast (leather). Flavor is horse blanket, sweat and leathery yeast, no sweetness, bitterness or acidity, chocolate and caramel notes. Dark bodied and creamy palate.

Dark pour with medium head, large bubbles in the head. This has no distiguishable aroma, with a taste like a very bland Guinness (in fact this is like a bland version of the Sooner Stout). There is a subtle taste of hops, but it comes off as a bad impersonation. Palate is left feeling smooth. Later, a more roasted caramel taste shows up, and it must have hit the right temperature because when colder, this beer has close to nothing. Far too think of a palate... lack of flavor. Poor effort.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle, Downtown Spirits. Dark thick black colour, off white head. I suppose this was a fairly standard imperial stout, lots of thick roasty flavours, not overly hoppy on this occasion. Felt rounded more than aggressively bitter or boozy. Good, just somehow missing the extra bit of excitement.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle thanks to duchammer: The label we drank had a double decker bus on it. The name gives it some bonus appeal. Poured a dark brown with red edges and tan head. Aroma and taste is roasted malt, but falls a bit flat.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: 200th rater! I actually don’t know when this was brewed cause I don’t see any info on annual release. Whatevs. Black beer with ghost white lacing. Aroma is dry, ashy malt that’s acidic. Flavor is a bit flabby and light... And weak stout. I’m actually surprised this is an Impy Stout. Just a bit too acidic and weak.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: "A spot purchase in Seattle that I might have avoided if I’d looked it up. I was encouraged that so many of the off reviews are years old, and at first this had a nice sweet milk chocolate roasted coffee aroma, and looks great. Lower abv so a less thick body was expected. The giant white chunks were a turnoff though, as was the lactic quality that did not belong, and only grew as the beer warmed. It’s not a milk stout and wouldn’t have been a great example if that style either. A beer that could have been quite good but it seems this one has a long history of quality control issues. Still has its good points, but way under average for the style."

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle from QFC, Seattle Black color with small beige head. Nice mild aroma, roasted malt, fire oven bread. It has smooth mouthfeel; roasted malt flavor and some coffee, but not ashy luckily, with some lactose; correct bitterness. Not exciting, but solid.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle - Roast malts and chocolate with some dark fruit. Jet black with a rich beige head. Chocolate and dried dark fruits. A long finish with a big bitterness.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle share taster. Dark brown, no cap. Aroma of lactose, chocolate, raisin, and booze. Taste is sour. Not bad.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: This Russian Imperial is the best value that there is. At $4.79 for a 22 Oz. I defy anyone to find a better deal. This is a very good imperial russian stout. The price is right, and it is overall a very good tasting stout.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle. Pours a near black color with a small tan head on it. Nose is a little roasty with some nice chocolate coming through, though subtly. Taste is chocolatey and slightly sweet with just a little roasting in there. Good brew and really glad I found it.

column1: Hale's Pikop Andropovs Rushin Imperial Stout
column5: On tap at Last Drop. Pours black with two finger head. Smell ashy chocolate roast. Taste more creamy and fruity, ashy finish. Decent.
Jasna herbata ze szczyptą opalizacji. Piana słaba. W aromacie tylko słód. Trochę utlenione w kierunku miodowym. W smaku to utlenienie też obecne. Jakaś dziwna paloność w posmaku. Niesmaczne
Barwa ciemnozlota, piana nikla. W aromacie sporo miodu i slod. Aromat miodu nie przeszkadza a wrecz mozna pomylic z piwem miodowym. W smaku wodniste z zerowa goryczka. W odczuciu gladkie.
Barwa złota, piwo opalizujące. Piana biała, mało trwała. Aromat mało intensywny, czerwone jabłko i nikłe nuty słodowe. W smaku słodowa słodycz, posmak ziołowy chmielu, goryczka średnio niska.
Aromat trochę miodowy i jakby... cynamonowy? Słodki, ale przyjemny. W smaku przeciętnie ze wskazaniem na mdło.
Bottle: 330 ml, Price: 0,56 eur, Nieko gero.. tik statistikai

Kolor: Ciemnozłoty, klarowny. Piana: Biała, dość obfita, drobnopęcherzykowa, szybko obrączkuje. Zapach: Słodki, słód, mokre zboże, lekki karmel. Smak: Słodkawy, mdławy. Wysycenie średnie, ciała niewiele. Kiedyś tzn. jakieś 10 lat temu smakowało inaczej i dużo lepiej.
Ocena wystawiona na podstawie wspomnień z degustacji w ramach uzupełnienia profilu.
Nie wyróżnia się niczym szczególnym poza nietypową butelką. Smak, kolor w porządku.

Wygląd: Barwa miedziana, klarowna. Piana niska. Aromat: Typowo słodowy, lekko ziołowy od chmieli, wad brak Smak: Rześkie, lekkie, ziołowe. Słodycz i goryczka zbalansowane, wysycenie niskie. Bardzo dobrze się pije. Ogólnie: Zaskoczyło mnie pozytywnie jak na jasne pełne ! (Butelka 0,33)

Bardzi fajny aromat, słodowy, intensywny, pozytywne zaskoczenie. Z wyglądu nie jest źle, jest piana, trochę średnio trwała, złote klarowne. Faktycznie pełne w smaku, nie jest wodniste, raczej słodowe niż chmielowe, niska goryczka. bardzo pijalne ogólnie fajne piwo. Pozytywne zaskoczenie, spodziewałem się słabego lagera a mamy porządne piwo
Gold, slight haze, white head. Crystal malt sweetness, a little grainy dryness in finish, citrus hops, some resin. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a slightly hazy light orange with a small white head. Faint hop aroma with a bit of fruitiness to it. Taste was rather plain and light malted with a decent balance and slightly hoppy end. Nothing special but a drinkable pale.

Nice and cloudy, I mistook it for the wheat when it was brought out with it. Reminds me of blood plasma in color and clarity. Smells like well... nothing! I smell nothing. Lots of corn. I guess A novice may find it very drinkable, but I'll pass though.
cloudy light yellow, nasty verrie hoppiness with no bitterness, a waste of a taphandle
Pretty faint in the nose and in the looks, a little thin perhaps. Too many floral hops. An interesting initial taste, vanilla all about followed by a surprisingly sweet roastedness near the end.
choclate aroma, looks fairly light, choclatey with a sweet vanilla flash in the beginning and a floral hop finish
Aroma of malts and sulphur. Taste is rather malty. Some grainy and sulphur notes. Low bitterness. A bit worse that Lubzer Pilsner

Tasted on 07.01.19. Small head almost completely disappearing. Clear golden colour. Malty aroma with quite intensive metal. Noticeable hoppy bitterness with pleasant malty background and intensive metal.

500ml bottle, 5.2 % abv, shared by djoeye. Spotty lacing from a snow white head. Clear pale golden body. Pale malty nose, sweet and dry. Doughy flavours with hints of herbal hops. Distant bittersweet end. Medium bodied. Clean in the mouth. Accepted. (PivotekaH7, Tromsø 29.01.2018).

Aroma; pale malts, grass, bread, dough. Look; white head, pale clear golden body. Taste; pale malts, grain, bread, grass, and finishes quite smoothly. Feel; ok n normal. Overall; fair enough. [50cl.btl abv5.2% xp4.06.18 abseits@PivotekaH7 29jan2018] 5353'10
Osobiście lepiej smakuje pils ale każdy ma swoje priorytety. Średniej klasy ?Nie wiem. Ale z sentymentu do pilsa..Pijalne

Bottle. Clear golden beer with a small white head. Aroma is malty with notes of bread, caramel, cereal, hay and herbs. Flavor is malty with notes of caramel, dough, bread, herbs and floral hops. Well balanced.

Bottle, 5.2%. Clear yellow with small white head. Aroma is malt, grainy, fruit, hop, notes of cardboard and a notes of grass. Flavour is malt, grainy, medium sweet, hop, notes of grass and a little bitter.
Bottle from Kaufland. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, light grainy and light hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 250815
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grass, straw and hops. Light bitter finish.
Clear light golden color, average head. Nice spicy hopy taste, little bit artificial. Good export variante. Nice bitterness.
Looks a bit like beer, smells a bit like beer, is even packaged like beer, is it beer? I’m not sure.

Crystal clear classic larger look - reminds me of a Crownie. Sweet nose, a little malt. Nothing much happening in the mouth, more sweetness but I’m not sure what it is. A little soapy. Not bitterness. Not a great beer.

Ugh. All this brewery’s beers taste the same. They’re really quite bad but not offensive enough to rate really poorly in my book. This one has rust and bananas and not much else - OK maybe lemon detergent. Good head retention. Crap beer.
Agree with the below post. This is a disappointing beer. Actually it's not a beer at all.

Awful, awful beer from Geelong south of Melbourne. It looks like a standard lager, perhaps a bit yellowey. There is definate acetate and other unpleasant things in the smell. The taste is a bit like Budweiser mixed with dishwater. Actually make that washing machine water - there's a hint of old smelly socks in there somewhere. Genuinely bad.

Aroma: Hay and citrus fruits. Appearance: Gold color with hazy liquid and minimal white head. Taste: Light bitterness with medium sour touch. Palate: Light body with oily liquid and average carbonation. Short sour citrus finish. Overall: Refreshing and easy to drink but with strong features.
Cervesa correcta, es noten tocs a cereal i a llevat, lleugera i fàcil de beure. Cerveza correcta, se notan toques a cereal y a levadura, ligera y fácil de beber.

Barwa słomkowo żółta, piwo mętne. Piana średnio obifta, średnio trwała. Aromat drożdżowy, już sam w sobie sycący, bardzo przyjemny. W smaku chmielowy, z niezłą goryczką. Jest jak dobry domowy obiad u babuni. Niby nie spełnia wymogów światowej kuchni, ale jak smakuje! Naprawdę dobre piwo.

Murky golden body, white head. Bottle (basically a Growler) foamed quite a bit, but it came out great. Small carbonation, good juicy bitterness. Very tasteful and smooth, surprisingly good! Many thanks to Ori for bringing this all the way from Heidelberg!

Enjoyed on tap at Vetters in Heidelberg, DE while eating with some co-workers. I didn’t take tasting notes, but remember this being an above average pilsener that went down nice and smooth with a light crispness. Another great beer from a great brewery.

Draught at the brewpub Cloudy deep blond color; creamy head. The aroma is light, but with crispy malt and Hallertau hop. Good body structure, quite good malt taste, some sweetness, very well balanced by a strong and quite aromatic hopping. Long final, with medium/strong bitterness. Refreshing, very enjoyable.

An unclear light yellow beer with a small white head. The aroma is sweet spicy combined with notes of yeast. The flavor is very sweet with loads of citrus notes. Thanks to sk8viking’s wife for bringing this rare beer to Denmark.
1l. Bottle. Thanks to my Wife. Light hazy golden color and a small head. Sweet fruity farmyard aroma and sweet fruity taste. Medium body and a light hoppy sweet finish.
From a bottle. Golden coloured.Fresh and soft mouthfeel. More fruitiness in the aroma and in the flavour than in your average German pilsener.

Slightly sulfury nose, pale gold-yellow color, nice lacy head. Warm round malt taste - sweetisch. A little egg-like too. Could benefit from more hops. Thin body and not convinced of the balance. Thanks Martina!
Golden color with small white head that dissipates quickly. Sweet aroma. Taste is sweet at first. Well balanced. Taste is fresh.
Pours a copper golden with white head. Light toasted malt aroma and taste. Light earthy balance. Notes: bottle from Berchtesgaden, Aug ‘19
In der Nase etwas eigenartig, senfig, süß, ich vermisse Malz. Im Trunk leicht Karamell, Malz, irgendwie unrund, hinten bitter - meh.
0.5l bottle@: Fast 10K ~ Last 3K in 4:49min/mile....now it's time for a few good 🍺!

0,5 l bottle from Rücker, Lengerich. Clear dark golden, nearly amber in the glass. One finger frothy head. Malty smell with some fruity elements in the background. Taste is more smooth, some malt and caramell, short metallic sequence. Later fruity elements with malt and grain. Okay, but nothin´ more.
Bottle. Nose is sweet grains, citrus. Palate is also pretty sweet, grain, citrus. Too sweet for me.
Golden. Aroma is quite murky hops, some cornflakes, and nice caramel malty body. Taste is slight bitter, slight malty sweetness. Quite balanced. If it werent for the murky hops... Not bad.
Bottle. Fruity and hayish malt aroma. Pale golden, offwhite lace. Medium light sparkly body, papery/oxidized, acidic on the tongue, dusty, light cheesy finish.
Bottle. Clear copper color with white head. Aroma is sugary, syrupy, toffee, caramel, a bit nutty. Taste is syrupy, caramel. Oily mouthfeel with natural carbonation. Meh.
Frisch gezapft. Trüb und hellbraun mit mittelgroßer Schaumkrone. Malzig. Süffig. Süßlich. Runder Abgang.

Bottled, 500ml from Millets farm Shop, Frilford. Gold with white head. Easy drinking if thin, sharp malty bitter, some sharp hoppiness, a light tinny type taste, then a slightly sweetish malt. Reasonable enough.
Bottled from pack of Woods beer from Spring Show at Malvern. Poured a golden orangey colour, with now head at all. Plenty of fruitt in the nose, also with a dry finish.

Bottled purchased from fancy garden centre farm shop betwen Hereford and Ledbury Sat 4th March hadn’t realised this was actually out of date by 5-6 weeks until I had drank it. Amber beer very clean, sharp bitter taste wasn’t up too much really.
Poured from the bottle with no head.Quite sharp and bitter but nothing special.
Bronze with not much life. Aroma is clean, crisp and grainy. Flavours are mellow with traces of vanilla, caramel, some oakiness and smokiness. A dry finish that is more a whisper than shout.
Bottled. Amber with a slight haze, poor head and low condition. Caramel and strawberry nose, with a fruity malt body with some suggestion of hops and a forgetably short dry finish.

Bottled, with a sediment but not bottle conditioned (I think). Gold with a slight haze, poor head and low condition. Big initial aroma of hazelnuts with a hint of hops in the background. Full bodied with hazelnuts again dominating but the hops start to become more obvious towards the end, finally leaving a dry, hop bitter finish.
Butelka . Ulala la bamba mocne masełko, slodowe mdłe. Jest angielski sznyt ale poza tym badziewie

Bottle from Crafty Pint. Appearance - golden with a proportionate head. Nose - light lemon and barley. Taste - lemon barley water ago. Almost like a shandy. Palate - light bodied with a creamy texture and a fairly good finish. Overall - it’s solid but unexciting.
Slightly floral, hay aroma. Head disappears very fast. Medium bitterness, lightly sweet, lightly sour. Ok beer. But could have a stronger flavour and aroma.
Golden yellow with a large airy head. Peachy sweet hops aroma. Dry sweet and fruity. Nice and smooth.

From cask. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild butterish and light hoppy. Bitter, light citrusy and hayish to light cornish. Ends bitter and slight herbal. Dry and bitter into the far finish.

Cask at GBBF 2011. Clear golden coloured with a small white head. Fruity aroma of caramel, butterscotsch and hops. Fruity flavour of caramel, grass and hops with notes of butterscotsch. Dry hoppy finish.

Cask (handpump) @ St George’s Tavern, 14 Belgrave Road, London, Greater London, England SW1V 1QD. Clear medium yellow colour with a small to average, frothy - fizzy and open, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, light to moderate hoppy, citrus, lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, citrus - lemon. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20101227]

Bottled, 660ml, from York Beer & Wine. Yellow gold with slight head. Not sure of the maturation length of this but it doesn’t taste as if it’s been ’lagered’. Thin, grainy and largely tasteless apart from a little boiled caramel note. Not very impressive unfortunately.
Golden color, small head. Toffee aroma. Malty toffe flavor with some citrus.
Sampled at SBWF09 Slightly hazy golden. Yeasty citric aroma. Fresh flavour with medium bitterness. Fruity and slightly yeasty.

On tap at the brewery pours out a amber with some ruby highlights topped with a small tan head. Nose is lots of sweet malts pit fruit and some toffee. Taste is more of the sweet malts caramel toffee wood and pit fruit.
On tap at brewpub. Nice caramel color, sweet maltiness on nose. Bitterness low, only 16 IBU. The malt really shines through. Nice beer.

On Tap at the BrewPub Clear deep amber mahogany. Small but fine and dense light tan head. Cinnamon spicy holiday aroma, Nice malty flavors, rather dry and low hops as a Scottish Ale should be. Not very big at 5.6 but a nice malty brew with a little spice. Pleasant

Bottle:   Fiery amber, thin frothy white head, little lacing.   Soft fruity start, pale breadiness, touch of caramel and biscuit.   A bit too soft overall.   A bit stronger on the tongue, more caramel and fruitiness, soft breadiness and biscuit.   A sweet and malty beer for sure, but not much in the way of peat, campfire, or charred wood.   Body and mouthfeel are moderate.   Tasty finish, caramel, a bit more fruity than most, and less of that charred wood/ashy/campfire stuff.   Coulda used some of that, along with minor dark pitted fruit.   Otherwise alright.

On Tap at the brewery. Cola colored pour with an off white head. Aroma was some good malt, a little vanilla and some roast. Flavor was pretty similar. Maybe a session Scottish ale? Nothing to write home about.

Taster - Whitstran Brewing Company - Prosser, WA Aroma – Good strong malt and hops aroma. Appearance – Amber in Color, Thin head and clear. Flavor – This had some strong Caramel and German malts with a great flavor from the Yakima and Golding hops. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, crisp texture with a dry Scottish finish. Overall – This beer was very even and had a good balance. The hops took over so made it off style.

Had at the Picazo 7 seventeen restaurant in Prosser. One of only 2 beers they had as it is mostly a wine bar. Poured a nice copper clear color with froathy offwhite ehad. Aroma is malty and earthy. Flavor malty with slight peat flavor. Nice heavy creamy mouthfeel. Slight hop finish. Wouldn’t say this is a true scottish ale, but still enjoyable.
Copper color with big spots of lacing. Bitter aroma with tones of caramel and nuttiness. The flavor is much the same as the nose but with stronger malts. Medium body with a malty finish.
Sampled draught at Whistran Brewing in Prosser, WAAmber color, light head and lacing. Nose of faint malt, dry flavor with some creamy hops, light caramel. Finishes dry and a bit boring.

On tap at the brewery pours out a light cloudy golden topped with a white head. nose is light bread grain and a touch of hops. Taste is more of the light grain a little biscuit note and a light hop end.
On tap at brewpub. Light pale straw color, very clear. Hint of honey on the aroma. Light, not bitter, only 14 IBUS according to beer list. Very easy drinking cross between a lager and an ale.

Bottle: &nbsp Bright golden, chunks of sediment float around, small frothy white head, little lacing. &nbsp Sweet sweaty aroma, very mealy up front. &nbsp Some pale fruitiness too. &nbsp Thankfully the taste is much better. &nbsp Light sweet breadiness, moderate carbonation. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are average. &nbsp Fairly smooth on the finish, some straw/hay, generally grassy, with a soft sweet bready background. &nbsp Tiz okay.

On Tap at the brewpub. Slightly hazy light golden with a small but persistent ring of fine bubbles. Very mild light grain aroma and flavor. Nary a hop to be found but I cant imagine this brew needs more than about a dozen IBUs to get to the balance it needs. A beer for the masses, great for washing down your dinner but strangely similar to their other two lighter beers I’ve tried so far.
On tap at the brewery in Prosser. Probably the best of the bunch Ihad in the sampler. Light yellow color with a thin white head. Aroma was some biscuit and some hops. Really nice lawnmower beer.

Taster - Whitstran Brewing Company - Prosser, WA Aroma – Light pale malt aroma with a light hop backing. Appearance – Golden in Color, Thin head and clear. Flavor – Easy malt build with a light addition of hops this was built well. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, crisp texture with a dry finish. Overall – A very good hot day summer beer this beer was cold and very refreshing.
Had on tap at picazo 7 seventeen restauraunt. Poured clear gold with tons of bubbles. Looks like champagne. Slight cream taste, but flavor mostly light malt with some lemon. Nothing great.
Pale yellow with spotty lace and a thin head. Small malty aroma with some lemony notes. A touch bitter. Little malt flavors with lightly bitter hop presence.

Sampled draught at Whistran Brewing in Prosser, WAClear yellow, light head, short lacing. Nose of light hops, fruit and husky grain. The flavor is thin, watery, light malts, more ale than lager. Refreshing at best.

Straw colour. Slight pale malt aroma. Slight husky, citrusy character and black cherry fruitiness. The warm fermentation shoots for ale-like notes but (not unlike Keith’s) it just ends up being funky. Lagers need to be lagered.

On tap at the brewery. Pours out a clear Amber topped with a sand head. Nose is light Citrus hop some malty chocolate notes and a little bit of orange peel. Taste is more of the malty notes some Citrus and pine hops
On tap at brewpub. Light golden, clear appearance. Says its 46 IBU but the bitterness is slight. Round on palate nice finish with hops finally showing through.

On Tap at the brewpub. Clear deep amber, witha nice sustained off white head. Nice citursy hop aroma with some sweet malty brown sugar notes. Fairly bitter for an APA but not so hoppy flavorful. Somewhat metallic and brown paper bag-ish. Lingering bitterness but just not ideal. Pretty dry and a nice quick finish.

On Tap at the brewery. Poured a hazy dark orange with an off white head. Aroma was nice and hoppy with a good malt undertone. Flavor was strange. Really nice hops notes on the front, but then an incredible harsh bitter on the back. I made it a few sips in and had to give up. This was brutal. Probably would have been a drain pour at home.

Taster - Whitstran Brewing Company - Prosser, WA Aroma – Good malty aroma. Appearance – Amber in Color, Thin head and clear. Flavor – This was a very malty pale ale. The hops where very light. The beer did happen to be very well balanced. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, crisp Pale Ale texture with a dry finish. Overall – A very nice after mowing the lawn beer . Very nice clean easy to drink beer.
Sampled the Dry-hopped "Over-the-edge" version. Malty and very dry - nice hop flavor, not much else. Enjoyable but boring.

Light amber with a thin head and sheet lacing. Aroma is lightly floral and bitter. Malty flavors that needs more in the hop area. What is there is bitter and slighty fruity. Malty finish that seems more like an amber than pale.

Sampled draught at Whistran Brewing in Prosser, WAClear bronze, light head, good lacing. Nose of crispy brewed hops, not fresh but not musky. Almost a day-old hop smell. The flavor is nutty, light malts and more toffee. The finish is creamy. Fairly good!The dry-hopped version (Over-the-Edge): About the same, more hop nose.
Had the Over-the-Edge. Bright copper colour. Toasty, slightly vegetal aroma. Tastes toasty and pithy, with strong blackberry notes.
On tap at the brewery pours out dark brown almost black topped with a small head. Nose is chocolate coffee and little leafy hops. Taste is more of the chocolate coffee roast.

Bottle: &nbsp Dark brown, large frothy beige head, sticky lacing. &nbsp Lactose like sweetess on the nose, soft chocolate, a little touch of hops. &nbsp Soapy start to this one, soft roasted malts, a little tart and ashy on the backside. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Finishes quick, not much lingers. &nbsp Light overall, very pedestrian, and almost not even in the category of Stout in my book. &nbsp Meh...

On Tap at the brewpub. Clear but dark brown with some mahogany highlights. Lasting thin light tan head. Classic roasted and slight coffee aroma. Roasted flavors. Standard and predictable. bitter chocolate and slight coffee.
Thanks Justin! Thinly poured black, small tan head, rich aroma of espresso and maltballs. Fairly dry and roasty, light bodied, touch of carob. Great example of the style.

On tap at the brewery. Poured a nice dark brown color with a thin off white head. Aroma was chocolate, coffe, and some good roast. Flavor was more of the same. A little of the nice carmelized bitter notes, and a perfectly enjoyable brew. Could have a couple of these and be happy.

Taster - Whitstran Brewing Company - Prosser, WA Aroma – Dark malt with hints of dark chocolate and coffee in the aroma. Appearance – Dark Brown in Color, Thin head and hazy. Flavor – This beer had some great flavors. Lots of oat like qualities and the roasty malts where impeccable. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, crisp texture with a dry chocolate finish. Overall – The best beer for the day here at Whitstran.

Dark brown with mahogany edges. Tannish head with a little lace. Huge roasty aroma with a touch of chocolate. Some smoke and coffee tones as well. Flavor is largely roasty with some hints of coffee and slightly bitter. Small bodied with a roasty finish

Sampled draught at Whistran Brewing in Prosser, WAdark ruby, light head and lacing. Nose of robust roast, starbucks coffee. Balanced and robust, nice chocoalte mix with barley tastes. Oats add creaminess, good finish. yum.
Very dark brown. Strong raw coffee aroma. Toasty flavour is also a bit nutty, but mainly coffeeish. Sweet front, dry finish.
On tap at the brewery pours out a hazy amber topped with a small head. Nose is belg yeast some spice and a nice malt. Taste is more of the belg yeast spice some fruit esters bubblegum sweetness.

Taster - Whitstran Brewing Company - Prosser, WA Aroma – Nice Belgian yeast and good malt backing the spicy aromas. Appearance – Amber in Color, Thin head and hazy. Flavor – A very nice easy to drink Belgian Abbey. Good malts and the hops gave this a spicy flavor. Palate – Good Mouthfeel, Belgian texture with a dry finish. Overall – A very good Belgian ale. I actually liked this beer. Very well brewed.

Cloudy amber with an off-white head and spotty lace. Spicy notes in the nose. Malty and yeasty, a touch bready with sweet caramel. A little sour and funky in the flavors. Bitter and spicy. Good balance of the malts, spices and hops. Finishes lightly sour

Sampled draught at Whistran Brewing in Prosser, WACloudy dark mahogany, tan head, light lacing. Nose of toffee with fig, sweet plum, nice hops and creamy toasted malts. Sweet and sour flavor, unique but tasty. Finishes balanced, nice.
Cloudy chestnut colour. Fruity, sugary aroma with bubblegum. Strange character - tart, vinous notes clashing with sweet, candyish ones.
On tap at the brewery pours out a hazy straw color topped with a white head. nose is a nice Germany yeast some fruit esters. Taste is more of the yeast a light citrus touch and spice.
On tap at brewpub. Almost a lagerish aroma, dark yellow, heading towards orange, not very cloudy. Can taste wheat but no banana or cloves, not much like Bavarian wheat beers I’ve come to love.

Bottle: &nbsp Dirty straw water, thin soapy sudsy white head, little lacing. &nbsp Okay, a bit stale straw/hay nose. &nbsp Not very wheaty. &nbsp Sour right up front. &nbsp Sour, thin, like a baby lambic. &nbsp Not a German Hefe by any means. &nbsp Pretty much garbage.

Looks like apple juice very little carb. Aroma of spice, apples, banana yeast bread. Almost flat. Needs more carb or more secondary ferment here. Taste is pretty spot on for the style. Rich banana bready flavors pair up with the higher abv. All it needs is some co2. Tragic.
On tap at the brewpub. Hazy light yellow with a a small quick white head. Claoms to be a Bavavarian Hef, the classic German yeast aromas and flavors are quite mild. Slightly sweet and very tasty.
On tap at the brewery. Pretty nice Hefe. Some good hefe flavors, without being overwhelmingly yeast. Very clear yellow beer though which was interesting.
