Taster - Whitstran Brewing Company - Prosser, WA Aroma – Big wheat malt aroma with clove and banana esters. Appearance – Golden in Color, Thin head and hazy. Flavor – Good German wheat malt with a light hops backing this had a nice Hefe flavor. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, crisp texture with a dry Hefe finish. Overall – This was a very nice Hefe. I would add a tad more hops to round out the flavors.

Bottled: Light golden. Clear. Medium lasting white fluffy head. Malt, sweets, grass and light hoppy aroma. A bit thin in the flavour. Some maltsweetness and light hoppyness. Is ligth bitter in the end. Quite uninteresting beer.
Pale golden colour. Rich head. Faint hoppiness in the nose, maybe some malt as well. Medium bodied. Unclean bitterness against a discreet but firm malt background.
Bottled.Rather pale golden with an ok head. Some malty and maybe hoppy aroma. Quite lively with a fresh flavour.
Bottled. Pale golden with firm, creamy head. Papery malt aroma. Sweet with clean maltiness. Bold, rounded mouthfeel, slightly burnt. Less malty and distinct than I expect a Franconian festbier to be.
Pale golden, medium sized head. Sweet malty and grassy aroma. Sweet, smooth malt. Beside that, not much else. very easy-drinking. Some herbal notes in finish.
Bottled. Straw gold, moderate head and good condition. Sweet grainy malt aromas with hints of hop flavour in the mouth. Soft and smooth finish with some bitterness but nothing stunning.
sampled at the brewpub. Amber in color with a small compact off white head. Aroma is caramel and some floral hops. Taste is the same, pretty simple beer. smooth.
On tap. Strange spritziness disrupts the body. Crispness is imparted, yes, but with some artificiality. Caramel and some slight musty aroma = very nice. Sugry flavoring is a tad strong.

Amber in color. Some sweetness to the taste, with a decent amount of maltiness. Very smooth. Medium body. My wife liked this alot. I'm glad someone else added it, as I couldn't remember how to spell the darn thing!

Deep amber color with a thin head and some lace. Sweet fruity (berries) aroma with malty undertones. Very sweet and friuty (berry) flavor with a slight maltiness and a touch of hops. Very smooth and medium bodied.
Bottle from Biershop BW - murk golden color, white head. high on carbonation. medium sweet, some bubblegum. not really a masterpiece.

Flasche 0,5l: Heller Bernstein, Ocker, kräftige Trübung, kräftiger stabiler feinporiger Schaum; frische Nase, malzige Süße, Malz, Getreide, kräftige Hefearomen, etwas Karamell, dezente Fruchtigkeit, leichte Zitrusnoten; frischer Körper, dezente malzige Süße, Malz, Getreide, etwas Karamell, kräftige Hefearomen, leichte trockene Würze, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, leichte Fruchtigkeit, Kochbananen; angenehmer malzig-trockener Nachgang mit deutlichen Hefearomen
Tap at a Restaurant in Tübingen. Pours dark Amber. Nose is banana, even some dunkelweizen notes. Palate is floral, citrus, nice banana. Finish is short and Fruity. This is a nice take on hefeweizen.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A. BBE 16.06.2016. Pours hazy yellow color with a large white head. Wheat and apricot on the aroma, banana, some toffee and herbs. Flavor is wheaty and sweet with banana and toffee, some hay and herbal notes. Decent palate cleanser. 3333
Hefetrübes orangegelb mit schöner Schaumkrone. Reichlich Hefe, fruchtig, Banane, malzig, spritzig.

Bottled (as Kloster Weizen Hefehell), from Biershop Baden-Württemberg. Cloudy straw colour, rich creamy head. Fruity nose with some mashed banana. Mid sweet with medium body and soft, somewhat oily mouthfeel and prickly carbonation. Dough, banana and custard. Very low bitterness. Solid hefeweizen.
* Old rating, many thanks to kevnic2008 for this beer. Best before Nov 10. Mild-weiches, schön fruchtiges Hefeweizen. Nett und süffig.

It’s unclear, pale golden with a huge, creamy head. The aroma has notes of yeast, light fruit and wheat. The sweet flavor has notes of yeast, fruit, light wheat, and the finish is spicy and slightly dry.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig, leicht würzig. Geschmack sehr fruchtig, hefig, leicht würzig.

500ml bottle. Aroma is light citrus, light apple, yeast. Appearance is cloudy yellow with a huge white foam. Taste is sour, light bitter, very light sweet. A bit watery, a very thin texture, leaves some bitterness. Overall a good but not superb Weizen,

Cask at The Beehive, St. Albans in 2012. Chestnut and clear with a white head. Malty aroma, with some orange peel and raisins. Fairly sweet, malty flavours and caramel with some grassy hop at the end.
Cask at Oluthuone Leskinen, Oulu. Originally rated 19052012. Colour is dark copper with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, bitterness and malts.
Hand pulled at The Charles Dickens, Southwark. Mahogany ale with citrus grapefruit hops aroma. Taste is bran, malt, Ready Brek, oats, slightly sweetened. County 45 of 46 for me too...
5th September 2009 Cambridge Blue. C;lear amber beer. Light crisp palate. Very well balanced if unremarkable beer. Not dry. Refreshing but utterly standard bitter.

(Cask at Gallows Bird, 20120523) The beer poured mahogany coloured and clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had malts and caramell. Palate was medium bodied with low carbonation. Flavours were malts, mildly caramell, mild roastedness and lowish bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter. Weak and watery.
Pint at the Old Manor in Bracknell. Fair fluffy head on a dark red beer. Light, dry hops, and a bit flowery. Slightly floral hop aroma. Pretty unremarkable.
Cask conditioned handpump Bell & Bear Emberton. A chestnut coloured beer with a whitish head and lacing. Bready malts in the nose. Chocolate and orangey flavours in the mouth. Pretty tasty.

Sampled this bitter in the Last Post, Paisley (JDW) in January 2009. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear tawny with russet highlights and a thick creamy white head. Prickly dusty hop aroma has floral notes through it. Good lacing throughout and a rich creamy mouthfeel. Pale malts give a rich digestive teabiscuit edge. Juicy fruit notes of red apple and gooseberry give a short intensity in the mouth. Fruit notes fade to lead into a citrus burst of hop resin in the mellow aftertaste. Decent bitter with a sweet finish. An ok session ale.
Cask by handpump at Counting House, Glasgow (2 Mar 12) - fruity hop aroma, copper coloured ale with a thin off-white head, caramel with a hint of honey, oily feel and prolonged bitter aftertaste
A very mediocre beer, nice color and head, a very slight bitterness but a huge letdown.

Pours transparent Coca-Cola brown with a nice light tan head. Aroma presents nice roast malt, earthy and nutty tones. Satisfying flavor starts with roast malt and adds nutty, caramel, earthy and subtle chocolate notes. Mouthfeel presents average fizz but firm body. Go nuts!
Draft at North Location. Clear light brown/amber with a thin tan head. Scent is toasted nuts and malts. Taste is caramel, nuts, dark sugar and roasty.

Appearance: Clear, brownish-amber body with a small, faintly beige-colored head. Lovely! Smell: Earthy, toasted nut nose mainly, with lesser notes fo roasted malt and brown sugar. Spicy hop scent in back with a faint touch of grassiness to it. Taste: Nutty dark caramel taste with hints of roast and brown sugar, though it’s never overly sweet. Earthy, lightly spicy hop character with a mild bitterness. Finishes a bit dry, and eventually with a bit more lingering bitterness as it warms. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: A nice, enjoyable nut brown ale that’s good for a pint or two.
Clear, darkish brown with a creamy head. Aroma of dry cocoa and light pecan. Flavor is dry cocoa, caramel and pecan. Light-medium body is slightly tingly and finishes roasty-dry.

I really enjoy this beer. This is what I expect in a nut brown. This actually has a rich toffee maltiness, with all kind of nutty flavors throughout, mixed with some dry chocolate and cocoa flavors. Highly enjoyable.

Date: January 05, 2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: Brown with ruby highlights, whispy tan head Flavor: lots of rich dry chocolate malt flavor, low bitterness Overall: more of a porter Date: October 25, 2008 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Appearance: clear dark red, creamy tan head, thick scattered lace Aroma: light chocolate aroma with a nice nutty character, light earthy bitterness Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, nice toasted malt, sweet bready caramel character, hint of dark fruit, well balanced with an earthy bitterness, light bitter toast finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20 Rating: 3.2/5.0 Drinkability: 9/10 Score: **+/4
Great taste. Great beer. Somewhat dry aftertaste, but thats expected. Deffinately worthwhile buying.
A nice session ale here. I caught alot of sour notes in this which was not expected. This beer has a good nutty flavor. Another good one from 5 Sizzions!

Pours a very clear brownish-red with small tan head. Better carbonated than previous vintages. More hop aroma and flavor than other Nut Brown brews. Not too malty with caramel and nutty flavors. Not bad.

Draft at 5 Seasons. This beer had a small sized tan head with fine sized bubbles that quickly and completely dissipated. The body was softly carbonated and transparent with a red-brown hue. The nose was malty, caramel and lightly hoppy. The flavor was mildly hoppy with a fairly smooth and dry mouthfeel. This beer had a fair amount of lacing.
01 May 08. Tap. Clear copper color. Clean malt aroma. Crisp malt flavor. Medium-light bodied. Finishes with an enjoyable sweetness.

On tap at the brewpub on 5/4/08: Transparent dark copper amber with a nicely-lacing frothy tan head. Aroma of sweet caramely German malt and some mild noble hops. Starts with decent fullness and sweet caramel maltiness with a good bittering hop balance before a smooth bittersweet finish with a touch of doughy yeast. A nice bock.

Full bodied with a slightly nutty and biscuity nose. I found this to be extremely smooth and well balanced. A bit of caramel sweetness follows throughout every taste. Slightly dry and fruity in the finish.

Date: 02/06/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: dark red, fine creamy head leaving solid lace, Flavor: dry malt flavor, a bit too dry for a bock, nice carmel malt character in the background, low bitter finish -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 02/29/2004 finally some sweetness in the bock! was way too dry last weekend, but has bloomed with some nice carmel sweetness, still well balanced -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 03/03/2005 Score: upgrade ii to iii Words: slight reformulation thanks to the new 6% law Body: nice body, Flavor: big malt flavor, nice light sweetness, touch of chocolate and carmel, upon warming turns into a wonderful rich creation with the perfect body and sweetness, a nice overall improvement -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 03/08/2007 Mode: growler Source: Blind Tasting Score: 2.2 Appearance: clear dark red, headless, touch of lace, Aroma: strong dry dark caramel malt aroma with a hint of tartness, Body: a bit thin body, Flavor: rich malt flavor, overwhelming tartness, a light fruity character like an apple cider, not a good sample -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 05/18/2008 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma with light chocolate and fruityness, Body: creamy body, Flavor: sweet dark caramel flavor, lots of fruity sweetness, rich chocolate, still a light tartness that does not distract and may be even a psyxhoxological, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 14/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ***/4
Pours a deep mahogany brown color with a tan head. Aroma is very light. It is of caramel and bitter roasted malts. Flavor is very malty with bitter roasted malts.

A delicious bock whose dark red-brown color is exceptionally inviting. The smell is not strong, but I don’t have an exceptional sniffer. Flavor is strong and hoppy, but not too bitter, with a little nutty undertone. This beer is smooth and tingly, and definitely worth more than a few sips. If ever you are in Atlanta during the spring and this is on tap, do ask for it!

Draft @ the 5. Poured a clear dark copper color with a thin beige head. The aroma was light but mostly fruity. Plums seemed to dominate the aroma. Malty flavor with some more fruit. The finish was semi-dry with a bitter hop finish.

nice brown body with a thick head and Solid feel to it. This was so full and rich. Nice chocolate tones and a hint of nuttiness in the foreground. it feels so good when it hits your lips. lol. no seriously, excellent beer.
kind of had a brown tint to it. very nice malt thing going on in the body. Very thick and full. Solid brew.
Medium brown; wispy head;sweet floral nose. Slightly thin to start. Big burnt malt at the back.

22 oz. bottle via BockyHorsey - Pours a clear brown color with a one and a half finger thick light tan head. Light lacing. Has a light toasted malt aroma. Flavor is light roasted malt with a tad bit of smokiness. Thin, dry palate. Light to medium body. Not bad. Thanks Bill. Wish Papago would get serious about bottling thier beer.
Mild vanilla, a little chocolate, a little hazel. Good dark schwarz-like coloring. No head. Thin. Decent flavor profile but not much coffee, nuts or fruit. Was looking for more.
On tap at Papago. Black with smallish head and lacing. Aroma is roasty malts and chocolate. Flavor is chocolate , coffee with a nice roasty finish. Body is a bit watery but good overall.

This beer is a deep brown color, it is slightly hazy and in the light shows a deep ruby note to it. The head is a frothy light brown color. The nose is light with notes of caramel and perhaps a hint of nuttiness. The taste is fairly dry up front, but then moves to a note of buttery oak. Quite light on the palate. While a bit dry, there is a definite caramel sweetness here. I also get a hint of chocolate. The finish of this beer is the most notable part, actually a bit rich, creamy, with notes of woody tannins, buttery oak and a definite note of hazelnut that comes to linger and dominate the finish.
Malty aroma. Black body with off white head. Flvor seemed to be of water at first. Got some spice flavor at the end. Not bad mild beer to drink.

tap scottsdale beer fest-pours a deep brown hue with a nice off-white head. Big nutty/chocolate aroma with notes of cashews, peanuts, pinion, and hazelnut. AWESOME! some hops in there as well. Flavors are a showcase of various nuts that were all brought together with a good body. one of the best nut browns i have ever had!

This is a great beer. It originally reminded me of Rogue’s Hazelnut Brown but this was better. This beer tastes just like it smells. Its nutty taste lasts throughout the full pint. No disappointment here. Definately try it if you’re in Phoenix!

Draught @ Papago: This one is a reddish-brown color. It had a bit of an off-white head. The aroma was quite nutty, with the predominate aroma that of almonds. Medium malt body, but not overly sweet. Taste of almonds also, with some bitterness in the finish. Very Good!
I had this at the Great Arizona Beer Festival in Phoenix. Nicely malted but kinda watery.

Earthy maple syrup lathers its pungent wealth onto the boisterous nut oil…Delectable perfume reminds of a cross between Saranac’s Caramel Porter and Rogue’s Hazelnut Brown…Thick mouthfeel renders the caramel malts beautifully and plays off the maple syrup vapor with aplomb…Maybe a bit strong on the sweet nuttiness, but if you like decadence and nourishment like I do, you won’t be complaining with this one…Definitely my favorite of their lineup…
0,3 litre Bottle from Total Wine And More, Laguna Hills, Ca. Dark brown with little head. Roasted malts, vanilla, coffee, Chocolate.

I had it poured in a glass. It pours a dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is vanilla, chocolate, and caramel. The taste is vanilla, light coffee, chocolate, and milk. It's a bit thin. There's a lotta sweet and not as much bitter as I'd like. It's okay.

Ar: ledwo wyczuwalny, kakao, mleczna czeko, sladowa kawa, migdaly, nieco wanilii, ciemny slod. Wyg: czarne, klar, piana gruba, drobna, super lacing. Sm: wysycenie srednie, super wanilowo-czekoladowe, lekka tlustosc lakto, slodko i kakaowo. Pos: czekolada, minimalny kawo-kwasek. Ov: super czeko-wanilia, ale mogloby i powinno dziac sie wiecej.

This is far from being rich as it says in the description, but it is nice good beer for me. Light and watery but that certainly gave the beer not disgusting ending. Toasted being the overall taste, has nice scent of vanilla that is not too much.

12 oz bottle into shaker. Pours a bit thin for a porter. White/beige lacy head. Heavy vanilla and typical porter aroma. Mouthfeel is a tad thin for the style. Loses most of its head fairly quickly. Somewhat malty with a real vanilla flavor, unlike some vanilla beers that can taste artificial. The not-so-thick mouthfeel and moderate alcohol make this one of the few session porters around. Very common in the Denver area, and a bit better on tap than out of the bottle.
Decent porter tastes of chocolate and roasted bark.. have you ever licked the bark of a tree monkey boy?
On n’a un goût de vanille qui domine avec un coté chocolat ,bonne bière . ...
A nice hint of vanilla without going overboard. Light weight for a porter, goes down easy. Bottle at the Burbank airport.

I have picked up this beer, at the drinks of the world, at Bern, trying this beverage, at home, in Epalinges, two days ago, during my seafood pasta meal. In my point of view, it is a good vanilla porter, not disgusting and well balanced, I could say that it is a rather light porter, a bit watery, some roasted malt, discreet side of coffee, hop and good dosis of vanilla, easy to drink.
Aroma of roasted malts. Dark brown pour. Taste is vanilla, roasty, bitter chocolate, malts, oats. Taste is a little watered down than it was used to.
Blikje met de naam "paceña cerveza" . Mooi goud van kleur, helaas weinig schuim. Smaakt mout zoet en heeft een klein bittertje. Ergens ook ietwat bloemig.

330ml bottle from Bien Manger, as Pacena Cerveza. Pale gold colour white foam head leaving some lacing and aroma of malt, grain, grassy. Taste is malty, some grain, hay, sweetish, with light grassy bitterness. Light bodied, high carbonation, dry grassy bitter finish. OK cold, fairly bland
Bottle from Bien Manger as Pacena Cerveza. Well balanced with some decent crisp hop character and a pleasant hint of sweetness. Decent enough.
Bottle. It pours clear yellow with a white head. The aroma is pale malty with notes of grain, minerals, light citrus and light grass. The flavor is moderate sweet and moderate bitter.
Bright and clear golden colour. Head is bubbly but somewhat dense. A bit sticky. Aroma is hay. Taste is bread and a bit of lemon. Grassy, bitter finish.

355ml bottle as “Pacena Cerveza” from Bien Manger. Pours clear gold with a medium-sized white head. Aroma is paper, malt, corn. Taste is the same, low bitter finish. Pilsener in name only. In reality - typical pale lager macro swill. At least it was a new country tick.
Bottle at restaurant. Pale golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, malts, a bit of hops and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, malts, water and grass. Pretty bad bulk Pilsener.

getrunken 2013 Als ich das erste Mal von diesem Bier roch, erinnerte es mich an den Geruch, den manches Haustier verbreitet, wenn man es schon länger nicht ausgemistet hat. Bei dem Geruch habe ich schon schlimmes erwartet, allerdings ist der Geschmack ganz passabel, wenn auch etwas wässrig - ein typisches Bier welches besser wird, je mehr man davon trinkt. Sollte man sich im bolivianischen Dschungel verirren, kann man sich darüber freuen, dies in der Überlebensausrüstung dabei zu haben, aber in einem europäischen Land 3 € für 0,35 l zu zahlen, kann man sich sparen...(naja, zumindest konnte ich meine Neugier befriedigen....)
330ml bottle (thanks martjoobolut). Clear golden color. Small size, white head, stays. Aroma and taste is like sweet caramel candies. Happens.
Bottle. Pours pale golden yellow colour. Thin white head. Sourness, swet, hints of malts in the aroma. Grainy, malty and bit sweet taste. Grainy aftertaste. Strange taste. Strange palate. Nit good.

A reasonable Lager (I wouldn't go as far as classifying it as a Pilsener), and a very welcome refreshment on the road in Bolivia. I was morsende by the overall quality there, however rather mid-range on a global level.
Bottle in macha, Bolivia. After a long bus journey you need a beer. This one works, just like any other .
Not sure if the Bolivians are aware of the difference between the two tropical lagers. But it was like a pilsener, good with traditional chicken. Thick foam.

Had this at the "bar" on a cayman filled river in the Amazon basin in Las Pampas near Rurrenbaque, Bolivia. Definitely the most epic beer run I’ve ever made. A bit more flavorful, fruity, and refreshingly dry and tart than the standard, but not a huge difference.

Crystal clear coloured body with a thinnish white head. Aroma of faint fruits, light malt, cardboard and even a tiny amount of hops. Light to Medium-bodied; Strong malty taste with a bit of sugars and a little fruityness throughout. Aftertaste, clean, tart and malty - very nice actually! Overall, definitely one to try - I was impressed! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased out of the corner store (you buy the bottles through a jail-like barred window) in Cochabamba, Bolivia (across from the Burger King) on 13-August-2006.
Bottle, pours a carbonated light gold with no head. A grainy malt aroma. This and fizzy palate, but a slight fruity touch to the otherwise dry malty flavour.

During my 4 months in Bolivia I had this quite a time. The locals often mix this beer with coca-cola! the taste of this beer is not so good though so it is understandable. Big bottle. Straw colour, small very short lasting head. Aroma of something sourish and malty. The flavour is somewhat harsh with a taste of some sour malt. Like any not so gppd brew it tastes better when served cold.

Straw-gold color, regular white head. Smells of grains, corn, malt, typical. Tart taste, different than the typical macro-Pilseners. This beer has a heavier malt ody, some lemon. Great for a hot day of swatting mosquitoes in the tropic heat. Good too, if you want to try a Bolivian Pilsener just a click or two off the mainstream.

Just another pale lager, just enough crispness, though, to make it refreshing, and just enough flavour of papaya to make it go down. Nice when it's ice cold and you're sweltering in the oppressive heat and humidity of the Bolivian amazon basin.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Portland Brewing Company--MacTarnahan’s Brewing Company--The Original Portland Ale--2003 12 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Clear thin light bright golden color. Mild lace CO2 head. Crisp tangy floral hop front. Tangy dry mild sweet caramel tart citrus butter body. Tangy clean balanced earthy hop citrus spice end. Pils Ale. Sampled 7/17/2003. MacTarnahan’s Brewing Company--Portland Brewing Company--The Original Portland Ale--2004 12 oz. Bottle. 4.50% ABV.--25 IBU’s.? (4.0 / 5.0) Golden Ale. Clear bright light golden color. Mild lacy head. Mild floral Pils hop front. Smooth crisp mild sweet caramel lemon butter Pils body. Clean balanced mild hop citrus end. Mild well made crisp brew. Sampled 6/1/2004.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12 oz bottle. Clear golden color with rapidly dissipating white head that didn’t leave any lace. Smells of malty caramel, soy sauce, and sprucy hops. Slightly sweet on the tongue. Flavor was similar to the aroma, but without the soy sauce. Slight hop bitterness. Okay, but nothing to write home about.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Poured with small nice sized head, then all gone..a yellow colour straight up, smells very faintly of lemons and syrup. non bittered really, a lack luster beer here. clean aftertaste though.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Slight barnyard aroma. Grassy. Light golden color with quickly diminishing head. Oily consistency. Flavor is ok but not great. Average flavor and finish.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle Pours a clear very pale yellow with a nice bright white head and lots of bubbles coming up. Aroma is a bit soapy and moderately bitter hops. Tastes of a very pale ale. Somt light malts and I suppose a balance of hops but pretty low on both sides. Papery stale quick aftertaste then just light fairly sweet malt trailer. Quite fizzy, and overal nearly Pale Lagerish.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Dark golden color with a moderate diminishing off-white head. Sweet corn, grass, lightly toasted malt, grapes, hint of pine pitch and honey in the scents. Grains and stomach acid flavors. Corn husks and light sweet white grapes also join in the mix. A boring APA at best.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Pours a slightly off-gold, almost no head. Aroma is fairly balanced, caramel, grapefruit, and a slight lemony aroma. Flavor is citric, somewhat balanced by mild hops. Overly carbonated, methinks. Very light and quaffable. Would be good on a hot day.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle. Hazy wit-like body, small white head. Light shortbread sweetness in the aroma topped with musty orange and herb. Zippy orange citrus flavor with very light pale malt underneath. Bitter orange rind finish. A very flavorful and refreshing pale.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: from the bottle. poured a yellow to golden with a white head that left some lacing. aroma, hops, grainy, musty, grass and not much else going on. flavor, weak hops, got some skunkyness, with a touch of citrus.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Pour is a bright golden with a small white head. Aroma has some hops and grains. Flavor is just the right amount of hops to put this over the top. Everything else is pretty much light and non-existiant. Still worth the time to find this one.
Tap, KBC Den Bosch 2006. Slightly hazy brown color, medium brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, some licorice, medicine. Quite sweet taste, malty, some sour note in it. Sirupy texture.
Yeasty aroma with curacao and apple. Alcoholic flavor with curacao, orange, yeast and leak. I threw it away after a few sips.
Bitter aroma with hops and malt. Clear yellow colour with no head and poor lacing. Malt bitter hop flavour. Fizzy palate.
23 Sep 05 - Light sweet and hoppy aroma. Clear yellow gold, awful head and lacing. Light fruit and hop flavour. Light tangy, some bitterness and some lingering sweet hops.

I believe this beer is also sold under the name of Mercat draught at the mercat hotel near the Victoria markets. It’s not terrible on tap, sweet and predictable, not dissimilar to Carlton Draught. Probably made with a lot of sugar. Devoid of any defining character.

Well... yeah it actually had pretty decent head retention and most of the objectionable aromas went away pretty quickly. Other than that it’s thin, metallic, astringent and kind of headache-inducing. And farmboy I can go you one better - I’m from Geelong :)
Coming from Barwon Heads, 20km from Geelong, I am ashamed to admit that this is as close to swill as you could possible get without drinking a bottle with the letters 'VB' on it.
Slightly bitter aroma and moderately bitter flavour. Very thin and watery. A real disapointment.

The lesser of the three evils - the other two being Geelong Bitter and Geelong Lager. This one still has the same insipid quality with unpleasant alcohol flavours coming through. The head is weak, the palate nasty and the whole experience definately not worth having.
Had on tap at Australian Independent Brewers.Just updating my records. A nice beer.

Very true to the style of Belgium wit for such a widely available and Australian brewed beer. Very nice esters produced from good fermentation (mixture of picking a good yeast and using it at the right temperatures...) nice cloudy light aperance....
On tap. Offers no real surprises, but executes its role as a tasty witbier with aplomb. Subtle fruity aroma, and a smooth, pleasant finish.

7 July 2005 - Fruity citrus and hop aroma. Cloudy light yellow colour with low head and sheet lacing. Sweet big fruit and wheat flavour and low hops. Low bitterness, lingering sweet fruit and thickish beer.
Draught at Sherlock Holmes, Melbourne. Cloudy pale yellow. Neutral aroma. Light bodied with rounded wheat malt character. Really mild and lightly yeasty. Unassuming.

A decent, if uninspired wit. Beautiful on a hot Queensland day at the Regatta with the typical orange-coriander flavors and light body. Has a pale cloudy appearance with a big fluffy head. Fine, nothing out of the ordinary.
A wonderful appearance from the pour, and a good example of witbier. Always going to struggle up against the class of Hoegaarden, but certainly a worth contender.

on tap. pretty weird sulphuric nose suggesting something went wrong but as with 3 ravens blond, i would say it made the beer more interesting. hazy yellow, lightly lemony with faint compost and some fruit tella sweetness
Tried this at the Regatta.Thought this was pretty thin with just enough of the witbier characteristics appearing to make it recognisable as a witbier.
On tap at the Regatta. Can’t believe I haven’t rated this already. A fair attempt at the style. Some spice and citrus in the nose. Relatively thin body with citrus to the fore. Clean finish.

Pours a semi-transparent deep orange/red, with an average sized creamy head that shows good enough retention and nice lacing. Reasonably intense aroma shows a caramel and lightly roasted malts base, red fruit notes and a grassy whiff. Taste follows the aroma closely: caramel and lightly roasted malts base, red fruit notes and a herbal/grassy underlying presence (a bit more distinct than in the aroma). Slightly sweet entrypoint with a balanced finish. Light bodied with low to medium, soft carbonation, resulting in a nicely smooth but not at all empty mouthfeel. Definitely an easy drinker as mandatory per style, well-balanced and interesting enough. A very well crafted bitter.

0,5l bottle from K-Supermarket Lasihytti, Espoo. Amber beer with good and stable, a bit cloudy head. Aroma has sweet caramel malts, some bread and dark fruits. Flavor has sweet caramel malts, wood, earth and somehow dry and bitter fruity ending. A bit watery.
Amber colour with an off white head,a malty caramel aroma. Watery mouthfeel, malt & caramel flavour with a slightly dry bitter finish
Amber color with off-white head. Aroma has caramel, dark malt and hay. Taste is malty sweet with long a bit sweet aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, dark malt, hay and bread.

Cask at “Il Giro del Mondo in 50 Spine” Apr.2019, Xander Beer – Brescia. Limpid dark orange/brown color with modest bubbly and escaping white head resistance. Pleasant roasty and bitter nose. Smooth and watery texture, aroma is moderate malty, braced cereals, cortex. Not much bitter final.

Cask at craft beer co , clerkenwell, next to the street food market. , havibg ethiopean food and english beer. M7ld malty and sweetish aroma, faint, but leads me to think of barley wine. Flavor is malty , caramelly, a bit lava stone caramelly , not very herbal as i have found some bitters to be.

Cask gravity, Elbow Room, Hinckley, 28/02/18. Maverick as an Ed Sheerhan-Adele duet. Drab but competent BSBB with aniseed, fenwater and Allsorts bobs. Slim topped russet. Crumb of Twiglet. Caramel on slate. Digestive afters with a nick of caramel sauce. Aroma of shrub sap and wicker chairs.

From cask at CASK Pub & Kitchen, Pimlico, London, 10.01.19. Clear, pale mahogany. Foamy beige head and lacing. Moderate aroma with dark crystal malt. Complex taste. Strongly maltdriven at frist, with dark crystal malt, dates, figs and prunes. Then hops takes over with lingering pine and juniper bitterness. Excellent!

500ml bottle. Pours copper/mahogany with an off white head. Aroma is toast, brown bread, flapjacks, licorice and citrus rind. Light, refreshing and full of flavour. Taste is toasted brown bread, caramel flapjacks, licorice, orange and grapefruit peel. Nice and malty complimented by a satisfying bitter finish. Fantastic example of the style.

Pours ruby brown, small but thick head, with very tiny bubbles. Aroma is fruity, dry resin, caramel, biscuit, bread, ripe apple, burned sugar, oak. Taste is sweet and watery, caramel, metallic, woody, bready, earthy, slightly fruity.
50cl bottle from a trade with Mariusz, thanks! A hazy golden beer with a big white head. Aroma of clove, mild banana and phenols, yeast. Taste of clove, herbal wheat malt, hints of banana and yeast.
Hell getreidig-hefiger Antrunk mit leicht erhöhter Karbonisierung. Die Hefigkeit ist insgesamt überraschend schwach, das Bier wirkt monoton. Trocken, mild. 8/7/7/8/8/7
* Old rating, many thanks to kevnic2008 for this beer. Best before 18.11.10. Mild-weiches, leicht fruchtiges Bier, frisch, aber nicht zu tiefgehend, nett und gut. Lecker!
Drunk on draught in Konstanz. Enjoyable fruity what beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled at "Xander Beer" (Brescia). Fraught and charged orange clearly color, very hazy aspect with a creamy and foamy head of long resistance. Aged and cellar nose, notes of banana, yeast, grains. A little smooth and solid taste, much round and full of flavour mouth, fruity and little sweet final.

50cl bottle. - pours a murky pale yellow with modest head. Shy dusty aromas of clove and yeast, taste is fruity (ripe banana, apple) and bitter caramel, dry palate (SW sweet malts), medium mouthfeel. Drinkable and thirstquenching, but nothing remarkable. "DLG prämiert 2012 Goldener Preis" - will these guys give anyone a gold award who doesn’t mess with traditional recipes?

(bottle) pours a murky golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of heavy clove, lightly toasted wheat, caramel and grass. flavour is mostly wheat and popcorn, again with heavy notes of clove and a hint of cinnamon. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.

50 cl bottle. Rated on 06.07.2010 Murky brown colour, disappearing head. Aroma has some ashy banana and hints of toffee. Flavour has ripe banana and toffee. Somewhat sticky palate with stinging CO2. Drinkable.
A cloudy yellow amber beer with good head. Aroma is properly malted, good body and fruity notes such as clove, not too creamy but a well done hefeweizen.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Im Glas steht ein sehr hell gelbes, stark getrübtes Weizen mit flacher, feiner Krone, die sich lange hält. Geruchlich dominieren hefig-fruchtige und bananige Züge das Bier. Das Weizen startet fruchtig säuerlich, mit leichter Bananen-Note im Hintergrund. Der Abgang hallt nicht allzu lange hefig sahnig nach. Das Weizen wird im weiteren Verlauf immer säuerlicher. Hält sich zwar im Rahmen, aber es macht den ersten guten Eindruck leider zunichte. Schade drum, Potential ist auf jeden Fall vorhanden!
* Old rating, best before 12 02 11. Many thanks to kevnic2008. Malzig-trockenes Bier, nicht zu tief, sehr süffig. Nett herb.
Trocken malziger Antrunk, mittelherb. Dann wässrig werdend, angenehme aber zu milde Röstigkeit. Schwach bitterer Nachgeschmack. 9/7/8/7/6/7

(bottle) pours a clear copper-amber colour with a frothy beige head. aroma of margerine and old meat, slightly perfumed, with notes of strawberries and brown sugar. flavour is roasted malts, light dark fruit, straw, herbal hops and burnt toffee. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
(Fasche) Es hat eine warme hellbraune Farbe, ist klar filtriert mit einer leicht bräunlichen schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist malzig bis honiglich. Der Geschmack ist wie das Aroma nir recht schlank.
The flavour is bitter-roasty, dark-malty, flowery-herb. A lot of flavours, drinkable, but nothing special. 11/9/9/9/10/10

Bottled. Ambery brown colour with a small off-white head. Aroma is mild toasted malts, some slight fruity notes, mild ashes and some slight caramelly notes. Flavour is quite similar, but is a bit thin and mild. A quite bodied dunkel.

50cl bottle at Alquitara. Brown colour with an easy formation of a creamy and frothy tan head. Aroma is moderate dry fruits, malty and slightly sweet. Flavour is moderate malty, toasty, slightly bready and a final moderate bittery with an average duration. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium to high.

Geruch malzig, leicht säuerlich. Malziger Start mit säuerlichem Zug, wenig passend. Mittig verdünnt malzig. Moderat schokoladig-bitter im Abgang. Recht schwaches Bier - zu dünn.Test vom 1.7.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. It pours a crystal clear dark golden body and a small, dense, off-white to beige head. Caramel dominates the aroma, but leaves some room for fruity hops and grains. Hints of honey. The flavor is quite bitter, with sweet honey notes and some fruity hops. Medium body, decent carbonation. The finish is nutty with honey hints, caramel and some fruity hoppy bittering notes. A beer that starts rather boring but turns out quite nice. 110128

Slightly smoky, forested nutmeat, caramel, sharp sourdough bread, sweet maple. Wow, subtle flavors, well intertwined. Head dies pretty quickly and this does have a tinge of sourness. I like that, some won’t. Not too sweet; has the other ranges of flavors to compensate! Aroma is very good, slight spice, lots of brown sugar and forest elements. Lovely reddish color. Ruppaner is a good brewery! Thanks Stefan!

50cl bottle from a trade with Mariusz, thanks! A hazy orange brown beer with a beige head. Aroma of caramel, dried fruits, clove and some phenols. Taste of dried fruits, carame, nuts, clove and some yeast. Good!
Pours a orange-brown with color a beige color head. Aroma is a gritty malt and leaf. Taste is a light roasted to burnt malt, slight sweet and wet.

Appearance: Medium to dark brown, slightly hazy. Lots of nice off-white head. Aroma: Wheat, metal, toasted. Taste: Sweetness, ripe fruit, wheat. Nice and interesting. Bought: Restaurant (Konstanz), 500 ml tap?, €3.60 Info: 14/4-2017
* Old rating, many thanks to kevnic2008 for this beer. Best before 05.11.10. Mild-weiches, schön malziges Weizen. Bananig-karamellig, erdige Anspielungen. Rund und gut.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A. Rated on 06.07.2010 Disappearing head, murky brown colour. Aroma has ash, banana esthers and some floral notes. Palate has somewhat stinging CO2. Flavour is ’slimy’ with banana esthers, some ripe fruits and toffee. Decent.

(bottle) pours a murky ruby-brown colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of rotten peaches and caramel, with a hint of roasted wheat, slightly metallic and oxidized. flavour is mostly roasted wheat and burnt toffee, with notes of banana, earth and a medium sweetness. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
(Flasche) Es hat eine hellbraune farbe, ist stark hefetrüb mit einer fast weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist ist hefig, etwas erdig und süßlich. Der Geschmack ist samtig, malzig und leicht süß.
50 cl bottle @ Timo A. Rated on 20100706. Aroma of malts, yeast, wheat and spices. Flavor of spices, wheat, herbs and yeast.
Bottle at a restaurant in Rome Deep copper. Creamy tan head. Spicy, somewhat yeasty, aroma. A bit metallic with a thin body. Usual bananas and clove along with rubbery notes.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkel nussbraunes Weizen mit prächtiger Krone. Der Geruch offenbart sich röstig bitter, dezent fruchtig. Der Antrunk erfolgt röstig mit guter Hefenote, und zarten Fruchtnuancen (Pfirsisch und Grapefruit!?) im Hintergrund, welche im Verlauf immer besser durchkommen. Der Abgang zeigt sich fruchtig bitter, minimal sauer werdend. Zum Finish verschwindet die Röstnote fast komplett und wird von dem säuerlichen Fruchtton komplett übertönt. Insgesamt doch ein leckeres dunkles HW!

500ml bottle picked up @ Hobsons Brewery, Cleobury Mortimer. Pours a clear amber, medium off-white head. Taste takes a caramel malt tangent, perhaps a little cake-like, alluding to sweet ginger cake without the ginger. Really a lovely fruity malty amber beer.
Well balanced English ale. Really "Real Ale". Taste, aroma, colour - everything in this beer is great. Want more and more, drink as much as I can.

11/2/2019. Bottle from Tuffins Supermarket, Craven Arms. Poured amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, citrus fruits, hops and dried fruit. Medium sweetness and moderate bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft to flat carbonation.
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 110219
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, hops, fruits and has a sweet finish.

Bottle. Deep amber with fine white head. Sweet malty aroma. Taste is raisin, sweet plum, toffee malts, vanilla. Low carbonation, bitter to finish. Not had this for years and I’m glad I picked up a bottle again. Lovely.
Cask at the Post Office Vaults, Birmingham. Lovely strong bitter with malt and fruity flavours
Lovely beer very fine in the middle Of the day. A great excuse for hobby drinking ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep amber pour. The aroma is quite sweet and slightly fruity. Has a bit of toasted malt, stewed fruit and a little bit of earthy/spicy hop flavour. Moderate body, some light fruitiness and a touch of lingering bitterness. Some soft pepper and a lingering sweetness. Decent.
Copper coloured with film head and lacing marzipan soft red fruits sweet finish tasty light ale.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Came to the table a clear dark amber in color, thin white head and low carbonation. Aroma is dominated by the Munich malt, some light caramel notes in the back. The flavor starts off with Munich and moves into a sweet caramel middle with a slight almost cigar smoke flavor towards the end. The flavors meld fairly well but the beer is just a bit watery for the complexity of the flavors. Overall the smokey notes make the beer pretty good and give it a bit more character than you normally see in an amber.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: On tap at Prairie Rock. Poured a deeper, garnet-tinted amber with a medium cap of off-white head… left some nice lacing. The aroma quickly hinted at rather nasty dark undertones.. bit of toasty cocoa emerges toward the back as a quasi-redeeming factor. Toasty caramel in the flavor along with some vinous-type dark fruit notes and some cardboard.. wouldn’t have been bad if the ingredients came across as fresher.. also not very well-blended. Sharp at the edges and back-end.. lighter-bodied.. ugly taste at the finish. Not good.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Dark amber beer. Carmael and chocolatey aromas. I found this to be rather one dimentional and cloying. Overly malty and not at all balanced. Somewhat watered down and somewhat drinkable. I did not order a second.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Very thin, weak, watered-down...with a mild sweet caramel base and a light hop bitterness that was just a hint. Some mettalic notes in the finish. Disappointing.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Brown/Copper Coloring with White Skin. Sweet Malt Aroma. Sweet Caramel and Light Musty Malt Aftertaste.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: So they also have an amber ale. Hmmmm. As ambers go this again was quite thin, but seem to be par for the course for this place. Malts and grains typical of an amber. Drinkable.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Dark copper color with a medium head. Nice aroma of caramel malts. Fairly strong malt taste. Not much else, but for an Amber, this is pretty tasty.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Schaumburg. Nice clear bronze/amber with a centered splotch and an off-white wrung for the head. Some caramel, peat, pecans, maple, brown sugar and hops in the nose. An affluent acidic edge strikes the palate first but then it’s quickly bygones, transitioning to a mild caramel and subdued nutty pecan profile. Hazelnut and walnut casings come in on the tail end and are the biggest contributors to the nutty finish. Decent.

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Served as a flat amber with just a ring for a head. Delicate orange hops in aroma with a mild bitterness in the flavor. Mouthfeel was thin and a little tinny, and that put me off. Prairie Rock Brewing Company, Elgin, IL

column1: Prairie Rock Clock Tower Amber Lager
column5: Odd Vienna. It’s a dark copper color with a solid off-white head, a strong earthy hop aroma, and a murky, muddy taste. ("This isn’t your Dad’s Vienna...") Roasted malts are there in strength, but the earthy hops muddle up the brew. Prairie Rock Brewing Company, Schaumburg, IL

12oz bottle (Old Notes-Brewed by Chicago Brewing Co.)-Pours a very dark golden with a small white head. Aroma of malt and grains. Taste of the same. This light bodied brew is nothing to write home about.
Sample at the Elgin location. Medium amber with a wisp of head, light clean malty aroma; clean, smooth, crisp, no hops to note, honey and lawn grass...bland.

Pours a clear, mahogany coloration with a medium, creamy head and visible carbonation. Smells of bready, slightly grainy and caramelly malt, dark fruits and herbal hops. Taste follows the nose, with a good balance of sweet, bready, caramel, slightly grainy malt, dark fruits: fig, plum, raisin, lighter red fruits: redcurrant and just a hint of herbal hops and estery spice: clove. Finishes with a light/medium bitterness and some bready/caramel malt, dark fruit and herbal hops lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation. Quite a nice Doppelbock with a good balance of sweet malts and bitter, herbal hops, as well as some dark/red fruit and estery spice adding some depth to this, with the clove actually standing out quite a bit.

500ml bottle. Clear, chestnut colour with ruby glimmer and average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Sweet-ish, dark and caramel malty aroma, notes of malt lozenge, some malt spiciness, a chocolately touch. Taste is sweet-ish, toasty dark and caramel malty, notes of malt lozenge, a touch of treacle, minimally nutty and chocolately overtones, a touch of dried fruit as well. Very nice.
Aussehen : Goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone Geruch : Würzig und Malz Geschmack : Würze und Malz lang anhaltend

Bottle from Drankenhandel Leiden. Sweet brown malt aroma with caramel, notes of dried fruits and lightly spicy. Sweet almost syrupy flavour with a light to moderate bitterness. Body is above medium with a mildly sticky texture. A bit sweet for my taste but pretty richly malty Doppelbock.

Doppelbock de 7,5 % abv pour 18,7° plato. Mon exemplaire était à 1 mois avant sa date. Couleur châtain foncé aux reflets noisettes, avec un petit voile. Bulles fines, en fontaine centrale, très vives. Mousse beige foncé, soyeuse, stable à 3 mm. Arômes de malt grillé, blé, genièvre, prune blanche. 1ère bouche très souple, au remarquable registre malt grillé. Arrière-bouche fine, complexe, avec un très beau malt. 2ème avec des nuances de vin blanc moelleux. Arrière-bouche longue, avec un malt cara superbe. 3ème avec des cerises blanches. Arrière-bouche avec une pointe de kirsch délicate. La longueur trouve encore plein de belles choses à nous montrer. Jambes très fines, serrées, denses. Levure vineuse, riche, grande ligne. Alcool qui fait un remarquable travail d'harmonisation. Finale superbe. CONCLUSION : très grand doppel dont la finesse n'a d'égale que la sévérité du regard du bouc .. Mais on ne s'occupe pas trop de lui dans de telles conditions !! (Ecoute de la dégustation: heavy minds, album de 2015, superbe)

Pours dark, clear amberbrown. Small white head fades instantly. Smell is surprisingly subtile. Caramel, tad chocolaty, rather sweet for sure. Taste is mildly bitter, pairing well with the otherwise overly intense sweetness. Creating that fine balance. Caramelly, chocolaty, more or less 50 50 between both. Médium body and medium to medium high Carbo. Clean fermentation profile. Very easy drinking beer. Lovely!
De Jaghana. Ambrée, légère mousse. Nez caramel cuit, malté, fruité caramélisé. Gout malté, épicé, fruité noir caramelisé avec corps onctueux, classique mais nickel pour le style, intense.
Bottle 50cl, a brown beer with low head. A very sweet doppelbock, caramel, toasted caramel, biscuit, bit heavy,
Kastanienbraun mit heller Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig und leicht metallisch. Geschmack malzig, leicht süß mit Aromen von Karamell und Dörrrobst.

L: -pours a clear copper with a small, quickly dissipating, sand-coloured head -low to medium carbonation visible S: -plums,raisins,spicy,cherries,herbal,syrupy -there's a metallic whiff that goes away once the Beer is in the glass for a few minutes T: -plums,raisins,bready,spicy,cherries,herbs,syrup F: -medium carbonation -medium body -alcohol noticeable O: A bit shy & rough on the nose, but nice on the tongue.
Bottled. A straw coloured beer with a reasonable white head. The aroma is on the sweet side but there’s a little corn. The taste is relatively clean and nicely balanced but really nothing special.
Bottled. Gold colour, low head and condition. Good initial hoppy aroma reminiscent of a German lager, Sweet malt in the mouth and a slight hoppiness in the finish.

Brewed (cheaply I suspect) for the UK market. This has a light sugary aroma that is followed by a sugary water flavour. There is a hint of caramel in there somewhere. The finish is quite long and consists of a chemical mouthfeel. OK, I suppose, for 75p.

Tap from brewpub. Dark chocolate, coffee and oatmeal malt aroma. Midnight black with moderate head. Creamy chocolate/caramel initially with a moderate astringent hops finish. Extremely nice stout especially on a nice 10 degree Maine night.

Any first impressions? -A frothy, creamy head covers the opaque black, lacing admirably. -Nutty caramel and roastiness coalesce in an expressive sweet aroma. -Heavy roastiness and caramel sweetness first massage the palate. -A puffy mouthfeel is achieved even without nitrogen, a smoothness which is appreciated. What if you dig deeper? -Sweet black grapes evolve in the nose. -Dry, roasty bitterness is combined to tea-like, herbal hop for a tasty curtain call. -Fruitiness is now found within the butterscotchy, fat malt. -A very good pint of stout was what I got, none of that quirky yeast and worrying aromas some guys below experienced. On tap at the brewery restaurant.

Pours a tan, one-finger head that goes very slowly and leaves a good lace. Black color. Low carbonation and heavy bodied. Coffee nose. Starts on the sweet side with a roasted chocolate/coffee flavor, finish is smooth. $4.25 for 16oz glass at Jack Russell’s Brew Pub Bar Harbor, Me.

2005 draught at the brewery, 8/14/2005. Opaque, deeply black beer with lacing. Big head, with little retention, recedes to ring. Yellowish colored. Coffee and nuts in the nose, with house yeast jumping out. Flavor smacks of house yeast character. Very earthy, dry, corky, lightly sour. Probably closest approximation is an old rubbery cork. Very odd, but at first, it’s quite novel and interesting. Some coffee and light grains, with light roast as well. But it loses most of its stout/malt quality towards the end of the pint and the yeast takes over. Corky finish. Watery and thin is the consistency. Low carbonation. Nutty somewhat, pretty basic and light bodied. Really wish I could have talked to the brewers about their yeast.

Smells of the clam flats around the coast. Looks nice enough in with a dark color. No head really to speak of, some lacing. Flavor is also similar to the clam flat smell. Not particularly good at all. Very watery.
Nice dark color, this is where the good stops and the bad begins. Little or no head, sickly smell with a touch of metalic at the tail end. Was too watered down, bad bad after taste.

column1: Maine Coast Bar Harbor Espresso Stout
column5: Name: Espresso Stout Date: 10/19/1997 Mode: Draft Source: Great Lost Bear, Maine black, thick tan head, slightly sweet roasted aroma, strong coffee flavor with lots of roasted character, slight overdone malt bitterness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Maine Coast Bar Harbor Espresso Stout
column5: Pours flat black with a dense tan head. Lacy. Smells first and foremost of coffee with underlying smoky malt aromas. Taste is of roasted malt followed by bitter coffee flavors. Smoky and creamy flavors. Milky flavors and mouthfeel not unlike a milk stout. Bitter, almost dry finish. Very smooth. Interesting concoction. First time I’ve had a stout brewed with coffee and it is a positive experience! Thanks to bennybrew for the growler.

column1: Maine Coast Bar Harbor Espresso Stout
Maine Coast Bar Harbor Espresso Stout
column5: Good stout, not sure I agree with the sweet stout classification, though. Very dark brown with a tan, foamy head that can be rekindled with just a swirl of the glass. Roasted, nutty, aroma with a hint of bitter coffee. Roasted flavors persist, more like a dry stout or even a porter with a subtle and effective use of the espresso. Not at all overbearing. Nice lingering flavors. Minor nit - a little thin on the palate.

Bottle. Plastic/fake cherry aroma. Hazy golden yellow with small head. Plastic and iodine flavor - I don’t taste malt or hops. Bought this in Feb so don’t know if this has been sitting around since the summer - can’t stomach this, it’s going down the drain.

(Bottle from Florian’s) Sour, fizzy, infected...Underfilled bottle as usual from Maine Coast. Gigantic foam pour. Cap opens with big pffffffttt!!! 99% of first pour was white foam. Foam oozes out of bottle as it takes about 15 minutes to decant a 12 oz. bottle with all the foam. Cloudy gold-yellow body. Aroma is sour, citrusy, iodine and yeast. Mouthfeel extremely prickly. Taste is citrusy, iodine, Band-Aid and yeast. Another "masterpiece" from Maine Coast. These guys have some real issues going on with their product but they don’t seem to want to hear about it.

Any first impressions? -Enormous foam covers the clear blond à la Belgian saison. -Faint citrus is perceived in the aroma, and a distant iodine phantom. -Herbal hops are met an iodine mess, this is truly horrific and disgusting. -The frothy carbonation and lean maltiness create a competent body for a would-be blond ale. What if you dig deeper? -Do I have to? You’re cruel. -Important herbal hop bitterness almost topples the iodine monstrosity. -If properly delivered, this would’ve been a very decent blond ale, but as is, it should hastily be taken off the shelves. Bottle; no date!

Pours a white, three-finger head that goes quickly and leaves traces of lace. Clear amber color. Light carbonation and medium bodied. Musty hoppy nose. Starts with some bite, I agree with other reviewers this has a sour, corky taste; still a clean finish. Nothing like any blonde I have had. $1.83 for a 12oz bottle from Maine Coast Brewery Bar Harbor, Me.

On draught at the brewpub 8/14/2005. The very low gravity of this beer, and relative low hoppiness did not help fight off the corky, sour, acidic yeast. At least the oatmeal stout had some roast to fight it off, the precipice, some hops, and the blueberry just seemed dry. But this one just gets clobbered and after about 2 sips, the yeast has completely taken over. I will say, the malt is ok in these beers, and this one, especially for a golden is not poorly malted by any means. Same golden color as the precipice, though with a little bit less rusty-tinged notes to it. Smells like a hint of toasted grains and then all cork. A bit watery, hard to finish. I really wish I knew what was going on with this brewery and its strange, to put it lightly, yeast.
Light yellow/gold beer. Thin fizzy head. Watery and refreshing but that’s about all it’s got going for it. It’s basically Maine Coast Budweiser.
Light Golden color with a fine white foam. Mild hoppy aroma. Light malt. Clean and crisp hops wiht restrained malt flavor. Thin flavor. light and fluid consistency. A bit harsh finish.

column1: Maine Coast Bar Harbors Best Bitter
column5: Reviewed from notes. On tap at brewpub. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a dark copper/Red color. Bar pour’s kind of slim white head left no lacing. The smell had a decent light caramel/nutty/English maltiness ( light soapiness). The taste was pretty much the same. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sessionability about it. It left a nice creamy texture over my tongue. Overall, good bitter to style, I’d have again.

column1: Maine Coast Bar Harbors Best Bitter
column5: On tap at Jack Russells Brewpub. Amber colour with a thin white head. Decent bitterness. Smooth texture. Seems well balanced. Nothing special but makes a decent bitter.

Any first impressions? -A ring of foam circles the hazy blond. -Crisp wheat and faint citrus fruit fail to excite the nostrils. -Dull banana and honey sweetness barely wake up the wet, wheaty softness. -The smooth carbonation fits the appropriately lean body, but it soon feels limp. What if you dig deeper? -It finishes dry, and mostly bland. -A salty, Cup-a-Soup is evoked by the flaccid nose. -Oh, the brewpub estival wheat ale...I still don’t see a purpose for it when the house blond could easily do the same trick. On tap at the brewery restaurant.

After sampling this one, and being thoroughly disappointed in this brewer’s offerings, I stumbled into the car my wife so lovingly drove and went back to the hotel to drink some of Atlantic’s offerings. I don’t think I’ll seek out this brewer again.
Yellow, fizzy, mildly refresing, but not exactly exciting. Watery hop taste with little aroma.
Had a bottle of this whilest up in Maine for the weekend. it was a pretty generic and average summer ale.

Reviewed from old notes. On tap at the brewpub, this was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a black color with a thin bar pour’s kind of head that died off immediately. The smell had a light chocolate covered banana thing going on, not bad but not exactly what I thought it was going to be for a true dunkelweizen (side note, what was I expecting, its not in a weizen glass), sorry, anyways. The taste was sweet through the chocolate covered banana, not bad. On the palate, this sat about a light to medium with a fair sessionability about it. Overall, well, actually I liked it for what it was, but it just didn’t seem like a true dunkelweizen but an American version of one.

OK, to be fair, I found this bottle 1/3 full in the barn while cleaning things up. Of course, being a connoisseur of aged brews, since I have been obliged to imbibe many of my own over the years, I had to give this a taste. I have no idea how long it’s been there, but I can say that I haven’t been to Bar Harber since my wife’s birthday (Jan 4) somewhere around the turn of the millenium. I rate this winter ale high on the scale because I am currently enjoying the aged version, and I know we both made the most of the fresh brew on that cold January night by the fire. -Al maxwell

From the archives: Oh damn me - this was available 10 years ago in Tartu. It was priced below anything else, it was sweet an honey-like. Drinkable and fulfilling for every student out there. Stay away from this one.

1.5l Bottle- Golden/Amber in colour with mild carbonation and a cream white head. Overwhelmingly sweet honey aroma which is a bit off putting. The taste is quite smooth smooth with honey featuring prominently. It is probably not natural honey but the beer is more drinkable than the aroma initially suggested. This bottle size is too big for one though as it just gets too sickly.

This was the first Russian beer I ever tasted, and it also was among the first I ever rated. We were visiting friends, and this bottle was brought on the table. And it was a 1½ litre plastic bottle, and it brought my prejudice out of the closet... It was sweet and sickening to put it short and the honey never was brought in the right context...

1,5 ltr plastic PET-bottle. Pale amber color, small white head. Strong aroma of honey. Light mouthfeel. Malty flavor with honey sweetness. This tastes actually like a light lager with real honey added.

1,5 litre PET bottle. Yes, the rating is right: 0.6! Hazy, light copper color, no head. Smells like dishwater, combined with sweet apples and apple syrup. Ditto flavor. Threw away the whole bottle after a sip. Luckily it was only € 1,25.

A hazy amber beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of honey. The flavor is also sweet with notes of honey, but here the honey is mixed with light notes of flowers and rose hips, leading to a dry end. The body is thin.
Plastic bottle. Orange colour with a small white head. Sweet honey, skunky aroma and a sweet honey taste, light harsh. Medium body with a sweet finish.
Plastic bottle. Clouy amber coloured with a white head. Sweet aroma of honey. Sweet flavour of malts and honey.
Big plastic bottle. Hazy amber coloured. Honey candy aroma. gr5vytvgr6gvt5gft5ft546gft j
Bottled. Honeyish orange colour, minor head. Weak honeyish aroma. Honey, rye and weak malt in flavour. Finish turns to somekind of vegetables. Dry finish.
Golden, small, aroma grain, sweet, malt, taste same, bittersweet, decent for 0.0.

500 ml can. Pours golden colour with creamy white head. Slight grainy aroma. Taste were sweetness, metal and low bitterness. Aftertaste was sweet and bitter. A brew with very thin and watery flavours.
Soapy, metallic and way too watery. Good one on a hot day if you don't want a sweet soda/alcohol beer. Pretty so-so as a non-alcoholic beer.

Bottiglia. Il naso riconosce indizi di orzo. L'olfatto viene stimolato in maniera normale e il modo in cui permane è appena percepibile. Il cappello di schiuma resiste abbastanza. La grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. Il liquido è di consistenza limpida e anche qui la grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine, con carbonazione nella norma. Il colore è giallo dorato brillante. Il corpo è medio. L'amaro è percettibile. La forza gustativa è leggera e la durata è corta. Le sensazioni boccali finali risultano di facile beva. Il finale è semplice. Al palato finiscono note di miele, cereali, carta ed erba.
Bottle. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy cardboard aroma. Sweetish malty grainy cardboard flavor. Has a sweetish grainy watery finish.

Bottle, 470 ml. Golden colour, surprisingly good, creamy white head stays for a long time. Weak hay and dry hemp on the nose, typical unfermented beer taste, weak and watery sun-roasted barley taste, but quite drinkable. This is from the better side of non-alcoholic beers, actually it's not as bad as some were before.
Waterly, dull. In fact just a bit sweet sparkling water with malty tones. Avoid.
How: Bottle. Where: Had at home. Appearance: Light yellow colour with a quickly fading white head. Aroma: Sweet malt, some bread. Body: Watery body, lively carbonation. Flavour: Sweet malt.

Can @ Friends/Dr Yeast. Appearance: pours clear straw with ok white soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: barley, bread, cardboard and light floral notes. palette: light malty aroma, average carbonation, light body, light to average sweetness, unbalanced by a light bitterness, short duration and a watery texture. Overall: uninspiring

Smell- weak, nonalco hops, nothing really. Foam- thin, bit to watery side, but not really, soft to half soft, weak bitter notes to sides of tongue. Small head, white, of looking. Appearance- light clear, yellow, orange amber, no carbonation. Taste- refreshing, weak bitter notes, with weak citrus, well this is probably one of best nonalco beers I had, Baltika sure rules in this regard. As simple as it gets though.

500 ml bottle brewed in Germany at 5.5%. Smallish, so-so lasting head. Clear gold, classic German lager colour. Very clean, uninterrupted honey and corny malt aroma. Moderate carbonation. Slightly earthily bitter hops go down to meet a slightly honeyed sweet bready malt rising upwards, striking a nice flavour chord, with a slight mineral aspect, and almost no 'sweetcorn' notes. The combination is really quite pleasant, even for myself whose favourite style isn't lager, so I imagine some drinkers would rate this very highly. Doesn't let itself get bogged down and sickly/soggy sweet, so it's a win as a lager in my book - I like them this way, ever so slightly pilsner-y, and Paulaner are happy to oblige.

Von Holzfass at Braustub Munchen. Thought that was the best way to check up on this MJ 500 beer. Bright gold, crystal clear, with a tall, slightly rocky head. Light lemon in the nose, with sweet biscuits, bread. Overwhelmingly malty. Sweet flavor os honey and biscuits, with light lemony hops and a slightly peppery finish. There is some sulfury minerals too. Soft, smooth body with low carbonation as expected. How does it stand up? Not well. It is sweet, lacks hops, and the malt character is far too simple to carry it. It does have a lovely and drinkable body due to the gravity pour, though. But I think that growth in the company may have led to cheaper malt bills, and there are just too many better lagers around to think this is still interesting.
(nez sympa de bons malt & houblons, ~pêche, bouche amplo-soyeuse, réconfortante après ménage, bien fait !)
Piana znika kolor jasny klarowny Lekki posmak starości od chmielu lub słońca skunks piwo nie jest złe ale nie zachwyca zwykły niemiecki lager z wyraźna goryczka i odrobina tresci.

Clear golden with almost no head. Aroma is mostly grainy with some bread sweetness. Taste follows with the malt being more prominent, quite bready, clean, more balanced on the finish. Medium minus body with medium carbonation. Decent lager but very one noted.
Plaisante, mais à un goût d'alcool assez prononcé qui ne développe pas beaucoup d'arome.

500 ml bottle. Pours a clear light golden with a white head. The aroma is lightly malty with grains, cereals, cardboard and some skunky notes. Medium body with an average carbonation, a light to medium sweetness and a light bitterness. The flavor is lightly to medium malty - sweet grains, cardboard, cereals. Overall not pleasant. Aroma: 4 Appearance: 3 Taste: 5 Palate: 3 Overall: 8

Bottle with expiry 10.18. Golden colour, rocky head that quickly disappears. Nose is faint, with cellar and malt. Mouth is cellar, malt, alcohol. Light bitterness, light sweetness. Lively carbonation, feels overcarbonated to a degree that makes it hard to feel the taste. Too alcoholic. Not very drinkable. I have nothing against a malty Helles, but this one is just poor.

500 ml bottle. Clear golden, small head. Grain, straw, citrus notes. Medium bitterness, minimum sweetness. Light bodied, watery texture, dry finish, lively carbonated. Well made and easy going Export. Not bad.
Pale pale yella. Aroma is soggy bread. Sweet malts, mild to no bitterness. Palate has more sweet graham cracker. An easy drinking beer, not bad, not exciting either.
Light fruity aroma. Cloudy golden colour with good head. Very nice honey flavor. Very light body with low to medium carbonation.
...name is self-explanatory, but at least it’s not just a marketing lie as are other beers. Not really any flavor, but what is there isin’t bad. Some hints of malt and hops, so it’s not the worst.

Crazy, crazy stuff. Light amber colour, poor head retention and a bit of chill haze. This is not your typical light beer - smells like a cross between cider and Samuel Smith’s Imperial Stout (seriously). The cider aroma isn’t the typical megalager cider aromas but more like the musty, stemmy cider aromas of Kellybrook Old Gold. Has the salty, sultana, tobacco and licorice aromas like SSIS - the resemblance is quite uncanny really. Flavour is pretty thin with apple and pear juice sweetness, thin malt, diacetyl, no hop character and a champagne-like acidity. Freaky shit really and quite enjoyable, though I’m sure it’s not how this beer is intended. An Aussie Berliner Weisse?
Eponymous. God ratebeer, this means it lives up to its name. Eponymous. 75 characters yet?

Surprisingly malty aroma. Tiny bit of a malty then bitter taste but still really watery. I'm going to be kind and say that this is probably better than most other lights, but only when consumed fresh. Damning with faint praise.
At least there is truth in advertising here, all lite beers need this label. Imagine carlton cold with extra water, sigh.
Цвет золотисто-соломенный. Пена не большая. Аромат: солод, немного травянистый, солома. Вкус: солодовый, сладковатый. Алкоголь во вкусе не чувствуется. Средний такой лагер.
Bottle. Pours amber with medium white head. Aroma is sweet, fruity, cookies, some nuts, light caramel. Taste is sweet, soft, cream pie, some caramel, light nuts, malts. Nice beer!

On tap. Il gusto al naso è indirizzato verso l'orzo. L'olfatto viene stimolato in maniera normale e la maniera in cui permane è sufficiente. Il cappello di schiuma è destinato a vita breve. La grandezza delle bollicine è a grana fine. Il liquido è di apparenza velata. Il colore è giallo dorato carico. Il corpo è pieno. L'amaro è non invasivo. La forza gustativa è elevata e la durata è buona. Il gusto è piacevole. Il finale è dissetante. Il retrogusto è di decente intensità. Sulla lingua si attestano indizi di zuccherino, miele, frutta secca, erba, agrumi e mela.
50cl bottle from Drankenhandel, leiden. Thick white head. Hazy golden pour. A bit sweet. Ok

Bock hell alemana. Poco aroma y espuma. Baja carbonatacion. Ambar claro. Gusto equilibrado ligeramente dulce. Refrescante. Esconde bien el alto grado alcolico. Parece mas una lager normalita que una bock. Nada de particular.

Company own 0,5 l screw cap bottle. Pale copper in the glass, nearly two finger frothy white head. Cheap alcoholic smell with some caramell. Taste starts more smooth. Caramell, some malt, some fruity parts, less alcoholic sharpness than expected. Above average for an Heller Bock, but not good, to be honest.

the aroma is malty and fruity with hints of grain, buckwheat, honey, toffee and flowers... the taste is rather sweet, fruity and malty, with notes of apple, honey, grain and some grasses... sweet and dry aftertaste...
Tap at Berlin Bar in Copenhagen. Clear golden color. Aroma reminds of Swiss cheese, weirdly. Taste is quite sweet, but not overwhelming. A little flat. The high alcohol content is not noticeable.

Flasche 0,5l: Golden, glasklar, stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; würzige + frische Nase, kräftige malzige Süße, leichte fruchtige Noten, helle Früchte, Malz, Malzzucker, Getreide, deutliche Hopfennoten; frischer + würziger Körper, angenehme fruchtig würzige Süße, leichte Hopfenaromen, Malz, Malzzucker, Getreide, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure; angenehmer fruchtig-würziger Nachgang

Bottle, pours rich golden-amber with a fast-settling head and aromas of golden malt and dry grass. Palate is rich and malty sweet, with dry bitterness cutting the sweet edge. It really does remind of a super-strong Helles, but done right, with everything in proportion.
Very thin. Dark malts and acidity that are not quite in balance. Not that enjoyable.

Flasche 0,5l (ABV: 5.0%): Dunkles Kupfer, Kastanienbraun, kräftige Trübung, mäßig stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; frische Nase, fruchtige Süße, reife Bananen, dunkle/eingelegte Früchte, Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, kräftige Hefearomen, leichte Röstaromen; frischer + fruchtiger Körper, reife Bananen, dunkle Fruchtigkeit, Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, Hefearomen, leichte fruchtige Säure, etwas dünn; fruchtig-malziger Nachgang mit Hefearomen

0,5 l bottle from my local Hol´Ab! market. Unclear dark brown in the glass, small one finger pale beige head. Yeast, wheat and fruity elements on the nose. Sweet berryfruity and caramell taste at the start. Later some wheat and yeast, low banana and sulfur. Getting a little bit dry in the second part. More on the thin side and can not fullfill all expectations.

Bottle from Lekkerbier, Sint Nicolaasga. Aroma is wheaty malt, caramel, lots of banana bread, soft spicy yeast, toffee. Flavour is sweet and lightly bitter. Body is medium. Decent Dunkelweizen, sweet with lots of banana.

(Bottle, Aufsturz, Berlin, 24 Aug 2016) Hazy brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with dark bread, prunes, raisins, chocolate and banana. Malty, slightly roasted taste with notes of dark bread, chocolate, ripe banana and dried fruit. Medium body, with a touch of sweetness. Tasty and well made dunkelweizen. Quite nice.
Cloudy orangey brown colour. Aroma has some biscuity malt and banana. Flavour has banana sweetness and a mild, yeasty aftertaste.

Couleur ambrée un peu trouble, petite mousse beige. Fort nez fruité banane avec note caramel et petite levures. Gout malté fruité (banane, fruits noirs) avec notes de levures et caramel. Corps un peu leger. Fin légère fruitée

Bottled. Brownish amber colour with a small beigeish brown head. Aroma is chocolate, wheat, toasted malts, soem toffee and yeast. Flavour is caramel, some toffee, yeast, mild bananas as well as some mild toasted notes.

Dunkelweizen from Baden-Württemberg, from a stubby 50 cl bottle with screw cap, perhaps inspired by similar experiments in the wine world. I pour this in a Maisel’s Hefeweizen ’vase’, in which it looks already majestic... Thick and dense, egg-white, frothy head as usual in this style, colour mahogany (orangey brownish) with yellowish edges, fully cloudy with a great deal of sparkling, almost like a sparkling wine. Aroma of red apple, banana, cookies, brown bread, cloves, ’speculoos’, cinnamon, gingerbread, chestnuts, sourish wheat coming through nicely. Fruity taste, restrainedly sweet, some banana, peach and passion fruit hints, wheaty sourness piercing through with very refreshing effect; soft and smooth mouthfeel, a bit powdery and fluffy as usual in this style, caramelly and somewhat nutty malt sweetishness in the middle, retronasal spiciness from the yeast (cloves) and finishing in a play of sweet, sour and bitter, all in a subtle way and working well together, but the sourishness lasts the longest; texture-wise, one could argue the finish is perhaps a bit thin and on the watery side. Though not Bavarian and not the most tasty Dunkelweizen I ever had, this is a perfectly acceptable, well-made and well-balanced example of the style (a style I prefer over the closely related Belgian witbiers), highly drinkable and very quenching. As a consequence, I don’t quite understand the averagely low ratings here...

Bottle 50cl, a cloudy amber brown beer with medium head. Nose is low on fruit yeast and with light toasted cereals. Aroma is on caramel, less malty, medium fruit notes, bread touch, bit watery, easy drinkable, finish is on pineapple and lemon, bit disappointed.
Sweet bitter hop arma with some nuts on the side? Clear yellow colour with poor head and no lacing. Bitter hop malt flavour. smooth palate.

21 Sep 05 - Simple slight sweet, light apple fruit and slightly spiritous aroma. Clear yellow golden colour, with poor head and lacing. Low malt, low hop flavour. Light tangy bitter finish and some lingering sweet hops. This beer is a bit ordinary.

I really don’t know what to make of this. I’m actually getting some enjoyment from this beer but I can’t believe it’s in the manner that the brewery intended it. Aroma is nuts, cider and metal, as with most of this brewery’s beers but perhaps less objectionable with the cideriness quite appley (Granny Smith). The beer tastes thin, sour, very appley and astringent. It really in no way resembles a good pale lager. I’d kind of describe it as cross between my insipid (but OK) home-brewed cider and a wussy lambic (maybe Belle-Vue Gueuze). Looks pretty good. High carb. Tastes like granny smiths.
Better than the Draught and the Bitter put together but still a crappy taste for the price.

Pretty screwed up. Better than the pale ale, i tasted more hop in this (but it ain't any where close to being hoppy). Classic Aussie chemical finish, (although, it does say that theres no preservatives). Pretty shite. Premium my butt!!!
Slight malt aroma and bitterness. Watery with an unpleasant aftertaste. Not worthwhile.

Well, this supposed ’premium’ stuff is slightly less bad than the confusingly named "Geelong Premium Lager", but that’s not saying much. This seems to have aspirations toward being like CUB’s Crown Lager, with added unpleasant floral aromas, flavours and aftertastes.

This beer was nothing special. Thought I was getting a German beer on the cheap before I got home. Never have had such a problem with overflowing bottles on opening. Didn’t get better even after 3 of these. I would have rather had a VB.

I was in Purvis cellars ogling all the beers I was yet to try. This place is seriously good. The amiable chap pointed me in the direction of this and given the price I thought I would give it a go. It looks and smells like a lager, little hop presence but a reasonable biscuity nose with overtones of orange. This citrus note comes across in the taste with a hint of dried fruit. Is this brewed correctly or are these esters that shouldn’t be here? Anyway, another rate and a reasonable beer but not memorable by any stretch of the imagination.
Smokey hop malt aroma. Clear amber colour. Sweet flavour with dried fruit and christmas cake. Fizzy palate.

A true bargain beer. A smooth, well rounded, easy drinking flavour, with a hint of honey and frtuityness to add interest. You wont be fooled into thinking it’s a true German beer, but it has enough of that essence to make its consumption a pleasure. I’m not aware of a better "drinking" beer for the price.
9 May 2004 - Slight fruit malt aroma. Clear yelllow gold colour and slight lacing. Simplistic malt sweet and hopping flavour, it has a funny artificial aftertaste with a slightly flat body.

Initially smells like Ovaltine, then heaps like pears but both of these dissipate and it smells really malty - honey, bread, golden syrup, diacetyl - so much so that it seems like some kind of artificial "German malt" aroma. Really interesting aroma but I’m not entirely sure about it. Flavour is pretty toffee-malty with no real bitterness but it’s not oversweet. Malt is kind of cardboardy.
