Really interesting stuff but a bit all over the shop, frankly.

Hints of fruity maybe even apple and honey notes in the aroma with some almost Old Speckled Hen volatiles. Smallish head that held and a bright copper gold colouring, pasturised clear. Sweet malty almost apple flavours. Weird that this is a Pilsener but even if others didn’t enjoy this I liked it.

Decidedly un-Bavarian. Very crappy Aussie stuff, and even though its in accordance with Reihensgebot, its still manages to taste like they threw a crapload of chemicals and additives into it. Dirty water-esque.
Sweet, fruity & strong aroma. Very light yellow but a decent head. Has a somewhat lemony taste that is otherwise undistinguished. Also a short finish.

Too pale & watery with a non-existant head. The flavour is flat and lifeless with an unpleasant cloying quality. The patronising label note gives an indication that this brewer is not to be taken seriously, and this over-aspiring beer is just another awful strike for Geelong Brewery.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Bottle: &nbsp Vibrant golden, soft haze, beaucoup carbonation, large frothy white head, decent lacing. &nbsp Musty nose, very basement like. &nbsp Not what I was expecting. &nbsp Very slight earthiness, some floral aspects... all very light but they are there. &nbsp Bubbley in the tongue, some wet blanket, straw/hay. &nbsp Very lively on the tongue. &nbsp Has this powdery sugar aspect on the back end, much like whiffing a freshly opened packet of kool-aid. &nbsp Moderate body, prickly mouthfeel. &nbsp Decent, but for a Pale Lager it comes across more as an Ale. &nbsp A little musty, earthy perhaps, but its light and fairly refreshing.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Bottle. Pours a foggy golden color with a frothy white head which was spilling out of the bottle when I opened it. Malty. Very malty. Some peppery spice in the aroma too. Bland flavor, yet crisp finish. Malty. Some lemon zest. Nothing really special about this, actually.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: I drank this with the expectation that the beer (Obama ’08) would give me something to be glad about this 4 year term. It wasn’t. First, why a "pale Ale"? Why not an amber or something. Poured a light yellow, cloudy (what else is new), with a big head (right on the money) that disappears just like our tax money! The aroma was lemony, and the mouth feel was just ok. The hops were mild. This beer pours and foams like it’s going to do something, but then it just sits there and disappoints. Like it’s namesake, it’s nothing special! Sent to me by my College Buddy Ken, who the beer group says after trying this, is not a very good friend. He has been asked not to send another bottle!

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Sampled as Mavericks Obama Presidential Ale. Pours with a golden body topped by a thick, foamy head with a good amount of lacing. Hmmm...not much to say about it except it has a light grassy bitterness. Light bodied and highly carbonated.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: 650 ml bottle from Bevmo. Obama ’08 presidential version. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a rocky white head that has good retention and lacing. The aroma is sweet canned creamed corn. The flavor is the same, obnoxious corn with a bit of dirt and some mildly spicy hops. The mouthfeel is thin and weak. The finish is short and dry.Overall: Memorable for all the wrong reasons, this beer sucks.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: 22 oz. bottle from BevMo (SD) - Pours a hazy light golden color with a larger two finger thick white head. Very light lacing. Aroma is light esters, herbal hops, and grain. Flavor is very light. Has some faint malt sweetness. Light body. A drinkable beer, but a waste of money.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Bottle Obama: Really does have a good drinkability. Has good flavor profile with some malts and hops. Food Pairing: Hot Dogs.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Like the president this beer was made for in support of, it fails on so many levels. First, you’d think that to celebrate a momentus occasion (despite on his failure so far) they’d create a new beer, not just relabel an old one. But that’s what they did. And then, they didn’t relabel a good beer, but a crappy pale lager. C’mon. The beer pours out a clear dark yellow color with a quick dissapearing act of a head. Aroma is musty grain, green apples and a bit of hay. Flavor has some mild vegie sweetness and little else. Just an awful beer to celebrate a monumentally huge landmark occasion.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Obama!!! Your lager sucks! When I see you on the label, I taste this cloudy, musty, and inadequate mouthfeel of grassy, somewhat sweet term of citrus mediocrity. Change is likely because I’m sure you can’t provide the big bucks. This lager is decent - but obviously fails especially if you’re going to market it with OBAMA. Shit.

column2: Half Moon Bay, California, United States
column5: Bomber of Obama ’08 from BevMo, Salinas. Nose of musty grain and hay with a little sweetness and background spiciness. Hazy darker gold with a medium, short-lasting white head. Flavor is light bitterness, grassy hay, and light caramelly sweetness. But shouldn’t this have been an amber or porter as opposed to a pale lager?

column1: Barley and Hops Rippen Raspberry Wheat
column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: The aroma is all about BERRIES, BERRIES, BERRIES and MORE BERRIES. Sweet Raspberries and Blueberries. I smell both, but the brew's name is specific. Great aroma, either way. I hope the flavor lives up to it. This beer is a slightly hazy, light amber. Small, creamy, white head with minimal lacing. The flavor is fruity, lightly malty and lightly sweet up front. Nicely balanced with lightly bitter and tart hops on the backside. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Short, fruity, tart and dry finish. Great Spring and Summer beer. Why it's on tap in February, I have no idea. A very good offering from what I've found to be a fairly mdeiocre brew-pub. Although, the food is very decent and the staff is great.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Light straw and some raw barley. Golden pour with decent head and lacing. Light crisp finish. Tap at brewpub.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: On tap at ATR Bethesda. Hazy yellow body with large head. Nose malty and sour. Flavour malty, some fruits and dry. Medium balance.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Draft. Hazy pale yellow color, thin white head. Aroma of subtle white pepper. Taste is watery straw.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Tap at the brewery. Pours clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is heavy Pils malt, corn notes and light spicy hops. Flavor is sweet malt dominant with light hops and bitterness and a sweet finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Taster on tap at the brewpub. Labeled 4.7%. Clear golden color. Minimal ring of white head. Good bready flavor. Lightly peppery. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter, just a light bite. Medium body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Decent blond ale, better than expected.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Pale gold yellow no head; aroma is slightly spicy with grain and hop notes; Flava is wheaty and flowery softly bitter; feels light; finishes vary dry and bitter like aspirin;

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a hazy very pale yellow color with a huge fluffy white head that left great lacing. The aroma was sour, tangy, corny and a bit fruity. the flavor was dryish, nutty, malty and had notes of cardboard and corn. Dry nutty and corny finish. Medium body. Not good.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Draft at the brewpub, July 2006. A light yellow beer with a thin white head. The aroma is very light with faint notes of malt. The flavor has a weird citrusy note to it combined with light malty notes - reminds me of a light beer. The end is dry and bitter and comes very late.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: Enjoyed on tap at the brewery with dinner. The beer had a traditional gold-yellow color with a good white head. Featured light-medium carbonation and body with a thin-average texture. The flavor was mostly sweet but had a slight sour taste too. The aroma was sweet floral malts.

column4: Barley and Hops Grill and Microbrewery
column5: On tap at the brewpub, July 2006. I was a bit taken aback by how many US brewpubs make a Kolsch, but I thought many of them were just very light quaffing ales that had little in common with the genuine article. This one was closer to the mark than most. Very pale, straw colour. Gentle fizz - not too carbonated. Featherweight mouthfeel. A touch sweet. The merest hint of biscuity malt. Not a lot to it, but clean and fresh, which is really all you’re looking for in this type of beer.

Keg at the brewpub. Slightly hazy amber, large frothy offwhite head, good retention. Aroma of white bread and mild citrus and herbal hops. Taste is doughy pale malt, orange, herbal hop. Medium bodied, high carbonation.

Pours a golden yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is light bread malts. Flavor is bread and earth. Has some carbonation and a light body. Better than your usual pale lager this is meant to stand in for, but still not great.
Draft at the Vierling. Lighter copper with a white head. Sticky, sweet aromas. Overpowering. Gross.
Draft @ Vierling brewpub. Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma of citrus, light malted. flavour is light malted with citrus.

On tap at the Vierling, Marquette. Hazy straw-yellow body, thin off-white head. Sweet, light, nectary nose. Grassy, bitter body with light sweet clover honey notes. Sharply carbonated. Bitter finish. Surprisingly tasty for a style that all but begs for mediocrity.

On draught at the brewpub in Marquette, Northern Michigan. Pours a clear golden pale straw colored brew with a thin white head that quickly dissipates to a thin white ring and some spotty lacing. Aroma of golden grain malt, some light citrus zest and grassy hops. Taste is light bodied, golden grain malt, some grassy hops, a touch of lemon zest and some white pepper. Finish is crisp, a hint of metallic texture but then a very light grassy hop aftertaste.

Bright yellow pour, with a wisp of creamy white. Aroma is a light waft of sweet malt sugars and hints of rock candy. Flavor is a sweet crisp run of nice pale malt, with a balancing parch of hops. Clean, refreshing and nicely drinkable. I give it high marks for a blond, having no detectable off-flavors, a nice sweet lemony malt flavor, good balance, good body, and good carbonation. That’s all I can ask for. However, based on previous ratings, I’m pretty certain that I’m chemically and physically incapable of detecting diacetyl.

5 oz draft sample at the brewpub, late July 2006. Very clear dull yellow-gold with a touch of head....nose is buttery corn and buttery butter, mmm diacetyl I can smell ya....thankfully on the tongue its much cleaner, malty and smooth, on the full/thick side to start, touches of vanilla cookie are nice....thins out too much at the finish; low natural-feeling carbonation.
Clear Pale/gold with small dissapating head. Faint malt nose, with faint hops. Light weight, with sweet midpalate and hop spice on the finish.Solid though not too interesting.

Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a rugged looking dark copper almost amber color with a thin finger’s worth of a bar pour’s kind of slim white head. Just falls out into oblivion. The aroma had a decent blend of some roasty malts, light nuts, some caramel/toffee crispness and then some citrusy and dried piney hops. Touch of earth. The flavor had a decent blend of sweet to bitter, somewhat coming through in layers (there’s that ’separation’ that I usually wish more beers could stay blended). Nutty sort of aftertaste with a malty finish. The feel was between light and medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. And ABV felt fine as well. Overall, decent amber ale that really isn’t anything out of the ordinary but still worthy to have again.
Keg at the brewpub. Slightly hazy golden, thin tan head, poor retention. Aroma of faint wheat. Taste is honey, dry wheat. Thin, almost watery. Meh.
Pours a hazy straw yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is light wheat, light earth. Flavor is a pleasantly sweet wheat with hints of honey. Has plenty of carbonation and a light body. Not bad.
Draft. Golden color, very basic wheat ale, slight hops, basic standard UP brewpub offering.
Draft at the Vierling. Clear gold with a light head and searched with a lemon...heVy wheat and oddly sweet.
Draft @ Vierling brewpub. Hazy light golden colour, white head. Aroma is wheat and a bit of lemon. Flavour is fruity, citrus. Slightly bitter, refreshing.

On draught at the brewpub in Marquette, Northern Michigan. Pours a semi-hazy golden straw colored brew with a slow dissolving white head that leaves behind some spotty lacing. Aroma of light golden grain malt, a hint of wheat some lemon zest and a touch of crystal hops. Taste is light bodied, some carbonation with flavors of golden grain malt, some citrus zest and a touch of lemon. Finish is crisp, no bitterness with some light golden grain malt aftertaste that quickly disappears.

A clouded orange-tinged pour, with a slimy white rim of head. Light off-lemon aroma. Flavor is a flowing, yet meaty, carbonated watery slush. Some greasy savory notes. Sweet, but in a weird earthy way. Soured honey dominates. Through the water, the palate is somehow cloying, without balance. A number of off-flavors bring this down.

5 oz draft sample at the brewpub, late July 2006. Cloudy, translucent golden hue with a touch of quickly dissipating foam....honey and hints of caramel and vanill in the dull unidimensional aroma.....body sweetish, somewhat cloying but lacking totally in malt presence, a bit mineralic to finish....little to say here, and even less to experience.
Nitro at the brewpub. Dark brown, thin creamy brown head, fair retention. Aroma of roast and a lactic twang. Taste is roasted malt, sweet finish. Thin, overly sweet.

Pours a jet black with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is roast, chocolate, and caramel, and something almost like lactose. Flavor is roast, chocolate, caramel, and cream. Has a very soft, smooth body. Not too bad.

On nitro at brewpub, pours a dark brown/black with a medium cream khaki head. Aroma of earthy chocolate malt and nuts, light hop Spice. Mildly sweet taste, chocolate and molasses, nutty, some licorice. Ok
Draft. Dark brown/black pour. A very basic i guess dry stout, roasted malt notes, herb and spice.
Draft at the Vierling. Mahogany with a beige head. Roasted malt and milk chocolate. Super thin and light.
Draft @ Vierling brewpub. Black colour, tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, bit of coffee. Flavour of roasted malts, some sweetness, coffee, but quite watery. Slightly bitter finish. Too watery.

On nitro draught at the brewpub in Marquette, Northern Michigan. Pours an opaque dark brown colored brew with a creamy beige head that has excellent retention and lacing from the nitro charge. Aroma of toasted dark malt, a touch of coffee, chocolate and some marzipan. Taste is smooth and creamy, medium, bodied, with flavors of toasted dark malt, a hint of coffee and some chocolate. Finish is semi-sweet with a lingering toasted dark malt aftertaste. very little bitterness if any.

Draft at the restaurant/brewery. Deep opaque brown-black body, thick creamy nitro head. Aroma of roasted malts and light butter. Incredibly smooth, creamy body with rather dry roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate, well-balanced and immensely quaffable. Very light sweetness. Definitely beats the thin, woody, acidic dry stouts so widespread these days.

5 oz draft sample at the brewpub, late July 2006. Served on nitro. Opaque and completely black with a lasting smallish smooth brown head....lovely sweet candy-like aroma, with chocolate, almonds and nougat all appearing along with a hint of roasty malt...mellow, moderately bitter chocolaty body with some medium-roast coffee thrown in towards the finish....smooth throughout, just a hint of bite, perhaps a little too thin at the end. Still easily the best beer that I sampled from this brewer.

On tap at the Brewpub Didn’t really consider this a Guinness clone, considering this beer actually had flavor. Pour of deep black with brown fringes and tan clean head. Tangy roast aroma. Heavy sugar and roast flavor. Strong scotch, oak, and oat flavors on the back end. Touch of earthy and chewy grain over a little charcoal. Palate is a little thinner than I would like, but it’s drinkable.

Keg at the brewpub. Slightly hazy copper, large creamy offwhite head, good retention. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit, pale malt. Taste is grapefruit, citrus, lemon, pale malt. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness.
On tap. Off white head and gold color. A-sweet citrus with a little pine and some light/medium malt. T-follows.
Draft. Very IPA-like pale ale, pretty hoppy, citrus and herbs, finishes nicely hoppy.
Draft at the Vierling. Clear copper with minimal head. Light, clean hop aromas. Similar flavors.
Draft @ Vierling brewpub. Dark golden coolour, off-white head. Aroma is massive citrus hops, grapefruit. Flavour is bitter, juicy, grapefruit, pine. Still good drinkable, malty backbone. Good stuff.

On draught at the brewpub in Marquette, Northern Michigan. Pours a clear golden pale amber colored brew with a decent off-white head that slowly dissipates to a white ring and leaves behind some excellent lacing. Aroma of Cascade citrus hops, a hint of caramel malt, some light pine and a touch of apricot. Taste is medium bodied, hoppy, with a hint of caramel malt, grapefruit and a touch of lemon zest. Finish is mildly bitter that lingers after the finish. Almost touching an IPA caliper territory.

On tap at the Vierling, Marquette. Hazy straw-orange body, thin off-white head. Bitter, citrusy nose. Bitter, rindy body with potent citrus and pine hops notes. Big bitter finish. Good heft. Solid pale ale.

Pours a nice clear golden color with about an inch of creamy white foam. Minimal lacing. Hoppy aroma. Piney hops dominate the flavor. Beyond that, it is fairly generic. The body is on the light side, but the carbonation is perfect. Light hop bitterness in the aftertaste.

This beer has a nice color contrast with its golden amber pour and white head. For aroma, you can definately detect some hops, citrus flavors, and a strong oak type scent. Slightly acidic flavor with a slight bitter finish, but overall a pretty decently well-balanced brew.

5 oz draft sample at the brewpub, late July 2006. Dark amber with just a bit of lasting head, no appreciable lacing....citrus and apricot prominent in the nose, delicate floral spiciness....sweet and a touch syrupy/thick at the front changing to rather sour and tangy and a mite lactic at the finish....somewhat low carbonation doesn’t help matters.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a thin white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is peach and wheat. Flavor is sweet peach, wheat, and bread. Definitely tastes of extract, but not in a bad way. Has plenty of carbonation and a light body. A pleasant drinker for those who like fruit beers.
Draft. Sweet peach muffin type flavor, creamy sweet wheat, sweet peach flavor.
Draft at the Vierling. Clear yellow with a white head. Fake sweet peach syrup aromas. Decent peach flavor and light.
Rust and some caramel. Not terrible, which is an achievement at this place. Tangy amd cloying off aftertaste. Tap at brewery.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.
On tap at Wonder Street. Medium amber color. Thin off white head. Maltier than the other ambers tried here. Earthy and citrus. Could definitely use more hop balance.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Dark amber colored beer with off-white foam. A lot of toast, bread, and caramel. Some soda water, too. Actually a touch of chocolate and cola. Okay. Slight nuttiness. The flavor is big on caramel and chocolate. Kind of nutty. A bit of cola on the back end as well. Typical garbage brewpub amber ale.
Dark amber body, thin off-white head, spotty lacing. Caramel malts. Not much else. A big amber ale. Medium to full bodied, mild carbonation, not much in the way of bitterness, semi-sweet throughout

"probably their most popular beer A) because it’s a malt bomb, so macro beer drinkers that are afraid of hops will love it, and B) it’s 8 freakin percent, so frat boys looking to get drunk quicker like it. That being said, even though I love my hops, this is a pretty stinkin good beer. Unbalanced, yes, but the flavor, mouthfeel, and aroma or all carmely, malty good! the best of their regular rotation."

Comes out of the tap a clear mahogany with a pale tan head. Malty aroma has hints of cloves and hops. Strong malty flavor has notes of cloves and horehound and a subtle hoppy undertone plus something of an alcohol nip. Thin but smooth body has light fizz.
On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: citrus, roasted malts Taste: similar citrus, roasted malts as in the aroma, bready A clean well made beer, a simple style, but this was crafted well.
Light amber with a fizzy white head. Very faint malty aroma. Toffee and alcohol taste with a roasty finish.

[Tap] Pours a bright copper color with a thin white head. Some caramel in the nose, with hints of alcohol and mild citrus. The taste is of caramel malts, sweet fruits and a Belgian-like sweetness to it. A bit cloying overall. One dimensional flavor profile lacks much of a hop balance. Not one of their best beers, in my opinion.
Empty and boring like gambling life. Pours golden with ok head. Light tangy end. Tap at brewery.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity malty grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy finish.
Draft at the source. Crystal clear yellow color. Scant aroma and subtle flavor. Plain.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Clear, pale straw colored pour with a white head. Just a bland, grainy beer. Some cereal/corn flake notes to it. A bit of soap as well. Pretty sweet flavor. Lots of grain, corn, and perhaps bread. A light grassy hop note, soap, and some subtle citrus. Kind of bland and watery, but crushable.

"another blonde ale that fails to impress, even though it IS quite a bit better than many blondes out there, but at the end of the day it’s still boring. Silver Peak actually says it best...the perfect microbrew for macrobrew enthusiasts. I didn’t know they existed...i thought they were just a myth. "

Comes out of the tap a clear straw yellow - I was not impressed, but I like darker beers. Crisp, malty aroma has a fruity hint and is not strong but still has merit. Malty, jazzy flavor has hints of hops and fruit. Smooth, dusty texture is rough around the edges and has a persistent tingle. IMHO not Silver Peak’s best, but still worthy of at least a try.
Light yellow with a fizz white head. Faint malty aroma and taste with a hint of citrus.

[Tap] Pours a clear yellow color with a fizzy white head. Nose of light malts, grain and sweet corn. Similar light flavors, with sweet malts and a mild grassy finish. Low carbonation levels. Crisp and thin, but without much going on here.

Draft sample at the brewpub. Pours a clear pale yellow color with a small white head. The aroma was barely there but included moderately sweet pale malts and was somewhat grainy. The flavor was dry pale malt lightly toasted bread and not much else. I could have used this to rinse between the other beers. Rating #12 for this beer. 6/23/10
On tap at Brewpub Appearance: Clear straw/yellow with a white head Aroma: Not much aroma of anything Taste: Pale malts, some light hop flavor Pretty bland, not much of anything.
Grapefruit husk and see booze. Not great balance. Some barky bitterness in finish. Hazy golden pour with ok head. Tap at brewery.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty citrus hoppy bitter flavor. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy bitter finish.
Draft at the source. Slightly hazy yellow color. Tropical fruit aroma. Taste is bittersweet fruit. OK.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Hazed orange pour with a white head. Sugary orange nose. A lot of grass as well. Some floral notes, bread, and a subtle earthiness. Lots of orange and floral notes on the tongue. Good bready malt, some bitterness, but an overall sweetness that is just too much. Slight astringency on the finish.
On tap at the brewpub. Hoppy citrus and pine with a light sweetness in the background. A bit weak in the middle. Solid IPA finish with a lingering bitterness.

Orange colored body with medium sized white head and soapy lacing. Modest florals, citrus, and grapefruit. Mild crackery malts throughout. Medium. Bodied with moderate to gentle carbonation, rounded finish with modest bitterness.
"a solid entry into the ipa category. strong enough to take notice, highly aromatic and flavorful. one of their better beers, with Red Roadster. recommended."

Comes out of the tap a pretty clear amber, and off-white head leaves some heavy lacing. Strong aroma is quite hoppy and inviting if you like hops. Fiercely hoppy flavor is quite bitter and has woody and fruity notes. Texture has strong fizz and good body.

On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: citrus, tangerine, pine, apple Taste: citrus/tangerine/floral hop notes, bready This was a great IPA, had a firm bitterness that kept the malts in check. An amazing hop bouquet.
Hazy light orange with a fluffy white head. Bready slightl hoppy aroma and taste with a watery citrus finish.
Roast and some off musk. A hint of coffee. Pours black with decent head and lacing. Bitter end. Best of their beers by a long stretch. Tap at brewery.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty caramel aroma. Roasted malty caramel and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty caramel and chocolate finish.
Draft at the source. Opaque brown color, tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Taste has cocoa and coffee grounds. OK.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Just about black in color with a tan head. Nose is quite heavy on the ash and roasted nuts. Some coffee, burnt sugar, and a lot of dark fruits. Just a general, sugary sweetness to the flavor. A lot of ash and roast, too. Some coffee grounds, cocoa, and ash. Decent enough, but a lot of sweetness.

Dark brown-black body with a medium to thin light tan head and spotty lacing. Roast, light caramel, chocolate, and almost a cinnamon like spice. Medium bodied with moderate to lively carbonation, semi-dry throughout, slightly muddled finish.

"this one can hold it’s own with Great Basin’s porter, but i still prefer GB’s. nice aroma of coffee and chocolate malt, less than full mouthfeel with more of the same in the flavor as the nose. their #2regular brew."

Comes out of the tap an opaque, warm, chocolaty sable with a thick light tan head that leaves some good lacing. Smoky aroma is downright ambrosial, with mocha and burnt hops notes. Delicious flavor has notes of smoked wood, quality coffee, chocolate and molasses. Firm body has good fizz and a lip-smacking fizzy and smoky finish.
On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: malty, toasted/roasted malts Taste: chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, hint of caramel A good porter without flaws. A solid brew for sure.

A - Served a dark brown-black color with a finger of tan-brown frothy head. The head slowly fades leaving behind some thick lacing. S - Aroma is a mix of chocolate malts and roasted coffee. There is also a touch of milk sweetness and hops. T - Starts off with roasted chocolate malts and a bit of coffee flavor. The is a bit of background hops noticeable. Through the middle a bit of lactate sweetness alongside some more roasted flavors come through. The finish is roasted and slightly sweet and lingers. M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. The beer feels smooth and just a bit creamy. The finish is slightly dry and roasted. D - Very drinkable. Nice balance of roasted chocolate and coffee flavors. The touch of hops that I tasted was a nice addition.
Black with a fizzy off white head. Big roasted grain and slightly burnt coffee aroma and taste with a cream flavor to the finish.
Clove and banana. Ok hefeweizen. Pours golden with good head and lacing. Light sweet end. Tap at brewery.

Draft @ the brewery. Pours a slightly hazy yellow golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy finish.
On tap at Wonder Street. Served in a shaker pint. Clear golden color (not cloudy). Thin head fades quickly. OK flavors and body, but not very true to the style.

Draft sample at the Reno airport from notes. Pours a hazy yellow gold color with a small white head. The aroma and flavor have pale wheat malts, banana and cloves, some citrus, doughy, watery mouthfeel, meh.
Draft at the source. Cloudy yellow color. Nice aroma of clove snd bsnsna. Taste has sourdough bread, banana, citrus. Nice.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Slightly hazed orange pour with a white head. Banana and an overwhelming spice nose. A sour lime and coriander mix. No thanks. Some clove in there as well. The flavor is heavy on white pepper, coriander, and clove. Astringent lemon peel finish. A lot of banana and bread sweetness as well. Just all over the place. Comes with a lemon, so negative cred to begin with.

"like anyone’s hefe, it can be refreshing on the right day, but it’s another standard, uninspired entry into the category. a little watery, decent malty sweetness and a slightly spicy banana-clove finish."

Pours a nice hazy golden, typical of a hefe but still attractive. Strong wheaty and lemony aroma has a hint of yeast. Refreshing wheaty flavor has a lively, tingly texture. Body is average but the tingle persists. Perfect for a sweltering summer day.
On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: clove, banana, slight malt Taste: doughy, clove, banana A solid German Hefeweizen. I really enjoyed this beer.
Dark yellow with a fluffy white head. Strong lemon bread aroma and taste with a hint of clove and banana. Watery palate.
Nice malty rich nose and flavor. Hops come out enough to balance, as does a fruity begian yeast with a little extra kick of sweetness. I’d go back to this...
Dark amber body, thin off white head, spotty lacing. All German malt with toffee and warm brown bread. Mild florals. Medium bodied with moderate to gentle carbonation .
"i’ve had this one on tap a couple times, and it’s a solid offering, if not their best beer. Just a hint of warming alcohol bite. Sweet and fairly hearty with a clean cereal malt finish."

[Tap] Pours an average copper color with a large and lasting foam head. Sweet grains and caramel malts in the nose. Sweet and malty taste includes caramel, molasses, sweet rolls and a grainy finish. Mild grassy hops trail off at the end. Average mouthfeel and low carbonation levels. A touch out of balance, but not bad overall.
on tap-pours an off white head and bronze color. Aroma is sweet medium malt. Taste is medium malt, earthy/slight copper hops.
"not great, but better than i was expecting. nice malty flavor with a subtle hop finish. balance is done quite well, the flavor is good, just a touch on the week side."

On tap @ Silver Peak poured a clear golden amber with a small lingering off white head. Aromas of carmel, biscuit, light earthiness and a light hint of citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, biscuit, earthiness and a trace of citrus with a smooth lightly bitter finish.
Not bad for a pale lager. Some caramel, grain, and hops. Not completely lacking in flavor, decent for th style.

On-Tap at the Brewery (There for the 04’ Reno Air Races)Filtered bronze color, no head or lacing. Aroma of light caramel & grains. The flavor is a bit carbonated & doesn’t have much aside from a light sweetness & moderate hopped finish. Decent, metallic tail. Eh.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Clear golden pour with a white head. Lots of bread, cracker, and grass. A bit of apple on the nose as well. Actually, a lot of apple. There’s a rather intense sweetness to the flavor. Tons of grain, apple, and bread. Slight grassy bitterness on the finish.
An ok pils. Adequate grainy malty bite, with faint sweetness. I’d love to see a touch more from the hops and the body, otherwise pretty much as expected."
A golden pils with no head. A grainy malt aroma. In mouth, a decent crisp pils with good german hopping and biscuitty malt. Medium bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 2007.
On tap at Silver Peak Reno, NV Pours out a clear gold topped with a white head. Some wheat and grain on the tast. But hey its a Pils
On tap @ brewery. Golden color, good looking pils despite poor lacing. Yeasty aroma, no sweetness. Flavor was very traditional, lacking sweetness and had some yeasty flavor; very mediocre.
"large amounts of toasted malt in the aroma and flavor. a nice, indistinguishable Oktoberfest. slightly better than Great Basin’s for local bragging rights due to the heavier malt profile. "
On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: fruity, malty/grainy Taste: fruity, grainy/malty A standard Oktoberfest style beer, no real flaws just a little dull.

Draft @ Silver Peak. Pours a clear, bright amber-orange color; creamy, off-white head with good retention and fine-bubbled lacing. Some dried red fruits and light chewy caramel in the aroma. Medium mouthfeel: average carbonation; dried red fruits, chewy caramel, and light sugar; basic, drinkable, and reasonably crisp, at least. Medium finish: very toasty malts and a touch of cereal in the finish; quite dry. A drinkable, straightforward Oktoberfest.
Poured a golden brown with off-white head. Toasty, nutty aroma. Flavors of fruit, nutty malt, and a little hops. Easy to drink and a thin body as with most of silver peak’s brews.
Sweet and syrupy without much else. Pours dark brown with ok head. Oily syrup consistency. Very bad. Tap at brewery.

"this is a popular beer due to the strength with the local college crowd, but it is surprisingly thin for a 10.5 abv brew. it’s not bad at all, but drastically pales in comparison to the much better dopplebock brewed once a year at the Great Basin brewery in sparks."
Dark red amber with a thin white head. Molasses and alcohol aroma and taste with a silky palate.

[Tap] Pours a clear and bright golden color with very little head and no carbonation. Aroma of grainy malts and sweet apples/grapes. The taste is of sweet grains, some corn, syrupy and bready notes and noticeable alcohol. Smooth and thick in body. This seemed more like a malt liquor to me and less of a doppelbock.
on tap-pours no head and red color. Aroma is cherry, medium malt. Taste is cherry, acidic, medium malt.

This stuff ain’t bad, although I have to admit that I was buzzed before I drank this, so my rating might not be 100% correct. From tap, poured a dark amber/red. Tasted fruity, yeast, malt, and kind of bready. The alcohol is amazingly well hidden. Easy to drink, smooth, and high abv, so this brew can really sneak up on you.

Growler(this is on tap only product, don't ask for growler). Minimal head(small on tap), off-white color, no lacing; clear and very dark amber body. Lots of red. Odor is malty sweet(honey, apples), light molasses, alcohol and very yeasty like dough. Full bodied, soft carbonation creamy to syrupy body. Wet with light salavation induced. Front is lightly sweet and yeasty like bread dough for a darker bread, hints of bitter and sweet fruit flavor on middle and well masked alcoholic flavor. Finish is yeasty and lightly toasty bitter with sweet malt overtones, similar to those in the odor. Fairly well balanced. Shamefully easy to drink and with its abv...be careful. Overall: Not the yeastiness of Tahoe brews, but close! Better fresh on tap, where it demonstrates a stronger fruity flavor and more sweet malt character. Sweet malts and fruit come to life as it warms(from odor to flavor).
"a below average brown...not the worst of the twelve beers we sampled only because i like browns better than bavarian hefes and weizens. definitely an uninspired sample of the style."
On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: malty, toasted/roasted malts, coffee Taste:coffee, caramel, floral, roasted malts A really good brown ale.
on tap-pours an off white head and copper/brown color. Aroma is mild medium malt-dusty chocolate. Taste is medium malt-roasty/nutty/dusty chocolate, secondary earthy hops bite.

Draft @ Silver Peak. Pours a deep, clear reddish-brown color; creamy light tan head with good retention and lacing that coats the glass. A very bland aroma that really just shows the SP house character and little else: a basic dry maltiness and a hint of berries. Medium mouthfeel: average carbonation; some light nuttiness, medium acidity, and a touch of dry cereal malts; again, very little here to speak of: a bland, lightly hopped brown; the hop character is quiet at first, but there’s a light juiciness that emerges, perhaps a bit too late. Basic finish of dry toastiness and cereal malts.
On tap. Poured a light brown with off-white head. Flavors of some fruit, caramel, and smoke. Pretty much a general brown ale taste. Very smooth and easy to drink. A little to watery, but still good.
Tap at Brewpub: Mahogany color, light head and lacing. Nose of toast and sesame seeds, plum flavor with some fruity and fig. Nice citrusy and malts and a dry hoppy finish. Good and chewy brown.

On tap. Pours clear, lightish brown with average off-white head. The beer is awful until it warms up, as most of the following description is non-existent until the beer has sat. Caramel, light hops and light coffee aroma with some alcoholic character. Front is pleasantly sweet with a semi-dry burst of more than soft, almost lively carbonation which is pleasant. Following is some alcoholic flavor, then bitter hops character with mostly light coffee notes and a long, but mild, bitter coffee aftertaste. Probably my favorite brown beer because it's not, really. It's flavored like a stout, but has the lighter body of a brown, obvious color difference and generally lighter "stout" character. Very smoothe.
Draft @ the brewery. Pours a golden pale amber color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.
On tap at the Wonder Street location. The last of the three ambers tried here. Light bodied with medium malts and low bitterness. Boring.
Draft at the source. Crystal clear bright yellow color. Aroma of light fruit. Taste is lemony lager.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Light amber in color with a white head. A nice bit of toast but mostly this just smells like cereal grains. Some grass, apple, and caramel. Meh. The flavor is just sugary and sweet. Not a whole lot going on here. Sugar, apple juice, and corn flakes.
"Red Roadster’s little sister in a way. Weaker, and not as good, but a little hoppier, and therefore more of a balanced traditional amber ale. Not bad, not great."

Comes out of the tap a clear amber - average, but acceptable. Malty aroma has a hint of wood. Malty flavor is rather hoppy and has a firm hint of apple. Smooth, fizzy texture has average body but is still satisfying.
On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: grassy, grainy Taste: grassy, grainy, harsh/astringent, earthy A decent amber ale.
Light copper with a fizzy white head. Faint malry aroma and taste with an off slightly spicy taste.

[Tap] Pours a light amber color with very little head to it. Sweet caramel nose. The taste is of sticky caramel, light brown sugar, some ripe fruit and grains. Light to average mouthfeel. Very little hop contribution. Not bad, but pretty boring.

Draft @ Silver Peak. Pours a clear, amber color with a small off-white head. Very light aroma, sweet malts, hints of fruit and a touch of honey. The flavor is dry, light sweet malts, hints of caramel, grassy hops; pretty straight forward basic amber.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: Draft @ the brewery. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel aroma. Fruity malty spicy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel finish.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: "I may have had this once b4...but will rate based off today’s. Great scotch ale and one of SPs best. Rich and flavorful. Aroma and flavor of chocolate and sweet and smokey peet. Delicious!" 2019 - lighter in color and overall palate than it used to be. Seems different for sure.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: 6 ounce sample on tap at the brewpub. Nice sticky, peaty, sweet caramelly nose with some light roastiness present. Very nice scotch ale aroma. Transparent dark amber body with a good off-white head present. Flavor is pretty light. Has a little peat and a little roastiness, but this is kind of thin and lacks the sweetness and body I prefer in the scotch ale. Fairly pedestrian.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: Draft @ Silver Peak. Pours a clear amber color with a small off white head that disappears into a small ring. The aromahad ample amounts of caramel and ripe fruits with a high level of sweetness. The flavor leans heavily toward caramel with additional notes of ripe fruits, toasted malt. There is some mild bitterness at the finish. Light alcohol notes as it warms. I thought it was a bit thin for a Wee Heavy, but overall not too bad.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: Draft at brewpub. Pours copper amber with an off white head. Sugary malty aroma. Flavor of dark malts and peat countered by a moderate bitterness. Ok

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: Draught at GABF 2008. Clear amber coloured with a small off white ehad. Sweet aroma of caramel, berries and fruits with notes of overriped fruits. Sweet flavour of caramel, fruits and berries with notes of overriped fruits. Dry finish of berries.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: Draft @ Silver Peak. Pours a clear, bright wooden-cola color; off-white head with fine-bubbled lacing. Good amounts of caramel, dried fruits, and candy sugar in the aroma without being overly sticky. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: solid caramel and dried dark fruits upfront (dates, raisins); nicely developed malt character and, again, reserved overt sweetness; really nice rendition; some toastiness at the core. Medium finish: toasty grains, dried fruits, and some light caramel and sugar; balanced end.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: Quite a nice scotch. Pour is a fairly dark reddish brown with a decent white head. Aroma is malty, sweet caramel, scotch, and a little bit of floral and hops. Most of the flavor is caramel, toffee, sweet malt and scotch, but there is a little bit of hops also (not much). A fitting medium mouthfeel.

column1: Silver Peak McHineys Wee Heavy Scotch Ale
column5: On tap @ brewery. Dark body, reddish brown and poor lacing. Aroma is intriguing; thick malts and balanced. Flavor is complex with big malts, but not overly sweet; well balanced and big, but not big enough to betray it’s strength! No real hop profile(grrr), but they are there as this is well balanced. Some scotchy flavor; rich flavoured. Full bodied, smoothe, nice mouthfeel. I’m not crazy over the flavors, but it is very well done.
"had to work really hard for any aroma out of this beer. like the color, but it looked thin. better body than the look or smell suggested. a little too spicy for my taste."
on tap-pours an off white head and cloudy amber color. Aroma is sweet medium malt, banana, medium fruit. Taste is sweet medium malt, banana, medium fruit.
Tangy raspberry and not a great backbone beer to support it. Pours red amber with ok heaf. Tangy finish. Tap at brewery.

On tap @ Silver Peak. Bright red, soda looking pour. Sweet sugar and raspberry syrup on the nose. Not much else going on. This pretty much tastes like a raspberry soda. Sweet, sugary, and berry flavored. I like it though. I guess I’m a moran.

"A tasty and refreshing hot weather brew. Bordering on wine cooler status, but without making you feel cheap in the morning. Not one I go for all the time, but a guilty pleasure. Also pretty nice mixed with their porter or oatmeal stout."

Comes out of the tap a clear reddish golden amber. Malty aroma has a strong raspberry overtone that is rather sweet but not too sweet. Raspberry dominates the malty flavor that is crisp and sharp. Dry body is a bit thin and not too fizzy; still, the raspberry flavor and a bit of fizz persist.
On draft at the restaurant. Aroma: sweet syrup, raspberry Taste: raspberry, odd bitterness This beer could use some work. Not the strongest beer in Silver Peaks line up.
On tap at Silver Peak Reno, NV Pours out a ligth pink topped with a little head. A light aroma of raspberry and ???hops??? Overall not that good.

On tap @ Silver Peak poured a clear washed out red with a small lasting light pink head. Aromas of bread, raspberry and a hint of citrus. Palate was light bodied dry and slightly tart. Flavors of bread, raspberry and a light hint of citrus with a smooth dry raspberry finish.
An okay raspberry aroma. Flavor is of sweet raspberry candy, like a Jolly Rancher. This is just overwhelming sweet and sugary.

Aroma of sweet raspberries and a little malted grain. Appearance is red/pinkish with little head. Flavors are one dimensional. Raspberry and grain, slightly sweet. Pretty boring, with not much going on.

Sampled draught at the taproomBright pink/ruby color, barely visable head, some lacing. Nose of husky grains and unsweetened raspberry extract. The flavor pulls it off, very light sweetness & moderate body. A bit syrupy but well done. WTF is with the color? Looks like a soda.
This beer had a nice color but a bad aroma and ok flavor. I feel like this is not how this beer was intended. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared with Srykzone via Facebook Chat. Pours a copper color with an off-white head and good lacing Nose of malts and floral and grassy hops. Medium body with smooth mouthfeel. Favor is lightly roasted caramel malts with floral hop bitterness that carries over into a dry finish. Very easy to drink beer and quite enjoyable/

22 oz. bottle from Hayduke with whom it was shared via facebook chat. My bottle was a gusher with a huge light tan foam that slowly faded. Sticky lacing. The nose was nice malt and soft hops. The flavor included soft fruit, malt, and earth. Near the finish some cocoa and spice was tasted. It was borderline Oktoberfest with the subtleness and spice. This was an enjoyable beer that one could spend some time with. It would be great while watching a game or shooting the bull. The sum is greater than the parts.
Bottle. Rich amber beer with an off-white head. Big toasty aroma. Toasty, malty flavor with light citrus. Medium bodied. Toast and malt linger with light citrus and light earthiness.

Bomber from Bottle Barn. Pours a ruddy copper with a 1 finger foamy off-white head. Smells lightly bready with some grassy hop. Medium body with strongish carbonation. Flavor is mildly roasted caramel bready with a nice dose of hop bitter. Finishes more dry than not, and it’s very drinkable.
(draft). Clear amber color. Medium off white head. Roasted malt aroma and flavor. Avg duration. Light dry finish. Thin texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

A deep copper ale with a thin white head. A light butterscotch aroma with light boiled vegetables. In mouth, a light caramel malt with light mashed chick peas, medium bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 16 2009.
Yellowish brown with no head. Faint sweet fruity and toffee aroma and taste with a metallic finish.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color with a small white head. Has a slightly roasted malty caramel aroma. Sweetish malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a sweetish malty caramel finish.

Date: 09/07/1997 Source: Brewpub rusty amber, whispy head, sweet malt aroma, light body, light hop flavor, just too light all around Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.6/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Keg at the brewpub, 03/02/16. Golden amber with a decent beige cap. Nose is caramel malt, light hop, breads, toasted grains. Taste comprises caramel, airy malts, brown sugar, toasted bread, biscuit, light fruit rinds. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with faint hop bitterness. Dull.

Draft at the brewpub, served in a flight. Pours a mostly clear orange-gold with a small white ring for a head. Generic slate of red malts, caramel, mild toast, straw, grass, and hay. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a floral, malty mouthfeel. Beyond boring. To make this your signature beer shows a distinct lack of ambition.

Draft at the brewpub. Clear light amber orange coloured pour with a halo of off white head. Aroma is nutty grains, light toffee, light raisin. Flavour is composed of hot alcohol, nutty, light caramel grains, brown sugar and a some earthy hop. Palate is semi sweet. Moderate carbonation meh.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours clear red-gold with a creamy white head. Mild lightly toasted bready malts in the aroma, with touches of pine. Light sweet flavor with some damp grains, grass, berries, harsh bitter grass, leaves. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Strong bitter grass in the finish, more grains, leafy hops. Harsh overall. Rough.

Draught at Dempsey’s. Clear deep amber liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of citrus, caramel, raw sugar and toast. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of caramel, toffee, toast and citrus. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Meh.
Draft at source. Nose is lightly caramel with some buttery notes. Very clear light red. Taste is a lightly burned toast sensation with a moderate bitterness. Not bad. Not great.
Draft - Light caramel and hops. Clear copper with a decent off white head. Light bitterness and some caramel. Not bad.
Pours an amber color with an off white head. Caramel, malt, toffee and slight hop aroma. Caramel, malt, toffee and light citrus hop flavors. Medium body and carbonation. Malt and caramel finish.

On tap @ Dempsey’s. Hazed light amber pour with a white head. Kind of watery, bland nose. Some light malt aroma of bread and toast. Light orange peel and grass. Flavor is sweet and malt forward. Notes of caramel, toast, and bread. A bit of bitter orange peel and grass. Kind of watery, a bit astringent.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear light copper color with an ecru head. Aroma and flavor scream crystal malt. Some caramel malt too, but this is heavy on the astringent iced tea.

Keg at the brewpub, 03/02/16. Light black with a well appointed tan head. Nose is light roast, toffee, raisins, cocoa sprinkle. Taste comprises chocolate dipped raisins, brown sugar, toffee, light charr, mellow roast, light ashen tones. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, drying close. Ok stout.

Draft at the brewery, served in a flight. Pours a dark brown color with amber edges and a small beige head that settles into a ring. Notes of roasted malts, tobacco, burnt sugar, cocoa, and caramel. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, slightly roasty mouthfeel. Smells good. Looks good. But it falls a bit flat once you drink it.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours clear brown with a creamy khaki head. Mellow dark malts in the nose, toast, faint roast. Light sweet flavor with bitter char, burnt grass, cocoa, earth. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Finishes with ashy roast, more bitter earth, grass, baking cocoa. So so.

Draft at the brewpub. Clear mahogany brown coloured pour with a fading reluctant head. Aroma is dark malts, ashy, raisin, harsh bitter. Flavour is composed of dark malts, burnt toast, slightly ashy, harsh bitter. Palate is semi sweet. Drying, moderate carbonation. OK

Draft at source. Nose is dark fudge with coffee and roasted grain overtones. Light black to deep brown with ruby highlights. Taste is similar to bad homebrew that kind of reminds me of a yeasty flaw I can’t quite pick out. Like autolysis or something going on. Weird.
Draft - Nice roasty notes and some chocolate. Jet black with a decent beige head. Roasty and toasty notes. Solid, but nothing special.

Draught at Dempsey’s. Opaque black liquid with small to medium tan head. Aroma of coffee, ash, citrus, grain and toast. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of coffee, toast and earth. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Decent. Bit harsh bitterness.

Alhohol should not be made to sniff, swirl or spat. If I had to rank a scent to the beer, it smells just fine. Looks dark like a stout or porter. Taste is similar to Rasputin but slightly milder. It’s a good winter time brew or to be paired with their beef tacos. The grease/seasoning in the beef tacos pairs nicely with this beer and worth checking out. It’s certainly worth checking out if you like Rasputin or the Icelandic Smoked Porter.

An ok stout. Nothing special. Pours a very nice deep black with a tan head. Smells of vanilla and cinnamon, and a bit of malt. Taste is lacking, a little thin for a stout. Paired with Peanut Butter M&Ms in vanilla ice cream, smooths it out to he point of having no taste. Had in the bottle.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark black color without much head. Roasted malt aroma and flavor. Mild hops. Burnt.

On tap @ Dempsey’s. Listed as the 2009 Reserve Barleywine, but I believe it is the same beer. Copper pour with a small khaki head. Really sweet and fruity nose. Notes of sherry, candied orange, caramel, and raisin. Really, really sugary. Fair amount of pine, surprisingly. Flavor is nearly cloying. Tons of caramel, sugar, and fruit. Sherry, candied orange, raisin, and dates. Mild pine flavor and bitterness. Hints of booze, too.

Tap at the brewpub. As the 2011 Anniversary Barley Wine at 11.25%. Pours hazy glowing dark amber with a slight off-white head. Sweet malt aroma. Full bodied. Brown sugar flavor with enough bitter to keep it from seeming to be too sticky. There is a mild spicy hop aspect. Nice.

From tap at Toronado, Barley Wine Fest 2010. Pours cloudy orange with a huge off-white head. Aroma is dry hoppy and light fruity. Bitter, dry malty and solid fruity. Dry and fruity into the finish. Smooth and distinct hoppy finish.

2004 vintage on tap @ Dempseys poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of sherry, toffee, carmel, fruittiness and a hint of spice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a lightly dry finish. Flavors of sherry, toffee, some brandy notes, light fruittiness and light spice with a smooth bittersweet finish.
Tap @ Toronado 2005 barley wine festival. Rudy color with a laced tan head. Brown sugar, molasses, bitter but balanced hops.

Draught, Toronado. Body is dark amber. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel, cookie), lightly hoppy (resin), with a note of wood. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, syrupy texture, soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Almost devoid of aroma, but with an ok flavor balance, this was a snoozer.
The bartender at Dempsey's ALe House in Petaluma, CA said this has been aged for over a year. Dark amber color. Wonderful fruity lambic taste.

column1: Three Rivers Orchard Street Raspberry Wheat
column5: Pink/orange cloudy body. Smooth palate, but too much raspberry and wheat for me. Not my style at all.

column1: Three Rivers Orchard Street Raspberry Wheat
column5: Pours a deep pinkish amber w/ no head. Aromas of rasberries and thats it. This is bad, just bad. Acidic with no brett character. Extremely dry and fruity. No hops or malt, just fruit. BAD!

column1: Three Rivers Red Apple Flyer Cider
column5: Draft @ brewpub. Clear, warm, gold, flat. Aroma is the skin of Granny Smith apple, and somewhat sulfuric. Flavors are a bit sour-sweet, but finishes dry due to the good strength. Has too much acetylaldehyde. Starts to taste like pale lager after a while!

column1: Three Rivers Red Apple Flyer Cider
column5: Golden and smells like apple juice. Very sulphury and lactic cider with only a little bit of apple character. Wonky balance.

column1: Three Rivers Red Apple Flyer Cider
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear yellow with a thick white head. Aroma of apple and bready malt. Flavor of very sweet apple, some tangy qualities. Apple juice-like with a light palate, very drinkable. Ok for a cider although I overall enjoyed it. 7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

column1: Three Rivers Papa Bears Golden Honey Wheat
column5: Draft @ brewpub. Nice warm honey-gold and clear. Aroma is weak, not forthcoming. Sipping reveals a thin, rather sweet rendition, oozing sweetness, simplicity, and candylike character. Playful, and simple, needing more depth and complexity to be good. Can be called cute. Surprised this is billed as their best-selling beer.

column1: Three Rivers Papa Bears Golden Honey Wheat
column5: Golden, bright. No aroma. None. Honeyish sweetness on the palate, with a light cascadey, fruity hop character.

column1: Three Rivers Papa Bears Golden Honey Wheat
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear yellow with a white head. Aroma of wheat and sweet malt. Flavor of sweet malt, honey fruits. Not too sweet, this is very mellow and drinkable. Actually quite a nice wheat ale. 7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

column1: Three Rivers Papa Bears Golden Honey Wheat
column5: Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub: Yep it is golden alright. Silky and sugary sweet, this actually might go well with some sweet breakfast cereal. Crisp finish.

column1: Three Rivers Papa Bears Golden Honey Wheat
column5: On tap @ Three Rivers poured a clear yellow with a minimal white head. Aromas of honey, bread and a hint of carmel. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, honey and light lemon with a crisp clean finish.

column1: Three Rivers Papa Bears Golden Honey Wheat
column5: Light gold appearance. Flavor is mostly sweet honey and wheat notes. Finishes a bit stale.

column1: Three Rivers Papa Bears Golden Honey Wheat
column5: Pours as clear as day with a very quick to run head. Nose of adjuncts and honey. (I know thats an adjunct too!!!) SERVED TOO COLD!!! Honey sweetness dominates, with its' typical light body. Refreshing but with a somewhat swill flavor. I would have cut back on the honey and added Gambrinus honey malt, but then again, the brewer was not making this beer for me.

Draft @ brewpub. Lovely red, the color of strawberry soda with a decent head. Smells like crystal malt and American hops, but is clean and inviting. Thin beer. Easy, balanced. Could use more hops but the malts have nice caramel and toasty flavors.
Golden-amber. Thin head. Caramel and hop nose. The palate has more caramel but it tastes good, and is balanced by some hops that are almost cilantro-like in their character.

best beer in this place 7/17/10. orange amber brown with a bunch of sticky spots of whitish foam. aroma and flavor are of faint caramel malt, bitter earthy hops, orange and grass. it finishes with a nice bitterness before grassy hops linger in the aftertaste. crisp. the best of the bunch since it doesn’t taste or smell like a dirty wet rag. 6/3/6/3/13/3.1
Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub. Reddish amber with a thin wisp of air. Slippery and sweet at first with a tart, caramel, almost appley’grapey finish makes it distinct.

Pours a nice deep amber w/ a creamy white head. Heavy caramel aroma and no hops present. Lots of brown sugar sweetness but with a HUGE diacetyl flavor. Rich and enjoyable but I would have used darker crystal, maybe 80, and less of it. Far better than Avalanche,... Add some hops!

Pint at the brewpub. Pours copper with a white head. The aroma is earthy and musty with notes of grilled pineapple and an herbal bite. The malts are strong with a bready flavor. There is an adequate amount of hops in the flavor with an earthy, grassy finish. It’s okay.
Draft @ brewpub. Orange with nice lace. Bright cannabis aroma. Palate is somewhat oily and thick. But it’s super hopped, and lingers nicely, like it’s got a lot of hop oils.
Amber. Big dank aroma of citrus, weed, wood. Loaded with hops. Rich hoppy character with marijuana notes is balanced with just enough crystal malt. Very drinkable.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear orange with a thick white head. Aroma of caramel malt and a hint of citrus. Flavor is mostly malty but also some citrus and hop bitterness. Palate is a bit harsh, some mineral qualities. Meh, not a great IPA and I expected better. 7/4/7/3/14 [3.5/5]

on tap 7/17/10. golden orange with a white blanket of foam for a head. it smells and tastes like a dishtowel that is used to wash something greasy but not rinsed out or allowed to dry... then it sits for a day or two and starts to get rotten. squeeze it out into a mediocre ipa... that caramel, oranges and simcoe dirty hops. it is bitter and crisp... 3/3/3/3/8/2

On tap @ Three Rivers poured a clear dark copper with a lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, pine and earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and dry. Flavors of carmel, pine and earthiness with a dry bitter finish. Hoppy but well balanced!!!

tap-NM IPA challenge-high desert brewing. pours a deep orange almost amber hue with a sudsy white head. some decent c hop aromas come out along with a good toasty malt base. this beer definately leans towards the malty side with some hops lingering around. I didn’t have the diacytl issue that Whaleman had, but this beer is definatly not great.
Dark ruby-brown color. Buttered popcorn in the nose. Buttery flavor. The hops don’t get the job done here and fail to balance out the diacetyl issue.

Pours a nice transluscent amber w/ a good lasting lightly tan head. Aroma of grapefruit from cascades/centtenial, and caramel from light crystal malts. Nice body with a good bite from columbus or simcoe.(?) Very drinkable but still delivers the hops> 60-65 IBUs. Very nice example of the style. This breweries best.

GABF 2010. Pours a very light golden with thinning white head to a film. Aroma is grass, herbs, solvent, almost a strange glue or rubber cement thing going on and harsh white wine. Flavor is light cracker, corn, dms, more solvent glue, wine, metallic finish. Ugh.
Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub: Roasty brown. Sweet caramelly nose that carries to the flavor. Sweet and brown-sugary that leaves a caramel tingle behind. Bit thin, otherwise very good.

On tap @ Three Rivers poured a cloudy reddish brown with no head. Aromas of carmel, toffee and light fruit. Palate was medium bodied and flat. Flavors of carmel, toffee, light fruit and a hini of spice with a sweet finish.

Dark malt roastiness, sweet caramel, honey-like aroma. Clear burnished copper coloured body with a decent, tan, fine bubbled head that lasts well and laces. Sweet initial flavour with a musty, floral honey character is chased by some roasted malt bitterness before a lingering sweetness takes hold of the aftertaste. Medium body with smooth texture and moderate, gentle carbonation. Sampled at GABF 2005.
Deep mahogany with nice lacing. Sweet caramel in the flavor, little hops evident, and no indication of the 7.5% alcohol.

[At GABF 2004] A pale brown beer with a small orange head. The aroma is sweet malty with fruity notes as well as notes of prunes. The flavor is malty and primarily fruity before a dry end sets in. An interesting beer.

Served on cask. Hazy chestnut body. Very malty aroma plus some peat smoke and apples. Flavor of caramel, honey, and some more fruit. Fairly sweet with some woody hops. Improves with warming. Decent fullness. I'm a big fan of the style but this is an average Scotch Ale.

Pours same color as the brown and amber ales. Not much of a head but has some smokiness and abv in the nose. Big maltiness with some sweet caramel in the background. Abv is not that apparent on the palate. Smokiness is very upfront and defines the character of this beer. I can tell this has been fermented too warm, but it is still far better than most American examples and is commendible for its' smokiness.

Draft @ brewpub. Nice dark brown-black with red tint. Aroma is curiously salty with mild cocoa, coal. Clean. Creamy and easy going. Mild with nice smooth cocoa and subdued flavors. No roast, just mellow, dark, and creamy ale.
Dark brown. Thick, slightly rocky head. Coffeeish aroma with hints of chicory and chocolate. Palate is the same - only chocolate first with coffee secondary.
A brown porter all Fuller's. Tan lasting head. Aroma of nutty dark crystal with no hops. A descent EKG flavor. Very mild roastiness with a subdued malt flavor. Very well balanced.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a small light tan head. Aroma of roast and a hint of sweet malt, also some nougat. Flavor of roast, a hint of lactose, vanilla, char, and light sweet malt. Ok stout, nothing crazy but gets the job done. 6/4/7/4/14 [3.5/5]
Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub: Pitch black with a thin cloudcover of tan. Couldn’t draw an aroma. Pretty, bitter coffee tones here with an ashy, smoky, almost dark chocolate flourish at the end.

On tap @ Three Rivers poured a hazy brown with a minimal brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and a hint of smoke. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, smoke and light chocolate with a dry bitter finish.
Pours almost pitch black, super roasty, bitter and dry. Tons of chocolate and coffee. No hint of the alcohol content at all.

I hate nitro! Nitro brown head on top of a transparent black body. Not much aroma. (NITRO!!) Smooth with a roasty flavor. Raisins and chocolate. Belgian special B? Could use more unfermentables: Chocolate, roasted barley, black patent. However, this is surprisingly roasty for such a lightly colored stout.

Draft 6 oz’er at the brewpub. Classical APA visual ... deep aroma with a rocky head. Light hoppy nose. Musty/metallic hoppiness. Very tart finish. Not quite as "grapefruity" as NW pale ales, but a quality brew.
(Great American Beer Festival 2004) Dry earthy and hoppy. The palate is loaded with cirus. Very good and drinkable.

Golden body, minimal white head. Orange citrus and a stemmy grassiness in the aroma along with some cookie sweetness. Hop-forward flavor - orange rind and biscuit, finishes with yeast and grapefruit flesh. Pretty typical APA.

On tap at Klosterbräu Bamberg. Clear dark golden coloured, small to medium sized white head, grain and alcohol in the nose. Sweet malty, bready and grainy with noticable alcohol. Also sweet and alcoholic finish. One-dimensional.

pale, golden, amber, orange, hazy, cloudy, frothy, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, medium sourness, light body, medium body, thin feel, creamy, lively, average carbonation,
Bocken varer lige til påske. Malty aroma of bread and grain. Sweet malty flavour with a toffee note, some herbal hops and a hint of alcohol
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of grains, caramel, sugary, fruity. Taste is rather sweet, grains, straw, caramel, light foral, a bit boozy.
Bottle @ Dolles Bockstival — Bocken varer lige til påske, 5000 Odense C. Pours clear Golden with a White head. Straw and alcohol. Some alcohol and marzipan. Bready malty. Quite good actually.

Tap. Clear golden color with white head. Aroma is pale malts. Taste is boozy phenols. Oily mouthfeel with low carbonation. Quite a boozy Bock, not my thing. We were hardly able to finish it, and we were 4 persons.

Optisch wunderbar, goldgelb, stabiler Schaum. In der Nase leider etwas plädderich. Im Trunk ebenso, seltsame Nebengeschmäcker - und das vor Ort vom Fass. Im Abgang dann endlich die Honignoten, dennoch sehr herb und bitter. Neue Chance aus der Bügelflasche: Kaum besser, aber trinkbar.
On tap at brewery. Aroma is of honey banana and biscuits. Taste is filled with some caramel and honey sweetness with grassy hop finish. Ok
Frisch vom Hahn im Klosterbräu in Bamberg. Klares Amber mit stabilem Schaum. Ungewöhnlich und neu für mich: Malzbittre im Nachtrunk.

Golden colored, clear, medium white creamy head, OK lacing. Aroma is malty, caramel, candy, some alcohol, herbal notes and bit metallic. Taste is medium sweet malty, caramel, bit candy-sugary, some honey notes, grainy, herbal, light+ bitterness, bit metallic. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. (on tap at the brewery)

Draft at the brewpub, July 2006. The brewpub came into new ownership early 2006, so this is the same recipe but a different brewer from the two former ratings. A hazy light yellow beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet with light notes of citrus and other fruits. The flavor is sweet citrusy, my first guess at the hop was fuggles, but it was Brewers Gold. A very easily drinkable beer - won’t offend anybody. Listed at 5.4% ABV.

No discernable nose, fizzy, short-lasting head; murky yellow color, little or no flavor. Not exactly sure just what they were trying to accomplish here. Reminded me almost of a blonde ale, in color only. Advertsied as a "pilsner-like" offering - nah.

This was the best of the five I sampled & that isn't saying a whole lot, very undercarbonated, the flavors & body seemed flat although the beer arrived with a nice fluffy & bubbly white head, the head though totally disappeared within a couple minutes, the aftertaste was sour, no wheat qualities to the beer at all

Draft at the brewpub, July 2006. The brewpub came into new ownership early 2006, so this is the same recipe but a different brewer from the five first ratings. A hazy amber beer with a thin orange head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of caramel, but also a light note of butterscotch. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel, and butterscotch as well as light notes of wood, leading to a dry and slighlty bitter end. Listed at 5.4% ABV.

One of the worst beers I’ve ever had. Thought I was driking vinegar- don’t waste your money. The restaurant in Gettyburg, PA has a nice atmosphere with good food but just skip the brew and order a Diet Pepsi.
all the beer served here taste like it has some kind of infection. must be tatsted to fully understand how bad this beer is.
You know...the food here was really good. Unfortunately for Gettysbrew, I’m not rating their food tonight. Way more of a sour than a bitter.

wow,,this place is a tourist trap..tried the sampler,,all beers tasted the same,,except the barly wine(ill rate that next),,this was sour where it shouldnt have been...i swore every beer there was infected with the same thing..terrible.stay away

Had a nice amber appearance, but that’s the good news. Thin, cidery, sour aftertaste. The server mentioned the use of hop oils [or was that on the menu?]which may account for the weird finish. I know bad beer - because as a homebrewer, I’ve made plenty - and this reminded me of some of my bad extract batches.

I honestly couldn't tell this beer apart from at least two others from my sampler, no distingushable qualities at all, amber color, decent bubbly white head but it disappeared after a few minutes, once again flat flavors & body, very sour in the finish, undercarbonated

Draft at the brewpub, July 2006. The brewpub came into new ownership early 2006, so this is the same recipe but a different brewer from the two former ratings. A hazy amber beer with a dense brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with strong notes of caramel, while the flavor is slightly acidic combined with light notes of roasted malt, leading to a dry end with notes of butterscotch. The mouthfeel is very smooth. Listed at 5.4% ABV.
"No roasted malt," no kidding. This is very smooth, and very sweet. Slightly watery and unimpressive.

This was the worst of the five sampled, no head, flat, undercarbonated, sour, undrinkable, nothing like the commercial description claims, in fact it's very opposite, there was no rich malt character & certainly no roasted flavors, this beer along with the entire restaurant is very disappointing

I don’t see how anyone can give any extra points for any of this brewers "beers" . This can’t actually be classified as any style of beer as all gettysbrews taste the same.flat and watery with an bacterial infection flavor
Flat stout is what this beer amounts to. I hope they get this straightened out.
A barleywine? I think the bartender messed up on my sample and poured me 3 glasses of the SAME THING! Nothing about this is either barleywine or good.

More of a stout, really. Under no circumstances could this be called a barleywine. No real malt flavor, just a slightly sweet stout beer. Definately felt like I was getting taken for a ride paying twice as much as the other brews at this brewpub for what was a similar beer.

flat.which i can stand in a good barleywine..but flat out terrible as well..this was the last one i tried on a 5 or 6 beer sampler...i was saving it for last because all of the others tasted like infected sugar water..all exactly the same,sour nonsense...as a fan of big beers i didnt think a barley wine could be so bad i could not drink it...it was the worst of all..undrinkable...tasted exactly like SOY SAUCE...i could have made a freakin stir fry with this stuff

Belive it or not I couldn't honestly tell this supposed barleywine from the bitter, no distingushable barleywine qualities whatsoever, not an ounce of malt in the flavors & body, watery, bland, undercarbonated, flat, sour, very undrinkable, just plain awful

column1: Elk Grove Big, But Blond Ale
column5: Dms laden nose with very little malt present. Grain astringent and thin on the palate. Dry and astingent finish.

column1: Elk Grove Big, But Blond Ale
column5: Light, malty aroma. Golden color with fine white head. Thinnish in body with mild carbonation. Grainy flavor with very mild hop. Finish is dry, and there is some bitter. Goold light ale.

Aroma of light wheat and light citrus. Darkish gold color with a fine white head. Almost medium bodied with creamy carbonation. Light wheat flavor with some citrus notes and mild bitter. Refreshing. Finish is not entirely dry, and the bitter is mild. Good wheat beer.
Very soft nose with lite hop and malt notes. Bready and dry on the palate. Clean finish.

Growler. Decent citrus hop aroma backed by malt. Reddish amber color with a beige head that might lace. Medium bodied. Moderate carbonation. Spicey hop flavor, but the malt doesn’t show up immediately. Rich malt when it does. Seems a bit rough, but that might be the hop. The finish is arguably balanced, fairly dry, and has a citrus/fruit flavor tagging along.

Huge amount of haze (chill haze?) make this beer, well, not a real looker. Light cookie and clover aroma that doesn’t exude much. Very dry flavor with a prominent hop bite. Flavors/aromas from the hops are restricted to a candy-like apricot jam riff. Some notes from the yeast--some funky, farmy yeast flavors in the background, intended or not.

~3.5 Pours a cloudy golden color with white head. ~Sweet, clean hop scent. Similar to Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. ~Light crisp hop taste. Again reminds me of Sierra Nevada. ~Medium to light feel, clean crisp finish. ~Very similar to Sierra Nevada IMO. I do like this one a tad better though.
Hoppy mildly biscuity nose. Nice mouthfeel with good bittering. Nice clean finish.

At NorCal Brewers Guild Festival at Raley Field. Aroma of hop and malt. Hazy amber gold color with a little head that left lacing. Starts with a Thompson Seedless grape flavor! Ends on a balance of fruity hop and malt. Quite different. Very enjoyable.
A very fresh, energetic offering in the swollen pale ale ranks of California brewers. Highly drinkable, with a top-notch balance of hops and malt. Yum. The best Elk Grove beer I've had.
Very roasted bready nose. Rather astringent overroasted mouthfeel. Mildly astringent with some lactic sourness. Dry astringent finish.

Very dark brown color with a head that never arrived. Toasted malt aroma with a hint of plum (actually looks a bit like prune juice). Rather thin in body with creamy carbonation. Toasted malt with a fair amount of bitter; possibly a hint of smoke. Very good combination. The finish is toasty dry and seems to have hop bitter as well as burnt toast bitter.

Deep brown-black. Minimal head. Malted milk, dark-chocolate aroma. Strongly roasted, leaning towards smoky flavor, with plenty of bitter roast. Carbonation is a bit strong and leads to a slightly acrid acidity in conjunction with the smoky notes. Otherwise a perfectly acceptable brewpub stout.
GABF '03. Poured a decent black color with minimal tan head. Musky coffee aroma. Chocolate taste with dry grain finish.
From the Jug at the GABF Colorado Convention Center, Denver 09/10/2008 Malt aroma. Bronze coloured and a little rich on the palate with some alcohol present. Slightly bitter malt finish.
Herbal nose with a very slight touch of anise. Soft and clean body with a very clean and dry finish.

Draft at the brewpub. Darkish amber color with an off-white head that barely lasted long enough to reach the table. Caramel aroma. Medium body with near creamy carbonation. Mildly sweet caramel flavor - with a very light touch of smoke. Finish is not dry, and there is only a little bitter. Somehow it seems balanced, though. Good marzen; wife really liked it.

16 ounce sample on tap at the brewpub. Aroma is a bit faint, sweet, fruity, with some mild anise presence. Some coffee is detected in there, too. Aroma could definitely be more assertive. Mostly opaque black/dark brown body with a small, weak tan head with below-average lacing present. Starts off sweet, sugary, and chocolatey. Becomes more roasted with more chocolate and a bit of coffee in the middle. Some metallic hop flavors later. Very nice. Balanced, drinkable, and very flavorful. An enjoyable brew! Wish the aroma was more present, though.

~Pours a deep copper brown color with small creamy head. ~Nice mellow malty scent with lingering hops. ~Kind of a sweet rye like flavor with bitter hops. Good distinct flavor. ~Medium feel, bitter finish. ~This is a nice brew. I enjoyed it.
Hop forward nose with a slight touch of Diacetyl. Thin and overly carbonated body with mild Diacetyl and roast notes. Hop astringent finish.

Reddish amber color with a creamy tannish head that stayed. Very hoppy aroma. Thinnish body with creamy carbonation. Lots of hop (citrus and pine) to go with a robust roasted malt. Strong flavors. The finish is fairly dry and has lots of bitter.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: tap at Dj’s - light grainy taste and aroma with lemony tartness. thin and watery...too bad cause the taste could be pretty nice otherwise.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: Keg at the brewpub, 01/02/16. Golden yellow with a minimal off white covering. Nose is thin, light grain, vague citric notes, straw, pale malt.
