Taste comprises light bread, citric peel, lemon, wheaten tones, cereal, light melon trace. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Nothing in a glass !

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours very clear, pale yellow with a creamy, white head. Muted pale biscuits in the nose, faint hay. Light sweet flavour with mild cereal, hints of butter, straw. Light bodied with average carbonation. Lightly papery on the finish, with more cereal. Rather bland. Mediocre overall.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: Draft a the the brewpub. Clear yellow golden coloured pour with a thin film of white head. Aroma is subdued pale grains, mineral, grassy. Flavour is composed of thin grains, wheat, chalky mineral, tangy grassy. Palate is dry and chalky, thin, gassy. Highish carbonation. Pretty bad. Bland.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear pale gold with a small white head that settles into a ring. Notes of wheat, faint florals, bread, and minerals - just not much to it. Light-bodied, with moderate to medium carbonation and a relatively clean mouthfeel that’s also malty and plagued by the same mineral chalkiness present in all of their beers. Bland but inoffensive.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: Draft - Pale malts. Clear gold with a decent white head. Pale malts. Touch of biscuit and a decent finish.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: On tap @ Downtown Joes. Clear golden pour with white foam. Sort of a bready and crackery malt character to it. Slight biscuit malt note too. Decent malt flavor and sweetness to it. Light bitterness and grass. Kind of your typical light blonde ale sort of beer. Nothing too great about it. But, it’s easy drinking.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: Draught at Downtown Joe’s Napa. Clear light golden liquid with medium white head. Aroma of grain, hay, bread and light butter. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of grain, bread and hay yellow. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation. Very forgettable.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear gold with small frothy white head. The aroma is faint wheat and malt. Thin mouth, wheat, off finish, nah.

column1: Downtown Joes Lazy Summer American Wheat
column5: draft at source. A very neutral nose, light honey. Crystal clear. Taste is a tart lemon and grainy wheat character. Mediocre.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Pours amber with a slight white head. Light resin aroma. Flavor is pine resin over malt. Nice bitter finish.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: Clear golden with a fizzy white head. Faint malty aroma and a watery palate but a decent bready and hops taste

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: Gold body with minimal off white head. Aroma is hoppy with some earth and a faint note of bready malt. Light hops throughout and rather simple.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear orange color. Head was thin and white. Aroma was of light malty caramel and toasted bread. Mild hop bitterness on the tongue with a toasted bread flavor. So so.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: Poured dark gold clear color with some white head. Slight hop prescence to flavor and aroma but mostly sweet and watery. Refreshing but not much else there. It is though 5.8% which it masks.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: I visited Downtown Joe’s many times during a recent 5-night stay in Napa on vacation from England. I switched to this from Tail Waggin’ in the misguided belief that it was lower in alcohol. It certainly tasted lighter and had more of an English light ale feel. I am certain the great atmosphere in the bar also aided consumption but I woud happily drink this anywhere.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: Draft. Golden beer with a nice white head. Citrus hop aroma. Citrus flavor with some thin malt backing. Could use a bit more malt. Lingering bitterness.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: Had on tap at the brewpub in Napa. Very good brewpub pale ale. Light orange appearance, good thick white head with decent lacing. Good subtle bitterness with some underlying citrusy fruitiness and a nutty back end flavor. Decently thick mouthfeel.

column1: Downtown Joes Ace High Pale Ale
column5: on tap at downtown joes: golden brown with a white head that disipates quickly. nice hop nose casade. your typical pale ale for a brewpub style. hops, hops and more hops. not over the top but a slightly grassy feel. med bodied. similiar to their amber.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours mostly clear amber with a creamy topping. Bland aroma, just a few leaves and lightly toasted grains. Light sweet flavour, very bitter, with a quite odd fruit syrup note, some burnt caramel, harsh grassy bitterness. Light bodied with average carbonation. Astringent and harshly bitter on the finish. Hard to drink.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: Keg at the brewpub, 01/02/16. Yay - a brewpub amber ! Reddish amber with a decent light beige cap. Nose is pretty thin ... light fruit esters, caramel, grain. Taste comprises sweet malts, toffee, candied fruit notes. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. The blandometer is pretty high with this one!

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color with a khaki head that settles into a ring and laces the glass. Notes of mildew, sweat, wet leaves, nuts, wet grass, and faint toast. Light-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a bitter, earthy moutheel. Not as mineralic as the others, but also more foul in other ways. Had an old, damp quality that was so unappealing. Also was listed as "Tail Waggin’ West Coast Bitter" - is it intended to be an amber ale or an English bitter? It’s that same lack of attention to detail that characterizes the beers.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: Draft - Bitter sweet toffee and hops. Deep Amber with a decent beige head. Malty and very bitter hops with a long finish.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: Draught at Downtown Joe’s Napa. Almost clear deep amber liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of caramel, citrus, pine, toffee and raw sugar. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of citrus, caramel and toast. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Meh. Very bland. Not too offensive.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: Draft a the the brewpub. Mid amber coloured pour with a lasting greyish loose head. Aroma is tangy tart red berry., nutty malts solvent. Flavour is composed of dirty toast, nutty malts, red berry, bitter, dirty hop. Bland and terrible. Palate is dry and chalky, grainy, highish spritzy. Aggressively bitter and dirty. Dirty.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: Draft at source. A moderate citrus nose with some toasty malt character. A weird malty taste like it was made with extract.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear copper with medium frothy off white head that lasts. The aroma is faint grapefruit and wheat. Medium mouth, very bitter, bready malt, light, decent.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Clear amber-copper pour with lacy white head. Aroma is really grainy, sticky caramel malt. Taste is sweet, brown sugar, caramel, boiled hops. Meh.

column1: Downtown Joes Tail Waggin Amber Ale
column5: slight malt heavy which is too bad - I like the hops used in this beer - there’s just not enough. about average for the style.

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: On tap 3(?) oz. sampler at Downtown Joe's Restaurant & Brewery. Hazy, reddish dark orange with creamy head and excellent lacing. Aroma of bread malt and pine. Taste of pine and bread malt. Medium body and medium carbonation with a foamy mouthfeel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Tap at the brewpub in Napa. Amber pour with a nice full white head. Aroma is very mild. Palate is light to medium. Taste is sweet caramel malts, then just a hint of bittering hops late.

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Tap - good thick head, dark amber color, smooth dry hopped flavor with a sweet malt backbone

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: I had this at the brewpub in downtown Napa. I thought it was a tasty beer, with good balance between hops & malt

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Copper red with a fizzy off white head. Sweet malty and hop aroma with a bitter sweet resin taste. Decent.

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Pours a clear amber color with a small white head. Grassy aroma, biting bitterness. Easy drinking, could be a good session brew.

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Reddish amber body with minimal head. Aroma is caramel and some light grapefruit. Simple slightly sweet and somewhat underwhelming bitteness.

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear dark orange color. Head was thin and off white. Aroma and flavor of biscuity malt and light flowery hops accented by mild hop bitterness. Pretty standard.

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Pours amber red color with offwhite head. Aroma is a bit malty with slight earthy hops. Flavor is pretty bitter and abrasive and not well balanced at all. Overall, not too good.

column1: Downtown Joes Golden Thistle Very Bitter Ale
column5: Draft. Rich reddish-amber beer with an off-white head. Rich caramel flavor with lots of bittering hops. Some astringency. Lower hop aroma than expected. This one seemed to have too much bittering hops and no where near enough flavor hops.

column1: Downtown Joes Old Magnolia Oatmeal Stout
column5: On, nitro, pours dark black with lots of tan head, light aroma, very smooth (appropriate for a nitro) but rather watery and tasteless, tap at brewery.

column1: Downtown Joes Old Magnolia Oatmeal Stout
column5: A very tasty stout! Tons of maple oatmeal and hints of milk chocolate. Pours a porter dark brown with a short, frothy head. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Downtown Joes Old Magnolia Oatmeal Stout
column5: On tap @ Downtown Joes. Dark brown in color with a dense khaki head. Plenty of rich, dark chocolate. Solid roast character, some bread, treacle, and molasses. Just a touch acidic on the tongue. Good coffee and dark chocolate flavor. Pretty intense roasted malts. A little on the bitter side. Decent dark fruit and licorice as well. Pretty nice.

column1: Downtown Joes Old Magnolia Oatmeal Stout
column5: Pours a dark opaque brown with a very creamy Irish coffee foam head. The head retains well. A gorgeous beer to covet as it sits, untouched on a weathered oak bar. Creamy foam coats the glass. Iced mocha aroma. Mouthfeel is utterly phenomenal, but it’s nitrogen infused, so it’s a little like cheating. Baker’s chocolate, coffee, and just the slightest hint of peat. Good oatmeal stout.

column1: Downtown Joes Old Magnolia Oatmeal Stout
column5: A good oatmeal stout. Easy drinking. Pours a deep red/brown color, with a thick tan head. Smells slightly nutty. Taste is smooth, not heavy like a lot of oatmeal stouts. A little sweet. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Downtown Joes Old Magnolia Oatmeal Stout
column5: Black with a creamy tan head. Grain chocolate and sugar aroma and taste with subtle toffee notes to the finish.

column4: Van Dyck Fine Food and Brewery
column5: Average, not much flavor. Poured very mirky yellow, with no head. Aroma is faint lemon. Flavor too is lemony with a tiny bit of a hop bite, and some subtle sweetness.

column4: Van Dyck Fine Food and Brewery
column5: on tap-pours a light white head with pale yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain &__. Taste is sweet grain, with a hops bite, musty. OK carbonation.

column1: Van Dyck Union India Pale Ale
column4: Van Dyck Fine Food and Brewery
column5: Good stuff, their best offering. Poured a nice orange with no head. Aroma is fresh hops. Flavor also fresh citrus hops with a bit of sweetness, just enough.

column1: Van Dyck Union India Pale Ale
column4: Van Dyck Fine Food and Brewery
column5: on tap-pours an offwhite head that laces with copper color. Aroma is medium hops, sweet. Taste is good medium hops with a bite, medium malt, bitter finish. Good carbonation.

column4: Van Dyck Fine Food and Brewery
column5: This isn’t a bad pale ale. It has plenty of hops, but they arent really blalnced very well, and overwhelm the flavor a bit. The hops are very acidy on the palate.

On tap at the Great Bear. Nice aroma of grains. Golden with a small white head. Good consistent smooth flavor with hardly a hop taste. Crisp refreshing mouth feel. Overall a good solid beer, one of the few consistent beers from this brewery.

20-Jan-08 (Draft: Great Bear Brewing Co. in Wasilla, AK) An aroma of soured fruits provides a poor first impression, but an accurate one. Soured fruits are also evident in the flavor, along with sweet grains and some corn. Almost no hop flavor or bitterness. Light-medium in body with light carbonation. Light-golden color, somewhat hazy, and the small, white head quickly fades away to a thin ring. Though on tap at the brewery, the perception of soured fruits obviously make me question the freshness of this beer. It is wintertime in Alaska after all, and dark beers rule up here, and this beer is targeted for people just getting started with craft beer.

Had on tap at the brewpub in Wasilla, Ak. Light gold in appearance, thin white head. Aroma, nondescrpt, a bit of fresh lake water perhaps. Flavor has a bit of honey sweetness to it with a touch of mown grass. Decent mouthfeel. Refreshing, but not all that flavorful. Brewed for the masses.

Had on tap at the brewpub in Wasilla, Ak. Very good for a brewpub fruit beer. Cloudy, murky light orange appearance. Sweet blackberry aroma is enticing and carries over to the flavor. Surprisingly, very natural is the flavor in its sweetness. Very good creamy mouthfeel. A well done Fruit beer by a brewpub.

20-Jan-08 (Draft: Great Bear Brewing Co. in Wasilla, AK) Lots of flavor to this usually dull style of beer. Lightly sweet, wheaty flavor with a slightly fruity character, but balanced by gently bitter hops. Medium in body, so not your thin watery American wheat beer. Sweet, wheaty aroma. Dark straw to pale golden in color with medium haze. Small whitish head settles to a wispy layer. Overall, for a boring style of beer, this is solid. It has good body and lots of flavor, and the balancing use of hops really sets this beer apart from its peers.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a lightly hazy golden yellow with a small almost none existant head. Aroma of wheat, some banana/clove and citrus. Flavors of teh same...want more hops in my American Wheats.

had during a trip to alaska. nice and refreshing, that’s what i remember. wish i would have taken notes on this one to get more in depth without there being other ratings out there. worth a try but guess it’s not that memorable.

column1: Great Bear Big Su Strong Ale
column5: Nice stuff here, this is what I drink whenever I am visiting Wasilla, if they happen to have it on tap, Im drinking it. Rich caramel background, with some citrus hop bite in the finish. Well structured and malty, with a sweet candied fruit finish. Very enjoyable.

column1: Great Bear Big Su Strong Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a golden yellow color with a small white head. Aroma of caramel, floral and hints of citrus. Flavors of caramel sweet malts, some hop bittereness and on the thin side for 8%/

column1: Great Bear Big Su Strong Ale
column5: Yellow in color with good head for an Ale. It had a nice carmel smell that I always enjoy. I don’t remember much else about it except enjoying it.

column1: Great Bear Old Town Brown Ale
column5: On draft at the brewpub 7/14/05: Big head on this ruby red draft. Light timber-based aroma. Highly bittered draught ... woody, cedar and mild hazelnut. Pretty good.

column1: Great Bear Old Town Brown Ale
column5: Had on tap at the brewpub in Wasilla. Murky, light brown appearance with a good sized off-white head. Aroma is slightly nutty. Has a sweet, malty flavor with some subtle chocolate acents. Good, thick mouthfeel to this one.

2003 bottle, drunk in november 04. like clark mentions, looks like cherry cola. smells like tart cherries and chocolate truffles--more balanced, less one-dimensional than bell’s cherry stout. lightly stale and astringent finish, but overall not too bad.

Dark chestnut brown, black with plenty of bubbles. Looks like cherry cola. Decent off white head. Smells like tart cherries and has an interesting sour smell on the nose. Right away the tart cherries come out. I am glad that it is not too sweet, I am not glad that there is very little else here other than tart cherries. Finishes with a dry nothingness that is reminiscent of club soda. I think they were so concerned with not making a cloying cherry beer, that they forgot to also make it something other than not cloying. Way too carbonated for a stout.

Sampled this at the Polar Beer Fest. I knew from the start this was a tough one. It has an off smell that is reminiscent of vinegar. Taste is very acidic, with the tartness seeming to come from anything but cherries. There is no balance at all to this. Not a great effort.

(Draft)Great, Great, Great. This is one of two winter seasonals that they have on tap. The beer has a nice this head, subtle cherry nose with a slight tart cherry finish. Not as overpowering as many other fruit beers and the brewer said it will get better with time. If you are near Detroit, you have to drive over to try it before it is gone.

draft at brewery.lovely orange with a light thin head. unspectacular aroma, mostly of caramel malt and some fruity esters. fascinating flavor though, not quite a barley wine but not really an american strong ale. lots of fruitiness that nicely complements the malt--perhaps a barleywine using a belgian yeast? or a regular yeast strain fermented higher than normal? it’s like there are some side-effect flavors, but they seem to belong perfectly! either way it’s a very warming drink, one that i will most definitely drink again! probably the best beer that stoney creek puts out.

Interesting aroma, a combination of vanilla and chocolate and undertones of some spice. Very dark, almost a black beer. This beer lack some balance and heavy of the vanilla malt taste and while there is a noticeable hop presence, it doesn't match up evenly. Bitter on the aftertaste.

Overload on the black and possibly chocolate malts in combination with a lot of bitterness. Just not groovin', not smooth at all. Needs more rounded characteristics and more definition of exactly what this beer is supposed to be.
Draught @ Klosterbraü, Bamberg. Pours deep amber with a White head. Dark fruit, caramel , fudge and intense metal slash iron. Poor, industrial and artificial.

Draft at Michaelsberg Cafe. Clear dark brown body and a creamy white head. Aroma of caramel and roasted malt. The taste is medium to heavy sweet and light to medium bitter. Sticky texture. Nice and warming.

sampled november 2014 at klosterbrau (not to mention september 2001 at michaelsberg cafe but that rating seems to have disappeared). had high hopes after enjoying the helles kloster bock and wasn’t disappointed - rich shade of dark brown, light purple tinge and a head that wouldn’t die; aroma hints at molasses and stonefruits along with some burning hay; sticky but easy-to-skull as is the case with the best dunkelbocks, good hit of bitterness, some red berries; excellent stuff
On tap at the Brewpub. Fast schwarzes Bier mit einer schönen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr röstmalzig, schokoladig, Geschmack schokoladig, röstmalzig, vollmundig, sehr lecker!

Dark brown pour. Big tan head that sticks around as a thinner layer for a while. Little lacing. Big scent of roasted malt. And bread. A roasted bread flavor as well. Sweet, yet dry. Almost stout-like. Good beer.

(draught) pours the darkest ruby brown colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of heavy coffee, toasted malts and some light notes of chocolate. flavour is the same, with toasted malts in the foreground, a tad boring. lightly sweet, medium body and carbonation.

Tap @ Cafe Michaelsberg, on the far (north) side of the monastery. Bright chestnut with a tan head. This has a fairly rich, bready aroma with molasses accents. Soft body, maybe a bit metallic with good hearty bread character and light molasses. Nice bock.

Draft @ Cafe Michaelsberg, billed as "Klosterbock Dunkles." Very dark brown with red tint and a thick tan, aerated head. Big bready malt aromas. Smells like a brewery brewing. Quaffable palate. Big malty bready body. Finishes clean with some lingering toasted dark bread crust and toffee. Lovely lip smacking brew!
tap at the cafe michaelsberg.Dark golden brown, golden head. Roast, orangepeel, raisin. Light nutty bready, noncloying sweetness, fresh. Fruity aftertaste, almond retronasal. Chewy mouthfeel.

On tap at The Klosterbrau Brewpub, Bamberg. Dark golden brown with white head. Heavy big sweet beer with alcoholic fruity notes, lots of prune in the body with darker roasted malt flavours. Some pine nut in the finish. This is a seasonal which has recently been brewed for the tourist market. Get in quick.

Clear amber body with a big, foamy and stable ivory head. Aroma is toffee, herbs, some dyacetil. Taste is crispy, notes of pepper, mild roasted malts. Dry finish. Low body, soft carbonation, oily texture.
On tap at brewery in Berlin. Amber orange with a small creamy beige head. Malty nose hints at caramel. Flavor is soft, sweet caramel with toasty notes. Crisp dry finish. Tasty. tasted on 8/21/19.
Bready and caramelly aroma. Light bitter, buttery taste, light bodied beer.

Dark brown, good head lasting a minute or so. Caramel malty spicy nose. Flavor is balanced caramel without excessive sweetness, nice non astringent bitterness, hop flavor subdued, some coffee notes. Not sweet like a Munich dunkles.
Tap @ Lemke am Alex. Pale amber color. Grainy, sulphury aroma. Malty sulphury flavor. Hint of Apple. Disappointing.
Tasting tray at Lemke. Amber, clear with a minimal white head. Aroma of hops, malt and caramel. Malt and caramel end, light bitter.

Flasche 0,33l: Kastanienbraun, dunkles Kupfer, deutliche Trübung, eher flüchtiger mittelporiger Schaum; frische + sehr fruchtige Nase, fruchtige Süße, dunkle/eingelegte Früchte, Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, Hopfenaromen, Feigen, Datteln, leichte Nussigkeit; frischer + fruchtiger Körper, eher trockene Fruchtigkeit, dunkle/getrocknete Früchte, Malz, Malzzucker, Karamell, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, Hopfennoten, leichte fruchtige Säure; angenehmer fruchtig-trockener Nachgang

A malty smell, light aroma of cola. The head is small, beige and fizzy, it disappears fast. The body is dark brown. A malty taste, light sour and bitter. The body is rather light, creamy and lively with a lot of carbonation.
Pours a copper-amber with soft white head. Roasted malty, bready aroma and taste. Notes: on tap at the brewpub, Nov ‘18

From tap at the brewery. Hazy dark copper color with beige head. Malty aroma, caramel, bread, grain, herbal, light roasted malty notes (mostly in the taste). Sweet and bitter taste. Light to medium oily body with soft carbonation.

column1: Watch City Rabbie Burns Quintesensual Ale
column5: Bottle conditioned version, bottled on 8-6-03. Deep copper to light brown in color,slightly couldy with a small off-white head. Aroma is of fruit,chocolate and nuts. Flavor is of bread,malt,chocolate,sweet malt yet it finishes dry. Good mouthfeel due to a low amount of carbonation.

column1: Watch City Rabbie Burns Quintesensual Ale
column5: Great roasted malt smell, almost coffee. Dark brown color. Flavor is dominated by roasted malts with a thin body overall.

column1: Watch City Rabbie Burns Quintesensual Ale
column5: Light smokey roast smell. Brown color. Kinda smokey scotch tasting, with a little fruit. Goes down easy. Creamy

column1: Watch City Rabbie Burns Quintesensual Ale
column5: 6 OZ sample at brewpub: Clear red-orange in color with good lacing. Light fruity aroma. Nothing to get excited about.

column1: Watch City Rabbie Burns Quintesensual Ale
column5: Pour is very dark brown, small tan head. Aroma is light, roasted malts, some dark fruits. Flavor is very complex, starts with the roasted flavor, then you get some dark fruits like raisin and plum, then the roasted flavor comes back to roasted maltiness again. Very easy drinking.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a yellow color with a small white head. A grainy sweet nose. The flavor is sugary sweet, banana, big earthy grain. OK.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Draft pour pint at the ski lodge. Clear golden pour with high carb and a foam head. Grain and straw dominated aroma. Flavor is soft fruit, grains, straw, and a dry finish.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Draft pour at brewery, amber color pour interesting to say the least, had to make sure I was tasting the blond, very light drinking, fruit flavors.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Draught at the brewpub Golden color with creamy head. It has a light grains and honey touch, but overall it’s too simple. Not bad, but boring.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Rich golden with a white head. Really nice floral, sweet honey malt nose. Light to medium body, crisp clean finish resulting as a simple, delightful summer brew.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Draft. Amber beer with a cream head. Light malt aroma. Malt and floral flavor with light honey. Medium bodied. Malt and light honey linger with light floral notes.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Government Camp, Or - on tap at the brewpub. Medium gold pour, white head, good lacing, Neutral aroma. Flavor has some brief fruity notes reminiscent of pears, some grainy notes, a hint of hay. Mouthfeel is thick enough for the style. Passable.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Sample at the brewpub. The beer is a clear golden-orange color with a thin off-white head that diminishes quickly. Spotty lacing on the glass. Sweet fruit and floral hops in the nose. Light body with flavors of mild hops and sweet malt, plus more fruit. The finish is clean and fruity with a malt aftertaste. Average overall.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Light golden color with a small white head. Buttery flavor with the bready malts up front and very mild hop finish. This had a strange roasted chocolate note to it, not sure what was with that, maybe they just put it on after a porter and some flavor was still in the tap line, but it was a bit odd. This just wasn’t my beer, between the buttery notes and the funky roastiness, it was just my least favorite of the sampler tray.

column1: Mt. Hood Highland Meadow Blonde Ale
column5: Draft at Axe Ace Grill, Govenment Camp, OR. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a longlasting white head. Has a malty hoppy aroma. Malty bready and slightly hoppy flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a malty bready hoppy finish.

Handpull cask at the Ale Wagon, Leicester. Deep golden and clear with a quickly disappearing white head. Lemon balm, vanilla and mucky sulphur on the aroma. Tastes much better than it smells, with a citrus-tinged bitterness challenging the initial malty sweetness. More caramel in the aftertaste. Not bad by any means.
Bottle from the Real Ale Warehouse. Pours clear golden with a thin white head. Aromas of grassy hops and malt. Taste is light sweet and faint floral notes, some biscuit. Rich tea. Ok.
Cask @ Stafford Beer & Cider Festival. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, malt, grass, straw and hops.

Cask @ Stafford Beer & Cider Festival. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 280717
Bottle. Pale golden in colour. Hoppy (floral hops). Mildly citrus fruity. Mild. Subtle. Sweetish. Quite tasty. Drinkable. (2008)
On draught. Clear golden, smooth, bitter with a hint of hops. A great example of a session bitter.

Cask at The Great Western, Wolverhampton as ’Holdens Golden Glow’. Dark yellow, clear, still, dense creamy white head, thick lacing. Aroma is airy and light, non-deScript. Some sweet apple notes later on. Body is medium, soft carbonation, rounded. Taste is apple sauce, yeast, sweet honey-ish malt, fudgey. Occasionally hints at egg. An interesting and quaffable beer, intended to be knocked back by the pint - and I could easily drink it in those quantities.

500ml bottle from Moonshine & Fuggles beer shop, Ironbridge. Golden colour, white foam head and aroma of citrus, grassy hop. Flavour is malt, grain, straw, hay and some citrusy bitterness. Light bodied, soft to medium carbonation, dry bitter finish. Quite OK.
Cask. Clear golden color. Aroma of sweet hay. Taste has bittersweet straw. Light body.
500ml bottle at home, clear golden beer with a white head, notes of cereal, wheat, straw and malts. Good but it ain’t mild!!!

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap. Black. Big toffee. Chocolate roast aroma. Medium body chocolate and roast. Okay beer.

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: A simplistic black with a white head. The aroma is weak but smells a bit burned. The malts were over roasted, i.e. burned. There was no depth or complexity and the aftertaste was a bit of charred.

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Very dark beer with minimal head, roasted malt aroma with a bitter taste witha lingering bitter after taste

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Pours dark with a nice head that stays for a while. Weak aroma. Taste of hops, bitter stout flavour and coffee. Doesn’t go down as smooth as some. Solid beer, nothing unpleasant about it at all.

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at the brewery : virtually pitch black with a lingering white head - strong and fairly intense flavour of coffee and a hint of bitterness. Really quite similar to the Skullcrusher also available by Merchant House. Not an original flavour but a satisfying beer on the whole.

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Had @ the Merchant Ale House in St Catherines, Canada - drinking this beer on draft .. . pours a deep black brown .. mild cocoa head .. . deep earth, minerals, tar, and sweet medicene .. . something off in the nose .. . just a bit off/harsh in this beer. boo! .. . . .. . .almost as bad as the Skylon Tower’s 3D movie...

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Deep black pour with a thin off-white head. The aroma is quite roasty. A touch of light molasses and some dark fruit. A bit of light cocoa and a little bit of roast. Soft palate and decently balanced. A bit of dustiness as well. Some soft toast and cocoa as well. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Cooked vegetables, basement aromas, leaves, earthy, bubblegum, leather, leaves, leaves, earthy, roasty, caramel, floral, chocolate

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at Merchant Ale House. Pours dark with foamy head. Hints of chocolate and some smokiness that i didn’t expect.

column1: Merchant Ale House Drunken Monkey Oatmeal Stout
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Good beer, I had on tap at the bar in st kitts, easy to drink, nice bitterness and decent head retention. Recommend you give it a try

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Cloudy orange-yellow colour. Touch of caramel in the taste but nothing to prominent or noteworthy.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: as i write this, one week ago exactly, i was sitting in the Merchant Ale House in St Catherines, Canada drinking this beer on draft .. . light flowers .. good foam .. hazed gold .. light bitters .. light honey and hay .. . a simple golden ale, sessionable .. . . My name is Nick. My father thought of it shaving..

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Just tastes like any other light ale, it has a smooth finish and also ruff flavour at the fruit, tastes a little water, but I would drink again

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: [1536-20080719] Tap. Mild apple fruit aroma. Slightly hazy, yellow body with small quick foamy white bubbles. Bland wheatgerm flavour. Light body has a slight tang. Fair. (@ Merchant Ale House; St. Catherines, ON)

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap- Served to me a deeper gold with a thin white fizzy cap, leaving no real lace. Nose of straw and somewhat fruity pale malts with a hearty dose of grains and grass. Sweetish grainy flavour is pleasing, some fruity almost citrus taste leads into grassy, biscuity hops bitterness in the end. Clean and sessionable, though pretty mainstream. Quite enjoyable after the strawberry beer.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: A blonde ale with a thin white head. A grainy seltzer aroma, rather mineral. In mouth, lightly sweet malt again very mineral, light and unchallenging. Watery bodied. Enough said. On tap at brewery, July 28 2007.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Medium yellow, decent sized white head. Decent grainy aroma, light malt. Taste follows suit, again decent graininess, fresh, light. Simple, kinda boring, but compared to other usually boring brewpub lagers/light ales, this isn’t too bad.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Draught at the Merchant Ale House. Pale golden colour with a tiny head. Aroma is mild but not unpleasant - a bit bready with straw-like hop notes. Taste is fresh but bland - light sweet malt, a slight fruitiness, minimal hops in the finish. Does what it’s supposed to do, I guess, but it’s just not my style.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Draught. At Merchant Ale House, shared with jerc and GregClow. Poured slightly oily and cloudy gold, no head. Aroma almost oily, thin candyish malt, wheat - sweet, but not bad. Taste - nothing new here, light, sweet, a bit harsh on warming. Ehh - at least no corn or adjuncts.

column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at the Merchant Ale House. Golden yellow in colour, thin non-lasting white head, no lace. The aroma was of floral hops, some grains, grassy, slightly sweet. The flavour was of lemon zest, apple skins, grass, light floral hops. Clean mouthfeel, light body, meduim carbonation. Finishes fairly quick, slightly sweet.

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Drank on tap (20 oz) at the brewpub on June 26, 2015. Light caramel, small head. An even blend of chocolate malt and light hop aroma, mild cereal notes. The taste is water down, some barley notes and a bit sweet, little bitterness. More like Leafs hockey!

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: dark red in color, slight hop to the aroma with a hint of coffee beans, had a little chocolate taste with hints of coffee and bitter hops, a little rough on the palate, not terribly enjoyable

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Little aroma to speak of, maybe cocoa with an alchohol. Brown colour. Taste of burnt coffee with cocoa bean and hops. Carbonation on the tongue is nice and a bite to it. Below average ale.

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: as i write this, one week ago exactly, i was sitting in the Merchant Ale House in St Catherines, Canada drinking this beer on draft .. . pours a light maple brown .. sweet wood and light sap .. easy .. . nice finish .. simple amber ale .. . . do canadians like hockey?

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Hazy amber pour. The nose is soft and fresh with a little bit of soft herbal hoppiness. Fresh with a touch of fruity esters as well. Peppery hops that just balance the touch of cocoa. Solid brew really. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Tastes of a typical amber ale, dark in colour, nice finish and flavourful finish, good offering, would have again

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: [1540-20080719] Tap. Grainy yeast and a bit of earthy sand aroma. Slightly hazy, dark amber brown body with no lasting head. More yeast grains and a bit of house tang in the flavour with a lingering sand characteristic. Medium body is under-carbonated. Drinkable. (@ Merchant Ale House; St. Catherines, ON)

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: 2008-07-19. Dark amber-brown body, near headless. Nutty toasty-roasty malt in the aroma smells like the dust emanating from the bags of a specific type of malt that they used at Black Oak, but I don’t recall what it was. (6+) Same character carries over to the flavour, takes on a hint of the house yeast, hints of florals briefly, light bitterness, glimpses of cocoa, bit threadbare at times. Average palate. Rather decent and shows lots of promise but only delivers on part of it. Nice. Draft at the brewpub

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: On tap at the Brewery- According to our server, this is one of their "flagship beers" that is always on. Clear deep amber liquid sits beneath a one finger white cap. No lace to speak of. Floral hops and caramel in the nose with sugary grains and cereal. Pretty sweet malts and some bread crust lead into caramel and a nutty component. Sweet, slightly thin ,slightly bitter finish. Good.

column1: Merchant Ale House Old Time Hockey Ale
column4: Merchant Ale House / Murray Street Brewing
column5: Clear light brown ale with a thin off white head. A light diluted malt aroma. In mouth, a rather diluted brown ale, like something they rinsed from the fermentor with water, and put in a keg. Watery like crazy. On tap at brewery, July 28 2007.

Undistinguished but drinkable low-grav Scotch from this popular bp on Martha's Vineyard; I hope their other entries are more interesting! Some nice earthy notes in the aroma, but it's weak. Flavor is rustic, piney, quite sweet but with a bit of hops. Very quaffable for a scotch, but totally unmemorable.

Small head falls quickly into a small white ring; very dark brown, translucent. Strong malty nose, maple/caramel character in the flavor, roasted grain, slightly porter-like. Bittersweet coffee/chocolate also; slightly thinnish and over-carbonated esp. at the end. This is a bock? It's ok, drinkable, but so what? Why don't these guys do an Imp Stout instead of a new bock/IPA/APA every week.

Can from Yamaya. Hmmm? Did they just now revive this one after 15 years? Aroma of light sewer spirits stink and some mild stone fruit. Medium gold color. thin white head. Light sweetish malt (?) or something like it, mild spirits, and a smidgen of hops. Medium body, high carbonation. Junk.

Canned. An unusually classy looking can. The beer pours pale golden. with nearly no head. Neutral aroma. I was expecting a mellow adjunct flavour, but found a firm maltiness and notes of vanilla and oak. It is medium sweet and actually has decent hop bitterness in the finish.
VERY different which to me is good id rate this higher than Carlsberg's flagship beer by far. its certainly odd and by no means the best but I consider it a firm good especially for the price.

It’s a Gold, head with a with a funny taste to it Imagine a Stella but a less premium version that is what it tastes like if I’m going, to be honest with you, has a characteristic fruity aroma Pros and cons Has a Very artificial taste two it, cons Pros great price £1,40p Pros makes you drunk very Quickly cons don’t drink two many as you will feel the hangover the next morning, trust me I would give this a 2.5 as the price is pretty reasonable however the after taste is not exactly brilliant Additional information Skol super alc 8% Vol Company Carlsberg uk Ltd Served Cold Strong lager brewed and canned in the E.U Carlsberg uk Ltd, Northampton, NN1 1PZ Best shared because it gets you drunk super Quickly Well chilled because they want you two take your time with this drink as it has a of alcohol Ingredients water Malted barley glucose syrup, hops

500ml can. Gold colour with white head. Really weird smell unlike any beer I've had before - like armpit sweat mixed with petrol and stale white bread. Taste is better but still bad - sweet malt, weird sweetness (probably the glucose syrup added), sticky, white bread, corn syrup, weird soapy, syrupy, wet cardboard, stale. Not good.

13/11/2018. Can from my local post office stores. 8% abv. Pours golden with a foamy white head. Aroma of alcohol, malt, sweet syrup, fruit and grain. Medium sweetness, light to moderate bitterness. Medium body, very sticky texture, average carbonation. Sweet, syrupy finish. Not so bad.
Can.Tried in a moment of madness. Clear bronze appearance with a mouthfull of alcohol. That sums it up. Never again.

This lager tastes like it’s weaker sibling but with balls and a hairy chest. Right amount of gas and bubbles and unsurprising yellowish lager look. A couple of good gulps in and I’m quite happy with the strong beery taste. I’m getting stale bread and booze on the tongue followed by cola bottles soaked in sherry. I Like this stuff a lot.

I’m rating this to avoid having to drink another Malt liquor to get the style. I had a warm can of this when I was 14. It took about 5 or 6 big swigs to finish (which I alternated with swigs of pineapple and grapefruit Lilt to avoid vomiting). I kept it down long enough to have a smoke and stare into the distance for a few seconds. On the way down it tasted like old ox tail soup and kerosene, on the way up it tasted the same... except totally tropical for some reason.

Can from a little off-licence in Blackwater, Hampshire, who appears to specialise in tramp juice. Fruit yeast lager aroma, with a hint of booze. Bright gold. Initially, at least, the white head is big and foamy. Slow bubbles. Sweet. Saccharine, syrup. There is some boozey bitterness into the finish. Medium bodied. A tad sticky. Soft carbonation. Astringent but abrupt finish. When I took a look at the case I wondered who’d want to drink the advertised ’half litre’. Turns out it’s me. Not a good beer but goes down easily, tramp alcopop.

500ml can from Bargain Booze Darlington, 8%. Golden colour with a white foam head. Nose of malt, grainy, cardboard. Taste is sweetish, malty, grains, fruity & metallic, harsh boozy. Medium bodied, soft to medium carbonation, drying earthy boozy unpleasant papery finish. Chilled but still not cold enough to make it drinkable.

500ml can (Corner Shop, Denham) at 8% Sweet almondy aroma, classic ESL. Paleish, but the head is reasonably persistent. Light palate, covers the alcohol, softish. Sweetish malts, almond, fruity esters, remarkably clean. Finish has a bitter bite, a little metallic. Still fruity. Pretty drinkable, to be honest. Side by side with the previous 2 modern kraft IPAs, I’d chose this, to be honest. Nice clean ESL.

Beautiful yellow golden color. Medium lasting creamy head. Tiny particles floating around. Aroma is a bit spicy and malty, but a bit thin. Soft taste, slightly spicy, belgian blonde-like. Bit dry palate. Another good brew from the Scheldebrouwerij!
Not much porter taste left in the half-and-half, but there is little. Actually, very delicious and easy-drinking dark beer.
Brown with a low head. Aroma of caramel and roasted malts. The roastiness continues in the flavour which is quite sweet, yet balanced. A bit watery perhaps, but nevertheless accepted.

Courtesy of Acertain. Thank you, Andrew. The aroma is very malted milk ball with a punch of cocoa, chocolate and dishes fresh from the washer with a hint of soap still on them. The body is a ruddy dark brown and holds a diminishing tan head. Caramel, cocoa and lots of malt powder with a fairly bitter hop/roast kick in the finish. It gets a little metallic twang in the far finish. The defining feature is however the chocolate/cocoa malted milk ball notes. The mouth feel is on the thin side, but not terribly so.
Bottle at ÅBF08. Mild roasted aroma. Clear dark brown colour. Roasted flavour, some barley bitterness.
Sample at Aarhus beerfestival. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are malt and hops with notes of coffee.
Aarhus, DK Bottled Coffee and chocolate aroma. Flavor is with balanced sweetness to the dryness of the roasted malts
Black with medium beige head.Aroma of rosted malt and coffee,feels mild and smooth a littel thin with a smokey finish.

33cl bottle. Pours black with a brown head. Smooth caramel roast & liquirice. Light sweet & smooth - a bit of a weak body though. Low carbonation. Dominating sweetness. Mediocre all around - typical ørbæk!
Dark amber with no head. Roasted malt, coffee and caramel hits the nose. Flavor is rather sweet with roasted malt and caramel. Finishes light bitter.
[Sampled in 2005.] Funny mix of a porter and a pilsner. Despite its ABV it’s a bit watery. Notes of smoke, smoothness, roast and a flat finish.

GCBF. Poured a pale pink, like a cider. Loose, tall head with more pink. Pink pink pink. Aroma was a bit cloying and sweet. A bit of hops aroma came through, but seemed out of place. Mouthfeel was ok, but beer seemed overcarbed with a bit of acid bite to the back of the tongue. Flavour was a bit disjointed. Some nice malts singing backup, but a weird berry taste that I definitely do not associate with saskatoon berries (which I love) literally jammed up the taste. It was that ambiguous berry flavour that is all sweet and no berry that you find in blue drinks. I was pretty disappointed. Hops? there was hops in here?
Hazy pink colour. Light flavour - only a vague hint of fruit. A quick, light and bland beer...disappointing as I was hoping to sort out what Saskatoon berries taste like.

(1 ltr bottle) Pours a medium, white, non-dissipating head and an amber body. Nose of berry and slightly metallic. Artificial Saskatoon berry flavour - too jammy and sweet? Slight malt finish. Above average.

Big blue 1L bottle. Very loud pop announced to the office that it was beer time. A small rush of foam and all was quiet. Big head of medium bubbles quickly settles. Fruity berry aroma, smells like fruit jelly. Thin light brown colour. Reminds me of a heather ale. The fruit does not overpower the beer. Don't swallow too quickly to let the berry flavour fill your taste buds. Very little hop or malt. Almost no aftertaste. A refreshing change and probably very nice on a hot summer day. The berry flavour gets stronger as you drink.

aroma of berries, fruity, light and pleasant. Pours a copper brown with a slight reddish tinge. Head starts off thick but quickly disappears. Carbonation low. Overall delivery is flat. Hops weak, although the berry taste comes out a bit at the end. Better than most fruit beers I've had. At least this has some alcohol.

Can from Arden Wines- now brewed at 7.4% and distributed by InBev UK. Looks like I’m the first rater to have stumbled on this filth for EIGHT years. Jesus, I’m desperate tonight. Gold with a fat white head falling to a slick. Aroma of rotting apples, grass cuttings, a sprinkle of acetone. Tastes EXACTLY like flying saucers, apple Chewits and sherbet-sprinkled paper. Which is a relief. Tempted to drink, but won’t be doing so.

Pours copper clear, sudsy medium white head. OK retention. Strong skunky smell opening the can. Slight fruity malt smell after left for a few minutes. Touch of alcohol in the nose too. Thin watery mouthfeel. Terrible skunky malt flavour. Dont know how to describe it, just overwhelming crap taste! Alcohol very present in the aftertaste. Terrible stuff. I think I'll avoid Sköl Super after others comments. I can feel a headache coming on after this one.

Dark gold amber clear, medium size moderate lasting head. Very faint but not unpleasant fruity malty aroma when cool tending to bandaid when warmed. Medium thin body. Antiseptic and near-breath-taking alcoholic tasting start. Rank malt and stale hops can't cover the alcohol thereafter. Better than Sköl? Perhaps . . .
Less offensive smell than Sköl Super but same pure alcohol taste. Thinner as well (might as well be paint thinner). Obviously intended for soccer hooligans only. Never again.
Draft at the source. Pours dark brown with a light beige head. Coffee aroma. Taste is coffee, roasted malt, chocolate notes. Nice one.
Aroma: rich and roasty, coffee; Appearance: very dark amber pour with creamy offwhite head; Taste: follows nose with a slight offnote from malt; Overall: a solid porter.

Look forward to this every year. Perfect porter for the fall. Coffee up front but almost an equal amount of cocoa flavor is good balance. Mid-level alcohol is well hidden behind subtle flavors. Real Ale is quietly one of the best overall breweries in Texas, certainly a cut above Karbach, Deep Ellum, and St. Arnold’s.

Originally rated on 1/18/09. Tried this today at Opal Devines in Austin, A deep black body with a thin light tan cap that left fair lace. Aroma and flavors of coffee, roasted malts and nuts, a little sweet. A decent amount of alcohol that was well hidden. Overall a good porter that will drink again and would recommend
(Tap) clear, bright dark amber colour with a small brown head; aroma of coffee, milk chocolate, then honey, balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish
12oz bottle from HEB. pours dark brown with minimal light passing through and a large frothy light brown head. Hazelnut, coffee, roasted nuts, low carbonation, light mouthfeel.
Dark brown in color... Coffee and nutty malts on nose... Flavor is rich nutty malts, coffee, well balanced coffee Porter... done well as usual from real ale ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown with a thin beige head. Medium body and carbonation. Aroma of bitter dark malt and coffee. Nice taste of coffee with medium bitterness from some of the dark malts. Finishes dry.
Pours a dark brown, almost black color. Nice tan head. Tastes and smells of dark roasted malt and coffee, with a hint of hops. This is a good go to beer when it’s out.

Bottle. Pour is black with a thin tan head that leaves little lacing. Aroma is coffee, vanilla, dark roasted malts, and cocoa. Taste is cocoa, coffee, slight vanilla, chocolate, and roasted dark malts. Average thickness and slightly creamy.
Very easy drinking strong ale. Crisp, with nice dry hopping, but has some hop on the finish as well. Session 8%er?

Amber-apricot in color. Malty (bready) and smooth on the palate (not watery). Mild in flavor, but really well made and nicely balanced. Alcohol is hidden unbelievably well; it's barely noticeable at all. Very enjoyable to drink.

Draught. Body is hazy dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted bread, cookie), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin, pine, herbs), lightly yeasty (dough). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. Decent, nice flavor balance.
On draught in Jeju. Copper colour and low to medium carbonation. No aroma and very little taste. Some caramel, syrup and rice. No noticeable hop flavour. Very poor.
On tap, clear amber, medium head and nice lacing. Aroma of macro lager malts, flat. Tastes medium bitter, strong corn syrup and rice, not much more. Struggling with this.

On tap at Hollywood in Itaewon next door to Reilley’s Taphouse (they also have an ok tap selection). It poured more copper than gold but still had lots of hay in the aroma/flavor due to the probable use of adjuncts but had some caramel.

0.33l bottle. Nice one! A non-pale lager in Korea? Amazing.. Anyhow, this is a clear deep deep red beer with a small quickly fading off-white head that sticks nicely to the sides of the glass. The aroma has a mild burned and sweet touch over it. A bit of sour dark malts here as well. Not extreme, but it’s nice with something a bit different from the lagers. The carbonation level is average to soft and it has a thin and quite watery mouthfeel. Tastes alright I guess. Think this is a old bottle (not that it’s easy for me to read Korean) A bit "old" flavors. It’s light dark malty with caramel hints. Low on the bitterness and it ends mildly mouthdrying. All in all, drinkable and one of the better I’ve had so far here in Korea.
the best beer in korea. not saying alot, but i always viewed this as the premium beer. drank it on payday only. a reddish lager, slightly malty flavor. like a watered down Killians

Lyckas väcka sinnena ur sin djupa slummer genom att milt ruska om med sin väna alkoholstyrka. Inget för historieböckerna, ej heller för de riktigt kräsna finsmakarna, men Red Rock får livet att kännas en smula lättare. Bra så.
the best beer commonly available in the area of Korea that I lived.....and that’s sad.

draft - hmmm... this beer rises to the level of somewhat below average. Wow! That’s high praise for this brewery. It’s light amber with a quickly fading head and a mild lightly roasted malt aroma. The flavor is toasted caramel malt and not much else. At least it’s drinkable and has more flavor than their pale lagers.

Bottle. The very best beer I tasted in Korea! Red-brown colour. Aroma of toasted malts and and hops, which very much appears stronger in the flavour along with some caramel and good bitterness. Nice aftertaste indeed.
On Tap - The best Korean beer I had while stationed there for a year. Good reddish color with decent head. Was representative of a Killians-style beer, but not as good in taste or appearance.

Deep and dark in color. There was minimal head, but it was darker than I expected going into the political nature of the polcies against the White House. There was some maple syrup, brown sugar in both the aroma and the flavor. there was also some vingarey flavors that kind of ruined the climbing stage.

had day of the FA cup incident.... Pours a dark brown/black....has some good constant coco foam....some roasted cocoa / alcohol aroma....is quite smooth for a imp stout....whew! alcohol is very upfront, warming brew...a good imp stout but they need to bottle it so i can let it rest for a few years!!
Fresh out of the vat. Poured a dark black with a tan head. Aroma is malty and chocolate. Taste is chocolate and filled with coffe notes and caramel.

On tap at two rows in H town. Had no head at all, black body. Weak vinous/fruity aroma. Taste was kinda spicy and burnt. Had some bitterness to it as well. I did not like drinking this, wish it had some more carbonation. And yeah, the alcohol is very present. But hey, they said they were charging $3.75 for it, but they ended up only charging a buck! I still dont think id try it again, well, unless its only a dollar.
Slightly smoky with a mild chocolate finish. Crisp and light throughout, but the alcohol detracts rather than adds to the experience. Refreshing, nonetheless.

The Dallas two rows puts out an imperial that was far superior to this one. Matt is right in that the strength was obvious, but not at all in a good way. Mouthfeel was very sudsy, just a run of the mill imperial lacking character with a slight cardboard finish.

I thought this was great. The only drawback was that you could really taste how strong it was. It was not disguised well. Small, brown head. Aroma similar to palate, very strong. Initial taste was very powerful, strong, and bitter. It got better after the initial shock. Very interesting beer from this place.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: Bottle. Pours an amber body with an off white head. A malty body with a lightly grain body crisp with an light dried fruit sweetness and a thin slick body. Hints of berries and corn husk. Eh.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: Bottle. Pours slightly opaque amber with a thin effervscent head. Aroma is mild but hints towards berries and honey-butter. Flavor is sweetly subtle; fruity sweet, honey-butter, and slightly citric. Palate is inoffensive.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: caramel colored and flavored with a hint of German style hop. clear with short white head the beer is lightly sweet with malt. it is refreshing and does lose its carbonaton after a couple of minutes out of the bottle. i got an alcohol flavor like bourbon or better yet rye at first taste.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: Bottle from Capone’s. Pours clear deep coppery brownish, with ruby edges. Nose is caramel malt, brown sugar, vinous fruit. Tastes caramel malty, with vinous fruit notes. Medium palate heft, with a bit of a lack of balance and complexity. Not a repeater for me.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: 12 oz bottle from a variety six pack from EZ Liquors. Pours a clear red orange with a small off white foamy head that quickly disipates. Aroma of vegtables, old corn, musty basement and wet leather. Medium bodied with average carbonation and a smooth watery finish. Flavor of some amber malts, watered down caramel, and biscuit. This beer sure won’t knock your socks off, well maybe the aroma will now that I think about it.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: I like this beer. Not too heavy. Light enough to drink more than just a few. I`m tired of all those micro over flavored beers. This is a good beer for those who want more than a light beer and less than a heavy micro.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: No head, just white ring. Body is watered tea, yellow w/ orange and some brown. Aroma is sour, sugary, some toffee and cherries maybe. Taste is a little watery too with cherries and caramel. Aftertaste is skunky. My friend said it reminded him of a certain southern area of a woman.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: The color is light brown and a bit hazy. The beer has a nice aroma. Vert lightly carbonated. It is an easy, simple beer to drink.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: a rather underwhelming beer. cloudy w/ little head. citrusy and sweet, but very lacking in malt profile for a amber lager.

column1: Bucks County PennBrook Traditional Amber Lager
column5: (12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with hopdog, thanks Steve!) Amber lager? Who are they trying to fool? Pours medium yellow in color with a small, white head that quickly shrinks to a partial sheen. Lightly sweet aroma is totally overrun by wet cardboard, so the nose is pretty unpleasant. The very same cardboard also dominates the lightly sweet flavor, as I really can’t identify any malt or hops at work here. And wow, the watery, cardboard finish is really terrible. This is just bad stuff. And I’m surprised because they call it an amber lager. I never imagined it would be a pale lager, and a bad one at that. This really gives macro swill a run for it’s money.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: on draft, good amber color with decent big fluffy head, nose is very aromatic hop. flavor is overpowering hops, slightly unbalanced, odd finish. Nice beer but needs some work

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: draft- a well balanced, estery/fruity, ipa, reddish in color. would not seek out, but nice if its there.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: Draught at the Blue Dog in Chalfont. Clear golden-copper body with a sudsy white head. Aroma and flavor of fruit, chalky malts, weak black tea, and wood stems. Medium bitterness and some undesired sweet residual malt notes. Mild, but noticeable acidity. A remedial East Coast IPA.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: Draft at the Grey Lodge in Philly. Nice IPA. Along the bitter style. Godd have been a little more balanced.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: Dark golden ale with a thin white head. Strong diacetyl aroma, overpowers the hops. In mouth, caramelly hops with rather flat character, lingering with some nutty notes and a oily mouthfeel. Bizarre Ipa. On tap at the CNY Brewfest 2006.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: An average English style IPA. Nice blend of hops, just no epiphanies here. Sampled with a back of Wild Turkey Rye Whiskey.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: Very smooth IPA with a daker golden brown color. The aroma smells alittle skunky at first but then blends nicely into the flavor of the beer the more you drink. This is my first beer from flying bison brewery and I am impressed. I think IPA’s are one of the most challenging to brew and since its brewed in my hometown, Im excited to try other beers from flying bison.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: Floral and citrus aroma, while being deep amber with a medium head. Smells delicious, and tastes like a cross between an English and American IPA.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: Medium amber color, almost a light brown, cream color head. Bigger floral hop aroma, nice malt backbone. Flavor was little buttery, good dose of hops. Medium body, bitter finish. Nice English style IPA.

column1: Flying Bison Bird of Prey IPA
column5: grassy, floral aroma with a hint of lemon. Clean appearance, thin whitish head. Nice earthy flavor, but nowhere near the hop level I was expecting.

500ml bottle brewed in Germany at 5%. Crystal clear gold. Nice-sized head, OK duration. Grassy, corny, and slightly spicy aroma! Low-moderate carbonation, just right for the style. Grassy, tad lemony, earthy hops. Slight mineral aspect. Slight spiciness too! Malt adding sweetness and body but otherwise keeping well out of the way, and I think the beer is all the better for it. One of the better Helles I've had, although I wouldn't go so far as to say the best (that'd be Ayinger's). Sweet, but keeps the sweetness nice and light instead of getting bogged down - a real roof of the mouth beer. That's how I like this style. Some Heineken influence perhaps, and worth comparing to their Munchner Gold. If anything this might be better.
Clear golden with a frothy head. Hoppy, metallic smell. Malty taste, unfortunately with a lack of body. Low carbonation.
Złociste klarowne piwo z niezłą pianą która powoli opada. Aromat zbożowy, plus trochę trawy. W smaku podobnie. Praktycznie bez goryczki, fajnie zbalansowane piwo

.33 bottle. Hazy amber, low, ugly, unstable, white head, not too much lacing. Aroma malty, roasty, bready, caramel, a little bit of nuts. Taste thick, smooth,roasty rather sweet. Carbonation high, definitely tingling, a bit too high. Bitterness medium, roasty, a tad herbal, nice. Aftertaste bready, roasty, caramel, a hint of nuts. Nice.
500ml bottle in 2016. Clear mid golden with a white head. Bready malt, straw and floral hop aroma. Decent enough lager, but pretty simple.

Bue sous la tente à l'Oktoberfest. Robe dorée et limpide. Mousse blanche bien persistante. Arômes céréales floral miel. Goût légèrement sucré. Amertume légère. Texture fluide, un peu aqueuse. Carbonatation fine moyennement abondante. Honorable.
Kolor złoty, klarowny. Piana obfita, drobnopęcherzykowa. W zapachu słodowe. W smaku wodniste, lekki posmak alkoholu. Opakowanie piwa super, niestety samo piwo poniżej średniej.
500ml flip-top bottle (thanks Viil). Clear golden color. Medium size, white head, stays. Grainy, sweet, fizzy, sugary in aroma/taste. Drinkable brew.

Pours a clear, golden coloration with a medium, foamy head and slightly visible carbonation. Smells of doughy, slightly bready malt and grassy, herbal hops. Taste is a great balance of doughy and slightly bready, grainy malt and grassy, herbal hops, with just a hint of citrus coming through as well. Finishes with a light/medium bitterness and some grassy, herbal hops lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and medium/high carbonation. Perhaps not too exciting, but a very well-balanced, refreshing and highly drinkable Helles that starts out a little sweet, but gets balanced in the finish by a decent bitterness. Still a little too sweet and also overly carbonated for my personal taste, but a very nice example of the style nonetheless.

Bottled at 5.0% ABV. Clearest straw yellow, tall fluffy white head. Good lacing. Aroma: clean malt, light fruitiness, hoppy hints. Light plus body. Average to lively carbonation. Taste: fairly clean, malty, crisp, sweetish. Some bread. Restraint hop. Low plus bitterness. Well-drinkable but not a favourite of mine.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours a dark pepsi cola color with a "cream" head. Aromas of light burnt malts, fake smoke, and some caramel. Flavors of light fake smoky wood/malts and hay behind. Leaves a light smoke finish. Medium bitter. Watery feel.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bottle. Pours close to black big tab head. Taste smells of roasted malt coffee kind of dry. Little bit of cream. Not that great.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours a syrupy black with a generous tan head. The aroma of this beer was quite nice, and it promises a lot... Lots of roast, some creamy caramel, some floral hops. But the promises quickly become forgotten when you take the first sip. Yes, there is some roast. Yes, there is some creamy mouthfeel (which is actually the highlight of this beer). But this could be so much better... Where’s the chocolate? Where’s the hop bite? Where’s the warming alcohol? They may call this "Double Dark", but there is nothing "double" about this beer. It is simply average at best. Would not buy again.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 12oz bottle. dark black pour, small, lasting tan head. big aroma of chocolate, cocoa and roast. Nice taste, little sweet at first sip, not a lot of finish, but a decent beer.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap sample at Custom Brewcrafters in Honeoye Falls, NY. Opaque nearly black brown with smallish head and excellent lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and prunes. Taste of peaty roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Medium mouthfeel and carbonation. A very solid porter with some stout characteristics. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: My wife brought this one back from a trip to Rochester. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with an enormous foamy brown head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was toasty malts, malted milk and cocoa. The flavor was bitter, dryish and roasty with notes of nut, cocoa, coffee and malted milk. The finish was long, dry and roasty with lingering coffee and malted milk. Medium body. Too dry for my liking but decent anyway.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours from a bottle into a chalice glass. Head: Minimal tan head that dissipates almost instantly. Color: Deep brown/cola, not transparent. Aroma: Noticable chocolate coffee malt. Taste: Bitter Roasted, dark chocolate. Watery texture (not syrupy) Finish: Lightly roasted taste on the back of the throat. Lingers but at no point is overly strong. Overall impression. Mildly bitter, but easy to drink. Nothing overpowering. Could be something enjoyable to drink throughout the course of an evening.

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: bottle... dark breen, hint of glassy amber, big light tan head, lasting no lace, the bubbles are too big...really dead nose, a touch of cream, a little coffee, a weird vegetal note, and some off chemicals, something is just off... tastes like generic cream, super thin, nothing but sweetness, not very good

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: 12 oz bottle from a friend in NY. Pours dark black with a thin tan head. Nice roasted malt aroma that isn’t too overpowering. Medium body with a slightly slick/oily mouth feel characteristic of an oatmeal stout. Roasted malt notes up front that give way to a slightly dry finish. Well balanced and not overly aggressive. Overall an enjoyable, creamy well roasted porter. Overall: (B+)

column1: Custom Brewcrafters Double Dark Cream Porter
column2: Honeoye Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bottle 355 ml Aroma: Clean fresh aroma, hint of hops , light roast to it. Mild and refreshing. Appearance: Dark brown with garnet light. Large frothy , dark beige top. Good lace sown. Very presentable. 5- Palate / Taste: Dry roast ash like , dark soul has this ale. Clean , proper straight feel. Mid accented by dark chocolate hints. Finish accented by wild leafy hop hints. Tasty brew.
The only reason I rated this beer so high is the fact that it has been discontinued and I actually liked it. Anyone who recently rated it probably had a super old batch

(bottle) pours orange brown with a lingering head. the sweet malt flavor, watery palate and moderate carbonation reminded us of dr. pepper. i wasn’t too keen on the initial aroma (boozey) but after a few sips it blends with the palate. it has an interesting flavor and a smooth taste. would make a decent session beer but may be too sweet for some. in general, i think southern tier has better.

Poured dark orange with virtually no head. I thought maybe it wa sflat when I opened it hoever, it was carbonated. Mostly malt aroma with hints of caramel. Flavor is all malt. Nice body. A pretty good beer and a nice example of a mild.

Hazy light amber with a small white head. Aroma of freshly cracked malt with some caramel. Flavor is malty, with just a slight spicy bitterness in the finish. A great session brew, in a vastly under-appreciated style. Unfortunately, this is being discontinued for the time being due to lack of interest. Seems manly men don’t like drinking a beer with "mild" in the name. I guess I’m not a manly man.
This is a pretty good beer. Goes down really smooth, great back yard, by the pool kinda brew.

(12 oz bottle, obtained in trade with shadey, thanks Shane!) Another American mild ale that isn’t close to style. Unfortunately, not only is this one not to style (a fact which never impacts my ratings), it’s also pretty bland and boring (which DOES!). The light, delicate nose has a mild, sweet melon aroma. And the flavor is also lightly melony, with some gently bitter hops in the mix. But because the malt is so light, the mild hoppiness is modestly dominant. Light in body, but doesn’t seem watery. Light amber in color. Smallish off-white head maintains a thin layer and leaves some patches of lace on the glass. I don’t care that this isn’t to style, but I do care that it’s a boring beer. Blah.
A nice mild beer. Could have used a little more flavor to it, but the flavor that is there is still good. Overall this is another good beer from Southern Tier.

Golden pour with a big, creamy, white head. Aroma of corn flakes, hops, florals. Tastes like liquid corn flakes with a hoppy, fruity finish. Smooth as silk, well balanced, and up there with FFF Pride and Joy as the best mild ales I’ve ever had. Just astounding.

Hazy Orange, no head. Aroma of Orange marmalade and honey. Slight honey flavor a, some mild pine hop notes, as well some citrus flavors. A hint of sweet, then a dry finish. Very tasty. Thanks to Springslicker for this one!

I really enjoyed this beer. I’ve only tried about six milds. This would fall in the middle of the pack... my favorite of the style being Moorhouse Black Cat . This is a very light, refreshing amber ale. Small, fizzy, off-white head. Crisp, clean aroma and perfectly balanced flavor. Notes of iced-tea and straw in both. Light-bodied and watery with fizzy carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish. Perfect with food, much like a Vienna... only better as it’s an ale. Thanks to springslicker for the bottle.

Tap at Der Pschorr in Munich. Pours cloudy light amber with a huge head. Smells wheaty. Near medium body. Flavor is very lightly citrus with a wheaty base. Moderately dry and not hoppy, but good on a warm day.
Hazy amber with big white head. Aroma is grassy hops with some grainy citrus and sour dust. Lots of graininess. Not really good.

Hazy orange-brown color with white head. Aroma is unfermented malts, caramel. Taste is a bit bananas, a bit spicy, smooth texture, a bit watery. High but soft carbonation. Okay for a leichte Weisse, but there are better ones.
Trübes orangegelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig nach Banane, leicht würzig.
Hazy orange beer with small head. Aroma wheat. Flavor is wheat, citrus. Pretty nice for such a low alcohol level.

7/VIII/2012 - 50cl bottle @ Hacker-Pschorr Bavaria Bräu (München) - BB: IV/13 - (2012-851) Cloudy deep orange beer, big creamy off-white head, pretty table, adhesive, nice lacing. Aroma: bit of banana, bit floral, soapy, herbal hops, spices, vegetables. MF: ok carbon, light to medium body. Taste: some grains, citrus, grassy. Aftertaste: metallic, citrus, some grains, pretty clean bitter finish. Very refreshing. Not too bad for a low alcohol!
Hazy orange, thin to no head. Sweet banana flavour with a serious banana aroma. A bit to watery.

Tap at der Pschorr am V-Markt. Cloudy light brown pour, slow carb and a rocky, lacing beige head. Stripped wheaty nose, there’s a really nice nutty/chocolate note in with the wheat taste, but otherwise the overall impression is of blandness. Medium body.
Hefig-herber, recht wässriger Beginn. Weiter wässrig, wenig herb, noch trinkbar. Naja... 10/6/8/5//5
50cl bottle. Poured cloudy orange with a nice white head, some lacing. Aroma is yeasty, with notes of wheat and fruit. Flavor is mostly wheat and yeast. Watery. Refreshing.
08.09.2006. 0,33l Bottle. Golden yellow colour with white head. Aroma is rather weak with some malt and a little bitterness. Tastes very little for a vienna.
Bottle. Deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, caramel. Flavour is fruit, malt, caramel. Thin body. Thin beer.
Clear golden with tiny white short lasting head. Somewhat smoked aroma with hints of malt. Again smoked flavour with malt, ham and caramel notes.
Dark golden colour with almost no head.Aroms is light malty and with mild caramel flavor,less metallic then many others discount beers from Hareboe.
33 cL bottle. Pours golden clear orange with a crispy lacing head. Malty, slight mouldy. Flavour is mouldy, malty and slight metallic. Dry malty finish. Ok brew.
Dark golden colour, white head. Little malty aroma. Malty flavour. Watery aftertaste. Hint of harsh bitterness. Thin body.
Bottle. Darkish golden with a short fizzy head. Malty sweet aroma. Flavour is rather thin, bit caramellic, malty and grainy. Thin brew.
Bottled. Clear, golden (a bit darker than VIP Pils) with an off-white head. Malt, weak fruityness and caramel in the aroma. The flavor is the same. Medium to thin body. (061007)
golden yellow with little white head. Little malty aroma. Watery texture. little sweetness from malts. Little bite from sour hops.
Bottle. Creamy white fair mostly deminishing head. Bready malty aroma, Just OK flavor, but a bit waery palate and finish. Deasent discount beer.
Eiskalte 0,33l Flasche im Magic Ice, Tromsø. Goldgelb und klar. Pilsner Getreideduft. Recht wässerig im Geschmack. Etwas Getreide, Stroh und Gras. Nur gut aus Eisgläsern!
This beer is favoite of many North Norwegians. It´s a nice easy drinking lager, with not a lot of taste I have to say. but an ok lager on many occasions. Not bad.
Une lager agréable par son côté frais et dugeste, idéale après une longue journée de ballade. Une lager de soif

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.

Can from Systembolaget Sweden. Big and lastning white head. Clear pale yellow color. A bit soapy aroma. Mild and sweet malty taste with a touch of bitterness. Slim to medium body. Typical mainstream lager with a low bitterness.
Can from systemet. A classic bad mass produced lager to beh oenst............

thank you to henrik on holiday in norway 0.50l can gold blond colored body with a white head and with a spicy fruity malt aroma a spicy sweet malt watery slightly bitter taste with a slight bitter finish
0,33 l Dose. Goldenes Bier, flacher Schaum. Riecht süßlich, schmeckt süßlich, laff.
Smakupplevelsen, den lilla som ändå ryms i halvlitersburken, är inte mycket att yvas över. Minimal humle- och maltkänsla. Det positiva är att Arctic Beer inte har några oönskade bismaker.
Pours a very pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy corn aroma. Fruity malty grainy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy finish.

Feb 2009: Brown 500ml bottle, poured into a UK pint sleeve glass. The rear label asked for the beer to be served cool, it was. Light amber, dull gold in colour with a good firm foaming off-white head. Pioneer Hops and White Malts are used in the brew and the hops could clearly be found in the fairly sweetish aroma, my nose isn’t good enough to pick out individual types of hops, even if I knew them!
