Bitter and refreshing, tangy and tart, but not dry or coy. A true English Bitter in every sense. Good hop retension in the mouthfeel, the bitterness from them obviously stays too. This is a well balanced beer and one I’d love to try on cask one day (soon).
Handpulled cask at JDW Stanmore. Amber with a white head. Malty with good balancing complex hoppiness.
Cask, 4.3% at GBBF08. Weak fruit aroma. Hazy golden colour. Stable frothy white head. Good fruity flavour. Medium bitterness. Not dry and not sweet, but good.
A pretty standard British golden ale, with grassy aroma, flavoured with some floral-fruity notes and ending up in a weak dry, bitter finish. Watered palate (Cask at GBBF, 08.08.2008).
Had it at GBBF 2008. It was very malty indeed I liked it’s grains taste. NOt boring and very drinkable.

Bottle, Barleycorns, Nantwich. A summer drink for a summer that is yet to quite ignite. Poured a golden colour with a thinnish white head. Malty, sweet aroma. Some fruit and hop present in the flavour which again is a bit on the sweet side. Easy drinking. Quite enjoyed this.
Bottled. Reddish amber, white halo. Doesn’t look real. Sickly buttery toffee aroma with musty ganja-ish hops struggling to poke through. Caramel and green nettley hop, bit of citrus.
Cask. Yellow with a small white head. Weak aroma mostly grassy. Sweet with a hint of hops in the finish.

Cask@GBBF2007. Golden colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is fruity hops with some wooden hints. Flavour is earthy, cellary, fruity hops and some caramel malts. Finish and aftertaste are spicy and grassy in an unpleasant way.
bottle conditioned possibly off. light pale, with sour tones in both nose and flavour

Found some strange flavors in this beer; not necessarily all bad, but peculiar. Sweet, unfermented honey, zingy herbs and a big lemony flavor that I didn't expect. Somewhat thin-bodied. Yeast only plays a minor role.
I found this beer to have a fairly good, smooth, mild flavor with a sweet aroma.

Good head of fine bubbles and a nice malty aroma. It's body is a dark brown almost non-transparent color. Its head fades fast but leaves a nice lacing. It had an initial caramel taste with a slight aftertaste and a smooth initial taste that starts out strongly then fades leaving an aftertaste on the roof of your mouth.

Swet, malty aroma. Smokiness in there as well with some roasted malts. Not as much wheat characteristic as expected, but a smooth brew nevertheless. We visited this brewery across the street from Bell's and were impressed with its charming atmosphere. I am eager to try the 6-pack of brews we obtained at this brewery!

Water is more aromatic than this. Did the "brewer" forget to add finishing hops? Slightly darker than their blonde. Light copper/gold transparent color with white head. Start is medicinally bitter with mild mild mild hops. Lactic, astringent, and watery
Very dark red with a white foamy head. Vdery carbonated and fizzy. Decent, but not great

Very mildly mild mild sweet aroma in this guy with hints of sourness. Dark copper transparent color with a light tan head. Thin and watery to start with hints of roasted malts in the middle. Finishes lactic and thin.

A BEERLOVER'S APOCALYPSE PART 2: THE IRISH VALIANTLY TRY TO SAVE THE DAY I walk into the establishment (fake wood outside, jutting out of a chain motel) and the first thing I see is a video game room, full of kids. Tempted to find something to play; would that I had spent an hour here rather than in the floor above! Up half a flight is the "nightclub" where proper dress is required (in Plattsburgh?? I'd be surprised if you could find a suit & tie in this grimy dying postindrustrial wasteland). The bp is airy and spacious, with good window views of...McDonalds, Wendys, the interstate, etc. OK. Gambling is heavily promoted here; hey if I lived here I'd be spending every penny on escapism too, and I'd rather do it in a casino than this sad travesty of a "brewpub". I order the sampler, the waitress just takes off before I have a chance to ask for water or anything. Slight pepperiness, malty, caramel, a bit of actual hop bite, good body. I wouldn't make a real effort to have this again, but its quite drinkable.

Tap. Poured a reddish brown with a light tan head. Smelled faintly of chocolate and nutty malts. Tasted watery, fairly bland, with a hint of chocolate and little else. Not much in the way of hops, bland. Thin mouthfeel.

Faint, sweet chocolate aroma without much else going on. Slight roastiness. Dark copper/light mahogany color with transparent light tan head. Shit, this tastes like it might be beer. I made it through 4 other samples and now I am finally detecting some crappy, albeit beer properties. Start is bitter and slightly lactic. Turns roasty with hints of chocolate. Finishes bitter and medicinal.

A BEERLOVER'S APOCALYPSE PART 4: BROWN SUGAR-WATER I look around me. The clientele is all families; it was obvious from the menus, the conservative way the waitresses dress (the hostess is pretty cute, regardless; guess the place gets one extra point out of a hundred for that), and the decor -- 30s gangster, but "gangster lite" if you will. My wall is devoted to Bonnie and Clyde, with lots of cool photos, but none of their bloody dessicated corpses! C'mon don't tease us like that! My food arrives -- I can tell immediately that the chicken fingers and moxx sticks have exactly the same breading; economical, that. Potato skins taste a day old and microwaved, with fake bacon bits. Mozz is a very cheap variety, barely warmed through; fingers are dry and bland. Wings are the only saving grace, and they are quite sweet without a trace of heat, meaty, flavorful -- except I ordered "very spicy"! Oh and the salad was lifeless and consisted of iceberg, cucumbers, pink tomatoes, onions. Caesar dressing out of a bottle. The families around me are drinking from bottles. I walk past one on my way to the bathroom. Coors Light all around. No surprise there. Extremely thin, watery and bland; a brown sugar nuttiness, the only real flavor, comes out a bit in the end; little aroma except for the ever-present cookies.

Raspberry purree aroma, but at least there is an aroma to this beer unlike most smaples before this. Red/pink/oragne transparent color with a small white head. Hideous. Holy shit this is medicinal. Fruity raspberry taste up front with no sweetness. Finishes very bitter, thin, and medicinal. This tastes like the Kinney Drugs brand Guaifenisin DM that I was taking last week for a cold. I wish I was still congested...

A BEERLOVER'S APOCALYPSE, PART 6 AND FINALE: BLOW A BIG FAT RASPBERRY If only I had a girlfriend. Girls like wussy fruit beers, right? She (whoever she would be) would have to be patient with me on my beer-travels, she would have to be willing to serve good beer at our wedding, we'd have to have a keg or two of North Coast Old Rasputin, or McNeills Imperial maybe, if it was in the winter like now anyway. We'd have our beer cellar; our kids would be named Saison, Kriek, and Framboise (isn't that an awesome name for a girl?); we'd live on some wonderful farmland in southeastern Wisconsin where the wild yeasts amazingly mimic those of Belgium, and we'd.... One sip brings me back to reality. Oh, the color was bad enough, Kool-Aid watery pink; and the nose is all sugary raspberry jam with an uneasy underlying off vinegar; but the flavor oh my god the flavor is of the cheapest raspberry jam, hot peppers, vinegar and a smidgeon of sour milk. The absolute worst fruit beer ever, the worst beer I've had in a brewpub; if Coors didn't hold a special place in my heart, this would even challenge it for supreme worst beer of all time! I trudge out into the snow, weary from my ordeal, but a smile is on my face; I am not finished with my brewpub tour for the day -- Davidson Brothers in Glens Falls awaits, of which I have heard good stories (which indeed prove to be correct), and I cannot possibly ever duplicate this experience. I have found the worst of all brewpubs, and I have survived, to laugh and sing and write and drink another day. Rejoice!
Smells like a fresh batch of blueberry muffins. Tastes like someone dropped the muffisn in a bucket of water. Semi doughy and kinda fruity, but lacking substance

A BEERLOVER'S APOCALYPSE PART 3: BLUE IS BORING. Well after I got my beer I had to order some food; the menu was your basic TGI Fridays/Bennigans greasy lager-accompaniment fare, heavy on wings and burgers, cheapo steaks, salads that you know will be wilted and warm, etc. I go for a sampler plate, what the hell I need some artery hardening. I contemplate my beers, which the waitress could not identify; most look rather weak and clear, except the Oat Stout which is quite properly thick and well-capped by a lasting head. The rasp in particular looks scary. I'm guessing the pale one in front is the blueberry and hey I'm right! The food arrives (wings, chicken strips, fried mozz, potato skins, why am I torturing myself? because I'm masochistic enough to wonder which will be worse, food or beer?). What kind of bp has only 6 beers available, with TWO FRUIT BEERS, anyway? Very pale and clear, almost headles, faint blueberry/nilla wafer (the house nose, I guess) aroma; medium sweetness, trace of hops, canned blueberry flavor is well balanced with the limited malts, but the ingredients just aren't good. Barely tolerable.

Draft@ Coaches Norman, Ok. Light amber color with a white head. Mildly sweet pale malt aromas with a whiff of floral hops. Light/medium body. Decent flavor is lightly sweet grainy pale malts with a nicely bitter finish. Finally something drinkable besides their IPA

Date: February 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Norman Appearance: hazy gold, fine off white head, drippy lace Aroma: light citrus and floral hop aroma with a hint of sweet malt Body: body is a bit thin and watery Flavor: light crystal malt flavor, soft hops, a touch of bitterness Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.2/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *4
A fairly decent pale ale. Some hints of biscuit amid the malt....and a good balance with the hops. Smooth finish.

On tap at the brewpub in OKC. Pour is clear golden with white head and good lace. Light earthy and citric hop aroma. Biscuit malt. Clean yeast. Balanced lemony hop and biscuit malt flavors. Light, easy drinking body. High carbonation. Perfumish finish. Much better than I expected.

Light amber coloured body with a light tan head. Aroma of fresh english hops and some toffee. Medium-bodied; Hops up front in the taste with some nice malt flavours following. Aftertaste shows some sweetness and good hops. Overall, a good English Pale, especially for a brewpub! I sampled this beer from draught at the brewpub in Bricktown, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma on 13-December-2005.

I find it hard to believe that this ale has the 3% ABV that it was entered with four years ago. What you’ve got here is a sessionable copper bodied APA. The aroma is a light, sweet caramel with some grapefruit around the edges. The caramel flavor is smoothly balanced with a grapefruit/lemon zest/pine resin bitterness. The hoppy bitterness lasts long into the finish, albeit mildly. Nice. Coach’s Restaurant & Brewery, Oklahoma City, OK
Very respectable session pale. Nice hop aromas. Mild tastes of grapefruit. The fizz can have a bit too much bite to appreciate this beer.

Draft at Norman, 11/13/06: Dark orange or light red. Nice firm if thin head. Not much aroma. Smooth. Nice body. After the IPA, this was way mellow. Decently balanced, light malt component and vague hop bitterness. Got better as I ate my burger and the IPA flavors faded. Good.
(Tap) Pours amber with little head. Fruity and hoppy aroma. Taste has some floral notes as well. Pretty good mouthfeel, and balanced too. One of Coach’s better beers.

On tap at Edmond Location: Umber color with a short lived head. Aroma is light but contains a hop character that is mostly absent in the flavor. Well balanced flavor, but I gound myself wanting more bitterness at the end. All in all, still a decent pale.

Die meisten dunklen Biere in Tschechien haben wie die normalen Hellen 11°. Dieses ist aber ein leichteres 10-grädiges Bier, was man auch merkt. Es ist deutlich weniger gehaltvoll als andere Dunkle, was aber passt. Ein leochter Buttergeschmack darf auch nicht fehlen, passt aber ganz gut hinein.
Caramel and bit chocolate malt aroma. Dark brown color with small sized tan head. Light but clean malty taste, light caramel. Thin body, average carbonation. //bottle from Tesco Jaroměř
Piwo jak na tmave ma poprawny kolor z beżowa pianą . W aromacie spalony karmel, skórka od chleba. W smaku lekko palone, ze słaba goryczka.
Lane. Mało intensywne, lekki pumpernikiel, trochę karmelu, słodkie. Bardzo wodniste, nawet jak na desitkę. Niby bez wad, ale mocno średnie.
Bottle, cask. Beer with dark brown colour, head is white-brown. Huge caramel aroma with coffee. Taste is full of caramel, nuts, but bitter. Excellent beer!

Aroma; dark malts, dark caramel, dark raisins, dark grass. Look; fawn head on dark brown body. Taste; dark malts, dark caramel, dark toffee, dark almond, dark raisin, dark sweet bread, dark leaves - sweet finish. Feel; normal body, soft co2. Overall; very good tmave (= dark). [30cl tap@Krakonoš Trutnóv, 747315]

Aroma brød, malt, mørke frukter. Utseende mørk brun med rødskjær og lys beige skum som forsvinner fort. Smak røsted malt, plomme, humle. Rund, balansert, medium fylde, fruktig, noe kort. Flaske fra DjOeye 50cl 3,9% BF160717

500ml bottle bought from djoeye. A crystal clear rosewood coloured body. Remaining beige head, fair lacing. Lightly roasted malty nose. Hints of nuts and toffee to the taste character followed by a slightly roasted, mid-sweet ending. Decent. (Tromsø 15.07.2017).
Malty, yeasty, light roasty aroma, dark brown, frothy, tan foam, light sweetness, lightly sour, tones of roasty malt, oily feel, walnut,bitter finish

Karmel, diacetyl, akcenty chmielowe, słodycz, a miejscami nawet czekolada (sic!). Byłoby bardzo fajnie gdyby nie intensywny aldehyd octowy objawiający się zielonym jabłkiem i farbą emulusyjną. Zniszczył całe piwo.

column2: Neuhaus an der Pegnitz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle @ Berlin/Bavaria Tasting, Odense. Pours clear yellow with a creamy white foam. Nose is grain and hay. Watery. Quite clean. Bland and thin . .

column1: De Clerck Bière Blanche de Péronne
column5: Aroma 5. Appearance 4. Taste 4. Palate 2. Overall 10. Lime aroma, a bit soda alike. Mainly lime taste, sugar, and a light body. A bit chemical aftertaste.

column1: De Clerck Bière Blanche de Péronne
column5: Bottle: Big lively but vast and thicker white colored head on top of a hazy yellow colored beer. Smell lots of lemon, lemon zest, lemon soda, light soapy and hint of wheat. At first it smelled like the 0% white beers, but then a more lemon nose came through. Still not inviting at all! Taste is still a bit lemon ish, but there is a more wheaty character in the taste. Thus: lemon, lemon soda, wheat, watery and thin, not bitter but lemon lime fruity, maybe a slight lemon sour ish touch, soapy, some slight hints of grass, spices and a bit dishwater ish... Aftertaste is again lot of lemon with some plastic citron/lemon squit and grainy wheat. Low carbo, soft mouthfeel but also spicy on the tongue, low to slightly medium bodied and a more watery than creamy texture. Unfortunately this beer is pretty bad! Drainpour!

column1: De Clerck Bière Blanche de Péronne
column5: Hmm! This hasn’t recieved much in the way of praise has it? However...I must disagree..this is super! Pale straw, typically hazy, and a great white head that lasts to the bottom of the glass. There is a sweetness noticable on the nose, but for me the dominating aroma is of orange peel (curacao,perhaps?) and a slight spiciness. Yes! it is light in body, but surely that is the whole point of white beers, they’re supposed to be refreshing, and this one does just that. Smooth, with a sharp acidity that slowly fades and is replaced with genlte spicy finish that lasts. £1.99, Booths Keswick.

column1: De Clerck Bière Blanche de Péronne
column5: Bottle. Fucked up compared to there other stuff. Smelt like lemonade. Some subtle coriander., but otherwise just tastes like lemonade, dissapointing.

column1: De Clerck Bière Blanche de Péronne
column5: I have a problem with De Clerck beers. They are often quite interesting, but not always for the right reasons. This is a modern Golden Summer Ale - a fashion that seems to have spread over to France. As usual there is wheat to soften and refresh, and a fragrant hop. But - as seems typical of De Clerck beers - the body is woefully thin. I mean - this is REALLY thin. The mild flavours are quite pleasant - a hint of watered down orange juice, and the slightest splash of melon, but they fail to lift the watery body. It pours nicely, with a light, frothy (but short lived) head. In fact that is the best this beer can offer - the moment of pouring. It is all downhill after that.
Had this at the First Union Center in Phila before a Wings lacrosse game. An average fest beer. Has a very faint hop taste.
Copper in color with a bit of a cloudy appearance, very little head, sour aftertaste, very little hop profile as well

Had this at the First Union Center in Phila. before a Wings lacrosse game. I got this as a sampler. Glad I did and didn't spend $5.50 for a pint of this stuff. As obxdude before me says this beer is horrible. It taste like strawberry cleaning soap. The only good thing was it did look like a wheat.

Absoutely horrible, the appearance was the best thing about this beer, it had a dark tint to the golden color with a bit of haziness & cloudiness, but you pretty much get that with any wheat beer so I guess that really doesn't count, the flavors were down-right rancid, tasted like edleberries gone bad, like the franenberries in that nasty Count Chocola cerial, had a velvty palate, not at all drinkable, very nasty & horrible

column1: Red Bell Philadelphia Original Light Lager
column5: On tapm at brewpub (Wachovia Center). Pours a clear golden color topped by a foamy white head. A light grainy malt aroma. Flavor is mostly grainy malt with a very light hop presence. The beer lacks any real character.

column1: Red Bell Philadelphia Original Light Lager
column5: Crystal clear yellow beer. Malty and crisp with maybe a bit of citrus in the finish. Not too bad, not too great.

column1: Red Bell Philadelphia Original Light Lager
column5: Had this at the First Union Center in Phila. before a Wings lacrosse game. A typical light beer. Nothing fancy here.

column1: Red Bell Philadelphia Original Light Lager
column5: A little more drinkable than the big three's light beers, light golden color, very fizzy head, no hoppy tones at all, not much by way of a malty profile either, just your basic light lager beer, but still a bit better than all the known light beers

Bottle via Lubiere. Dirty amber with a tan head. Caramel malt with a strong resin hop presence, mixed tropical citrus with some stronger orange and lemon rind notes. Moderate carbonation and body, bittersweet, slightly dry, citrus finish.
Hoppy, and overall not bad. Not quite as in-your-face as some strong IPAs, which is to its detriment.

Brown bottle, at and from Luc Bourbonnière (merci!), savoured on January 18 2015; nose: basement, malt, resinous hops; mouth: basement, malt, resinous hops, finale in malt with presence of hops, medium-full body, average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly sweet, slick texture; overall: correct FRANÇAIS Bouteille brune, 12 onces, de et chez Luc Bourbonnière (merci!), savourée le 18 janvier 2015; nez : cave, malt, houblon résineux; bouche : cave, malt, houblon résineux, finale en malt avec présence de houblon, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement amère, légèrement sucrée, texture coulante; en résumé : correct

A dark golden DIPA with a thin off white head. In aroma, nice fruity caramel malt with smooth floral hops, resinous and piney, light sweaty notes, citrus pulp, nice. In mouth, a nice lightly sweet caramel malt with light treacle, floral resinous hops, light oxidation character, pleasant.
Draft at Toronado. Nose is a caramel with some slight grassiness. Taste is slightly sweet. Ok but a bit too sweet for my taste. Would like for flavor/aroma hops.
On tap. Pours a cloudy yellow hold, no head. Nice pine and citrus nose. Pretty balanced hop attack, a bit sweet on the finish.

2nd May 2013 7.75% Cloudy amber - brown beer. Good pale cream coloured head. Palate is slightly soft and semi dry with fine carbonation. Soft caramel malt base. Big resinous hops. Bitterish pine and lesser skunk and grass. Mild hop sting. Balances well with the sweet malt. Semi dry finish. Pretty drinkable.
This is a very tasty IPA. Good hop flavor with a touch of sweetness which I really like

12oz bottle pours clear copper with a thin light tan head of foam. The modest aroma offers up sweetness and fruity notes like citrus hard candy and a dash of cherry candy. The aroma doesn’t deliver much hoppiness but the taste sure does. I get resiny bitter hops that start out pine sap like and then climb into grapefruit and orange peel. To midway it picks up off notes of sweet cherry esters as well as some biscuit malts. These last two notes pull the IIPA apart at the seams.

Bottle; poured a dark orange/caramel color with a big frothy, off white head. Aroma of caramel, alcohol, and fruit. Flavor also was fairly malty; some nice sweetness. Some earthy and fruity hops. The earthiness lingers a bit. Fairly hot for the abv. Palate had a nice finish to it. Really just ok for the style.
Light copper color. Medium body, grainy, bubbly, lightly hopped. Malts are lightly toasty and bready. This is the one to order for your macro drinking friends.
On tap @ the brewpub: Pours black with a tan head. Aroma, roasted notes, some coffee, milk chocolate. Flavor, roasted malts, sweet chocolaty notes, a dry roasty bitterness on the finish.
Had on tap at brew pub. Taste was roasted coffee and malts, with a bit of chocolate. This one was not bad.
On tap at the Oakroom in Athens, Ohio. Not much aroma. Black, with not much head. Very chocolaty flavor.

I do like stouts. I was very excited to see this was ready when I stopped by the brew pub this afternoon. when the beer was poured I was pretty dissappointed in thebrownish head, it was thin and dissappeared quickly. The body was a nice bold black. The aroma smelled a faintly like othe stouts I’d had in the past, nice and roasted malts. But the taste was very disappointing. The nose was bland, there was no real maltly flavor. There was a small begining of a bitter flavor....but is disapated before it should. If you stop by Willoughyby, try something else.

Black body with a deep tan head. Nice looking beer. Lots of chocolate and coffee in the nose, along with some sweet, fruity esters. This had a lot of the elements that I like in stouts: full, rich mouthcoating body, roasty flavors, assertively hopped...so why didn’t I really like this? I just didn’t think the flavors flowed together very well, plus there was just an underlying sweetness that I couldn’t shake.
Smelled slightly malty. Dark, dark head with a slight head. Tasted just like coffe, bad bad coffee. It was really undrinkable. Very watery.

I must say, I was impressed. Black, with a good sized brown head. Deep roasted, toasty smell. Bittery something in the taste- not exactly coffee, but not exactly caramels... interesting flavor, without a doubt. One of the few Willoughby offerings that didn't seem too thin in the mouth.
This was very creamy. Some sweetness, medium roasted malts and a short dry finish. Body was thin and unsubstantial.

"Solid offering from this NE Ohio Brewer. Fairly tame for an imperial, but damn approachable with a very nice roasted malt profile. Still, black body with a diminishing head and a few spots of lace. Prominent coffee and roasted malt nose with hints of molasses and chocolate. Flavor follows suit with additions of black licorice, chocolate and nuts. Medium to heavy bodied, creamy and soft with a wonderful finish and aftertaste. Multiple samples of this could easily be enjoyed during a session. "

On tap at brewpub Following on the heels of a solid wheat my hopes for Willoughby this evening had me optimistic about their imperial stout. It turned out to be well made with no major flaws and some fun characteristics that would have me coming back more often if it were not such a long drive. This is probably one of their better beers overall and I wish it were on tap more than once a season. Aroma / Appearance - The deep oily black body and thin beige head were the ideal picture of an imperial stout done right. Not too heavy and not thin it flowed smoothly around the glass. Roasted coffee, vanilla, chocolate, mocha, and anise mingled into a dense array of chewy scents. Flavor / Palate - Raspberries followed by rich baker’s chocolate, licorice sticks, espresso, and hints of vanilla filled the mouth. Chewy and thick this was not cloying but balanced nicely between the lines of too thin and over the top. The finish of raisins highlighted was an all around excellent stout that was perfect for a cold snowy winter evening.

Black as night, great lacing. Starts off with a medium thick sweeeeeetness, turning roasted towards the middle and finishing with a nice moderate bitterness. Could have gotten syrupy, but stayed on the thin side, like all of the brewer's other beers. Flavors lingered for quite awhile afterwards.

(gabf'03) The Hopzilla sports a palate destroying 100 IBU. Ok - it's not as destroying as a Ruination, but it has a lot of hops. Lemon citrus with some fennel. Obviously trying to go for the big hop taste but lacking in some qualities.
GABF 2003: Cloudy yellow with a creamy head. Spicy pine hops in the nose. Creamy mouthfeel, starts and ends very bitter. I kept going back to this beer during the festival.
classic NW hop aroma, golden orange, chewy piney and fruity hops, great body and intense long lasting bitter finish

(draught) Dull orange, very slim white head. Nose are hops, but also bit of paint varnish. taste yields hops, orangey; light-coloured malts are there but the emphasis is heavy on the hops, laced with rinds of orangezest. There is a suspicion of sugar underneath - as the juice is promessed under the orangepeel. Medium to full bodied, quite bit sticky - sugar keeps hinting even if it isn't tasted. I'm not really impressed. I expected a hopmonster OK, but this stickiness is not really wanted.
Tap @ the Bistro's Double IPA Festival. Dark golden brown with an off-white head. Dark vinous fruits with a smash of hops.
Cloudy copper color. Malty aroma. Slightly sweet. Very nice balance. Full body. More of a Barley Wine than a Double IPA. Nice beer.
Hazy amber ale. Again, light floral hops aroma. Rather harsh german hops. A bit too harsh mouthfeel, need malts. (June 2004).
Tap. A medium golden color with an off-white head. The malts are emphasized with a light hop finish.
Amber color. Nice head. Slightly sweet. Moderately hopped. Nice malt flavor, although there's a slight graininess in back that I don't like. Medium body.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Black in color. Lighter in body. Slight licorice taste with a nutty grain finish.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Really great beer. The oatmeal is obvious, blunt, and savory. The high alcohol content is welcome as well.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: From beerboxer’s growler. Pours dark brown with a modest beige head and a treacle aroma. There is a dark molasses and chocolate flavor with a dry finish.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Growler from Buffalo Bills shared by beerboxer. It’s a stout. Smooth dark malt. Drinks good.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draft. Blackish beer with a dark cream colored head. Cocoa and light PNW hop aroma. Cocoa and light coffee flavor with backing PNW hops. Medium bodied. Cocoa and light coffee lingers with light caramel and backing PNW hops.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Black with a fizzy white head. Chocolate bread aroma. Bright palate. Chocolate toasted grain and coffee taste.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Sample at the brewpub on 8/7/10. Clear dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Nose is sorta metallic, but still has notes of chocolate and roast. Creamy chocolate flavor with a nice roasty and somewhat sweet finish.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Nice, rich stout. It pours dark brown with ruby tinged edges. The aroma is roasted grains, coffee, and toffee. The flavor is the same. I really appreciate the mouthfeel on this one. Velvety smooth and rich without being overpowering. I agree that it’s a little too sweet, but overall, it’s an enjoyable beer.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown to black with a small off-white head. Aroma is mild roasted and dark breadish. Dark roasted malt flavoured, liqourice dark toffee malty flavoured. Light bitterness coming through. Dry and roasted finish.

column1: Buffalo Bills Johnny Midnite Oatmeal Stout
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Didn’t want this shit but that’s life. Black wIth a small tan head. Sweet roasty aroma with some caramel and bread. Sweet and roasty. A little too sweet. Full bodiwd and rich but too sweet. It is what it is. Alright but too sweet.

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: On Cask: Served in a brandy goblet- Black, very black, were talking thick, stark opaque, matte black of deeper then deep, holy sh*t thats black! Nice fluffy tan head just over a finger high that takes for ever and a day to settle and at first there is a small amount of slow bubbling current about an inch below the head that creates a weird lavalamp-like motion for a good amount of time then finely just goes black like the rest of its girth. Loved looking at this thing. I could get lost in its blanktivity for hours. Smell is potently alcoholic, very whisky-like with some brandy hints, takes a bit to get through and reach some sweet molasses, maple syrup, cherry, and chocolate. Taste is quite smooth with the alcohol touching every corner in warming qualities giving mild flavors in some dark roastyness, lightly sweet chocolate and deep sweet cherry that lends some heavyness, touching in molasses and coffee. Not all that bold or rich as most Imp. Stouts that I've had. The feel is why it suffers some in the taste cuz its fluffy and airy with a medium body and not so hefty or thick as most. A fine drinker, but the alcohol makes its presense felt to much in alot of its character where it needs to be hidden more and sneaky.

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: Cask at the RAF 2003: Large roasted coffee bean aroma, black with a nice tan head. . . Looks like an imperial stout. . Very dry on the palate, a good raosted flavour, slightly creamy. . . But I found no mouth feel or flavour qualities of an Imperial Stout. . . just a easy going stout here.

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: Thick? No. Creamy texture with nothing really speaking to me. Some hints of smokes and roasted. Not the biggest of imperial stouts, but not all of them can be.

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: They spoiled a great name for an Imperial Stout. It was so watery and thin... so boringly predictable that the name should taken away. This is no Imperial Stout. No complexity, No big mix of flavors. Thick as the oil slick???? Maybe the brewers never heard of Worldwide, Expedition, or Dark Lord!!!

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: cask (RAF): Peter the Great..wasnt great..not at all in fact..it was dark and it had a tan head, but i think thats as imperial as this beer is gonna get..the aroma was very roasty with coffee notes and hints of sweat..but IMO, imperial stouts should not have an overly roasty aroma..leave that for the low gravity crap..the flavor here had some chocolate but more dominant was its peanut skin astringency and its wierd-ass bitterness that completely took my mind from what might have been subtle notes of dark fruits, chocolate, and raisin..NExt.

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: RAF. This was a pretender, not a contender. Almost watery, "thick as the oil slick", my sweet cheeks! No distinguishable aroma. I'm sad that they call this an imperial stout. An odd aftertaste of alcohol...but not in a good way.

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: This was another thin and boring IS at the RAF. Light in color and mouthfeel. The flavor is strong, but only in the roasted characteristics. Where are all the vinuous notes in Expedition and Dark Lord? The flavor is good, but one dimensional.

column1: Great Waters Peter the Great Imperial Stout
column5: Sweet, dark chocolate aroma, with strong alcohol presence and hints of smoked oak. Very flavorful; the strong alcohol comes through in the finish. A strong Imperial Stout.

Keg @ Great Waters. Amber pour with a small head. Nose is brown sugar, nut, caramel. Toasted bread. Light berry jam and caramel sweetness. Light bitter finish. Soft and easy going. Boring, but fine for what it is.
Draft at the source. Clear amber color. Aroma of toasted caramel. Taste is bitter caramel, light body.

Cask at the brewpub. Pours a near clear deep earthy amber with an off white head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has notes of bread and grain with a bit of toffee underlying. Flavor has sweet grains and bread with a bit of earthiness backing.
On tap @ Great Waters. Red orange appearance with an off white head. Slightly hoppy but mostly a caramel malty nose. Pretty bland caramel malty flavor. Drinkable but boring.

Tap. Clear red/amber pour with a small but frothy white head. Aroma is slightly sweet with caramel. Thinner mouthfeel. Taste is a little watery and the hops poke through. Some bread and caramel on taste as well. Just okay.
Honey Brown with White Skin. Sweet Malt Aroma. Flavor Carries on Aroma. Average Red.
Dark orange color with a thin head. Dusty malt aroma with a slightly sweet finish. Taste is more of the same, with nothing really standing out. Pinch of a hops finish.

Named after the owner, O' byrn's Irish Red is a another amber done very well and is cask-conditioned. It reminded me a little of a English Bitter but milder. Color is a hazy light brown, very small head that retained in small bubbles throughout most of the glass as I was drinking it. Very faint and light on the nose, has a slight aroma of hop and citrusy lemon. Taste is crisp, clean, light, a little watery, no real initial taste up front, but the middle gets a nice little dry hop and finishes with a citrus note and slightly dry. Hint of cinnamon maybe, too. Feels very clean but is watery, could be bolder and more medium bodied. Leaves a light pale citrus feel on the tongue. This could be better, but is pretty good and favored it slightly over the other amber.
Still not a red to rave about. One day will come. Light red colored with some slight, slight hops. But mostly an average unnoticable beer. Nothing offensive, nothing compelling.

Very plain... all too common red ale. Almost tasteless except for some tiny malt flavor. Having it on cask probably saved it from being rated as swill because it was so smooth. This was one of those beers at the Real Ale Festival that were easily forgotten and easily poured into the "dump-tub".
Tap. Light but rich gold pour. White head. Fruit yeast nose. Taste is sticky fruit and banana. Good stuff.
When I lived in Duluth/Superior in 2008 and 2009, I would go the Fitger’s every Wednesday night and watch Charlie Parr perform, and drink some of this great beer. Everyone recommended I try this one.
Pours a hazy golden amber with thin white head. Aroma is very light, mostly caramel. Flavor is vanilla caramel with subtle citrus notes. Body is fairly light but still creamy with med. carbonation.

On draught during Winterfest 2009 in St Paul, MN. Pours a semi-hazy dark golden brew with an average off-white head that slowly dissipates to a white ring. Aroma of strong alcohol fumes with raisin, dark pitted fruits, a hint of banana and some pear. Taste is full bodied, with flavors of banana esters, some yeast, apricots, a hint of pear and some sharp spice. Finish is semi-sweet, a tad metallic from the high alcohol with a lingering banana and alcohol aftertaste. It’s strong!
Winterfest 2009. This is a success. Alcohol in the aroma and flavor, but not too much for the style. Dark, fermenting fruit, plums, raisins. Lots of sweet malt and sugar.

On-tap at the brewpub: A nice surprise to see this on the board out of how many times I’ve either missed it or just didn’t review due to being at a beerfest. Well worth the wait... Limpid light brownish orange color, quite hazy looking with a very thin capping of white foam mostly sitting at the edges. Small bits of lace graze the 10oz glass within which it was served. And at only $3.00 for the 10oz, was a pretty good price I thought. Light aroma of berries, pear, and Belgian candied sweetness. Quite fresh and fruity with a bit of caramel to its backing, but altogether a bit too light. Would’ve been great to have this be much more forward on the nose. However, taste wise this was quite the spectacle of yummyness. Nicely soft, clean, creamy berryness ensues with a oily ease of lightly sweet sugaryness of fruit juices and malt. Notes of pear, apple, candied orange, and raisin begin to develope but stays favorably well-balanced with a big malty soothing undercarriage of caramely goodness and straight forward malt tone of sweet fruits. I really enjoyed the taste of this one. Has great fruity flavors and an altogether big malt body giving it a soothing creamy, nearly silky ease in texture to go down. Soft fulfilling rich malty finish lets off a sliced smidgeon of heated spice too. Yum. Feel is pretty malty smooth. Just about medium with a lightness to it at frist but grows expedentially as it goes. Creamy, soothing, soft, subtle, and caring nature of carbonation and overall body. A relaxing comfortable brew to behold. Great flavor profile and malty richness thats well-balanced and not to over eager and boozy. Listed at 8%, this was a fucking gem compared to the Blue Label reserve dubbel. Had 2 of these without any problem. A very nice brew. Again, to bad that for the most part, Fitger’s flat out refuses to growler they’re bigger brews such as this. As I begged for one, and only left with a Starfire Pale instead.

This was pretty good, but didn’t really feel like much of a tripel. Brown amber body with a ring ofr head. banana and some other fruit yeast aroma. Bit of alcohol with some pepper, banana, and some thick sweet maltyness with hints of alcohol here and there.

GTMW 06. After trying the El Nino and Redbeard from Fitgers, I figured they couldn’t miss. Oops. Slight haze, muddy amber body with no head. The aroma is banana and apricots. The flavor is apricots, peach, banana and pepper, fairly sweet. Full, sticky body.

Orange-tinted hazy dark golden pour, with no head, except for a white rim. Estery fruit profile wafts, backed with sugary sweet malt notes. Oily orange flavors, backed with a strong ester and hexane profile. Alcohol is absorbed in the front end, making a beautiful, hardly noticable appearance. Carbonation is light. Back end of flavor profiule is extremely sweet, with a good kick of orange, apricot and fresh yeast. Hops are limited to distant notes. Palate is coating, with a sugary honey dry oak aftertaste.

Goldish color. Sweet aroma with a bit o’ spice. Tangy taste to be sure... A little sweet as well along with some malt. There is some maltiness that comes in at the end. The alcohol wasn’t particularly well hidden. Odd Tripel.

[On-tap at Fitger’s] Pours reddish-brown with a nice beige head. Faint aroma, sweet notes of caramel, grape and pear. Taste has restrained bitterness, big maltiness, caramel, fairly sweet, light raisin and other indistinguishable fruitiness. Well rounded, and nothing stands out. Medium mouthfeel, average length finish. Overall, a nice scotch ale that doesn’t amaze, but is solid nonetheless.
DL06: Poured a hazy golden dark amber color. Aroma of olives and malt. Sour flavor with more olive juice. I don’t know what was going on here.

Ruby fringed hazlenute pour, with a frothy cream of a head. Light caramel and banana aroma. Extremely sugary off the bat. Toffee and caramel dominate, backed by oats and earthy tones. Nutty all the way. Blend this with hints of warm bourbon and rum. Bright and sharp on the back end, with mellow cherry truffle. Well done, but a little hot from the alcohol. Lots of vanilla note s and some hints of cinnamon. Surprisingly this has some spicy and estery yeast notes, despite the presence of Fitger’s characteristic malt and yeast flavor running the gamut of the background. Starts off sweet, but melds into a balanced, savory supple example.
Dark Brown/Red with Sandy Head. Malt Aroma. Sweet Malt Tones with a Warming that Tingles Your Lips and Continues All the Way Down Your Throat. Some Bread Dough. Very Nice Winter Warmer.

Dark red color with a thin head. Very malty aroma. The taste is overwhelminly of sweet malt with a bit of caramel. Man, the alcohol is not hidden at all; very upfront and personal. Definitely a winter warmer variety.

On-tap at the brewpub: Chestnut brown with a slow crimson hint, slim cap of darkened ivory, some stringing lacing sticks. Aroma is clean and somewhat subdued of a molasses caramel maltyness and slight chocolate with a good load of spicy alcoholic heat. Flavors are well into the full-on malt load here, yummy darkened sweet molasses, caramel and fig hints with a soothing backing of hefty chocolate thats mild and taming; mixing well with the other malts. Nothing overwhelms, very balanced, clean, chewy, big on flavors right from the get go and keeps a giving with malty goodness. Both of a slightly sweetness and mild milk chocolateyness; barely a roast noticeable way underneath. Warm and coating to the belly. Smooth and thick malt feel, medium bodied, clean chewyness, sensational drinkability, coats, soothes and warms. A perfect winter warmer after a day of hiking in the cold.
Another beer from Winterfest in St. Paul 2/8/03. She gives some head...her taste is malt.
Very malty with high alcohol, but alcohol is relatively subdued. Not fabulous but good.

column1: Town Hall Jesters Reserve Imperial Porter
column5: Had on tap at the pub for the 6th anniversary, 10-18-03 Fully, chocolatey brown in color, with a firm, solid white head atop...aroma: plain at first, but further gleanings reveal a thick, oily, syrupy character...deep and viscous...motor oil, even, I might say... Once in the mouth, big-time, fat chocolate flavor, that continually recurrs throughout the drink...teases the lips and tongue...full-bodied, thick and chewy, substantial texture! The kind of mouthfeel that is fully in control and drives your senses, no back-seat driver, it is in command! Nicely roasted, with a long, resilient finish, and significant alcoholic content that appears medicinal-tasting toward the end. Thick, bold, spicy flavor...I've loved many porters before, but few have delivered the goods like this maniac! Wow...wow...and, one more time, Woa-a-A-OWW!!!

column1: Town Hall Jesters Reserve Imperial Porter
column5: GABF '03, black with a small tan head. Aroma of dark fruit,chocolate and roasted malt.Flavor is bitter/sweet with a mild whiskey charcater and oak essence.

column1: Town Hall Jesters Reserve Imperial Porter
column5: Got a growler of this at the release party back in September, I think it was and sealed the neck with wax and cellared for a couple months. It held up amazingly well. Beautiful fruity, sweet and alcohol nose. Color is very dark, but not opaque. Carbonation was very light and little head formed, but that is how it was when first released as well. Taste was magnificent. Strong, plummy, fruity, slightly smokey. Apparent, but not overpowering notes from the barrel aging. Chocolate notes and alcohol, but neither of these or overpowering either. A beautifully complex beer that held up very well after several weeks in a growler!

column1: Town Hall Jesters Reserve Imperial Porter
column5: Produced specially for the 2003 Anniversary - Color is a solid inky old, faded black with a nice tan head of thick froth about 1/4 inch high, fades some to a thick skim on top and clumpy thick lace impressively sticking. Smell has lots of deep dark espresso chocolate with some very dark cherry hints, black sweet malts and cognac/brandish-like alcohol sweetness and warmth in the midst of the chocolate cloud. Taste is super smooth and chocolatey! Late hints of alcohol. The chocolate tone is nice and deeply sweet with some coffeeish notes in a late lingering finish. Very nice! The chocolate is quite complex in its its thickness and layering, much like a fudge and/or brownie mix. Feel is airy and fluffy full of creamyness with a late velvety textured palette with a supurb chocolate/cocoa/coffeeish drying. Oh this is quite heavenly, what a lovely Imperial Stout. I could drink this all the time, any time! Smooth and creamy, chocolatey and sweet, awesome and yummy!

column1: Town Hall Jesters Reserve Imperial Porter
column5: Wawood! stop brown nosing Town Hall in hopes of free beer. It aint happening! This for me was another taste I experienced in St Paul at Winterfest. She's all chocolate...like Halloween..very taboo..she gives decent head and is also very smelly.

column1: Town Hall Jesters Reserve Imperial Porter
column5: 5/8/05 Re-rate: Ar 9; Ap 4; Fl 8; Pal 5; Ov 18. A partial keg of this stuff had been sitting in Town Hall’s basement for 2 years and they brought it up for the "I Love Beer" pub crawl. Might actually have been the same keg from which I had my previous sample. Many similarities to the Czar Jack. I have no question that if Town Hall brewed this more often and gave more folks a chance to rate this that it would be in the Ratebeer top 100 as well. Bourbon barrell aroma. Not much head. Smells and tastes like Czar Jack but perhaps not quite as good. 2/9/03: Before I realized that this beer was aged in a whiskey barrel, I was unsure of the distinct hard alcohol aroma. However, with that knowledge, the aroma lends a unique quality to an excellent big beer. Kudos again to the brewers at Minneapolis Town Hall.

column1: Town Hall White Winter Belgian Ale
column5: Yeast!!! Yeast!! she's got a yeast infection..which I like but she scared me. I victomized her on 2/8/03 at the St. Paul Winterfest.

column1: Town Hall White Winter Belgian Ale
column5: Yeasty, citrus aroma with typical Belgian wheat hints. Appearance is that of white grape juice. Sweet for a Belgian wit and very good!
Bourbon aroma with chocolate notes. Both come through in the mouthfeel. Despite how good that sounds, this brew is nothing spectacular. Good, not great.

On tap at the brewery. Deep, opaque and black with a thick tan wrung for the head. Aroma mimics the standard brewpub formula for dry stouts, with chocolate annotations trying to cover up something that’s suspiciously similar to dog poop. Flavor’s saying "if you’ve had one, you’ve had them all." Straight forward semi-sweet chocolate, thinning, and turning astringent. Prickly carbonation. Pass.

On draft at the brewery, this brew poured a large sized head of brown colored frothy fine to medium sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind an opaque dark red brown colored body with no visible carbonation and an excellent sheet lacing. Beautiful looking brew. The aroma was malty and hoppy with dark brown malty notes that were roasted and nutty. The mouth feel was smooth and flat initially with a mild tingly in the finish like it was on nitro but we verified it was on CO2. The flavor was flat and hoppy with a mild malt note.

On tap at Kraftbrau. Large tan head that mostly diminished, excellent lacing, fine-very large sized bubbles, uncarbonated, opaque, and a reddish brown hue. Malty and hoppy aroma. Malty and mildly hoppy flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium body.

Draught at Kraftbrau Sept 27th 2003. Cask conditioned. Very dark amber. Okay dark brown head head. Slight meatiness to it. Burnt smoky robust flavours. Very good. Compairs to the Gahan House Sydney Street Stout from Prince Edward Island I had recently. Cheers to Vale for being a great hostess that night, made my trip to Kalamazoo quite enjoyable.

On tap: Pours with the darkest brown head I've ever seen. Aroma of scotch and soy sauce. The body is smoky and bitter with a meaty flavor, something I've never noticed in a beer. Tastes like it was fermented with a bratwurst. Very unique and robust with earthy mouthfeel. I was somewhat confused with this one, but overall enjoyed it quite a bit.

Unfiltered draft sampler at Kraftbrau. My first trip here has me finally tearing myself away from Bell’s across the street. This is light and yellow, just a little bit hazy. Sips very nice and cleanly. The hop character is actually fruity at the start, then settles down into a good German style. Very well done.

A hazy light amber hue with the standard fizzy and fading Kraftbrau head, some lace. The aroam hints of buttery biscuit malts, aromatic and floral hops, lemongrass and soem dusty yeast esters. The taste is lemony, bitter, and display a good malty backbone midway through the drink. Some yeast on the finish which has a noble bitter quality. The mouthfeel is fizzy and crisp. This is a good version of a helles, refreshing and nicely quaffable. A nice surprise indeed!

A tale of two Kraftbrau pilseners began with their Down Home Brew. It poured a cloudy yellow-orange, with a thin white ring of foam clinging to the glass. Very earthy, spicy, aromatic hops notes. The flavor was outstanding: strong biscuit and toast flavors, and dominated by earthy, spicy, grassy hops. A touch of lemon in the aftertaste. Strong carbonation enhanced lively mouthfeel. A very well-crafted pilsener. This was the better tale of two...
A biting Pilsner. This beer is malty and bitter. Taste is slightly sweet. A good Pilsner.

There is of course the eccentric house character. THis one has loads of lemon with great pale malt flavor. A heck of a lot like the Helles, and a bit more bitter--as it should be. Thanks a lot PsychProf. This is my kind of beer.
A very good, very snappy Saazy lager with a good, not too oily body. Meant for serious session work, this one warms without excessive sweetness. Good, good, good.
Light golden appearance. Malty aroma with a nice fresh Saaz aroma. Bitterness on finish of palate. THis is as close to homebrew as you'll get.
Pours a lifeless golden with a pleasant noble hop aroma. Light sweetness in the body finishes with a medium bitterness. Not my favorite style, but overall, smooth, and a pretty decent pilsener

Solid commercial pils. Clear golden body with a tall, persistent white head. Grassy aroma, hints of hay and honey. Taste is grassy, mild malty. Medium grassy finish. Low body, lively carbonation, soft texture.

75 cl ceramic bottle from Quelle, Mühlhausen. Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, light grainy, light fruity and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 110717
Bottle. Clear golden, medium white frothy head. Spicy hops on nose. Clean malts besides. Light body. Herbal hops and minor malts on nose. Medium bitterness. Decent -- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Flasche. Gold-gelb, klar, grossporiger Schaum. Aroma: Hopfen, Malz, säuerlich. Geschmack: Getreide, würzig, moderat bitter.

the aroma is malty and herbal with shades of buckwheat, flowers, grain and hay... the taste is clear and refreshening, malty with notes of grain, flowers, buckwheat and grasses... bitter and dry aftertaste...
Decent pilsner. Classic appearance. Aroma of grass and grain . Pleasant , well distinguished, hoppy bitterness in malty taste . Nothing extraordinary, but very solid.
Heldere gouden kleur met een goede kraag. Ruikt fruitig, hop, citrus. Smaakt fruitig, citrus, houtig. Goede bittere afdronk. Goede pilsner.

Bottle Aroma-grass, bread Appearance-golden, clear, white foam, Taste-light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, Palate-light body, thin feel, average carbonation, abrupt finish Overall-very refreshing

When poured into the glas it prodcues a dense rocky white long lasting head. The colour of the beer is clear golden. Lots of carbonation. Nice floral, herbal hops with a honeylike sweetness. The flavour is full of hops with malt and bread. Nice balanced hopy finish. Bitter-sweet aftertaste. Light to medium body with average carbonation. Overall very trinkable.
Посредственный пилзнер, с легкой горчинкой, впрочем, довольно освежающий. Но какого-то яркого вкуса я не почувствовал.
Grainy lighter coloured lager. the standard bitter bite from these seasonal beers that I don’t like so much. D&S Dresden

Eher mäßige Schaumentwicklung mit recht grobkörniger Konsistenz. Farblich stark goldgelb bis bernstein und klar. Riecht feinwürzig, leicht süßlich, frisch. Geschmacklich vollmundig, leicht würzig, malzig-nussig, im Abgang mit bitter-pfeffriger Note, die den ansonsten guten Eindruck schmälert.
Aus der Flasche getrunken (Getränkenarkt Dessau)- als Festbier ohne Jubiläum! Dunkles Amber mit schönem Schaum im Glas. Schön kräftig eingebraut ohne Highlights allerdings.
Aromat kiepski, s?odowy, niezbyt przyjemny. W smaku s?ód i chmiel, z wyra?n? nut? ?elazist?.
Solides festbier mit nussigen Röstaromen, hohe Restsüße und etwas Würzigkeit. Zeiteweise etwas dünn aber trotzdem nicht schlecht.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grass, straw, malt and hops.
50cl bottle. Pours clear dark golden with a medium good lasting white head. Aroma of tosted malt, barley. Taste is malty, grainy, some dry fruits, some caramel.
*Old rating, best before 15.05.05. Würzig-malziges Bier. Nicht zu tief, leicht süßlich, leicht herb, nett.
0,5l Flasche. Gelbes Bier mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Riecht leicht malzig; schmeckt auch so.
Bottle. Clear amber-golden. Small white head. Aroma is caramel with a bit grass, flowers. Taste is sweetish, medium bitter. Aftertaste sweet, bitter, caramel. Flat carbonation, medium Texturen.
A yellow beer with a small white head. The aroma is sweet malty - and so is the flavor, I find it somewhat boring.

This beer has a yellow body - hue apperance and a coarse white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the a bottle and it had a lot of carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is bitter with a mouty afther tast.
Bottle, 4.8%. Clear yellow colour, small white head. Fresh hop flavour. Also bready, but OK.
(Bottle 50 cl) Clear, pilsener golden with a white head. Clean, malty aroma. Medium-bodied, quite malty with a touch of cardboard and a dry, hoppy finish. 220906

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a fast-disappearing white head. Sourish aroma with notes of yeast – bordering vinegar. Don’t know if it’s bad or if it’s supposed to be this way. Notes of cereals. Flavour is – again – sourish with notes of yeast. Otherwise pretty standard lager-like. Finish feels ‘fresh’, although a bit thin, and is mildly bitter with grassy, cereal and metallic notes. 28-09-06.
Bottled. Pours light golden in colour with a small head. Malty and sweet. Notes of cardboard and hops. Thin and boring.
water and slight hints of what a good beer tastes like is what i taste in this beer, just hints and no real carracter.

Bottle - slightly sweet malty aroma. Sweet grainy flavor with only a hint of hops - fairly high carbonation. Very mild and bland for a landbier. Okay but like this type of beer to have more character.
Bottled. Golden. Lively and fruty pils with a herbal(is it fennel?) and a nice bitter ending.
pale and looks filtered. dry, vinous aroma and strange stewed apple in the aftertaste. nothing wrong with rough edges though

This was an orangey amber coloured, hazy beer with delicate, yellowish white, dense head and a pleasant aroma of walnuts, caramel, apple, melon, mandarin, honey, pepper and dried leaves; tasted very fruity, applish and somewhat citrussy, smooth and light on the tongue but nevertheless full, gracious, with a chalky and flowery, lightly hoppy finish. Very elegant and refined, almost ’feminine’ session beer. I still regret the demise of this brewery.

Bottle 33cl. Clear medium amber orange color with a small to average, frothy, good - fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, toffee. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081105]

Courtesy of Fonefan. It’s orange-golden with an OK head. The aroma has notes of oranges and malt. The flavour has sweetness and it’s quite perfumed with notes of malt, light raisin and other dark fruit, candy sugar and caramel. I think this would be a bit too much, if I were to drink the entire bottle.
Bottle, 7.2%. Spicy, yeasty, farty and fruity. Cloudy toffee colour. Rough hoppiness to begin with, turns quite yeasty, baking yeast. The flavour is also quite sweet. Unbalanced.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with a lacing white head. Slight spiced and earthy aroma. Light orange fruity and alcohol presence, a bit flat and oldish. Spiced and malty flavour - again seems a bit "tired". Unrefined malty flavour with mild yeasty phenols - a bit of fruityness. A bit dull malty finish.
33cl, recently out of business, exclusive brewery, last tasted one year ago from the brewery, complex, hazy, nearly no head, nice brew
Bottle: Poured a copper yellow color with a thin white head. Aroma is fruit with malts. The taste is a bitter citrus fruit with some honey and metal hops.

Bottle, at Spinnekopke March 2006.Hazy amber, thin white head and moderate condition. Pleasantly soft and fruity maltiness in the nose, nicely balanced fruity sweetness and spicy corriander in the mouth and much the same in the finish but slightly more muted.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Like the label says Yellow coloured and must cloudy also, somewhat sweet and a kind of spicy.
Bottled. Bright amber colour, airy head. Sweet and sugary with some herbal notes. Medium bodied with soft mouthfeel. Flowery with spun sugar. Quite interesting, but too sweet.
Teignworthy Reel Ale 4.0%. Bronze, floral, honey aroma, medium bodied, light caramel malt, hint of honey, nutty finish. Pleasant ale from Devon 3.5/5

Bottle from the Shops at Dartington. Appearance - golden amber with a big fluffy head. Nose - light metallic, lemon and bready. Taste - light caramel, brown bread. Still a metallic/citrus note. Palate - light to medium bodied. Dry, roasty middle and finish. Overall - decent.
cask oro carico naso piuttosto burro buon amaro finale bilanciata discreto amaro
Fra cask på Teign Cellars, Newton Abbot 27 Sep 16. Kopperfarget. Lett farget filmskum. Ok filigranser. Bra aprikosaroma. Smaken vassen. Spor av tørket frukt.

Cask, half pint at Teign Cellars. Dotted spots on the glass. Spotty lacing. Bright amber in body colour. Aroma of dried fruits and leafy hope. Taste of earthy malts, leafy hops and caramel. Rounded endnotes with a distant bitter touch. Satisfying (Newton Abbot 27.09.2016).
Cask ; Devon ; UK ; Caramel,fruit and floral aroma ; Orange color with smaller head ; Sweeter taste ; Lighter long bitter finish ; Good beer.

A typical South Western beer, not unlike St. Austell Trelawney i.e. a bitter flavour but really very little else. Drank it in several excellent pubs so gave it a good chance but to my mind just not up to the mark. Don’t like to criticize small producers but afraid I give this one a ’miss’.
Has a healthy looking golden brown appearance, but very little taste to it.
cask at gbbf 2011 .. amber ... soft musty toffee nose ... sofr fruits ... little woody malts .. osft toffee ... blah

Cask @ GBBF 2011. Pours a slightly hazy amber orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with weak hoppy hints. Fruity malty caramel flavor with bitter hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Aroma has malty nose with berry note. Pours chestnut body thin tan lace. Taste is medium sweet to bitter. Palate is medium bodied oily texture average carbonation and a bitter finish. A reasonable ESB but not a special one

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A deep ruby brown colour with a medium off white head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, slight toffee, fruits and subtle spicy hops. Taste of nuts, some fruits, subtle toffee and slight spicy hops. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. A dry, malt and spicy fruit bitterness in the finish. A rich, malty bitter with fruits and spice. Good stuff.
Cask at Tring brewery, Tring, Herts. An amber coloured pour with a small off white head on top. Malty, fruity, nutty, caramel aroma and taste. Quite drinkable and fresh as a daisy.
Dark amber/ruby with a tight creamy head. Aroma sweet, dried fruit.Taste is marked by sweetness throughout, but this is very drinkable.

28/9/2018. Cask at the St Albans Beer & Cider Festival 2018. Pours dark amber/brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, malt, chocolate, nut and toffee. Quite heavy sweetness, moderate roasted bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Very drinkable.
Cask at PoW, Farnborough. Malty ar9ma. Dark ruby brown. Think bubbly off-white head. Sweet and malty. Medium slightly sticky. Medium bodied. Slick. Long finish. OK and fruit. More of a ESA?

On cask at The Joseph Bramah (JDW), Barnsley. Pours dark ruby with a beige head. Aroma: dark malts, some roast, dried fruits, dark chocolate. Taste: light sweet, dark fruits, caramel, nutty, hint of spices. Medium body, moderate carb, light sweet, dry & bitter finish

Cask pint at The Archibald Simpson, Aberdeen. Dark ruby colour, nearly black. Off-white to beige creamy head, nice lacing. Aroma of ripe dark fruits and blackcurrant leaves. Smooth mouthfeel. The flavour is fruity with hints of blackcurrants, mild roasty notes with hints of chocolate. Excellent beer, a strong dark mild in my book.
Cask pint at the Edward Rayne, Raynes Park. Pours ruby with a beige head. Aroma of malt with toffee. Sweet taste and finish. Plenty of body.
Cask @ The Briar Rose (JDW), Birmingham. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits, malt, nuts and hops. Smooth sweet finish.

Bottle from the Food Shop in Dartington. Appearance - deep brown to black. Slightly off white head. Nose - chocolate, nougat and sweet cereal notes. Taste - more chocolate, sticky toffee and hazelnuts. Palate - medium plus bodied. Creamy and rich in texture. Balanced, elegant finish. Overall - a lovely mild, that perhaps could also claim to be a stout.

(cask) clear deep amber-ruby colour with a frothy beige head. aroma of hazelnut husks and gentle butterscotch, with some notes of green apple, caramelized malts and sweatsocks. flavour is mostly pumpernickel and douchi, with lots of toasted grain, some vanilla icing and a light toasted-bitter doughy finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.

500ml bulkybuddel bb06/2017, ta BeardedAvenger. Mild Martha paired with mampf-minded Marieke. - "Bottle conditioned" seems to be a much more fickle creature in mild UK ales than in sturdy Belgians...this one seems to have turned intransit: where i suspect were lush, cushiony dark malts and prune-jammed dark bread, now the leavened brown bread in decomposition back on its way to sourdough and autumn foliage: reminded me a lot of Struise Rosse in fizzy disembodied mouthfeel and autumnal tartness. - Keeping this neutral rating, as it is within BB date, as a placeholder until another domestic sample or the cask version comes my way...

Flaske 500ml på Tuckers Maltings, Newton Abbot 27 Sep 16. Delt med Rune. Ultramørk amber. Høyt tett lett farget skum med litt filigranser. Lett karamellaroma. Myk munnfølelse. Smaken litt karamell & røstet malt. Balansert. Bra men litt tynn.

500ml bottle shared with Finn at Tuckers Maltings Visitor Centre. Deep dark brown with a ruby glow. Fawn coloured head that laced well. Very nice in the glass. Malt-accented aroma, mid-sweet. Taste of chocolate malts, dark dough, and spiced dark fruits. Rather sweet malty ending. Medium bodied. Pleasant (Newton Abbot 27.09.2016).

15th December 2015 Bottleshare at Chez Smith. Thanks to Dan. Clear deep red - amber beer, good yellow - cream head. Palate is light, semi dry and has decent fine carbonation. Fluffy dark malts, pretty mild but tangy. Mild dark chocolate. Little estery sweetness. Airy semi dry finish. Tangy linger. Just another mild.

Bottle shared at Leighton’s, 5.3%, BB Feb 2017, from the Teignworthy online shop. Dark brown, big foamy tan head, dotted lacing. Aroma is a bit astringent with varnish, ash, polish, chocolate and apple. Body is medium, tingly carbonation, a bit foamy. Taste is chocolate, varnish, toffee, breathy malt, a bit thin and watery. I’m not sure about this one.

Bottle shared at Leightons place, 14/12/15. Thanks to Daniel for this one. Reddy copper coloured pour with a lively light tan head. Aroma is brown bread, nutty, , mineral, malt ??, raisin, hint of smoke. Flavour is composed of tangy raisin bread, brown malts, maltose, little brown sugar, mineral, Rye bread, Good mild.

Bottle split at the Bespin cloud network, thanks to Danny, 15/12/15. Rich chestnut brown with a well appointed beige covering that retains well. Nose is caramel, light varnish, dark fruits, dates. Taste comprises light toffee, tarte fruit rinds, biscuit, light spice. Medium bodied, spritzy carbonation, semi drying close. Ok mild no great though.

Bottle thanks to Dirty Danny. It pours clear deep / dark brown with a massive dirty beige head. The nose is earthy, toasty, leather, light spice, plain chocolate, dried fruits and twig. The taste is bitter, earthy, toasty, dried fruits, mild tang, leather and spice with a dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. A bit of a tang going on, but overall pretty decent.
Cask Handpump at the Great Western Hotel, Exeter 08/03/2003 Clear golden colour with some sweetness. Slightly malty dry finish.
Cloudy, even when careful this beer lacks sparkle in mouthfeel and quality. Soapy hops are complemented by a poor malt body. A good cause (some proceeds go to charity) but a poor beer.
9th July 2008. BBE date of April 2007! More like a porter to me. Slightly toasty and a little sour. Zero carbonation but drinkable.
Cask at GBBF08. Almost black colour. The flavours starts OK roasted, turns fruity. Seems to have a little hopbite, even though there is not much hop flavour

Cask at GBBF 08. Black with dark brown edges and a thin beige head. Looked in good nick. Choc and a bit tarry. Bit powdery in mouth. Pretty tasty, some dry malt, hey, a good, English stout. Good, tasty. Easy drinking.

Cask@GBBF2008. Deep ambery brown colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malts and some mild sweet notes. Flavour is roasted malts, dark fruits, caramel and smoked wood. Dry palate and rather sweet end.
Dark red brown with tiny beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, coffee and caramel notes. Flavor likewise with a sweet end.

A Mes rate: 50cl bottle at Laneys. Black red colour with a ring of bubbles. Malty and wheaty aroma with some fishy notes. Mellow stouty flavour that has nothing really to get excited about. Some nice coffee notes though. Very thin in the palate for a stout. Bit of a let down.
Organic beer, it gives the impression of being very nasty, which most of times is, but this was good, not so watery, and nice taste, black colour with some golden features, I like this good beer.
Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Kensington Olympia 06/08/2003 Dark coloured smooth on the palate and fruity. Slightly dry smoked finish.
[Cask conditioned] This is a very mild stout. Slightly roasty, but unfortunately rather thin.
This stout has a light, sweet aroma. Dark purple in colour this has typical coffee notes with good roasted flavours. But, it is the chalk-dry finish that lifts this beer.

Looks OK - has some head retention. Big acetaldehyde aroma with diacetyl and toffee behind it. Tastes watery but if anything it’s like sparkling apple juice with some toffee and rusty bitterness. Boring. Never seen it in a can as in the photo here either.

Gets marks for being better than the Bitter and the Draught and gets another mark for being better than Geelong Premium. Otherwise it's not that special. If I'm driving or taking it easy I'd have a Boags Premium Light anyday.
Smells amost skunked despite brown bottle. Watery & tasteless, duh it's a light. A waste of water.
’96 Bottle, thanks Seth. Clear golden pour with a white head. Mild sour aromas. Mildly sour stone fruit and big malty notes. Oak and vanilla undercurrents. Good body and mouthfeel.

Bottle ’96 - Pours golden yellow. Aroma is wine, white grapes, and slight malty. Light, refreshing with wheaty / malty taste with some a grape. Very good, would really enjoy this on a summer day by myself.

Pour from bottle at Zwanze Day 2014. 2011 Vintage. Pour is hazy orange with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Funky, earthy, somewhat grassy, some stone fruits, biscuit, and urine in the aroma. Taste is deep and earthy peach skin, some salt, light lemons, urine, some cheese and wax with a lighty sour finish. Medium body with soft carbonation. Has definitely lost a little but still get a lot of stone fruit and highly drinkable.
2011 bottle. BBT3 tasting. Poured a hazy golden color with an off white head. Woody, grapes, lemons/citrus, earthy, and some funkiness.

2011. Funky, barnyard yeast with strong notes of cheese and citrus in the nose. Taste open up funky, quickly turning sour as if blended with a 3F geuze. Grapes, spice, and further yeast complexity round it out. I'm fortunate enough to have tried this a few times, and it earns best-of-style accolades from me each time. Need more! copied from thomas, couldnt have said it better LOL

2011. Funky, barnyard yeast with strong notes of cheese and citrus in the nose. Taste open up funky, quickly turning sour as if blended with a 3F geuze. Grapes, spice, and further yeast complexity round it out. I'm fortunate enough to have tried this a few times, and it earns best-of-style accolades from me each time. Need more!

In short: A part-rustic and part-Sour blond ale with plenty of white grapes. Good original creation. How: Bottle 750ml, 2011 vintage, so probably around 1 year of age. Bottle from yopdoog, thanks a lot Trevor. The look: Cloudy dark blond body topped by a small white head. In long: Nose has plenty of fresh white grapes with a rustic yeast character bringing a dusty attic sensation. Taste is also loaded with fresh white grapes, crackery neutral malts, little salty notes, rustic yeast character. Medium tartness, mild-medium sourness, medium acidity. Overall very fruity (the grapes cannot be misted), rustic and with a semi-sour character that surely comes from the barrel aging. Starts very juicy fruity and ends very dry and with acidity and sourness. This beer is as much a Fruit Beer as it is a Saison as it is a Sour/Wild Ale. Quite nice. That’s a rare beer I’ve been wanting to try for a long time, I knew it would come my way eventually because I believe in Destiny, when Destiny says "if you touch me again I’ll get you thrown out of the club" I keep my hands off her.

Bottle 750ml. [ Courtesy of henrikb ]. ABV: 6.8%. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, bread - cookie, toasted - caramel, fruity - grape, light to moderate yeasty, grape - fruity. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light light acidic with a long duration, grape, fruity, tart grape, sour ? tart fruit notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20121103]

Opened this bottle for Todd’s 30th birthday. Been trying to find this beer forever, so happy to finally try it. Pouts a golden orange in color with a half finger worth of tight white head. It’s hazy in clarity. Nose is juicy white grape, mineral, and some stone fruit. It’s alluring, but doesn’t overwhelm your senses. Flavor follows the nose with more juicy white grape and mineral in the forefront. There is some very gentle band aid in the middle, and finishes with some saisons earthiness, more white grape, and lactic sourness. Mouthfeel is light, carbonation is moderate and slightly prickly, moderate acidity, and a long finish. This bottle lived up to the hype, it is near a perfect American wild. I will be actively pursuing another bottle immediately.

Golden pour with a small white head that quickly fizzles away. Sweet white grape meets tangy lactic acid in the aroma. As it warms, light spice notes emerge with subtle fruit and some earth. Flavor is sweet and juicy white grape interwoven seemlessly with a nice earthy saison. There is just enough tartness to keep the grape from overpowering. Medium to light body with good carbonation. I love the addition of sweet white grape to American sours and saisons. This was an amazing beer.

From old tasting notes. The cheapest beer I ever drank. Cost about $4.75 for a case of 16 ounce returnable bottles. Poured a clear pale gold color. Small bubbly white head. Malty sour crab apple aroma. Tangy light malt flavor is quite lacking. No hops to speak of. A cheap beer that promises nothing and delivers just that.
Bottle. Pours golden, slight head with a tiny bit of lacing. Aroma is copper, mild herbs, grainy sugars. Flavor is a touch sweet with herbal hop notes. A pretty good american lager.

From a 16 oz returnable long neck bottle, how cool is that in america? Of course its pale yellow and it has the typical cheap lager aroma, but in a good way. Taste is not bad, some hints of hay and the like. Decent carbonation. Refreshing lager with not many ill effects. Nice rather friendly finish without any bitterness per se but there is a slight hint of industrialness in there.
Goes down well on a hot summer day. That’s all I can say about it....Oh, yeah, it comes in 16oz. returnable bottles, which are perfect for homebrewing.

As many have said this is a good beer for the price, unfortunately I did not purchase this beer, it was given to me from a buddy. The beer is like Bud without the beechwood aging. Slightly sweet, a little skunky, not much to it overall. "Pocono mountain water makes the difference" This beer has drastically changed my opinion on the water up there.

Best beer for the price. Light golden color and minimal head. Not much of an aroma, but also no bad aroma. Easy to drink and no bad aftertaste. This is truly a rating on price. I was very surprised when this $12 case of 16oz beers turned out to be even drinkable. I actually enjoyed them, and will definitely buy this again in the future. As an added bonus, you even get $1.50 back when you return the empty bottles. Purchased in West View, PA 15229 at "Northern Beer Traders".
best beer for the money ..... period....Original beer taste! love this stuff!... Allentown PA

I remember drinking this stuff years ago when I visited my friend in college in Albany. We bought Gibbons and some Red, White & Blue. As I recall, RWB was pretty bad, I’ll have to check and see if it is still around. The Gibbons wasn’t all that bad. As I recall it was a typical low-end lager, golden color, with the obligatory malt and corn cereal flavor. I see from some of the other reviews that it is back in the Wilkes-Barre area. I’ll see about picking some up on my next trip to PA and recall those old days.

Gibbons Famous Lager is one of my father’s favorite brews. It’s been brewed for years but only available in the Scranton/Wilkes-Barre area for about the past fifteen years and only in sixteen ounce returnables. My Dad hasn’t drank Gibbons since the mid-80’s when my older brother brought a case (of cans) back from the Poconos. On my trip to Cooperstown, NY for Ommegang’s July 2005 fest I stopped in Schiff’s Beverage Center, Dickson City, PA and bought a case of Gibbons for $14.57 (including deposit) for my Dad. I was number one son the day I dropped the case off for my Dad. Gibbons itself is a coal cracker classic, corny aroma, yellow colored with some barnacle bubbles clinging to the side of the glass. Flavor is corny, creamy malt bubble gum macro beer. A great value for the price, and one of my eighty-seven year old Dad’s lifetime favorite beers. .
Another new arrival at Epps in Limerick, PA. Some redeeming qualities in this. The Lion brewery is not bad, and this one is fairly priced. I’ll probably lawnmower this one next spring.

Sparkling clear, honey- colored beer. Medium-sized, frothy/rocky white head. Excellent lacing. The aroma is of buttered popcorn. Lightly floral. Nice and malty. The flavor is malty and caramel-laden up front, but more than balanced out on the backside with a wonderfully bitter hop addition. Not sweet in the slightest. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Medium-length, bitter, crisp, clean finish. Very, very drinkable beer.

Tap. Pours clear hazel, large creamy beige head, dissipates slowly, nice lacing. Aroma is tobacco, roasted malt, nutty, coffee grounds, hints of smoke. Flavor is medium sweet, light bitter, slight hint of acidity, hints of smoke, tobacco and cocoa. Medium body. This is complex and udervalued by craft beer dorks.
4 oz pour on draft at District ChopHouse. Clear dark amber with beige head. Aromas of cocoa, caramel, toffee. Tastes of cocoa, malt, caramel, toffee. Medium body with a dry finish. Tasty brown ale.
On tap at the brewpub. Amber body with somewhat weak head. Average for style, with a medium body and crisp carbonation.
Smell is grainy , sweet, chocolatty almost. Taste is sweet, with a bitter back . Malty, dark malts . Some cacao .
Fairly drinkable. Light but and roast aromas. Pours brown with good head and lacing. Tap at brewpub.
Not a bad brown. Sweet caramel, some chocolate, and some biscuit to round it out. A little watery.
Draft at the Chophouse. Poured a dark brown color with a very wispy tan head. Aroma was nutty, light sweet malt notes. Flavor was light sweet malts, with some light nutty notes. Toasted.

On tap 5 oz. sample at the District Chophouse & Brewer in downtown Washington, DC. Nearly clear, mahogany-raspberry with a khaki head and very good lacing. Aroma of dark roasted malt, chocolate, nuts, brown sugar and mild earthy hops. Taste of roasted malt, sweet dark fruit, caramel, brown sugar, nuts and mild earthy hops. Medium/light body and medium carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught at brewpub. Brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt with nuts. Taste is more nuts. Nothing particularly remarkable.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden deep amber to hazzlenut brown with a small off white and creamy head. Aroma is tosted malty, breadish and dry caramelish. Toasted. Bitter and dry caramelish into the finish. Light toffee note.
Nice clear amber light color, great aroma with nice citrusy hoppy hints. nice bitterness but too malty for me ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
