Tap. Pours clear orange, small off white head, good lacing. Aroma is light, toffee, hint of cinnamon, dark bread. Flavor is medium sweet, very light bitter. Interesting malt profile, minimal hops. Medium body, clean.
On draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber with an ecru head. Nutty nose. Flavors of toffee and citrus. Bitter finish.

On nitro (aka Velvet) at the brewery, pours a murky amber brown with some white head. Nose has soggy grains, bread, yeast, light straw. Flavor follows with caramel, grain, bread. Finishes a bit watery actually. Not great.
Draft to taster at brew pub pour clear light copper with thin ecru head. Nose toffee and caramel malts with light dank. Taste similar to nose with more grainy malt late.

4 oz pour on draft at District ChopHouse. Velvet version (nitro). Clear golden amber with off-white head. Aromas of floral notes, herbs, spice. Tastes of caramel, floral notes, aged hops, bitter wheat. Very light body with a dry finish. 6/4/7/3/13 Earlier Rating: 1/18/2016 Total Score: 3.8 4 oz pour on draft at District ChopHouse. Clear amber with beige head. Aromas of toast and biscuit. Tastes of toast, biscuit, caramel, citrus. Medium body with a dry finish. Good amber ale. 7/4/8/4/15
Great tasting beer. Strong flavor with minimal aftertaste. Creamy head and hoppy hoppy! Great fresh beer made right at the district. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewpub as "Velvet Amber". Amber body with a durable and creamy head. Nice mix of his and malts, with the good more evident than usual for style. Mild. Earlier Rating: 6/24/2015 Total Score: 3 On tap at the brewpub. Medium dark amber body with a good head. Typically malty for style with about equal sweetness and bitterness. Medium body and carbonation.
Farbe hell bis amber. Geruch Zitrone und Malz. Im Geschmack dann malzig. Hopfig, leicht citrus im Abgang.
Geruch cremig und nach Sahne-Karamell. Geschmack relativ süß, aber auch Bittere im Nachgeschmack. Wenig Besonderes, aber ganz gut gemacht. Etwas pappig.

column1: Rocky Bay Black Castle Scottish Ale
column5: Draught pint at the brewpub October 2005 Well if these guys are going belly-up, I may as well enter my old notes, as it looks like I’m not going to be getting a rerate. Thickly hazed beer (as are most of their beers) is a very deep mahogany with a slight, almost burgundy tinge. Sandy-beige colored head is medium in size, fading slowly to partial cover/ring, providing light lacing. Light creamy malt sugars mix with a very subtle fruitiness. Very mild roasted coffee is notable and a bit of honey comes on in the finish. Warming allows more creamy, somewhat caramel-like sugariness to emerge. No alcohol or flaws in the aroma Round, soft and sweet, the unfiltered, malty texture is always a bright spot in their beers. Hints of licorice quickly fall away, leaving cherries, vanilla and honey-cream sweetness. Lightly sweet caramel is very simple and the beer finishes about the same as it starts (caramel, honey, cream). Light coffee notes as well, picking up a bit of bitterness from some hops. Fresh, nutty yeast. Well-made beer, but very basic malt flavors without a truly developed fruitiness. No flaws noted in flavor. Medium body, medium carbonation.

column1: Rocky Bay Black Castle Scottish Ale
column5: Pour is dark amber reddish with a little foamy head. Carbonation goes away fast though in this one. Nose is sweet malt, sugar, molasses, and a little hoppiness. Flavors are clean, slightly watery (uh-oh) :) and dry. Good scottish, i’d call it average. It’s not a standout, but then again it’s not aweful either.

column1: Rocky Bay Black Castle Scottish Ale
column5: Maine Brewers Festival 2005. Dark brown, small beige head. Sweet malty aroma, bit of a bite? Flavour is malty with a sharp note to it. Dry earthy finish? Something else. Not unpleasant but lacks the big bad sugary malts of a great scotch ale. Average palate.

column1: Rocky Bay Black Castle Scottish Ale
column5: (Draught) Sampled at The Waterworks Pub & Brewery in Rockland, Maine. Tiny bubbles with a fully dissipating head. Beautiful copper colour yet the nose is weak and the body is too thin. Mild corn flavours are malted with a minor ABV kick. Not enough to "wow" me...

column1: Rocky Bay Black Castle Scottish Ale
column5: From a fresh growler. Pours a clear ruby brown with a thick tan head. Smells bitter and of malt. Hints of caramel. Tastes of malt and molasses though not as strong as the smell would hint at. Bitter with caramel flavors. Mouthfeel is thick, sweet and sticky. Is remarkably easy drinking for a scotch ale. A solid offering from Rocky Bay.

column1: Rocky Bay Foghorn Nut Brown Ale
column5: On tap at The Waterworks Pub in Rockland, Maine during Rockland’s first annual Chocolate March Festival (I always wonder when somebody calls something a 1st annual - how do they know it will become an annual thing...) Deep amber in cloudy with a fairly thin head. Aroma is very subtle: Some malt and yeast. Some Dark chocolate and expresso flavours with a very clean finish.
Alla spina. Lager rossa non particolarmente interessante. Malto, caramello, alcool e un debole retrogusto metallico. "Skippabile".

On tap at Polpo Matto. Oh boy this is bad. Clear light brown pour with a white head. Bland and lifeless with nothing more than low grade caramel malt and nondescript low grade hop bitterness. A real mess.
On tap, amber colour, medium malt aroma, metallic and bitter flavor, bitter hops final, enough alcoholic and not much more
alla spina ambrata poca schiuma non persitente dal nome ti aspettersti malto luppolo e un certo corpo ma sembra una birra annacquata se non nel grado alcolico

33 cL bottle in Fiumicino airport, Rome. Pours clear and golden orange with a dense off-white head. Aroma is malt driven and with a mild caramel note. Light acidic touch with a presence of alcohol. Flavour is dry malty, minor caramel touch, and with a light bitterness. Solid alcohol presence beneath. Ends warming and solid alcohol flavoured. Light sweet malt flavour before the finish and a light growing bitterness into the finish. Somewhat too alcohol flavoured for my liking.
Alla spina al festival Musica W di Castellina Marittima (PI); pressoché imbevibile nonostante l’alcool non sia poi così tanto sull’etichetta. Ma è difficile notare altro nel sapore.

Warm golden with a weak head. The aroma is malty and pilsner-like, and very boring. The moutfeel is rather oily. the flavour is sweet, malty with light notes of caramel, fruit and a light note of citrus in the finish. Drinkable, but no pleasure..

Rome, Italy airport. Very clean orangish amber brew average foamy head. Heavy malt aroma, sweet like high fructose corn syrup. Smooth, a bit peppery. Dry bitter aftertaste lingers a bit. Very warming alcohol feel in the chest and belly.
Bottled, in Trastevere, Roma, Italy. Pale larger, approaching European strong. Not as harsh as some others sold alongside it e.g. Ceres Strong, but not a noteworthy drink either.

Bought in the Rome airport. Pours golden brown and effervescent with a thin, well maintained white head. Aroma of caramelized alefruits, grainy, with notes of toffee and brown sugar. Taste is grainy, sweet, with toffee. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and sticky with lively carbonation.

column1: Rocky Bay Viking Plunder Winter Ale
column5: Maine Brewers Festival 2005. Dark brown body, fairly hazy moderate beige head. Muted dark malts in the aroma, and slightly earthy roast malt. dark sweet malty flavour is much more simplistic than I was hoping for based on the recommendation of a fellow festival patron. Dark fruit beings to emerge as it warms up with some chocolate glimpses. I did not get a lot of complexity out of this but maybe I should have had more patience and let it warm up some? Alcohol is virtually invisibile, to the point of questioning whether or not the abv claim was exaggerated. Average to medium palate. Has stoked my curiousity though (especially now that I have read Clark’s rating!) so I may have to seek this one out again.

column1: Rocky Bay Viking Plunder Winter Ale
column5: On draught at the pub on 10/23/2005. Served cold in a shaker, the beer is highly unfiltered with a deep brown-to-mahogany color, with chestnut edges. A soft, wispy, creamy beige colored head perches atop lightly, being retained only at a light covering, with slight, spotty lacing. Would like to see some better head retention. Smells of deep chocolate, hints of light roast, dark fruits and bits of caramel and black malt in between. A slight hint of earthy, husky malts, dry soil and damp, old coffee rinds really add a nice effect. Perhaps some anise-like notes in there as well. I really wish they would serve this at a proper temperature and in a concave glass, so I could get a better sniff at it, but that might come across as a bit snobby in this down to earth pub. The flavor is what really wows you in this one. It dosent come on strong, brash or burly at all. Quite the contrary. It starts out with a good, thick, chewy chocolate fudge flavor, with an easygoing, porter-like roastiness and a soft malt sweetness on the end. Low carbonation and a supple, substantial mouthfeel make it immediately attractive, while notes of barley, dry toffee, anise, figs and prunes make their way in. After about a quarter of my glass, I thought this was a nice chocolate porter of about 6% abv. It tastes no where, and I mean no where near 10%. And another thing that was very enjoyable was the almost exclusive malt focus. It dosent use the hops for much, if any, flavoring and relies on its complex balance of something like 8 malts to attain the flavors. No bitter hops notes, as a proper old ale. And even without the hops bitterness, it still runs a perfect line between keeping it well-malted, but never too sweet. As it warms, some brandy and more dark roast notes emerge, with perhaps, a vanilla-like flavor. Lots of yeast dryness (Chico Ale yeast). Body is medium-full and the beer is incredibly drinkable. I would put this in the top 3 most drinkable beers I’ve had for the ABV. I bet this would be absolutely killer on cask.

column1: Rocky Bay Viking Plunder Winter Ale
column5: This is a superior brew in the world of high-alcohol beers. With none of the cloying sweetness or estery notes of most high-gravity beers, it goes down easy and makes you glad you bothered. We’ve drained the keg at the local pub and are clamoring for more. I predict this ale will be a local legend before you know it and rightly so.
Det gælder for denne hvidtøl som det gælder for Fuglsangs julehvidtøl, de er gode. De smager lige præcis som de skal.

330ml bootle, thanks to djoeye for sharing. Lasting, creamy white head leaving crocheted lacing on the glass. Deep dark brown coloured body. Aroma of dark dough and caramel. Sweet taste of prunes and sweet dark bread, impression of kvas. Soft in the mouth. Very sweet, ok in smaller amounts (Tromsø 11.11.2014).
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a medium tan head. The aroma is slightly metallic and sweet with notes of dark fruit and sweet tobacco. Sweet and grainy flavour with some sweet dark fruity notes.
at peters sort øl smagning. Dark brown, small lght brown head. Aroma is bitter malty, slightly spicy. Flavor is bitter malty, very sweet
From Andreas. Bottled, 101109. Dark brown with beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel and some sweetness.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a brown head. Aroma and flavour of sugar, caramel and sweet malt.

Moderate malty aroma with notes of heavy toffee. Large, frothy, light brown head. Good lacing. Mostly lasting longevity. Dark brown body. Flavor is heavy sweet and toffee. Finish flavor is moderate sweet. Light to medium palate, and lively, watery texture.
Bottle. Nice head with short duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are sweet malt and molasses. Not a sweet as other Danish "hvidtøl"
Bottle. Creamy lightbrown excellent fully lasting head. Dark red-amber wonderfull colour. Moderate malty and yeasty aroma. Moderate sweet flavor. Short slightly metallic finish. Watery palate.

Bottle. Surprisingly high and creamy light brown head. Clear very dark red body. Distinct malt aroma with dried fruits. Sweet malt flavor but not as sweet as feared. Low carbonation, no hops bitterness, long sweet aftertaste. A nice surprise.
Clear golden colour, classic lager whit malty taste and booze. Nothing to remember

0,33L bottle (from Tallinna Kaubamaja). Pours clear dark golden with small off-white head. The head doesn’t stay. Aroma is malt, caramel, burnt sugar, metallic. Flavor is sweet, malt, caramel, burnt sugar, some bitterness, very noticeable alcohol. Carbonation is high. Overall: too boozy, but not the horror I thought it will be.
Pours golden with medium white head. Strangely refreshing with even some hops in it. Nothing too good though.

0.33 l bottle, thanks hanniku! Sweet bready aroma with tart alcohol, honey and toffee. Bready, honeyish and toffeish taste with tart alcohol, cherry. Medium body. Fairly boozy, alcohol dryes finish and leaves hot sensation.

Bottled 330ml Tallinn. Clear pale amber color, small white head. Cardboardish and harsh aroma. Medium-bodied. Light sweetish malty flavor, some green apple, paper. Not really alcoholic, just lame and papery.
330ml bottle. Clear golden color. No head, looks like shit. Papery, malty, alcohol in aroma. Alcohol, malty, grainy flavor. Nasty stuff.

330ml bottle (Stockmann, Tallinn) Meh - papery aroma. On swirling, there’s a hint of some gluey solvent too. Wallpaper - paper plus starch plus glue. You can feel the alcohol. Finish is just more bloody paper. Leaves the mouth needing a cleanse - Marduk suggests casting a /Neutralize Poison/ spell! So much wallpaper. Yeugh!

33cl bottle. Aroma of cane syrup and some caramel. Beautiful orange color for a strong lager. Unfortunately no head at all. Malty enough for the claimed type. Hoppy bitterness is rather weak. Medium body, oily with no carbonation (I would say it is typical for double bock). Better be served colder than usual revved up beer.

Orange, white head. Nose is malts and caramel, some hay notes. Taste is pretty much the same with light hops, mild dryness and bitter alcohol in the finish. Thin to medium body, medium carbonation, slightly oily mouthfeel. Better than expected.

Brown bottle. Dark golden body with a medium to small head. Sweetish malty aroma. Sweet malty taste with medium hoppiness and light alcohol bitterness. Has a bit richer body than local "strong pale lagers" but somehow it doesn’t offer much more depth of flavours. Relatively clean and drinkable but not something exciting.

Bottle picked up at Tuckers Maltings, Newton Abbot in November. Black as black can be, too sweet but there were some dried fruits on the nose and kicking about in the flavour dept’ other than that I was somewhat dissapointed by this.
Cask Stillage at the Metropolitan Cathedral Crypt, Liverpool 19/02/2003 Dark coloured and strong in alcohol. Some hoppiness. Lasting slightly malt finish.

Bottle, bought at St Albans Beer Festival 2004. Reddish orange colour. There’s quite a lot going on in the aroma, but a lot of it is rather hard to pin down. Definite sour cherries, as others have remarked, dried fruit and cocoa are definitely in the mix somewhere, but its a bit muddled. The sour notes and cherries continue on to the palate, with more spicy fruit. A fair ration of bitterness helps to hold things together. Rather good, but I would probably have been able to appreciate the subtleties better had we not been at GBBF all day before.

Sour cherries and light malty tones to the aroma. Clear brownish red with low tan head that diminishes rapidly to ring. Sour cherries, thin malts, underlying lasting sweetness. Light, very dry body with strong carbonation. Bottle sampled post GBBF with chris_o, daniel_brown and maeib.

Bottle round Chris_o’s house. Ruddy colouring and a soured jelly aroma. Cherry flavour and strong metal bitterness. Fizz on the tongue and thinnish in the mouth. Very nice, but honestly at this stage I was more interested in the chilli which Chris’ wife Ruth had prepared for us.

Black with brownish shine, totally opaque; slim, slightly irregular but rather dense brown head. Sourish-lactic nose, Flemish brown-like, superimposed on the classical chocolate cake. Whew -taste! Bitter, sweet and sour at the same time - some jumble. Flavours of smoked/cigar ash, bitter chocolate, fruit acids, lactic, berries, grapes and sweet cake. Very full-bodied, chewy. Aftertaste is acid-etched sweetness. Extremely likeable and dangreously drinkable for its ABV. Searched long after this -well worth the waiting. Thanks to MatW!

What a wonderful name for a beer. With this strength of beer you may well suffer brewers droop. This is a dark ale with earthy, root vegetable flavours complemented by roast malts. Quite sweet, yet vineous at the same time this has a nice fruity, dry finish. The alcohol is quite well hidden so beware. Similar to, but inferior to Traquair House Ale.

A clear chestnut colour with a thin slighty off-white bubbly head. Caramel & bready malt aroma with subtle spicy note. Taste is similar with a soft, dry, malty bitterness in the finish. Light bodied with slightly oily texture, low carbonation. A nice bitter for autumn or winter evenings.

Cask at Wiliam IV, Totnes. Sweet malty aroma. Chestnut. Thin bubbly head. Malty with caramel sweet core and slightly sour berry streak. Light-medium bodied. Slick. Average carbonation. Ling I'd muted finish. Enjoyable enough bitter.
Cask. Pours red Amber with english no head. A: earthy, skunky T: Low saturation, medium body, dry sweet dates, bit caramely, Bitter,
Cask half at the Volunteers Arms, GBBF. Pours mid brown with a white head. Aroma of malt and toffee. Similar taste. Sweetish finish.

recently in Dorset tried this ale for the 1st time have not had such a gorgeous beer since brew 10 disappeared, I wish I could drink it where we live but so far have not found it nearby. Hope to do so or try to get it delivered as it is so good. would rather buy it locally than risk it travelling so far to Lincilnshire

Cask at The Devon Arms, Torquay. A clear deep amber colour with a medium off white head. Aroma of caramel, bready malts, slight fruit and subtle spicy hops. Taste is similar of caramel, bready malts, slight fruit and subtle spicy hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A soft, dryish, malty bitterness in the finish. A nice and simple, no thrills premium bitter.

13/4/2018. Cask at the Salisbury Arms, Cambridge. Pours bright bronze with an off-white head leaving good lacing. Aroma of malt, sweet caramel, hops, fruit and flowers. Medium plus sweetness, moderate bitterness. Medium to full body, oily texture, soft carbonation.

Pours amber translucent in colour with small white head. Aroma is sweet malt, caramel and biscuit with a touch of grassy/vegetable like hop notes. Taste is medium to high sweet but with enough savoury bitterness from the hops to keep it even. A tad watery on the pallet but certainly a drinkable ale. Decent
Smell slightly sickly sweet crystal malt notes. Taste fruity notes, bitterness. Malty aftertaste. Ok but maybe a bit sickly sweet overall

6 3 6 3 12 Bottle at Tesco, Bournemouth. Clear amber with a small off white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, nutty notes and light fruit. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and bitter. Above light bodied with soft carbonation.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: From old tasting notes. Hazy, reddish brown color. Big rocky beige head. Sweetish wheat malt nose. Crisp, bittersweet toasted malt flavor hints at wheat and citrus. Nice flavor and body. Very refreshing.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: From the file last updated in 2010. Pours dark with big head. Didn’t get banana or spice.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Nor’Wester Beer Company--Dunkel Weizen-1997 12 oz. Bottle. 5.50% ABV. Dunkelweizen. Nice Brew.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: english pint / chocolate, caramel, fruit aroma. good appearance, but thin palate and lack of good flavor. not really wheaty, a little bit buttery, fruity and sweet, and just lacking.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: This is a good ale, I wasn’t hoping for much as it came in a bundle, but I was pleasantly surprised.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Clear light chestnut color with a smallish beige head. Mild chocolate and caramel aromas with some hints of DMS. Quite light and fizzy on the palate. Some light, dark malt flavors with just a touch of sweetness from the wheat late. This just seems to be a light dunkel with only a slight trace of wheat and no other major attributes. Really is not that bad as a brew, but don’t market something you don’t really have.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Boy, I sure do love Dunkel Weizens. Too bad this NorWester beer isn’t a Dunkel Weizen! It’s a dunkel all right, and judged as that, it’s a pretty good dunkel with some noticeable roastiness. Yet the wheatiness that I love so much is sorely lacking. It’s as if NorWester/Pyramid used a crisp American Wheat to add dark malt to. This beer is also somewhat watery and light-bodied, even for a dunkel. There just needs to be more grain bill present. Nevertheless, I admire their attempt at this rare style.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Dark brown. A pretty descent beer, just not a whole lot there. Certainly very drinkable, but just nothing outstanding.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: hazy brown, off white head. lemon aroma with yeast, roast, coffee and wheaty malt. hint of rye? tart malt flavours with a coffee-ish finish.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Pours amber/brown with a thin tan head. Cereal, light hop and nutty aroma. Some citrus and wheat. Wood, earth and spice. Some burnt notes and lots of brown sugar. Radek nailed it with "Flowery". Finish was a bit off. Odd stuff, but drinkable.
500ml bottle (thanks Viil). Clear golden color. Medium size, white head, stays. Sweet, malty, caramel, grainy, dusty hops in aroma/taste. Drinkable brew.
50cl bottle shared. Medium creamy white head. Clear golden pour. Easy drinking.
De la part de Jaghana. Jaune dorée claire, forte mousse. Nez malté, grains avec note de legumes. Gout malté, doux fruité avec bonne petite amertume houblonnée. Bon corps. Classique , ca passe
0,5 l Flasche. Helles Gold, stabiler, flacher Schaum, schöne Gardine. Riecht und schmeckt muffig, ansonsten herb und leicht süßlich im Abgang.
Bottle.Clear golden colour with medium white head.Aroma of biscuit and corn malty and bready with hint of caramel and hops.
Bottle at local fair. Pale golden color, clear, big white head, lacing. Aroma of grainy malts and mild.biscuits with straw and grass. Mild bitter taste dry finish, classic hell taste, lagery, crisp.
500ml bottle. Bready, malty beer with medium body, colour. Taste is sweet with hint of medicinal hop. Nice.
My favorite beer. Period. Classic. Amazing head. If bottle is not reasonably fresh and cared for u may have issues. But it is really refined and unique.

"Maxlrainer Schloss Gold", Flasche (50 cl) von Grabsch, Berlin-Lichterfelde. - Goldgelb, klar; sahniger Schaum. - In der Nase mild brotiges, tiefes helles Malz mit Anklängen an Vanille und Honig und feine Kräuter, die eine milde aber aromatische Hopfung zeigen. - Antrunk weich und satt hellmalzig mit zarter Vanille. Ganz milde aber elegante Hopfung mit Kräutertee, zarte Anklänge an Seifenlauge (die aber nicht störend wirken). Milder rezent, vollmundig, weich, leicht mineralisch. Im Nachtrunk etwas strohig-dumpf, sogar muffig: hier verrät sich der Hopfenextrakt. - Schönes, klassisches Export mit Tiefe und Charakter, enorm süffig. Die Biersorte "Export" schneidet auf RAB ja ziemlich schlecht ab (schon weil sie unsinnigerweise mit dem Hellen zusammengeworfen wird), aber dies ist einer ihrer besten Vertreter. Könnte richtig klasse schmecken, wenn auf Hopfenextrakt verzichtet würde ...

Drinked in bottle. On the nose a soft hops notes, some maltiness every very proper soft in your nose. In mouth is light bodied, balanced and refreshing, the final has a elegant continental hops note with a tiny sweetness on the tongue.
Brown in color but somewhat Amber in taste. Crystal and caramel malt forward. Toasted bread and earthy notes. Odd yeast character. Semi sweet round mouthfeel. Decent finish.

Amber coloured body with a thin tan head. Aroma of caramel, malt and mushrooms. Light to Medium-bodied; Decent mild earthy flavours with some sweetness, but not much. Overall, not as great as expected, but good to try, as this is a rariety. Thanks very much to Phil (haddon90) who gave me this bottle long ago and I kept it for something special. I sampled this 65 cL bottle on 15-May-2004 at the May RB Party in Toronto, Ontario.

Some spice and some sweet barleywine-like characteristics hit me from this basic brown brew. Seemed kinda like a nut-brown ale as I got into it - earthy and caramel and malty right through the slightly too sweet finish. Not bad - cheers Jeremy.

If I’m going to brew a brown, this is what I want it to taste like. This is a bottle of pure goodness. Nice sweet malt taste with an all so subtle hop bite. Yeast, bready, chewy and everything I love. I love you guys.
clear copper, white head. aroma of honey, earth, and toasted bready malt. flavour stars malty and sweet but pithy bitterness takes over a bit too quicky. not bad.
Amber in colour. Aroma of caramel malt and some hops. Flavour of light malt, mild hops, some caramel. Light body. Finishes slightly sweet, dry. Not bad.
Malty nose, amber, with a small white head. Soft malt flavour, backed by a nice hop aftertaste. Light bodied, sweet. Fair. Thanks Jeremy.
Dark amber , rather small crown . Aroma had woody , sweet notes . Medium bodied, slightly earthy. Pleasant brew.
Amber-bronze colour. Medium body. Sweet caramel malt in the aroma and flavour, with some anise and hops in the finish.
Medium amber color, average beige head. Aroma is quite malty, pretty sweet. Flavor is a little more toasty, but lighter. Delightfully smooth. A nice beer.
Уже, наверно, десять лет прошло, как пил его. В своё время был неплох, кажется.
Golden, slightly bitter and acidic (like other Chornomors). Sweetness is more evident in bottled than in draught version.
Pale golden, poor head. Aroma like a young wine, sour. Sharp, metallic, a little bit grainy, light sweet. Unpleasant aftertaste. Bad balanced, awful

From a 500 ml. bottle, freshness date on the back label, sampled in a lager glass. Poured a clear orangey golden with a foamy white that slowly dissipates into a thin sudsy lacing. A faint, largely clean nose, cereal grains and sweet pale malts, a little lemony. The carbonation is active, lending towards a light-medium body, crisp, dryish and a tad watery, tastes of a watery tart, lemony citrus, cereal and thin sweet pale malts, fusel alcohol flavor towards the end, a dry, watery tart, sweet malty finish, passable drinkability. This was, for me, barely o.k., I doubt I will be buying this again, there are better cheaply priced east European pale lagers on the shelves of the stores in my area.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy fine to medium sized white colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a transparent light orange colroed body. The aroma was malty and slightly acidic. The weird flavor was just off and contained acidic notes. A horrible one that I would not buy again.

Bottle. Poured hazy pale color with a large frothy white head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Light sweet grainy aroma. Light to medium good with a syrupy texture. Medium sweet flavor with a soft sweet short finish. Not much character.
16.9 oz bottle- An aroma of corn on a light golden body with a head that diminished quickly. A taste of wheat and corn. A light body. Not bad for a beer that traveled quite a while.

Sampled from bottle. Pours faintly cloudy yellow-gold with a thin, white head. Sour, wet-hay-like aroma is followed by a semi-sweet, sour malt flavor. Medium-light body with higher levels of carbonation. Quite an unpleasant experience. This beer taste quite old - which is a real issue when a brewer ships a pale lager 1/2 way round the world. I could imagine this being a decent lager at the source (sort of).

This would be a fine, fine drink... if I was into corn syrup and chewing on tin cans. Looks dandy, if you enjoy lifeless pours. Tastes like tin foil, corn syrup, diesel fuel, and white sugar. The description reads, "developed to satisfy the need of Ukrainian consumers for high-quality premium beer." I repect Ukranians more than this.

Chill-hazed golden with a white head that settles in scummy islands. Industrial aroma with a husky corn resumé. Corny, gasoline and vegetables with a touch of sweetness in a flavor that makes me squint and frown as I sip. Who needs that? Purchased from Di Carlo Fine Wines and Spirits, Mundelein, IL 60060
it’s gold alright, with an orange tine and a nice puffy head. Wheaty aroma. Tart flavor, hint of sugary syrupy, fresh corn, and grain. Very light bitterness in the middle. OK.

Large white head on top of a deep gold body. Aroma of wheat and vomit. There are hints of grain and corn. The taste is slightly sweet. Notes of lemons and some corn. Also some bread. This is alright for the style.
Typical tartness of other Chornomors is not quite evident here. Golden coloured with well balanced malty/hoppy palate. Full bodied and drinkable.

I poured a 22oz bottle into a nonic pint glass. Its best before month was notched August 2013. It cost $4 ($0.18 per ounce). Appearance: Dark, hazy shady of copper with barely visible sediment floating in suspension. Forms a large, off-white, soapy head which retains and laces fairly well. Smell: Reminiscent of an English-style brew with a fruity notes plus overt maltiness. Taste: I’ve always been surprised that the altbier style is inherently German since it drinks like a British pub style ale. Berkshire Mountain Brewers Alt is a good example of this as its quite close to being an ESB with its pure malty flavors and under attenuated sweetness. It’s quite tasty for such a light bodied brew and satisfying for sure. Right away I get a flavor of wet grain and toasted malt. If you’ve ever homebrewed, it’s akin to tasting the vapor of wort boiling in the brew pot. There’s some tasty fruit flavors to be found in here as well, especially red apple and a hint of cherry. Very mild caramel/toffee or other confectionery sweetness on the backend with some dry, biscuity bitterness as it finishes. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this, and actually found the palette became more enjoyable the more I drank. Drinkability: It’s small beers like this that show how much can be done with less. Berkshire Mountain Brewers Alt is only 4.5% ABV and while it’s palette is fairly complex, its robustness is mild but strong enough not to bore you. The mouthfeel itself is quite comfortable with calm carbonation, but is not a thin or watery beer at all. I was able to drink the entire bomber myself quickly and easily.

Bottle that I kept for too long. Pours a clear ruby brown with a thin beige head. Malty, a bit of age already, and some sour notes. Huh… soured up nicely. I doubt it was supposed to though. Has some nice acid actually, a bit like an Oude Bruin. As a sour it’s not too bad actually. Lots of lacto. Rather interesting. Actually drank a good amount of this and thought I would dump the bulk of it.
Tap at the brewpub.Orange, clear, tan head. Peppery hoppy aroma, and very clean. Hoppy and malty balanced flavor. Really well made and very quaffable.

I had this on tap at the brewery and bottle from the brewery at home. Has a dark amber color with little carbonation and a malted smell. Taste is of malt and finshes very smooth. Overall this was a very good beer. On tap it had a much smoother finish than the bottle.

column1: Triple Rock Punched In The Rye
column5: Orange color with hardly a head. Some citric hops in the nose, although not overwhelming. Nice malt aroma. Slight rye zing in the flavor. Some grapefruit. Long bitter finish. Medium body.

Dark beer, drunk one year past sell-by date. Silky smooth with lively but gentle carbonation. No hop character but bursting with malt, rye and yeast derived flavours. A perfectly crafted beer and a real pleasure.
Bottle. Pretty banana-y and caramelly. Yeasty, with quite a bid of whole meal bread flavour. Alcohol shows ever so slightly. Nice though.

Very dark red/brown colour. I haven’t had enough beers made with rye to isolate the characteristics associated with it, but there’s certainly everything but the kitchen sink in here. I picked up wheat (strong), caramel, vanilla, bready yeast, banana (faint) and roast malt. However, I found it a bit of a hotch potch and, in truth, too sweet for my palate. Interesting though. Bottled at Bedford Beer Festival 2004.

Arendsnest, Amsterdam, Nov 2002. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted bread, burnt caramel), lightly hoppy (herbs), with a light note of banana. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.
Bottled - Bedford Beer Festival. Lots of banana and rye aromas in this dark brown coloured beer. The taste is too sweet for me having banana and bubblegum galore.
Bottle at the Bedford Beer Festival 2004 (Wednesday Session). Wheaty and dark, refrained sweetness. This is good.
A nice tasty dark beer.Brewn in den Hool on a very small (farm) brewery. 7 km from Coevorden. ’pluim’ voor de familie.
A deep red beer with a huge beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and yeast. The flavor is sweet with a sour background and notes of roasted bread, rye, as well as hints of caramel.
Light brown colour. Spicy and sweet flavour. Some hints of sweet malt in palate and a caramel finish.
Reddish brown coloured. Yeasty aroma with notes of strange herbs (Dutch drugs?). Yeasty flavour with notes of rye malts.
Okay beer. But it has a strong flavour of unfermented beer. Like it is sweet like wort before adding the hops. Netto Dresden
Пиво просто ОГОНЬ!!! В меру сладковатый вкус с приятным кофейным послевкусием. Пьется легко, мягко. Рекомендую всем любителям темного пива со сладковатым вкусом!

Отличное темное пиво. Имеет превосходный сладковатый вкус с незабываемым кофейным послевкусием. Покупал в магазине "Хмель и Солод" по улице Циолковского, 57 город Екатеринбург. Отличное темное пиво. Имеет превосходный сладковатый вкус с незабываемым кофейным послевкусием. Покупал в магазине "Хмель и Солод" по улитце Циолковского, 57 город Екатеринбург. [Translated from Google]

Чарующи ароматное тёмное и сказочно вкусное, фирменное пиво. Вкусное темное пиво с выраженной сладостью солода и кофейными нотками. Купил в баре Eibauer в Челябинске, улица Чичерина 35д, ТК Ригас Charming fragrant dark and fabulously delicious, branded beer. Delicious dark beer with a pronounced sweet malt and coffee notes. I bought it in the bar Eibauer in Chelyabinsk, Chicherina street 35d, TK Rigas [Translated from Google]
Delicious dark beer with a pronounced sweet malt and coffee notes. coffee, red, light sweetness,
Piwo klarowne o rubinowej barwie, piana beżowa szybko opada. W aromacie słodowe, karmelowe, chlebowe nuty. W smaku karmelowe z lekkimi owocowymi estrami.

Flasche 0,5l: Kastanienbraun, dunkles Mahagoni, glasklar, wenig mäßig stabiler mittelporiger Schaum; frische + recht würzige Nase, eher trocken, kräftige Röstaromen, fruchtige Säure, Röstmalz, Getreide, Hopfennoten, etwas Vanille, Kaffee, dunkle Schokolade; im Körper kräftige malzige Süße, Malz, Malzzucker, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, dunkle/eingelegte Fruchtigkeit, kräftige Röstaromen, nussig, Kaffee, etwas Vanille, recht dünn; malzig-süßer Nachgang
Aus der Flasche getrunken (Supermarktkauf). Klares Braunkupfer mit imposantem Schaum. Ziemlich malzig süß. Sehr süffig.
Obfita piana, ciemny bursztyn. Aromat s?odowy, niezbyt intensywny. W smaku s?odko, nieprzyjemny posmak.

Maker: Münch-Bräu, Eibau, Germany *** Beer: Eibauer Lausitzer Dunkel (bottled, 500ml) *** Style: Dunkles *** ALC.VOL.: 4.2% *** "A wonderfully quaffable traditonal brew, re-created for yozur enjoyment." [brewery note] *** Colour: Dark reddish brown; medium, creamy beige head. *** Nose: Brown bread. Hints of caramel and roasted malts. *** Texture: Medium body, watery. Moderate carbonation. *** Taste: Sweetish. Roasted malts, caramell, slightly artifical sugar (with a bitter side note). Middle: The same. Finish: A bit bitter at least, with a little more explicit roasted malts. Short, aftertaste with the same artifically sweet note as before. *** Impressions: The fact that the brewery has added artifical sweetener (saccharine) to the beer doesn’t bode well. This accounts for the unpleasant sugary-bitter note that is typical of saccharine. Too sweet and one-note by half. Tastes like the malt beer for children. "Wonderfully quaffable?". Naahhh!

column1: Sports City Cafe Scottish Export Ale
column5: the peeted barley, smoky aroma is not at all subtle as it should be for this style. there is a slight buttery aroma coming from the dark orange body. the light colored head never develops into very mich. the taste is very smoky, nothing compared to stones smoked porter but that is an entirely different story. light sweetness peaks from behind the the smoke. the finish is surprisingly clean.

50cl can. Pours clear pale golden colour with a mid-sized to small white head. Aroma of grainy malt, mild grassy hops. Taste of mild grassy hops, grainy pale malt, a bit dry, watery mouthfeel. Earlier Rating: 1/29/2014 Total Score: 2.9 Ins Glas ergießt sich ein klares goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig, getreidig, grasig. Geschmack hopfig, grasig, lang anhaltende Bitterkeit.
Pale golden color. Grassy hoppy beer with lots of hay character. Wonderfully balanced.

Copenhagen 8/11 2014. 50 cl from SuperBest. Pours clear yellow with white head which quickly subsides. Aroma is neutral slightly malty. Medium carbonation. Not much taste either. But a clear bitterness. It may be the Reinheitsgebot but there is not much character to this beer.

Bottle as Eibauer Jubiläums Pilsner 1810 from trade with Beerhunter111, many thanks my friend. Golden color with huge white head. Perfumed malty aroma with nice bitter hops. tast starts malty, after short time nice portion of grassy, bitter hops arrives. Medium long hoppy bitter finish. OK.
Can golden colour with medium off-white head.Aroma of hops and corn even grass flavour, medium body and slight metallic mouth feels short with bready finish.
Bottle from the HerbFest in Dresden. Pours light gold with a slight white head. Light grassy aroma. Hay even. Flavor is bready and grassy. Bit of hop "tang". Finishes fairly bitter.
Draught- Golden in color, white head. Cereal and and hay in aroma. Light bitterness in taste with sweetness in aftertaste. Dry mouthfeel.
Draught @ Woolshed Aroma has butter, hay, grainy malt, hints of mint and herbs. Flavour has grassy hops, grainy malt and butter. Quite strong on grassy hops. Refreshing and smooth – not harsh at all.
Tap at Woolshed, Helsinki. Colour is clear golden with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Grain, some sweetness and malts. Again quite boring pilsener.

(Keg at Woolshed, 20140801) The beer poured golden and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had grain, grass and mildly malts. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, grain, grass, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was grainy, sweet and bitter. Not bad but somewhat thin pils.

Светлое пиво с легким крепко-насыщенным вкусом. Уникальный сорт пива. На вкус вначале крепкое и сладкое, затем отлично смягчается, благодаря хорошо сбалансированным пропорциям ингредиентов. Купил в баре Eibauer в Челябинске, улица Чичерина 35д, ТК Ригас35d, TK Rigas Light beer with a light strong-saturated taste. A unique grade of beer. The taste at first is strong and sweet, then it softens perfectly, thanks to the well-balanced proportions of the ingredients. I bought it in the Eibauer bar in Chelyabinsk, Chicherin street 35d, TK Rigas35d, TK Rigas [Translated from Google]
Clear golden, white head. Light to medium sweetness, Malty - hay, grains, rice, alcohol. Good carbonation. Dominant medium bitterness. Bitter finish. Very drinkable Bock.

Draught at Berlin Bar. Low fluffy lasting white head. Hazy yellow body. Mild slightly spicy grass aroma. Thinbodied and watery dusty straw flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish. Disappointment.

Copenhagen 4/5 2016. 50 cl bottle from Meny. A small monk with a staff on the label. Pours clear yellow with small white head. disappears completely after half a minute. Aroma is malty sweet and quite grainy. Medium carbonation and watery palate. Flavor is quite sweet. Followed by medium bitterness which dominates the aftertaste. Some slightly metallic notes of alcohol. Not very exciting - but a no nonsense thirst quencher with a healthy alcohol content.

0,5 l bottle. Clear dark red golden nearly copper in the glass with a big white head. Malt and grain with a Bock-sweetness on the nose. Starts malty, light apple fruity, than followed by an alcoholic bitterness, low roasted. Okay.
Dunkel goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher weißer Schaumkrone. Geruch fruchtig, malzig, scharf getreidig. Geschmack sehr malzig, fruchtig, grasig.
Bottle from Voldby. Clear golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, grainy and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 040814
Tap at Woolshed, Helsinki. Colour is clear golden with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Grain, sweetness and malts. Fresh but again too sweet for me like most of the heller bocks.

(Keg at Woolshed, 20140801) The beer poured golden and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had grain, malts, grass and hint of sweetness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were grain, sweetness, grass, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was grainy, sweet and bitter. A very grainy and still rather balanced heller bock. Alcohol was well hidden.
light sweet malty aroma,golden, clear, white foam, light sweetness, light body, oily feel, fizzy, long finish,
Julie does not mind and likes it more than me. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
on tap at Beer Engine 28Sept2012, Seriously the acetone paint thinner note that is in this beer dominates the caramel sweetness, it burns and at 8 percent thats something I wouldnt expect.

Nice deep chestnut brown in color with a few tan bubbles here and there for the head. Viscous legs slide down on the walls of the stem glass. Aroma unravels maple, brown sugar, caramel, Milky Ways, sugary pecans and apple juice. Sweet malts come calling first for flavor, trotting along with caramel and toffee. Sugary and roasted qualities seem to hit simultaneously and are trailed with a suggestion of smoke. Mild chocolate, squeezed pears and prune juice manifest on the tail end, residing in pockets in between the teeth and cheeks. Medium bodied and palate feels as it should. Batch might have been boiled a tad too long. Finishes like brazed pecans. Thanks to my Secret Santa (kujo9) for sending me this one from my wish list!

Bottle, found for only $3.99 in Dayton, lucky me! Anyway, the beer has a nice reddish brown color with a initial large frothy head which fades into a msall covering and left good lacing on my glassware. The beer comes off with a big caramelized and toffee malt nose with additional prune and apple aroma. A bit of earthy ester and hazelnut as well. The taste starts with a caramel and sugary sweet forefront supported by a nice apple like twang. The finish displays some mocha, mild bitters, and a touch of nutty qualities. The feel is lively and yet a bit oily as well, makes this bier quite quaffable despite it size. Wow, worth the long wait. This is a great brew and a dug it completely. Sure it isn’t quite to style, but then maybe that is why I like it so. Get ya some.

Dark black pearl with rich burgandy shallows and a dense, thick and foamy head. The aroma is like grape soda with sweet maple tones. Carbonation is light but crisp enough. Grape notes in the flavor with generic stewed prunes and punch. Hops is light but detectable and survives as an afterthought. Toffee in waves and a general lack of complexity. All in all, not too bad, but need some work.

Lovely to look at, and a delightful nose; smoky and sweet caramel, earthy. Head intiially forms nicely. Then dies. That’s OK, fairly normal for bocks. Still and thicker in the glass as it warms. Uh oh, is it going to get excessively sugary? No! But it turns watery and bland. Palate marks are way down as this warms. Still, tasty until the end, and it didn’t get ugly, just nonexistent. Needs more smokiness. Some nice burnt plastic malt action.

Deep red-brown body, thin light tan head. Rich aroma of dark caramel, toffee, raisin, prune and a hint of coffee and burnt sugar. Drinks like prune juice, with dense raisin and prune mingling with dark caramels and toffee, also offering the coffee hinted at in the aroma. Rather syrupy body. I’ll repeat one word: dense. One of the best American versions of the doppelbock I’ve sampled.

Bottle. Poured a very small sized tan head with fine-small sized bubbles that fully diminished. Carbonated, mostly opaque with a reddish-brown hue. Malty, caramel, and chocolate aroma. Malt and caramel flavor with a smooth mouthfeel.

This bottled brew poured a frothy head medium sized brown colored mostly diminishing bubbles. The body was semi-opaque softly carbonated and dark ruby red brown in color. The aroma was malty with a mild hoppiness and brown beer note. Its mouth feel was thick and smooth with a mild finish. The flavor was very interesting with an initial malty raisin flavor that mellowed in the finish.
Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, fruity, candylike.(Very similar to charms blowpops.) Flavor is like the aroma with the addition of chocolate. Very good.

Yet another taste of 2/8/03 at Winterfest in St Paul. WAWOOD puts way too much thought into this...I don't know who he enjoys the beer..read his freakin comment. BAHUMBUG! I smelt her roast, she was dark complected and gives better head..I like her. I tasted her camp fire.

This brew was offered as a "Surprise Beer" by the folks from the Twin Cities Hops locations at Winterfest in St. Paul on Feb. 8. Supposedly, "4 N" is a play on the word "foreign". I was unable to understand the server's explanation of the connection with the beer, however. Not much head. Reddish black. This is one of if not the best beers I have had from Hops. It reminded me of "An Aaron Beer," which I detail in my review of Hops Lighting Bold Gold. Perhaps that's what this brew actually is, a mixture of several of Hops' mainstays. It is very flavorful, not exceptional, but tasty.

23.06.2013, tap @ Boston Beer Works Canal St.: Tiny shortlasting head. Aroma is slightly neutral, roasted grain, hay, caramel, chocolate. Taste is slightly sweet, caramel malts, hay, grass, chocolate, nuts. Medium bitterness. Boring.

Draft @ Canal St. location on 7 June 2013 before the Bruins vs. Penguins Game 4. Hazy copper color thin white head in a mug. Nose is light peated malt and some caramel covered grain. Flavor of malts are caramel and fruity, slightly sweet and a touch peat. The body is a bit thin but after all, it’s a Beer Works brew. I do not taste hops of any kind. Overall it’s decent. Easy enough to drink with some ok malt flavors.
I thought I would really like this beer, but it was a bit of a disappointment. Hard to drink, but I drank it, I paid for it, didn’t I?
(Draught) Pours a clear amber body with an average cream head. Aroma of nuts, mustiness, earth, and light roastiness. Flavor of nuts, caramel, and peat.

Nitro at the Salem Location: Deep copper with good clarity and a dense light tan head that laces well. Soft aroma with a rich malt presence. Definitely some peat character with a mild earthy smoke note. Light fluffy feel with an easy going malty flavor. Some caramel sweetness is balanced by an earthy peated malt presence. A surprisingly solid attempt at a style I didn’t expect to see from a brewer that I consider a "tourist trap". Kudos on the solid effort. (It was awesome that they got the peated malt quality).
Tap@Beer Works, Boston, Ma. Pretty smooth , sweet and malty.Some toffee and caramel, but doesn’t have the peaty malt character of some of the better scottish ales. This is a bit thin.
Clear copper color. Aroma of malt and caramel. Weak flavor of caramel and malt. The palate is light and watery.
Pretty okay. Good smell. Light yellow-y orange color. Smooth. Not bad, but not super special though.
On tap at the Beer Works by the Garden. Nice copper color with a perma-perfect head that lasted and lasted. Smooth and creamy. Yum!

Deep golden in color with a small white head.poured pub-draught style with nitro,very creamy,smooth texture.Clean subtle malt and hop balance.I mistaken thought this was a Wee Heavy on the menu, my bad.A decent 60-70 schillings Scottish ale.

on tap-pours a thin off white head that laces and hazy amber color. Aroma is mild medium malt, hops. Taste is nice balanced/mellow medium malt, citrus/spicy hops-some bitter. English style. OK carbonation.
POurs medium amber. Notes of hops on the nose with some light fruits. The palate shows a dry hoppiness that bends into a bit of the grapefruit note on the finish.

Draught pint at Fenway location on 4/14/07 One-finger of white head atop a very pale, brassy-gold body that is clear and shows brisk carbonation. Head laces lightly, with moderate retention. Nose is moderately hoppy, certainly showing more hops than either malt or yeast. I believe this is a single-hop EKG beer, though I am not positive. Regardless, the main force is certainly EKGs and there are a fair amount of them in here. Still, this hop is not exactly bursting with aroma and flavor by the time it makes it to the US and I really dont see the reason for using it unless you’re getting it fresh in Englan and using it immediately. Dusty, lightly sweaty and with some sourish-cattiness, it nonetheless posesses some dry, yellow fruits and light floral notes (dry lilacs, lavendar, vanilla blossom). Very grainy malt bill is also quite dry and gives some toastiness as well as a small amount of light, pale malt sweetness. Clean yeast, and very low bitterness overall. The sourish-catty flavors persist somewhat, being the biggest drawback to this beer. Lemon and light white grapefruit, toasted malt, floral-herbal hops and light vanilla all combine in the flavor to give a sort of American golden ale-meets-English pale-meets-American pale ale flavor. Low bitterness, but ample, I’d say, bolstered by the relative dryness of the beer and the brisk carbonation. Toasted malt is a little too strong, crowding out the finish and giving too much acidity (though it’s still rather light, overall). Some wateriness and only a medium-light body at best, but drinkable, if somewhat pestered by unclean/old hop notes and too much dryness/wateriness.

@ fenway location. Ok nose, Mainly citrus with some toffee. Hazy brownish orange color, good head that slowly faded. Bitter flavors Grapefruit, metallic, lemon, grassy. Medium body, kinda creamy mouthfeel, citrusy bitter finish that lasts a while. Grew on me as it warmed up. Pretty tasty
(tap) nothing very "special" about this... average... average... average, and i don’t know where beaconstreet got this vanilla cake thing from... and we were drinking out the same glass. *winks*
Vanilla cake scent wafts off this a little. Also hints of an aroma slightly like lit matchstick heads. Nice brown. Even-handed dosage from the hops god-brewers here.
Light bodies, hoppy/floral aroma, with a taste much the same. Moderatly hopped, quite plain and mediocore.
cloudy blond, nice head, fruity and fresh, well-hopped, floral with spicy notes, smooth, sweet with a fruity finish
origionally rated AUG 20, 2009. Smokey flavour and aroma. A surprising beer with lots of flavour.

33 cL bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours cloudy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is mild rubber, plastic and vague smoked. Smoked, mild meat and slight acidic. Vague caramelish note. Lingering dark malty and subdued smoked.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours an almost clear amber with an off-white head. Roasted malt and caramel in the nose combined with some smoke as well. Medium body, sweet caramel and again a distinct smokiness - Bamberg style. Discreetly bitter. The smoke seem intended and I guess this really should be categorized as a Smoked. 230310
Smokey flavour and aroma. A surprising beer with lots of flavour. Brewed for the city museum in Alkmaar

The beer floods out of the bottle. The color is hazy amber and the head is huge and creamy. The aroma is rather weak with notes of malt, light licorice and flower. The flavour has sweetness and notes of roasted malt, syrup, flower, light licorice and it is both delicious and full bodied.

Bottle 50cl. @ home. Clear medium amber color with a average to large, frothy - creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate hoppy, orange, light to light moderate yeasty. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20081128]
Bottle 0,3ltr: Amber coloured ale with a fruity taste and bitter finish brewed for a museum in Alkmaar.

Unfiltered and unpasteurized beer, which produces a great creamy body. the experience in palate is just incredible, though the rest of the features are not as better. aroma is good, at the begining but disapeear soon, the taste is bit bitter and the aroma of malts lacks in the taste. However is a very good Dutch product.

Bottle, 5.8%. Gusher though quite cold. Almost clear dark copper colour. Very big, stable tan head. Fruity, soapy aroma. The flavour is malty with nice aroma hops and a hint of smoke. The aroma hops are soapy and perfumy, not good in the aroma, but OK in the flavour. Good mouthfeel.
Nice aroma, nice taste. Fruity, sweet taste with a nice bitter finish. Dry palate.
Uitstekend bier, lekker van smaak en niet duur, het is lekker om in de wc van school te drinken.
Prakticky tady přidávám tento komentář, jen aby tady něco bylo, protože zpětně dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.
Drinkable, mediocre lager. Empty taste with weak aroma but without major flaws. bought in 5l keg.
Soft. Easy. Medium maltiness. Is there any grass? Maybe. Some spices probably. Cheap. Ehhh, meh.
Clear golden, white head. Malty, grassy aroma with strange artifical lemon notes. Flavour has malt and dead hops. More of that strange, slightly soapy lemon. Dirt cheap and poor.
Lattina 0,5 l. Giallo paglierino con schiuma bianca. Aroma pressoché inesistente. In bocca sgradevole sapore di tubo, artificiale, bolle giganti... ogni sorso = 2 rutti. Imbevibile.
50 cl can bought at Lidl, Vienna. Some metallic notes with some shy hops and mal flavour. Watery body
330ml can at home. Clear golden color with white head. Malty aroma, grainy, grassy, light hoppy. Sweet and light bitter taste. Light thin to oily body with average carbonation.
From lidl. Playing KB Dark Side. In adnams glass. Drinkable macro beer. Better than more expensive alternatives.
20.4.2014. Sweetish grainy nose with dull hops, slightly metallic. Taste is similar to basic lager with dull grainy taste.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton. A ruby coloured beer with a whitish head and lacing. The aroma is rich fruity malts. The taste is malty and full of berry fruits. Good alcohol presence and a decent full body.
Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 19/06/2001 Dark coloured and fruity. Strong in alcohol. Has the feel of an old ale.

Hazy dark tawny colour. Spicy fruit aroma with yeast, woodiness and a hint of burnt caramel. Also woody and a little bitter on the palate, with a big hop presence too. No sweetness at all and some lactic, sour edges on the finish. Warming alcoholic afterburn. This was very close to its BBE date, so it may be that it develops that woodiness over time. Comes over a bit like a hybrid between a strong ale, a porter and a hopped up old ale. Very interesting. It won’t be to everyone’s taste, but I liked it a lot. 500ml bottle (bottle conditioned) from orchard-hive-and-vine.co.uk

Cask Conditioned. Dark amber with chunky big head. Big fruity malt aromas followed by a smooth apple, blackberry flavour with sweetish malts and a chaser of dry bitter hops. A real winning beer as good as it gets.

Wow! This is scrumptious! Brobdingnagian head. Yeasty nose very like a Belgian. Smooth, persuasive, luscious, fruity body rather like an Abbey Dubbel. Flawless hop bite in the finish to clean away the sweetness. Yum! This is a winter seasonal in the cask, but is available all year round bottle conditioned. It is a Winter Warmer with a little Belgian twist and and extra slap of hops. Very soft, and ever so easily consumed. A beer gone quickly - thoroughly enjoyed - and left wanting another just to fully savour all the flavours. I really enjoyed that, and now I'm wondering if 4.4 is a high enough score. O, yes, did I enjoy that! This little brewery with its tap at the Queens Head in Herefordshire, uses only local ingredients and was founded in 1987 by husband and wife team Gaye and Steve Dunn. A rare and enchanting beer.
Sehr dunkel rötlichbraunes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, Kaffee. Geschmack röstmalzig, leicht schokoladig, Kaffee.

Schwarzbier mit rötlichem Schimmer, feinporiger Schaum. Würziges Aroma dunkler Malze. Sehr malzbetonter Start, der etwas zu süß ausfällt, was der röstmalzige Abgang aber wieder gekonnt ausbügelt. Gerade zu kräftigen Gerichten ein gutes Schwoarzes.
earthy, cooked vegetables, rotten eggs, soy sauce, butterscotch, chocolate, brown, sparkling, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, heavily sour, medium body, sticky, soft carbonation,
Deep reddish color with small head. Sweet as krosovice, fine beer but remember to have your toothbrush ready.

Das Bier startet malzig, der zu süße Unterton wirkt sich dabei störend auf das Gesamtbild aus. Ein billiger Hopfenton kommt im Nachgeschmack zum Tragen und wirkt sich ebenfalls nicht sehr harmonisch auf. Nicht überzeugend, definitiv. Test vom 25.10.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 7,5,5,2,7,4 - 4,45
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown/black. Aroma and taste are sweet caramel, roast malt and hops.
Bottle. Brown colour with a nice creamy beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and caramel

Bottled 50cl. Courtesy of Quack-Duck. It pours a rather dark beer with a nicely remaining delicate and nicely lacing light beige head. Interesting aroma which is mainly sweet, chocolatey, bready with hints of fresh cut grass and faint compost. Pumpernickel and chocolate in the taste. Unmemorable malt profile. Definitely overly sweet with hardly any bitterness. Smooth. Medium bodied. A beer with some nice, pleasant components. But the cloying sweetness makes it a bit dull and ruins its qualities. Dissapointing. As expected, there are a lot of residual sugars in the finish. Thanks a lot Stefan!
Bottle. Dark brown colour with large creamy light brown mostly lasting head. Malty aroma. Roasted notes. sweet roasted flavor. Too sweet

hummm, disappointed, i never enjoy Exxx in ingredients, E954 is sacharine... ok. But the beer is really light boddied. Taste is a vague roasty, woody notes in the far background. Foam looks like soap bubbles and fade away directly. Rather wattery and artificial. Too sweet is not but taste sweetly fake. Beer seems over-rated to me... Pass your way on that kind of beer. Even Oetker Kostritzer seems better to me. Heineken Boehmische Brauerei should do better, espacially for the price at supermarket. Only the stikker on the bottle is nice. Ended up in the sink...

(Dose) Es hat eine goldgelbe Farbe, ist blank filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist schlank, getreidig, etwas oxidiert und mit etwas würzigem Hopfen. Der Geschmack hat einen fast wässrigen Körper mit leichten Papp-Noten im Abgang. Die Bittere ist mittelstark mit einer würzigen Hopfennote.
Bottle from supermarket, from old notes. Student times beer i used to have, normal pils actually

0,5 bottle. Pours golden color with small white head. Hoppy aroma, grass, metal notes. Taste is hoppy and refreshing, medium bitter. Aftertaste is short and bitter. Light body, average carbonation. Decent refreshing pilsener.
The Frankfurt Brew. Dusty, Hairy Aroma, very light Hops. Dark as Pils go. Taste is kind of raw, bitter and metallic. Body is Zoo soft and washed Out.
Pale yellow, small white lacing. Strong barley aroma and likewise taste. Long lasting aftertaste. (Velp 201408) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Antrunk und Abgang sind gleich herb. Malzaromen sind im Abgang kurz zu erkennen. Kommt schön frisch rüber. Fazit: Typisches Pils, schmeckt für den Preis ganz Okay, gibt aber bessere Biere!

Geruch relativ neutral, Geruch leicht hopfig mit Betonung auf leicht, Schaumkrone ist nicht nennenswert bzw. schon fast nicht existent. Der Einstieg ist überraschend geschmackig, frisch, aber haut einem nicht vom Sockel.Fazit: Trinkbar aber nicht

Bottle: Golden. stable White head, sweetish worty nose with some herbal-hoppy undertones; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, light bodied and soft; lingering bitterness in the pale-malty and herbal finish. Not bad for a cheap Supermarket beer...
0.5L bottle at home, yellow-golden beer, small head, aroma and taste is just normal pilsener, decent beer and it was cheap

An unclear dark yellow beer with a very fine head. The aroma is a nice fruity aroma with malt notes. The flavor is dominated by anise from beginning to end with a lot of malt sweetness but lacking a little bitternss. In my opinion the anise is too dominating.
Bottle: Fruity and spicy aroma with plums, cherries, cloves and pepper. Hazy dark brown color, brownish head. Flavor is very spicy and fruity, cinnamon and plums, lebkuchen, speculatius,

[Thanks to fonefan]. Bottled. Brown colour with an off-white head, dense and with a good duraition. Aroma has burnt sugar, sweet and cookies notes. Flavor has hints of chocolate plumbcake, slightly sweet and a mild bitterness. Bittery final with notes of chocolate. Dense, creamy and smooth on palate.

19.12.12 Luke 6 i Ølkonsortiets julekalender. Urs: rødbrun, holdbart skum og godt med kullsyre. Noe bunnfall og dis. Duft: rik malt, tydelig belgisk gjær, noe frukt og tiltalende duft. Smak: fyldig og søtlig, mye malt og noe alkohol og litt humle i ettetsmaken. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle: Poured a dark brown with light brown head. Aroma is sweet sticky fruit and roasted malts. Taste is sweet fruit with spices and just enough alcohol to make it winey.

More attitude than the blonde, there is a lot of head on a deep brown body. Medium plus mouthfeel, with a tad of bittersweet cocoa and lots of chocolate malt. Bit of sour finish and strong carbonation. Alcohol catches up to you. Overall satisfying.Thanks Phyl21ca/boutip for the hitchikers.

75 cl bottle at Delirium Café, Göteborg, Sweden. Hazy copper, thin beige head. Candyish, a bit roated malt aroma, with clove and cinnamon. Very smooth mouthfeel. Unbalanec flavour with a cloying sweetness, and unmasked alcohol. Still, quite interesting.

Bottled. Very much Belgian X-mas here, overloaded with spices. Dark brown colour. Sweet cake with clove and very spicy nose. Banana tidbits, thick mouthfeel and seet with apparent alcohol. Bit too much. Gingerbread. Licorice. Overwhelming sweetness. Props though for the fact that something is happening here.

Bottle, at Plan B, RBESG pub crawl, August 2005. Quite dark colour, with some reddish notes. Quite yeasty aroma, with plenty of spices showing through. Plenty of plummy, cherry fruit on the palate, with more festive spices - cinnamon to the fore. Quite sweet, and full, but remains clean on the palate. Very nice.
Bottle. Brown color with a off-white head. Sweet light sugary body with a sweet palate and light raisin notes.

Cinnamon and nutmeg spiciness greet the nose along with a fair amount of alcohol and burnt brown sugar sweetness. Opaque black body with low tan head that recedes to a dense ring. Spicy, nutmeg flavour with notes of chocolate and some dark malt roastiness. Soft texture to the fine-bubbled, lively carbonation. Bottle sampled at Plan B in Copenhagen.

I bought this bottle from the brewery. There’s not a lot of head from a pour into a pilsner glass. It’s pale gold and decently carbonated and a run of the mill aroma. It’s a bit grassy and has some sweetness from the malt. There’s not much of an aftertaste. Overall, it’s drinkable but generic and leaves little impression.
Not very good at all. Comparable to budweiser and other generic garbage. Don’t even bother
Bottle, pours a nice head, the taste is pretty basic, overall its not bad, not much life

Bottle from the brewery. Light golden with a still body and no head. Aroma of straw, wet cardboard and icing sugar. Very low carbonation, almost flat. Generic mainstream lager flavour - too-sweet sugary malt, wet hay, light grassy hops. Poor.

[2593-20091118] 341mL bottle. Grainy haystack and generic wet straw aroma. Clear, yellow body with a quick foamy white body. More generic straw grain yeast flavour. Medium body. Boring. (from the brewery)

Bottle (341ml) courtesy of tupalev. Pours a clear bubbly pale gold with a small diminishing white head. Mild aroma of biscuity malt, light grassy hops and some sugary sweetness. Flavour of grain, light grassy hops and some mild sugary sweetness. Average bodied. A typical average Ontario Lager.

Bottle from the brewery/ Light yellow with a ton of bubbles - seems very carbonated. Head goes away very quickly. Mild aroma - some light malt and a hop or two. Taste - ok. Very grainy. Mouthfeel over carbonated. Not bad really, bordering on watery, grainy taste is nice enough. The poorest of the 3 I have had from the cold crown though.

Drank from bottle. Malty aroma with a bit of ginger, barley (or is that just malt?) and toasted caramel. Flavour has loads of bread and grain. Some sweetness comes from the malts. Becomes almost creamy in the mouth, medium bodied. Very little aftertaste -- leaves the mouth feeling clean.

Bottle from brewery-Pours a deep golden with a short lived white fizz, but there’s a lot of lace. Fresh, floral hop nose, spices, lemons and lime zest, biscuit and cookie. The flavour profile is a leafy green hop flavour, grass with lemon and biscuit cookie at the finish. Finishes bitter and crisp. Well made, and at the price, there’s no reason why this wouldn’t be a mainstay for me.

Bottle (341ml). Via trade with Matt7215. Very pale clear gold, large white head that runs away quickly - looks kind of dead in the glass. Pretty decent aroma - light cereal grain oiliness and soft grassy hops - some biscuit - yeast? Tastes the same - sweeter, only lightly bitter, medium-quick finish and a bit chewy, lightly carbonated, nice and grainy - a decent version of what tastes like a classic Canadian brew, with that Euro hop character added in. Very decent.
neutral aroma, golden, average foam, malt flavour, light bitterness, light body, soft carbonation,
Bottle, 3.3%. Rough aroma. Clear golden colour, small white head. The flavour is acceptable, some bread, some rough hoppiness. Thin mouthfeel.
Bottled. Pale yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is grass, grain and some maltyness. Flavour is quite much the same.
Clear golden with medium white head. Sweet and cardboardish with grainy notes.
bottle, bought at the brewery. Pale golden colour, large white head. Malty, slightly hoppy, slightly sour with a hint of cardboard.

Bottle: Pale golden coloured; nearly no head to speak of, visible carbonation; faint sweet-malty, also cardboardy nose; watery; slightly bitter flavour; short grainy finish with a faint bitterness. Very bland !
The beer is presented as a premium product but the quality is very poor. The beer was infected and smelled and tasted like butter. spoelbakspeciaal, bah.

Clear, golden lager color with a smallish head. Mild, soapy, fruity-hoppy aroma with some chlorine. Mild, slightly sweet, quite metallic flavor with little hops. Quite watery, slightly oily, moderately carbonated palate. Quite tasteless and watery pilsener with very little hops, malt, ABV and character. Not the worst beer in the world, but at 2,30€ a bottle, it’s definitely a never-again brew.
Bottle picked up at BBF2013. Light gold with a short lived head. Aroma is light sweet malt, flavour is sweet with a citrus bitter base.

Farblich ist es kräftig Gold, die Schaumkrone ist nicht so gut-mittelmäßig. Geschmacklich wird es durch den Hopfen und die Würzigkeit geprägt, im Nachgeschmack ist es ein wenig bitter und wässrig. Fazit: Ordentlich! Test vom 28.2.2009, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,11,11,9,13,11 - 10,60
Bottled, brought from Budyně nad Ohří. Clear golden color. decent bitterness. ("Sametová hořkost".) very boring and average for me anyway.

500ml bottle @ Christmas tasting on 28 December 2010. Old bottle (at 4.1%), not sure where from. Darkish gold in colour. Smells pretty bad - very oxidized and cardboardy. Tastes rather better - bready malts and breakfast cereal with a lick of bitter hops. A little residual sweetness in the mouthfeel. Would have been doubtful about rating this in view of the age except that I’m not sure it’s made any more. And, to be hoenst, the other Louny beers I’ve tried were no great shakes even when fresh.

Bottle 500ml. @ ChrisOs - Christmas Tasting. Clear medium yellow color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, toffee, cardboard. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20101228]
28th December 2010 ChrisOs Christmas Tasting. Clear gold beer. Short lived white head. Very light palate. Mild sweet toffee malt. Trace of orange hop. Light dry finish. Insubstantial and dull.
Gold clear lasting white head. Really bad old aroma. Tastes ok ish. Ok in mouth but aroma is terrible. Not great
cereal, golden, clear, average head, medium bitterness, light body, average carbonation, bitter,

I really like this. Light, golden brown in colour; has an almost honey smell to it, bitter, malty; tastes pretty much as it smells with a delicious honey-malt taste to it; slightly bitter after taste; light fizz.

(bottle, courtesy of Quack-Duck) Clear, golden colour with a short foamy white layer. Sweet, bready malty nose, slightly buttery with honey and a shy but noticeable, slightly floral hoppy touch. Sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Bready, slightly cara-malty and a bit honey-fruity taste; dry, malty, moderately hoppy finish. Okay.
neutral malt aroma, poor golden, white foam, light bitterness, light body, soft carbonation, astringent,

(bottle, courtesy of Quack-Duck) Clear, golden colour with a fluffy white foam. Moderately sweet, grainy and citrus-fruity hoppy nose. Light-bitter flavour, light bodied with a slightly sharp, fizzy carbonation. Slightly papery and grainy malty taste; dry and moderately bitter finish with metallic hops. Smells pretty good, the rest is very average.

Bottle: Golden, slightly hazy, small foamy head, malty-bready nose with shy bittering hops; light dry bitter-sweet flavour, very light bodied; short dry bitter,a bit perfumed finish. No pleasure......
Looks good, smells very hoppy. Bitter flavour, very hoppy indeed, hardly no malt to taste. Slightly watery, but alright at only 3,8% ABV.

ciemne piwo ale dosc jasne moze jakby cit ciemniejsze niz polotmavy.. Piana srednia i srednio trwala, w miare cos tam na szkle zostaje. Ale w ustach poza przypalonym karmelem nic. I jakby wafle kakaowe sie jadlo.

Rated:27.03.2007, together with chmurarz Bottle brown, 500 ml, extract of wort 10% Very beautiful indeed, quite strong firm, off-white head with brownish shade and the body of dark amber to brown reddish coulur, aroma of pinetree, resin, and slight Bohemian hoppy accent, taste is very bitter with caramel note, hops are very strong so that the aftertaste is dry, but the bitterness is not lager-like but Bohemian pilsener like, which tastes good, aftertaste is dry. Medium to full bodied.

on tap. pretty much what one would expect of a beer from usti nad labem - apparently rough and a bit ugly but with some warming quality underneath it all. faint molasses and raw sugar, touch of plum, light tinny bitterness

500ml bottle, very beautiful indeed, quite strong firm off-white head with brownish shade and the body of dark amber to brown reddish coulur, aroma is pinetree resin and old socks, taste is very bitter with caramel note, hops are very strong so that the aftertaste is dry, but the bitterness is not lager-like bitterness but bitter ale-like bitterness, which tastes good, If the aftertaste was not so dry i would say it is a bitter. medium to full bodied, one of typical czech brews - very bitter,however aroma is kind of stinky and repulsive. I wish I had drunk it on a hotter day
Pours dark brown with a medium head. Aroma has fruits and raisins. Balanced malty taste with a a bit sweet and fruity aftertaste.

Bottled (as Zlatopramen Dark Beer). Dark reddish/black colour with thin brown head. Soft malty aroma with hints of chocolate and apple. Flavour of roasted malt and a bit chocolate and slight bitterness in finish. Very wellbalanced.
[Draught] Reddish brown coloured. Lots of apples in the aroma. Very sweet and malty flavour. Rather thin.
A deep red beer with a beutiful long lasting head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of licorice and caramel. A nice Czech dunkel.
Bottled Dark brown. Tanned small head. Crispy and "citron" and "dry" aroma. Taste is carbonated, sweet malt, mouthfeel is quite full considering very low ABV. Slightly bitter finish.

(Bottled) Clear, very dark reddish brown with a medium, foamy and beige head with not much lace. Mild, roasted-malty aroma with coffee and hints of licorice. Roasty, neutral, slightly burned-malty flavor with hints of coffee. The finish is dryish and slightly ashy with the coffee more evident. No aftertaste to speak of. Almost medium-bodied, yet slightly thin palate with a bit foamy and lemonadey carbonation. Pretty decent dunkel for the ABV. (Bottled, rated Jan 15, 2004, was 5-4-5-3-12=2.9) Dark red color with medium, off-white head. Malty aroma with a hint of perfume. The first sips taste dry and chalky, but after that the flavor changes to sweet. There’s a lot of roasted coffee in the flavor. Overall impression is a bit watery - perhaps this could use somewhat higher ABV.
Nice 14 strong lager. Cereal Taste, balanced palate. looks nicely. Drinkable
Beer with gold color, clear, medium bitterness, some foam in the top, (drunk a 50cl from tap on Clubovna, Brno).
Average strong Lager. Pretty nice color and aroma. Good taste but somewhat of an industrial aftertaste.

Hazy straw color with a white head. The aroma is full of grass and biscuit malt with some sugary notes. The flavor has quite a bit of bitterness. There is some strong pils malt notes as well as some grass and earth notes. There is also a light metallic character. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Bottled , Central Bohemia , CZ , Malt,caramel,butter and some herbal aroma , Clear golden orange color with smaller head , Sweet taste with longer finish , Medium body , Pleasant strong lager.
Sweet, dark golden beer with a long bitter finish. Fizzy, oily texture, some fruityness. Good beer.
Barva: světlejší jantarová. Vůně: lehká sladová. Pěna bílá, řídká nedržící. Chuť: plné pivo s vyšším řízem, sladová chuť, středně hořké, chmelový dozvuk který se mění na sladovou stopu.

Light hazy copper golden body and fine, medium large white head. Peach sweetness, but mild. Only standard malts and Pilsner yeast apart from that. Prickly mouth feel. Medium sweet taste, clearly the alcohol doing its job. Even some heat in the aftertaste. And it’s only 6.5%... Neh, this isn’t for me. (50cl bottle)

Sárgaréz színe van, amin egy buborékos, közepes méretű, fehér és elég kitartó hab terpeszkedik. Illata füves, virágos, komlós és kissé fanyar. Igen malátás íze van, sárga színű gyümölcsökkel, kis élesztővel és egy kis vajas beütéssel, amibe aztán berobban egy jó nagy adag komló, virágosan, keserűen és kissé csípősen. Elég testes, és szénsavas. Utóíze kesernyés, kissé fémes és igen száraz, hosszan tartó. Jó kis szomjoltó, főleg a a keserűbb ízek kedvelőinek ajánlott, de van benne valami érdekes, engem kissé zavaró mellékíz.
Very nice beer with good amount of hop and very good qyality beer, taste is just hwat I need when the day comes to end (warm evening) and I want to drink a strong vell balanced, rounded taste drink

One year old. A deep dark stout with a thin brown head. In aroma, peaty chocolate, boiled veggies, so-so. In mouth, a light sweetish malt with chocolate malt balss, light alcohol, not bad. On tap at Boston Beer Summit, Jan. 15 2011.

Pours an oily opaque black with a small creamy froth of beige head. Has a sweet toasty dark caramel and chocolate nose with some roasty coffee notes. Starts with good rich fullness and sweet dark malts with some plum complexity and a touch of roasty tartness and bitter balance. Finishes slighly drier but still full bodied. An enjoyable imperial stout.
Bottle dated 01.22.08 claiming 9.8% ABV. Sweet balsamic aroma. Very mellow charred coffee flavor that was very lightly sweet. Hints of black olive. Pretty nice.

Thanks to the efforts of Rob (RooftopRogue) and ClarkW. Pours out jet black with little in the way of a head. Rich roasted coffee aroma with hints of anise, molasses, raisins, and a wisp of chocolate that carried over to the flavor. Rich and robust in the mouth with a warm, alcohol feel as you swallowed. Creamy and flavorful. Thanks, Guys!!

Thanks to ClarkVV a few of us in Champaign, IL where able to taste this beer. This beer produces a serious aroma consisting of licorice, molasses, and alcohol. It was black in color and it failed to produce a head. This beer offers the palate a sweet licorice taste that fades to a bitter sweet flavor as the taste of alcohol appears. This beer fades smoothly leaving the taste of oatmeal lingering on the palate. It actually held its own fairly well on a night packed with the heavy hitters of the stout world.

Bottle courtesy of Rob (rooftoprogue). Poured on the night of Edward’s (brooklynboy) surprise tasting. I’m not sure what the last rater was thinking, but this is great stuff. Held its own against the likes of Yeti, Alesmith, Expedition, Southhamption Imperial, and about 20 other stouts rated above 3.95 on this site. A great example of a East Coast style.
