Lots of French Roast Coffee, a lush mouthfeel, raisan, notes of molasses, and full bodied. Great creamyness, possibly from oats? Reminded me a bit of an imperial Kalamazoo. Nice work to WatchCity.
GABF 2003 - The beer is a dark opaque brown with a brown head. It's a bit too thin for an imperial stout, and the flavor is rather sickly-sticky-sweet for my tastes.

22oz bomber from the brewpub, bottled date 12/05/2002. Pour is jet black, with a small dark brown head which quickly recedes and leaves almost no lace. Aroma is roasty, doughy, sweet, with some grape raisin hinting in the back. Flavor is a good punch of sweet chocolate cookie, hints of the grape and raisin, and ends with some good roasty character to it. Full body, slight touch of alcohol in the end, long lingering roastiness adds a good finish.

Same bottle as Hopdog, Weeare138. Tomdecapolis, and Egajdzis. Thanks steve. Pours a nice amber, slight haze and a very thin head. Aroma of spcies like cinnamon and nutmeg, warm apple pie, floral hops and caramel malts. Flavor is also loaded with spices, more cinnamon sweet gale, nutmeg and slight ginger root. Spices get a bit overwhelming, but is nice in a small sample. Could never drink a whole bottle of this stuff.

Thanks to hopdog for this... Bottle has a keg label on it, stating it is 9.1 abv, vintaged ’03. Appears a hazy orange with a small white head and tiny bits of lace. Smell is flowery, sweet caramel candy, with cinnamon and nutmeg standing out. Taste is of spicey, sweet cinnamon with dashes of nutmeg. Mouthfeel is of spicey garbage, along with a half-decent malt balance that just isn’t making up for everything else that is lacking in this brew.

22oz bottle acquired in trade. 2003 vintage. Poured a deeper and slightly hazy amber color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, lots of spices (nutmeg and ginger), and some dark fruits. Tastes of caramel, ginger, nutmeg, and dark fruits. Light alcohol in the finish.

Poured a hazy amber color with a small, off white head that quickly diminished, leaving light lacing on the glass. Aroma of spruce, ginger, light dried fruits, and caramel malts. Taste was full of spices, cinnamon, light ginger, caramel malts, some nuts, light wood, and the alcohol was well hidden.

Thanks to hopdog. Pours an orange amber with not much head. Aroma was very spicy, almost along the lines of a Christmas Ale with the nutmeg and all spice along with some caramel. Flavor of the same with maybe more of the yeast.

2004 bottle, aged a year at the brewpub and sold there for $8.95 a 22oz. Consumed on 12/22/2005. This will be the last bottle I buy from them until I get some assurance that they have corrected their bottling issues. It’s almost as if they have tapped a keg, served half of it and then let the other half sit for a year and the bottled it. Upon opening, there is no carbonation, with a sour and tart mix of spices and old, stale malts. Bready and very medicinal from the nose, with plenty of spoiled fruits. Pouring the dirty, muddy, flat, uncarbonated brownish-date colored liquid and taking a sip, it is intensely oxidized, with muddled maple, brown sugar and caramel malts thick and sluggish in a water medium. 95% oxidation flavors and 5% beer. Truly despicable that they are selling these bottles.

More of a critique than a rating, but some things have to be denounced. This was the 4th Watch City bottle I’ve tried in the last year, 4 different products (spring saison, biere de bordel, obscurite triple brown being the other ones) and they have huge oxidation problems with their bottling line. For having been at the pub, I know they are very good brewers, I consider their scotch ale as one of the best I’ve had, but those bombers they sell for takeout have been at least regularly highly oxidized, usually very low fills that barely reach the bottle necks and very expensive 8-9$. Clark sent them an email and nothing has been done, bottles still being sold, so he suggested I do enter the rating. It is of a headless muddy brown color, flat and without carbonation. Fruity oxidized, earthy nose grows into a nightmare in mouth where total syrupyness fmor the malt strikes heavy oldish spoiled apples and penny-like oxidation that eradicates all the pleasure.

on tap at WBUR’s brewers offering. Good nose, fruity, Plum, raisin, apple come to mind. Nice orange brown color. Small to no head. Sweet, spicy, fruity flavor. Same as aroma with maybe a little pine. Medium bodied, fruity dryish finish.
Art of Beer Fest ’04. Dark brown with a slight haze and a small off-white head.Fruity and spicy aroma. Sweet malt flavor with a hint of caramel and butterscotch.
A little too sweet with caramel and butterscotch flavors. Quite tangy and a little sour, but not very well balanced.
Poured a nice golden color and had a typical IPA scent and flavor. Enjoyed the nice citrus bitterness.
On tap at the brewery, pint size. Very ho hum for the style. Nonetheless enjoyable. The usual players, namely citrus and pine hops. Average mouthfeel.

Pours a slightly hazy copper color, with an inch of nearly white foam. Good lacing througout the glass. The aroma is full of candied peach and mild hops. The malt is light toffee and mildly fruity. It blends into a pronounced pine/citrus hop bitterness. The aftertaste is full of that same pine/citrus. Not quite medium body and smoothly carbonated. I would have liked some more malt, but still this beer is nicely drinkable

From Growler: Nice amber orange with small white head. Piney hop nose with peach , green pineapple and more. med weight with light sweetness and drying bitter finish. Creamy vanilla/peach flavor iwth light pine though a bit light in the mid palate. Great quaffing IPA

Dark Orange Coloring With Big Off White Head. Nice Citrusy Orange Aroma and Hops. Heavy Hops on the Tongue to Begin With...Then The Orange Flavors Come Out Very Nicely...Very Rich Flavor...Like Sucking Juice From an Orange..Dry and Fruity Ending. Excellent IPA !!

Hazy orange color with a medium head. Very nice hoppy aroma with a strong hit of orange. More of the same in the taste, but definitely on the sweet side. There’s a strong malt balance to the hops as well. Certainly not to style, but a damn tasty brew in my opinion.

Very hazy appearance, deep amber hue, nearing on orange, with an acceptable film of froth above. big, juicy aroma, dripping with fruit, cherry pits, drizzling nectarines, brimming over with berries, jumping with juicy fruit. On the palate, a big blitz of hops, and fruitiness, but there’s an overwhelming, how else can I put it, plasticene feel? ...a little soapy?...Just a little sticky-icky, and rubbery, too. Big, beefy presence on the palate, rounded and rimmed with just slightly bitter hoppy flavor, ...I like it okay, but it needs some work.
St. Paul Winterfest 2/8/03. Excuse me, but I got a little sauced this night and was unable to read alot of my notes. I remember her lace she wore and her tastey snatch.
Nice overall hoppy bitterness, a bit on the watery side at the Pittsburgh location.

Brewed by the Minneapolis location and served at Winterfest in St. Paul on Feb. 8. I had tried this brew a year ago on the night they tapped last Spring. I remember it being quite tasty. This time around it had a little bit of a diacetyl finish. Floral, perfumy hops in the nose. Initial mouthfeel is pleasant with fruity hops. But this brew must be heavy on the finishing hops and light on the bittering hops because the bitterness was only skin deep. Had a little bit of a homebrew feel to it as well.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: Cloudy dark yellow with a fizzy white head. Banana bread and bubble gum aroma and taste. Decent.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: GABF:2003 earthy, alcoholic, bitter for the style, carmels, not enough texture and body, good.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: GABF 2003: Cloudy orange without much head. Sweet spicy aroma, average mouthfeel and ends sweet.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: This was my "South Dakota" rating, taken at the GABF in 2003. The address of the brewery was then changed to that of the corporate office in Minnesota. Dark amber. Coriander, cloves, orange and lemon in the nose, but dominated by banana. A bit lacking of carbonation, but the big banana flavor and bread flavor is nice.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: Color is a liquidy off purpley brown with a thin cream colored head thats foamy and fades to leave tiny spots of lace. Smell is a bit faint of sweetish type malts with some raisin and fig, yeast brings out a bit of candy-like notes of toffee and honey glaze. Taste is uneventful unevenness with bland character, weak malts, light raisin and dried fruits of grape and fig, far too sweet, uneven and unpleasant sour notes dart all over. Very light body for a abbey dupple, nearly watery feel and was just plain and boring. This needs alot of help.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: MABR-Brown color,Malty aroma ,caramel and light fruit presence.Alcohol upfront in the taste that turns to a malty flavor with a bitter sweet after taste where the alcohol seemed to reappear.very nice brew I wish i could get more.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: Copper color.All of the qualities of this beer are subdued. Not much in the aroma, not much in the flavor. What little aroma present in the beer was of roasted wood. heavy on the palate.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: Another taste at St. Paul Winterfest 2/8/03. She was very stanky and I think everyone there knew it...including her. Orange in color..sweet but not too sweet. if you know what I mean.

column2: St. Louis Park, Minnesota, United States
column5: Served at Winterfest in St. Paul, MN on Feb. 8. Sweet, somewhat hoppy aroma. Flavor is way off. Has similar flavor profile to the Schultheiss Original Berliner Weiss. I believe it is better than the Schultheiss (which may excite those who like it), but it still isn't good.

Pours a clear brown (dark lighting so hard to see color), thin creamy head. Moderate malt aroma, no hop. Good malt flavor, some sweetness. Medium body, light hop bitterness. Pretty good, but their Alt is better.

On tap at Herkimer Pub & Brewery. Dark brown, ruby lowlights and a thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark malts, and a hint of chocolate and caramel. Thin bodied brew finishes up dry. In between it’s uninspiring with roasted malt and light chocolate.
On tap @ Herkimer. Dark red/brown appearance with a light tan head. Sweet brown malty nose. Slightly hoppy, somewhat nutty, brown malty lager flavor.

Appears darl brown, cloudy, reddish tint. Holding tan head. Aroma of light nuts, pecan and almond. Flavor is mostly of a toasted malt, some coffee, a tiny bit of toffee and sugar. Mostly watery, coffee palate. Not reminiscent of a dunkel, but rather a dunkel gone scotch ale or stout. Light, carbonated mouthfeel, heavy coffee taste on the finish.

On tap at the brewpub on 05/31/2009. Clear dark brown body with ruby highlights and a creamy tan head. Sweet roast and chocolate aroma. Roast, chocolate and mild bitter flavor. Light body with moderate carbonation. Nearly a porter really.
TAP: at the Herkimer, 2.1.09. Pours a dark black, maybe a little red on the edges. Some toffee/malt on the nose, but the taste was not appealing. Overly dry.

On Tap. Dark brown color with pretty small head. Decent lacing. Sweet malty aroma. Rather sweet beer overall. Flavor is sweet malt and chocolate some roasted nut. Little bit of hops in the finish. Pretty decent dunkel. Service at the bar could be a little better though.

This looks like my kind of beer. It even smells and tastes like my kind of beer. Lots of fresh (not burnt) malt with a nice balance of hops and just a dash of vanilla/toffee. The trouble is that it tastes like they took this nice beer and then mixed it with water. There’s a good beer in there, but it takes some work to find it.

Sampled at ABR 07 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Pours a semi-hazy dark brown brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that quickly dissipates to a fine film and white ring. Aroma of roasted multi-grain malt, some flowery hops and a touch of vanilla. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonated with flavors of dark roasted caramel malt, some flowery hops, some mild fruit character and a touch of vanilla. Finish is light, semi-dry with a multigrain malt aftertaste. Probably the best sampling from Herkimer at the ABR.
ABR 2007. Dark brown body with no head. Roasted malts on the nose and similar taste. A little ight on the finish.

Dark brown liquid with a diminish lid of dark tan/brown bubbles. Roasted and black malt scents with just a bit of ash in the background. Light sweet malt mix with smoky malts. Fuller feel that gets trimmed by a bit of acidity. Bits of iodine add a somewhat peaty dimension. Sweet finish and linger. A smoked porter with training wheels.

12oz bottle. Black brown body, rusty beige head. More roast in the aroma than smoke, Pretty weak example of the style. Sort of tastes like a homebrew version of Stoned Smoked Porter. Cheapish feel to it. Drinkable, but unimpressive.

Black with a brown filmy one finger head. The smell is a bit boozy with some smoke, hops, and burnt malts. The flavor on the other hand is a very smooth blend of smoke, licorice, chocolate and malts with no booziness! Body is also pretty light with no carbonation and a very creamy feel to it. I never heard of Mantorville Brewing before I had this beer, but this is a pretty good smoked ale! I’ll be on the lookout for more offerings from them in the future

12 oz. bottle. Pours oily black/brown with a quick little khaki creamy/foamy looking head that leaves a small ring around glass. Aroma has subtle, noticeable smoke and peat along with some good roasted malt and dark fruit like plum, raisin and fig. Taste has a peat/smoke flavor along with nice bitterness and a tangy plum fruit finish. Palate is medium and slick with a dry finish. Very surprised by this beer, quit enjoyable!
Bottle. Black of course. Aroma has roasted grain and coffee. Roast in the flavor, with more coffee, as well as very mild acidic quality. But I do not pick up the smoke in the flavor or aroma.
Has a nice smokey roast and coffee flavor. Has a boozy smokey taste, not bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(bottle) Pours jet black with light red around the edges and a very dark tan head that towers in the glass and takes quite awhile to recede. Aroma initially is very sweet and similar to concord grape juice, with some black licorice and chocolate, yet the smoke is very subdued. As this warms however, the smoke becomes far more apparent, and more roasted malts make their presence known. When cold, the flavor is very weak, with just a bit of smoke in the flavor coupled with an odd sweetness. Initially the beer was overcarbonated which made drinking it quite difficult, and the mouthfeel was very thin. I would suggest giving this beer a lot of time in the glass, because when it warms the aroma and flavor get more smoky, chocolate and dark fruits appear in the flavor, and the carbonation lowers to an appropriate level.

I just visited Mantorville, MN to check out the little brewery in this charming, history rich small town. I meet with owner/brewer Tod Fyten to check out his brewery and talk beer. While I was there, I was able to get a six pack of the newly bottled Stagecoach Smoked Porter that is no longer under agreement in Black River Falls, WI. This is only the second time it’s been bottled and is now bottled in Duluth, MN which stays true to its Minnesota roots. So...lets give it a try. Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a Sam Adams perfect pint. Pours a black, thick viscous liquid with a nice tight mocha head. This one is as dark as night. In the nose I get notes of chocolate, coffee, peat smoke, and tobacco. There is a good amount of sweet roasted malts that blend well around the palate and finishes with a touch of smokiness. This almost has a spongy-like mouthfeel that starts out very smooth and ends with a little carbonation bite. Overall, this is a very enjoyable porter that I would recommend giving a try.
Rich and bold flavors from a dark brown body, though the smoke notes (not intensely smokey, just roastsed) are paired with a lactic/sour twinge that is less than ideal for my taste. Bottle.
Pours dark brown with off white head, aroma is smoky. Taste up front is chocolate leading into a bit of smoky flavor that ends bitter and roasted. Average of the style.
Bevuta alla spina alla festa di quartiere. Forte prevalenza del malto sul luppolo. Fgr

Tra il dorato carico e l’ambrato, schiuma bianca poco persistente. Aroma di orzo maltato e leggera crosta di pane. Al palato attacca dolce sempre con malto d’orzo per poi passare ad un tostato di crosta di pane con una coda erbacea e lievemente piccante. Corpo leggero, ben carbonata.
Aroma of malt and light hops. Pours golden clear with big white head some lacing. Tastes slightly sweet note of corn and honey with a weak hop finish that is short. Drinkable.
A marzenek marzene, oktoberfestbierek oktoberfestbierje. Über alles. Mindenekfelett.
amber medium head malty caramel note medium low bitterness caramello ben ambrato amaro contenuto

Intenso color biondo con soffice schiuma bianca. Aroma piuttosto banale e classico, discretamente maltato e luppolato. Gusto dolciastro, improntato sul malto piuttosto che sul luppolo con poca complessità; corpo medio-lieve ma finale persistente.
Draft. An amber beer with an orangey head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and light notes of metallic hops.
dark amber Color. Bready, caramel med body. Malty, moderately dry. Again, like other beers I had, it was not bad, but not outstanding.
Questa marzen non mi è dispiaciuta anzi, l’ho trovata molto bevibile, maltosa che lascia un discreto palato.

Wonder why there arer only 6 notes for this beer? Pretty simple marzen with straight forward sweet caramel malts and very low hop impact. Not a lot of appeal for me here but the simple sweet malts will have its fans.
Cask at The St. Albans Beer Festival 2013. Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, earthy notes and cocoa. Reasonably good body for a mild. Roasty and caramel flavours.

Cask at PoW, Farnborough. Low key sour chocolate aroma. Opaque cola brown. A few beige bubbles cling to the rim. Initially light bitter before some underlying creamy choc sweetness comes through. Sour berry edge. Medium bodied. Slick verging on creamy. Long dry astringent finish. OK if bland.

Cask at GBBF '18, day 1, 07/08/18. Black with a well presented lasting tan covering. Nose is brown bread, toffee, dried fruits, grains. Taste comprises liqourice, spice, fruit slice, dried frutis, brown bread, nutty, toffee. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close. Decent mild.
Cask at GBBF 2018, Olympia, London. A dark brown coloured pour with a small beige head on top. Roasty, malty, chocolate on the nose. Tastes similar, roasty, malty, chocolate.

Cask at GBBF. It pours deep brown with a small beige head. The aroma is earthy, umami, leather, liquorice, spice, tangy, treacle and chocolate. The taste is slick, oily, umami, liquorice, earthy, bark, cacao nibs, ashy, treacle and fruit cake with a slick finish. Medium body, fine carbonation and slick mouth feel. Not too shabby.
Cask @ Charlies Bar. Dark reddish brown with a small tan head. Malty and roasted tones. Malt, coffee, fruit and hops. Light body with a long bitter / roasted finish.
Cask at Wallington BF 2007. (Backlog / historic rating from old records. NO tasting notes taken / kept) (Backlog)
Cask at Greyhound, Hartshill. Pours brown with a light tan head. Plum, slight sour fruit, smooth. Decent mild.

Cask at Charlie’s. Dark chestnut brown with a medium sized light brown head with good retention and lace. Brown sugar, light hazelnuts, twigs, mild syrup, dark rye bread, light roasted malt. Medium body, soft texture, light to medium sweet and bitter. Dry finish.
Cask @ Dove Street, Ipswich. Medium head with medium duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, hops, fruits, caramel and has a nice bitter finish.
Bottle at the 'Back to the Roots Classic German Beer Tasting' session. I only took numerical notes while having this.
Sampled at Müllerbräu Pfaffenhofen. Semi lasting beige head. Opaque red brown color. Nice malty sweetness that lingers. Big body. Low banana aroma.

Bottle: Almost clear, chestnut-amber coloured, smaller off-white creamy head; mild caramelly nose with cacao and some zesty traces, wheat and yeast far away; mainly sweet flavour, a very faint acidity still detectable, light to medium bodied and a bit sticky; shorter sweet caramelly finish with traces of dry cacao-powder. O.K., but a bit monotonous…
Pours a dark brown color. Aromas of bread, malt, and some fruit. Flavor has a touch of sweet malt and clove.

50 cl bottle @ Timo A. BBE 21.08.2015. Pours hazy dark orange-brown color with a small head. Sourish fruity aroma, malty, some wheat and wheat. Strong carbonation, wheat and yeast on the flavor, slightly fruity. Decent. 3223

500 ml bottle. Thanks Timo A. Pours a dark hazy orange amber colour with a small foamy head. Aroma of sweetness, some herbal notes and bread. Flavour of banana, herbal hops, bready maltiness, sweetness and some grass. Medium bodied. A bit foamy mouthfeel. Decent.

500ml bottle. Very nice, hazy chestnut colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, beige head. Wheaty, fruity, yeasty aroma, notes of banana, hints of apple, a nuttily malty touch, some clove, some mustard-like spiciness. Taste is slightly sweet wheat malty, some banana, a touch of apple and clove, minimally tart fruit acid counterpart. Nice surprise.

Bottle 500ml. @ home on the terrace. [ As Müllerbräu Müller Weißbier Dunkel ]. Unclear medium to dark brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, wheat, chocolate notes, moderate yeasty, weissbier yesat, light banana, clove notes. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, caramel, sweet malt, fruity, soft banana - warm banana, light clove, chocolate notes. Body is medium, texture is creamy - watery, carbonation is soft. [20150426]

Bottle. Dark amber, average and mostly diminishing head. Moderate, malty - some wheat and lightly sweetish aroma, faint sourness, light caramel with light banana. Body is medium, malty – some wheat and lightly sweetish flavor, light caramel and faint bread with light banana. Finish is average malty – lightly wheaty and lightly sweetish, light caramel and faint bread, light banana and faint sharp metal. Not too sweet but really nothing special.
Milchig trübes orangebraunes Bier mit ordentlicher weißer Schaumkrone. Geruch fruchtig, malzig, leicht hefig, Karamell. Geschmack süß malzig, Malzbonbons, Karamell, hefig, Gewürze.

Bottle 33cl. @ home. Clear light sparkling, medium to dark yellow color with a large to huhe, frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy hoppy, grass, moderate to heavy yeasty, barnyard, tart sour notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, and a dry and peppery finish. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090426]

(Bottled, BBE 31.7.2009) Clear golden with a medium, foamy and cloudy, lacy head. Aroma is quite original with cookies, coconut, ripe fruit, and lambic-like tartness. Pale-grainy maltiness and quite evident tartness in the flavor, with hints of caramel and Xmas cookies. Almost medium body, pretty foamy carbonation (but strangely it suits this one). A very strange brew, and very hard to categorize. To me, this feels like 70% Xmas-Orval-spiced tripel and 30% lambic, but your mileage may vary. BBE is gone a few weeks ago, but I doubt it matters much.
33cl, from De Bierloods Adegem, not complex brew, not balanced, hazy, good head, nice brew
Bottle, 33 cl. (bought @ Bierloods) Almost clear darkgolden color, with white head. Aroma fruits, malts, bit yeast. Medium body. Taste sweet, fruit and alcohol touch, bitterness end.

Nose of grains, malt, cocos, a sweet smell that is characteristic for the brewery; later some citrusfruit notes too, and other yeasty aromas. Colour is dull (yeast somewhat in suspension) orange. Very fine, slightly irregular white head, quite stable. Sweet taste, with typical fruity, orangey-bitter surrounding. Like it or loathe it - I could do with a little less sweetness. It is not cloying. Retronasal gets notes from orange-filled chocolate. Definitely alcohol in the mouthfeel, reasonably full-bodied. The taste keeps evolving, in the aftertaste, the flavours turn to some kind of fruit-liqueur, quite pleasing. To be honest, this brewery gives me the creeps for its unending label-story. Pierlala is a labelbeer for the town of Ursel, probably Augustijn. But, as the hands are shown, there isn't much wrong with the beer itself. You could get much worse...

Pours hazy copper, brief cream head of faint bubbles form a ring. Nose is earthy, caramel malts, bread and some lager characteristics. Flavors of sweet malts, grain, brown sugar. Subtle hop finish. Short finish. Balanced. Good ESB and very drinkable. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle courtesy of the Tampa Crew. Pours hazy caramel color with a white head. Nose is malt, vegetal notes, celery, spice, and bits of biscuity malt with some earthy hops. Flavor is similar- large cooked veggie nose followed by biscuity malt and earthy hops. Light in body and some earthy hops in the finish.

Bomber from Whole Foods Market Columbus, OH. Pours a clear amber color with a large creamy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of caramel and toffee malts, floral hops, fruity notes and faint nuttiness. The taste is caramel malts, bubblegum, fruit notes and a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied. Pretty tasty.

Pours an amber color with an off-white head. Aroma is of floral hops, caramel malts, and a very slight hint of alcohol. Flavor is a little week with the caramel malts coming out pretty strong. Light floral hops as well.

Bottle from the brewery. Pours a cloudy golden colour, with a white retained head of one-quarter inch. Mild malty and faint hoppy aroma. Above average mouthfeel, understated hoppiness and a balance that was good wth a meal. Very good drinkability. Very pleasant for the style.

medium brown, mild head. nose of some floral hops and medium crystal malt. moderate bitterness with crystal malt before nice floral hops. overall the residual sweetness ends up being a bit high, though it is drinkable, a bit sweet for the style

Bottle. Poured clear dark amber hue with a large frothy off-white head that Mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium aroma of hops, malt. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Well balanced flavor of malt, hops with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. This is a good brew with a steak from the grill.

July 17-19, 2008: Buckeye Yuppie ESB has lots of fresh citrusy and slightly minty hops in the aroma. The flavor is soft ans has a slightly buttery flavor. This beer has a hazy, bright copper color, light beige-colored foamy head, and a smooth, mellow medium body. Overall it is a good ESB with more hops than expected. Draught sample (45 IBU, 5.5% ABV)at Skipper’s Bar & Grille in Athens, Ohio during Ohio Brew Week 2008. Rating #17 for this beer.

Sample at Neil’s HSC initation. The beer pours a hazy bright orange color with a medium thin off-white head that diminishes steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel and earthy malt. Medium, clean body with flavors of caramel malt, light hops and a bit of bread. The finish is sweet and malty with a lingering caramel aftertaste. Overall an average ESB that skews too far on the sweet side.
22oz bottle purchased at Buckeye Beer Engine. Pours a cloudy amber with a medium white head. Caramel malt aroma with just a touch of hops. Corn and caramel malt flavor with barely any hop character.

Schön dunkelgold im Glas, würzig-malziger Geruch. Der Antrunk ist vollmundig-süßlich und leicht erdig. Der Hauptteil ist noch einen kleinen Tick mehr erdig-würzig und schön angenehm muffig. Leider keine Röstmalzanklänge vorhanden. Im Nachgeschmack kommt eine angenehme Herbe hinzu, die den etwas mufffig-modrigen Charakter dieses Bieres noch etwas unterstreicht. Auf der Zunge verbleibt eine angenehm süßlich-würzige Note, gepaar mit einem angenehm herb-muffigen Ton! → Ein sehr leckerer Bock. Nicht zu süß und nicht zu herb! 13+12+12+12

Tap in a steinkrug. The head is creamy and lasting. The aroma has notes of caramel, candy sugar, roasted malt, chocolate and cocoa. The flavor is sweet with a light bitterness and notes of licorice, candy sugar, roasted malt, carameæ. light raisin and nuts - it’s quite delicious!
Bottle pours amber colour with a white head. Aroma of yeast, citrus and a bit of hops. Taste is sweet malt.

Bottle 500ml. @ home. Clear medium yellow orange colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate to light light heavy malty, hay, toasted, pale malt, sugar, bock alike aroma, sweet malt, polish stark bier malt notes. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, sweet malt, dry, bock alike. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110818]
500 ml bottle in Germany, Yellow-brown color, white quick to leave head, good lace. Malt and fruit aroma. Sweet, fruity ends slightly bitter, malty. A nice Heller Bock.
Bottle@Home. Malty and apple aroma. Amber color, off-white head, good lace. Sweet, bitter, very herbal, apple, rather malty, medium body.

Amber color. Malty aroma with candy sugar and caramel. Caramelly sweet, slightly herbal flavor. Full bodied beer, packed with malt. Flowery hops, next to the sugary maltiness in the aftertaste. Likeable, but not the best bock available.
Bottle. Clear amber / orange colour with a small moslty diminishing white head. Sweet aroma and taste. Not much hops in this one. Below usual german bock standard.
Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishinghead. Orange colour. Nce moderate hoppy and light malty aroma. Sweet flavor. Light bitter average finish. Oily palate. Nice beer.
Pleasant smell, a little malty. Nice bronze colour. Warm malty and fresh flavor with a pretty, bitter finish. Hops are very concisely.

On the afternoon of Tuesday 17th May 2016 I visited The Tustin Brewery and had one of the most disappointing flights of beer I have ever had. Beer number seven of the eight and the best so far. Mahogany red with just a collar around the rim for a head. Malts rule this semi-sweet brew with molasses pushing through a caramel flavouring and aroma.
Red real clear garnet, malty but lean real drinkable, great carbonation. Bett
Sampled at Great American Beer Festival 9/24/15. Notes of caramel malt, toffee and light fruity esters. Pretty straightforward stuff here. OK.

Tap at the brewpub. Pours ruddy brown with a beige head. Aroma is a little nutty with roasty malt. Med body. Flavor is a little nut, a little chocolate. Cross between amber and brown? Gets a citrus note in the finisf.
30 June 2014, tap at Tustin Brewery. Red/amber, clear, no bubbles. Nose is toasty malt. Med body and moderately fizzy. Bready, toasted malt, a bit acidic. Decent.
Draft at the brewery. Clear red amber pour, with an off white head. Caramel malt, bread, notes of nuts, and a bit of fruit. Malt forward amber, but rather boring.
Draft. Pours amber with a thin head. Caramel malts, light bready notes, and faint fruity citric hops. Balanced; not bad.
Tap. Pours a red to brown color with moderate white to tan head. Aroma is chewy malt, slight marsh mellow something going on. Taste, meh. Not complex and nothing exciting.
(Draught) Pours a clear amber body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of caramel, grass, wet leather, and nuts. Flavor of caramel, roasted grain, bread, and earth.
Reddish pour. White head. Floral hops and caramel malt. Simple, boring and not worth the effort.

On the afternoon of Tuesday 17th May 2016 I visited The Tustin Brewery and had one of the most disappointing flights of beer I have ever had. This was beer number three and I was hoping for some vanilla, yeast and banana action from this misty, dull yellow brew: sadly I have to report that not a lot was going on in my glass apart from a little citrus note or two in an otherwise very un-Hefe like beer.

Tap. Pours quite hazy pale golden, medium creamy white head, good lacing. Aroma is faint, hints of wheat and lemon. Flavor is light plus sweet, hint of bitterness, wheat and grain, lemon zest. Medium body, some acidity. No actual hef esters.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours gold with a creamy white head. Lemon aroma. Med minus body. Flavor is a little bready after the lemon leaves. Maybe a banana hint. Finishes lemon/wheat.
30 June 2014, tap at Tustin Brewery. Orange and a bit hazy. Nose is a bit yeasty and sweet. Med body and mildly fizzy. A bit watery or mild, light yeast notes. Meh.
Draft at the brewery. Hazy straw yellow pour, with a soapy white head. Dry wheat bread, lemon peel, hay, and light notes of banana sweetness and fruity esters. Overall quite dry for a wheat beer.

Draft. Pours hazy gold with a thin head. Wheaty and light yeasty, with light generic citrus notes, and a dry yeasty finish. A little overcarbonated, and slightly higher on bitterness that is typical for the style.
Tap at the pub. Rating #30. Very cloudy and thick dark golden yellow. Mild aroma and flavor, slightly fruity, mostly citrus, but not over the top. (2570)
Cloudy yellow pour, white head. Aroma of stale malt, lemon peel and wheat. Flavor is wheat and lemon, water.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a very hazy pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy bitter citrus flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy finish.
(Draught) Pours a cloudy maize body with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, banana, straw, and lemon. Flavor of lemon, wheat, and mineral with a dry finish.
(Draught) Pours a clear pale yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of grain, mustiness, nuts, and sulfur. Flavor of grain, grass, and cereal.

On the afternoon of Tuesday 17th May 2016 I visited The Tustin Brewery and had one of the most disappointing flights of beer I have ever had. This was beer number two. Pale golden pour, weak white head that faded quickly. Slight farmyard aroma, then nothing worthy of note in the nose or taste, must have really subtle flavours because I could not find any.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours light gold with a lacing white head. Light citrus aroma. Med minus body. Flavor is bread/citrus, and there seems to be a touch of salt. Finishes very, very lightly bitter.

30 June 2014, tap at Tustin Brewery. Light yellow, clear, no bubbles. Nose is light lemon, sweet, straw malt, some skunky lager hops. Thin body and moderately fizzy. Lemon, maybe lemon candy, slightly sweet, a bit bitter. Nice and refreshing.
Draft at the brewery. Clear pale yellow pour, with a white head. Dry grain, light sweetness, and a touch of bitterness. Pretty bland and watery, but still makes for a refreshing blonde.
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Plain grainy and pale malts, with very light flowery bitterness, and light earthy notes. Decent, I guess.
Palest of yellow, white head. Watery aroma of old hops and spent grains. Flavor is o light and barely anything noticeable. Not offensive, but not good.

On tap at the brewery during RBSG 2012. Is this a second-runnings beer? Or maybe a fifth-runnings beer? Nothing stands out at all, other than the inherent drinkability of a beer that has barely any character. Kinda-sorta pale/honeyed malt, I guess.

On draft at the brewpub. It pours golden yellow with a small white head. The aroma is light grainy with hints of noble hops and light breadiness. The flavor has stronger notes of noble hops with some grains. It has a nice light frothy mouthfeel and a spicy bitter finish. Really a nice blond ale.

On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Clear golden with a medium sized white head and good lacing Aroma: Light malts and some citrus Taste: Pale malts, honey, grassy with a nice bitter finish A nice beer, easy to drink and has a bite too it.

On the afternoon of Tuesday 17th May 2016 I visited The Tustin Brewery and had one of the most disappointing flights of beer I have ever had. Beer number four of the eight and I am beginning to think I made a mistake coming here. Light amber in colour with a white wisp for a head, this beer had a strange chemical taste, the first beer on the flight to actually have a taste, so at least we are finally getting somewhere.
Light malt aroma with northwest hop variety aroma as well. Hoppy bitter taste very crisp and refreshing, have with the spicy wings.

Tap at the brewpub. Pours dark gold with a white head. Citrus aroma. Med body. Flavor is very strong earthy/citrus hop. Malt is roasty, but somehow it also seems not roasty. Finishes bitter and hoppy.
30 June 2014, tap at Tustin Brewery. Orange, clear, no bubbles. Nose is lemon hops and some cereal malt. Med body and mildly fizzy. Lemon rind and mild cereal malt. Faint bitterness. Decent.
Tap at Tustin, A nice way to finish an evening of drinking, but this one is mild and bland a suitable beer for those venturing to the hop side, but not enough punch and too much malty finish for me.

On draft. Clear golden pour, with a white head and some lacing. Moderately hoppy aroma, with flavors of caramel malt, bread, light hops, and some citrus. Not a very interesting pale ale, rather bland.

Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Fruity and lightly piney hops, with light malty sweetness. Bright and clean and drinkable, with great hops flavor and not a ton of unnecessary bitterness. All those nerds below me clearly don’t know how to drink beers, with one was pretty damn good.
(Draught) Pours a clear orange body with a medium white head. Aroma of grass, earth, and caramel. Flavor of grass, orange, grapefruit, earth, and minerals.
Sparkling gold color, white head. I smelled some hops in this along with biscuity malts. But the flavor left me wondering where the hops were. Malty with spent hops on the finish. Meh.
On tap at the brewery during RBSG 2012. Pours clear pale gold. Metallic hops, light fruitiness, mostly a plain malty brewpub beer. Other reviews called this very hoppy but I just don’t see it.
(Bottle) Pours a clear pale yellow body with a spare white head. Aroma of light citrus and florals Flavor of malt with a watery mouthfeel.
Light gold with a soft sparkle. Slightly grassy, limey aroma with faint pale malt background. Soft palate with hints of french bread and hay.
Absolutely horrible. No aroma to speak of, a VERY pale yellow color, and virtually no taste. Beer-flavored water at best. Skip this one if you ever see it.
Grumligt ljusgul i färgen, vitt skum. Doftar citrus gräs, lime, metall. Smakar friskt, vattnigt, citrus lime metall, jästigt torr på slutet. Trist.
Bottle. Clear golden/yellow color. Aroma is malty with some lemon in it. Taste is a bit watery with some malt and grass. Very thin,
Bottle from Switzerland.Clear pale yellow colour and white head. Aroma and taste of lemon and lite malts. Wheat ale?? Pale ale I think. Very watery and boring finish, but it´s beautiful bottle....
(Bottle) Pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of corn and grain. Flaor of malt and light lemon with a water mouthfeel.
Pale straw colour. Slightly lemony aroma. Light, slightly lemony body. Very quick finish.
Claims to be a wheat beer, but there is only the slightest wheat flavor. But much more palatable than a lot of chinese beers. Pale yellow color, and a slight wheat aroma.

Poured from 610 ml bottle at Kaiyi's Kitchen in Dali, China. Label indicates 12°. Clear, sparkling, light golden yellow with a small white head and fair lacing, both of which disappear quickly Aroma of light caramel malt and rice. Taste of light caramel malt and rice with a hint of hops. Light/medium body and gentle carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Yellow. Fizzy. Bland. Slightly grassy flavour and aroma. Slightly tart finish.

Bland unexciting aroma of malt. Yellow color that is not very attractive. Good carbonation though. A mild chemical taste, that might be green tea, but I'm never sure with Chinese beers. Heavy flavor of rice. Avoid

Big bottle. Thanks A. Pours gold, two second fizzy head. Nose of acetaldehyde, flavour has some Asahi dryness going on. No vegetables at least. Finish is rough. Asian beer is just as bad as I remember it, the North Americans rating Bud and Coors as the worst they’ve ever tried really have no idea.

Poured from 470 ml bottle at restaurant in Lijiang, China. Clear bright yellow with tiny white head and fair lacing both of which dissipate quickly. Looks exactly like . . . Well, you know. Mild ricy aroma once the beer warms a little. Taste of rice. Not strong. Unpleasant astringent aftertaste. Thin body with high carbonation. Unpleasant mouthfeel. An absolutely dreadful beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
(Bottle) Pours a clear yellow body with a moderate white head. Aroma of soapiness and sweet corn. Flavor of grain and corn.
Golden with a soft sparkle. Appley aroma bears perhaps some lightstruck notes. Fizzy, malty, grainy. Kind of sweet.

Another generic Chinese beer. For all of the different beers in this country, you'd think they'd taste a little different. Anyway, a malty aroma, golden color, mild carbonation, and generally uninteresting flavor. But a 22oz is about $.68
330ml bottle. Poured a very thin pale yellow with absolutely no head at all. There was very little aroma to speak of and the taste was watery and thin - no substance to this beer at all.
Awful corn fired watery mess with a nasty metallic aftertaste. Not even a proper kick due to low ABV. Cheap and grainy. Bad.

...bottle. Didn’t realize this was a mid-strenther, but couldn’t really tell. Watery, light bodied mouthfeel, with hints of malt. Other than that, nothing, it was cheap, but still not really worth it because it has no alcohol, there are other better choices if you just want to get ripped.
Good head,gold colour beer,carbonation good.Head back to lace cover.Aroma good hops and malt a mushroom smell.Flavour bitter,hops,metallic taste bitter finish as well as metallic.
Sorry Sully from Stanmore. This beer is very ordinary but I’m reasonably sure that it is not mid-strength. I’m drinking one at the moment (oh dear!) and it says 5% alc. vol.
This is a very average beer. However, if you are on a tight budget is very good value for money - how many beers do you see for less than AU$25 per carton??
bottled. standard yellow, fizzy stuff. light body, cardboard, a hint of bitterness, that’s all

Mid strength beers are the lost soul of the beer world. They meander from pub to pub trying to ply their wares to those drinkers who can’t choose between full strength and light. At this ABV you are getting one standard drink which means that the allure for designated drivers is not there either. In keeping with the XXXX style of midstrength this one is called gold, because it is valuable or desirable? No, more likely that it is metallic and would appeal to sheilas.

This beer is the midstrength version of the Haagens regular malt lager, and I COULDN’T PICK OUT A DIFFERENCE! Pale golden, clear, medium head. Pretty boring. Sweet malt is really all you get for flavour (the same as all corn-adjunct, over-processed pale lagers on the market). I wouldn’t choose to drink it again if an alternative were available, but I wouldn’t turn it down if the beerfridge was empty on a Friday night. This is my standard review for all "two-star-or-less" piss. Surprising, given this is supposed to be from an "independent brewer"-- it doesn’t taste much different from the macro brewers lagers.
a good drinking beer good overall flavor and texture dosent have the body of regal but a good midstringth beer

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: Hmm, the beer we tried was called Shark Bite Imperial Red Ale... Not sure if that’s the same beer or not, but it was tasty! Loads of malt to balance out the incredible amount of hop presence. This one is thick and syrupy, like liquid gold. Smooth and very mellow in spite of how big this beer is. Very nice.

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: Clear, deep red with a short off-white head. Hoppy, citrus aroma. Good pine and resin qualities as well, with very little malt. More flavor that the Shark Bite, but still nicely balanced. Grapefruit, oranges, wood, malt, and a little caramel.

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: On tap. Clear dark brown and reddish in coloured with a small head. Both malty and hoppy. Starting sweet and finishing bitter.

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: Bottled, snagged from BevMo. Good tasting brew, hangs somewhere between a good Red and a good single IPA. More malty and smoother than a full IPA, but a little complex in flavor like and IPA. I have only been to the PizzaPort site once, and I am way overdue for libations down that way...

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: Hazy red amber, lasting off white head.Hop nose. Tart fruity hop taste with lasting finish.Good body.

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: Damn good amber ale. Hoppy, but not too hoppy. Seems almost to be their flagship ale, the restaurant is rarely without it. And I can’t seem to leave without having one every time. Malty enough to satisfy hunger. Hoppy enough to make you hungry. Huh?

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: On tap from the brewpub. Tasted during trip to California. Brown colour. Some aroma of nuts and sweetness. Really amazing taste, extreme tasteful and light at same time. This is a "most try" if you come to Pizza Port (Solona Beach).

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: On tap at the 2005 OBF. Pours mahogany with a small off-white head. Big citrus hops in the nose giving this beer a very crisp, long trailing, bitter finish. Malts tasted kinda caramel and cerealy. Nice beer, but the bitterness just stays with you forever.

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: had this at OBF. amber pour, with a light head. malty aroma, a little hops in there too. decently full mouthfeel, caramelly malt base and a good bite from the piney hops to balance it. this was ok but pretty "meh"

column1: Pizza Port Shark Bitten Double Red Ale
column5: Poured a nice bubbly 1 inch head at the Oregon Brew Festival, that faded quick. Sweet nose, yet a bit more bitter then my nose prepared me for. Strong malty carmel taste with a hoppy finish.

Pulled from the cask at Port Solana. Pours a golden color with a very nice white head. Aroma is malty sweet and citrusy hops. Flavor is light malty sweet mild hops citrus. Light citrus finish. Good beer.

Resinous green hops oversee their citrusy friends in a quite quaffable number…Pineapples floating around for good measure help to balance it all out with their intrinsic sweetness…A competent and tasty thirst pharmacist…

(Nitro Draft: Pizza Port in Solana Beach, CA) A light style pale ale, mellow like an English pale ale, and kind of boring actually for a Pizza Port beer; It’s on nitro, so the pour is a full glass of creamy white head that eventually settles to a half-inch thick, white, creamy head; Very mellow flavor, lightly malty with some mild bitterness and citrus; Light, smooth and creamy on the palate; The mild nose is lightly hoppy with a bit of citrus; Light golden color; Lacing is more clumpy and dense than fine and delicate; NOTE to ratebeer admins: even the Pizza Port beer menu calls this a pale ale

On tap@Solana beach pub: Rich golden color with a small (bar pour) creamy white head. Nose is sweet with a hint of citrus. Flavor starts light and sweet followed by a touch of light grapefruit and a lightly bitter finish. IPA? More of an extra pale IMHO. Good with pepperoni pizza with extra cheese.
Served on nitro, it poured extremely smooth and fluffy. Aroma and apperance are more like a Pale than an IPA. Slightly bitter and fruity. Finished more bitter than expected.

Light gold color. VERY large creamy head. The pour looked like a blond Guinness. Aroma is a touch citrusy and fruity. My nose made a huge dent in the foam while testing for aroma. A very creamy, medium bodied IPA. Fruity and a touch sour. Malts are fruity with a touch of banana. Hops are spicy and floral. Sort of understated for an IPA. Very creamy. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter with a touch of banana about halfway through.

Yummy hops, honey, and gardinia in the nose. Most of wich goes into the mouth with mellow resins, a little musk, malt, fresh hop flowers, and a hint of vannila. Finishes with a thick and toasty charactor but still manages a dryness. Unfortuanatly I think the nitro killed a little of this.

This was listed as a Pillbox Pale on the board but while I was drinking it I classed it as closer to an IPA and am therefore figuring it's the same beer. Poured from the cask it looks like a cloudy Boddington's, never really clearing up, with a good thick enduring foam. Sweet lemon and orange aroma, creaminess on the palate but relatively light in body. Sweet fruity and lightly biscuity malts, lemon hop flavors and a hint of honey. Finishes fairly dry with a touch of grapefruit.

This was a very nice PA. It was the perfect brew to start off a night of hard beer drinking. Very nice hops up front, but it ended up with a weak watery taste, kind of like a reverse mullet- all party up front, business in the back.
smooth and nutty. thin and with a bit of gravy and sweetness. some hop and malt and a bit of beery in the finish.

En botella.Color marron con buena espuma q desaparece poco a poco pero no se queda.Aromas a maltas caramelicadas y nueces.Suavemente lúpulada,cuerpo medio.No es la mejor brown ale,pero es muy interesante.un poco dulce.
Brown with a thin brownish-tan head. Malty with a caramel-like sweetness. A bit thin, but smooth. Hints of nuts.
12oz bottle. Pours dark red/brown with a small creamy head. Aroma of syrup, heavy malts, caramel, toffee, toasted nuts. Flavour mainly of nuts, caramel, and malt. Quite thin.

12 oz. bottle, pours dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma of toasted malts, nuts and a little caramel sweetness. Flavour is quite light, with nuts, toasted malts and some sweetness - sort of a muted, metallic finish. Decent but nothing special.
Bottle. Light brown, clear, thin tan head. Sweet, almost a little syrupy aroma -- heavy malt. Medium body and carbonation. Strong nutty taste and finish. A little too nutty for my preference.

pint at Tylers Apex, 3/20/11. Good aroma, sweet, malty. Nutty, salty, a red wine streak about it. Brownish orange color, ok head and lace. Bitter flavor, Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, mild bitter, sweet finish. Tasty, flavor had a nice citrus bite mixed with chocolate and caramel. Good brown

On tap at The Monk. Pours a brown red. Lots of red tinges on the edge with a small white beige head. Aroma is predominately sweet caramel malts and chocolate. Flavour brings out peanuts, salt and sweet malts. Palate is a little watery. Just ok

On tap at Urge for the Total Tap Takeover with BP and GF. Malty red/brown pour. Total brown ale. Nice malty sweetness to it, but with enough body behind it to make it worthwhile. Nuttiness lingering. Not bad.
One of my least favs of gf beers, it smells like yeast and toasted malts. Taste is bitter malts and slightly wheat tasting. It’s ok but not my fav.

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: A great porter. This recipe made the transfer to Ortleibs Brewery and Grille at Sunnybrook. Excellent vanilla aroma, and a smooth, dry, vanilla finish.

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: What an excellent example of a flavored dark beer, just about black in color with an awesome soft lacy tan head that followed the beer all the way down the glass, rich malty profile, the perfect amount of vanilla in the flavors & aftertaste to blend everything together, sweet malty aftertaste, very smooth, very drinkable, could have sat in there all night & drank this one, awesome porter

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: This is a good winter warmer. I had this recipe lasy Christmas at Sunnybrook, and they have promised to make it a yearly brew. Well worth trying if you are in the area.

column4: Ortliebs Brewery & Grille at Sunnybrook Ballroom
column5: A little below average when it comes to this style of a seasonal, amber in color, soft lacy white head, more of a hoppy profile than a big malty one that provides a lot of the alcohol associated with this style, a little unbalanced toward the hoppiness

pours a clear amber color with an decent head. Aroma of malt, mild citrus and grass. Taste of malt sweetness, bit of grain and citrus in the background. Mild bitterness and a clean finish. fairly light body, quite smooth and a pleasant feel, although there a tinge of metal as it warms. Decent beer, nice change from all the Pils.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, süß, leicht würzig. Geschmack röstmalzig süß, leicht fruchtig.

#358 Bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit cremigem Schaum. Verhalten getreidiges Aroma. Im Antrunk erstaunlich frisch und gehaltvoll, einem guten Export ähnelnd. Leicht röstmalziger Geschmack, schön rezent und hopfig-herb ausklingend. Könnte für meinen Geschmack noch ne Nuance würziger sein. Nichtsdestotrotz ein gutes Bier, irgendwo zwischen Märzen und Export. Gelungen! Test vom 11.4.2011, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,9,12,11,10,11 - 10,90

The beer in the glass is amber-colored, with a beautiful sparkling head. It smells malty bitter and hoppy-flowery, very bitter. Starts with a well balanced malt body with some caramel. The middle part shows some caramel and aroma hops. The finish is malty-bready, caramelly with a subtle hop aroma.
Small head. Pretty straightforward. Not much on character. Some good hops. That’s about it.
I really like this local beer. It is different than most other beers in the area. Kind of a brown beer.

Pours light amber with small head. Nondescript aroma. Starts out okay-ish while cold, but as the beer heats up it quickly loses carbonation and gains a rather unpleasant funky metallic flavour. Not good.

Das mit Abstand beste Bier der Brauerei! Die Schaumentwicklung ist zwar mies, das Bier selber allerdings ist durchaus gut trinkbar. Der Mittelteil besticht vor allem durch de süß-herben Geschmack, ehe es im Nachgeschmack sekündlich malziger wird und genau im richtigen Moment aufhört, noch malziger zu werden. Ordentliches Bier! Test vom 16.6.2005, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,10,12,12,8,9 - 10,00

Bottled thanks Bierkrug! Almost clear amber, rich firm head. Some metal shows up in the nose, between doughy malt and grassy hops. Dry and crisp with slim body and rounded mouthfeel. Doughy malt lies as a firm foundation, the salty grassy finish becomes gradually more bitter. Notes of blood and metal lies on a distance and ruins some of the fun.
Bottle. Amber color, thin, sugar, moderate carbonation. Nothing that stands out in the end. Easy to drink.
OBF. Very nice mix of dark fruit and caramel malts. Cherries might add another dimension, but they don’t jump out at you. Still, very nice Dubbel.

750 Thanks to the brewer of FF. Pour is muddy ruby color with thin dissapating head. Nose is cherries, sour, and some malt. Flavor was wattery and terrible. No cherry flavor at all and this brew was just bad. I dont know what when wrong here.
At Oregon Brewers Festival 2008 Pours out a nice brown topped with a off white head. A nice aroma of light cherries and spice. A little sweetness on it. A nice mix with the cherries and spice.
On tap at OBF--Poured a deep chestnut body with a rich beige head. Lots of cheeries and dark fruits in the nose. Lots of malty caramel and sticky nutty residue. Quite good.

OBF 2008. I thought this was just going to be the dubbel they bring every year, but the cherries added a nice twist to it. I didn’t get a lot of cherry flavor, but it did tend to add a good sweet fruit flavor to the finish that before I read that this had cherries I thought tasted like pie. The spices blend well with caramel tones and a sweet fruit flavor to give this an interesting pie like flavor.

Very interesting beer, Belgian style.. Nice cherry undertones. Well balenced carbonation. Hints of spice in flavor. Thick beige head, apricot amber. Got this 750 at the brewery, thanks again CZettler.

Pours a very dark amber/ brown color with beige head. Aroma is spicy and fruity with a lot of cherry and berries along with subtle hint of malt. Well balanced with a nice amount of roasted chocolate maltiness to balance out the cherry and spice flavors. Slightly dry finish.

Draught: Aroma of cherries, medicine, and maybe a little juniper. Poured orange/amber in color with a medium-sized off-white head that diminished. Hazy. Sparkling. Tasted of cherries, then toasted malts, sourdough, pretzels, and a bit of chocolate. Medium body. Thin, sticky texture. Lively carbonation. Malty, salty finish.
Draft. Amber/orange color with small head. Cherry aroma. The taste was like the abbey dubbel but with cxherry notes throughout. Malty with some plum flavors in the finish.

Sampled at BCTC. Orange-amber body with a sudsy off-white head. Aroma of cherry twizzlers and a hint of cognac. Fruity sweet, cherry Life Savers taste with light herbal bitterness and a woody element. Smooth, medium full body is lightly syrupy, but makes for a pleasant sipper. This is a solid, well-made big fruit beer overall.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle from 2002. Sampled on May 16 2009. Thanks to Baresi/Mikael. Light hazy pale golden colour. Cottony white foam. Jelly fruity, with floral uk hops in aroma. Flowery, berry-ish hop flavour with light bitterness. Incredibly fresh for being this old. Is it the effect of having tasted a 1982 Vintage Beer minutes earllier? Hopbitter finish. Citrusy fruit cake.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Bottle on May 16, 2009 Slight bit hazy, pale golden color, white head. Fruity, floral, sweet, "hallonbåtar" candy, lemon like citrus scent. Fruity, bitter, "hallonbåtar" candy, hoppy taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, fresh. High bitterness.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Coors have taken over the famous Bass Museum which makes Worthington White Shield and other historic ales. Part of the Bass/Worthington history is the annual brewing of a Royal Ale. On 3 July 2002 The Queen and Prince Philip arrived in the town of Burton on Trent by Royal Train to celebrate 1,000 years of brewing in the town as well as 100 years of the production of Marmite. Marmite is made from surplus brewers yeast, and was sent out to soldiers serving in Mesopotamia (Iraq) where vitamin deficiency diseases were common. After visiting The Abbey Garden where monks first brewed beer in Burton around 1002 AD, they moved on to The Bass Museum and started the mash for Queen's Ale and Duke's Ale - a tradition started on 22 February 1902 by King Edward VII. The beer is a lovely mahogony colour and has a rich fruit cake and alcohol aroma and taste with a good sharp bite of hops to offset the sweetness. A very smooth and tasty but not too complex beer which leans toward a Barley Wine, but is less assertive.
August 14, 2015 - on tap at Herkimer. Orangish pour but hard to tell in dim lighting. Aroma and taste were malty and grainy.
opaque copper color. no head. light aroma of lager yeast. dry grain flavor, some taste of nuts and wood. very dry finish.
A very enjoyable beer. Light orangish red color. With whisps of white head. Malts on the aroma and a light refreshing body with roasted malt flavor

On tap at the brewpub on 05/31/2009. Somewhat hazy amber body with a large rocky white head. Toasty malt and noble hop aroma. Sweet toasty malt flavor with some floral and noble hops. Medium light body with moderate carbonation.

On draught during the ABR ’08 in Minneapolis, MN. Pours a clear golden pale orange brew with an average off-white head that has some nice retention and spotty lacing. Aroma of light caramel malt, a touch of vanilla and roasted nuts. Taste is medium bodied, malty character of caramel, toffee, some roasted nuts and grassy hops. Finish is semi-dry, crisp, with a light caramel and toffee aftertaste that quickly disappears.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear light orange-golden color. The head was thin and white with decent retention and lacing. Pleasant aroma of caramel and subdued vanilla cake batter. Dry on the tongue with fresh cereal grain, noble hop, caramel, and light toffee flavors. Pretty tasty.
Draft @ Brewpub: Copper, no head or lacing. Nose of ripe canal water and malt, light caramel, some diacetyl. Dry mouthfeel but a sweet flavor, odd. Not that good.
Pours amber/red with minimal head. Not a lot of aroma: a bit of malt, just a touch of roasted nuts. Lightly roasted malt and just a hint of hops on the palate. Refreshing and not wholly undrinkable.

Draft at brewpub. Aroma: Lightly toasted malt with a note of almonds. Some light herbal hops. Appearance: Orange-brown in color and clear. Light khaki head was small and foamy with decent retention. Fair lacing. Flavor: Lightly toasted grainy malt, toasted nuts, light herbal and earthy hops. Medium-light bitterness. Finishes clean. Palate: Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Overall: Nothing special, but drinkable. Went well with my dinner.
Dark gold color with a thin head. Slight wheat aroma. A little hoppy with some barley. Not what I’d call a shining example, but inoffensive.

Pours auburn brown with a nice copper/red color when held to the light. About a 1/2 inch head that diminishes quickly with minimal lacing. Slight fruity, raisin aroma. Mild bisquit malt and candi sugar flavor. Definite yet mild Belgian yeast character to both aroma and flavor. Nice mouthfeel, medium body, slightly sticky and mildly carbonated. A nice beer. Serving type: growler

The beer is a beautifully clear auburn brown that really shows off some reddish copper color when held up to the light. About half an inch of light tan foam recedes to a thin ring in a minute or so, but the etching at the bottom of the Chimay glass keeps a steady stream of tiny bubbles slowly rising to the surface. Scant lacing. Aroma of candied fruit and a little bit of bread. I like the flavor - toasted and biscuit malt, light candi sugar, and a tangy fruitines that reminds me a little of gooseberry. A hint of black tea tannin in the finish and into the aftertaste. Medium body, gentle carbonation, quite a pleasant beer.
Like the name for sure, but didnt like the beer as much. Not really my style of beer in the first place. Once again, a bit to sweet for my tastes, but still drinkable.
Not the Best of Show this year at Winterfest but still not bad as there was some coriander or some spice and some Barley Wine characteristice with fruits and caramel.
Clear deep copper. Nose sweet and spicy, lots of caramel and candy sugars. Tastes of candied raisins, bit nutty, lots of sugars. Some fruitiness, berries. Strong stuff, but good.

Growler poured to the very top, good job, guys. Sweet caramel malt spills immediately from the aroma...on further inspection, wide-open, earthy, dark fruits, raisins, nuts, nice...sweet and lovely... Deep brown color, with burgundy highlights, with nice, if short -lived, fizzy brown head. Taste: sweetness again, big, rich malt, caramel and mellow fruit, light spice, ...and absolutely delcious. Some grit in the texture, some give and play, a tasty dance on the tongue. Fullish body, sweet, fruity finish...solid. Might lack a touch of complexity, but it’s simplicity is reward enough, if the flavor is this fine. An easy-drinking dubbel, impossible to stop drinking it. I like this quite a lot, it’s a respectable dubbel, and I’m happy that the first beer I’ve reviewed out of the city of St. Cloud, MN is such a gutsy and tasty one.

The winner of the St Paul Winterfest 2/8/03. I describe her as very sweet. Problem is when a guy describes her as very sweet you know that means she isn't very good looking. She had orange hair and gave no head. A sour puss..GAY! I don't understand why she won.

Co-winner of the traveling Showshoe Award at Winterfest in St. Paul, MN on Feb. 8 (along with Cywrens Song Chocolate Raspberry Stout from Hops Restaurant & Brewery - Eden Prairie, MN) for best of show. I was less than enamored by this brew. It had a hard alcohol aroma (vermouth?). Very sweet to the taste; the alcohol is not overbearing. Not bad, just too sweet.

Compared to the Goldflint, it is more aromatic, less watery, Also there is a little more hops in here, but still not that much. a little bit of spiciness that livens it up a little from very boring to lightly boring.
Draft @ Brewpub: A dull amber color, light head and nice lacing. Nose of light malt and hop, not much there. The flavor is all band aid, super woody and medicinal. Horrible.

On tap at the St Paul brewpub (sampler). I would normally expect an Irish Ale to have an element of red in the colour. This was decidedly golden in appearance. A touch of smoky malt in the aroma. Smooth and malty of the palate, with a more apparent smokiness. Not much hop in evidence. Drinkable, but nothing special.
Clear light amber body with creamy off-white head. Aroma is mild, medium sweet, caramel, faint peat. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, faint peat. Watery light body.
From tap. Pours orange with a white head. Aroma is dry malty with a slight citric note. Flavour is smoked, rather dry and slight hoppy citric. Finish is rather bland.

Pours a nice clear reddish amber, with fizzy carbonation but next to no head. No lacing, exceptionally mild and inoffensive malt in the aroma. A little bit of caramel malt, but not really enough to give it much character. A very little bit of peat in the finish, but no where near enough to give it character. Light bodied and very average. What makes this Irish? Well, at least it isn’t green.
Copper color with no head. Dusty hops aroma. The taste was beyond weird... it tasted like I was sucking on a sugar cube while walking through a suffocating grain silo. Odd to say the least.
Dark red. No head. Was served very cold with little taste before it warmed with with a hops taste. Slightly bitter. Filling. Not bad.
Winterfest St. paul 2/8/03. I am Irish so I may be biased...but she tasted good...she's a red who who wears lace. A tough combo.
Served at Winterfest in St. Paul, MN on Feb. 8. Aroma is malty and sweet. Unfiltered with no head. Murky and ugly, Knockadoon doesn't score many points for aesthetics. Not very refined and not great.

Can 355ml (Beer Rep) Clear deep copper colour, small steady off-white head and lace. Pine-resiny aroma. Medium-bodied. Flavour is resiny and piney with good citrus too. Also a bit bready with decent amount of crystal malt sweetness. Stylish classic West Coast IPA.

35.5cl can at home, bought at Van Erp Groningen. Appearance: clear, rich golden to amber with a medium, stable, white head. Aroma: candied sugar, orange peel, citrus, candy. Taste: medium sweetness and high bitterness. Notes of orange peel, candied sugar, hop bitters, bitter grapefruit in the finish. Palate: medium bodied, watery to oily texture, medium carbonation and a dry finish. Overall: more malty than most classical IPA's. Good dominant bitterness. Not as fruity maybe, but still a good IPA
Tried courtesy of Ryan and Liz in 2019 with Andy. Lots of pine and an intense bitterness. Leaves your tongue dry.
12oz Dose. Klarer Bernstein. Viel fester Schaum. Honigmelone, Malzduft. Wunderbar bitter-malziger Karamell Antrunk. Etwas Harz und Walnuss. Langes bitteres Finish. Schön trockenes IPA.
Fruity, hoppy, dry: a decent ipa thats all I can say about this beer. Maybe a bit boring, but at least decent

355ml can pours deep amber with small off-white head. Aromas of candied, toffee, toast and citrus / herbal hops. Tastes of caramel malt, orange peel, pine resin, grassy notes and herbal characters. Slightly oily texture. Long finish with medium grapefruit bitterness. Sweet, but Balanced AIPA with plenty of punchy hops.
Bier met goed veel hoppige en bittere smaken. Heeft in de verte ook iets van citrus en grapefruit. -backlog de BierApp-
Pine and grapefruit. Decent malt backbone. Amber pour with ok head and lacing. Bitter lime Manafort. Can.
Strong resin hop aroma. Clear red orange color with a large white head. Moderate bitter beginning with a lightly sweet finish. Light Palate.

Barwa złota, piana obfita, drobnopęcherzykowa, trwała. W aromacie grejpfruty. W smaku głównie nuty żywiczne, bardzo przyjemne na początku, ale zanikające po utlenieniu. Poza tym cytrusy, lekki metaliczny posmak. Mocno goryczkowe, męcząco pod koniec.
Pours a hazy light golden yellow. Aromas of straw/grass/hops. Flavors of light fruitiness, caramel malts, mellow hop finish.
Had this on tap a while back at the Indianapolis Ram. All I wrote down is "Tastes like nothing!"

Draft at Indy brewpub. Poured a clear copper color with a moderate fizzy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium malty and hop aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium balanced bittersweet flavor with a medium bitttersweet finish of moderate duration. Smooth drinkable session brew.

This should iwthout a doubt be called the un-beer beer. No taste, no aroma, extremely dry and light. Beer flavored water. More like a german style pilsner but with the appearance of an american standard.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy copper with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is candy sugar, wood, dark fruit. Medium body, caramel, oak, candy sugar, boozy finish, very good.

On tap at the brewery. Hazy brown appearance with a sticky, light tan head. Rich and malty with moderate hop resin bitterness and moderate sweetness. Notes of oak, red wine and light tropical fruits round things out. A full bodied sipper. Decent barley wine.

Clear dark copper with a light tan head. Absolutely lovely nose of sticky toffee and cherry and molasses and dates/raisins and a little boozy heat. Big chewy mouthfeel with some molasses and dates predominately on the front, with a cherry like sweetness and boozy dark sugary malts on the end. Perhaps a touch of ginger throughout. Pretty nice.
Poured on tap at bar. Poured a rich orange/brown color with minimal head. Not much aroma and not very impressive.
A middling barleywine. Roasted with a thick plum character. Tried with the parents at the brewery in Dec, 2013.

On tap @ Coopersmiths. Copper pour with an off-white head. Nice sherry, dark fruit, and caramel aroma. Kind of a candied fruit and raisin note. Flavor is watery and has a lot of green apple. Bread, caramel, and a touch of booze.
Tap at brewery. Dark burnt orange appearance with a big orange cream head. Quite hoppy sweet wine-like aroma. Very strong and sweet flavor that’s wine-like. Somewhat hard to drink.

Draught at CooperSmith’s. Pours clear amber with an average, fizzy, off-white head, diminishing with spare lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel), light hops (flowers, herbs), average yeast (earth) with notes of apple and pear. Medium bodied, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and a bitter finish. Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.

tap at the brewpub. pour is a deep red like a cloudy ruby with a decent head. smells of alcohol pine, vanilla and caramel. first taste i thought wow, this is grainy. same on the second and third. once i got past that to the other flavors which are mainly booze, some fruits, like banana and oranges, but the husky grain flavor domninated this sweet brew.

Draught. Head is fully diminishing. Body is medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (resin), with notes of alcohol and toffee. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, slightly husky. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. A simplistic, alcohol-heavy rendition.
A pretty solid red ale. Sweet and pretty full bodied. Lots of caramel, some toast and bread. Not much lingers in the aftertaste. Tried with Jess at the Nebraska Beerfest in 2016.
22oz bottle. pulled from a forgotten shelf. Poured amber color with a small sized off white head. I could tell this had some age on it. Citrus, some floral hops, and a bit stale.

"Good blend of malts and hops here. aromatic, dark (for the style), and flavorful. I wasn’t expecting much from this brewery after dumping their holiday ale, so this was a very pleasant surprise. 1/09-had an off aroma...maybe the glass they served in. i’ll wait to have another off one to downgrade...or not.
On tap at the brewery. Pours deep ruby with an off white head. Smokey burnt caramel nose, light chocolate wafer. Flavor is sweet with dark caramel and toffee but finishes smokey and a bit astringent.

Draft pour as part of the full sampler at Hoppy Brewing. Clear dark red/amber with off-white head. Aromas of chocolate and floral notes. Tastes of light chocolate, caramel, floral notes. Medium body with a dry finish.

Clear golden amber with a one-finger khaki head that leavesgenerous lace. Aromas of tangy citrus and roasted malts. Lemon and orange flavors up front supported by modest toasted malts. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, prickly mouthfeel and a clean finish.

Bottle. Bronze beer with a dark cream head. Cocoa and caramel aroma with light grapefruit. Grapefruit and cocoa flavor with nuttiness and caramel. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and light pine lingers with cocoa, caramel, and light nuttiness.
Reddish brown in color... Aroma of caramel malts, nuts... Flavor is rich and malty, notes of toffee, hazelnut, coffee... Not much hop balance... Okay ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an amber color with off white head. Malt, caramel, toffee, nut, chocolate and hop aroma. Caramel, toffee, malt, chocolate, hazelnut, biscuit and hop flavors. Medium body and carbonation with a malty finish.

On tap @ Hoppy Brewing. Dark amber pour with a white head. Toasted malt, bread, and some toffee on the nose. A bit of grass and straw. Pretty meh. Flavor is basic amber ale. Bread, toast, toffee, and caramel. Light floral hops, grass, and a mild bitterness.
copper in color with a small head. Aroma is of hops and citrus. Taste is of malt, caramel and hops.
On tap at the brewpub. Copper color ok head and decent lacing. Ok balance of the citrus hops smell and the malts. Taste is decent light bitternes, hops, and malts.

Pale orange color with some red highlights. Decent head. Nose is fruity and sweet with lots of fresh cascade hops (I actually thought they were cluster hops because of the almost fruity pebbles like aroma that is the sunset wheat standard). Taste is sweet and smooth with a nice drinkability. Decent bitter finish with a pretty nice mouthfeel.

On tap at the brewery. Listeed as an APA with 5.5% alcohol and 38 IBUs for this batch. Clear orange color with a small, white head. Very nice floral hoppy aroma with a nicie and sweet APA taste. Slightly syrupy mouthfeel. One of their better offerings.

Light color for a pale ale, with little head. Fruity aroma. Decently hoppy flavor, seemingly both dry and sticky at the same time, with unpleasant notes in the finish. (on tap, Grapevine, TX location)

Colour of old gold, clear; very fine lacy white head, stable. Nose is slightly spicey and sweetish - some madeirisation? - though not old. Very little aroma, really. taste of orange rind, high percentage of unfermented sugar; sweet surrounded by bitterness. Very rounded, full-bodied. Alcohol prominent. In the aftertaste, the non-hop bitterness becomes obstructive. Again one of Van Steenberge's labelbeers for a community in its neighbourhood. Served in one of the village better restaurants as 'apéritif'.

Draught at Il Locale. Low fluffy white quickly disappearing white head. Hazy orange red body. Mild malt straw cinnamon caramel aroma. Cinnamon grass straw caramel flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish.
Kick 030516. Deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is cinnamon, caramel, malt. Flavour is cinnamon, caramel, malt. Weird beer, but still drinkable.

Keg at The Italian Job, London. It pours a clean rich golden color with a medium white head. Aroma is bready and spicy with notes of cinnamon and green vegetables. Taste is medium sweet upfront with bread and caramel, then more dry with green notes and cinnamon. Light bodied with ok carbonation. Overall, not a fan

On tap @Bir&Fud (Rome). Pours golden with a medium white head. Aroma of malt, cinnamon, grass, not good. Flavour is medium malty with a light bitter end and cinnamon notes. Light body, light carbonation. No...

Supert krankupp på Circus 25.1.16 sammen med Ovesen. Den andre av to skuffelser denne kvelden, alle de andre var i klassen meget gode/fremragende. Kobbergylden med ok skum. Iflg, Agostino (bryggeren) er denne beregnet for klassisk håndpumpe. Gress, kanel, ingefær, nellik, gymsokker og selleri - en lite tiltalende combo. Ufrisk. Tørr avslutning.

From tap at Cirkus with JMD 25.01.16. Clear dark golden. Beige head. Not much lacing. Aroma of cloves, ginger, lemongrass and sellery. Similar taste, with cinnamon and raw vegetables. Well made, and medium bitterness in aftertate is pulling it up. I am, however, giving it a mediocre rating on my Hedonistic scale as I don´t particularly like it.
Draught @ Luppolo 12, Rome. Pours amber with a offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caremal, spice, cinnamon. Flavor is malty, caramel, toffee, spice, light cinnamon. Medium body, soft carbonation. 060414

Alla spina. Nebuloso color aranciato con persistente cappello di fragile schiuma bianca. Aroma speziato, pungente e acidulo con sentori di salvia, limone, cannella e forse chiodo di garofano; gusto inizialmente acidulo che evolve subito verso un amaro prepotentemente erbaceo con forti note di erbe medicinali e spezie, che ricreano però un bouquet decisamente spiacevole. Corpo lieve, effervescenza debole, setosa ma anche un po’ acquosa. Non fa per me.

Tap at Open Baladin, Roma, 10/02/13. Hazed dark amber with a decent frothy off white head that retains well. Nose is pale malts, spice, cinnamon, caramel. Taste comprises pale malts, toffee, spice, caramel, cinnamon, light fruit. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, hint of spice in the finish. A decent enough spiced bitter.

Tap. Kinda woodsy to my palate, lighter copper color, spiciness, definitely not overdone in terms of the flavoring, but not catching as much hops as I would’ve liked. Didn’t take excellent notes on this one, but was an interesting enough brew as a one time thing.
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.
Bottle at home, from Asda. Pours clear amber, nose is sweet toffee, very light fruit, taste is dry, toffee, some berries.
