A fruit beers brewed with a mixture of wild berries from Scotland. The foam is moderate and chunky, the aroma offers blackcurrant and raspberry, and a lot of other fruits, but the aforementioned black currants and raspberries are the main theme. The taste is a fine blend of various berries with the sweetness of the berries featured. It does not have much other than berries to offer, and you can miss a little fruity acidity, now hop bitterness is omitted. It is actually fast boring, although it initially had good rates.

0,5L bottle. Pours clear amber-copper with off-white head. Aroma is sweet some British hops, caramel. Flavor is very sweet, caramel, fruit syrup, and some British hops. Overall: not as awful as I expected to be, but still not great.

Amber beer, beige head. Starchy and candy sweet nose, hints of malt. Flavor is messy malt with toasty and caramel notes, intense sweetness. Like someone steeped fruit caramels in cheap beer. Drinkable, but not much else.

Bottle, 500mL. Home. A sparkling brown orange beer with a medium white foam. Thin bubbles. Good persistence. Fruity aroma (red berries, blackcurrant, blackberry), herbs. Medium dry bitterness : refreshing. Light body, thin watery texture, average carbonation, dry bitter finish. Overall, a bit light but refreshing with red berries aroma.

Bottle. Light copper body, small head. Aroma has "Forest Fruit" flavoured tea and strawberry jam. A light bitter with some added fruitiness, mostly raspberries and blackcurrant. Quite watery and more jammy than fruity. Resembles jam jar washing water.
500ml bottle. Clear golden color. Medium size, white head, stays. Metallic, hops, watery aroma. Raspberries, some kind of other berries as well, malty taste. Overall meh brew.
Amber Farbe, kaum Schaum. Geruch ausschließlich nach Waldbeeren. Geschmack wässrig fruchtig nach Waldbeeren. Im Abgang dann ganz minimale herbe Noten vorhanden.

0.5 l bottle from local supermarket. Small head, copper colour. Well, it tastes like an ale flavoured with fruits. Just as promised on the label. Quite refreshing in the summer. Not for those who expect more beerlike experience.
Marcle cider is an alias for Westerns. Not sure about the millennium one though. Light golden and very flat, subtle, sweet and with a bitter aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I should have known something was up with 8.4% ABV content. The best way to describe this stuff is medicianl. It sort of reminds me of the first time I tried a single malt with my father-in-law. It is quite rough on the nose as the alcohol hits you from square one. The drink is not too distasteful, but the aftertaste really put the hammer on me. Probably the best way to describe this cider is that it is strong English cider that perhaps my palate is not quite ready for.
On gravity cask at the Merton Beer Festival. The smell is juicy apples and a bit of apple skin. The taste is super dry apple skin, dry apple. The body is light with light carbonation.

500ml bottle. Deep orangey gold amber colour, thin white foam head and aroma of apple, sweet, honeyish notes, Taste is tangy apple, green apples, apple skins, woody oak, drying with lots of tannin. Pithy mouthfeel, medium bodied, low carbonation, dry tannic finish. Quite OK.

Bottle 500ml. clear glass. Clear medium to dark orange color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy apple, tart apple, scrumpy apple, sharp apple, oak. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet with a short duration, dry, woody. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat. [20110410]
bottle at jans ... golden amber .... soft sharp apple nose ... fizzy ... light apple ... long dry tanin linger ... dry mouthpuckering ...i dont like this at all

Bottle from The Hop Pocket, Bishops Frome, Herefordshire, consumed at home 25.09.10 Pours warm gold with medium carbonation. This has a real farmhouse character, wonderfully rough and tart and an absolute contrast to the standard Gwatkin Golden Valley cider just consumed. I wish I knew how a scrumpy was differentiated from a standard cider, its lovely but coarse, dry but tart mmhhh.. it would go well with a bit quality of cheddar. Good stuff. A6 A4 T6 P3 Ov12 3.1

Cask… Cloudy yellow cider with no head. The aroma is a touch acidic and very reminiscent of three-day-old sliced apples. Medium-bodied and watery with no carbonation. Tastes like apple cider that I stuck in the fridge until it fermented a bit. Sweet with just a whisper of acidity. Finishes bone-dry and a touch abrasive. Not bad - not altogether good.
Pours hazy golden. Aroma of apple and pear juice. Flavor is apples and a little acid, with a dry finish. Certainly gets better as it warms.
Cask @ Redlight. Light caramel colored pour. Pleasant sweet apple aroma, not cloying and a little citrus. Musty apple skin, vinegar taste. Pleasant easy to drink cider.
Cask @ redlight redlight. Very light blonde, no head. Slight apples in the nose, some lemons. Musty, apples with skins. A strong tannic astringency, at almost tea-like levels.

Cask at Redlight Redlight. Pours a lightly hazy golden yellow color. A swirl of the glass shows a thin body. The nose is oddly tart, with a bit of wild yeast funk and tannic apple skins. Semi-dry, dusty, and earthy. Flavors are nearly as wild, again very dry and tannic, with a good amount of tart yeastiness. Thin bodied, very dry, and dusty. Interesting, wild cider.

33cl bottle at home. Dark brown with a medium white head. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Sweet with herbal bitterness. Malts, clove, flower, herbs, brown sugar, some honey and caramel. A nice herbal brew.

Bottle/pint glass. Lovely polished wood colour, with a thick, rocky white/beige head. Aroma is mid-powered (unless a recent bop on the nose has dampened my sense of smell) - malty, dark sweet (honey/caramel) with hints of booze. Heavy on the sweetness, with a light/mid-bitter finish. Mid body, gentle carbo.

Bottle [as Tilburg 2009 Honingbier] @ home shared with Dutchdrebus. Hazy dark orange to reddish color, small off - white head. Smell and taste malts, slightly sourish, slightly honey, a bit weird. Average body, fizzy carbonation. Earlier Rating: 2/22/2013 Total Score: 3.9 (8-4-8-4-15) 33cl bottle @ home. Hazy dark orange to light red color, full sized a bit creamy beige head that lasts for a decent while. Aroma of malts, lightly sweet, vineous, slightly herbs or spices. Quite rich. Taste malts, pretty vineous again, slightly herbs or spices, honey, lightly yeast, caramel. Nice aftertaste of malts, a slight bitter and a bit vineous again. Medium to full body, medium carbonation. Nicely balanced. One of the best beers from Sint Servattumus I’ve tasted.
Poured a murky, milky reddish brown with a dense off white head. Aroma of spicy banana and caramel malt. Medium body, flavour of sweet, heavy banana and cinnamon and a dry,sweet finish.
Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense light brown head. Aroma : Honey, sweetness and fruits. Flavour: Fruits, honey, sweetness, light spice. Medium bodied. Ends sweet and fruity

33 cL bottle at Arendsnest. Pours clear and golden amber with a huge off white head. Aroma is caramelish, oxidised and herbal honey. Sweet, caramelish, light fruity and mild honey. Medium dry, light phenolic. Lasting honey sweet impression into the finish.

Battle shared. Pours a murky brown with a small tan head. Aroma of honey, cheesy feet, caramel and some dark fruit, a little sickly. Flavour is over medium sweet, light bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Couldn’t finish my glass of this.
33cl bottle shared with Kermis. Almost no head. Hazy amber pour. Honey in the aftertaste. Minimal carbonation. Ok.

Bottle (33 cl) from The Cracked Kettle. Clear deep amber, medium off-white head. Fruity and earthy, alightly almondy aroma with some wood and honey, and a clear touch of alcohol. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Semi dry, medium bitterness.

22nd March 2011 Bottle at Arends Nest. Clear reddish brown beer. Big fluffy off white head. Dry palate, semi crisp. Dry sweet malt, very dry. Slightly spiced bubblegum. Finishes very dry. Too bloody dry by a country mile.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear golden-light orange color. The head was white and left some lace on the glass. Unusual aroma that included the likes of apple cider and a bit of honey. Not what I expected. Light to medium bodied. Delicately sweet up front with mild bitterness at the end. Fruit forward flavors including apple, lime, and subdued orange. The fruit flavors were supported by some spices, predominantly clove, which were initially muted, but grew in intensity somewhat toward the end. I wasn’t all that impressed with this beer at first, but it grew on me a bit.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: Pours a cloudy golden color with a thin white head. Aroma of hops and spices. Flavor of hops and spices. The body is light with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. I doesn’t feel belgian much.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: GABF 2007. A hazy golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet and quite spicy - among others I pick up coriander. The flavor is sweet with notes of coriander, leading to a dry spicy and slightly wheaty finish.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Light, clean Belgian ester nose. Almonds and citrus. Pours a clouded amber, thick and meaty with a rim in off-white. Wow. Intense hop flavor, actually very forward and mixed with delicious phenols. Really grassy and parchingly dry in the hops. Fresh and dank. Reminiscent of marijuana strains. High carbonation actually lifts this a lot. The malt is hidden beneath a wonderful blossom of hops and yeast flavor. A nice beer. Maybe a touch out of balance, but something I’m really digging.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: Really interesting mix of Belgian style and IPA boldness. One of my favorites from this brewpub.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: (Draught) Pours a lightly hazy golden-amber body with a small white head. Aroma of coriander, passion fruit, honey, and herbal. Flavor of spruce, honey, herbs, and citric hoppiness with a bitter finish.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: [draught @ the brewpub] Hazy golden yellow color. Aroma is slightly sweet, with some citrus and slight acidity. Flavors are full of herbal bitterness and some smooth, grainy malt character. Refreshing, funky complexity. Lingering bitterness in the finish. Awesome stuff.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: Date: 02/11/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub clear dark gold, wispy beige head, streaks of lace, light spicy aroma, nice hop flavor on a dry malt base with some spicy esters adding complexity rather than balance, a touch of candy sweetness comes and goes, the spices give way to robust hop flavor and a long bitter finish, called an abbey IPA it alternates between the two rather than marries them, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.8/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: **/4

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: Draught@Redbones. Very nice. yeasty, but soft, with some lovely citrus rind and wild flower aromas. Palate shows some bitterness and a very soft refreshing acidity. Citric, slightly estery. A very pleasant Belgian pale ale.

column1: Cambridge Golden Ring Abbey Pale Ale
column5: Slightly cloudy golden body with a small white head. Light-medium oily body. Not a very tasty beer at all. Generic half roasted malts, a little sweetness, a little citrusy hops, a little bitterness. I didn’t feel any of the advertised wild yeast that many reviewers got. I was looking forward to drinking a Golden Ring but ended-up regretting it. Same goes with many men wearing a golden ring.

50cl bottle. A hazy orange brown beer with a huge good lasting creamy beige head. Aroma of caramelized malt, wheat, red malt and clove. Taste of burned caramel, dark reddish malt, clove and some mild ripe banana.

Many thanks for this beer to Jacek Wigier (wineofdreams@gmail.com). Piwo ma intensywny aromat, startych do surowki jablek, Zapach swiezej moreli na drzewie, Wyglad to spora gesta i bardzo trwala piana, metne, brazowo-bursztynowa barwa. Piwo ma przyjemny smak sliwek, bananow, ale glownie sliwek, powidel nawet, karmel i pieczone ciastka korzenne, bardzo smaczne trzesciwe przyjemne.
A dark wheat beer. Ok taste. Pretty rich flavour. A good beer for hot summer nights. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Berlin Bar, Copenhagen. Hazy dark amber color with frothy white head. Aroma is banana, wheat, dried fruits. A little sweet. Soft bitterness in finish. Lighter and sweeter than other Dunkelweizen.
en hvedeøl med lidt mere smag, hvor den syrlige del er væk til fordel for en mere maltet smag.

Copenhagen 8/6 2017. 50 cl bottle from SuperBrugsen. Part of a Giftbox of German and Czech Beer. Happy German fellow sporting a glass of pale wheat beer. Not the best advertisement of a Dunkel. Pours hazy dark amber with big white head. Settles as fine thin layer of foam covering the surface of the beer. Moderate lacing. Aroma is sweet banana, lemonade and tart berries. Medium carbonation an watery palate. Flavor is rather sweet but balanced by tart sourness. Aftertaste is mostly sour with some sweet notes. Unfortunately rather thin and watery. Quite generic but slightly weak Dunkelweizen. Not even the guy on the label seems to be willing to drink it.
Tap@Taphouse, Copenhagen - dark amber pour with off-white head. Medium sweet to light toasty malty aroma and taste, caramel, wheaty, some banana, bitter finish.
DØE. Hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, caramel, banana and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet. Sweet finish. 290515
Kedelig og ordinær øl. Meget flot etiket. Pæn farve og skum, men savner noget i smagen

Bottle at Berlin Bar. High creamy lasting withe head. Clear dark brown body. Dusty sweet apple pear caramel roasted malt aroma. Very sweet malty flavor with caramel, little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long sweet finish.

Listed as "hofbrauhaus vertriebs" but made in karlsberg strasse homburg. Mine is a yellow can that says St. Wendeler lager. 5.0% alcohol. piss and no head. taste is bland white cracker, cereal. slightly bitter. aroma is not unpleasant but some kind of kitchen-construction smell. overall this is a very palatable and think-nothing-neither-pleasant-nor-bad lager. I would drink it again.

the aroma is malty and floral with shades of grain, hay, buckwheat and some herbs... the taste is rather clear and refreshening, malty and herbal, with notes of grain, straw and some grasses... the aftertaste is bitter and dry... Earlier Rating: 7/20/2018 Total Score: 2.7 tried it as St. Wendeler Pils... the aroma is malty and floral with shades of herbs, grain and straw... the taste is malty and herbal with notes of grain, hay and candy... dry and bitter aftertaste...

Jaune paille limpide, belle mousse épaisse et tenace. Nez discret, plutôt sur le grain. Bouche fade, légèrement sucrée, sans amertume, aqueuse, sans carbonation. Manque de tout, alors que ses arômes pourraient être pas trop détestables.

Can. Nose: pilsner malts, hints of German hops. Light body. Taste: very clean and fairly unintense on the other hand. Light minus spicy bitterness. Unremarkable mass market beer. Earlier Rating: 5/29/2018 Total Score: 2.5 Canned as St. Wendeler Pils at 4.6% ABV. Aroma: faint malts, bit bready, distant hops. Light body. Taste: malty, grainy & bready. Clean. Only traces of hop at ending. Thirst quenching. That's it.

500 ml can. Golden color with white foam. In the aroma of malt tones and notes of herbs. In the taste of citrus sour, excellent neutral maltiness with small grain tones, moderate herbaceous bitterness. In the aftertaste, bitterness turns into hoppy tones.

500ml can from T-Market, drunk at home. Pours clear with a very brief frothy head, medium lacing and some bead. Faint aroma of hay and caramel with some floral notes. Lightly fizzy in the mouth with medium carbonation, some gentle bready malt flavours, but no real hop presence, a good balance between the soft sweetness and mild bitterness. Overall, well balanced and refreshing, but just another terribly ordinary, averagely malty supermarket pilsner, wrongly listed here as a lager.
Can sample at a tasting at The Dancing Camel. Thanks Stas and Max. Clear pale gold with a white head. A little metallic and corn aroma. Bitter and paper in the mouth. Light body, soft fizz.

Can sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Max. 4.9%. Clear yellow with a white head. Grainy aroma with light noble hops notes. Flavor has sweetish graininess, and a bit of bitterness. Light-bodied. Drinkable.
*Neutral-grainy beer. Not too deep with a neutral Bitterness. Easy to drink but (for me) way too grainy. Ok.
33 cl. can @ home, bought @ Netto, Givet as St. Wendeler Pils. Clear golden with a white head. Grainy aroma. Very bland and boring but drinkable.

What the hell is this? Almost no nose, pale gold color, and a weak head. Light honey-ish tastes. Lemony tones in the middle mix with a fresh hop finish to give a cleaning fluid aftertaste. Medium, round body. Nothing winter about this.
Sweet corn nose. Golden with a soft carbonation and a little head. Ok and normal first in taste, than a strange acidic aftertaste. Why is this a Winterbeer? I don*t know.

A- Pours a clear russet hue with little to no head. S- Nose has tons of caramel, dark fruit and pine notes. T- Very full bouquet of darker fruits, raisin, caramel that leads into a fairly intense piney hop wave on the back end. M- Thick with medium carbonation. D- This is an excellent barleywine that is perfect to sit and sip on.

On tap at the brewpub ages ago; review from notes. Pours a clear amber color with a firm tan head. Citric sweet aroma -- candied oranges, caramel, pine. Flavor is much the same, lots of deep sweet maltiness and a strong fruity hop profile. Plays well off the alcohol notes but this is a little tough to get through a snifter. Palate fatigue from all angles -- boozy, sweet, thick. A nice offering in extreme moderation.
A fairly well done barleywine of the hoppier variety. Nice malt body, bit of alcohol burn in the finish. Doesn’t greatly stand out, but it’s a nice barleywine.

Draught at the brewpub. red-brown color with a small beige head. Fruity and piney hop aroma and a good amount of caramel as well. Malty flavor with some deeper caramel and dried fruit, but a big hop flavor and bitterness come together with smooth alcohol in the finish to really balance things out. Moderately fruity but very resiny and piney. Full bodied. After the last couple years of sweeter barley wines, I like the hoppy balance of this one. Definitely similar to something like SN Bigfoot.
Clear copper brown with a fizzy tsp head. Molasses caramel spice and toffee aroma and taste.
On tap at the 2003 Toronado Barleywine Festival: Nice creamy mouthfeel. Full maltiness. Underlying citric hop notes. Very well balanced. Nice. (Note: This beer took 3rd place in the festival.)

On tap at the Toronado Barley Wine Festival 2003. Dark pour with little carbonation. Butterscotch and toffee flavors. Additional comment from another taster was that this tasted like weak coffee from 7-11. Go figure.

This would’ve made a strong 1100th review, but just had an off flavor to it, sorta soapy. or cardboardish. green dragon sprays cold water in each glass before pouring the beer. maybe a little contamination in aging (this a ’12). otherwise aromas of alcohol and cherry. bright cloudy golden color. well-balanced on the palate.

On draught at 2014 CellarFest at Bailey’s Taproom. 2009 vintage. Amber golden color. Aroma is very oxidized, with caramel, citrus hops, and burnt sugar notes. Taste is caramelized hops, oxidation, burnt citrus, and dark malts. Smooth mouthfeel, but with a wicked hop note in the finish.

6 ounce sample on tap at Beveridge Place Pub. Sweet, fruity, and vinous aroma. Nicely aromatic. Transparent garnet-amber colored body with a small, off-white head. Starts sweet, sugary, and caramelly. Nice malt character. Light roastiness in the middle, before this finishes with more sweetness and vinousness. Really tasty and easy-drinking. Dangerous.

A: Poured a copper color with a tannish head, some lacing S: Burnat sugar with notes of citrus and pine T: A caramel backbone and sweetness, some brown sugary sweetness, citrus and pine with a nice hop bitterness and light booze sting M: Big body, well carbonated with a sticky feel on the palate O: Good and very drinkable

On tap for Brouwer’s Hard Liver ’12. Pours ruby orange, with low carbonation. Musty caramel and fruit on the nose -- slightly dank. Flavor adds rubbing alcohol and soap (and this is at a spot that thoroughly rinses their glasses). Not a fan of this one.

On tap for Hard Liver ’12, pours an opaque orangey dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of candied sugar, caramel, twizzlers - very sweet. Flavour is syrupy with caramel sweetness, no hop presence, just lots of sweetness. Palate is syrupy thick with an almost cloying sweetness. Quite nice but overly sweet.
Cloudy. Sweet and sticky flavours and aromas. Plenty of estery fun but over-all I found this one a little too sickly and boozy.

Had the ’06 of this on tap at Bailey’s Taproom’s Cellar Fest (Jan. ’10). Colour... garnet-brown with a thick off white head. Nose... lactose-like with hints of caramel. Palate... lots of CO2 for an ’06! Slightly musty grain, dry on the soft palate, some toffee and caramel, bitterness around the edges and a slightly oxidised character

Tap at Horse Brass in two different years! 02 and 05. Both versions were very tasty though different, with a much more pronounced earthen/pine hop presence in the 05. The 02 was a smooth malt bomb, delicious meld of caramel, brown sugar and dark fruit. The 05 had all that but a little less pronounced and with more hoppiness. Would drink both versions again in a heartbeat.
Draft at Uber. Pours a reddish amber with a thin head. Aroma is sweet: and syrupy, in a good way. In the mouth, it’s a little harsh, but still interesting, with notes of caramel, banana, etc.

31st July 2017 Hackney Bottleshare. Thanks to Leighton. Almost clear dark amber - brown beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is smooth and semi dry, decent fine carbonation. Smooth malts, some smoke and then something like horse shit, never tasted horse shit - but I imagine this could be similar!Tangy dry finish. Horrendous! Yuk!

Smoked, dark malts, loads of grains and cereal flavours, phenolic. Hazy brown, small, creamy, beige head. Light bitter. More intense grain and cereal malts, smoked flavours, light citrus fruits, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Unbalanced ESB, too phenolic, smokey, doesn't work. Bottle shared at Leighton’s - thanks to Leighton!

July 2017 - Bottle share at LKS. Thanks Leighton! As 'WinterCoat ESB'. Dark brdown, orange hue, translucent, foamy off-white head. Aroma is pretty phenolic and smoky, mega phenolic, burnt grass, the soil under a garden incinerator. Body is light and frothy with soft carbonation. Taste is more of the same – phenolic, smoke, lightly woody. Obviously not meant to be like this and wouldn't do well if judged to style/for flaws. Objectively, I don't mind the smoky vibes that much but the thin body spoils it. (5-4-4-2-11=2.6)

Bottle shared at Leightons place, 31/07/2017.Many thanks to Kenny for this one. An oily black brown coloured pour with a halo tan head. Aroma is solvent, harsh alcohol, jammy fruits, brown sugars, . Flavour is composed of bitter dark choc, bitter roast, blackberry, plum, ashy roast. Palate is semi sweet, ashy roast, hot alcohol. Woody cherry. Little harsh.

Bottle shared in Hackney - sourced via trade. Pours clear amber with a small, creamy topping. The nose has some smokey phenols, leaves, toasted grains. Light sweet flavour with notes of meat, dried berries, leather, smoke, a little plastic. Light bodied with average carbonation. Odd mouthfeel, some tooth-coating goo. Finishes with more phenols, mild bandaid, leathery berries, leaves. So so.
Synes denne her øl har en underlig eftersmag af noget syrligt, det ødelægger desværre øllen ene del.

Tap at the Lord Nelson, Copenhagen. Poured a clear dark amber with a thin broken white head and some clingy lace. The aroma is rich red berry fruit, yeast, light malt. The flavour is moderate bitter with a sharp, crisp fruit, light aniseed, spice palate. Medium to light bodied with soft carbonation. More like a Christmas Ale than an ESB.
Bottle. amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is milky sour, berries, caramel. flavour is milky sour, berries, hop, malt, yeast, caramel. Slightly infected.

Bottle.Pours cloudy amber with an off-white head. Aroma of malt, fruitiness, sour berries and yeast. Flavor is sweet and malty with some sour notes and caramel.Medium body, average carbonation.Slightly infected.

Bottle 500ml @ Geokkjer Pours cloudy brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and grassy hops. Taste is light sweet, light bitter and light sour. Tastes a little infected. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottle BB 11/16. Dark brown color with beige head. Aroma is dead yeasts, a bit oxidized, spruce. Taste is spruce, spicy, caramel, bitter. Quite a spicy finish. Medium carbonation. Intense. I would not be able to finish a bottle of this on my own.
Brown with small offwhite head. Mild malt and caramel aroma. Flavour has dried fruit, brown sugar and warming alcohol. Sweetish and bitter, nicely balanced.
Clear golden with a off-white head. Aroma is malt, sugar and some spices. Taste is both sweet and sour with notes of malt and caramel.
Bottle. It pours brown with a beige head. The aroma is high malty with spicy and light hoppy notes. Light toasted malty with a light sourish note. Some spices.

Tap at the Lord Nelson, Copenhagen. Poured a clear dark amber with a round bubbly white head. The aroma is sweet malt, ripe red berry fruit. The flavour is moderate to strong bitter with a strong rich fruit alcohol spice palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Appearance: Cloudy deep brown/amberish color with a fine off white head. Good lacing. Aroma: Fruity, malty and some spices. Palate: Medium + body. A bit sweet and an ok bitterness. Average carbonation. Taste: Fruity, malty and some spices. Overall impression: A little bit so sweet. Otherwise an ok ale. Personal stats: Bottle from Mr Hyvik.

Tap @ fairbar Aarhus. Cloudy dark brown, small off white head, okay lacing. Aroma, malty, yeast, roasted notes, spices. Taste, malty, spicy, yeast, hoppy bitter, fruity. Too much carbonation. Nice christmas beer.
50cl, at 6.5%Vol, exclusive Danish brew, from the brewery, complex brew, spicy/malty and slightly fruity/roasted, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, nice X-Mas brew

50 cl bottle. Originally rated on 20101103. Pours copper color with a minimal head. Aroma of caramel malts, ripe fruits, licorice notes, toffee and some nuts. Flavor of caramel malts, ripe fruit notes, nuts, hay and toffee. Promising aroma but a bit boring flavor.
This review is exported from olutopas.info with no comment. Original rating date 6.11.2010
Bona cervesa molt equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza muy equilibrada y sabrosa.
Handpump somewhere in England. Brownish with a thick creamy head. Malty and fruity aroma. Caramel, hoppy and fruity flavour. A bit to flat.

First tasted this in the Woodsman, Burneston in June 1986. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear copper red in colour with a thick creamy white head. Strong metallic taint in the short aroma. Creamy smooth mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt base gives digestive biscuit base with tart fruit notes of woody redcurrant. Aggresive bitter hop resins and hard water salts add to the astringency building up in the aftertaste. Finish is harsh and metallic with a touch of malt. Would avoid this one.
Cask (handpump) @ Harlequin, Sheffield, Bedfordshire England S3 8GG... brown ... light sweet toffee nose ... dull malt ... light hop... soso

[RBESG, Sheffield] Cask @ The Halequin, Sheffield. Pours deep caramel amber with a nice, medium, creamy, white head. Sweet caramel aroma, light berries and a touch of roasted malts. Low carbonation, perhaps just a wee bit hin. Sweet flavour, lots of toasted caramel and soft roasted malts. Low flowery bitterness in the finish. Reminds me of a Kilkenny a bit.
Cask in the harlequin, Sheffield. Alround rating: Dycetyl, toffee, green king like appley sweetness. No hop character. Poor.
RBESG Sheffield 2009 Grand Tasting at the Harlequin. Cask. Clear amber colour. Aroma of sweet ryebread, caramel. Flavour is light toasted malts, caramel, bitter, rye. Bitter finish.
Cask @ Harlequin Sheffield. Dark brown color. Caramel in the aroma. Caramel, grapes and a bit of earthy hops in the flavor. A vague fruity finish. Not too good.
Dark amber/red tinged pint. Taste malts, roasted nuts, burnt bitterness, a mild creamy bitter finish. Ok, a little dull.

Cask (handpump) @ Harlequin, Sheffield, Bedfordshire England S3 8GG. Clear medium orange amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, roasted, nutty. Flavor is moderate sweet amd moderate to light heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (270708)

Light yellow in appearance – a little lighter than your standard micro lager. The almost-nonexistent aroma is barely inviting: traces of malt and sugar, and no hop character. The taste is quite lemony, and there’s even a dusting of lemon on the lips at the end of the pint. Overall very light and simple; more annoying than refreshing.
Dry, touch of malt. Acidic hops, vinegar was added? Could it be cheap white wine? Trying to be crisp, but why brew this? Like their pilsner wit more carbonation.
Very malty nose, pale yellow, tiny white head. Slight malt flavour, watery, lifeless. Poor.

Very light malt aroma, some aromatic hops but to faint to have some effect on me. Medium body, some cream, with slightly unusual flavour. Not sure what kind of hops they used, but my feeling tells me that must be something I do not drink to often. I believe highly acidic hops makes that "strange white vine" taste as C.Khaki mentioned below. Interesting pilsner/lager .

A fruity aroma with malts, pale gold in colour. The head is faint yellow in colour with large bubbles that dissapears quick. It has hints of white wine in the taste which I find really strange. Alot of carbonation in the mouth with a faint lingering bitter finish. Nice but odd with the wine taste.
Nice appearance, reddish brown with a nice sized head. Great lacing. Nutty caramel pine. Nice sweetness, a but thin.
Sampled at Raley Field Brewfest. Poured amber brown, malty, nutty, hoppy, alcohol, little caramel, little metalic.

Draft 2006 vintage on tap at SBC brewpub. Copper color with lacy white head. Brown sugar/molases in the nose. Buttery feel on the palate, mild hop bitternesss which I like in a barleywine. A nice winter warmer but drinkable enough for a Sunday afternoon (like today).

Draft. 2007 vintage. Brown beer with a dark cream colored head. Rich malt aroma. Rich malt flavor with a light vegetal characteristic and light piney hops. Medium-plus bodied. Caramel and rich malt lingers with light pininess.

Draft at the Oasis in Citrus Heights (Sacramento). 100 IBU. Rich malty aroma with resiny hop. Very dark mahogany color with fizzy carbonation. Very roasted caramel with pine/resin hop. Definitely some heat, but it does not interfere. Finish is the sweet goes away and leaves all that wonderful bitter. It is a tad harsh.

Samples of the 2005 and 2006 brews at the Sacramento Brewing BW festival. The 2006 version was totally lacking in BW character, perhaps due to the use of lager yeast. There was no discernible maltiness, it was way too bitter (overhopped), and there was an unpleasant petroleum-like finish. The 2005 version was much better and truer to the BW style - slightly sweet and moderately malty with a flowery honey overtone. My rating is a composite (overal for 2005 is 13, 2006 is 8.

4 ounce sample at Sacramento Brewing’s Barleywine Frestival. 2005 Vintage - 2 years old. Faint, lightly vinous, lightly boozy aroma. There are also somelight fruit notes and no hops to be found. Beautiful transparent garnet-amber body with a nice light tan head. Fruity, sweet start with some booziness and grapey vinousness in the middle. Finishes with some dry hops and tannins. Too thin and watery IMO. Seems kind of minty and "green".
Very roasted malt and nuts nose. Very dark and sweet brew. some hops noticeable piney and bitter. Nice soft beer but not big.
02.20.05 Tap at Toronado BWF Darker color with small head. Chill and balanced BW in an everyman style. Strong PNW influence is obvious. A bit sticky and thick, but tasty. Tends toward cloying.
Tap. Mahognay color. Loads of hops in the aroma and bitter on the palate.
Bottle share on 47812 thanks to Mark. Black pour with thin tan head. Light malt caramel chocolate toffee cocoa notes. Thin.

500 ml bottle of Celtic Black Ale in Scotland. 3.9% ABV. Near black body with a short weak head. Mild simple aroma of dark malts. The flavor follows. Mildly bitter. Overall: weak, disappointing black ale.
Bottle from Cafe Kisimul, Barra. Pours dark brown. Nose of molasses, sweet coffee, sticky toffee pud. Medium body, burnt toffee, raisin, sweet on the palate.

Brown bottle, 500ml. Pours black with a brown hue and no head. Scent is dense caramel and surprisingly little else. Taste is medium caramel, light cherries, light almond. Mouthfeel is surprisingly grainy while still retaining a water finish. Good.
Bottle from Sainsburys. Pours deep brown, nose is light chocolate, toffee, taste is similar, hrash, dry.

This is very very poor, tastes like cheap home brew with dye in it, as a native Stornowegian trying it in bottle the County Bar I am ashamed. May I suggest the misguided amateurs who concocted this travesty take a wee trip down to Thwaites (home of Thwaites Tavern Porter) and see how the professionals work.

Bottle, from The Highland Bottle Shop, on the train from Inverness to Plockton 21/10/13. Very dark mahogony brown with a thin light tan swirl atop the surface. Nose is dark fruits, bready malts, fruit cake, earthy. Taste comprises cardboard, dark fruit tang, faint cocoa, light tarteness to the fruit. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, drying finish. Sub par home brew-esque state of affairs!

Pours black with a tanned head that quickly leaves. Smells of sour malt with a hint of coffee. Taste of sour malt with an aftertaste of sparkling spring water. Not really what I expected from a porter but refreshing.

Bottle from a restaurant in Stornoway. Has a strong bread and barley aroma, very little head and a black body. Flavour is a watery mess of nothing followed by a hint of malt; palate is all water. This was a big disappointment - I hope this bottle wasn’t skunked as I got it from a local eatery!
500ml bottle from Sainsbury’s, Prestwick - very dark brown with a slight haze, no head, liquorice aroma, sour, malty, spicy, sour bitter finish

why not rate it? from old notes. Fred fest 09. nose of bour on pale malts dark fruits wood. pours orange amber thin head. flavors of sweet fruits bourbon wood pale malts and some heat. in great shape for its age. smooth and delicious.

Pours dark hazy amber with little head. Smell is fruity, dark fruit, bit of alcohol, lighter smells as well. Taste is a bit fruity with alcohol on the end. Bitterness and some malt sweetness, some caramel. Decent carbonation and drinkability. Ok

From tap at Brouwers. Pours hazy dark brown with a small white head. Aroma is overripe fruity, vanilla, dense caramel. Smooth toffee and vanilla flavoured. Subdued sweetness. Wooden and vanilla flavoured into a smooth medium dry finish.

On tap for Hard Liver ’12, pours a murky dark orange with a small beige head. Aroma of bourbon barrels, toffee and caramel, dark dried fruits - the barrels are perfect on the nose. Flavour of vanilla, bourbon barrels, dark dried fruits with a slight sourness, and some toffee. Great mesh of flavours with great execution on the barrels. Excellent.

On tap at Brouwer’s Hard Liver ’12. Pours a dark orange. Grain, fruits, and bourbon on the nose. Lots of bourbon. It’s hot, it’s fruit, and what’s that note... bubble gum! Bizarre. Tasty, but... hmm. Odd.

09 on tap at Falling Rock. Deep orange pour with a big 2+ finger off white head. Bourbon nose with dark fruits and orange peel. Med body with lots of raisin, dates, vanilla, orange and bourbon. Smooth with a warm sweet bourbon finish.

98 draft. cloudy opaque dull brown and orange body with a small off-white head. surprisingly bright nose for something that’s presumably been sitting in oak barrels for over a decade, and the expected signs of oxidation are happily absent. grain bill seems to have more pale malt than most vintages of boardhead i’ve had (which were more dark caramel in color). though it’s turbid and yeasty, the malt is succulent and decadently chewy, the hops balance the sweetness and both the level of alcohol present and the bourbon and oak flavors themselves are well-matched for the body, weight and sweetness of this beer. call me surprised, i wasn’t in the mood for anything like barley wine and certainly wasn’t feeling like bourbon barrelled barley wine, but this stuff impressed me. legit.

1998 vintage on tap at Fredfest. Pours murky copper with a decent beige head anda fruity aroma. There is a delicious fruit, toffee and vanilla flavor that is mellow as can be. There is still some carbonation and a powder dry finish, and a subtle bourbon trail. This complex brew has aged very well.

Tap @ FredFest... Holy crap!!!! This was a buzz beer right from the gates. Half pours only allowed this to last about a half hour into the fest. Poured clear, golden with an off-white head. Despite being a 1998 vintage, this still had so much heat going. Lots of whiskey flavors, oak and wood tones, creme-brulee, malts, and big time sweetness.

98 vintage. Goodness. This beer was brewed when I got married. That’s perspective. Sherry nose, amazed in the complexity between caramel and wood. Sublime, more impressed at how this beer as stood up, velvet as a fine port, melodic. Visceral. Wood note has crescendoed, and the bourbon seems to have become sweeter and condensed and taken on notes of cherry. Applause all around.
On tap at brouwers pours out dark golden color topped with a ring of a head. Nose is Oak vanilla Rich sweet malts. Taste is more of the oak Barrel vanilla a nice rich caramel sweetness.
GABBF draft. Deep Amber, almond head. Aroma raisin. Malt, vanilla. Taste vanilla, raisin, oak, malt, rich and smooth.

Draught at GABBF. Pours clear tawny with a medium, creamy beige head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is caramel and cookie malt, dates, figs, raisins, vanilla, alcohol and earthy hops. Flavor is sweet caramel malt, alcohol, dates, figs, light earthy hops and bitterness with a sweet finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

On tap at Glacier brew house. This was poured into a wine glass. The appearance was a dark brown color with no head and no lacing. The smell had a big fresh boozy sweet vanilla. A light sweet woody traces my nose nicely. The taste copied the smell and added a big boozy punch on my taste buds in the aftertaste. On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a fairly good sipping quality about it. The carbonation was smooth as a good barleywine should. Overall, this was a pretty good barleywine that I would have again.
Had on draft at the brewery. Bourbon, vanilla, warming, malty, fruity alcohol. Really enjoyed all of Glaciers big, warming, barrel aged beers.

Sample at the Brewpub. Poured dark caramel. Malty sweetness in the nose, oak, and some vanilla. Taste is almost like a port - lots of dark fruit, raisin. Oak and caramel present as well. Full bodied. Sweetness was high, but not overbearing. Only had a sample, so not sure how is like that for a full pint. This was the 2011 version.

rare beer on tap. Fuck off, im a beer celebrity. # 1 rater in the whole fucking state i should get free shit and vip tables everywhere. Nose big and sweet strong residual sugar presence dark fruit chocolate and oaky barrel whiskey notes. Toasted bread. Pours dark auburn tan creamy head. Oaky presence throughout toasted brown bread dark fruit more wood and tobacco residual sweetness. Smooth but bitey carb.

Draft: Poured a chocolate brown with a thin off white head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel malts, and bourbon. Taste is similar with lots of chocolate (which worries me about a BW), caramel sugary malt, and vanilla bourbon burn.

This is marketed as a different beer than the regular Big Woody, and the alcohol percentage is different, so I think it warrants a new entry. Light and clear brown color, scant white head. Aroma of vanilla. Taste is smooth vanilla and caramel. Nice.

On tap at the Bistro Barrel Aged Beer Fest. Pours a clear copper with a small tan head that has good retention and leaves some light lacing on the glass. Aroma is vanilla, caramel, a bit of oak, some bourbon, a bit of light alcohol, and a little bit of cherry. The initial taste is sweet vanilla, followed by some oak, caramel, a little bit of nuttiness, and some bourbon. The finish is warm with alcohol. Medium bodied. Low carbonation. Enjoyable barley wine. Perhaps a tad too sweet, but very good.
Cask Stillage at the Bhurtpore Inn, Aston 10/07/2002 Mid to dark brown porter with caramel flavours. Slightly dry lasting finish.
Cask handpump and the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. Black with a slim off-white head. Quite fruity and malty, but needs more body and alcohol.

Hand pulled at the Bartons Arms, Birmingham. Tasty, yet light Porter. Dark black, with a small beige head. Nice restrained flavour, which if critical, is perhaps too restrained. Nonetheless very pleasant, with some balckberry flavours.

Gravity Cask, Catford Beer Festival. Acidic as hell - almost like a lambic. Blackcurrant. Dark as night. Oak qualities and some ripe, damp earth. More interesting than pleasant, though it is pleasant enough.
(Cask condtioned). Sampled at the Wear Valley CAMRA beer festival, where it was served at room temperature with no carbonation. Dark ruby colour, OKish porter with just too little of everything.
Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival. Dark mahogany color. Vinous, dark wood, dark fruits, plums, and sweet. Too bad this place is gone.
On tap at the 2003 Toronado Barleywine Festival: Great chocolately malt flavor. Firm bitterness. Wonderful balance of flavors. Better than anything I ever had at the actual brewery.

Sampled at the second annual Bistro’s West Coast Barrel Aged Beer Fest, 13% abv aged on American oak for 8 months originally brewed in 2006: Pours an oily transparent dark mahogany with a thin ring of light tan head. Aroma of big licorice, oak and milk chocolate with some sweet earthy dark caramel notes. Starts rich and malty sweet with some fresh earthy oaky notes and plum complexity toward a drier mildly warming finish. A pretty nicely aged oaky barleywine.

22 oz, Free GABF sample. Dark brown. Some malt goodness (chocolate) and tropical fruit in the nose, along with a bit of oxidation. Flavor is fairly balanced, but a bit dull. Mild hints of chocolate and caramel along with a light hint of hops on the finish. A pretty good BW.
Draft at The Bistro’s BA Beer Fest 11/11/06; 2005 Vintage, Nose was fruityand spicy with an oak addition, Deep cherrywood color without a head; flavor showed oak, hops, and fruit.
deep dark red with little head.(although the head left nice lacing.)sugar and bourbon in the aroma.light mouthfeel with bourbon in the flavor.smooth mouthfeel.
Tap @ Toronado Barleywine Festival in San Francisco. Notes of coffee, chocolate, and ripe fruit. Surprisingly good and different.

Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival and last weekend I had it on tap at the brewery. This was brewed in 2001 and aged well. At the brewpub I drew a glass from the last keg they had. Festival Rating (9, 4, 8, 4, 18): dark mahogany color with a brown head. Strong fruit nose, wood, vinous, and cherry. Brewpub rating (7, 5, 8, 4, 17): mahogany color with a lush tan head. Oak wood and hops leap to the front. Dark vinous fruits and cherry. Lots of wood. This beer took 4th place at the festival.
On tap at the 2003 Toronado Barleywine Festival: Smoky. Some roast. Nice full malt presence. Mild bitterness. Creamy.

Had on tap at the brewery, this is a definite malt monster. A bit cloying for me overall, although not horrible. Notes of raisins and caramel apparent in the aroma. Pines, caramel and malt in the flavor. Goes well with the St. Louis ribs they serve.
Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival. Amber color. A little pine, fruit, honey, plums, and caramel.
On tap at the 2003 Toronado Barleywine Festival: Citric hop aroma. Big malt presence. Light body. Not bad though.

Cask Version. Dark brown color. Medium head. Aroma is malty, sweet and fruity. Medium bodied barley wine. Malts are fruity and slightly sweet. Hops are slightly bitter. Nicely balanced. No alcohol bite. A little mild and frankly kind of uninteresting. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
well, it doesn't really give me the barleywine feel, cause i'm not sure if it really is one. It kinda gave me a slightly hopped up vegetable beer jacked on alcohol. Decent.
Tap @ brewery. Little head. Alcohol nose with hops very present. Light amber esp for the style. Good mouthfeel at first but as it warms the sweetness becomes cloying. Rather one dimensional.

Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival. Amber color with a brown head. Vinous, dark fruits, and lots of hops. I like it. Brewed in November 2002 and sampled in February 2003. I had it twice and liked it both times.
On tap at the 2003 Toronado Barleywine Festival: Super grassy. Tastes like it's been dry-hopped with lawnmower clippings. Creamy and some malt in back. Too much fresh hops.
Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival. This beer is made with 50% wheat malt and aged for 6 months. Cooper color. A zesty aroma and flavor. A little sweet with some honey.
On tap at the 2003 Toronado Barleywine Festival: Malt liquor with a dollop of cream. Gah! Metallic. Not good. What I imagine a barley wine brewed by Budweiser would taste like.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler at M&P. Supposedly aged in Gentleman Jack bourbon barrels, this barley wine was complex, flavorful and smooth to drink. After all the trash we went through, this was a welcome end to the evening. I enjoyed it.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Aged in Bourbon at Bailey’s for the Anniversary Party 2008--Poured a deep brown-black body with a swirling off-white head. Sweet bitter buttery nose with a caramel malty spine. Mild bourbon and a hint of booze in finish. Nice!

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: On nitro tap at Green Dragon which led to a discussion about the pros and cons of nitro taps. Red amber beer. Thick intoxicating aroma almost makes you drunk. Creamy airy body, of course. High alcohol. Seems to be lacking in character and definitive flavour profile.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Pours amber with a small white head. The brewer warned it might be a bit undercarbonated, but it was a lighter bodied barleywine, so it didn’t feel to heavy anyway. Soft palate, smooth caramel and a subtle spiciness to the hops. This was aged in bourbon so it had a nice buttery character, not overwhelming, but very complimentary. This wasn’t over the top, but just a solid easy sipping barleywine, no excess alochol, just smooth and mellow.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: [2006 Lucky Labrador Barley Wine & Big Beer Festival] 4oz Taster – This was a cloudy dark amber color. Very sweet and simple profile. Has a peach flavor coming off the brew. Liked the flavor and the rich malts. I was thrown by the little complex flavor that this beer should have. Seemed to come off light to me.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: The words "Blast off" will forever by associated by me with Robert Esmie and this beer won’t change that. Hazy amber colour. Old (oxidized) smell is chewy and peachy with thick, fat malts. Quite sweet and simple profile, again a bit peachy. Decent flavour but lacks complexity and flavour development...which you’d expect a 3 year old sample to have.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Draught at Rose and Raindrop, Portland (2003 vintage). Clear pale brown. Nutty roastiness and grapefruity hops up front. Sweet, mature and full bodied. Restrained aromawise, flavourwise it has loads of toffee and alcohol and some crystal malt flavour. Lightly salty finish with fairly low bitterness.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: This is a relentless barleywine fron the beginnging and never lets go. Delicious sweetness on the patale, big and malty with alot of alcochol, but never cloying. Lots of fruity and yeastiness coming through in the finish with alot of hop bitterness.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sweet start, red fruits and slightly herbal, mid palate bitterness and some warming alcohol, somewhere between a malty british barleywine and maybe a Lagunitas product, pretty damn good from this tiny southern Oregon brewery.

column1: Mia and Pias Blast Off Barleywine
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival aged one year. Reddish mahogany color. A cherry and slightly medicinal flavor and aroma with some vanilla.
Great example of true cider. Leather, tannic, funky, and yet smooth. What true cider is meant to be.

500ml bottle. Pours a vigorously carbonated gold with a head that sticks just for a short while. Aroma is medicinal apple, some fresh appleskin. Flavor is tart and medicinal, feel a bit of sweetness even at 6.9.

You might disregard my opinion since all I've had is American hard cider, most of which I've made myself. I have never tasted anything like this, and I truly wonder if this bottle's journey to a bottle shop in New York state has altered its character and intention. It smells great; I like the first taste and the sticky astringency in my mouth afterward, but the mid to aftertaste reminds me of musky sheep. I do not enjoy it, but I want to since its my first English cider. Next year, I'm coming to England to see if my palette is just dumb, this cider is especially funky in nature, or if it somehow went bad across the Atlantic.
Flaske. Tog en flaske efter en cidersmagning. Ikke så god som den anden dunkerton der var mere rustik. Masser af æble sjovt nok ovenpå en tør loet livlig cider. Meget drikbar.
Taster at THBS. Pours pale yellow, sparkly head. Apples, grain, light eggy scent. Sweet.

Bottle. Waitrose. Was slightly shocked that this is no longer made at the original mill in Pembridge, but in Cheltenham. I remember visiting Dunkertons, pre RB days and parking in the shittiest, muddiest car park ever, and watching the antiquated machinery in action, and absolutely loving the place. Hey ho, that’s progress, I suppose. Anyway, this pours pale gold, with a light haze. No head. Nose has woody apple, akin to a ripe Russet. Apple cider lolly. Wood shavings. Touch of savoury smoke. Some wet leather funk. A bit spewy and pissy. In a good way. Taste is sweet, with a leathery, funky dryness. Bit of cardboard. Semi dry on the palate. Very easy drinking. Low carbonation. Funky and woody finish. How this has got such a low average score, I don’t know. Also, this is probably in my imagination, but this feels cleaner than a Pembridge made version? Still great, though. Need to drink more cider.
Botella. Unclear yellow colour. Pleasant apple rubber real cider aroma. Flavour has apple, rubber and fruit, sweet, quite pleasant.

500 ml Medium dry bottled cider from dunkertons. Very carbonated but full of flavour. Medium dry would certainly be a perfect description for this. Lots of character and flavour, dangerously drinkable and moorish. Probably the best bottled cider in the uk. (Along with the premium) Readily available from Waitrose or online via their website.
Sampled at the 2018 MN Craft Cider Festival at Como Park in St. Paul, MN. Drier cider.
Bottle at KØ18. For citric and nicely funky aroma. Hazy golden colour. No head. The flavour is nicely funky. Mild acid. Good spoke flavour. Astringent but good apple core.

dark reddish-brown colour, big dense creamy head with a beautiful lace, butter and banana aroma, notes of corn show up while the beer gets warmer, sweet, medium-bodied with a touch of sourness in the finish, light corny finish - honest, that's all
dark red-brown colour, few foam, subtle aroma of hops and grapefruit, floral with a touch of spices (netmug ?), medium-bodied with a bitter finish
brown colour, almost no foam, strong hop aroma, citrusy, slightly buttery, medium-bodied with a strong bitterness, very long bitter finish

Name: Keltic Ale Date: 08/07/1998 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy amber, solid tan head and nice lace, Aroma: dry malt aroma, Body: light body, Flavor: light malt flavor, balanced hopping, lasting hint of bitterness in the finish, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 03/16/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: Deep amber, thin beige head, solid lace, rich malt aroma and dry carmel malt flavor, just enough hops to keep it in balance and from showing any sweetness, a lot of peat shows up in the finish after just a bit of warming, the carmel starts coming throuqh at the end of the second pint. Overall: The first runnings of the mash was boiled with brown sugar to create a carmelized sugar character. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 03/20/2005 Score: iii to ii Appearance: deep clear amber, scant head Aroma: big sweet candy aroma Body: thin body Flavor: lots of sweetness, lots of carmel, a hint of body eventually shows, was better before this year’s batch of yeast caused too much attenuation, Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Pours a clear copper amber with a thin ring of white head. Nice, sweet toasty caramel and mild peat aroma. Starts semi-sweet, lightly earthy and caramel malty with good authenticity and viscosity. An enjoyable Scotch ale.

Draft @ the downtown location. Poured a clear dark golden amber color. The aroma was sweet and fruity. A little grapey. Malty caramel flavor with notes of cola and fruity. Actually reminds me of a Dr. Pepper. Medium bodied.
Neutral aroma and slighty dark appearance. Lacey. Sour off-taste dominated over any maltiness,if peaty and smokey then just too old, not finishable.
It started as thin and did not make up from there. I want that heavy and thick malt flavor in a scotch ale and this was just a little short
Dark amber with sticky head and lacing. The aroma is nutty and sour. The flavor is caramelly & sweet with a smooth finish, not too bad.
reddish brown with a spicy nutmeg nose. also had a very nutty flavor with a hint of malt
Watery malt, diacetyl and artificial flavors. Looked like an amber lager. Quite possibly the worst Scottish Ale I've had. Obviously filtered though the menu said it wasn't. Sugary, pure yeast aroma.
Brownish red, with a frooty malt aroma. Rich and sweet at the start, then has a earthy flavor, too. Seems a bit lacking somewhere. Sampled at the Great Atlanta Pub Crawl, 2004.
Reddish brown appearance. Nice malty aroma. Flavor is malty with some cherries, grapes, and spices. Somewhat of a nutty backbone. Pretty good just not great.

Comes out of the tap an opaque and chocolaty sable. Tempting aroma is of roast coffee and chocolate with a hint of molasses. Malty flavor has strong hints of Coca-Cola and molasses with an undertone of mocha and touches of cherry and hard cider. Texture is very smooth and strongly fizzy, but just a tad thin.
Mild water/caramel aroma. Taste watery, mildly sweet, a bit of alcohol. Green apple bite in finish.
The body was a deep amberish brown in color. More hazy than cloudy. Longer lasting head around edge of glass. Nutty slightly spicy (nutmeg, cinnamon) aroma. Decently fruity, medium body malt.
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of light dust, hay, caramel. Rather sweet, grains, herbal, slight note of nuts, rough bitternes.
Bottle @ Bockstival Afterparty with MrOrla. Pours clear pale yellow with a White head. Lots of grains. Dry and roughly bitter. A bit flabby and thin finish.

Bottle from Kaufland, Jena. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, light grainy and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 150216
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grass, straw, bitter hops and malt.
Aus der Flasche. Goldgelb, wenig Schaum. Herber Duft ohne Nuancen. Flacher metallischer Geschmack.
Von der Flaschenoptik ja wie ein Polihemd. Riecht auch so und scheckt dann auch so lasch wie ein Hend mit hochgeschlagenem Kragen: Austauschbar und profillos.

0,5 l bottle from kappldav123. Thanks a lot! Clear golden in the glass, big white head. That´s what you can expect from a Pilsener. No real nose. Taste has a low grainy bitterness, watery structure. Below average stuff.
* Old rating, 0,5l crown-top bottle, best before 03.03.02. Würzig-herbes Bier. Malzig mit deutlicher Herbe im Nachgeschmack.

I drink Braugold everytime I visit my friend in Erfurt. I am sure that they changed recipe since they moved production to Braunschweig. Or is it water ? I felt Braugold rather bland and tasteless. It is still nice beer though. It always goes well with Thuringer Bratwurst and Sauerkraut. Colour is very pale yellow, light body, slight gas, sweet finish.
Goldenes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch hopfig , grasig, malzig, Geschmack hopfig, blumig, trocken, leicht metallisch.

Draught @ Braukeller Rostock, Doberaner Str. 27, 18057 Rostock, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany. Clear dark amber color with a average to large, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, dark bread, roasted, caramel, brown sugar notes, alcohol notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090921]

(Bottle 50 cl) Clear dark brown with a warm, reddish hue. Distinct sweetness from the roasted malt, and notes of charamel and a faint touch of smoke. Both good looking and solidly brewed. A beer with character. 210101
Canned. Roast red. Fruity, appley, very sweet and grainy with big alcohol punch. Cheap to buy, but even more cheaply made.

column4: Två Bryggare / Österlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: Hazy blond color; big head. Lightly malty aroma, a bit sour. Tastes like a wheat beer, with a little fermentation problem.

column4: Två Bryggare / Österlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: Bottle, from a Systembolaget store in Malmö. Gold, fluffy white head that thins quickly, low condition. Some fairly chunky sediment in the bottle. Fruity nose with some apple citric notes and a smokey starchiness. Thin in the mouth with some chalkiness and a chemical/metallic note throughout. Aftertaste has a lingering nastiness like sucking a leaking battery. Sediment in the bottle smelled of decomposing cabbages. And I thought Malmö was bad.

column4: Två Bryggare / Österlenbryggarna / Bryggeriet i Ystad
column5: Bottled. Golden coloured with average head. Light acidic aroma. Medium bodied, medium sweet, rather soft and mild, but with an annoying sour tone. A decent beer with a problem.

Cask (handpump) at the Old Fountain, Old Street, 31 July 2009. Clear darkish brown colour. Some toffeeish malt. Fairly dry with moderate bitterness. Not too much like Newcastle Brown thankfully and not really much like a brown ale at all. Decent enough.

Cask (handpump) @ Old Fountain, 3 Baldwin Street, London, Greater London England EC1V 9NU. Clear dark amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, roasted, nutty, caramel. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090731]
Cask@Old Fountain. Deep amber colour, not much head. Aroma is caramel, some mild tealeafs and caramel. Flavour is quite much the same. Rather nicely balanced brew.

[Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen] A hazy dark orange beer with a thin dense brown head. The aroma is sweet matly with some notes of berries, and a touch of sulphur. The flavor is sweet with notes of toffee to start off, then a lot of fruit, before notes of citrus from the hops comes along for the bitter end. The citrus lingers for a long time.
Cask conditioned at Charlies. Dark amber coloured. Malty aroma with some hops and fruits. The flavour is not as sweet as most brown ales. It is more grassy and quite bitter. Interesting.
Cask@The Market Porter, Borough, London. Acidic, with a sweet nutty character, and grainy, thin mouthfeel. Some toffee, Thin short flavour, and a little bit fishy. Some burnt rubber.
Typical English ale appearance with a lightly hopped aroma, and a caramel/lightly hopped flavour. Overall a basic hopped ale.

Firstly this is not a brown ale, in fact its a lightish amber. But the big thing about this beer is the flavour. There appears to be plenty of dry hops, combined with well balanced malt. It drinks lighter than its declared strength, this was the cask ale. Overall quite a good strong(ish) English Ale.

2/19/05. On tap at Toronado Barleywine Festival ’04 in San Francisco, CA 2/19/05. 2004 Vintage. Dark caramel brown-red. Another oily appearance for another big bad barleywine. Things are starting to get a little samey, and that might be why I really couldn’t get excited about this beer. Somewhat leathery nose with funky fruit and faint bitterness. Crazy rising flush of a finish. Dry with a silly alcohol-liqueur sweet edge. Woody sharp and some unwelcome sourness that does not match with the malt in any meaningful way. It’s ridiculously unbalanced and has little of interest apart from its slick texture and the action in your mouth. Not a good beer-- not awful, but not much.

Draught, Toronado. Body is dark amber. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel, molasses), lightly hoppy (flowers), with notes of sherry, wood, maple, whisky, and wort. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic. There’s some raw worty scent lurking in this one, which carries some vagueness into the mouth experience. Some nice elements as well, though, so it’s ok, but not a standout.

02.19.05 Tap at Toronado BWF Brian and Dave from Boulder Creek fed me this a few times and I blame them for my behavior at the event. Thanks fellas! Sweet, round, and smooth. Maybe too much on the candi, spicey sugars. Fruity hops. Peppery finish, sweet middle. Raisins.
Tap @ Toronado Barley Wine Festival. Dark amber color with a laced tan head. Citrus zest, fruits, and plums in the flavor.
On tap at the 2003 Toronado Barleywine Festival: Sweet. Candi sugar? Big malt backbone. Mild hops. Nice but a little sweet.
Tap (Cuda Na Kiju, Warsaw) Bright orange, spongy head. Light wheaty aroma, a bit sweet. Palate sweet and a bit sticky, full, and a bit flat. Sweet wheaty taste. Dull dull dull. And Sweet. Meh.
Tap (Cuda na Kiju, Warszawa). Cloudy orange color. Medium size, white head, stays. Sweet, meat jelly, faint banana in aroma. Banana, dusty, flourish and sweet in taste. Dirty and messy. Nope.

Bottled 500ml. -from Area 12 Torino. Pale golden coloured, medium sized white head, yeast and banana in the nose. Sweetish malty, yeasty, caramel and banana with mild fruity finish. A bit watery but ok.

Weeelll... this seems adequately obscure. Found in Italy by Ogi, thanks! Poured a misty golden body with a small white head. Sweet yeasty aroma, slightly citric, mild glue and banana, not bad. Taste... somewhat lean, yeasty, light plastic, light sweetness, some lemon, slightly bitter, vaguely lactic. Not as heavy as most, interesting in several ways, but far from great.

Draught. High creamy and long lasting off-white head. Hazy yellow body. Mild smoogth sweet banana apple pear aroma. Bittersweet malty banana lemon flavor with low carbonation and a long sweet aftertaste.

Bottle 500ml. Unclear hazy medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, moderate yeasty, fruity, light banana. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light rubber - plastic bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20100604]
Bottle. Cloudy yellow with a medium white head. Banana, clove and light citrus in flavour and aroma. Ordinary.
Bottle in a bottleshop at RBESG Rome Day 2. Hazy golden yellow colour, white head. Aroma of banana and CO2. Flavour is rather thin, just a lot of CO2 with banana flavour and yeast. Light bodied.
bottle in street ... hazy yellow ... typican banana wheat nose ... again nice clean banana ester hop

Birra dal color oro slavato (?) , opalescente, la schiuma chiara e abbondante, il profumo è fresco e floreale. al palato delude, risulta morbida, ma tendenzialmente acida, con un corpo leggero che la rende ancor meno godibile.

12/2/2019. Bottle from Tuffins Supermarket, Craven Arms. Pours slightly hazy pale gold with a small off-white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, flowers, malt, grass and caramel. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, average carbonation. Watery finish, otherwise not bad.
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, hops, fruits and has a a light bitter finish.
Bottle from Tuffins, Craven Arms. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - citrus. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 110219

Bottle picked up from Hay Wines, Ledbury, Herefordshire. Consumed at home Saturday 7th November 2015. Pours gold but it is a little hazy. When you drink an Orval, then Brussels Beer Project Babylone and also Sierra Nevada Torpedo followed by this, it has to be said that this is found wanting a little in the flavour department, it’s fine just a rather ordinary beer that is a little thin and lacking in flavour a little, I guess it may be regarded as subtle I think thin and watery with a limited malt and hop profile. A6 A3 T6 P3 Ov11 2.9
Cask at the Wellington; clear golden amber pour with a bubbly white head, aroma has malts plus citrus, taste has some leafy hop action, light citrus, plus some malts.

Bottle from Saucy Pears. Appearance - golden amber and cloudy. Nose - oranges, soapy. Taste - orange shred, light malt. Then astringent on the finish, Palate - light bodied with a dry texture and a fairly astringent finish. Overall - very unpleasant.
Bottle thanks to AshtonMcCobb. Pours hazy pale golden. Nose is soapy, malty, some orange. Taste is light, lemon, malts, straw slight bitterness.
Bottle at ash’s. Pours hazy pale orange, nose is lemon fairy liquid, taste is thin, sweet, soapy, floral.
Bottle at the School’s Out Tasting. Pours hazy gold with a thin white head. Aromas of mild green, fairy liquid, soapy. Taste is lemony, soapy. Astringent finish. Can it get any Worcester?
Bottle @ home thanks to Countbeer. Clear golden color, small white head. Smell and taste malts, lightly hops, lightly fruity, nicely bitter. Average body and carbonation.
Bottle at the 'Back to the Roots Classic German Beer Tasting' session. I only took numerical notes while having this.
Sampled at Müllerbräu Pfaffenhofen. Long lasting beige head. Clowdy yellow color. Big banana aroma. The banana also dominate the taste. A litle sweet finish.

Bottle, courtesy of Koelschtrinker. Pours cloudy orange. Aroma is pretty typical for a German hefeweizen, maybe a little more grass than usual. Body is medium and pretty dense and bready. Sweet too. Some grains. Quite good.

(bottle) murky deep golden colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of rotten peaches and clove, with a touch of overripe banana and yeast. flavour is mostly the same, lots of rotten fruit and clove, with a light hint of wheat and a rather chalky finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Hazy golden with medium white head. Aroma of clove and less banana, some yeast. Very clean. Taste is again yeasty stuff. Finish is more banana. Not bad.

Farbe: trüb, bräunlich, dunkler als ein normales Hefe. Schaum: fein, beständig Nase: relativ würzig für ein Hefe Geschmack: voll, feinperlig aber viel Kohlensäure. Abgang erdig, Weizen, Kellerhefe, Banane, etwas bitter. Nachgeschmack: ebenso. Nicht schlecht, erdige Weizenvariante..

500ml bottle. Cloudy dark golden colour with huge, frothy, off-white head. Slightly bready, wheaty and yeasty spicy aroma, hints of dried banana, orange, some clove, a touch of speculoos. Taste is initially quite neutral, wheaty, strawy, later slightly sweet malty with hints of banana, a touch of speculoos again. OK taste, but starts with a watery section making up almost two thirds of the course.

Bottle. Golden, cloudy, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate, malty – some wheat and sweetish aroma, light fruitiness and banana, faint yeast. Body is light to medium, malty – lightly wheaty and sweetish flavor, light caramel, light fruitiness and banana with faint yeast. Finish is average, malty – lightly wheaty and lightly sweetish - sweetish, light caramel, faint fruitiness and banana. Sweetish hefe with caramel - lacks character.
Trübes orangegelbes Weissbier mit grobporigem weißen Schaum. Geruch fruchtig, bananig, hefig, Nelke. Geschmack estrig fruchtig, bananig, etwas Nelke im Mittelteil, bananig im Abgang.

500 ml bottle. Pours a hazy golden colour with a foamy head. Aroma of wheat, grass and yeast. Flavour of sweet caramel, yeast, wheat and some banana esthers. Medium bodied and a bit foamy mouthfeel. Sweet.
Cask @ Lord Raglan, Nangreaves. Amber with a small creamy head. Light texured and slips down the palate with a smoothness. It has a light toffee sweetness behind its malts.

Cask conditioned at Stratford upon Avon Beer Festival ’15. Hazy gold with white head. There was a stale cigarette aroma to this which did follow into the flavour, fags, tobacco, quite dry. I really wasn’t that keen on it.

Cask (handpump) @ Babington Arms, 11-13 Babington Lane, Derby, Derbyshire England DE1 1TA. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, light hoppy, detergent, light yeasty, phenol notes. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, some underlying tartness. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100117]
Cask. Pours an almost clear amber with an off-white head leaving laces. Lightly fruity nose. Medium body, a little fruit and licorice with a vague underlying tartness. Fruity, orangey finish. 170110
Cask at Cloisters ... copper ... sweet toffee malt ... fruity bitter malts ... light hop ... bitter background.

Cask gravity at Ashford Rugby Club BF 2008. Clear copper, thin beige head. Pretty good easy drinking bitter, with some yellow grapefruit sourness on finish. Bit of tea. Some really nice fruit and a very tasty, slightly different bitter.
Cask Stillage at the Memorial Hall, Northwich 22/09/2001 Amber coloured and pale. Some fruit flavours and a slightly bitter finish.

(Cask conditioned). Sampled at the Wear Valley CAMRA beer festival. Low (natural) carbonation. Golden colour, citrus aroma. Fruity flavour, very refreshing despite being served at room temperature (should be moderately chilled).
Cask at Ye Old Elm Tree, Durham, £2.85/pint. Decent if slightly uninteresting, reasonably hoppy bitter.
4.1 jarrow. Cask at the Kings Arms Sunderland. Pours hazy golden amber with a thin white head. Aromas of caramel, little else. Taste is light sweet. Chalky finish.

500ml bottle as a Christmas gift: This one was an easy going, inoffensive and fairly average bitter that was easy to drink but done little to catch my imagination or make it memorable. Whilst certainly drinkable, it somehow seemed a little plain and basic sadly and as such it’s not one I’m likely to pick up again I’m afraid.

Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Festival ’14. Brown with white head. There is a caramel note within the malts, smoothing rather than over the top, breadcrust hints, baked malt then a pleasant leafy, fresh hoppy note with a woody finish. Good stuff.
Bottles from Fenwick and Coppers, Newcastle. Amber coloured with a burnt toffee and red fruity flavour with a sweet, creamy bitter, peppery hop finish.
Cask by hand-pump at Bon Accord, Glasgow - hazy golden amber, thin creamy off-white head, fruity malty aroma, good patterned lacing, sweet earthy, toffee, easy to drink, good carbonation

1/2 at the Tilley Stone Gateshead. Nice looking light brown beer with an off white head. Fruity hop aroma. Nice dried apple and rich tea biscuit flavour. More hop in the finish. Definitely at the hoppy end of the English bitter spectrum, and not out of the ordinary, but strangely pleasurable.
On cask at Black Bull, Melsonby. Pours copper with white head. An inoffensive run of the mill bitter.

Crystal clear amber beer with a head that sustains. In this bar anyway. Plenty of juicy citrus fruit in the taste. Only let down by a rather vegetable aroma of cabbage and potatoes. Otherwise ok. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask @ GBBF 2011. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with earthy hints. Sweetish fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty earthy finish.

Cask. Deep ruby ale with a thick light tan head. Nose is incredibly malty with a light grassy hop. First mouthful is full of malt with some hay/strawlike notes but then out bursts the hoppiness. Really well balanced and makes the sweetness get blasted by the bitterness and then finish with a nice bittersweet dryness.
[Cask from The Three Judges] Deep amber colour with a small head. Aroma of caramel and toasted malt, lots of esters, berry fruits. body feels on the watery side, fruity palate, touch of dryness.
Aroma guives honey a touch of roasted malts, grassy. Taste gives more grass than expected, but to be honest this beer is durhamed out its nut.
Cask Handpump at Blind Jacks, Knaresborough 28/04/2004 Mid brown colour and very fruity with some sourness. Quite bitter slightly dry finish.

(Cask conditioned). A brand new beer from the enterprising brewers of Durham, sampled at the Wear Valley CAMRA beer festival. (Room temperature). CAMRA stated the ABV to be 4.2%, brewery website says 3.9% (possibly not updated - they speak of the beer as a project in the making). CAMRA write "Bonnie" (which is logical), brewery website says "Bonny" - I guess they have their reasons. Low (natural) carbonation. Reddish brown colour. Malty aroma and flavour, moderate hops. The North East English style is really a marriage between English bitter and Scottish "heavy". Not a bad brew (quite good, actually), but a beer as malty as this would profit on a higher ABV.

Date: 10/04/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Durham hazy yellow, big white head, mild banana and clove aroma that follows through nicely into the flavor and lingers into the finish Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Cloudy lemon-yellow with minimal head. Aroma is banana, some yeast, clove, lemon. Taste is banana, clove, lemon tart. Light and refreshing body.

Big, very dense white head on top of a golden, crystal clear body with decent carbonation. Loaded with bananna esters and phenols. Very buttery and light. Wheat does stand tall and proud. Buttery wheat cloys for quite some time. Really a good interpretation of a German Wheat.

Yeasty wheat aroma. Smells authentic. Good flavor, malty and yeasty and with the typical hefe flavors. The only complaint is that it has a weak finish (hops not satisfactory) and that the body is not crisp enough. I know that a hefe is not really crisp, but that is the best description that I can give. Still, not too bad, and one of their better beers, even if it is seasonal.

Cask. Golden, cloudy with a short head. Lovely floral hoppy scent. A bit thick and sticky in the mouth. Moderate bitterness, some sweetness on the end. Hint of carbonation. Grapefruit predominates. Lots of citrus hop at the start then a little malt. Very nice at first but looses its taste after a few sips.

Pours a generally clear golden yellow with thin white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of light fruit, light malt, some light caramel and honey. Flavor is generally the same with light notes of honey, caramel, fresh fruit. Generally light to medium body with a quick finish.
Bottle. Slightly hazy orange appearance.Poured flat and was surprisingly thin considering its strength. Not a lot going for it.

Cask-conditioned at the Cornish Beer Festival, The Star, Bath 16/07/09. Amber coloured with next to no head. Aroma of red fruit, a touch of caramel and some dusty hops. Relatively easy drinking given the ABV, with more fruit and sweetness, and an earthy, bitter finish. Good.
bottle from Darts Farm. Hazy deep amber colour, mid-sized head. Fruity and malty with hints of citrus fruit. Hoppy with a lemony character, es pecially in the finish.

500 mL bottle brought back from England by my wife. Poured a clear amber color with no head at all. The aroma was very malty and earthy. The flavor was fruity, with only a faint bitter finish. I’m not sure if the beer was flat, or just very softly carbonated, but it wasn’t that great.

Cask conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Hazed amber with white head. Pretty basic bitter, however i think it was a little tired, there was a sharp yeastiness, old ale type flavour. Malty, fruity and a touch sweet.
