Bottled. Pours clear gold to murky amber, depending how much yeast wriggles into the glass. Creamy suds and mouthfeel. Juicy hop fruitiness in the snout. Hoppily fruity and bitter, with an almost guezey fustiness. Earthy and sourish. Feels homemade, but pretty good.
Bottle picked up from Darts farm, Topsham Devon, November 2006. Poured dark amber colour, quite fulll flavoured and fruity nice hoppiness to it.
very nice beer, not really bitter, but the flavour, strong, sweet and be carefull while dirnking it. I like these bitters.

column1: Gilded Otter Naked Under Me Kilt Scottish Ale
column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: From a growler. Pours hazy brown with a fizzy off white head. Tastes slightly bitter, nutty, light booze. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like malty booze and light nuttiness.

column1: Gilded Otter Naked Under Me Kilt Scottish Ale
column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: A: Dark Brown hue, mild Off White Head, mild Lacing S: Dark Malts, Nutty, mild Caramel T: Dark Roasted Malt, mild Caramel, Smokey M: Mediocre Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Smokey, Watery Overall, a Scotch ale that is very drinkable but lacks in taste, especially in caramel.

column1: Gilded Otter Naked Under Me Kilt Scottish Ale
column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the Otter. Pours a mostly clear ruby hued cola brown with a thin lightly tanned beige head. No real big aromas, but nothing off putting, so I guess that’s a plus. Light caramel and malt. Kind of watery, faint sweet malt flavor. Finishes up with a bit of a metallic twang and a bit of an acrid roast bitterness.

column1: Gilded Otter Naked Under Me Kilt Scottish Ale
column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: Pint pour @ the brewpub. Color is dark brown but can still make out that it is a clear beer. Aroma is green off the bat, too young, its mainly a very youthful metallic sweetness. Taste is the same, way too young. It also has a very thin body and weak body. This would be the most disappointing beer I have had from this brewpub.

column1: Gilded Otter Naked Under Me Kilt Scottish Ale
column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: Very dry, earthy, peaty, little sweetness; rather odd for a Scotch I thought but the house profile seems to be on the dry side so whatever. Sweeter/maltier on the nose than the tongue, slightly thin but quite decent.

column1: Gilded Otter Wallkill River Dark Wheat
column2: New Paltz, New York, United States
column5: Clear dark, faint sweetish nose, malty-sweet, no carbonation or hops to speak of, very slight stale mown grass character, bland and flat.

Super ruby color with a rich, white, lingering head. Aroma of raspberry of coarse, but also cherries and citrus (I did have this as a "half and half" over the wheat). Full berry flavor comes through, not really tart and definitely not sweet. Very dry and clean. Hate to say it but I rate it over New Glarus.

Nitro tap. Clear golden. Easy going going grain nose. Flavor is sweet grainy malt with light honey graham cracker and a light grassy bitterness. Nitro really adds a nice dimension. Wouldn’t have thought.

Tap at OSS. Nitro pour. Clean and easy, not unlike a Boddingtons or similar UK draught. Steady foamy off-white head. Smooth, cream golden malt. A little watery, not much depth. Hyper-sessionable light body. OK. Sublime. Simple. Brewhouse bland aroma. OK.

Draft at HopCat Madison. Pours crystal clear gold with Guinness style foam that slowly settles - mesmerizing. Aroma of light vanilla, straw. Taste is peppery, moderately bitter, silky smooth creamy mouthfeel. Very nice.

On tap. Golden pour with the expected thick head, which does not go away. not much aroma - slightly astringent and floral. Flavor is a good balance of malt and some floral hops. Definitely some resin in the finish. Thick, silky mouthfeel, as expected. Not a huge fan of the style, but good for what it is.
Draft. Clear copper color with thick white nitro head; thick lacing. Subtle malt aroma. Smooth, creamy malt upfront. Pleasant bitter finish with slight resin. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Backlog rating on 8-15-2012 at 800 Degree Three Fires (Fort Wayne, IN) This nitro beer pours a lot of foam and then is reduced to a small creamy smooth white head that is fully lasting, transparent yellow body, very little carbonation observed, and a generous amount of lacing adorns my glass. The aroma is biscuits, malt, hops, and a suggestion of fruitiness. The flavor is sweet, malt and mild hops. The mouthfeel is smooth and this beer is medium bodied. This beer has mild English hops and is very quaffable.

[Tap] Pours a clear brown color without much head. Nose is of chalky malts and maybe a hint of nuttiness. Toasted breads, light grass and caramel in the taste. Smooth mouthfeel and low carbonation levels. Nice and sessionable.
On nitro at WOB. Creamy gold pour with a thick white head. Light earthy citrus hop aroma. Creamy malt body with a touch if hops. Very good.

Tap. Yellow pour with a monster white nitro head. Slightly bready, mostly a little grassy hop kick late. Easy drinking. Nitro was a good call with this to add a visual and palate element to an otherwise kind of ho-hum beer.

This draft brew poured a small sized head of cascading foam white colored bubbles that were and left behind a uncarbonated transparent orange colored body and an excellent lacing. The weak aroma was hoppy and malty. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of creamy smooth malt. An OK brew just nothing special.

Bocks are not a style that I drink a lot...and haven't had a lot of them to compare too. This one seems better than average, but I have had some with more flavor and balance. Somewhat of a complex flavor, with caramel, toffee, bread, light fruit & maple. Gives it a sour and tart aroma. Enjoyable for sure.

Clear dark brown body with a thin tan head. Light aroma of grain, maple, and tea. Palate is a bit thin for a bock. Flavor is pretty mild. A somewhat sweet entry of maple and biscuit leads to a lightly bitter tea finish. Not bad. I was expecting more flavor, but it’s drinkable.

12 ounce bottle from a Pick N Save. Dark brown, poor retention. Aroma of maple, nuts, tea, caramel. Taste is tart cherry and brown malts. Hints of raisin. Thin. Seems like some infection here that has stripped out all the flavor. Hints of maple emerged after I typed that entire previous sentence. Sad. Coulda been great. Checking the bottle for a best by date, and.... it's completely illegible. Turns out this is bad but I still respect this brewery... for now.

I would pin this as more of a porter or maybe a schwartzbier than a bock but whatever. It's pretty good. It is mildly roasty, smooth and very pleasantly drinkable. I think their might be a faint woody tone from the maple but I don't know jack shit about beer so bite me.

Pretty brown ale, tasty, drinkable… if it weren’t on the label, I don’t think I’d detect maple syrup. Pours dark brown, clear, effervescent, with a big, creamy, long lasting head. Aroma roasted grain. Taste starts faintly sweet, with a roasty dry finish. Medium body palate. Overall very pleasant, drinkable beer… nicely balanced winter brew.

Bottle in cellar. Poured at home in a snifter. Deep brown with a modest off-white head. Aroma is big maple, biscuit, brown sugar, caramel, cocoa nibs. The taste is similar with cocoa nibs, nuts, caramel, burnt wood, and Wurthers candies. Medium body and carb. Slight bitter finish and then sweet.
Draft at Fishale. Nice dark chestnut color with a head of tiny tan bubbles. Light aroma of chocolate, caramel malt and oddly enough crayons. Flavor is okay for a bock but I’m missing the maple. Fine.
Pours a dark brown color with tan colored head. Maple, molasses, sweet dsrk fruits, raisins and dates on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with maple syrup like sweetness.

Dark mossy aroma, dubbel-esque. Clear dark root beer black-brown. Thin khaki head. Dry, woody, a little dark malt comes through. Earthy moss tones and some tannic acidity. Medium body, a little astringent. Didn’t like. Growler County.

Tallahassee, Fl - ABC Fine Wine & Spirits - Betton - pint bottle. Deep, dark brown pour, thin, but persistent khaki colored head that clings to the edge of the glass. Aroma has a hint of maple sweetness, some dates and raisins, could be a bit bolder. Flavor is solidly bock-like, raisins, dates, a hint of chocolate, just a wee-bit of the advertised maple. Decently thick mouthfeel. Not bad, just nothing jumps out about it.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Sampled on draft at the Pittsburgh location this beer poured an oily black color with a medium sized creamy brown head that lingered forever and produced good lacing. The aroma was a pleasant mix of coffee, bakers chocolate and toasty malts. The flavor was a wonderfully complex mix of tangy malts, sweet chocolate syrup,coffee, vanilla, fruity hops, port wine, rum, anise and leather. The finish was incredibly long with notes of chocolate, vanilla and rum standing out. The body was thick, smooth and oily - coating the tongue and refusing to leave. Incredible.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: A very fine beer. Deep mocha in color, with strong mocha/coffee notes mingling with chocolate malts, roasted nuts, and a pleasntly warming alcohol flavor coming through.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On tap at the Lucky Lab big beer fest. Excellent stout, very rich chocolate and coffee flavor with a big bold roastiness. Smooth on the palate with coffee notes trailing off in the finish.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Not bad for a chain brew, this was black with the usual tan head, malty aroma, and roasty flavors, and a very slight hop flavor.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Wow, after reading the other two ratings i wonder if i had the same beer. Great dark color, but thats it. Quite weak, watery mouthfeel, light hop finish, with a touch of sweet malt. Mostly just watery.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Deep charcoal. Frothy foam. Mocha laden aroma, with undertones of baker's chocolate, light caramel, and leafy hops. Velvety palate. Flavors of cardboard, acidity, roasted malt, mocha, and a long bitter charcoal finish. Lacking in mouthfeel, but quite full of flavor.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: A decent imperial from a chain brewery. It had a nice flavor, with light touches of malt and hops. Probably one of the better beers they have... there is hope.

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: "a decent enough nutty malty brown ale. light in body and flavor, but what is there is nice, and makes for a decent session ale...nothing less, nothing more."

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: Draft. An amber beer with a thin tan head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of caramel and metal as well as a light note of something skunky, leading to a dry and metallic finish.

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: Sample at the brewpub on 8/7/10. Clear reddish copper pour with a medium tan head. Grainy and malty aroma with a bit of roast and not much hop. Dank and nutty flavor with some roast at the end.

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: On tap. Clear warm orangey brown with an off-white head. Sweet nutty aroma with a lightly smoky edge. Medium body, nutty accents, burned caramel and a vague smoky finish. 130709

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden deep orange with a small off-white head. Roasted malty aroma. Mild acidic and light roasted malt flavoured. Light fruity. Light roasted flavoured finish. Simple and not really nutty.

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: Name: Northern Mild Nutty Brown Date: July 06, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear amber, wispy grey head Aroma: light malt aroma Flavor: sweet caramel and chocolate flavor, touch of nutty character, light earthyness, touch of the ever present bitter astrengency Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 8/20 Rating: 2.3/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: *+/4

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: I’ve had this in the bottle and on tap on several different occasions. On tap would probably be my favorite. My rating on this will be on the bottled version. A medium sweet (undefined) aroma. Reminded me a bit of smelling a sugar bag, with a touch of vinegar. Appearance is a chalky brown, off-white head with a medium thickness to it. Flavor has that odd acidic/vinegar like quality, but mostly it’s lightly roasted, with a touch of nut and malt to it. Easy to drink, but I think I’ll stick with this on tap.

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bomber from Brew It Up. It’s too bad this brewery gets a bad rap on the ratings system. The brown was exceptionally smooth, although medium-bodied. There’s really no carbination to speak of, but I tend to like that. Good palate, enjoyable brown.

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: Bottle from Brew it Up! in Sacramento, CA. Poured a brown color with a small head. Nutty flavor with a hint of chocolate. Medium bodied beer that was very even on the palate. Good beer.

column1: Brew It Up! Northern Mild Nut Brown Ale
column5: ~Pours a brownish amber color with small creamy head. ~Has a mild malty scent. ~Has a toasted malt flavor and maybe chocolate? ~Medium feel, light bitter finish. `Roasted flavor is strong and distinct. Pretty good brew. Scent was definitely lacking.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Roasted malts and chocolate in the aroma. Opaque dark brown with thin ring of tan/brown head that partially covers. Sweet chocolate with roasty finish and some resinous hops. Definite alcohol warming. Medium body is luxurious and creamy in the mouth. Sampled September 2003.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: I also sampled this at the Extreme Beer fest in Boston 2004 and it was delicious. Similar to a few of Magic Hat seasonal offerings, (they love experimenting)roasted coffee, chocolate, sweet & dry so many tastes, they do so much with their flavors but they all have their distinct style. A bit watery but it doens’t take away from this excellent brew, just makes me want more!! Another winner form Magic Hat!

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Dark, dark brown with a thin, tan ring of bubbles. Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and white toast. A touch of dark fruit pops it's head up from time to time. Moderately thick body. Roasted, bitter flavor dominates through out. The alcohol, while not imperceptible, is difficult to find except for it's warmth. Towards the end, the hops really contribute pine, citrus and additional bitterness. I think a little time to mellow would really help this one out. Subduing the intense bitterness and bringing out the fruit would really make this amazing.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Extreme Beer Fest 2004: Dark ruby color without any head. Roasted aroma, full creamy syrupy body, starts sweet and ends bitter. Not sure why everyone else rated this so low, I'll have to try it again.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Extreme Beer Fest '04, Black,no head,low carbonation.Fruit and roasted malt aroma and flavor.Sweet malt finish.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Extreme Beer Fest '04: Very dark brown with aroma of espresso and fruit. Taste is nice and smooth with a light coffee flavor. I like it.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Draft @ extreme beer fest'04: Good nose, Dried fruit, coffee, berries. Nice brownish black color. Coffee, chocolate, raisen/plum and a tad of whiskey. A little on the thin side, but a tasty offering from Magic Hat

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: A very decent Imperial stout from a company I don't always trust. Very thick with molasses. Sweet, but not syrupy or sticky. Well-balanced - roasty and warm. Fuzzy alcohol feeling.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: On tap at Bling Tiger, NY - I was a bit skeptical about this one, considering I'm not all that fond of their Heart of Darkness Stout, but I must admit I was really impressed - this beer is very, very, very much like Storm King, but a much thicker mouthfeel - this beer truly is "chewy" - sweet, but it has a lot of hop bitterness that actually lends itself well to the chocolate/coffee flavor going on - some cherries and plums in the mix - what's this? it burps up the taste of pine? quite odd - great if you can find it.

column4: Magic Hat Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: On tap at Three Needs in Burlington, March 2. Thick espresso-shake-black, very stable medium-brown head. Wonderful aroma first seemed to be that of raisins, but later was more cherry-chocolaty with hints of French vanilla. Medium-sweet flavor, more chocolate than coffee, nice bitterness towards the end but also hints of metal. A little on the thin side in the body (oh Magic Hat, thou art close to a great brewer, but put some BODY in thy brews!), finish nice & roasty-toasty; goes down just a little bit too easily, like its just fading away. A good, not great, Imperial; the Thumbsucker whiskey cask-aged version I had tonight is a bit more complex and interesting, but both are worth trying if you can get your hands (or at least thumbs or nails) on them.

The black wasn't black enough and the tan definetely wasn't tan enough. It was more like pond water. I have to give it to the gluek brewery, they are very proficient at sucking. Hey, if your going to suck, mine as well do a good job of it. Tastes just like the other eureka's, there's no point in describing the taste, for its reputation speaks volumes.

OK....i was in the liquor store. I read the tag carefully...it said and i quote..."Black and tan"...a bock mixed in with a brown ale...and what the hell does this wind up smelling like....yeah, you got it. It smells like g'DAMN HONEY AGAIN!!!! Every single You Reek Ugh beer smells like honey!!!!! This one however has the distinction of also smelling like robitussin and nyquil. As if it matters (understanding you obviously know whats coming if youve read this far), the appearance is a clear and lightlly carbonated orange thing with a forced mini white head. The taste makes me wanna bust out the milk.... Imagine this if you will...you're watching Seinfeld and Kramer enters the room...you know that surprised look he would have on his face...well yeah, that was me standing aghast after i sipped this putrescence of liquid. It begins with a strange...well i wouldnt call it bockness, more like a grainy malt. Literally, straw, and dirt along with corn!!! Blegh...then this dry nasty malty ending that reminds me of roasted dung beetles (yes...im running out of ways to describe how bad this is). Terrible mouth feel, and very bad beer. So this is why they are so close to the budweiser.....
No head clear amber coloured body, yeasts some malts like smell, high carbonation no bitter yeasts chemical absolut discusting
Tap at 2e Flevo Bierfestival, Almere: Amber colored brew with an very mediocre taste. Why Almere,why, do you have this breweries with bad beers.
Aroma of light fruits, citrus, some yeast, a little hoppiness. Flavour is fruity, light sweetness, with some bitterness in the finish. Decent, but rather ordinary.
Bottle. Golden- yellow colour with a white head. Aroma is yeast, flower, malt, citrus. Flavour is yeast, flower , malt, hop, citrus, grain. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

Bottle 750ml. ABV: 5.5%. Clear medium yellow colour with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, light citrus, moderate yeasty, fruity yeast, fruit, yeast. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average duration, fruity, pale malt, yeasty. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft - fizzy. [20131122]

Bottle, 75cl. An unclear, pale golden beer with some microfloaties. The aroma is quite weak, mostly fruity, with some malty notes. Dry on the palate, with a pleasant carbonation level. Medium to thin body. It’s grainy and fruity in the mouth, with some bitterness towards the end. Short fruity finish with some bitterness. Rather boring this one. 131122

Bottle @ Scooper Tasting in Ulfborg. Pours cloudy yellow with small and quickly vanishing white head. clear aroma of hops, yeast and vegetables. Bitter, hoppy flavour, with pronounced notes of citrus and a good deal of yeast. Slightly rough aftertaste. OK but nothing truly revolutionary.

Bottle 750ml @ fonefan Pours slightly hazy golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, sugar, yeast and hint of dried fruits. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light to medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle @ Invasion U.S.A, Ulfborg 2013. Pours hazy yellow with a small creamy head. Rotten fruit, yeast - too much, grass and dust. Overcarbonated.

Bottle, 5.5%. Hazy yellow with medium white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, yeast, little straw and grainy. Flavour is malt, medium dutch carbonated, fruit, yeast, grainy, hop, little straw and a little bitter.

1. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 25/01/2002 Dark coloured and strong in alcohol with some fruit aroma. Smooth on the palate with a roast malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich 13/04/2004 Dark coloured slightly rich on the palate and fruity. Smooth slightly roast dry finish.
Cask at Briar Rose (JDW) Birmingham. Wonderful, wonderful stuff. Even my non-beer-drinking wife liked the taste of this. Viscous black, gentle dryness, gentle roasties, just outstanding.

Cask@Catford Beer festival. Can’t complain with this one, top quality. Coffee bean, riasted malt, lightly tart and acidic, with a nice roasted bitter chocolate finish, tasty indeed, thanks to spiesy for the recomendation.

Very dark brown, opaque colour. Strong coffee aroma which carries through onto the palate, where roasted malt and chocolate also put in an appearance. Quite dry and very smooth, with a good depth of flavour and some sweetness. Long, dry malty finish, with some bitterness in the aftertaste. In a festival dominated by average bitters and thin milds, this stood out. Excellent stuff. Cask, Catford Beer Festival.

Cask Conditioned, Masque Haut, London. Black as the night with a dark brown scummy head. Supper roasted flavour, juicy and scrumptious. Was very impressive. It looked like an imperial sitting in the glass. Wonderful stuff.
Cask-conditioned @ JDW. Coffee roast and a touch of fruit and some woody aromas. Quite dry and thin with minimal bitterness. Served far to cold but didnt improve much as it warmed.

JDW Faversham. A good roasted barley flavour and a dark dark dark colour. A strong mild. Not much going on - pleasant but boring. [2.5] JDW Welling. Black with dark mahogony edge barely visible. Coffee coloured creamy foam head. Soft roasty notes which emerge clearly with chocolate and coffee flavours in the finish which ends abruptly leaving only a memory of the flavour. Hops and dark malts play together throughout. A spanking good ale. [3.7] JDW Rochester Third time for this one, and it just gets better every time. Bags of roasty, coffee flavours in a smooth and dangerously drinkable base. Touches of wine here and there. Interesting edges and corners. Served in perfect condition. This is top drawer.

(Cask conditioned). Sampled at the Wear Valley CAMRA beer festival. (Room temperature, low natural carbonation). Listed there as a stout (I would even say dry stout, though it's a tad sweeter than the Irish ones), but another local CAMRA website claims that a beer named Luddite has been judged as a "strong dark mild". I'll leave that to the category freaks. Anyway, this beer is pitch black with a delicious roast aroma and flavour, but the mouthfeel is a bit thin despite the relatively high ABV. Add a little nitrogen, and it would compete with draught Guinness (or rather: Beamish).
this is interesting... bits of acetic acid, buttery feel, butterscotch. Gone wrong to the point of curiosity.
Light amber, no head. Lacks aroma, bit fruity. Sweet, slightly sour fruity bitter. Not good.

Amber coloured. Some grassy hops, and a hint of sulphur, in the aroma. Dry, hoppy flavour, with a touch of fruit. Slightly sharp finish. Decent enough, but there’s not really much to hold the attention. 500ml bottle (bottle conditioned) from the Beer Seller, Lincoln. Best before 31 Jan 2005.
Bottle. Not much of an aroma, maybe some grainy malt and a touch of lemon. Palate is thin and boring, slight lemon tang and grainy pale malt.

Bottled at The London/Joet Gathering Chez Chris_O. A little bit of hop was discovered lurking at the back of the aroma of this amber coloured bitter. The taste was crisp and clean with some abrasive hop but otherwise was very plain and ordinary.
Bottle & Chris’ Place Miurky gold. Aroma is malt with strong tobacco pouch, sheesh. Flavour is malty, slightly fruity and buttery and then some ashtray.
Cloudy orange beer with a foamy off-white head. Quite odd aroma with some hop, grass and fruit. Harsh and sharp flavor. Hayish, yeasty and citrusy. Not a beer for me.

Bottled: Unclear orange coloured. Has a small beige head. Light hopped and light spiced aroma. Apart from some hop characters the flavour has some fruity and sweet notes. Ends on a medium bitter note.
Weak hop aroma. Hazy golden bodyt, small white head. Hop flavor, some tobacco.
A hazy orange beer with a small white head. The aroma is spicy and yeasty. The flavor is very yeasty with notes of caramel and coriander.

Bottled. Gold, moderate head and condition. Nondescript nose, some malt in the soft body and a thin dry finish. One of many lagers made by Martens, possibly weakend for English tastebuds but still better than most UK 4% lagers, that’s no recommendation though.

Half-pint, gravicask at Cowes Ale House. Clear amber-reddish body, filmy layer, scattered lacing. Moderate smell of slightly roasted caramel malts. Decent caramel fruity flavours. Mid-dry bittersweet end. Satisfying. (Isle of Wight, Cowes 21.10.2019).
Mørk nøttebrun. Bobleaktig filmskum. Klar. Lett nøttearoma. Smaken tørket frukt. Tørr syrlig avslutning.
Bottle from Garsons, Titchfield. Dark amber strong ale with a malty taste. Not as hoppy as I was expecting

Unknown origin or method of dispense, early April 2017. I like this, even double-fisted with a Citra. Fat cream collar over clean bronze. Nose a touch coppery but flavour is subtly red vinous with a Rodenbach-like aged tang with iron and caramel. Bitter balancing finish. Subtly complex silky bitter with mysterious Belgian streaks.
Quite thick with a caramel maltiness. An aftertaste of bitter hops but not as strong as you expect.
Cask at the William Shenstone, Halesowen. Pours dark brown with a small head. Aroma is burnt caramel and boiled sweets. Taste is bready throughout with some dark berries on the finish.

Fra håndpumpe på The Mossy Well, Muswell Hill (London): klar rødlig kobber med ok skum. Igjen en god, maltdrevet øl hvor Fuggles og Goldings bidrar til den fine smaken med urter, jordtoner og hint av citrus. Lang og god ettersmak. God kropp med krydderfornemmelser og noe bær i anslaget.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A clear amber colour with a medium off white head. Aroma of toffee, bready malt, some sticky fruits, slight orange peel and subtle earthy hops. Taste of toffee, bready malts, fruit, some brown sugar, a hint of orange and subtle earthy hops. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. A soft, bittersweet, earthy hop bitterness in the finish. Nothing wrong with this at all. A typical British premium bitter.

.Pours a dark amber colour with ao small creamy off white head. A pale toffee and light malt aroma, a rich sweet brown sugar toffee and malt flavour. A smooth and lingering hoppy oily resinous bitter finish.

Cask handpull at The Crosse Keys London as Goddards Ducks Folly, 5.2%. Dark amber, translucent, still, foamy white head. Aroma is bready, musty dried sugars. Body is light, smooth with tingly carbonation. Taste is resinous, British- hops forward, floral and bitter resin, wood chip and bitter herbs, soft malt backbone backing it up. This is an unashamedly old school properly bitter bitter. I quite like it.
I can’t agree with the lightly flavored as it was bursting with a nice raspberry aroma and flavor. It managed to cover up most of the cool yeast from the base wheat, otherwise pretty solid.
Can smell the raspberry, which is a good thing. Cloudy wheat beer appearance with a slight pink tinge. Tastes of raspberry and wheat beer. Not too tart or sweet.(k)

A very weak representation of a fruit beer. Aroma is nice if you put your nose close enough. Body is light and raspberry flavor is too. Could have used greater amounts of fruit. Finish is light and boring.

Pours a clear light amber color with a white head. Sweet raspberry flavoring and a bit of sugar. Some grassy hops underneath, a bit of soda water, and a bit of malt. The flavor is a touch watery, almost like soda water. Raspberry, a hint of sugar, very mild malt, and a definite grass note and mild bitterness.
Sweet raspberry flavor with some banana only a little tart. This was given to me by a friend it was good.
On tap at the brewpub. Clear light yellow, lacy head. Aroma-raspberries. Taste-raspberries, wheat, well put together. Good beer.

On tap @ the brewpub. Cloudy light orange with a small white head. Banana and bubblegum up front with some fresh tart raspberries, as well as some artificial sweet raspberry behind. Flavor has the bananas dominating withthe sweet and tart raspberries behind, still sort of artificial but no longer very sweet. Minimal bitterness. Light to moderate prickly caarbonation with a light to medium body. Actually, pretty good--pleasantly surprised.

Name: Double ZZ Raspberry Ale Date: July 13, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: muddy yellow with a pink hue, fine white head Aroma: sweet banana and raspberry aroma Body: creamy body Flavor: sweet raspberry flavor backed up by more banana sweetness, just a hint of raspberry tartness, only a hint of the clove in the background Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **4

On tap. Poured a hazy yellow color with a small white head. Aroma of banana ester and of course raspberries. Flavor was tart with a sweet raspberry finish. I generally don’t like fruit beers, but this was a solid offering.
Notes of banana and bubble gum with a raspberry sweet/tartness too. Flavors of initial tartness then raspberry, then banana. A little lingering sweet/tart thing. A nice fruit beer.
Nice yeast presence in this one that makes the nose and mouth pop with some banana and clove. Otherwise standard.
Bit different for a wheat beer. Has an atoms of bananas and you can taste banana too with a slight warming aftertaste of cloves. Pretty good.. (k)
Banana and clove are typical of a Hefeweizen, but the light body is too sweet and lacks that refreshing finish typical of the style.

A hazy light yellow pour with a white head. Very heavy clove spiciness on the nose. A touch of bubblegum, moderate banana, and some sweet wheat bread. Taste is also heavy on the clove with a mild banana note. Some good malt and wheat sweetness, mild citrus peel, and a light bitterness.
It has a citrus tone to it, even without the lemon they with it. I really wanted to love it, but I ended up wishing it was...well, just better.

My Bottom Line: Citrus fruit, banana esters and crunchy wheat coalesce in this American Weizen’s doughy body, forming a perhaps generic, but quite enjoyable pint. Further Personal Perceptions: -A ring of foam surrounds the cloudy blond. -The cushy mouthfeel is one of this beer’s most endearing features. -Both the aroma and flavour profile are straightforward and well developed. -Light hop bitterness concludes each sip. On tap at Kern River Brewing.
On tap at the brewpub. Hazy yellow. No head. Aroma-lemon, banana, clove. Taste- much the same, on the light side. Crisp, lightly sweet.

On tap @ the brewpub. Cloudy orange with a small creamy off-white head, fading to a film. Loads of banana in the aroma with some faint spicy clove notes. Flavor is much the same with just a little bit of lemon. Big wheat finish with bitterness around a 2 or so. Light prickly carbonation with a medium body. This is not an American Wheat--this is one banana-y hefe.

Name: Harvest Moon Wheat Ale Date: July 13, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: muddy yellow, fine white head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet banana aroma, touch of clove Body: creamy body Flavor: sweet banana flavor, light clove Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **4

On tap at the brewpub in Bakersfield. Poured a really nice cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma was banana and cloves. Flavor was a bit of the same, but also a bit on the sweet side which was surprising. The banana was not overwhelming which was nice. Decent wheat.
Not robust as described. Had all the requisite parts, but not a big enough beer to be a nitro blend. Probably would have liked just co2, but the blend makes it come across a bit weak.
Pleasant enough, but the flavour is a little weak. It’s very dark, perhaps black, with a thin head. Quite fizzy too.
A very dry porter. Chocolate flavor and aroma with a fairly light body. Roasted malt give a slight burnt finish.

Black in color with a creamy khaki head. Coffee, roast, and dark chocolate open things up on the nose. A bit of earthy hops, licorice, and maybe some cocoa powder. The flavor is almost chalky and astringent. Lots of roasted malt, some dark chocolate, and a coffee ground note, too. A hint of dark fruit as the beer warms.

probably one of best and most consitant offerings from Lengthwise. Slight acidity from roast malts but not a detriment, actually blends nice with sub flavors of coffee and caramels... Not sweet, again slightly on the raosty side and maybe moving from a porter to a stout.. Give it a Robust porter for style, My personal guess is the name may help in marketing a dark beer with body to a location where it is rarely less than 95F in the Summer months.

On tap the brewpub. Dark amber-brown, decent dense head. Aroma-roasted malt, hint of chocolate, coffee. Taste-earthy, creamy, roasty, cocoa and coffee notes. Somewhat low carbonation. Very creamy, smooth mouthfeel.

On tap @ the brewpub. Clear deep dark ruby with a one finger cramy beige head, good retention--as a nitro should have. Loads of unsweetened chocolate up front with some moderate roasted malts. Flavor is much the same with hints of caramel and smoke, though the finish did turn a little burnt and ashy. Bitterness peaked around a 3 in the dry finish. Light prickly carbonation with a medium body. Not too bad.

Name: Kern County Porter Date: July 13, 2009 Mode: Draft, Nitro Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear dark ruby red, creamy tan head, sheets of lace Aroma: rich chocolate aroma, touch of dark caramel sweetness brings out the chocolate Body: creamy nitro body Flavor: rich roasted and dark chocolate flavor, touch of coffee adds good bitterness Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.7/5.0 Drinkability: 8/10 Score: **4
On nitro tap. Poured a black color with a creamy brown head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor was strong with coffee. Body was too light, but other than that this was a great beer.
Nitro pour. Dark brown with a lasting creamy tan head. Light roasted malt flavor, mild sweetness, with an earthy bitterness. Seemed a little thin, but the body was creamy from the nitro. Pretty okay.

On tap at the Hungry Hunter. Poured a gold/orange color with a small, white, quickly dissipating head. Aroma of citrus hops. Flavor was good. Malt base with a citrus tart finish. Medium body with mild carbonation.

On tap at the Hungry Hunter in Bakersfield. Really carbonated at the outset, but bubbles fade fast. Orange/straw colored. A bit of hops on the nose, but nothing much. Flavor is ok, but hops aren’t the first thing you taste. Slight chemical twang is a little offputting.

Bright cloudy orange body with a very fast fading head. There’s really no aroma at all - slightly bitter, hints of citrus and hops, but not anything in particular to put my finger on. The flavor is more of the same, except here ther is biting lemony-tartness that isn’t balanced by any pleasant hoppiness or maltiness. There is some mustiness, mildewy flavor to it, making it not such a pleasant beer experience overall.

Bottle from IrishBoy (thanks!) - cloudy orange, with a small, fizzy head - mildly tart aroma of peaches and citrus - tart and acidic up front - some notes of hickory and grainy malts - mild orange sweetness and some lactic qualities - finishes with peaches lingering tartness - an off bottle? - if so, it appears to be common with this beer.

This pale ale pours a medium orange gold color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is citrus, peaches and apricots. A medium bodied American Pale Ale. Malts are fruity and sweet. Lots of apricot and peach flavors. Hops are mild and somewhat herbal. More in the style of an English Pale Ale, Perhaps a little off, kind of buttery and the peach thing, but drinkable, Nice balance. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter

12 oz bottle a freebie from IrishBoy - Pours a hazy amber color with a half finger thick off white head. Aroma is citrus and herbal hops. Has some malt character, but has a lingering bitter presence with an odd twang. Light to medium body. Worth a try. Thanks Richard.
12oz bottle from IrishBoy. pale orange with a spectacular white foamy head, Malt aroma with a hint of citrus. Carbonation is good, tastes a little off. tastes a little moldy.

Body is a light copper and gold with a very thin white head. Aroma is very malty, with caramel, and is earthy. Taste is mettalic, and has a bit of a twang to it perhaps a slight infection, but it might just be how it is, some caramel, is also presense, with some grapefruit.

From a 12oz Bottle. Pours the color of coppery straw with a thin layer of wispy white head. Buttery diacetyl aromas saturate my nostrils, but the sweet corn and stale canned pineapple notes that greet my nostrils from underneath aren’t too pleasant either. Medium bodied, thinly carbonated mouthfeel. Seems too underattenuated to me, making it less drinkable, but at the same time, not a whole lot of flavor seems to be going on. Lots of stale fruity flavors with only a faint whisper of hops in the final smack. Needs more carbonation, crisp maltiness, and some sort of hop character to give it a better clean, refreshing character. Needs less body and buttery character to improve the drinkability. Not the refreshing, easy drinker I was looking for.

I got a bad bottle. Something happened, me-thinks some dirty bottles or fill lines. Tarnished brass in the glass, nice little white head says healthy. The nose has a flat almost wheat-malt element that tries to hide some soured fruit notes. This reminds me of a cross between lambic and madeira. Oxidized/ Diacetyl notes of butterscotch don’t add the character I usually enjoy. The dried apricot turns to soured orange rind. The finish is soured and tangy. While I will try to revisit this I can’t help but think this is either past its prime or flawed before it left the brewery.
Bottle from 2016. Black with small shortlasting head. Aroma is roasted and licorice. Taste is roasted, licorice, chocolate and some vanilla. Sweet, but not to sweet. Nice and drinkable.

1 finger off-white head. Deep, dark brown beer. Aroma is raisins, mint, light coffee, charcuterie, fruity and herbal liqueor, salty liquorice and lots of hops of the citrusy and peppery variety. Not up my alley at all when it comes to this style but very different and weirdly pleasant to sniff. Taste is dark chocolate, charcuterie, leather, tobacco, light soil, black pepper, light mint, light chili, slight black tea note and citrusy hops at the back. Semi-watery mouthfeel. Low bitterness. Very low carbonation. Barely any alcohol in the taste at all. Overall: Such a weird stout. According to the bottle, the recipe has remained unchanged since 1999 but this feels way more experimental than traditional. Even though I rate this so low, it does have some sort of charm to it and it doesn’t taste bad. It’s just so far away from where I want my Imp. Stouts.

February 2016. Probably from a Systembolaget in Stockholm. Drinking whiskey and Ribena in a deep bubble bath aroma. Some juicy zwetschgen and blueberry once the mad whipped beige head collapses. Flavour more smokey wee dram tipped in Ribena and blueberry juice. impressive oily smoked wood under berries. Bubblegum and humbug. Falls far outside the modern US-biased definition of what constitutes imperial stout. I like it.

Bottle. Black, with dark-reddish tinge against light. Malty (roasty malts, coffee, dark chocolate, burnt sugar, toffee, liquorice, vanilla). Fruity (dark fruits). Sweet and very smooth. Less extreme than other Imperials. Really enjoyed this. An excellent beer! (2008)

Bottle as a gift from Albin ( ratebeer name Wanabe_me ) awsome bro ! Thnx very much ! Pours very dark brown, close to black. Creamy, bit darker , good sized head. Smell is darksugar. palmsugar pops to mind. I had some palmsugar that had coffee aspects, this scent reminds me of that. Doesn’t smell like there’s actual coffee in this, but I do get the aspects... The sweet, earhtyness, factors are really strong, and very attypical for an impy. Taste is sugary, aromatic, again that coffee-like-palm-Sugar aspects. a certain dryness ( roasty ), a certain bitterness. rather sweet, a thick, sugary ( special Sugar ) mouthfeel. it’s definately off the charts compared to any other imperial stout I’ve had. it’s not comparable with anything I’ve had before, accept of one of my homebrews, with loads of Palmsugar in it ( hence the constant remembrance of it ) Accept for the fact this is many, many times better in both quality and taste. I really enjoyed this, but have a hard time to view this as an imperial stout, since it’s so different. I’d be very curious to find out how this is brewed, is it indeed palmsugar? This seems like it could have a style on its own. I applaud it ! Thnx very much Albin, I enjoyed this more that I thought i would !

A pitch black beer with a miniscule light brown head. Nose has intense aromas of roasted coffee beans, dark chokolate, salty caramel and liquorice. Taste is sweet and roasty with a lingering, dry roasted aftertaste. Soft carbonation and full palate. Very nicely made beer with a perfect balance of sweet chokolate and dry roasted flavors.
Black color. Roasted aromas, smoke, coffee, sweet fruits. Dark chocolate, coffee, raisins and roasted taste. Mediocre.
Pours black with little off white head. Aroma is roasted and licorice. Flavour is roasted, heavy sweet, licorice and coffee.
Backlog, early amateur rating! @ Havregatan 20130208. Bottle from Systembolaget. [ Vintage 2012 ]. Roasted malty with chocolate and coffee.
Botella. @La Barrica 13,Candas 11/02/2016 BBD: 22/08/16 Color negro, spuma beige, sabor negro, notas torrefactas, cuerpo medio.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: The beer pours from the growler with a pale tan colored head. Lightly hazed, with a bright copper / pale amber color. There is a cracker like, nice lager like maltiness up front, some touches of metallic hoppiness, Nice cracker like maltiness, touches of caramelized malt character, metallic hops, some touches of herbal character, slightly menthol character,as it warms perhaps a touch of . The beer is quite light bodied, but has some light heft to it that sits a bit on the palate. Quite smooth. This is pretty nice, much better than I might have guessed.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: ReRate-i had this about 2 weeks ago and it as not very good-lots of butter/diacytl thing going.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: A rich caramel base flavor with a dry smoky aftertaste. Excellent with food or by itself.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Really tasty. Not a very strong aroma of roasted malts and caramelized sugar. Dark like a Porter with a thin head. Good weight with a smoothness that filled the mouth. Strong burnt sugar with malts and a slightly bitter finish. Well done and balanced.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Dark, almost burnt, concentrated amber color. The head is thin and has a light brown tinge to it. Aroma has an interesting fruit character to it that is berry leaning; but is very subtle. Rich, sweet, malty notes, deeply caramelized, slightly nutty, deeply caramelized notes, and a touch of umami richness from the contrast notes. Sweet, a bit on the rich side, though not overly heavy. The beer has a nice dense, concentrated malt character to it, a meaty, chewy beer with lots of melonoid character. The beer has a touch of spiciness in the finish that seems more grain / malt related than hop, but it could be a touch of that too. The bitterness balance here is quite light, there is just a touch of it here in the finish so that this doesn’t get cloying. An incredibly satisfying beer, especially after driving the entire day.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: From a growler. Translucent pour with a small head. Aroma is sweet, with wheat and fruit. Moderate sweet, slight bitter. Roasted malt, caramel, nuts, some apple as well, and a little chocolate. Finishes sweet, with a little more chocolate. Medium body, a little syrupy. Very enjoyable.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sweet, almost raisin-like aroma with some red apple notes. Deep brown in color with a bit of off-white head. Flavor freatures that red apple peel taste; moderately sweet with a hint of roast flavor.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark brown/amber with a thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate and some roast too. Flavor also chocolate and roasted malt as well as lager malt/yeast. Sturdy palate for a bock. Pretty good, an enjoyable bock. 7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Brown with an average sized off-white head. Aroma is of wheat, sweet malt, light fruit and a hint of roastiness. Taste is the same.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: The Dark Bock had been on tap for awhile when I went to High Desert, but, luckily, I got one of the final pours before High Desert was officially out of the stuff. I would agree with just about all the other reviews on here: dark brown with a decent off-white head; really malty aroma and taste; high drinkability; generally a pretty solid beer. However, the body seemed a little thin, and, even though I thought it was tasty, it didn’t really taste like a bock at all to me, maybe a little too chocolatey and sweet. Still, the Dark Bock is one of High Desert’s better efforts.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: 10 oz glass at the brewery. Rather dark brown with some head. Sweet aromas that really gave away its bockiness. Very malty aromas. Flavor was still very sweet. The alcohol came in at the finish and was very well recieved. I like this brewery.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Dark amber body with a silky tan head. Caramel and toffee aroma with some sharp fruitiness underneath. Has an interesting berry quality. Tasty cookie malt flavor with medium sweetness. Light roasty note. Medium smooth palate. Not too cloying. A solid bock.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sampled August 2014 A steady pour from the growler into my teku glass produces a fat, one-finger thick, pale, almost light tan colored head. The beer is a copper color that shows a lightly hazed, golden tinged, lighter version of the same when held up to the light. The aroma has a sweet, almost honey like malt character to it up front, and this is backed by a slightly spicy, somewhat herbal hop character. The hop character has a nice lemon zest note to it that melds well with the light herbal notes The beer has a solid, herbal and grassy hop character to it that also contributes a biting bitterness from beginning to end. The bitterness does a good job of drying things out in the finish to help balance the up front cracker like, slightly hay leaning, and chewy rustic bread character that the pale malt contributes. Suggestions of lemon zest, hints of sage, a slight peppery note towards the finish, a bit of lemon pith as well, and a lightly herbal leaning woody note. The body of this beer is nice, it has a certain texture to it that keeps it from being overly light, it has a certain chewiness to it, but it is quite quaffable. This is one of the better beers, and likely the best, that I have had from this brewery; I am pretty sure this batch is pretty fresh, which certainly helps, both the malt and hop character are quite brightly presented here.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Tap @ High Desert. Pours a clear golden appearance with a small, off white head. Honey, chewy grainy, herbal, fairly earthy aroma. Moderately sweet, pale malty, grainy straw, lightly fruity, honey flavor. A little syrupy. Ok.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a beautiful straw gold with a nice retentive white foamy head. Weaker on the nose, but hints of light malts, grass, and light hops are able to be picked out. The flavor: outstanding! Extremely crisp, extremely hopped Nobley, lots of straw and grass...this pilz rocked! The Noble hop note lingers with the sour grass...and its great! Definitely check it if its on...

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Deep straw color and tight sudsy white head with abundant lace. Strong burnt butter and butterscotch in the nose. Initially overpowers any hop or malt aromas. Some bready malt gradually comes out after some warming. Considerable nuttiness in the flavor. Firm spicy hops and a nice bitter finish. Medium body with a lot of palatable texture. A solid Bohemian Pils but could be better balanced if the diacetyl was toned down.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Spot-on. Pours a lite gold with a thick tight white head. Malty munich aromas with a fresh saaz aroma. Gotta love those noble hops. Nice sweetness and a smack of APPROPRIATE diacetyl. A good bitter finish. The best beer I had at the brewery and one of the best American made pilsners.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: tap at brewpub: well, this just about completes my High Desert beers. This was a very good pilsner-great straw/hops aroma, appearance of golden yellow with lots of carbonation-flavor full of saaz-y hops-hop burps much like an IPA! highly hopped and spicy-another good brew from my hometown brewery.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: A vigorous pour into my teku glass produces a voluminous, fat-three-finger thick, pale tan colored head. The beer is a bright amber color that shows a brilliantly clear light amber hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells fruity, with sweet malt, it has a backing hay like malt, and a touch of green beer / herbal character, with the finish having an amped up dried hay grain character. The fruit character has notes of not quite spiced cider. The beer is sweet, malty in a pale malt sort of way and finishes with a touch of husky, dried hay character and a solid cracker like maltiness. The beer has a spiciness to it, that somehow seems a bit like green chile (though just a suggestion), hoppy and herbal, perhaps even a hint of menthol, perhaps even something a bit like cinnamon, and definitely a touch of black pepper in the finish. There is some slight fruit character that leans towards green apple, perhaps a touch of pear even. The body is chewy, a bit viscous, and definitely sits on the palate a bit, and is about right for a Bock, but may be a bit on the thick side for a Pale Bock, sometimes, but it is satisfying non-the-less. Definitely tasty, but it seems to be a bit out of parameter for your typical Pale Bock.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Cloudy pour. Aroma was light, with both malt and hops. Surprisingly hoppy taste, with light sweetness - well-balanced. Not what I expected from a bock, but very good.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Copper in color and slightly hazy with a small off-white head. Aroma is of wheat with a hint of hops. Taste is surisingly hoppy for the style, but not too much so.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Ya know, im not a fan of the bock style at all, but this definately changed my attitude all for good!!! Take Dead Guy Ale and make it more hoppy-thats what you have in this beer. i will be going to this place weekly!!!

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Sampled August 2014 The beer arrives from the tap with an amber tinged, nicely tan colored head. The beer is a clear, amber color. The aroma has a nice hop fruit character to it up front that smells of grapefruit, a bit of guava notes, tart tangerine zest, and some Curacao orange character. Towards the finish there is a hint of supporting toasted nutty whole grain malt character, and some grain character that accentuates a dried hay like note that also might be in the dominant hop aromatics. This has a nicely biting bitterness to it that gets more pronounced through to the lingering finish. The finish also has a linger citrus zest character that leans towards not-quite-ripe oranges, ruby red grapefruit zest, and even a touch of Meyer lemon zest. The body of this beer is quite light, perhaps a touch on the thin side, which helps to make this quite quaffable. Really though the malt character is not quite as rich as one might expect from something called an Amber Ale; on the hand this makes this more sharply hoppy. The malt character plays a supporting role here, there is a touch of toasted nutty red malt character, and a bit of whole grain cracker like notes. I wasn’t expecting something that was so hop focused, this is definitely a nice surprise, and a beer I am enjoying.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draft - Caramel and some floral hops. Clear copper with a rich head. Caramel, roast malt and a little aromatic hop bite. A really well balanced and flavourful amber, that doesn’t lose site of the malt. Very well done.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: growler-pours a foamy light tan head and amber color. Aroma is herbal hops, some light/medium malt. Taste is spice/herbal hops, some light/medium malt-honey.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Amber pour with frothy off white head and lace. Light caramel with no hops. Light caramel flavor and a very light bitter. Medium bodied and fizzy.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Good easy drinking beer with great floral hop aroma. Does have a long lasting flavor profile. A good beer for this small pub

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: ReRate-this batch has a better body than the one i had back in september of 03. much rounder and the malts are more pressent. tap at brewery: im with Andrew exactly on this one other than the palate. THe palate was just a bit thin to be great, but thats kind of the problem with most amber/red ales. Aroma and hop flavor were great though.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: The hoppiness really stood out for a beer that is classified as an "amber". The taste was smooth and sweet and it led to a unique complex hop finish. Not indicative of the style, but a solid beer from this random little brewpub in Las Cruces, NM

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: The beer is a clear brown color that has some red highlights to it and it is topped by a frothy, tan colored head. Toasted, brown crackers, touches of dark fruit, maybe a hint of herbal hop character. The beer has a light sweetness to it up front, which accentuates a solid berry like fruitiness that is backed by a toasted, well browned, whole grain bread crust character. The finish has a light herbal note, a light bitterness in the finish, and perhaps a touch of roast character that lingers a bit on the palate with a coffee like touch. There is a fullness to the body here that clings just a bit to the palate, a bit on the chewy side, but certainly a quaffing brew. Quite a tasty brown, perhaps a touch on the fruity / sweet side, without being overly of either; I am a bit of a Brown Ale fan though, so take my judgement here with a grain of salt.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Rich brown color, cloudy. Earthy aroma. Slightly sweet with the expected nutty flavor. Lighter than most brown ales, with a little hoppiness. Not a bad beer, but just didn’t excite me at all.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: [At GABF 2004] An unclear brown beer with a fine orange head. The aroma is sweet and primarily roasty, while the flavor is sweet with hints of nuts. More powerful than an English Brown Ale, but lacking something compared to its American cousins.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: tap at brewery: hmm, i was kind of discouraged by this ale. Pours a nice deep mahogony color with a little red around the rim of glass. aroma was slightly sugary/spice/with a hit of earthy tones(grass), not common in brown ales. flavor was slightly nutty, a tad leathery also. palate was just a tad thin. not a bad brew.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draft - Caramel and grapefruit hops. Clear gold with a rich head. Pine, resin, orange and some caramel in the finish. A well balanced IPA that although has nothing exciting is nice and easy to drink.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: A vigorous pour from the growler produces a two finger thick, pale tan colored head in my teku glass. The beer is a rich amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, rich copper-amber hue when held up to the light. The aroma has a huge toasted, nutty malt character to it up front. There is a soft citrus hop character, a touch of herbal hop character, but really this is surprisingly not hoppy; it is like an old school IPA from the 90s or earlier, but by todays standards doesn’t seem to have much hop character to it at all. It doesn’t even smell like a malty IPA, more like an amber ale. This does have a big bitterness to it that provides a bite to my first sip. There is lots of malt flavors here; sweet, caramelized, sweet tea, nutty toasted malt, and lots of English biscuit character. Soft citrus notes play up a grapefruit character, caramelized tangelos, some menthol notes that also provide a palate presence, and an herbal, woody, not quite rosemary like character all perfume the mostly more dominant malt character (at least for an IPA). A weird beast, definitely not at all what I expected, seems to be an American take on an English interpretation of an IPA. Certainly not bad, but I was hoping for a hop fix, and this certainly doesn’t fit that bill.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Piney floral hop aroma and taste. Taste continues with the hop flavors coating the mouth nicely and giving a nice lingering bitterness. A nice moderate IPA. Notes: Called "Fresh Hop IPA" at the pub

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Had this on tap at their pub in Las Cruces. Pine/citrus aroma. Clean taste with a nice bitter hop bite. Very good, but I liked their ESB a little better.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear orange with a white head. Aroma of caramel malt, sweet orange, citrus, and some odd malty notes that are difficult to describe. Flavor of caramel malt, iced tea, piney, orangy hops, some acetone, and mineral notes. Just kind of odd tasting - from what it’s hard to say, but a disappointing IPA (and it’s fresh hopped too, oh well). 6/4/6/3/11 [3.0/5]

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: growler-pours a retaining light tan head and gold color. Aroma is pine/citrus, some medium malt. Taste is pine/resin hops, secondary medium malt.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: growler pour thanks to jwattsrugger. A nice smooth ipa. Classic yellow orangish color. Nice citrus notes. very drinkable.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Growler thanks to Jcwattsrugger. Pours like chunky apple cider. Tons of hop sediment. Nose and tastes of dry hops and caramel malt. Slightly bitter.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On-Tap- Served a copper color with a small head with a bit of lacing. Aroma was primarily of pine with a hint of citrus. Starts with a nice hop tang. Flavor of some citrus and a bit of biscuit. Quite refreshing. Fairly medium body, crisp and clean. Seems to be well balanced. Very drinkable. Enjoyed enought to get a growler to take with me.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Amber orange in color with a decent sized off-white head. Aroma is of light citrus and grain. Taste is not quite hoppy enough and a little watered down. Mostly just grain.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draft - Huge candied peach aroma. Clear gold with a thin head. Tastes very similar to the smell, although some grain peeks through mid palate. Finish isn’t cloyingly sweet, but mellow peach. This is way to sweet and is that sweet beer for people who don’t like bitterness.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: The beer arrives from the tap with perhaps a light haze, though it may just be the dim bar and the fact that the beer is so cold I can’t really get rid of all the external condensation. The beer is a light gold color and is topped by a fluffy, pale tan colored head that leaves lots of lacing stuck to the sides of my glass. The aroma is dominated by the peach aromatics, it is noticeable as soon as the beer is handed to me and pretty much overwhelms anything else coming through. The beer is quite cold, on the dry side, well carbonated with an effervescence, and finishes dry and a touch astringent. The peach flavor becomes more prominent as the beer warms up and boosts the perceived sweetness just a bit. Soft straw like grain notes, and maybe a touch of cracker describe the malt presence here. This is light bodied and quaffable, though it is not to light. What I expected, peachy, refreshing and simplistic; not a bad example of a fruit beer, though not overly interesting either.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Tap @ High Desert. Pours a clear, yellow appearance with a white head. Spicy, fuzzy peach, a bit floral, fruit forward aroma. Slightly bitter, a touch grainy, peachy flavor. Probably would be refreshing on a hot day, but nit really anything special.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Pours clear with a thin head. Aroma was very peachy, sweet without being cloying. Tastes of (surprise!) peaches and malt. Light finish, just a touch of hops. While I enjoyed this beer, it’s just not my style of beer. Too light and sweet. My wife, on the other hand, had 2 pints.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. It was so good that I only got pints of this beer (3 of them) because it was too good to pass up. Pours a clear light orange with a white head. Aroma (please ignore the prior rater) is SUPER peachy. It smells like a fresh peach. Sweet, but not artificial. Flavor is again, very peachy, whole peaches not just the juice with just a hint of the background wheat malt. I think I’m drinking a peach. Best peach ale ever because it really tastes like actual peaches without the sweetened juice. Awesome stuff. 9/4/8/4/16 [4.1/5]

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: tap at brewery-good wheat beer here-not a lot of peach flavor-mainly ads sweetness to the brew. not to shabby

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Draft - Light sweet grain and a bit of citrus. Clear gold with a rich white head. Wheat and some sweetness with a clean finish. Decent, but nothing special.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: The beer pours from the growler with a one-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head. The beer is a brilliantly clear, copper hued color. The beer has quite a bit of buttery character, lots of malty character, but not much wheat character that I was expecting. the buttery notes really seem to dominate here. Soft caramelized malt character, no real wheat character, a touch of metalic character, and a soft buttery note that becomes a bit morenoticeableas the beer warms up. The body is fairly light here, but definitely has a viscous quality to it. Not bad, but a pretty standard wheat beer.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Tap @ High Desert. Pours a clear yellow appearance with an off white head. Straw, grainy wheat, a bit fruity, slightly herbal aroma. Light lemon fruitiness, fairly dry, a bit grainy flavor. Not very exciting but it’s easy to drink.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: good refreshing wheat brew in this desert climate here in New Mexico. just plain good and refreshing. ReRate-pours semi-cloudy light orange hue with a nice white head-fluffy. Aromas of citric hops ( i dont remember that much hops in this beer), red wheat, pale malts. Smells like a very fresh crisp beer. Flavors are hoppy, pale malts, grainy sweetnes and decent palate. A very respectible wheat, even after the fact I thought it sucked when I had it the first time.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Decent stout. Roasted malt aroma but not strong. Dark and creamy looking with a thin head. Smooth and lightweight palate. Felt like a milk stout. More roasted malt flavors with some sweetness and a slight hops bitterness. Nothing unique though but very drinkable.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: A steady pour into my teku glass produces a one-finger thick, lightly browned, dark tan colored head. The beer is a rich black color that is quite opaque. The nose has nice roasted nuttiness, lots of roasted grain, chewy burnt grain husk, and just an overall, smooth rich maltiness. Touches of dark chocolate, a solid toasted whole grain character that becomes more prominent as the beer warms up. Smooth up front, but then a bitter, sharp roasted character kicks in towards the finish, and lingers nicely on the palate. Black, concentrated, malt-sweetened coffee, charred malt, burnt dark chocolate. Bitter hop notes meld with the roasted, bitter malt notes. There is a light malt sweetness to the beer, which really helps to balance the roasted malt character. Overall the roast character is kept really smooth here, it is sharp / biting in the right ways. The beer is quite quaffable, light enough, but still definitely a stout with enough palate presence, heft, and viscosity. The malt sweetness that is here even seems to provide suggestions of vanilla after the beer warms up quite a bit. A rich toasted nutty note, lots of rich dark maltiness, malted candy notes (without being overly sweet), and burnt caramel brittle are all more noticeable as the beer warms up. This is a really well balanced and easy drinking for a standard Stout; I really like how smooth it is, but still has enough of a bit and sharpness from the roast character to keep this interesting. There is a burnt smokiness to this brew that lightly influences both the aroma and the flavor. This is defintely a beer meant for drinking throughout an evening.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Tap @ High Desert. Pours a dark reddish brown appearance with a creamy brown head. Roasty malty, cocoa, a bit herbal aroma. A touch fruity, very roasty, slightly smoked, dark chocolate flavor.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Roasty aroma. Black in color with tan head. Flavor is quite roasty with slight red apple peel under tone. Roast flavors coat and linger.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma of very roasted malt. Flavor of tons of parmesean cheese (it’s like I’m eating a carton of cheese), some roastedness. Smooth palate. Decent stout. I don’t know what my finding of parm cheese in this beer means but it did take away from my enjoyment. 7/4/6/4/14 [3.5/5]

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a fairly dark black with a bit of reddish brown hints near the edges. Low retentive white almost tanned head. Very sweet roasty aroma, small hints of coffee. Flavor starts malty malty malty and never really goes anywhere else. Slight roast is there...ever so slight hint at burnt coffee, and ends in a very subtle hop note. Good, but would almost be better billed as a sweet stout!

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: aroma of coffee and rich roasted malts. Super sweet and hoppy. Palate is somewhat thin, but the flavors make up for it. Nice roasted finish that has a real nice kick.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Dark, nice head. Unground coffee bean aroma and taste...not overly complex but VERY good. A crispy hop finish emerged as it warmed.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Amber-copper in color with descent white head. Malty sweet aroma and taste. Taste also has a touch of alcohol and a bit earthy.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Light brown with a tint of red and a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet malt and toffee with hints of leather and peat. Taste is of peat, light hop notes and caramel withe a hint of maple.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: tap at brewery-Im not a scottish ale type of person, but this one was a solid brew. pours a deep red color-slightly hazy. Aroma of currant, earthy hops, and alcohol soaked fruits (this batch came in at 7%). Palat was thick and chewy-flavors of peat, earth hops, rich malts that tingle the tongue. A solid offering from my local brewery.

column2: Las Cruces, New Mexico, United States
column5: Probably the most average of all of the brews I had there but it still kicked ass! The aroma was of sweet maple syrup. The taste was a bit hoppier than I expected. Also had some hints of alcohol before the clean, non-lingering finish.

Pours a hazy golden orange, little to no head and lacing. Pine, floral notes, hints of lemon. Balanced taste, both bitter and sweet. Hoppy, sweet citrus, hints of resin, grapefruit. Really nice imperial IPA.

Golden cloudy colour. Small white head that clings to the glass. Earthy grapefruit hops. Sharp bittering hops as the beer enters. Soft maltiness, but it drowns in the hops. A little one dimensional perhaps. Papery and salty finish.
Aroma of pine, floral and light citrus. Pours hazy yellow orange with a small but frothy head. Taste is bitter with nice pine and floral. Very intense and bitter.
Nice orange pour. Aroma of hop and grapefruit. Similar taste with the perfect blend of caramel malts and dry bitter finish. A really well built beer.

Draft. An amber beer with a lazing beige head. The aroma has notes of citrusy hops and grapefruits. The flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of hops lending it notes of grapefruit, combined with notes of over ripe fruits and alcohol, the latter leaves a burn in the mouth, before the very bitter finish sets in.

Had this at the Portland Int’l Beer Fest in July 2010. Colour... apricot-orange with no head. Nose... sweet, strongly grapefruit-like hops. Palate... cloying, sweetly coating yet bitter with orange slices, lemon drops, Sour Patch Kids and a long bittersweet finish.

Tap at GABF 2009. Pours a hazy bright orange with a nice fluffy sticky white head. Aroma is very piney, sappy, sticky resinous dank hops, with lots of citrus oil and grapefruit- modest malt backbone. Flavor is orange zest, pine resin and tar, white pine sap, mint and lots of fresh citrus fruits- decent malt backbone- lightly sweet, and a resinous bitter finish. Nice!

Light orange with a fizzy white head. Huge hops aroma with caramel and grapefruit hiding in the background. Tastes of hop resin and more resin, orange, and caramel. Not overly bitter and reasonable smooth for what it is.

Draft @ the brewpub. Nose is just a torrent of pungent, resiny, dank stickiness. Cotton candy, papaya, mango, weed, light background of a wet cellar - sure smells like Amarillo, though not sure. Honestly - the nose can not be improved on. Taste is a slightly subdued version of the nose to start, sticky and fruity, with a mid-range of a tannic, almost vinous bitterness that’s more evident as it warms. Finish is crisp and clean, carbonation is perfect. Enough body for substance, no lingering sweetness or stickiness. Just enough caramel/biscuit malt to balance. Awesome beer. Damn close to a worldbeater when it’s fresh like this.

Yellow brown and cloudy color with a creamy off-white head. Thick lace. Aroma is nice and strong with grapefruit and strawberry with floral notes and some hops in there as well. Flavor is mostly hops, less fruit than I would like. Some strawberry and grapefruit flavor in there. It’s supposed to be 100 IBUs, but I thought it was well balanced. Medium bodied. I like it, but I wish it had a creamier mouthfeel. Doesn’t quite feel like a double IPA to me.

Listed as 21st amendment strong ale at mad mex robinson so I guess this is where it goes. Quite dark but bot brown. Sweeter perfumy aroma. Wew, strong alky impact on the first taste, certainly no effort is made to hide the alky, after all it is a strong ale. Quite flat from the tap. Finish is bitter medicine, over the top.
Tap. Dark mahogany brown color with a tan head. Dark malts, slightly sour, caramel and toffee, and very little spice that I usually expect in a Belgian Strong Ale.

Medium brown color. No head. Somewhat yeasty, although it almost tastes and smells more English than Belgian. Some alcohol in the nose. Caramel flavor. Some plum. Mild bitterness in the finish. Medium body. Not the best Belgian-style beer but nice to see the attempt.

I think this is the first time that I have had an american brewpub beer which truly resembled one of the darker trappist beers. Taste was average though, lots of plum, raisin, and yeast. I really appreciated where they were going and it was a good beer, but dont expect a truly trappist taste.

Sample @ Brewhouse in Phoenix Medium sweet aroma along with some roasted nut as well. Dark body but add some light and it has an amber color to it. Left some good lace on the small sampler glass. Decent roasted nut flavor with the added sweetness well blended together made this a good brew. Smooth and enjoyable beer.

This beer is lightly hazy, amber tinged, brown color. It is topped by a wispy tan colored head. The aroma is certainly malt focused; there i sa nice mix of raisin notes, toasted and sweet malt notes, some biscuit type aromas and perhaps just a touch of roast character. Overall the aroma is quite nice. The taste finishes with a nice nutty note that almost picks up a hint of roast character. There is some caramel / toffee sweet malt notes up front and it is joined by a nice, supporting spicy hop note. This beer is nice, soft, easy drinking, yeat flavorful, Norther English in character, but definitely better than Newcastle.

On tap at brewery: This has some hazelnut and roasty flavors, but overall, it’s fairly subtle, no, boring; I didn’t catch any creaminess in the palate, but there is plenty of astringency. Just not that good.

Aroma had that caskiness to it along with standard brown ale nuttiness. The mouthfeel was super creamy, but I thought it was lacking flavor. The flavor intensified as it warmed but it was still just a plain old brown ale.

Shrewsbury Beer Share, 2nd Oct 2017. 0.5 litre bottle taken my me: Five of us split the bottle. Cloudy dark golden pour, white crown. Bananas ruled the nose, vanilla ruled the flavour. Label scared a couple of the group, they thought it a bit freaky. Liked it.

500ml bottle @ monthly tasting, Chez Sophie, Oct 17, courtesy of Jeremy. Thanks chap. Pours a misty golden orange, small white head. Aroma has some pleasant yeasty weiz esters. Taste delivers what the aroma promises, smooth easy-going with just enough banana / vanilla yeast emerging. Not too full-on. Refreshing.
Draught at Monks cafe Wallingatan. Thick but short head clowdy copper color. Huge banana aroma and taste that ends with a light sweetness.
On tap. Trübes dunkel orange goldenes Bier mit mittelgroßen leicht beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch nach reifen Bananen, Nelke, Hefe. Geschmack sehr fruchtig, trocken, reife Banane.
That name really rolls off the tongue. Hazy orange with enough banana and clove to clue you in to the style.
*Old rating from 2010. Nettes leicht karamelliges Bier. Frisch, malzig-weich, leicht süßlich, ganz leicht herb und nicht zu tief. Nett.
Kobber klar skum råhvid tæt Gær hved korn støv Bitter lidt sød moderat Livlig cremet ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Farven: Mørk, uklar rav. Skumkrone: Meget flot. Duft: Gær, meget banan og hvede. Smag: som duft. Eftersmag: Som duft, men også en let bitterhed (en positiv overraskelse). Mundfylde: gennemsnitlig. Generelt: En god gedigen hvedeøl, med lidt mere bitterhed over sig en man sædvanligvis får fra en hvedeøl.

(50 cl bottle) Pours a clear amber with little, white head that fades quickly leaving a little lace. Aroma is banana, dust and this wheaty acidity. Oily texture, medium carbonation, medium body and a sweet finish. Flavour has moderate sweetness and aroma notes.
Bottle - amber pour with very thin white head. Aroma and taste is light fruity wheaty and floral, light herbs, notes of banana, very light clove.

column1: Big Time C. Brown Brown Ale
column5: Quite dark in appearance, almost porter like. Really great chocolate aroma with just a touch of burnt toast. Sweet flavor with a light roasty finish. A solid brew that I am going to return to next time at Big Time.

column1: Big Time C. Brown Brown Ale
column5: I had this on both regular draft and nitro taps--and it was suprisingly good--though not outstanding. Mahogany bodied with a nice layer of cream and an exciting sweet rounded brown ale and chocolate aroma. Light chocolate and carmel form one half of the dichotomy and the hop backbone the other.
