These disparate elements--clash and coalesce--playing off each other delectably. A good find from Big Time.

column1: Big Time C. Brown Brown Ale
column5: Looked like a cloudy cider...almost like toilet water? Not very attractive IMO. This beer was just weird from start to finish. Not a typical brown as far as taste, it had a weird maltiness, followed by a very sour finish....yuck!

Frothy, thick beige head sat atop this dark brown/black beer. This beer tasted like melted choclate ice cream....the creamy texture and sweet choclate flavor said it all the way. The finish had definite notes of alcohol.
Poured from a bottle. I Must admit it was my first cream ale ever and I found it’s mild taste without bitterness quite enjoyable

On tap. Pours a clear brown-amber with a small, creamy, long lasting, off-white head that leaves curtains of lace. Mild, sweet aroma of caramel malt, brown sugar and leafy hops. Sweet flavour of bready malt, caramel, sour dark fruit and a hint of nuts with a dry, bitter hop finish. Light to medium body with a watery texture and soft carbonation. Ok.

Rating #1826 - 2015.07.09 - Russell Tap Takeover @underground_edm. Amber pour, decent white head. Aroma of toffee malt, grassiness. Taste is sweet, light, refreshing. Little character beyond the aforementioned sweetness.

On tap @ The Local. Clear light Amber, compact white head. Grainy with a bit of caramel, thin and bland. Who put this on the site as a mild ale when the brewery itself calls it a cream ale? Who cares. It’s pretty featureless regardless.
Poured from 341mL bottle. Clear copper colour with minimal off-white head. Some toasted caramel malt on the nose. Mild malt, nut and bread taste. Light body.
Not bad. Pours an iced tea color. Some roasty aromas and flavors. A touch of coffee on the finish. Pretty good for a cream ale.

On tap at Underground. K, cheating here. Took 3 sample glasses and dumped them into one glass - Apx 4-5oz. Medium amber. Everything from here on are in the light or faint category. Smellz - toasty, grains, random citrus, mostly malts. Flavz: very similar with more obvious malts and less grain. Watery was expected. A pint could be drank in three big chugs.
On tap at cambie hostel, Vancouver. Nice brown color, no special head. Average Aroma, very nice smooth taste. I enjoyed it..

341ml bottle pours a pale amber color with a finger of white head that disappears quickly leaving no lacing. Aroma is light malts and hops. Taste is malty sweet with some unflattering hop bitterness. Not one of the better cream ales out there and not recommended.

Enjoyed on cask at St. Augustine’s. A bit of carbonation here, just tapped cask. Some colour in the body and even a bit of red. Smooth, some flavour, Ok drinkability for a basic mild ale.Tad of hops and malt.Decent cask.
Cask Stillage at the Howcroft Inn, Bolton 12/10/2001 Amber mid brown coloured and slightly sweet on the palate. Full hop finish.
Bottle. Cairngorm also still release this under the Aviemore name. A pleasant enough slightly sweet malt accented ale. Nothing special.

(Cask conditioned). Sampled at the Wear Valley CAMRA beer festival. (Room temperature, low natural carbonation). Copper coloured. A Scottish "heavy" like it should be. Good, but not so very special. Aviemore brewery changed its name in 2001 to Cairngorm brewery. Website: www.cairngormbrewery.co.uk Cairngorm also brew Tomintoul beers.
highly carbonated into the bottle and not pasteurized so short shelf life. This was fresh and tasted like the fresh drafts we had in college. Three malts-sweet, but not a Creemore. Dry aftertaste.
Pours a copper amber with smallish head. Malty, one the sweet side. This bottle seemed to have a lot more bitterness to it that previous ones.

Copper/amber colour; hints of caramel, fusel alcohol, and toasted grains in the aroma. Lightish malt flavours (bread, crackers) in the palate. Sweetish - maybe 15-18 IBUs. Slight nut and caramel finish.
Faint floral hops aroma, copper, small vanilla head. Malt flavour, hoppy after taste. Smooth, nice session ale.

Faint aroma hard to tell what it is since there isn't much here. Light brown, dark gold in colour. Light malty hopy taste with a slight bitter finish for something that has hardly any visible carbonation it foams up in the mouth quite a bit. Its a toss up between being smooth and bitter. Decent for the style but I don't have alot of knowledge about cream ales.
On tap @ the Crown City in Pasadena. Poured a light, clear yellow color with a small white head. Light hoppy and ctiric aromas and tastes. Lively body with a dry finish.

Draught at Crown City Brewery, Pasadena Golden yellow (dark urine) colour with NO head (dirty glass?). Aroma of grains and husks. Over-sparged, tannic, grainy and cereal flavor. Little to no hop bitterness. Surprisingly no off-flavors, just lacking. A bit watery with an odd watery aftertaste.

Clear light yellow/gold color with a thin white head (nice lacing). I couldn't detect much in the aroma besides faint honey. Sweet honey flavor with the wheat component having a faint presence. Tangy tartness. A little syrupy. Moderate carbonation. Sweet, oily aftertaste.
Dark malt, medium sweet. Medium light roast , malty a bit thin in finish . Drinkable.
Malty aroma with a hint of chocolate. Some hints of chocolate malts in the flavor. A little watery, but overall not a bad beer.
Darker amber color, thin head. Lighter caramel aroma. Nutty, some off plastic flavors. Thinner. Its drinkable.
Light chestnut colour. Slight caramel notes in the aroma. Slightly nutty, plasticy flavour. Take away the plastic and this wouldn't be so bad.
Funky aroma, with a bit of malt. Not entirely sure what I am picking up in here. Flavour is mostly malty with a hint of hoppy bitterness.

This beer has a nice tan head with a rich dark colour. The beer has hints of roasted coffee and almost a grape scent to it. Included in the flavour is also roasted coffee and malts. The body is a little watery and the finish is the same. Altogether a average dark ale. Good non the less!

(Bottle) My final request of my friend upon his completion of his masters at the University of Waterloo, "bring me your beer!". Pours a thin almond head and a very dark reddish-brown body. Aroma of strong malt and floral hops. Flavours of caramelized malt, smoky and hoppy. Lightly carbonated feel with a slight bitter finish. Very good.

Sweet malt hop aroma. Very dark reddish amber. Thick light brown foam that goes to a thin lace around the edge of my glass. Malt, sweet dark caramel with a very, very subtle roasted bitternes. I can almost taste the alcohol when the bitter aftertaste kicks in. Creamy, smooth, bitter in the finish. Refreshing though. There is nothing overpowering about it and it relativly mild all the way through.

column1: Mia and Pias ND Dairy Golden Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: a sweet maltiness with notes of honey in the nose and flavor. Creamy feel for such a light beer. OK.

column1: Mia and Pias ND Dairy Golden Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: This is not the greatest beer I have ever tried. Sweet maltiness, with some hints of light fruit and grassy bitter hops. Yawn.

column1: Mia and Pias ND Dairy Golden Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled draught at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsPale yellow, average looking. Nose of mint & 2-row. The flavor is mild & fruity with a bit of a sharp finish.

column1: Mia and Pias ND Dairy Golden Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Light gold with a foamy head and spotty lacing. Sweet caramel and some gum. Grassy hop aromas. Candy like with gummi bears or something. Some bitter tones. Standard golden ale, nothing exciting.

column1: Mia and Pias ND Dairy Golden Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. strange name. quite pale, light, not a hell of a lot of flavour there, hint of raw sugar

column1: Mia and Pias ND Dairy Golden Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pias. Slightly buttery, lemony. Lagery, sweet grainy malts. American hosp to finish. OK.

column1: Mia and Pias Rods Rodeo Red
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: possibly the best they had on, which was a surprise. Nice balance between darkish and caramel malts and brighter and earthy hops.

column1: Mia and Pias Rods Rodeo Red
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler at M&P. This had a nice flavor.... for a barley wine. Seriously, it tasted like a barley wine. Would even be a decent barley wine, but its not supposed to be.

column1: Mia and Pias Rods Rodeo Red
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled draught at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsRuby brown color, off-white head, nose of caramel corn & light roast. The flavor has a nice hop accent as well as a rich nutty malt flavor but there’s some diacetyl.

column1: Mia and Pias Rods Rodeo Red
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Mahogany with a foamy tannish head and spotty lacing. Roast and bitter aromas. Some funky one as well. I’m not spending too much time on it. Flavor is better with the roast coming out with some caramel and bitter hops. Medium bodied with a tangy palate and bitter tail.

column1: Mia and Pias White Pelican Porter
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: high scores so far, but there was something wrong with ours. Weak nose and body, and a very unpleasant plasticky aftertaste. Least favorite beer in a long while.

column1: Mia and Pias White Pelican Porter
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler at M&P. Pretty standard Porter, but after all the trash I waded through to get to this one it made it taste that much better. Previous description says it all.

column1: Mia and Pias White Pelican Porter
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: One of the best Mia and Pias beers i’ve had, smooth chocolate, medium roast, very smooth palate. Soft earthy note in the finish, dark chocolate lives on in the aftertaste. Really good porter, big flavor for 4.2%.

column1: Mia and Pias White Pelican Porter
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled draught at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsDark black, creamy head. Nose of very subtle roast & smoke like a fine molasses or maple syrup. None of the astringency of a stout. Nice finish, excellent porter.

column1: Mia and Pias White Pelican Porter
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Brown with amber edges. Tan head and big spots of lace. Aromas of chocolate and roast. Diacetyl appears here as well. Bitter hops, some roast with not a lot of chocolate. Buttery flavors.

column1: Mia and Pias White Pelican Porter
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. standard porter, light touch of plum in the aroma, toffee and dry grain taste, a bit thin

column1: Mia and Pias White Pelican Porter
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pias. fairly thin. Caramel, toasty, some chocolate. Pretty light though, but its alright.

At first I thought this was going to be a very enjoyable beer. Dark opaque blackish brown color with a creamy beige head (not on nitro). Moderate lacing. Roasty, barley aroma with a substantial coffee component that made me anticipate the first sip. The flavor started off well - roasted coffee flavor with a light chocolate aftertaste. Light acidity and mildly astringent. Moderate mouthfeel and carbonation. Dry finish. Then it warmed up and pulled a Dr. Jeckyl and Mr. Hyde on me. It became very acidic and quite astringent. The nice flavor vanished and I was stuck with half a pint of beer that I didn't want to finish. The rating reflects the transformation. Some work and this would be an excellent stout.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: decent irish stout with a semi dry malty finish. Light roast and chocolate on the nose and flavor. Thin, but tasty.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: On Nitro tap at Bailey’s TapRoom Portland OR. Pours out a black topped with a tall brown head. Aroma of roast malts and some chocolate. Tast was nice more of the roast, some coffee, along with the sweetness. Not bad.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: I have to agree with some other reviews--this stout comes off a bit thin. Especially for a Guinness-style stout, it misses the mark. The flavor itself could be nice if the consistency were heavier.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler at M&P. Beautiful black beer with lasting mahogany head. Could be a flavorful beer but had a strong hint of diactyl. Disappointing.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: I’d had this beer a few times before and been indifferent about it, feeling it was a bit watery. Then, low and behold I try it again and wham, they changed this thing into a beautiful beer. What once was, well like they say, very guiness-like, now was rich, heavy bodied, and had a well done smoked character to it. Chocolate malt flavor, roasty and rich, very well balanced with a light smoked finish. Very nice stout, please stay with this recipe.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Draught at alehouse. Black with tan head. Aroma of chocolate, roast barley. Notes of coffee, chocolate and toast in the mouth, with a disappearing finish. In the style of Guinness, it’s not quite up to draught Guinness from Ireland. It will do in a pinch.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled nitro at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsLight roast & coffee in the nose, creamy chocolate. Nice flavors due to the nitrogen. A good dry Irish stout with a robust finish. Kinda bland though.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Black with a foamy nitro head. Some chocolate and roast. That sour funk is here as well. It has some similar flavors to a homebrew I dumped. Sour chocoate and roast.

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. below average dry stout. decent instant coffee aroma, quite dark, not a lot of flavour, light hint of whipped cream, not particularly dry

column1: Mia and Pias Otto Mulligans Irish Stout
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pias. Failry decent Irish dry stout, if a little thin. Chocolatey and coffee roast, but a little thin. Not bad though.

column1: Mia and Pias Emmett & Annas Pivo
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: standard euro pils with slight but not unpleasant skunk to it. pretty average for the style across the board.

column1: Mia and Pias Emmett & Annas Pivo
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap @ M&P. Pretty standard Pilsner. A little bland but true to flavor. Nothing special.

column1: Mia and Pias Emmett & Annas Pivo
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Draught at ale house, served in Imperial Pint. Pale gold colour, white lasting head. Aroma of new hay, malt and bread. A burst of flavour then it faded fast, just dropped off the table. It could take a bit more bitterness in the finish. An unchallenging workaday pilsner and session beer.

column1: Mia and Pias Emmett & Annas Pivo
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. not bad for an american pilsner. honey hay aroma, nice soft texture, some apple sweetness, could use a bit more bitterness though

column1: Mia and Pias Emmett & Annas Pivo
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pias. Vague saaz, lightly honeyed, smooth, soft body, pretty easy to drink.

column1: Mia and Pias Applegate Trail Pale Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: a boring pale ale with little in the way of aromatic or flavorful hops and a plethora of house flavor from many different styles,.

column1: Mia and Pias Applegate Trail Pale Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler @ M&P. Bland and slightly contaminated diactyl flavor. Unimpressed.

column1: Mia and Pias Applegate Trail Pale Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Pours amber, very clear, with a medium white head. Fruity yeast and hop nose. Similar taste, nothing bold standing out, but just a mild balanced taste all the way through. Nice light hop finish with just a lightly bitter finish.

column1: Mia and Pias Applegate Trail Pale Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled draught at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsClear amber, a bit of lacing, no head. Nose of light hops & pale malt. The flavor is a bit on the bitter side with a floral hoppiness.

column1: Mia and Pias Applegate Trail Pale Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Amber with a light head and good lacing. Sweet caramel with some berries. Light hops being bitter and piney. Flavor has the hint of berries as well then bitterness. Malts do a fair job of backing it up. Decent pale, but the hops could have stood out a bit more. The best so far.

column1: Mia and Pias Applegate Trail Pale Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. decent pale ale, some apple in the aroma along with the expected pine, pretty drinkable, light-bodied

column1: Mia and Pias Applegate Trail Pale Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pia’s. nice American APA, but a perhaps a but more subtle for the style., pine, lychee, aromatic American hops. Well balanced, uncomplicated. Nice session ale.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: just ok. Had the right malts, just not enough of them, so the bread and toffee was not the slightest bit rich. Still had the house flavor, too.

column1: Mia and Pias Spring Lake Amber Lager
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler @ M&P.Pretty thin simple, toffee and syrup, didn’t have too much else to say about it, not very good.

column1: Mia and Pias Spring Lake Amber Lager
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: On tap @ Bier Stein: Just a hint of diacetyl, some grassy hops and some sweeter buttery maltiness. Just a hint of caramel, smooth on the palate with just a bit of bite in the finish, very obviously a lager.

column1: Mia and Pias Spring Lake Amber Lager
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled draught at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsCopper color, light head. Nose of juniper berries & diacetyl, light caramel. The flavor is smooth with a bit of nuttiness & carbonation in the finish. Not bad, really a Vienna.

column1: Mia and Pias Spring Lake Amber Lager
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Light amber with a filmy head and sheets of lace. Slightly bitter hops and a sour aroma. Could be from the citrus as there are a lot of lemons in the nose. Bitter with a nice backing of malts. Caramel with some citrus. Nice mouthfeel with a solid body and a bitter tail.

column1: Mia and Pias Spring Lake Amber Lager
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. reddish tinge. sweet, light nougat flavour, a bit lemony, no bitterness at all

column1: Mia and Pias Spring Lake Amber Lager
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and pia’s. Pretty thin simple, toffee and syrup, didn’t have too much else to say about it, not very good.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: an ok IPA. Maltier than I care for, and a fairly standard hop profile, but nothing wrong with it :)

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler at M&P. All I wrote down was awful. I dont think I even finished it and it was just a sampler. The equipment is bad or something.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap at Rose and Raindrop. Clear, deep amber colored with light red hues. Good dense white head leaves a coating, foamy lacing behind. Light citrus hop aroma with just a touch of caramel. Medium bodied. Malty with a light sweetness. Very solid hop bitterness that approaches harsh but doesn’t quite cross that line. Lingering bitterness. Fair, would benefit with a good dry hopping.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled draught at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsCopper color, light sticky head, well retentive too. Nose of grapefruit & light citrus, fruity melons & malt blend. The flavor is excellent, the hops, sweetness, body & alcohol all take turns in a kaleidoscope of flavors. Finishes smooth, clean (surprisingly). decent.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Dark amber with a foamy head and good lacing. Butter and slighly sour nose. Diacetyl! Meh. Bitter, orange and mango hops. No butter thankfully. Malts are backing fairly well. Medium body with a bitter tail. The nose fails here, but the flavors help out a bit.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. a bit messy but with enough hops to cover the flaws. big cascade aroma, quite thick in the mouth, hint of watermelon and mango, decent bitterness

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pias. Heavy long and sticky palate. Loads of lychee, woody pine. Too sweet and sticky. I still probably underated it.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: They claim to use four pounds of hops per barrel and that hoppiness is present through out the cascade accented brown colored brew.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: nope. outside of the cloudy look and the lemon, this is weak sauce. No distinct yeast or wheat character, just beer flavored water (though less offensive than the porter). Boooooring.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampler @ M&P. Surprisingly flavorless. I dont just mean bland, I mean no flavor at all. Really surprising and upsetting.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Sampled draught at Mia & Pias Tap Room, Klamath FallsLight haze, white head. Nose of butterscotch & hop resin, lots of wheat. The flavor is balance but upsetting. Finishes tart and problematic

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Slightly cloudy gold with a foamy head and big lace. Light wheats and grass. Some flowery and bitter notets. Muted and dull flavors of wheat. Some lemons and other notes of citrus. Average body and a flavorless finish.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. it´s pretty tough to approach the american wheat beer at a brewery that doesn´t seem much good. this was remarkably bland, lemon aroma, plain flour flavour

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pia’s. Thin lemony American style wheat. Short, dry-ish finsh, pretty soft and uneventful.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: On tap at the PDX Green Dragon. Pours brown, dark with a red hue and soft khaki head. Toasted malt nose with a cherry and caramel character. Not as earthy as many German doppels, but a bit fruitier and more sessionable. Hops were a bit stronger leading to a bitter and floral finish. I think they changed the recipe since I didn’t pick up any of the soy sauce or acidity that others described.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Yikes, this is bone dry, with a huge amount of herbal vegetal flavors. Bittersweet soy sauce maltiness, too much roasted acidity, unbalanced.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap in klamath falls. very sweet doppelbock with a little terriyaki in there for balance, not much in the way of a finish

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: caramely and nutty malt aroma, brown/ruby with a tan head, too much veggie maltiness, dry not sweet and slight stickiness

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Clear ruby black color with no head & a little lacing. The aroma is malty with a light fruity sweetness. Lots of sweetness & roast in the flavor, not much hops. Finishes roasty, full boded. Refreshing doppelbock.

column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pias. Sweets soy, caramel and toffee.. But even sweeter and thinner than most, man, why the hell did we go to Klamath falls?

column1: Mia and Pias Flash Flood E.S.B.
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: not a great example of the style, but a pleasant enough beer with very light floral hops and a sweet malt backbone.

column1: Mia and Pias Flash Flood E.S.B.
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap @ Eastburn... Poured amber with a creamy, off-white head. Yeast and malts on the nose. Big biscuit malts flavors and a touch of hops. Overall mellow.

column1: Mia and Pias Flash Flood E.S.B.
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: on tap at mia and pia´s. amber, light floral aroma. pretty mild flavour, hint of rusted tea and sugar, not particularly pleasant

column1: Mia and Pias Flash Flood E.S.B.
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: Tap@Mia and Pias. Odd, empty flavour, short shot of hops in the finish, but nothing in between. tasted english, as it should, but fell short.

column1: Mia and Pias All American Amber Ale
column4: Mia and Pias Pizzeria and Brewhouse
column5: aka Spencer Creek: an ok amber that does nothing wrong but also nothing to excite. Malt and hop balance, but that’s about it.

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: prefer the regular verison to this slightly as it’s juuuust not quite big wnough to be as interesting on the No2. Not really a different beer, though, is it?

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: On tap at Barclays, and something was wrong here. Pours attractive deep brown, but the nose was like kitty litter, and the flavor wasnt much better. I dont think it was the beer, but there was definitely something wrong.

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: Draft @ Valley Brew. Pours a dark chocolate color; creamy, light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing. Solid amounts of toasted bread, cocoa, and bread yeast in the aroma; singular. Chewy nougat, caramel, and chocolate upfront; nicely dense and flavorful dry stout, with just a touch of lactic / milkiness; loads of cocoa. Nicely toasty at the core. Lengthy finish: dry chocolate, cocoa, and toasty malts; again, very nicely dry and toasty.

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: Name: Black Cat Stout Date: May 31, 2008 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Noog Four-O Appearance: black, fine tan head, streaks of drippy lace Aroma: rich dark chocolate and caramel aroma, nice fruity character Flavor: rich dark chocolate flavor, touch of roasted grows into a coffee character and leaves a long black malt bitter finish Name: Black Cat Stout Date: July 07, 2009 Mode: draft Source: brewpub Aroma: dry roasted and dark chocolate aroma Flavor: same rich dark chocolate flavor, caramel sweetness shows up to enrich the chocolate, roasted comes in along with some coffee bitterness Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: 1/5/08, 11th and Final Brewery of 07/08 Roadtrip with Bikesandbeer and his girlfriend Jesse. Drove out the way to get to this brewery, which was worth it, really nice people and good food and good brew. Pours black with a thin half finger head. Nose is sweet and malty. Taste is sweet, malty and light and pretty good overall stout.

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: (Old rating discovered in a dusty pile of forgotten notes, and I wish the notes on this one were more complete.) Thanks to aspidites for this!. Pours translucent black with a tan head. Medium body and moderate carbonation. A bit of ash on the exit

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: Unique muddy, pipe smoky, woody aroma. Flavor is hugely, intensely smoky, earthy (basement?), almost overpowering, but good. Lots of both roasty and hoppy bitterness going on. There’s some raw aspect here that I can’t quite place that doesn’t sit well with me but I can’t help liking this.

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: 12oz bottle from beervirgin72 - Thanks Dawn! - Pours black with a big mocha head that stays well and laces in layers. Aromas of roasted malts, some chocolate, and a touch of coffee. Lots of roast in the flavor and even a bit of burnt malt. Some coffee and dark chocolate show through as well before the dry finish. Smooth and easy drinking. I think this is a dry stout.. Pretty tasty though.

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: 12-oz. Thanks, Aspidites! Pours deep opaque black with thick moussy tan head. Big roasty and slightly sour nose. Medium body; lightish attack. Roasty, ashy, malt-sour mid-palate. Clingy ash finish. One of those beers you could drink a lot of without noticing, but not remember for long after. Nice but undistinguished.

column1: Valley Brew Black Cat Nitro Stout
column5: On tap @ Valley Brewing poured an opaque black with a minimal brown head. Aromas of coffee, black malt and a hint of bitter chocolate. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bitter chocolate, coffee and roastiness with a smooth dry bitter finish.
"for just a golden ale, this is just about as good as they come. nice fresh aroma, if a little light, of hops and semi sweet malt. great for the style, just pretty good overall."

Cool that it is name after Brett "Hitman" Hart. Hazy golden color. Nice aroma of bread and biscuits. Bready and biscuity up front with a moderate pine/citrus hop finish. Once again, another well made brew from Valley Brewing Co.
At the brewery, pours a dark gold color with faint hoppy nose. Subtle hop bitterness in the flavor.

1/5/08, 11th and Final Brewery of 07/08 Roadtrip with Bikesandbeer and his girlfriend Jesse. Drove out the way to get to this brewery, which was worth it, really nice people and good food and good brew. Pours golden yellow with a bright white ring. Light nose. Taste is sweet light and hoppy.

Nice light brown with impressive white head. Strong, dank hops aroma - apricoty pine needles. Nice dry pale maltiness, great peachy/coniferous hop character in flavor. Pleasant, moderately malty body, lingering, thorough hoppiness. Very good!

Date: 04/07/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, 50 Beers on the Wall pale gold with a light haze, fine dirty white head that suds up upon demand, lots of lace, light sweet malt aroma with light spicy floral hops, malt flavor with decent bitterness and light tartness, Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.5/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

On tap @ Valley brewery poured a clear gold with a small lasting white head. Aromas of straw, light carmel and light fruitiness. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, straw and a hint of citrus with a dry bitter finish.

Poured a hazed amber color with a large off-white head. Aroma of grapefruit juice and a touch of malt. Falvor of bitter sweet grapefruit juice and some malt for the base. Mild- to moderate bitterness on a dry finish. Light to medium bodied.

Bottled. Hazy yellow in colour. Minor white head. It has a bitter aroma with juniper berries. The flavour is bitter, juniper berries are present. It has a sweet, dry and bitter aftertaste. Great label drawn by Bret "The Hitman" Hart. I watched this guy with his tag team partner Jim "The Anvil" Neidhart in the mid 80-ies when we got SKY-channel. Kinda fascinating then, nice beer now. Would be kinda neat to get an autograph thou ;)
Bottled. Hazy orange colour, small white head. Nice hoppy aroma. Flavour is quite grassy and hoppy. Long mouthdrying feeling. Too dry and bitter for me. One of the best labels around .)

Bottle from perrys. Highly carbonated. Pours clear Ruby mahogany, large foamy beige head, long lasting. Aroma is pretty cardboard, malt, roast. Flavor is medium sweet, malty, roasty, cardboard, meh, double meh. Huge carbonation on light body. Wonderful combination. I don’t know if this has been sitting on shelves for years, but no bueno.

"tasty, but ultimatly a bit to mild for me...not that it does anything wrong. the malt aroma and flavor and slightly dry finish are just what they were going for, i just wanted a little more. 5/10-another "good for the style" beer. a flavorful mild, but still a mild."

A- Pours a clear copper color with a small, off white head. S- Smell is faint, slightly bready, roasted malt, caramel, a bit perfumey. T- Roasted malt, light hops, bready, very light caramel backbone. M- Thin with medium carbonation. D- I could drink this one all day. Insanely drinkable.

Amber pour with a huge off-white head. Nose of malts and more malts. Medium body and good carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavor is again mostly malts and the finish is smooth and clean. Very easy drinking.

Draft. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel as well as lighter notes of hops, leading to a dry chewy finish.

Bottle thanks to Wavers1. Pours reddish brown. Nose of caramel malt, slight honey, light hops and barley. Taste is barley, caramel malt and slight raisin in the finish. Body a bit thicker than expected, but still on the lightish side.

Dark orange-brown color with a small head. Aroma is nutty and smoky, with caramelized malts and carbon dioxide. Flavor is thin, but moderately bitter. This is certainly a drinkable beer, and I like the nuttiness. But overall, I have to say it’s a bit boring.
Draft at the brewpub. Hazy amber pour, off-white head. Malt, fruit, bits of caramel. Thin and not very interesting.
Hazy brown with a small white head. Fruity aroma with quite a bit of yeast. Sweetish thin fruit and malt flavour.
Hazy amber with a large beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and deep fruits. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, caramel and dark fruits. Finished sweet.
a well balanced session beer, nothing less, nothing more. i like my reds a little more bold and assertive, but this one’s still pretty good."
Tap @ the brewpub. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are burnt caramel, fruits, malt, nuts and hops.

Sample at the brewpub on 8/7/10. Clear red pour with a thick, frothy beige head. Dark malt and caramel aromas with some earthy hop in there as well. Malty flavor with plenty of caramel and a mild earthy hop finish.

A copper amber ale with a thin off white head. In arma, a caramel malt with light funky herbal hops. In mouth, a light caramel malt with light mineral hops, not very west coast, a bit too light. On tap at brewpub, August 27 2009.
Copper brown with a fizzy white head. Faint malt aroma and taste with some musty notes.
Dark amber with a white head. Roasted caramel aroma. Medium plus body with creamy carbonation. Flavor is light roast caramel with a lot of florality. Finishes bitter, but not expremely so.
On tap at the brewery. This reddish brown ale poured with a modest off-white head and a toffee aroma. There is a substantial caramel malt base with some carbonated hop bitterness.
On tap. Clear amber golden with a small off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt and a little caramel. Medium body, lightly burned caramel and nuts. fairly hoppy finish. 130709

From tap at the restaurant. Pours clear and golden orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is mild roasted caramel malt. Roasted malt flavoured, light bitterness. Roasted lingering malt finish with a mild persisting bitterness. Light fruity note.

Date: July 07, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy dark copper, creamy beige head, sheets of drippy lace Aroma: light sweet caramel malt aroma Flavor: rich caramel and chocolate flavor, light sweetness balanced by a light earthyness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4
22oz bottle. Golden color. Lots of citrus. Sharp bitterness and a touch of lemons.

Had this on draft as well. Slight hop aroma, not real pronounced but somewhat subdued. Still, enough to keep me interested. Hop taste on the first sip with a balancing malt profile that makes this drinkable in mass amounts. It’s that good.
Draft. Golden amber beer. Slight citrus aroma - not as strong as many IPA’s. Rich malt and citrus hop. Relatively balanced.
hoppy resinous oily piny mouthful of hops with an extremely well balanced malt backbone that begs to be consumed in large quatities.

Tap @ Bistro 7th IPA Festival. A dark golden amber color with a creamy tan head. A malty body with all glacier hops. An interesting twist in the flavor, slightly sweet, smooth, and not as assertive as others at the festival.

Orange gold color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is citrusy and floral, a touch smoky. A medium bodied IPA. Malts are fruity (apricots and oranges) and sweet. Hops are grapefruity and floral. Nicely balanced. Smooth taste. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Excellent candied orange smell, great orange color. Tastes like most tripels I’ve had, maybe a little better. Great palate. Well done.
Bellissimo colore dorato con testa bianca molto attiva. Bubblegum lava sulla lingua sostenuta dal pane di banana. Sentori di agrumi ai lati della lingua.

Flaske: Efter at have misset denne øl for fire år siden i Californien og drømt om at smage den i 10, lykkedes det endeligt. Den skuffer bestemt ikke. Klassisk belgisk trippel med et godt bid og god friskhed. Dejlig.
This is one of the best tripels I've had. Nice aroma, really great balance of spices, this is very easy to drink. could drink this all day.
Pours bronze with little head; aromas of honey and melon; the sweet palate immediately identifies itself as an American variant.

An outstanding tripel, especially coming from outside Belgium. Tried for the first time in 2011 in Alaska when it still had its other name. Flavorful and slick on the tongue. Lots of coriander and citrus. Well balanced.

Poured from an offensive looking can. Imagine a beer company allowing a can to be produced with art work depicting a naked woman throwing her underwear to the skies while riding on a reindeer. Blitzen? Nevertheless, twelve ounce can cost $3.25, which helped to ease the outrage I felt regarding the can. Pour is dark orange. Aroma is spicy with some nutmeg, clove, light bubblegum, orange and coriander. Flavor is fairly dry, slightly phenolic, and a little bitter. Body and level of carbonation are medium. I thought it was good, but for me it was not a top Tripel.

Can, consumed in an RV. Pours lightly haze golden orange, medium creamy white head, good lacing. Aroma is belgian yeast, spices, honey, orange peel, coriander. Flavor is light plus sweet, light bitter. Medium body. Not bad.

CAN. A clean orange to gold, zero dead.. Yep, can is Spot on, citrus peel & coriander/spices.. Yeastie body with hits of coriander, peppercorns & big orange notes, a touch of booze?.. Sourced REAL a gastropub Waikiki
Can at Kantishna. Hazy caramel color. Smells of spice and banana. Spiced flavor, A tad flat.

Bomber, labeled McKenzie Hopasaurus Rex. Nice brilliant copper pour with a large, lasting white head. Aroma is pretty interesting with candy earthy hop notes. Flavor is also quite good, some sweet sugar/syrup/caramel malt, resinous, earthy, citrus hops. Medium-plus bodied, sticky. Actually really nice! The only beer I had at Steelhead that wasn't gahbage.

Copper orange color. Meaningless to the consumer date code was not looked at by the friend who was nice enough to pick this up for me. mckenzie brewing 345 G 1302 2014 I assume that’s the year at the end, as this smells and tastes way past it’s prime, smelling like a Barleywine and tasting like bitter ass. Wish I knew the store, cause the cascadian dark ale also has 2014 at the end. Yay! Drainpour. I wouldn’t hold it against them (maybe the retailer and distributor) if they just dated their stuff so the average consumer could decipher it, but they didn’t.
Draft - Caramel and candy floss hops. Clear gold with a rich white head. Bitter, caramel and tons of orange with a light booze finish. Proper old school imperial.

Thick foam. Beautiful copper. Umm, yea, so this is hop heaven. Lasting grassy grapefuit rind bitterness long lasting on palate. It’s like several hop varieties are fighting each other in a good way for my approval. Well done. Makes me want to go to Eugene, OR again.
Golden amber with a very earthy and sharp hops and the end. It’s a not overwhelming taste but a great double ipa. Curious about the brewery and it’s association with steelhead.

Bottle, as McKenzie Hopasaurus Rex. Pours clear amber with a medium off-white head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving a nice residual and good lacing. Aroma is light, buttery with notes of citrus, caramel and pine. Flavor is medium sweet and medium bitter, not really that well defined, smooth and easy to drink but undistinctive. Lingering harsh bitterness gives away the IBU, but the ABV is pretty well masked.

floral, grass, citrus, vanilla, banana, orange, hazy, white foam, medium sweetness, very bitter, lightly sour, medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish, all in all very drinkable IIpa. balanced enough to cover up alcohol, but not mind blowng as far as complexity. aroma reminiscent of a highland scotch when glass is empty and warmed, must be the malts.

Bottled as McKenzie Brewing Co. Hopasaurus Rex IPA. 100 IBU, 9.5% ABV. Dark orange-brown pour with a good sized off-white head. Nice retention and lace. Heavy caramel and barnyard malt aroma with resiny, earthy hop elements in the background. Smells sweeter than it tastes. Light sweet, medium bitter flavor. Full body, creamy-sticky-oily texture and a long, yet subtle bitter finish. Malty style versus aggressively hopped. Good beer.

Bottle with the McKenzie label. Pours hazy light copper with a foamy off-white head. First impression was resin aroma, next was non-citrus fruit, then citrus. Full bodied. Almost chewy. Very hoppy with a fair amount of brown sugar background. I’m going with earthy/resin/citrus for hop flavor. It’s pretty smooth - the hop burn is mild, but the hop impact on the mouth continually increases. It finishes very, very hoppy. Nice!

An imperial-style India Pale Ale. Extra deep gold color, extra strong, extra bitter, extra aromatic, extra everything. This was a very delicious IPA, rich and smooth with ample amounts of flavor and malt character. The hopping is so aggressive, but it never gets out of hand, it still stays balanced, right into the finish.
Tap @ the Bistro's Double IPA Festival. Swampy and murky amber brown color with a tan head. A grainy texture with hop fuel like peat bog. Some toast in the flavor.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: 2002 Bottle via Indiana_Red: Way past it's prime but fun to try. It's lost its acidity and fizz. Flavors of sweetness and vegetables. Clear brown color. It was just fun to try something this old. Probably amazing back in the day.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: 22oz caged/corked Bottle Clear redish brown. No head. Lost most of its carbonation over the last 16 years or so. Some woody soft maltiness and a litel wet brown paper character. but lacking almost all of the sour I assume it started with. Past its prime for sure....likely past its drink ability even.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: Bottle in Seattle. Very well past it’s prone. No head, mostly still, dead fruit and cherry nose. Oxidized, vegetal. Not good.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: Deep rich brown coloured body with a lot of movement and some finer sediment floating around with a thin off-white head. Aroma of sour grapes, tons of earth, nuts, caramel, yeast and a noticeable bit of chocolate. Medium-bodied; Assertive earthy malt bite at first with a lot of chocolate, peanuts, yeast, alcohol, prunes and even more figs. Aftertaste is complex but on the earthy and nutty side with a lot of sugars, some of them caramelised and a good dose of alcohol noticeable to finish. Overall, a good, but not amazing beer - definitely nice to try, but I was expecting a bit more complexity and/or interesting flavours - this was just an abbey dubbel with more of a focus on malt, definitely belongs in that category. Still nice to sample, this a day before heading back out to Bottleworks to see what rarer beers I can find. I sampled this 33 cL bottle (NOT stubby as shown in picture, slender like most belgies) purchased from Bottleworks in Seattle, Washington on 25-April-2009 sampled at home in Washington (the real Washington) on 10-January-2013.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: Quite dark color, medium foam. Aroma is caramellish and toffee, some bready yeast. Flavour is too sweet for me. Medium body.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: 330 ml bottle shared by dbsdelight- thanks again, Dan! Dan said he found this at Corral Liquors years ago for $1 a bottle. 2004 vintage with a slim shape like a Struise bottle, not the Duvel-shaped one in the picture. Pours a clear amber with some sediment that hazes it a bit and a small off-white head that settles into just a ring. Aroma of brown sugar, toffee, dried fruits, candy apples, and a little Belgian yeast. Flavor of caramel malts, toffee, brown sugar, nuts, dried fruits, and rust. Light-medium bodied, with low carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel and sticky finish. Interesting beer that has held up okay since 2004 but probably won’t last any longer.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: Pours a hazy brown. Smells of bread and apple juice. Very sweet with a moderate bitterness. Lots of caramel aromas.Light alcohol touch. Also aromas of dates. Bready. Fullish bodied. Soft carbonation. Over the top.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: 2004 Bottle pours hazy nut brown color with thin tan head. Aroma is nutty, raisin, plum, dark fruit. Medium mouthfeel. Flavor is more raisin, nut, dark fruit, bready, and finishes semi dry. A pretty tasty brew. Not quite a 4 though.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: Pours burnt orange. Nose is tart fruit, cherries, plum, grapes, some burnt caramel. Flavor is yeast, tat fruits, some funk, sweet fruity esters, toffee.

column1: Bottleworks Van den Vern Grand Cru
column5: Bottle. Pours cloudy reddish brown with a huge lasting beige head. Tart apples on the first sniff, followed by bread and raisins. Rich malty taste of dried fruits- apple, raisin, date, fig- bread, and spice. Subtle and smooth with a sweet and slightly bitter tobacco finish.

column1: John O Gaunt Coat O Red
column5: Bottle conditioned, from The Offie in Leicester. Faintly hazy chestnut red, thin and quickly dissapearing head and minimal condition. Low sweet worty malt and gentle hop in the nose, sweet caramel and more worty sweetness in the mouth. Slight beefiness in the finish. Tastes like the priming sugar didn`t ferment out.

column1: John O Gaunt Coat O Red
column5: Plain caramel bitter with a well hopped caramel aroma and a fruity hopped flavour. Overall a slightly above average bitter.

column1: John O Gaunt Coat O Red
column5: Bottle Conditioned. From Bottles, London. BBE Feb 2004. Yep - a bit of fruit. I've not been impressed with John O'Gaunt in the bottle - perhaps they will be better in the cask. The three beers I've had have been thin and less than mediocre. All too many British brewers try bottle conditioning and fail big time. Bitter seems to be a damned awkward beer to condition in the bottle. This spilled up on opening, disturbing the yeast so you get it in the glass if you want it or not. There is possibly a reddish tinge, but it's mostly a muddy, murky brown. Some thin, slightly sharp, fruit on the nose. Thin to medium body with a slight harshness that becomes quite irritating, leaving a bloody taste in the mouth. Some fruit, but really not much in the way of quality flavours. Very poor. Nice labels - shame about the beers.

column1: John O Gaunt Coat O Red
column5: Cask Conditioned at The White Lion, Fewcott, Oxon. Reddish amber beer with thin head. Dry malty tobacco flavours with a juicy sweet malt finish.

column1: John O Gaunt Coat O Red
column5: A bitter from a relatively local micro brewer. This has a sweet biscuity aroma, slightly smokey, too. Flavours are of juicy, fruity malts followed by a good degree of dryness and some smokiness. Good story on the label as well!
Tap@John Harvards, Boston, Ma. Not bad, but a bit thin and uncomplex when you compare it to Schlenkerla. Some bacon juice smokeyness, with touches of caramel and chocolate. Sweetish.
Tap @ brewhouse: body is like a porter. Aroma is roast with chocolate, hints of coffee. Finish is chocolatey roast with a smokey feel. Enjoyable.

Found my notes on this from the Wayne, PA location. Poured ruby, with aroma of smoke, malt, and some cabernet. Tasted malty, with smoke, peat, cabernet, and cognac overtones at the finish. I enjoyed this beer.
Deep ruby/chestnut colour. Light smoke colour. Light smoke aroma. Smoky flavour to start with a mellowing finish. Average rauchbier.

Bottle. Very light citrusy hops aroma. Hazy gold with no head. Citrus hops and biscuity barley malt flavor. Medium body, flat carbonation. Considering this brewery went out of business about 2 years ago, I wasn’t expecting much from what was obviously and old bottle.
Pours brassy gold with a short, off-white head. Scent is crisp citrus and water. Taste is malt....barely, borderline bitter. A bit flat. Probably would not have been bad when fresh.
12 oz bottle. Pours dark golden in color. A bit citrusy that trails off at the end. Fairly crisp.
12 ounce bottle.A gold pour white head a fruity aroma taste of citrus feels very thin almost like water but finishes clean and smooth

22 oz bottle This was picked up in Indiana and I think it might have been infected at some point. Regardless I will leave a rating until I can get another bottle (if that ever happens). This had some promise but in the end was marred by the sourness that I am pretty certain is not intended. Fortunately it was a fairly inexpensive experiment. Aroma / Appearance - The foamy head that took over the entire glass was the first warning sign. Eventually though it did settle into a golden yellow body that sparkled like champagne. Yeasty and bright the nose was somewhat crisp. Whether or not they meant to it ended up smelling like a typical Jolly Pumpkin release. Flavor / Palate - Here is where the problems really begin. Sour apple juice is the primary player in something that seems flawed from the get go. If you get past that it seems to have some promise. I just hope that it is not indicative of the remaining bottles that I have yet to open like the stout.
Pours golden with a thin white head. Arom is of citrus hops and malt. Mouthfeel is thin. Taste is carmel and malty with a bitter hops aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a clear light amber with a slightly off-white head. Aroma is dominated by malt notes giving a grainy aroma, some molasses and caramel present. Flavor is dominated by malts as well, slight piney undertone, but mainly a grainy biscuit flavor.
Pours dark orange with a mostly receding off-white head. Notes of soapy hops, cheese, pear, citrus and acidity. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Found this one bottled at a liquor store in St. John, Indiana, as part of a mix 12 pack of various beers from Indiana brewers. Very citrusy brew overall, with plenty of lemon, lime and grapefruit in the nose and flavor. Pucker-dry finish. Not bad!

Maybe a bad bottle - virtually flat beer with no head, almost no carbonation. tasty though, with pleasant maliness mixed with slight hops / spice finish. Will seek out a new bottle to re-rate - with more lively carbonationt his brew would be quite good.
Hazy gold pour with thin white head. Acidic malty aroma. Citrus , sweet malts, and a small hop presence

bottle - Poured lightly hazy gold with almost no head. It had a light citrus and malt aroma. The flavor had a considerable citrus character with some sweet malt. I don’t know what happened to the carbonation though at least, despite the unusually high amount of fruit flavor for this style, I don’t think it’s infected. However, this beer makes the third or fourth bottle that I’ve had quality problems with of the eight beers I’ve tried from this brewer. That’s not a good record.

Bottle courtesy of stfun. Pours gold and hazy with a huge white head. Smells soapy with touches of light citrus and perfumy. Tastes of citrus and slightly watery (as is fit for this style). A little too lemony for a kolsch, but a nice light drinker.

Bottle straight from the brewery: Pours a clear pale golden with a small, stringy-lacing wispy white head. Aroma of semi-sweet, grainy pale malts and the slightest hint of fruity esters. Body starts about average for the style with a very mild flavor and grain husk notes before a slightly more bitter and drier crisp finish. Pretty drinkable and close to style, but that’s about it.

fizzy, simply overpowering effervescence, or maybe the lack of flavor is the worst part of this beer. The beer wasn’t awful, but for the price of a pint, i could have bought several pints of any random light macro brew without losing out on quality. Summed up: reminiscent of bud light at twice the price and twice the fizz.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a shaker. This beer poured a very pale golden color with very lively carbonation bubbles floating around and a huge white head that would not go away. It took about five minutes to get the whole bottle into the glass due to the overwhelming amount of foam. The aroma was made up of sweet pale malts and some light citrus and lemon. The flavor was very light and crisp with a slightly sour lemon note. The mouthfeel was expectedly thin with good deal of carbonation. Average at best.

From the bottle this pours a pale yellow body with a thick fizzy head. The aroma is pale sweet malt and lemon grass. The latter turns into lemon juice in the flavor and dominates the drink. Nothing I’d care to repeat. Pat’s Liquors, Porter, IN

Bottle. Sweet and slightly grainy aroma, not really appealing. Clear golden body is heavily carbonated with a soapy white head. Crisp medium body, slightly oily. Taste is biscuity, bready, and slightly grainy, sweet and malty with a touch of citrus but no hops or bitterness. Can’t call this a Kölsch, but can certainly drink it.

Tap at brewery: Geez go figure, served way too cold even for a Kölsch, finally after waiting about 20 minutes able to taste. Well it is a bit grainy and has some sweet malt background with almost no bitterness minus a hit of citric twang. Drinakble but hardly to style.

Enjoyed on tap at the brewpub. Bright golden yellow with more haze than I’d expect in a kolsch. Very mild fruity sweet, citrus aroma. The flavor was also very sweet, but still very drinkable. A bit of a drier finish would be ideal. Nice silky body. Middle of the road.

Bottle looks very simple, but okay. Beer in the glass deep golden, zippy, nice head. Starts mild but not washy, fine hoppy-dry notes. Not as bready as other beers of this style. Finish well balanced, a bit moldy, but still okay. Better than exspected!

It’s golden with rapidly vanishing head. The aroma has notes of celluloses, old grain and hay, the flavor is slightly sweet and quite bitter in a harsh way and notes of malt, grain, light fruit, and the finish is slightly bitter/harsh. The body is quite full considering it’s a low alcohol...

Definetly one of the better low alcohol/calory lagers I have tried: Pale and heavily carbonated, but with a nice rocky head. The carboard in the nose is very effectively masked with a good load of bitter and aromahops, likewise is the taste dominated by hops. Body is fuller than expected. Really nice brew actually.
50cl bottle. It is a good dunkel with dark ruby colour, medium, beige head, and low Co2. Taste is coffee, dark fruits (ex. blueberry). There is smoke in the end of gulps. Nice.

50 cl bottle. Rather a dunkel than a schwarzbier. Body is ruby/brownish with a tall, vanishing beige head. Aroma is caramel and cherries. Spicy taste with malty sweet notes, mostly caramel. Malty finish. Medium to low body, average carbonation, thin texture

Draught at Smoke Ring, Roma. Pours clear tawny with a small, creamy beige head, medium retention. Moderate rich caramel and toast malt, dark fruits and light hop bitterness with a lightly sweet finish. Medium body and carbonation.

“Maxlrainer Aiblinger Schwarzbier“, Flasche (50 cl) von Grabsch, Berlin-Lichterfelde. - Tiefdunkles Kastanienbraun, sahniger Schaum. - In der Nase mildes aber gediegenes dunkles Malz, Schokolade und zarter hopfenwürziger Hallertauer Hopfen. - Antrunk weich und satt dunkelmalzig mit vornehmer Bitterschokolade und leichter Kaffeebittere. Mild rezent, vollmundig, sahnig. Im Abgang trockener Kakao und nur angedeutete zitrusfruchtige Hopfenherbe. Etwas leerer Nachtrunk. - Hochindividuelles Dunkles mit weichem Körper und allerfeinsten (doch zurückhaltenden) Aromen. Das Dreimaischverfahren schmeckt man!
Bottle - clear nutbrown color, white head. easy Dunkel (why do they call it Schwarzbier?), malty, nuts, caramell, medium sweet. okay.
Dick Rosty, BrownAleLauby & NutSour🚀 Schwarzbier Milestone👌❤ leider ist der TwoHourKorpus etwas zu watery😉 Do It Again Maui🙂 0,5l Buddel.

How: Bottle. Where: Bar Central Birger Jarl, Stockholm. Appearance: Ruby/amber colour with a large beige head. Aroma: Roasted malt, caramel, some chocolate and liquorice. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Roasted malt, caramel, rather sweet.

50cl bb11/2017 merci idiosynkrasie for catering to another preferred style. - Somewhat of a misnomer, going by the smaller print and Bierartbeschreibung "Dunkel Export" here. Immediately betrays its Dunkel pedigree in its stewed maroni caramel nose, some straight up cooked barley soup and Schwarzbrot sourness - no real intensely aromatic Schwarz roast. More Dunkel export and diluted caramel sirup in taste, tolerable but standard, with an grassy bitter finish that partly makes me question this Schwarz’s origins in a lighter export. Not bad as such that...

500 ml bottle, served in mug. Pours brown-reddish with medium-sized head. Roasted malt, nuts, raisins, some smoke, a bit acidic. Light bitterness, overall mild taste. Light bodied, soft carbonated. A bit watery and therefore easy drinking even in summer. Okay Dunkel.

0.5 l bottle from Pivoteka, Zagreb. Shared with Višnja 666 and Goran. Reddish brown, small off-white head. Caramel, metallic, light roasty, nuts. Sweet, malty, nutty. Light body, soft to medium carbonation, light sweet finish. Average.

Tap at the Royston Hotel, Melbourne. Poured a clear medium reddish brown with a thin broken off white head. The aroma is roasty malt, red berry fruit, light coffee notes. The flavour is moderate sweet with a dry roasty, smoky, fruity, liqourice, raisin, light coffee, hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

BB 08/16. Poured a translucent deep reddish brown with a one-finger dense foam head that retained very well and laced OK. Carbonation very high and fine. Aroma of toasted malt, sweet dark fruit (raisins) with a hint of sweet chocolate coming through as it warmed; alcohol well hidden. Taste of sweet roasted caramel malts with hints of vanilla, chocolate and liquorice; taste is quite sweet; not much bitterness (thankfully); alcohol well hidden. Medium body. Crisp and smooth with a soft syrupy mouthfeel and with a quite sweet (even sweeter as it warms) finish. Good.

Bottle from Thirsty Crow (September 2014). Dark cola brown, 2cm tan head, coffee, golden syrup, raisins, prunes, dark chocolate, thick, syrupy texture, earthy bitterness, sweet, slightly smoky finish. Excellent.
Pours black with fast disappearing airy head. Light aroma of molasses and dark malts. Taste brings in some anise and licorice. Light body, despite the syrupy tastes, licorice sweetness on the finish.

Pours a dark brown almost black colour with a lasting creamy off white head, aromas of malts and toffee, lightly floral with an earthy background, flavours of fruits, rasin and plum, hint of vanilla, roasted malts, full bodied with a moderate bitter aftertaste, awesome.

When poured, the Bootleg - Raging Bull immediately announces its intent. A rich loamy head accompanies a dark nectar of a beer, with an immediate scent of coffee and fruits assaulting the senses. On first taste, the rich coffee is apparent, but surprisingly the 7.1% isn't. The lingering sweetness of the underlying dark fruits tempts the palate for just another sip. Definitely work a taste. Frangimus

Bottle @ home. Pours a deep reddish brown / black appearance with a dark brown head. Some burnt sugar, dark grapes, plums, dark chocolate, and light coffee in the nose. A bit on the sweet side. Kind of gooey mouth feel. A touch medicinal. Thick brown sugar. Too sweet and the booze is a little high.
Thick malty aroma. Dark but clear ruby brown colour with excellent head. Toffee malt flavour wit excellent finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Looks like a coke without the bubbles in the glass. Very much coffee on the nose. Taste of caramel, toffee. Even a touch of blueberry. Hops come through the longer the ale out of the bottle. Clean finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330mL bottle. Pours deep dark marhogarny with a lasting mocha head. Big burnt molasses aroma with a slight spicy hint. Light on the bitterness, bold sweet toffee/dark chocolate flavour with ashy notes.
Pleasant wheat aroma. Orange, yellow colour cloudy. Medium bitterness, medium sweetness.

2004 Autumn Brew Review: Hazy Gold Coloring. Watery Overall. Some Wheat. Hard to Detect Any Honey. Rerated: 5-13-07: Pale Yellow Color with White Ring. Sweet Cereal Grains Aroma. Initially Sweet Grains Flavor...Moving to Very Dry Grains/Wheat Aftertaste. Very Subtle Honey Flavor.
Autumn Brew Review 2004. Yellow color, a little cloudy. More wheat aroma than flavor as everything seems to disappear once it hits your mouth. Thin.
Light yellow and cloudy. Very light palate. Nice wheat aromas. Flavor also has a hint of wheat. Thin and watery.
Old rating from notes. Bitter hop aroma. Red color. Thin and watery, with just some hops and very light malt in the flavor. Not much going on and not much to offer.
Pale Amber Color with White Ring. Sweet and Subtle Hop Aroma. Sweet Malt, Caramel, Grains, Light Dry Hop Aftertaste. Session Ale.

Pours a clear light gold, topped by an inch of very frothy soap-sudsy white foam. Good head retention, excellent lacing. Noticeable citrus hops in the aroma - not bad at all. Flavor - fresh citrus hops and caramel malt. No real complaints from me, except that they could have been a bit bolder. Body on the light side, but excellent carbonation that compliments the hops. Citrus and a hint of pine hops in the aftertaste. Let’s call it a dumbed-down version of a West Coast pale ale. Bump up the body a little, and this would be a very nice beer indeed.

Sampled draught at the Autumn Brew Review in Minneapolis, October 7 2006. Light amber with little head and a touch of lacing....faintly fruity, PNW-hopped aroma, fresh but very light and indistinct....clean and refreshing body, moderately fruity and moderately dry towards the finish, but metallic traces near the finish seriously hurt this beer for me....overall, rather dull.

On tap at the brewpub in St. Cloud. Light copper pour with a white spongy head, good lacing. Fresh lake water aroma, not much else comes through. Brief hints of hoppines, with some citrus undertones. Very quaffable, middle of the road pale ale, nothing offensive yet nothing to wake you up and say wow. Smooth, clean mouthfeel, turns a bit stinging near the end.

Doughy aroma with faint hops and citrus. Gold in color with average sized small bubble white head. The head is almost cask-like. A solid layer of sheet lace. Actually a pretty good beer. My expectations weren’t too high considering the relatively low ratings of Ohara’s other brews. However, with the small volume of ratings and solid experience I personally have had with 2 of 3 other Ohara’s brews, I’m not ready to write them off yet. Some bitterness evident; enough to keep the palate interested. Session qualities. Well balanced; moderately sweet. A little thin, but above average for a brewpub beer.
In a bottle in Dresden, not that flavourful or complex for a stout. Basically bad for the easiest style
Aroma 6. Appearance 4. Taste 5. Palate 3. Overall 12. Roasted malt and coffee aroma. Light taste of roasted malt, a hint of bitterness.
Draft @ Drinkers Pub, Eindhoven. Pitch black, thick creamy brown head. Roasted malty, milky chocolate, coffee, predominately sweet, lightly bitter. Medium body and carbonation.

Servis en pinte en pression. Jolie mousse peu persistante. Au nez une odeur de fumé de chocolat et de café torréfié. Côtes goût on est sur des arômes chocolaté et cafeiné. Faible en alcool avec une texture moins épaisse que les autres stout que j'ai goûté. Dans l'ensemble une bière agréable et pleine d'arômes.

Draft. Pours dark brown with a very thick creamy beige head. Tastes like burnt nutty malt, smokey wood, light ash, tobacco, and earth. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like burnt nutty malt, smokey wood, light ash, tobacco, and earth.
A dark / black Irish Stout with high, creamy, light brown, longlasting head. Aroma is roasted, coffee. Taste is bitter.
---- personal review, no claim to be representative or neutral ---- repost undesired --- ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

"Just called Oharas Stout, but I think this is it. Didn’t do anything special for me. Poured on nitro, it was a little too thin to stand up to it. OK, all the usual suspects, just not anything that great."
Sort med lys brunt skum. Kakao, litt røkt og mørk sjokoladelukt. Bitter søt mørk sjokoladesmak. Kort ettersmak, medium kullsyre
Donker bier, ivoor kraag. Aroma van chocola, geroosterd, koffie. Smaak is licht bitter, wat waterig maar toch mooi. Slechts 4,3%
on tap-pours pale yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet grain/light malt, melon. Aroma is lemon/fruit-melon hop, sweet grain/liht malt.
I’ll just ask why? On tap at the brewery with nothing to it at all. For instance, I rated flavor low not because it’s bad just because there’s no flavor. No aroma. Did I ask why?
On tap @ Raccoon River. Light yellow appearance with a white head. Nice sweet pale malty lager nose. Quite sweet, slight soapy pale lager flavor.
Tap. Very pale pour with a white head. Mild aroma and taste - some corn character and little else.

I doubt there’s any lagering going on with this one, but Golden Ale/Blonde Ale doesn’t seem appropriate... this beer is very pale yellow with a white head. The nose is sweetened corn and lemon, with a fresh but flavorless introduction, quick dissolving into a thin, mildly buttery, forgettable twang... there’s some light notes of fruit, but still, there’s really not much in there to be found. Bland, simple, mailed-in for the Bud drinkers, so no surprise it’s not the best beer in the world.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden color with white head that left only a tiny bit of filmy lace. Light sprucy hop aroma accented by a hint of honey. Malty cereal grain flavor. There was also a peculiar industrial cleaner type flavor lingering somewhere in the background. Crisp and dry on the tongue.

On tap at the brew pub. The body was pale yellow with a thin white head. The aroma was grassy with some carrots and lemon zest. The taste was watered down green bell peppers with slight spice in the finish.
Draft-4 oz. sampler--Looks like and tastes like most light lagers. Gold color with no head, slight aroma, and the soft corn taste. It least it tasted fresher than most light beers.

On tap at the brewpub during the 2006 Crescent Moon Beer Bus Trip. Pale blonde in color. Flat with no head. Tastes like a BMC that sat around until the next morning opened. FLAT. Diacyl and metallic finish. Very corny. It sucks.
Pale yellow with a gluey head. Sweet grassy aroma with a light cereal character, and a hint of soap.
On tap at 515.. pale light yellow pour... thin head white... light malt vanilla aroma..taste is similar.. pretty boring overall
on tap-pours yellow with a white head. Aroma is vanilla, cream, light malt. Taste is soft vanilla, cream, light malt, slight hops.
I’ll just say no. On tap at the brewpub. Far too much vanilla, syrupy, overly fizzy. Did I say no?
On tap @ Raccoon River. Yellow appearance with a white head. Light vanilla nose. Poor vanilla and not very smooth cream ale flavor.
Tap. Very light yellow pour with minimal head. Nice aroma of cream soda. Dies on the palate - tastes unfinished. Good start, but this could be developed into something nice.
Average light gold color. Nice vanilla aroma, could be used as a room freshened. Enjoyed the vanilla flavor, hops did not clash. Palate rougher than I thought it should be.

Draft at the brewery. Very pale yellow colored body with just the slightest haze possible. Flavor is strange vanilla syrup, stenchy and sour bread and cereal grains and some simple, sour and stale saltine crackers. Nose has some notes of burnt pepper and burnt almonds... the cream ale element is fairly easy to see, there’s some light milky notes, even coming off as cream soda, and if I had to say something nice about it, I’d say that vanilla is a good thing to put in a cream ale, since it actually works without being difficult. But overall there’s not much to get excited about.
Eh.... Tastes and smells like lightly fermented cream soda, almost no beer flavor whatsoever. Certinally not my thing.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden color with thin white head that left a bit of lace on the glass. Cloying vanilla aroma and flavor that suppressed any malt or hop flavor that may have been there. Sweet on the tongue. Tasted a bit like cream soda.

On tap at the brew pub. The body was pale yellow with no head. The aroma was vanilla pudding with some light herbal notes. The taste was strong vanilla with some menthol and potatoes. This was a strange combination.
Tap - small foamy head, medium amber/red color, sweet malty aroma and flavor, pretty flat, very generic, nothing special
on tap-pours dark amber with an offwhite head. Aroma is medium malt-honey/caramel. Taste is medium malt-caramel, some earthy hops.

On tap at the brewpub. Orange beer with thin white head. Sweet, caramel aroma. Smooth malty flavor with a bit of hop at the end. It’s a generic red, nothing very exciting, but it’s one of their nicer beers. Very drinkable.
On tap @ Raccoon River. Orange amber appearance with a white head. Light caramel malty nose. Caramel, somewhat bitter malty flavor with some more bitterness on the finish.
Tap. Light amber pour with a thin white head. Nearly no aroma - just a little caramel. Taste is not unpleasant but not exciting. Malt and caramel.
Poured a nice reddish orange little head. Nice caramel malt aroma. Flavor was toasty malt with nice balanced sweetness.

Draught at the brewery. Filtered rusty red colored body with a small near-white head. Nutty, chewy caramel malt base with some honey and caramel candy sweetness across the middle, and a bran and dog food note that develops across the back. Astringent and coarse texture, with some harsh burnt peanuts in the finish. Hop presence is nutty and bready up front, but gets consumed in the dog food bran malt flavor in the back. Forgettable.

Draught at the brewpub. Clear orange-red color with off white head that laced the glass. Light fruity aroma (plum and fig) accented by a hint of toasted bread. Fruity flavor with malty caramel and toast notes. Reminded me a bit of a fresh-tasting Bass Ale.

This was a fairly solid amber ale. The body was a rusty colored dark red with a slightly off white head. The aroma was sweet caramel with some toast and peanuts.The taste was toasty with some caramel. There were also almonds in the smooth finish. I enjoyed this one.
Draft-4 oz. sampler--Wow, about the most average beer I’ve had in a long time. Solid malt aroma with a malty taste. The color was a dark red with a small white head.
Tap. Cloudy yellow with big white head. Grainy tasting with a strange bitterness. Don't care for it.
On tap at Django ..down town..light brownish or dark orange pour..who knows ..white head.. nice mild hopps sone pine..overall decent ipa..i likez!
Dark pour on draft. Decent hops. Decent malt. Decent everything. Don't love it but great for Iowa state fair ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
on tap-pours gold with a white head. Aroma is sweet pine/orange, some medium malt. Taste is sweet pine/orange hops, some medium malt.
Hey, my 900th beer! On tap at the brewpub. Straightahead IPA. Hoppy aroma. Smooth, medium-body. Dry, bitter finish. Nothing too unique but well done.
On tap @ Raccoon River. Golden orange appearance with a moldish spore looking white head. Mildly piney, earthy hoppy nose. Decent piney hoppy flavor.
Tap. An awful example of an IPA. Light gold pour with nearly no head. Aroma is slightly skunky. No malt balance - not that there is enough hops to need it. Boring.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a mostly clear, golden colored body with a thin, creamy, white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is sweet lemony citrus and a lighter caramel. Some grainy pale malts and a light floral. Flavor is similar. Grainy pale malts with a light caramel and a decent hop backing. Some lemony citrus and a light grapefruit with some pines and florals. Pines grow slightly into the finish to give this an almost moderate bitterness as it dries with a light residual sweetness. Medium length aftertaste following a light to medium body and light carbonation. Overall, an okay ipa. There is a decent hop presence to this, but its nothing special. A bit thin feeling and slightly sweet at times. Eh...

Fresh growler courtesy of CanIhave4beers. Pours amber/gold and slightly hazy with a lasting, generouse white head. Smells of juicy citrus, ginger, coriander, spicy, perfumy. Tastes of grapefruit, grassy, peppery, some juicy fruit gum, melon, honey, a touch of resin, bitter finish. If I were local, I’d be drinking multiple pints of this one weekly.
Tried at the 4th Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Piney and caramelly aroma and a great balance.
Golden color with a small white head. Very little aroma. Reminds me of an english wheat. Malt O Meal with a touch of bitterness.
on tap-tight tan-mahogany/dk copper. A-med malt-molasses, dusty. T-very sweet/sugary dk fruit, med malt-molasses, slight spice hops. Could not finish this. Oops.

On tap at the Festival of Iowa Beers. Pours light bronze with slight head, nice rich toffee aroma but way lightweight for a Scotch ale. Sweetish light flavor, but I could taste none of the peat I expect in this style. I see others could taste it, but I sure didn’t.

Draught at 2nd Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Clear amber color with thin off white head that laced the glass. Light brown sugar aroma and flavor accented by fig and smoky peat. Slightly sweet on the tongue.
Sampled at the Festival of Iowa Beers. Good malty flavors. Drinkable but not outstanding.

On tap at the brewpub during the 2006 Crescent Moon Beer Bus Trip. The brewer calls the current version of this the "Ringed Tail Rye." A rich looking amber with a white head. Has a limited aroma of roasted grains. The palate is full and complex- lots of scottish peat flavors. Very malty and very chewy. Has a nice single malt scotch flavor.
Dark amber with a small off white head. Heavy malt aroma. Caramel/toffee flavors with a touch of earthy peat. A touch thin in feel. Slight alcohol with a sweet malt linger.
on tap-pours black with a brown head. Aroma is oat/dark malt-roasty/molasses/dark chocolate. Taste is oat/dark malt-dark chocolate/roasty, some earthy hops. Soft carbonation.
On tap at the brewpub. Opaque black, tan head. Roasty aroma. Flavor starts out sweet then leads to a dry, roasted finish. One of their nicer beers.
On tap @ Raccoon River. Dark brown appearance with a smallish brown head. Slightly milky dark malty nose with some espresso. Milky, slightly acidic, slightly roasty dark malty flavor.
Tap. Dark brown pour with minimal head. Nice taste and aroma of roasted malts, chocolate. Palate is a bit flat. Good overall.
Tried at the 4th Annual Festival of Iowa Beers. Big chocolate and subtle coffee make a rather complex and delicious beer! Voted it as my top pick for people’s choice at the event.
Poured black with a nice beige head. Aromas of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt. Taste was coffee, chocolate, and lactose sweetness. Could have used more hops to balance it.

Draught at the brewery. Deep, rich black colored body with a nice-looking dark brown creamy espresso head. Heavy char, roast and smoked malt all over this thing, and the body is somewhat thin so it’s comes across a little like soy sauce and the drippings of an intense campfire put out with a jug of water... the liquid smoke and charred meat and wood almost make it too much to deal with, but over time I developed a fondness for just how rich, smoky and black this thing is.. it’s pervertedly charred and smoky, but honestly not that bad. Oily and astringent in the finish... wouldn’t be considered anything great, but it’s good for what it is.

Draught at the brewpub. Carbonated. Opaque black color with khaki head that laced the glass. Roasty aroma accented by a whiff of anise. Roasty malt and dark chocolate flavors with a hint of toffee. Sweet on the tongue and a bit chewy. Good stout.

On tap at the brewpub. The aroma was black with a light khaki colored head. The aroma was chocolate with some coffee and pancakes. The taste was old coffee with some milk chocolate. There was also some toffee in this smooth beer. Nice to see a stout not on nitro.

Draft-4 oz. sampler--Solid black beer with a tan/brown head. The aroma was full of roasted coffee. The taste was of roasted coffee and malts and the lacing lasted throughout the drink. The finish was sweet, needed to be chewier.
Too much banana here. Sweet and aggressively fruity. Light and slick. Tried for the first time in 2008.
Lots of banana. Really cloudy. Not sure what to make of this. Somewhat milky. Tart.

Tap. Pours a super murky light orange color. Looks incredibly yeasty. Light carb. Aroma is yeasty, fruity, wheat. Flavor is also slightly sweet, fruity, with a gentle tart finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

quite an unimpressive attempt, especially when compared with the american wheat they make. mouthfeel is almost foamy. hazy yellow color, and a flavor so underwhelming that it fades from memory as fast as it fades from the taste buds.

On tap at the brewpub. Pour a hazy yellow with very little head in a plain ol’ pint glass. Smells just like a banana boat, or at least what I’d imagine a banana boat would smell like.
