column5: Slightly dark color with ruby tones. Lightly malted fruity aroma. Very smooth drinking, slightly sweet with a mild mix of citrus and malt with a bit of hoppieness.

Pour on tap at the brewery, clear almost water-colored pour with thin to no head, aroma is slight corn, grain, touch of vanilla. Taste is similar, not much there with grain, some cereal, finishing watery. No thanks.

Location: Draft at the brewpub, 3/3/14 Aroma: The nose is light and dull, some pale malts as well as mild grass hop notes Appearance: This one pours a clear golden color with a small white head and minimal lace Flavor: The taste is much the same, mild sweetness and mild grassy hop bitterness Palate: The body is light and dull, hits the goal feel-wise, with a clean, mildly dry finish Overall Impression: This beer is fine. Unoffensive. It is what it is, and what it is isn’t for me. I’m sure plenty of people probably want beers like this, but I don’t really know why a micro-brewer would choose to appease those people.

Draught @ Oak Creek Pub and Grill, Sedona, AZ Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, biscuit and floral. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours clear yellow with a white head. Aroma of malt, fruitiness, biscuits and herbs. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some herbal notes, bread and some bitterness. Medium body, soft carbonation

On tap at the brewpub. It pours a clear golden body and a dense white head. Weak malty and fruity aroma, biscuits, grains and pears. Soft on the palate, with a bit low carbonation level. Fruity flavor, pears, orange notes and some peaches. Low on bitterness and malty flavors. Short, fruity finish. Drinkable, but too sweet and boring. 130818
December 2011. sampled at the brewpub. Pale yellow color with a white head. Malt, hay and hops. Too light to be really enjoyable.

Pale yellow pour, white head. Had this at OC. Flavors of watery malts, light faded hops, but it lacked any offensive or awful flavors that are often found in light beers....for the style it was pretty ok.
Not really any odor or color to this but it has a decent inital flavor. This really tastes more like a pils than a pale lager to me. Crisp and refreshing. Light but sessionable on a hot day.

On tap at Brewery & Grill in Sedona. Very light color with a small but durable white head. Aroma of a very light pilsner; i.e., less corn and more hops than a typical macro light. The flavor starts with a promising faint hop note that quickly fades. Clean and refreshing but, as is to be expected, not much here in the way of flavor or aroma. Still, way above average for style.
U know the place your at is a touch touristy when they have a micro light on the beer flight. Anyways pours yellow with white head. Tastes grassy, lemon, grains, light hop bitterness.

Sampled 1702, Tucson; November 2011 Arrives from the tap with a lightly browned head that sits on top of a deeply, dark brown, almost black colored beer. When held up to the light it is mostly opaque but does show some brown hues around the edges. The aroma smells of smooth roast, buttery diacetyl, perhaps a touch of dark chocolate, a toothsome toasted grain character, some brown bread whole-grain notes, and some cold pressed roasted coffee like notes. The diacetyl seems to dissipate a bit after some time, though it never disappears from the nose entirely. The beer has a soft sweetness to it that lingers through the long finish; this is boosted by a hint of noticeable diacetyl derived buttery character. The roast flavors are quite smooth and well integrated; it provides a touch of bitter roast malt character, a richly roasted mocha coffee note, lots of dark chocolate and a well integrated, dark malt sweetness / maltiness that provides a chewy quality to this fairly light bodied beer. This is actually light and quaffable, but still has a creaminess and texture to it (perhaps provided by the oatmeal) that provides enough viscosity to keep this from seeming watery. Despite the noticeable diacetyl, this beer is actually fairly good; it would have been better without it, but there is not so much that it severly detracts from the overall character of this beer.

Perhaps the best brew made by OC, at least of those that I’ve tried. The oatmeal stout pours a fairly straight black color with a tan head that sustains itself quite nicely and provides a solid coating of lace around the glass. The aroma was of coffee and roasted malts. The flavor did not finish lactic or dry, but with a light bitterness from the roasted malts. This beer doesn’t run away with excess sweetness, thankfully!

Muddy brown (not a deep, rich brown, but the brown of a swollen river). Some roastiness in the aroma, and some yeast bitterness in the aroma, as well. Not a bad oatmeal stout. Some richness in the middle, some sourness in the end, malts throughout (albeit mild). Prett decent.
Hazy mahogany with minimal head. Aroma is sweet caramel malty, with faint roastiness. Taste has a nice roastiness, good coffee tones, mild bitter burn in the swallow. Decent beer.
Zlatnozute boje, bijela pjena srednje debljine, trajnija. Aroma povraćke, kukuruza, metala. Blage gorčine, neutralnog finiša. Vodene teksture, jake karbonizacije.
Clear golden with a frothy head. Strawy smell of hops. Malty taste with that typical sweet aftertaste most low alcohol beers have. High carbonation. A decent low alcohol beer.

A small taste from wiosna (bottle) @ One Pint Pub. Pours clear golden with a high head. Aroma is sweet grainy malts. Flavor is sweet grainy malts with some hops. A bit too sweet and worty but pretty decent.
Malziger Geruch und Geschmack, durchweg dominant. Leider etwas zu süß. Getreidig. Geschmacklich nicht ganz so übel wie gedacht, allerdings gibt es deutlich bessere Alkoholfreie
Bouteille 33 cl - couleur ambrée, pas de mousse, goût sucré, très sucré, limite on ne dirait pas de la bière

I'm not much of a pilsener drinker, but (fwiw) this is my favourite n/a brew in that category. Additionally, it's inexpensive. I don't really miss alcohol in the flavour, don't detect much wateriness or excess sweetness, either - so this is what I normally drink when I want a pilsener. It captures the style as well as numerous 'standard' brews, and I certainly don't know of any other n/a pilseners that come close to it. Bearing in mind that pilsener is such a difficult style to excel in anyway and that a 0.5% ABV target increases the problems immensely (much more so than for fruitier styles), this one gets high marks from me.
Bottle at bar. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, malts, a bit of hops and toast. Bitter finish with citrus, malts, a bit of hops and toast. Drinkable.
Bottle from our Kiosk - golden color, white head. easy n/a, not too sweet. malty, corny. okay.

Bottle, 330 ml. I'm in the hunt for drinkable, 'real beer-like' non-alcoholic beers. There are two ways of making alcoholfree beers: 1. Interrupted fermentation (that's why most of the non-alcoholics have a half-fermented smell and taste). 2. Boiling method, when the alcohol is boiled out from the fully fermented beer. This one was made with the 1. method, and it's surprisingly good, looks like a beer with a deep golden colour and a decent head. Good carbo, intensive malty and hay aromas with some sweet background. Taste is just OK, a bit sweet and sour, watery palate, but not a disaster. One for drinking, but if u have to drive, or simply don't want to get alcohol, choose sparkling water.
33cl bottle from Maksimarket, Tallinn. Mild grainy aroma with light grassy notes. Sweet and grainy with a slightly grassy and lightly bitter finish. Drinkable N/A
500ml Dose. Limoduft und Geschmack. Kaum Bier. Sehr süss, künstlicher Citrus. Nein danke!
Eine langweilige Radler-Kombination, von der ich nicht mehr weiß, ob sie noch verfügbar ist. Schmeckt nach Zitrone mit leichtem Biergeschmack hinten raus.
Geruch is Lemon, Geschmack is sehr süß, aber irgendwie wenig definiert vlt etwas Lemon aber Grape? Oder gar Bier? Wird nach hinten raus immer süßer

Sampled from 0.5 l can from local 'LIDL', best before August 2018. Slightly hazy, greenish yellow with a thin, frothy, slowly diminishing, white head. Sweetish, slightly artificially and quite fruity aroma of lemonade and hints of grapefruit. Rather sweet, a bit sourish, quite fruity and a slightly artificial taste of fresh lemonade and some grapefruit, followed by a short, minimally bitter, slightly tart finish. Medium body, a little astringent and moderately effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Pretty good, refreshing Radler actually, less sweet than many other industrial examples and by far not as artificial.
Can. It pours slightly hazy yellow with a small white head. The aroma is artificial grapefruit. Thin malty flavor with artificial grapefruit notes.

Actually - not bad as a lemonade. I don’t know if here is really 48% of beer or not. So - yellowish colour, with almost no foam. Smelling like a citrus lemonade with grapefruit. The same taste and with no traditional aftertaste. I would say if you have no other choice - try this, but I would focus another sorts of beer, but this exemplar is still drinkable.
Kupljeno u kauflanda u Šibeniku... Osjeti se limun i grejf..gorko pivo...ipak lošije od drugih radlera..
05-Feb-2016-Flasche-0,33L. Aroma : "Lime". Antrunk: Fruchtig, getreidig. grapefruit nur zu ahnen. Geht so - weckt aber Erinnerung an Lager+Lime in GB Ende der 60er/Anfang der 70er :-)
Bottle at Craigs. Pours clear lemon with a thin white head. Aromas of lemon and grapefruit juice, lemonade. Taste is lemonade. Sweet finish.
Bottle at craig’s. Pours hazy pale yellow, nose is lemon, dull toffee, taste is similar.

Cask (Regal (JDW), Cambridge) 7 Rich grainy husky aroma. 4 Russet, loose head. 7+ Lovely rich malty taste, tons of grains, a bit husky. Some dry cigarette smoke. 4+ Earthy undergroathy hops in the finish, husky and grainy too. 15- Pucker bitter. So full of flavour, but enormously quaffable too.
Cask Handpump at the Richard Hopkins, Newton Abbot (JDW) 18/06/2003 Amber coloured and slightly sweet on the palate. Malty with some dryness in the finish.
Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Amber with a slight white lacy head. Bitter with a malty aftertaste. Clean decent bitter.
This beer has a good deal of pine hops on the nose along with, oddly, some alcohol vapours. This is a bitter beer that suffers from a thin mouthfeel. Average.

Pale amber with a fruity hop aroma. Smooth and easy to drink. As the earlier reviewer remarked, hoppy on the palate without much bitterness, so finishes rather soft and lacks a little "grip". No sweetness in my sample though. Distinctive "Cascade" hop notes, but I later learned that this beer uses Bramling Cross, a British variety (although, in fact, originally derived from a cross between a Golding variant and a wild Canadian seedling) with a pronounced "American" character. Well made and very pleasant, but nothing spectacular. Not quite sure what Tring are aiming at here as they alredy have a 4.2% bitter and a couple of "summer" ales in the portfolio. Handpump, The Crosse Keys, City of London, July 2003.

Sampled cask conditioned at both Akkurat & Oliver Twist, Stockholm, Sweden. Interesting experiment, drinking the same cask ale within half an hour on two different pubs. It was amber coloured, and at Akkurat it had a pronounced flowery hop aroma, which was less obvious at Oliver Twist where it was sweet, but the soft, whipped cream mouthfeel at Akkurat was not there at Oliver Twist, where it was more watery and fruity. Also the hop aromatic finish was more powerful at Akkurat, but at both places the bitterness was rather low. I believe this was the last beer from a big shipment that both pubs racked, and somehow Akkurat got the better hand this time, however I know both places do their utmost to assure good quality of their cask ales. Rating stated is the one that was served at Akkurat.

Bottled. The pun towards a certain Swedish leftist (now ex-)politician gets very obvious once you see the label. Orangey amber colour with fine head. Discrete smokey nose. Clean hard maltiness, rather sweet. A pleasant smokiness creeps up on you and lasts into the salty finish. Between the lines you could tell that the Akkurat staff weren't really that happy with the ingredients they could use at the experiment brewery. Probably the best lager ever to come out of a Carlsberg brewery though...

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Enjoyed the trip to Bush shack but this takeaway wasnt as good. It could have been the wrong label. Mine was not a dark wheat. Had no wheat beer character at all. Nutty Caramel, thin, even slightly soapy. Will have to try this again to give it a fair chance. Have a few more of their beers to sample yet. Beer wasnt infected but think in wrong bottle?

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Sweet malt hop floral smokey aroma. Brown colour with great head nad lacing. Sweet malt burnt hop flavour. Fizzy palate.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: 12 Jan 06 - The irst wheat beer I’ve had with a chocolate grain aroma. Cloudy medium brown-orange colour (What colour should a wheat beer be ?), with a good head and lacing. Grainy malt flavour. Thin and hoppy chocolate finish.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Okay, this rating is probably not reflective of the brewer’s intentions, as the product I tasted HAD to be off-- it was undrinkable! Fom the bottle it poured a dirty orange-brown (bad start for a wheat beer). Sour aroma, and VERY sour palate-- had to spit it out and dump the rest. Both bottles that I got from the brewery were like this. A disappointment.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Interesting beer. Dark copper colour with a big wheat beer head. Aroma of roasted malt jumps out of the bottle which is kinda weird. Milo and roast malt phenolics are the main aromas - they definitely aren’t using a German or Belgian wheat beer yeast here. Tastes very dry - malt sweetness is completely absent, but there’s a fair old hit of charcoal in the finish which reminds me a fair bit of Uerige, oddly enough. Not a whole lot of flavour but it couldn’t have been easier to drink - I nearly inhaled the entire glass in one go and I wasn’t all that thirsty. High carbonation but it kinda works. I think that either they’ve changed the recipe significantly or, like mutant suggests, this is a mislabelled bottle. I’m tipping the former, as it seemed like there was a bit of wheat malt flavour in there. Nice.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Bottled. Cloudy pale yellow. Loadsof lactic acid up front. Medium bodied with clean mouthfeel and notes of lemon and heavy citric acid sourness that completely dominates. The lactic/citric acid character is Berliner weisse style, but it’s less crisp and fresh than Berliner Weisses. Sure, it’s an interesting, and fairly refreshing beer but the sourness goes abit overboard and it gets very one-dimensional.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Dark reddish colour with a big, loose beige head. Slightly sweet aroma. Strong dark caramel taste which is a bit yeasty. It is a bit roasty and somewhat bitter. Quite a mess yet quite drinkable, if that makes any sense. On reflection, due to the appearance, maybe this is another beer in the wheat bottle. I don’t know.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Drainpour :( Suprisingly dark golden colour with slight hazy when cold. High carb supporting large white head. Strong smell of green apples in aroma, with a bit of pear behind it. Very thin watery mouthfeel. Urgh, bad green apple taste reminded me of oxidised homebrew. Maybe I got a bad bottle??

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Hazy yellowish colour with a decent head. Doughy taste with a spicy aftertaste.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Hazy straw yellow colour with a large white head. Pine hoppy aroma and a medium texture but little else with this beer. Re Rate 14/11/05 "Dark Roasted Wheat with arabica coffee like flavours" 3.4% Light tawny amber body, light tan head, chocolate malt aroma, mocha taste but a bit watery at the end.

Date: 04/12/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory, NC Appearance: yellow, Aroma: estery aroma, Flavor: flavor has lots of character, orange, clove, citrus, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Clear orange/golden color with hardly any head at all. Somewhat faint aroma, but some peach, malt, banana, and a hint of spice. Somewhat sour in the flavor, but nothing overwhelming. Pretty complex, some green apple, spice, and other fruits in the taste. A fairly good beer, and worth trying! Had this on tap at Union Jack's in Knoxville, TN!
Nice belgian waft to the aroma, with a yeasty smell. Light brown, very smooth flavor. Light and heavy all at once. Good beer.

Amber and headless. Coriander, clove, and those little colored crystals used on cakes in the nose. A bit of peachfuzz, and green apple in the the thick taste. spices everywhere, yet the underlying caramel sweetness stayed with it until the aftertaste. Some alcohol, too, very warming.

Mostly yellow - gold, maybe a touch darker. Winey, floral aromas. Big malty flavor, fruity (banana ?) flavors as well. ddries out nicely at the finish. More a Duvel - style golden than a triple? Pretty good.
Deep reddish-gold with a medium body.Pronounced sour wine-like aromas and flavor.Strong with malt and fruity accents. Very good.

column1: RJ Le Cheval Blanc Sainte Paix Fraises
column5: Bouteille 660ml (un restant ou re-release?). De couleur dorée et voilée. Nez fruité aux notes sûres (fraises) avec des notes de grains. Mince en bouche et très effervescente avec une texture légèrement aqueuse. Goût fruité légèrement acide et aux notes sûres (arôme de fraises) dès l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un léger goût de grains sucrés. Post-goût très court composé d’une légère aigreur fruitée. (notes de 2005)

column1: RJ Le Cheval Blanc Sainte Paix Fraises
column5: nez:Fruite fraise framboise. couelur rouge tres trouble gout:Goute plus les framboises que les fraises je dirais.

column1: RJ Le Cheval Blanc Sainte Paix Fraises
column5: 660 ml bottle, picked up the same place tigg got his, Rahman. Lightly cloudy, salmon-mandarin orange color, big quickly dying fizzy white head...sweet strawberry soda aroma seems reminiscent of aspartame...artificial, honeyed and cloying as it warms...watery, lightly fruity, seltzer-water character in the body, nothing beery or malty about it...dry finish. Pretty bad, but I suppose it could be quite old? Then again, it is a fruit beer and this brewery is not the greatest ever...

column1: RJ Le Cheval Blanc Sainte Paix Fraises
column5: Huge strawberry aroma with an underlying bready yeast. Hazy golden body with fizzy white fully-diminishing head. Good malt base with a tart yeast flavour. Fruit could be more assertive but is definitely there. Some sulfur/phenolics also apparent in the finish which seem to build the more you drink. Very high carbonation is perhaps a bit over the top for my taste. Overall, this is my favourite of the Sainte-Paix series. (Note: This beer was marked retired when I sampled it - not sure whether it has been re-issued or whether this is an old bottle but I picked up the bottle yesterday at a local bottle store with a good reputation - Depanneur Rahman). Bottle.
Floral notes and some citrus, too. This is a semi-flavorful lager. Needs considerably less carbonation!

Poured piss from a small ying yang...smelled like it was aged a few years in some white trash basement...flavors somewhat redeem...mango, peach, flowers, vomit, sweetness..adjuncts...spritsy mouthfeel...What is this nonsense.

For an american reg, I was not goin to expect much more than a new additon, but i was most surprised. This was slightly above average, the ass taste was not prestent, and i didn't want to finish it before we got out at the 7-11. Good work, but really , with those skills please make some good imperials, stouts, porters, you have the potential, i see, and so should you, may the god of beer be with you.
Almost none-existing white head and brownish body. Aroma malts. Watery and sweet.
Clear Golden with a small white head. Aroma is honey, malt and hay. Taste is medium sweet
A danish, amber, foggy Witbier with very low head and with bitter orange and time. Aroma is malt, yeast, orange, spice. Taste is bitter and light sweet.

Hazed golden color with a fast vanishing head. Rare and not to inviting aroma. Medium body and an average carbonation level. Moderate sweet and moderate bitterness. Caramel malty, fruity, herbal and some cardboard in the flavor. Not to inviting this one. [Bottle from a Advent calendar 2017 – Hatch #15. Bought at Best of Beers in Aalborg, Denmark]

33 cl bottle purchased at the brewery. Slightly hazy golden colour with a few white bubbles on top. Sweet aroma with caramel malts, fruits, thyme and spicy notes. Wheat malts. Taste is sweet. Medium body with a creamy texture and a flat carbonation. Finishes sweet with spicy notes and caramel malts. Odd and rather unbalanced.
Cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma is malt, spice and sweet. Taste is sweet with notes of spices and malt.
Beer so strange, crazy and miserable that you have to be very local to think it's good

Copenhagen 19/6 2017. 33 cl bottle from Refsvindinge Brewery. Black widow spider in it’s web on the label. Pours hazy golden yellow with small white head. Settles as thin almost transparent layer of foam barely covering the surface of the beer. No lacing. Quite weird aroma. Not like any other Witbier I have encountered. Some fruity lemonade but with some strange chemical odor chiming in. Glue and butter gone bad. Soft carbonation and thin palate. Flavor is medium sweet followed by strange slightly spicy aftertaste. Aftertaste is lightly sugary. Fairly short. The Widow certainly seems to have pretty strange desires.
Bottle from Voldby. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma and taste is malt, thyme, light bitter orange, hops. Medium body. Soft carbonation. The finish is sweet with taste os thyme.

Flaske. Farven er orangegul med en hvid skumkrone, der mere end hurtigt er væk igen. Der står hvedeøl på flasken, så udseendet er såmænd OK. Aromaen og smagen er malt, citrus, frugt. Hvilket ikke helt passer til en hvedeøl.

Bottle back in the day, poured a lightly hazy red color with a medium tan head. Nose is lemon, berries, dark fruit, wood, and vinegar. Flavor was most of the same with some cherries and wet wood. Medium bodied. Finishes with a perfect amount of tartness.

Bottle shared at a tasting at the Dancing Camel. Bought in Milan, 2018. Hazy reddish brown with a white head. Vinous, sour-sherry aroma, vinous, alcoholic, a little woodsy and dry taste. Full body, long, vinous finish. Rich and complex.

Green bottle, 75 cl, 2013 vintage, savoured on August 17 2017; eye: dark brown, hazy, ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: acidity, malt, light sourness, malt, fruity, light cherry, slight wild yeasts; mouth: acidity, malt, light sourness, malt, fruity, light cherry, slight wild yeasts, light sourness, light wild yeasts, slight musk, finale in malt with light presence of musk, medium body, below-average carbonation, lightly bitter, really slick texture; overall: correct FRANÇAIS Bouteille verte, 75 cl, millésime 2013, savourée le 17 août 2017; œil : brun foncé, trouble, anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : acidité, malt, légère aigreur, malt, fruité, léger cerise, très léger levures sauvages; bouche : acidité, malt, légère aigreur, malt, fruité, léger cerise, très léger levures sauvages, légère aigreur, léger levures sauvages, très léger musc, finale en malt avec légère présence de musc, corps moyen, carbonatation sous la moyenne, légèrement amère, texture très coulante; en résumé : correct

Bottle from LCBO. Pours a murky reddish brown colour with a small head that reduces into a film. Aromas of cherries, strawberries and oak barrels.Taste matches the aroma with a sour backbone. Very enjoyable sour.

Italia, Italian way, Ma... EH! Rare je traverse la frontière des Outaouais pour du vin, mais ça l'air que la bière y est. J'demande au gars ... Sucrosité? Fruit ? De quessé ça goûte? Pis de répondre : - Brown beer, sour, no fruit, nice for a gloomy day. Anyway. Pas de fruit ? Ça sent la cerise, cherry blossom etc. Un beau brun bouette... J'me f'rais une toune en Si... si seulement le si était un B. Ça sent tout bon sauf pour une légère cenne noire, une-cenne-la-tonne-de-cuivre. Ouain, une touche oxydée. Mais dans yeule ça paraît juste pas. CHÉ BON CHA ! Le bois est présent, shoot ta barrique, tire ta bûche, c'est ma fête, j'me gâte. 16$ la quille, pas trop peu, pas trop trop, je suis le minipoteux du Bowling. Un post qui veut rien dire, sauf que cé bon toé chose. Content de comprendre l'étiquette, de comprendre la bière, de boire avec mon moé. Pas la meilleure, sauf que pour à soir, j'avais besoin de ça. Santé!!!

Picked today part of the LCBO 2018 Spring beer program, dropped it at home as I was placing it with the others from the same collection. As it started to fizz, I opened it to salvage the disaster. Although I'm not a fan of the sour, I like the aroma and the taste of this one.
Reddish and funky smelling, has a bit of an off metallic flavour, a sour beer but fairly sweet, too much going on with the malts, just okay.

March 2018 - Keg at Moor Taproom, Bermondsey. As 'Panil Barriquée'. Pours a dark brown, hazy and opaque, foamy light brown head. Aroma is oaky, prunes, papery cranberry. Body is light with tingly carbonation. Taste is a little better than the aroma - lots of tangy plum and redcurrant, cranberry. Has a papery, somewhat acidic finish. Not bad. (6-4-7-3-14=3.4)

Keg at Moor bermondsey. A murky nut brown coloured pour with a a lasting loose beige head. Aroma is musty grape, vinegar, must, red berries, . Flavour is composed of super dry, bitter grapefruit, clean lacto, musty, airy, pithy. Palate is uber dry, pithy, abrasive carbonation.

Moved rating from mistaken European entry. Typical Flemish Red look, with very creamy carbonation with a dense brown-tan cap that looks great. Aromas dance with mineral and sour fruit, it just FEELS sour. Taste all sour fruit with a pretty dominant acidity, very acetic. Indeed some lemons and dry, dry cider, mysterious sour fruits, plus wet stone and slight earthy pungency, Really too light with nothing deep, complex and fruity in the body to counter the sourness, hence not all that great or interesting. Still pretty OK though. This acetic ale would (and still may) make a great Carbonnade Flamande. Rating added 4/22/2011 (updated 4/25/2011)
Bottle. Brown color. Aroma of malt, butter and fruity tart. Strenge taste of buttery caramel, red fruit, mild tart and malt. Seems infected or messed up, strange.

750ml bottle. Cloudy chestnut colour with average to huge, frothy, slowly osteoporosing, minimally lacing, off-white head. Concentrated fruity aroma, gooseberry jam, some rhubarb, white grapes, disguised, minimally chocolatey, malty background with a touch of coffee. Taste is chocolately dark malty, notes of coffee, slightly vinous, fruity overtones with notes of gooseberry, white grapes, minimally tart, slightly bitter finish. A bit unbalanced and inhomogeneous, nevertheless a nice, though not fully working combination of flavours.

Bevuta come "Agreste riserva" 75 cl. Purtroppo finita immediatamente nel lavandino. Gushing all?apertura, carbonazione con bolle giganti che ha reso imbevibe il tutto. Ho cercato di servirla in coppa. Colore bruno. Al naso indefinita, in bocca un dolciastro sgradevole e acidità aggressiva (ma non come una sour, mi ha dato piuttosto l?impressione che fosse andata a male). Bottiglia avariata?
Bottle at Campground Brewdown 2014. Pours a murky brown with at thin white head. Smells of old paper and tart musk. Tastes of bad paper, funky and dissapointing.

[6682-20140816] Giant bottle. Toasted bready sour aroma. Hazy, pale brown amber body with a quick foamy white head. Light lemony bitter flavour. Medium body is a little sour. Good. (7/3/7/3/15) 3.5 (@ Campground Brewdown 2014, Millmont, PA)

2014-08-16. Hazy dark amber body with a small off white head. Aroma is pleasant, sweetish malt has a little spice to it, almost like Christmas spices. Flavour has sweetish malt base with lightly tangy fruit below. Smooth average to light bodied palate, soft carbonation. Not super complex but enjoyable. Magnum bottle at Campground Brewdown

Red copper, cream copper head, quickly disappearing. Light roasted Malts, chocolate, hint of coffee and a cherry-like sourness. Spectacular aroma. Taste.... Not so spectacular, aggressive sourness follows a light sweet entry and fades into a herbal bitterness. The second sip is better. Roasted malts, chocolate and some coffee, light riped fruits.

Assaggiata il suo alias "agreste riserva", prezzo 10 euro, formato 75. Totalmente sbagliata la sua classificazione e etichettatura, leggendo i commenti non sono l’unico. Floreale e fruttata all’olfatto, subito acida e aggressiva in bocca, note di ciliegia, praticamente una lambic. Retrogusto asciutto. Avrebbe il suo senso se una sapesse che birra compra. Pessima figura del produttore.
Bottle. Brown color, beige head. Aroma of caramel, butter, diacetyl and sugar. Flavor is buttery, sweet with a sour base. But infected overall impression.
Brow bodied. Butter, sticky toffee, white chocolate. Bleh. Taste is also pretty bad. Somewhat sweet and dry ending. Either a brewing error or just not nice. (Bottle at Colin’s De Molen tasting)

My first Ukraine rating. Funky, skunky monkey smell. Pale goleden/yellow with a Ukraine sized snowdrift of a head on it. Watery and vaguely cereal laced. Nice steady gas release, but not much flavor or body. Yet I could see it being a good warm weather quencher lawnmower beer.
Bottled, now brewed by Chernigivskiy Pivokombinat (4.7%). Bright golden. Neutral aroma. Sweet with notes of cereals and peas. Clean, hard mouthfeel. Useless.

Good label, nice big bottle, gold. Brown bottle, not green like the pic here. Tart and grainy lager aroma. I agree that you should drink this cold. Tart malty flavor with some astringency. Has some character, but not the best beer in the world. Zippy carbonation with some ale-like qualities in the finish. This is a marketing dream-name: Bartender: "What'll it be?" Patron: "I'll have a Taller Beer, please." Announcer: "They always go for the taller beer."
Bottled(500ml). -quite good golden coloured beer with nice head, fruity aroma with hints of hop, bitter finish
Fairly standard lager: light color, slightly fruity aroma, medium body, palate is neutral and watery. I wanted more hops.
A huge, frothy head. Quite fresh aroma and flavour with hints of hop. A bit fruity.
Golden color. Unbelievably rich head. Hens food aroma with some maltiness. No bitterness. Standard Ukraine Pils...

A non-dry, yet crisp pilsener that's a touch rough. It's flavor smacks of the Eastern European/Soviet taste that's rather malty for a lager. Moderate fizz. Lacks the delicious yeastiness of some of the Baltic States lagers.
Had it on tap during Spring celebrations in Kyiv. Very fresh but not remarkable.
very crisp, clean tasting. not as harsh as some of the other pils i have had out there. another good one from yantar brewery.
Rated based on notes taken 29 Apr 2012 -- On tap at the brewpub, this is a very nice solid Pale ale.
Very frothy whit head with a copper color. Aroma is hops. Kind of piny? Taste is pretty bitter. Not super complex. Light body.
Draft at the source. Clear golden amber color, thick white head. Aroma of floral pine. Taste is lightly bitter, fruity. OK.

On tap at the brewpub in San Antonio where it was listed as Cinco Peso Pale at 5% ABV. Appearance: Pours amber with a semi-durable head that leaves good lacing. Feel: Near medium body and medium carbonation. Flavor: Appropriately hoppy. Some malt flavor with a dominate input from hops. Moderately bold for style. . O: good but not great.

This pale ale is very aromatic displaying toffee, vanilla, and flowers. The body and bitterness are in perfect balance. It comes through with a long finish which is definitely Cascade. A solid brew, enjoyable.

Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 1/23/14 Aroma: The aroma is light hops, a little citrus, with floral and caramel notes Appearance: This beer pours a copper-orange color with a small head Flavor: The taste is much the same with some light sweetness and light bitterness Palate: The body is on the lighter side, with a clean finish on the mouth Overall Impression: There isn’t too much to say here. It is a fine APA, but nothing special. It is both on the simple side and on the light side.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a light golden with some light amber highlights, clear, average head with average retention. A one dimensional aroma from Cascade hops, typical grapefruit and orange-peel like aromas with a little light caramel malt in the background. Flavor like the hop aroma is also a bit one-dimensional, very light candy-like sweetness, some cracker-like malt notes, and a medium amount of bittering. Another example of a very simple pale ale recipe which has been executed fairly well. This beer has a clean finish however it either needs more finishing hops to carry it or it might have been an old beer. Weak overall.
(Draught) Pours a hazy golden body with a medium white head. Aroma of citrus, florals, and caramel. Flavor of florals, biscuit, orange juice, and grass.
Copper with whisps of off-white head. Mildly hoppy and balanced malt body, the hops definitely feature tho. Aroma is mildy hoppy.

On tap at the brewpub. The beer pours an orange-white color with a white head. The aroma is very well balanced. I get some caramel and toffee malt as well as some pine from the hops. The flavor is more of the same. The beer is very well balanced and the malt keeps the beer from being bitter, while still allowing some hop flavor to come through. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

On tap at the brewpub in San Antonio. Appearance: Pours golden with a semi-durable head that leaves good lacing. Feel: Light body and near medium carbonation. A bit watery, Flavor: Good balance. Light-roasted grain flavor with a complementary touch of hops. Too mild. O: Certainly not a bad version, but this is a style I seldom like much. Still, better than their similar Texican.

The beer pours blonde with a good head. The aroma is a little thin, but displays both hops and malt. The taste is grainy though not as dry as a continental pils. The finish is spicy, but could be spicier, and pleasantly long. One of the better domestic pilsners I have drank.
Draft sampler with a white head. Aroma of malts, yeast and grain. This one tasted funky to me, my least favorite of the brewery.

On tap at the brewpub. The beer pours a golden color with a white head. The aroma has a lot of biscuit malt, as well as some yeast and lemon notes. The flavor is a little bit different. I get the same biscuit and lemon notes, but I also get some grain and banana notes. The banana is actually quite strong and was unexpected and doesn’t really go with the other notes. Creamy, medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. This tastes more like a hefeweizen blended with a pilsner.
Golden-clear in color with slight white head. Clean tasting with a strong body...a smooth pils.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours pale yellow with a medium white head. Good head retention. Nice American style pils. Not very European at all. Crisp and clean finish. Good pilsner.

On draft at the brewpub in San Antonio. Pours a cloudy dark golden Ripe banana yellow with light golden yellow hues when held to a light source and a one finger frothy white head with decent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap. Slightly hoppy aroma with subtle bready yeast, pilsner malt, crisp light fruit notes, grass and straw. I’m picking up some apple and pear which along with the bready yeast notes provide an interesting balance in the nose. Surprisngly full bodied for the style but still extremely refreshing and quaffable. Very similar to the aroma with a nice touch of bready yeast adding complexity to the crisp light fruit notes and pilsner malt. Hints of apple and pear along with hints ob earthy grass and straw. I’m not the bggest fan of this style but I really enjoyed this beer.

Had as "Summer Pils" : pours a mid cloudy yellow .. . medium head . .lacing is prime time mr klein .. . a touch of the sweet side, a little soapy in the back .. but a good summer refresher .. why is there so much sand at the beach? i prefer brick ..
Very pale urine colored. Head left seom decent lace. Nice Saazy nose. Very thin. Dryness shows up very late. Except for the "water" element, it really isn’t that bad. Not.
Not what I expected. Good yellow-orange view with superb head. But a "model paint" scent and unusually acidic flavors detracted from this otherwise smooth, mouthy beer.
Awesome amber beer with outstanding caramel malt character. A hint of cloves? Very good beer. Ask for this one first!
Bottle sampled at omhper, thanks. Short head. Clowdy appearance. Small malty aroma. Fine nobel hop taste. Well fermented without sweetness. Small acidity.
Vom fass, im Geruch recht würzig klassisch hopfig, im Geschmack getreidig herb würzig hopfig, nicht so schlecht
12-10-18 // 330ml straight from the bottle. Bought at HopShop Trier. On my way to Trier Bier Festival at Kraft. Smooth Helles with a light and fresh citrus and grassy aroma.

Bottle 330ml. @ home on the terrace. [ As Zils-Bräu Hell ]. [ Trade by Beerhunter111 ]. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, pale malt, citric, soured milk - lacto, light soapy. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, sweet malt, fruity, lacto, citric, light tart. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20170705] 5-3-5-3-8

August 14, 2015. Bottle. Tasting at omhper, thanks for sharing! Clear golden with a medium sized white head. Aroma is sweet wort, light spicy yeast notes, some sulphur and grass. Taste is light to medium sweet grainy, light bitter and slight citrusy notes in the finish. Light to medium bodied, average carbonation.

How: Bottle. Where: Tasting at omhper, 2015-08-14. Appearance: Clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma: Malt, caramel, spices, grass. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Malt, caramel, grass.

Light golden bit hazy with a frothy white head. Aromas of straw, white bread, floral and light herbal notes arise. Softly carbonated with a light texture and light-medium body. Swift malt-floral sweet-bitterness, well balanced. Thirst quenching.

Draught Dense, very white head over deep-golden beer. Banana, yeast, Pilsner malts. Very dry (for a Helles), fine and slightly hidden restsweetness. Again banana, but hardly sweet. There’s a lot of iron in the water, but I didn’t trace it in the head. Mineralwater quality, soft carbonation, and quite slick. Sweetish, soft, but indeed very pleasing Helles.
Bottled, from the brewery. Hazy pale golden, small head. Grassy, spicy nose. Dry with light-medium body and clean mouthfeel. Fruity with serials and faint spicy hops. Mid bitter finish.
Many thanks for this bottle to Beerhunter111. Pours pale golden with airy white head. Clear aroma of hops, yeast and grain.
Sampled at omhper, thanks. Short brown head. Opaque dark amber color. Fruity acidity with some light caramell and mild roasted malt taste. Almost no aroma.

August 14, 2015. Bottle, best before august 22, 2015. Tasting at omhper, thanks for sharing! Clear dark amber with a very small off-white head. Aroma is light sweet with some malty toffee notes, dark bread, slight citrusy. Taste is light to medium sweet, bready and malty, slight citric finish. Light to medium bodied, soft to average carbonation.

How: Bottle. Where: Tasting at omhper, 2015-08-14. Appearance: Brown colour with a beige head. Aroma: Malt, citrus, a bit sour, caramel. Body: Medium body and carbonation. Flavour: Sour, malt, citrus, caramel.

Draught Very good dense head, yellow-beige. Fully opaque, well-carbonated, foxy-brown beer. BIt bready, breadcrust, again banana in the aroma. Sweet, quite sweet-bready, coloured malts and melanoidins, ripe banana, some filandrous exotic fruit (taste, not feel), sweet roots. Finish has a drier, earthy flavour. Feels much better bodied than it probably is, near chewy. Well-carbonated. Sweet - but far from bad.
Bottled, from the brewery. Hazy chocolate brown small head. Bready nose with a whiff of lemon. Mid dry with medium body and rounded mouthfeel. Toast, grass and some lemon. Low bitterness.
Many thanks for this bottle to Beerhunter111. Pours a brown color with a minimal head. Light sweet aroma of roasted malt, coffee and raisin.
On tap at the Brewpub: Rötlichbraunes Bier mit geringem Schaum. Geruch röstmalzig, leicht muffig. Geschmack wässrig malzig mit leichten Röstaromen.
Getreidig-karamelliger Beginn, wobei diese beiden Aromen aber nicht sonderlich gut zusammenarbeiten. Herb-muffig, modrig alt wirkendeMalzigkeit, dazu auch noch wässrig. Brotiges Finish. 10/7/8/7//7
This one is preety good as well from this out of the way pub. Nice looking beer that is for sure. Taste is a bit off for me but it is good.

On tap at the brewpub. This beer like the Helles has a very mixed bag of ratings. Again I think the brewmaster is playing around with the process. This beer poured a cherry brown clear color, with a nice soft tan head. A fine looking beer. Aroma is roasted malt and dark fruit. Taste is more roasted malt, and sweet fruit. Palate is dry with some sweetness. I think that this was their best beer.
Draught at Hotel am Markt, St Goar, Rhineland, Germany. Gold with white head. Malty, grainy, cereal lager beer, some vague fruitiness, reasonably smooth. It's okay.
Can Pours a clear, pale yellow with a decent lasting head. Light with some hop zest. A hint of mowed grass and clean finish. Maybe the best inexpensive beer in Morocco.

Rating #1380 12.12.2014 500mL Can #11 from the 2014 BeerAdvent Calendar (Costco). Clear, pale yellow pour with a weak white foam that fizzes away quickly. Aroma is toast, mild grass. Taste is mild floral hops, mild grainy, mild toffee sweet, and quite grainy on the finish, which is dry, but crisp. Mouthfeel is bubbly, but satisfying.

Pours a clear straw with effervescent carbo and a rapidly disappearing white head. Aroma is sweet corn with some herbal skunky notes. Flavor is same oxidized sweetness with a mild bittersweet aftertaste. Light palate. Forgettable
500 ml can. Just a tiny malt smell. Pale gold color with white head. Bitter taste, not really strong. Unusual for a supermarket cheap beer.
*Old rating. Best before 06.10. Malty and a bit grainy. The beer is slightly malty, worthy, slightly grainy with minimal bitterness. Nice.

It pours a pale yellow beer with a white head. The nose is metallic with notes of herbs, butter and lemon. Weak sweet flavor with a low bitterness showing a poor biscuitty characteristic. Dry buttery finish.

If there was a generic definition of beer, this is kind of how I would define it. It is quite carbonated, golden yellow in color, minimal head It tastes like....beer (obviously I don’t have a great palate). No smells or notes that jumped out at me....maybe dandelion or grass. Drinkable but thoroughly average.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.
From the notes. .5L can bought in Verbier, Switzerland. Pours golden, white head, basic beery.
At the Brewery - a creamy, smooth drink, light enough to drink without feeling stuffed at the end of a pint or two. Not going to change your life, but a yummy brew, none the less!

(02.03.06) On tap at Old Dominion brewpub, Ashburn, VA. Black hued with creamy off-white head. No discernable carbonation. No aroma. Medium bodied stout that starts with light sweet malt and roasted malt flavor. Finishes dry with light lingering roasted malt bitterness. Thin textured and watery. Monodimensional in flavor with very little complexity. An ordinary drinkable stout.
On draft at the brewpub, 9/1/05: Creamy ... nice irish look ... smoky, sugary, lightly tinged with a bitter chocolate sense. Bit thin.

Dark brown with a small, thick brown head (nitro). This one smells of mild roasted malt, mild coffee, smoke, chocolate, with an aroma that is mild overall. Upon first taste, I’m quite surprised at how thin and watery it is. Taste is mildly bitter with hints of roasted malt, bitter chocolate, slight hints of smoke, perhaps even a bit of wood. Overall it’s dry and mild.

Dense black colour, with a moderate, creamy head. Very dry, with roast and smoky malt and hints of chocolate. Quite tasty. Smooth palate, but there’s not much body to it and the overall feel is a bit weedy. I’d rather got used to stouts being a bit bigger than this in the US. On tap at the Dominion brewery.

Had this on draft at Dominion on 11/21/04. Black body with a small dense tan head. Is this on nitro? Nose is roasted malt, light coffee and a pleasant underlying sweetness. Taste is roasty, sweet, light coffee, and some bittersweet chocolate. Body is smooth and creamy with a light oily feel. Hint of bitterness. Finishes with more roasted malt coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Nice beer!

Poured a chestnut brown color with a tight, creamy, khaki head and left light lacing on the glass. Butterscotch and roasted aroma. Watery and dry, very light chocolate and mild roast as well. Disappointing mouthfeel.

(draft) Nitro creamy tan head atop brown-black body. Aroma is medium sweet, chocolate, coffee, roasty, hint of smoke. Taste is medium sweet, coffee, some chocolate, roasty. Light-medium body, fairly clean finish, though the roasty coffee lingers.
On tap at the local Brewery. Big Bodied Black beer..with nice balance of flavor. Great dry roasted malt

On tap at the Brew Pub. Deep black color with a creamy head from the nitrogen. Reminded me of Guinness. Chocolaty aroma. Roasted malt and some coffee as well. Nice balanced flavor with toffee, roasted coffee, and a hint of chocolate. Very nice stout!
From the file last updated in 2010. Pours dark brown. Aroma is dark malt and chocolate. Flavor is dark malt and chocolate. Not bitter.

This beer comes compliments of beerguy101 without whom I’d probably have at least 100 fewer ratings. This beer pours a brownish red color with a somewhat impressive head, tan in color at least for a sweet stout. Good lacing as well which was surprising. The aroma is mildly malty...definitely sweet with chocolate, coffee and vanilla with a hint of oak and twigs. The flavor is medium to somewhat full bodied, nice flavor development, long lasting somewhat wet finish. Heavy chocolate grains, coffee and cocoa. A dash of cherry and licorice mixed with oak chips caps off this sweet stout.... wonderful balance, light and milky texture as it warmed....a shame this company went out of business...true its only one beer I’ve tried, but it would have been nice to have tried more.

It was the zesty BeanDip that gave me this beer! I think she got it from her beer of the month club, which in turn got it from a distributor, which obtained it from the brewery in Richmond, VA; and that’s how I acquired this beer!!! THAT’S CRAAAZY!! I poured maybe 3oz of beer liquid into the glass and I got a caramel colored head the filled the remaining 6” of the glass? The body is a dark crimson brown, waiting for the head to settle……… Aroma is full of cream; sugar + milk = cream, notes of chocolate and sweated coffee, again waiting for the head to settle…………. Watery palate, kind of chalky, the flavor is ummm, bittering & dry coffee and more coffee, nothing exciting going on here, however I would really like to visit the Main St. Brewpub! Thanks for the experience BeanDip!!!

bottled-Huge head (took up almost half my glass). Smells and tastes exactly like it's title: sweet and stout. Also has a slightly burnt, chocolatey taste. Nice dark color typical of most stouts. It's not bad, but I've had many better stouts. I might pass on another bottle - unless of course there wasn't anything else available!

Bottled - Sparse head with some bottles; little to none with others - what gives? Head is either nonexistent or a thin ringlet. Excruciatingly thin body for stout; wispy mouthfeel does not fit for the brew style. Over carbonated. Dark brown with reddish nuance. Nice burnt roasted flavor. Aroma is best aspect: coffee-like toastiness. Slightly below average due mainly to physical properties, but I guess I would drink again considering it's local. Slight extra credit for being within walking (stumbling) distance from my place.
No real nose. Sweet rice milk taste. Decent to drink, but artificial. Watery feel for the mouth. Uninteresting.
It's a pleasant enough beer to drink, but certainly nothing special and not worthy of a beer of the month club that costs $44.95. Very light in color and body for a stout.

Pours a nice color with a rich aroma of roasted malts. Unfortunately the beer hits it's climax before you taste the first sip. Very watery palate with a very dry roasted malt flavor profile. Nothing sweet about this stout as it has no discerning characteristic other than roasted malt.

A deep garnet on the pour, the head miniscule, the color “Who Cares”, the lace “MIA”. Nose, sweet, lightly toasted grain, not much else. Start sweet, top “Cadaverous”, finish bland, dry aftertaste, Watery, a bit of hops, I guess this passes for beer, but just barely!

Pours very dark brown with an inch thick tan head. roasted malt nose isn't big by any means, also there is a slight green pepper aroma. This is terribly thin and watery. Yesterdays cold cup of coffee!! Slight bitterness in the aftertaste. Poor quality stuff. No alcohol in it either... Maybe this IS last nights coffee!
Fra cask på Teign Cellars, Newton Abbot 27 Sep 16. Gylden kopperfarget. Filmskum. Lett fruktaroma. Smaken tørket aprikos. Lett syrlig etter hvert. Avslutter bittert.

Cask ale, half pint at Teign Cellars. Spotty lacing from a missing head. Near clear amber coloured body. Smell of plums and apricot. Berry fruit flavours alongside brown malts. Distant bittersweet end. Easy going (Newton Abbot 27.09.2016).
draught at Well Hosue Inn, Exeter. Amber-golden coloiur, mid-suzed white head. Malty, slightly hoppy with a fruity touch.
Cask handpull at the Digby Tap, Sherborne, Dorset. Deep amber colour with a small off white head. Mild caramel malt aroma. Quite sweet with an oily texture.

Cask. The Pub, Leicester. Amber with a white foam. Aromas are woody with Weetabix and earthy hops. Lemon and green apple with hints of strawberry. Flavours are mixed autumn fruit with red berries. Weetabix with slightly tart lemon. An OK fruity bitter.
Cask at The Theobald Arms, Grays, England. Clear pale amber colour with small white head. Woody malt and mild English hops in aroma. Wood and hoppy bitterness in flavour. Not that inspiring.
Cask-conditioned at the Highbury Vaults, Bristol 07/02/10. Copper coloured with next to no head. A malty bitter with a hint of barley sugar, and some decent hedgerow hops in the bitter finish. Good.
Cask Handpump at the Pot Of Beer, Manchester 13/02/2004 Copper amber coloured and slightly sweet on the palate with sour fruit aroma. Some dryness in a lasting malt finish.

Sampled cask conditioned at Oliver Twist, Stockholm, Sweden. Pale amber. Vague hay hop aroma. Light body borderint to watery. salty and soft of notes of grass and a moderate late resiny hop bitterness.

Completely opaque, black as night. Thin light brown head. ALCOHOL and some serious roastedness, but hop presence is discernable as well. Some grainy notes, lots of dark cocoa, bitter and ALCOHOL. A smokey whiskeyish character stands out in the mouth. Great roastey finish, surprisingly sweet as well. floral tones fade in and out of the roastey alcoholic brew. Its got some power, but I was left waiting for the massive warming effect I thought an imperial stout aught to bring.

Only had a few ounces of this, but it was memorable. Super heavy on the tongue and very rewarding. Had a nice & aromatic, licorice ambience to it. Brutally intense and very attention-getting. Nice and deep alcohol nip in the finish.

With the swanky label and odd shaped bottle I thought I'd be in for a rare treat. A good Japanese craft beer. What I got was an average pilsner. As 90% of all Japanese beer, a clear golden color with a slight white head. Some mild hops in the nose with a brief sweetness quickly followed by bitterness. Crisp finish and easy drinking. Better than the typical Macros but I was expecting more. Great bottle but the beer wasn't worth the time or effort to find.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Tasting from early 2008. On draught it produced a muddy, deep, matte brown with a few stray bubbles rising here and there. Holds a short, creamy pad of white for the length but manages little lace. Meaty, pumpernickel, and warm rye bread nose with a little Bovril and grain husks thrown in. Quite light in the mouth given the pronounced aroma. Carbonation is soft, quite smooth in the swallow. Chocolate malts dominate, some mild yeasty notes late, a good lot of whole-grain bread and Bovril. Malty, dry length has just a little smoky roughage. Better as it warmed, just a light sugary sweetness comes in to balance the dry. Not bad at all. Would have liked to compare the draught to a bottled sample. (On draught at the brewery, Yallingup)

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Dirty amber-brown, cream coloured head. Fizzy and thin, but roasted malt is present in the form of toast and toffee. I liked their other dark selections better.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Murky light chocolate colour with a light tan head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Malt and caramel taste follows a thin watery start and finishes with some body. Drinkable considering it was first thing in the morning.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Porus brown with beige long lasting head. Aroma of caramel with a hint of chocolate. Smooth though thin body. Sweet cola like flavour with a touch of chocolate. Drinkable, but not great.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Dark Amber, almost brownish colour with off coloured head. Sort of a moca-cola artificial flavour.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Faint hazy cola-amber colour under a large fast fading beige head. Soapy woody hops and artificial caramel and boot polish aroma. Thin body. Generic flat cola and stale freeze dried coffee flavour. Artificial faintly sweet malty and chemical adjunct finish and aftertaste.

En fût sur place. Nez légèrement malté de grains pâle aux notes mielleuses avec des notes de houblon floral et fruitées (notes d’agrumes et de pommes). Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture à la fois aqueuse et très légèrement crémeuse. Léger goût fruité (agrumes, notes de pommes) avec un très léger goût de grains de malt pâle lors de l’entrée en bouche suivi d’un léger goût malté (légèrement mielleux avec de faibles notes de caramel doux) avec des notes de maïs sucré et herbeuses (foin) et une finale très légèrement amère de houblon floral. Arrière-goût court, très légèrement amer de houblon floral. [notes 2006]

[5325-20130501] Tap. Light fruity yeast aroma. Clear, pale orange body with a quick foamy white head. Light grainy fruit yeast flavour. Medium body. Average, a little rough. (6/3/6/3/11) 2.9 (@ brewpub, Kingston, ON)
Tap at the brewery. Very interesting. Aroma of leaves, and white wine. Taste is sweet, and smooth. Palate is oily, with a thin-to-medium body. Yellow, crisp, with no head.
Draught at the brewpub. Clear golden colour. Small white head. The flavour starts off strangely caramelly, turning bready. Faint grainy finish.
this reminded me of a macro ale. Cooked veggies, corn, and some sweet apples. really not very good.

On Tap- Clear light goldencolor with a nice head that fades quickly to good lacing. Mild clean aroma with a hint of citrus. Nice light taste of citrus, crisp and refreshing. Nice clean finish. Fairly light body with good carbonation, quite smooth. Nicely balanced and goes down easy. Much better than I expected.
On tap at the brewpub. The palest yellow of all the KBC brews I tried. Stinky, sweaty, sweet aroma. Sweet biscuity malt, thin, with a celery/grassy note in the finish. Not good.

Verre de 10 oz dégusté directement à la brasserie. Arôme: Légère odeur de céréales. Apparence: La couleur est dorée. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de céréales avec une pointe fruitée. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #2511)
On tap at the brewpub. Is this a lager or a cream ale? For my first Kingston Brewing Co. beer, I think I should’ve thought about it a little more...

On tap- Tapped a golden liquid with a one finger short lived head. Pale malts and grains fill the nose, and lead into grass and a similar apple aroma that I found in the cask offering. Taste is of sweet grains and pale malts with only the slightest hop coming through, giving way to some biscuit. Finishes a bit thin and seems to be more of a pale lager than the cream ales I have sampled in the past (eg. McAuslan Cream Ale). I’ve heard they are going to start selling this one through the LCBO somehow, and I have to wonder why.

2004 bottle shared by greg, the bottle was actually stained on the inside of this thing, pours a light clear brown with no head at all, the aroma has some dark fruit with a little bit of spice, kind of like a dark red wine or something, the flavor is flat and uncarbonated with some cardboard mixed in with the fruit, the abv comes through as well, well past it’s prime but still cool to open up!

2004 bottle cracked open in 2013. Way oxidiized, sherry port aroma. Somewhat watery, seems like the body has fallen out from under it. Raisin, prune, brown sugar. Past its prime, very deteriorated, but still drinkable.

Bottle from nuplastikk...thanks Greg! - Pours clear amber with a ring of white head. Wow is this oxidized. Smells like sherry and port, with some caramel notes. Taste is the same--pretty sickly sweet with some caramel and sherry and a long sweet malty finish. Slick and fairly thick with very little carbonation.

dark golden body with a creamy tan head. considerable lacing. smells sweet, bread, caramel and some citrus hops. tastes earthy. doughy. of caramel and butterscotch and slight bitter and citrus hops. definetely pear in their. dries your mouth out. more hoppy than I would expect. does this make sense for this style?

Orange, grapefruit, and black pepper in a light, yeasty aroma that never comes together. Hazy, orange-copper coloured body is topped by a low off white head that recedes to a light cover with plenty of lacing. Strong grapefruit character and some mild butterscotch in the fairly simple and sweet flavour. Moderate soft bubbled carbonation to the lightly astringent medium body. Bottle (trade, Aug-05) sampled with MartinT, Olivier_MTL, Rastacouere and Siroy. Thanks, Kinz!

Nicely lasting off-white head covers the hazy caramel pour. Slightly buttered (Ringwood?) nose is lightly yeasty, rather bready and mostly floral. The aromatics are generally low, leaving a globally sweet feel. Maltiness appears mostly faint in mouth, the grapefruity/orangey hops thus appearing pretty sharp. Growing astringency gets chalky after a few sips. Light-medium bodied, fine soft carbonation. I had never heard of the brewery and can’t say this one convinced me to particularly seek the rest of their lineup.

Any first impressions? -A veil of head covers the faded cardinal red. -Cranberry juiciness and subdued maple sweetness make for a timid lure. -Delicate fruitiness evokes mangoes, cranberries, and pomegranate, but all overall there isn’t enough malt sweetness or hop flavor to hook me. -Carbonation is active for a barley wine, attempting to hide the lack of maltiness. What if you dig deeper? -Barely any hops in the aroma, which is surprising. -Black pepper lurks behind the shy fruitiness. -Some resinous hop bitterness follows diluted grapefruit. -Lack of personality and of plain old tastiness will make this one disappear from memory real fast. Bottle; 2004 vintage.

Wiilliamsburg Brewing has gone out of business, but some examples of this beer might still remain in select markets. 2002 Vintage. Grand Illumination Ale pours to a beautiful, deep, murky, caramel color, with a slight tan head that fades, and a soft carbonation. The nose on the beer is complex and aromatic, with big aromas of sweet, caramel malt, toffee, pipe tobacco, some flowery hop aroma, and peppery waves of alcohol. The palate is lush and full on the tongue, with huge complex malty and fruity flavors. Sweet malt, caramel, toffee, butter scotch, and subtle hints of jammy fruit, coat the tongue, and slowly slide down the throat. Grand Illumination finishes with more of those complex malty and fruity flavors, then ends with a warming, sweet malty and peppery alcohol burn that lingers. Grand Illumination Ale is a very complex, very delicious, very warming, comforting barleywine, just perfect for the Christmas/Winter season. Again the brewery has closed, so this beer has become even more rare.

(12oz bottle, 2004) Lightly hazed copper body topped by smallish beige head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, chocolate, orange, cranberry. Taste is sweet, chocolate, caramel, fig, light grapefruit. Smooth, watery medium body, surprising in its capacity to hold and hide the alcohol as well as it does (I would never guess the ABV within 2 percent). Definitely on the malty side of the style.

Bottle: Deep copper, somewhat cloudy, with a thick beige head that fades to a small coating on top of the beer that lasts. Aroma: light apricots, figs, lightly tart apple/cranberries, citrus/floral hops, and a sweet cloying malt that comes through towards the finish. Taste: mild citrus hops, lemon grass, though this is not very hoppy or bitter for a barleywine, syrupy malt, caramel, light toffee, bitter grass, and a hint of cardboard. There’s a barely percievable hint of sourness in here that doesn’t taste like it belongs, perhaps it’s a bit infected but I can’t be sure.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear deep amber with an off white head that dissipates quickly and completely. Aroma has a good amount of earthy and musty grains with a hint of sweetness. Flavor has similar musty grain note with a bit of earthy grass and grains underlying.
on tap-pours a light tan head and copper color. Aroma is medium malt-peat/caramel, some sour. Taste is medium malt-roasty/peat, some sour.
(Draught) Pours a deep amber body with a small cream head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, roasted malt, and mustiness. Flavor of roasted malt, nuts, some cocoa, and caramel.

This was actually a good scotch ale. Aroma was sweet malt,with some caramel and toffee. Flavor is predominately caramel and malt, with a touch of chocolate in the end. An enjoyable session on a cool day.

Name: Irish Ale Date: February 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Norman Appearance: clear dark amber, wispy beige head, streaks of lace Aroma: light sweet malt aroma, sweet caramel with a touch of chocolate Flavor: sweet caramel malt flavor, touch of butterscotch adds more sweetness, light chocolate Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

(Tap) Pours a murky brown color with a nice tan head. Smooth, earthy aroma. Peat and some smoke in the taste, with a medium palate. Some oak in the flavor as well. A pretty complex beer by Coach’s standards. It is one of the better offerings here.
Color is dark brown with minimal head. Tastes like a dry brown ale with some hints of whisky and some peat smoke. I really enjoy this beer.

On tap at the Edmond location. Poured dark brown with a thin head. Everything in this beer is muted and thin. Just left me wanting something to hang on to about it. Really seemed more Scotch than Irish style wise, but the malt was not as dominant.

(On tap) Clear, warm mahogany with a reddish tint. No head to speak of. Vaguely tart, malty nose. Medium body with accents of roasted malt and then - unfortunately again - some moldy, fusty notes before a short, dry finish sets in. Had this in spring, so not really a winter special anymore. 200306

Draught-OKC Bricktown. Pours brown with a tiny frothy tan head. Aroma is light chocolate roasted malt (smoky) and trace yeast. Smoked malt, medium sweetness, low bitterness and no acidity, caramel malt body. Medium bodied and creamy palate.
(cleaning out my beer bottle collection as pictured in my profile and utilizing ratebeer.com) As I recall, this was a nice sweet bock with hints of malt.

Name: Mohren Bock Date: 04/25/2001 Mode: Bottle Source: Chevy Chase, DC dark amber, thin white head, strong sweet malt aroma with a hint of floral hops, rich malt flavor, Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Clear red-brown with creamy medium-beige head. Aroma is mildly sweet, floral, and lightly caramel. Taste is malty caramel. Watery palate.

In a blind taste, I would never be able to distinguish this from Aass Bock. Delicious middle-of-the-road Bock, with a rather thin body. The malt is lovely: rustic, woody, in the tradition of St. Georgenbrau and Mahr's kellerbiers.

Dark yellow appearance. Creamy with a caramelly sweetness. A surprising amount of hops. Tried this at the Mortensen house in Grasten, DE with Anne in 2008. Bought at one of the beer stores across the German border.
Dark red color with small head. Malty aroma. Sweet malty taste with some bitterness.
Bottle @ Home. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, grassy hops. Taste is malt caramel, brown sugar, some light grassy hops. Medium body, lively carbonation. 070409
October 2005. 0,33l Bottle. Golden colour with white head. Malty aroma with moderate bitterness. A little sweet.
Bottle. Pours a clear bronze colored beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is bitter and sweetness with notes of syrup. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweet. Overall a nice beer.
Brown with a decent head. Malty aroma with further notes of corn and hay. The flavour is mostly sweet (cane sugar and caramel). Approved.
Aarhus, DK. Bottled. High carbonation and dominated by caramel - with the characteristic stinging palate from added sugars
Brown colour with small head. Caramel in nose. Bread, malt and some bitterness in taste. Could be worse.

Muddy brown color with a small, creamy head. Sweet, earthy aroma with a hint of lemon. Earthy, musty caramel malt flavor with a slight tingle to the finish. Light to medium bodied with a short, bitter finish. Basically a below average beer.
33 cl bottle. Amber/brown color. Beige, disappering head. Caramell and hints of fruit. Ok bitterness.
04 03 2003. Пляшка. Не можу зараз чітко описати та був непоганий балтійський портер
Had this in Kyiv at an outside beer stand. The color is a very dark brown. Has a very sweet aroma and taste with some honey character. The taste also reminded me of whole wheat bread.
Beatiful brown colour. Hints of juniper berry both in aroma and flavour. A full palate with pleasant sweetness.
Brown color. Aroma of sweet licorice. Full flavor of licorice, burnt sugar and notes of juniper berry. Sweet in a favorable way. Fine one.
Full-bodied dark ruby bottom-fermented porter with creamy head and flavors of chocolate, cherry and raisins. Nice winter beer.

Butelka 0,5 litra, zakupiona w Tesco w Karwinie. Barwa jasno-złota, klarowna. Średnia, biała piana, która szybko opada, zostawiając sporo śladów na szkle. Aromat słaby, odrobina słodu i chmielu. W smaku słodkawe, wodniste, trochę pustawe, ze średnią, długą goryczką.
Standardowy czeski lager tylko trochę wypruty z charakteru by zrobić go bardziej masowym. Do wypicia.
Bottle. Low but lasting fluffy white head. Clear yellow golden body. Mild straw grass aroma and flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short finish.
0.5 l bottle. Pours clear golden with minimal head. A: slightly malty T: thin body, flat, mild bitterness, super low maltiness, watery.

getrunken Anfang 2018 Unter dem Namen "Staropramen Déčko " ist dieses Bier noch erhältlich. Das rührt davon, dass "kleines D", bzw wörtlich übersetzt "D-chen" auf Tschechisch eben "Déčko " bedeutet. Das D steht für Dry und bezeichnet ein kalorien-reduziertes Bier. Es schmeckt dementsprechend wässrig und langweilig. Lieber weniger Biertrinken um Kalorien zu sparen anstatt dieses Getränk.

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.
Fles 50cl in Benesov. Grassig, bitters, wat waterig, zoetje. (7-2014).-----.
Prakticky tady přidávám tento komentář, jen aby tady něco bylo, protože zpětně dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.
Trockener, wenig getreidiger Antrunk. Geringfügig herb, wässrig, kaum aromatisch. Keine Würzigkeit, kein Nachgeschmack. Nja... 7/8/7/7/9/7
50cl bottle. A clear pale golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting white head. Aroma of straw, mild flowers, pale malt. Taste of mild grainy malt, straw, watery boy, mild bitter hops...

*Schön malzig-fisches, leicht säuerlich-interessantes Bier. Sehr süffig, etwas besser als das Jubiläums-Pilsner, da nicht so malzig. Eine leichte Herbe ist spürbar, rund, interessant weich-malzig mit leichter malziger Säuerlichkeit im Nachgeschmack. Spannend.

Golden body, white head. Aroma has wet bready malt, some metal, grassy hops. Flavour has paper, toast, harsh grains, metally notes, noticeable bitterness. Smooth palate, but bit metally. 3 time metal in one rating. Great!
Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma is malt, frass and fruity notes. Flavour is malt, grass, fruity notes, light caramel and light pine.
Pours a clear and yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is malt, yeast and fruit. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness with notes of bitterness. Overall an average beer.
Bottle @ Early Winter Tasting, Odense, 2011. Pours clear pale yellow with a off white head. Sulphur and grain. Very dry and sharp / unrefined.
Golden with a small white head. Grainy aroma with some hay and cardboard. Dry grainy flavour with herbal hops and a nice, bitter finish
Bottled 330ml. -from Wein Kultur, Berlin. Light hazy yellow coloured, small white head, bready grainy nose. Sweetish malty, quite bready and grainy with light stale acidic bitter finish. Not good.

Wein Kultur, Berlin. Áttetsző, sápadt szalmasárga színű pilzeni, mely egészen méretes, ám már nem annyira kitartó, kissé krémes laza fehér habot fejleszt. Illata gyengén gyümölcsösen komlós, enyhén papíros. Íze nem éppen a legjobb, elég vizes és jellegtelen: kevés maláta, füves komló és fémes lecsengés, malátás-fémes utóíz. Azért annyira nem rossz ez, de egy bőven elég volt belőle.

Bottle. Metallic malt aroma, pale honey colour with a thin head. Flavour is sickly cloudy malt. Not nice Earlier Rating: 11/15/2010 Total Score: 2.3 Draught. Pale gold with a thin head. Bitter acidic aroma. Bitter taste with some notes of lemon. Thin feel with an ok aftertaste
Courtesy of ogivlado, thanks! Small white head, golden. Very light bready yeasty nose. Crappy grainy taste, apple compote. Bearable but crap.

(Bottle 50 cl) Fully golden beer with a nice and creamy head. Quite full, sweet and delicious. Brewed on oats-malt, which is quite unusual. The brewery claims that the oats should have an aphrodisiac effect!.. Hmm.. 020703
No special aroma, light fruity/fresh taste (oatmalt). Well balanced, stressed bitterness.

Is pretty close to a Dortmunder or Helles although it is sligthtly more bitter than a typical member of theese styles and there is a slight honeyish sweet note which I suspect comes from the oat. Other than that a pretty well balanced, fullbodied, smooth and easy drinkable beer- but all in all not overly exiting.
Cask at The Vine; clear copper pour with a creamy off white head, aroma has sweet caramel and light fruit, taste has sweet caramel, light bitterness, light spice and toffee apple.
Gravity cask at Dudley beer festival. Pours orange with a medium head. Aroma is caramel, alcohol and toast. Taste has caramel and Christmas spice to start and toast on the finish.

Sampled 24th November hand pulled at The Swan Chaddesley Corbett.This is a Christmas seasonal offering from this brewery and is brewed differently every year so this is the 2012 version.First off,this beer is done no justice at all in the bottle(though it can be good).On the hand pull this beer is a delight.It is generally brewed once though in recent years 2 or even 3 brews have been done if capacity permits and even these can differ in flavour(and strength).This one,or was it 4!,well,,got to get it when its there! was mid brown in colour and similar to last year.(2009 it was a lighter golden colour).It sports a creamy off white head which stays on the glass.Aroma is of malt with some fruitiness and also alcohol featuring this year for some reason or other as this one isnt as strong as last years.Anyone fortunate enough to be able to drink the draught form will know what i mean when i say beware,the 6.3% is a very conservative rating!!The malt taste remains throughout as does the fruity background.The hops are there too and the alcohols there for sure.Great tasting beer.

Brown 500ml bottle, best before the end of June 2011, drank and reviewed on a snowy afternoon, 30th Nov 2010. Poured into a ’Batemans’ badged UK pint sleeve. Good amber body with a creamy, light tan coloured head of foam. The head left some good lacing as the beer level dropped. Aroma reminded me of sultanas and raisins, so a Rum hint within the smell, along with a heavy wiff of yeasts and alcohol. The taste is sharp and crisp, with the currents already mentioned coming through in the aftertaste. The alcohol is just about held in check, but not quite. A tinge of cinnamon also appears as the initial flavours fade in the mouth. In other words a Winter Warmer sort of beer. Very drinkable and a good warming brew, it fortified me for the walk into town through the cold and falling snow.

Bottle @ pre-GBBF shindig, August 2009 as Special Strong Ale. I like Bathams as a brewery. They are ultra traditional and have a small chain of pubs in the Midlands. Nothing much has changed at Bathams for decades, beer range included. Unfortunately, the bottled version of this beer didn’t work too well for me. Copper colour. Odd musty notes & a little cardboardy. Not really a strong ale. Not horrible but not too appealing either. Probably an old bottle but there was no BBE date so it is hard to know. Must try to find this one from cask some time.

Bottle 330ml. @ Chriso’s pre GBBF Shindig ’09. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, oxidide malt, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090801]
Bottle at Chriso pre-GBBF tasting 09. Cloudy gold colour with thin white head. Musty on the aroma. Not good. In fact it was poor.
Slightly hazy amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel and dried fruit. Sweet and fruity flavour
Bottle at Chris-o’s Pre GBBF tasting and 2009 ... amber ... sweet melon watter hop ... big toffeee ... fruity hop ... little spic.

A Mes rate: bottle at the ever brilliant Chris O’s Pre GBBF Extravaganza. Russet colour, just about holding on to an off white film. Sweet and puddingy. Lots of spice, Something vaguely meadish about it. Faint peppery bitter finish with more pudding. Uneventful and not great. It did however give me the opportunity to use the words puddingy and meadish in my notes. :) WIN!

Bottle from Edeka in Alfeld - clear golden color, white head. a very thin beer with low carbonation. medium sweetness. first impression is very weak, but it does have some interesting floral hoppy notes and some malty dough in the background. I don't know what to think of this... a good Pale Lager.

Crystal clear golden color with frothy white head. Aroma has clean malt, light bready notes and some woody hops in the background. Taste is clean, malty at first but gets more earthy and bitter on the finish, really well balanced. Medium body and carbonation, feels really crisp. One of my favorites readily available lagers.

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.
bottle @ supermarket (ingolstadt) yellow colour, normal body, average carbonated, white head, malty, hoppy, lightly bitter, easy to drink
Pours yellow with a small head. Fruity aroma with malt and caramel. Tastes malty with fruit and grass notes, nice. Light body

caramel, bread, dough, barnyard, leaves, alcohol, cooked vegetables, soy sauce, skunky, cough drop, banana, bubblegum, basement aromas, butterscotch, licorice, woody, rotten eggs, cooked vegetables, clove, raisin,
Farbe: klar gold Schaum: fein gut Nase: kaum. Bisschen Gerste. Geschmack: feinperling, fast schaumig, bitter. Abgang bis Nachgeschmack Gerste. Sonst eigentlich nichts. OK.

Bottle from a supermarket near Koln, Germany. The beer is yellow colored with a large and stable white foam, carbonation is good. The aroma is malty, with light caramel, hay, grass, yeast, citrus and a little spices. The taste is light medium sweet and starts malty and goes to some bitterness/fruitiness, floral and grassy notes and with a hint of spices. The finish is light bitter and further a little watery.

Pours clear golden with medium white head. Aroma is malty, vegetables, some cardboard, light sweetness, dust. Taste is dusty, cardboard, dry, malts, some light notes of vegetables, potatoes, sweetness. Drinkable beer!
Bottle from getränktmakt in Regensburg. Big lasting white head. Clear and light sparkling yellow color beer. Malty with a fresh citrus touch. Malty taste and medium bitterness.

Bomber; thanks Alex!! Rosy brown with thin, soapy white head; syrupy and sweet with raw grainy candy malts; nose is rich and sugary and body is mostly flat and thin; remarkable tasty for the age IMO as it drinks strong, smooth and sugary sweet; very nice; thanks brah
