22. Thanks, Riverside! Wow, what an unexpected delight to see emerge from the Bottleworks cellars.Crystal clear rubied amber. Nice loose creamy tan film with a little bit of body to it. Enormous orangey zesty nose, just a ton of life to the aromatics. Tangy caramel there as well. Creamy medium still body. Beautifully aged candied fruit hop combined with a slightly tanied malt base...what a beautiful pairing. Hops still show some fruit skin bitterness but none of that acetic lingering resin. So the sweetnesses really get a chance to work together, but in a subdued state so that neither is overpowering. Great, great beer after 6 years of mellowing.

22oz bottle that I picked up at the 10th anniversary release at Bottleworks last week. So this one has intrigued me for sometime and when I saw it on the shelf, I had to grab it. Holding the bottle up to the light, you can see a good amount of ’debris’ in the bottom from what used to be a whole hop that was placed in the bottle when it was bottled. Reading about others having gushers, I get this one colder than I normally would have and open it up over the sink ready to act fast...but this one opened with a slight hiss and absolutely tame. Pours a cloudy orange light mahogany color with zero head. I am wondering if this bottle may be bad. I raise this glass to my nose and immediately greeted by malty biscuit notes and hints of hop resin! I take a sip with a bit of trepidation. Pleasantly I am greeted with some light carbonation. Taste is semi sweet bready malt with some notes of orange zest and bittering hops on the back end. As this warms, the 9.6 does show up a little bit. Amazing how well this beer has held up and how it can still have such hop presence being 6 years old. Wish I would have gotten to try this one when it was fresh just to know how much it has really changed, but super impressed with how this beer tastes right now. Glad I picked this one up and it was a nice way to end my day.

22 oz. bomber, and man, people aren’t kidding - this one sprayed all over. I’m really wishing I’d opened it over a bowl and saved all I lost - it ended up with somewhere around 14 oz left. One other thing - there isn’t a hop cone in the bottle. There are five or six hop cones in the bottle. Trevor (at Bottleworks) held it up to a light for me, and there was a good two centimeters of sediment at the bottom. Insane. Anyhow, once it calms down a bit, it pours a very murky orange amber with a small head. The nose hits you with a ton of hops, and an equally staggering malt contingent - the caramelly, syrupy malts that remind you of cap’n crunch when they’re mixed with stale hops. Very bitter aftertaste. Huge, huge flavor. Man, would I have loved to try this fresh. Quite an experience - this one really put a smile on my face, for the novelty if nothing else.

This is a crazy bottle. Noted with a ""DH"" on the bottle cap. I’m guessing Dry Hopped. There is an entire hop cone in the bottle! The bottle gushed upon opening, but I salvaged what I could. This is an insanely hopped beer. The concept is pretty simple, with the entire hop cone in the bottle. But it seems nobody has thought or done this since. This bottle has aged a bit in the fridge and stll is as hoppy as hell. Absolutely amazing. I’m still stunned at the flavor and the concept.

22 oz gushing bottle into a 2 oz Snifter glass. We popped this one as a little inventory celebration. Upon uncapping this brew literally sprays EVERYWHERE! Quickly pouring it into the snifter reveals a gorgeous deep orange hazed color with golden notes when held up to light as you see hop chunks floating around in the brew. A very foamy white head sits up top and retains throughout the experience. A blast of Northwestern hops of all sorts comes through in the aroma: citrus, resin, pine, and more. It’s balanced with a light sweet malt characteristic as well. The flavor starts in with the sweet malt (as it should) and immediately is overtaken by all sorts of floral and citrusy hop madness. Very in your face, and a very resiny feel on the palate (along with chewing hop chunks, or catching them and spitting them out). A bit of carmalized malt is present throughout the body, but this one is straight hopped up to the core!! A beautiful bitter finish ends this guy with all sorts of hop flavors running over your palate. I never had this fresh, but I think it’s aged fantastically!!!

Bottle Shared at the "Pitonka mini RB fest" Thanks Larry Hazy medium amber solor with a gusher of a head. Lots of deep hops in the aroma and flavor. Strong but not sharp. Full malt flaros as well. Ballances and big.

Thanks to Pitonka for sharing this one. Dry hopped bottle! Huge gushing beer! Heavy orange color, small white head. Aroma is huge resinous hops, citrus pine, the whole 9 yards. Flavor is more huge hop kicks, decent malt back to it. I would of loved to have this fresh.

Bottle (dry hopped): Cloudy dark straw, moderate sudsy white head, loads of hop petals floating about, spotty lacing.   Huge, yet soft hop aroma.   Floral, but not in the bitter sense.   Moderate bitterness, floral, caramel, bloody tasty.   Strong hop flavor at the finish, slight heat, but definitely easier than it was in March of 2003.   Big body, moderate mouthfeel.   Tangy finish, slight citrus, sweet, and nothing like the brash example it was earlier.   Mellowed out very nicely.   Simply enjoyable! &nbsp Glad I got this as a freebie from Kevin at Bottleworks.

Dry hopped bottle tasted at Pitonka’s tastingDry hops in the bottle and a gusher! Winner! Light dirty hazy amber, nice head, light lacing. Nose of dusty old hops yet it’s huge and oaky, the opposite of citrus and grassy. The flavor is nice and balanced, plenty of hops and maltiness. Very good (aged) IPA!

Cask at the Chelmsford Summer Beer & Cider Festival, Essex. Pours clear pale gold with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of caramel, hop, biscuit and fruit. Medium to heavy sweetness, light bitterness. Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation.

First tasted this in the Anchorage Hotel, Troon in July 1991. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear straw in colour with a thin white head. Zesty grassy notes present in the short aroma. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a slight digestive biscuit note with hints of gooseberry fruit and kiwi. Strong floral notes of hop resins flood the long aftertaste with pine resin evident. Finish is bitter sweet with hops still present in the mouth. An ok session bitter but not as complex as similair strength bitters out there.
Cask at GBBF 2010. A dark golden beer with a thin yellowish head. The aroma has notes of citrusy fruits, malt, and hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and hops. I find it boring.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 10, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium orange yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is light moderate malty, toasted, malt, light apple, light hoppy, chamomile tea. Flavor is moderate sweet and light to light moderate bitter with a average to long duration, apple tea. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20100803]
Cask@GBBF2010. Yellowish golden colour, small off-white head. Aroma is honey, nectar, fruits, grass and some earth. Flavour is fruits, wood, grass and some mild floral hoppyness.
From cask. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is roasted malty and slight breadish. Mild fruity and vague citrusy. Bitter and slight malty into the finish. Dry finish.
Handpulled cask at the Black Lion in Lynsted, Kent. Gold with white head. Light bodied ale with a malt accent. Drinks like a mild. OK.

Cask at the Trafalgar with Mes, 25th April 2008. Orangey gold in colour and served in great condition, but it was downhill from then on. Slight aroma of creamy vanilla and tastes of nothing much. Average weight and utterly bland and forgettable. A waste of money.

A Mes rate: Gravicask at the Trafalgar. Slightly hazy pale gold with a thin white head. Bland aroma of straw and some light chlorine. Flavour is less offensive but very bland. Pale wheat and straw with a light sourness at the back of the palate and some corn in the finish.

Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. ’Light’ being the operative word... Gold with a small white head. Very little aroma. The taste is also rather thin. A slight, not unpleasant biscuity malt flavour is not enough to tempt one into spending a full session with this brew.

Moderate foaming which is renewed from the bottom of a relatively high carbonation. Regularly malty flavor featureless carries the flavor go in an equally anonymous hoppy bitterness, although just manages to bring the beer in reasonable balance. Easy to drink and thirst-quenching has been the only real positive to highlight.

Tap. Light Clear golden, small white head. Hay, grain, a whiff of grass. Flavor is light sweet brewmash, grass and a light flowery, very light flowery finish. Watery texture. Tiny body. Bland but quite drinkable compared to most macro low alc’s.

Bottle @ Home. Pours light golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, grain, straw. Taste is malt, grain, grassy hops. Thin watery body, lively carbonation. Refreshing, and pretty good for a low alchohol beer. 081011
Bottle 33 cl. Yellow pour with a fair white head. The aroma is best but a bit hop sensation too. The taste is sweetmalt, hints of grain and a comfortable hoppy finish
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a medium to small white head. The aroma is grain, cereal and light hops. The flavour is very thin with notes of metal, light malt and cereal. Overcarbonated.
Bottle. Golden clear. More than expected malty aromas. Aqua taste and finish. Dry. Not bad for a low alcoholic beer.
Bottle, pours golden with small white head, aroma is corn, fresh and malty... flavor - corn,malt... a bit thin but ok low alcohol beer....
Clear golden without head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 230611

Can from the grocery store in Reykjavik. Pours a clear, pale gold body with a moderately sized, fizzy head. Dissipating. Aroma is dominated by floral and herbal hops. Little to no malt aroma. Very pleasant Saaz-ish hop character. Sweet, lightly bready pils malt comes through first in the flavor - somewhat candyish. Cut with some of the hops, but they play a lesser role than in the nose. Light, crisp body with bubbly carbonation. Dry, lightly bitter finish is surprisingly clean. Overall a pleasant, clean summer beer that hit the spot after a busy day. If the flavor had matched the aroma in its balance the beer would be much better.

A pale yellow-golden beer with an average white head on top. Not very aromatic; some metal notes and faint dusty hops. Very light malt body. Fairly dry with a tight lemony acidity. Barely any hops to speak of. Skinny body. Diluted. Notes of lemony fruitiness in the finish.

750ml bottle @ Matt’s. Pours a clear light golden colour with a tiny white head. Nose is champagne and sour apples. Flavour has a moderate sweetness and subtle sourness from the apples. Decent but I preferred the Rosé.

Corked bottle Very pale color, fizzy, no head. Mild aroma, but the flavor is delicate, nice, with very light residual sweetness. In France there are ciders with similar ABV but more character. Elegant, light though.

750mL bottle, pours a mostly clear blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out dry apple skins and some champagney notes. Flavour brings out light sweetness from the apples, with some champagne character and a little leather. Not as complex as the Rose version, but this works pretty well. Moderate-to-heavy carbonation. Good, but nothing special.

Light green. No head. The aroma isn’t much. Sweet, lightly fruity, maybe a bit funky as well. Bit fizzy. So for me, maybe not the greatest balance but it does have more character than the average cider of this type, with a bit more than the usual acidity in the finish.

A very light blonde cider with aroma of sweet apple jam, light mineral notes, light acidity, pleasant. In mouth, a nice sweet bubble apple juice with light mineral notes, light acidity, pleasant. Mondial des Cidres 2017.

Bouteille claire de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée lors d’une dégustation entre amis. Arôme: Odeur de pommes mûres. Apparence: La couleur est paille avec une très faible densité de bulle. Saveur: Goût de pommes légèrement sucrées. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement sucré. (Rating #7261)

750ml bottle. Crystal clear pale blonde, effervescent bubbles and a thin ring of white foam. Flavors are green apple flesh/skin and apple candy with floral notes. Light body, lively carbonation, slick texture. Dry tangy finish.
Bottle - Light fresh green apple. Clear gold with a ton of bubbles. Lots of green apple with a light sweet finish. Very sweet and refreshing.

Superbe cidre de début de journée, bien parfumé par les pommes et légèrement acidulé pour une prise en bouche des plus intéressantes. Belles bulles naturelles et finale rafraîchissante. J’aime également les notes de vin blanc et de fleurs qui nuancent le tout agréablement.

Bottle (750 ml). Split 4-ways. Clear white-ish golden with a foamy quickly vanishing white head. Aroma is of fresh McIntosh apples along sugary - not artifical - notes and mild grassy presence. Taste is mildly acidic with again fresh McIntosh apples flesh and mild grassy notes. Light body, but never watery. Big persistent bubbles, never too agressive, but giving a nice ample mouthfeel. Apple flesh finish. I was impressed by how present the apple is in this one which is not often the case with low abv cider. This is quite tasty and extremely easy to drink. Good job on the mouthfeel as well, I think there’s not another cidery doing a better job than Du Minot with "bubbles" in Québec. The free 1 oz sample you can get at the cidery won’t give justice to this one, it’s worth buying a bottle to give it a proper try.

No head and a fairly dark reddish brown color. The aroma was not very strong, but it did have great malty sweet tones to it along with some caramel. The flavor was full and rounded...some alcohol...definite toffee and caramel...sweet malty goodness.
Tap. Medium golden color with an off-white head. Some hops in the aroma and flavor with some sweet malts.

Medium gold color, hazy. Small head. Aroma is floral hops and malts. A medium bodied, unfiltered Pale Ale. Unfiltered and very dry hopped. Malts are slightly sweet and nutty. Hops are slightly floral and rater dry. Well balanced. A nice subtle beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Bottle shared by Bhensenb. Pours a purple cola color with a light biege head. Aroma is sour and the flavor is slightly sour with a hint of raisins.

2002 bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours dark brown with a delicious plum and chocolate aroma and a thin tan head. There is a slightly sour dark fruit flavor that has mellowed over the years, blending well with the spices and candi sugar. A very pleasant drink.

Bomber from Schultsc. Thanks for the great trade for this bottle filled in 2002!!! Pours very dark brown with a fizzy transient light tan head. Aroma is like mildly sour cola with raisin. Med body. Pretty smooth. Light heat. Dark malt, chocolate and raisin flavors. It is amazing how this has aged. It seems fresh!

Draught at brewpub. This is the 10th rating for this brew, so I get to put it on the map. Sweet, unique aroma. Indicates dessert beer qualities. Clear amber body with a white head and excellent lace. Allspice notes in the palate. It’s higher strength is evident. Coriander also detectable. Unique and excellent brew.

Draft. Clear copper color with a frothy ivory head. Spicy, phenolic nose with some warm malt and banana notes- this came as a surprise since when I ordered it the bartender told me it was an American Strong Ale. Sweet and somewhat hot. Bready malt flavors with some spiciness. Dry and musty. Slight astringency. Nice.
Draft. Amber beer with an off-white head. Yeasty, sumemr fruit aroma. Fruity (summer), yeast, spice flavor with slight bubblegum. Medium body. Lingering yeast, fruit, and earthiness.

On tap @ O’Brien’s. Pours clear gold with infused copper hues and expansive off white head. The aroma is light with sweetness, mild spices and a hint of tartness. The taste is sweet up front and moves more fruity with green apples and cantaloupe (just under ripe). There’s also a consistent lime then slight lemon tartness throughout.

On tap@ O’Brien’s: Deep amber color with a medium bright white head. Flavor starts rich with tropical fruit and a touch of honey followed by a spicy hop bitterness and a light, dry citrus rind finish . Medium-full body is creamy with moderate carbonation.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear light orange color. Head was one finger high and off white. Aroma was not unlike a wit, actually. Yeasty bread dough, coriander, and orange. Sweet and effervescent on the tongue with a light bitter citrus peel note accented by vanilla, coriander, and clove. Reminded me of a strong with beer.
Clear golden amber with fizzy white head. Malty aroma. Smooth silky mouth feel. Good bitter bite with a hoppy perfume to the finish.

Som ölkännare vill jag ge detta öl högsta betyg. Len smak och trots styrkan så slår alkoholen definitivt inte igenom. Fulländat öl som passar såväl till vardags som till fest. Skall njutas på flaska så klart. Gillar man inte detta öl så vet man inte vad öl är. Tummen upp! Skål alla ölkännare 👍🍺 🙂
Can from some Friends. Sweet malty taste and aroma. A medium hop taste and Body.
Tasted and smelled to much aluminum. Not sure if something was up with this batch. Nice color and foam, but that's about it.

Väldigt god. Det är ingen spritsmak i den här ölen. Jag drack den här på nyår och blev förvånad över att den var så god. Mariestad är ju kända för att göra god öl. Åker jag till Tyskland någon gång så kommer jag köpa flera plattor av den här :)
Bottle. Sweet sugary malt nose. Golden, offwhite thick foam. Medium body, sweet malt, all right grassy hop counterpoint. Sticky sugary finish.
Flaska från SB. Klar, gyllengul kulör med vit skumkrona. Doft och smak av bröd, ljus knäck, lite peppar och trä. Spritig och söt munkänsla.

Can from my dear sister, thank you! I was always wondering on purpose of these beers. Why would anyone want to brew this? It tastes not so good. High voltage? Meh, I choose quality spirits instead. Why so? Like really...
0,5 boks fra Systembolaget Strømstad, delt med Ketil feb-18: klar gylden med ok skum. Mild, floral duft og smak med litt citrus. God munnfølelse og søtlig ettersmak.

Aroma of caranel, malt, grains and a hint of fruits. Pale golden with a white head. Medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium body with a average carbonation. Overall an OK strong Lager, but rather boring.
Can from Systembolaget. Color is golden and clear with a medium white head. Aroma is malt and hops an easy aftertaste of hops. Nice and sweet a little watery ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
(nez et bouche qui font poser la question : est-ce une bière ? ont-ils voulu la noircir avec de la vase et du café ? Jesus !)
Une brune/ambrée plutôt bien faite, assez classique, sur le caramel. Finale avec une légère amertume. Achetée sur UnePetiteMousse.com
Bottle from Une Petite Mousse.fr. Dark brown color, off white head. Malts, roast, straw, caramel, yeast. Ok

Comme sa soeur L’Orge, très bonne attaque, caramelisée, agréable et belle effervescence mais aucune longueur. Très aqueuse pour son style et son degré d’alcool. Dommage. Loin d’être mauvaise mais reste frustrante et trop légère par rapport à l’Orge...

Ambar oscura miel. Aroma ligeramente dulzón y a ciruelas. Que es el sabor predominante, en una cerveza bastante aguada, con algo de café y bastante de miel. Esconde bien el mucho alcohol que tiene. No destaca especialmente por nada.
Bottle sample at a tasting a at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks Vova. Pours an hazy orange to brown with a beige head, aroma of caramel, honey, cookies, flavor of caramel, honey and cookies, light bodied.

Bottle sample at a tasting a at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks Vova. Deep reddish amber with a beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel and fruitiness. Sweet flavor, sugary, caramelly, slightly toasty, with some fruitiness. Medium-bodied.
Bottle at home. Amber Brown color. Medium body and medium carbonation. Sweety and malty aroma. Taste of alcohol. Overall ok.

Bottle. Cloudy red-brown colour. Light brown head. Fruity aroma with a bit of alcohol. A bit metallic in the beginning, but this is replaced with a maltiness with hints of caramel and hazlenut as it warms. The flavour is malty and fruity. A bit metallic and sour. Not a lot of body. Gives a warm feeling.
Cloudy red-amber color. Nice nose of malt, wood, hop. The flavor is nothing special, just some sourness.

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega kirjutan igale õllele selle sama teksti. Hindamiseks teen vaid ticki.
Can: Golden, white creamy foam; sweetish grainy nose with mushroomy spots; mild sweetish-bitter flavour, thinnish MF; slightly lingering metallic-bitter finish. Meh...

I have bought this can, after visiting one flat at Carrouge, at the landi. I drank it right after, waiting the bus to Lausanne. In my point of view, it is a drinkable lager, but you don't have expect nothing exciting about this beer. The color is gold, transparent, average carbonation, thin and white foam. The taste is watery, some malt, some hop, but the sensation is in the mouth boring, the aromas are not so generous.
0.33l bottle. pours clear golden with a medium white head and a nice lacing. sweet corn in the nose, flavour of cardboard, grains, and grass. lively carbonation. boring.
Drink cold (8°C) Eye: pours a copper colour with a small fast dissipating head. Nose: honey and hops Mouth: honey, hops, malts, cider, a bit metallic. Palate: bread, hops. Overall: good beer.
Cheap beer, so is the taste. The kind of stuff you want to drink rather to get drunk than for the pleasure of the taste. A bland lager that’s probably cause a headache tomorrow morning.

Golden colored with medium sized white head. Grassy, slightly metallic aroma with sweet fruits and lemon. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is also on sweet side with same grass as well. Aftertaste has peachy-lemony tone.

this is the rating of farmer(landi)4.5 vol% (not the 4.8) pale color not much foam not much smell and taste but doesnt have as much that old damp bread hint that the the 4.8 has in smell and taste but its deadly boring why have they a 4.5 and a 4.8 with the same name and not much difference? Earlier Rating: 1/10/2008 Total Score: 1.4 pale color allmoust no head smells of old damp bread and perhaps very hidden hops tasts of malt hidden hops with old damp bread aftertaste a hint of hops tasts a little bit better than it smells but not specially good something more is strange, and that is the fact,that the farmer 4,8 on the picture is in a can i bought mine in little bottles,was a multipac (aarg!!) but i bought a canned too, but this was 4,5!! so i underline that this rating is the 4,8 and make a new entry for the 4.5
clear bright golden colour with few foam, hay and paperboard in the nose, tart and sweet, medium-bodied, dry and insignificant finish
Pale color; very light aroma and flavor, boring beer brewed for the Landi markets.

From the memory. Draft. Golden colour, standard lager head. Nose of grains, straw, some yeast. Light body. Light sweet grainy taste with yeasty notes. Low bitterness. Nothing to talk about really still it was somehow nice sitting & drinking this back in ... Nevermind

Сармат Світле , Sarmat Bright, 4,4%abv, 11’, 0,5L bottle bought in a supermarket in Kremenchuk, Ukraine. Production date 24 квітня April 2013. Enjoyed at Day of Kremenchuk, the 70 year anniversary for liberation of the city. Scents strong malty dunst from brewery. Falling white head. Yellow golden bubbly body. Taste is malty, grains, carbonation, metal, very little messages from hops. The feel is somewhat carbonated, a little watery. Aftertaste; mild with some hops, malts, cardboard, grains. Overall a typical malty east block lager.
Обычный такой лагер.
Clear yellow color . Aroma of malt and maybe some yeast. Taste very light without aftertaste. Eurolager... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
500ml bottle from a supermarket in Odessa. Fast diminishing head. Straw coloured body. Mild citric aroma. Lightly sweet fruity taste. Clean and foamy mouthfeel. Rather dull on the whole (15.07.2009).
Bottled. Golden colour. Papery fruity aroma. Yeasty and rather sweet with clean mouthfeel. Lightly hopped, low bitterness.
Dark golden and a nice head. Yeasty and hoppy aroma. Weissbier-like, rather dry palate.
Golden color. Yeasty hoppy aroma with a slight weissbier feel. Some band aid flavor, still not so bad taste.
The flagship of Sarmat brewery turned to be a fairly standard eurolager, easy drinkable and unexciting. Too thin.

0,5L bottle, bought at supermarket in Ukraine, enjoyed with new friends in Nikopol UA. Abv 4,4 to 4,6, and 11’. Printed brewed at Efes Ukraine Donetsk. Scents hoppy, grassy, fresh and fruity. Almost no head, but normal straw golden body. Taste of mild hops, sweet malts, smooth mouthfeel and only slightly watery. Aftertaste sweet rye bread. Overall a decent lager beer, almost to premium lager.
Не худший вариант из Жигулей, но и явно не лучший.
Next parody to the USSR brend .Golden color , very small head. Sweet aroma and unintelligible taste. European lager? Maybe. But not Zhigulivske ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Actually doesn’t say "Sarmat" on the label but is the Zhigulyoskoye from the SAB Miller brewery in Donetsk. Dull gold. The aroma is mostly grainy with a light hint of apple. The taste is fairly bland, maybe lightly appley, and with little of anything interesting. Mostly just boring.
Plastic lire bottle. Golden color, no head. Urine-like aroma with some apple. Warery with some aaple and grainy notes. No specific aftertaste. Sad beer.
Bottled. Pale golden, small siry head. Fruity nose. Sweet and dense, light bodied.Notes of sulphur, butter and dried plums. Salty finish.
A sweet flavour with some hop in it. Acceptable bitterness. Not that interesting really.
Golden. Slight hens-food aroma. Malty hens-food feel in the flavor. Not that fine really....
Pale lager with famous post-Soviet name. Unfortunately the taste differs quite a lot year by year: from disgusting sweet and floral to fairly dry and hoppy.
Dark golden color, cat food, touch of lemon, a malty mouth and a dry finish. Boring.

A clear gold color, a bit deeper gold than most Japanese macro's. Medium sized white head. Light malty aroma, little trace of hops, very thin feel, not much carbonation, sweet.....very sweet, like sugar water. Koedo, in my book, you've struck out.
Давно не видел в продаже, но с десяток лет назад было одним из лучших на рынке.
From the bottle. The aroma is very light with some dirt. The taste is also light and undistiguished. A little bit of bread.
Nice label, but the beer is not exiting. light golden, poor head, metalic hop aroma. Bitter, thin, dry and bitter aftertaste.
They do have some promising names, but that's really doesn't help. No meaning in drinking this beer.
Pale golden. Hens food aroma and flavor. Sourish. Not even worth to be referred as a Standard Lager...
Fairly average lager hopped with Noble Bavarian hops. Small head, pale golden color and some interesting hop aroma.

An extremly broad taste and bready fillingness overwhelms you in this very dark brew. Its almost pitch black, but still not thick like a guiness. Its a black pilsner, if now that is possible. The best beer i have ever drinked. This one beer isnt favouritized by the inhabitants as they like bright pilsner beer, and Sarmat creates many brands of those. They are though far off in quality from this one. Strangely its a pretty rare to find beer even in Russia and Ukraine. But its worth the chase. I tried to figure out what ingredient was this incredible flavoured enchantment coming from. The best i figured i think its based upon a summerdrink they all make at home there, non alcoholic water they put in a barrel and add a piece of bread into it. A chilling drink. Now that is pure speculation but there is something incredibly bready in its flavour. Maby they use real baked dark bread into the brewing process. This is the absolute favourite beer of mine. It actually is so much finer than any other i have ever tasted, its the absolute best one so far. I ran into it on a trip to Ukraine, and ever since i would never miss out on a dobre shubin going there. Dobre means Good, and shubin is a familly name. They are found in either half litre bottles or 2 litre plactic bottles.

Small light brown head, brown body with ongoing carbonation. Sweetish bready aroma with notes of spice. Taste is bitter lightly roasted grain with notes of pine needles. Sweetish and fruity. Bitter pine needle aftertaste. Clean and drinkable, but a touch watery. (0.5l bottle.)
Nut-brown with an ok head. Some prune-aroma. A bit burnt, bitter flavour, (but it could come from the smoking Russians surronding me).
Dark copper color. Not much aroma(I had this on a restaurant where people ate and smoked at the same time). Malty flavor. Light bitter finish.

"There is a legend in Donbass about the mine ghost - Good Shubin (Dobry Shubin). At the end of the XIX-th century there was a mine foreman, Shubin, who worked in one of the Donetsk mines. He had the unique intuition and he could foresee collapses and methane blowout. Before every shift he came down into the mine to listen to its depths and to warn about any possible danger. Ever since miners believe in existence of a good mine ghost and even ask him for aid". This was from the label. Sourish, no head, almost undrinkable.
PET 2,5L as Camarad Original. Clear yellow-golden, creamy white head. Very faint raw sugar sack aroma, traces of malts. Dry husky taste o cheap lager. Not too watery though. Drinkable.
A yellow beer with a white disappearing head. The aroma is weird, but also with more normal notes like hops and grass. The flavor is malty and hoppy with a thin body and a dry end. A boring beer.
1L. plastic bottle. Very pale yellow coloured. The plastic notes in the aroma of this beer is quite unpleasant.Extremely weak and watery flavour with some faint chemical notes. A very bad brew.
Hazy light yellow beer with almost no head. Strange aroma, grass and plastic tones. Extremely thin flavor, little citrus and hops. Nasty dry aftertaste. A very bad beer!
New mass beer from Vitanta: yellowish, watery with some plastic notes. An example of mass-produced lager without taking care of quality.
Bottled. Adherent of good persistence foam. Limpid yellow color, much effervescent and diamond. Hop, malt and much balanced scent. Fresh, prickly and bitter taste. Persistent and pleasant.
Very nice straw color, oily texture, big malty body and good hop aroma. Strange, but it's tastier than bootled. The draught versions are differ enormously.
Extremely dry dunkles with pleasant hoppy bitterness and evident caramelly accent. A better substitute to Vitanta Chisinau Bruna.
An orange beer with no head. The aroma is slightly bitter and sour aroma. The flavor is slightly sweet, sligltly cask flat, and very nicely bitter. A really nice beer.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Tasted 6/4/2016. Draught at Bush Shack Brewery, Yallingup, WA. Described as a "Milk stout with chocolate aroma and taste". Poured an almost opaque black with ruby tints and with a one-finger light tan foamy head that retained well and laced well. Carbonation virtually nil. Aroma of sweet caramel, nice moderate strength roasted grain and chocolate. Taste of chocolate with the chocolate taste coming more prominent as it warms. Medium to high body. Smooth with a syrupy mouthfeel and sweet chocolate on the finish. One to sip and savour. Very nice and different.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Listed as a milk stout. On draught @ Bush Shack brewery, Yallingup. Muddy dark brown, opaque, with fine carbonation rising up to a dollop of whipped tannish cream that lasts. Thick chocolate mudcake and icecream nose, quite nutty, rich yet dusty with a little hint of wood and yeast. Quite meaty, chunky in mouthfeel, full and rounded with a smooth finish. Light tannins and rust notes peak out under some robust chocolate malts and a flavour eerily reminiscent of velvety chocolate icecream. A hint of wood and roasted nuts in the aftertaste, linger long amongst the sweet chocolate, giving good balance. Better warmed up a little, the carbonation very light, the sweetness restrained from offsetting it. Not exactly session stuff, but it has come a long way from when I first tried it half a decade ago. Cleaned up and tasty, a nice ale.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: malt chocolate aroma. Coca cola brown colour with fair head and lacing. Sweet malt chocolate flavour. Fizzy palate.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Aroma: definate hints of cocoa, malt and other mochery coffee notes. Appearance: short lasting cappacino coloured head made from big bubbles. Chocolate coloured and clear with hints of red and large floculated particles (chocolate or yeast?). Flavour: Super sweet chocolate with a hint of hop and roastiness. Palate: medium to thick mouthfeel with a lingering chocolate/cocoa film and taste.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: 21 Jan 05 - Sweet choc well rounded malt aroma. Dark brown-black colour, good brown head but doesn’t retain well, with suds lacing. Sweet choc lightly roasted malt. Tangy, thickish mouthfeel. This beer could offer more complexity.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Dark ruby colour, foamy head doesn’t last at all. This reminded me far too much of Chicos. When I first smelled it from the bottle the aroma jumped out at me, but when I poured it into the glass I thought that it was a more authentic cocoa-ey aroma, but that didn’t last long. Smells like artificial chocolate flavour - choc topping/Chico - and not much else, perhaps a bit of yeast. Tastes SWEET. Like Mackeson’s or Sweetheart stouts. Blech. This is Chico-flavoured soft drink with some roast malt astringency, and I don’t really like Chicos. No good at all. Lucky they do some other good stuff.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Down a potholed muddy road in Yallingup you will find this little boutique brewpub and cafe. Very relaxed atmosphere with the feel of a University pub. Selection of about six beers on tap, also made available in bottles. This is the rating for the chocolate ale from the bottle beer. Dark brown, medium tan head that lasted half the glass. Cocoa powder aromas along with roasted malt. Bitter dark chocolate palate, a little yeasty. Not bad at all!

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Pours dark brown with amber highlights when held to light. Huge tan head fading to medium lasting. Toffee and fake chocolate aroma. Thin watery feel. Sweet cola with artificial chocolate flavouring. Not great, but not horrible either.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Amber brown colouring with a lower tone for its good head. Smokey chocolatey brew. Its OK.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Coffee/chocolate milkshake aroma, brown colour with a generous lasting head and good brussels lace. This tastes like they have dumped a whole packet of cadbury's drinking chocolate in it. No big flavours but otherwise it is inoffensive.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Tasted 6/4/2016. Draught at Bush Shack Brewery, Yallingup, WA. Poured a hazy golden colour with a one-finger white foamy head that retained OK and laced well. Carbonation low with medium sized bubbles. Aroma with hints of sour lemon as well as hints of honey and grain. Taste softly of lemon. Light body. Smooth, crisp, clean, slightly dry and soft with no real bitterness but hints of lemon on the finish.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: On draught @ Bush Shack Brewery, Yallingup. Produced up lightly hazy, a sunny yellow with few and far between carbonation and a quickly diminishing head. Predominately grainy nose, barnyardy and dusty with a sly hint of lemon and an earthy, honey sweetness. Very clean on the palate; lemon candy atop bready, gritty grains and musty, pleasantly sweet honey. Finish is dry, crisp and dusty. The body quite light with moderate carbonation. This works and I don’t know why. Tangy, refreshing sweet/sour mix that is balanced but light. A handful of US hops wouldn’t go astray though!

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Down a potholed muddy road in Yallingup you will find this little boutique brewpub and cafe. Very relaxed atmosphere with the feel of a University pub. Selection of about six beers on tap, also made available in bottles. This is the rating for the citrus beer. Bright pale yellow, clear, huge foamy head. Really stinky aroma-- my father-in-law said it smelled like his fermenting homemade wine, so I think they may want to clean their lines! Fresh palate (in sharp contrast to the aroma), a light lager backbone with some citrus oil zest and hints of honey. Average but enjoyable.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: This came in a wheat ale bottle with a handwritten "sour" label on it. But it is definately the citrus beer from the appearance and taste. Hazy lemon colour with absolutely no head. Sour lemon and orange aroma and tastewith nothing else. Couldn’t drink more than one of these....ever.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Another drainpour :( Strong green apple aroma upon opening that only got worse. MCG with lasting med head. Horrible flavour, I suspect this bottle was bad. Big green apples with a hint of honey.Thin very watery mouthfeel.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Amber-Golden type of colouring with a thick cloud like head. Zesty citrus flavour with a hint of honey.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Large white "egg yolk" head that lasted well and had good lacing. Initial light citrus bitterness that is nice and cleansing but by mid-palate it has fallen away.

column4: Bush Shack Brewery (ex Wicked Ale Brewery)
column5: Medium hazy muddy gold under a medium size short lasting white head. Faint artificial honey, yeasty sour dough and citrus flower hop aroma. Medium light zingy body. Medium wheat beer like sour with touch of bitter lemon zest flavour. Light sour and mild honey sweet finish. Flavours not all that well integrated but probably the best from this brewer.

22 oz bottle poured. Thanks, Wyatt! Alaska beer night! A treat to try such a praised belgain strong from these guys. A dense, jet black pour, moderate tan foam head. Aroma is more modest than expected, dark fruit, raisin/plum, soft spices. Flavor has plenty of the same dark fruit, paired with spices, and just a hint of chocolate. Lingering plum and raisin spice that sticks around forever in the palate. Smooth enough for a strong. Well put together, and wonderfully complex. Love it.
This is a very fine BSA. Cinnamon, spice, cocoa, and Belgian yeast. Come together in a complex empassioned way. Nice.
Bottle from Ben's. Poured into a snifter. A deep ruby brown with huge light tan head. Earthy-spice aromas and flavors with notes of brown sugar and plums. On the sweet side but not too much so.

From notes. Had this one at a get together at Erik’s house for the AFC/NFC Championship games on January 21. 22 oz bottle. The pour is a nice darker garnet tinted brown color with a thick light tan head that slowly falls down to a dense cap with a couple spots of lace. The aroma is pretty good. There is a strong Belgian yeast right up front with a darker fruitiness and a bit of sweet malt happening. This one is intense. There is a bit of oxidation on the front of the nose, and it does come off a little cardboard-y. The flavor is much of the same. The fruits are light and sweet with a nice yeastiness and a strong bit of sweet malt after that. The oxidation exists here as well. The mouth feel is medium bodied and softly carbonated with a sweet fruitiness and a pretty good yeasty finish. Not too shabby. 7 4 7 4 15
Pours dark with light brown head substantial for abv; aromas of porto and raisins; creamy rich palate; rich like a dessert
Too sweet. Much prefer a tripel. The beer is. Not bad, but the sugar is just too much.

Bomber from Alaska Liquor Store, Skagway. Nose is candi sugar, black raisins, and a hint of banana ester. Clear dark brown with a medium, lightly lacing, tan head. Flavor is moderately sweet with a white peppery note, dark fruit, and hints of cloves and char. Very nice.
From a 22 oz. bottle. Pours a dark cola with a tan head. Aroma of toffee and caramel. Flavors same. Smooth and tasty.

650 ml bottle. Pours a dark red/mahogany with full head. Aromas of candi sugar, sweet dark malts, and metallic Belgian yeast. Rich flavors follow same - sweet and thick with a little spice. Right on...

On tap at prospector. Perfect example of dark strong. Tulip glass. Dark and some head and lace. Nose of plums with a bit of chocolate. Alcohol totally hidden. Palate is rich and thick and creamy. Complex and rewarding.

Well...it is what it is. One of those beers that is good, tasty, drinkable, but forgetable. I like the flavor, a little rusty of a mouthfeel, but the chocolate malt aftertaste is decent. Appearance is semi-thin....dark brown, but not quite coffee black. I haven't sampled a lot of Baltic Porters yet, but this seems to have that European-porter feel to it. Worth the try and the price was right, but think I'll be bored of this by the time I finish the 6-pack......................................UPDATED 3/15/13: Sampled a single after two years. Better than I remembered from the review. Upgraded a point on appearance and mouthfeel. Not "bored" at all from this beer. It is good stuff.
Pours dark black with some foam. Light aroma of malts. Light upfront with some sweetness of marshmallow but a bitter, boozy kick. Roasty. Tasty. Tap.

Bottle. It pours brown with a small khaki head. The aroma has sweet cola, light root beer and nuts. Sweet on the nose. The flavor has more sweet cola with a strong earthy finish. Weak body. This bottle seems off. It starts off very sweet up front and then finishes overly earthy and bitter. Pass.

Pours a deep dark brown. Aroma is strong dark malts, dark fruits, dark chocolate. Taste is dark roasted malts, dark fruits, dark chocolate, burnt brown sugar, hint of smoke, hint of vanilla. Complex and better than I expected.

Pours a very dark brown with ruby glints around the edges of the glass when held to light. Half finger tan head. Smothers relatively quickly. Mild smoke, lactose, vanilla, and a British porter quality in the aromas. Pretty lively for an impy porter. Very British. Lactose, vanilla, sweet, cream on fruit.
Chocolatey roasty imperial porter. I wanna try one of these old ass 750 bottles because it’s pretty cool.

Drank from a nonic glass poured from a twelve ounce bottle. Pours black with a little bit of beige head. Aromas of roasted malts and chocolate. Tastes robustly sweet with a toasted flavor. Not a great Imperial porter...

Black pour orange hue with a thin off white head .... Aroma of dark fruits, roasted and some sweet chocolate malts .... Taste is of mostly dark fruits, plums, roasted malts and sweet chocolate malts .... Simple and full bodied porter .... Finish has a lingering sweetness .... Smooth and rich brew with a very light lingering bitterness ... Has some oily qualities in the mouthfeel ... Simple and tasty

Appearance dark brown, good amount of lacing and lots of sediment. Characteristically smooth for a good porter. Notes of chocolate, coffee, malt, oak, hop and bits of citrus really makes this stand out.
Pour is a dark chocolate black with a tan head. Aroma is of chocolate and malt. Taste is thick and full of chocolate and coffee. Finish is full. This is a great porter, I will find more of this.
very mellow and sweet 2010 on tap. vanilla a little fruit and honey. bright lemony and gold. perhaps aged peach. very nice with no abbey spice left. syrup and yeast.

Bottle shared by someone at a tasting at Sean’s, thanks! Poured a hazy creamy gold with a white heads that dissipated quickly to the edges. Aroma was full of hay, bread and grain with a backing yeast note and just a bit of spice perhaps. Flavor was sweet with grain and bread notes with a balancing yeast note.

Had this at BCTC after the fest, back at the campsite. Pours a lightly hazed yellow with a thin white head. Soft hay and musk on the nose. Medium bodied, sweet and yeasty. Toast (but faint). Tasty with a spicy caramel sweet tartness on the finish.

Ratebeer Winter Gathering. A: Pours a light clear golden yellow with a small white head. No real retention or lace noted. S: Aromas of light sweet fruit, yeast, with hints of bread. T: Yeasty and fruity in a nice way. Hints of doughy bread, light baking spices, and white pepper. M: On the lighter side of medium, smooth

(Old BA rate - tap) Poured with a nice finger of frothy/foamy white head. Great lacing for the style. Deep golden/yellow color. Touch of hop bitterness, light yeasty sourness, some hay like aromas. Touch of sweet malt, yeasty and light bake bread flavor. Good bit of hop (earthier) bitterness in the finish. Thinner MF with nice snappy carbonation. Dry, dry finish. Hugely drinkable and refreshing. Such a low abv, but a ton of great flavors. Dry finish and refreshing yeastiness really makes this easy, but straightforward

(22oz bottle) Pours a lightly cloudy yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of lemon, Belgian yeast, pear, clove, delicate florals, and subtle coriander. Flavor of moderately acidic citrus, Belgian yeast, pear, some funkiness, and candi sugar with a soft mouthfeel.
Golden pour, creamy head. Aroma is yeasty and malty with a wisp of earth. Flavor is dry and yeasty with a hint of fruity sweetness. Not bad, actually quite good.

The beer poured with a clear yellow appearance and a small white head. The aroma was malty with some notes of yeast and dust. The flavor was malty and bready. Sweet with a citrus component. The beer had a "wet" finish.

Soft dusty banana, straw, lemon, citrus, and light tart tangy in the aroma. Pours cloudy yellow with nice big bubbles and a frothy head. Flavors of wheat, banana, light belgian yeast, some lemon. Spicy notes in the finish. Citrus, wheat, peppery hops. Nice lively carbonation, extremely quenching. Subtle, but fantastic. Amazingly drinkable and lots of great flavors on a somewhat uninteresting beer style. Wow.

Pours pale yellow with w thick white head. The nose has apple, basil, cut grass, and some dust. Clean flavors with just the slightest Belgian yeasty character. Medium body and very easy drinking. A nice little beer.

2L(!) bottle. BBE 31.10.2012, rated on 04.09.2012 Aroma is malty with some coffee, nuts and chocolate. Flavour is malty and slightly tart with some coffee, hints of chcolate and alcohol. Good, somewhere between Dunkel and Dunkler Bock. Does not look or taste like Heller Bock.

2000 ml bottle. Thanks Timo A. Pours an amber colour with a white head. Aroma of toasted malts, grass and grainy malts. Flavour of toasted malts, nuts, grains, grassy hops and some dried fruits. Medium bodied, dryish malty finish and some alcohol. Something between a Heller Bock and a Dunkler Bock.

2 l bottle. Thanks Timo A! Pours clear copper color with a small white head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, some fruity notes, grass and malts. Flavor of sweet caramel malts, fruits, toffee, grass and mild spice notes. Medium carbonation, malty bitter palate. Balanced brew. 4424

Bottle 500ml. w. swing top @ home on the terrace. Clear medium to dark red amber colour with a large, frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, bread, caramel, sweet malt, malt extract. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, caramel, burnt sugar - caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110902]

It is beautiful red-brown with a creamy head. The aroma has a light sourness and notes of roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit and light nuts. The flavour has sweetness and a light sourness, notes of roasted malt, caramel, dark fruit and berries and it ends on a slightly dry note.

Bottle, 6.5%. Citric and sour aroma, a bit unpleasant. Clear dark brown colour, fizzy head disappearing completely. The flavour is malty, but also a bit sour and quite clearly infected. Almost drinkable. Unexpected from such a big brewery.
Draught: Poured a reddish brown with off white head. The aroma is sweet malt and caramel. Taste is caramel, malt, and hops.
Bottle.Red brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, alcohol, caramel. Flavour is sweet, roasted, alcohol, malt, fruit. Ordinary beer.

Bottle. Clear, reddish brown body with an off-white head. Some cooked vegetables in the aroma, but luckily they disappeares rather quickly, and are replaced by some alcohol, malt and a roasted note. Sweet and malty flavor, with a little fruityness and dried fruits. Medium to full body. Sweet, malty finish. I miss some of that warming feeling, but it is a quite nice bock. (070928)

(Bottle 50 cl). Beautiful deep amber coloured beer with no head to speak of. Actually surprisingly light for a bock, with a small body. Or else I’m enjoying it too cold. Sweetness yes. Bitterness, yes. But this bock doesn’t make the bells peal. 250903

Pours black with one finger brown head. Nose is roasted malt, smoke, coffee, and tiny bourbon notes. Taste is roasted malt and a bit of booze. Not a great taste as far as complexity. The palate is oily and medium bodied. Decent stout I suppose.

On tap at the Burger Bar in Mandalay Bay. Poured a jet black with a one finger brown head. The aroma was roasted malt and coffee. The flavor was roasted malt, without much else. There was a HUGE boozy aftertaste. It was almost like I was drinking liquor. Glad I got to try this, but not very impressed.

Jet black pout brown head w/ nice lacing. Some bourbon notes sweet malts and alcohol a good roastiness. Nicely coated palate lightly creamy. Warm swallow chocolates carmels roast notes alcohol hint of wood.
Mulled roasted coffee flavors. Thought I tasted some chicory up in here. Cloying with not much body to throw around.

My first Deschutes and I went straight for the Imperial. It was lighter in color... my Imperial Stout better be blackety black!!!! Very plain coffee roast nose and slightly chalky and bitter (which is good). Not a strong Imperial Stout, although it did boast 9%.

Aroma seems to lack a strong character, slightly chocolatey. Flavor begins slightly bland, then a bourbon/chocolate flavor follows. Not a lot of hop character, another imperial tasted at the RAF that seemed a bit thin for the style. Smooth mouthfeel, soft finish, average for the style.
RAF: very sweet, brown sugar aroma. Dark with little carbonation, alcohol present and warming. Rather bitter, with a slightly thin finish (watery). Dry finish in the palate.

cask (RAF): Roasty yet sour with notes of coffee and chocolate..Bitter rendition with a salty and fruity background with chocolate and roasty notes in the flavors..thin body for an imperial i must say..

Real Ale Fest - Smoky/salty aroma. I want to rate this one higher but it really tasted more like a porter (malty chocolate roast) rather than a imperial stout. Seemed light...maybe they are going to tweak it a bit?

(On tap at Real Ale Fest - Chicago) Smoked Polish sausage aroma flows from the opaque body. Milk chocolate and plum flavor, but the body is a little thin. Finish is smooth and roasted and helps to round out a pretty good imperial stout.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: Aroma is powerful and extremely pleasing. Deep orange/red color, with a fine, full head. Small particles everywhere in the brew, even with a half pour, but it’s a 5 year old, bottle conditioned beer. Flavor is extremely malty and concentrated. Caramel, toffee, a bit of roast, with hints of cherry and other fruits. Aged malt character is truly outstanding and it’s not overwhelmingly oxidized. Immensely chewy. Best aged beer I’ve had in a long time.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: Bottle, dated September 1, 2002, purchased and savored at Choice City Butcher and Deli, Ft Collins, CO. I am not sure how Russ procured this, but thanks. Pours cloudy brown with a spare, rocky, light brown head, diminishing, spare lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, chocolate, toffee), average hops (flowers), average yeast (dough) with notes of dates and honey. Full bodied, creamy and alcoholic texture, average carbonation and a bitter finish. Long duration, moderate sweetness, acidity and bitterness.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: On tap at Clarkston Union Bells event. Pours a hazy golden amber color with smallish soapy white head. Aroma is dough, molasses, grains. Flavor is dried fruits, yeast, candy sugar, raisin, molasses. Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finishes sweet. Excellent stuff.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: Cask; 2003 RAF: Cloudy rust color. Frothy foam. Lightly smoked aroma. Hints of dark grape, bread, and caramel. Thick palate. Full bodied. Smoke flavors overrides plum, candied fruit, and yeast with a hint of iron and raisin. Underlain by a mildly coarse hop presence. Reminiscent of Bell's Batch 5000 with more barleywine-like aspects. Highly impressive.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: Wow! It is amazing how much flavor and uniqueness can be stuffed into a 4 ounce glass!!!! Warm sugar cookie dough dipped in rum, rolled in hay, drug through a field of oats, dipped in rum again, and finally poured into my glass with a hops-infused cherry on top. (Jeez, that sounds like I just stole this out of DaSilky1's notebook!)

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: Bells comes through again. Dark fruit with aged oak plum. The alcohol is strong and warming. Bitterness in the end, sweet in the front.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: A beautifully unexpected highlight of the RAF for me. Sweet molasses cookie aroma, rich and comforting. Doughy texture, bready and wonderful. Medium orange-amber hue. This is going to sound rightfully cheesy, but I can tell that so much love and care went into this...maybe they helped craft it together?

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: cask (RAF): swamp clouds of brown...aroma defined in chocolate wedding cake drizzled with candy carmel, sugar cookie, and port wine..onslaught of thick smoke and an evident chocolate foundation..super silky smooth mouthfeel and a semi-bitter finish..nice.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: Malty aroma. Flavor is chocolate/carmel. Hoppy as one would expect from this brewery. This is not one of their better beers IMHO, as the complexity of the malt pales in comparison to some of their masterpieces. ABV covered smoothly, just not a lot going on in the malt.

column1: Bell's Wendy and Larrys Wedding Ale
column5: Cask: Clear orange brown. . . fairly large toupe bubbles through on the medium sized head. Sweet hops up front, rolls into caramel and honey. Sugary mouthfeel but still has a solid malt presence. Flavour diminishes quickly, but still another solid offering from Bells.

May 2010: No Horny Toads mentioned on the font. One of 24 taps in the Greenroom, Flagstaff, just a few miles from the brewery. Amber/orange in colour, very little head on my pour. Hops, hops and more hops seemed to be the over riding theme with this hoppy IPA. The hop mix/blend/interwoven combination however produces a very drinkable beer. Can’t call it well balanced because someone forgot to put any malted barley into the brew! Pity we didn’t have time to visit the brewhouse.
Draght. Had a pint of this at a friend’s house tonight. Very, very good. I’ll be looking for this in the tap rooms.
7/28/11 horny toad at pap Seems confused...lots of diffrnt hops(pine,citrus,floral,spice) fighting each other but caramel/malty sweet... Weird. Bitter finish. 7/3/6/3/13

Tap at Papago. Hazy amber-orange color pour with a nice head. Aroma is mostly citrusy hops with some caramel malt in the back. Flavor is pretty balanced between sweet and bitter. Not mind-blowing, but good.
Light orange pour. Grapefruit peel, resin, caramel aroma. Flavor is bitter, good citrus peel, lemony notes. Not half bad!

On tap at Papago on 8/6/10. Pours clear dark amber with a one finger off-white head. The nose is caramel and ripe citrus. The taste is caramel, ripe citrus and a decent pine finish that lingers. Medium bodied. Decent IPA.

Sampled at GTBF. Muddled orange-copper pour with a 1/4 inch eggshell head that left a bit of lacing. Quite hoppy with an amazing natural tangerine presence. Also possesses Ponderosa and honey. Medium mouthfeel...really solid beer.

On tap @ 1702 - Poured a slightly hazy golden color with a thin white head. Light layered lacing. Aroma and flavor is pine and floral hops with a touch of toasted malt sweetness. Has a slight lingering astringent aftertaste. Medium body. A nice IPA. Nice to hear Mogollon is ramping up production.

Draft at the brewpub. Clear reddish-orange color with an off white head that laced the glass. Smelled of malty caramel, light sprucy hops, and vanilla. Dry on the tongue with moderate hop bitterness, especially at the end. Pleasant malty caramel and vanilla flavors, but only minimal flowery hop flavor.

Poured with the amberish color and with a huge and nice head (concave up). Very nice presentation. The flavor was of caramel malts (didn’t catch much except the hops in the flavor) with some definite hops in the aroma.
On tap at Bjørn Hansen’s stand at Gladmatfestivalen, Stavanger 2007. Pale golden colour, low head. Industrial pilsener aroma and flavour. Some bitterness. Boring.
Moderate hoppy aroma. Average frothy initial apperance. White head. Fair lacing. Fully diminishing longevity. Clear light yellow body. Light bitte initial flavor. Light to medium palate.
Can. (Best before november 2003) Courtesy of Hansen. Pale yellow with small white head. Somewhat weak aroma and flavor, but still ok.
Can BB 2003. Courtesy of Hansen !!!! Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Yellow colour. Nice week hoppy aroma and flavor. Nothing wrong with this one. Watery palate but still ok beer.
Can. Courtesy of Hansen. BB 2003. Golden colour with a surprisingly nice white head. Aroma and taste of malts and hops. Standard pale lager.

(Can 33 cl) Bjørn Hansen, the crazy man from Gentofte, fought for years to get beercans introduced in Denmark. One of his methods was by civil disobedience at a grocery store in Vordingborg. He has provoked plenty of court trials, from which newspaper cuttings mark this beercan. The beer has a decent head and quite a lot of bitterness. 280404
Looks like beer added water. Pale-yellow. Head ok. Not much aroma, metallic? 5,7% alcohol, well the rest 94,3% must be mostly water.
Light golden colour with ok head. Weak aroma. Light and watery body. The flavour is bitter with a dry finish.

column1: Govnors Public House Heaven Hill Imperial Stout
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: I could really notice the alcohol in this one. Not an high ABV but present. Not really imp stout, but smoother and a tad thin.

column1: Govnors Public House Heaven Hill Imperial Stout
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: Nice rich roasty aroma/... like from a chocolate smokestack/... but I want my damn Imperials/... blackety black/... My first and last ratings rap! This had a big smoky sweet nose but lost it after that. It was thin and watery. Nice aftertaste of whisky and bakers chocolate.

column1: Govnors Public House Heaven Hill Imperial Stout
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: Bourban cask aged (RAF): poured brown and cloudy.. i could see through it and im sick of that crap..especially in "imperial" stouts..what the hell..this also had an unattractive head of big fish egg-like bubbles but i attribute this to the gravity pour of the cask..the aroma was spicy whisky with chocolate covered raisins..the flavor was big chewy bourbon injecting ripe fruits with some added chocolate and an extra bourbon kick at the end..a very warming beer...

column1: Govnors Public House Heaven Hill Imperial Stout
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: Sweet cherry alcohol aroma, small bits of chocolate, though a pleasant aroma, it was hard to find. . . Dark brown, small thin toupe head. Dark chocolate flavours with some sugary alcohol - pretty mild for 8.9%, missing the thickness and veinous qualities one would expect from an Imperial stout. Too much sugar and not enough fruit.

column1: Govnors Public House Heaven Hill Imperial Stout
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: Chocolate/whiskey aroma. Very chocolatey malt flavor. Bourbon kicks in towards the end. Again , aging this type of beer in bourbon barrels does seem to provide a finish that drowns out the malt. Where is the fruit? Not very imperial.

column1: Govnors Public House Heaven Hill Imperial Stout
column2: Lake In The Hills, Illinois, United States
column5: Pours a light brown color and you could see right through it. The aroma was pretty nice. Roasted and malty. Creamy alcohol, chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, a little oak and some coffee. Worth drinking, but not the best, to be sure.
Golden color with an small size head. Slightly fruity aroma. Thin dry flavor with some straw.
Viel Kohlensäure, ansonsten ein durchschnittsbier, das in keiner Rubrik einen besonderen Trumpf ausspielen kann. Test vom 8.11.2004, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 7,7,9,9,6,9 - 8,35

50cl screwtop bottle. Pale golden, coarse disappearing head. Strongly hayish aroma, pale husky malts, little honey and mint. Sweet pale malts, balancing menthol herbal bite, little honey wax. A tad coarse carbonation. Pretty nice hoppiness, could use a drier malt base.
Bottled (from Ambrosetti, BB 01/2010) Golden color, small white head. Sticky grassy aroma, sweetish malts. Sweet malty with harsh grassy notes and some cardboard. Industrial pale lager.
Bottled. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is grass, malts, with some mild fruits as well. Flavour quite much the same with a mildly dusty tone to it.

(33 cl bottle at Delirium Café, Göteborg) Label states 5.2% ABV and manufactured by "Haus der 131 Biere". Clear pale golden color, small white head. Sweet malty and abit fruity scent. Sweet malty taste, metallic. Spritzy mouthfeel, no bitterness.

(Bottle 33 cl) Pours very pale golden with a creamy, white head. Aroma of pilsener malt and a whiff of hops. Thin body with the main flavours being metal and brewing cereal. Very unpleasant and a disgraceful product from an otherwise fine brewery. 170406
A yellow with a white head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of caramel as well as hints of straw, the flavor is dry and dusty with notes of straw, and the body is thin.

Bottle, courtesy of the Danes @ ZBF 2005. Chestnut red, butter yellow head and moderate condition. Low hints of fruity roastiness in the nose, soft and quite thin in the mouth with hints of breadiness, and a gentle bitterness in the finish.
Bottle. Golden colour with a medium white head. Floral hoppy aroma and taste. Light body.

Draft. I am absolutely sure I had this one, though my notes I’ve kept from my trips to Capitol City over the last year or so have disappeared. What I remember of it (I distinctly recall having a Wee Heavy on tap because of the "odd" name) is that it poured a brownish color, had a quite refreshing flavor. Notes of caramel, touch of alcohol. I’ll see if I can’t update this in the future.

Date: 03/22/2002 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Dark ruby, headless, strong malt aroma, rich malt flavor, well balanced, just a hint of bitterness -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 03/23/2003 malty but bland, pox on cap city Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20 Rating: 3.5/5.0 Score: ***/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

On tap at ODBF 2004... This beer rocks!... Sparkling clear, mahogany ale with a small, creamy, beige head. Weeping lacework. Aromas of molasses, maple syrup, toffee, port and wood. A hint of smoke. Decently balanced flavor. Sweet and malty, but also tangy and well-bittered. Full-bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Lengthy, semi-sweet, astringent finish. Well done!

On tap at Old Dominion Brewfest. Pours a dark reddish auburn. Aroma is roasty. Taste is sweet with caramel malt, a good dose of hops, brown sugar, chocolate, dark fruit and smokiness. Noticeable alcohol content but it doesn’t negatively impact the brew. Mouthfeel is very full, round and creamy. Nice.

Dark brown pour with a reddish tint to it. For a scotch ale, I like to taste a bit of peat butt didn’t notice any in this. Medium bodied and a bit smoky. Dried fruits and light caramel tastes. Nothing remarkable.

Deep brown with a purple-ish tint, very little head, lots of toffee, caramel & sweet malty flavors, very smooth & drinkable, a slight hint of smoke in the finish along with more malty caramel flavors, a nice Scotch ale

Setting: Served on tap in a pint glass at the brewpub. Appearance: Über-dark crimson - almost black - topped by a modest off-white head that goes to a film of small bubbles right quick. Leaves small splotches of foam as remains of the day. Aroma: Caramel and toffee malt sugars with hints of prunes. Flavor: Intensely malty and sweet. Caramel and pruny/plum flavors dominate the mouth. Kind of a simple taste. Some roasted or smoked malt flavors would have been welcome. Palate: Rather heavy in body with lingering sweet aftertastes. Overall: A little bit on the cloying side with the sweetness, but not horrifically so.

Had this on draft at the Manayunk event. 8% alcohol. Pours dark brown, with aroma of malt and toffee. Tastes very malty with an underlying sweetness. Slightly tart finish. This is a scotch ale, but it has some flemish sour and some belgian dubbel qualities. Nice complexity. One of the top beers at the Manayunk event, in my opinion.
a nice dark ale. a tad bitter with a heavy flavor. Never got a scottish feel to it... more of a strong ale or a bitter. Still a good starter beer...

Super dark brown colour with a thin light brown head. Sweet aroma of chocolate, coffee, plentiful sugars and roasted malt. Medium-bodied; Roasty flavours favouring sweet malt and some bittering qualities. Aftertaste shows the coffee and dark chocolate flavours while still having sweet characteristics. Overall, a nice beer-sweet and still roasty-well done and a good one to try this season! I had this from a growler purchased from the location in Shirlington (Arlington), Virginia by my sister's fiance. I tasted this on 30-November-2003.

Bottled from the Greene Kiing brewery shop. Aparently they brew it there now too. Funny colour for a wheat. Hazy golden copper with little head. They must use a weissen yeast with this one cos it has those banana esters along with some peachy, orange notes too. A little thin. flavor has plenty honey and wheat. some lasting sweetness. the first taste was good but ultmately forgettable.
Bottled version. Dunno what to think, don’t look like a wheat beer, and only vaguely tastes of one. I might have enjoyed it better if it was labelled differently.
Well, was not really a Weiss Bier, and they never said so, but it was a little far from the fron flavor, the wheat.

This is a seriously strange beer. Starts with an aroma of cloves and peat, however changes to light fruityness, canceling out the peat, then later on back to peat, with cloves and little wheatyness all the way through. Taste starts harsh smokey peat, however changes as with the aroma to a far smother peaty fruitiness. Reminds me of a scotch ale in some ways, however maybe needs a little more refining.

[bottle from asda] pours an orangey yellow colour with a quickly diminishing head. The nose is fruity, some peach notes and a little citrus fruit, smells pretty industrialised though. body is a bit weak, sweet finish.
VERY light style of wheat beer, no head (which is disappointing ) Lightly spiced nose and also on the palate, this bears little resemblance to "classic" wheat beers.

Bottle from Sainsbury’s. Clear yellow with white head. No yeast. Fruity orange / banana aroma. Spritzy mouthfeel and yes, there it is, a smoky peaty flavour. Classic ’Northern German’ wheatbeers must be clear and smoky then - Kristallrauchbier, no less. Actually its drinkable but that house character of Belhaven’s is beginning to annoy me somewhat. (Try using different yeast if you’re going to brew different ’classic’ beer styles, guys?)

(Bottle 50 cl) I find the back label’s claim that wheat beer originates in Northern Germany rather amusing. Wonder what would’ve happened during the war if the British general staff had lacked the same sense of geography. Would they’ve been looking for Hitler in the Eagle’s Nest around Flensburg somewhere? Anyways, I remember having this for the first time at the Copenhagen Beer Festival in 2003 concluding that the Scots should keep away from producing wheat beers. After having finished this I haven’t changed my opinion. This amber-coloured, slightly hazy beed has an oddly smoked character - pretty much like whisky-malt. Indeed a very different wheat! 250104
From a small bottle.Light gold,hey imagine that,small head,light malt,nothing outstanding.
Bottled. A lightcopper/dark gold coloured beer with a thin lemony floral aroma. The taste is wheaty and a bit perfumed. Drinkable if unspectacular.

Growler fill from the brewery. Dark opaque brown, small airy beige head. Big roast malt aroma with minor notes of chocolate. Taste is roast grain bitterness, hint of coffee and semi-sweet chocolate. Medium weight, slightly oily. Minor metallic tinge at the finish.

On tap at Ellicott Mills Brewing. Dark Brown with amber tint and white head. Roasted malt chocolate aroma. Sweet caramel malt and roasted malt flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee. Slight hop finish. Really like this brew.

Tap. Pours clear dark brown with a small, frothy off-white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is caramel and cookie malt with dates and plums, and light earthy hops. Flavor is malt dominant with light hops and bitterness, dark fruity esters and a sweet finish. Full body and medium carbonation.
Draft. Deep brown, clear, light tan head. Medium body, smooth, nice finish. Very well done... alcohol strength is masked well.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma with hints of dark fruit. Fruity malty caramel and dark fruit flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with hints of dark fruit in the aftertaste.

on tap-pours a rich tan head that laces and cloudy brown color. Aroma is faint medium malt-molasses, medium fruit. Taste is roasty, medium malt-molasses, medium fruit, barely perceptible earthy hops. Medium body. Mild carbonation.

Deep brown in color with a creamy off white head. Aroma is malty, with caramel, vanilla, yeast, raisins and some other sweet fruits. Flavor is much of the same. Caramel, and malts are at the forefront. The raisn notes showed up in the flavor as well. Finishes with a little bit alcohol. A very respectable dopplebock.
impressive as hell. Insanly nice doppelbock. Very dark and easily the most complex beer i had all night. A little heavy on the alcohol, but stil more then well worth it. Bling!!!

Black body with creamy tan head, nice lacing. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some chocolate, alcohol, light raisin, vanilla. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, some chocolate, coffee, alcohol, cherry, light raisin. Finish has some alcohol burn. Creamy full body, some stickiness.
A very nice and smooth doppel. A touch of caramel blended with some chicory. Not quite the Church Brew Works Doppel but still a wonderful beverage.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Diabolical Dubbel
column5: DraughtThe beer as it forsakes the keg a tea color, hazy and the head portly in size, light tan in color and the texture semi-creamy, as it erodes the lace forms a nice concealing sheet upon the glass. Nose is sweet malt with hits of caramel, fresh and clean to the senses, start is sweet, and has a nice malt profile with the top moderate in its feel to the palate. Finish is entertainingly acidic, the hops gratifyingly spicy, nice dry and lingering aftertaste, a fine representative to the style.

column1: Rock Bottom Long Beach Diabolical Dubbel
column5: Bottled (RAF). Pours a pretty standard reddish brown color with little head. The aroma was crazy good and dominated by crab apples, raisin, plum, toffee and candy sugar. The flavor was just a little flat. This could have been really good if the flavors matched the nose. Unfortunately, it was unable to do so.

Had on tap at Piece. Served in a tulip. Freshly tapped that day. It’s been a while since this was brewed so I was definitely excited to have it. A: Pours a hazy amber color with a thin white head forming on the pour. It recedes to a thick ring and sticky sheets of lace are left down the glass. S: Piney hops with a slightly fruity sweetness melding in there. Caramel and bready malts balance this hop bomb out. T: Great semi-bitter hops resinous hops are upfront with some mild pine flavor. It mixes nicely with some mango and pineapple citrus sweetness. The hops are taken back down to earth by a nice caramel malt body. M: Medium bodied, slightly sticky in feel with a nice prickly carbonation. O: This had some great hop flavors and it was very refreshing. Easily drinkable for the ABV. It seems Wingnut is back and better than ever. Get it while it lasts. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 04-17-2012
On draft at brewpub, poured a darker golden color, aromas of citrus and pine hops, and some light malt. Flavors are the same with a touch of caramel on the back end, nice beer overall.

Gold copper with a small head. The aroma is mostly citrus and pine, with light caramel malt. The flavor is similar in balance, with strong bitterness and some slight alcohol warming. Really drinkable for the most part, tasty stuff.
Amazing. Darker pour and good head from the tap. Very hoppy and strong but fruity and citrus notes give this an awesome smooth taste ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark amber with light pine notes. Citrus kicks in with a subtle sweet malt that balances the double nicely. Big finish.

On draft at brewpub. Clear copper amber, no head. Nose is earthy malts, some citrus and dankness. More of the same on the palate but the ABV spicy hotness is evident in the finish. Good but not great. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Enjoyed on tap at Piece while having some beers with a friend on a crowded Saturday night. Appearance is a dark but bright gold with a rich white head that laces. Aroma mostly citrus and pine, more citrusy than other IIPA’s. Taste is very citrusy and bitter, more hoppy than malty, surprising for an imperial ipa, thought this one was pretty good. Would gladly enjoy again!

On tap at Piece. Pours a hazy deer amber with a near white head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has grassy and pine hops with a slight old fruit note and backing sweet grains. Flavor has sweet grain up front with a nice hop note with resin, pine and a bit of grass.

Aroma of hops. Nice lacing. Ok head on this one. Dark amber pour that is kind of cloudy. Creamy mouth. Taste is pretty sweet at first. The hop notes take over at the end and really balance this out. For 9.5% alcohol, this is too easy to drink. Nicely done.

Reviewed from notes. Pours a moderate orange amber color with an off white head. The nose is citrus with a bit of rind and some mild spicing. Maybe herbal qualities. Taste is citrus and orange. Fairly bitter with a finish in the dry side. Drinks well and was one of the better beers I had there. Piece’s hoppy offerings are defintely above the rest of their brews. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 11-02-2010

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Uppa Kriek Without a Mash Paddle
column5: RAF 2003: Bottle. Hazy strawberry shade. Sticky, chunky foam. Medicinal aroma alongside notes of whiskey, wood, sour cherries, must, and leaf. Buttery flavors followed by sour cherry pie filling. Finishes with a touch of coconut and acidity. A respectable example, only lacking in acidity and malt depth.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Uppa Kriek Without a Mash Paddle
column5: Bottle RAF. Doesn't seem to be a true kriek. A musty aroma with hints of yeast. Mostly-lambic type flavor witha hint of cherry. Just not enough of the classic yeasty, musty, cheesy lambic flavors for me.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Uppa Kriek Without a Mash Paddle
column5: Bottle at the RAF 2003: Hazy pink orange, thin white lasting head. Thicky musty aroma, very natural. . . Reminds me of wandering around in the creek behind my house when I was younger. Some pretty nice farmhouse aromas as well - grass, stone, and wood. A very natural sour flavour, tart and bitter, some acidity like orange juice and a little metallic in the finish. Overall a very interesting selection and one I enjoyed.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Uppa Kriek Without a Mash Paddle
column5: A beer of nostalgia for me. Aroma brought me back to picking cherries as a child during the middle of June...chasing away the blue jays and stepping on moldy fruit, stubbing my toes on the pits. Tasted exactly like past-the-prime cherries I've nibbled on: nuttiness of the pit, as well as the juicy bite that consumes the mouth. The thing is, I don't want a beer to taste like this. I don't eat those cherries anymore because...I know better.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Uppa Kriek Without a Mash Paddle
column5: Hmm, well there was some bite to this. I mostly tasted fish, which is not a good thing in this instance. Some sour mash thrown in for good measure.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Uppa Kriek Without a Mash Paddle
column5: This was way off style, almost like a plain-old lager with some cherry juice added. The Belgian yeast didn't help a bit. Totally unbalanced, not even close. I'd prefer one of those teeth-gritting Chapeau Banana beers before trying another Rock Bottom attempt at a fruit beer.

column1: Rock Bottom Chicago Uppa Kriek Without a Mash Paddle
column5: Poured a golden color with just a touch of pink from the cherries. A well-formed head again with little red hue to color it. Dry and musty with a strong sour kick.
