It didn't seem quite right, maybe a bit accelerated to achieve the sour they were looking for. An interesting beer that was well worth drinking, but something was just a little off.

On tap after an 8 year hiatus. Pours with a clear, light bronze hued body with a lasting off-white head. Aromas are grainy, wheat, cereal, warm and malty, with mild esters (very mild for a dubbel). Flavors are of fig newtons, malty, nutty, soil, mild esters. Odd fruit flavor that I can not place. Persimmons maybe? Very lively bubbles, dry on the mouth.

Re rating this based on tasting at brewery. aroma is cereal. The beer is warm now. Flavor is banana. Finishes sweet. Original rating: On tap at streets if London. Rating this based on a sip of my brothers beer. Aroma is of banana. Some caramel. Flavor is really similar. Finished slightly dry, and is thick and oily.
A very good belgian style. Pours a deep red, with not much head, and a fruity smell. Very smooth drink, with a fruity aftertaste. Enjoyed. Had on tap at Marin Brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Color of maple syrup. Fluffy head. Spices overwhelm the palate. Light piney hops. Pretty one dimensional. Don’t taste the dark fruit I would expect from this style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours very dark amber with a creamy beige head. Roast malt aroma with a hint of spice. Med body. Flavor is roast malt with yeast/spice. Somewhat tangy. Tasty. Not dry, but not very sugary either.
Draft. Brown with a beige head. Roasted malt and spice aroma. Very fruity, malty, spicey, yeasty flavor. Rich and complex. Lingering esters. Medium body and easy to drink.

Draft at brewpub, my version had fermented out to a solid 7.7. Deep brownish burgundy color. Raisiny aroma, but not strong. Belgian yeast notes were faint in the mouth, woven with dark fruits and a good malt body. It was good, but somehow not quite distinctive enough. Perhaps needs a funkier yeast?

Cask at the RAF 2003: Great yeasty aroma, though more like a tripel than a dubbel. . . Dark red brown, not too much spice in the flavour, but fruit and malt are very nice on the palate. Though a strange dubbel a beer I would do again.
The yeastiness didn't seem to mix with the red fruitiness (plum, grape, raspberry) and made it seem like a jumbled mess. Something was missing.
Deep dark brown. A kind of medicinal rubber quality. Fairly thin in the palate. Dark, malty, and grapes.

I've had plenty of "gimmick beers". Ones with stupid labels depicting the Man Show or Monty Python... Ones with hot peppers floating in them or died green, but this is a different gimmick beer altogether. The gimmick here is to overdo the IBUs to an insane level and let the hophead drown in the bitter trainwreck. The nose was quite nice, a hoppy perfume with enough malt to notice. Sweet malts do make themselves known at the beginning of this ale, but surprisingly, the 177IBUs take a long second or two to gather speed and stregth before they collide on the sides of your tongue like a hop-filled tidal wave. Dry and grassy, the aftertaste lingers on into the next beer that you drink. A neat idea, big alcohol and big IBUs.

I admit it, I got this one for the name at the end of session 1 of the RAF...had no idea of the IBUs. Citrusy sharp, slightly flowery aroma. Enjoyed it because it woke my mouth up after a long night of sweet nectar. Maintained a semblance of balance, but made my tongue numb in a almost intriguing fashion.
Ridiculous IBU level at 177. Plus a 9.5 ABV. Surprisingly easy going. Hits the tongue with a malt presence, but then goes into the huge lingering bitterness that would be expected.

cask (RAF): 177 IBUs on the wall with my palate nailed there too..Hello..this beer was hoppy, go figure. mango and orange citrus zeal aroma..scrapped bits of hop resin, tangy pine sap all combine in unadulterated, wacky, off-balanced bitterness...did i mention it was cloudy brown with a thin head..cool...it was a fun ride none-the-less.

Absolutely huge piney, floral aroma. Though the hops are pronounced the aroma has some sweet malty sugar as well. Rich orange peel flavours, and other soft fruits like pears. . . nice lingering sweetness from some good malt presence. Very impressive to stay balanced and sport 177 IBUs as well.

A nice balance of malt and hops in this beer. Totally unexpected at 177 IBUs. The malt is strongly caramel and chewy. The hops were citrusy and floral but nearly to the extent I expected. The 177 IBUs are well hidden leaving a statisfying beer to drink.
On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown pour with a tan head, Coffee and chocolate inthe aroma and taste.

Had this on cask. Pours a dark brown with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, roast, and earth. Flavor is semisweet chocolate, caramel, bread, and roast malts. Has a soft, smooth body. Thought not very strong on flavor or aroma, I enjoyed drinking this.

Tap @ Dragonmead: Almost fully black body with not much of a head, only a thin film & a chunky, khaki colored collar around the edges. Aroma has strong notes of bitter chocolate, roasted malt, black coffee, & a hint of brown sugar. The taste has a larger coffee-ish presence; generic coffee bean notes with roasted malts, bittersweet chocolate, & a little nuttiness. Bitterly roasted finish, a little watery. Another decent, yet slightly unexciting beer by Dragonmead.

My first nitro-dispensed porter - man is it creamy! Indeed, non-lactic creamy smoothness overwhelms enjoyably. Quite dry, very little bitterness, essentially no sweetness, just all around smooth, soft, and comforting.
Draft at brewery. 04.22.2010. Pours dark brown with thick tan head. Nose of smokiness, burnt malt, oaty. Tastes creamy, burnt, a bit sweet. Oily mouthfeel.
On tap at the Dragonmead Brew Pub. Poured a dark brown color with an off white head. Roast, chocolate, nuts, and some earthiness. Blah.
hand pull. pours murky brown with thick creamy white head. aroma of roasted malt and sugar. taste is brown sugar and some hops. lots of roasted nuts very silky and crreamy
Nitro draft at Dragonmead. Smooth beer all around and I enjoyed very much. Good finish... better than I remember from previous visits.
draft... this was the best of the several porters I had but still not something I can recommend
nitro body. earthy choco comes out in the nose. flavor of bitter chocolate, peanut shell, nuts and grass. dry finish. creamy, dense mouthfeel

Dark mahogany pour with a huge tan head. Aroma is slight coffee. Flavor of mild chocolate and huge coffee, with a bitter bite at the end. A little light bodied for my taste. I like a motor oil stout. Good stout for a non-imp.

Dark brown pour with hints of red. Tan head and lace. Aroma of light coffee. Flavor of chocoffee with a hint of abv. Good bitter, caramelly flavor as well. Medium bodied. Solid pretty complex flavor for a brewpub stout.

(Tap) Labeled as the "Export Stout" at the Memphis location. Pours a very deep brown color with a small tan head. Aroma of molassas and burnt caramel. Silky mouthfeel, and average carbonation. Taste included dry grain notes and a touch of coffee. Very light alcoholic warming at the end. Nice stout.

On cask (Irish yeast), Nashville brewpub. Nice pillowy tan head over a clear but very dark ruby black. Smells like fruitcake and sweet, roasty, dusty coffee. Lighter in body than I was expecting. Some of the roastiness and the deep red fruitiness comes out, but mostly it’s a smoothly sweet and fairly bland beer in the middle, giving way to a slightly roasty, slightly bitter finish that lingers quite a bit. Not quite a dry stout, the appellation "stout" is definitely appropriate: this doesn’t fit an a more specific box. Classic.

Didn’t find a entry for their foreign export stout, so I’m entereing my opinion here. On draft at the Memphis locale. Opaque with a nonexistent head. Nice fruity, roasty aroma. Deep caramel, coffee, chocolate notes with a notable warming effect of alcohol. Very satisfying as a desert beverage.
Bottle Conditioned: My what a fine stout it was. Malts galore and a hint of hops to boot. The lace impressed even the non stot lovers.

Beer engine cask tapped by some crazy laymen with a jackhamer..(RAF)..nice dark mud color with shit floating around inside and a fat, sticky, glass-climbing tan head...it feasts the air with buttery roastedness and carmel-lubed whipped cream..flavors were subtly roasty, moderately bitter, slightly salty with nice memories of toasted pumpkin seeds and blackberry jam on an a slice of toasted 15-grain bread with the crust just slightly charred. Good low grav. stout.

One of the best stouts of the RAF. Came out of the engine with beautiful dark brown head atop a dark, dark brown body. The aroma was really very nice with chocolate, burnt toast, a touch of coffee, and, as Trappist Ales Rule pointed out, a nice amount blackberry jam. A really nice mouthfeel and wonderful balance made this a delightful treat.
On draft at The Beer Engine. Very dark brown with an off-white head. Chocolate and sweet malt in the aroma. Very full mouthfeel, creamy. Chocolate flavors.

Date: 06/23/2007 Mode: Growler Source: Tasting, RBSG 2007 clear dark brown, frothy beige head, spidery lace, toasted chocolate aroma, rich dry dark chocolate flavor, light bitterness, -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Date: 07/23/2007 Mode: draft Words: Buckeye Beer Engine ditto Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Draft at the brewpub. Aroma: Strong toasted nuttiness, caramel, and toasted malt. Some herbal hop notes. Appearance: Dark brown in color and clear. Light khaki head was full and frothy with good retention. Fair lacing. Flavor: Lots of malt with notes of toasted nuts, caramel, chocolate. Hops come through with a touch of earthy herbalness. Medium-light bitterness and a dry finish. Palate: Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Overall: A nice brown ale. Drinkable with some good flavor.

Sampled at the RBSG ’07 Grand Tasting room, pours a clear dark brown brew with a very thin off-white head that quickly dissolves. Aroma of light roasted chestnuts, caramel, and some flowery hops. Taste is lightly carbonated, medium bodied, with some caramel and roasted malt flavors. Finish is slightly bitter with a watery malt aftertaste. A very good balanced brown ale.
Sampled at the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting. Nutty aroma on this brown beer. Roasted malt flavor with a nutty finish. finish was a bit watery
On tap @ the Beer Engine: Pours brown with an off white head. Aroma nutty, caramel. Flavor, caramel, some nutty notes, earthy bitterness.
RBSG 2007. Growler. Dark brown color with no head. Nutty aroma. Lots of toasted malt flavor with a watery chestnut finish. Slightly bitter, but nicely subdued and not screaming.

This has a great head retention over a clear medium-dark brown body. There’s a big nuttiness in the aroma and flavor, backed up by a solid maltiness one would expect in a robust brown ale. Low hopping. Almost salty in the finish.
On tap: Aroma is lightly malty. At the brewery so smell is a little hard to judge. Nice malty flavor with caramel, nuttiness, and roastiness. Lightly bitter and maltiness in the finish.
Tap. A deep brown color. Modest off-white head. Malty, hoppy aroma. Very smooth, medium bodied. Balanced nicely between malt and hop. Would be a good session choice.
Cask at the RAF 2003: Clear dark pink. . . chocolately raspberries. Pretty good flavour for a juice, or kool-aid, but not a good flavour for beer. . . something bad happened with this one.
Sorry Todd, I have to admit that I, too, didn't like the Framboise. Vinegar thinned out with sugar water and blended with raspberry gummi worms.
Unfortunate from a good brewery. I guess it didn't come out as planned. Stale nose with a fake fruity rubbery taste. Some raspberries I think in there.
Brite, Kool-Aid red. Ridiculously sweet with a raspberry candy flavor.spacerspacerspacerspacer

cask (RAF): red tinted transparent liquid with a halo of cask-created ugly big bubbles...vinegar, rancid raspberry, and floral alcohol in the nose...soapy thick mouthfeel with raspberry notes, urine, soap, and raspberry soaked cardboard.

Garnet red in color. Raspberries and sweet malt in aroma. Alcohol evident with frutiness that takes center stage. Slightly thin and is in need of perhaps more malt to balance. Overall enjoyable to drink.
On tap RAF: Sweet candy-like raspberry aroma erupts from the glowing red body. Body is smooth and well balanced with a semi-bitter finish. Nice beer characteristics for a fruit beer.

Spicey, fruity nose. Tasted like gardenias and tangy spices. Very different...takes some getitng used to, but very good. Extremely floral in all facets of the experience. The description claimed to have used 200 pounds of fresh apricots.
Had this in the sampler too, I thought it was way too hoppy and too similar to the red and the ipa. I’d like to think I can tell the difference in styles but they pretty much all blur the line.

On-tap at the Natick location. Part of a sampler, trying to do my part and explain the differences in beer styles to my woman. Probably a typical and obvious offering to attempt to convert a drinker of A-B products. Hoppy though.

Draught pint at Owen O’Learys 4/24/06. Pours a bright golden color with a white fluffy head. Nice lacing throughout the glass. Nose is lightly hoppy with some grainy malt tones. Flavor has some light malty flavors nad had more of the hop presence throughout. Hops were very prevelant and controlled the beer.

On draught at the Framingham/Southboro location, 5/6/2005. Pale-gold, small, rapidly dissipating white head. Aroma of light grass and hay, some grain husks. Flavor is very watery, with a fleeting malt sweetness, low bittering hops, mainly just a hint of grassiness. Finish is just chalk full of soapiness. Once you note the soap, the beer becomes very difficult to finish, as the soap really stands out. Light body, mostly attenuated, lively carbonation. 3/2/3/1/6 Rerate. Wow, this is pretty much a completely new beer. Much more malt body, gives a firmer texture on the palate, and while the carbonation is still too heavy, there is NO soap! Hops are aromatic, of light lemon and herbs, with low bitterness in the flavor. Some minor fruitiness gets swallowed up early, and there is a touch of light honey, with plenty of barley flavor on the end as well. The head was retained throughout the entire pint and even left large lacing. Score is for this version.

Has a light golden color and a lightly hopped smell. Taste was pretty watery and very Budweiserish. Overall I did not like this beer too much, in fact most of the beers I tried from this place did not sit well with me.

Has a nice amber color and a hopped smell. Taste was again watery malts, but then finished with a nice hop flavor and was more bitter than the their IPA... Overall this was one of the better offerings from this brewery, but still nothing spectacular.
Pours a black from a tap, slightly off-white head. Aroma was nice and roasty malts, maybe a slight hint of smoke, flavor was thin and lactic like a watered down milk stout. Meh.

On draft at Southborough location (Natick location no longer exists). Definitely not as good as their IPA but an OK stout for the style and better than I remember them serving at the old Natick location.

On tap at the Framingham location. Beer pours black/very dark brown. Head is a mocha brown, relatively non-standard for Irish style stouts. Good lacing, which surprised me a bit considering the beer isn’t nitrogenated. The selling point for this beer is its flavor, which has tons of coffee and a bit of smoke mid-palate, finishing with a silkiness and a lingering tart flavor that I assume comes from the rather mild dose of hops. It is a smooth, thin, clean, and rather well-carbonated stout that stands up well on its own, and is divine when mixed with the O’Leary’s IPA in a Black and Tan (even if the stout doesn’t layer well). Wonderful brew that I’m sure I will enjoy again and again.
Got this on tap and found it to be a little undercarbonated but full of flavor. This is a typical stout but with a little less force.

Has a very dark brown color with little carbonation and a roasted malt smell. Taste was again watery roasted malts and finished with a kind of sour bitterness. Overall I did not like this too much or much of the others from this brewery due to the watered down taste they have.

Has a nice amber color with little carbonation and a malted smell. Taste, beleive it or not, was not watered down. It was nicely malted and finished very smooth. Overall this was the best beer I have tried from this brewery due to the fact that it did not seem to be watered down.
Smells very strongly alcoholic. Tastes similarly strong, but it’s surprisingly easy to drink. Definitely one to have in small doses. On tap at the Rubicon brewpub.

looks like a typical bw, smells on the sweet side, with some wheat and cool malts in there as well. not very balanced, but quite tasty. the body is just great. thick and full without being cloying. flavor is a tiny bit hot, sweet, and complex, lots of different sweets here. good stuff. i’d buy in a bottle."

On tap at the brewery. Aroma is malty, and gives up some of the high abv. Flavour is so much more floral and fruity. Even burps up fruity! One of the best barley wines I’ve had. Palate is verydry which keeps you wanting to drink more! Best Rubicon beer I’ve had!

Sample at the brewpub. This brew is a clear dark amber color with a medium foamy off-white head that recedes steadily. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Dark fruit and sweet malt in the nose. Full-bodied and chewy with flavors of caramel malt, ripe fruits and wheat. The finish is fruity with a sweet malty aftertaste. Decent beer overall.

From tap at Beachwood BBQ. Pours hazy dark amber with a small tan and creamy head. Aroma is wheat, fruity and phenolic. Smooth fruity, solid hoppy and dark toasted malty. Bitter and dry malty into a slight hot finish.

On tap at the brewpub. This one pours a very rich reddish amber color with a very thin off white head. The aroma is sweet with cherry syrup, oranges, caramel. The flavor is similar with some floral hops and mostly syrupy sweet dark fruit. The alcohol is definitely noticeable. This lacks the complexity of a barley wine.
(Draught) Pours a clear deep amber body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of bread, orange, caramel, and florals. Flavor of orange, cherry, bread, caramel, dough. and toffee.

Sample at the brewpub on 8/7/10. Pours clear red/copper with a minimal head. Aroma of caramel (not just caramel malt, but caramel candy) and cherries. Sweet and syrupy flavor with cherry and caramel before a boozy finish. I was digging the sweetness in the nose, but the syrupy flavor kinda turned me off. Still not bad overall.

Not an overly powerful aroma, malty and fruity. Dark copper color, tiny head that disapated quickly. Perfectly clear. Interesting flavors, very sweet.... malty and fruity. Strong strawberry taste, some cotton candy. I dont think these flavors were produced with wheat, barley, hops and yeast...... extract maybe? Couldnt tell there was wheat in it. Very syrupy in the mouth. Slight alcohol heat..... but it is 11-12%. Overall this was a very nice "beer". Totally unique. Reminded me of a dessert port.
11th October 2008. GABF. This version a lighter 10.5% abv! Clear dark amber beer. Sweet aromatic barleywine. Just a little hop in the finish.

Hazy copper with thin foamy lacy head Aroma is tart fruity Flava is tart oaky sweet grainy hints of citrus and berry and tobacco Feels medium to light and silky Finishes mildly tart with notes of oak and limeade
On tap at Tuulensuu Tampere. Aroma of light tartness, apples, lemon, malts. Medium body and tartness. Easy drinkability.
Keg at craft beer experience. Pours golden, nose is funky, hay, sherbert, taste is quite sweet, funky, dry.
Keg, or box? Clear amber. Nose is apples, leather, tart, little funk and woody. Tastes quite sweet, only a bit funk and leather. Ok, easy.
Sweet and sour gueuze. Quite tart, think gooseberry, but with a little sweetness coming through. A style I want more of.
On tap in brussels. Amber color, white head. Sweet, sour, quite easy lambic...
Fles 37,5cl thuis als Timmermans Gueuze Lambic. 4%. Gelijk aan Geuze Belle-Vue maar dan iets zuriger. (9-2009).
From old tasting notes. Bubbly orange amber color. Brief beige head. Interesting fruity yeasty malt nose. Tart fruity malt flavor is subdued, yet tangy. Brief earthy sour malt finish.
Sur og let i smagen om de plejer at skal være. Dog ikke så syrlig som mange andre timmermans, så godt kold kan den bruges som hvidvin.

37.5cl bottle. It pours a clean golden color with a fizzy white head. Aroma is tart lemon juice and weird syrupy sweetness. Taste is similarly syrupy with medium sweetness and light acidic lemon juice. No real complexity or funk. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, not sure what goes into this beer exactly
12oz Flasche. Kastanienfarbenes Bier mit cremigem Schaum. Kräftiges Malz und Hopfenaroma. Geschmack auch überwiegend malzig.
Good IPA. Fresh hops and smooth taste. This organic beer is a must. Dark and well balanced.

"yeah...pretty much this "We went for drink ability when crafting the recipe for this". that really says it all, they were going for easy accessable and got it. nothing offensive, but average subdued floral and citrus flavored ipa. that’s about it."

Pours a clear light copper color with a honey aroma. Taste is slightly sweet, with honey notes. Typical light IPA flavor and bitterness. Surprisinglt dry with a light earthy finish left on the tongue. Easy drinking with a true organic flavor.
12oz bottle. Pours golden, white head. Like many "organic" beers, bit off with the constituents, bit rough around the edges. Not much to rec.
Bottle from world beers. Pours a dark amber. Thick white head. Scent is kind of malty. Little hops. Taste is all malt and a little hops. Ok beer.
It’s a good ipa not great not what I aspected when I bout an organic beer. Good aroma good taste not really a bite which I like in my ipas

This beer isn’t horrible and it isn’t great. Kinda in between. The aroma is actually nice, very typical of a west coast IPA. The flavor is there but goes away as it doesn’t leave much of an impression. Its alright.

@ Party Toen / Florence KY - Cloudy medium amber with a 2" frothy head, many bands and swirls of lace. Taste belies the IBU count - caramel malt begins things, adding butter rum and taking charge all the way through the palate before yielding to smooth, but definite, bittering near the back end of the finish. The hops are sufficient for an IPA, but arrive so late that it seems like this is some other style. Actually quite drinkable, and light on the stomach.
(bottle) amber/orange with whitehead. Floral/citrus hops. Flavor is citrus hops, some caramel malt.

column1: John S. Rhodell Honey Vanilla Lager
column5: Hazy yellow with a foamy white head. The aroma was potent vanilla and a hint of spice. Lightly carbonated and medium bodied. The flavor was heavy vanilla with touches of spice. Pleasant drink and refreshing.
Tap at the brewpub. Slightly hazy deep yellow pour with a clingy white head. Mild grain and honey sweetness. Decent for the style.

Probably the most popular pilsner brew from Sarmat, in Ukraine. I dont like this one, its pretty annoying to drink. A bright pilsner with a sharp blade is what it is. The broadness in its taste is irritating you somehow and you will quickly understand that this is not what you like to drink. Its made to get drunk by only. I dont like it at all, and are unhappy if im only left finding this in the "stores" when im in the east. Bad brew, unpleasant to drink. Crap. You must though understand that the beer brewers in Russia have the hardest possible time to attract market. They will do their best in making quality stuff as 1 litre of their cheapest but quite fine vodka costs as much as one half litre of this brew. They do their best in creating their beers. This one is their worst beer of all.
Golde with almost no head. Not much of anything, sweetish maybe... Not very exciting.
Golden. Slight sour aroma. Some bitterness to be found. Oh well...yet one meaningless again....
Dark amber. Hensfood with some prune. Some smoke and raisins in the flavour, though thin.
Light brown color. Hens food aroma. Chemical, somewhat sour hens-food flavor. Yuk...
Colored almost like honey, and smells alittle in that way as well. Has a quickly disappearing head. A somewhat bitter taste
Pale yellow with no head and some carbonation. Some bitterness and pepper in the flavor. Nothing special
Golden, frothyheaded and meaningless beer. Czech wannabe with no bitterness.
A great name, a not so great beer. Golden with a frothy head. Watery with not much from anything.
Yellowish and thin. I'm wondering why they called it pilsner: I couldn't find here any hop aroma or taste. Even malt was uneven...

Bottle. Amber Gold. Strong, smooth, sweet (almost syrupy), malty (caramel), fruity (oranges) beer balanced by earthy flowery hoppy bitterness. Almonds? Nice sweet-bitter balance. Very warming alcohol. Liked this. Decent. (2008)
bottle lieve ambrato dilo velata discreta schiuma media persistenza discreto malto un filo etilco buona nota amaro lieve agrume file fruttato leggere pepato riscaldante
From 500ml bottle. Very dark drown colour with slight ruby hint. Aroma and taste are similar. Treacle and malts with sweet nuttiness. Good drink ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cloudy orange deep amber color, huge off white head. Aroma of pear, malt, sweetness, wood, alcohol, dried fruits. Medium to full body, lively carbontion. Taste of pears, malts syrupy sweetness, red fruits. Too sweet. Slightly dry. OK. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Bottle 0,33 from Metro c&c in Rijeka. Cloudy brownish dark orange liquid with average beige head. Average body, med to light carbonation. Alcoholy taste and aroma. Fruity aroma. Very sweet. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone
bottle from Darts Farm. Deep golden, small white foamy head. Full-bodied, sweet and malty, sirupy almost, with dried fruit and some dry hops in the finish.
Bottle, 500 ml, courtesy of and shared with JFK. Orange colour, white head. Very light sweet malty aroma.. Malty caramel, bready, sweetish at first, bittery finish. Thin to medium body.

Bottled (backlog). Slightly hazy amber colour, small white head. Aroma is bready, sweet fruity, mildly alcoholic and some glueish and toffeeish notes as well. Flavour is very similar, but is quite strong on the stinging sweetness.

500ml bottle from Cheese & Wine Shop, Darlington. Clear deep amber gold colour, foam off-white head leaving lacing and fruity aroma with raisins, apricot. Taste is sweetish, malt, toffee, warming, fruity, plus some grassy bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, lingering dry grassy bitter finish. Nicely drinkable.

0,5 flaske importert av og delt med Ovesen ombord på Fridtjofen nest siste dag i juli: gylden med fint skum som varer. Lett aroma av gjæret plommesyltetøy. Smaken har en elegant bitterhet kombinert med plommer, svisker og annen tørket frukt. Meget god, men på ingen måte det jeg forbinder med en barley wine, til det er den for tørr. Minner mest om en kraftfull belgisk blondine. Alkoholen er holdt eksemplarisk godt skjult.

column1: Free State Bubba's Best Brown Ale
column5: Fairly thin and wheaty. Dark and sweet, reminded me of the time I tried sorghum. I must give this respect though, because I drank it half-flat and it was still more than decent. Fully flat would be pushing it though.

column1: Free State Bubba's Best Brown Ale
column5: Very faint aroma, some hop and malt is detectable, though. Chestnut brown in color, clear, with a lasting creamy head. Flavor is balanced between faintly astringent bitterness and bready, light, sweet brown malt with a hint of toffee. Malty, mostly dry finish. Good session ale.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Pours a hazy amber with a nice white head. Quite sour aromas of cherry... makes it fresh. Quite full. Short, sharp bitter fininsh. Tastes a bit like a mix between Belgian strong ale added a twist of lambic.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: (Bottle 75 cl) Pale golden, slightly hazy beer with a tall, pretty and very white head. Dry, malty, spicy and not very bitter with this traditional artisanal, musty touch - typical bière de Garde. 260603

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle conditioned. Opened with a bang, but beer remained stable in the bottle. Mostly bland and metallic lagerish beer with soft wheat notes. There are nice flavours and not so nice flavours, but on the whole the negative points dominate.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Light malt aroma, average hops contribution but sort of perfumey, citrus, and ? silly putty. Some musty yeasts, honey, and lactic aroma, too. Cloudy light amber, with a few small chunks, topped by decent foamy off-white lacing head. Light, thin body with soft carbonation. Light-medium sweetness and acidity to start, and light salty finish. Some light bitterness in the after. OK, but not a keeper.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: hazy orange colour, fine creamy head and a beautiful lacing, spicy and citrusy nose, corn notes, tart and very dry, rather light-bodied, acidic, short dry finish - thin, fresh and quite pleasant

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Hazy light blond color. Smells like some (bad) lagers. Very poor in the front, dry. Very ligth hoppiness at the end.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottled. Cloudy pale golden. Fruity and sweet, mild , soft and simple.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Hazy yellow colour. Aroma: old and fermented. Flavour: Alcoholic bitter, sweetish, fermented, bitter. Light-bodied and imbalanced. Though it has to be said that the beer I had expired november 2002.
Discontinued. Color varies from pale to deep golden. Medium-to-thin head. Palate is unclean, malty and sweet. Bitterness is too strong and not of hop nature (kind of artificial).
Draft. Dark brown red pour. Aroma is pasties and spice. Flavor is fruity and spicy cinnamon roll fruity.

Draft flight 8/13/04-Pours a amberish brown with a small head. Aroma of caramel. Taste of the same with more caramel on the back end. This medium bodied brew is not bad but comes across more of an amber instead of a Scottish ale.
A Scottish Ale must have a better profile than this. This beer is amber in color, quite pale to the standards. The aroma is mild at best. The flavor is even less so. Any Scotsman would disapprove.

Draft. Very dark brown with a thin off white head. Smoky aroma with some burnt caramel. Similar flavor that starts sweet and finishes a little smokey with a creamy texture. I would order this one again.

Draft at brewpub. Dark brown pour with off thin, off-white head that dissipated quickly. Aroma of dark caramel,earthy with slight smoke. Flavor complex, caramel and dark malts, dark fruit, very earthy with a little smoke. Med/thin body, light carbonation.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was rusty, ruddy brown. The aroma was smoky and earthy. There were mushrooms and bread crust. The taste lightly earthy with some caramel and bread. A thin body, but this is good for the style.

Available on tap at the brewpub, this beer pours a clear dark amber brew with a light beige creamy head with good retention. Aroma has characteristics of caramel roasted malt, a touch of peat smoke, and some light toffee. Taste is lightly carbonated, with taste of smoked caramel malt and no bitterness. Finish is sweet, soft and creamy. I agree with one other posting, this is more of a Scotch-style than scottish ale.

On tap at the Rail House. Nice deep red/amber color, good thick off-white head. Rich malty nose, some caramel too. Flavor was nothing too impressive but still quite satisfying. More like a Scotch-style than a Scottish....malts dominated taste and nose. This was really a beautiful looking ale though. Sessionable.

Mothers milk? No, this is better, much better. The finest example of Scottish Ale as I’ve ever had. I have been back numerous times and this beer has never failed me. Enticing roasted coloring, Sensous chocolate/malty aroma, Full unfiltered scotch malt flavor with a perfect finish that leaves the tongue with a satisfying smack to the roof of the mouth.
Brewer Compares This to an 80 Shilling. Dark Brown Colorig with Sandy Large Bubbly Head. Dry Malt...Dusty. Dry Hops Ending. Tasted Muddled and Unbalanced.
Keg at the Euston Tap in 2017. Clear amber. Aroma of west coast hops, pine and biscuity malt. Zest citrus, peal and caramel flavours.

This is a backlog rating from 2008 from a bottle, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time. Words to describe this beer are pale malts, citrus, floral notes, nice APA.
Okay for watwcing baseball, but not a heck of alot of flavour. Some citrus and a touch of bitterness.

Bottle. Color: Clear golden, frothy white head. Aroma: Hoppy, citrus, floral. Taste: Refreshing over medium hopbitter, hints of citrus, orangepeel and flowers, slightly resinous. Medium body, average carbonation. Nicely balanced. Good beer.
This one is actually quite nice, a classic West Coast pale ale with a mild and almost subtropical nose and aftertaste. Not that much bitterness, but a refreshing ale, just as intended I figure.

resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, pale, golden, amber, orange, light sweetness, medium sweetness, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, very bitter, lightly sour, medium sourness, heavily sour,
Denne øl skulle være tørhumlet, tjo den har måske mere krydret smag, an ikke bestemme hvilke smagsnuancer der er men den virker meget kompleks.

Aroma: sweet, fruity; Appearance: clear golden pour with creamy white head; Taste: follows nose with a nice hoppy bite; well balanced; Palate: medium-light body with short finish; Overall: refreshing. Would get again.

Pours a clear, light golden, straw coloration with a medium, fizzy head. Smells of citrus fruit: tangerine, grapefruit, with a hint of pine. Taste follows the nose, with a hoppy citrus taste of tangerine and grapefruit, with just a hint of pine and biscuity malt coming through. Medium body and carbonation. This is your typical citrus/pine Pale Ale and a very solid one at that. Nothing special, but perfectly nice and easy-drinking.
Farbe, Helles Bernstein. Dezenter Schaum ,Geruch dezent nach Kräuter und Hefe wenig zitrus. Im Mund sehr schlank leichte Bittere, Grapefruit und wenig Malz .
Aroma: Strong dark chocolate note, fantastic. Almost black in color, lasting thin tan head. Chocolate but not much else, a bit watery. It’s good but not fantastic.
Draft at Churchkey. Very dark clear maroon brown color, tan head. Aroma of brownies dipped in coffee. Taste is toasted brownies. Nice.
On tap at Hopcat. The name surprised me. Solid body with dark color. Chocolate aroma and malt.

Bottle poured a black hue w/ a thin dimming tan head. Moderate boozy chocolate aroma. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish of short duration. Tastes are roasted coffee, dark chocolate, dark toast, and earthy hop. Medium bodied. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Scent of shit and throw up with a hint of malt. Smooth with a lasting bite. Eh. Over rated
Bottle, chocolate dominant aroma, chocolate and roasted malts on the aroma, good stuff

Draft to taster. Looks good; a lightly translucent dark brown with foamy beige head. Smells malty with a nice balance of chocolate and mild coffee. Tastes like it smells, but not as chocolatey, with more roast than coffee. Mouthfeel is medium light to medium-bodied. Solid beer.
Touch of smoke not a lot of chocolate, more coffee. There is no smell. Not caramel. Smooth porter not a lot of bready malt. Julie gives 3.5 ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with a brown head. Aromas of nuts and malt. Flavors of nuts with hints of coffee and chocolate.
Kind of an odd one. Not really getting chocolate flavors... mostly just tastes like a wheat beer with roasty malt.

12 ounce bottle at home. Smells some what fruity Light white head. Light yellow with bubbles of carbonation. Really can taste the peppercorns. Smooth. Different and above average for the style. Cheers!

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a cloudy bright yellow color with a medium sized soapy white head that left minimal lacing. The aroma was tangy, sweet and fruity with a black pepper note. The flavor was dominated by strong black pepper followed by faint vague fruits and cracker. Long pepper finish. Medium body. Meh.

12 ounce bottle labled as just "Nicie". The beer is a clear yellow with a white head of foam. Good head retention. The aroma has notes of moderate skunky notes with hints of peppercorn, dried grass, and orange peel. A bit of pith. Taste has dry, floral aspects. Fairly bitter. Medium body and medium to high carbonation.

12oz bottle. Nicie. Pale yellow-tan body. Not much of ahead, looks like a soda. Medium bodied, thin, mild. Kind an undesirable play on an undesirable style. The peppercorns don’t add much, I mostly get coriander and orange peel. Bland malt tones, not a lot going on. Unimpressive.

My bottle does not say spicie, just nicie. Has the by line, tho. $2 @ vintage. Hay yellow color. Smells a tad metallic. Very good soda water like carbonation, zesty. Actually, this comes across like a highly carbonated wheat ale. Becomes a little medicinal in the middle. In the end it finishes a little better than many bitter wheat ales.
Backlog entry: This beer doesn’t stick out in any particular way. Alighted with style, somewhat different with the spice.

Bottle pour light gold with moderate white head that rapidly dissipate. Nose coriander, lemon peel, peppercorns, spruce. Taste very spicy up front almost like cleaner. Peppercorns, lemon, and fruity wheat.

Citrus aromas are present though not as prominent as you might think from the added lemon and orange zest. Coriander and pepper are clear though again not overwhelming. Not much malt, just a touch of biscuit. Color is a pale yellow with a fairly good-sized white head. Taste is peppery, with light to medium bitterness and fairly dry sweetness. The palate is light bodied, just a bit thin, perhaps just slightly lively carbonation and a long finish that starts with just a light hint of sweetness and then goes into a long peppery finish. Overall while it is not might favorite style, it’s not bad. The lemon/orange zest is restrained; the pepper and coriander start slow but come more to the fore and stay there as you continue to drink. Interesting.
Aroma spices/black peppercorns and wheat. The flavor is orange zest, mild coriander, wheat and a citrus/spicy finish.
On tap at Hopcat. Pours cloudy pale. Low aroma. Getting orange and overwhelming malt character. Good wheat beer.
Nice, firm but on the lighter voluminious side. On tap at the brewpub, where cowboys speak with an "eh?"

Deep orange-brown beer, thin white head. Caramel malt aroma faint cherry aroma with a touch of toast. Thin body. Flavour is semi-sweet up front, thin through the middle, fairly tart finish. No peat, no chewy malts, WTF? Doesn’t really do it for me.
Golden-brown colour. Lightly malty, with hints of toffee in the aroma. Slightly tart, but otherwise a light, clean, vaguely toffeeish affair. Faint cracker note in the finish.
Sparkling brown with tan head.Great carmel malt nose. Lightly carmelized malt flavor with no noticeable alcohol heat
Easy brown look with small head and an aroma of honey roast, but wet sock as well. Caramel and honey roast flavor, but rather dank and musty at the same time.

Last rating was in 2003 and it’s been that long since a Honey Brown has appeared on the Dix menu. It sucked then but it’s been completely revamped now. Hazy amber-brown colour. Light crackerlike aroma. Toasty, lightly toffeeish malt character. Hints of chocolate. I’d say it pretty much picks up where the last Big Ridge Honey Brown left off and travels further towards the brown ale style. Not bad...I’ll be back over the long weekend to take a closer look at this.
Sparkling light brown with beige head. Very light sweet malt nose.Light rather bland malt flavor with a slight dirty line taste
Black with brown head.Burnt carmel nose and flavor with bitter dry malt end.Slightly on the thin side

On nitro tap at the brewpub. 5.0% ABV. I was wondering if this was the same beer as Breakfast Stout when I first saw the listing on this site, but Coffee Stout is lighter with much lower ABV and is served on nitro tap rather than being naturally carbonated. I really enjoyed this stout- even though it was served a bit cold the roasted coffee and malt created a pleasant aroma. Flavor was packed with dry roasted coffee beans and nice roasted malt, creating a smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Bitter aftertaste. Surprisingly tasty for a beer with nitrogen carbonation and a nice complement to their Breakfast Stout.
On tap at brewery, Nice dark brown with medium fluffy brown head, aroma of fresh brewed coffee, nice roasted malt taste with espresso, and a pleasant finish, very nice.
another innovative brew. Nice hints of vanilla to balance out the roasted malts. Great with a steak.

On nitro tap at the brewpub. 5.0% ABV. Poured dark brown with a classic nitro head (thick, creamy, light tan). Served too cold to detect much of an aroma, but notes of vanilla and light roast were apparent. The vanilla works well in the flavor- I did not find it overpowering, and it added a sweet note to the dry roasted malt character. Thin-bodied but creamy. Certainly not the most complex offering but enjoyable nonetheless.

On tap: served way too cold. Nitrous tap didn't do much either. I thought the flavor was fairly dull, not much going on as far as complexity is concerned. Vanilla was not very apparent. I was expecting something sweeter.

A nice dark brown with a good sized head, aroma was of roasted malt and vanilla extract. flavor was overcome by the vanilla, and not in a good way, way too much vanilla, made this sickenly sweet for my taste.

column1: PH Woods Fat Lip Brown Porter
column5: Aroma is malty, sugary, smokey. Well roasted palate with chocolate and coffee. Balacing crispness to the finish.

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: Lager en format 50 cl, avec du maïs, dans le style north american light ... Mon exemplaire était récent, et venu d'Afrique sans passer par les USA. Bouteille verdâtre mais ceci ne pose aucun problème avec un produit industriel, dont la production relève de SOBOA à Dakar. Le maïs me fait penser à des pop corn. La bière elle-même par contre n'est pas très pop … assez corn … et pas du tout rock'n'roll !! La gazelle sautait allègrement par-dessus ce liquide jaunâtre, sur un air rock'n'roll de Stormwind (album de 2001), et s'en allait en rêvant dans le vent du soir ..

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: 500ml bottle from Bien Manger. Golden colour, white foam head and aroma of corn grain, malt, citric, grass. Taste is sweet, malt, grainy, corn, alittle fruity, and light grassy bitterness. Light bodied, spritzy carbonation, dry grainy finish with some residual sweetness. Standard bland pale lager for drinking cold.

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: Bottle from Bien Manger. Fairly light pour with head gone quickly, corny, a bit skunky, but some reasonable hop character. Certainly had worse.

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: Magasin africain ''boniface'' Strasbourg. Dorée claire, légère mousse. Nez houblon frais avec un côté grain pas si mal. Gout malté grain et papier humide avec côté houblonné citronné, sec, typique léger africaine. Corps aqueux, fin avec très légère amertume. Mieux que prévu mais très légère

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: Bottle 0.33l sample at RBBWG 2018 at Beerlovers Bar, Antwerp, Belgium. 10.03.2018. Pour it light golden color with no head. Aroma malty light corn. Taste ah corn, sweet honey, soapy, feel really like corn all the time.

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: 0,33 l bottle. Not very good common lager but after hot day ice cold beer is very good!!

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: 630ml bottle [another big "thank you very much" goes out to Aziz!]. Clear, yellow-ish, pale golden colour with small to average, frothy, fading, white head. Strawy and grainy aroma, hints of maize, a touch of ammonia. Taste is dry, grainy, slightly strawy, minimally soapy; light and watery, fairly carbonated.

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: Dirty 500ml bottle with barely visible best before date. Pours clear gold with an airy white head that last a few seconds. Aroma is very faint: bready, paper, cereal. Taste is watery watery malt. Gassy and watery as hell really.

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: Can shared with JMD on board Fridtjofen 20.12.18. Clear pale straw colour. Diminishing white head. Not much lacing. Aroma and taste of wet cardboard, wet grass and maize. Some bitterness.

column4: Société des Brasseries de l'Ouest Africain - SOBOA
column5: 0,5 boks (takk til Nilsas!), delt med skibsrederen ombord på Fridtjofen mens vi planlegger romjulsbrygging des-18: klar lys gylden med kort skum. Ditto aroma og smak med malt, støv, mais og litt citrus. Første slurken var helt ok, deretter ble det bare verre og verre. Men et nytt land er et nytt land!

12 oz bottle into a pint glass. A: Pours a mostly clear copper color. The head sucks - not even a finger high (eggshell shade) and crap retention. No real lacing, either. Frankly, this isn’t much to look at. S: Wow, this seems pretty treacly to me. Brown sugar, caramel, toffee, and vanilla comprises most of the aroma. Some musty mineral water detracts harshly at first, but thankfully seems to calm down some. In its stead, it’s replaced with some fruity esters. The more it warms up, the more estery it becomes. I still think it’s too sweet, but there is some promise within the aroma. T: It starts decently enough: fruit esters hit the palate first. It kind of goes to crap afterwards. Why? Because it finishes with a one-two ’combination’ of must and plastic. It’s not something that works - rather, it’s something that makes me go "why is this in my beer?!" There are some faint rumblings of brown sugar and molasses on the finish, too. Take away the off notes, and this would be an okay sweet beer. M: It’s a weird mix of sweet and astringent on the tongue, and it doesn’t mesh well. My tongue is left both overly dried out and overly coated in residual sugar. Add in low carbonation, and this beer doesn’t just taste messy, it FEELS messy. O: Every once in a while, DuClaw will surprise me quite a bit - X-1, for instance. All this does, however, is remind me exactly why I don’t buy 6 packs from these guys. If these guys put as much effort into the main line as they do on their limited stuff...well, let’s just say I’d be doing a lot more local drinking. Wait, it reminds me of another thing to say. I HATE CRYSTAL MALT! This tastes like it’s freakin’ loaded with the stuff. Both are good enough reasons for me to never need to drink this again.
Drank from the bottle, a gift from a friend. Good solid, olde English style. Has a strong overpowering smokey flavor. DuClaw has better beverages out there.

Pours a cloudy brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, toffee, grains with mild fruity notes. Taste same as aroma with some mild bitterness. Palate is a medium body. moderate carbonation. Finish is caramel malt, grains, some mild toffee notes and fruity with some bitterness on the end foe balance. This brew seems a bit lacking for an old ale. Overall it still not too bad, a good brew.

Appearance: dark amber, with a short, thin beige head. Aroma: blast of caramel malts, molasses, some nuts, and booze. Taste: burnt sugar (not in a good way), molasses, caramel, astringent alcohol. Finish: overly burny booze, lingering sweet malts. Notes: Not as good as I’d hoped. Overly burnt and boozy for such a relatively low alcohol content. Low rating could partially be blamed on palate fatigue (Beer, Bourbon, BBQ Fest, Timonium, MD, 2014).

Pours deep mahogany brown with little head. The aroma is like apple butter; fruity and spicy, with some caramel malt. Sweet, rich flavor. Strong in the finish. A lot carbonation in the body. This was pretty good.
Pours a reddish amber with a white head. Aroma of grape and caramel. Taste is very grape with barley wine type bitterness and an alcohol burn.
Bottle at blaw. Copper color. Small head. Huge caramel aroma and malt. Grains. About the same taste. Wow. Big caramel malt blast. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nutty, caramel and dark fruit on the aroma. Appearance is brown and hazy. Off white head with poor head retention. Malt forward with a dark caramel character of plums with a light chocolate flavor. Fruity esters are present. Mouthfeel is medium-high. Carbonation is medium low. Alcohol warmth is evident. Overall it's a decent old ale that needs more time to develop more complex flavors and aromas. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Amber orange color, bit of a mild fruit, some mild hop blended with a bit of hops. Overall I thought it was kinda average
Bottle. Pours reddish amber with off white head. Nose and taste of molasses, old fruits, licorice, caramel, burnt sugar, earth and toasted grain. Medium body.
Klar lys med hvitt skum. Aroma malt eple. Smak malt eple humle. Lett øl med moderat bitterhet. Gave fra Roger
Sofiero Original 5.2%. Pale golden, barely detectable pale malt aroma, light bodied, pale malt, hint of lemon, oaky malt finish. Pale lager from Laholm, Sweden 🇸🇪
Et greit øl, men ganske anonymt. Mellommørkt i farge, lite smak og ettersmak. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Burk 330 ml från Systembolaget. Ljus guldgul med mycket skum som sedan stannar kvar på insidan av glaset. Maltig doft med inslag av kemiindustri. Söt och maltig smak, liten beska. Detta är en mycket dålig öl.

Can from Sytembolaget. You know, this is a weird one because it is on the one hand a diabolical tinny lager but then it has this weird fruity (appley?) taste to it which is actually quite nice. Jury is out but hey, I've had worse.
Prakticky tady přidávám tento komentář, jen aby tady něco bylo, protože zpětně dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.
Bottle @ hallinghansen, Mr “if he shows up” Orla and Dedolle’s Siberian cold tasting. Clear yellow body with a small white head. Straws, malt, light.
Bottle @ Hallinghansen, Mr “ifheshowsup” Orla and Dolles Siberian cold Tasting. Pours Clear pale piss yellow with a White frothy head. Watery and short - Very Short nose and flavor. Slight grainy.
Can. Pours clear piss Golden with a white head. Aroma of grains, rough malts, some wierd soapy character. Taste is light malty, grains, light apple.
zapach ciężki, słodowy, kurz, ogonki z jabłek. kolor złoty, klarowny, piana biała, zwykła. w smaku wytrawne, woda, kukurydza, kurz. goryczki praktycznie nie ma. nasycenie wysokie

On tap at New Albanian, pours a cloudy amber orange with a medium beige head. Aroma brings out lots of resinous hops upfront, followed by caramel bready malt and some sticky toffee. Flavour is along the same lines, with resinous hops galore upfront, and a big caramel bready malt backbone. Excellent interplay between the hops and malt. Chewy and balanced. Really good.

Tap. Pours clear reddish orange, small beige head, good residual and lacing. Aroma is piney hops, caramel. Flavor is medium sweet, full bitter, pine, floral and perfume hops, caramel malt. Medium body, some acidity. Lingering bitterness. Meh

Comes out of the bottle slightly hazy dark amber with a thick and fine-bubbled buff head. Aroma has malty and fruity components with a snip of hops. Flavor has strong malty and hoppy components with fruity and cloves hints. Mouthfeel has decent viscosity and fizz, and finishes mainly spicy wood. A good elector indeed.

Draft/growler from the brewery. Not sure what they’re going for here, but it’s good. A darker amber beer, almost brown, this has a sturdy palate. Nice hoppy flourish in there, but an almost brown ale, malty base. Good on a cool night. (#5880, 12/3/2014)

Bomber thanks to Ray. Nose is very piney, earthy, very pungent, strong hop aroma. some honey malt sweetness and caramel in the nose too. Taste is slightly thin, watery and flat initially. Seems like a watered down barleywine honestly. could benefit from more malt backbone and carbonation.

Poured from a bomber into a snifter glass cloudy amber with a thin head. Aroma is fruity malty very subtle hops. Flavor is overly bready sweet caramel with a bitter finish. Can’t place what is off for me with this brew. It doesn’t seem balanced from start to finish. Slightly below the average imperial red-disappointed.

Aroma: Malty nuttiness with caramel; a touch of mild citrus. Appearance: Copper red with a patch of bone head. Flavor: A little more butterscotch than caramel; citrus presence builds toward the finish, but can only be described as "light" at best. Palate: Medium body, tacky texture, soft carbonation, long finish. Overall: Rather shocked I hadn’t rated this, but maybe it’s been that long. A maltier imperial amber that’s pretty clean, but not too exciting.
I am an ale enthusiast. You cannot taste any alcohol sweetness at all. Malty offering with complexity and depth. An absolute treat!

Woody, toasty, toffee, nicely bittered. European style bomber, bad label. Aroma is actually a little muted. Dryish, the bitterness really hits you on the back and sides of the tongue. Medium body, long woody finish with some grass and raisin. Not quite what I expected, but decent. New Leaf Market.

My Bottom Line: Toasted bread and caramel wade in lax residual sugars, as peppery hop bitterness balances out. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam shrouds the cloudy red. -Fruity touches are also felt. -I have no idea if this bottle was close to being fresh as there is no date on it anywhere. -The hop character is rather muddled. -This is on the sweet side for my tastes in the style. Bottle.

MBG Winter ’06. Murky dark copper, minimal head. Nice dark fruits up front, but not much else. Flavor has a strange fruity sourness, almost no malt to speak of, thins out in the finish. Strange take on a BW.

on draft at the brewery, aged 2 years. amber colored with little head and carbonation. fruity and alcoholic aroma (rum and dates), with a rather english yeastiness. a bit thin and unfortunately a bit phenolic but not bad in the least. would benefit from a fuller, maltier mouthfeel.

Draft at MBG Winterfest. Poured hazy copper color with a medium frothy head. Good sweet fruity aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Sour dark fruity flavor with a long finish with a small alcohol tone.
Golden color. Crisp but uneventful. Very weak in flavor for a barley wine. Quite an upsetting discovery.

Not a whole lot to smell. I put my nose right down into the glass,too. The taste was overpowered by the alcohol and there was an odd maraschino cherry aftertaste. We'll give this another shot when we visit the bistro this Summer!
Cask at the RAF. Not much nose here, even with the high alcohol. Some type of earthen grain and oat taste. Thin textured with some spiced apple alcohol thrown on top of malt.

cask (RAF): transparent amber with aromas of cherries over grand manier soaked angel food cake and pinches of salt..Strong alcohol kick in the mouth with fruit cocktail after all the water has evaporated..slighlty warming..smooth mouthfeel w/ tinglers of cherries and bitterness in the end..somewhat sweet also.

This was less than impressive. The bartender tried to sell this to me as a belgian golden. This has just a hint of horsesaddlle, wet cardboard, some coriander and clove. Just comes across tasting sweaty.

Bottle; 2003 RAF: Hazy auburn liquid. Fizzy foam. Soft aroma of fruit, vague spices, soil, and cardboard. Citric undertones. Mild metallic flavors. Earthy qualities. Light acidity. Soft, watery palate. Further evidence of the American struggle to brew a proper, respectable Saison.
bottle (RAF): big soapy, yeasty, brown sugar aroma..metaliic and bitter and semi-watery mouthfeel..smoked chocolate malts lead you to an astringent ending and aftertaste.

Bottle from the Shops at Dartington. Appearance - deep amber with a nicely proportioned head. Nose - brown bread. Light caramel and possibly ginger. Is there a bit of red fruit in there? There might be. Taste - caramel shortbread without the chocolate. Palate - creamy and medium bodied. Fairly dry finish. Overall - good example of the style.
Bottle shared with Ashton McCobb. Pours clear golden with a thin white head. Aromas of caramel, light ginger, red fruit. Taste has brown bread, caramel. Chewy finish.

Pint on cask at The George Inn, Blackawton, Devon. Pours clear mid brown with a cream head. Aroma: bready malts, lightly floral, fruity. Taste: light bitter, caramel malts, toffee, twigs, hint of grass. Medium body, soft carb, light bitter finish. A bit dull
Cask @ Navigation Tavern Autumn Beer Festival 2017, Mirfield. Clear copper with a creamy head. It is very light textured with a low to medium bitterness.
Fra flaske 500ml på TapHouse Newton Abbot 27 Apr 17. Delt med Rune. Mørk gylden. Skum langs glasset. God maltaroma. Smaken balansert. Lett fruktig men dominert av malt. Godt øl.

500ml bottle shared with Finn at Tuckers Maltings Taphouse. Clear copper coloured body. Patchy layer, fragile lacing. Doughy aroma with citric hints. Bread, toffee and red fruity impact to the flavour character. Slightly jam-like. Dry, bittersweet finish. Smooth. Decent version of the style (Newton Abbot 27.04.2017).

Bottle 500ml. Light unclear medium orange colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate hoppy, orange - citrus. Flavour is moderate sweet and light to light moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120806]

Bottle. Golden brown with a very large foam. Aromas are yeasty with stewed apple and weetabix. Bready with light lemon and some wheat. Flavours are earthy, ripe apple with pear and toffee. Yeasty with citrus on the finish. OK.

Bottled@chriso. Amber colour, small slightly off-white head. Aroma is caramel malts, fruits, nutty and some floral and grassy notes as well. Flavour is fruity, floral, caramelly, mild nutty notes as well as some bready and crystal malty notes.
bottle at chrisO ... copper ... thin white lacing ... soft zezty toffee ...light grassy nose ... soft fruits ... light toffee and again grassy ... ok

I haven’t seen this beer in a long time and there is no reference to it on the Wickwar website, so I suspect it may be retired. All I can remember about it is that it wasn’t memorable when served in Bristol pubs. A slightly malty bitter, but there are numerous better examples of the style.

Cask Conditioned, at the Market Porter, Borough, London. Amber with a small to medium beige head. Sulphurous aroma. Bitter and sour flavour. Dull malts with moderate bitter length. Overall, a dull bitter.
Sampled cask conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden. Nut brown. Fruity with obvious strawberry flavour. Sweet and solidly malty with salty, really bitter finish. Strawberries!?!

Can. Copper colour, no head and low condition. After a day at work my trousers smell more like beer than this swill. Slight cranberry juice flavour in the mouth, but that is way too expensive to be an additive (23p per can). Truly a waste of malt and hops, regardless of how little of each they used.

Redruth is an ancient Cornish brewery that is now under the control of a Hong Kong company that seems to care little for quality. This is a cheap and nasty canned product available in supermarkets. Attractively coloured rusty water. And again... I bought a four pack of this (or was it six?) - I've tried various ways of drinking it - including mixing it with some of my strong home brew. Yesterday I was looking for something light to wash down my meal, and this served quite well.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Luscious toffee and juicy cherries are defocused by a babel of slightly metallic carbonation which quickly benumbs pleasure...Earthy hops and fresh cereal redeem the moment but those furious gas jets are still a bit overexuberant...

column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: (10/2006. Draft.) Aromas of caramalt with a hint of hops. Clear, light amber, tending toward the golden end of the spectrum. Predominant character is of caramel with some slight bitterness, but this beer is actually very well-balanced. Medium bodied. Medium-high carbonation.

column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Tap. I had this at a casino just across the border in Nevada. Slightly sweet and musty with a golden color.
Typical American lager. Not much to smell, not much to taste. Crisp and refreshing. Overall pretty generic.
Tap. Light golden color with a white head. Light yeasty flavor. Crisp but not altogether interesting or good.
"more clove and banana flavors than usual, this is a better than average hefe. still not my favorite style, but very crisp and refreshing. recommended during summer."
(tap at Fuddruckers at what used to be the Blue Frog and Grill) hazy yellow gold colour with a small white head; slight aroma of fruit; simple flavour, very forgettable
Hazy yellow with a fizzy white head. Sweet wheat bread aroma. Tastes of banana bread and light clove. Decent.

On tap at the brewpub. It pours pale cloudy yellow with a white head. The aroma is sweet wheat bread, bubble gum and mild clove. The flavor is sweet bubblegum and a little clove. Yeast character is not very strong. A little too sweet for a hefeweizen if you ask me.
On tap at the brewpub Appearance: Pours hazy yellow with a nice big white head with some lacing in the glass Aroma: Banana esters Taste: Watermelon, banana esters and spices Decent

Bottle: &nbsp Pale yellow, fairly cloudy, large frothy white head, dies quickly, sparce lacing. &nbsp Wheaty nose, very faint citrus aspect. &nbsp Mild wheatiness on the tongue, slightly mealy, no real citrus. &nbsp Fairly clean, albeit not overly flavorful. &nbsp Light for the style, but at least it doesn’t have really any off flavors. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate, feels a little bubbley. &nbsp A little plain, but not off. &nbsp Light quencher for the summer. &nbsp Better than I was expecting.
Slightly hazy yellow with a fizzy white head. Grain and fruit aroma with a soapy grainy taste. Blucky.
On tap. Hazy yellow with a creamy white head. Fresh, citrusy nose. Medium body, again more citrus than banana and some yeasty accents. Dry and phenollic finish. 250709
From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild citric to acidic estery and wheaty. Dry estery banana fruity flavoured. Slight phenolic and dry finish.

Draft at the brewpub. An unclear light golden beer with a lazing thin white head. The aroms has notes of lemon, wheat, and chlorine - is it the water? The flavor is sweet with odd wheaty notes combined with notes of yeast, banana, and cholirine, leading to a dry wheaty finish.
On tap at Blue frog brewing. Pours out a clear crisp golden topped with a white head. nose is corn and some bread malts. Taste is more of the corn sweetness cereal malts and some light hops.

"way more and way better than expected for the style. BF is a solid brewer...only a couple mediocre beers, and a bunch of tasty ones, if nothing truly exceptional. big body for a blond and a crisp malty backbone, with just enough hops to notice."
Light gold color. Sweet aroma. Big hoppy bite and a slight sweet finish. Much more flavor than your average blonde. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
(tap at Fuddruckers at what used to be the Blue Frog and Grill) clear yellow amber colour with a small white head; slight aroma of fruit; neutral flavour with a light bitter finish, very forgettable
Pale golden color with a nice white head. Nice rich flavor for a blonde malt and some spicy/floral hops. Nice balance. Not much aroma some floral/spice elements.

15 June 2012. Bottle. Yellow, clear, no bubbles. Nose is grassy and sweet. Med/thin body and a tad creamy and faintly fizzy. Tastes of stale grass and some caramel malt. Meh. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a golden straw color with a floral aroma. You can really smell the hops in this beer. Taste was a little hoppy throughout with a bitter aftertaste. Overall, a clean tasting beer with a surprising bitter aftertaste that changed this beer from enjoyable to just okay.

On tap at the brewpub. It pours golden with a white head. The aroma is mild berries with a hint of noble hop. The flavor is sweet white bread with a strong bitter noble hop finish. Mild cardboard in the background. Nice hop character, not so much with the malt.

Went to blue frog in fairfield today. pretty nice place. ordered this. My wife ordered the sampler tray. I wasn’t disappointed, but wasn’t really impressed. Beer was kinda heavy feeling. I was thirsty. Didn’t really do the trick. Nothing really great about the food at this place either, except the fries. The fries were awesome. This beer is ok, but i didn’t want to take a bottle home with me.
On tap at brewpub Appearance: Pours clear light copper color with a small white head and some lacing left in the glass Aroma: Pale malts and citrus Taste: Malts, slightly bitter flavors and citrus OK

"for the high abv, definitely on the thin side. this is probably a beer to NOT be served draft style to be fully appreciated. as it was, it was very smooth, but all the great flavors were too weak to stand out."

Nitro. Dark amber brown beer with a big dark cream nitro head. Sweet malt and light roast aroma. Caramel and light roast flavor with light nuttiness and light cookie dough. Medium bodied. Nutty caramel lingers with light roast and light sweetness.

From tap. Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Aroma is vegetable and roasted malt. Dark malty and roasted flavoured. Mild acidic note. Dry malty and medium bitter finish. Simple and straight forward.

Light aroma of toasted malts - darkly toasted malts. Dark brown color that is essentially opaque, except that light gets through at the top edges. Creamy head. Thin to medium body. LIghtly, moderately carbonated. Flavor of dark toasted malt, with undercurrents of coffee and chocolate. Mostly toasted flavor, though. In fact the flavor is the least bit harsh. Not really sweet or burnt though. Just sturdily flavorful. A bit different from many of the type. It is relatively smooth, and the finish is dry. Actual hop bitter seems to be detectable in the long finish.

Deep, dark brown with fine, sparse head. Potent aroma of chocolate and woody hops with some vinous aspects. Full, vibrant flavor with balanced sweetness, medium-strong smokiness. Well balanced, creamy finish. A quite good stout. A little too smoky to be optimal for me.
Tap. Black color with a brown head. Smooth nitro tap. Chocolate and coffee flavors.

column1: Blue Frog Horney Toad Barley Wine
column5: Tap. Hazy and murky brown color with a tan head. Vinous, wood, caramel, malts, and sweet.

Tap. Pours hazy orange medium off white head, good lacing. Aroma is grainy, a bit metallic, copper. Flavor is light sweet, medium bitter. Medium body, bitterness on the finish. A bit low on carbonation
On tap. Copper color and sweet aroma. Good balance of hops and malt. Nice 7.2% ABV that is not noticeable at all.
Tap. The brewery called this a California Red Ale. Dark golden color with a tan head. The malts are richer and the body is fuller in this beer than the amber. Some hint of caramel.

On tap. Pours amber color with off white head. Smell is strongly of malts with hops, toffee, citrus and caramel as well. Malt and citrus flavors meet the palate first with a slightly bitter hop finish.

Amber colored pour with a small off-white head. Nose is toffee, toast, and bread. Fairly sweet with a mild hop character, mostly spicy and floral. A very light roast in there. The flavor is mostly just sweet toffee, toasted bread, and some caramel. There’s a hint of roast, some spice, floral hops, and a very subtle bitterness.
From beerboxer’s growler. Pours reddish brown with a modest off-white head and a brown ale and spicy aroma. There is a mild smoked malt flavor with a sweet and dry finish.
Growler shared by beerboxer. Pours orange/red. Aroma is citrus and roast malt. Flavor is roast malt, citrusand citrus.
On tap at buffalo bills. Has a nice red color some hops a lot of malt flavors best buffalo bills I’ve had.

Draft. Rich amber beer with a cream colored head. Malt and light grapefruit aroma. Grapefruit and pine flavor with malt backing. Medium bodied. Grapefruit and pine linger with backing malt. Hoppier than I expected.
Clear light copper red with a fizzy white head. Malty aroma. Nice body to the beer and a well balanced sweet malt and citrus hops with a round caramel finish.

Tap @ Gustosa, Peschiera. Pours clear dark golden with a firm, staying, creamy white head. Aroma is sweet, has some pear-candy quality to it, corn, malts. Highish carbonation, light and fairly ashy dry mouthfeel. Flavour has soft butter, corn, grass, weak metal. Lingering dry bitterness at the finish.
Bottled 330ml from York Beer & Wine. Pale gold with white head. Slightly soured malt aroma leading to a carbonated, sharp tinny flavour. Some perfumed hops notes, pretty standard stuff.

During my stay in Desenzano, Italy I drank quite a few of these. This beer poured a pale yellow. The aroma was a little too perfumey for my liking and the taste was a typical low quality European lager skunky taste. This is a beer you drink just to drink - not for the taste. The more of them you have the better they start to taste!
Alla spina alla Wuhrer, dal bicchiere di Dude. che vi nota un aroma escrementizio; io lo correggo: è spezzatino, anche nel sapore si nota. Una lager fin troppo decente e personale per Peroni...!
Though this might be the wrong beer im writting about, ill change it if im wrong. But i have to say there is nothign to write about here and therefore am not to bothered about it anyway.
Bottled. Sweet perfume aroma. Golden color, white head, good lace. Sweet, artificial fruit flavors, perfume hops, almost like candy, medium body. Strange beer. Bad? No, I somehow liked it a little.

Draught. Compact and enough creamy head, good adhesion and duration. Yellow gold color, a lot kindly bubbly, good perlage. Pleasant and balanced malty scent, fresh grass and hoppy notes on the end. Fresh taste, pungent and pleasant taste, much deciding but not prevailing bitter. Medium end with a good alcoholic tenor. 01/23/2005 [Bottled ratings 3/2/4/2/5]
Not much to say: this beer, like many other Italian lager is nothing special. anyway it seems less watery and more hoppy. almost decent...
If you've had one skunky European Lager, you've had them all apparently. The saving grace for this one is that is DOES have nice malty textures.
Standard lager look: clear golden color and fluffy white head. Unremarkable aroma, round taste. A decent everyday beer.
Can. Watery pale straw, little head. Barely anything decent to taste, awful, bland and weak.

Can. Straw gold almost nonexistent head and low condition. Faintly fruity aroma, stale old hop taste and a slightly oily mouthfeel. What is the point? Its too strong to be classed as non alcoholic, too weak and bland to be of interest to anyone, its only redeeming feature is that it is cheaper than bottled water. 89 pence for 4x440ml cans. The fact that Cains have admitted to "brewing" this amazes me.

Threlfalls was a Manchester brewery which was bought out by Whitbread in 1978. Robert Cain who now brew this lager were bought out by Bodingtons in 1985. When Whitbread took over Boddingtons the Cain brewery was closed down. In 1991 the brewery was acquired by The Danish Brewery Group, along with the rights to the Threlfalls and Robert Cain names. More recently, the Midlands based drinks company, Gardner-Shaw, has taken over Cains. All of which leads to some slightly stained water in a can. Was it worth the effort?

Copenhagen 12/10 2019. 33 cl bottle from Meny, Vermlandsgade, Kbh. S. Simple brown label stating the name of beer and Brewery. 2Stout” in miniscule letters in the background. Pours clear dark brown with a medium-sized light beige head. Bubbly. Settles as thin, almost transparent layer of foam struggling to cover the surface of the beer. No Lacing. Aroma is medium-intense, sweet and with hints of humid basement. Caramel, brown sugar, butter, metal. Some light yeasty odor of basement lurking in the background. Light carbonation. Thin, oily, texture. Flavor has a strong, sugary sweetness. Faint bitterness. Aftertaste is sweet and sugary. Lingers for a while. A bit too sweet for my taste buds. Kind of goes with the style.

Vraiment horrible. La mousse ne tient pas. Le gout est vraiment horriblement sucré. Comme dit sur un autre avis, ca se rapproche nettement plus d'un coca que d'une bière et pour une stout à part la couleur... La liste des ingrédients n'est pas sur l'etiquette et je les soupconne même de rajouter du dextrose ou autre sucre pas cher. Le seul point positif c'est que mon 7eme brassin perso, une stout est bieeeeeeeen meilleur que cette bière là.

Bouteille 33cl Mousse : Fine couche beige Couleur : marron caramel Nez : Sucre, caramel, léger torréfié Bouche : Sucre, caramel, malt cara, un certaine douceur mais totalement dominé par les sucres. Avis : A éviter, encore un machin sucré, plus proche d’un Coca que d’un Stout.
Trop sucrée, pas le goût d'une bière encore moins d'une stout, pas de mousse. Mais je l'ai finie, quand même...

J'arrive pas á mettre 0 mais c'est bien 0 même sur 20. J'adore les stout en règle générale mais là j'ai ADORÉ . Cette odeur de riz moisi et ce petit goût entre le beurre rance et le vomi . j'en cherché une comme ça depuis ma tendre enfance... Ironie. Bref c'est bien la première fois que je ne pourrai pas finir une bière. Désolé pour le brasseur qui s'est tué à produire cette bière.
Nera con riflessi color rubino, schiuma avorio fine e persistente. Al naso ed al palato è dolce.
Bière sombre sans mousse. Au nez on sent les bonbons et au goût cest hyper sucrée à un tel point que je ne l ai pas fini car écœuré. Ne me convient pas du tout.

dd-mm-2019; bottle; at home (bought at an unknown location). The looks of the beer are alright. Big negative feature: the beer foams like crazy. After pouring only a small amount of beer, the glas almost overflows with foam. The light brown foam is frothy and rough and collapses quickly. The beer itself is dark brown with a coppery red glow. The beer is seemingly crystal clear. The beer is a bit lighter than most Stout beers. The aroma of the beer isn't that good. There are some simple malts, giving not much aroma. There seems to be candy sugar or some additional sweeteners, that are little aromatic. No roast, no chocolate, no toast, no coffee. Hops bring a slight herbal note. There is mainly sweet bread malts. Not a Stout in any way. The taste is unbalanced. Waaaay too sweet. The sweetness is also quite boring; seems just like sugar water. Hops are bitter, but the balance is off towards the sweet side. Bleh. The palate of the beer is also bad. Slick beer, medium body and medium carbonation. The finish has sugar water with some bitterness. This beer has nothing good to offer besides the looks. Threw it down the drain.
Bottle at home. Dark brown body with a medium offwhite head. Sweet caramel, malt, chocolate, sugar. Cloying sweet.
33cl Bottle @ Saveur-Biere, Lille, France. Brown colour with a thin tan head. Aroma is malt, sweet, chocolate. Taste is malt, caramel, brown sugar, milk chocolate. Medium body, average carbonation.
Really light in color, and smooth going down. Very obsequious in presentation and flavor.
Light copper with very little nose to speak of. Buttery, bland with just a tiny hint of hops at the end. A major disappointment to many people at the 2003 RAF.

Cask at RAF '03. Copper with little head. Nose is sweet and fruity. Tastes rather sweet, with some odd cloying citric flavors, ending with a medium bitterness. Sam could have kept this a secret and I don't think anybody would have really minded.
Durchschnittliche Schaumentwicklung mit eher grobkörnigem Schaum. Farblich goldgelb und klar. Riecht würzig, minimal muffig. Geschmaklich würzig, geringfügige Malzsüße, wenig herb. Durchschnitt.

0,33 l bottle. Pours out in a mid golden, mighty white foamy head. Mash, malt and grain with sweetness on the nose. Boring taste, little bit grainy, citrus sweetness, grassy, but nothing that can convince.
Old rating, 0,33l, best before 02.2007. Frisch-süffig-würziges Bier. Typisches Export, leicht muffige Herbe, würzig-süßlich und sehr süffig.

330ml bottle. Clear golden colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, white head. Strawy aroma with cautious bitter hoppy overtones. Taste is minimally sweet pale malty, bitter hoppy overtones with a grassy touch in the finish.

Stubby bottle, 330 ml, poured into a lager glass. ABV is 5,2%. Small white head, with a very good retention. Lots and lots of bubbles in the beer, going like crazy to the surface. Colour is pale golden yellow. Very malty aroma, stale bread. Lots of malts on the taste too, giving it a wort flavour. Overall quite sweet. Medium on the body, with average carbonation. Dry on the palate. Average brew, maybe ideal for warmer days.

Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Starts mild, almost too mild for an export. Then more and more spicy, a bit grasy. Light dry notes. Well balanced finish, quite drinkable. Not bad!
Golden with a small white head. Aroma of malt, cereal and straw. Sweet and grainy malt flavour.

Erfrischend süß-herber Antrunk mit erfrischend beiläufig bitterer Note. Später dominiert, wenn auch nur leicht, die Herbe in Kombination mit Malznoten. Aromatisch, harmonisch und erfrischend, angenehm herb. Absolut gelungen! 9/11/11/11/7/11
Bottle. Pale blonde. Grainy aroma with a hint of apple. Malty flavor. Medium bodied. Short aftertaste.

Bottle 330ml. Clear medium yellow - orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, cereal. Flavor is moderate sweet and light light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100417]

On tap at the brewpub, Barrington MA, on 20 April 2010. Labelled as Stockbridge Steam but I guess this is the same stuff. ABV not stated but OG 1051. Clear amber colour. Good carbonation level - lively but not too fizzy. Not much aroma. Clean and refreshing. Dry and slightly hoppy on the palate. Hit the spot fine - a decent example of the style.
