Bomber. Pours amber with a pinkish white head. Smells of caramel with some fruity character. Tastes sweet and peppery with some nice fruity hints on the finish. Enjoyable like all their beers.

22 oz. bottle. Clear amber, small white head. Light fruity aroma, some grain and honey as well. Medium body, very lightly carbonated. Caramel sweetness with little character, some mildly astringent bitterness that results in a fairly dry finish, although some sweetness still comes through as a slight stickiness. To me, thisis basically non-descript and lacking in character.

Bottle: Good nose, I get a nutty, citrusy, doughy aroma. Peanut, lemon/lime, sourdough. Clear orange color. Just a minute amount of haze. Sweet and bitter flavors, peanut butter, lite metallic, lemon. Thin and tart, finishes fairly clean. Interesting, not like other "steam" beers I've had. I don't like the flavor combination.

22 oz bottle. Cloudy medium brown, medium long-lasting foamy off-white head. Sweetish nose of corn, grass, light floral hops. Flavor moderately malty, largely dry, somewhat bready, clean longish finish with light hoppiness. I'm finding it hard to say a lot, good or bad, on this one, but overall it's tasty and drinkable, probably as good as the standard (Anchor Steam) for the style, and another quality addition to this under-known brewery's lineup.

Has a light golden color with a sweet smell. Taste is light and slightly sweet, finishes with little bitterness. Overall I have never had a 'steam' beer before so I cannot compare it to others of the style, but it was a light too light for me.
A very good steam beer. Cloudy and dark tan in color. A bit of hops in the nose. An underlying sweetness that didn't seem to come from the malts behind the hops. Enjoyable!
Draught at Hotel Okuyumoto, Hakone. Clear golden – white head. Light metallic, grainy, hay,straw, light hoppy → pleasant hoppy, dryness, freshness. Plain.
clear golden color white foamy head, smooth slightly hoppy taste, nothing special, its ok

Clear golden color with a huge white rocky head. Mildly sweet aroma with what must be the "Maribana" hops. A watery texture, rather weak taste but very smooth. I'd thought this would be better but it's rather bland. Not nasty mind you, just very plain.

Hard to find as it is a limited specialty brew and is now being cleared off the shelves in Japan at cut rate prices to make room for more "Seasonals". Clear yellow, good head, not displeasing aroma. Flowery hop character is more evident in this version than from what I recall of the normal Ichiban brew. Perhaps a step above the standard Japanese lager, some nice cereal maltiness is detectable but nothing too assertive. I enjoy Kirin’s brews more than most of the other Japanese brews but it is hard to understand why such large breweries do not take more chances to try to produce more radical departures form the norm as they have the resources and expertise to do it.
I’ve had this brew a few times over the years. It’s a good example of a cream ale that has no bells or whistles. It has a smooth taste that does it’s job.

(Draught) Pours a hazy golden body with a small off-white head. Aroma of cereal, grain, sour dough, and delicate apple. Flavor of grain, cream corn, and some chicha qualities with a dry finish. Kind of blah.
(on tap at the brewery in Colorado Springs). Pours a clear yellow color. Medium size white head. Light citrus and malt aroma. Sweet wheat taste. Good lacing. Creamy texture. Soft carbonation.

On tap at Phantom Canyon poured a hazy gold with a small lingering off white head. Aromas of cream soda, carmel and vanilla. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, vanilla and a hint of spice with a smooth lightly sweet finish.

Draught at the brewery. Beer is slightly hazy, light caramel brown. Head is small, off-white, frothy, mostly lasting head.The aroma is malty with light notes of caramel and cookie, trace notes of husky toasted grain; Hoppy with light notes of floral apricot; Yeasty with light notes of sweat and basement; Trace note of tropical fruit, light notes of green apple peel.The flavor is lightly sweet, lightly/moderately acidic, trace bitter with a moderately long, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish. Unclean aftertaste.The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is soft-average.Slightly husky, mostly OK, nice enough malt character and fruit esters.

Had this beer on 4/23/2003. Aroma is a light sweet malt scent. Color is a pale gold with a slight haze. Taste is sweet and creamy. Starting with a light medium body it goes down with a creamy feel. Finish is a lightly sour/sweet malt flavor backed by a very genteel bitterness. Overall its not out standing but is creamy.

On tap at the Phantom Canyon Brew Pub. Poured a light yellow color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas and tastes of grain and lightly spicy. Subtle as I had to search for both aromas and tastes. Thinner body.

Draught at Phantom Canyon. Pours gold-brass with a small foamy white head and creamy lacing. Sour yeast (sweat) and malt (grain) aroma with fruit (pear, apple) hop notes. Sweaty yeast and grainy malt bitter lightly acidic hop with apple and peach notes. Light to mediium body fizzy and dry palate.

had this in eary july while the family was in the springs for flemdawgs wedding on the 2nd. from the tap. poured gold in color. with a small white head. aroma spicey, malts, sweet. flavor got a strange sweetness, spicey, malts. this was a differant kind of beer I have had a couple of cream beers but I do not remember tham being like this one. not one of my fravorites from this place

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a yellow gold color with a boisterous head that hangs in there, lace and all. Very enjoyable and easy to drink. Quite lager-like in the mouthfeel with a subtle ale-imparted diacyl. Crisp finish.

had in july while in the springs for my son Flemdawg wedding on 7/2.from the tap. finally a beer in my favorite color. poured black with nice tan head that left something on the inside of the glass. aroma chocolate, coffee, malts, floral. flavor this was I think the best of the lot that I tried, got bittersweet chocolate, roasted malts, coffee

The tap poured a black, opaque beer with a nice creamy tan head that lasted well and left beautiful lacing on the glass. The aroma has a definitive coffee presence with nice notes of chocolate in the background. The body was quite full with a creamy, smooth texture and light carbonation. The flavor begins with the bitter-sweet chocolate and then the middle explodes with coffee and roasted malts. The finish is very long and smooth as silk. This was an outstanding stout.
Black with a tan head and good lacing. Floral hoppy aroma. Dark roasted hop flavor. Slightly dark palate.

Deep, black opaqueness. Tan, lasting head. Thickish and creamy mouthfeel. Roasty, with a hint of sourness. Some coffee notes about. A bit of burntness in the finish, which I liked. One of Phantom Canyon's better beers, indeed.

On Tap @ Buckeye: Lasting white head on a hazy, fizzy golden body. Laces well. Bready & toasty malts, and a flowery, perfumey hop. Clovey, banana and raisiny grape aroma. Some sugary sweetness and corn aromas as well. Well balanced, a little on the sweet side though. Lightly bitter in the finish an especially the aftertaste w/ some toasty and cereal malt flavors and sugary sweetness. Some moderate plum fruitiness and a light alcohol flavor as well. Medium carbonation, full, smooth body, but well hidden alcohol. Pretty decent beer, but I still prefer the Dubbel.

I had this a while ago, so I'm going on memory. Crystal clear yellowish color, white fluffy head. Aroma was pure belgian, strong in the candi sugar. Flavor was good, but by the end of the snifter is was too sweet for me. Alcohol was pretty obvious throughout the flavor.
One of the most solid triples out of the U.S. that I have sampled. Liquid gold.

From cask at the brewpub 2/21/03. Deep gold, large fluffy head present til the end. First couple of sips were apricot and sugar. Then it settled in to total melon mania - honeydew and cantaloupe. The finish was full of spice and some hops - stuck to my tongue for a long time. (apparently the cask they took to the RAF didn't hold up as well as the one they kept at the pub)
Stinky. I couldn't put my finger on the aroma and my nose wanted no part of studying harder. Vineous, with fuzzy peach skin added to give it a peach wine flavor. Very evident 10%abv!!!

Cask at RAF '03. A surprise triple. Not like the Tincture. More wine like in approach and flavor. Settles into a medicinal flavor, almost like a synthetic basketball. Other notes of apricot and tangerine present.

Draft at Manchester, CT location. The description of this was "This unfiltered, amber-colored IPA is medium in body and has a citrus hop flavor and aroma. 5.8%ABV. Pale and Crystal Malts with Centennial and Cascade Hops"...Pint. Piney, sweetish aroma with a grapefruit presence. The aroma is unfortunately rather faint. Moderately hazy/hazy amber color with a frothy yellowish off-white head and badass lacing. Absolutely gorgeous! Light piney grapefruity start with mild hop bitterness. This is backed up by a ton of maltiness. Lots of cereal and cardboardy chewiness in the middle. Subdued grapefruity hop flavors to finish. This is a nice session IPA that won’t kill your tastebuds with hops.

@ Framingham location. Good nose, sweet. Floral, piney. Clean orangy copper color. Good head that faded to a ring, nice lacing. Bittersweet flavor. Citrusy, grapefruit and orange. Caramel/toffee backbone. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, grapefruit bitter finish. Solid IPA. I always enjoy this one.
Pours brownish red with a small head. Light hop aroma. Flavor is light citrus and mild hoppiness. Pretty tasty but a little short in the finish. Pretty good.

At the Framingham location. Nice ruby brown color, medium white head and lacing. Nose is pine cone hops. Solid body, syrupy hops and more pine, slightly acidic, bit of citrus, firm malt backing. Strong bitterness at first that levels off a bit. One of their better brews.

Manchester, CT. Cask conditioned hand pulled. Damn this is great. The beer arrives looking very very dark amber, with a tight creamy hand pulled head, interspersed with some larger bubbles. Just the way I like it. Aroma is mild, with a pleasant understated hop aroma, mild malts, and a touch of fruitiness. Flavor is big and hoppy, with a strong malty backbone to carry the bitterness. Hoppy, but well balanced. Full bodied, with that cask temperature and smoothness I've come to know and love. I wish all beer was cask conditioned, because it would be so tasty that way.
Framingham, MA - Has a nice amber color and a hop smell. Taste is of the hops and finishes with the typical hop bitterness. Overall it is a good IPA, but nothing special.
Draft at the Phoenixville brewpub. Pours pitch black with a medium sized brown head. The aroma is a mix of chocolate and roasted malt. The taste is pure milk chocolate.. Quite sweet.

5.0% version at Iron Hill West Chester that the bartender claimed was different than this alias...Pours black with a creamy medium mocha head (nitro)...nice lacing. Aroma of nice dark chocolate...slightly sweet. Flavor has layers of roastiness, sweet dark chocolate, mild espresso, and vanilla. Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with a roasty chocolate finish.
On nitrogen at Iron Hill Phoenixville. Pours completely opaque black with a big head. Prominent cocoa and vanilla taste as advertised. Medium body with oily texture. Pretty good actually.

Nitro at IH Lancaster. Dark body, aroma is blocked by the tall off-white head. Matly-coffee flavor balanced with the creamy head, hints of chocolate balanced with vanilla... vanilla seemed to be prominent

Nitro at IH Pville. Pours a deep brown almost black with a very creamy tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla, lactose, roasted malt and light coffee. Flavor of rich chocolate notes, vanilla, lactose and light coffee.

Nitro at Phoenixville BrewPub (with 17lbs melted Belgian chocolate and 10lbs lactose): Aroma of chocolate, lactose, Belgian chocolate, and light roasted malts. Poured brown/black in color with a medium to large-sized, thick, creamy, dense, beige, brown head that lasted throughout. Very nice head. Cloudy. Not sparkling. Flavor is lightly sweet and slightly bitter. Tastes of Belgian chocolate, light roasted malt, tiny hint of alcohol, and lactose. Medium body. Slightly chalky texture. Nitro carbonation. Slightly chalky, Belgian chocolate finish. Great balance of lactose and roasted malt. 8.3%ABV is very well hidden.

On draft in Lancaster - this beer is dark with a white head. The aroma has a nice hint of chocolate. The taste is roasted malt with hints of chocolate and coffee and it was smooth and creamy on nitro (I think) Excellent Beer!

Draft at North Wales. Dark brown pour with light tan head and aroma of malt, chocolate, oats, licorice. Tastes roasty, with a solid oaty and lactosy milt stout element, coupled with some heavier stout flavors such as licorice and prunes. Very nice.

On tap @ the North Wales location. Listed as The Don Milk Chocolate Stout (they said this was just invented by one their waiters named Don). Waiter kept saying, ’are you sure you want this one, it has caffeine in it?’ On Nitro. Poured a dark brownish/red with a small off white head. Stronger chocolate aromas and tastes. Lighter coffee and roasted malts as well. Medium sweet. Overall not a bad beer - would like to try it without Nitro.
Another quality stout from Iron Hill. Dark beer with a cream colored head. Heavy coffee flavor which is only matched by the tart contrast of the chocolate. Simply wonderful to drink.
Draft at the mountain view location. Amber pour, and some white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, small amount of bready / biscuit malt. Tasted very standard, but just too sweet in my opinion.

16 ounce sample on tap at the San Jose location. Aroma is quite malty, caramelly with some mild fruitiness. There is also a touch of buttery diacetyl and light metal. Ringwood? Transparent orange-amber body with a small off-yellow head with light lacing present. Slightly astringent start, which becomes quite malty, burnt, and toasty. A little buttery diacetyl is also in there. A light, herbal hoppy bitterness is present in the finish. Pretty boring, and a bit flawed.

Draught. Pours dark amber with a small white head. Aroma is caramel malt, citrus hops, and apple. Flavor is the same, plus a bit of roasted malt. Moderately hopped, with an odd apple maltiness and butteriness that seems like a flaw, although it’s more prominent on some occasions that I’ve had this beer than on others.

(Sampler at the San Jose location) Face Off Red is a red-amber ale with a fleeting white head. The aroma is spicy and herbal, like an ESB. It is medium-light in body, pretty smooth, and perhaps a bit chalky. The flavor is well blended and balanced, with a decent bitterness.

Outstanding amber here. Huge malty aroma and flavor. Tons and tons of roasted malt, very rich beer. Body is smooth and full, but not too heavy. Gorgeous red color. Why the heck is this beer only a 3??? Looks like the rest of the ratings are 7+ months old. Maybe this brew just needed some time to mellow out. Or maybe with the most recent batch they’ve finally got the recipe down. Because right now... it is SUPERB. One of the best ambers I’ve ever tasted.

Draft at the San Jose brewery. Looks ok; medium ruddy amber with a suggestion of head for a minute. None of their beers really holds a head. At first, this beer seemed sour; there was soap and aluminum in there and it was disappointing. After a couple drinks, though, it started to stake out a bit of a flavor profile--more of a rye-like sourness and a moderately interesting herbal hop finish. Curious about their hop use, there’s never any classic citric bitterness or resinous overtone, and it’s always clingy. May have more to do with their ale/lager yeast alloy, smearing the flavor note there.

aroma is weak. little cinnamon or maple syrup. smell is medium brown to orange color. flavor inital syrupiness but watery & bland. flavor has a bit of spice little corriander. and maybe a little pepper. peppered stout sounds good

Damned nice for something brewed for a hocky arena! I drink more than my fair share of the Tied House Amber and Dark and was pleasantly surprised by this one. We thank the bar guys that poured it in case we needed to try it. It's very much in the family of the Amber and the Dark ales. A bit more hoppy with good if a bit lighter color. I'd still go for either of its cousins, depending (Amber for Pizza at Premier where it's on tap or Dark at the bar in San Jose.)
Tap. Mahogany color with a tan head. Hoppy aroma with a fruity malt flavor but also kind of light on the palate.
Draft. Pours red with light beige head. Malt and fruity yeast aroma. Bready malt with fruity yeast.

Sampled on draft this beer poured a red-caramel color with a medium sized foamy orange-tan head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was sweet and vegetal with notes of orange and honey. The flavor was sweet, tangy and bready with a vegetal note, golden fruit, a bit of white wine and a hint of medicine. Long finish. Medium body. Ok.

Keg at Appalachian, Collegeville, 29/11/13. Dark mahogony brown with a good sized tan covering that retains well. Nose is dark fruits, sugars, toffee, light spice. Taste comprises dark fruits, straw, brown sugars, light spice, dates. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry closure. So so, lacks any great character and depth.

Despite the fact that one of the great attributes of Belgian beers is that they cannot be contained by style guidelines, I discourage anyone from thinking of this as a dubbel. I’ve heard that there’s been some discussion by the BJCP to distinguish between Belgian abbey ales and American abbey ales, which would allow for better classification of this beer. Medium amber with off-white, evanescent head. Smell is spice, yeast, mild light fruitiness (plum). Rather light in flavor and mouthfeel; spice is dominant with slight cherry and plum underneath. Tasty session beer.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a lightly hazy ruby with a medium beige head. Dark fruit, yeast and candy. Estery yeast. Big sweetness, candy, light bubble gum. More yeasty esters, lots of sweetness. Long pungent bitter finish.

Cloudy, dark copper color, very little head. Scent of spices, with slight caramel malts. A bit thin, but flavorful, the spices also dominate the taste. Thin and smooth, adequately carbonated. Easy drinker; doesn’t really stand out among dubbels or ABC’s brews.
Pours medium to dark amber,opaque and has a thick ,full and tan in color head.Your mouth will be full of flavors malts,hops and dark fruits like a slightly bitter plum
Pours medium to dark amber,opaque and has a thick ,full and tan in color head.Your mouth will be full of flavors malts,hops and dark fruits like a slightly bitter plum.
Deep amber/copper pour with creamy off white head and lace. Brown sugar and coriander aroma. Brown sugar, sour malt, and Belgian yeast on the flavor. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Nice beer.

On tap in Harrisburg. Pours much lighter than I would expect from a dubble. Aroma is dark fruit with a hint of yeast. Medium in body with a fair level of carbonation. Flavor is a bit light, but not bad with typical belgian yeast characteristics and a fair amount of sweet malt.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: simple american pilsner..little thin body..hop end..nice beer for summer sweet..

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: Clear straw color with creamy head and lacing. Malt and earth nose. Smoothing drinking pilsner. A little thin in body but good malt profile with a slight hop bite. But not much else going fore it.

column4: Triple 7 Brewpub at Main Street Station
column5: A new offering. Light colored with little head. Average malt grain aroma. Sweet beer with a hint of bitter ending. In the end, a decent lager.

Maple syrup and whiskey. Not as thick as one would expect, but some sticky sweetness in the taste. Had a vague medicinal nose that was off putting. While malty it did have a touch of light hops in the end.

From the description, I didn't expect something so golden. The nose was smokey and sweet...an old pipe tobacco store smell. Maple syrup was the dominant force, as if they held this glass right up to the tapper on the tree. Alcohol seemed stronger than 6%, maybe due to the whisky barrel aging. Whew, I'd put this on my pancakes anyday!!!

Keg @ Dragonmead. Murky brown pour with a small head. Earthy hoppiness. Woodland / hedgerow Character. Gentle toffee and toasted grain. Well balanced. Skews somewhatssweet. Unexpected chocolate accents. Earthy, Peppery hop. Toasty finish. Actually pretty solid biere.

Sampled from the tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy deep amber with a tan head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has lots of straw and a bit of hay plus a touch of bread. Flavor has light bread and straw with some hay backing.
Bottle, Ann Arbor, MI. Murky appearance. Sweet prune aroma. Sweet. Treacle. More old bruin than esb.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, very hazy dark red pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of tart berry, cherry, caramel, toffee, some nuts, hints of earth, spice, yeast. Taste was tart cherry, berry, some earth, spice, slight grass, bread, toast, plum, finishing fairly sweet, slightly tart.

Bottle. Cloudy reddish brown in color. Crazy amount of carbonation, so the glass was all tan head. Smells of yeast and fruit, with a hint of acid and vinegar. After the head goes down, it has moderate carbonation and a thin, watery body. Sweet and tart, plum-like flavor, with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Okay, but I hoping for more.

On cask. Aroma of mild tobacco, leather, and a touch of fermenting crab apples. Appears a hazy orange-brown with thick off white foam and beautiful lace. Palate is filling, creamy, soft. Overall, very good!

Tap: metallic copper-y body with a solid brown overlay, mostly cloudy & topped with a light beige layer of foam that lasts for only a few moments. Aroma is pretty mild with notes of spicy hops, faint toffee, nuts, some polished wood, & an apparent mustiness. Taste is a little strange... Has the base of a brown ale with malty notes of caramel, nuts, toffee, & slight cocoa powder, but there’s a musty, almost wet cardboard note throughout. Not oxidation... just... cardboard-y in a very surreal way. Some zesty & lightly bitter hoppage throughout. The off-flavor was distracting. I’d like to try this again to see if that was just a fluke or what.
On cask at the brewpub. Rather light mouthfeel and hop flavour. unfiltered, light brown and lacy. OK drinkability.

Just barely an ESB in terms of bitter, but good. Golden color. Unremarkable nose. Balanced and light. Update on cask: beautiful beer. Great gradient and head. Very rich. Pretty malty, oatmeal. Still not much bitterness.
bottle. Amber with small head. Fairly average ESB style, which is to say that it’s much better than the other Dragonmead brews I’ve had.
Tap. Cloudy golden, white head. Malty, slightly grainy aroma, hoppy notes. Bittersweet flavour, malt and bitter, slightly spicy and floral hops.

0.4 litre glass at the brewery on 28th Oct 2018. Slight haze to the golden pour, snow white crown. Grainy nature to the nose and taste, lightly hopped with a floral and mild citrus leaning if you sniff and sip slowly/deeply. Pleasant enough, but without getting me excited.
Frisch vom Hahn in der Brauerei getrunken. Für den Norden recht mild und leicht blumig hopfig.
Vom Fass im Brauhaus in Flensburg. Trüb gelbes Bier mit dünnem Schaum. Herb grasiger Getreideduft. Kerniger Antrunk. Zitrone, Apfel, Hefe. Sanft säuerlicher Abgang.
God smag af malten i øllen, en lille smule gær gør desværre at den ikke helt når de sidste point.
On tap at the brewpub. Leicht trübes goldgelbes Bier mit einer geringen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch getreidig malzig, leicht hopfig. Geschmack angenehm hopfig bitter, grasig, Getreide.
Draught @Brewpub. Slightly hazy, golden color with a thick white head. Light citrusy, hoppy, grassy aroma. Flavor has citrusy notes, grass, hay. A fruity pilsener, quite tasty.
From tap at the brewpub. Clear golden colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops and fruit.
light fresh sweet malty aroma,yellow,cloudy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light fresh malty beer.

03.08.2014, tap @ Hanssens Bräuerei, Flensburg: Nice creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly dry, hay, flowers, weeds, grain, grass, light malts. Taste is slightly grainy, hay, grain, flowers, grass, cereal, weeds. Medium bitterness, slightly dry grainy mouthfeel. Nice one.
Hansens Schwarzbier 5.2%. Blackish brown, nutty aroma, medium bodied, toasted caramel malt, biscuit, oats, hob nobs. Lovely Schwarzbier from Flensburg, Germany 🇩🇪

Beautifully light durable foam. Good aroma of hard-roasted malt. In the beginning, its roasted malt tastes the most, but later the taste contributes with slightly sweet dark chocolate which in turn is carried on to light taste of coffee and a little smoke. Very tasty Schwarzbier with good taste.

0.4 litre glass at the brewery on 28th Oct 2018. Lovely dark brown body, slight ruby hue to it, on top a smooth tanned blanket of foam. Malty little number all round really, not a lot happening in the hop department with the malty molasses taking complete control. Must be some hops about though because the sweetness doesn't run riot and even calms down mid sip. Liked this.
Frisch vom Hahn im Brauhaus getrunken. Fast Braunschwarz mit intensiven Röstnoten. Karamell- und leichte Pfeffernoten im Nachtrunk.
Vom Fass. Dunkelbraunes Bier, feiner beiger Schaum. Haselnuss RöstmalzAroma. Antrunk ist leider recht wässerig. Erwas Röstmalz, Kaffe. Auch schnell weg. Zum Glück nicht so süss.
Dark brown, almost black. Sweet with toffee-tones and light coffee. From tap in the brewery restaurant in Flensburg.
Tap at the brewpub. Dark brown color, tan head. Toasted malt, light caramel, a hint of sweet coffee. Sweet, malty, clean, balanced on the finish. Light body, easy drinking. Classic, simple.

Draught @ brewery w sister. Appearance: pours clear dark brown with small soapy beige head and lacing. aroma/taste: bread, caramel and chocolate. palette medium roasted malty aroma, average carbonation, medium body, average sweetness, somewhat balanced by a light to medium bitterness, average duration and a watery texture. Overall: ok caramel dominated schwarzbier
En god schwartzbier, med ristede noter og en del sødme fra malten i øllen...
On tap at the brewpub. Dunkel orange braunes Bier mit einer geringen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, Karamell, etwas Kaffee. Geschmack sehr karamellig, süß malzig, schokoladig, lecker.

bereits 2010 getrunken und erst gestern wieder. EIn Bier mit Geschichte und Geschmack - auch wenn es inzwischen von einer industriellen Brauerei kommt. EIn uriges, solides Helles, das nichts übertreibt. Es hat einen angenehm getreidigen Geschmack das eine schöne Balance zwischen Hopfen und Malz, so wie es heute wieder sehr gefragt ist. Keine große Spezialität, aber ein wirklich schmackhaftes Bier.
Draught at gasthof Willbald hentch. Tiny short lasting white head. Clear malty aroma and taste. Big drinkabillity.
500ml on tap at the Cafe Drechsler, Vienna. Aroma is malt. Appearance is pale yellow with a small white foam. Taste is light bitter. Ok.
Täiesti ok õlu. Midagi nuriseda pole, kuid midagi väga kiita ka pole. Lihtsalt joomise õlu.

Klare, gelbe Farbe mit weißer Schaumkrone. Malziger, hopfiger, leicht getreidiger Geruch. Geschmacklich malzig, leicht getreidig, leicht grasig. Mittlere Süße mit leichter Bitterkeit, mittlerer Körper mit spürbarer Kohlensäure.
Hellgelb bis gelb, feinporiger weißer Schaum. Hopfennoten, fruchtig leicht, prickelnd im Mund.

Bottle from Spar in Hainburg a/D Austrian brewery no.28, almost done with Slovakia, time to look after neighbors ;) This is one of the better helles I had so far. Unlike many others it's missing metallic notes (finally!) Malts are decent and it's not even sweet. Good job.
Aroma: malt, earthy hops, honey. Taste: solid malt flavor. Moderately sweet. Bittersweet aftertaste.

Tap at Gasthaus Seidl, Vienna. Pours clear bright gold with a small white head leaving good lacing. Aroma of grain, grass, straw, veg and yeast. Medium sweetness and moderate and slightly odd bitterness. Toward medium body, slight oily texture, average to soft carbonation. Okay to start with but went a little downhill.

0.5l bottle. Malty and yeasty aroma. Clear, extra pale yellow color. Low white head. Malty aroma. Light body, watery texture, moderate carbonation. Malty aftertaste with small bitterness. Average beer.

On tap at the brewpub. Deep amber-copper color. Nose is lightly sweet caramel and toasted malt. Flavor initially showcases the caramel/toasted malt backbone but gives way to an herbal/wood/earthy hop flavor that cuts through the mild sweetness and draws out into the finish. Nice character and palate presence.
A light brown clear with lacing off white head. Smell of hints of carmel and spicy notes. A well drinkable beer.
(Draught) Pours a clear golden body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of mustiness, grain, grass, and nuts. Flavor of nuts, grain, biscuit, and caramel malt with a dry, bitter finish.

Draft at the OF. Orange brown-tan color, looks filtered. Nice foamy beige head. Malty aroma with a touch of citrus fruit. Crisp and woody, with a nice sandy dark malt sharp aftertaste. This really hits the spot, capturing the best parts of Brown Ale, Lager, and hoppy APA all in one. Quite astringent and soapy at times, but still achieves an excellent balance with the deeper dark malts. This is a great California Common!

On tap at Titletown Brewing Company. Light amber with a medium off-white head. Aroma of light hops and malts – nothing really stands out. Semi-thin body with lightly toasted malt, light biscuits and a touch of planty vegetal hops.

Another mighty fine brew out of Titletown. Sampled from draught:pours clear copper colour with a medium sized white head. Full of nutty and lager-like aromas it is lightly carbonated, and rich in malt flavor. a very long, lingering hop finish compliments this fairly strong tasting beer.
Pours a bloody amber color with a lot of lacing. Aroma is lightly hoppy and malty. Taste is like an APA but finishes malty biscuity.

Got the last glass served on draught at the brewpub/restaurant in Green Bay, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-clear amber brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that leaves behind a fine film and thin ring. Some spotty lacing. Aroma of sweet caramel and light bread malt, a touch of citrus zest and some dried light fruit. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with fruity flavors of caramel malt and light citrus zest. Finish is slightly dry at first and then clean cut.
Appearance is amber with light off-white head with abundant lacing. Aroma is of light hops, sweet biscuity malt, and light caramel. Taste is the same with a slight crisp, dry finish.
Liked it quite a bit better than Anchor Steam, actually. Full-bodied and flavorful.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee India Brown Ale
column5: On tap at Rock Bottom Milwaukee as Brown Bear IBA. Dark brown with a creamy brown head. Aroma of maple syrup, nuts, caramel and mild citrus hops. Taste is mildly hopped with nuts, chocolate, caramel and a mild bitter finish.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee India Brown Ale
column5: On tap as "Brown Bear India Brown Ale". Poured clear, medium-dark brown with a short, dense off-white head. The aroma picked up pine resin and grapefruit hoppage over sweet caramel and nutty malts.. fresh and well-balanced. The flavor found bitter pine and grassy notes throughout, with a mostly nutty base.. very bitter finish.. the malts got lost along the way. Very bitter on the palate, and it lost direction after the initial taste.. too sharp at times.. just OK.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee India Brown Ale
column5: (Milwaukee) Brown color with a small light beige head. Caramel and pine aroma. Flavors of pine, mild citrus with light toasted malt. A bit rough and seem young. An interesting effort.

a dark black beer w/ a thick nitro tan head that laced the glass nicely... the scent was very light, some carmel and malts the palate was smooth and creamy w/ no real carbonation. Tasted of very sweet malts hint of honey and light hops. a mild flavor not overly porterish but a good beer.
Very dark. A sweeter porter than I am accustomed. Full bodied. Roasted malt palate.

Near black with a stable small bubbled light tan head. Black malt, roasted malt and lightly citric hops aroma. Smooth and creamy feel. Roasty flavors with only enough honey to give it a light dryness. I could tope this for a good session.

Caramelly and malty in flavor and aroma, a medium brown color. Not much of a head. Alcohol was slightly noticeable but not by any means overwhelming; smooth. Even though this was not a great doppelbock, I enjoyed it.
Had this at a bachelor party this weekend. It was very drinkable, and would go well with strippers (not that I would know or anything).

This beer actually matches the commercial description very well. A dark color, with a caramel flavor and aroma. Thickness is about where it should have been. A slight alcohol burn was present, but nothing beyond what I usually expect from a Dopplebock.
Mediocre. Remarkably thin. Would be a good "session" doppelbock, if there is such a thing.
(En fût à la brasserie): Du chocolat noir très prononcé, de la vanille, de la noix de coco, des houblons terreux et une légère acidité sur corps moyen et velouté.
"really smooth, as a milk stout should be. you can feel the lactose in there. choclately, sweet ans very slightly bitter...not quite as good as Snow Plow, but close."

Draft @ Pizza Port Solana Beach, Solana Beach, CA. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma. Roasted malty milky chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.

From a growler courtesy of my neighbor from the source. It poured a dark brown color with a small head. The aroma is sweet with roasted malts and some vanilla. Taste has chocolate and caramel. Apparently there is lactose in it but I’m not sure I could identify that ingredient. Creamy texture with long silky finish.
(Draught) Pours an opaque black body with small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, lactose, roasted malt, and minerals. Flavor of lactose, chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and subtle anise.
pours a dark black hue with a small light brown head that is mostly diminishing aroma of chocolate malt, cream, coffee toffee and bread flavor is the same
Sweet aroma. Black in color with white-tan head. Light roast and sweet with hints of strawberry. Notes: GABF ’09

On tap at the brewpub. Pours with a black body and a lasting brown head. Aromas are roasty, cocoa, caramel, lactose and some light esters. Flavors are creamy, lactose, coco-puffs, lightly nutty. A bit lighter on the body, creamy. A well done little milk stout.

On tap at Pizza Port (Carlsbad) with Andy, James and Dallas for Dallas’ bachelor weekend. Dark pour. I have no notes on the aroma, but the palate is caramel and chocolate. There is an awesome, chewy, swishy mouthfeel that makes this taste like one of those caramel-filled chocolate Easter eggs from Cadbury. Absolutely delicious.

Draft at Pizza Port Solana Beach with Andrew, Brendan and the big boy daddy dad Bachelor, Dallas. Pours a deep black body with thin lacing. Aroma is light roast and chocolate milk. Mouthfeel is medium with light malts, roast, and milk chocolate.
Solid. Has a somky sourish twang, that sturck me as odd at first, but I came to dig it. Try the white pizza.
I thoroughly enjoyed this beer. Very dry with a toasty chocolate and toffee overtones. Fairly hopped with little head and a deep semi-opaque appearance.
Dark brown, with superb dry cocoa nose. Taste is dry with cocoa notes as well as coffee, brown sugar, and toffee. No bitterness. No real ending flavor, the sweetness just faded away.

Cask (handpump) @ Richard John Blackler - JDW, Units 1 & 2, Charlotte Row, Great Charlotte Street, Liverpool, Merseyside, England L1 1HU. Clear medium to dark amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, light roasted, light to moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, white sugar sweet, malty, wood - tobacco notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120117]

Cask at the Sussex Arms, Twickenham Green - 13/10/12. Chestnut brown with a thin off white head. Nose comprises malt, nuts, toffee and damp carpet. Tastes of biscuit malt, light toffee. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation and a bitter finish. File under ’W’ with the classic formation!

Cask @ The Liberty Bounds, JDW, Tower Hill EC3. Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with dry bitter hints also weak hints of apple. Has a fruity malty dry caramel finish.
Has very little nose, and almost no taste, its main asset is that it is crisp.

Cask conditioned handpump Cordwainer Northampton. So Fuggles are beautiful ay? This is a brown bitter with a whitish head and lace. In fact it’s a dull brown bitter. Hints of fruit, but otherwise very little going on. Really uninteresting.
Hand pulled cask at the Moon & Sixpence (JDW) Hatch End. Copper with a thin off white head. Fruity malts with a late developing English hop finish and a hint of caramel.

Cask at Blue Boar, Billericay. Pours a mahogany/dark copper with a cream coloured head. The aroma reveals a candy sugar sweetness with a little vanilla and malty bitterness. Thin and a little creamy on the palate, there is also a slight creamy taste to this beer. This is followed by a light biscuity bitterness with a vanilla edge. The vanilla flavour continues into the aftertaste but finishes abruptly with the re-emergence of the dry biscuit bitterness. A very easy drinking light, sweetish beer.
Cask at the Willow Walk (JDW), Victoria. Mahogany with a thin cream head; malty aroma; fruity flavour with some toffee; and s gently bitter finish. A simple bitter.
The Felix, Nuneaton. Dark copper, slim white neck, lace aplenty. Allsorts aroma. Stale red fruit flavour boiled sweet notes, caramel, Allsorts. Soporific.

Rerate, cask half pint, at The Regal (JDW), Gloucester. Reddish brown colour, small white head. Very moderate malty aroma. Malty and nutty flavour, not sweet. Some roasty notes. Decent hops in the finish. Original rating: Cask at the Lord Moon of the Mall, London. Copper to chestnut colour, low head. Moderate aroma, a little malts. Malty flavour, surprisingly bland, minimal hops. Boring.

column1: Barrel House Hopped To Hell IPA
column5: i don't know if its quite hopped to hell but its pretty close. nose is very hoppy and citrusy. flaovor is also very hoppy, but also sweet (this is the sweetest ipa i've ever had). very similar to stone runiation but a little less bitter and quite a bit sweeter. this is a great beer and if you're in cincy you shoud try it.

column1: Barrel House Hopped To Hell IPA
column5: The best English IPA I've had. Malty sweet with English hop bitterness. It maybe 3Floyds version of an English brewed IPA. Oily mouthfeel. Bitter finish.
honestly going off of memory of having this on tap at hop in brew ages ago. but it was a glorious beer that never tired. i want to find it once again...

This is a bit thin for a stout, but the flavour is prettu spot on. Big rock yeast.... But very clean tasting. I’m not reaaly getting the pepper at all, its sort of a hint of something that could have been there but they made up for it with something else. Not bad but still missinv he bite.

Pours black with an amazing head. Very nice aroma. Roasted malt and burnt coffee. Flavour is very nutty with strong roasted malt flavour. Bitter coffee in the very fresh, Slightly metalic chocolate and coffee ire present but not over powering. This is a damn rine stout. Dry drinkable and very well balanced this is excellent.

Draft at the Tongue and Groove. Pours black, pale tan 2-finger head, great lacing. Nose is nutty and chocolatey, very dry, a suggestion of oats perhaps? Flavours are rich, with oats, cocoa, coffee, very thick and chewy. A significant improvement over Guinness, but not my favorite stout.

Draught at Hop In, Calgary, AB, Canada. Pitch black colour with small tan head. Dry roasted malt, liquorice and mild coffee in aroma. Dry hops, roasted malt, liquorice, salt liquorice, chocolate in dry flavour. Thin.

We headed out to see a film festival screening of Zack & Mimi Make A Porno, but it was sold out, so instead we hit the Hop-In Brewpub to have a pint. This was on tap. Pours a near-black brown with a creamy light brown head displaying excellent retention and decent lace. Low aromas of roast, chocolate, faint acidic fruit. Creamy smooth roasted malt, chocolate, and a lactic quality make up the palate, which is a tad on the thin side. Overall not a bad beer, but the lighter character had me thinking this was more of a London style porter.

Draught at Hop In Brew Pub, Calgary Black color, creamy head. In the beginning the aroma is creamy, with roasted malt; then it shows a light cheesy touch. The flavor has a more evident cheese touch, reminding me Casera (cheese from the central Alps, similar to tomme, but produced with semi-skimmed milk). The final is a bit weak. Not bad, but indeed peculiar.

Here’s a recipe for a new cocktail; 1 part water, 1 part Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout, 1/4 part fig juice. I call it Big Rock Mcnally’s Reserve! Seriously though, it’s inoffensive but nothing great. That said, I still buy it at the pub, because I love Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout, and it’s cheap cause I live in the city where it’s brewed. I also give it points ’cause it’s one of the only stouts I can drink when I’m super thirsty, cause it’s very smooth, like more smooth nitro than canned guinness. There’s nothing WRONG with this beer, but it doesn’t stand out. Drink it! It’s okay!
Dark brown colour. Light chocolate and some lactic acid in the nose. Nutty, lightlyl fruity body. Fairly bland. Yeah, not much going on. Which means they’ve hit the mark of imitating Guinness.

, this Guiness clone was freshly available at Drop In in Calgary, where I had drinks with Presario. Stout style, coffee, pepper, with sour finish. Slightly better than the draft Guiness. Could not drink much

just found my notes from this. hmm....so after a week in new york i snuck away from my friends at niagra looking for a refreshing tasty brewed beverage of the local type....that wasnt broklyn lager...damnit i drank way way too much of that while i was there. i was very excited to see hop devil around the corner.i was even more excited to see a south hampton tap as found a stool. as hungover as i was i really wanted something fantastic. i was ready for anything. if nothing else let it be the ipa. i was fairly disapointed to find out it was a brown ale but the bartender assured me it was very rare. so i decided to give it a try. dont get me wrong it was a good brew....but it was a brown ale and im not a huge fan of the brown ales. light brown in color with a small tan head. aroma nutty roasted malt. flavor bittersweet roasted nutty malt. light to medium body with moderate carbonation. solid brown ale. but.....it was still just a brown ale. but it was a great beer to get the night going.
Draft at Half Time. Poured an amber body with a small tan head. Aroma was carmel and toasted malts. Flavor was toasted almond and carmel. Nice balance but not very exciting.

On tap at Hop Devil Grill. Deep ambjer brown in color with a tan head. Caramel and malty aroma. Nutty and roasty. Malty and nutty flavor. Light in body. Finish is malty. Well balanced. Sweet. Enjoyable beer. Nice.

on tap @ DBA, copery amber with a tiny head that disapated quickly. Really light in body. Aroma clearly of almonds.. taste is full of almond flavor but a bit burnt.. hint of something metalic. not my favorite.

Tap @ Barcade. Amber color with a small head that quickly went away. Nice roasted nut aroma. The taste is full of nuts, sweet malts and caramel. Light enough to be a very good session beer. Mellow sweet flavors are subtle enough to keep on drinking.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

Very red appearance--I would have expected darker. Excellent soothing, slightly oily palate. An aroma like milk out of a plastic gallon jug that is just at the moment when it will go sour in the next twelve hours...yet as the beer warms it reveals a sticky toffee flavor that is more pleasing. The overall effect of the beer left me pleased but wishing for something that was missing. (on tap, d.b.a., Manhattan)

Faint but potent bock aroma with some vanilla notes. Deep ruby brown. A little vegetable/nut, fruity flavor, woody, extremely well-balanced and not bock-metallic. Nice bite to the backend with long finish. Very good.

This copper colored Double Bock poured with a thick foamy head, and long lasting lace. Very malty and upfront sweetness, fruity balance followed by a brief hop bitterness. Not as good as the German champions, but close.

Draft: Sparkling brass color. Beautiful ring of well retained foam. Exciting aroma of concord grape, glazed malts, soft earthy hop traits, dark honey, leather, black cherry jam, and chocolate covered plum. Delicious flavors of molasses, concord grape, leather, spiced rum, and long spicy hop tinges. Lovely balanced finish with spicy hop undertones and candied malt. A very complex and rich example.
Fairly malty double bock, but nothing striking about this beer. Dark amber color, lasting white foamy head. Mild in flavor.

Comperable to the good German doppelbocks, but not quite as good as some. Copper appearance with a great-looking head. Caramel in the nose, as well as in the flavor. Slight hops in the long-term. Smooth finish. I would have liked a bit more maltiness, though - I likes my doppelbocks super malty.
*Old rating. Many thanks to kevnic2008 for this bottle. Best before 19.10.10. Mild-weiches, leicht süßliches und süffiges Pils. Etwas herb-komisch, aber rund und gut.
Drunk on draught in Konstanz. Fresh hoppy pils. Refreshing. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at "Xander Beer" - Brescia . Golden clear and limpid yellow color. Very foamy and resistant head duration, good bubbly aspcet. Fresh malt nose with notes of grains and an herbaceus final. Good prickly body, medium alcoholic perception, valid overall balance.

(bottle) pours a clear yellow colour with a frothy white head. aroma of floral hops, powdered sugar, light peaches, yeast and bread dough. flavour is mostly peaches, with a hint of floral hops and notes of yeast, cardboard and corn. light-bodied with average carbonation.
#1298 Dieses Pils scheint in der Rezeptur wohl schwankend zu sein, denn mein Edel Pils war sehr bitter und grobschlächtig; überhaupt nicht "Edel" oder gar feinherb.

Bottle, thanks Quack-duck. Nice flowery hop aroma, Golden, lacing white head, a few floaties. Flowery hops on straw malt. Minerals, unfortunastely I get a little bit of metallic cabbage as well. Dry sparkly body, pleasant perfumed exit. A schame about the DMS, I hope I just have a odd bottle, otherwise a great aromatic pils.
Pours a light gold with a fast disappearing head. Lots of carbonation. This was way better than I expected it to be.

Bottle from Quack-Duck, vielen Dank! Yellow with a fluffy head of medium duration. Some straw maltiness in the aroma but above all this beer is full of the lovely, classic aroma of Tettnanger hops, combining grassy and herbal elements. There is also a faint soapiness but it doesn’t manage to blur the picture. Quite high carbonation, light body, bitter, hoppy, aromatic taste. Fast, refreshing, hoppy German pils suitable for the summer time but very enjoyable even during winter. Very good!
Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild, modest dry, more spicy. Modest sweet. Finish with some soft-grasy notes, but still well balanced. Quite drinkable. Nice!

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas ergießt sich ein schön goldgelbes Pils mit mittelfeiner, schnell verschwindender Krone. Der Geruch ist hopfig herb, relativ schwach. Der Antrunk erfolgt angenehm hopfig herb, anfangs recht mild, dann zur Mitte wird die Herbe noch etwas intensiver. Das Finish wird dann etwas süßer. Gut abgestimmtes Pils!

Tasted from a 50 cl bottle in 2006. Typical top-fermented blonde thirst-quencher with creamy, sticky head and cloudy peach blonde colour; malt sweetish, bit fruity, sourish hint with a somewhat refreshing effect, finishing in a herbal Saaz hoppiness. Was nothing too special but certainly not bad in its style.

Bottled (from thebelgianbeershop.com). BBE in 2007. Hazy golden colour with huge off-white head. Aroma is sweet malts along with yeast, some grassyness and also mild fruity and wooden notes. Flavour is quite much the same along with some herbal notes. Big yeasty and grassy finish.

Bottled. A slightly hazy golden beer with a medium beige head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of fruit and yeast, but also some dusty hoppy notes, the fruits are mainly peaches. The flavor is sweet with notes of fruit, prunes, and dusty hops, as well as some quite spicy elderberries, leading to a dry and quite dusty finish.

Has that typical hearty characteristic, as usual, for the Belgian stuff...this one seems a bit smokey on the palate though. Maybe a little bitter and acidic too. Overall, nothing different and unusual than what I had been drinking a lot of at the time (transcribing from notes).

Pours a hazy golden amber, topped by half an inch of white foam. Okay head retention and lacing. Fruity and slight malty and slightly flowery aroma. Sweetish beer up front with caramel, candi sugar, and some sort of fruit - maybe apricot. Then it is pretty dry and grainy with a bite from the carbonation. The hops are there for balance, but they keep a low profile - more floral than spicy or bitter. Fairly smooth beer, medium body with ample carbonation.

The swing-top bottle is labelled "11.2 oz" but looks to be 500 ml, sure enough it turns out to be so as I pour it into my Chouffe tulip....a huge frothy white head ensues, abundantly lacing the glass atop the very heazy yeast-flecked golden body....the aroma is doughy-soft, yeasty-sour with noticeable hints of marzipan and sour cherry, lightly pungent and quite pleasant....body offers lots of sour fruits, a light and refreshing, moderate-to-high carbonation, honey and some faint herbal-grassy notes....nothing much in the way of Saaz hoppiness, but I found this pretty pleasant and enjoyable as a light, simple forget-about-it Belgian ale.

Bottle from Super Saver. Hazy deep golden pour with 1-finger off-white head. Aroma of heavy citrus and hops, soem fruit, and some yeasty cobwebby funk notes. The flavor was citrusy, with a fruity malt presence, some lime, apricot, and even some cacao notes as it warmed.

Pilsner hops and creamy fruit Belgium creamy yeast. Expires in one year. Yeasty malty aroma. Light orange fruity and creamy, with sediment. Medium plus mouthfull unexpected, active carbonation, fresh, fruity, sugar, a touch metallic. Unique Belgium found at SuperSavers, NJ.

Bottle (Utobeer): BIg spicy estery nose with pepper, allspice, pineapple and lemon. Golden colour with a huge, fluffy head. It kept trying to creep out of the bottle! Body is a little thin. Sweetish fresh fruit notes, with a suprising almost tart grape mid. Spicy, bitter dry finish. Interesting, but not great.

Bottled best before 5/07. Pours a clear, light copper color with a huge frothy, white head. Malty aroma with yeasty notes of bananas and spice. This one is a bit strange to me. The flavor is rather thin. It’s spicy and astringent with a dry finish. Nice bitterness.

[5327-20130501] Tap. Fragrant fruity raspberry perfume aroma. Clear, amber orange body with a quick bubbly white head. Creamsicle Campino raspberry fruit medicinal yeast flavour is quite overpowering. Medium creamy body. Really interesting but wow it’s strong! (7/3/6/3/13) 3.2 (@ brewpub, Kingston, ON)
A golden ale with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet perfumy raspberry with notes of pine trees. In mouth, a sweet fruity malt with butterscotch, raspberry jam, fake. On tap at brewery.

Draft at brewpub. Golden. Stable head. Raspberry soda aroma, heavy on the perfume and grandma house. Thin and light, with overwhelming soap. Lots of crabtree and evelyn products. Strangely interesting. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at the brewery. Not too bad. Aromas of raspberry, and caramel. Taste is sweet, with average length. Palate is thin and watery. Aroma is amber, with a thin head.
Draught at the brewpub. Distinct raspberry aroma, a bit rough. Clear red amber colour. Distinct soap flavour! Not much raspberry. Soap beer.
golden pour with little to no head. Aroma of artificial raspberries. Flavor is obviously artificial, just a bunch of mixed berries. light bitter finish.
On tap at the brewpub. Deep golden, brief whit head. Artificial powdered candy raspberry aroma and flavour. Very thin, watery palate. Blech.
Draft at the brewpub. Sugary, raspberry aroma. Kinda flat and stale and I’ve never really liked raspberries.

Verre de 10 oz dégusté directement à la brasserie. Arôme: Odeur de bonbon à la framboise. Apparence: La couleur est dorée. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de framboise. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est mince avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence d’amertume de framboise en arrière goût. (Rating #2510)

On tap at the BP- This one was brought to me a hazy clouded golden white. (Is golden white a colour? My notes are getting sketchy at this point anyway) The nose shows off tahiti treat and watermelon juice with sweedish berries and a floral component that seems mis placed. The flavour is over the top sweet raspberry with no real fruit juice flavours, just artificial syrups. Tastes like really sweet soda and the finish is prickly. Wow, worse than the pils. Bleargh!
Pours amber with some white head. Mild sour notes, rich malt flavour, some berries. Quite nice.

Bouteille 33cl Mousse : Fine corolle blanc cassé Couleur : Cuivré caramel brillant Nez : Fruits rouges vineux, cerise et fruits rouges Bouche : Attaque aigre-douce, vineuse et fruité cerise cherry / fruits rouge et sucré correctement dosé qui adouci le tout. Seconde bouche sur les mêmes saveur avec un boisé doux parfumé. Avis : Spécialité très agréable à découvrir , pas trop acide du fait d’un sucre correctement dosé.
fantastic red sour, perfect balance between malt forward and tart sour. the only downfall is that it’s a bit sticky sweet. online saveaur bier

Dark brown colour, almost black, small but stable head. Nose is initially sauerkraut. Mouth is intensive cane sugar and vinegar, some raisin. Medium sweetness, lightly sour. Maybe too sweet, but still good.

Brown with a thin, foamy head. Aroma full of prunes and balsamico. Taste is sweet up front, full of plum juice and beet root sweetness. Goes quickly sour though, with the balsamico dominating the end. Thick, syrupy body with a carbonation that is prickly but not over aggressive. Not my favorite style, but a nice dessert beer on a warm night.

0.33l bottle at home, bb 14.05.2016. pours a clear deep mahogany with a steady dense off-white head. aroma of balsamic vinegar, mostly. flavour of balsamic vinegar, oak, slight raisins. quite sour, slightly sweet. interesting, but too much vinegar.
Un bel équilibre aigre doux. Nez légèrement vinaigre, très bonne en bouche, avec une aigreur légère bien balancée par le sucre. Du boisé aussi. Une certaine finesse.

330ml bottle. Clear, chestnut colour with ruby glimmer and small to average, frothy to creamy, half-way lasting, moderately lacing, off-white head. Tart-ish, fruity, minimally spicy aroma, notes of morello, sweet cherry, a touch of raspberry vinegar. Taste is sweet-and sour fruity, minimally slightly sugary, minimally tangy, notes of morello, sweet cherry, raspberry sherbet. Slightly too sweet, minimally artificial, sugary. Not top of the style, but quite solid.
Trop aigre. Comme du vin vinaigré. Ne me plait pas du tout. Fruité peu présent et caché par l’acidité. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Oud bruin, réalisée par Verhaeghe pour le compte de Vanuxeem (beershop, mais ancien brasseur, rappelons-le quand même), sur le modèle vraisemblable de la Duchesse de Bourgogne, mais un cran en-dessous sur le plan abv avec 5,4 % ici pour 6,2 à la Duchesse ..(mais n'est pas Duchesse qui veut !!). Ceci étant dit, mon exemplaire avait 2 mois de plus que sa date limite, et avait donc gagné vraisemblablement par l'âge ce que la noblesse lui avait retiré .. Brassage avec malts d'orge et de froment, garde en fûts de chêne durant 18 mois. Ce liquide de ma bouteille avait donc au minimum 3 ans et demi depuis son brassage .. c'est beau la bière dans ce cas de figure (on n'est pas pressé, comme pour les ipa que certains veulent boire dans les trois mois … oh misère d'un monde speedé !!). Couleur roux châtain foncé aux reflets auburn, et à la clarté nette, pure. Bulles très fines, en fontaine centrale, très vives et virevoltantes. Mousse brun tendre, très crémeuse, stable à 3 mm. Arômes de chêne, vin rouge, Rodenbach grand cru, pointe de fruits rouges et noirs. 1ère bouche très souple, à la magnifique entame vin/fût/fruits noirs/baies. Arrière-bouche très vineuse, remarquable. 2ème aux fantastiques nuances fruité/aigre doux. Arrière-bouche très fine, longue. 3ème sur un ensemble aux nuances très savantes. Arrière-bouche à la grande harmonie. Longueur qui peaufine toutes les nuances précédentes, avec un fruité très particulier, et du très beau chêne. Jambes fines, denses. Levure d'une belle ligne. Alcool très bien pour son niveau, il a gagné notoirement par le vieillissement de mon exemplaire. Finale souple, très douce. CONCLUSION : exceptionnelle bière, qui donne toutes ses lettres de noblesse (même sans être duchesse) au style de la oud bruin ...
375ml can. Pours a clear golden honey wioth a rocky loose snow white head. Malt and grain aromas are basic as is the flavour that is quite crisp and clean. Average but okay for a low alcohol beer..
i think the contents is 99.9% water. the other .1% is a cheap beer strained throught an old sock.
Oh this is bad stuff...........do they still make it? I had the misfortune of tasting it when it was released and never again....horrible, should be banned
Some say they’d, "rather have a bottle in front of me than a frontal lobotomy", but this stuff will make them reconsider. Extremely pale, watery, insipid and weak.
Bottle. Pale yellow in colour with a thin white head. Thin bodied and highly carbonated. Watery and flavourless. Fizzy mouthfeel. Boring and Bland. Terrible.
canned. couldn’t be a whole lot worse - flavourless, very fizzy, yellow, some chemical nasties. dang
Light straw body, poor head, sweet and boring, a little bit smoother and a little bit sweeter than the gold, lacing, vanilla malt, head lasted well. Hopefully they wont bring this across to W.A.

Weird, dull, tinny colour with a clumpy head which formed a shape which looked like a crumpled up used condom - looks like they’re using chemical heading agents to me. Very little aroma, but there was a faint tomato sauce tinge to it. Very watery flavour with a hint of brown sugar and apples. No hop character at all. A bit fizzy and bloating. It’s no good, but it’s hardly offensive. Frankly I was expecting more (less?)
Looks like a beer for 5 seconds then the head disintigrates. Tastes absolutely diabolical, really nasty. Needed a quick single straight to mid off to get away from 487. Nearly got run out.
Pathetic crappy light beer. I probably wouldn't even drink one of these again if I was given one for free.

Having had Diamond before I can tell you that this is definitely more assertive though only by half an IBU or so. Very little aroma it just sits in the glass with very little character or development. Don’t waste your stomach capacity on this.
Shockingly void of any real taste, especially for a Molson product. Hard to critique something so tasteless.

I’m Joining the Club! Pours pale yellow, Sickley smell of sour corn, nice mouth feel light and crisp good body flavour of malt and corn. Not bad, but it has the typical shitty molson pale lager flavour that I have come to hate. Like i said. Nice body but thats it.

Smells like it might have been made with some grain, though maybe thats just my expectations when it says beer on it. It’s almost yellow, but it’s really just golden clearness. Once the corn smell fades from the sip you just took gives you a hind of almost malt, alcohal and then watery fading so it’s smooth....??? pretty weak. The taste is almost as transparent as the beer. I can read FINE PRINT throught this one. It’s not offensive at all, but it’s not really good in any way either.

Revisiting this Manitoba guzzel beer after a couple decades. Can sent from trade: There’s really not a lot to say about this beer as it is so indistinguishable from other macro adjunct lagers. Fizzy carbonation, pale yellow, weak heading, cardboard aroma, thin body, fast uneventful finish, annoying dextrose sweetness from extract brewing. Like all mass produced national brands, over priced for what you get.
A-W-F-U-L. Club is one of those beers that has that strong metallic taste to it ... even when it comes from the bottle. Staw away from it!
Wow. Piscator was quite harsh on this beer. I had one the other night at the Highlander Sportsplex, and have to admit it was quite undrinkable. I only bought it to rate it, so here goes...

And I thought Manitoba was the only place Molson dumped this crap? I guess it’s other places too (unfortunately). This beer is more of a joke in this province than anything else: they used to run some pretty bad commercials about how the beer was "brewed for people like you". The commercials are gone, but folks still remember them and laugh. Anyway, the beer is really bad: pale yellow, very fizzy, and lots of gross chemical and mild fruit aromas. The flavors are mostly sharp and grassy, but not in any sort of good way. It vaguely reminds me of those homebrew kits that consisted of a 1:1 ratio between malt extract and corn sugar. Yuck! I’m slightly embarrassed that I can check the "I can get this beer today" box.

unoffensive Molson product. Aroma is slightly grassy, light fruity notes. Pours straw yellow, head is half decent. Palate is thin. Weak overall flavour and finish. Not a good beer but I've had worse...

Ahh the elusive Club Ale is back up again. It's existance in southern Ontario is unknown. The only time I ever saw it was at the Molson store in Barrie where I bought a case of it awhile back. This to me is by far the only decent Molson product around, which isn't saying much to begin with. Slightly better then Molson Stock Ale. White head and a light golden colour like everything else.

Cask: Pours a beautiful dark brown and almost opaque, with a thick tan head that sticks around to the end, leaving strong lace all the way down. Aroma is strong roasty malt, coffee, caramel, some chocolate, and some smokiness. Flavor starts with a roasty and sweet malt attack (mostly roasted coffee and caramel), middle gets some hints of chocolate, end is lingering bitter chocolate, and slight smokiness. Very full and lingering in the mouth.
Cask version: Red-brown color with good lacing, sweet caramel aroma, full bodied, robust taste.

RE-RATE Ya know, this isn't actually all that bad. It Is a tad light on the flavor, but not all that bad. Nice flavor actually, a bit of malts and maybe burnt carmel; I'm not quite sure, but it's pleasant. I've kinda gotten to like it. It pours with little head (still) but does leave some lacing. The last couple sixers I've enjoyed. Even the carbonation was better than the first sixer I rated. I like this much better than Killians Red, and it's comparable to Leiniekugel's Red, though this is an ALE and Leinie's is a lager. I'd recommend this for a try.
Decent enough amber color and a big caramel aroma. Rich malt and caramel flavors but zero bitterness. Another bust for the power plant.
A great ESB. Very malty with minimal hop presence. The breadiness that Indra has mentioned comes through and stays the whole time. The mouthfeel is a tad on the thin side.

Fresh, fruity, pleasant hop aroma, with some light caramel, breadiness, cidery apple and pineapple. Darker amber in color, uneven head and slightly hazy with good lacing. More cidery fruity flavors, sweet grain, lightly spicy hop bitterness and some tea-like flavors. Light-medium body, palate on the watery side. Fruity hop aftertaste and sweetness. A little bit much in the way of cidery flavor and sweetness.

On tap at the brewpub. First of all, the bartender called this a "Belgian White", but Indra’s description nails this beer to a "T", so unless someone can prove otherwise, I’m lumping my rating in with the Tripel. As stated by others, this is not cloudy, but crystal clear rich gold with a white head. Has a slight medicinal aroma. Floral at times. The flavor is sweet and malty. I get a bit of pineapple and plenty of coriander. Good lacing. It’s a pretty tasty beer.
Yes, an appropriate glass would make this handsome trippel a higher score. Very sweet but not cloying and pear, apple and toffe notes dominate this brew. Nice.

First of all, served at a very cool temperature in standard shaker style pint glass. Definite points off for that. Lightly floral sweetness in the aroma, some white wine/grape, pear, peach and honey. Very slight head atop a clear, medium golden color. Sweetness and fruitiness factor into the flavor prominently as well, with some green apple and grape. Slightly alcoholic tinge and a lightly syrupy mouthfeel, a little cloying. Finishes with the fruity flavors of Welch's Harvest Blend™ juice, faintly flowery and malty.

Had 8oz on tap (under the name "Bock You Like A Hurricane") at Dad Watson’s in Fremont, Seattle. The color was ruddy red-orange with slight clouding and a thin white small grained head that left almost no lacing. Smelled primarily of malts and a slight hint of citrus and spices. Taste was subdued sweetly malty, slightly hoppy, slight hints of fruit. The finish was stronger on alcohol than I expected.

(Draught) 4oz sample at Dad Watson’s Brewpub in Seattle. Deep reddish-orange body with a fully dissipated head. Spiced ginger and cider aroma. Flavour is hoppy, milky and strangely ginseng? Average at best.
Clouded reddish amber appearance. Grainy mlat (animal feed) aroma. Sweet malty, burnt raisin scones, fruity palate, mild hop bitterness in the finish.

Very opaque, deep ruby body with a perfect tight creamy head. Beautiful curtains of lace. Caramel malts and some berries and spices. fitting for a bock. Some mildy roasted notes in here too. Nice and earthy. Alcohol initially, then followed by a bounce from malts to spicy, earthy hop tones. Alcohol stands out a bit too much considering its only 6.2%

Pours clear dark mahogany with a full, tan head. Aroma is cocoa, coffee and roast. Taste is chocolate and light brown sugar, moving to strong roast and light coffee notes. Finish is roast. A good porter.

Draft to mini-mug taster at Wisconsin Brew Pub. Looks good; a semi-transparent cola with foamy light beige head. Smells and tastes of dark malt, chocolate, and bitter hops. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied and moderately hoppy. Sessionable and enjoyable.

Bottle. Dark brown, creamy foam. Aroma: caramel, slightly dried fruit, slightly nutty, other fruits, sweet, lollipops. Taste: malt, caramel and roasted malt, a little chocolate and dried fruit, light creaminess, medium hop bitterness, normal and drinkable.

Had on tap. This is a easy to drink porter from Central Waters! It pours dark brown / black with decent carbonation. Has a nice roasty malt flavor to it with some chocolate and slight bitterness. I think it's very balanced and a smooth drinking porter. I look forward to trying more from Central Waters.
Bottle, 330 ml from De Caigny, Essen. Black with medium beige head. Roasty, chocolate, cocoa, smooth. Caramel. Medium sweetness. Medium bodied. Some bitterness in finish.
I though it was good. A little weak in the scent but tasted pretty good. Drink again

12 fl.oz bottle. A very dark brown beer with a huge good lasting tan head. Aroma of coffee, dark moderate roasted malt, dark fruits, caramel. Taste of dry dark moderate rosted malt, nuts, caramel, red mal, raisins, dry roasted bitter finish.

7 3 7 3 15 Bottle shared at Kim Jong Un Buurtcentrum, Zaandam. Dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, cocoa, toffee and malt. Flavour is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Zwart bier zonder schuim. Smaak is licht bitter en licht zoet met iets van chocolade, kokos en ietwat chocolade en koffie.
Porter rating #200! Draft pour at SAVOR 2018's Saturday session. Clear dark brown with beige head. Aromas of cocoa, malt. Tastes of cocoa, malt, chocolate. Medium body with a dry finish.

Pours deep dark reddish brown with a small white foam. Aroma is rich toffee and caramel with some light pine hops. Taste is a nice sweetness, caramel with a touch of toasted toffee. Beautiful. Then I am looking for a big hop bitterness and this is where it falls flat for me. The hops is subdued.

Where Purchased: 473ml can from LCBO #310 part of the 12 Beers of Christmas 2017 . Consumed: from a draught glass. Aroma: Smells very malty with a follow up hop smell. Hops are quite subdued for 43 IBU's. Appearance : pours filtered deep red brown with thick head that lasts to the end with sticky lacing which sticks to the bottom of the glass. Taste: Slight sweet and lots of malts followed up by some bitterness. Palate: medium body. Medium to heavy bittersweet aftertaste. Low carbonation. Overall: very well balanced on the intake, but too heavy on hops on the finish. If it wasn't for the malts the hops would have made this beer almost undrinkable. I was glad to try and will probably buy again. MB. The Beer "Bear"on.

Can: Poured an amber color ale with a medium size off-white foamy head with OK retention and limited lacing. Aroma of grainy malt notes with light caramel notes. Taste is a mix of dry grainy notes with some light dry caramel notes. Body is about average with good carbonation. Not very exciting.

Keg (Clocktower Red, 5.3%) at Clocktower Elgin St, Ottawa. Clear copper colour, small head. Toasty nose with a wealth of spicy, citrusy hops. Medium bodied with dense, rounded mouthfeel. Malt sweet with peat and bread. Long floral resiny bitter finish.

473 ml can from lcbo. Quiet pour with moderate carbonation and an aroma of malt with hints of musty fruit. The beer has an attractive burnished bronze hue, ecru head, and lots of lace. It has a smooth malty start with hints of hop dryness emerging in the middle. There is a long finish with toffee and caramel flavours blending with soft fruit notes at the end. Very drinkable!

Belle mousse brunante, sur un liquide relativement foncé et opaque, un peu de conifères en nez mais aussi une bonne dose de caramel. Bouche bien plus amère que prévu, ce qui est bienvenu étant donné l’extrême rondeurs des malts. De ce fait, les houblons laissent échapper des notes quasi tropicales qui jurent (avec succès) avec le noisetté. Avec bonheur, on se rend compte qu’il ne s’agit pas ici d’une autre ennuyante rousse irlandaise. Passablement réussie.

At the Bank st. brewpub location. Pint arrived with barely any head at all, most likely way it was poured from tap. Has a very dark colour, deep reddish look. Has a hoppy aroma for sure. Same can be said for the flavour, as the hops are fairly strong. A bit of a sweetness on the palate and a pretty good, smooth mouthfeel. Not too bad. As an update, had the Cask version. Much more hoppy when not carbonated. Barely any head leads to weak lacing. Has a dark amber appearance. Still nice and bitter, not as flat as you would expect. Slightly wet mouthfeel. Still pretty good.

Aroma: Smelling weakly of malts, coffee and soil. Appearance: A reddish brown clear ale, a warm off-white head, some lacing and curtains. Taste: Tasting of brown bread, caramel and grape-fruit peel. Palate: Little carbonation, soft texture, medium body, dry finish. Overall: More an american red to me, must be some C hops in it. Note: On-tap in Clarence Street Reviewed 2012-03-23.
Aroma:light butter, grapefruit... Appearance:dark redish, good beige head... Flavor:grapefruit, malty...

Looks good - they got the head and Lacing right, combined with ruby clear pour. Finishes on bitter side with even a little wooden astringency. Creamy texture. Evident barley crisp here as well. Soft carbonation. Tap at brewpub.

From the keg at the Clocktower pub Elgin Street, Ottawa. Brown colour with an off-white head. Sweetish taste with notes of caramel, cocoa and hazelnut. Low bitterness and carbonation. Rather thin mouthfeel. Not bad, but a little thin and sweet.

Keg at Clocktower Elgin St, Ottawa. Nut brown with mid sized head. Caramelly nose with some hazelnuts. Sweet with medium body and clean mouthfeel. Butter and cocoa powder, caramel and light spice. Low bitterness.

On tap at Glebe Brewpub. Pours an average size brownish head, a bit foamy and goes away after a little bit. Has a dark brown appearance with red hues. Weak lacing. Aromas of coffee and dark roasted malts. Flavours of mocha and some coffee, a bit of chocolate. Also a bit smokey as well. Hints of caramel. Somewhat bitter on the palate but not too offensive. Still goes down pretty easy.

Rather normal brown ale. Dark brown colour with a decent off-white head. Malt and barley aromas with some hops in the background. Rather nutty, malty taste with very little bitter, some chocolate sweetness. Little aftertaste. Low carbonation and a somewhat thin body. OK.

Very pedestrian brown ale here. Pours a syrupy looking brown aroma of barley, nothing else. Faint nip of hops in finish but this tastes more like an RAN than a brown. Average carbonation. Tap at brewpub.

On tap @ Clocktower Ottawa. Pours a virtual opaque brown with a mid-size, creamy, mocha head. Aromas are nuts, wood, and caramel. Tastes are coffee, semi-sweet chocolate,and roasty malt. Medium body, good carbonation, and a medium bitter finish. This beer may be a little on the robust side for a typical brown ale but I believe the rate-bee rians (rate-beerites?) have sold this beer a little short. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

Dégustée en fût sur place (Bank St). De couleur brune foncée et claire. Nez de grains de malt moyennement rôtis et légèrement sucrés, léger de noix avec des notes de houblon herbeux ainsi que des traces de chocolat. Mince-moyenne en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi qu’une texture légèrement huileuse. Léger goût de noix grillées avec des traces de chocolat lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de grains de malt rôtis et légèrement sucrés avec des petites notes de pain grillé puis en finale l’on retrouve une légère amertume de houblon herbeux. Post-goût moyen, légèrement amer de rôti et de houblon herbeux avec des notes de noix. (5 avril 2013)
On tap at the brewpub (Bank St.) Great robust chocolate malt flavor with caramel lingering in the finish. Light body and soft carbonation.

On tap at the Market brewpub. Dark brown body with a thin off-white creamy head. Decent malty/hoppy aroma with chocolate hints. Well balanced malty/hoppy taste with chocolate and brown sugar notes. Ends with a decent bittersweet finish.
En fût au Clocktower. Couleur brune foncé, mousse beige. Arôme de chocolat. En bouche, chocolat, un peu de café, malt, herbes. Finale choco et un peu d’amertume florale. Très bonne.

On tap at JT Whitneys When I snifed the sampler glass, the first thing that sprang to mind was velvet cake. The dark black body was covered by a thin marbled head. My first impression upon taking a sip was of expresso, creamer and chocolate. It was a little chewy but still a little too thin. Smooth, dry subtly sweet finish. Overall it was good - one that I might have again next year.

I should first mention that I’m not a huge fan of J.T. Whitney’s, except when it’s my birthday. As hezron mentioned tonight, I must be more susceptible on my birthday. In any case, I certainly enjoyed this stout. It’s not terrible impressive compared to a Dark Lord, but then again, what is. Pretty good for a brewpub imperial. The aroma starts off with a nice, but subtle burnt raisin aroma. Then, the thin, chocolate body gives quickly away to the low-bitter coffee finish. I enjoyed the lasting finish experience with this "session" stout. Thanks to hezron and brigadier for joining me on my b-day.

Black color with a medium head. Burnt malt aroma, but a tad of a sour end. Dirty and burnt malt flavor with a generous helping roasted goodness. Slightly sour finish. Slight infection? Still, an okay stout.

Very little head, dark muddy brown in color. A hint of raisin and licorice aroma. Full body with a creamy texture. Initially sweet roasted coffee and leather taste which changed first to metallic then to bitter. (My first rating!)
Not much of a scent to it. A dark brown beer, with kind of a chocolately taste to it. More of a sweet stout than an imperial stout.
Hand-pulled cask @ The Church End Brewery taproom. Little in terms of aroma, but a strong malty backbone. Light in the mouth, fruit cake on the finish. Acceptable.
Fra cask/gravity på Plymouth CAMRA Beer and Cider Festival 24 Sep 16. Stråfarget. Filmskum. Bra plommearoma. Smaken balansert fruktig. Litt malt. Tørr bitter etterhvert. Svakt syrlig avslutning.

Gravicask on the second day at Plymouth Camra Beer Festival 2016. Clear golden body. Bubbly white head, scattered lacing. Aroma of ripe fruits. Blended flavours of bread, caramel and lemony hops. Mid-dry bitter ending. Rounded on the swallow. Satisfying (Shared with Finn, 24.09.2016).

Cask at the Anchor, Digbeth, Birmingham. Poured a clear light amber with a frothy white head and lots of broken lace. The aroma is weak citrus fruit leading to a medium bitter flavour with a zesty red berry fruit palate and some liqourice and a little hop spice. A bitter though? It’s surely a pale ale.

Appearance: Clear golden color with a nice white head. Ok lacing. Aroma: Malty, light citric hoppy and fruity. Palate: Medium body. Moderate sweet and a mild bitterness. Soft carbonation. Taste: Malty, mild hoppy and fruity. Overall impression: Ok handpull ale. Personal stats: On tap @ source.

Tasted this in the Three Judges, Glasgow in September 2003. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale gold in colour with a thin white head. Light citrus aroma of lemon drops and elderflower short in intensity. Fizzy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a weak citrus note of burnt oranges and cereal.
