Strong flavour of hop resins in the dry bitter aftertaste is classic Church End. Finish is bitter edged with hop resins still delivering dry floral notes. A good summer session bitter.

Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 21/02/10. Deep gold in colour with a slight white head. Aroma of apricot and peach, with a hint of spicy hop. Flavour was sweetish, with cereal malts, more fruit and a bitter finish. Ok.
Cask. No head. Hazy orange body. Banana peach appple aroma. Mild fruity bitter falvor with a spicy note, low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

Cask. Cloudy pale yellowish colour, short bubbly head. Aroma is fruity, bit sweet and with some citrus. Ok mouthfeel. The flavour has a mild fruitiness with a soft bitter hoppiness, some sweetness. Little apple too. Simple.

From tap at Lord Nelson. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Mild fruity and yeasty aroma. Mild crisp grassy hops flavoured, light metallic and yeasty too. Bitter and dry flavoured finish. In poor condition.

Cask pint in the Auctioneer, Blackpool on 8th Sep 2016. Clear amber pour, off-white crown that hung around. Light toffee aroma and flavour with some mild hop bitterness late on. My sweet tooth liked it.
On cask at the hornet easy drinking some sherry aroma quite sweet caramel looks great in the glass
Deep amber ale. Sweet - hints of sherry, burnt caramel. Very subtle malty bitterness in aftertaste. Consequently tastes rather lacking, due to imbalance of sweetness.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A clear amber colour with a thin white head. Aroma of toffee, some fruity malt, subtle plum and bread. Tastes of grain, some caramel, subtle apple, bread and some roastiness. Light bodied but a watery texture. A soft, grainy bitterness in the finish. Disappointed by this because it smelt like a fruity, malty bitter but it’s quite grainy and thin. Ok for £1.95 though.
Leeds Beer Festival. Copper-amber with next to no head. Sugar sweet nose with a high sweet taste.

Cask@lychgatetavern, wolverhampton. Copper beer with medium head and good lacing. Very little aroma. Taste is a little caramel, grainy in a low alcohol beer way. Not very nice. I was robbed by this beer.

Cask (handpump) @ Barony Bar, 83 - 85 Broughton Street, Edinburgh, Scotland EH1 3RJ. Clear medium amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, nutty, caramel, berry - toffee notes. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20101031]

On tap in the Stockbridge Tap, Edinburgh. A bit of a disapointment to be honest. Looks great with a nice deep red/amber colour. Aroma was sparse but there were hints of the malt and some sweetness coming through. The palate was smooth, really smooth, like silky smooth. It was the taste that was the let down. First impressions were watery, so I had some more but it was still watery. Don’t get me wrong there are hops in there and they crop up occasionally but my overall lasting memory is watery.

From cask. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white and dense head. Aroma is light roasted malty and light butterish. Bitter hoppy and roasted malt base. Slight caramelish. Bitter and crisp fruity intothe finish.

Cask, gravity at Chadlington Beer Festival, Chadlington Village Hall, Oxon, 05-06-10 Pours amber with a white filmy head. This is quite malty and with toffee showing up front its a bit too sweet and uninteresting for me. A6 A3 T7 P3 Ov13 3.2
Flaske. Klar karamellfarget. Fyldig skumtopp moderat karbonert. Smaker metall,røstet malt og noe tørket frukt. Er det egentlig noe poeng med juleøl på 3.5%?
Bottle from ICA Maxi at Eurostop outside of Örebro. Light bready smell with a weird aroma, sulfur but more like outdoor toilette. Similar taste. Not that clean.

330ml bottle from Ica Aptiten, Stockholm. Clear dark amber. Two-finger size egg-white creamy head, leaving some lacing. Anonymous aroma, faint notes of dark sweet bread and dark sugar. Mildly carbonated, thin and watery. The tastes are light and gentle, roasted sweet notes, caramel and biscuit.
*Bottle from Hemköp in Stockholm. Nice round and quite deep. Fresh but malty. Hints of dried fruit, spices, very easy to drink. Malty depth - especially for this ABV. Round and malty-caramelly brew.

Beautiful foam that is lasting. The aroma is full of both hard roasted malt and raisins. The taste varies over dried fruits, like raisins, prunes and dates. It is perhaps a little early (or late) to rate Christmas beer, but Mariestads Julebrygd can suitably be drunk all year round. It is clearly comparable with Belgian beer, for its yeast have this peculiar richness and taste as just Belgians have expertise in brewing.

Clear nutty color with a fine off white head. Caramel malty, nutty and a bit fruity aroma. Medium body. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Average carbonation. Caramel malty, a bit bready and mild fruity flavor. Quite decent Swedish 3,5% beer. [Bottle from EuroCash at Svinesund, Sweden]

Takie sobie piwo ale o ladnej bordowej etykiecie, ciemno brazowej barwie, pianie sredniej ale mimo to trwalej. W smaku gorycz z palonym cukrem, slodowo toffi ale z domieszka solidnego chmielu. Dziwne zestawienie, nieco ciastezek korzennych tez wyczulem.

Malt and wort in the fragrance. The same applies to the taste. But a little watery, too. Light bitterness in the aftertaste that fills the upper part of the mouth briefly. Not nearly as good. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.
Poured from bottle, clear Cooper with low off white head. Aroma faint with notes of caramel, bread and herbs. Taste is mild with some sweetness and some bitterness but not much of body.
Bottle in Liljeholmen. Clear amber with a medium head. Sweet with malt, light caramel and fruit. Thin and not that interesting.
Cask at GBBF: Poured a golden with a white head. Sweet malt aroma. Taste is sweet with malts light hops bitter.

10/7/2019. Cask at the 30th Ealing Beer Festival. Pours clear mid-gold with a small bubbly off-white head. Aroma of citrus, hops, straw, malt and tropical fruit salad. Medium plus sweetness and light bitterness. Moderate body, oily texture, soft carbonation.
Cask @ Ealing Festival. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are fruits, malt, hops, grass and has a nice sweet fruity finish.

29Jun2018 Sweet grain and cereal malts, molasses, bread, biscuit. Slightly hazy, dark gold, small, creamy, white head. Light sweet. More grain malts, caramel, biscuit, dusty straw, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Decent. Cask at The Hand & Flowers, Marlow.
Cask @ Thornbury Castle, London. Paler golden with next to no head. A pale ale with an appealing dryness. Has some slightly tangy fruits with a low fruitiness. There’s a hint of grain in its nose.

Cask ½ pint at Gig House, Wokingham, on June 14, 2017. Buttery, sweet, not what I expected taste. Buttery, sweet aftertaste. Medium full, low CO2 mouthfeel. Very low to low bitterness. Clear golden color, white head with lacing. Malty a bit fruity hoppy scent. Not something I’d go for again really. 6/4/4/3/9=2.6

Cask gravity at the Berko beer fest . a light hazed golden orange coloured pour with a lasting loose off white head. Aroma is semi sweet Base malts, vanilla, orange rind, grassy citrus. Flavour is composed of grainy, damp hay, straw, tangerine, grassy hop. Little pineapple. Palate is grainy, moderate carbonation, raw grains. Rustic.

Cask at the Hope And Champion, Beaconsfield. Poured a clear light amber with a frothy white head and a little broken lace. The aroma is light citrus malt. The flavour is moderate to light bitter with a big citrus fruit, light yeast, light malt palate. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Very light citrus nose. Very pale straw colour. Good head with quick settlement. Light bitterness with a hint of lemony sharpness, increasing maltiness towards the end of glass. A light ’summery’ ale.

Gravity dispense at the brewery, 05/04/14. Clear golden amber with a god sized off white covering. Nose is caramel, biscuit malt, marshmallow, light citrus. Taste comprises bready tones, popcorn, caramel, toasted notes, hint of orange. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close. Decent enough sessioner.

Light amber color, little head, light floral aroma. Bitterness of hops at first sip, underlying malt at the finish without losing the bitterness. Palate is very light, almost watery. The water source that Los Gatos uses seems best suited to their pilsner, which is excellent.

Samples at Los Gatos Brewery. Nice copper hue. Aroma of citrus hops and biscuit malt. Medium, oily, tangy body. Citrus hops, grapefruit, biscuit malt and hints of caramel fill the mouth. Long, earthy finish. Nice brew.

Draught at the brewpub. Gold with a white head. Lightly citric and floral nose with some weird esters. The flavor is lightly bready with some dough and a medium bitter citrus-hops finish. Light bodied and crisp. Not bad, but pretty boring for an APA.

On tap. Some malt with a grassy, strawlike hop bitterness at the finish. It’s basically their pilsner with some more malt thrown in. I didn’t find it very well balance or comlex, which are two things I look for in a Pale Ale.

the first time I went to Los Gatos Brewing I was unimpressed but this beer is really good. It’s hop character is over the top, almost an IPA, but the balance is just right. This beer is much better than the 3.17 it has now.
Gold,creamy lasting off white head.Fresh hop nose. Unripe hop flavor. Softly carbonated. Rather bland
Amberish color. Aroma is citrus hops. Flavor is mostly the same. Mild citrusy hops, medium balancing caramel malt. Thin. Somewhat watery. Average.
GABF-on tap-pours a light tan head that laces with amber color. Aroma is medium hops, secondary medium malt-sweet. Taste is medium hops, secondary medium malt-sweet. OK carbonation.
Tap. Orange color with a laced tan head. A good sweet hop and malt aroma with a touch of fruit.
Dark brown with a fizzy white head. Roasted grain and light coffee aroma and taste with a clean finish.

Draft. A deep red beer with a lazing tan head. The aroma has notes of matl, caramel, and diacethyl. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of fruit combined with medium notes of diacethyl and caramel. Too much diacethyl for my liking.

On tap. dark brown with a warm tint of orange and a creamy beige head leaving some laces. Sweet aroma of hard roasted malt and a little butter. Medium body, hard roasted malt and vanilla. Dry, malt bitter finish with some coffee accents. 100709

From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Roasted malt and light coffeeish aroma. Roasted malty flavoured, sweet and vague toffee/butterish flavoured towards a mild roasted acidity. Bitter and roasted finish.

Date: July 09, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: black with ruby edges Aroma: light roasted aroma, light sweetness Flavor: rich roasted malt flavor, dark chocolate bitterness, light caramel sweetness, lasting bitter finish Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4
I had this on tap at the Thirsty Bear Brewpub during RBSG 2009 with kp, beerguy101 and beastiefan roasty, yet with a sweet element to it that just didn’t quite work for me.

~Pours a clear dark amber with white head. ~Malty, yeasty, and spicy sweet scent. ~Nice malt flavor on this one. Not too sweet, light citrus hops. ~Light feel, bittersweet finish. Some tingles on tongue. ~Enjoyable brew. Better than expected.
Very roasty and toasty. Coffee, chocolate and wood undertones. Really quite hoppy. Full complex and rich. Nice beer to sit and savor.

I had this on tap. It is a nice schwarzbier-type. It is almost black, with a medium, light brown head that steadily diminishes to a thin top and lasting ring of foam. The aoms is pleasant, mild aroma is toast with hints of chocolate, coffee. It’s dry, smooth, and clean. The taste is similar, on the lighter side for the style, but still with a good fullness and range of flavour. It’s mostly toasted grain with light chocolate and coffoee elements - a bit dry and rather clean, but light on complexity and depth. Ther e is a faint licorice quality but this is weak. It’s still tasty, though, and very drinkable.

$6 pint at the brewpub. Lots of black patent malts in the nose. Holy ash-tray. ig-time smokiness. This stuff smells like a hybrid of smoky bowling alley and Northern New York white trash. Moderately transparent black body with a light tan head that leaves decent lacing. Kind of thin, watery, and chalky with a roasted, burnt chocolate flavor. A bit musty, too. Not much in the way of hops. Pretty bland, thin, and unimpressive.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: full mouthfeel full flavour dour witj something going on to give it dimension. hint of lace. bit of grape gum character.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: From tap. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity, slight wineous. Dry, marcipan like. Citric. Sour and fruity. Sweet and citric. Lingering marcipan like finish.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Draft Taproom (Charlottesville). Tart, not sour... somewhat earthy. Nice offering.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Draft at Whole Foods. Straw pour with off-white head. Nose was fruity, tart, hops, oak, white wine grape notes. Tart flavor, some oaky tannins, hops, lemony bitterness.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Draft sample at Baptized in the Funk. Hazy golden amber color, white head. Aroma of summer fruit, light tannins. Taste is softly sour stone fruit, vnilla. Delicious.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Golden color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of bacteria, wood, citrus, lemon, and funk. Taste of oak, lemon, skins, bacteria, wheat, and sour.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Tap at Toronado Seattle. Browish pour, little head. Classic NB sour aromas, not a huge amount of complexity. Deeply tart, not totally dry but not sweet. Exactly what you’d expect the base beer for these others to taste like, but it works a bit better than you might have expected. My favorite NB sour save for Eric’s ale.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: On draft at pine box for 4th anniversary. Really fresh it seems on draft. Orange peel, lemon and lots of funk. Really makes you pucker but in a good way. Really fantastic. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Aroma is tart, skins, very funky, really nice. Appearance is golden, white head, slight haze. Taste is initial funk, followed by a nice tart sour, quite funky and nice. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, crisp carbonation, funky warhead sour aftertaste. Overall, this is a very solid offering.

column4: New Belgium Brewing Company (Lion Co. - Kirin Holdings)
column5: Sample, 1-ounce, draught, during the Great American Beer Festival, savoured on September 26 2015; eye: golden, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: acidity, sourness, fruity, slight musk; mouth: acidity, sourness, fruity, slight musk, acidic finale with presence of fizzy sour candy, medium body, rather carbonated, slick texture; overall: correct FRANÇAIS Échantillon, 1 once, en fût, durant le Great American Beer Festival, savourée le 26 septembre 2015; œil : dorée, limpide, pas d’effervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : acidité, aigreur, fruité, très léger musc; bouche : acidité, aigreur, fruité, très léger musc, finale acide avec présence de bonbon sure pétillant, corps moyen, plutôt carbonatée, texture coulante; en résumé : correct
On tap at the airport. Its alright. Pretty amber color. Taste pretty good but not outstanding.

Draft. An amber beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and hops. The flavor is sweet with light notes of malt and caramel, leading to a lightly bitter finish. Not very exciting, but an OK session beer.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is light fruity hops. Sweet malty and fruity flavoured. Fruity and bitter finish.

Tap at the brewpub: Nice hazy deep golden with a dense and lacing white head. Fresh cascade aroma- orange citruses. Rounded on the palate with a mild sweetness in the background of the flavor. Caramelized pale malts hold up a subdued cascade/citrusy hop middle. Not much bitterness. No major off flavors, just typical.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a clear golden color with a small off-white head. Has a malty hoppy aroma with some hints of grapefruit. Sweetish malty and slighlty hoppy flavor. Has a sweetish malty hoppy finish.
clea gold body, no head, stale hop nose, flavor is club soda and EKG, lacks depth, tastes like soda water with bitter extract, no real hop flavor, bland and stale
Draught at the brewpub Clear golden with a white head. Slightly vinous(?) aroma with sweet fruits. Some flowery hoppiness in the flavour but overall pretty bland, papery and stale.
Sampler at the brewpub. Copper coloured with a small white head. Nice hoppy aroma. Grapefruit and caramel make for a nice combination. This is a good, refreshing and well-balanced brew.

Draft at the brewpub. Very nice floral hop aroma. Beautiful amber color with a nice white head that laced a little. Thinnish body with moderate carbonation. Flavor of citrus hop lightly backed by caramel malt. It’s a hoppy little thing. That’s the finish too. Dry and hoppy. Really good ale.

Draft at SFBC. Off-white head that was mostly lasting, little to no lacing, transparent, visible carbonation, and a golden hue. The nose was floral and that was all I could get in this area, The flavor was hoppy, some grapefruit and pine and lightly bitter tasting. The mouthfeel was fairly smooth with a slight tingle to it. Light body. Again, just another so-so brew from this establishment as nothing really stands out to where I want more of it.
Tap. Golden color with a white head. Smooth wheat fueled flavor but lacks complexity.
Clear blond beer with a small white head. Yeasty and fruity aroma. Raisins I think. Slightly bitter, somewhat fruity beer with a bitter finish. A good well balanced beer.
Don’t really know what to think of this beer. It is somehow creamy and somehow yeasty and there’s even a little aroma of spices and alcohol.
Hazy golden pour, small white head. Big aroma of tropical fruit, yeast, and some subtle spices.

Strong amber commissioned by Arelbières in Arlon, with thick, creamy, off-white, sticky head and bright copper colour. Spicy and fruity aroma of honey, apricot, pepper, aniseed, ginger, citrus peel, whisky, flowery hops. Sourish onset, then turning sweetish, light citrus, caramelly maltiness, spicy notes, finishing mildly flowery hoppy with warming alcohol, but the spices - typically overused as this brewery so often does - also generate a drying effect. Nonetheless quite an agreeable brew.
Een lekker biertje met een goede nasmaak en een lekkere geur. Een aanrader.
Bottle, Arlon. Nice orange colour, white foam. Medium carbonation. Well balanced beer with aroma of banana, peach and honey with spicy aftertaste. Very good.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig süß, fruchtig, würzig. Geschmack röstmalzig, hefig, fruchtig, dunkle reife Früchte, Karamell.

Hazy, amber orange beer with a light frothy white head. Noses of bread, light floral and a bit of barnyard. Offers a light fizz with aslick texture. Light bready sweet with notes of bitterness and a medium body. The finish is light to medium lasting. Nice.

Il faut toujours revenir à St Monon pour savoir ce qu’est une vraie bière... Cette cuvée Ermesinde est définie comme une spéciale belge, ambrée du pays d’Arlon. C’est une bière naturelle refermentée en bouteille d’un niveau de 8 % abv. Très belle couleur ambrée rousse moyenne. Aspect légèrement trouble dû à un petit voile de levure. Bulles moyennes partout, moyennement vives mais continues. Mousse beige claire qui vient très vite napper le breuvage, mais va le tenir pendant toute la dégustation. Un peu comme certaines trappistes de haut vol. Arômes de whisky des Northern Highlands, genièvre grand cru, malt noir, avec une pointe d’abricot confit et un soupçon de thym. Superbe. Texture de la 1ère bouche entre doux et structuré, avec une sublime prise sur des nuances de thé premier cru. Arrière-bouche fraîche et pourtant nerveuse sur du malt et du houblon. 2ème bouche à l’équilibre magnifique avec une pointe d’épice, sucre d’orge et candi brun. 3ème prodigieuse, savoureuse, ample avec un équilibre délicat. Arrière-bouche d’une finesse impressionnante. La longueur commence avec un nez de miel fin et une bouche de bois blanc. Elle poursuit sur un whisky Speyside de 12 ans, et quelques fruits noirs avec une légère pointe de cassis. Elle finit sur du malt caramel et des feuilles d’automne sous la futaie, avec une pointe de noisette. La levure est la hauteur de tout ceci et contribue à l’harmonie boisée. Elle n’est pourtant pas trop douce et présente une pointe de sel marin d’une délicatesse extraordinaire. L’alcool est progressif, bien dosé (quoique j’aurais accepté pour cette bière un petit degré en plus parce qu’elle le mérite tellement...). La finale est évidemment attendue comme le Messie, et ma foi (sans jeu de mots) elle confine à l’absolu (toujours sans jeu de mots). Conclusion : une divinité est née (nous approchons de Noël …) et j’ai pu la recueillir dans mon verre. Quel faveur et quel plaisir divin … (non, pas le vin, la bière...). Nous ne pouvons que réciter 3 ave et dire une messe pour ce brasseur, et surtout pour qu’il continue à nous fournir pareilles merveilles. Merci St Monon.
Ambrée opaque, effervescence moyenne, col blanc moyen. Principalement maltée, avec des notes de cannelle, de miel, de banane et une petite amertume sur la fin. Mais l’ensemble ne convainc pas trop...

(Bottle, Chez Moeder Lambic Saint-Gilles, Brussels, 25 Oct 2013) Dark amber colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with notes of caramel, dried fruit and spicy hops. Malty, fruity taste with orange peel, crisp-bread, caramel and a balanced spicy bitterness in the finish. Almost full body, with a certain sweetness. Quite tasty and well made. Nice one.

column1: Beach Chalet Beach Blanket Blond Ale
column5: Slightly fruity aroma. Clear golden color. Not much of a head. Grainy flavor. Subtle underlying bitterness. Some yeastiness in the flavor. Subtly malty. Not bad except for the graininess.

column1: Beach Chalet Beach Blanket Blond Ale
column5: Tap. Light yellow golden color with a thin head. A yeasty aroma with a dry palate. Very clean but not very complex.

on tap-pours a retaining thick tan head with thick lacing and dark brown color. Aroma is sweet medium malt-cocoa, banana, clove. Taste is initially slight ashy, sweet medium malt-cocoa, banana, then somewhat tart finish.
From tap at the brewpub. Pours golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is slight estery fruity. Light caramelish note. Mild fruity too. Simple. Light bitter and slight acidic finish.
Tap. A reddish orange color with a foamy light brown head. A dry malty flavor with bread. A weizen spice is very muted. Has some chocolate. More dunkel than weizen bock.

Tap at the brewpub: (Listed as Brewers Special and it was a Belgian style ale, so I’m pretty sure it’s this) Hazy light golden topped by a white ring of head. Very oddly phenolic aroma- clove, plastic, pool water, banana, and a vanilla background. Decent creaminess to the body. Sweet flavor with evident candi sugar mixing with clovey phenolic and banana. This stuff is like a German Hefeweizen with candi sugar thrown into the boil. Not so good, but not terrible.
Tap. Very light golden ale with a white head. A nice pepper, clove, and spice aroma and flavor.

Cloudy yellow/orange color with a very small head. Spicy wheat aroma with a strong citrus element. Flavor is bursting with citrus. Lemons, even oranges. Tastes almost like Tang. Slight graininess underneath. Medium body. Not bad but the citrus is way too exaggerated.
Tap. Hazy golden yellow color. Very strong wheat flavor in this mild unfiltered wheat beer. A slightly sour bite in the finish.
Tap. Dark brown color with a light brown head. Nitro pushed. Smooth roasted malty flavor and aroma but a rather weak aroma.

On tap @ Magnolia, pour is a huge deep black with a puffy brown head that dissolves to nothing. Smells of slight chocolate, grainy coffee and deep malt. Taste is malt forward for a stout, and a nice blend of bitter and succulent sweets. Nice body, and a deepness to it that makes it a sipper for sure

Pours black with a medium foamy mocha head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, roasted nuts, brown sugar, slight smoky notes. Taste is chocolatey and roasted with light smoky notes. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

[2/2/16] Draught at Magnolia Gastropub and Brewery in San Francisco. 9.1% Black with a tan head. Nice aroma of smoked sausage, some coffee. Bittersweet flavor with roast, coffee, smoked meat. Medium-bodied.

Tap at the Delirium Hoppy Loft, Brussels. Poured a clear dark brown with a round light tan head. The flavour is moderate sweet with a smooth rich dark chocolate, charcoal malt liqourice bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Draft at Delirium Hoppy Loft. Pours black with a ring beige head. Aroma of smoked malts, peaty notes, toffee, licorice and caramel. Flavour is over moderate sweet and light to moderate bitter. Above medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Thx! for sharing. Sampled draft @ Delirium Hoppy Loft. Black with no head. Nose is hugely smoked soy sauce, varnish, light nail polish. Taste is glue, varnish, soy sauce, sugar, nail polish, herbal chocolate, heavy umami smoke,… Thick syrup body. Odd with the vanish, nail polish, smoked soy sauce notes,… Potentially polarizing but I am not a big fan of umami forward beers esp. coupled with odd notes like here.

On tap at Smokestack. Opaque black coloured pour with a lasting mid tan head. Aroma is big solvent alcohol, treacle, boozy fruit cake, dried fruits and burnt sugar. Flavour is composed of warming alcohol, rum and wood, dried fruits, burnt toffee, unrefined sugars fruit cake. Palate is solvent, fruit cake, semi sweet, moderate carbonation. Lingering unrefined sugars.
Draft. Not much here for such a big beer. Thin body, thin flavors. Some tobacco, some dried fruit. But pretty faint.

On tap at Smokestack Magnolia. It pours a dark brown/black with a tan head. The aroma is fresh pumpernickel bread, dark chocolate and a little coffee. Light licorice notes as well. The flavor is super smoky with tobacco, dark chocolate, fig, prune and a heavily roasted finish. Very thick, full body. Tasty.

Sample at GABF 10/03/2014, thanks to my sis for assistance with note-taking. Flat black color with a medium khaki head that recedes steadily. Small patches of lace. Aroma of roast malt, chocolate and coffee. Full-bodied with flavors of charred malt, black coffee and dark chocolate. The finish is roasty with a burnt malt aftertaste. Pretty good overall.
Nice IPA grapefruit aroma is pretty big here. Some pine as well. Bitter end. Golden pour with good head and lacing. Tap at brewery.

Draft at source. Old school DIPA from an old school brewery. Lacing bf and head are strong. Light haze to golden body. Thick not sweet maltiness covers up some bitterness but a drying bitterness still breaks through. Hops are dull and unspectacular. They don't pop or shine like modern versions try. This would have been very nice a decade ago and it's just quaint now.

Pours hazy green-golden with a one-finger white head. Tastes of bitter hops almost like a hopped hefe. It’s full bodied and the alcohol adds to the bitterness. It’s creamy and frothy. The bitter hops and alcohol are an attack on the taste buds. Wow!
Reddish gold beer. Smells pretty floral. Lots of prickly hop flavours, short and bitter, light sweetness in the end but it is fine for balance.

Poured into a tulip, the appearance was a semi-copper color with a slight transparency about it. Quarter finger white foamy head swiftly dissipated. Mild stringy lace, sliding. The aroma had some dried grassy hops, toast, citrus rind -sweetness, some leather and a touch of earthiness. Malt base was there, slightly stiff. The flavor leaned into the sweetness of the malts and tried to blend in the hops, somewhat bitter and sweet, but that mainly stayed separated. Aftertaste was malty. Finish was slightly sticky. The feel was just a tad under medium bodied with a decent sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt fine. Overall, west coast styled DIPA? Maybe, in an odd sort of way. Old school DIPA? Perhaps. Enjoyable? Somewhat. Would I have again - only if someone offered me. It wasn’t too far off.
12oz bottle. Poured a copper color with a small off-white head. Poured a mostly clear copper color with a white head. Aroma was pine, sweet caramel notes. Resin. Some light spicy notes, pine finish.
Bottle to glass mug. Pours a cloudy yellow with sparse head. Great mouthfeel with malt backbone and lots of hop notes
12 oz pour, rust copper clear pour with some creamy an head, minimal lacing, medium body, smells of pine, somewhat on the sweet side from caramel, taste resin,
Pours a clear light rust orange with carbonation. Has a sweet aroma of citrus, pine and caramel. A strong taste of citrus hop, pine, caramel, and some fruits. A mild malt aftertaste.
Draft at the source. Clear golden color. Nice citrus aroma. Taste has bitter summer fruit. Very nice.

Cask at the RAF 2003: Good dunkel colour, wonderful german malt aroma - strong nutty presence, barley, bitter hops. Bit too light on the palate, and could use a bit more to help round out the flavours, not quite as robust as a true German dunkel, but overall well done for the style.

Cask conditioned at the inn on the Green, Bristol. Brown with a slight head. Aroma was slightly malty. Flavour had a bit more malt with a fairly hoppy, dry finish. Served in good condition, this was a decent enough session beer.
Cask ocnditioned @ South Western Arms, Soton. Boring brown toffeish bitter. Although not sweet with mild hops towards the end. An uninteresting session beer.
Cask Handpump at the Crescent, Salford 02/04/2004 Golden amber coloured with some sour fruit flavour. Bitter lasting slight malt finish.

Cask conditioned - handpump - Malt Shovel Northampton. A brown coloured beer with a bit of diacetyl and toffee in the aroma. The taste has quite a bit of diacetyl but I think this didn’t detract like it sometimes can do. Easy to drink if not outstanding.

On tap at Trinity Brewhouse, Providence RI, November 2009. No ABV stated. Presented to me as simply as Trinity Kolsch but I guess it was this one as we have it as a Winter seasonal (as opposed to the other one which is down as a Summer seasonal). Extremely pale straw colour. Thin white head. Very light biscuit malt aroma. Light and fresh on the palate. A pleasant enough quaffer. Not sure about the Altbier reference in the commercial description.

Tap- Smells like a normal american macro pale larger with a hint of hop and maybe apple scent. Light apple juice color. Tastes crafy wheat/ hop home made taste. Light and a little fizzy in a negative way. Couldn’t compare it to anything else.
On tap at the Trinity Brew Pub. Poured a lighter yellow color wtih a smaller sized white head. Aromas and tastes of lighter fruitiness, and had a gerneric hoppiness to it.

On tap at the pub, 3/7/03. No head, very light apple juice appearance, followed by a light sour-apple aroma. Sweet/sour fruity (apples & pears) flavor, intensely hoppy and extremely dry and champagne-like finish. This may well be an excellent kolsch, it seems well-made, but I just can't get into this style yet, sorry.

Have you ever watched a movie that started out with a BANG! an amazing first scene or two, great photography, music, performances, direction, everything riveting and gluing you to your seat, thinking, "oh my God this could be a masterpiece!" and then....as quickly as it started it falls apart? This is that movie in beer form. Very dark brown, nearly opaque, thick pour, thick small creamy head with lots of lacing, huge caramel aroma -- followed by an intensely bitter, thinnish flavor/body that completely undermines the hints of caramel that occasional waft through; at the end it has an off-milk quality that is truly repulsive. I asked the waitress if it was bad; she took a sip and said it was fine. Whatever. I wish I knew what the brewer was thinking when he created this monstrosity!
Draft at the source. Hazy golden brown color, medium beige head. Aroma of caramel, subtle pine, light spice. Taste is rich toffee, butterscotch, nice body. Very tasty.

On tap at the brewpub. This was listed as the "Scotch Ale" and was given an ABV of 8-9%, so I’m assuming it’s the same beer. Aroma gave a bit of graham cracker and caramelized sugar, but was otherwise quiet. Flavors expressed a nice dense, tight brownness and dense malt sugars. A touch of butterscotch. Moderately well balanced sweetness and alcohol. I think this was really well put together, but somehow didn’t have the extra edge to make it particularly excellent or standout.

Part of a sampler at brewpub. Rating this from memory because it has been awhile since I was there but tried several of the Trinity offerings over the course of a couple of visits where I ordered sampler flights each time. Overall impression was that they made a decent brew in each of the styles they offered but nothing overly spectacular in any of them.

On draught at the brewpub. Cloudy brown pour with a tiny tan head. Aroma of brown sugar. Thick mouthfeel, taste of sticky molasses, almonds and brown sugar. One of my favs from Trinity for the winter season.

(Draught at the brewpub) Poured deep dark brown and cloud with white head. Aroma was malty and sweet. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Tasted of malts, hops, molasses, metallicness, lightly roastedness, bitterness and caramell. Malty aftertaste.

Cask. Vastly superior beer pumped out of the cask. Hops were much more present and gave a subtle undertone of evergreen. Balanced outt he malts and masked the alcohol. Nose was also much thicker and wetter (if wetter makes any sense but it did when I reviewed it into my notebook). More of a creamy, thick mouthfeel. Tough to leave after one pint.
Best beer sampled here. copper color. malty. citrusy. Pepper? slight roasted malt flavor as well. good beer.
Clear dark orange color, sweet aroma with hints of caramel malts, fizzy and thin. Ends quickly.
I was really taken by the gigantic neverending head on this one. wicked mega sweet with slight maltiness.

On cask. Opaque medium-to-dark maple color, big thick lasting bubbly head. Aroma of butterscotch, pine bark, loamy soil. Extremely sweet, no hops to speak of, butterscotch with hints of cherry, vanilla and (faintly) whiskey. Pillowy soft hot-chocolate-with-melted-marshmallow mouthfeel. Alcohol invisible until it warms quite a bit. Awesome, just a notch below the Imperial Stout. This is a brewpub worth going out of your way for.
Not bad. Very light bodied, with a mild heather flavor and some semi=present hoppiness. A good beer for summer, or an introductory to good beer. Very easy drinking.
Light clear golden. Light sweet floral/herbal (thyme?) nose. Sweet herbal flavor, very clean-tasting, light and dry at the end. More herbs; rosemary? Nice but very unassuming.

On tap at Willimantic on the way home from a weekend in Boston for EBF. Pours a hazed orange amber with a thin white head. Bright citrus and pungent hops. Big and earthy, lots of malt. Earthy and malt. Smooth with a long grapefruit and quinine bitterness.

Growler from the brewpub. Pours a murky orange-brown with a thick white head. Aroma of citrus, caramel malt, grapefruit, and tropical fruits. Flavor of caramel malt up front with a dry, citrusy, fruity finish. Nice hop character. This is very similar to the Three Cents just a little maltier. Very tasty, great stuff! 8/4/9/4/17 [4.2/5]
Pours amber with a nice white head, Smells of citrus, resiny, some sage. Tastes of bitter citrus, some dry malt, pepper, spice. Finishes with a nice spicy hint.

(growler) Small off-white head atop lightly hazed dark amber body. Aroma is medium sweet, tangerine, grapefruit, light pine, spearmint. Taste is medium sweet, pine, grapefruit, some orange/tangerine, bread/caramel, light straw. Slightly astringent hoppiness in the finish. Medium body, some resin.

Cask at Brewpub. pours a slightly hazy light orange with a nice tight fluffy white head and nice lace. Aroma is nice raw fresh hoppy aroma- very floral, citrusy resinous and some pine needle. Grapefruit and pine sap flavor resiny, with a good bready light sweet carapils malt and a raw tacky cohumulone bitterness gets a bit prickly but nice. . Very drinkable. Nice IPA.
This was my favorite of all the beers I had there. This beer was a murky straw yellow, but very appetizing. Smooth, bitter flavor but very balanced.

Enjoyed a pint of this one on draught at the brewpub in Willimantic, CT. This beer pours to a murky, deep orange color, with a tight, white head that fades, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is very inviting, with fragrant, spicy and piney hop aromas. The palate is firm, with some good sweet and caramel malt flavors, paired with a nice, spicy/herbal hop flavor. This beer finishes with more of those good malty and hoppy flavors, up front, then ends with some good spicy/piney hop bitterness that lingers. Another well done IPA from Willimantic. I really enjoyed the hop bitterness and hop flavor in this beer, as the pint warmed, you realize you are drinking a very hoppy and bitter beer. This one went great with a cup of their spicy potato soup, and would work well with a number of dishes on their menu.
Clear gold with almost no head. Floral and citrus hop nose, light pine and mild malt. Sweetly bitter citrus hop flavors, a mild caramel malt. Good.

Man was I happy to see this on cask. Came with a frothy creamy 1 finger full of head, atop a dirty orangish color. Aroma is strong floral, citrus and piney hops. Flavor starts with some nice mellow malt sweetness, sweet caramel, followed by a firm but pleasing bitterness and a rush of delicious hop flavor. Floral and citrus hops dominate, the finish out with some piney hops. Finishes very smooth, and insanely drinkable, even at 6.9% abv. I must say this year’s batch was better than I recalled the last batch, maybe a slightly different recipe? Who knows, but I just can’t get enough of this batch, and on cask? Insane.

The description at the pub said this was 6.9% and "an unfiltered IPA with Nugget and Golding Hops with 5 Malts". Floral citrusy-orange crisp refreshing aroma. Mild pine notes--nice. Mild/moderately transparent copper/amber color with an off-white head. Sweet, orange, citrusy hops to start with nice sticky caramel malty middle. Finishes grapefruity bitter. Nice IPA.

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: On tap at brewery, sweet and sour, big raisin flavors. Tons of Dark fruity malts, I really like it

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: Old cleaned up notes: Pours dark copper with a thin white head. Smells fruity and earthy with some spicy hints. Tastes of chocolate, raisins, molasses, some boozy hints.

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: This was a real treat, have I mentioned before that Willibrew is awesome? Probably, and it is. This one came a dark brownish red color in a much too small 12 oz. glass. Aroma was sweet chocolate, figs, raisins, caramel, and molasses. Mouthfeel is exceptionally smooth and full, like drinking liquid silk. Flavor starts very sweet, chocolate and caramel highlighting, then becomes very fruity, with molasses soaked figs and raisins highlighting. Slight hints of alcohol in the finish, but it sure isn’t off-putting at all. World class.

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: Draught. Lots of fruits in the aroma with significant sherry notes...hints of blackberries and licorice as well. Nice, complex nose. Mildly hazy dark garnet mahogany color with a light tan head. Sweet notes to start turning a very malty chocolate with hints of sour cherries. Astringent, cherry/vinous notes blended with the chocolate malts remind me of chocolate covered cherries....mmmm...magnificent! I dig this beer. The alcohol is undetectable.

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: Dark fruit esters are strong in the nose with some lightly roasted malts and perhaps a hint of smoke. Opaque black body with shy off-white head. Dark fruits are slightly sour with some bread-like yeast notes leading to the finishing roasty flavours. Medium body is effervescent on the tongue. Sampled at the brewpub with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: Dark brown hue, light off-white head. Strong earthy nose, deeply malty, somehow peaty feeling with several dark fruit suggestions among which dates and grapes stand out. Heavy dark dried fruits in fact. Very appealing, especially with that slight leather touch. Feels even more vinous in mouth, the fruitiness is as expressive as can be yet still leaves room for plenty of dark bread aspects. Light acidity level and well contained sweetness contribute to overall balance. Nice rather thick body proposes medium carbonation level.

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: Raisins and dates surface gently from the kind roastiness...Grapey vinosity appears in the back as warming alcohol is whispered from the classy carbonation...Refreshing ideas soothing the tastebuds and mind...

column1: Willimantic Mail Order Raisin Old Ale
column5: 2003: Dark elm body, small lasting hints of foam topping. Woody, parchmenty sweet nose. Sweet, musty, wet flavor and mouthfeel, caramel, no alcohol; shifts from old and bookish to grassy and fresh over the course of the tasting; long sweet finish, hints of lemon at the end. No hops to speak of. Best of the five I sampled. 2005: just a hair less interesting than the Jack Daniels version, perhaps a bit less flavor than I remembered. Downgraded by .1. Still a must-try.
Bevuta alla spina direttamente in monastero. Birra ambrata. Buona ma niente di particolare.

Bevuta alla spina al Klasterny di Praga, sulla collina vicino al castello. E’ la tipica birra praghese: maltosa, torbata, dal gusto complesso ma terribilmente beverina, con un piacevolissimo amaro finale. Davvero una bella scoperta questo minipivovar

A rich Belgian dark ale that has toffee and sweet chocolatey sugar notes, but I found it a bit cloying and a bit too sweet, however, it certainly was a relief from ubiquitous pale Czech lagers. Opps my mistake, this was a lager, but it tasted, as noted below, like a Belgian ale.

Imagine my surprise when I tasted this semi-dark beer - it was like being transplanted into Belgium! It is brewed, intentionally or not, in the style of Gouden Carolus with a rich malty flavour, leaning towards toffee with some spiciness and a nutty finish. Unusual and pretty good. (Draught at Klasterni, Praha)

went to the monastery expecting it to be a tourist trap with boring beer but this is very original stuff. on tap amazingly full of life and no worse bottled. had an absolutely massive head which my nose made a big dent in as i tried to take a first sip. slightly cloudy deep amber. some bockish black bean and toffee apple with a slight raspiness balanced by some belgian tasting yeast. apple peel bitterness, smooth and tasty and with a weird treacle aroma. good to know that while standard czech beers are declining in quality, there are some new breweries like this, avar, vrchlabi and berounsky medved who are coming up with adventurous but distinctly czech beers

i'll always be grateful to motelpogo for lugging this one back from the czech republic in his smelly backpack. this is an amazing beer. i thought the czechs couldn't do anything good over 5% but no. this one combines the fullness and richness of a doppelbock with the mysteriously vanishing soft drinkability of a czech pilsener. colour-wise it's bizarre: a deep sort of strawberry-amber (but then i always get pink and orange wrong). the mouthfeel is amazingly buttery, sticking to the roof of your mouth lonnggg after you finish. as well as the amazing, rich fudgey malt flavour you get heaps of fresh spicy saazy tingle, and enough bitterness to balance it perfectly without sticking out. beautiful stuff.
Drink this at a sportbar near the brewpub, it was closed, so i can some german football matches. But the beer is a hazy golden coloured beer with a light sweet taste, i nice thick head
Tap @ brewpub. Hoppy aroma. Clear, golden coloured with a thin, white head. Taste is hoppy, watery and carbonated. Not really great.
Draught at the brewpub. Hazy orange coloured. Malty aroma. Sweet malty flavour. Very mild with little hops.
Draught at the brewpub Hazy golden color. Malty aroma. More malty and sweet taste than the other Berliner beers, also the final is still sweet, with correct bitterness.
Draught. Slightly cloudy golden colour. Tight creamy head. Malty flavour, slightly hop aromatic. Good mouthfeel. Quite mild, but it does have some flavour.
Dark yellow (honey) and cloudy. Aroma is fresh and light fruity. Taste is malty fresh with pronounced hop notes and light fruitiness in the aftertaste. O.K. Helles without special character.

I had this beer many years ago at one time when I was only giving ratings to the beers but was too lazy and stupid to write down my thoughts. I will update this as soon as I get my hands on this beer again.

6/20/03, draft, Berlin. Here we go with the context again. I tried this one on tap at the Luisen Brau brewpub across from the Charlottenburg Palace in Berlin. While I was there sitting at the bar, a group of about 30 male, German tourists (from Bavaria I'd guess) serenaded the entire pub with several verses of a traditional drinking song while the bartender artfully filled glass after glass with the house brews. That alone must have added a few points to my rating! This is an unfiltered, amber beer with a healthy white head and great lacing. Aroma is apricots, floral hops with a hint of red wine vinegar acidity. Very hoppy tasting brew, lemon and spicy with a fruity finish. Medium body, round mouthfeel with light carbonation. Good flavorful beer in a great atmosphere.
Cloudy, blond beer with a medium head. Slightly sweet, yeasty taste. Lightly carbonated. Neutral finish.
the best option as you gaze at the boring, not-very-old castle. what you hope for from a brewpub - quite yeasty and fruity, very cloudy and with a creeping, tangy bitterness of mandarin pip
Tap @ brewpub. Aroma is quite weak, caramel malty. Hazy, dark brown coloured with a lasting off-white head. Taste is sweet, caramel malty, some licorice and carbonated. Watery body.
Draught at the brewpub. Hazy brown coloured with a beige head. Aroma of malts and caramel. Flavour of malts, caramel and hops.
Draught at the brewpub. Deep dark brown coloured. Roasty aroma. Rather sweet malty flavour.
Draught at the brewpub Dark color, big creamy head. Aroma of roasted malt. The body is round enough, quite malty, too much caramel and some roasted malt; just correctly bitter. Simple.
Draught. Very dark brown colour, small head. Malty, sweetish aroma. Flavour is also malty, and has a hint of coffee.

Draught at Luisen Brau, Berlin. Dark brown body, fine light tan head. Weak malty, fruity and grassy aroma. Tones of brown sugar. Roasted and sugary flavor. Mostly sweet with a bit of hops. Drinkable but rather bland.

6/20/03, draft, Berlin. Tasted this one at the Luisen Brau brewpub in Charlottenburg district of Berlin. Beautiful dark brown color and a creamy beige head which left nice lacing as I drained the glass. Mild aroma, primarily nutty malts with a hint of hops present. Flavor is hoppy first, then roasted grain, sourdough bread and a bitter hop finish. Rolls smoothly onto the tongue, lies there for a moment, then bursts into a carbonated creaminess. Nice beer in a great location.
Slightly cloudy coca-cola brown coloured beer with a small head. Light malty aroma and taste. Lightly carbonized. Neutral taste and finish.
pretty dark and murky with liquorice aroma. more like a czech tmave than a dunkel. not much wrong with it and some faint baked apple in brown sugar

Mommsen-Eck (Haus der 100 Biere) has been a watering hole of mine since before the Berlin Wall came down back in 1989: every trip back to the city sees me re-visit the place for food and beers. On returning now I’m always looking for something on the menu I’ve not had before instead of having something I know; hence the 500ml bottle of Black Jack was ordered during one of my evenings in here during Jan 2012. Black Jack is in fact a dark brown colour with ruby red tinge to it, the body being clear without haze or mistiness to the eye. The collapsing beige head gave it a great initial look; it also produced some impressive lacing as the beer level sank. Sweet malty molasses hit the nose, too strong for anything else to have a showing. The taste was also sweet molasses, caramel and toffee being the flavours I found, with a dark chocolate bitterness arriving towards the end of each sip. The texture was oily more than rich or creamy, the alcohol content didn’t appear to have any influence on the body depth or taste, would have liked to feel at least a hint of it when drinking such a good looking and smelling brew.

It’s black with a red hue and a creamy, lasting head. The aroma is like the moderately sweet flavour. It has notes of roasted malt, caramel, light licorice and some dusty and damp cellar. The finish is dry.
Dark, almost black. Clear. Has an off-white head, moderate lasting. Nice faint toasted, roasted aroma. Flavor is sweet, more toasted notes. Caramel and toffee. Creamy texture.
coffee, chocolate, black, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,
Bottle. Huge creamy head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, caramel, syrop and hops.
Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. DArk red-amber colour. moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Light bitter slightly roasted flavor. Short light bitter finish. Oily palate.
50 cl bottle in House der 100 Beers Berlin. Pours nicely with a dark reddish brown colour. Malty flavour with a strong aroma. Tasty drop
Bottle 50 cl. Clear reddish brown with a beige head. Sweet aroma of hard roasted malt. Light body, hard roasted malt and some bitter chocolate. Dry, malt bitter finish. 040409

Bottle 50cl. Clear dark red brown color with a large, creamy, good, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, roasted, coffee. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20090404]

Bottled. A very dark red-brown beer with a thin tan head. The aroma is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, as well as hints of roasted malt. The flavor is very sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and light notes of roasted malt.

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: The addition of syrup spoiled that beer. It is too sweet. Sourness is only in the background. I prefer "original" version. But appearance is surprising - completely green. Resembles dish detergent, also in aroma a little bit. Tastes like cheap apple hard candies. In the summer I would be able to drink it only for refreshing, not for sensory pleasure.

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: 500ml bottle. It is the better flavored weisse from Berliner. It is sweet but not too much, there is also light acidic taste and chestnut, hazelnut. Very refreshing!

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: Valójában egy ízesített nyáron jól Iható sör , azonban kicsit túl tolták benne az aromát és talán a savakat. Lehűtve viszont üdítőnek kiváló.

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: Pours a bright ecto-cooler green on tap with bubbly green-white foam that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of somewhere between green apple, floral notes, and sweet kool-aid. Taste is sweet too, like a green apple jolly rancher that has some spicy floral notes underneath, almost like black licorice. Weird and way too sweet, not for me.

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: A funny beer served in Berlin at right conditions and warm weather. Green beer with white head. Aroma sweet champagne notes (champagnebrus whatever thats called in english). Taste sweet and very refreshing in the warm weather. Great under the given conditions.

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: Weird aroma of pudding creme with a note of almond and bit yoghurt signs. Cloudy green in the glass with medium rocky head. Taste is semi sweetish with bit tarty hints, but all is taken by artifical notes of that green syrup. God, why?

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: Dieses Getränk ist etwas ganz eingenes, manche mögen "besonderes" sagen. Es ist nicht sauer wie die klassische Berliner Weisse, bitter wie einfaches Bier und auch nicht zu süß wie die meisten Radler. Es hat einen Geschmack nach Ahoi-Brause aufgelöst in saurem Bier. Das ist so abartig, dass es schon wieder gut ist. Ich werde sicher nicht der große Fan von dem Zeug, aber probieren sollte man es doch mal -und sei es, dass man es kennenlernt.

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: Kwestia gustu. Kwaskowate, lekko chemiczne, mało piwne ale wciąż smaczne i z pewnością nie zasługuje na tak niskie oceny. Najpierw trzeba spróbować klasyczne żeby ocenić. Kindl jest kwaśny i inny od pozostałych piw!

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: Green color, middle foam size. Aroma is very close to tarragon. Taste is like tarragon lemonade with weisse beer, sour and sweet. Actually is not beer at all, beer mix.

column1: Berliner Kindl Weisse Mit Schuß Waldmeister
column5: olpestus fasti della sommarustical besta losskarrnis bella gutas oras van dassa hasi
Sweet malty stout. Hand pumped so no carbonation. Slightly sweet finish. I'm impressed. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught. Ultra dark pour. Choco aroma. Slighty bitter choco taste with smooth finish.
pitch black, mild white head. velvety moutfeel, but a bit too much carbonation. flavor with some chocolate and coffee notes. solid sweet stout, would be better with less carbonation
On tap at Arbor. Poured a dark brown. Aroma was chocolate, malt and a hint of coffee. Flavor was more of the same, with a sweet caramel touch. A very good stout.

Tap: Black, hand pulled, no carbination. Grand aroma of sweet chocolate, malty coffee and toffe. Goes down incredibly smooth for this stout. Very well balanced, extremely drinkable with good mouth feel. One of the best stouts I’ve had to date.
pleasant semi-sweet chocolate aroma, black with a hint of brown underneath a thin head, slight cappucino intially with some smoky chocolate, medium body but full flavored

Tap: Yeah, no real head, a little thin compared to the two other new stouts ABC is offering up. A little bit of coffee, slightly vinous mouthfeel. Had a little tang to it that hit me in the salivary glands.
Tap: Lack with decent head. Coffe up front. Coffee with chocolate undertones. Bitter finish. Was decent but I am not a true stout fan only because I can’t stand coffee.

On tap: Nice mocha coffee aroma. Light cream. Dark brown, virtually black with a big off-white head. Decent retention. Nice lacing. Good coffee flavor. Light chocolate. Finishes bitter black coffee. Lightly salty.

This is just plain luxurious. It's a milk stout without any lactose (! for vegans!) - it has all the usual suspects, coffee in medium measure, roast somewhat less than that, some chocolate, some (apparently non-)lactic sourness. I was not expecting much, yet this is more full bodied than some - perfect body. Great experience.

Poured a dark straw color with a thin whispy head. Classic Belgian aroma. Nice refreshing fruity-hefe flavor. Light-mdium body. I expected an alcohol and dry finish - none. Very nice way to start the night.

A nice beer from the Dane, sampled over at the Hilldale location. Pours a cloudy yellow colour with a big fluffy white head. Aroma is really nice, orange peel, citrus fruits and wheat. Taste is soft and spicey, very creamy, lots of carbonation and a generous of amount of fruity nuances. A really impressive beer from these guys. Review no. 1700! :)"

On tap as "Ride the Dragon" Tripel. Pours a hazy gold, a compact white head still leaves a lot of streaky lace. Only a faint yeastiness on the nose. Flavor nicely combines yeasty flavors with the sweetness of honey and apricot nectar, a bit of pineapple on the aftertaste. Somewhat more than medium bodied, a bit peppery and prickly on the palate.
Brew pub tripel turned out pretty good. Fruity, syrupy, faitn alcohol. A very drinkable tripel.

One of the better domestic triples I have had in some time. LOts of light fruit with just a hint of floral hops and pale malt. Touches of apple, apricot honeysuckle and candi in the flavors. Backdrop of cloves and wheat. Fairly dry in the finish with just a hint of sweet pale malt. Quite nice.

A feal fruit salad. Pours a hazy peach colored beer with a nice nose of candied apricots. Lots of plum, peaches, apricots and pear - lots of pear. Nice long-lasting head, give style points. Long lasting fruit finish, but lacks some body and complexity. Would age well in oak - but this is a brewpub, so I’ll give it a 16.

Poured an almost clear golden yellow, with decent-staying creamy head. Aroma was fruity (namely apples and dates), with some alcohol present. Mouthfeel was carbonated almost to the point of being tingly, and the taste was light, fruity, and hoppy. Malt flavor was not distinct, but added bulk to the beer’s body. This was almost champagne-like, and left a nice fruity aftertaste.

Hazy yellow color with no head. Floral aroma with a substantial alcohol content. Very spicy grass taste with some apple present too. Bitter and pucker inducing. Alcohol plays a major part here. It seemed out of balance to me.
Apple/pear/alcohol aroma, tastes very alcoholic, perhaps more than the ABV (if thats possible). A beautiful light cider color, a touch harsh tasting but aroma represents the flavor fairly well.

Copper to umber in color. Modest dark ecru head. Aromas of caramel, toasted to light roasted malt, mild spice and dark fruit. Full and a bit oily in feel. Sweet flavors with dark fruit and well developed malts. A touch more hops in this one. Finish was some wood, spice and butterscotch. A good sustaining Doppel. 5/10

Pours a clear dark reddish coppery color with tan colored head. Caramel malt, sticky sweetness, and some light cereal on the nose; follows onto the palate. Full bodied and thick. Finishes with caramel and nuts.

On tap at Great Dane-Doty for the beginning of Madison Craft Beer Week, and dispensed to a pint glass with a clear, mahogany color, modest, off white head foam that persisted as a ring and layer of film, and wavy cling to the lacing. The aroma was toasty, with caramel, sweetness, and plenty of smooth malt. The flavor added some moderate hop bitterness and a touch of toffee to the medium+ body, with a little dryness at the finish. A smooth, hefty Doppel, with a bit of warmth.

I had this one last week after a few other brews and it pretty much finished me off. Really great tasting and super filling. Pours a dark but translucent copper colour with a small white head. Malt profile is noticeably upfront but integrated well with fresh hop notes. Big full bodied taste with a soft fruity undertone, it’s got some rich caramel notes running straight through it. Fantastic beer

Medium caramel-amber, cream-colored head is small but dense, leaves a respectable lacing. Sweet honeyed malt aroma with some fresh bread elements. Flavor begins nice, sweet, malt syrup, honey, then takes an off dive at the finish towards bread crusts, with some stale, metallic notes. Full bodied, pronouncedly syrupy but escapes being cloying.

On draught at the downtown Madison Great Dane brewpub. Pours a semi-clear reddish amber color brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates to a thin ring. Aroma of caramel malt, brown sugar, toffee and some mild alcohol. Taste is medium bodied, flavors of toffee, dark pitted fruits, caramel malt and some floral hops. Finish is semi-sweet with a brown sugar and caramel malt aftertaste with some mild bitterness.
good, not great. low carbonation, nice sweet brown sugar flavors, a slight alcohol burn.

On tap at the downtown location, pours dark red with a thin white head. Nothing much in the nose, and flavors were lacking imagination. It kinda had that cheap-Genny Light-hangs-around-too-long taste, finishes just a little malty. Gonna have to give this a "meh" rating.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear copper color. Head was off white and left a bit of lace behind. Smelled of dark fruits and subdued alcohol. Medium bodied with alcohol, toffee, and plum flavors. Decent, but I didn’t like it as much as some of the previous raters.
Moderately malty flavor with a surprisingly clean finish. One of my favorite local dark beers.

Super hazy ruby glowing brown coloured body with almost white/yellow highlights because of the haze. In addition, tons of chunky large particles at the bottom make for a crazy look. Aroma of bananas, clove, anise, liquorice, canned corn and yes - wheat and yeast. Full-bodied; Strong yeastie flavour with wheat, bananas and cloves most noticeable. Aftertaste is mellow and wheatie, showing some alcohol and a plentiful amount of sugars. Overall, a pretty good weizenbock, not complex near the end, but the flavour shows well. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Chevy Chase Wine & Liquors in Washington, D.C. on 03-May-2008 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia on 05-July-2008.

This Weizenbock is one of the best in the Baltimore area since DeGroen’s versionin the 90’s. I would put this up against Aventinus from Germany and prefer it over Clipper City’s Hang Ten and Victory’s Moonglow Weizenbock.

Bottle. Lately i’ve been wanting to try as many wheat beers as I can find in my area, so I picked this up too. I read the reviews and to be honest i wanted to like it as much as everyone else did, but i cant. I do like it, but not as much everyone else. I need to try this in the fall. I’ve been drinking too many hefes lately. I need to revisit this in the fall next to Schnieder Aventinus and other weisnbocks.

I sampled this at a beer tasting at Total Discount Liqours in Eldersburg, MD. I liked it and got a 6pk. It poured a cloudy copper/amber color with a tall thick foamy head. There was a distinct wheat aroma and a bit of a mild citrus scent. The flavor was a nice smooth sweet taste that had a crisp clean tangy spice to counter balance it. A very good weizenbock, worth a try

Pours cloudy copper with a good head, but the head doesn’t last. Looks delicious. Kinda smells like seafood. Full flavored,, full bodied, medium dark wheat that is a little sweet. Cold clean mouthfeel. Spicy, yeasty, sweet finish. This is a really good weizenbock.

Draft. Poured a cloudy brown color with a thin off white head. Attractive aroma of banana and clove. The flavor was similar, but there was also some shoe leather, subdued roasted nuts, and a hint of raw alcohol.

12oz bottle. Deep red-brown color, very cloudy and thick in appearance. Mystery ABV...I’d guess 6.8% or so. Certainly an enjoyable beer, but not really a world class weizenbock. Malty sweet and rich, worth a try for the enthusiast.

Great Weizenbock. The catchy name and package originally drew me in. I’ve also had this on draught at the Rams Head Tavern in Annapolis. Both are good. Pours thick murky cloudy brown. Not the prettiest beer....but the taste is great. Clove & banana flavors abound with a slight bitterness. The package art is great and very Annapolitan. Only negatives are it’s appearance and drinkability.

12oz bottle. Basically a spot on weizenbock... huge doughy banana and clove in the nose, sugary, starchy, bready, with a well developed nose. Chewy, moderately thick texture, frothy as well, with the banana and clove done perfectly, not that it’s a hard style to nail. Nice and spicy, not overy done, and sweet but also not too much so.
Nicely done, especially the strong banana tones and flavor. Other fruits present with a slight hops zing. Very drinkable, though not much to look at.

Bottle from the Shops at Dartington. Appearance - golden amber with generous lacing. Nose - sweetcorn and green beans. Light pickled onion note even. Taste - crisp citrus and more corn. Palate - light bodied, creamy texture and a nice crisp finish. Overall - good example of the style.
Fra cask på Exeter Inn, Topsham 29 Sep 16. Stråfarget. Filmskum. Forsiktig maltaroma med spor av frukt. Smaken tørket frukt og litt malt.

Half pint, cask ale at Exeter Inn. Lacing rings from a dissipating white head. Bright amber-gold body. Hop fruity nose, floral. Oily hops to the taste buds, caramel malts beneath. Distant fruit bitter endnotes. Satisfying (Topsham 29.09.2016).
Cask at Old Green Tree, Bath. Pours golden with white head. Fruity malty aroma. Fruits and caramel in flavor.

Cask at Barrel House, Totnes. golden pour with thin white head. Muted aroma of light citrus, honey, and biscuit. Honey and biscuity malt in the taste with some light earthy herbal tones and a twist of citrus at the end. Brief aftertaste of very light citrus. Decent session ale.
Darker yellow in colour with a very active head out of the bottle. The aroma is intensely lager in type but it has a more hoppy ale texture. Medium to full bodied.

(Bottle). Unpleasant tart aroma and taste with hints of hops, citrus, raspberry and caramel malt. The flavor also has a somewhat strange and uggly flavor that I can not quite place, but according to the label, there are flavor of black currant in the beer. However, I can not find it, and I really like black currants.
Home cask from the brewery. Sweet malt on the nose. Pours lifeless pale amber. Flavour adds stong bitterness with the malt again returning in the finish. Refreshing and pleasant.
Bottled ; Devon ; UK ; Caramel and floral aroma ; Hazy golden color with huge head ; Medium sweet and bitter taste ; Medium body ; Lively carbon ; Pleasant beer.
bottle from the brewery. Hazy golden colour, lovely hop aroma. Solid malty base with just the right sweetness to balance the aromatic hops that have a citrusy touch.

On tap at the source. Comes to the table a light golden almost amber color with a small quickly disappearing head. Buttery caramel and light bready malt with barely enough hop aroma to balance the sweetness. Light bready pilsener malt flavor with a small shot of spicy hop bite. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a sweet mouthfeel. Decent light pilsner brew but needs a bit more breadiness.
Tap at the brewpub. Clear light orange pour with bubbles. Cereal and caramel sweetness - not bad. Slightly sweet.
on tap-offwhite-gold. A-med malt-caramel, fruit. T-med malt, fruit, some earthy hops.

3 Oz sampler. Mildly caramel sweet notes in the nose with the typical City Steam licorice aroma. Transparent copper color with an off-white head. Start is lightly caramelly with some roasted cereal malty in the middle with mild spritzy hoppiness to finish.

So I dunno, after walking 3 blocks in downtown Hartford on a sunny early Saturday afternoon and feeling like I was going to get killed (I walked past a group of teens who looked at me and mouthed obscenities, then threw an iceball at me for absolutely no reason), after feeling all nervous about my car parked right on Main Street, I thought, well maybe this brewpub will live up to the hype more than the last one. Maybe this will be nirvana in the midst of a shambles, a vortex of light in the middle of one of the worst urban darknesses in America. Sadly, I was mistaken. My first beer, this "vienna" is solid, medium-sweet caramel-apple flavored, but has no hops at all, little nose, and a very light wispy conclusion. Oh well darker is better right? On to the IPA...

Pours clear copper with a medium head. Aroma is nothing to write home about. A bit of grass and caramel. Medium in body with good carbonation. Flavor is surprisingly not all that happy. Sweet malt flavors are up front with a bitter end. Despite the lack of complexity, I actually quite enjoyed this.

Bottle from Table and Vine, I think. Wicked fresh. Hazy copper with lasting dense head and lace. Mild spicy piney aroma. Medium crackery nutty malts with mild fruity sweetness. Assertive spicy lingering bitterness. Fairly dry. Nice draft-like texture. Very good.
Bottle. This one had a bit more hop aroma compared to the blonde on blonde and was a lot more bitter as well. OK, but I prefer the blonde on blonde.

A good beer but not great. Pour is dark amber with a thin white head. Aroma is mostly a caramel malty thing with light hop notes. Malty and sweet in the front with a dry hop middle and a bitter finsh.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Julio’s Liquors (Westborough, MA) au coût de 2,10$. Arôme: Odeur de pamplemousse et autres agrumes. Apparence: La couleur est orangée opaque avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence d’un moyen col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de pamplemousse avec une pointe d’orange et de caramel. Longue durée de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence d’orange en arrière goût. (Rating #5746)
Amber with a thin head. The aroma is sweet malts with not much hops. The flavor is fruity sweet for a moment then is extremely bitter. Decent but a bit harsh. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at the cabin in NH. Pours perfectly clear, penny copper with a large, lasting, slightly off-white head. The nose holds bread, caramel, grains, some unfermented wort, barley juice, light pine and leaves. Light to medium sweet with some dry bread, pine, off smokey notes, dry caramel, berries. Medium bodied with fine, creamy carbonation. A bit of dirty, earthy bitterness on the finish with more pine and leaves, dry bread, further off smoke notes, alcohol and more dry caramel. Mediocre, really.

Sampled at Julio’s Spring Beer Fest. Pours amber/orange with a small white head. Grapefruit, citrus aroma. Quite sharp. Flavor, too, is bitter grapefruit hops. Not a lot of malt balancing it out. Medium bodied. Decent, if average, IPA.
bottle, decent IPA, citrus notes & pith, grapefruit & orange. malty backbone. pretty balanced, decent flavor. Not bad
Bottle. Pours orange amber with white head. Nose/taste of grapefruit peel, caramel malt, harsh grain, pine and bitter rotten oranges. Medium body.

column1: City Steam Green Eyes & Red Hair
column5: on tap-pours a dissipating light tan head and amber color. Aroma is sweet caramel malt. Taste is smoky, sweet caramel malt, secondary flowery hops. Mild carbonation. Right on for style.

column1: City Steam Green Eyes & Red Hair
column5: Tap at the source - Clear orange, thin creamy off white head. Nice nose that held soft notes of smoke, caramel, and faint dark fruit tones. Smoked malt flavor up front fades into more toasty dark fruit notes. Rounds out with just a kiss of sweetness. Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, smoked finish. Nicely done and perfect to drink with a b-b-que meal...

column1: City Steam Green Eyes & Red Hair
column5: Draught @ Brewpub: This one pours a clear amber color, with very little head on it. It does leave some lacing down the glass. The aroma is decent enough, with mainly caramel malt to the nose. Hints of some peaty smokiness also. Mainly a medium-bodied caramel malt flavor, but finished with peaty taste on top. A hint of dryness in the finish also. Nice.

column1: City Steam Green Eyes & Red Hair
column5: I've been really digging Scottish ales lately, so though the previous couple of samples I had here were mediocre, I had some hopes for this one. WRONG! It sucked, bigtime. Pale and thin looking for a SA (light amber? looks like a goddamn amber ale), light malt body, hints of smoke in the nose, basically no hops, no carbonation, no flavor. Very very weak.

column1: Maple Leaf Mad Walters Winter Ale
column5: Little nose, like most of the beers here, but otherwise far and away the best thing I tried. Why didn't they turn this old-timey low-ceilinged place into a German-type brewpub, or just a place that served German food and decent German beers? Woulda been a lot better than what we have now. Oh, but the ski bums want a "brewpub" so they can be all cool. That's it. Anyway this is light brown in color, sweet and lightly spicy (nutmeg & anise) on the nose, full-bodied for a change, warming, fruity, earthy. Purty good, but I wouldn't drive for it.

Black beer with tan head and good lacing, light carbonation. Strong, winter warmer, strong alcohol, resinous. Strong beer, not a ton of complexity, but enough to satisfy, good for the style--rough and tumble beer, a true RIS!

On draft at the brewpub in Tucson. Pours black with a tan head. Mild malt nose. Flavors of dark fruits and a hints of coffee and chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel with moderate to light carbonation. Crisp finish.

Draft at brewpub. Pours Black with almost no head. Not getting much on the head. Lots of licorice and molasses notes on the tongue. Slightl hoppiness on the finish. Lingers a bit. No discernible alcohol burn. Solid for style.

on tap(2012 vintage) pours thick black with a medium brown head. Aroma is equal parts malt and hops, roast, big pine and resinous hops. Flavor is big roast and semi-sweet cocoa with a big dry finish of ash and pine. Really nice stuff.

[Cask] Sampled on cask at the brewery in mid January. Pours an inky black color with a average looking brown head. Very viscous looking. Boozy aroma complements espresso and general roasted malts. The taste is vanilla, coffee, smoke and heavy roast. Thick palate. Lingering alcoholic heat. A really solid beer.

Growler gift from Southern Johnny. This was a weird but enjoyable Stout. Pour was near perfect (Black, thin tan head). But the aroma was like tar, licorice and chocolate. Medium mouth feel with a bitter caramel, coffee flavor. Damn Good.

Growler at RBWG in March 2010. Pours a dark mahogany color with a lightly translucent, chestnut tinted edge. A thin, swirly, light brown film sits at the head, leaving behind minimal, spotted lacing. A quick shakeup indicates lacking viscosity, as the body seems a bit thin for the style. Aromas are very well balanced, giving notes of mild chocolate, burnt caramel roast, singed molasses, and some nougat. A subtle dash of earthen hops supports the roast in evening out the choco-caramel malt. Flavors follow suit, very smooth and chocolaty, pulled together nicely with toasted caramel, nougat, and mildly bitter, earthy hops. There might be a bit of coffee in there for good measure. As foreshadowed, the palate is a little on the thin side, lacking that weightiness that most good imperials show. Still, carbonation is spot on, and it comes across smooth, without much alcohol burn or cloying, sugary finish. Overall, it’s a pretty solid stout. Not stellar, but not terribly flawed either.

Ratebeer Winter Gathering. A: Pours a nice deep black with a nice darker shade of brown head. Lite retention with some spots of lace. S: Aromas of deep roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, toasted malt, and earth. T: Very roasted borderline bitter. Lots of bitter coffee and dark chocolate. Earthy but not smokey. M: Medium in body, a bit thin for the style. Good carbonation.
RBWG 2010 growler. Pours black with brown head. Roasted malt and chocolate aromas. Flavors of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate. Full body with moderate carbonation.
Warhead RBWG@RLRL-thanks to Beerlando-growler-pours an off white ring for a head and black color. Aroma is dark malt, earthy. Taste is dark malt-cocoa, earthy hops. Occasional.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a cloudy yellow to orange color with a bar pour’s kind of slim white head that dissipated immediately. No lacing was left. The smell had a decent sweet apricot with a light grassy and somewhat wheat edge in the background. The taste started off with the sweet apricot and let in a decent tart apricot edge to balance. Grassiness was somewhat there but maintains a decent background. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was somewhat sharp but still carried a delicate smooth behavior to it. Overall, I say this was a pretty good sessionable fruit beer I could have again.

On tap at TCB - Pours a hazy straw color with a light head. Has a very light fruit (apricot obviously) aroma. Flavor is sweet and fruity, but not overbearing like alot of fruit beers. Has a smooth light finish. Not bad. The wife really likes it.

Light gold color. Small head. Aroma is apricot and malts. A medium bodied fruit beer. The apricot flavor is fairly pronounced and somewhat sweet. There is supposedly over 700 pounds of apricots in each batch. It very pleasant. Light and refreshing. Malts and hops are fairly mild; the fruit is in the forefront. Balanced is OK> Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is sweet.
Light golden color, nice aroma of apricot, sweet apricot flavor, but very cooling and refreshing with a nice drying finish that begged for another sip. Quite good for a fruit beer.

Cask at the Back of Beyond (JDW), Reading. A rather ordinary bitter. Chestnut with a thin white head; fruity malt flavours developing slowly (perhaps served too cold?); and a nutty dry finish. No complaints, but nothing to enthuse about.
Cask conditioned at the Bag O’Nails, Bristol 22/5/07. Brown with a slight head. A sweet, malty aroma followed by a fruity flavour and sour finish. Not a beer I would bother to drink again.

Cask at Charlie’s Bar, Copenhagen. A hazy amber beer with a beutiful orange head. The aroma is sweet and freshly hoppy combined with notes of fruit. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of peaches, caramel, and elderberryflowers. The body is a bit thin.

Cask handpull at The Phoenix, Canterbury. Chestnut with thin beige head. Earthy, muddy in mouth with caramel and earthy/berb hop. Soft in mouth, and finish is not too assertive, fades quite quickly. Hop of finish needs to be more pronounced for my liking
Cask Handpump at the Vernon Arms, Liverpool 20/05/2002 A mid brown slightly rich beer with some bitterness in the malt finish.

Hand pulled at the Anchor, Birmingham, during their Archers weekend. Dark amber, with speckled lacing and a nice bitter aroma. Choc notes which linger on the finish.
