column5: Brasserie Audomaroise, Saint Omer. Tap. This is the amber with some chicory flavour - slight coffee, nettles, endive, braised celery heart, celariac, brown sugar and raisins. Sounds good, but it’s all a bit blurry - and having a lot of flavours is not in itself a great thing, it’s how the flavours work together that matters. So, points for originality and being intriguing, but minus points for pulling away from being aesthetically pleasing.

column1: Audomaroise Ambrée à la Chicorée / Bière des Cossettes
column5: 75 cl swingtop bottle "Ambrée à la Chicorée". Hazy amber, nice creamy offwhite head. Grassy aroma, wet cardboard, sweetish fruit Quite sweet, some harsh bitterness, burnt caramel. Not as bad as their rhubarb beer

column1: Audomaroise Ambrée à la Chicorée / Bière des Cossettes
column5: Bottle. Brownish/red beer with a steady bubble based head. The aroma is quite fruity and the flavour tastes more like strawberry/raspberry than a chicory, with a bitter and slightly dry finish. Overall a nice beer.

column1: Audomaroise Ambrée à la Chicorée / Bière des Cossettes
column5: Bottled. Hazy amber colour. Restrained, but very peculiar aroma, for which I struggle to find descriptive words. Fairly sweet, notes of caramel, salty finish. Ann odd experiment.

column1: Audomaroise Ambrée à la Chicorée / Bière des Cossettes
column5: Amber, slightly hazy. Very thick, foxy head, fast collapsing. Nose is like caramelised, slightly burnt, bitterish. Faint aroma's anyway. taste is quite bitter, obviously. Chicory, not coffee. There's quite some malt too. Retronasal the bitter gets stronger. Mouthfeel isn't very full, despite the malt. A bit oily, specially on the palate. Aftertaste consists of burnt caramel-like flavour. As clearly all beers of this brewer, very restrained profile. With chicory, perhaps for the best.
Clear golden with a decent white head and a lot of bubbles. Fruity aroma. Taste is rather fruity, grainy, with very little bitter elements.
Simple pilsner, very pale yellow color, but taste is not as watery as the appearance suggests. OK. Drinkable.
Fles 50cl in Hirschhorn. Prima pils. Lekker volle smaak. (8-2010).--------.

19.04.2018 -- 0.33l bottle from marktkauf, 0.79€. pours a clear pale golden with a steady head. nose of hay, bread, apples. flavour of grass, bread, citrus zest, less sweet as expected from the aroma. grassy bitterness in the finish. classic, if a bit light.
typical pilsener. grassy / hay aroma. also a slight malty taste. overall okay
Klares goldgelb mit dem Schaumkrone. Malzig, süßlich, getreidig, etwas Stroh, leicht herb.
On tap at pizzeria farfalla. Golden color compact White head classic pils look. Aroma light malt, straw, hay. Clean, light body, carbonated, dry finish.
[backlog] 11-12-15 // bottle at home. Clear golden colour. Big white head. Classic german pilsener. Clean and crisp. Grainy. Light bitter.
Riecht getreidig; hintergründig zitronig. Antrunk Getreide, Süße. Mitte weiterhin getreidig geprägt, süßlich, Spuren von Früchten. Abgang mit Würze und Herbe; wirkt streckenweise vergoren. Ok.

0,5 l bottle. Thanks a lot to kappldav123. Clear golden in the glass, nearly two finger off white head. Smells grassy with some hop bitterness. Taste starts with grain and malt, increasing hop bitterness, some bready elements. And again a respectable german standard Pils, but not really special.
a very session-able brew that pours a thin red with white head. Low IBU crisp dry and refreshing. Fairly priced widely available.

Enjoyed via 12 oz bottle. Pours a nice deep red color. Initially, I thought it might be similar to Hop Head Red or another one of their hop-forward examples. However, I was surprised to get heavy notes of malt in both the aroma, as well as on the palate. Definitely a "Dusseldorf" Alt, the drinker gets notes of Munich malt flavors, balanced to a pretty fair extent by the use of what I sensed to be German noble hops. It is a shame that this one is retired (I must have just lucked out and got an old bottle), as it was quite enjoyable.

Pours a slightly cloudy deep amber. Foamy tan head with some lasting power. Aromas of hops and caramel. Good flavors of caramel and malt, with a hint of citrus on the finish. Bought this because of the display at Sun Devil Liquors, but was nicely surprised.

Date: 09/03/2006 Mode: Bottle Source: Roadtrip clear dark red, big beige head, bits of lace, sweet bready biscuit malt aroma, good blend of malt flavors, a touch of chocolate, nice nuttyness, good dry carmel, bready biscuit, a bit oxidized, a touch of hop flavor and bitterness to keep it all in balance, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Roasted malt and dried fruit aroma. Amber color with a tan bubbly head. Flavor is sweet initially, with malt, rasin, and some caramel flavors. Slightly dry finish with a light bitter duration. Palate is full bodied. Flavor is nice and rich but not too heavy. Good.
Red in color with creamy head. Aroma was malts, roasted grains and hops. Flavor was rich in malts, caramel, dough, and a hop bitterness to the finish. Medium bodied and very satisfying. Good alt.

Pours a translucent ruby amber with an average off with creamy head that left some lacing. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, citrus hops, vanilla, lots of sweet malts! Flavor of sweet malts, slightly fruity an d little hoppy. Lingering hop bitterness.
Deep red color with nice head and lace. Tastes malty with an after taste of hops. IMO it’s a good blend of the two.

Rust hue with lasting creamy tan head, good lacing, oily, medium body, roasted grain malt a little doughy, light carbonation, light to medium hop, brown sugar or carmel hint of nutmeg or cinnamon and a little peachy smel maybe cobblerl, average duration. Decent average for Green Flash from what I have sampled.

Bottle: Reddish caramel, or "Ruby Red", moderate sand colored head, foamy, decent lacing. &nbsp Grain oriented nose, some meat and potatoes as well. &nbsp Reminds me of a nice meal! &nbsp Rich malty start, hop bitterness is lower than expected, still coming across as a meal, meat, potatoes, and vegetables all mixed together. &nbsp Decent body, moderate mouthfeel. &nbsp Meaty beer, just not overly interesting or filled with hoppy goodness that I thought this Red might be. &nbsp Still decent, probably great with dinner. &nbsp Hearty malty brew.
On draft at the brewpub it is a clear light Amber color with a slight head. The aroma is nutty and the taste is thin bitter with some hints of citrus and toast. With a bitter finish
On draft at the brewpub. Pours a clear copper with an off white head. Nutty nose. Flavors of wheat toast and grass. Bitter finish.
Sample. Amber color. Malty aroma. Taste is very similar. Is just alright. Nothing special.

Aroma: Hints of caramel malts, but very faint. Appearance: Clear amber with white head. Taste: Medium sweetness with faint hints of bitterness at the edges. Palate: Medium body, slick texture, soft carbonation, soft finish. Overall: Nothing overwhelming here. A nice, drinkable beer that went well with my burger.

Sample at the brewpub. Clear dark amber color with a medium off-white head that dissipates steadily to film. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, hops and caramel. Light-bodied with flavors of earthy malt, caramel and mild hops. The finish is sweet with a malty aftertaste. Decent overall.
Sample at Buckeye Beer Engine on 3/22/14. Clear copper color with a thin off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel and crisp noble hops. Malty and caramelly flavor with a dry hop and bread finish.
tap at beer engine. pours amber with a beige head. notes of bread, earth, czech hops, skunk. well crafted with some distinct flavors, but not my cup of tea.

light brown with moderate white head. nice crisp nobel hop nose. flavor of moderate, but sharp bitterness followed by some mild munich and some toasty malt flavors before a very pleasant floral noble hop flavor before a nice dry finish. a very well made alt, with prominent but balanced bitterness. with the paltry ratings that this beer has received, i wonder if people really understand the alt-style, i imagine not

On tap at the Beer Engine. Poured a orangey amber with very very light carbonation and a fast-fading off-white head. I can’t place the flavor - it reminds me of another style. I guess it’s the resinous hops but it’s more muted here than in the style I’m trying to name which I guess might be an IPA or a DIPA. A nice brew but not for another pint.

7/07/2008: Buckeye Arthur has a toasted orange color with a dense, fluffy biege head that provides good lacing. The aroma is dry and earthy with some wet grains and a hint of citrus. The flavor is also somehwat grainy, but I like the soft floral bitterness and soft, creamy mouthfeel. This beer is somewhat dry overall and has a mdium-full body. Nothing really jumps out, but it is still good and very sessionable. Draught at the Buckeye Beer Engine in Lakewood, Ohio. Rating: 6/4/6/4/12=3.2 . . . . . . . . . . July 17-19, 2008: Buckeye Arthur Ale doesn’t have much of an aroma and its flavor is grainy and plain with undertones of bread crust and a really milkd hop presence in the back. The beer is golden amber in color with a beige head on top. Overall this beer is smooth and easy to drink but isn’t particularly interesting. Draught sample (5% ABV) at Skipper’s Bar & Grille in Athens, Ohio during Ohio Brew Week 2008. Rating: 5/3/6/3/11=2.8 . . . . . . . . . . Rating #14 for this beer.
Draught at CAH under the name "Ale House Pilsner." Pours a clear light golden color with a thin head. Nose is a tad sweet in a weird way, and taste crappy lager sweet. Not a fan.
Drank from the tap at the brewery. Faint aroma of light malt. Taste is very clean, slightly watery with an almost graham cracker like aftertaste. Not bad for a light beer.
You have to rate it based on style and this is a pretty decent light beer. Not as bad as some of those macros out there, but you must remember, it is still a light beer.

Tasted on a recent visit to Woods on South in Charlotte, NC. Generally light in color with a very thin white head that dissipates to nothing. Aroma is very faint, some wheat present. Very little flavor to this beer with a slightly bitter finish. Reasonable for a light beer.

Draught. Think Sam Adams light with a bit less flavor. This is a decent take on the "light beer" idea. No off flavors or anything else gross on this one, but no pleasing flavors or body. This is really watery, but does manage to produce a nod at European hop flavor and maybe a drop of malt sweetness. Yeah, in summary this has no real bad taste and it kind of tastes like beer.
Pretty decent light beer. The only Carolina Blonde for me is NEEZY (with her hair died blonde). She is my Carolina Brunette. But this is a pretty tasty light beer, IMO.
Draught.Clear golden color. The head was gone by the time it came to the table. Subtle citrus hop flavor and taste. Crisp finish with honey/buttery aftertaste. Not bad.

Another house beer from Carolina Ale House in Cary. Gold pour with aroma and taste of malt, some hopcit, and finishing honey crispness. Earlier Rating: 4/25/2005 Total Score: 1.7 Pale gold pour with slight hopcit aroma. Not much taste, with some hopcit. Bland.
Bottle. Very weak beer. Small fizzy head (more than a bud) and pale body. Weak malt flavor and watery finish. Just weak all around.

taste? not there. refreshing i suppose. taste like a bad version of carolina blond. while i will drink this, i wouldnt buy it again. this is a drainpour at best. good god i never thought id say this, but id drink miller lite over this beer.
Decent brew. Reminiscent of Killian's but since its by a microbrewery, it had a littel more flavor and body. Decent beer overall, nice and easy to drink, good everyday styule beer.

Not a bad beer. Amber in color, decent eggshell head. Taste was syruppy, sweet. The finish was lacking, it had a slight graininess to it...the malt kinda gave up on the beer and led to a slightly bitter finish that bothered me. All in all, not bad though.

Draught@The Brewpub. Deep ambery reddish brown colour with mediumsized foamy brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, some slight dark dry fruity notes as well as some chocolate and toffee. Flavour is roasted malts along with some dark dry fruityness, toffee and mild notes of grass.

Draught at the brewpub. Dark murky brown, small creamy beige head. Roasted malts dominate, with raisins and figs, and notes of coffee, and spicy citrus hops. Medium bodied and very smooth. Very well balanced with a dry finish.

First rating Rating added 3/10/2006 Draught at Pannrummet, Göteborg, Sweden. Black color, creamy brown head. Sweet scent with some burnt in it, fruity hops as well. Very hoppy taste, hoppy aftertaste with a bit burnt flavor. Fruity and citrus in the hops. Lacks bitterness, but otherwise great. 8/4/8/3/16=3.9 Second rating (Draught at the brewpub) On March 28, 2008 Clear dark brown to black color, light brown head. Roasted, a bit sweet, chocolate and licorice taste. Sweet malty scent. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness. 7/4/7/4/15=3.7 Rerate (Draught at the brewpub) On September 26, 2008 Clear deep dark red color, dense light brown head. Roasted tones and roasted barley scent. Roasted and fruity sweet taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness. 7/4/6/3/14=3.4

Bottle. Aroma of strong liquorice - sweet and salty. Almost black colour, semi-stable head. Flavour is dusty, liquorice, malty. Hint of salt. Coffee aftertaste. Solid mouthfeel. High carbonation. Vintage 2003, thanks to rickgordon.
Roughly 1 year old sample Roasted chocolate, some minerals. Dark brown. Creamy lightish body.
Dark brown, almost no head. Aroma from coffee, cocoa and tar. Flavor brings coffee, cocoa, cream. Malty with some fruits. Malty finish.

A dark brown beer with no head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of roasted chocolate. The flavor is roasted with notes of chocolate, roasted bread as well as hints of sourness, before a dry end sets in.
Dark brown, stoutish. Aroma of toffee and carmel. Mouthfeel is light about like water. Finish is sweet and somewhat chalkish.
Dark murky brown. Only marginally prettier than a barley wine - yikes. Toffee-coffee aroma with a hint of candy caramel. Fairly light and wet - with vague toasty, nutty notes.

Bottled: Brown coloured. Light brown thin head. Malt, fruit, light alcahol in the aroma. Is fresh. Cocoa, maltfullness, fruit and some spices in the flavour. Is light bitter and grassy in the end. Quite like this.
Röstiger, recht süßer Beginn. Süffig, mittelstarke Bitternoten, zum Ende wässrig. In Ordnung. 10/8/9/8//8
Cloudy reddish brown with an off-white head. Smoke aroma. Taste is caramel and prunes with some wood and a dry finish.
on tap at the brewpub. Thick creamy off white head. Slightly hazy amber pour. Bitter sweet caramel finish
On tap at the brewery. Nice tan head and glowing mahpgny colour. Caramel and molasses aroma. Bready flavours, slightly sweet, some caramel. Not bad.

My Bottom Line : Earthy hops and toasted, caramelized malts roam within this Dunkel’s foamy, sugary mouthfeel. Further Personal Perceptions : -A clinging sheet of foam decorates the coppery mahogany. -Fruity edges add diversity. -Malts seem to provide more sugar than actual malt flavors. -The flavor profile is not really cohesive, but it remains flavorful throughout. On tap at the brewery gasthof.
Smooth, tasty dunkel that packs a lot of malty flavor, more so than some of its counterparts making it a great easter-time beer.

Draught at the brewpub: Hazy, ruby-amber coloured, firm creamy off-white head; caramelly toasty nose with a subtle fruitiness underneat; dryish bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied; chocolatey traces in the dryish bitter and dark-malty finish. Not too bad......

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden dark brown with a small tan head. Roasted malt, breadish and mild caramelish aroma. Flavour has the same with a nice sweetness and good bitterness to match this.

At Unionsbräu in Munich. Does not have as pronounced a unique aroma as Unionsbräu’s Helles(actually a Kellerbier) or Maibock. A decent dunkel but not super exciting. A little thin in body and a little lighter in flavor than I would want. Still decent. Serving: Tap
Dark brown with nice thin head. Hints of diacetyl, toffee on the nose. Butter palate with some toast and light toffee. Still drinkable, but not by much.

Sampled at the brewpub, amber-orangeish color, with a white head, floral hops accent, with a note of orange fruitiness, toasted malt in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a herbal fruitiness from the sterling and saaz hops, earthy spiciness, zesty citrusy note, leading towards a fruity hop bitterness finish.

Draught pint at CBC 5/5/06. Pours a light coppery color with a small off white head. Nose is light apples, some toasted malt notes. Palate is clean and smooth. Flavor is lightly hoppy, some toasty and spicy notes. FInish is lightly bitter.

Draft at Bukowski, Boston: poured slightly cloudy yellow in a pint glass with a thin wisp of ahead. Light banana aroma. Mild apple. Decent body. The flavor is thin: light lemon, somewhat grainy malt flavor. Decent but kind of lacking. 6-3-5-3-13 Draft at Brewery: Pours orange with a small white head. Earthy aroma with hints of chocolate. Light citrus flavor. Lightly carbonated. Good.

Moderately sweet and malty Vienna character with some toasted malts and no hops notable in the nose. Hazy glowing copper-tan coloured body is topped by a dense, fine-bubbled, white head that recedes slowly to a persistent cover with excellent lacing. Toasted, nutty, malty and sweet flavour with light, spicy, herbal hops and fair balancing bitterness in the dry finish. Medium body with moderate carbonation and a creamy texture. On tap at the brewpub with MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

New England Road Trip Easter ’05 with MartinT, tiggmtl and Rastacouere, beer #64. Sample at the brewpub. Ridiculously generous, lasting head with thick gorgeous lacing tops the pure gold body...herbal, grainy sourdough nose feeds my desire...luscious body with complex dissimilar leafy greens jousting at caramel, bitter smokiness, and vanilla cream, but alway fresh grass underlies and an odd pungent farmy texture coats the superb mouthfeel as tongue leads to throat and ecstasy. Easily one of the best Viennas around...

Funky, cheesy wort and citrusy flowers waltz languorously atop the luxurious green Saaz hops...Really reminiscent of L’Amère à Boire’s succulent Cerna Hora...An undying head and nutritious malt body reach perfection and send the soul high above...

Hazy gold, superbly laced white head, fully lasting after 30 minutes. Strong Saaz nose, floral and lemony. As clean as it gets. The melting between the Vienna malts and hops is remarkable to say the least. Grassy rosewater. Very appealing. Grainy malty palate, VERY malty, but unfortunately not my favourite variety. The bitterness is very solid, balancing. Now I know my friends all liked it more than me, but I’m with them on the brewing efforts part. It’s just unfortunate that this wasn’t a dortmunder with the almost exact same recipe using all pils malt instead, because I would have given out the big marks on that. I just don’t enjoy the grainy Vienna as much as the biscuity and charming chewy pils types. Marvellous April beer, a little hidden treasure some will say.

On draught at CBC, March 16, 2005. Served in a tumbler, well-chilled but not overly so, this beer appeared a copper-yellow with light orange tints. Moderate amount of off-white head is well-retained. Slight chill haze. Aroma is not overwhelming, due in part to it being served in a shaker. Husky graininess, light pils malt and toasted malt, with a dry, yet spicy, hops bitterness (saaz). Flavor is much more explosive than the aroma would suggest. Big dose of sweet toffee and honey up front, great malting, with a smooth, lightly dry, saaz bitterness. Crisp and clean on the finish, some light citrus hops notes are perceived as well (sterling). Body is medium to medium-full but yet wonderfully drinkable, as are so many of CBC’s low gravity creations. You can almost taste the cracked grains in this, as you can in the Regatta Golden. Malt is varied, as well, with some light caramel, toffee, toastiness and honey. A touch of fruitiness is also apparent up front, from the yeast and provides more depth. A bit of astringency on the end, from the graininess and drying hops effect, but it’s minor, and I’d rather this beer tend more dry than sweet. Carbonation is soft and bubbly, no alcohol apparency. Keep em comin, CBC!

Deep golden to light orange in color with a small white head. Huge malt aroma, with a touch of bread and a trace of floral hops. Clean crisp malt flavor with subtle floral hops and a slighlty sweet finish.Full malty palate for the style, which I feel is much better than people are giving it credit for, a good session lager.
Growler: Clear orange with a thin white head. Fresh malty aroma, full bodied and ends slightly sweet. Too light for my tastes.

Leicht karamelliger Antrunk, leicht säuerlich, hefig-herb. Im Mittelteil deutlich aber dennoch verhalten fruchtig, dies geht langsam in einen seichten Malzton über. Dieser Malzton steigert sich im Abgang und wird würziger, auch die Herbe wird etwas kräftiger. ZUdem ist das Bier hier relativ süß. Nettes Exemplar. Vielen Dank an den Doppelbock für das Bier! Test vom 11.5.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,11,10,10,11,10 - 10,10

Wow, a nicely balanced biére de garde, very drinkable and yet with plenty of unique character. I’m thinking that down below are some ratings of old or off bottles. Big thanks to Sebastian for bringing this 75 cL bottle to me. Tall, off-white and bubbly head recedes, over a thickly cloudy, coppery reddish-orange beer. Smells like caramel malts but also sweet oranges and a bit creamy, and I’m thinking of orange creamsicles. Interesting. Flavor is an immediately tasty and balanced combo of lightly sweet oranges and caramel riding along on lively carbonation into a dry, moderate bitterness. Incredible balance, so easy to drink. Really, really lovely. I hope to get some more and drink it fresh one of these days.
Sampled at the RBESP 2004 Lactic sour, green wood and hayish. Cloudy orange, low head. Lightish body. Couldn’t really get used to it...
A hazy orange beer with a small collapsing orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of coriander and yeast. The flavor is sour and malty - I’m wondering if it was over the best before date?
Hazy dark blond. Straw-like, dusty aroma. Pale malt notes in the flavour, with a slight lacticity in the finish. OK beer, but a little too yeasty.
Bottled. Cloudy orange colour, pale orange/off-white head. Floral nose with a big yeast presence. Quite malty for being a ’Garde’. A bit sour and lactic. Dry bitter finish.
Bottled: Unclear orange coloured. Off white head. Is sweet and malty in the aroma. Some fruitnotes. Flavour is a little sour and "old". Some fruitnotes and maltsweetness. Is light bitter in the end.

Light floral hops, but not very strong aroma. Grain. Cloudy butterscotch with lacing head. Medium body with light carbonation. Starts tart, with lactic acidity. Tart berry inish, some wheat and chalky bitterness. After is dry bitter, grainy.

Also this one is 1 year old. Copper color. Nice aroma, almost like the Hommelpap (fruity, with oranges…). Quite simple, not as much sweet, with some sourness and a late bitterness. Thanks Joris for sharing this bottle.
Bottled. Pale orange, cloudy. Pale orange head. Fruity peach aroma. Sweet and malty with grassy, orangey bitter finish.

On tap at the brewpub. Deep gold in color (unless you are looking just at the brown paper poke) with a small white head. This has the aroma of enantiomeric alpha-D-glucose and likely has plenty of it instead of malt. It produces the desired effect of corn grain ethanol in beer form. Not great, but good kitsch.
On tap @ the brewpub. Dark golden coloured with a medium sized head. Malty with notes of metal, fruit, bread, pines, alcohol and grains.

Chicago Trip. Monday 12:30+. On tap. The funnest beer I don’t like. Tried for a malt liquor and succeeded. Supposedly the clientèle gets the joke and pints are served in a paper bag. Don’t quite smell the gasoline but the taste is bang on. As it warms the gasoline comes through. Orange-copper.

On tap at Piece.. served in a fitting Piece-stamped brown paper bag. Poured a clear, deep coppery-amber with lots of rising carbonation and a well-retained cap of off-white head. The aroma was of sweet corn and caramel with some floral accents and something akin to Candi sugar.. peppery spices in there too. The flavor was a sweet blend of grainy corn and alcohol with what felt like some sort of Belgian-inspired spicy yeast.. warm and peppery spices and booze at the back-end.. oddly arousing. There were waves of sweetness and spiciness on the palate.. medium-bodied and almost syrupy.. grainy throughout. Warm finish. It’s Dolemite, BABY!
Pours an amber color with a white head. Aroma is malty with some corn. Flavor is malty, with some corn and a clean finish. Goes pretty well with their pizza.

Draught, passed around the table by TheBeerCellar2 to myself, NachlamSie, and shp555. First of all, the damned thing comes in a pint glass in a paper bag with the Piece logo on it. I’m giving bonus appearance points for presentation there. Past that, it’s definitely a malt likka. Lots of corn, but actually in a sort of fresh way. A weird sugariness fills up the mouth and gives it very round edges. Definitely nothing to be excited about, but it blows most other malt liquor out of the water.

Draught courtesy of TheBeerCellar2 during my Dark Lord excursion. Well, I wasn’t too excited about this one, but really curious. The pour is darker gold than most other malt liquors I’ve seen. Pretty much what I would expect from the style, but surprisingly clean given the constraints of the style that usually spell disaster. To keep this beverage this crisp and relatively balanced while using corn, no hops, and a alcohol content at 8% is pretty impressive. There are flavors of corn, a little sucrose, slightly bitter malty flavors on the back of the palate. Probably not something I would drink again because it does have all the characteristics of a style that doesn’t do it for me, but I was much happier with this than the one other premium malt liquor I’ve tried.

Draught, served in a pint glass surrounded by a small brown paper bag: dark golden appearance, with a thin white cream…smells absolutely like a malt liquor: sweet corn, honey, bready, malt filled alcohol and hay. Sweet, alcohol malt flavour with a bit of tang. The initial flavour is much better than the other malt liquors I have experienced and makes me wonder at the amount of few adjuncts used in the creation of this one: for the flavour is an even balance of sweet sticky malt and crisp hops; I didn’t think it was allowed to use noticeable hops in a malt liquor…anyway, the finish does remain true to the style with a sour malt twinge and a slightly foul hop aftertaste…but this is one of the better tasting and easier drink malt liquors I have come across.

Pours a nice straw color with good head and some lacing. Nice and clean with a good alcohol burn. Served in a pint glass with a paper bag with a Piece logo on it. It is a good brew that will creep up on you if you don’t watch out. It’s nice when a brewer brews something like this just for fun.

From what the bartender said, this brew had 9.5% alcohol and it tasted every bit of it. Malt taste was pretty good, fairly light with good carbonation. The alcohol gave it a real kick from start to finish. Each beer was served in a pint glass with a little paper bag around it. I’ve seen it done before, but still pretty fun.

Tasted on tap at Piece Pizzeria Brewery. It poured a nearly clear golden amber hue with a quickly disapating white head. Sweet orange floral aroma with a turbo hopped taste. Went great with the spinach & garlic pizza. This 7.2%er pleased this hophead.
On tap at the brewpub. Orange pour with a big white head. Aroma is floral and fruity. Taste is grapefruit, bitter, and light toast. Good finish.
Tap at Piece. Pretty decent APA/IPA. Clean golden malt bill. Kind of a new school hop bill, but not as pronounced as its Chicago peers. Fruity, delicate hops. OK.

Pours orange honey amber with a creamy white head. Aroma brings sweet malty and hoppy oranges, a subtle blend of the two. Flavor of oranges and zesty malts, lightly sweet on the tongue on a smooth medium body.

On tap at Piece wicker park with duke. Pours a pale yellow amber, mild head. Aroma of bubblegum, hay, mango. Flavor is gooey sweet citra hop, bubble gum & pale bready malt, finishes a little sweet. Med mouthfeel, quite drinkable.

Clear golden yellow, small white head. Melon, bubblegum, fresh hay. Slight bitterness upfront transitioning into more mellow sweetness. Medium long finish, chewy medium body. Nicely done, pretty well balanced. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Super malty ale that is easy to drink. Not much odor with a hint of citrus. Pours light yellow in color. Had this a piece watchin the World Cup ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

7/20/2011: Piece Dysfunctionale... Aroma: Smells like TANG! Appearance: Golden orange color, hazy; thin white crown. Flavor: Toffee malt, lots of citrusy hops; moderate bitterness. Palate: Medium-light body; softly, slightly oily. Overall: Delicious bitter! I’m going to have a pint or two... or three... Draught (6.5% ABV) at Piece in Chicago, IL. Rating #104 for this beer.

Growler pour, thanks Andy! Great brew here, an IPA but not a huge one, very easy to drink. Draft. Golden hazed pour. OK in the smell think in el Dorado. Flavor is more melon with just a hint of earthy caramel malt.

Had on tap at Piece. Served in a nonic pint glass. A: Pours a golden amber color with a pure white head. Some splotches of lace are left behind. S: Nice balance between light fruit, grass and sweet malts. Definitely on the lighter end though and I really got to dig my nose in there to get anything. T: Taste is a little richer with some grassy hops, mild bitterness, a little citrus rind and the sweet, malty finish to give it a little balance. M: Medium to light bodied. Pretty drinkable with nice carbonation level as well. O: Solid overall. Nicely balanced, but I prefer several other offerings from Piece in the hops category. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 08-01-2012

Draft: Deep black. Creamy, charred caramel head. Intense aroma of coffee bean, tar, peachy hops, and coconut shells. Black currant, rubber, mud, butter toffee, almond, and black cherry whispers. Asserts more vinous aspects as it warms. Softly firm, dense, creamy body. Beautiful creamed coffee notes and quite caramelly at first. Vague cherry, vanilla, powdery chocolate, and tingly vinous hints. Ink notes prevail throughout its entirety. Closes with hints of toastiness and pie crust alongside a ravishing blend of espresso, dark chocolate, and smoke. Muted tingly vinous notes. Overall a voluptuous Imperial marriage of caramel, coffee, vanilla, and chocolate.

Draught [snifter]: (this rating is for the imperial stout they "The Truth" - I believe it is the same. . .) Deep ruby black w/ a lasting (it remained when the liquid was gone) dark brown creamy head. . .vinous and coating. Old fashioned instant coffee aroma mixed with large fresh whole coffee beans, hints of pine, basil and hops. Tremendous mocha coffee flavours that coat the mouth and offer a slight sweetness before hammering the palate with bitter dark chocolate and a strong bitter black coffee. Full body, but in the end it is over-powered by the coffee and is missing the complex fruits and other flavourful dimensions of a great imperial stout - though even Jule said "Oh, my, that's good!"

Light golden amber with definate cascade hops aroma. Rich, chewy malt body is caramelly and sugary...cookies and biscuits. Hops is citrusy at the finish, some grapefruit and orange rind...big flavor from a small pizzaria!

Draft on tap at the brewpub (Chicago, IL). Surprised to find a new entry here. Pours a nice deeper copper hazy pour, nice glowing orange, amber glow. Frothy offwhite head atop is sizable, good stick around and lacing. Aromas are a bit carmelized, gentle earthiness, spice, faint florals and toast. Initial is medium bodied, touches of toast, biscuit and carmelized malt, faint dark fruit meets earthy hop, subtle spice. A gentle giryth but not as toasty or rich as other examples. Some toast, carmelized elements preach harder into that backend. Earthy hop, faint spice, but that malty life gives the character here. Finish is a bit toasty, carmelized and earthy, gentle spice and earthy hops. A bit spicy as we finish and it really lingers on. Different than your typical Okt. Solid. A sweeter nose leads to a more complex beer.
Draft at piece. Orange and cloudy with white head. Biscuits and malty earth tastes - slightly fruity. Very enjoyable Oktoberfest.
Cloudy red pour with a thin red head. Big grain aroma with some sweetness in there. Medium mouth full of grain, sugar & bread.

Draft sampled at the brewpub. Pours hazy copper with an off white head. Aroma of malt, light citrusy hops, grain. Flavour is light moderate sweet and moderate bitter. Light to medium bodied with light carbonation.

Draft at Piece. Pours a hazed orange with a thinnish white head. Nose is toasty malt and an herbal hop note. Very clean with faint sweetness. On tasting, rich and round malt. Clean and bready. Balanced bitterness overall. Great malt character, drying finish. Really solid Oktoberfest.

Flavor is a bit sweeter than many Octoberfest beers and I really appreciate that. Definite caramel note. Much more restrained on the maltiness than many Oktoberfests as well. I usually don’t like this style but this is one I did enjoy.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear earthy orange with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is full of malts with notes of bread, hay and grain backed by just a hint of caramel sweetness. Flavor is similarly malty with mainly bread and hay notes backed by some sweet grains and a hint of caramel.

On tap at piece under the name ’octoberfist’. P is a clear pumpkin orange w little head and no lacing. Nose is harvest malts , wheat and some pumpkin. Taste is similar ; light spicing over a wheaty base... A bit underwhelming.

Murky red brown with a small head. Light malt aroma with dry tannic toastiness and a touch of earthy hops. Dry and toasty flavor with a tannic bite and just a little sweetness. Coarse body. Not somethingij could get into. Needs some more malt and overall balance.

Pours a murky copper with no head, looks like a soda. Lightly toasted malt aroma. The flavor is almost correct, if not for being too light and the alcohol ruins it. Slightly nutty toasted malt, nice lagered flavor. I could see this recipe being reworked into something delicious.
Pretty mediocre for a Piece offering. I had it a bit too long ago to have many specific comments, but I remember it as weak, watery, and uninteresting.
Tap at brewery 7/6/0-cloudy yellow appearance with rocky thin head-aroma of citrus and grains-palate is full bodied for a wheat and definately something i could drink all day.

This barely cloudy Summer wheat is a nice "little brother" to their mighty "Top Heavy Hefe"! Light and slightly fruity (not as much so as, say, Gumballhead) with a wheaty taste that doesn't fall towards the banana side, but more of a clean, hoppy, light citrus side. Refreshing and perfect with their spinich dip, but they also had FFF Gumballhead on tap, so my wife opted for that instead.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Un hommage sympathique à une figure du Nord, Raoul de Godewarsvelde. Une bière agréable sans être exceptionnelle.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: 07/05 0.75 l bottle courtesy of Doggythedog, thanks for sharing! It poured golden body with floating particles and medium sized head above. Biscuit malt and fruity yeasty aroma. Slightly sweet flavor, slightly sour, touch of wood, coriander and other herbal spices. Medium to thinner body with slightly sweet finish. As we all agreed on tasting, a fine beer, no obvious flaws, but so ordinary that it can easily become boring.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Botted 750ml. -Courtesy of Marko (thanks!), shared with heavy and him. Golden coloured, medium sized white head, dusty metallic nose with hint of spices. Sweetish malty, slight spicy and mild hoppy herbal taste with notes of cardboard near the end. Nothing special here.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: 0.75l bottle from a Carrefour in Lille. Brought to Croatia when it couldn’t fit in my luggage by Plavec, whom I thank enough! Shared with the Croatian crew. Poured a misty golden body with a fluffy medium sized white head. Soft creamy nose, some metal, dust and flowers. Sweetish, slightly vinuous taste, light herbal hops, a bit corky. Creamy sweetish ale, highly drinkable, without any flaws, but hardly more than "ok".

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle 75cl. A cloudy orange beer with good head. This is a basic triple kind of beer, mostly dry, good malty and wheat presence, slightly metallic hops. A bit heavy yeast aroma, correct in the average, not too lemony and acid but quite astringent, remains drinkable.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottle@Home. Citrus aroma. Yellow colour, white head, good lace. Sweet, citrus, light bitter, bit citric. Watery yet sparkling. Very boring.

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Bottled. Hazy golden, rich creamy head. Light-medium bodied with some fruitiness. The nose provides grassy hops, later on vailla and raspberries join as well. Lively and well rounded - very well structured and homogenous. I like this!

column4: Brasserie des Sources (formerly: de St. Amand)
column5: Yellow-gold with greenish shine throughout. Very thick white head, big bubbles, stable. Grain, pale malt, maybe some candi sugar in the nose. Whilst pouring I had a drain-odour, but that was immediately gone. Taste is quite dry, bitterish with an outspoken pale malt underbuild. There is candi sugar. Retronasal, the bitterness definitely gets hopcharacter, together with a cheese-rind flavour. Quite clean palate, medium-bodied. Some alcohol, sugar and dry; no new aftertaste. Overall a rather strong blonde, not yet triple. Clean tasting. Named after a local folk-poet.

12 oz. can. Canned 08/28/19. Pours a thick, well retained, white head, slight lacing, over a clear dark yellow (SRM 4) body......nose is heavy wheat, bread from malts, light lemon tones from hops......taste is wheat malts, with slight bread notes, dry throughout, finishing with mild lemon notes and light bitterness.....mouth feel, medium light body, no alcohol, moderate carbonation. This meets the style cleanly and nicely with the appropriate hop choice for the fruit notes, creating a pleasant refreshing and drinkable beer for the warm time of year.

Can. Orange citrus aroma with notes of wheat malt, straw, clove and bubblegum. Pours clear, pale golden colored with a large off white head that has excellent retention and some lacing. Starts with wheat malt, straw and clove flavors. Finishes smooth, but dry with orange citrus and bubble gum flavors. Pretty nice wheat that is also quite different from most.

Can. Cloud dark gold with a thick, creamy, white head that lasts and laces well. Aromas of wheat, pine, lemon, straw, grapefruit, slight bubblegum. Flavor is the same, wheat, straw in the front, pine, lemon, grapefruit follow with a slight, lingering bubblegum. Medium bodied, smooth with a dry, wheaty finish.

Draft at Bru Craft. Mostly clear deep yellow pour with a finger of soft pillowy foam. Thick lace. Medium-light caramel malts. Full, juicy, and zesty. Some peppery hops. Crisp finish. Slight plastic aftertaste.
Clear deep yellow appearance. Aroma is slightly fruity and slightly bready. Taste is fruity with orange, sugars, fruity pebbles. So gumball makes sense with the sugary fruit. Thick palate. Tap
Great hoppy wheat beer. Citrus and piney with a lemon twist on the finish. Big yeasty notes.
A tasty summer wheat beer but I guess I'm not getting the hype. Easy drinking wheat with some lemon notes but a bit of chalkiness on the back end.
At Trolls Pub Louisville. Blond colored beer with small white head and no carbonation. Hoppy floral aroma. Full palate. Finish is bitter sweet fruited.

Pours clearish topaz with a thin ivory head. Aroma offers tropical, butterscotch and fresh malt notes. Flavor provides tropical and citrus, raw malt, resiny hops. Texture features fair body and peppy fizz. Get gummed up - but please designate a driver or contact Lyft.
Pretty cool, but also a bit odd. Like the kid at school who has the best birthday parties, but also likes to eat dirt.
Good head and lace, but not extreme. Filtered it shows a very clean yellow color. The touch of honey is done right, sweetness without being cloying.

column1: Big Buck Polar Bear Brown Ale
column5: Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a dark red close to brown color with just a cap of a little white head that slides out into oblivion. No lace. The aroma had some semi-sweet nutty to caramel malts. Earthy bitter hops, some citrus. The flavor leaned into the malts fairly sweet. Hops make a good play to add a bigger than normal bitterness in this style. Aftertaste was full of the hops and so was the finish. The feel was between light and medium bodied. Carbonation felt just a touch over. ABV felt decent. Overall, as a brown ale fan, it’s hard to recommend this one. And Big Buck brews better beers than this, to be honest.

column1: Big Buck Polar Bear Brown Ale
column5: Weak head, some lacing. Slightly cloudy. Carbination was 'sharp' on the tongue. Overly hoppy aftertaste. My least favorite of five I tried on this particular evening.

Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass at the brewpub. The appearance was a decent looking hazed over brown color with light orange tints to it. There was a light lacing that came down from a one finger white foamy head once it died down. The smell had a mild burnt caramel maltiness to it to lead to that typical soapiness from a Bitter, but actually, its quite subdued than most Bitters I’ve had. The taste was mildly creamy sweet. Instead of the hops showing any kind of flavoring, it seemed like the malts were roasted enough to provide a slight bready to toasty effect. On the palate, this one sat at a light on the body with a pretty decent sessionability about it, if I wanted to have this again. The carbonation was there but subdued for the most part. Overall, it was not a bad Bitter. It wasn’t a bad beer to me, but not really a real Bitter.
Good head and strong lace. Golden brown color that was appealing. A bitter, but very mild, with almost none of the standard 'vinegary' taste associated with such brews.

We tasted all of the beers at big buck today, and this was the best of current availability (the belgian strong being second). Nice and dark, great color, but an unimpressive head. Aroma and taste were malty and complex and nice, a little hops as part of the complexity. On the heavy side of medium body. Quite nice, that’ll be my drink of choice if I go there again.

On tap, going on about 2-hr memory. Dark amber color, very nice head and retention. Especially sweet, particularly in the finish. Perhaps a nutty sweetness. Quite unique among the doppelbocks I’ve tried.
Head and lace are good. My favorite of the five I tried this particular evening. Nice color and the right level of bitterness.

On tap at Big Buck, Gaylord. Part of the "Brewer’s Private Gourmet Collection," listed at 12.7% ABV. Presumably this is close enough to this listing to rate here. Deep opaque brown/black body, thin ring of medium brown carbonation. Sweet nose with molasses and licorice. Chewy body with a ton of sweet chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and berries; smooth, silky, sweet, and rich. Little apparent alcohol despite the likely-inflated ABV.

GABF 2006: Deep black color with a brown head. The aroma was of sweet roasted malt with some mild chocolate notes. The flavor was very sweet with a good bit of chocolate and roasted malt. The finish was warming to the point of just a light burning.
draft at 2004 MSBF. good murky black appearance, minimal head. unmemorable aroma of molasses and toast, lightly bitter. average flavor for an imperial stout, feels very thin.

Draft at 2004 MBG Summer Festival. Small tan head with fine-small sized bubbles that were mostly lasting. Uncarbonated, opaque with a dark brown hue. Malty and coffee aroma with a hint of chocolate. Malty flavor from start to finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium bodied beer with fair lacing.
Draft at MBG fest. Black full body. No carbonation. Tannish thin head. Very coffe and malty tast and aroma. Very pleasing brew.

Michigan Brewers Guild Summer Beer Festival Saturday July 24, 2004. The draft brew poured a small head of finely sized brown colored mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a great lacing. The body was opaque and black in color with no visible carbonation. The aroma was strong with big roasted malts and a lingering roasted malty note. It had a mouth feel with strong roasted malt start and finish. The flavor also contained the same strong roasted malts. It was very good, but the roasted notes tended to overpower the rest of the beers highlights.

Terribly unbalanced mesh of soy sauce, chocolate, and alcohol in the samples from the Michigan Summer Beer Fest. I saw more than one sample dumped to the ground after a small sip. Very strange aftertaste, chocolate-licorice and alcohol linger.
Chocolate foam with reasonable lace. Pretty 'thin' taste going down and leaves a trace of burn with the slight medicine after taste.

Poured into a pint glass, the appearance was a dark brown almost black color with an off white foamy head that dissipated at a nice pace. Sly stringy lace. The aroma had some sweet to roasty graininess up front. Then some dark chocolate and a touch of coffee bean. The flavor took all of the prior mentioned aromas to blend and then add in a touch of earth and peat. Sly woody to peat to roasty aftertaste. Quick dry crisp earthy/peat/roasty sort of finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a great smooth feel rolling all about over my tongue. Good carbonation. For the ABV, though low, it feels like right the brewer says it’s at. Overall, nicely done Irish dry stout, somewhat crushable.
Dark. Dry cocoa, roasted, burnt malt. Chalky medium body with a dry finish. Very nice.

Bellingham, Wa - on tap at Boundary Bay. Nice dark black pour with a thin khaki colored head. Grainy aroma with a hint of unsweetened dark chocolate. Flavor is bold and rich and has some nice baker’s chocolate accents, some fresh potting soil and a touch of coffee. Mouthfeel leans to the thin side. Rating #41 of my 2016 vacation.

Serving: from nitro tap at Boundary Bay Brewery and Bistro. Aroma: light malt aroma. Appearance: average-sized, creamy, light-brown initial head with fair lacing and mostly diminishing longevity. Clear, dark-brown body. Taste: lightly soapy initial flavor and lightly roasty finish with short duration. Palate: medium-to-full body, watery texture and soft carbonation. Overall: I wouldn’t drink this again.

On tap at Boundary Bay, pours an amber-tinged deep dark brown with a medium beige head. Aroma of lightly bitter dry roast, oats and a touch of bitter dry cocoa. Flavour is quite dry and very bitter, with bitter roast and metallic notes dominating. Thin body with a weak flavour profile. Not too inspiring.

Draught at the brewpub Black color, with beige creamy head. Light aroma of cardboard, paper and roasted malt. Dry mouthfeel, smooth, but maybe because of some diacetyl there is also a light milky feeling, so it lands between Dry Stout and Milk Stout; ordinary bitterness. Easy.

on tap at the infamous boundary bay and bistro in bellingham. dark rich color with off white head. full of chocolate aroma and coffee. taste was simple with chocolate coffee taste and small layers of hoppy after taste

Draft at the Old Town in Ballard. On nitro, alas...but this beer is big enough to fight through that. Pours jet black and a wee bit chalky looking under a dense and creamy tan brick of nitromousse. Nice roasty nose with mild chocolate notes coming through. Creamy medium body, I mean really creamy silky smooth, with virtually no carb showing. Roasty chocolately mid palate, very rich and approachable and pleasant. Mild roasty finish. Very agreeable. Love to try this on CO2 some time.

Sample at Boundary Bay brewpub. Poured a dark but slightly permeable black with tan head. Aroma of coffee, some roast and slight chocolate. Taste was warming, layered and very decent. Malt is toasty with good residual hop bite. Excellent offering.

Nitro tap at the brewery. Black pour with a pillowy light beige nitro head. Mild aroma of coffee. This is a smooth, creamy, low sweetness stout that finishes very dry, as the name suggests. This tastes of pleasantly coffee and chocolate toastiness with a touch of smoke and char. Slightly acidic.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Draft @ Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar, Montréal. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty smooth weak hoppy aroma. Fruity malty creamy hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty creamy grainy hoppy finish.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: On tap at Le Cheval Blanc. Clear orangey-golden with a medium creamy white head, good retention, leaving some lacing. Aroma is herbal forward with citrusy hops and honeyed malts. Taste is of chewy honeyed malts alongside herbal hops, caramel and mild citrusy presence. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel. It’s a bit boring but it’s easy drinking and I liked the combination between the honeyed malts and the herbal presence.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Draft at the brewpub with Linh, Ken and Nica. Pours a clear blonde yellow body with thick white head. Aroma is grains and bitter grass. Mouthfeel is medium, crisp and dry with notes of bitter grass, light grains, faint skunk character and lemon malt. Pretty plain overall, but not terrible.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: nitro-tap on the premises. clear golden pour with an obvious creamy off-white head, good retention and lacing. lightly toasted cereals, big chewy cardboard notes (!), herbal, grassy, slightly earthy english hops, some fruity notes too, dash of citrus and minerals. low carbonation, light body - creamy indeed, short grassy-earthy-citrusy finish. balanced but boring and almost bland.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: On tap at brewpub. Malty and earthy beer. Creamy texture. Not bad, but not really good neither. Not much to say about this one...

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Decent for style. Pours orange with creamy head. Great lace. Soft creamy texture. Malt forward aroma that finishes woth light malty sourness. Not bad, especially for style. Tap at brewpub.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: En fut a la brasserie. Malté. Rafraichissant. Un peu terreuse. Fine amertume. Crémeuse. Belle équilibre sucre/amer. Étanche la soif. Bien réussi.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Dégustée en fût sur place. De couleur ambrée-orangée et voilée. Nez de grains de céréales amoyen-léger de houblon assez floral et avec des herbeuses et fruitées (agrumes, notes de pêche). Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture crémeuse azotée. Léger goût de levures fruitées (agrumes, léger de pêche) avec un léger goût de grains de malt pâle et de petites notes métalliques (azote) lors de l’entrée en bouche suivi d’un goût de céréales légèrement plus sucrées puis en finale l’on retrouve une légère-moyenne amertume de houblon floral aux notes herbeuses. Post-goût moyen et un peu sec, léger-moyen amer de houblon floral aux notes herbeuses avec un léger goût fruité (zeste d’agrumes). (été 2006)

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: Slightly hazy blonde with a creamy off-white head. Nice aromas of citrus and a touch of pine, a touch grainy as well . Low nitrogen level, lots of grapefruit in there, light to medium body, light caramel, lingering bitter finish. I think they re-shaped this beer since last time I tried one and they re-shaped it good! Highly drinkable, love the hoppy profile of this new light cream ale. Really well done.

column4: Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Nice cream ale nitro pour, amber color, white head. Mellow hoppy aroma, citra and sorachi ace combine quite well with a honey-like malt aroma. Taste is light, slight hoppy bitterness, nice. Body is good for a cream ale, although still on the heavy/overly creamy side of things. I like this.
Draft. Served in a goblet??? Very dark and opaque. Sweet and heavy, with chocolate flavor and aroma that is, perhaps, the strongest I’ve encountered. Some obvious alcohol in the aroma.

Draft on the Hill. Pours lovely black with nice tan head. Big coffee nose, slightly sweet with a touch of chocolate. Tastes like mildly bitter roasted espresso, touch of mocha, really nice. Medium body, a bit lively. Very tasty beer.

Cask at Shirlington. Thick, dark, and not too far from the Fuel (as I was informed that this was what Fuel is before the coffee is added). Rich aroma, and rich flavor. Fantastic chocolate flavors, and virtually no alcohol flavor. Don’t remember the head too well, but it certainly was thick.

This beer rocks! Pours as thick and dark as used motor oil. Burnt orange highlights when held up to bright light. No real head or lace to speak of. The aroma is of espresso, dark, Belgian chocolate, soy sauce and coffee grounds. The flavor has lots of alcohol, everything burnt, espresso and bitter-sweet chocolate. Very well-hopped. The alcohol and hops do a good job of balancing out the flavor. Full-bodied with a heavy, oily mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Lengthy, burnt, dry finish. Great, world class stuff! So much better than expected!
Deep amber-brown color with a quickly dissipating head. Nutty, mildly smoky aroma. Deep smoky/roasty, mildly nutty flavor. Mildly yeasty with a hoppy finish. Pretty good, robust, rich flavor.

Coal black body. Aroma strikes me as "porterish," medium sweet and very roasty malty. Taste is of a robust porter, big malty roasty, coffee, some velvety. No alcohol detected, and the beer has a pretty full body.
Pours clear golden with heavy carbonation and a huge white head. Aroma of acerbic malt. Taste has light grassy elements, malty. Palate is much of the same. Pretty good.
On tap, @Festival de la cerveza de Aviles, 11/08/2015 Color amarillo dorado, sabor maltoso

Can from a corner shop in Leiden. Pours clear light golden with a big frothy white head. Aroma of wet newspaper. Taste is old news, watery and a lot of that cellulose, some sweet corn, but this one was a clear drainpour.
old hoppy aroma,pale, clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, soft carbonation, light hoppy finish.
Courtesy of Henrik. Yellow coloured and clear. Has a white head, medium duration. Moderete malty aroma, notes of flour. Flavor starts light sweet and finish moderate bitter.
5 liter keg. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grass, straw and hops.
Gold pour. Floral aroma. Taste is slightly sweet, little doughy, and a little bitter. Medium carbonation.
nuts, barnyard, grass, rotten eggs, golden, hazy, frothy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, sticky, soft carbonation, long finish, bitter,

500ml can. Best before: 19/03/2012. It pours an industrial-looking gold with the typical "too perfect" looking bright white head. It leaves the typical spotty lacing. The smell is malty and grainy with some bready scents, some spiciness form the hops and some fruitiness. The flavor is industrial-tasting. But for industrial it isn’t horrible. Maybe due to the freshness. It has a slight wateriness, metallicness, and tartness, but also some pleasant nutty flavors, doughy malt, and a nice hop presence. It isn’t horrible but not something I would recommend.
A can of fermented liquid malt extract. Nothing enjoyable about it. Apparently this brewery cannot turn it into a decent beer.

Sparkling clear amber hue. What the heck is the commercial description all about. I entered it straight from the menu, but it’s not even close to being something I would consider golden or pale. The off-white head is medium-sized. Mostly, but not fully diminishing with minimal lacing. The aroma is very yeasty with heavy notes of coriander, clove, alcohol, light lemon and very light grapefruit. I detected Banana in the nose as well. Very Hefe-like. The flavor is very well balanced for a strong Belgian ale. Lightly sweet, spicey and fruity up front. Lightly bitter, spicey (allspice, cinnomon and clove) on the backside. Full-bodied with a fizzy and watery mouthfeel. Short, dry and crisp finish.

Ja was soll man dazu sagen... um den Kalkreiniger GEschmack von Berliner Weisse zu überdecken müssen halt 5% Sirup her. Pluspunkt: der Kalkreiniger-Geschmack ist weg. Minuspunkt: Schmeckt immernoch zum Kotzen, aber jetzt ist das Zeug halt rot anstatt weis und schmeckt wie purer Zucker mit Sauerkraut. Passt einfach nicht. Fazit: WÜRG Test vom 21.9.2004, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 0,3,1,3,4,0 - 1,25

Light ruby coloured ale with a fading pink cover. Ridiculously simple nose with raspberry perfume and hesitating wheat notes. More of the same in mouth, nothing to write about really. Thin. Biting carbonation. Yuck.
Bottle. Hazy red colour with a nice light reddish head, Aroma of sweetness and raspberry. Also flavour of sweetness, raspberry very tasty and not much of a beer. But refreshing.

(Bottle 33 cl) Courtesy of Elisabeth. Hazy pink - almost lilac or beet root coloured - with a lilac head. Sweetish berry aroma. Light in body with lots of sweet berry notes and some biscuity touches. There’s a discreet, underlying tartness. Interesting. 080707

Bottle. Average creamy reddish head that mostly diminished. Spar lacework. Light cloudy reddish color. Aroma of raspberry, apple, sugar, sour milk, vinegar. Light bodied with a thin and sticky texture. Moderated sweet flavor, light sour notes. Cream cookie like finish.

From 33 cL bottle. Pours artificial pink with a diminishing pink head. Raspberry aroma, sweet and sour. Flavour is sweet and sour raspberry . Sweet sour finish. Okay pre mixed (good aroma and flavour) but a bit one dimensional.
Bottle. Clear pink colour with a creamy pink head. Aroma and flavour of raspberry.

Bottle thanks to Saxo. Creamy pink excellent fully lasting head. Red/Oink colour. Powerfull raspberry aroma and flavor. Light yeasty. Sweet average finish. Watery palate but I cant help it. I am addicted to raspberry!!!!!!!
Bottle. Clear pinkish colour with a medium creamy pink head. Heavy raspberry aroma and taste. Way too sweet for me.
Bottle. Medium head with ok duration. Color is rasperry red. Aroma is pleasantly sour fresh - almost like a lambic. Taste is rasperry fresh with some acidity.
I really enjoyed this beer and am mostly just scoring this for me. Sorry for the inconvenience. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask at the brewpub - Great Barrington. Pours clear yellow with a fine, creamy white head. Moderate raspberry aroma, touches of white grape. Light sweet flavor with cereal, straw, slight butter, drying raspberry. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Mild sweetness to finish, further mellow raspberry character, corn flakes, hay. So so.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear golden yellow with a thin white head. Raspberry and wheat right from the beginning, crisp, sweet. Medium bodied, a little empty though moving quickly from raspberry to wheat and then finishing up with some crisp wheat bitterness and not much else.
Sample at the brewpub. Pours gold with a white head. Smells of raspberries, some dry malt, dough. Tastes of hay, touches of tartness, some hints of raspberries. Some earthiness on the finish. Decent.

Cloudy blonde body with a small white head. Only a little raspberries on the nose. Taste is not of the raspberry-juice kind. More like a dried raspberries and raspberries flavoured cotton-candy. Taste was dry straws with the residual sugar and sourness flavour or the raspberries but without the juice. Aggressive carbonation (a bit too much so). Highly drinkable fruity beer that I found surprisingly enjoyable. What’s happening to me? I actually like a girly beer. Ok, enough about this rating, I’ve got to go freshen-up.

Has a very light golden color with some carbonation and a light raspberry smell. Taste is lightly of raspberry and finishes rather bland with little flavor. Overall this has got to be the worst beer from this brewery, I did not like it at all.
Quite sour aroma - grapes. Brown with a low head. Sour lactic flavors, not pleasant really
An unclear a brown beer with a small light brown head. The aroma is sour with notes of prunes. The flavor is also sour with notes of malt and prunes. Yuk.
Bottled. Dark brown, light brown/yellow head, which is thin. Sour-ish up front, followed up by some toffe and notes of hops. Earthy, little vineous flavour with a sour-ish, lactic overall feel.

Thanks Per, I liked this one! Dark brown pour with a medium brown head that won't go away! Aroma is a mix of hops that I usually associate with Jamtlands. It is earthy, like old twigs. It also as vinuous quality with some sourness. Interesting and tasty brew. Moderately dry finish. Excellent beer!
Bottled. Ruby in colour. Vinuos aroma. Dry, yeasty, lively , funky and light bodied. Lightly soapy and orangey. Very pleasant.

Very dark brown, nearly black. Yellowish-brown head, rather thin. Nose with chocolate cake and chocolate toffee. After a while, there is sourness in the nose as from wheat, or certain untreated grains. Like the cooking soup for mussels. Taste: eeehh! - very outspoken acidity. Special malts/grains used no doubt - including roasted barley. Wheat haze is not visible - but with such a deep-dark beer? There is definetely a retronasal arome of a fine, heavy cigar. Mouthfeel is very surprising: light and spritzy and ,at the same time well-bodied. Temperature and yeast culminate to give a more vineous character at the end. If I had to formulate a criticism, 't would be that the taste is so at odds with the looks of this beer. In fact, this beer is a combination of bière de garde, a dark Weizen and a Schwarzbier.
On Tap at John Harvard’s in Framingham, MA. Poured a dark gold. Very complex- each sip cycled through about four different flavors.

Tap at the brewers (from notes once again). Pours out a nice golden color with a small white head. Slightly malty aroma with a touch of hops. Very smooth drinkable taste with a very good balance. Not a bad brew, would not mind a growler of this on a summer day

Poured a cloudy orange brown color. Had a mild, light citrus hop aroma. Had a strong hop flavor with an aftertaste of old beer. It left some lacing on the glass. I thought for sure this was an American Pale Ale, I asked the bartender if he had the taps switched,
A little farty in the nose, sparkling amber color, almost no head. Very buttery in the middle - I hate diacytel-laden beers. Slighty dry toast-like finish. Oily mouth feel. Just a bad mix of flavors.

Housebrew, La Terverne de Nesle, yuck. Besides the terrible atmosphere the beer was'nt great either. Malty, grainy and a bit farty nose. Amber color, no head, soft carbonation. Sweet and grainy with a light bitterness, pricks and taste goes fast.

Sulfury nose like a clogged drain, hazy pale orange color and no head - not a good start. Light citrusy maltiness with some vanilla. Was that cherries? short tight spice end. Very thin and watery. Overall pretty friggin' cheap stuff.
La Taverne de Nesle, sulphury, acidic noste. Cloudy lemonjuice like color, brussels laces, flat carbonation. Pure lemon - maybe some peach. Watery finish.

Whilst working in Adelaide, myself and workmates ventured for a Friday bevvie and ordered a Pale. Grudges all round, we complained that the taps were infected as it was initially clear "this isn’t Cooper’s". Wasn’t that bad though! Poured a slightly hazy pale straw with a thin soapy white head. Little aroma. Mouth feel was decent with low carbonation and good body. Sweet castor sugar and bready yeast, quite gluggy and arguably lacking in definition with only a light hint of sour leafy hops. Finish is a little short and forgettable. Know nothing of the brewery and haven’t seen this beer advertised anywhere else in Adelaide. Still, it actually wasn’t that disagreeable a drop.

Actually I didn’t think this was was too bad. Looks the goods with pale yellow gold colour, slightly cloudy. Sweetish nose with a waft of malt. Thick palate, again driven by sweetness although not necessarily malty. Tails a little at the finish and doesn’t really offer any hoppiness. Probably not for the purists but I can see some ’crowd pleaser’ appeal.

Ewww.... I had this once before and thought it was pretty decent (and a dead ringer for Coopers Pale) but this time it was terrible. Really, REALLY yeasty aroma with some metallic notes. Tastes sweet and fruity like fruit cup cordial (or Fruity Lexia cask wine). To be avoided.

Dim, pale peachy browm colour. The aroma is like sweet cordial, really short industrial finish. Traditional crap Aussie chemical additive finish, really bad, and unbelievably thin. Hard to believe its an ale.
Light honey colourand Light fruity aroma, bitter hoppy flavour with some sourness. Quite refreshing and IMHO the best of this mediocre brewery's offerings to date. But I stand to be corrected.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: Bottle. Golden. Aromas are apple juice iwth some acidicy. Flavours are sweet apple with lemon and some woodiness. Fairly refreshing.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: A "low" alcohol version of K9 in all its different appearences. Sweeter and blander than the original.

column4: Magners GB / Shepton Mallet Cider Mill (C&C Group)
column5: This is bar none the best "low alcohol" cider I have ever tried. Where as the regular K Cider (both the american 6.4% ABV version and the English 8.4% ABV version) border on an excessively dry taste bordering bitter, the folks at Matthew Clark got it right this time. Its much sweeter than the regular and it lacks the abusive aftertaste. The truist English cider drinkers might fight it a bit disappointing, but it more appealed to my tastebuds. The nose was a little more subdued than the original, but I must admit that I thoroughly enjoyed the aroma of the original. This one will likely be difficult to find in the American market as it is 6.0% as a low alcohol variety.

A commercial description of this beer reads" A Refreshing light bodied beer for those new to craft brews. Brewed to taste similar to American Lagers. ", I say why bother.Not my style.Next to nothing in the aroma and flavor department.Water with a bit of back wash has only slightly more bosy than this beer.But I must admit, if it keeps the patrons happy and they don't have to carry macro swill..god love them.

Pours with a very pale yellow body topped by a thin white head with some lace left behind on the glass. Grainy malt aroma similar to freshly mashed malt. Sweet grainy malt flavor with a subtle bitter hoppiness and a mutty finish. Very flavorful for such a light beer. Light bodied, slightly dry and smooth.
Compact and little long-lasting foam. Pale colour and enough bubbly. Ordinary and light scent, discreetly pungent. Taste without particularitity, lightly sour finish.
Not a bad beer,but nothing great, pale gold, easy drinking, would be good on a hot day.
Bottled(500ml). -pale yellow coloured with no head, sweet malt aroma, grassy and too sweet
Light yellow color. Sweet malt and a faint hint of grass in the nose. Body is very sweet with a light bitterness that dries off quickly towards the end. Too sweet, rather disgusting.
Bright yellow; light faint hop in the aroma. Light body. Bland, with vague grassy hop, low bitterness and quick finish.
Light honey malty aroma. Bright pale. Very light on taste, but you can find faint decent qualities (sadly well hidden from taste buds). Sadly this beer was to light.
Sweet malt aroma, straw yellow, a small head. Tasted of malt, felt stronger than 4.3%, a harsh beer.
Clear pale yellow w/ slight head. Mildly sweet aroma. Light body. Sweet malt, some green apple, mild bitterness & alcoholic tingle.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Aroma; fruit, dark fruit, yeast, roasted sweet malts, nice scents. Look; necksneaker beige head on ultra dark brown near clear body. Taste; dark fruit, soft caramel, nutty plummy frageances, choco-like syrup, n finishes fruity while waiting for dry notes. Feel; good body n co². Overall; it`s good good. [Session w Finn @PivotekaH7]

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Spandert av djoeye. Delt med ham i H7. Svart. Mokkafarget høyt skum. Sjokoladearoma. Smaken nøtter med sherry i bakgrunnen. Alkoholen godt kamuflert.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Bohužel pouze podprůměrný stout se slabými tóny ve vůni, která není moc příjemná. V chuti lehce sladovost, kává a pražený slad, bohužel ne dobře vyváženo. Pěna slabá, rychle se vytrácející. Na Belgii člověk čeká více. I tak ale díky za zkušenost.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Aromat anyżowy, apteczny, karmelowy, cukrowy. Kolor czarny brąz. Piana wysoka szybko opada do pierscienia. W smaku slodkie karmelowe miodowe slodowe przyprawy korzenne slodka kawa. W odczuciu nieco mdłe. Niczym nie zachwyca.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: 19.04.2013, tap @ Kulminator: N�ytral lett frisk lukt med preg av m�rk malt, humle, gras, kakao, litt lakris. Lett beisk smak med preg av m�rk malt, humle, nitrogen, sur kaffi, beiskt gras, umoden banan, gj�r, sjokolade, karamell, lakris. Middels bitterhet som set litt. Grei.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Bottle. Pours dark chestnut with off white frothy head. Aroma is dark chocolate, little coffee, dark caramel, winey - dark grapes aromas. Flavour is smooth chocolate, dark caramel, alcohol. High carbonation. Thin, but good.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Belgische stout hmmm. Vooral heel vlak ,waterig, niet uitgesproken, tikkie vanille en zoetig. Verder geen stout naar mijn idee.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Fijn biertje hoor, deze Belgische buffel. Donker van kleur, stevig van smaak. Tikkeltje suiker en 9 stevige procenten. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: Black color with a medium white head, aroma of chocolate, coffee and belgian yeast, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, ok.

column1: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Belgian Stout
column5: 330ml bottle from De Garre, Bruges (€4.50): Quite a strong beer at points but still not as overpowering as some imperial stout thanks to the good balance & the nice sweetness coming through from the chocolate, dark fruits & even a little caramel malt. It was drinkable with a smooth feel & good complexity as well. An interesting beer that I'm glad I managed to try, although there are definitely better imperial stouts out there to be had.

(Bottle 33 cl) Reddish brown - actually more red than dark. A decent brownish head. Some roasted, malty notes with spicy touches. Rather unusual Dubbel as this is both sour and bitter - particularly in the finish. Has coriander and zewier added - whatever that is. 260298
Clear dark amber with a medium light brown head. Fruit and malt aroma. Fruity, malty and chalky taste. Sweet start with a light bitter finish.
Clloudy. Yeasty aroma with tropical fruit. Yeasty, sweetish malty flavor with ornage. A hint of fruity sourness present. Good lacing, but overall a disappointing beer.

It’s a nice, warm golden beer with an OK head. The aroma has notes of malt, caramel and hints of flower. The flavour has a pleasant sweetness, notes of malt, caramel and again hints of flower. The finish has a light, but becoming bitterness.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with a nice white head. Aroma and flavour hops and malt. As a discount beer it is actually quit good.
Heavy hoppy aroma. Large frothy off-white initial apperance. Good lacing. Clear amber body. Heavy bitter initial flavor, light smoked. The finish flavor is light harsh. Medium palate.

Bottle. Creamy white fair mostly deminishng head. Dark yellow colour. Light malty and hopy week but ok aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Nice average bitter finish. Slightly smoked? Oily palate but too fizzy.
Bottle. Surprisingly good beer. Clear amber colour with a nice creamy head. Rich malty aroma and taste. Semi bitter finish.
Amber colour with medium off-white head malty taste like brown bred,some bitter finish.
Amber and clear. Has an off-white head, mostly lasting. Aroma is floral, hopped. Flavor starts a bit sweet, but finish is mainly bitter. Dry texture.

Bottle. Two finger frothy white head that mostly diminished. Slight lacing in glass. Body was clear light sparkling and color was pale amber. First sniff gave the impression of a light Bock style beer. Aroma was light caramel, bread, grain. Light bodied with a thin texture and a soft carbonation. Slightly sweet flavor. Very bad stringent finish. Can’t believe how bad this one was.

Bottle bought in Maribo right across from the brewery. Golden colour with an average lasting medium sized head. Aroma of malts and hops, little sweetness. The flavour is fresh, malty, little bit sweet with a touch of hops. Average aftertaste.
Head big and long lasting. Amber colour. Aroma sweet and malt. Taste sweet and malt.

750ml corked and caged bottle (courtesy of Headbanger) poured into a Stem Glass at 41°. Color is a deep gold with a slight haze. Carbonation is very active giving it a small tight white head. Aroma is rich and sweet with a caramel scent that makes me think of a caramel apple. It has a lighter medium body with a light crisp mouthfeel. Flavor comes in light with toffee and a faint apple note that is backed by a mild hop spice. The aftertaste has a rich feel and the toffee turns to honey with a note of black cherry, then finishes clean with a light bitterness on the end. Overall this brew kicks ass, it has rich bold flavors yet comes across light and easy.
bottle that I grabbed for $1.50 at a rip an run. orange pour, minimal head, some haze. light caramel, grass. generally sweet. light yeast. light to medium body.
Bottle shared by a friend, medium sample. Hazy amber color, short frothy head. Bit spicy aroma, some caramel. Bit sweet in taste, bit spicy. Ok.
I taste it with rosted porc with french old mustard. Good taste of sour and ale.
Bottle. Pour is amber with a frothy head, aroma is malty. Taste is malty, toffee, sweet. Good, but it could be bolder and less lacking in character
Bottle @ RVA 22nd. Sedimenty and amber. Smells metallic and warm. Wheaty and sweet. A little harsh.
Apple nose, with cherry hints, not strong. Cloudy amber, fine floaties, thin head. Honey, mild breadiness. Full body, harsh mouthfeel.

750mL bottle shared by obguthr at the 22nd Ratebeer gathering. Hazy amber, thin head, fair retention. Aroma of yeast, bready malt, nuts. The taste is yeast, bread, caramel, nuts. Medium bodied, lingering spice.

Bière peu orthodoxe, mais assez réussi. On relève des notes de fruits, voir même de légumes, mais sans être bizarre. Belle mousse blanche, robe cuivrée, légèrement sucré, ce qui n’est jamais une bonne chose dans une bière.
Pours a very hazy amber with a white head. Aromas of citrus and bananas. Taste the same with some malt sweetness. Not to bad. Long lasting head. Decent lacing in the glass.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear orange amber with a creamy beige head. Fruity and malty nose that is light, but not bad. Malty fruity citrus flavors that are lightly sweet but have spicy hops to balance some of that out. Slightly watery like most of their’s, but not bad.

Draft at brew pub. A California common steam lager in a harbor town in Michigan. A good story and a good version of this brew. Good use of yeast and hops to produce a refreshing flavor with a finish that had a fruitiness. Good lager.
The texture is reminiscent of Anchor, but this one is much bolder with its hops, to the point of obscuring what remains.
Clear gold/copper. Sweet caramel malt aroma and flavour. Some bitterness but sweetness overwhelms. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Mild malty and hoppy nose. Pale head. Pale copper color. Malty and hoppy taste. Some hints of geapefruit.
Bottle. Pours clear orange with small beige head. Aroma is sweet malts, caramel, english ale. Taste is bitter, slightly burnt, sweet malts, hay.

Tap @ Oak Barrel. Crystal clear golden with pure white head. Mild nose of grass and herbs with malt. Bitter with herbs and basic bitter malt body. Sticky with a medium body and bitter finish. A strong basic bitter.

Kuparinruskea, hieman punertava kirkas olut pienellä, hieman pitsiä jättävällä vaahdolla. Tuoksu mieto, yrttistä humalointia ja hieman karamellia. Maku hieman karamellisen maltainen, loppupuoleltaa toisaalta hieman humalan katkeroittama, mutta samalla myös turhan vetinen. Aika kevyt suutuntuma.
Bottle from market. Pours copper color with small slightly tan head. Aroma and taste have caramel, bisquits, floral, grass and hops. Bitterness is very nice and this beer is very smooth.

On tap at the Oak Barrel in Helsinki Airport. Clear golden with white head. Light grain, bisquits and bread with bitter grass and light citrus and pine. Dry with medium bitterness and medium carbonation.

(Draught at Oak Barrel, Helsinki Airport, 28 April 2016) Golden amber colour with creamy, white head. Malty nose with toast, apricots and orange peel. Malty taste with notes of toast, apricots and a balanced resiny bitterness in the finish. Medium body, fairly dry. Tasty and well balanced, but hardly exciting. Quite enjoyable.
Bottle at home. Copper colour, small white head. Aroma of caramel malts and floral hoppiness. Really nice bitterness troughout. Light to medium sweetness. Good English style bitter!
0,5l Flasche. Helle Kupferfarbe mit cremigem Schaum. Bitter malziges Aroma. Geschmack nach verbranntem Karamell und etwas Citrus.
Sweetness of this one was subdued, Abit of hop flavor to it, very nice drinking. One of my favorite Strauss beers. on tap at Universal.

Draught at Karl Strauss La Jolla: Pours an amber color with light head and lacing. The nose is husky with some sweet syrupy caramel and bright grassy hops. The flavor is really strong with husky malts and strong metallic lagerish qualities. The finish is thin and it has a medium body. Eh.
Amber mahogany in color with a minimum amount of head. Nose is mostly malt. Sweet malt flavor makes this a overall well marzen that i wouldnt mind drinking again.
