One of the better strauss beers. Malty flavor, good creamy mouth feel and a bit of hops in the aroma. Easy to drink.
Character dominated by the house yeast. Caramely, butterscotchy, malty flavor, with a touch of hop, European stlye. Good session beer.
Light in color and body. Semi-sweet body with a noble hop finish. Almost reminds me more of a pilsener. An average beer.
pretty basic pale lager. a little better than the macro garbage, but still not very good
Can, pours a nice yellow colour, taste is pretty good, it is good for a lager, I enjoyed drinking this one, good offering.

473ml can from jimmay. pour yellow with a small white head. apply aroma, some grainy 2 row, trace level hopping. the flavour is much better. decent malt stucture with hopping to balance. finishes tight and dry. quite drinkable even if it is a little boring. ive had worse craft light lagers, much worse.
500 ml can from brewery. Pours pale golden in colour, smallish white head. Mild malt aroma and flavour. Better than the big guys.
Can. Pours a slight pale gold / light hay. Sweet and hopsy nose. Crisp, hospt with a smooth slightly floral hops finish. I wasn’t expecting much as I don’t lke the style. Dry and crisp. Good brew.

This lager poured a light golden colour with a quickly dissipating head. To the nose there are scents of hopps, juniper, citrus and dough. First sip was smooth and flavourful with flavours of caramel, butter, hopps and a little spice. Finish is slightly hoppy with a little bitter value there along with a little...smoke? Palate is also slightly hoppy with bitterness lingering. Seriously underated.
50 cl can, Mulmur, ON, Canada. Slightly hazy pale golden, head is only whisps of lace on the side of the glass. Really nice pepper aroma, sharp but mellow first sip, with a nice long sweet finish.

500ml Can: I’m a Neustadt fan, albeit rarely a pale lager fan, but that said this is a vastly underrated beer. Pours very light gold, a surprisingly nice foam head that never left straight to the bottom. Lots of citrusy grapefruit and sugar coming out of the aroma, it’s quite pleasing. Very lightly carbonated and quite smooth and light I snagged sweet biscuit and wheat notes off the top and found those grapefruit hops shortly after. This might be a new go-to for me during summer cottage season this year.

[1503-20080628] Tap. Grainy malt aroma. Clear, orange brown body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Grainy banana flavour has some toasted bread. Medium body is a little astringent. Drinkable, plus the setting helps. (@ Bootlegger’s Cove, Big Tub; Tobermory, ON)

Pours with some crazy bubbly white head. Dissipates quickly, but wow. Unexpected. Slightly hazy and yellow. Sweet a little hoppy, wheaty and a bit of corn meal. Tastes like a wit, wheaty, grassy with a hint of citrus. Surprisingly complex.

I am sad they discontinued this beer. Everyone I introduced it to began to buy it as a regular beer. It needed more advertising. It is deceiving as it is a darker looking lager but tastes much lighter. There is some complexity to the flavors with small hints of nut and currants but is by far not over powering. You can certainly drink a few of these puppies. In Ontario, Canada there has been a rash of cheap buck a beer options. Most of these beers are not great but this one was one of the best for the price. BRING IT BACK! Please!

Bouteille de 341 ml achetée dans une LCBO de Cornwall. Dégustée le 21 août 2005 (pint). Bière brune foncée limpide. Mousse peu, col mince et éphémère. Peu effervescente, bulles moyennes. Odeur de petits fruits (berries). Douce, assez sucrée, amère en finale.

Originally rated June 2004. Dark red with brownish bubbly head (that lasted about 2 minutes... not bad). Nice mild aromas of chocolat and coffee, but this is nowhere near a stout. You can drink many of these without being full. In fact, you could only buy this beer in 24 packs, but it did not sell. Now, you can finally buy it in a 6 pack. Watery with hints of coffee and nuts, with a sweet smooth aftertaste. Very well priced and Lakeport’s best beer along with their Honey Lager.

341ml bottle sample. There was a time that I drank this quite regularly. Pours rather dark and cloudy, small head. Smells of malt, hops and nut. Tastes much the same as smell sweet roasted malt, nut and slight hops. Has a slight watery consistency, good though.

No surprise this one’s retired, I suppose. Had a bottle that had been sitting in a beer fridge for who-knows-how-long, but I doubt the date had any effect on the taste. Pours dark with very little head...I wasn’t getting much out of the flavour, possibly due to the cold temperature, but at the same time, something about this beer made me scared to try it when it got much warmer. For a dark lager it’s okay, but I don’t know anyone who enjoys dark beer but is willing to skimp on it.

The after taste is sort of of malty and the colour is dark and sexy... But it still has that swishy foamy taste of a lager ... which is not my thing... Scottish ales are strong heavy meals in a glass... this a little watery . I guess I’m being judgmental because I really like Scotch ales. But, as lagers go this quite good.
well there is some malt in there......surprisingly. Aroma is still quite grainy, lots of corn mixed with slight caramel flavours.......this is odd. But drinkable, but not repeatable.

341 ml bottle, 5% a/v Pour is very unusual for a macro, it has both colour and head go figure. Medium brown colour with a decent tan head. Nose is nutty, and chocolatey, taste is hops and malt, nothing extravagant, very thin mouthfeel, most dissapointing aspect of the beer.
not bad at all......a bit thin and watery but has enough bitterness in the finish to make it worth buying......probably the best lakeport product
amber color some head only thing scottish ale like is the slightly darker color drinkable but nothing to be that interested in
Good one while talking about an average price average beer. Good taste and color.
Good for a light lager, but standard, clean and crisp super light lager. Bingo Kremenchuk
500 ml bottle. Light golden color, clear, snow-white foam. Aroma: grain, apple, slightly spicy hops and wort. Taste: light, watery, pils-malt, crackers, drinkable with fish.

Aroma; caramel, herbs, sweet malts, vgtbls, grain. Look; good frothy off white head, clear golden body. Taste; sweet caramel malts, grassy hops, vgtbls, grain, and finishes sweet and caramel grainy. Feel; normal body and co2. Overall; pale lager. Very easy. [tasted@DK summer 2018] 4443'10

Kiev 5/10 2018. 50 cl from draft at Ukraine Hotel. Pours clear pale yellow with medium-sized White head. Settles as thin layer of foam barely covering the surface of the beer. . Moderate lacing. Aroma is rather sweet. Sweet malts, honey, grains with a sugary touch Light carbonation. Thin, watery and lightly lively texture. Flavor is sweet followed by very light bitterness. Aftertaste is sweet. Fairly Short. Fairly standard Eastern European brew. Way too sweet and fairly unpleasant.
Botella 0,5l No tenia suerte y tenia que beber de 4%... Un lager tipico,industrial,con sabor dominante a malta,ligero dulzor,notas de amargor alejano,pan,herbal.Acuosa,nada especial

Bottle at 4.0% ABV. Pours brilliant gold with a medium-sized white frothy head. Retention: above average. Aroma: pipeline water, grainy malts, some cooked corn. Light to medium body. Soft carbo. Taste: malty, clean, accompanied by an unwelcome metallic touch. Tiny bitterness. Forget it.
bottle @ shop (budapest) yellow colour, normal body, average carbonated, white head, bittersweet taste, easy to drink, typically drink beer

Bottle, didn’t catch the date, if there was one, drunk 10/10/16. Clear, filtered honey-golden with a moderate amount of white head. Looks good for a macro. Smells malty in the nose with some faintly discernible hops. Hint of flowers and grass. Otherwise, honey, a good dose of cereal character and light pepper on the end. Didn’t find too much flaw, perhaps some wax and very light corn, but nothing obnoxious. No oxidation so it might be, somehow, fairly fresh. Maltier and sweeter than expected, with a touch of saccharine-like character, some wax and corn on the end, but by and large actual malt flavors, with ample carbonation and a hint of grassy, floral hops. Fine, drinkable stuff.
pale yellow colour, some white head; aroma of some grain, bread and grass with sourish notes;taste of grain and bread gain with cardboard notes; poor lager
Draught at Park Inn (Brewery Tap) Woodsetton. Pale yellow beer with chunky head. Aimed as a refreshing spring bitter it is both fruity and hoppy. Lemon flavours with a tangy grape finish.
Geprobeerd bij de brouwerij ’t Kuipertje met LiekevdV. Het is een licht troebel geel bier met een volle schuimkraag. Het heeft een lekkere wat kruidige smaak van gember.
Bottle @ RBBWG 2016. Thanks Benzai! Clear orange beer, no head. Soft carbonation. Bitter and dry, some citrussy notes. Very unbalanced. Not good.

20/II/16 - 33cl bottle @ RBBWG V (Ben’s place) - BB: X/2015 (2016-176) Thanks to Benzai for sharing the bottle! Clear orange beer, small to no head. Aroma: sweet, sugary, alcohol, yeast, almonds. MF: ok carbon, medium body., some alcohol noticeable. Taste: bit sweet, lots of yeast, banana, soft bitterness. Aftertaste: yeast, alcohol, pretty bitter, some citrus.
Sampled at RBBWG16 . Thnx for sharing ! Pours blonde, small white head. Smell is sweet, bit yeasty. Taste is sharp, malty, very yeasty. Blank, standard taste, thin MF and high carbo.

Bottle sample @ RBBWG 2016, thanks Jeff. BB 12/2015. Dorée, col blanc. Profil typiquement belge, retrouve un fruité noble et légèrement fleuri. Râpeux en fin de bouche, amertume métallique, pils, pâle, belge.

0.33 l bottle at RBBWG 2016 in Antwerpen, best before October 2015. Hazy, golden amber with a white head. Sweetish-malty, yeasty aroma of clove, vanilla, honey, and some citrus. Sweetish-malty, yeasty taste of vanilla, honey and clove, followed by a short, slightly bitter, yeasty-spicy finish. Medium body, slightly effervescent mouthfeel. Not good.

Thank you for sharing Benzai! 330 ml. bottle sampled @ RBBWG V. BBF 10.2015. Quite hazy citrus, little bubbles. Nose is yeasty awful unpleasant perfume & chemical lemon. Taste & body is fizzy moldy perfume, spoiled lemon, herbal, industrial, fizzy, chemical. Pretty dreadful to be honest.
Bottle at RBBWG, thanks for sharing Benzai. High carbo, dusty, yeast, boring Belgian. Meh.
Blond filtered appearance. White head. Golden malts, white sugar, light herbal. Quite tasteless, but not bad at least. Boring beer. (Sampled during RBBWG 2016)

Sampled @ Ratebeer Belgian Winter Gathering 2016. Clear yellow golden color, average sized white head. Aroma is malts, wheat, grains lightly, a bit sweetish. Taste lightly malts, sweetish, lightly hay. Ok body and carbonation.
Bottle as "Påskens Krudtugle." Clear dark golden/amber. small head and fizzy carbonation. Hay, hop and some metallic aroma. Taste is mostly sweet and bitter.

Copenhagen 28/2 2017. 33 cl bottle from Aldi. As "Påskens Krudtugle". Very disturbing combination of purple and yellow with the paranoid owl basking around on the label. Pours clear golden yellow with white bubbly head. Settles as very thin layer of foam. No Lacing. Aroma is sweet malts with sharp and harsh notes in the background. Metallic notes of alcohol. Medium Carbonation and slightly thick palate. Flavor is medium sweet followed by quite light bitterness. Aftertaste is sweet and slightly metallic. Fairly unpleasamt discount strong beer. If you only are looking to get plastered this will get the job done. Otherwise avoid it!
Clear copper of color with a white head. An aroma of malt, sweet appels, nuts and toffee. A flavor of malt, metallic, toffee, nuts, fruity and hops in the finish.
A Danish, amber Easter lager with white head. Aroma is caramel, malty, light yeasty, raisin? Taste is light bitter, sweet. Pearly. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Klar gylden boble de let forsvindende skum, let sæd duft, let sprit lidt sød, lidt bitter eftersmag. Ikke en man plaffer mange af uden at blive træt af den. Men som ledsager til en fedtemad med rå løg der kunne den sgu nok godt bruges, neee mæææe! Free Føroyar!!!

Gylden med et ikke særlig holdbart hvidt skum. Tørt græs og maltsødme/karamel i duften. Smagen er sødlig men tør. Mangler lidt krop. Eftersmagen består stort set kun af bitterhed. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A pretty alchoholic sweet flavor with a watery mouthfeel. Light amber in color with a white head.

Bottle as "Påskens krudtugle". Pours crystal clear golden with a light lacing and diminishing off-white frothy small head. Aroma is rather weak with maize, straw, bread, toast, paper, sulphur. Taste is light+ sweet, light bitter, light metallic and very light sour. Body is light, texture is thin and oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden colour with a tiny shortlived white head. Aroma of malt, hops and hay. Taste adds citrus notes. Lightly bitter aftertaste. Thin body. It’s a fresh but boring discount beer.
Bottle. Pours clear amber with quickly vanishing white head. Clear aroma of cardboard. Ditto taste, pathetically enriched by some stray hoppy and malty notes. Bad.

Name: Bourbon Daddy Date: 04/30/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Rich O’s, New Albany IN black, thin tan head, light sweet roasted aroma, huge rich and chewy chocolate malt flavor with a big bourbon character that blends instead of takes over, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 17/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Score: ****/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Big thanks to KP for the giant mason jar o’ beer. Poured almost black with a ruby tint and a tan head. Roasted aroma with chocolate and a balanced amount of bourbon. Roasted flavors that matches the aroma. Creamy with a light carbonation and a bitter finish.

Growler/mason jar shared by kp: Pours a rich opaque black with a thick, nicely lacing tan head. Pleasant aroma of rich bourbon and light roasted malt. Starts with a nice balanced sweetness and malty caramel with some dark chocolate. Finishes with a good bourbon character but no warming alcohol. A very nice bourbon stout. Thanks kp!
Growler from KP: Poured dark, dark brown with a thick brown head. Chocolately, nutty aroma.Huge chocolate, bourbon flavor with nuts. Burning alcohol to me. Damn tasty though.
Black body with ruby around the edges. There’s a good creamy head on top that pits nicely. The bourbon and oak over the stout flavors blend nicely. Good roasty malt with a slightly bitter finish.

Smoke, chocolate, coffee, bourbon, pine? Brown/black hue; tan, frothy, average sized head. Moderate to heavily sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter finish. Light alcohol. Medium-heavy body, oily texture, soft carbonation. The bottom line is: the bourbon flavor is a bit sharp, but Damn Good!

Sweet noseof bourbon, espresso, charred malts, and some light cream. Has a black body with a medium sized brown head. Light bourbon flavor throughout, sweet woody notes up front, then some butter and a heavy bourbon finish.

The Bourbondaddy is a stout aged in a used bourbon barrel. I had this last year at about this time, and I remember liking it, but I don’t remember much else about it. This time around I actually paid attention to what I was drinking. It’s a little bitter at first, but after that it’s very good. Nothing extremely special, it tastes the way it should - a medium stout with a little bourbon flavor added.

Draft at Fest: Opaque with a small tan head which diminished leaving an oily layer, good lace. The aroma has notes of vanilla, oak, whisky, roasted and burnt malts, pineapple, floral hops, and dusty yeast esters. The taste starts with a coffee and mocha nature. A nice balanced bourbon and vanilla kick, not over the top. Fruity and smoky finish. The feel is rich and smooth. Another winner from New Albanian, worth a trip to seek out their beers. Sweet (almost like an Imperial) !

I tried this after it was aged for 18 weeks; the assistant brewmaster said he liked it best at 12. Nevertheless, I thought the mouthfeel was fairly thin. I don't understand why they use nitro, although the creaminess factor might play a role. Aroma was that of a stout with a dash of Crown Royal or Jim Beam. I don't anticipate trying this again but appreciate the novelty involved.

(Speciaalbierbrouwerij Oijen Poort van Megen) Bottle 300ml at home, poured into a glass tankard, ABV 6% Brown coloured beer with good activity in it, quite murky body and almost two fingers of tan head, tin and somewaht frothy, sitting on top.Okay retention I’d say, it leaves light lacing on the glass. Weird aroma. There are some malts but also some sour-ish fruity notes, like old cherries. Sour taste, and not the good one. Slightly infected I reckon. Fruity notes of cherries and grapes, not much of the spices mentioned on the description, metal notes on the finish. Medium thin body, average carbonation. Not good.

Bottle: Served in a shaker: Medium sized creamy vanilla colored foamy head on top of a murky brown colored beer. Aroma has loads of green olives with a light malty, herby and woody touch. Not much else. Not really inviting... Flavours of grapes, yeast, light tart, malty, olives, dough, bread, some berries, some herbs and bitters. Not sure what happened here... Infection? It’s unbalanced for sure and strange in aroma and flavours. Aftertaste is grapes, tart, malts, olives, dough and yeast. Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, medium unbalanced body and a creamy tarty texture. Strange beer.
bottle at Gollem, Amsterdam. reddish brown pour, rasiny, dried dark fruits, sweet maltiness. Sort of a mess, not so great

19th December 2010 Cloudy amber beer, little white head. Light frothy and airy palate, dry. Turns creamy. Sweetish malt base with a touch or orange and honey. Finishes frothy and airy. All right but somewhat over carbonated.

Bottled. Copper colour with a mediumsized fluffy to foamy slightly off-white head. Aroma is sweet malts, mild toasted notes, toffee, some berries, spices and mild raisiny notes as well. Flavour is wood, mild toasted notes, sweet caramelly malty and mild toffeeish and yeasty notes. Pleasant in flavour, though aroma was a bit out of balance.
Nice medium brown, little red color. Smell is not good. I don’t exactly know what I smelled but I absolutely didn’t like it. Taste is just fair. Low carbonation, not very good this one.

Sehr süßer Antrunk, in dem das Malz vor einer erkennbaren Honignote liegt. Die Süße flacht zwar mi t der Zeit etwas ab, bleibt aber weiterhin zu stark. Dahinter sind die Aromen deutlich schwächer gesäht, wenig kräuterartig, sogar wässrig. Im Abgang schwach malzig-würzig. 11/9/8/8/9/8

Bottle. The aroma is very malty, light smoky, some smell of dark bread. The pale beige creamy medium large head has a normal duration, the body is nearly black. The taste is malty, some chocolate, a light bitter finish. The body is light to medium strong, light creamy with a lively carbonation.

Bottle 300ml. @ home. Clear medium to dark light red brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, dark berries - raisin - plum, oak - ash, tobacco. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20101012]

The bottle opened on the way home from the beer store. The colour is dark brown, almost black. Te spongy head is beige-brown. Very smooth chocolate aroma, without being too sweet. The taste isn’t quite as strong or good, but the finish and aroma makes up for it. Nice!
Bottle. Dark amber colour, small head. Caramel aroma and flavour. A bit watery and fizzy. Boring.
Amber colour with a small off-white head. Perfume fruity aroma and a light roasted fruity rotten dry taste. Medium body and a sweet dry finish.
A nice spicy and fruity brew. There is a good balance between the sweetness and the bitterness.
Quite sweet and light. A bit fruity aftertaste. An above average cheap Belgian beer.
Okay beer. A bit bitter, not much else going on with it. Pretty standard plain Oktoberfest beer. 2018 bier advent
Bottle. Quite balanced, almost neutral. Individual character components could be more intense. Grainy maltiness combines with hops of generic grassy earthy character.
Bottle,from trade with Beerhunter111, many thanks. Golden color with medium white head. Strong malty aroma. Taste, malt, metallic notes.
Flasa od Beerhunter111. Zlata flasa, slaba biela pena. Vona sladova, sladka, jemne karamel. Chut sladova, karamel, trosku trava, jemne citrus. Umela chut.

Kolor: złocisty, klarowny. Piana: obfita, drobnopęcherzykowa, strzelająca, dość trwała. Zapach: słodowy, chlebowy, lekko chmielowy, trochę niezbyt świeżego chmielu. Smak: średnia pełnia, wyraźne nuty słodowe, chlebowe, lekko miodowe, trochę nut chmielowych, goryczka w kierunku średniej. Wysycenie: średnie, delikatnie w kierunku wysokiego.
Aus der Flasche getrunken (Angebot bei EDEKA). Trinkbar. Nur wo ist der Hopfen versteckt? Unterm Schnee???

Bottle.Clear,golden-copper,nice,creamy head that unfortunately vanishes almost immediately.Aroma grassy,malty,slightly nutty,bready.Taste full,sweetish,smooth,carbonation medium,bitterness less than expected but it is definitely there.Aftertaste malty,bready,a bit of grassy hoppiness.Not a bad Märzen.
Bottle. Golden color with white head. Aroma has malt and some caramel. Taste is malty with fairly long somewhat bitter and sweet aftertaste. Flavors of malt, grass, sugar.

L: -pours a clear golden with a small to medium,foamy,white head -medium to high carbonation visible S: -honey,doughy,marzipan,spicy,faint smoke T: -honey,doughy,spicy,grassy,grainy,apples,marzipan F: -low to medium carbonation -light body O: ok-ish one, but it lacks the body and carbonation of a proper Festbier

Bottle 50cl. Poured into a shaker. Clear medium amber, two finger frothy off-white head, mostly diminishing, very light lacing; aroma malty, bread, grain; taste light medium sweet and bitter, malty, toffee, with average duration, malty and hoppy finish, light spicy notes; medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation; fresh and drinkable.

15th April 2013 Craft Clerkenwell. Clear deep amber beer, little off white head. Palate is light and crispy, semi dry. Well integrated sweet malt and fruity hops. Tiny bit of caramel. Sweet orange marmalade, red berry fruits. Finishes minerally crisp. Well joined up and very drinkable.
Cask at JDW Charlie Hall; copper pour with off white head, malt aroma, quite sweet tasting a bit jammy a bit malty ok ESB.
Smooth and is a glowing copper coloured ale with a small head. The aroma reveals its strength and there’s some fruits evident here too - same when it comes to its taste.

Cask conditioned handpump Eastgate Northampton 20/02/13. A ruby coloured beer with a thick white head and lace. Good fruity hops throughout but oversweet malts. Berry aromas. A little shallow in the mouth. Doesn’t carry its ABV. Balanced fruits and malts but overall too sweet.

Cask at the Claude du Vall (JDW), Camberley. Deep golden amber with a thin cream head; malty aroma with a hint of spice; soft malty taste that leaves the mouth dry; and some warming alcohol to finish. A pleasant pint.
Cask by handpump at Society Room, Glasgow - clear brown, good off-white head, minimal toffee malt aroma, toffee flavour, hint of berry fruits, sweet, very easy to drink

Cask - The Bell Hotel (JDW), Norwich. Poured a copper-brown with a creamy off-white, mostly lasting head. Good bittersweet character with resin, grassy hops, some grapefruit and citrus, yeast and biscuity malts. Medium-ish body, modestly lingering finish, soft mouthfeel. A nice ESB with a subtle spice component thrown in for good measure. Plenty of character and highly quaffable, despite getting on a bit in ABV.

On tap at The Gooseberry Bush, Nottingham. Dark chestnut ale with an initial sweetness like marzipan but settles down to a bittersweet ale. Deceptively light - can’t call it a session ale due to the ABV but it tastes like one. Very smooth mouthfeel.

The Felix Holt, Nuneaton, 19/01/13. Ruby with a level cream top lining the glass. Oak, slightly Flemish, cranberry, alcohol nose.Very heavy toffee and fudge; red berries, slight sick, spiritous hints, barrel, cocktail with grenadine, drying fruit skin hints. Not cutting it after a zesty half of Saaz single hop.

Cask at moon under water jdw. Chestnut brown thin off white head. Neutral aroma with some caramel and cotton candy. The malt and hops fight for the fore in this beer. Flavour is a little muddled. Grassy hop finish. Sweetish. Hints of treacle.
Cask @ Beacon Hotel. Pours pale misty straw yellow, small white head. ight pale malt nose. Taste is surprisingly light bodied, thin malt, lightly floral but food drinkability overall.
Cask at Beacon Hotel, 31/05/17. Grassy aroma. Gold. Thinnish bubbly white head. Light bitter. Slightly malty, Light bodied. Watery. Low carbonation. Abrupt finish. Poor show. As bland as bland gets.
Cask, 1/2 pint by gravity at PRAF 2016, Town Hall, Paisley (20 Apr 2016), caramel, toffee aroma, golden with a thin bubbly white head, caramel, toffee, vanilla, sweet, oily.
On cask at Beacon Hotel, Sedgley. Light golden with a white head. Very astringent start, face pulling. Quite smooth and creamy toward the end. Mixed up.
A session ale. Lacks body and complexity. But it has a grassy hop aroma and a pleasant malty taste on the palate. Better than many but can’t compare to the Ruby Mild.
At the brewpub, Sedgley 22/11/2014. Golden with a slight, white, head. Easy drinking beer, with a hint if citrus fruit, crisp malts and decent, bitter finish. Fine.

Gravity cask. Pale orange, clear, still, a whisper of white head. Aroma is light lime and cheese. Body is medium to light, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is soft malt, light bitterness, not much going on in the flavour.

Cask at the Le Gothique Wandsworth Beer Festival on 29 March 2013. Poured a clear golden-amber, with rocky white head. Aroma of straw, raisins and biscuity. Delicate grassy hop flavours, with some caramel and dried apricot. Finish was tinned fruit, chewy malt and toffee.

Cask (gravity) @ Le Gothique Restaurant and Bar, [ Wandsworth Common Beer Festival 2013 ]. Royal Victoria Patriotic Building, John Archer Way, Wandsworth, Greater London, England SW18 3SX. Clear medium yellow orange color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, fruity, moderate hoppy, pineapple. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, pineapple, fresh. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20130330]
6th July 2013 Black Country Beano. Cask at the Beacon hotel. Light haze on this gold beer, little white head. Mild carbonation. Light floral touch. Light marmalade hops. Light dry finish. It’s fine.

Cask @ Beacon Hotel, Sarah Hughes brewpub. Pours clear golden yellow, small white head. Aroma is lightly sweet malt. Light and super fresh to taste with noticeably sweet malt, floral shades, gentle bitterness. Good stuff.

Cask at Beacon Hotel, 31/05/17. Malty biscuit aroma. Gold. Very thin white head. Light bitter. Herbs, malts, unsure and confused... sure what Im picking up! Light bodied. Watery. Light carbonation. Muted finish. Drinkable.
Cask. Pour is gold with a thin head, aroma is very sweet. Taste is sweet, light fruity, zesty. Good
Cask at the source. Clear golden color. Aroma of light lemon. Taste is light lemon. Plain.
Cask at the Beacon Hotel; clear straw yellow with a thin white head, aroma has light citrus, taste has lemon and sweet malts.

Cask at the King’s Head, Bridgnorth. Mid-gold with a tight white head. Pixy Stix aroma with a hint of coriander and a bit of sulphur. Taste feels more focused: sweet with a decidedly bitter edge. Chalky mouthfeel. Bittersweet finish. What’s the surprise? Seems like a fairly standard beer to me, albeit a well-executed one.
Birthday beer 1. Cask@beacon hotel, sedgley. Golden amber beer with medium frothy head. Aroma of slightly sweet malts. Taste is sweetish malts, hop bitterness and a touch of caramel. Good.

Cask at Craft100. Pale orange, still, clear, no head. Aroma is caramel, bready, biscuity. Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is biscuity, soft lemon citrus, minerals, soft bitterness. A good rounded and balanced beer.

Cask at the Le Gothique Wandsworth Beer Festival on 29 March 2012. Poured a clear, light amber, with a rocky white head. Aroma of spruce, fresh hop and light fruity esters. Caramel and tinned fruit in the flavour, with biscuity malt. Finish was light hop resin, dry grain and cereal.

Cask (gravity) @ Le Gothique Restaurant and Bar, [ Wandsworth Common Beer Festival 2013 ]. Royal Victoria Patriotic Building, John Archer Way, Wandsworth, Greater London, England SW18 3SX. Clear medium yellow orange color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, fruity malt, toasted - caramel, light to moderate hoppy, herbs, grass, sharp. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, fruity, malty. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130330]

Cask, gravity at Shrewsbury Folk Festival main bar, Shrewsbury, Sunday 28th August 2016 Dark gold edging towards light amber, it’s ok with a light bitterness throughout, actually it’s quite bitter with a rustic English hoppiness. Dry finish, it’s fine. A6 A4 T6 P3 Ov12 3.1

Cask at the Old Swan. Poured a clear medium amber with a frothy white head and some broken lace. The aroma is peachy fruit, malt. The flavour is light bitter with a fresh fruity light hop bitter palate and a mellow lingering bitter finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Cask at the Olde Swan; clear golden amber pour with a creamy off white head, taste has biscuity malts, light fruit.
Cask at the source. Crystal clear golden color. Aroma of fruity fresh hay. Taste is fruity straw. Nice.

Cask@ma pardoes (olde swan) brewpub, netherton. Golden beer with medium head and good lacing. Aroma of malts and a touch of biscuit. Taste is malts, some biscuit, a little fruit and a touch of caramel. Creamy palate. Another well balanced beer. Very good.
Cask at Ma Pardoes, Netherton. Sweet, clicking malt brew. Sticky honey, full bodied Best. Typical Black Country Bitter, in an all time classic boozer.
On cask at Olde Swan, Netherton. Pours caramel brown with an off white head. A cracking sweet traditional Black Country bitter. Sweet fruit, hint of caramel, silky smooth on the palate. Gorgeous.
Cask-conditioned at The Olde Swan, Netherton, 22/11/2014. Deep gold with a frothy, white, head. Sweetish, biscuity malts, a hint of apricot and lingering, bitter, finish. Enjoyable.

A hazy amber gold coloured beer with a weak white head. A light, caramel aroma, a little butterscotch plus a hint of fruity hop. Dry mouthfeel. A dry malt taste to start, then a butterscotch flavour comes through that does detract from the hoppiness that struggles to make an appearance towards the end. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hand-pulled pint in the excellent Kinver Constitutional Club on 3rd June 2014. Pours a good solid gold with white head that hung around. The nose was fruity with light maltiness, biscuit and bread like. The taste followed on in the same pattern, malty rather than hop bitter. Fairly smooth for a bitter and very easy to drink.

Cask at GBBF 2016, Kensington Olympia. Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of dark malt, light roast coffee, biscuity malt and mild earthy note. Reasonable body for a mild. Nice roasty flavours. Not overly complex.
Cask at White Lion Bridgnorth. Clear chestnut cream head. Malt light chocolate caramel biscuit

Cask at GBBF 2016, Day 1 - London. Pours clear brown with a foamy, tan head. Nice beer, with notes of brown bread, light toast. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Finishes with decent balance, more brown bread, mellow bitterness, hints of cocoa, more toast. Good mild.

August 2016 - Cask at GBBF 2016 as ’Olde Swan Dark Swan’. Dark orange brown, still, clear, small foamy off-white head. Aroma is chocolatey, dense breads, some teacake. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is cola, light coffee, smooth malts. Decent mild. (3.3)

Cask at GBBF ’16, day one, 09/08/16. Rich chestnut brown with a decent beige head. Nose is mild fruits, toffee, light spice, brown bread. Taste comprises earthy fruits, dates, raisens, cocoa powder. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, semi drying close. Adequate mild.

Cask at GBBF 2016. It pours clear deep brown with a small white head. The aroma is toasted nuts, cocoa powder, earthy, twig and caramel. The taste is dry, bitter, woody, earthy roast, leather, dried fruits, twig and toffee. Light - medium body and soft carbonation. Decent enough balance and drinkability, but it didn’t stand out from the crowd.

Cask at GBBF 2016 09/08/2016. A nutty brown coloured pour with a a thin beige head. Aroma is nutty malts, dried apple, woody plum. Flavour is composed of sweet liquorice, plum, raisin, green apple, liquorice. Palate is semi sweet lowish carbonation, bog standard mild.

Cask at the Old Swan. Poured a clear dark brown with a frothy light tan head. The aroma is smoky malt. The flavour is smoky liqourice with a light nutty malt, spicy hop palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Not sure this was a typical mild though!
Cask at the Olde Swan; clear nut brown pour with a creamy tan head, light coffee and fruit aroma, taste has dark fruits and coffee.
Cask at the source. Clear deep maroon amber color, thick beige head. Aroma of burnt toast. Taste is fruity coffee, light body.

1. Cask Handpump at Oakwood High School, Rotherham 22/02/2003 Amber golden coloured with some sour fruit aroma. Lasting malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Bankers Draft, Sheffield (JDW) 06/10/2003 Amber coloured smooth on the palate with a fruit aroma. Slightly dry malt finish.

Sampled cask conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm. Brownish amber. Hay aroma. Fruity with wonderfully soft and chewy malt character. A hint of apples and a balanced bitter finish. Superb in it's simplicity. Oh to drink loads of this beer.
Draught at Somers Club, Halesowen. Meium Brown premium bitter strong on hops and dry bitter flavours. A goodly amount of malt present too.

Growler from beerbud...Poured a deep umber with a ring of mocha foam the dies quickly... aromas are roasted malts and a subtle touch of chocolate. On the palate it was lacking a bit of umph but was quite drinkable and lacked any major flaws. Lack of carbonation and a bit more focus on punching up the flavors and they may have better luck. Not to familiar with the brewery but based on the listings seems like a decent brewpub that enjoys brewing a wide variety of beers for the masses. Cheers to that !

Appearance: clean and clear with blacks bordered by garnet and cherry woods. Tan collar but no real head to speak of. Nose: roasted and toasty all around. Dark Ghirardelli cocoa powder. Roasted marshmallows with a nice char, just the way I like them. Vanilla bean. Rich black earth. Palate: wet woods old and deep, ash, and scorched earth. Bark and twigs in the middle, burnt of course. Unsweetened pure black cacao Ghirardelli chocolate tingles and grabs sides of cheeks. Acrid burnt black root. Raisins and prunes for a touch of meaty goodness. Final Thoughts: a solid quaffer of a porter perfect for slaking a hard working man or woman’s thirst. The last of my Amherst flight of four, I declined on any growlers to go but did get my lucky hands on a t-shirt.

On tap at the brewpub. A good example of the inconsistency of the lineup, this porter is rather bland and the carbonation and taste is off. Certainly not a batch that should have been served. Dark, a bit of aroma, some hops that gave it some citrus. It could have used: less carboantion, more malting, particular chocolate malt.

Deep dark black. Tan head. Roasted malt, raison, port, coffe'ish nose. Dark espresso, burnt flavor, bitter chocolate, raison, dark fruit, slightly viscous, with a great body and mouthfeel. A very nice brew from the ABC...

column1: Golden Pacific Half Dome Pale Ale
column5: When I think of a Pale Ale, Sierra Nevada is what comes to mind. This is OK compared to that. Nice amber color with a little white head. The aroma had me expecting a lot, but the taste is a bit lacking but not too much. You can clearly taste the hops but it's not as strong as Sierra Nevada. Overall not bad but I'll stick with SN.

column1: Golden Pacific Half Dome Pale Ale
column5: Bottle. A medium golden color with an off-white head. A malty pale ale with a little toasted and vanilla character, which gets old quickly.

column1: Golden Pacific Half Dome Amber Ale
column5: A nice dark golden color. A decent sized head. Very smooth. About the smoothest beer I've had in a while. Some hops but not too much.

column1: Golden Pacific Half Dome Amber Ale
column5: Bottle. Dark golden color with an off-white head. A sweet malty flavor with a slightly burnt aroma.

This is the 7.0% version that the brewpub lists at Dubbel Vision, so I’m not sure if its a new beer or not. Draft at the source. Clear maroon color, tan head. Aroma of toasted nutella, cocoa, cafe au lait. Taste is smooth cocoa powder, coffee grounds. Not bad.

On tap 4 oz. pour at Franklin's Restaurant, Brewery & General Store. Very hazy, rusty brown with a khaki head and very good lacing. Taste of sweet dark fruit, caramel, banana and chocolate. Sweet for a dubbel. Light/medium body and low/medium carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Pours a muddy brown with no head. Flavor is spice, licorice, mint, sugar and a tiny bit of hops and alcohol. Moutfeel was crisp and refreshing with little aftertaste. Easy to drink but the flavor caught me off guard.

On tap at Franklin’s. Poured a nice looking brown mahogany color with a thin white head. Aroma was straight up banana and malt. having this after the batch #400 was like drinking the skinny little brother of the 400. Not bad, but a lot of banana and (probably unfairly) thinner than the previous beer. Very drinkable though.
Draft. Mahogony beer with a light tan head. Banana and spice aroma. Banana, clove, spice and light malt flavor. Medium bodied. Banana, malt, and spice lingers.

Stopped by the brewpub to pick up a growler and saw that they were offering this on cask. I asked for a sample and the bartender told me, "Tell me if you like it, I think it’s weird." The sample of the cask Double Vision pours a clear purple brown with no head. The aroma is heavy alcohol and vinegar. The flavor was similar, very astringent, citrus bitterness, fusel alcohol and a little metallic tinge. Finish was very pungent. Needless to say, I passed on the cask version. The version on tap that I ultimately got for my growler was much better. Pours a purpley, brown with a thin white head. Aroma was spicy, bread, nuts, clove and slight citrus all marry well. Flavor has much more of the grain, biscuit, dark/sweet fruit and a bit of yeast. Definite alcohol on the end and slightly thick on the tongue. I don’t love Belgian, but this was very drinkable and a nice change of pace from Franklins.

Pint at the brewery. Cloudy bread crust brown body. Proper clove, toast, mild fruit and nuts in the nose, more of a pulpy fruit character tasted, makes me think of pulp (as in orange) from plums (which I guess doesn’t really exist). Nutty, bready, soggy, chewy, toasty; overall it’s a pretty solid dubbel, with just a hint of alcohol at the end.

Growler sample courtesy of artusory. Muddy medium brown, minimal head. Roast, pepper and spice up front, chewy yeast background. Flavor has some faint banana, pepper and more spice, hard to pinpoint. As it warms even more, get a certain vegetal character I can’t pinpoint. Mouthfeel rather thin at times.

Courtesy of artusory Growler: The aroma is fruity and yeasty with some notes of burnt wood, alcohol, and vegetables. It pours a cloudy brownish-orange with a small off-white head. The flavor starts yeasty with some candi sugar, fruit, burnt wood, and slight vegetal notes. The finish has some faint bitterness and alcohol.

Pours a hazy dark copper mahogany with a thin ring of wispy white head. Has a lightly toasted, bready caramel malty aroma with a touch of light fruit. Starts lightly malty sweet with some dark candi sugar drying out toward a more bitter, earthy finish. Fairly well-balanced and authentic.

On the menu as "Belgian Tripel" and served in a 10oz goblet. Pale, yellow with a filmy, white head and little carbonation. Aroma is sweet, spicy, with plenty of alcohol esters, bananas and some clove. Flavor is pale and fruity, and a little bit of spice. Sticky in the mouth, dry and astringent finish. A touch too boozy for it’s own good.

Hazy, pale body with small, white head. The aroma is very esters, banana, clove, some spice and alcohol. The flavor is slightly sweet, slightly boozy, with lots of apricots, bananas and peach, some spice and a good dose of alcohol finish it off. Medium/full body has soft carbonation and a warm, astringent finish.

Listed as Belgian Tripple (9.5%): Pours a slightly hazy golden with a nicely-lacing frothy white head. Aroma of sweet pale malts and bready Belgian yeast with a touch of spice and fruity esters. Body starts full, pale malty and sweet with nice light fruity complexity and a hint of coriander before a slightly warming, drier finish. Very true to style and enjoyable.

Hazy gold, fluffy off-white head. Nose is full of sweet orange peel, pear, corriander, banana, and fresh bread. Flavor shows just a bit too much alcohol, (this batch was 12%...yikes)but still pretty tasty regardless. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry sweet finish. A nice interpretation....

Hazy orange body with minimal white head. Aroma is medium sweet, coriander, other spices, orange. Taste is sticky sweet candy sugar, orange, spicy, and hint of alcohol. Alcohol warms on the way down. Nice medium body.

Lovely beer. A hazy copper gold color with lacy head. Spicy, sweet, orange aroma. The flavor is sweet, mildly orangy, well-rounded, full bodied, and slightly spicy (corriander-ish). High alcohol, but not a strong alcohol flavor. It's a great Belgian-style that does its heritage proud. I very much enjoyed this beer.

Great Beer! Hazy, golden hue. Small, creamy white head. The aroma is of dark bread, fuzzy fruits, candy sugar, bananna and alcohol. Way sweet up front, but almost balanced out on the backside by the tart, acrid and lightly bitter hop addition. So, a fairly well-balanced tripel, although the high ABV is definitely evident. Not necessarily a negative in my book. Medium-length, dry, pungent and astringent finish. My 500th rating. Yeehaw!
Flesje gedronken met TomHendriksen bij brouwerij. Bleek gelig bier met lichte vlokken en stevig schuim. Fruitig, moutig aroma. Smaak is fruitig maar wel wat plat. Nasmaak is iets bitter.
Geproefd met Inoven bij brouwerij ’t Vølen te Volendam. Het bier is helder geel met een dunne schuimkraag. Het heeft een moutige geur en een moutige wat zoete smaak.
clear yellow, small white head. aroma is malty,flowery. flavor is malty, flowery.
50 cl. bottle. Clear yellow colour with a white head. Aroma and flavour of hops, yeast, wheat, spice and fruit.
Pale golden color with a thin, bubbly white head. Fruity aroma with spices, yeasts and citrus. Taste is lightly bitter. Finishes dry with citrus. Ok.
Bottle@Yespr’s - Yellow clear pour with small white head. Aroma and taste is sweet with notes of malts and yeast, some wheaty notes, grassy herbal hoppy notes, dry finish.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild spiced and slight estery. Carbonated. Flat malty. Light herbal. Dry and cardboardish finish.

Draught (backlog). Hazy yellow colour with a small but thick head, which leaves some lace. Aroma is a bunch of spices, some citrus, mild acidic notes as well as quite strong on the yeasty side of things. Flavour is yeasty, some citrus, spices, some acidic notes and mild wooden notes as well. Nicely fresh, but at the same time a quite dry palate.

(Draught at Arendsnest, Amsterdam, 24 July 2013) Hazy yellow colour with dense, white head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of lemon, tropical fruit, wheaty malt and hints of coriander. Malty, fruity taste with wheaty malt, citrus, tropical fruit, grass and a gentle bitterness in a fairly dry finish. Medium body, quite dry. Solid and quite enjoyable witbier.
Poured pale and milky with a frothy white head. Aroma of zesty, spicy citrus. Light body, flavour is muted lactose and light orange with a minimally sweet end.
Aroma metálico, sabor agresivo, con tonos de jabón y final amargo pegajoso. No recomendable.
Ambar. 1 dedo de espuma. Aroma a Granos de café, muy marcado. Prometedor. Pero el sabor no esta a la altura. Excesivamente cereal. Y final muy amrago, duradero.
Легкий, освежающий , с горчинкой. В целом - достаточно простой по вкусу лагер.
Botella de 33 cl, en Cerveceria Internacional. Color dorado. Sabor a malta, dulce, suave.

Shared 20cl on tap. Pours a clear light golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma is hay, malts and floral. Average carbonation and light watery body. Taste is metallic and light, more bitter than sweet and dry finish. Overall, a regular lager... And the bartender told me that it was very good. Never trust him again.
Poured a light amber with a small off white ring. Aroma of chemically sweet malt. Medium body, flavour is cloyingly sweet and unbalanced.
On tap at a pub. Average looking lager. Golden color, persistent white head. Somewhat grainy and straight forward lager, average.

33 cl. – clear green – bottle @ home. Procured from Carrefour. Pours a clear amber orange with a tiny synthetic white head. Smells like an industrial lager but rawer, touch solvents and superglue mixed with this odd sweetness like watered down cheap candy sugar, I am not feeling it. Taste is bitter, surprisingly some hops here mixed with a watery mess of watered down brown honey and chemicals, sweet grains and caramel. The whole thing is really watery. Despite all of this you still get a light alcohol burn, garbage ingredients I suppose. A total mess, not much of a surprise there. Label at least doesn’t look to bad.
Bottle. Pale piss yellow. Flavour is sweet caramel and some itchy hops. Thin and unacceptably poor.
Super dulde, galleta, caramelo en nariz, malta y miel en boca, un poco empalagosa, alcohol demasiado presente
This is the best beer! It tastes like Pez candy but not as sweet. It reminds me of being in Germany. If only I could find it in the U.S...

A pale yellow cloudy beer with an OK head. The aroma is a sweet pineapple aroma with slight hints of orange - definatly not a beer aroma. The flavor is way too sweet and acidic - not a beer taste - rather like a sodapop. It has faint hints of malt but no bitterness. Very boring for a beer.
nutyy/malty aroma, bronze colour with an average and rapidly disipating head, mild malty and woody character, dry hoppy finish, another decent ASDA offering

Bottled. Amber, initialy good head but soon goes, moderate condition. Toffee, caramel and smokey malt in the nose with a hint of cow dung. Malty in the mouth with more traces of lingering woodsmoke. Mouthcoating dry smokey finish.

Nut and toasted malt aroma. Copper hue with a small off white head. Good toasted malt taste with hints of coffee and dark chocolate. A quite complex ale that is most enjoyable and refreshing. No blandness here thank you very much!
Draft at the brewery. Lightly cloudy gold, huge lasting head. Neutral spicy aroma. Clean complex earthy, herbal hop flavor dominates with a hint of grains in the background. Almost IPA bitterness.
Draught at the source: pours clear light gold with a whitish head. Aroma is light grass, with thin maltiness. Taste is a bit grainy, sort of bitter. Pretty standard fare.

Piwo słomkowe, nieco mętnawe. Piana znika bardzo szybko. Chmielowo-słodowy smak, w posmaku nieco nut zbożowych na kartonowym tle. Wyraźna, dość ostra goryczka utrzymuje się na podniebieniu przez dłuższy czas. Dobre nasycenie.
Melko laimean makuinen. Maultaan hieman tummempi kuin väri antaa olettaa. Jälkimakua löytyy vaikka ensivaikutelma onkin pieni pettymys. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Suomenlinna jatkaa laatuoluiden linjalla Seth Lagerin jälkeen myös Pilsillä. Kyseessä kirkas, kullankeltainen olut paksulla valkoisella vaahdolla, joka jättää hieman pitsiä. Tuoksu maltainen ja voinen, mutta aavistuksen liian köykäinen. Maku sen sijaan on mainio. Voinen makeus on vahvasti esillä ja yllättäen toimii kokonaisuudessa loistavasti humalan tuoman katkeruuden vastatessa jälkimausta. Todella toimiva pils!
Draught at the Soumenlinna brewery restaurant. Medium white head. Cloudy solid yellow color. Fresh hop aroma with a spicy and citrus tuch. Firm bitterness and clean malt taste. Slim body.
Hyvä peruspilsneri. Nopeasti livahti kurkusta alas. Tasapainoinen ja raikas kebabin kaveri.

Ppirs just short of a clear golden yellow body with a frothy, well lasting white head. Nose has notes of hay, some florals and touch of honey. Taste is dry with a nice bitter finish, a little metallic note as well. Lively carbonation and light but not watery palate. Quite nice and refreshing, decent bitterness and some aroma hops that separate this from the basic light lager. Palate is surprisingly good as well despite the low ABV.

(Bottle, Oak Barrel, Helsinki Airport, 26 May 2015) Golden colour with frothy, white head. Malty, fresh nose with notes of bread, grass, hay and grainy malt. Malty taste with bread, hay, grass, a touch of peaches, some vanilla and a balanced grassy bitterness in the finish. Medium body, with a touch of sweetness. Fresh and tasty pilsener. Quite enjoyable.

How: Bottle. Where: No. 18 in the Hjulkalender from my wonderful wife. Appearance: Golden colour with a white head. Aroma: Caramel, bread, malt. Body: Light to medium body, medium carbonation. Flavour: Malt, hops, caramel, a little metallic.
Tried for the first time in 2007 and only now getting to the ratings transfer. Weak in appearance, aroma, and flavor. Tired chocolate flavor, a little breads, not much else.
Backlog rating LCRBM/Bruxellensis 2006: Nice layering nitroporter bubbles, creamy head. No aroma. Very light nutty. Very lightbodied, watery.
Taste is like watery Guinness with a strong metallic aftertaste. The name is really the best thing about this beer.

"THAT explains it! a stout made by our good friends at Bud. I was excited to see a new stout, complete with a 3d boxer taphandle, while on vacation. more excited as it came out, cascading on nitro. the flavor, however, was entirely underwhelming. if you’re a Guiness fan it’s almost comprable, but i’m a fan of bigger stouts than this."

(Revised from 2007 rating.) Pours a deep brown with a cascading khaki head. Well, A-B has its Guiness clone and competitor (or had). Smooth, creamy, and dry. Very light, too. A little too light, in terms of aroma and flavor. Faint roast and chocolate and coffee and cream. This really isn’t (or wasn’t) bad. I wish they still made it, to be honest. It was my go-to when we took visiting friends in college on the A-B brewery tour.

(old notes) Used to get this on-tap from the Busch Gardens beer room every once in a while. Black pour, tan head. Not much aroma, just roasted malts and a little chocolate. Taste is a fair Guinness knock-off, a little more alcohol and a little too thin. Perfectly average.

Overall, it’s not a bad stout. Nothing really special here but I would take it over pretty much anything else AB makes. I have a feeling if it wasn’t associated with AB it would probably have a much higher rating.
Draft from awhile ago. Pours black. Nose/taste of roasted barley, baker’s chocolate and dark malt. Dry finish. Plain.

I can't even find this anymore. If you did. A blind taste test this would score much higher. But because it's brewed by AB people have a predisposed hatred of it. It's a bit chocolatier Guiness. Still a nice stout. Regardless of the brewer ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tasted on tap in standard pint glass. Poured a clear, dark brown color with fluffy off-white foam which dissipated fairly quickly leaving very little lace. Aromas of bread, roasted barley, no hops, no yeast esters. Some malt-sweetness, slight hops bitterness, more roasted barley. Completely missing any malty, fruity complexity. Light body and thin, bland mouthfeel, Characteristic Anheuser-Busch watery and metallic tastes with sharp, overly fizzy carbonation. Stouts are great, but this is a sadly lacking version.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a black color with beige highlights and a huge creamy off white head that left incredible lacing. The aroma was dryish and roasty with a hint of vanilla. The flavor was dry and bitter with roasty malts and almost vanilla cream. Medium length finish. Medium body. Not bad for a style I dont care for.
Dark black almost brown, with no head remaining. Smoky with a very distant rear cocoa finish
Really nice example of the style with a little more smoke and peat, dark with nice head but little lacing, not thin and finishes reletively clean

This poured a black color with a big fluffy tan head. Aroma was almost not existent due to the large head but was a bit dark rasoted malts and smoke. Flavor was really smokey and a little chocolatey. Loved the smoke here but the rest was way too thin must like most of there other beers.

On tap at the brewery. This was a very run of the mill dry stout. Aroma was pretty weak but could pick up roasted malt. Pour was a nice near black with a two finger tan head. Taste was flat and roasty like the style usually is. This isn’t bad, but all nitrogenated beers taste the same to me. Like a beer that has been sitting out for a day. For what it is, though, on par with a Tetleys or Beamish.

Creamy head, almost like chocolate mousse. Very dark, almost black for the most part. Not much aroma, it just comes across clean nosed. On the palate, it’s pretty much flat, like most Irish jig stouts. Very nice lacing on the glass, makes me want to peak behind. Mildly roasty and ropey on the tongue. Above average dry stout. Surprisingly not as bitter as other DS I’ve had. Has a finish like stale bark beer, but in a good way. Can’t get used to beer without carbonation.

At the Church Brew Works. They called this batch O’Casey’s, (March 17, 2007) although the description was referred to as the same as O’Bryan’s. Black brown, off white head. Aroma is molasses, coffee, chocolate. Flavor is molasses, coffee, chocolate, pine. Thin body, but nice bitterness.

Pours like a typical Irish dry stout. (ie. no description necessary) Aroma of dark coffee and roasted barley. A nice mouthfeel with a quick bitterness at the end. The extra abv was a welcomed addition to a rather tame style. The best beer I had there.
Very black, persistent brown head. Roasty smokey nose and taste with a touch of bitterness. Medium bodied.
High quality dry stout. Smooth and tastey. Just the lightest hints of chocolate. Very creamy. Another success for the Church Brew Works.

I am really touchy about smoke in beers but this one was very well done - prominent smoke but not one dimensional. +++ Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a very dark brown color with a medium sized foamy tan head that left a touch of lacing. The aroma was bacon bits, a hint of nut, wood, more bacon, pepper and a touch of raisin. The flavor was woody and smoky with some bacon, some toasty malts, nut and a hint of bread. Sweeter than I would have expected but it really worked. The finish was long with wood and bacon lingering. Medium body. Well done.

This poured a lightly cloudy medium brown color with a small beige head. Aroma was of caramel, grass, light toffee and medium strength smoked malt. Flavor was a nice blend of caramel sweetness with smoke bitterness, not too sweet, but not offensively smokey. Definitely a smoked beer I wouldn’t mind have more than one glass of.

Had this at the 2011 Pittsburgh Ratebeer Christmas Eve Eve Tasting. OK, this beer has been brought back into production by Lithy and he did a good job. IMHO the first version of this, 2003, was not too good. I normally do not like smoke beers but this was a special treat. Appearance is not black like other smoked beers that I find acceptable, more of brownish thing here. Dull and smokey on the aroma, no doubt this is a smoke beer. Oh my, what a smokey impact on the buds. However, it seems to have nice balance, no ill bacon or anything like that. Most smokeys are way over the top but this is behaved and a gentleman. Friendly, and easy! Does have a decent amount of CO2 and this helps me enjoy it. BIG THANKS LITHY! Finally a smoked beer I can appreciate. I’m gonna say its up there with east end heritage porter and Ofallons smoked porter, my two most liked smoke beers.

This was one of the more palatable smoked beers I've had. Malts are sweet caramel and medium thick and the finish was mostly dry. The smoked flavors start with the aroma and follow the tastes from beginning to end, adding a consistent character to this. I was pleasantly surprised. Dark orange/brown color.
nice lighlty smoked beer. the smokiness comes through asa flavor component and does not overwhelm the malt character of this beer. finishes on a dry note with a lingering smoky sweetness.
Very heavy on the hops with both scent and taste. A light head which vanishes fast. A good session beer.

500ml bottle 3.8%. Clear golden amber colour, foam white head and aroma of malt, hay, light citrus. Taste is malt, straw, fruity with spicy bitterness and some sweetness. Light bodied, medium carbonation, dry finish. OK.

Had this @ Galtres festival. Reading other reviews I'm sure I didn't have this at is best. I thought it uninspiring and a little ordinary. I will reserve final judgement until I have tried it again, but I wasn't a fan. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Small offwhite head. Clear paleish yellow body. Light floral gooseberry aroma with mealy fruity notes. Dry-sweet dusty strawy gooseberry taste with resiny floral notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Dry resiny floral gooseberry aftertaste with papery spicy notes. Nice, drinkable, pleasant. (0.5l bottle, from House of Trembling Madness, York.)
Best of a long day. Good golden colour with white head. Creamy texture, with a crisp hoppy taste. A good 3.7 / 5.0 for a good session beer.
Golden colour, thin white head. Nose is strong flowery/floral hops. Taste is floral and fruity with a dry hoppy finish. Strong flowery English bitter. Good flavours.

The Crown, Nuneaton. Bright orange gold with a fine white collar shrinking to a halo. Good tang of orange-accented hoppiness on the nose; some earthy yeast, pineapple jelly. Crisp and biscuity with tangy hop, malted milk linger, ripe satsuma burps. Good.
Cask at Cloisters ... amber thin white head ... light orange hop ... grassy bitterness ... dry linger ... mostly hop dominated.

Bottle thanx to Joes. A clear yellow/golden colored beer, with a thick white head. The aroma of fruits, malt with some hops. The taste has a nice bitterness with sweets of fruits, like orange with citrus. There are malts. It’s fresh. The aftertaste is bittersweet.

Bottle@BlindTastingSession. Sharp yeast aroma, citrus, fresh grass. Yellow colour, hazy, white head, good lace. Light sweet, light sourish and pretty bitter start, in the finish almost just the hop bitterness. Citric (lime), malty and grassy. Dry mouth feel in the finish, medium body. Very unusual but nice Golden Ale.

Bottle conditioned. Very dark brown with a thick beige head. Sweet malty aroma. Taste is, - well it doesn’t say anywhere on my bottle that this is a stout, and it clearly isn’t - fruity, malty, hoppy and a touch sour. Light bodied, foamy mouthfeel. Pretty good easy drinking porter-ish beer.
Hand pulled at the Wellington, Birmingham. Smooth, malty style Porter (I thought?). Some biscuit and bread wrapped in the smooth, watery choc. A bit light and untroublesome.
Cask@St Albans Beer Festival. Sweetish undeveloped malt character, some green apple characters, with a touch of caramel or something, this is a stout?

Cask (gravity dispense), St Albans Beer Festival 2005. A very odd stout. Reddish brown colour - not very dark for a stout. Not a lot of aroma, but what’s there is dull and vaguely malty. Bits of caramel and fruity malt on the palate, but no great depth of flavour. Thin and seemed very tired to me (it being the last day of the festival). More like a mild than a stout. I have a bottle of this so I’ll re-rate soon to see if the festival conditions were to blame.
Cask (gravity dispense), St Albans Beer Festival 2005. Cloudy ruby beer, dark fruit flavours with some bitterness. Dark plums, figs and dates
Cask (St Albans 05): Light brown in colour. Chocolate aroma. Malty sweet start with some nice toffee notes. Easy drinking.
From A Bottle.Auburn in colour,large head,aroma is of hospital corridors,strange, taste is of oak and surgical spirits,very dry with a medical tasting theme.

Bottle Conditioned. Dark red in appearance with a beige head. Aromas are fruity sweet berries and floral, perfumed hops. Flavours are roast malts with fruit, smooth chocolate and a good deal of dry hops. Hints of smokiness, too. Nice and dry on the finish. Has to warm up a bit if chilled to give its true character.
Cask conditioned - Gravity - Derby BF. A black coloured sweet stout. The aroma is of sweet (perhaps milky) alcohol. The taste is excellent with caramel and toffee full flavours. Very nice indeed.

Dec, 2003: Gravity fresh @ Pig’s Ear Beer Fest, East London. A mild. Good red and black berries aroma. Soft, easy to drink - berry fruits with a light but noticable touch of hops. Very tasty. [3.7] Oct, 2005: St Albans. Gravity. Crystal malt. Soft subtle hop. Pleasant. Not the same beer as I had at Pigs Ear. Hmmm. Has somebody made a mistake somewhere? [2.5]
Lactic aroma. Cloudy brown color, light brown head, fair lace. The flavor is bitter and lactic. It's thin. Short finish.
Draft. Aroma of malt, grain and some citrus. Taste has grainy malt, grassy citrus and bitter herbs. Solid.
At the brewery, taster from plank. Golden with white head. Sweet malts, light buttery, light earthy, green beans. Moderate sweet and bitter. Light body and soft carbonation.

Bottle pours near clear gold, with a very small white head, that nearly disappears. Aroma is fruity at first, yellow fruist, later quite faint. Taste moderate bitter, not so much more. Problem is the carbonation: too soft, too little CO2. Makes it a flat and undistinctive beer; easy drinkable.
Draught at the brewpub. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Light bitter slightly soapy flavor. Average light bitter finish. Oily plate.

(Pelgrim Stoombier) Bottle 330ml at home, served into a tulip, ABV 5% Orange coloured body, mostly clear, with a small and thin white head on top, average retention. Aroma has hints of hops with faint citrus, tropical fruits, grass. Taste is kind of dusty, still some citrus, malts, tropical fruits and grass. Medium thin body, high carbonation. Good.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Hazy golden/amber colored brew with an decent dry bitter taste, slightly hints of honey and citrus. They got new beerlabels, much better than the one on the picture.
0,33l fles helder goudgeel met een witte kraag. Geur is fris met gras en hooi ook citrus. Smaak is vlak en muf houdt het midden tussen boterbabbelaar en dunne appelsap.

Tap at De Pelgrim. Clear golden with very big but short lasting white head. Light sweet malts, toffee, honey, light spices, baklava, light herbal in the finish. Medium sweet and very light bitter. Over medium bodied with creamy carbonation. Massive mouthfeel for the ABV.

0.2 l on tap at the brewpub. Clear, golden yellow with a medium large, creamy, stable, white head. Sweetish-malty, slightly grassy aroma of straw, honey, vanilla and hints of citrus. Sweetish-malty, slightly grassy taste of straw, sweet malts, honey and hints of citrus, followed by a short, slightly bitter, slightly grassy finish. Medium body, smooth and slightly creamy mouthfeel, average to lively carbonation. Bland but okay.

Lukt: Frukter, plomme, noe søtlig duft. Utseende: Lys gulbrun. Skum/kullsyre: Tynt skum. Smak: Frukter, plomme, noe syrlig avslutning. Hvor: Nydt@Ølsmaking hos Bryne. Medium: Flaske@330ml, ABV@5%, Når@12.12.2015
Bottled. Cloudy yellow. Flowery ginger aroma. Light bodied, clean and mild with discrete honeyish finish.
Yeasty rosebudaroma. Golden color, small frothy head. Thin. Very yeasty, yet fruity flavor. Rosebuds and orange. The overwhelming yeastiness spoils the fun.

Light citrus and jasmin aroma. Cloudy honey color, white head that diminishes fast, few lace. Light sweet, jasmin, malty, bit thin. Some hops in the finish. Special because of the jasmin but that's it.

Bottle: BB somewhere in 2012: Served in a Palm snifter: Small white foamy head on top of a hazy to murky yellow colored beer. Aroma has lots of ripe banana tones. There’s also some yeast, liquor tones, cream and some vanilla. Flavours of vanilla, marzipan, some cream, some bananas, some marshmellows while this all is more bitter than sweet. Also hints of yeast, grains, malts, oat and older flowers. Aftertaste is bitter with herbs, yeast, and some grainy malts. Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied and a creamy texture. Decent beer. Leans more towards a creamy sweet tone, but has a nice bitterness.
Golden, yellow colour, small white head, citrus fruity smell, bitter medium carbobation fruity warm citrus like a bit nutty aftertaste
33cl bottle at the Arendsnest 10th March 07. Good white head. Hazy amber pour. Surprising drinkable for a fruit beer. Good effort.

2nd December 2009 Pigs Ear. Hazy amber beer. Palate starts soft but turns crisp and then back to soft and frothy but with a carbonated sting! Great palate! The blackcurrant is nicely judged and neither too sweet or to acidic. Finishes semi dry with some minerals.

Kruik @ Cafe Buitenlust, Oirschot. Shared with Thompson. Cloudy, hazy, opaquepale yellow color, no head. Smell slightly fruit, a lot of cardboard. Taste s dull, faint bitterness, faint sweetness. Boring and not good at all. No carbo, low body.
Acorn beer? The nuttiness and the wateriness of this beer undermine any of its novelty. A must miss.

Clear orange body with champagne-like bubbles and no head at all. Citrus, wheat in the aroma, and not very pronounced. Cheese or mould as well. Luckily not as sour or skunky as expected. There is some medium heavy flavour of fruit. Pleasant bitter aftertaste saves this unfortunate beer. Feel it’s underdeveloped (as in the brewing process). Keep up the work, brewer. (2,25 EUR, 33cl bottle)
Bottle from the pigs ear fest, had at home. Alround rating: Thin wheaty, very nutty, a bit of butteryness, no hop and on the sweetside, overly carbonated also. Not a win.

Bottle, courtesy of a hardcore Danish crew Cloudy pale blond color. Strange aroma, spicy and nutty (peanuts). The flavor is lightly sour, possibly infected, sweetish, and nothing else worth mentioning. Poor.
Botella. cloudy yellw. Fruity yeasty aroma, bit sour. Pleasant fruity wheat bit alco flavour.

Bottled. Orange and cloudy withrich head. Interesing aroma of peaches and fresh summer flowers. Light bodied with balanced sweetness and some esters. Low bitterness. Thanks jbrus for this and many other fine beers!
Honey color. Cloudy, thin frothy head. Yeasty aroma with cherry, orange and rosebuds. Very yeasty bitter flavor. Rosebuds and an orange fruitiness. Rather thin, bitter finish.
Grains and malts in the aroma. Cloudy honey color, white head, good lace. Very malty, light sweet, light spices. Short malty finish.

Bottled (old backlog). Slightly hazy yellow colour with some stuff floating around. Mediumsized creamy white head that leaves quite a nice lace. Aroma is citrus, zestyness, some yeast as well as some sweet grainy notes. Flavour is wheatlike, mild spices, yeast, citrus and some slight toffee. Some slight notes of alcohol to be noted.

Bottle @ YNWA, Kolding. Pours clear neon-yellow with small floaties. A nice, creamy white head on top. Aroma is sweet, lemony, oranges, apples and a light doughy tone to the malts. Fine, light mouthfeel. Flavour is softly fruity, good sweet maltiness and apple notes again. Fine, powerful, citric bitterness at the end. Very drinkable.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a cloudy yellow with a small white head and an intense grainy aroma with citric notes. The flavor is grainy with some notes of roasted grain. There are lots of different notes in here, biscuits, caramel, mocca, citrus, ripe fruits and spices. The finish is roasty at first, becomes sweet like ripe peaches and then turns on to more hoppy bitterness. I love this brew!

Bottle from Bierkoning. Nice peachy colour. Slight head. Nose of oranges and citrus. Taste also fruity. Hoppy. Nicely carbonated. Not sure what spelt tastes like but a pleasant tasting beer. Quite spicy in the finish. Really good, actually.

Bottle. Nice suprise. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Orange colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Orange notes. Nice well-balanced powerfull bitter flavor. Average nice finish. Oily palate. Good stuf.

Cloudy dull yellow, immediately fading head despite the active carbonation is a sad sight. Little aroma really. A certain graininess is felt, but not much more. In mouth, the focus is totally and only on cereals and spelt of course. Still, the focus is really well pulled. Even though there are pretty much no other flavours, those feel quite sufficient, hay-like, strawy and pleasantly simple.

Very soft beer, just like the others from Ooijen Brewery. Hazy yellow, small head. Aromas of coriander, wheat(spelt?) and oranges. Tastes sweetish, wheaty, some spices and near the end there is a typical spelt-taste, like eating spelt-bread: bit earthy, bitterish and nutty. Nice one.

Very pale yellow; thick, huge white head, going lacey. End of bottle is full of super-flunky islands. Nice perfumey nose, with coriander and lunaria. Very nice. Taste is rather soupy because of the coriander, but that is the only negative I can find. Sweet, but not overly so, with a spicey character. rather light mouthfeel. Nice - not as great as the Eikelbier, but all the same. Maybe a touch too much coriander?
Bottled. Cloudy pale yellow. Spicy, wheay nose. Soft and light bodied with notes of mustard. Refreshing!
Malty aroma with a hint of citrus. Cloudy honey color, white head, very good lace. Light sweet, light lemon, refreshing, medium body. Light bitter finish.
Cask, The Two-Tailed Lion, Leicester. Golden with a white head. Lemon curd with citrus tang. Jammy sweetness. Hedgerow finish. Nice.

Clear golden pour with a thin layer on top. Solid lacing Moderate intensity in the aroma Decent sweetness and a mild bitterness Soft carbonation level Malty, fruity, wheat and herbal flavor Not to exciting this one [Handpull at Salopian Bar in Shrewsbury, England]
Cask at The Albert, Llandudno. Clear yellow appearance. Aroma is zesty, lemon and orange. Flavour is citrus, lemon, smooth and grassy.

Sample@GBBF2018, London, with the the Malmö crew - golden orange coloured pour with a medium white head. Aroma and taste is fruity, light lemon zesty, with notes of straw, hay, light pale malts, crisp on the palate, refreshing wheat ale.

My Bottom Line: Citrus zest and green peppercorn-like hoppy notions ride this fluffy and lean Golden Ale. Further Personal Perceptions: -A slice of foam floats atop the barely misty golden. -The cask conditioning job here is quite nice. A surprise to find such an authentic cask mouthfeel in Helsinki! -The finish is balanced, with a few cereals peering through for good measure. -Drinkability is quite high. -The citrus character is obviously not just from hops here (added zest, I presume). On cask at St. Urho’s, Helsinki.
Lemon and citrus taste. Cloudy golden colour. Refreshing with an attractive bitterness. Fair strength.
Pours a light pale golden with a very thin white/yellow head. Citrus forward aroma and citrus taste that makes way for bitter hoppy finish.
Light refreshing, hoppy but not overpowering. Drank this outside in the sunshine during the heatwave and it was perfect.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours pale gold with a small, lasting white head. Aroma of lemon drizzle cake, citrus fruit and hop. Moderate sweetness, moderate bitterness, light tartness. Light body, slight oily watery texture, average carbonation. Light, refreshing, zesty golden ale.
Cask at Thomas Rigby's. Pours a clear light yellow with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma combines lemonade and earthy wheat. Flavor has earthy wheat with some lemonade underlying.
Bottle from a Vínbúdin in Reykjavik. Amber with a frothy cream head. Mild caramel aroma. The taste is caramel, light spice and toast. OK.

33 cl bottle at 3 Frakkar, Reykjavik. Pours clear dark amber with a small white head. Aroma of caramel and weak grains. Taste is moderate sweet malty, bread and caramel, rather one dimentional this one, watery mouthfeel as wel.
Copprr colour, white foam that dosnt last. Mild sour hay mixed with malt in the aroma. Malt, tofee sweet, mild sweet bitterness in the aftertaste. Watery high in carbon. Where is easter?
Bottle at Paul’s tasting. Pours amber with an off white head. Sweetish malts, with some lighter grainy notes and toffee. Nice.

Bottle at Paul’s for the Blind Stout tasting. Pours a clear orange amber with a thin white head. Sweet caramel and grain. Musky grain, toast and a bit of maltiness. Not a lot going on here. Toasty, caramel and grain into the finish. Drinkable.
Bottle at Paul’s apartment. Pours amber brown. Nose and taste is toasted apple, toasted dark malt, bready malt and toasted grain. Slight vegetal notes. Light and thinnish body.

Bottled (thanks SADESA, backlog). Deep amber colour with a mediumsized slightly off-white head. Aroma is bready, mild rye, some nuttyness as well as mild metallic, toasted and chocolaty notes. Flavour is rather similar, but rather thin and really leaves no aftertaste. Rather thin body.
Better than traditional american lagers with subtle roasted nutty pine bitterness. Nice dark amber color. Light lacing. Drinks easy, but perhaps too thin.
Bottle in iceland 2008. Dark brown with rich malt and chocolate flavours with a fairly roasted bitter finish.
330ml Bottle - Dark amber with a foamy head. Malty aroma with hints of grain and fruit. Malty and grainy taste with hints of dried fruit, caramel and spicy malt.

Pours a very dark coffee-red with a light khaki head that isn't too large. The aroma is typical big malty lager aroma. The flavor is interesting however. The dominant flavor is brown sugar and the flavor is sugary indeed. It's definitely on the sweet side, especially for a lager. A little wood and such mixed in there as well. If they'd dry it up a bit, it probably wouldn't be too bad, but right now it's too sweet.

Dark and reddishly semi-transparent, I managed to pour it with a decent head, which surprised me. I'd have guessed this was a sweet stout before opening it up, but the arome is very much like a certain bad macro bock. Slightest hint of dark fruits with a heavyish tinge of sweetness. Not all that bad but nothing exciting. By the time I had smelled it, the head had nearly vanished. This reminds a lot of their low ABV sweet stout in the flavour, but surprisingly this is almost, but not quite, adjunct free. I'd have guessed otherwise, but again I guess wrong. Taste is sweetish, some dark chocolate, sweet dark malts, not much complexity. Not watery by any means and really, I wouldn't want that flavour to be bigger, thus ruling out me wanting it to have a bigger body, which it would otherwise need. Not quite bad to be an automatic drain pour, but bad enough that I'll say no thanks to another.
Dark Brown, little head, quite sweet nose. Very thin lack of body. Not a very good beer, even by icelandic standards

Dark brown w/ creamy beige head. Sweet nose of malt, molasses, brown sugar & milk chocolate. Creamy texture--a touch thin. Sweet milky, malt flavour w/ molasses, licorice, milk chocolate, candy sugar &, perhaps, sugar.
Dark brown , creamy small head . Sweet malt ,milky chocolatey . Very interesting taste . Unusall brew ...

Reddish brown colour. Caramel and brown sugar on the nose. Sweet but bland palate. The combination of sweetness, lack of body and lack of melanoidins (those compounds that manifest themselves as luscious, rich maltiness) tells me this beer has too many adjuncts. Some sort of unfermentable caramel perhaps? Not unlike a Peruvian schwarzbier in that respect.
Dark brown. Light fruitiness in the nose; caramelly sweet. Body is very sweet and smooth with hints of caramel. Finishes lightly bitter which is the only thing saving this much too sweet beer.

I was very dissapointed by this one, it wasnt bad but it was far from great. Good malte taste was totally ruined by to mach water.. this would be great beer if it wasnt made in Iceland : re-rate 2004 batch ; this one looks like it more carbonated then they JólaMaltbjór, and has a destinct dark caramel nose. Color is black, but not darkness. Palate is very watery and a bit to smooth, this is way more drinkable then other disasters from Egils, and quite frankly their best beer, but it doesnt make it that good, and far from being something great....

Dark black, but with clear reddish shine. very little, yellowish head. Rich malt nose, with sweet chocolate tones. Very sweet, malt-sugars, sweet worts at first, but going over in liquorice. Hint of bitterness at the end. Very slight carbonation. Pretty empty. Aftertaste turns to sweet-liquorice again. Too sweet. It does resemble a German Maltztrunk. Wonder where those 5.6 ABV are hiding.

Sweet malty aroma, hint of caramel and brown sugar. Ruby in colour, a tiny toffee head. Roasted malt, and rich caramel flavours, as it warms it tastes of maple butter. Creamy, with a fine sweetness, really pleasant mouth feel. Great example of the style, my first Easterbeer. Thanks Eirikur.
A nice porter, roasted coffee and cacao bitterness with a nice black pour and decent beige head. Slightly hoppy, almost fruity, toffee and various other notes.
Bottle - dark brown with large frothy, thick head. Good chocolate - coffee aroma. Good mouthfeel. Strong tasting chocolate coffee, hint vanilla - good all round porter with de dent aftertaste.

Bottle from Asda, very dark brown with small dark head. Aroma: dark chocolate, bit of coffee, hint of vanilla, roasted malts. Lightly sour with malty aftertaste. Medium body, light carbonation, boring.
Vanilla, roasted malt aroma; vanilla, roasted coffee, chocolate and liquorice flavours, and a light, smooth texture.
Chocolate hints. Black. Hoppy aroma with caramel hints. Overall very acceptable. Will try again.
black with good head retention. aroma rasted malt and liquorice. dry roasty taste hint of spice

Bottle bought from Asda, Ipswich. Poured dark brown with a maroon tint and an average sized beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and dried fruit. Moderate sweetness, medium roasted bitterness. Medium body, oily and watery texture, soft carbonation.
