Bottle from Asda. Poured a clear dark reddish brown with a frothy off white head. The aroma is sweet caramel malt, with a dry charcoal liquorice hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Bought from ASDA . Pours a nice dark colour , small white head . Coffee , caramel aroma. Tastes good , medium body

Clear 500ml bottle at home in Blaendulais listening to Krishna Das. As ’Asda Extra Special Whitechapel Porter’, 5.2%, undated, brewed at Shepherd Neame. Pours like cola to form an opaque black beer with a dense creamy brown head that endures permanently and leaves thick lacing. Aroma is bourbon biscuits and chocolate truffles, ashy notes. Smells pretty inviting. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is a little thin and metallic up front, then some soft toffee and liquorice notes, ashy earthy finish. Not far away from being pretty accomplished. Looks and smells like the real deal and then falls away. Really grows on you though. (6-4-6-4-14=3.4)
Bottle shared by omhper thanks. No head. Clear dark red brown color. Big roasted malty aroma. Sweet caramell malt taste with a distinct acidity. Mild bitterness.

Good-looking black beer. Mild ale-y smelling, with just a twinge of hop aroma. Choco-lactose on top of dark roast flavor. Dry, a little watery tasting (though not watery feeling.) Mildly hopped. Fairly quick coffee finish. An off note in the backend disturbed an otherwise very good palate. Easy drinking.

Overall a good Brewpub stout. No real aroma - excellent thick dark black pour with a heavy, creamy head with a lot of lacing. Detect a little bit of hoppiness in there. Smoky, roasted flavor starts off strong but fades and sours near the end - bit of an aftertaste - thus the low marks on palate. Overall a good choice for #400 for me.

Cask @ Bull & Bladder, Bathams brewpub, paired with a pork pie and mustard from the bartop fridge. Pours a deep clear amber, small off-white head. Aroma is light caramelised malt. Very light on the palate, gentle caramel, gentle malt grain.. a classic that really should be drunk by the gallon, but unfortunately I had to make do with a half. Next time!
Cask @ GBBF 2017. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Cask at the GBBF 2017. Day 1. 08/08/2017. A clear amber copper coloured pour with a halo of beige head. Aroma is sweet praline, nutty malts, nutty choc.. Flavour is composed of of earthy nutty malts, choc, little vanilla. Palate is semi sweet, lowish carbonation. Meh.

August 2017 - Cask, handpull, at GBBF 2017, Kensington Olympia. As 'Bathams Mild'. Very happy to catch up with this classic Midlands mild, which I have wanted to try for some time. Dark brown with an orange hue, big foamy off-white head. Aroma is light chocolate and cola. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is watery chocolate malts, demerara and molasses, watery finish but smooth malts and very drinkable, some good nuance over the course of a third, maybe even more from a pint. (6-4-7-4-14=3.5)

8th August 2017 GBBF Day 1. Cask. Clear deep amber beer, small pale tan head. Palate is smooth and semi dry, modest carbonation. Dry sweetish malts, some toffee. Ripe fruits. A trace of annoying eggy yeast. A bit flat and eggy but jus about passes muster.

Cask at GBBF 2017, Olympia, London, Aug 2017 - Dark brown in colour. Medium foamy off-white head. Roasty malts, some caramel. Dark fruit notes. Quite dry. Sweet roast malty fruity throughout. OK. Very drinkable. (2017-08)

Cask at GBBF’17, day one, 08/08/17. Drank a good few gallons of this back in my days living in Brum and the Black Country but time to catch up on a rate ! Rich mahogany/chestnut brown with a decent light beige cap. Nose is biscuit, toffee, grains, brown bread. Taste comprises brown bread, dried fruits, glimmer of honey, dusty, biscuit crumbs. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, drying close. Decent ’classic’ mild.
Cask at GBBF 2017. Clear copper, medium tan head. Fruity, caramelly, slightly sulphury. Dry, medium bitterness.

Sweet caramel, dark, sweet, toasted malts, toffee, elderflower. Clear, dark brown, small, frothy, white head. Heavy sweet. More caramel, dark roasted malts, burnt toffee, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Quite sweet in palate. Cask at GBBF17, Kensington Olympia.

Cask at GBBF ’17, 11/08/17. Chocolate aroma with a sour more medicinal/red wine edge. Reddish brown. Frothy off-white head. Sweet. Fruity. Sweet liqueur. Malt base. Medium bodied. Slick. Flat carbonation. Muted finish.I know I am going to score it much higher than average but I really like a beer like this. Goes down so easy.
12oz bottle. This beer sucks. It is bland all around. Tastes like they took any of your american macro brews and put a new label on it.
This beer has a light golden color, which held to the sun is this beers only redeeming quality. The taste is acrid and it is virtually undrinkable.

this i can honestly say, was fuckin terrible, i dont know if i should be thanking heemer or kicking his ass for a pour of this crap. Extremely light color that is skunked beyond belief and tastes like wet luandry. AWFUL. what a piece of crap to have for number 1300.
This stuff gets worse as you drink more. A very light gold. Aroma of old moldy sweat socks and some vomit. The taste was light carrots and peanuts with rotten lemons.
this tasted like fleghm and snot. ew. i dont want to drink my cold. got worse as it got warmer. sick dood. i cant wait to read heemer’s rating...

I bought this sixer on a novelty idea since I was heading out to Knoxville to play a whole lot of Texas Hold Em Poker. I passed around the bottles and figured, eh, what the hell, I’d try one. So I poured this out a rather clear and light yellow color with little carbonation after a small frothy soapy head. The aroma was relatively non existant...some cold glass, a hint of corniness, but nothingness really. The flavor wasn’t as bad as I expected. There’s really nothing to it...they managed to make it not suck, but they also managed to get little to no flavor in there. A hint of corn and sweet malt, but once again...nothing! Overall mouthfeel was weak and watery. It was a nice novelty idea...and oh yeah, I got the Ace of Spades under my cap...top that!

I bought this beer for 50 cents at Kreston’s in Wilmington, Delaware. I’m happy to say that my cap was the Queen of Hearts, which may get me laid tonight. The beer was middle of the road, but not as bad as most BMC shit. I could actually see buying a case of this and playing a drinking game involving which person gets the better cap card. Decent aroma, taste, and finish.

I have to give this beer points for originality (in marketing that is). You would think that with as much creativity and effort that they put into marketing this beer they could have put a better beer in the bottle. Not offensive but still bland and pointless.

Alright, heres the deal: i am allowing the price of this beer to influence my rating. I bought this stuff for 1.99/six pack (6.00/24). For the price, it's damn good. If, however, I were to pay an average amount for this beer, it would not be rated as well. It has minimal head, a bland aroma but a decent flavor. Sort of sweet and a tad skunky. To me, its more refreshing than most American standards. Again, for the price, it's great.

Wow. This was the cheapest bottled beer I've ever bought! It was less than $3.00 for a 6 pack of bottles. That's cheaper than the cheap shit. It's not as bad as other cheap beers. It's brewed by Matt for Wet Planet Beverages, and they also own Jolt Cola.

Some faint caramel and yeast in the aroma, lending some banana and clove, along with a certain vague spiciness and sugary sweetness. Massive, lasting head. Honeyish amber color. Malty and sweet flavor profile, some floral notes, spices and a bit of hop tingle. Lots of effervescence and lacing. Finishes with yeast esters, sweetness and spice. The lasting impression is of banana bread with a bit of caramel drizzled over the top. Very low bitterness and hop flavors. Interesting.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: Bottled. Almost clear and pale golden coloured with a medium sized white head. Malty with notes of grain, metal, hops and hay.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: 50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a lacing white head. Aroma is dry cornish with a mild spiced hoppy note. Flavour is mild cornish and light bitterness lurking through. Light acidic note and mild bitterness. Dry finish mild mouldy touch throughout.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: Light sweet and grainy aroma. Clear golden colour with plenty of bubbles but a small white head. Sweet grainy flavour with some herbal hops and light finishing bitterness. Light body with crisp carbonation that dimples the tongue. Bottle. Entered from notes.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: Light golden color, little to no head. Nose is of sweet malt with slight leafy notes. The body is smooth but honestly reminded me of bile/some kind of stomach acid. Light bitterness, very very gross.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: Pale yellow w/ Small white head. Some sweetness in the nose w/ a hint of hops. Light feel (but not too light). Somewhat sweet, some bready character, & a mild-moderately bitter finish.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: Hint of hops and spice, pale yellow, small white head. Good pilsner flavour, crisp not much malt, pleasant mouth feel, average.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: Hazy light gold; balanced biscuit & herbal hop. Slightly minterally, crisp, faintly sweet finish.

column1: Steiger Hell (The Beer From Hell Brewery)
column5: Pale gold lager, white frothy head. Sweet malty aroma with some spice .Quiet similar to radegast, pale rye bread. It does get a bit better while you are drinking.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is fruity and light toasted malty. Smooth fruity, crisp hoppy, light peachy and mild citrusy. Smooth fruity into a light bitter finish.
Draft. Clear deep golden color. Aroma of light citrus and straw. Taste is slightly sour with nice balance.
Draft at brewery. Very good american pale. Aggressive hop aroma and taste make this interesting but it is not overly strong to be like an IPA. One of my favorites at Franklin’s.

On tap at Franklins, Hyattsville on 14 July 2006 (noted at 6.0%). Unusual to find two different APAs on tap at a brewpub at the same time. Hazy amber colour. Good strong hop presence. Big on grapefruity Cascade. Another good APA. The hops are a bit more aggressive than in the Twisted Turtle but there is less of a malt backbone. Honours even.

Served on draft at the brewpub. Pours a hazy copper color with a large creamy offwhite head. Good head retention and lacing. Faint aroma of citrus hops. The taste is wretched. Big herbal and citrus hops. Way over-hopped. A chemical note. No balance whatsoever. Medium bodied. Looks decent, but other than that I could barely manage a few sips.

on tap-pours an offwhite head with copper color. Aroma is citrus grassy leafy cascade, light caramel/toffe malts. Flavor is resinous/pine/citrus and orang-hops, secondary light/medium slightly sweet malt.

Sampler at brewpub. Pours clear light copper with off-white head. Aromas of citrusy american hops, caramel, and english malts. Flavors of hops, some citrus, caramel, and english malts. Nice mouthfeel and carbonation. Decent pale and one of the better beers on tap.

Tap at Franklins. Pours a hazy light copper with a thin head. Aroma is citrus grassy leafy cascade, lean toffee and light caramel malts. Flavor is nicely hopped resinous, pine, citrus and orange notes, cascade is big, almost piney sappy spicy centennial as well. Clean and crisp good APA.
Cloudy dark orange copper color. Aroma of juicy hops and sweet caramel malts. Nice body. Taste is upfront bitterness with some pine hops. Pretty good.

Gravity pour from the friday firkin. Cloudy orange with a pillowy white head. Huge aroma of hops and grapefruit. Flavor is mostly grapefruit and citrus hops. Much like drinking grapefruit juice, only not as bitter. Very smooth with a nice pale malt backbone. Quite drinkable.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: 500 ml schooner glass at the Karl Strauss in LAX. Pour is slight haze golden orange copper with a smallish off white head that falls with some light lacing. Aroma is citrus fruit hop, big, mildly sweet clean. Some toastiness from the malt behind that. Taste is the hops, citrus fruit up front, nice mineral earthiness through the finish. All throughout, the toasted malt balances the hop out. Palate is light bodied, decent carbonation, finish is mellowed out by a bit of wateriness. Decent enough for an airport bar.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: Served cold from tap at Universal Studios brewery. It wasn’t nearly as hoppy as it should have been for an IPA, it had a very nice finish though. Poured clear amber with a thin white head, leaving trace amonunts of lacing. Aroma was somewhat weak and hoppy. Taste was middle of the road.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: Draft. Seemed a little closer to a regular PA than IPA, but it’s not bad. I expected very little since the only other Karl Strauss beer I’ve ever had was their Oktober fest. A decent amount of floral hops, could be more assertive.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: The head of this beer sticks around forever. All the way down the glass. Pretty impressive. Serious hoppy citrus nose. Hoppy flavors dominate the beer, and hang around in your mouth long after you’re done.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: Clear light amber/copper coloured body with a thin white head. Assertive west-coast hops in the nose-some floral-some citrusey. Medium-bodied; Strong hops up front with little else following behind. Bitter floral hops resent with an adequate malt backbone. Aftertaste plain & bitter-not too great. Overall, a decent IPA-good for a layover before Australia! I sampled this beer on draught at the Karl Strauss Brewpub in Terminal 7 at LAX after a flight from Washington and before our flight to Sydney. This was sampled on 31-May-2004.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: Sampled draught at LAX airport. Clear amber, small creamy head. Grapefruity hop aroma. Clean malt profile, loads of cascade hops. Soapy, grapefruity finish with good bitterness.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: This beer has a huge hoppy nose. I could smell it when he was pouring out of the tap across the bar from me. It smells like hops and nothing else, it tastes like hops and nothing else. Strangely there is no bitterness. This beer is also lacking any kind of malt to balance the taste and lacking body as well. It tastes like they just dry hopped a keg of carbonated water. Good to try if you like hops because thats all you can really taste.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: Draft. Orangeish gold, hard to comment on the head as it seemed to be gone when it was served. Aroma is fruity malt and hoppy. Seems like an APA with a bit more cascade hops. Overall not bad too and quite drinkable, especially when it’s the best choice at one of your favorite restaurants.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: On tap at Disneyland’s California Adventure, pours a medium-yellow with small head. Aroma is more of malt than hops. Medium-bodied, I could hardly taste any hops at all. The low alcohol content does not help. Pretty weak and tame for an IPA. Dissapointing.

column1: Karl Strauss Star of India Pale Ale
column5: (Draft: Yard House in San Diego, CA) Moderately malty, but it’s fairly sweet and sugar until the finish when a slightly tart, bitter grapefruit rind flavor takes over; It’s moderately bitter, but never actually hoppy; Medium bodied; Almost no nose, very light hoppy aroma, and for an IPA, that’s criminal; Ligth amber color; Off-white head settles to a thin layer, but the dense, thin blacket of lacing is excellent

column1: Cannery Skaha Bluffs Light Blonde Ale
column5: This poured a well-carbonated light gold colour, with no resemblance at all to urine. The head was foamy white, and of only modest size but it did deliver some nice lacing. Aroma was floral and hopped, pleasantly so. Taste was clean and refreshing with some bitter crispness from the hops; precious little malt was on display.

column1: Cannery Skaha Bluffs Light Blonde Ale
column5: Very pale straw colour. Light aroma of freshly crushed 2-row. Slightly bready/grainy character. Sweetish flavour. Light body.

column1: Cannery Skaha Bluffs Light Blonde Ale
column5: Pale golden colour, thick white head and lasting sticky lace. Light grassy aroma, caramel malts, some lemony citrus, a bit of dustiness and spicy hops. Very subtle, but not boring. Crisp finish. Well-balanced and easy to drink. Nice session beer.

column1: Cannery Skaha Bluffs Light Blonde Ale
column5: Golden in color with a light fresh hoppy aroma. Light sweet malty body with a hoppy balance and mostly a light malty aftertaste with a bit of hop aroma.

column1: Cannery Skaha Bluffs Light Blonde Ale
column5: This actually isn’t bad for a light beer. It pours very pale and sa\tarts off very bland, but has nice hop aftertaste. This is a step up from macro light beers.

column1: Cannery Skaha Bluffs Light Blonde Ale
column5: Hazy straw,no head, no bead.Neutral nose. Bland watery lightly malty flavor. Not much here at all,don't waste your time.

column1: Cannery Skaha Bluffs Light Blonde Ale
column5: Named after one of the best rock climbing areas in the world in which I have spent many days. Body is golden and slightly hazy. Aroma is hoppy and slightly floral. Taste is semi-sweet with a light note of hops. Not much else though. Finish is crisp and dry. A decent beer after a day on the crags.
Good head, with a great apricot and hops aroma and a solid malt base. The apricot seemed a little artificial, but I enjoyed this nonetheless.
Golden in color with a fluffy white head, light-bodied but very smooth, not much by way of any kind of apricot aroma or flavor at all, tasted almost like faintly flavored water
Re tasted, bottle 33 cl. Clear, golden with a white head. Aroma sweet malt, some yeast. Medium body. Taste malts, sweet, coriander, a regular blond. Little dry ending.

Bottle thanks to xnoxhatex. Pours a hazed orange yellow with a white head. Pale malts that are grainy with hay. Sprizty carbonation. More of the grainy malts that are sweet with a drying finish. Not much to talk about here, so how’s the weather?
bottle. thanks xnoxhatex! pours hazy gold with white head. nose is grainy, hay, honey. flavor is grariny, hay, yeasty, and so blah but nothing awful.
Bottle from belgium. Hazy gold color with creamy white head. Fresh yeasty blonde aroma with very dry malt. Dry malt flavor, yeasty, spice, nice strong ale. Medium boy wdith nice carbonation. Nice.

Bottled. Hazy orange colour with mediumsized white bubbly head. Aroma is caramel malts, some spices, zest and yeast. Flavour is quite much the same with some slight notes of alcohol also burning in the background. Quite thin, watery and boring.
Een heel lekker belgisch blond biertje. Veel smaak, een beetje zoet, niet bitter. Iets te veel koolzuur of maakt dit het net iets specailer.
Cloudy yellow colour with a small white head. Malty aroma with floral and yeasty notes. Light malty sweet flavor with a yeasty and fruity note.
Golden/orange colored brew. Sweet aroma. Sweet malty flavored beer with some spices. Average blond.
(Bottle 33 cl) Clear, golden with a white head. Sweetish malt aroma with some yeast. Medium body with sweet, pale malts and a vague, metallig edge. The finish is dry. Some overripe fruit. 150807
33 cL bottle. Pours slight hazy orange with a lacing white head. Slight sweet fruity, toffee aroma. Soft caramel, slight fruity and a minor liqourice note. Creamy dry finish.

column2: Santa Fe, New Mexico, United States
column5: Murky amber with small white head. Taste is of smooth sweet hops, very frothy. No distinguishable smell, but the taste is fantastic. Perfectly balances bitter with sweet hops. Hints of coriander, a little like a hopped-up wit. Fits perfectly with the fish and chips.
The other pale ale. This one with a little less body than the Mesa. Not particularly sweet, mostly watery. Tried at the brewery in 2007.
On tap April 9, 2007. Contaminated. One sip and I was outa there. Too bad. Eskes is the only brew pub in town. If in Taos, skip this place and head for the Adobe Bar.

Smells wonderful, nice full hoppy aroma, with hints of fruit, and a big whiff of rich caramel. However, that's where the fun ends. I wish this beer tasted like how it smells, but it was not the case. Tastes almost identical to the irish ale and rio refresco, bland bland bland. Like chewing plastic, there was really no flavors through the entire glass.

Draught. Pours clear light yellow with an average, creamy, white head, mostly lasting with good lacing. Aroma is heavy malt (cereal, grain, meal), average hops (grass, herbs), average yeast (sweat) with notes of chalk. Light bodied, thin texture, soft carbonation, and a bitter finish. Long duration, light sweetness and acidity, moderate bitterness.

This beer wouldn’t get a such a generous rating if I wasn’t comparing it to the other bubbly glasses of garbage I drank at Eske’s. The Rio Refresco was only slightly more refreshing than a glass of water from the Rio Grande, and nearly as opaque. It would have been a bit better if it was cold or decently carbonated. Also, when served with a lemon, it tasted like Pledge. Why do I know what Pledge tastes like? Why would I give a beer that tastes like furniture polish a flavor rating of two? It’s probably because I’m drunk.
Still, lightly hzay golden with a firm creamy head. Velvet texture. Little flavor; only a hint of orange essence over the starch.

Light yellow, slightly murky. Aromas were mild, mainly of wheat and light hops. Flavors were hard to find in this one, pretty bland and a little sour. Not like a wheat at all, but maybe I should have put a lemon in it to liven things up a little.

50cl bottle from a trade with Mariusz, thanks! A clear golden beer with a white head. Aroma of grainy and spicy malt, spicy hops. Taste of strong grainy malt, spicy and metallic hops, cereals, long bitterness. Boring!

330ml on tap at Sternbräu Rankweil. Aroma is malty, "forest". Appearance is light cloudy amber with a light brown-ish head. Taste is sweet and light sour and some bitterness. Palate is light dry. Soft to medium carbonation. OK.
*Old rating. Many thanks to kevnic2008 for this bottle. Best before 29.10.10. Schönes mild-weiches Bier. Würzig-süßlich mit minimal bitterer Note. Lecker.
#211 Ein saft- u. kraftvolles Export, dass die Balance zwischen Malz und Hopfen packt. Toll! Test vom 11.8.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 12,12,12,12,10,12 - 11,90
Golden colour with a white head. Easy taste of fruit, malt, hop. The body is a bit on the light side.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and it’s not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog! Ins Glas ergießt sich ein blassgelbes Bier mit grob seifiger und kurzlebiger Krone. Der Geruch ist süßmalzig mit hopfigem Hintergrund. Der Antrunk fällt sehr hopfig bitter aus, insgesamt sehr herb. Im Abgang ist das Export ebenfalls sehr hopfenbitter. Zwar legt sich die bittere Note zur Mitte ein wenig, aber dafür kommt dann im Abgang eine leicht muffige Note hinzu. Nein, mit diesem Bier werde ich nicht gut Freund. Da gibt’s bessere Export-Kameraden!

(Flasche) Es hat eine helle, sonnengelbe Färbung, ist klar filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das schwache Aroma riecht nach süßlichem Honig. Geschmacklich sehr schlank, leicht süßlich mit einer Spur DMS. Es gibt eine leichte Bittere und die Karbonisierung ist gut so. Zusammengefasst; eher uninteressant.

(bottle) pours a clear yellow colour with a frothy white head. faint aroma of floral hops, earth and light toffee, slightly bready. flavour is mostly herbal hops and grain, with some slightly obtrusive notes of cooked vegetables and a very mineral finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Bottle 50 cl from Quack-Duck. A clear yellow beer with low head. Very basic lager, not too malty, not very hopy, dry with a long bitter finish. Not exceptional, in the lager average.
Bottle. Sweet barley malt and weed/grass hops aroma. Golden yellow color with moderate head. Sweet barley malt and moderately bitter grass hops flavor. Average Export beer.

On tap in Palm Harbor....poured a reddish-brown, hazy, with a small beige head. Aroma is malty, light choco-caramelish, vaguely mocha-ish. Hops balance the flavor pretty well, with the strong malty flavor being held politely in check---thank God for that. A bit too thin in the mouth though. Finishes lightly bitter and dry, but not terribly disappointing.

Draft - Crimson and browns, velvety light tan head. Aroma held notes of chocolate, grapefruit, spice, and light coffee. Flavor was almost a match to aroma. A good hop bitterness and sweet malt combo provide a nice balancing act. Full bodied yet somewhat thin, soft carbonation, bitter drying finish.

Draft at the Linebaugh location... Very murky, ruby ale with a small, creamy, beige head. Great retention. Nose of milk chocolate, cinnamon and leather. Well-balanced flavor is a little alcoholic with notes of caramel, mocha and grapefruit. Nicely bittered. Full-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Finishes bitter and then dry.

Very enjoyable mirco brew. Although Hoppers doesn't necessarily consider it so, I would classify this beer as a brown ale. The aroma offers pleasant notes of cocoa and butter (but not butter in a bad way). This beer starts off light with hints of cocoa and a nutty flavor, and moves gradully into a deep, yet soft, liquor flavor. It settles very nicely on the tongue and produces a pleasnat display of brussells lace as well.
A apple juice look on pour. Smells of apples as well. It is a very sweet cider but pleasing after you’ve had a glass or too. Not to potent but enough to get you feeling it.

Bouteille verte de 750 ml achetée chez Apple Barn & Country Bake Shop (Bennington, VT). Arôme: Odeur de pomme avec une pointe d’épices. Apparence: La couleur est paille. Saveur: Goût de pomme avec une pointe de miel. Courte durée de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence de pomme en arrière goût. (Rating #1358)

750ml bottle: Pale yellow body without carbonation. Very fine particles can be seen suspended in the body, but to be honest it takes concentration to really see them because it’s mostly clear and filtered. The aroma shows some crisp & sweet apple and just a bit of lightly tart apple. Smells very fresh. Taste is fresh apples as well as a bit of tart apple, with just a hint of alcohol showing through, creating light flavors of clove, then some hints of wood. Light bodied, still, finishes with some light residually sweet apple.

First off, this is the first cider I’ve had since my college days and Woodchuck. Pours clear yellow and very still. Nice sweet and tart aroma, very crisp. Flavor is a bit too sweet, I’d rather have it be a bit more tart and crisp. It is dry, however. Very crisp. Nice.
Pours yellow and fizzy. Smells of tarte ripe apples with a hint of spices. Flavor is light and clean with hints of tarte apples.

Lightly spicy aroma is bursting with fresh apples. Clear golden body is quite viscous on the sides of the glass. Quite dry, woody flavour has plenty of sweet apple character that lingers into a leafy finish. Medium-dry body - feels dry across the tongue but has plenty of residual sweetness. Wine glass. Just above fridge temperature. Bottle (Winooski Beverage Warehouse, Dec-05).

Poured a pale golden color with no head. A very still cider. Sweet and funky, apple, and vanilla aroma. Aroma was very sweet and spicy. The first sip knocked my socks off. Taste was that of a nice apple pie. Very sweet, though tartness was also included, as well as cinnamon, and crisp apples. The mouthfeel did not hold up to the taste. But this was still a very nice cider.

750 ml bottle. Pale golden, no carbonation; is that what "English-style" means? Pleasing soft sweet apple/vanilla/cinnamon aroma. Flavor is fairly sweet also, with a bit of tartness at the end and also some metallic hints, but not enough to really ruin it. Above average cider with a good dry/sweet balance that just isn't distinguished enough for me to be likely to try it again.

column1: Southampton East End India Pale Ale
column5: Draught, at the Blind Tiger, NY. When Spiesy & AustinPowers drank. Amber with a lovely lacy head. Good malt and decent, fullish hop aroma. Hoppy flavour with a good, long bitter finish. I’d love to go and sample a few more of these beers on location in South Hampton. Maybe this summer?!

column1: Southampton East End India Pale Ale
column5: Nicely hopped IPA, even though in appearance, the body is a little light in color. Easy drinking, not too bitter or stringent. I will order this again, if not buy a growler.

column1: Southampton East End India Pale Ale
column5: This is a mighty fine IPA from a mighty fine brewpub. Excellent lacing coats the glass and sticks to the sides like cement. Perfectly hopped, leaving a lingering, near perfect hop bitterness in the finish. My only complaint is that I think it should have had a bit more of a malt presence.

Orange colour, slightly hazy. Slight gushing, thick white head, not very stable. Nose with a bit of (cooked) vegetable, malt, carbondioxide. Quite dry taste, citrussy notes, but very restrained. Grainy-malt comes on, but retronasal (hoppy) bitterness. Mouthfeel is dry, but spritzy because of high carbonation. No new aftertaste. Pleasing, but not really characterfull. Would probably make a good session beer.

From can on board Fridtjofen with JMD on the way to Havnedagene i Haugesund 16.08.19. Cloudy orange golden. White head and lacing. Decent and refreshing aroma and taste of wheat, coriander and bananas. Taste and some bitterness is lingering on. Good for a non-alcoholic beer!

Aroma: banana, some, clove, caramel in the back ground Appearance: hazy amber color Taste: banana, some clove, caramel in the background Palate: medium-light body, flat Overall: It has darker appearance and some caramel tone which are uncommon for hefeweizen.

Can. Pours a hazy orange colour with a creamy light beige head. Sweet aroma of banana, wheat, spices and hay. The flavour is similar with more hay and some metal. The mouth feel is light and watery, light body and light bitterness. Not far from a hefeweizen but naturally lacks body.
330 ml can. Dark orange and hazy, white head with plenty of lacing. Mostly watery taste but includes banana and yeasty parts.
Clausthaler Weizen boks 0.33L fra Extra Hamna. Farge uklar gulbrun med offwhite skum. Lukt noe frukt, malt. Smak malt, banan, noe krydder. En litt ubestemmelig hveteøl, helt grei.
How : can Appearance : cloudy deep orange, huge white head. Aroma : banana, honey, floral and apples. Palate : light body, lively carbonation.
*Old rating, best before 12.03. Weich-frisch, leicht süßlich, malzig-hefig, die Hefe überdeckt die Alkoholfrei-Note recht gut, süßlich-süffig im Nachgeschmack.

0,5l can. Labelled as Weizen. Nice, unfiltered look, golden and hazy. Tall, white head. Smells good, yeasty and of course reminiscent of wheat beer. Could this be the first really good non-alcoholic beer? It masks its low ABV well, but there is the typical wheat taste that I’m not too fond of, and a weird, burnt aftertaste. But, at the end of the day, slightly more interesting than all the other non-alcoholic beers I’ve tried so far.

0,5 bojs fra Coop Mega: uklar gylden med tett skum som varer helt ned. Hveteølpreget er til stede i aromaen, og aller mest i smaken. Cremet munnfylde takket være det imponerende skummet. Trolig den beste alkoholfrie øl jeg har smakt, og uten den metalliske ettersmaken som vanligvis skjemmer slike.
A very boring beer. Slight bitterness, and pretty sweet. Amber in color with a white head.
33cl bottle: Pours clear golden with a lasting egg white head. Sweet aroma & taste of malts - grain & caramel. A bit sticky, citric & the palate is too thin.
Moderate malty aroma. Large, frothy, white head. Good lacing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Clear yellow body. Moderate bitter flavor. Medium palate.
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a medium white head. Sweet malty aroma and taste. Not hops in this one.

33 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow to orange with a dense white head. Light earthy and sweet corn aroma. Sweet and light fruity flavour. Caramel malt and rather sweet into the finish. Light bitterness in the far finish.

Golden with an OK head. The aroma is sweetish, malty and slightly fruity. The flavour isn’t very strong, but it’s sweetish, smooth and certainly not unpleasant, just a bit boring. It has notes of malt and hints of fruit.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. aroma is fruit, sweet, malt. Flavour is fruit, malt, sweet. Boring beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear, yellowish-golden, with a bubbly, white head on top. Weak nose with a fruity sweetness and some grass and grain. Decent hoppyness in the flavor, with fruityness and sweetness. Thin body and short, fruitysweet finish. Definately not an interesting specimen, but drinkable. In small amounts that is. Boring. (071212)

(33cl bottle) Clear, golden colour with a foamy white medium head. Sweet, grainy nose with notes of honey, hay and a shy touch of herbal hops. Sweet and slightly bitter flavour, light to medium bodied, medium carbonation. Soft grainy and chalky taste, slightly honeyish fruity; dry, malty, slightly tart and bitter finish. Not the one I was waiting for but better than expected.
Bottle. Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of malt and hops.

Bottle. Yellow colour with a white head. A very standard cheap lager beer. Light malty and hoppy aroma and flavour. Why do Aass produce all this standard stuff with different labels, when they allready have a standard good lager beer.

I don’t know why Aass bothers to brew cheap beers like this. They have obviously used the cheapest raw materilas avilable. Their standard pils is qiute OK, this has hos extract giving a harsh bitterness, cerals, mosty like frosted cornflkaes..
Bottle.1250 ml!. Pours pale with a small creamy white head. Weak malty aroma. Sweet taste, light in hop department. Watery mouthfeel. Average macro pilsner.
330ml bottle. Clear golden body with a dense white head. The aroma has a faint hint of malt. Flavor is a bit sweet malt and fruity with almost no hop at all. Body is a bit watery. Rather average.

Can. Dense lasting white head. Very pale golden, almost liveless body. Interesting label; 1800-century farmer with baggy trousers, smoking a pipe,with a big stick in his hands (!) Well... Nice but limited aromas of grassy and flowery hops. Quite sweet mallty/grainy taste. Very lightly hopped. Thin-bodied, quite watery. Overall an average, but not that bad, Norwegian macrolager.

330ml bottle. Pale golden body topped by a small foamy head. Notes of fruits and wheat in aroma. Orange fruity sweetness in taste mixed with a touch of barley malts. Overcarbonated. Fairly standard Norwegian pilsener (21.11.2006).
Can. Golden colour with a big white head. Light malty, carboard aroma and a sweet malty taste. Medium body with a sweet finish.
(Can 50 cl) Pours a clear, pilsener golden with a white head. Fresh, lightly hoppy aroma. Medium body with some lightly sweet pilsener malt. Very discreet hopping. But quite quaffable. 150906
Can. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of fruits and spices. Flavour of fruits, spices and hops.
Bottle:Yellow colour, with a nice creamy foam.Aroma of hops,yeast,friut, and a bit of banana! Malt and a dry bitterness in the end.Thin body, short finish.

Sweet candy, brown sugar notes. Bit of melon. Malty & a light dose of floral hops, musky hay. Clear copper brown with light tan foamy lacing head. Medium watery body with vibrant carbonation. A light malt sweetness to start, watery. Finish has hops bitterness but also a tangy sour note. Light sweet after. Weak overall.
Dark, almost black colour, slightly brownish head. Spicy aroma, little malty. Dry, little spicy flavour. Little sweet, bitter flavours ...

Very clear red-brown, chestnut. Medium thick, creamy head, collapsing. Brown sugar and chocolate toffee in the nose. Sweet, liquorice, roasted malt, sweet coffee. Retronasal especially roasted malt. Rather refreshing mouthfeel, surprising for the style. Roasted malt, bitterish aftertaste. Inoffensive. Clone of Tongerlo 6 brown, no doubt.
Shared bottle from a cellar cleaning. Pours reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma of fruit and malt. Taste is fruit, sweet malt, and alcohol. Past it’s prime for sure, but drinkable.

GABF 2004: Light copper color with a lacey white head. Aroma hints at strawberry candy and fresh hops. Starts with a nice candy malty sweetness and some light fruit complexity. Full bodied and well balanced, but has some different flavors from what I’m used to in a barleywine. Still hides its alcohol well and is a unique and good beer.

This is not a normal barleywine - slightly sweet, but very earthy and piney and metallic - also thinner and very very easier drinking than most BWs. Warms up to a super smooth and not AT ALL 10% brew - not thin from the alcohol and not cloying from the sweetness of the malt. Wonderful and thanks to Indra for this rare treat.

Deep rich wood color - like that ancient but well cared for chiffarobe in a classy antique shop. This is the highlight of a really mediocre microbrewery and it is very, very good. Excellent balance between plumlike fruitier tones and spice and nut action. It's six dollars a bottle and well worth it, if only becuase it's an excellent brew among lackluster entries

This beer rocks!... Clear mahogany ale with a small, white, fizzy head. Lasting, stratus wisps of head float atop the brew throughout the tasting. The nose is of orange blossom honey, fig, caramel and evergreen. Caramel, toffee and pineapple in the flavor. Well-balanced by the hops and alcohol. Full-bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Great brew!

Intriguing aroma, with caramel-drenched cinnamon rolls, lightly perfumed flowers, nutmeg, faint berry and apple fruitiness, butterscotch, prickly pine needles, a slight earthiness as it warms and wafts of alcoholic vapor. The reddish-orange of a California sunset, lightly hazy with a quick-settling head. Flavor profile is buttery, toffeeish, sugary sweet, and lightly nutty with a generous dosage of spicy hop flavors and bitterness. Finishes strongly with fruit and more evident alcohol. Sends a pleasant warmth coursing through one's veins. Excellently done.
The foam stability is medium. The aroma malty, light, a bit bitter. the taste is malty, a bit bitter and watery. Drinkable.
Beer with yellow color, light body, light bitterness, some foam on top, average carbonized, (shared a 50cl can beer with PG, bought at "Pyaterochka", Saint Petersburg, RU #991)(#12 RU).

Pours clear golden with a white and rather stable head. Aroma has malty notes of fruits and grain combined with moderate sourness. Taste follows the aroma, sweetish fruity flavour, hint of yeast and dryish finish. Well-balanced overall. A nice one for a bulk lager. (Poured from a 0,5l can, bb 04.04.20)

Bottle, 500 ml. I got this as a present from a friend. Deep, darker shade of golden, shows there are stuffs inside. Decent off-white foam, can be recalled by swirling the glass any time. Aromas of sweet malt and some faint fruits like ripe apricot. I miss the hops big time, which makes the palate sweet. Fruity tones in the background, but the hoppy bitternes is missing unfortunately. Medium- aftertaste with sweet end. Usually i never get disappointed with Carlsberg beers, and this is a fair lager too from Baltika (Carlsberg Brewery) with a good carbonization inside, but it could be way more exciting with some more hops (or other kind of hops) inside to balance the sweetness of the malt. Not bad, extra point for the label design... Sooooo Russian.
Can at 4.7%. Clear golden colour. Basic white head. Aroma: malts. Light body. Clean grainy taste. Restrained fruitiness.
Light aroma and taste of malt and grassy hops. The aftertaste is slightly dry. Not very good, not disgusting just boring!

Held onto this .5 L bottle way too long. Brought from Russia in 2004 along with other beers, vodkas, and our wonderful boy Vanya. Wanted to share this with a Russian-speaking acquaintance who could never make it out and whose diabetes got worse. Okay, I’m opening it to celebrate our move, having let it "lager" for 4 years. At least it’s been in the fridge almost the entire time. Pours straw yellow, lots of bubbles, and a nice big head. Smell is light bready malt, a whiff of adjunct. Taste is actually above the usual cheap lager. A bit of fusel at first, but it clears away quickly. Does in fact seem to be an all-grain taste, just a basic balance of hops. Light citrus note. Goes down very well in the summer. I’m sure if I’d found this in a store around here, it’d have sat in an uncooled warehouse under florescent lights for months and tasted awful. Probably cost 75 cents American over in St. Petersburg.
500mL bottle. Another sample of urine. This one has an amazing white foamy head. Nice skunky hop aroma (for a lager). Not much flavor. Very light beer. Body and texture. An OK Lawn-mowin beer.

Pour is a bright gold with a big fluffly white head. Aroma is sweet malt with a bit of vegatable. Flavor is again some sweet malts and some grassyness. Nothing great but it is refreshing after cutting the grass on a humid day. Bonus it that it only cost $1.99 for an 18 oz bottle.

Very pale straw color with a moderate, white, fluffy head. Nice small bubbles continually stream to the top. Aromas of pale grains, grass and wild flowers. Very sweet, with malt and corn syrup. Small amount of herbal flowers come in mid quaff. Somewhat thin and fizzy in feel. A light euro lager, that still has some of the strong qualities and flavors. Certainly beats many micros.
Not a bad Cerveza, smells ok no skunky aroma, the color and clarity of the beer is good, the taste is a little bitter for a cerveza. overall it is good.

Not a bad tasting beer , a cross between a rolling rock and a Corona Light. Light Aroma , not as pungent , typical skunky mexican beer , but for 3.99 a six pack bottles , aint too bad of a beer , you get what you pay for..... Not as discriptive as the preppy douchebag fratboys below, but you get the point......

Canned. Pours a thick, and I mean THICK head. Tastes at first like a cheap Dos XX knock off, then finishes much worse. The disturbing part is the head that begins to resemble styrofoam in a finished glass after a few hours. Will not try again.
Pours a mellow golden yellow color. Aromas of grains, light hops, and a funky musty smell. Flavor is bland with a weird funk, add a lime to it to kill the funky taste and it is almost drinkable.
This was a straight up shitty beer. Smells like strong rotting vegetables, corny and very lightly malty. Kind of an oily mouthfeel, with almost no flavor to speak of. Bland and boring and watery.

A pretty bad beer. The aroma is corn like and skunky. Its got that rubber taste that so many south of the border beers have along with the weakest hops and malt imaginable. The palate is very weak. I won’t drink another.

Pale yellow, light fizzy head, no retention. Nose of skunky chewy tic-tacs and grains steeped in antifreeze. The flavor is chewy, large body and lots of things I can’t be my hands around. Thick proteins, light hops, watery finish, skunky film left behind.

If you like Coors, you will like this beer. It has much the same lack of flavor, lack of character. Since it is in a can, I can’t see it. Just as well. I bought it ($7.99 for an 18 pack) so I will drink it...maybe I’ll try making ice cubes with it...
Eh...certainly not anything special about this lager that I could detect. Like a slighty watered down Corona. Not offensive by any means, but not noteworthy.
Tastes a little skunky. Reminds me of some of the cheaper European brews like Holsten, or something like that. Not too bad for a cheap Mexican Esque beer.

Clean golden pour with creamy white head and lace. Aroma is pilsner malt and a touch of perfumy hops. Flavor is the flat pilsner malt with a floral hop finish. Slightly sweet start with an ok bitter. Light/medium bodied with good carbonation very ok
3 oz draft sampler pours golden with a white head. Aroma of grains, malts and grass. Taste is malts and grain. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft: Clear, light gold with a small white head. Grain, lemon aroma. Taste is barley malt, honey.... Good solid lager feel and taste.
Pretty hard to drink this beer. I had it on tap at the brew pub. A very flat chicken feedy taste. Would not recommend.

tap at the main brewpub - Note that all the beers were billed as "Main Street Brewing", no mention of Turonis, though at least that keeps them separate from Main Street Brewing in Ohio. Pours yellow-gold and has an aroma of grain malt and fruit. There’s some mild bitterness in this mostly sweet and light bodied brew. It has a clean, lightly bitter finish. A decent beer.
Tap. Honey barley malt aroma. Pale yellow color with moderate head. Honey barley malt flavor. with lightly bitter herbal hops finish. Very nice - spectacular for a light beer.

Tap: Golden hue with a lasting fizzy head. The aroma is that of wet pale grains, light noble hop herbal and grassy vapours and a hint of DMS. The taste is almost akin to Bud Light but with a bit more faint noble hop and pils malt character, light veggie tones. The mouth feel is crisp and refreshing enough. My bowling teammates actually liked the ales over this and I guess that says a lot. Boring...

IBG Winterfest 2009. Poured clear amber color with an average frothy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate sweet grainy aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and lively carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met for this first beer from this brewer.

STL Microfest. Pours light yellow with a large white head. Aroma has pale malt along with some diacetyl. Medium body with prickly carbonation. The taste starts with lightly toasted pale malt, diacetyl and spicy hops. The finish is mainly spicy hops. Fair.
Tasted 6/7/08. St Louis Microfest. Pale golden hue. Sparse white head. Mild grainy nose. Crisp and grainy palate. Light bodied with a mildly tart dry finish. Simple and easy.

On tap at Turoni’s, pours a clear copper with a small beige head. Aroma brings out light fermented out honey and crisp biscuity malt. Flavour is crisp, with biscuity malt and a touch of honey. Unassuming but clean. Meh.

Gold pour with creamy white head and lace. Aroma is light malt with a toucho honey and floral hops. Flavor is sweet malt with a toucho honey and floral hops. Medium bodied with good carbonation. It tends to thin out on the back side.
3 oz draft sampler pours golden with a white head. Aroma of honey , grain and yeast. Taste is sweet malts and yeast.
tap at the brewpub - Light aroma of honey and grain malt. Sweet taste, mild honey, subtle hops. It’s light bodied with just a hint of bitterness in the finish. Refreshing.
Tap. Honey and barley malt aroma. Medium yellow color with a moderate head. Strong honey and barley malt flavor. Nice malt flavor - easy drinking.

Tap: Golden hue with a small frothy head. The aroma has notes of sweet honey, grain, a hint of herbal hop and the standard house yeast ester. The taste is pretty much for the masses, moderate sweetness with little bitterness and has a twangy and almost soapy character. The mouth feel is soft and easy to drink. Something to have with pizza and for your friends who are not beer geeks.
Medium to light body with little nose. Not too much taste for me. Maybe a touch of honey at the end.
Draft. Very light aroma and taste. Pours a light yellow. Has a grassy with a honey taste.
Very nice beer, no residual sweetness. Good exemplar of the style. Pleasant to drink, not too hoppy.
nice gold pour with a creamed head. the nose has some honey and straw. taste is straw honey and something rubber with peanuts. leafy finish.

On tap at Turoni’s, pours a clear deep copper amber with a beige head. Aroma brings out toasted bready malt, with very low hops. Flavour is subdued, with toasted malt and nonexistent hops. Nothing going on here. Meh.
Light brown pour with creamy off white head and lace. Aroma is light/medium malt with earthy hops. Sweet malt start with a touch of spice and no bitter. Medium bodied with good carbonation.
3 oz draft sampler pours amber with a white head. Aroma of caramel , floral and grain. Taste is nutty, caramel and grass. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
tap at the brewpub - Pours amber and has a mild caramel malt aroma. It tastes of caramel malt and mild hops bitterness. Light to medium bodied, some light hops lingers in the finish. Decent.
Tap. Caramel and light herbal aroma. Amber color with small head. Sweet caramel malt and lightly bitter grass hops flavor. Tasty - an easy drinking beer.
On tap in the restaurant. Amber in color with a 1 inch foamy head. Mild bitterness with floral hops. Overall a very drinkable brew.
Draft. Pours a reddish amber with an off-white head. Aroma is strong caramel and malt with floral hint. Not the best finish but has a good taste. Overall a good beer.

tap-st louis microfest. pours amber with a fizzy off-white head. aroma of caramel and light diacytl, but acceptible considering the style. flavors are very sweet with lots of earthy caramel malt tones. some light sourness on the finish. husky toasted grains fade long into the finish. not bad but not great.
dark tan pour and a sticky head. the nose is roast caramel and leafy hops. leaves a taste like squealing tires smells. there is some caramel mixed in there too, but this is not pleasant.
It was a dark amber color. The head was huge but quickly dissapated. The taste was faintly nutty and VERY faintly hoppy.
Draft. Dusty chocolate malt and ash aroma. Black with nice tan head. Musty light chocolate and wood ash flavor. Very light body. Pretty dry and thin.

One would expect a stout to have a very nice thick head, but this one had no head at all. It had good carbonation, an overly roasty flavor and a decent body (not thick by any means, but not watery either). I probably won’t get this one again.
Black pour with a soft tan head. Aroma and taste of mocha, nuts and cocoa. Slight off end taste of acidity.

black pour with a brown head. chocolate nose. watery but alright. slight roast finish goes well with the sweet chocolate. light citrus that balances well. this is dusty, very dusty with a seedless grape note that detracts.
This stout always seems to come up just a bit short. There is nice malt profile there, you just have to search for it.

Draft at Fest: Near opaque with big creamy tan head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of roasted and chocolate malts, nutty, chalky, and floral hops. The taste is bittersweet with a lactic tone. Undertones of vanilla, plum and lemongrass. Smoky and chalky on the finish. The feel is lively and dry, medium-bodied. A good stout, quaffable, worth a try.

Draft: Prune liquid. Silky head mostly dwindles. Nice roasted malt and soft vanilla nose. Lightly chalky black malt edge paired with caramel, esters, chocolate fudge, and molasses. Mellow carbonation. Slippery body. Understated hop snap paves the way for soft notes of vanilla and roasted malts. Finishes lightly seared with a touch of apple acidity, which is the only distracting element. I credit Eric, (the sort-of new head brewer), for the turnaround of this once-undrinkable, so-called stout.

Mostly coffee and chocolate, some vinous notes but not enough to compete. Medium body and very smooth finish. Nothing too wild or breathtaking here, a "stout for the masses." Above average and what I will get at Turoni's from now on.

Growler and tap: Black,very dark brown. Dark brown head,medium,but not very lasting. Roasty,mocha,creamy aroma. Thick mouthfeel,medium,to full,body.In your face roasty,mocha flavors. Some chewy caramel and chocolate as well. A real clean tasting stout. Finish is loaded with roasty,mocha flavors. Very lingering.Quite a good stout,unfortunately,served very cold,in a chilled glass,unless requested otherwise. Quite a step up,from the nitro version(blah) last year.

Black and oily without any sign of head. Chocolate, milky nose. Taste started out thick and sweet, slight chocolate and non-dairy creamer flavors, but turned to a sweet, almost grape juice flavor that killed it in the end. Very unbalanced and grapy as it warmed.

my advice is to avoid this beer. I have never had a dubbel before but I’m pretty sure it is not supposed to be like this. The glass came with very low carbonation, and no head. half way through the glass the carbonation was completely gone. The taste wasn’t to terrible, and as I said I can’t compare it to other beers of this style. The beer tasted of sweet toffee with a hint of chocolate.

Dark brown pour with small, off-white head. Aroma is yeasty with strong mustiness, moderately malty with notes of cookie and caramel and lightly hoppy. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter in the finish. Medium body. Watery texture. Drinkable enough, but lacking the big fruitiness and complexity of the better dubbels.

Deep Amber color with very sweet aroma with a slightly apply nose. Big sweet kiss on the lips, with caramel and bubblegum very pronounced. A bit of bismuth and clove hidden underneath. A bit too much bubblegum, though. No alcohol detected.

Pours a slightly hazy golden color on tap with fluffy off-white head that dissipates to leave moderate lace. Aroma and taste of fresh grassy hop notes, hints of citrus, and bready pale malt. Solid, easy drinker.
5oz sample from honeymoon. The cascade hops really shine through. This beer was very easy and pleasurable to drink. Refreshing hops and attractive aroma. One of my favorite from this brewery.

The best in their mediocre lineup, Smoky Mountain’s Appalacian Pale features a spicy hop attack that is more East Coast style, lacking the big citrus components of its West Coast brethren. More resiny with a mild earthy pale malt. Pouts clean clear amber.

5oz on tap at Smoky Mountain in Gatlinburg. Poured a clear copper color with a small white head. Aroma was some light floral notes, earthy, spicy hop profile. Body of the beer was malt heavy, with some light hop notes. Okay.

Keg at Smoky Mountain Turkey Creek, 16/02/15. Clear golden with a moderate off white covering. Nose is tangerine, juicy citric hops, grassy, toasted malt. Taste comprises tangerine, melon, citric pith. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. Decent enough APA.

5oz on tap at the brewery. Caramel, bready malt. Light kind of citrus orange hop. Clear orange color. Thin white head, leaving good thicker sheet of lace. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Medium body. Kind of slick, light carbonation. A mediocre pale ale -- kind of sweet and malty.
Good american pale ale. Taste like it’s made with water straight from the mountains of Tennessee. Dry but not too much hop bitterness.
Clear light amber. Nice piney hops in the aroma turns into apricots in the flavor. Surprisingly bitter finish.

Draft: Clear gold, off-white head. Grapefruit, grain scent. Taste is watery, bitter, grapefruit-peel. This was not very good......may have been a bad run, judging by past reviews...... Flat and dull.......
Delicious Pale Ale. It wasn't just hoppy like Sam Adams 48 Latitude, but had a great flavorful finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Suprisingly, I had never had their porter during the many trips I made to this place, so getting to try this was kinda cool. And the beer turns out to be a very nice beer at the same time. Aroma was chocolate defined. Tons, and tons of chocolate with a underscoring of roasted malts. Can’t recall the last porter I had that had this much chocolate. Appearance was dark, dark brown to black, no head. A bit thin and watery in the mouth. Flavors are chocolate, roasted malts but suprisingly not really sweet and finishes a bit on the dry side. Nice suprise!

Tap at the Toronado. Very dark brown color with a foamy light brown head. A fruit aroma with a chocolate malt flavor. Interesting beer. It has the belgium elements with a light fruit doppelbock element with the porter chocolate and malt aftertaste.

Deep black brown color. Medium head. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malts. A medium bodied porter. Roasted malts, choclately and somewhat sweet. Slight hop bitterness. A touch thin for a porter, and a little watery. But, it finishes well and it somewhat dry. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is dry and clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Showshoe ESB Pours a nice copper color with a tan head that clings to the glass. Nose is well-balanced with sweet malt and hops. Full mouthfeel with great maltiness throughout. Nice beer but nothing special.
~Pours a clear copper with small off white head. ~Light malty citrus scent. ~Acidic citrus hop flavor with biscuity malts. ~Light feel, acidic finish. ~Decent summer brew. Good sipper.
Draft. Rich amber color with a thin off-white head. Roasty/nutty aroma. Slight roast flavor with citrus hops. Roastiness takes away from the enjoyment and leads to a muddled beer.

Medium brown color. Small head. Aroma is malty. A medium-bodied, mild tasting ESB. Malts are nutty and sweet. Hops are citrusy and grapefruity. Nicely fruity, yet bitter enough for an ESB. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is bitter.
Tap. A nice brown color with a nice head. Aroma is pleasant spicy and toasty. Taste is also spicy with nice hints of grains.
Slightly hazed mahogany. Nice spicing not overdone or astringent so melds nicely with porter like malt.
Bottle thanks to Springlicker. Pours brown with white head. Nose and taste of caramel sauce, toffee, brown sugar and light molasses. Lighter medium body.
Draft - peaty, caramel, a little boozy and toast. Reminds me of a scotch ale. A good first sample from the brewery. Fairly sweet

Draft at turkey creek pub. Pours amber and moderately clear. Nose is rich bready malts, toast, and a touch of coffee. Flavor is similar, rich bread, caramels, toffee, toast, and just a faint roast malt flavor like on the side of coffee or chocolates. Not overly amazing but I actually liked it considering the "mass-market" approach of the establishment.

Aroma is a very sweet caramel type aroma. Smells like a bunch of sticky raisins. Taste is very sweet and creamy. Sort of a grainy earthy taste. Very sweet which I like. I can taste the alcohol in this. Hardly any hop taste. A slight sour twinge but barely there. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 oz bottle pours brown with a very very thin tan head. Aroma is mainly sweet fruit. Taste is also sweet with a slight hint of alcohol. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Date: May 08, 2010 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Simpson Satisifier Appearance: hazy dark brown, wispy head, bits of lace Aroma: sweet caramel aroma, touch of dark fruits, lots of earthyness Flavor: sweet caramel flavor, nice fruity sweetness, touch of candy character, light earthyness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4
Draft in Gatlinburg. A deep amber pour with a thin tan head. Malty scent with a hint of nuts. Taste is sweet malt and light spice, bitter finish.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, humble-looking, brown body with a woefully thin, short-lived head. A rather dull look, I must say. Smell: Let’s have a sniff! Smells of simple toast, fire-licked nuts, cocoa, and an open box of Sun-Maid raisins. Taste: Essentially, what you smell is what you get in the taste, with a follow-through of toasted bread given a light dusting of sweetish cocoa powder. Slight nuttiness throughout. Background dark fruitiness. Very mild bitterness. Drying finish. Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Light carbonation. Drinkability: Never exceeds being merely ’okay’. The relatively light body and carbonation leaves this one feeling a bit lean in the mouth. Can we get some melanoidin malt up in this?

column1: Rocky River Brewery Twin Peaks Pilsener
column5: A pretty medicore attempt at a pilsner. With all the Bohemian and Classic German Pilsners I've been sampling lately this is a joke. A slight sour flavor with nothing but water to back it up. As much of a pils as Miller Lite and honestly not a whole lot better.

column1: Rocky River Brewery Twin Peaks Pilsener
column5: Could have used a little something. lacks the crispness that I like in in a American Pils, and didn't have the depth of flavor I expect in a European. Not bad, and very drinkable, but nothing to set it apart from the pack

column1: Rocky River Brewery Twin Peaks Pilsener
column5: Bright yellow with a small head that stayed until the bottom of the mug. Strange soft banana pudding taste, although the beer was very light and watery. Not the best brewpub pils I'v had!

column1: Rocky River Brewery Panther Creek Porter
column5: Date: 04/12/2003 Mode: Draft Source: Brewfest, Hickory, NC black with ruby edges, light malt flavor, bitter roasted flavor, hint of chocolate, a porter? Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 2/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.3/5.0 Score: */4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Rocky River Brewery Panther Creek Porter
column5: Bottle-Mellow Mushroom-Chattanooga, TN. A small sized light brown head with fine-small sized bubbles that mostly dissipated. The nose was that of chocolate and mild coffee. It had a mild coffee taste to it with some malt notes. The mouthfeel was creamy and smooth and medium bodied. This beer had an excellent lace to it. This was a mild Porter in my opinion.

column1: Rocky River Brewery Panther Creek Porter
column5: TheDM and Hotstuff vacation brew 5. This bottled brew was enjoyed at the Mellow Mushroom in Chattanooga Tennessee which had 40 taps and about 72 different bottles of beer. It poured a small head of fine to large sized light brown colored bubbles that left behind an opaque dark brown colored body with no visible carbonation and a fair lace. The aroma was mild with notes of dark malt. The mouthfeel was intially thin and unbodied, but finished very stong smooth and full bodied. A strange but nice finish. The flavor was that of dark malt, mollasses, hops and mild coffee. It was a well rounded and very enjoyable brew.

column1: Rocky River Brewery Panther Creek Porter
column5: Deep black pour with a thin tan head. Good aroma full of coffee, vanilla, and roasted malt. Great smooth taste with some chocolate and caramel dominating the flavor. A damn good porter. Sample bottle given to me from the owner of the Beer Sellar in Knoxville, TN!

column1: Rocky River Brewery Panther Creek Porter
column5: This was a very nice porter. Pitch black apperance. Flavor was quite bitter like this morning's coffee minus cream and sugar. Some dark chocolate and smoke was detectable. The aftertaste was slightly sour. The body was a little thin but the excellent flavor of the beer made that a non issue.

column1: Rocky River Brewery Panther Creek Porter
column5: Black with a tan head. very faint burnt toast aroma. Coffe and malt, with some sweetihs, milt chocolatey aroma. Dry, light finish. decent flavors, but a thin body.

column1: Rocky River Brewery Panther Creek Porter
column5: Very dark brown, almost black. Caramelly, chocolatey, and smokey. Woody, oaky and dry at the end. Just like a Slopoke candy sucker that had been licked and stuck to an oak barrel that once aged some fine bitter porter.
50 cl flaske 5,5%. Overraskende god påskeøl. Masser af smag og en dejlig sødme som varer ved.
En fin øl, stor sødme og en god.smag af malten. En rigtig god påske øl der passer til maden.
A danish, unfiltered, copper Easter Ale with light head. Aroma is malt, caramel. Taste is bitter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle as Påskebryg, 5.5%. Hazy amber, offwhite froth. Malty aroma. Yeasty, doughy. Sweetish, malty flavour with light floral hops.
Usikker på om det er samme øl. Påskebryg 2017 har 5,5% alkohol. Jeg synes resten kan passe. Frisk øl, men noget ordinær.
50 cl. flaske. 5,8 %. God gylden øl fra det bornholmske. Endnu en af de gode fra Svaneke Bryghus. Dejlig læskende og super flot etikette. Årets bedste påske øl.

Copenhagen 1/4 2016. 50 cl bottle from Meny. Yellow label formed as Bornholm. Pours slightly hazy golden yellow with white head. Settles as flimsy patches of foam. Malty aroma. Quite sweet with notes of caramel and bisquits. Some fruity sourness. Medium carbonation and watery palate. Taste is sweetish followed by medium bitterness. Rather short aftertaste. Works okay with food but not something I would go out of my way to get.

Tap@Taphouse, Copenhagen - golden amber coloured pour with white head. Medium sweet malty aroma and taste, bready malts, doughy yeast, caramel sweetness coming in, some floral hoppy backing. Fair for style.
Bottle at home. Pours clear golden body with a small white head. Grainy, malty, corn. Blah

500 ml bottle. Slightly unclear golden body with a fast disappearing white head. Aroma is mild malt, grain and bread. Flavor is like a rather ordinary lager with a light malt profile and moderate bitterness. Medium body and a bit light in aftertaste. Drainable, quite straight forward lager with focus on the malty side.
On tap at The 024 - tried the 60 - good ipa; tried the 90 - i'd go out of my way for it; the 120 -extraordinary. Someone described it as IPA essence - that works.
0,3 litre Bottle from Total Wine And More, Laguna Hills, Ca. Amber with white head. Booze, alcoholic, strong, unpleasant.
De Beershelf. En copa Teku. Viendo Mr. Robo. El alcohol se nota sin molestar, y se sube mucho a la cabeza. Predominantemente maltosa , con notas a galleta,pero el lupulo se nota tambien
I had this at Global Brew. Pours copper with a white head. Taste citrus, hoppy, boozy. I thought this was good. It thought this was ok strong. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I was definitely excited to find this. It was definitely worth the price. To label this an IPA is almost unfair. There's so much more to it. It definitely has a Belgian strong feel to it. I poured it from the bottle into a tulip glass. It pours a reddish mahogany with a small, off-white head. The aroma is so complex and appealing. I get dark fruits, molasses, cinnamon, bourbon, and hops. The taste is at first cherries, apricot, grapefruit, raisin, and booze. Later in the glass, you get more molasses, cinnamon, date, and bourbon. There's a tingly burn at times. It lingers quite a bit. This is something you definitely have to savor. Needless to say, it packs a helluva punch. This lives up to the hype.

Pours deep hazy brown amber with a minimalist tan head. Aroma is bonkers. Creamy dark fruit and wet bready malt. Toasted candy raisin. Taste follows with incredible depth. Finish is strong and brings those sugar hops with notes of pine and some mild bitterness. Toffee and bourbon. Unlike any other IPA I’ve tried. More like a Belgian. Still, awesome and unique.

Bottle Matt bought back from Dana Point, CA. Pours an inviting amber, cloudy at first but settles into a deep bright limpidness. Small fizzy white head. This is a HUGE BEER. Smells of apricot, goji berry, light fig, candied apple, jam, malt, cream, tonnes of booze and hop. Like a hoppier, less malty, more alcoholic wee heavy — some rye spice in there. Very smooth and despite the massive booze (almost 18%!) it is still surprisingly and dangerously drinkable. Taste has even more booze and jammy fruity malt. The big oily hops and booze keep it from being overly jammy/musty. Finish has some floral/vanilla sweetness and bubblegum esters. Body is oily and big. This is an unbelievably big beer, executed well and with perfect balance. Almost feels like an experiment in how much you can crank up the ABV and accompanying hop/malt in a beer without making it taste like gimmicky or like a spirit/liquor. Huge, apple sweetness and crispness, wood-y whiskey complexity, most enjoyable when it can be nursed.

Bottle from BevMo in Dana Point at home in HK. Rich ruby-copper pour with fine white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is complex - candied apple, deep pine resin hop, chewy bready malt like a wee heavy. In fact sort of like a massively hopped - with pine resin - big scotch ale. Taste is sweet but not quite treacly and hugely bitter. Jammy fruit, tingly bitterness. Rich palate but not too heavy somehow. Very good enormous pine-forward IPA, balances by giant sweet plum-bread malt.
Absolutely one of the best beers I’ve ever tasted. I love it!! Wish it was available all the time. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Easy best Imperial IPA I ever had... You don't know you are drinking 16.5% ABV beer. Absolutely amazing!

750ml at home. Hazy orange amber pour with a fading, thin off white head. Raisins, candied oranges, burnt sugar, Belgian yeasty funk, figs. Very low carb. Full bodied, boozy finish with orange, caramel, raisins and spice. Delicious.
Pours clear amber with compact white head that dissipates quickly; stone fruits on the nose mingled with fruit cake; sweet syrupy palate with a complex finish.

Bottle pour at the Oliver twist... Deep Hazy murky amber... Thin white lacing.. Soft sweet caramel crystal toffee fruit nose.. Long sweet caramel crystal toffee fruit... Soft sweet caramel toffee fruit. Soft sweet caramel toffee fruit.. Big soft and rich w
Pours ruby amber, with one finger bone white head. Aroma is dried fruit and toffee. Taste is sweet plum and light toffee, moving some licorice and clove. Finish is Belgian yeast. A good Belgian.
Extremely smooth. Well carbonated. Abv nicely hidden. One of the best quads I've tasted. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Super Cellars in Westwood, NJ. Aroma is caramel, banana, booze, rum-soaked raisins. Taste is boozy caramel, creme brûlée, bananas foster. Very creamy and dreamy.

From Jan 2006 Poured from bottle(bottled on Aug 27th 2004) a ruby semi *clear* gold with a very nice head of foam that diminishes slowly but never leaves the scene. The smell was immediately apparent right after I removed the stubborn cork....a whoosh of mixed fruits including bananas and plums. Oh, and there's a bit of a sour smell there as well. Could be good. ;^) The taste is very fruity as well. Tons of plum with some banana and some citrus and also, a sweetness that smacks of caramel. In the far background, I sense a bit of clove. Wow. This son of a gun is so complex and wonderfully harmonious with its flavours. And dang, the 12% abv is there but is pretty well hidden. Why was this beer retired??? Thank goodness I have 3 more bottles. *Clear as in I'm drinking from the first 3rd of the bottle. What is left in the bottle is looking a bit more cloudy. Btw, I've had this one a couple of times in the past(+2 years ago) and the bottling dates weren't a year and a half from when I tried them like this one(much less) so the aging done by Liquid Solutions or whomever has definitely paid off big time, imho! Bottom line: If you see some around your neck of the woods....grab 'em!

Color: the lightest Quad I have ever seen. Looked and tasted more like a triple to me. Reminded me of their golden monkey beer. I would've taste tested them side-by-side to see if this wasn't a bomber. Notes of plum and rum soaked raisins. A bit peppery. Prominent alcohol taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours murky amber from the bottle. The frothy white head soon fades. Aroma is apple cider, plum, vinegar. Taste is sweet with caramel and fruity notes, soggy sponge, tart apple vinegar. Big bodied with mild carbonation. The imperfectly hidden alcohol makes itself felt in the finish. Okay.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark amber with a small bubbly white head that fades to a ring. Sweet aroma, with booze and oak, caramel malt, and dark fruits. Taste is quite sweet to start then picks up an oak and hops bite before going back to sweet with dark fruits and brown sugar again. Alcohol burn on the end. Lingering sparkly sweetness. Excellent.
0,25l on tap @ Angleterre. Pours clear golden with a low head. Aroma is slightly fruity malts. Flavor is sweet and malts with some hops. Decent.
Pump tap at st urhos pub, helsinki. Hazy copper color, white head. Aroma has some malts, hops, citrus. Balanced taste, citrus notes, malts. Good real ale.

Bottle, pours copper with a very slight head. A little toffee, acidity and caramel malt on the nose. Palate is malty, but lightly tart and acetic, sweetish and slightly cloying finish. Faulty, I assume.

Cask gravity at my friends wedding down Sumerset way. It pours clear amber with minimal head. The nose is earthy, wood, leather, nut and caramel. The taste is bitter - sweet, wood, caramel, toasted nut and brown bread with a short, toasted finish. Medium body and a touch flat. Condition could have been a bit better, but this is all in all a fairly standard bitter. OK.
[Sorry - shitty numbers only rating from July 2010. Bottle in Skewen. "mild malty, soft bitterness, OK">
Origin: Bottle. Vessel: Bottle. Supplier: ASDA (Bristol). Full and malty, served slightly too warm.

From bottle. Malty, herbal hopped aroma. Big bubbles carbonation. Frothy lacey head over cloudy amber beer (both Glastonbury beers I’ve tried so far have had some cloudy residue towards the end of the pour). Good balance of fresh sweet maltiness with light herbal bitterness. Vanilla notes in the dry sweet finish.

Bottle from ASDA Poole. Cloudy orange. I like this one, good nose and great balance of hops against quite a malty caramel backbone. But, hideously overcarbed again, took two careful pours to get it in the pint glass.

Cask at Craft Beer Co, Islington on 24th April 2015. Hazy copper with thin decaying off-white foam and spot lacing. Caramel malt aroma with pungent earthiness. Fruit and maltiness in liquid with some spice, before a fruity finish with black pepper and late bitterness. Light in body and mouthfeel.
Cask - deep golden body with a clean white head. Aroma of white wine, hay, yeast and soil. Taste of citrus, grapefruit and flowers with some orange and soap. Medium body.

column1: San Francisco Billy Goat Double Bock
column5: The bocks brewed at this establishment - especially the St. Stephen’s Bock - are the best I have ever tasted from an American microbrewery. If you visit San Francisco during the late fall and winter, be sure to stop by the pub and see what bock is on tap.

column1: San Francisco Billy Goat Double Bock
column5: Not even a good try. This was downright piss-poor. Very little head. Not much abv. Light Amber color and a lighter body than any bock I've ever had.

column1: San Francisco Billy Goat Double Bock
column5: Black/brown, medum head, not long lasting. Chocolate aroma with a hint of hop, powdery cocoa flavour. Silky smooth down the throat. So nice I had to have another and another and I'm just about to go for yet another.

Bottled. Old rating from my second rating notebook, apparently missed to add this. Amber colour, small head. Flavour is malts, some fruits, alcohol and yeast. Flavour is fruit, alcohol, and mild yeast.
Light hazy amber coloured, average white head. Some sweet yeasty aroma, little fruity. Medium body, finish is little sweet-bitter. An average beer.
Bottled. Hazy amber coloured. Very yeasty aroma and flavour with some very unpleasant notes of rotten nuts. Thin and undrinkable.

Bottled (BB 07/2005) Clear amber color, tight white head, some lace. Nose has toffee, smoked ham (!) and grassy hops. Malty with light toffee sweetness, rye, smoke, finishing to bitterish hops. Unbalanced and not very enjoyable.

(Bottled) Clear amber color with a small, vanishing, lacy head. Sweetish-caramely, fruity and slightly yeasty aroma with acidic and sour hints. Sweet-malty, somewhat fruity and hoppy, slightly acidic, bitter and sour flavor with rye and toffee hints. Medium-bodied, bitter and acidic palate with moderate carbonation. I’m pretty sure this is Tongerlo 6 Blonde, since it felt familiar from the first sniff. A slightly below-average blond, but drinkable.

(Bottle 33 cl) Actually more amber than blond, what I usually refer to as fully golden. Filtered with a HUGE head that never flattens - quite impressive. Typical Belgian yeasty notes, otherwise fruity with some nutty notes. Fresh with some bitterness in the palate. "Celestus" is a brand for a Belgian supermarket-chain (have forgotten which) and I wonder if this is just a Tongerlo 6 Blond in disguise? 050305

The disembogues from the 330ml brown bottle a lightly clouded amber color with a dinosauric semi-creamy light tan head and as it slowly fades to nothingness the lace forms a satin sheet to lie upon the glass. The aroma of ripe peaches, sweet and appetizing; crisp with the start sweet and the malt profile perfect, top is light to moderate in its feel to the palate. Finish is stern in its acidity, the hops ever so mild but pleasant, very dry and lingering aftertaste, ah what is better than a well made beer, “Hell Yeah”, another well-made beer.
YMER in the aroma. Unpleasant flavour. Very yeasty and rather watery. Thin body with a weak mouthfeel.

A bit darker blond beer with a small white head. The aroma is candy sugar and light malty. The taste is initially very sweet and fruity with a more bitter finish. Quite an ok beer but lacks that little extra.
hazy golden-orange with a fine head and a nice lace, candy sugar and undefined fruits in a discreet aroma, medium-bodied with a moderate dry bitterness - incredibly lacking of character

Quite unusual and interesting spice lager. Perhaps, it's not my kind of beer, but I will never forget it. Clear golden appearance, poor head, lovely spicy aroma, grassy (to say the least) palate. Funny.
A very interesting beer. Aroma from pepper, and some other spices. Flavour from marzipan and bitter almond.
Golden. Fine creamy head. Spicy peppery aroma. Interesting flavor of marzipan. Slight bitter in the end. This high rating cod of the attempt to brew something different.

Bottled. Straw colour, moderate head and condition. Well at least it looks like beer. Rollercoaster ride of aromas starting with marzipan followed by a peppery herbal note that turns to curry powder and finally settles on chicken skin. In the mouth there is still some marzipan noticable but anything else is drowned out by chicken stock. Did not linger long enough in my mouth for any judgement on aftertaste that sretches beyond one sylable.

Almond extract is evident in both the aroma and flavor. Unlike Baltika's other numbered beers, which are in ascending order with beer strength, #10 is only 5.2% ABV.
