I have bought this bottle, at the coop, supermarket, in front of the train station. We have tried this bottle yesterday, at home, relax, during the apero. I was pleasantly surprised with this beer, not a great one but it is acceptable, best before 01/19. The body is clear, yellow and slightly troubled, normal carbonation, thin and white foam. The taste is fresh not so rough than an original, a kind of witbier, malty, creamy, a sensation of wheat, fruity, a touch of coriander, orange peel, a sensation of peppermint at the final and discreet, really refreshing, not bad.
On draft in Zermatt. Pours a cloudy gold with an off white head. Light toast aroma and flavors. Inoffensive and boring.
Ekstrem stærk smag af alkohol, lettere brutal i smagen Ikke dårlig, men helt klart en "billig øl"
33cl bottle. Pours clear golden with a white foam. Very sweet & strong alcohol nose & taste. Sharp, sweet & watery. Nasty shit!

Bottled(330ml). -Courtesy of faroeviking (thanks Jacob!) Golden coloured, small white head, lively carbonation, sweet wet cardboard nose. Weak but sweet malty and strong alcoholic taste and that’s it. Unpleasant sharp alcoholic finish.

Bottle (Dansk Styrke 3, 8.1%, brewed by Neptun Bryg, Saltum) shared with ogivlado who received it in a trade with faroeviking (thanks!) Poured a golden colour with a small lasting white head. Fizzy. Extremely so at times. Oh man. Nose... alcohol, dust, cardboard. Proooomising. Not. The taste was almost exactly as I expected. Bad, sweet, riddled with alcohol, some maltiness and dusty hop shows up but not nearly enough to hide the nastiness. Almost offensive. The 1.5 feels a little too high.
Clear golden with no head. Malty aroma with dominant alcol notes. Falvor likewise. Alcohol well hidden.
A golden beer that cannot have other purpose than to make someone drunk. Both aroma and taste has a lot of alcohol, quite a lot of sweetness, a little malt and even less hops.
Bottle. Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops and alcohol.

In Denmark we have something called "drink with the animals" when you study biology. Unfortunatly there is no picture of this brew, but the bottle is covered with a huge rhino, and Brutalis is the name of a notorious danish rhino who caused havoc in every zoo he was transfered to. So when you pass the Rhino field in copenhagen zoo, you ofcourse drink a "Brutalis" - its extremly nasty though. Spirit with actificial sweet malty notes trying to cover it up.

33 cL bottle. Pours golden yellow to orange with an immediately gone and what looked like a white head. Sweet malty aroma. Medium to full bodied. Grainy flavour, quite sweet malt base. Dry malty and only vaguely bitter finish.
Golden colour whit white head.Aroma is sweet and malty feels watery but with strong alc.Bad Discount beer.
Can from Carmine Street Beers, New York. Aroma is wheat, spicy yeast, coriander, citrus, curaçao peel. Moderate sweet, light bitter. Body is medium. Smooth Wit, well-brewed.

Ar: przejrzale banany, kolendra, gozdziki, super intensywnie, rasowo. Wyg: metne, pomaranczowawe, piana gruba, rozne ziarno. Sm: wysycenie wysokie, przejrzale banany, gozdziki, ziolowe tlo, ziarniste i sycace, lekka goryczka skorki pomaranczy, bardzo dobrze, ale dosc ciezko. Pos: gozdziki, jakby ziarnisto-zytnia mini goryczka. Ov: po prostu ale bardzo solidnie.

Honestly may be partial on the rating as White Rascal was recommended, rather than my usual stumbling upon. The beer offers a wheat body you would expect from a Belgian, however only minimal front pallet spice and citrus, leaving you wanting more/unsatisfied. The best way I could describe it would be an average alcohol content with a generic taste reminiscent of Blue Moon without the orange after your third Blue Moon in a row. In absence of other Belgian options it is sufficient, but not one I would seek out on purpose.

Can @ Friends/Grumpy brewer. Appearance: pours hazy golden with good white soapy head and lacing. aroma/taste: barley, wheat, bread, coriander, orange peel and fruity notes. palette: medium yeasty and spicy aroma, average carbonation, medium body, medium sweetness, somewhat balanced by a light to medium bitterness, average duration and a watery texture. Overall: refreshing wit

You're getting a lot more fruit than just oranges with this beer. It has a very fruity flavor, with hints of banana on the tongue. Very low hops, some malt, and all flavor. This brew is not your typical wheat beer flavor, so if you drink this expecting Blue Moon or Shocktop, you'll be disappointed.

Pours cloudy pale gold with white lace diminishing. The aroma has spicy coriander notes. Taste has the banana notes of a classic wheat beer. Sweet predominantly with a light bitter finish. Palate is medium bodied clammy feel average carbonation and a soft bitter finish. I liked it but I wish American bars served smaller offerings.
Pours hazy bright golden with a full white head. Aroma is wheat, citrus and Belgian yeast. Taste is thin plum, moving to wheat and Belgian yeast. Finish is light citrus.
Has a very nice spicy + orange + wheat aroma. This is my second time having this beer and I am I would soon visit this beer again.

12 oz can. Smells of coriander and orange. Hazy, straw yellow in color. Tastes of banana, with a hint of orange. More on the sweet side. Finishes with a banana taste. OK beer, but there are better whites out there.

On tap at Old Chicago. Pour was hazy straw with good inch thick head that impressively perservered throughout the entire experience. Smooth and creamy with no aftertaste making it a great session brew.

column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Draught. Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted light bread, caramel), lightly hoppy (flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Great session beer.

On tap: No head, just some thin patches of white on the surface. Golden and slightly hazy. Fruity, apple-like nose. Fermented apple juice in the flavor, also. Rather carbonated. Milky and watery at times. Some earthy malt flavors with hints of yeast. Some alcohol notes, though, not that strong. Apple flavors were much too dominant.

Draught. Body is light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (lemon, flowers), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of honey, strawberry, diacetyl, hint of milk. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter, lightly acetic. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.
Perfect beer if you like making love in a canoo. It’s f’ing near water but it’s true to it’s style. An extremely light ale for massive drinking in a college town.

Extremely fluffy and creamy to compensate for the absolute lack of substance. Some kolschy malt flavor, but stale and leaning toward the soggy chew of an old toliet paper roll. (New puppy in our house - his favorite toy gave me the inspiration)

12 oz bottle from Jimmie's in Alpena. Pours dark like a coke with crazy foam. Took me 5 minutes to pour it and I probably slurped a third of the beer in foam. Foamy head remained until the beer was gone and is probably still floating somewhere down the drain. Nose is malty. Taste follows suit but has a pleasant hop bite. Nice brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 10/5/2015. Pours lightly hazy deep ruby red/brownish color with a 2 finger dense and rocky khaki head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Dense soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Fantastic appearance. Aromas of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, chocolate, light cocoa/coffee, light plum/apple, herbal, grass, light pepper, and roast/toasted earthiness. Nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt, earthy hop, and light fruity yeast notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, chocolate, light cocoa/coffee, light plum/apple, herbal, grass, light pepper, and roast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/spicy hop and roast bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, nuttiness, chocolate, light cocoa/coffee, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, earthy hop, and light fruity yeast flavors; with nice malt/bitterness balance and zero astringent flavors after the finish. Light dryness from roast/hop bitterness as well. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderate creamy/bready, and lightly sticky/chalky balance mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice English brown ale style. All around good complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, earthy hop, and light fruity yeast flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.

Rated on 01-12-2012 (Bottle) This beer has a medium sized smooth tan head with a lengthy retention, hazy brown amber body, fast rising carbonation observed, and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is caramel malt, nutty, sweet, and dark fruits. The flavor is sweet, dark fruits, malty, nutty, and a hint of roastiness in the end. The mouthfeel is soft carbonation and this beer is light-medium bodied. This is a session beer and there is not a lot of character with this beer.

12oz bottle poured into a mini 12oz looking pint glass thing. Appearance: Awesome. Two finger tan head, nice and clear brown color, with outstanding lacing. Looks great. Smell: Not much there. Some caramel malts with some traces of roastiness with some nuttiness and maybe some coffee. Smells like your typical brown, really. Taste/feel: I am surprised. I’d almost give this a four, but I can’t quite do it -- this is JUST the brown ale you want to have on a hot day like today. Nice and cold, fairly thin but creamy feel, not too much carbonation, and tastes way better than I expected. It’s not bursting with flavor, but it has a nice creaminess. The flavor is primarily nutty caramel with a touch of roastiness. It’s not too bold, but it’s very enjoyable. I’d buy it again.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy fine to medium sized tan colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a typically carbonated transparent light brown colored body. The mild aroma was brown ale The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The thin flavor contained notes of brown malt. An OK brew just nothing special.
Bottle. Light brown, cloudy, tall foamy off white head. Lots of carbonation, medium light body. Not my favorite brown. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

draft at the tap room - Pours medium brown with a small head and a straightforward caramel malt aroma. As with my previous two samples, the sweet flavor gives way to a similar bitterness as the others. Same kind of hops? It’s medium bodied with a mildly bitter finish. Decent.

12 oz. shorty bottle served in shaker- poured a darkened brown with a shade of plum color, several dulled tan frog eyes and a similar colored ring around the vessel for a head. Aroma of toffee, caramel, and some dulled hops. Hits the mouth with a slightly uneven medium body, malt doesn’t have as much sweetness as the nose suspected, some very mild hops in the middle, finish is cloyingly sweet and just a touch acidic. Not too shabby.
Thanks to my Michigan pusher, Steve! Nice chestnut brown pour. Very fizzy pour with a modest nose. Taste is interesting, a trace hoppy but mostly fruity with an ever so mild tartness. Not bad.

Courtesy of Strykzone. Poured a dark red amber, with a tan head and light lacing Nose of lightly roasted malts with some chocolate. Medium in body. Kind of at thin mouthfeel. Flavor is light chocolate with some grassy hops. Finish show a little nuts and light bitterness. Pretty basic beer but quite drinkable.

Appearance: 1 finger thick white head that dissipates after a minute. Hazy orange copper color. Aroma: citrus, pine, floral, honey. Flavour: citrus, grapefruit, pine, honey, floral, grassy. Overall: this is a well balanced full bodied IPA with a dry finish.
Bottle. Pours Amber brown. To be fair mine has wheat floaters in it. However the palate is light and crisp. The taste is light. Citrus. Below average.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 12/21/2015. Pours moderately hazy orange/copper color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of grapefruit, apricot, pineapple, mango, lemon zest, orange peel, citrus rind, pine, honey, light caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus/tropical/pine hops and moderate bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of grapefruit, apricot, pineapple, mango, lemon zest, orange peel, citrus rind, pine, honey, light caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness. Moderate amount of pine/citrus rind bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, apricot, pineapple, mango, lemon/orange rind, pine, honey, light caramel, toasted bread, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a while. Nice complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/tropical/pine hops and moderate bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero hop astringency after the finish. Moderate dryness from bitterness that increases through the glass. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately sticky/resinous, and fairly creamy/bready balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warmth lingering after the finish. Overall this is a nice American IPA. All around good complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/tropical/pine hops and moderate bready malt flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. A nicely enjoyable offering.
Bottle: Cloudy, orange-amber with a small off-white head. Caramel, orange aroma. Taste is slightly floral bitter, caramel malt, orange malt. Fairly average, but a nice, long bittering.
(bottle - 12 oz) Copper pour with a white head. Aroma is full of hops and some dry grass. Flavor is insanely bitter, almost to the point of undrinkable. Not good. [9/9/15]
Bottle at home. Purchased at GVL West Party Store in Allendale. Pours a yellowish orange with a thick off white head. Aroma is floral with some pine. Medium to lighter bodies. Nice beer.
Not as terrible as everyone said a bit soapy lightly grassy. Avg palate. Bad after taste of soap... Yuck.

Rated on 01-08-2012. This bottled IPA pours a very small creamy, smooth head that is fully lasting, gold transparent body, very fizzy, fast rising carbonation, and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is caramel malt, citrus, and orange pine hops. The flavor is grapefruit and orange pine hops and has a short dry finish. The mouthfeel is light carbonation and this beer is light-medium bodied. The hops are upfront as they should be for this beer style, but they are not in your face hops. This beer is easy drinking even for us non-hop heads.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass. The pour is a clear copper color, maybe a touch lighter. With a two-finger slightly off white head and pretty nice lacing. The aroma is incredibly full of piney resin. There is a nice hoppiness and strong citrusy presence. Nothing too fantastic. The flavor is similar. There is a solid hoppiness coupled to a light bitterness before the resin flavor takes over. The mouth feel is decent, there is a medium creamy carbonation, and the aftertaste is bitter and dry, with a touch of resin. Not the best IPA out there. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to my neighbor. This beer is a nice hazy copper colored body with a thin but lasting creamy white head. Spotted lacing. The aroma and flavor are herbal, grassy, and fairly malty for an IPA. The palate is medium bodied and has a rather malty feel. A very drinkable beer, which is fortunate, as I have an entire six pack. A bit malty for an IPA, however.

Bottle from the cheese place in frankenmuth; $3.50. Odd I hvae to pay a stupid deposit for this stupid bottle. The gov't, they'll figger out anything to get money from you. Smell certainly raspberry mild aroma. Taste is somewhat raspberry. Sweeter than expected but not as sweet to make it pleasant.
It’s okay. Not as light and refreshing as I expect from these. Raspberry flavor is kind of week and only in the finish.
Best beer at mountain town. A little weak on the raspberry but a great taste for anyone who likes wheat.
12oz bottle. exactly what it says it is - a raspberry wheat beer. probably awesome if you like this sort of thing

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 5/26/2015. Pours hazy deep orange/copper color with a 1 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of sweet/lightly tart raspberry, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with well balanced raspberry juice, pale malt, fruity yeast, and earthy hop notes; with solid strength. Taste of sweet/lightly tart raspberry, pear, apple, wheat, cracker, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Light herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of raspberry, wheat, cracker, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice robustness and balance of raspberry juice, pale malt, fruity yeast, and earthy hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and fairly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a nice fruited pale wheat ale style. All around good robustness and balance of raspberry juice, pale malt, fruity yeast, and earthy hop flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. The base pale wheat ale was very well done to style as well. A nicely enjoyable offering.

050 13 526 ... I want to assume that means this was bottled the 50th day of 2013. Poured about three months later into a shaker pint on May 17th. Appearance: The label is much like Mt. Pleasant’s other brews -- a train, with a colored background. This one is purple/pink, making it somewhat eye catching. The beer pours with a two finger head that doesn’t last two long. The color is a super hazy purple and brownish hue. Not much lacing. Smell: Heavy raspberry with a dribble of beer ... definitely heavy on the raspberry, and not much else. The wheat and some malt is also traceable. Taste: Well, I expect anybody that dislikes fruit beers to hate this one, as it’s definitely raspberry forward. It’s super easy drinking and has a significant raspberry profile, but I don’t find that it’s too much. I was a bit iffy on the first sip, but I got into it. There’s a tart character on the taste buds as well, which makes this super thirst quenching on a hot day. The after taste has a bit of wheat flavor to let you know that this is a beer. The feel is like a mildly carbonated pop, and is easy to slam if you’re super thirsty. Look, it is what it is ... it’s a fruit beer, and it doesn’t try to be anything else. A LOT of raspberry, minimal bitterness, a solid sweetness and tartness... this beer would be absolutely fantastic for somebody that isn’t a fan of beer and/or craft beer. This isn’t a great beer, but it’s solid enough for the style. By the end of a bottle it becomes a bit much with the amount of sourness and sweetness, but that’s just enough for me... I couldn’t have much more. Another good beer from Mt. Pleasant.

Golden color brew with a white head. Not a very good aroma, makes me think of a smell you would find in a hospital. A mild raspberry flavor that somehow makes the beer taste awful. Leaves a bad aftertaste.
Wheat, wheat, and more wheat. Raspberry is there, but it might as well not be. The wheat is over the top on this thing.
tap. Amber with small head. It may come as a shock, but this tastes like a generic wheat beer with mild raspberry.

12oz bottle, pours a murky amber with an insane amount of bright white head. Took several minutes for this to settle to a point I could even think about beginning to drink it. Once settled though, not a bad looking beer. Not much in the way of aroma, want to say I pick up some berry, but it is faint. Wheaty taste with raspberry flavoring, reminds me of a friends home-brew. As far as raspberry beers go, it doesn’t stack up to Rubaeus, but certainly you could do worse on a hot day.

Got this bottle from a cheese place in frankenmuth. Smells like good ol' lager beer, good ol' fresh lager beer, quite nice. Taste tho, you immediately know this is an ale, has a couple negative ale attributes from the first taste. Mellows out in the middle, starts to settle down to a decent golden, but perhaps not, blonde ale. Simple and easy, it hides its alky content well. Not bad for what it is, but it lacks the civility of a basic blondie.

12 ounce can into pint glass, no can dating. Pours lightly hazy medium golden yellow color with a 1-2 finger dense white head with solid retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings down the glass, with some light streaming carbonation. Aromas of lemon, pear, apple, cracker, biscuit, light honey, herbal, light pepper, and floral/grassy earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of pale malt and light-moderate earthy hop/fruity yeast notes; with solid strength. Taste of lemon, pear, apple, cracker, biscuit, light honey, herbal, light pepper, and floral/grassy earthiness. Light herbal/grassy/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of cracker, biscuit, light honey, herbal, light pepper, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Nice balance and robustness of pale malt and light-moderate earthy hop/fruity yeast flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Lightly increasing dryness from lingering bitterness. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately bready/grainy, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 5.2%. Overall this is a nice Blonde ale. All around nice balance and robustness of pale malt and light-moderate earthy hop/fruity yeast flavors; very smooth, clean, and refreshing to drink. Not overly yeasty, but a bit fruitier overall; still very well balanced and flavorful for the ABV. A nicely enjoyable and well made style example.
12oz bottle. Hazy golden / yellow with small head. Grainy, some citrus, and some fruitiness.

Bottle. A hazy golden color body with a small fizzy white head , quickly fading leaving a small amount of lacing , medium carbonation . Aroma is of corn , spent grain , grassy hops , slightly metallic . Flavor is spicy hops , dry grain ,and sweet corn , slightly metallic . Medium body , creamy mouthfeel ,short spicy hop finish , quite sessionable . A middle of the road ale , from a pretty good brewry .

on tap at soaring eagle casino, mt pleasant mi...golden, clear pour with medium white head..aroma of grain, grass...very earthy and expected..flavor is lightly malty with a slightly bitter, earthy finish..

12 oz. bottle, has a clear gold pour with faint orange at the sides, made a quick head that fades pretty quickly, faint malt and fruit aromas, some off-ness on the nose that comes across as stale, does not smell fresh, clear or bright like a good beer, flavors are the same as the aromas but with some malt sweetness and more off-ness in taste than I find on the nose, mouth feel is medium or a little less, not a good beer.

12oz bottle under the Mt. Pleasant moniker. Slightly hazy, golden straw color with small white head. Aroma is some corn, grain, grassiness, dry and spicy hops. Flavor is banana, slight alc, grain, slightly metallic, meh. Medium to with active carbonation. This is my first dissapointment from this brewery.

12 oz...Appearance is tan colored with a small amount of head. Aroma of sweet corn. Taste is sweet corn, with a slight taste of bittering hops. A touch of skunkiness, as well as a metallic flavor is there as well. Lively carbonation. Dry finish. Not anything I would buy again.

Bottled as Mt Pleasant Gamblers Gold. Pours a murky pale orange with a pretty large fizzy head. Aromas are pleasant enough: dough, yeast, a little citrus and a little bit of cloves. Flavor is very weak. A bit of a washed out sampler of the aroma, but the nose is way fuller and more interesting. Tastes like I would imagine a lemon grass tea might.

6oz sample at MTS - Aroma is pretty much non-existent, sneaks in some pale malts and doughy yeast. Pours clear gold with a small head and good lacing. Flavor matches aroma is just a step above water. Palate is clean. Bland and boring, but non-offensive and easy drinking.

06Aug2019 Dark malts, toasted malts, burnt toasted bread, dark chocolate, cacao. Hazy, very dark brown, small, frothy, off-white head. Light sweet. More sweet chocolate, cacao, dark malts, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Decent. Cask at GBBF19.

Bottle to glass,pours a ruby to black color with a small rapidly diminishing light tan head.a malty nose of chocolate,bread,and roast.Sweet and a little thin. This is a stout that I would not pour out but I sure would not go looking for it.
Bottled. Pours dark with a slightly off-whit head. Aroma is slightly sweet and malty. Rich but lots of a nutty and roasty character which off-sets any sweetness.
Notes from summer. Pours black. Aroma and taste are smokey burnt sugar. Did not enjoy.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 10/8/2014. Pours nearly opaque dark brown/black color with a 1-2 finger dense and rocky tan head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, herbal, and roasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of roast/bready malt and moderate earthy hop notes; with good strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, herbal, and roasted earthiness. Good amount of herbal/roast/charred bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toast, dark bread, light smoke/char, and herbal/roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of roast/bready malt and moderate earthy hop flavors; with a good roasted bitterness/sweetness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy, and lightly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very nice American stout style. All around good complexity, balance, and robustness of roast/bready malt and moderate earthy hop flavors; and very smooth to drink. A very enjoyable offering. Very big on flavor for the ABV.

Draft at Mountain Town Station. Pours black. Small off white head. Mild chocolate aroma. Flavors of roast, chocolate. This is good, but I have to laugh when I read the description. I would consider this a mild light bodied thin stout. Flavor is good and its very drinkable. Definitely not rich and hardy as described. Not something you’d seek out specially, but solid and easy drinkable.
Notes of dark fruit, burnt grains, smoke and a pretty rough tobacco aftertaste. Dark chocolate undertones. Burnt toast finish.

bottle to snifter. Large light brown head on top of a very dark brown to black beer. nose is light chocolate with some peanut butter notes. Taste is initially sweet with a light coco powder, but then finishes very bitter, astringent, and puckering, with some oversparged coffee grain flavors. something just doesn’t finish right with this beer. weird.
Almost black. Tan lasting head. Bitter sweet chocolatey malt aroma and flavor. Some bitterness on the finish. A desert beer for sure.

12oz bottle. Enjoyed at robotopera’s lakehouse in Michigan. Pours a very dark brown color, not quite black. Thin brown head. Awesome aroma... Surprising amount of earthy bitter hop on this, coffee, dark chocolate, and heavy roast. Some light dark fruit. Loose ropes of lace. Moderate bitter taste, light sweet. A lot less sweet than expected for a "sweet stout". Good bigger coffee in the finish. Medium body. Kind of slick texture. Lighter carbonation. Not so chewy. Solid, hoppier, more bittter stout. (sweet stout?? you sure?)
On tap at tap room. Not much aroma, but there's the cascade. Nice crisp flavor, and would be killer either fresher or with more dry hop. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at the brewery Clear golden with a medium sized off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is floral and grassy. Flavors of floral, caramel and grassy Nice, clean and crisp.
Overall, good IPA. Herbal aroma with hints of flowers. Medium pine bitter taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at Midwest Brewfest. Pours a chunky, thick amber with an aroma of piney grapefruit. Flavor is grapefruit and sour fruit peel. Thick mouthfeel. Another winner. Shock me! (listed as Ace’s IPA)
On draught at the 2007 Parkville Brewers Festival. Pours a dense dark gold with a big hop-over-malt flavor balance.

2004 Recipe: A bit of a letdown. The hops have changed to a blend of Cascade and Centennial, with EKG for dry-hopping. The aroma is a nice blast of grapefruity resin, and the bitter finish is solid, but that's only because the malt is essentially absent. Pale gold, very dry, as close to a "no malt, hop-juice" beer as there is. Lightly hazy red-amber color. Med strength aroma with notes of citrus (grapefruit) and resin. Notable citric/piney hop flavor, with medium caramel malt backbone. Nice balance, and pretty close to the way I like my IPAs. Fairly smooth, tingly mouthfeel. Bitter, almost puckering finish.

Seasonal wheat beer. Poured a hazy straw with a nice, white head. Banana cream, vanilla, clove and peppery nose. The light body is fizzy with carbonation. The wheat malts help add some creaminess, but just aren’t substantial enough. There are lighter notes of banana and graham, but needs more yeast in the pour. OK.
Very authenic German Weizen, just like I was back on Germany again! Soft, unfiltered with proper cabonation and fantastic banana and clove flavor.

On tap at the original Rick O’s location. The beer was right on style, and fine, but pretty base line and forgettable on the whole. That being said, I would probably order it again if I am in the mood for a simple, middle of the road stout, but I feel like they (NABC) offer many more preferable beers, both their own and those offered on the incredible Rich O’s bottle list.

(draft) First time drinking the non-bourbonized version of this stout. I got an almost overpowering sense of chocolate - both in the aroma and the flavor. Pretty good, but would probably be too much for me to wrap an evening around. I was pleased to detect no coffee or licorice at all.

Draft: Per Michael, the brewer, intended to be used in their Bourbondaddy Stout (aged in Woodford Reserve barrels), but sometimes released on its own. A big roasty stout. A very nice beer in its own right.
Cloudy yellow with creamy white head and lace. Light malt and floral hops on the nose. Light semi sweet caramel. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Just a tick off somewhere.

Honey-blonde with a mild head and exhibiting a crisp, honeyed nose. Surprisingly dry body that contributes crispness across the light grain and mild corn palate scored by notes of grapefruit on the champagne-like finish. This improves with each sip, though I’m not generally a fan of the style.

On tap at the Yard House, Waikiki. This was listed as Big Aloha Blonde, but a visit to Sam Choy’s confirmed it is the same beer. Hazy gold with a white head. Mild malt nose, a touch toasty. Light malty flavor, again, a touch of toastiness. Not too hot on this one.
Tap. Light cream malt aroma with a hint of lemon. Pale yellow color with small head. Creamy malt flavor with a hint of hops in the finish. Moderate carbonation. Very tasty - great style-wise.

Taster - Big Aloha Brewery (Sam Choys) - Honolulu, Hawaii 2008 – Great Hawaii Beer Run Aroma – Light malt aroma with a nice hint of hops. Appearance – Light pale yellow in color, nice head and clear. Flavor – A crisp creamy flavor. I know it sounds weird but that is what it had. . Decent malt profile very light hops. Palate – Crisp Mouthfeel, good creamy texture with a nice dry finish. Refreshing beer for a hot day. Overall – Nice easy creamy ale with the weirdest feeling it was too crisp in the Mouthfeel and flavor. This had creamy qualities it was just odd. I did however enjoy.

On tap at Sam Choys in Honolulu, HI. Poured a light to medium yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas of corn and gerneric malty sweetness. Tastes of the same. Some light citrus as well. Thin body.
Draft:Supposed to be like Bud Light. Poured clear yellow with a medium white head. Mild hop and corn aroma. Flavor is crisp, lightly bitter. Mild corn aftertaste. Decent.
Medium-maize. Light and smooth with a ghost of hop-kiss. Bitterness rolls off the back of your tongue at the end.
Pale yellow colour, mild and non-descript aroma. Flavour is slightly lemony, very little evidence of malt or hops aside from a bit of bitterness in the finish. Unimpressive.

As Aloha Red. A reddish dark amber ale with a thin off white head. In aroma, weird grassy malt with light boiled veggies. In mouth, a nutty malt with light soy notes, strange, so-so. On tap at brewpub, Nov. 30, 2012.

Pours a really nice dark mahogany color. Moderate head, but no lacing. Aroma is carmel and nuts. Taste is the same with a dry finish. Reminds me of a nut brown ale. This beer would improve greatly if it wasn’t so watery.

On tap at the brewpub (Sam Choy’s). Pours a clear, amber colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice, sticky lacing throughout. Aroma is caramel, sour dark fruits, and a faint bread. Flavor is thin caramel, sour fruits, and some earth. Finishes dry with a light, earthy bitterness that leaves a medium length aftertaste. Light body and fairly fizzy carbonation. Overall, a pretty bland beer. It looks pretty solid, but aside from that the only going for it is the dry, somewhat bitter finish. Not very good.
Amber pour with creamy white head and lace. Caramel malt with a bit of citrus aroma. Caramel malt with a light earthy bitter finish. A tad thin and watery.
Characterized by an amber body with a decent head. Light malt aroma and simple caramel notes and hopping that beckons one to recall an E.S.B. Somewhat thin and with mild bitterness. Forgettable.

On tap at Sam Choy’s. Clear copper with an off white head. Sweet nose, malt syrup-like, somewhat herbal. Rather sweet flavor, malty and caramelly, a bit spicy. Finishes with a toasty biscuit. Good lace. OK.
Tap. Just the barest hint of malt - not much aroma. Cola brown color with moderate head. Caramel malt flavor. Slightly spicy finish. High carbonation. Very nice beer - not a typical APA.
Draft at Holokai Grill. Amber body, malty nose, medium off-white head. Lots of diacetyl, malty, some spicy hops. Nothing special here.

Taster - Big Aloha Brewery (Sam Choys) - Honolulu, Hawaii 2008 – Great Hawaii Beer Run Aroma – Amber malts with a hint of spice, molasses and chocolate. Appearance – Dark amber in color, nice head and clear. Flavor – A deep amber malt flavor with some great molasses and spices also lingering n the flavor. Very light in the hops. Palate – Nice Mouthfeel, good texture with a nice dry finish. Overall – This was a great beer. Had flavor full of body and goes well with the crab we just ate.

On tap at Sam Choys in Honolulu, HI. Poured a deeper orange color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, roast, and light citrus. Tastes of caramel, roast, citrus, and nutty. Light lacing left on the glass. I was getting some butteriness in both the aromas and tastes.
Tap@Aloha Beer Lounge. Hazy golden color with white head. Tart grainy pale wheat, citrusy, clove aromas. Nice banana, clove sweet estery flavors with some citrusy tartness--good hefe
Had this while on vacation in Hawaii. Not a bad brew with the typical hefe profile that you’d expect, just not quite enough of it.
On tap at Sam Choy’s. Murky yellow with a white head. Wheaty nose, lemony and spicy. Flavor is more spicy, almost comes off like a wit. Soft lemony finish. OK.
Tap. Very sweet banana/orange and wheat malt aroma. Hazy pale yellow color with small head. Sweet banana/apricot and wheat malt flavor. An above average Hefe - well made.

Taster - Big Aloha Brewery (Sam Choys) - Honolulu, Hawaii 2008 – Great Hawaii Beer Run Aroma – Wheat in the aroma with a slight off metallic hint. The lemon took from the aroma. DO NOT DUNK THE LEMON. Appearance – Light golden yellow color, nice head and Hazy. Flavor – A full wheat flavor but it was so mush dactyl it was very off on the flavor. Way too bitter and a tad metallic flavor. Palate – Had a hazy Mouthfeel, very poor and lacking texture with a nice dry but metallic finish. Overall – This was a beer that should have been poured out. It had a nasty flavor.

On tap at Sam Choys in Honolulu, HI. Poured a deeper and cloudy yellow color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas of bananas, cloves and lemons (served with a lemon slice). Tastes of bananas, cloves, citrus, and some wheat.

Draft: Served with a lemon which I removed promptly. Poured a cloudt yellow with a thick white head. Mild banana and clove aroma. NIce. Started off good upon tasting it. Typical banana/clove notes but then it disappears into a sourish finish. Mild chlorine hints in the finish.

I generally like German Hefe-Weizen style beers. This is a German Hefe-Weizen beer, and I like it. I had it at Sam Choy's Seafood Restaurant in Hawai'i of course. It was served me cutely with a lemon in it, which I left there. This added to its pleasant tartness, its citrussy taste. It has a nice lightly cloudy golden tinge to it and is a quite pleasant brew. It was probably my favourite from the Big Aloha Brewery, but of course this could be due somewhat to it being a Hefe-Weizen, currently my favourite style of beer.
GABF '03 Cloudy golden color with banana and yeast aroma.Nice tart flavor with god mouthfeel.
Banana aroma here. Very yeasty tones in the taste, authentically flavored but a tad watery. Cloudy tangerine-colored.
Starts off carmelly and nutty, finishes slightly astringent with some earthy hopping
Draft: pours copper with a medium white head. Aroma is a bit perfumey with notes of roses and a little cinnamon. Flavor is mild malt, hops, and spice. Bitter finish. Good.
Reddish caramel colored, with a caramel-candy flavor. Sweet and syrupy. More like an overdone Oktoberfestbier than a steam beer.
Orange-amber with a mild aroma, but a nice strong flavour with a good malt/hop balance, while still holding a light and refreshing mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Ehh. Real tight nose. Using "honey" in the name suggests sever things. None of which I get in this beer. Expected a more viscous beer. Sweetness is detectable but not pronounced. Good follow through though.

Draught at the brewpub Black color, with small beige creamy head. Mild aroma of roasted malt and bread. The mouthfeel is dry; flavor of roasted malts, with light touch of lactose and maybe honey. Correct bitterness. Pleasant.

A dark porter with a very thin dark brown head. In aroma, a lightly peated chocolate malt with light bacon and dark fruits. In mouth, sweet chocolate malt with cherry notes, honey, light smokey notes, very nice. On tap at brewpub, Nov. 30, 2012.
Tap@Aloha. Black color with tan head. Dark roast malt, chocolate aromas. medium body with average co2. Dark roast flavors with dark chocolate, pale malt, and maybe some honey--very tasty

Pours translucent black with red hue. Off white head. No lacing. Light aroma...chocolate. Taste is the best part of this beer. Roasted malts, sweet chocolate, sugar, dark chocolate and acidic aftertaste. Alittle watery. Bubbles on the tongue.

All Sam Choy’s beer tastes the same. It is just beer. Nothing exciting nor flavorful at all. Then none of the local Hawaiian brew has been. It is true: Homebrewing good brew does, in fact, turn one into a beer snob.

This beer was the highlight of my sampling at Big Aloha. A perfectly crafted, and somewhat unique, island brew. Deep brown with sasparilla underpinning and a respectable head. The nose easily fills with a sweet roastiness, true to its honey porter name. As the bartender tells me, island honey (acacia?) is used for this brew. It certainly adds a distinct and pleasurable complexity the well put togther porter base. The sweetness complements the heavier roast notes that are richly nuanced with chocolate, coffee, and maltiness. MIlk chocolate finish. A medium-bodied, flavorful and quaffable brew.
On tap at Sam Choy’s. Clear dark brown with a tan head. Light nutty nose. Decent choco-nut flavor, but not much to get excited about.
Tap. Dark chocolate, coffee, and licorice aroma. Dark brown color with minimal head. Fudge malt flavor with a licorice/hops finish. Nice full body - damn tasty.

Taster - Big Aloha Brewery (Sam Choys) - Honolulu, Hawaii 2008 – Great Hawaii Beer Run Aroma – Deep Malt aroma with a great hint of honey and other fruitiness. Appearance – Brown in color, nice head and clear. Flavor – A great flavor for this porter it had depth and character and the best it had great flavor. Yheaaaaaaa A great Beer in Hawaii. Loved the dark malts and light chocolates and fruitiness. Palate – Had a great Mouthfeel loved the finish this was the best thus far on my trip. Overall – Loved this beer it had flavor and taste and was just overall a great tasting porter.
Can 50 cl. Golden color, clean, snow-white foam . Aroma: pils malt, a little crackers and a little sour-grassy hops. Tastes: malt, cookies and watery, hops traces, so....

Pours clear light golden colour. Moderate white frothy head. Good lacing. Aroma: cereals, corn, herbal hop, slight alcohol. Light plus body. Average carbonation. Taste: medium dry, light pilsner malt, spicy and herbal hop, some alcohol. Light plus bitterness. A bit harsh.
Aroma: Fruity sweet and grassy. Flavour: Fruity sweet with a watery metallic aftertaste. Colour: pale amber with a white head. From: Can @ Supermarket Lake Garda Italy Jul. 2019.

Canned 500ml. -from Auchan Desenzano, Italy. Pale golden coloured, small to medium sized white head, dusty grainy nose. Sweetish malty, watery, dusty grainy and touch of grass with short dry bitterish finish.

13-01-2019; can; at home (bought at an unknown location). The looks are truly that of a Pale Lager. Golden yellow, crystal clear, frothy white head. Nothing really special. The beer just looks rather simple. The aromas of the beer are very simple. Some grainy malts, hardly any hop and a soapy aroma. The aroma is thing, light, nothing really is there. Just water with a little touch. The taste is almost not existing. Hint of malt sweetness and hop bitterness. But, to thin, watery and cheap. The palate is also not great. Thin body, watery texture, very high carbonation. The finish is dry but has no real flavour. This beer has little to offer to be honest.

Canned 0,50L. Blonde pale yellow color, limpid aspect with light bubbly and foamy head. Dicreet wheat and straw aroma, simple alcoholic and watery nose. Medium prickly taste, washed out and moisted straw and corn palate, light metallic final.
can bb10/19 oro limpida buona schiuma discreta persistenza un po grossolana cereali lieve metallico crusca non molto amaro ruvida
In holland we call this: 'Slootwater' or 'Uilenzijk' Look it up in the dictionary ;)
33cl can. Clear straw yellow with a white head. Malty, grainy and hay. Average carbonation and light watery body. Overall, a common lager.

Lattina. L’intensità olfattiva è flebile e la persistenza olfattiva è sfuggente. Il cappello di schiuma ha una discreta resistenza. La grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. La consistenza del liquido è limpida. Le bollicine sono medio-fini. La carbonazione è bassa. Il colore è giallo dorato brillante. Il corpo è snello. La struttura è rancida e appiccicosa. L’amaro è percettibile. L’intensità gustativa è leggera. La persistenza gustativa è corta.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: On tap at Stoke pub, Guildford, England-- Pours hazy amber with thin white head. Nose is rupee fruits. Aromas are caramel malts, ripe fruits, sour in taste. Fizzy carbonation, light body. Abrupt sour finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brew pub. Poured a clear amber color with a two finger off white head. Aroma of citrus. Flavor was grapefruit and some malt.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: From the tap poured an amber color with a fair amount of head. Nice hoppy flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: Tap. Butterscotch candy and malt aroma. Amber color with small head. Old butter and barley malt flavor with moderate grass hops finish. Strong diacetyl level - maybe a bit old.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: On tap, Brewpub. Pours a yellow orange color. Aroma is on the light side, but definitely features some citrusy notes (perhaps lemon zest), and hops. Flavor is a surprisingly appealing mixture of grapefruit, orange, lemon, and some sweetness for balance. Not nearly the most bold or novel IPA I’ve had, but you gotta five this brewery props for putting out some real drinkable stuff.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: Taster - Brew Moon Brewery - Honolulu, Hawaii 2008 - Hawaiian Beer Run Aroma – A very light aroma. I think I smelt some hops. Appearance – Golden yellow color, clear with a small head. Flavor – A nice easy to drink beer with a good light flavor. Palate – A decent nice easy dry Mouthfeel. Overall – Not bad this was a good go out and surf all day and need a beer at the end type. Just a pick up and chug beer.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the Brew Moon located in the Ward Center. Poured a medium amber with a small sized off white head. Aromas of light roast, caramel, and earthy. Tastes of roast, earthiness, caramel, and some citrus.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: Sampled at the brewery. Tastes of hops with a nice creamy finish. I would have liked a full pint of this one.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: Draft at brewpub. Not bad. Hoppy aromas were sided with somewhat hoppy flavors. Not much in the way of malt, but a decent APA.

column1: Brew Moon Big Bang Pale Ale
column5: Taster had a brassy astringent aroma. Hazy iced tea color w/ sustained thin creamy tannish head. The nice hoppy profile still allows for gentle malty sweetness. Palate may have been stronger if it hadn’t been sitting too long.

Sampled at Honolulu location. Colour is deep brown, a bit too dark for the style. Warm & inviting aroma and caramel malt and brown sugar. Flavour is nicely sweet, with strong brown sugar notes, and a faint touch of hops before the boozy finish.

Sampled at Honolulu location. Despite the similar name, this is NOT the same as the Eclipse Oatmeal Stout that was available at the mainland locations. Deep black with tan head. Aroma is very roasty with some smoky hints. Strong espresso flavour, hides it's alcohol well. Body is a little light, but it's otherwise excellent.
lemony hop aroma, thin, dry, and pretty smooth; drinkable beach brew, that’s all

Color is deep yellowish amber with a white foamy head about a finger high. Smells of light hop and some maltyness. Taste is pretty clean and smooth with a good balance of hop and malt and is slightly sweet. Body is light to medium with a small hop sweetness covering the mouth. Drinkable, sure, but could be much better.

Pale golden apple juice colour with a small white head. Faint malt and a strange whiff of tobacco in the aroma. Flavour is grassy, slightly fruity, and pretty weak. It's a thirst-quencher, but little else.

Bottle: &nbsp Colar in color, moderate frothy light beige head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Soft toasted malt nose. &nbsp Fairly simple. &nbsp Soft sweet malty start, a bit toasty, not quite burnt in the roasty sense. &nbsp Light sweetness, slight lactose. &nbsp Seems fairly smooth, and not very big nor bitter. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Not as smokey or burnt as many other Schwarzbiers. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Finishes with a decent roasted malt base, with a cream and sugar like coffee finish. &nbsp Not half bad, better than I expected. &nbsp Many of these in the style are somewhat acrid, but this one is not.
Draft sample at the brewery in Whitefish. This was an easy drinking black beer that reminded me of the more widely distributed Kostritzer. Pretty straight forward.
Bottle, thanks Salwan! Black with a one finger head. Aroma is floral and yeast. Flavor is mostly non bitter dark malts and some yeastiness. Finish I yeast esters and short.

Sampled at GABF on 9-18-2010. Comes almost black with a thin head. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Tastes of the roasted malts with some smoke. Some bitterness and somewhat thin. Good but not great.
Very rich aroma. Expected a bit more to it. Bit thin mouth feel. Alcohol up front when it shouldn’t have been. Overall a very good beer though. Definitely worth a 2nd growler.
Sampled at the brewery. Near solid black, ruby edges, creamy light tan head. Aroma of roast chocolate malt, floral hops. Taste is roasty, milky, some smoke. Very smooth and mild.

Bottle… Pitch black lager with a small, creamy, off-white head. Decent retention. The nose is a touch nutty and, unfortunately, gives off a warm perspiration-like note. Full-bodied and lightly creamy with medium carbonation. The roasty, carbonous, medium bitter flavor also hints at a vinous, tawny port-like component. Nutty, roasty, moderately bitter finish. Kudos to Skyview for sending this beer my way!

Draft. Best I’ve tasted yet from Great Northern. Plenty of roasty character, a bit of mocha, no metallic pr soapy character. Some sweet fudgy/toffee character and a bit of port/wine character in the mouthfeel, along with a bit of fruit. Not bad. Not bad at all.
Probably the standout offering in Great Northern’s lineup. All in all not a bad schwarz, roasted malt character, dry finish.

On draught at the brewpub in Whitefish, Montana. Pours a near opaque dark brown brew with a thin off-white head that slowly dissipates to a fine film and good lacing. Aroma of dark roasted chocolate malt, some almonds, and a touch of coffee. Taste is smooth, creamy, full bodied with a smokey dark malt falvor. Finish is smooth, creamy following by a thin flowery hop bitter aftertaste.

Tap @ Dog & Grog Virginia City. This stout was quite dry with plenty of hop & dark roasted malt bitterness. Quite minimal on any sweetness. Well into medium bodied. I felt it could have been more complex with more flavors but not bad.
mellow roasted nose. black with an initially huge head. big body, very soft creamy cool coffee with mild piney hops. very dry in the finish

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On nitro tap at the brewery pours dark brown almost black topped with a tan head. Nose is nice light coffee notes and a roast malt. Taste is more of the nice roast malts some smooth coffee chocolate notes.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Nitro tap at Squatter’s in SLC. Poured black, brown at edges, creamy nitro head. Aroma was lightly of chocolate, milk chocolate. Flavor was chocolate malt, faint roasty note. Medium body. Like a Guinness, but just a touch bigger in the flavor. Nice.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Black with a thick creamy tan "nito head". The nose rich with espresso and roasted biscuit The taste starts with coffee then turns to espresso. Heavily roasted malt come next with a nutty/smokiness in the end. Mild hops come late and provide a slightly dry finish.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Bob got super sick trip to Utah – Feb 2010 Dark brown in color, thin tan head with a good aroma. Dark malts with coffee and chocolate flavors this was a great beer for the day.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On nitro at the brewpub Appearance: Pours black with a nice amount of tan head Aroma: Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee Taste: The same as the aroma. A little thin on mouthfeel, but silky and smooth. Very nice beer.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: On tap at the SLC brewpub. Pours a dark cloudy mix, with a powerful nitro infused head. The aroma is roasted malts. The taste is quite nice; the head is really sweet and crisp, while the main aspect is a roasted malt. Sweeter than Guinness and more nutty. I really like this beer. Real quality. Thick, almost a meal in itself.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Nitro Special at the Squatter’s Pub in the SLC Airport (Concource C)Pours a dark black color with light ruby edges and a thick creamy tan head, which diminishes faster than most nitro pours I’ve seen. Anyways, the nose is very nice with a rich coffee and roast bouquet and very little hops. A bit nutty and not quite as dry as I like in the stout. The flavor is nutty, as expected a full and creamy mouthfeel. Much more robust than your typical Guinness, which is tinny and watery these days. Nice stout, I’m always pleased to be able to drink a new pint while passing the time on a layover.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: (Draft) Pours a dark brown body with a light tan head. Flavor of roasted malt and coffee. Chaulky, dry mouthfeel.

column2: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
column4: Squatters Craft Beers (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: coffee aroma, thin body due to nitro. mild hops come late with a slightly dry finish. nothing special

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: Awesome citrusy west Coast IPA. Lots of orange amd lemon here with a touch of pine. Very drinkable. Pours golden with good head and lacing. Bitter end. Tall can.

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: This is one of my VERY favorite I.P.A.'s. I have yet to have a beer from this brewery that wasn't great !!!

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: Bottle pour. Clear golden with a nice soapy head. Aroma is citrus, lemon, grapefruit, and grass. Medium smooth body. Salty with a bitter finish.

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: Dose in Kalifornien. Vielschichtig und gut! Gelb-Gold, Trüb, wenig Schaum. Aroma: Voller Fruchtkorb (Aprikose, Zitrus. Geschmack: Frucht (Zitrus) und Bitterkeit sehr gut abgestimmt und balanciert. Dazu Getreide, etwas Kiefer.

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: Draft at Scapegoat in Scottsdale. Poured a golden color with a small white head. Aromas of citrus hops and pine. Flavor has the citrus hops, pine and lots of bitterness.

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: A Pizza Port IPA at Trader Joe's!!!. That being said, this isn't their best one. Thin while wildy over bitter. Bitterness would be fine at a 10% abv, but it's all that's there with this malt. Would like more hop flavor too. It's a truck of bitter. You can only go so many IBUs on this malt and dry hop/hop flavor. Pizza Port is still easily one of my favorite brewers so I'm conflicted and confused on not loving this. More hop flavor PLEASE!!!

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: 473ml can, Antenna America, Shinagawa Station. Pours golden, quite transparent, nice white foam on the top, leaving beautiful lacings. Crisp resiny nose, hop oils and some citrus peels, lemon and some orange marmalade. Tastes crisp and dry, good fresh hop bitterness, light sweetness (really light) and lots of citric spritz. Super light and elevated, uplifting IPA, dangerously sessionable. Goes down too quickly, superb balance.

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: Mostly clear golden pour with a white head. Aroma is a little dank, grassy and herbal with some citrus. Taste is sweet up front with medium bitterness and a balanced finish.

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: Excellent Brew! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Pizza Port Swami's India Pale Ale
column5: Len krämig smak med lätt citronton. Bra humlad med skarp citronton i beskan och aromen.
An ok discount-beer. Clear brown colour, medium head, white. Flavor is mainly sweet, has a little note of bitter finish. Caramel too.
Bottle Golden colour with a small short lasting head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Flavour has toasted malt, caramel, biterish finish. Tasty discount brew.
Red brownish colour with a very small head. Sweet taste of caramel and malt. Watery body and heavely carbonated
Foamy white head, clear dark golden body. Mild sweet creamy and malty aroma. Sweet malt and slightly roasted flavor with vague toffee tones. Watery mouthfeel. Not too bad.
Deep golden colour with a small white head. Mostly malty aroma with a light sweetness. Malty flavor with a light sour grainy finish.

(Bottle 33 cl) Pretty, dark golden beer. But interestingly this is all-malt - rather unusual for Harboe. Very malty touch - even in the nose. A Harboe effort of creating a "Carls Special"? Well, not that bad. 100699
A boring and neutral beer from Harboe.......................................

Bottled: Dark golden. No head. On a hot summer day after drinking a good deal of beer, this might be OK, but its boring. Some malt sweetness in the nose. Slightly hoppy that leads to a vague bitterness in the end. BORING.
Mild aroma and flavours. Sweet and sour. Very boring as most brews from Harboe.
Nice looks, but lacks both taste and aroma, like most Harboe beers. Strange sourish aftertaste.. but cheap!
Donker rroodbruin bier met schuim. Smaak is bitterzoet met iets van karamel, ietwat rook en bittere chocolade. Erg fijn bier om te drinken.
Bottle from Italian supermarket. Clear very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty and roasted malt. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and roasted light bitter finish. 240719

0,5l bottle at home bought at Interspar in Bolzano, Italy. BB 12/2016. almost black color, small tan head. smells bread, tobacco, spices, bitter herbs, hints of caramel. ok smell. light to medium body, rather bubbly carbonation, light / bit watery mouthfeel. tastes of caramel, bitter herbs, spices, light peppery, light licorice, light breadish. finishes quite balanced lightly dry with notes of spices, caramel and licorice. rather good one, not too sweet and easy to drink.

Pours a dark brown color, topped with a rather small sized tan colored head. In teh aroma, you can find some caramel malt with some gentle coffee notes. Taste starts sweet, caramel presence with a bit of a soury feel. Some coffee notes. Not the best one, but pretty adequate.

Birra abbastanza interessante, con leggere note di frutta rossa e un tocco di marzapane. Per il resto si avverte del tostato e del maltato (a dire il vero il tutto è abbastanza leggero). Bisogna lasciarla riscaldare prima che dia il meglio di sè. Corpo leggero.
Bottle, 50 cl. Overall nice. Coffee dominated strongly the aroma, lacked other aromas.

Dark brown color, average sized tan head that vanished immediately. Some lacing. Aroma of vanilla ice cream, caramel, nuts, strawberries. Taste of chocolate, nuts, caramel. Nice body considering its just 4,5%, lively carbonation. Winey acidic finish finish spoils a bit this cheap surprise. Very nice.
Bottle 0.5l. Dark mahogany liquid with unsteady average foam. Medium body, light carbonation. Drinkable. A bit sour in aftertaste.
Bottle from Eurospar supermarket, Malcesine, Italy. This is a very dark brown-chestnut coloured beer with malty, chocolate and roasted notes followed by red fruit and a nutty finish.
Brown crear, coffee head Toasted malts, chocolate/toffee hint Sweet Nuts, toasted malts, fizzy A drinkable dark beer

Mostly clear, green-gold, very thin head. Light Belgian aroma, dubbel-esque, contrary to the appearance, and a little smoked/tawny smelling. Tart, clear gel Belgian flavor, astringent bittering (what little of it there is.) Unripe sloes, stonefruit flavors. Medium body, flabby, sour finish.

Had this at the Wheeling restaurant. I suppose Ernest is right in saying that this is an oversimplified version of a Belgian Strong, but it’s still decent nonetheless. Basically, it’s a generic version, but it’s drinkable.

Draught. Body is light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), with notes of banana and clove. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Alcohol seems to be well-hidden, but this is an over-simplified representation of Belgian golden ales. I'm glad more and more microbrewers and brewpubs in America are attempting to replicate Belgian beer in general, though.
